title: When Moore Is Less for Microprocessors
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Internet's Chain Of Foolery
description: FIRST, the bad news: Bill Gates is not going to send you to Disneyland or give you free Microsoft software or pay you to test it. No one is going to close the Internet down for a day of spring cleaning. And the Miller Brewing Company is not celebrating the millennium by giving away free six-packs of beer to two million computer users.

title: Boeing and Airbus Battle Over Singapore Airline Sales
description: As cat fights go between global giants, it does not get much better than the current one between the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Russian Bombers Face Off Against American Fighters
description: Russian bombers flew close enough to Iceland and Norway last week to cause the United States and Norway to scramble fighter planes as a precaution, a National Security Council official said tonight.

title: Agony, Ecstasy, Agony: Enter the Computer
description: DR. EDWIN ROTHMAN, 66, an osteopathic physician from Haverford, Pa., recently bought his first computer, a 400-megahertz mail-order machine. His immediate goals? To use the Internet to pursue his rare-book collecting, to get up-to-the-minute information on his investments and to send E-mail to his four grandchildren. Dr. Rothman, while no stranger to gadgets, has never used an A.T.M. and has never turned on the cell phone that came with his car. Here are excerpts from a diary of his experiences.

title: Sports of The Times; Trying to Regain Control of a Genie Way Out of the Owners' Bottle
description: PAUL SILAS was at the office early yesterday morning preparing for his first draft as head coach of the Charlotte Hornets. With his team picking third, Silas was excited to be in position to snatch one of the great young players in the National Basketball Association draft. He got his wish, selecting Baron Davis, the 6-foot-2 1/2-inch point guard from U.C.L.A.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patterns column of the Fashion page on June 22 about an exhibition on mannequins at the Museum of the Fashion Institute of Technology misidentified the maker of a mannequin modeled after Dianne Brill and an Asian mannequin. He is Adel Rootstein, not Pucci.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, ROBERT MURR
description: PHILLIPS-Robert Murr. Of Stockbridge, MA, formerly of Cincinnati, OH., and New York, N.Y., on June 29, 1999. Cherished husband of Sue Ochs Phillips. Loving & nurturing father of Scott and Debbie and Pepper & Valerie; special person in the lives of Larry and Lynn, Jacki & Jan, and Carol and Bruce. Doting grandfather of Callie, Grace, Sophia, Nellie, and Micah. Treasured brother of Ann and Bob Friedman. Everyone will miss his gentle caring and wry humor. A Service Thursday, July 1, 1999, at 11AM at Hevreh of Southern Berkshire. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: A Cancer Fighter Keeps Fighting Injustice
description: STATISTICS are dry, so first a snapshot, if you are of sturdy stuff, to help explain the work of Dr. Harold P. Freeman, the longtime cancer fighter who has just been named president of Harlem's North General Hospital:

title: U.N. Takes Up Plan to Limit Population
description: The General Assembly today began debating an action plan first drawn up five years ago to limit world population growth, although developing countries remained deeply divided over some aspects of the plan.

title: Barak Creates Wide Coalition With 7 Parties
description: Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak today ended the tortuous six-week process of forging a broad coalition Government by clinching a deal with the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILCH, TODD DAVID
description: PILCH-Todd David, 7/1/61-1/15/99. Happy Birthday in Heaven. There isn't one day that goes by that I don't miss you. I will never stop thinking about you & wondering if you are okaythat's what big sisters are for. With all my love, Sue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Mark Morris Will Build Brooklyn Dance Center
description: A gleaming new center for dance is rising at 3 Lafayette Street at Rockwell Place, one block west of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Partial demolition and rebuilding have begun. By next summer, if all goes as planned, the Mark Morris Dance Group will have a home, and New York will have a three-story space with modern studios that will be available at low rentals to other groups for classes and rehearsals. An additional street-level floor and mezzanine in the building will house retail businesses.

title: Stock and Bond Markets Both Like What They Hear From the Fed
description: The stock and bond markets both rallied yesterday after investors got a surprise they liked from the Federal Reserve Board. The central bank signaled that a quarter percentage point increase in its short-term interest rate target could be enough to keep inflation in check.

title: Ailing Foreigners Burden Emergency Rooms in U.S.
description: They look like any of the anxious patients who walk into the city's polyglot emergency rooms.

title: White House to Present $7.8 Billion Plan for Everglades
description: After years of negotiations among environmentalists, farmers and thirsty Florida cities, the Clinton Administration will formally present a plan on Thursday to redirect billions of gallons of water a day into the Everglades in what supporters say is the largest effort at environmental restoration in history.

title: BANK LICENSES REVOKED
description: Russia revoked the licenses of four banks under pressure from international lending agencies that want the Government to limit spending on ailing banks, the central bank chairman, Viktor Gerashchenko, said. The central bank's board withdrew licenses of Uneximbank, Promstroybank of Russia, Mosbusinessbank and Mezhkombank. A team from the International Monetary Fund is in Moscow this week to review Russia's progress on an economic program that would help it secure a new $4.5 billion loan.

title: Big Board Sets Levels For Trading Halts
description: In its quarterly adjustment of ''circuit breakers,'' the New York Stock Exchange yesterday set the level for a trading halt in United States equity markets beginning with a drop of 1,050 points in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Coke Expects Sales to Decline 1% to 2%, Mainly in Europe
description: Citing the recall of its soft drinks in Europe last month -- the biggest in company history -- the Coca-Cola Company estimated yesterday that its beverage sales fell 1 percent to 2 percent in the second quarter compared with sales in the period a year earlier.

title: New Frontier for Mobile-Phone Operators Lies Underground
description: PARIS  If you flinch every time you hear an electronic approximation of Beethoven's "Fuer Elise" on a mobile telephone, you will be grateful that few mobile-phone operators have installed widespread networks in underground metro systems around the world.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Raises Interest Rates But Is Neutral on the Future

title: Nortel Receives Qwest Contract
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, one of North America's largest phone-equipment makers, said today that it had won a three-year contract from Qwest Communications International Inc. for more than $600 million of fiber optic equipment.

title: AT HOME WITH: Robert A. M. Stern; A Dean's Remodeling Job: Himself
description: CAN the New York architect Robert A. M. Stern, famous for replicating old-money architecture right down to the eyebrow dormers, shed his gray shingles to become a hipper, populist educator in tune with the restless talents of tomorrow?

title: Some Hear a Screech, Others America's Story; For Aiding Immigration, No. 7 Line Is Named a Historic Trail. Who Knew?
description: When the White House released its list of 16 so-called National Millennium Trails the other day, it read like a flashback to one's sixth grade social studies textbook: There was the trail marking Lewis and Clark's expedition to Oregon, the Underground Railroad used by enslaved African-Americans fleeing the South, the trail along the venerable Mississippi River, stretching from New Orleans to Minneapolis.

title: Refugees' Worse Deal?
description: To the Editor:

title: James B. Boskey, 57; Fought Child Abuse
description: James Bernard Boskey, a children's rights advocate and an expert on alternatives to the courts for resolving disputes, died on June 14 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 57 and lived in North Caldwell, N.J.

title: A Stay of Execution For the Silicon Chip
description: SCIENTISTS at Lucent Technology's Bell Labs have examined the future of the silicon-dioxide-based transistor that is used in billions of chips and have pronounced the technology both half full and half empty.

title: 3 Black Firefighters File Bias Claims Against Department
description: Three black New York City fire lieutenants filed discrimination complaints against the Fire Department yesterday, charging that they were denied transfers to desirable posts because of their race.

title: When Crime Becomes Art
description: Every now and then a movie comes along that generates a firestorm even before its release. The latest example is Spike Lee's ''Summer of Sam,'' about those terrifying months in 1977 when David Berkowitz, the so-called Son of Sam killer, was on the prowl.

description: BOTH-Robert. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Stewart. Services today, 1:00 PM ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

description: It was the last day of duty-free shopping bounty that Europeans have savored for five decades, and Stella Horton knew it.

title: Turkey Reports No Strife After Kurd's Sentence
description: Fears that violent rampages would follow the death sentence given to the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan, on Tuesday have so far proved unfounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, SYLVIA GOLD
description: FARBER-Sylvia Gold. Her family notes with deep sadness the passing, after a brief illness, of the dearly beloved wife of the late Milton H. Farber, former President of South West Farber Inc. (Farberware). Loving mother of Marilyn Farber Jacobs and Alan S. Farber and adored grandmother of Stanley G. (and Janice) Jacobs, Jr. and Scott A., Tami L. and Michael J. Farber, cherished sister of Abe (and Honey) Gold, mother-in-law of Karen Farber, treasured stepmother to Margaret Jacobs Haviland, Susan Jacobs Corria and Lisabeth Jacobs, a dear and loving friend to many. A consummate scholar who continuously attended college courses, even in her later years, and received the respect of her peers at Palm Beach Community College. She was also known for her creativity in the arts. To every endeavor, she brought energy, enthusiasm, intuition, a keen wit, a striving for perfection and strong committment. A longtime member of ORT. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to ORT or to The Children's Service League (of Westchester County, NY) of which she was a member. Courageous and proud to the end, she will be sorely missed by all of us. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 180 West 76th St., NYC at 10:00 AM, on July 2nd. Shiva will be held from 1:30PM6:30PM at The Princeton Club (15 West 43rd Street, New York).

title: College Prep By E-Mail For the Eager
description: THE fall term at the University of Pennsylvania does not start until September. But more than 200 incoming freshmen have already met some professors, debated politics and discussed the meaning of poetry -- all by E-mail.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: U.S. BANCORP, Minneapolis, will acquire the investment banking unit of John Nuveen Co., a financial services firm, and make it part of its Piper Jaffray brokerage subsidiary.

title: F.B.I. Finishes Examining Sites
description: A team of F.B.I. agents sent to Kosovo last week to investigate possible war crimes has completed its examinations at two burial sites, concluding that many of the victims died of gunshot wounds to the head, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Allan Carr, 62, the Producer Of 'Grease' and 'La Cage'
description: Allan Carr, the producer behind the popular movie musical ''Grease'' and the Tony Award-winning Broadway hit ''La Cage aux Folles,'' died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 62 and also had a home in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The euro rose after the Federal Reserve suggested it did not need to raise interest rates any more, capping returns on United States deposits. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0338, up from $1.0320.

title: On Line, Choreographer Pushes Back Boundaries
description: AS a modern dancer and choreographer, Cathy Weis was one of the first to use video, lugging the bulky video monitors on stage and integrating them into her performances as if they, too, were dancers. Fifteen years later, Ms. Weis is now one of the first in New York's modern-dance hive to create a live interactive and collaborative dance form on the Web.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Should I wonder whether this is the guy from Third Avenue who doesn't have any money or the guy from the third world who doesn't have any? That's not my job. I'm a doctor.''

title: Capital Buys Auto Lots
description: Capital Automotive REIT said today that it had agreed to buy MMR Holdings L.L.C., a closely held company that owns 58 auto lots worth about $206 million. Terms of the deal, which increases Capital's holdings by 41 percent, were not disclosed. Separately, Capital, a real estate investment trust based in McLean, Va., also agreed to provide $75 million in real estate financing to Sonic Automotive Inc., an operator of auto dealerships.

title: Time to Do Some Patriotic Relaxing
description: THE Fourth of July isn't only about fireworks. It's about relaxing with a vengeance, and this year there is a bevy of new accouterments to make that pursuit all the easier. Good news for day-trippers: a new Igloo cooler that plugs into a car cigarette lighter and needs no ice or ice packs. It's $119 at Zabar's, 2245 Broadway (80th Street).

description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Some Users of Artificial Stucco Find Headaches Are Real
description: IT'S not just athletes who are on steroids -- American houses are using chemicals to bulk up. In the last two decades, home exteriors have undergone a stylistic shift with flat facades giving way to columns, pediments and bulging 3-D details like quoins, keystones and dentil cornices. How can people afford to build houses with such opulent facades?

description: Mail-Well Inc., the world's largest envelope maker, agreed to buy New York City-based Enterprise Press for an undisclosed amount of cash to enter one of the largest commercial printing markets.

title: A New Coalition in Israel
description: Israel's next Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, is a career soldier relatively new to civilian political deal making. But he has shown great skill in stitching together a cabinet coalition. His government will be broad based and generally united in support of negotiating peace with the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARKEY, FRANCES
description: SHARKEY-Frances. On June 30, 1999. Wife of the late Melvin. Survived by Richard, Allan and Barbara. Beloved aunt and great aunt. She will be sorely missed by friends and family. Services Fri. 10:30am at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Italian Banks in Merger, but French Banks Fail to End Fight
description: Two major moves to consolidate European banking went in different directions today as two of Italy's biggest banks agreed to a friendly merger and efforts by the French Government to negotiate an amicable solution to a three-way bank merger broke down.

title: Austria Refuses to Cede Klimt Paintings
description: Five important paintings by Gustav Klimt plundered by the Nazis and claimed by their Jewish owners' descendants under a new Austrian law will not be returned, at least for now.

description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

description: Manufacturing in the Midwest expanded at a faster pace than forecast in June, and the index of leading economic indicators rose in May, suggesting growth could accelerate in the months ahead.

title: CHARTER TO ACQUIRE BRESNAN FOR $3.1 BILLION
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable television company owned by the billionaire Paul Allen, said yesterday that it would buy the Bresnan Communications Company, a cable company partly owned by the AT&T Corporation, for about $3.1 billion in cash and stock. Bresnan, which had said earlier this month that it was considering offers, will bring about 690,000 customers to Charter, mostly in Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Nebraska. The purchase is the latest in a string of cable acquisitions orchestrated by Mr. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation. Bresnan is based in White Plains. Blackstone Group, the New York-based investment firm, owns 40 percent of Bresnan.

title: Stevenson's Big Shot Pays Off
description: If brashness has its virtues, and if imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, Pete Sampras won't mind at all that his was the signature shot that Alexandra Stevenson decided to emulate when she saved a match point against Lisa Raymond and rallied to a 2-6, 7-6 (10-8), 6-1 victory to reach the Wimbledon quarterfinals in her professional debut.

description: Despite an earlier accord, Russia and NATO are still arguing about exactly where Russian peacekeepers should go in Kosovo and whose orders they should follow. Page A10.

title: GLOBAL ONE CHIEF RESIGNS
description: In another blow to Global One, the ailing joint venture owned by Deutsche Telekom A.G., France Telecom S.A. and the Sprint Corporation, Gary Forsee announced that he would resign as chief executive. Based in Brussels, Global One offers international communication services to multinational corporations. But it is losing hundreds of millions of dollars a year and all of the partners are unhappy. Mr. Forsee, previously president of Sprint's long-distance business, said he had resigned for personal reasons. Michel Huet, Global One's executive vice president, will head an interim executive committee while the owners decide what to do. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Samsung-Daewoo Swap of Businesses Falls Apart
description: The pending swap of businesses between two of South Korea's five largest conglomerates, the Samsung Group and the Daewoo Group, fell apart today, in what may come to be regarded as the first sign of a renewed commitment to allowing market forces to reshape the country's economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

description: WHEN the organizers of last month's European contract bridge championships in Malta had 10 days to shuffle and deal about 200,000 hands of cards, they turned to Per Jannersten. ''That's getting to be a ton of cards,'' Mr. Jannersten said, speaking literally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: A Subtle Defensive Shift Upsets a Shaky Contract
description: Trials that will determine the United States representation in the World Women's Team Championship to be played next January in Bermuda approached their climax yesterday. In the final, with the winners earning a trip to Bermuda, a Southwestern squad headed by Jill Meyers battled a Northeastern team headed by Lynn Deas. After 64 deals of a scheduled 96, Meyers led by 46 imps.

title: Clues in Search For Financier Lead to Europe
description: Federal investigators hunting for Martin R. Frankel, the Connecticut money manager wanted in a huge insurance fraud, say they believe that they have traced him to Europe and are actively pursuing leads there, Government law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SOARS. Copper posted its biggest one-day gain ever after Phelps Dodge became the second mining company in a week to cut output. In New York, copper for July delivery rose 5.15 cents, to 75.95 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EXSTEIN, RUTH ADLER BURNHOLZ
description: EXSTEIN-Ruth Adler Burnholz, 97, on June 30th, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Henry and Myron. Loving mother of Nancy and Ann. Beloved grandmother of Tom, Dan, Peg, Julie, Leslie and cherished great grandmother of eleven. Services on Thursday, July 1, 3PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: China in No Hurry to Reopen Talks on Joining Trade Group
description: In public statements and private signals, China has indicated that it will not resume talks with the United States any time soon over its proposed entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: AOL Is Giving Its Subscribers More Reasons to Stay Home
description: America Online's next generation of software, AOL 5.0, will be introduced this fall. The release will have a number of new features intended, apparently, to tempt users to forgo the greater Internet in favor of remaining on America Online's proprietary site.

title: CHIPSET UNIT SOLD
description: The world's No. 2 chipset maker, Via Technologies Inc. of Taipei, said that it would acquire about half of the National Semiconductor Corporation's Cyrix microprocessor design unit for an undisclosed price, putting it into direct competition with the world's biggest microprocessor maker, the Intel Corporation. The division develops central processing units -- the chips that are the heart of a computer -- using X-86 architecture. The United Evening News and other Taipei newspapers reported that Via would pay $175 million for the Cyrix unit. Via said the final price had not yet been determined.

title: More Computers Added to Insure a No. 1 Match
description: The Bowl Championship Series has decided that it needs more gigabytes. It has added five computer ranking services for the 1999 season to help sort out which college football teams deserve to play in the national championship game, which will be held this season by the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 4, 2000.

title: A Multimedia Site For a Multifaceted Man
description: Benjamin Franklin, the classic American overachiever, would surely be proud of The Electric Ben Franklin (www.ushistory.org/franklin), a Web site that has recently been introduced. Not only does it include the full texts of his autobiography and his contributions to The New-England Courant and the Declaration of Independence, but the site also features a few electronic liberties. Visitors are invited to watch videos of an impersonator expounding on what Franklin might have thought about the Internet. The Quotable Franklin page applies animation to the image of Franklin's face on the $100 bill. The result could be considered lifelike: his mouth is always moving. LISA GUERNSEY

title: Celebrating Scarpa, In Glass and Concrete
description: Carlo Scarpa's architecture is distinguished by an intense investment in materials and crafted detail, and closely related to the work of Louis Kahn and Tadao Ando. Two important shows in Montreal celebrate Scarpa's career. The first comprehensive retrospective of Scarpa's work -- he died in 1971 -- has drawings, photographs (below left, the Castelvecchio museum in Verona, Italy, completed in 1973) and four new models at the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal. Through Oct. 31; information from (514) 939-7000.

title: The Presidency as a Blooper Show
description: SHADOW

title: Danish Ballet Names Director
description: The Royal Danish Ballet has named Aage Thordal-Christensen its artistic director, effective immediately. This is the first administrative post for Mr. Thordal-Christensen, a dancer and choreographer. He succeeds Maina Gielgud and has a three-year contract.

title: Former G.M. Units in Deal
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the big computer services company, has won a contract estimated at as much as $2.5 billion from the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, the auto parts company spun off from the General Motors Corporation. Electronic Data, which itself was spun off from G.M. in 1996, had run Delphi's worldwide computer systems under a larger agreement with G.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: From Blissful Companions, a Sound That Defies Labels
description: Beyond the astounding music, the best thing about the JVC Jazz Festival's ''Remember Shakti'' concert Sunday was the radiance of the musicians' smiles. Bliss is the goal in the Indian spiritual practices that inspire this legendary fusion band, and each player, seated cross-legged on the floor of Symphony Space, bore the elegant demeanor of an adept. But there were many earthly reasons for the players to be so pleased.

title: Mother's Away. Landscapers Play.
description: SOMEWHERE in the attic of this old Maryland farmhouse is a faded picture of my grandparents Grace and Carroll Raver standing in the front yard in front of four sticks just barely taller than Granddad, and he was not a tall man.

title: Hazardous Lotteries
description: To the Editor:

title: Smaller Than a Regular Mouse, But Big Enough for Travelers
description: Most laptops give you two options for a pointing device, either a touchpad or a trackball, and many mobile users don't like either. Unfortunately, most tray tables aren't big enough for a mouse. And many of the smaller laptops, in the subnotebook class, have eliminated the serial ports and the mouse ports to save weight.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 15 about the theft of fossils from Federal lands referred imprecisely to the value of relics involved in a court case against David A. Hutchison, who pleaded guilty to theft of Federal property in Wyoming. Although prosecutors said the value was $220,813, their actual value remains in dispute, and for sentencing the amount was set at $1,000 to $2,000.

title: Too Much Medicine for the Elderly?; A Cash Hemorrhage
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER DELAYED DEAL
description: Britain's largest bank, HSBC Holdings P.L.C., missed a second deadline for completing its purchase of Seoul Bank of Korea. As the Government vowed the five-month-old talks with HSBC would continue, its sale of a 51 percent stake in Korea First Bank to Newbridge Capital Ltd. also appeared stalled. Creditors of the insolvent Hanbo Steel Company have also rebuffed foreign bidders, saying they would hold out for a better offer. For its part, the Government says the assets are still on the block for the right price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: House to Debate Financial Overhaul Law Today
description: After more than 20 years of failed votes in Congress, and hundreds of millions of dollars spent on lobbying, lawmakers are on the verge of the first broad display of support to remake the nation's financial system.

title: Private Schools Fare Little Better on New 4th-Grade Test
description: Students in private and religious schools did only modestly better than those in public schools in New York State's new and tougher fourth-grade reading and writing test last winter, state officials said yesterday -- fueling the debate over the relative merits of public and private schools.

title: FED RAISES A RATE, BUT THEN SUGGESTS THAT MAY SUFFICE
description: The Federal Reserve nudged its benchmark interest rate up by a quarter of a percentage point today but said there was no clear case for another rate increase to keep inflation at bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: CORNING SHARES LEAP AFTER PACT WITH INTEROUTE
description: The shares of Corning Inc. jumped yesterday after the company, one of the largest makers of optical fibers for telecommunications, said it would sell at least four million miles of optical fiber to London-based Interoute Telecommunications P.L.C. for Europe's largest broadband network. Shares of the company, based in Corning, N.Y., rose $4.9375 each, to $70.125. Corning, which invented fiber optics in the 1970's, will provide about 80 percent of the large-effective-area fiber needed for the $1.5 billion project. The 13,000-mile route will connect 70 European cities in 17 countries.

title: Too Much Medicine for the Elderly?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS WATCH
description: WHO SANG THAT? -- The International Lyrics Server (www.lyrics.ch), a popular source of music lyrics, is back on line after a five-month hiatus. After reaching an agreement with the National Music Publishers Association, the site no longer features full lyrics but does allow users to enter a phrase to find a song or artist. For example, who sang the line ''lawyers dwell on small details''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOSACCO, ELIZABETH
description: LOSACCO - Elizabeth. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Frank. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth Massa. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue, Bronx, until Saturday 9AM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Lucy's Church, Saturday, at 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on June 4 about ''The Embodied Image: Chinese Calligraphy From the John B. Elliott Collection,'' an exhibition running through Saturday at the Art Museum of Princeton University, misstated the birth and death dates of the calligrapher Wang Xizhi. He lived from A.D. 303 to 361, not B.C.

title: A Vote to Let Ellis Island Keep $6 Million a Year
description: The House Appropriations Committee is scheduled to vote today to let Ellis Island keep $6 million a year in ferry revenues, rather than to continue turning the money over to the Treasury. The legislation would give the island its first stable source of funds for preservation.

title: As Media Suits Flourish, Malaysia Judges a Journalist
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia's Court of Appeal will decide soon whether to uphold a three-month prison term for a Canadian journalist for contempt of court.

title: Miniature Pinball With Buzz, And a Bunch of Apes on the Run
description: Two innovative new games for Nintendo Game Boy and Sony Playstation systems are finding new uses for idle hands. On the smaller-scale Game Boy, Nintendo delivers Pokemon Pinball, a Game Boy cartridge that outdoes ordinary pinball wizardry by challenging players to collect 150 little monsters by flipping and tilting the ball around the fast-moving but sometimes disorienting matchbook-size color LCD screen. Because a whole pinball field won't fit on the device's tiny screen, players see half the board at a time.

title: In Rating Montreal Design, Even Tourists Get Their Say
description: Vacationers prowling Montreal for the jazz festival (which opens today and runs through July 11) take note. The fifth annual Vox Pop Commerce Design Montreal competition, sponsored by the city, invites everyone to fill out a ballot to vote on their favorite new interiors and architecture. The readily available ballot is also a handy guide for navigating Montreal's cooler streets, especially Rue Ste.-Catherine, Rue St.-Denis and Boulevard St.-Laurent. It is as good a tool as any for finding a hip restaurant, like Via Roma (see above). Sylvie Champeau, an organizer of the competition, said the intention is to develop ''an even more critical public that demands more of good design.'' Voting ends Aug. 31.

title: Aid Bill Listing Yugoslavia as Terrorist Passes
description: The Senate tonight overwhelmingly passed a $12.7 billion foreign aid bill that designates Yugoslavia a terrorist state.

title: Kotsay Home Run Ruins It For Mets
description: The Mets had their chances to pull within two games of the Atlanta Braves. But the Marlins' Mark Kotsay ruined the Mets' night when he drove a fastball from Armando Benitez over the right-field fence in the 10th inning for a game-winning home run.

title: Fed Statement on Rates
description: Following is the statement issued by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term rates:

title: Pawns in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoo Changes Some Rules, Upsetting Some Geocities Users
description: In a move that has unleashed a grass-roots outcry, Yahoo has imposed new copyright rules on members of Geocities, a provider of free home pages that Yahoo bought in January for $3.6 billion.

title: Becker Offers His Goodbyes Quietly
description: It was the day of the long goodbye at Wimbledon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Pearson Sells Macmillan Reference Unit
description: IDG Books Worldwide announced plans yesterday to acquire Macmillan General Reference in an $83 million deal intended to expand its reach in the market for how-to books through a list of 3,000 titles ranging from Betty Crocker cookbooks to Frommer's Travel Guides.

title: Death Match on the Green (but Take Turns)
description: AH, golf. A venerable game of patience, practice and exquisite concentration. A game of nuance and constant incremental striving for perfection. The lush greens inspire a Zen-like contemplation of the landscape. Custom dictates a sportsmanlike demeanor toward one's fellow players.

title: Chernomyrdin Back Home At Old Company, Gazprom
description: Cementing the relationship between the Kremlin and big business, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin was installed today as chairman of Russia's biggest company, the natural gas monopoly Gazprom.

title: SCHRODER ENDS $300 MILLION DEAL TO BUY DANKA UNIT
description: Danka Business Systems P.L.C. said yesterday that Schroder Ventures had terminated a $300 million agreement to acquire its outsourcing division after learning that the division may lose a major customer. The London-based provider of office-imaging equipment and services said Schroder had decided not to go through with the acquisition after being informed that the International Business Machines Corporation might exercise an option to terminate its outsourcing agreement with the division, Danka Services International. Danka said it learned of I.B.M.'s intentions in a letter on Monday.

title: Miami Cubans Are Outraged At Treatment Of 6 Refugees
description: Miami's large Cuban-American population was bristling with outrage today, a day after the Coast Guard used water pumps and pepper spray in an attempt to turn back a boat carrying six Cubans who had come within 150 yards of the Miami Beach coastline.

title: Uneasiness Prevails As Loft Law Expires
description: Loft dwellers in New York City were left wondering about their homes last night when a state law expired that since 1982 had protected residents of commercial buildings from eviction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBERG, ETHEL
description: MARBERG-Ethel. Beloved wife of the late Louis, devoted mother of Ilene and Paul Lieberman, loving grandmother of Wendy, Amy and Barry. Services Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY Wednesday, 1 PM. ''Bernheim Apter Goldsticker'', Maplewood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JUDITH
description: FRIEDMAN-Judith. Beloved wife of Dr. Jacob B. Friedman; devoted mother of Marilyn and Rosalynd; adored grandmother of Janet. Services 12:30 Thursday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Stop the Exodus
description: Does Serbia without Kosovo inevitably mean Kosovo without the Serbs? President Clinton and other NATO leaders have repeatedly said no and promised that Kosovo would be a multi-ethnic democracy. While they fought Serbian nationalism with more than 1,000 combat aircraft, however, they use mostly words against Albanian extremists.

title: Searching For Buried Treasures
description: Every day in the summer, Ettore and Diana Nannetti start at 6 A.M. for Manhattan Beach or Coney Island. They're trying to beat traffic, but not to nab a place in the sun. Mr. and Mrs. Nannetti search the shore for buried objects as they wear headsets and hold their Minelab Excalibur metal detectors. When the monotonous tone in their headsets rises in pitch and volume, they know they've struck something. And by 10, when the sun is starting to climb in the sky and the tanning is getting good, they're gone.

title: The Man Who Gardens With Furniture
description: MOST people look at a lettuce and see salad. Designers look at a lettuce and see lettuce green.

title: Mia Hamm and Company
description: The American Women's World Cup soccer team has burst into national prominence in the last several weeks, selling out stadiums and drawing the largest audience in the history of women's team athletics at Giants Stadium in New Jersey. They will face off against Germany this evening in the quarterfinals outside Washington, with millions of new fans hoping they advance to the semifinal round.

title: TELLABS TO BUY NETCORE SYSTEMS FOR $575 MILLION
description: Tellabs Inc., a maker of telecommunications equipment, agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Netcore Systems Inc. for about $575 million in stock. Tellabs, based in Lisle, Ill., said the acquisition of Netcore would increase its ability to help its customers build data, voice and video networks. Netcore develops Internet switching products. Tellabs said it expected the transaction to dilute earnings by 1 to 2 cents a share in 1999 and to be neutral or add slightly to earnings in 2000. Tellabs earned $1.95 a share, excluding charges, last year. Shares of Tellabs fell $1.8125 each, to $67.5625.

title: Board Shifts on Special Education in Summer
description: A plan that would have required about 18,000 special education students in the city's public schools to attend summer school this year has been rescinded under pressure from legal advocates, officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Warns That Arms Race May Begin Between Koreas
description: The Clinton Administration is increasingly worried that South Korea may be pushing ahead with several missile projects that could further fuel an arms race on the Korean Peninsula, just as North Korea appears to be preparing another launch of a long-range missile.

title: In the Void of the Damned, a Desire to Hold On
description: You get a shot of reality with your drink order at Monk's Place, the ramshackle gin mill that is the setting for ''Small Craft Warnings,'' Tennessee Williams's 1972 rap session of a drama. The bar stools are filled each night by a motley assortment of grifters, drifters and rowdies, fellow travelers in the shabby margins of life, consigned to the fringes by dint of criminal misdeed, decadent impulse or illness of the head.

title: Profiting From Profiling
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Practical' Solution; F.C.C.'s Give and Take in SBC-Ameritech Merger Deal
description: At first blush, the $72 billion deal announced Tuesday with the Federal Communications Commission seems a high-stakes gamble -- with SBC Communications Inc. betting as much as $2.3 billion that it can compete in 30 new markets within 30 months for the right to acquire Ameritech.

title: Owners and OfficialsIn New Arena Talks
description: The co-owners of the Islanders and officials from Nassau County met in Mineola yesterday for the second time in eight days in an effort to negotiate a deal for a new arena, something the team claims is essential to its survival on Long Island.

title: Duck Before Entering: Mount Vernon Reinterpreted
description: In a $1 million venture, the clothing designer Tommy Hilfiger and his wife, Susie, will build a playhouse in Greenwich, Conn., a child-scaled reinterpretation of Mount Vernon. The playhouse, which is being erected temporarily on the grounds of Christ Church Greenwich, will have replicas of six of the main rooms at Mount Vernon and a version of the columned porch. Allan Greenberg, the Washington neo-classicist architect who wrote ''George Washington Architect'' (Andreas Papadakis Press, 1999), designed the 325-square-foot playhouse, below, which will open to the public as part of the Tomes Higgins Designer Showhouse in Greenwich from Oct. 3 through Oct. 24. (The 1861 Tomes Higgins house, at 216 East Putnam Avenue, was the rectory for Christ Church Greenwich.) The playhouse will be distinctly child-size, with 4-foot-3-inch doorways. ''Grown-ups will hit their heads,'' Mrs. Hilfiger said. But children should check their chewing gum at the door: the furnishings are real. Hank Cochran, a curator affiliated with the Manhattan antiques dealer John Roselli, is collecting authentic accessories like the 1780 boy-size military dress hat (inset right) and small-scale period cutlery and Chinese crockery (inset left). ''We want the experience to be seriously educational,'' Mrs. Hilfiger said. No stranger to cross-marketing, she will sell unfurnished duplicates of the playhouse through her store, the Children's Shop, at 289 Greenwich Avenue. Proceeds will benefit the Children's Development and Educational Foundation in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITT, JACK
description: SITT-Jack. The partners and staff of Brown Raysman Millstein Felder and Steiner LLP extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Sitt family. Jack was a special person who brightened so many lives. He will be sorely missed. Richard Raysman Catherine McGrath Carla Craig

title: Blood Donors' Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Healtheon And WebMD Plan to Buy News Service
description: The Healtheon Corporation and WebMD Inc., the companies that are combining in an attempt to dominate the use of the Internet by the health care industry, are buying Greenberg News Networks, a privately held medical news service, for $250 million in stock, people familiar with the deal said yesterday.

title: City Hall Weighs Ouster of School Board Head, a Close Ally of Crew
description: Six days before the Board of Education chooses its president for the next school year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday was weighing whether to push the board to oust the current president, William C. Thompson Jr., from the post in favor of a mayoral ally, city and school officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: F.D.A. Approves Abbott AIDS Drug
description: Abbott Laboratories said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved a reformulated ''soft-gelatin capsule'' version of its AIDS drug, Norvir, nearly a year after manufacturing problems forced the company to cease selling the drug in capsule form.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, WILLIAM B.
description: BERGER-William B. Of Denver, CO. The Board of Governors and members of The Leash in New York note with profound sadness the passing of their fellow club member. Bill was an outstanding gentleman, sportsman and businessman. He will be missed. The Leash

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on Thursday about the American Marketing Association's appointment of Dennis L. Dunlap as its chief executive misspelled the name of the parent company of his previous employer, the Mobium Creative Group. It is R. R. Donnelley & Sons, not Donnelly.

title: 3 Advertisers Decide on Accounts
description: Three interactive advertisers have made decisions involving accounts.

title: Heart Valve Defect Found to Be Rarer And Not as Serious
description: For more than two decades, the major medical journals have been filled with reports of the high incidence and devastating complications of a heart condition called mitral valve prolapse. It was called the most common cardiac disorder in young people and the most common heart-valve disease among people of all ages.

title: Daewoo Sells Switching-Equipment Division
description: The Daewoo Group, South Korea's second-largest conglomerate, said today that its Daewoo Telecom Company unit sold a division producing telephone switching equipment and other telecommunications equipment for 400 billion won ($345 million), the latest asset sale aimed at avoiding Government sanctions against the company.

title: AT&T Consolidates Interactive Account
description: The AT&T Corporation has consolidated its interactive account with the Strategic Interactive Group in Boston, a unit of Bronnercom, which had shared the assignment with Modem Media.Poppe Tyson in Westport, Conn., a unit of True North Communications. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REESE, GORDON KENNEDY
description: REESE-Gordon Kennedy, 82, of Fanwood, NJ, died Sunday, June 27, at Woodlands Genesis Elder Care Center, Plainfield, NJ. He was born in Pittsfield, MA, and was a resident of Fanwood since 1950. Prior to retiring in 1970, Mr. Reese was employed in international marketing with the U.S. State Department in Washington, DC. He also had an extensive career in international marketing with General Motors, Pfizer and Bon Ami. Mr. Reese was a graduate of the University of Virginia, class of 1940, a member of the Westfield, NJ, Tennis Club, and served as a lieutenant with the U.S. Navy, retiring in 1945. Surviving are one son, Gordon K. Reese, Jr., of Sacramento, CA; one daughter, Sally Anderson, of West Tisbury, MA; one sister, Anne Taylor, of Ridgewood, NJ; and three granddaughters, Allison Reese of Sacramento, CA., Amanda Reese of San Rafael, CA., and Elizabeth Anderson of West Tisbury, MA. Funeral services were held privately. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Saying It In Pixels, Round 2
description: DIGITAL cameras are getting better and faster and cheaper at a motor-drive pace. A year ago the price of megapixel cameras, so called because they capture images made up of more than a million picture elements, fell below $1,000 for the first time. Now we are seeing the first 2-megapixel cameras in the same price range, and the best one so far is the Nikon Coolpix 950.

title: Too Much Medicine for the Elderly?; On-Line Diagnoses
description: To the Editor:

title: Slight Increase In Budget Of Prosecutor Is Considered
description: The president of the Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders said today that the nine-member body would consider a modest increase in the County Prosecutor's budget to temporarily prevent the layoff of more than 50 people.

title: Accounts
description: * Sky Bank, Salineville, Ohio, part of Sky Financial Group, to Blattner Brunner, Pittsburgh, as the first agency to handle the new bank network's account. Billings were estimated to be as much as $2.5 million.

title: After Bitter Debate, Council Passes a Bill on Lead Paint
description: The City Council approved a measure yesterday to replace the city's 17-year-old law meant to protect children from poisoning caused by lead paint, capping weeks of rancor and more than a decade of legislative fits and starts on one of the most complex issues in public policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFER, HELEN
description: SAFER-Helen. Lido Beach Synagogue mourns our beloved member, Helen Safer, wife of Alex Safer, mother of Marty Safer. Daniel H. Mehlman, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOOKSTAVER, DOUGLAS, B.
description: BOOKSTAVER-Douglas, B. 7/1/60 -7/23/92. Of all sad words, the saddest are ''it might have been.'' Mumsy, Dad, Bobbi & Julie

title: Former Head of Charter Panel Attacks Giuliani's Latest Plan
description: The chairman of a commission that drafted sweeping changes in the City Charter a decade ago sent a stinging letter to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, asserting that Mr. Giuliani's latest plan to revise the Charter was ''overly politicized'' and ''profoundly undemocratic.''

title: Kosovo's Living Delay Burial So Its Dead Can Bear Witness
description: The body of Haxhi Gegollaj's son is not really buried. Rocks and dirt are piled up over his body at a spot a hard, 45-minute hike up a ridge outside the town of Lubizhde. His black jacket pokes out from under the stones. That is how Mr. Gegollaj knows that Nexhat, 22 years old when he died, is there.

title: Lawyers for Officer in Louima Case Say 3d Juror Has Doubts
description: Lawyers for Charles Schwarz, one of the two police officers convicted of torturing Abner Louima, said yesterday that a third juror had joined two others in saying they would have voted to acquit Mr. Schwarz had they known certain information before the verdict.

title: U.S. Releases Files on Abuses in Pinochet Era
description: The C.I.A. and other Government agencies had detailed reports of widespread human rights abuses by the Chilean military, including the killings and torture of leftist dissidents, almost immediately after a 1973 right-wing coup that the United States supported, according to once-secret Government documents released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMANN, HENRY
description: HEINEMANN-Henry, 58. A resident of Hudson OH, died suddenly on Sunday, June 27 at his home. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Patricia, having just celebrated their 35th wedding anniversary on June 20th. He was a cherished father to his three sons; Eric and his wife Colleen, John and Henry Brian and his fiancee Carson Coleman. He was a devoted brother to Dieter and Herbert of Bremen, Germany. He also leaves behind a loved mother and father-in-law and was a loving brother-in-law and uncle. Born on August 19, 1940 in Bremen, Germany, he immigrated to the United States at age 19. To expedite his United States citizenship, he served in the U.S. Army at Fort Bragg, NC in the 82nd Airborne division as a paratrooper. After serving in the Army, he went to night school at City College of New York, where he received his accounting degree and was a member of the Sigma Alpha-Delta Chapter, Honor Service Society. Mr. Heinemann began his forty-year finance career as a securities clerk at Chase Manhattan Bank and later became manager of financial controls in their International Department. After working at Chase, he went on to become a Senior Financial Officer at Chemical Bank. He then became a Chief Operating Officer at First American Bank of New York which was acquired by KeyCorp, where he was an Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Key Technologies. In Wyckoff, NJ where his family resided for 20 years, he was very active in coaching youth soccer for the Wyckoff Torpedoes Soccer Club. In Bremen, Germany he played soccer, in his teens, for the Werder Bremen Soccer Club. Hank had many interests. He was a prolific reader, loved music, golf and nature. He never missed an opportunity to watch a sunset. Friends may call at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, NJ on Friday 7-9PM. A Funeral Mass will be held Saturday 10AM at St. Elizabeth's RC Church, 700 Wyckoff Avenue Wyckoff, with burial at Mary Rest Cemetery, Mahwah. Memorial contributions may be made to the National Marfan Foundation, 382 Main St, Port Washington NY 11050-3136 or The Province St. Mary of the Capuchin Order, Burse of Lt. William Donohue, 210 West 31st Street, New York, New York 10001-2876.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the former Greek military dictator George Papadopoulos on Monday misstated the party affiliation of former Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, who criticized the Papadopoulos Government. He is a Democrat.

title: PURCHASE BY COATS VIYELLA
description: Britain's largest textile company, Coats Viyella P.L.C., agreed to acquire Hicking Pentecost P.L.C. for $:68 million ($107.1 million). Coats is offering 205 pence in cash for each Hicking Pentecost share, surpassing a bid of 175 pence made earlier in June by American & Effird, a unit of the Ruddick Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. The Barbour Threads division of Hicking Pentecost supplies a diverse range of manufacturers.

title: Sports of The Times; The Aging Veteran And a Rookie
description: THE raucous cheering from behind the ivy-covered wall had long since given way to polite applause, and this was the surest sign that Boris Becker was on his way out on Center Court. On Court 5, one long mis-hit away from tennis's most hallowed turf, Alexandra Stevenson was completing a Houdini-like performance that was Becker's trademark when he first won Wimbledon in 1985.

description: The snazzy new drug benefit drew most of the attention. The rest of President Clinton's Medicare plan drew sparse comment, though many noted what they took to be its modest scope.

description: Wall Street's core business -- the underwriting of stocks and bonds -- slowed slightly in the second quarter as market interest rates rose.

To Andy, the entire Mezey family, and all of his father's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Lawrence S. title: Software Will Let You Mingle With the Crowd at a Web Site
description: Although E-mail, chat rooms and instant messaging have turned parts of the Internet into a conversation parlor, surfing the Web is still a solitary activity. Or it was before Gooey, a new communal Web-surfing program.

title: Lightweight Alternative With Zip for the Road
description: For those on the go, ''companion'' computers, bigger than a Pop-Tart and smaller than a breadbox, might be just the right size. Compaq's Aero 8000, released last month, boasts quite a bit under the hood for a lightweight alternative. It runs on a zippy 64-bit, 128-MHz SH4 processor and also features a smart card reader and writer built right into the unit for those needing file security on the road. The device comes with a voice recorder and 16 megabytes of RAM, which can be upgraded to 64 MB. It also has a 7-hour standard battery life and the ability for remote users to synchronize the unit with servers running Lotus Notes, Novell Groupwise and Microsoft Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. title: Merrill Lynch Is Settling Copper Trading Complaints
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which was accused by Federal regulators of helping finance and profiting from 1995 copper trades intended to inflate copper prices artificially, announced yesterday that it was paying $15 million to settle the complaint without admitting or denying the charges made by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Gillette Accuses Rival of Patent Violations
description: The Gillette Company has accused the American Safety Razor Company of infringing its patents for disposable three-blade razors and imitating the appearance of Gillette products.

title: Nets Thrilled to Get Eschmeyer, A Big Center, With 34th Pick
description: All things considered, the Nets were overjoyed with the outcome of tonight's National Basketball Association draft. Having nothing better than the 34th overall pick, they did not expect to fill a need. But they may have done just that by selecting Evan Eschmeyer, a 6-foot-11-inch, 255-pound center from Northwestern, with the fifth pick of the second round.

title: Future Murky for Tale-Telling Honduran Boy
description: The future of Edwin Daniel Sabillon was as murky as his tall tale of a 3,200-mile journey yesterday, as New York City officials began deliberating whether the 13-year-old boy should be returned to relatives or allowed to begin a new life here as a foster child.
