title: It's Independence Day for Fleury and Free Agents
description: Although today is Canada Day, Don Baizley plans to show up early for work in his office in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: WYNDHAM RECEIVES $1 BILLION FROM INVESTOR GROUP
description: Wyndham International Inc. said yesterday that it had received a $1 billion investment from investors that include affiliates of Thomas H. Lee Equity Fund IV L.P. and Apollo Investment Fund IV L.P. The owner and franchiser of hotels and resorts said it would use the money to reduce debt and settle forward equity contracts. Wyndham said the equity investment was part of a financial reorganization plan connected to a $1.8 billion credit agreement with the Chase Manhattan Corporation and $650 million in secured loans from Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bear Stearns Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Reinventing 'Macbeth,' With a Real Birnam Wood
description: Dunsinane can seldom have looked as spectacular as it does in the ''Macbeth'' staged in Fort Tryon Park by the Gorilla Repertory Theater Company as the opening production in its eighth season. The massive walls, arches and stairs of the Fort Tryon Memorial, about 100 yards from the park entrance at 190th Street, form the backdrop, with the tower of the Cloisters behind it rising dark in front of the moon and, opposite, the Hudson River glittering through foliage 150 feet below. Processions of witches, killers, apparitions and armies camouflaged as trees seem quite natural as night falls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: 25 Years Later, Disco Fire Haunts Its Survivors
description: It was early in the disco era and, on a Saturday night, places like Gulliver's, with feverish dance floors filled with swaying bodies and flashing strobe lights, were irresistible to teen-agers like Judy Grella.

title: A Sicilian Pianist Plunges Into Virtuosos' Territory
description: Epifanio Comis, a pianist from Catania, Sicily, gave a decently pleasurable but also somewhat frustrating debut recital in Weill Hall on Sunday evening. The frustration came partly from his choice of virtuoso pieces -- Chopin's ''Polonaise-Fantaisie'' and ''Grande Polonaise Brillante'' and Liszt's ''Tarantella'' -- that took him into realms of virtuosity where he was not completely secure. His right hand here was fast and even, but not quite accurate enough to astonish.

title: Artest Joining Friend, But Not Preferred Club
description: Ron Artest nearly staggered up to the podium, the relief washing over him, the shock filling his eyes. He had been taken by the Chicago Bulls as the 16th pick in the draft. As he made his way toward Commissioner David Stern, he took one last look at his own dream team, glancing at the Knicks' table on the floor of the M.C.I. Center and raising his hands as if to say, ''What's up with that?''

title: U.S. Investigates Undersea Cable
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether the AT&T Corporation and other established telecommunications companies are using a $1 billion undersea cable project to unfairly squash competition from upstarts like Global Crossing Ltd.

title: A Wary Eye on Implants
description: To the Editor:

title: Annan Urges Swift Action On Assistance To Kosovo
description: Warned today that urgent action was needed to reintegrate refugees flooding back into Kosovo, United Nations members were cajoled or shamed into pledging additional money and personnel to help secure and assist a democratic, multiethnic Kosovo.

title: Irate Headmaster, Irreverent Alumnus: The 'Family Guy' Saga
description: An Episcopal priest and private school headmaster who has been waging a successful one-man campaign to get advertising withdrawn from a Fox sitcom called ''The Family Guy'' said yesterday that he had begun the crusade out of annoyance that a colleague's surname was chosen for the show's unruly leading family.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN TARIFF CUT
description: The Mexican Energy Minister, Luis Tellez, announced that a 4 percent cut in the tariff for imported natural gas scheduled to start today would remain in effect unless an anti-dumping lawsuit filed by United States petroleum producers was resolved in Mexico's favor. The suit contends that crude oil has been below the cost of production and was filed against Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iraq and Mexico, which together account for about half of the oil imported to the United States. Rick Wills

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Microsoft's Accounting Under Scrutiny
description: The Microsoft Corporation announced yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the company's accounting practices involving the stating of financial reserves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, REGGIE
description: BLUM-Reggie. The members of Women's League for Israel are deeply saddened by the death of Reggie Blum, valued and dedicated member and officer. To her beloved husband, Dr. Harry Blum, her children and grandchildren, we extend heartfelt condolences on the loss of a caring, loving woman. We will miss her. Harriet Lainer, President

title: Late-Season Spurt Helps Shares in Quarter
description: Statistically, the spring quarter was another banner period for stocks, as the main gauges all climbed between 5 and 12 percent, shattering records along the way.

title: Banks Raise Prime Rates
description: The Bank of America Corporation, the biggest United States bank; the No. 2 Chase Manhattan Corporation; the Bank One Corporation, and Keycorp raised their prime rates to 8 percent from 7.75 percent yesterday after the Federal Reserve increased interest rates for the first time since March 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, GARY
description: ROSENZWEIG-Gary. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Gary Rosenzweig, a dedicated supporter who shared his family's devotion to Jewish causes. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Ruth; his daughter, Joy; his son, Claude; his grandchildren, Jake, Danielle, Aaron, and Esther; his brother, William; and his nephews, Jeffrey, Charles, Stephen, and Ronald. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Not Ready for the Final Lap
description: While some are consigning President Clinton to his retirement, he is pushing energetically ahead and calling on Republicans to cooperate on items on his agenda. Page A16.

title: After 2 Years, Hong Kong Looks More Like China
description: This former British colony passed its second year under Chinese rule today, and to a growing number of critics Hong Kong is taking on a disquieting resemblance to its motherland.

title: James Bond Could Pull A Daring Escape Here
description: How does a restaurant in Montreal, a city known for its brutal winters, create a space for al fresco dining during the temperate summers? In a move worthy of Maxwell Smart, or maybe James Bond, the architect Luc Laporte designed Via Roma with a retractable roof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: The Other Steffi (Jones) On Defense for Germany
description: Under different circumstances, Steffi Jones might have found herself in the American lineup for Thursday's quarterfinals of the Women's World Cup, instead of anchoring the German defense. Tens of thousands of fans might have been cheering for her team, not against it. Perhaps she, too, could be riding a tidal wave of popularity instead of trying to sustain a ripple of interest back home.

title: Mr. McCain's Challenge to Mr. Bush
description: Senator John McCain has delivered a critical challenge to his fellow candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination. Speaking yesterday in New Hampshire, he declared that any candidate who promises to reform anything -- from education to the military to the tax code -- must begin by fixing campaign finance. The current system, he said, is ''nothing less than an elaborate influence-peddling scheme in which both parties conspire to stay in office by selling the country to the highest bidder.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHBEIN, MILTON
description: FISCHBEIN-Milton. Of Sunrise, FL. Formerly of White Plains, N.Y. On June 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Ethel. Father of Martin and Francine. Father-in-law to Toby and Edwin. Loving grandfather of Michael, Benjamin and Adam. We will remember him forever.

title: For Starr and Hubbell, an Accord of Sorts
description: The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr today formally declared an end to the Arkansas phase of his wide-ranging investigation as he accepted two new guilty pleas from Webster L. Hubbell, once the No. 3 official in the Justice Department.

title: Tour Director Admits Failure
description: Two weeks after he banned almost 20 riders and officials in hopes of producing a Tour de France of renewal and redemption, Jean-Marie Leblanc, the race director, admitted failure today. ''We are beaten,'' he said at a news conference called to announce that the bicycle race, scheduled to begin Saturday in western France, would reinstate Richard Virenque, a French star who now rides for the Polti team of Italy, as well as Manolo Saiz, a Spanish team official, as ordered yesterday by the governing body of the sport.

title: Glowing in the Dark
description: Sojiro Inoue, 29, a product designer from Kobe, Japan, came to this country originally to study medicine. On a lark, he transferred to the Rhode Island School of Design. Since graduating in 1996, Mr. Inoue has designed everything from cheap trash cans to invisible hearing aids. He has worked under Karim Rashid for Umbra and, among other things, developed new products for Felissimo in New York. Mr. Inoue's latest brainstorm is phosphorescent furniture, including a night stand for Habitat that glows like a night light at bedtime ( above left) and a series of inexpensive lamps made of pliable polyethylene fabric. The lamps, $75 to $150, from the designer's studio (212) 255-1325; for other furniture: www.sojiro-inoue.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIGGS, EDWARD IKEN (TED)
description: GRIGGS-Edward Iken (Ted). On June 29, 1999. Beloved brother of Henry and Thomas, loving son of the late Harriett and Henry Griggs, adored uncle of Henry III, Elisabeth, Peter, Thomas, and Susan. Services Saturday, 11AM at Christ and St. Stephen Church 120 West 69 Street, NYC. Interment Hillside Cemetery, Terryville, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to Christ and St. Stephen Church.

title: Colombia's Drug Money
description: To the Editor:

title: For All the Yankees, It Was a Day of Oops!
description: Paul O'Neill unleashed a sturdy throw from right field to third base, but it bounced off the glove of Scott Brosius and skipped high in the air. Andy Pettitte was casually backing up the play and tried to corral the ball, but it trickled past his fingers and sailed into the box seats. The ball spilled a fan's beer onto a boy's new Yankees cap, and the soggy kid looked as gloomy as the Yankees felt. Especially Pettitte.

title: Knicks Pick a Project, but He's All of 7 Feet 2
description: The Knicks looked overseas instead of in their own backyard, chose foreign over the familiar and selected potential rather than the popular choice. Ron Artest of St. John's was available when the Knicks used their No. 15 pick in the National Basketball Association draft last night, but they took a gamble and selected a 7-foot-2-inch, 260-pound Frenchman, Frederic Weis.

title: A leading forecaster of ad spending predicts stronger-than-expected gains for this year.
description: A LEADING forecaster of advertising spending has raised his estimate for 1999 after cutting it earlier because of concerns about the worldwide economic turmoil last fall.

title: Before the Palm
description: To the Editor:

title: Law Confronts a Peddler of Private Data
description: Using deception to ferret out personal information, including Ennis Cosby's credit card records after his killing and the home addresses of organized crime detectives in Los Angeles, a private detective built a $1-million-a-year business here selling information that ended up in the hands of everyone from the tabloid press to a reputed member of the Israeli Mafia.

title: Technological Pioneering, Past and Present
description: HOW THE WEB WAS WON:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAGO, HELEN
description: DRAGO-Helen on June 29, 1999. Beloved wife of Richard. Beloved mother of Richard W., Diane, Linda Drago-Keedy and Robert. Devoted grandmother of Christopher Robert and Jennifer Michele Keedy. Dear sister of Mary Klimosky and Agnes Anastasia. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10AM at Holy Name R.C. Church. Reposing M.J. Smith Sons 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

title: Capturing Wright's Inspiration
description: Rigid, rigorous and heavy on the horizontals, Frank Lloyd Wright's design is revered for its abstract geometry. But he took his inspiration from much softer organic forms: the botanical-patterned chiyogami (ceremonial wrapping paper) and katagami (mulberry paper stencils used to dye kimono and obi fabrics) of Japan. His collections at Taliesin West inspired the fabrics, $40 to $80 a yard, below, recently introduced by Schumacher and designed by Kristie Strasen. Information: (800) 988-7775.

title: Bomb Suspects' Lawyers To Need Security Checks
description: Citing the risk of a ''disastrous security breach,'' a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that lawyers for defendants in the embassy bombings and terrorism case must submit to Government security clearances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: President's Top Security Adviser Questioned by Senate Committee
description: President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, made an unusual appearance this afternoon before a Senate committee to answer questions about how the White House has handled the allegations of nuclear espionage by China.

title: A Jolt From Sculpture in a Genteel Garden
description: If monumental sculptures need monumental spaces, Paris offers a feast of possible sites. Yet it was not until Fernando Botero's voluptuous bronzes appeared along the Champs-Elysees in 1992 that sculptures were displayed in the city's public spaces. Was it feared they would detract from the city's own monumentalism? If so, the panic is over. Open-air sculpture shows are now as frequent as, well, say, museum strikes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANISH, ARTHUR
description: KRANISH-Arthur. Of Chevy Chase, Maryland. On June 28th, 1999. Journalist and dealer in fine books. Beloved husband of Allye. Loving father of Clif, Steven, Michael and Erica. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Laura, Sam and Shoshana.

title: Creating Editors And Publishers
description: Can one be taught to be a book editor or publisher in a few summer weeks? Surely not. But this is the time of year when prestigious publishing courses pop to prominence at several major universities, and students who want to go into publishing get a sort of fast-food literary gruel, which is not without value. The courses are the closest thing book publishing has to finishing schools, and, like finishing schools, they are expensive, arguably a bit elitist and very likely worthwhile. They are also unsurpassed as the method for filling the empty entry-level spaces at the bottom of the publishing gulch.

title: Technological Pioneering, Past and Present
description: DIGITAL MCLUHAN:

title: Jacobs in Maine Seeking Bonus
description: A year ago, for breaking the American record for the women's 5,000-meter run at the New Balance Maine Distance Festival in Brunswick, Me., Regina Jacobs won a Volvo S70. On Saturday evening, if she breaks the American record for the 1,000 meters there, another bonus awaits her, this year's version of the car.

description: Q. -- I have heard a lot about the Microsoft Windows registry. What is a registry and what is it used for?

description: To the Editor:

description: William M. B. Berger, who started one of the first mutual funds in Colorado and later sold his fund company and used the proceeds to establish a vast collection of British art, died Tuesday at University Hospital in Denver. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLLWEILER, MAY
description: VOLLWEILER-May. Of Dobbs Ferry, NY. Beloved wife of Kurt. Devoted mother of Steven and Alan. Cherished grandmother of David, Jill, Jennifer, Evan and Todd and great grandmother of Kaitlyn, Kurt and William. Service at 12 noon, Friday, July 2, 1999 at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford, (Saw Mill Exit 17) Dobbs Ferry, New York.

title: Can It Pay to Surf the Web?
description: IT sounded like a great idea at the time.

title: Housing and Medicaid Laws Lapse as Budget Talks Hit Wall
description: State budget talks collapsed today, as New York reached the unfortunate milestone of going three months without a budget, and lawmakers failed to extend laws that protect loft tenants, lower New York City property taxes and trim Medicaid costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTY, RICHARD SERVIS
description: PETTY-Richard Servis, 86. Died on June 26, 1999, at Blue Hill, ME. He was born August 2, 1912, in Hampton, NJ, the son of Robert D. and Florence (Servis) Petty. He was educated at Lehigh University and New York Law School. Shortly before graduating from law school in 1937, he married Marcille Littlefield. While still attending law school, Mr. Petty worked for a firm specializing in public finance and continued in that field after graduation. Following service in the U.S. Navy in World War II, Mr. Petty served as counsel in charge of the Navy Department's New York legal office and then put his public finance expertise to work as a partner in the firm of Mitchell, Petty and Schetterly. That firm ''handled the financing of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the Indiana Turnpike and perhaps twothirds of the turnpikes in the country'' during the highway building boom of the 1950s, Mr. Petty estimated. The firm also handled large-scale bond issues for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and many of its municipalities. Mitchell, Petty and Schetterly was merged into the firm of Brown & Wood in 1979 and Mr. Petty retired as a senior member of that firm in 1985. Recently, Mr. Petty became a member of New York Law School's 21st Century Societythose alumni who provided for the law school in their wills. Mr. Petty's will includes a bequest that would create the Robert D. Petty Scholarship Fund in honor of his late father, a former Dean and founding father of New York Law School. Mr. Petty was motivated to help future law school students by sharing memories of his own Depression-era experience. ''I had a hell of a time financially at the Law School, as did many of my classmates.'' He is survived by one son, Kimball Petty, of Little Deer Isle, ME; one daughter, Gail P. Clarkin, of Coronado, CA; and grandchildren Marci Rose and Dustin Rose. At Mr. Petty's request, gifts in his memory may be made to the Robert D. Petty Scholarship Fund in care of Diana Leo, New York Law School Office of Development, 57 Worth Street, New York, New York 10013. For more information, contact the Healey Funeral Home, South Street, Blue Hill, ME.

title: Gun Flow to Criminals Laid To Tiny Fraction of Dealers
description: A study performed for the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has found a compelling pattern of evidence demonstrating that guns used to commit crimes move quickly from manufacturers to juvenile offenders and older criminals through a relative handful of corrupt dealers.

title: Judge Annuls Rule Allowing Sale of Air Rights by Theaters
description: A year-old city zoning rule that lets Broadway theater owners sell the development rights above their buildings to developers of nearby sites has been overturned by a Manhattan judge.

title: Sir John Woolf, 86, Producer Of 'African Queen' and 'Oliver'
description: Sir John Woolf, who produced such films as ''The African Queen,'' ''Oliver!'' and ''The Day of the Jackal,'' died on Monday at his home in London. He was 86.

title: Court Upholds Prison Ban on Sexual Materials
description: Reversing a lower court decision, a Federal appeals court today allowed New Jersey to ban sexually oriented books, magazines, and films from a state prison for child molesters, rapists and other sex offenders.

title: In America; Restless Radicals
description: If there is one thing political observers should have learned in the 90's, it's to never underestimate the talent Republicans have for squandering a big advantage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, DOROTHY JUDITH
description: HABER-Dorothy Judith. On June 29, 1999. Beloved mother of Ruth Haber Jonas and the late Edgar Haber, mother-in-law of Carol Avery Haber and Saran Jonas. Grandmother of Eben, Graham and Justin Haber and of Elizabeth and Frederick Jonas. Great-grandmother of Julia and Timothy Eisen and of David and Zachary Jonas. Service will be at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, at 10:30 AM, Friday, July 2.

title: In the G.O.P., It's Power vs. Ideals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Bush Announces a Record Haul, And Foes Make Money an Issue
description: George W. Bush announced today that in four months his campaign has amassed $36.3 million, smashing all records in Presidential politics and assuring that he will have the resources to dominate, if not overwhelm, the Republican field throughout the primary season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Negotiations Continue for Ulster Accord
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, and Northern Ireland's political leaders talked today past a midnight deadline in an effort to break an impasse threatening the peace settlement that has promised to end sectarian violence in the British province.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a protest in Yugoslavia against President Slobodan Milosevic misspelled the surname of an organizer. He is Vladan Batic, not Babic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Holbrooke Nomination Passes One Hurdle but Faces Another
description: Richard C. Holbrooke's long-delayed nomination to be the chief American diplomat to the United Nations won the approval of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, but the date of a final vote for the nomination on the Senate floor remained uncertain.

title: McCain Exhorts His Party To Reject Campaign System
description: Putting the overhaul of the campaign finance law squarely at the center of his Presidential bid, Senator John McCain today called on the Republican rank and file to rise up against a system he branded ''an elaborate influence peddling scheme in which both parties conspire to stay in office by selling the country to the highest bidder.''

title: The Fed Makes a Minimal Move
description: William McChesney Martin Jr., the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board during the great economic expansion of the 1950's and 1960's, once said that the role of the Fed was ''to take away the punch bowl just when the party gets going.''

title: AUTONATION CHIEF EXECUTIVE AGREES TO STEP DOWN
description: Autonation Inc. said yesterday that Steven Berrard, who helped H. Wayne Huizenga build the company into the world's largest auto retailer, would step down as chief executive as the company tries to lift its lagging stock price. Mr. Berrard, 44, will retain a seat on the board of the company, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and continue as co-chief executive with Mr. Huizenga until a new chief executive is named. Starting with no dealerships, the two men in three years forged Autonation into an enterprise with annual sales of about $20 billion from new and used cars and automobile rentals. Autonation shares fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $17.8125.

title: The Fabric of America
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Irabu, at His Best, Silences Favorite Foe
description: With Orlando Hernandez cheering him on -- ''Go!'' Hernandez yelled, in English, Spanish or Japanese -- Hideki Irabu rushed out of the Yankees' dugout to pitch the fifth inning last night, feeling great, his confidence high, probably the best it has been since joining the Yankees two years ago. But there was a problem.

title: Joshua Nkomo of Zimbabwe Is Dead at 62
description: Joshua Nkomo, the once-fiery African nationalist and guerrilla leader who was father to Zimbabwe's struggle for independence, died today in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Sylvia Sidney, 30's Film Heroine, Dies at 88
description: Sylvia Sidney, whose vulnerable but spunky persona helped make her the ultimate heroine of realistic movies of the 1930's, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Dodgers, Best Paid in N.L., Are Third Worst on Field
description: Major League Baseball and Federal and local law enforcement officials staged a showy news conference at Fenway Park yesterday warning that they would crack down on the production and sale of counterfeit merchandise during the week of All-Star Game festivities in Boston.

title: New Video Releases
description: Affliction

title: Reviving the Economics of Fear; In Bad Times, Consumers Might Simply Refuse to Spend
description: Anyone who lived through the Great Depression or studied economics in its aftermath quickly learned that even when the Government prodded people to spend more, they would not do so in frightening times. Then came the prosperous decades. Americans began to spend freely, in good times and bad, and the image of the recalcitrant consumer faded from college courses. Now, suddenly, it is coming back.

title: Private Schools' Shield
description: To the Editor:

title: LUCENT GETS CCOM INFORMATION FOR UNDISCLOSED TERMS
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the closely held CCOM Information Systems, giving it software that makes it easier to move data on computer networks. The price was not disclosed. CCOM, based in Iselin, N.J., makes software that lets large businesses simultaneously update voice mail, payroll and other data bases. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., uses CCOM software in its new Definity products, which let consumers send telephone calls through either traditional voice networks or newer data networks like the Internet. Lucent stock rose 62.5 cents, to $68.0625.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHN WOOD GROUP P.L.C., Abderdeen, Scotland, an energy-services company, agreed to buy Kreisler Manufacturing Corp., St. Petersburg, Fla., a maker of metal parts for aircraft engines, for $25.5 million.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Men Without Women'

title: H.M.O.'S WILL RAISE MEDICARE PREMIUM OR TRIM BENEFITS
description: Health maintenance organizations will increase Medicare premiums or cut benefits for most of their six million elderly subscribers next year because they consider the Federal payments they receive inadequate, a trade association for the managed care industry said today.

title: Drop-Dead Beauty and Luxe, With an Intimate Index of Change
description: When it comes to architecture exhibitions, nothing hits home like a show about houses. It is a subject to which everyone brings an intimate familiarity, strong opinions and feelings both buried and exposed.

title: It Is Bright, but Will Men Wear It?: Color Is Back as Men Rediscover Their 'Inner Peacock'
description: LONDON  After seasons of gray, gray and more gray, bright color is making a comeback. Menswear designers are showing a rainbow of colors on the runways of Europe for spring 2000. But the question remains: Will men buy it?

title: Zenith Raises Spending Forecasts
description: A leading media services agency is raising its forecasts for worldwide advertising spending, citing the improved global economic climate and diminished fears of recession.

title: Law Went Too Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, BARRY M.
description: SCHREIBER-Barry M. On June 30th, 1999. Beloved husband of Debbi. Dear son of Frances and the late George Schreiber. Cherished brother of Robert (Helen) Schreiber and Carol (Roy) Swanson. Adored uncle and nephew. Services today, July 2, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mold Scare in Poland Causes Another Coke Recall
description: Following the discovery of mold inside one batch of glass bottles earlier this week, the Coca-Cola Company is recalling all of its soft drinks in the same-sized bottles in Poland, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELCHER, JONATHAN KNAPP, MD.
description: BELCHER-Jonathan Knapp, MD. Died suddenly, June 24, from complications from Leukemia in San Jose, California. Dr. Belcher was a member of the teaching faculty of the San Jose Medical Center Family Practice Residency Program, and he also held a faculty teaching appointment through the Stanford University Medical School. For over twenty years, he was a clinical consultant at the Women's Community Clinic of San Jose and the Tri-City Clinic in Fremont, California. A son of the late Benjamin and Nancy Belcher, Dr. Belcher was born in Greenwich, Connecticut in 1940, was educated at the Hotchkiss School, Princeton University and the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Dr. Belcher is survived by his wife Elena, his children Debra, Barry, Aaron, Phoebe and Katrina and his granddaughter Hannah, as well as by four siblings, Benjamin Belcher, Sara Wardell, Ward Belcher and Jane Phinney. Funeral services were held in San Jose, California on June 28 and there will be a memorial service in Salisbury, Connecticut later in the year. Dr. Belcher is remembered by his medical colleagues as an exceptional teacher of medicine and by his friends and family for his exceptional passion and generosity. Memorial contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood of Connecticut (New Haven).

title: BEER PRODUCERS JOIN
description: Brazil's two leading beer producers are joining forces in a move that could create the world's fourth-largest brewery. Cervejaria Brahma, the country's largest brewery, and a rival Antarctica Paulista said they would form a partnership. Brahma is expected to take over Antarctica.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the film and theater producer Allan Carr yesterday misstated the title of a 1977 film starring John Travolta, whom Mr. Carr selected for the 1978 film ''Grease.'' The 1977 film was ''Saturday Night Fever,'' not ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Album of the Week
description: GUILLERMO KLEIN: ''Los Guachos II'' (Sunnyside). Record stores will file it under jazz, but there's nothing in popular music right now like ''Diario de Alina Reyes,'' the lead track from Guillermo Klein's second large-ensemble album. It's constructed out of a series of rapid, beautiful melodies, and it sounds as if Mr. Klein composed them without worrying about length; he was going to find a way to fit them together. It's a three-and-a-half-minute jumble of sound, with Mr. Klein's nicotine-stained voice opening up into hand percussion and muted brass, doublings and triplings of vocal lines, some synthesizer arpeggios, then (believe it or not) lyrics written in palindromes; the tapes run backward for a sequence of the song, and then the instrumentation opens up to a full band, with brass and woodwinds.

title: Defender of the Loft Unbowed After 17 Years
description: AS Wednesday night dissolved into Thursday morning this week, Chuck DeLaney, recovering from a rather stressful day, sat down in his loft to a late supper of Pakistani takeout, and, more trenchantly, a generous gin martini.

title: Crew Says School Board Chief Is Hostage of Mayoral Politics
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew charged today that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was putting politics ahead of education in considering a plan to push the Board of Education to oust its president, William C. Thompson Jr., in favor of a mayoral ally.

title: Lott Says That, Despite Snags, Holbrooke Is Likely to Be Confirmed
description: With at least three Senators blocking a final vote to confirm Richard C. Holbrooke as the chief American diplomat at the United Nations, the Senate majority leader Trent Lott said today that the nomination ''has some problems'' but that Mr. Holbrooke was still likely to be confirmed.

title: Disability Law Can't Protect All; Invisible Illnesses
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Dies After Beating; Girls Are Held
description: A 25-year-old woman died tonight after a severe beating by two teen-age girls who, the police said, assaulted her when she complained that their car was blocking the street.

title: Financier Faces Fraud Charges
description: David Blech, the former biotechnology financier, was charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission with defrauding investors and brokerage firms of $22.5 million by manipulating 10 stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Out of the Box: Familiar Faces Glisten Above The Footlights
description: Yet another name-brand star of the small screen is taking his bows on a New York stage this summer. He's visiting through August, or in other words, until he is due back on the set of his long-running, Emmy-winning police series, Tuesday nights on ABC. In the interim you can catch him in a little theater off Union Square, where he is delivering just the sort of sensitive performance that landed him a juicy part in prime time.

title: Blocked Artery Sends Koch To Hospital for Treatment
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch was hospitalized and treated for a blocked artery yesterday after experiencing chest pain during an early-morning workout at a gym.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTMAN, LEE
description: FELTMAN-Lee. July 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Lenore and Joan. Loving grandfather of Laura, Mark, Lisa, Stephanie and Rebecca. Respected attorney for over 50 years. Service Friday, July 2, 12:30 PM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARKEY, FRANCES
description: SHARKEY-Frances. On June 30, 1999. Wife of the late Melvin. Survived by Richard, Allan and Barbara. Beloved aunt and great aunt. She will be sorely missed by friends and family. Services Fri. 10:30am at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: PERSIAN GULF NATURAL GAS
description: Mobil Oil Qatar Inc., a unit of the Mobil Corporation, could sell up to 500 million cubic feet a day of natural gas to the United Arab Emirates as part of a $10 billion project to build a national gas grid in the southern Persian Gulf. The United Arab Emirates Offsets Group, backed by the Government of Abu Dhabi, said the agreement in principle to buy gas from Mobil Qatar was part of a project called Dolphin.

title: Gucci's Glam Slam vs. Prada's Vanity Sportswear
description: MILAN  The Italian menswear season, which closes Friday, has been about romancing the male. The fashion appeal has two aspects: sex and sport. And there are twin team-leaders: Gucci and Prada.

title: INSIDE
description: Joshua Nkomo Dies at 82

title: DaimlerChrysler Says Sales Fell in June, Against Trend
description: Surprising analysts, DaimlerChrysler A.G. said today that sales of its Chrysler-brand vehicles declined in June, which had been expected to be one of the auto industry's best sales months ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: 2 States Act to Limit Spread Of Video Poker Machines
description: Two Southern states took steps today to control the spread of video poker machines, which have brought impulsive gambling to the dark corners of thousands of gas stations, convenience stores and restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EVELYN V.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Evelyn V. Wife of Murray, mother of Phyllis and Charles, grandmother of Deborah, Joseph, Arthur and Jeffrey, greatgrandmother of Raphael, daughter of Minnie and Sol Bier, sister of Jack, Helen and Gert, aunt of Frances, Stanley, Allen, Andrea, Jerry and Norman, died on June 28, 1999 in her 97th year, in Carbondale, CO beside her granddaughter. She gave love to her family and friends for nearly a century and knew what it is to be dearly loved in return. After a blessed life, she died at peace. Mrs. Goldstein will rest at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUKAMAL, LOUISE
description: MUKAMAL-Louise. Wife of the late Isaac. Mother of Dr. Ronald, Dr. Harold, Joseph, Lila and Dr. Edmond. Grandmother and great grandmother and sister. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 12:30 P.M., Friday, July 2.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Ivy Teams Advance In Temple Challenge
description: Three Ivy League crews advanced in the Temple Challenge Cup yesterday at the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on May 17 described fraudulent trials of new drugs by Robert Fiddes, a California doctor who operated a company, now defunct, that he called the Southern California Research Institute. Dr. Fiddes had no connection to another company of the same name in Los Angeles, a nonprofit corporation that has conducted research on traffic safety since 1973.

title: Political Briefing; Forbes Passes the Hat Among Common Folk
description: Back in 1996, Steve Forbes spent $37.5 million of his personal publishing fortune on his first run for the Presidency. And he says he is ready to do it again the second time around, if necessary, which well may be the case given that he is still down in the single digits in the polls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: It's a Long Way From Altoona to Druggy Depravity
description: Every so often, at moments of high stress, Tom (Jason London), the Los Angeles paramedic who narrates ''Broken Vessels,'' has dreamlike flashbacks to the pastoral world back East that he fled in a big hurry. In these sequences Tom, who grew up in Altoona, Pa., and is nicknamed Tuna Fish by his boss, remembers speeding in his car through a bright-green landscape of farms and woodlands that look infinitely more wholesome than the place where he has landed. Whatever drove Tom to abandon such a pretty environment for the concrete wilds of Los Angeles, we wonder. Might he be fleeing some terrible personal blunder?

title: MONSANTO SAYS IT PLANS TO SELL TWO BUSINESSES
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would sell its artificial sweeteners business to pay debt and focus more on its drug and agricultural products. Monsanto also said it planned to sell a unit that makes biogums, food ingredients used to thicken products like sauces and gravies. The sweeteners unit sells its products under brands like Nutrasweet and Equal. The divestiture process will begin immediately, Monsanto said. It did not name any potential buyers. First-quarter sales of Monsanto's nutrition and consumer products fell 21 percent, to $304 million. Stock in Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, rose $2.5625, to $42.125.

title: P.C. Exports Eased
description: Technological advances that have made personal computers as powerful as supercomputers were just a few years ago prompted President Clinton to greatly ease restrictions on exports of high-speed machines to countries like Russia and China.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ON THE STREET

title: Shades of Suburban Blues
description: Is it the pointlessly curving driveways, the baronial delusions, the strips of flat lawn, the denial of nature, the spotless sinks, the boredom, or the way the lights go on at night even when no one is home? Why does suburban living seem so unspeakably blah?

title: A Boy's Best Friend And the Town Meanie
description: It would be so easy to make fun of Friendly, W. Va., where the little yellow school bus rolls by, reading ''Friendly Elementary School'' on the side. And it would be easy to ridicule the Prestons, who live there and are so down home that their television set doesn't even have a remote. The Prestons are wise, hard-working parents; the town has a kindly country doctor; the new schoolteacher is too sweet to be true. ''Shiloh 2: Shiloh Season'' could have turned sappy or simple-minded in many ways, but it never does -- despite the numerous close-ups of the title character, a soulful-eyed beagle with a troubled past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EXSTEIN, RUTH ADLER BURNHOLZ
description: EXSTEIN-Ruth Adler Burnholz, 97, on June 30th, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Henry and Myron. Loving mother of Nancy and Ann. Beloved grandmother of Tom, Dan, Peg, Julie, Leslie and cherished great grandmother of eleven. Services were held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLEVRITIS, GEORGE
description: PLEVRITIS-George. Of Fort Lee, N.J. and New York. On June 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Chrysanthe. Cherished father of Jon Spiro Plevritis, Esq. and Joannie Danielides. Grandfather of Philippe and Alexander Danielidies. Also survived by adoring nieces and nephews. Retired engineer, Allied Signal Aerospace, past President AHEPA Chapter 405, past Secretary Hellenic University Club, graduate of Stuyvesant High School and New York University School of Engineering.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about plans for a nationwide search for new school principals and superintendents in New York City misstated the role of Chancellor Rudy Crew's boroughwide deputies. They act as liaisons between the Chancellor's office and the school superintendents; they do not oversee the superintendents.

title: French Observatory Gondola Plunges in the Alps, Killing 20
description: Twenty people died today when a gondola in the Alps in southeastern France ran off a supporting cable and plunged 262 feet to the ground.

title: A School Regains Stellar Reputation; Students Outshine the Elite In Standardized Test Scores
description: On a muggy day in July 1987, two busloads of students, teachers and administrators traveled from their ramshackle school building in Queens to a sprawling cemetery in Brooklyn to memorialize the man for whom their recently revived high school was named: Townsend Harris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Bertelsmann Chief Turns Voting Control Over to a New Board
description: Reinhard Mohn, the 78-year-old patriarch who has controlled Bertelsmann A.G. for nearly four decades, began a cautious process today of making the world's third-largest media conglomerate less of a family business.

title: Web Concession From Microsoft
description: In a symbolic concession that it cannot control all facets of Internet technology, the Microsoft Corporation has agreed to license the latest audio and video player from Real Networks rather than favor its own less popular competing product.

title: Do Voters Care About Character?; Compassion Is Key
description: To the Editor:

title: But Natural Is Best, Stylists Say : Hair Takes a Short Cut
description: PARIS  Since the days of Samson, men have paid a great deal of attention to their hair, the abundance or the absence of which have a powerful effect on their self-image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHTER, BARRY
description: BUCHTER-Barry. Of Boiling Springs, PA. Died June 29th. in Carlisle, PA. Survived by two sons, a brother and a sister. He was proprietor of Highland House Bed & Breakfast, and previously was a Production Executive for ABC TV in New York.

title: For Fear of Libel
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Robinson's Fast Flurry Propels The Liberty
description: She had crept around the court all season, seemingly too timid to reach into the Liberty cookie jar and feast on some basketball glory. Crystal Robinson, formerly a star in the defunct American Basketball League, was now the shy one in the corner, trying to fit in with her new teammates.

title: Court Isn't Likely to Let States Off the Hook; Let Congress Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: INVACARE BIDS FOR DANISH MEDICAL EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: The Invacare Corporation, a maker of health care products, said yesterday that it had bid 945 million Danish kroner ($131 million) for Scandinavian Mobility International, a Danish maker of wheelchairs and mobility aids. The offer of 105 kroner a share was a 24 percent premium over Wednesday's closing share price of 85 kroner. Scandinavian Mobility shares rose 17 kroner, or 20 percent, to 102. Invacare, which is based in Elyria, Ohio, had 1998 sales of $797 million. It said the acquisition would give the company a foothold in Scandinavia.

title: Quoting Gotti's Father, Prosecutors Seek Longer Term for Son
description: Federal prosecutors asked a judge yesterday to impose the maximum possible prison sentence of more than seven years on John A. Gotti, citing his refusal to admit that he was the acting boss of the Gambino crime family and his failure to meet a deadline for paying a $750,000 fine after his racketeering and extortion conviction.

title: Some Worry Sport Utilities Are Too Much for New York
description: A promotional video for the GMC Yukon shows G. Richard Wagoner Jr., the president of General Motors, telling his chauffeur to take a shortcut across Manhattan. The driver cuts the wheel and the Yukon, a giant sport utility vehicle, responds, weaving through traffic, slaloming between safety cones, riding up on the sidewalk and, finally, careering around a truck on a narrow street.

title: Seductive Objects With a Sly Sting
description: With only half a year to go until the millennium arrives, wouldn't it be great to have a worldwide designer yard sale? Out with the Richard Meier plates! Away with the Michael Graves tea kettles! For when the dust has settled from this maniacally industrious chapter in the field of industrial design, only four figures of major artistic stature will be left standing: Ettore Sottsass, Gaetano Pesce, Philippe Starck and Shiro Kuramata. Two Italians, one Frenchman and a gentleman from Japan, the last, alas, no longer living.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, L. DENVER
description: HART-L. Denver. It is with deep sadness that we announce the death of the Reverend L. Denver Hart, Senior Associate Rector of St. Bartholomew's Church and devoted friend and colleague, on June 30th, 1999. He is survived by his partner, Bruce Webber, of New York; his mother, Jane Hart, of Zelienople, PA; and his brother, James Hart, of Palmyra, PA. Vigil prayers and visitation, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Monday, July 5, 6-8PM. Burial Service and Requiem at St. Bartholomew's, Tuesday, July 6 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the L. Denver Hart Memorial Fund, C/O St. Bartholomew's, 109 East 50th Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, WALTER
description: ROSE-Walter. Walter Rose of New Rochelle died June 30, 1999 at Sound Shore Medical Center. He was 101 years of age. Mr. Rose is survived by his son Stanley of New York City, his daughter Marion Reichner of Pearl River, NY and his son Martin of Greenwich, CT. Also, Mr. Rose was the loving grandfather of Jennifer Shepp, Michael Rose, Kenneth Reichner, Gordon Rose, Daniel Reichner and J. Carter Rose and the greatgrandfather of Garrett, Rachel, Eli and Sarah. He was married to the late Rose Gold, Rose who died in 1991. Mr. Rose attended Syracuse University on an athletic scholarship and graduated in 1922 with a degree in law. He was member and officer of Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity on a chapter and national level. Mr. Rose was a partner in the family retail furniture business, Joseph Rose & Sons Inc. in Long Island City and was President of the Steinway Street Merchant's Association. He was a retired Captain from 114th Precinct Auxiliary Police, a track and field coach of the PAL and an original founder of the Boys Club of Queens. At the time of his retirement in 1970 he became active in the Children's Service League of Westchester County until his demise. Walter Rose received numerous awards including Chancellor Eggers Award for Outstanding Support and Letterman of Distinction from Syracuse University. In 1995 he was inducted in the Westchester Senior Citizen's Hall of Fame for his outstanding Community Service. He was presented with a proclamation from the City of New Rochelle for his 100th birthday. Chapel Service will be conducted at the funeral home today at 10:00 a.m. with interment to follow at the Old Mount Carmel Cemetery. The family will receive friends and relatives at Mr. Rose's home today following the committal until 4:00 p.m. and from Sunday until Thursday morning at the home of Marion Reichner. Donations can be made to the Children's Service League, P.O. Box 340, Wykagyl Station, New Rochelle, NY 10804 or the Walter Rose Scholarship at the Sigma Alpha Mu Foundation, 651 North Range Line Road, Carmel, Indiana 46032. For more information, contact George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, NY 10801, 914-632-0324.

title: Residential Real Estate; Adding Affordable 3-Family Homes to Bedford-Stuyvesant Mix
description: By the middle of the month, two mostly vacant blocks in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn will begin to fill with a housing type so far absent from the neighborhood's revival: 45 three-family homes for people with annual incomes of $30,000 to $70,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Do Voters Care About Character?; Ignoring the Platforms
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Taps Silicon Valley For Support
description: Encroaching on political turf that Vice President Al Gore has cultivated for years, Gov. George W. Bush ventured into Silicon Valley today to fatten his already flush campaign treasury and to unveil proposals favored by the technology industry.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Rangers Fly Off for the Free-Agent Frenzy
description: Neil Smith and Dave Checketts began their jet-propelled shopping spree yesterday, seeking free agents to bolster the Rangers' roster. They took the company plane to Winnipeg to negotiate with Don Baizley, the agent for right wing Theo Fleury. Their next stop was suburban Los Angeles to talk to Pat Brisson, the agent for defenseman Stephane Quintal. They were considering another touchdown in California to see Jeff Solomon, the agent for center Bob Corkum.

title: BRAZILIAN TRADE DEFICIT
description: Brazil posted a trade deficit last month, reversing a May surplus, as weak commodity prices cut exports and a modest economic recovery raised imports. Brazil's trade deficit was $144 million, which compared with a surplus of $312 million in May. Exports fell to $4.31 billion last month, from $4.38 billion in May, on weak prices for key export commodities like coffee, sugar and soybeans. Imports rose to $4.45 billion, from $4.07 billion in May, a sign the economy may be pulling out of recession.

title: New Jersey Senate Passes Bill Requiring 'Smart Gun' Devices
description: Despite a barrage of criticism from advocates on both sides of the gun debate, the Senate narrowly approved a bill today that would require that all handguns sold in New Jersey include so-called smart-gun technology when it becomes available.

title: In Summer, They Speak The Language of Snow
description: The American Dance Festival helped bring the seasons magically together on Wednesday night. As everywhere else in America, it was summer outside Reynolds Industries Theater on the campus of Duke University here. But inside the theater it was eternal winter in two haunting productions choreographed, designed and performed by the Japanese-born dancers who are professionally known as Eiko and Koma.

title: Randolph Guggenheimer, 91; Saved Hospital
description: Randolph Guggenheimer, a Manhattan lawyer who helped spearhead the development of a community hospital serving the residents of Harlem, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: INDONESIAN DEBT COLLECTION
description: The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency said it would take legal action against 26 of the nation's 200 largest corporate debtors after they missed a deadline for promises to repay. The agency had imposed a Wednesday deadline for the borrowers to sign what it termed a letter of commitment. A spokesman for the agency said some of the corporate debtors had neglected to return the letter and others had returned letters with unauthorized changes.

title: Backing New York on Medicare, First Lady Lobbies White House
description: In the first public indication of a policy difference between Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband, the First Lady joined New York labor and political leaders yesterday at a White House meeting to argue against proposed Medicare cuts that could hurt New York hospitals.

title: Master Plan for the Everglades
description: The White House yesterday delivered to Congress a detailed blueprint for the most ambitious environmental restoration project ever undertaken in this country. The plan's basic purpose is to restore the historical flows of fresh water that once made the Everglades one of the world's most wondrous and biologically diverse ecosystems. It is the product of six years of work by the Army Corps of Engineers, scientists and environmentalists. But its fate, and that of the Everglades, now rests with legislators in Washington and Tallahassee. It is they who must provide the money -- nearly $8 billion over 20 years, shared equally between the Federal Government and Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Panel Sees No Short Cut To a Less Violent Media
description: The topic before a packed auditorium at the New School in Greenwich Village was ''Violence in America: Reel Life vs. Real Life.''

title: 9 Officers Are Suspended After a Suspect Is Beaten
description: Nine Newark police officers have been suspended from duty indefinitely because some of them beat a criminal suspect in a station house and others allowed prisoners to continue pummeling him in a cell, the authorities said today.

title: The Death of God, a Continuing Serial
description: GOD'S FUNERAL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

description: AMORELLO-Erna. February 2, 1920-July 2, 1998. One year has flown by, but not a day without thinking of you. We miss you so. Love, Susie and Kenny

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa rose almost 2 percent as a halt of exports from West Africa after a recent selling spree reduced available supplies. In New York, cocoa for July delivery rose $17, or 1.6 percent, to $1,055 a metric ton.

title: I.R.A. Talks Halt, to Much Teeth Gnashing
description: Marathon talks to resolve the disarmament impasse that threatens the province's peace settlement broke off early today. But a spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair said they would resume this morning and end with a statement on the ''way forward.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Resilient Americans Advance to Semifinals
description: The confused, disorganized American defense continued its maddening habit of early breakdowns tonight in the Women's World Cup. Brandi Chastain did the unthinkable and put a shot into her own goal in the fifth minute. Briana Scurry, the goalkeeper, spent the first half glaring at her teammates with the molten stare of a prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRAY, LEWIS, MARJORIE CRAIG
description: GRAY - LEWIS - Marjorie Craig. April 25, 1913-July 3, 1998. Educator, mentor, executive, visionary, friend. Lois Dennis, Emily Hammond, Anne Impellizzeri and Frances Updike Simonds

description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: California Bill Would Limit Handgun Buyers to 1 a Month
description: The California Legislature yesterday approved a measure to limit handgun purchases to one a month, making it the largest state to pass legislation that gun-control advocates say will reduce the flow of guns to criminals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURSTEIN, SHLOMO
description: BURSTEIN-Shlomo. Beloved husband of Haidee and father of Tamara passed from this earth on July 1, 1999.
