title: Steaming Through a World That Time Left Behind
description: This was old-time Pennsylvania railroad country, but there was nothing of the Rust Belt about it. There was no soot in the air, no grime to speak of, no debris scattered in weeds along the track beds. The landscape was actually scenic, and for a camera-toting tourist at the heart of it, in the historic town of Strasburg, there were plenty of pretty shots to be had: a Georgian brick home serenely overlooking a shady Main Street, a white barn and silo standing crisply by a green pasture, a Victorian station restored to its gabled glory. All with photo-album potential.

title: Suburban Features Behrens
description: Behrens, one of the leading handicap horses in the country, will head a parade of racing stars to Belmont Park for a Fourth of July weekend, with six stakes and $1 million in purses. Behrens, a 5-year-old son of Pleasant Colony, comes into the Suburban Handicap on Monday with a winning streak of three, and has finished first or second in all five of his starts this year.

title: Do Voters Care About Character?; Kennedy's Style
description: To the Editor:

title: At The Movies
description: Anticipation: The Next Movie

title: Bartle Leaving Shop He Helped to Found
description: John Bartle, a founding partner of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, the creatively focused London agency, said yesterday that he would leave in December to focus on what he described as other business options.

title: Giuliani Endorses Raises for Mayor and Other Top Officials
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided that he and the city's other top officials deserve a raise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: The Human Difference
description: We can embrace poetical reminders of our connection to the natural world, whether expressed as romantic effusions about oneness, or in the classical meter of Alexander Pope's heroic couplet:

title: Streetwise Styles Show Off the Body : Young Japan Breaks Free
description: PARIS  Ask a fashion aficionado to describe Japanese style, and adjectives such as poetic, purist, complex and intellectual inevitably come up. The thought-provoking shapes, ground-breaking fabrics and personal vision that have put Rei Kawakubo, Yohji Yamamoto and Issey Miyake in the forefront of design have also become synonymous with Japanese fashion as a whole.

title: Metro Business; Loews Selling 3 Hotels
description: The Loews Corporation, the holding company controlled by the billionaire Tisch family, plans to sell three of its New York City hotels as it moves to focus its lodging business on more upscale properties.

title: Foreign Affairs; Was Kosovo World War III?
description: A thoughtful reader, Allan Hoving, sent me a note asking an intriguing question: Was Kosovo actually World War III? ''O.K., so it was a short one, as world wars go, just 80 days,'' he wrote. ''But think about it: There was genocide by indicted war criminals, and the threat of nuclear war. Nearly every major power was involved -- even China. And historic realignments have emerged. . . . All this without a single allied combat casualty -- not too shabby for a world war.''

title: BRITISH SOFTWARE DEAL
description: Britian's biggest phone company, British Telecommunications P.L.C. said it would acquire Control Data Systems Inc., a closely held software company based in Minnesota, for $340 million. Control Data will become part of the Syntegra unit of British Telecommunications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, FLORENCE (NEE SOSNIAK)
description: LEVIN-Florence (nee Sosniak) of Newton, MA on June 30, 1999, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Leon Levin. Mother of Judy Levin-Charns, (husband Martin P. Charns) and the late Marc, (wife Sheila Levin). Grandmother of David Charns and Brad and Marissa Levin. Graveside services in New York, July 2. Memorial week observed at the home of Judy Levin-Charns and Martin Charns.

title: Health Workers Protest Planned Medicaid Cuts
description: More than 1,200 nurses, health aides and hospital workers gathered outside Gov. George E. Pataki's midtown office yesterday to protest his proposals to cut Medicaid spending by hundreds of millions of dollars. Several said the cuts were forcing some financially squeezed hospitals to eliminate some employee benefits.

title: 'High Noon,' Frame by Frame
description: Watching films on digital video disk, one gets into the habit of stopping the film suddenly to look at scenes in freeze frame. There may be no other reason for this than to use the disk's sharpness and clarity to see what any one second in a movie, especially a famous one, looks like as a still picture. Do it often and randomly enough in ''High Noon,'' Fred Zinnemann's classic western, released last week on DVD and in a new videocassette edition by Artisan, and the exercise reveals a production that, even caught unawares, so to speak, stays steadily on its game from first frame to last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: His Best Friend Falls for Her on Their Wedding Day
description: Leave it to the philosophical French to re-examine the romantic triangle in the light of the millennium.

title: Sports of The Times; At Age 30, Graf Is Showing She's Not Yet Over the Hill
description: CONVENTIONAL logic, and even John McEnroe's convoluted brand, suggested that Steffi Graf was not going to have enough fluidity in her muscles and fuel in the tank at the end of a long, soggy day. She walked out onto Center Court, into the gloaming, the sky offering only enough time to finish a set. But it happened to be the third set with Venus Williams, 19, finely tuned, long-limbed and ready to run.

title: Police Detective Injured As Homemade Gun Fires
description: A police detective was shot in the hand yesterday morning when he picked up a suspect's gun in the Bronx and it went off, the police said.

title: A Tale of Three Auroras And of Many 'Beauties'
description: Had the Kirov Ballet opened its season with Diana Vishneva and Andrian Fadeyev leading the cast of its new production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' the initial impression might have been somewhat different. Nor would it have been wrong to start off with Altynai Asylmuratova, New York's favorite Kirov ballerina since the 1980's.

title: Taking the Children
description: Tarzan

title: In This Draft, Finesse Is Selected Over Power
description: When the Knicks passed on St. John's forward Ron Artest with the No. 15 pick to select a virtually unheard of 7-foot-2-inch center from France in the National Basketball Association draft on Wednesday, a zinger was tossed out at the MCI Center in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, EILEEN
description: BERNARD-Eileen. The board of directors, other volunteers, and staff of the United Hospital Fund express their deepest sympathy to Herbert Bernard, our esteemed honorary and former director, as well as to his entire family upon the death of his loving wife of 65 years. Eileen was a source of light and strength to all who knew her, and shared with Herbert the strong values of charity, community, faith, and family. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family. Howard Smith, Chairman James R. Tallon Jr., President

title: Art in Review
description: Jose Bedia

title: INSIDE ART
description: Museum Fills a Gap In Its Dutch Paintings

title: A Rain Forest In the Bronx
description: Most members of the crowd have their faces pressed against the glass. Many are smiling, some wave and a few exclaim, ''Oh, look at how cute the babies are!''

title: The Case of the Once-Feared Camera
description: In baseball telecasts, the production toys are many: Bat Track, which measures bat speed; super-slo-mo cameras; CatcherCam and MaskCam; triple-split screens; instant replays; pitch-by-pitch sequences; Hit Zones; radar guns, plus managers, outfield walls, bullpens and bases all wired for sound.

title: Tree Hugging, 70 Feet Up In a Chattering World
description: There was nothing inherently dangerous about ascending a rope looped 70 feet in the air over a sturdy branch of the white oak called Nimrod. The padded arborist's harness cinched around my waist and thighs was clipped securely to a half-inch rope that could hold two tons. But acrophobia kicked in at about 20 feet, and by the time I was five stories up I felt like Humpty Dumpty just before his unfortunate fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBELMAN, RICHARD S.
description: DUBELMAN-Richard S. on July 1, 1999. Beloved and loving husband to Elaine for forty-five years, devoted father of Deborah, Elizabeth and Daniel, cherished grandfather to Rachel, Robert, Grace and Julianna. He was a generous spirit who used his unique, creative genius, animated sense of humor and deep determination to inspire and encourage others. He produced the Emmy Awardwinning motion picture, ''The Execution of Private Slovik'', which won the coveted George Foster Peabody Award. He photographed the famous ''Hey Mikey'' commercial for Life Cereal, the award-winning Crackerjacks and Polaroid series, and directed many other top commercials. He worked with great artists such as Laurence Olivier, Jack Gilford and Candice Bergen. His work won top awards at every major film festival, including Cannes (Lion d'or), Edinburgh, Venice, Sydney, Cork. He received five Clios, but was most proud of his innovative ballet film, ''Grand Jete''. He wrote ''The Adventures of Holly Hobbie'' which appeared on the B. Dalton best seller list, was published in numerous languages including Hebrew, and for which he won the Golden Scroll Award from the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror Films. He founded the Veritas Studios on 45th St in Manhattan. He was a champion tennis player at City College who loved Hebrew music. Funeral services will be held at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engel St., Englewood, New Jersey today at 1PM. Shiva calls can be paid to the Widow's home. Contributions to Children's Blood Foundation, Inc., New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, 333 East 38th St, Suite 830, New York, New York 10016-2745.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: At Henley, Classic Boats To Cherish
description: Among motor boat enthusiasts, the vintage launch has always been the queen of the waterways. Though its purpose -- to celebrate idyllic river life -- may be frivolous, the boat is not a frivolous enterprise. It must have beauty, history and fine wood patina, and it cannot make waves, so it can be properly admired as it purrs along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, HY
description: FRANKEL-Hy, died June 30, 1999. Hy Frankle, an extraordinary man who had immeasurable impact on many lives. Loved by everyone he met, especially his Woo and their children, Elizabeth, Shepherd, Dylan and Laura; sister and brother Sandy and Neil and their children, Cory, Adam, Jason and Rachel; sister and brother Clair and David and their children, Erica, Grant and Ari. Loved by a circle of close friends known as The Committee, and respected by all who knew him for his compassion and good works. Donations may be sent to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, New York, New York 10013.

title: NATO Commander Says Milosevic Is Moving Forces Into Pro-Western Montenegrin Republic
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, still firmly in control of his army, is sending reinforcements into the pro-Western Yugoslav republic of Montenegro, NATO's military commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, said today.

title: ASK JEEVES MORE THAN QUADRUPLES AFTER INITIAL OFFERING
description: Shares of Ask Jeeves Inc., an Internet search service that says it daily answers a million simply phrased questions, more than quadrupled in their first day of trading yesterday. The company, based in Berkeley, Calif., rose $50.9375, to $64.9375, Ask Jeeves sold a 12 percent stake Wednesday, raising $42 million. It now has a market value of $1.58 billion. Benjamin M. Rosen, 65, a director of the company and the acting chief executive of the Compaq Computer Corporation, has a stake worth about $91.8 million at yesterday's close.

title: Rapturous Companions On a Luminous Bridge
description: A one-of-a-kind cult item famed for its stupendous set, ''The Lovers on the Bridge'' was shown at the 1992 New York Film Festival and has remained splendidly obscure ever since. Now released for a theatrical run by Miramax and Martin Scorsese, whose previous collaborations were ''Belle de Jour'' and ''Purple Noon,'' its curiosity value remains intense. Here is lithe young Juliette Binoche in an eye-patch, playing a scrappy vagrant artist who takes up with an alcoholic fire-eater (Denis Lavant) on the Pont Neuf, the Parisian landmark where much of the film is set. These must be the only two cinematic lovers who have ever gone water-skiing amid fireworks on the Seine.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Approves Measure To Drop Financial Barriers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Provocation and Terror In Enigmatic Forms
description: In the current history of late-20th-century art, the German sculptor and idiosyncratic teacher Joseph Beuys has since his death in 1986 been the great absentee.

title: Political Briefing; Candidates Deliver Laugh Lines at Gala
description: New Hampshire says it is determined to hold the first Election 2000 primary, even if it has to hold it in 1999. Maybe. Maybe not. A lot of other states are jockeying to grab some of that first-in-the-nation glory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLLWEILER, MAY R.
description: VOLLWEILER-May R. On June 30, 1999, in Dobbs Ferry, New York. Beloved and devoted wife of Kurt. Cherished and devoted mother of Steven & Alan. Loving mother-in-law of Catherine and Pat. Cherished grandmother of David, Jill and Jennifer, Evan and Todd. Loving great-grandmother of Kaitlyn, Kurt and William. A dear and cherished friend of all who knew her. Service and burial at 12 Noon, Friday, July 2, 1999, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, New York.

title: Newspaper Concerns Bought by Hearst
description: Three weekly newspaper companies in the Albany area have been sold to the Hearst Corporation, which now has a cluster of newspapers around The Times Union of Albany, a daily and its biggest paper in New York.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Disability Law Can't Protect All; Unfriendly Flier?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Estimates of Surplus Grow, G.O.P. Rethinks Ways to Use It
description: With the projected Federal budget surplus having grown substantially since they first set their budget plans earlier this year, Republican leaders in Congress said today that they would rethink their tax and spending proposals but would not necessarily channel the entire windfall into a bigger tax cut.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wild Ascent Of a Small-Cap Stock, Perhaps By Mistake
description: Somewhere a portfolio manager is cursing a blue streak, and a few day traders are probably counting their profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEZEY, LAWRENCE
description: MEZEY-Lawrence. The Board and Staff of New Alternatives for Children notes with sadness the passing of Lawrence Mezey, beloved father of our Board Vice President, Andrew Mezey, MD. Elizabeth S. Pforzheimer, Pres. Arlene Goldsmith, Exec. Dir.

title: Suit Says Woolworth Fired Old Workers to Build Young Image
description: In the last few years of its existence, F. W. Woolworth Company illegally dismissed as many as 400 older employees and often replaced them with younger ones, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: U S West to Talk With Qwest
description: The board of U S West, the smallest regional Bell company, has agreed to allow management and its advisers to enter into preliminary merger talks with Qwest Communications International Inc., the company said last night.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Little-Known Panel Turns Mayor Into Defendant
description: It is made up of 19 ordinary citizens, most of them retirees, and has a paid staff of one. It operates in solemn secrecy and has sweeping authority to investigate public agencies and officials. Its roots reach back to the Norman Conquest. And even if most Californians have no idea what it does, it set the political establishment of the nation's sixth-largest city squarely on its ear last week.

title: A Port Authority Detective Is Shot at Kennedy Airport
description: A police detective for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was shot in the head early today on the grounds of Kennedy International Airport, the agency said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Through Rain and Gloom, Graf Delivers Message
description: The darker it got, and the longer it dragged on, the more impassioned the Wimbledon quarterfinal between Steffi Graf and Venus Williams became. Graf, the seven-time champion, had a statement to make in her rain-infested contest with Williams, the 19-year-old American whom Graf has deemed worthy to inherit her mantle. But not until Graf is ready to relinquish it.

title: Fire Traps 350 A-Train Riders in Dark and Near-Panic
description: A rubbish fire in a Brooklyn subway shut down power on a heavily traveled line during the evening rush yesterday, leaving 350 riders trapped for 45 minutes in heat and smoky darkness on a train halted in a tunnel and delaying tens of thousands of homebound travelers up to three hours, officials said.

title: Indian Official Denies Talks With Pakistan Over Kashmir Fighting
description: India is not involved in ''any negotiations'' and ''not even consultations'' with Pakistan, its Minister of External Affairs, Jaswant Singh said today, sloughing off speculation in both nations that back-channel diplomacy was under way to end the violent crisis in the mountains of Kashmir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: GO2NET IS BUYING PROCESSOR OF ON-LINE TRANSACTIONS
description: Go2Net Inc., an Internet directory and Web site operator, said yesterday that it had acquired the Authorize.net Corporation, a payment processor for on-line transactions, for $90.5 million in cash and stock to diversify its revenue sources. Go2Net said it would pay $13.5 million in cash and $77 million in stock for the closely held Authorize.net, which manages credit card and electronic check transactions for more than 34,000 on-line businesses. Authorize.net's executives and 22 employees are to remain based in Provo, Utah. The purchase price could increase based on its performance in the next two years. Stock in Go2Net, which is based in Seattle, fell $3.75, to $88.125.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The Fourth of July holiday will be observed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLIVY, CALVIN
description: POLIVY-Calvin. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Janet and Peter Herman, Annette and Steven Polivy. Dear brother of Charles and Allen. Adored grandfather of Lisa, Eric, Saretta, Lance, Brian and Jack. Funeral services Friday, 11:15 AM , at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hong Kong and Disney to Keep Discussing a Theme Park
description: Keeping its people in suspense, Hong Kong announced today that it would extend talks with the Walt Disney Company on building a theme park here until the end of October.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our motto has been 'yesterday's supercomputer is today's laptop.''

title: Foreign Buyers Mark Long Island Wineries' New Status
description: In a vote of confidence in the quickly expanding Long Island wine industry, a group of Chilean investors has bought Laurel Lake Vineyards, a North Fork winery, for nearly $2 million. Experts say it is the first significant foreign investment in a New York winery since the Legislature relaxed laws on winemaking in 1976.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Maintenance Firm's Lawyer Expects Indictments in Valujet Crash
description: The lawyer for an aircraft maintenance company involved in the crash of Valujet Airlines Flight 592 in the Everglades three years ago said today that he believed it was likely that the company and some of its employees would soon be indicted.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUGEN, ARLENE
description: RUGEN-Arlene. On June 30, 1999. Beloved wife of Cord. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Rugen. Loving daughter of Alice Karp. Dear sister of Robert Karp. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral: on Saturday, 10:00 AM. Interment: in Maple Grove Memorial Park.

title: Editorial Observer; A Bad Year for the World's Border Guards
description: Among its other casualties, the war in Kosovo punctured the sanctity of state sovereignty -- the idea that a nation's actions within its borders are its own business. This concept has organized international relations since the Treaty of Westphalia in 1648. That year, as Europe's religious empires crumbled, the Continent's powerful states agreed to respect each other's sovereignty, founding the modern state system. That has now been eroding for 50 years, but the events of the past year have been a blow like no other, and one that should be welcomed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, ROBERT MAURICE
description: WEAVER-Robert Maurice. On June 30, at the age of 88, beloved brother to Bruce Weaver of Washington D.C. and Elizabeth Weaver Brazelton of Detroit, Michigan, loving uncle of Carolyn Brooks of Detroit, Michigan. Service is on Friday, July 3 at 9 A.M. at St. James Presbyterian Church, 409 West 141 Street, Manhattan, under the direction of Roosevelt Memorial Chapel. Interment Saturday, at the State of Serenity Cemetery, Marion, Indiana.

title: In Madcap Padua, Gags Rule an Untamed 'Shrew'
description: Pretending to have a good time can be awfully taxing. And no place does the task appear more onerous these days than on the stage of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where the gamely energetic actors of ''The Taming of The Shrew'' are huffing and puffing and all but pulling hamstring muscles in a strained and groping struggle for laughs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro dropped to its weakest level ever on expectations that European economic growth will lag behind that of the United States. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0229, down from $1.0338.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: All-American
description: Twenty-five years ago you could answer the question ''What is American food?'' faster than you could say John Wayne. But steak-and-potatoes doesn't cover it anymore. Here are 12 all-American restaurants in New York City for the Fourth of July weekend. (These restaurant summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUGGENHEIMER, RANDOLPH
description: GUGGENHEIMER - Randolph. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Randolph Guggenheimer, a cherished friend and devoted humanitarian who fostered advances in medical and geriatric care through his extraordinary generosity. We extend our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Elinor, a prominent leader in our community who served as chair of the Women's Division and as an officer of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, a predecessor of UJA-Federation of New York. We also offer our deepest sympathies to Mr. Guggenheimer's son, Randolph, Jr. and daughter-in-law, Jane; his son, Charles; his grandchildren; and his great-grandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Whitman Set To Overhaul Police Policy
description: A day before the state is expected to issue a report documenting that the state police have tolerated widespread discrimination against minority and female troopers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that she would order an overhaul of the department's procedures for recruiting, promoting and disciplining officers.

title: Albany's Vacation From Inaction
description: New York's state government has taken gridlock to a new level. Budgets in Albany used to be delayed until some other critical deadline forced an agreement. But now even those triggers are not enough to make things work. On Wednesday night, cuts in the state Medicaid program lapsed, sticking the state and localities with tens of millions of dollars in unexpected bills. Protections for New York City loft tenants expired, terrifying many long-term residents with limited incomes. But nothing happened. The Legislature went away for a vacation and a ''cooling off'' period.

title: Halifax Journal; Canada Celebrates Immigrants, but Which Ones?
description: Certain countries, like certain people, find celebrating their own birthdays a bit awkward. Canada is one.

title: Sports of The Times; For Chastain, An Error, Then a Goal
description: SHE would not let it beat her. She would not let it ruin her life, or even her evening. Brandi Chastain had committed just about the most grievous offense a soccer defender could make. She had kicked the ball in her own goal. Now she had to get over it.

title: City College President Forced Out By CUNY Trustees Under Badillo
description: Yolanda T. Moses resigned under pressure yesterday as president of the City College, just days after the trustees of the City University of New York decided they needed a stronger leader for the struggling campus, members of the CUNY board said.

title: For a Coach and a Rookie, Lessons on and Off Court
description: Now that the N.B.A. season is over, basketball fans are invited to turn their attention to the U.B.A. No, that's not the women's league. It's the fictional outfit at the center of ''The Hoop Life,'' a new Showtime series that begins with a two-hour episode on Sunday night. (Future shows will be an hour each.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, LEO
description: BAUER-Leo. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member Leo Bauer. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Sam Wasserman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: FRENCH BANK BID
description: One day after the collapse of negotiations to end a bidding duel among three large French banks, Banque Nationale de Paris yesterday raised its hostile takeover offer for two domestic rivals, Societe Generale and Paribas, to almost $40 billion. Banque Nationale raised its bid for Societe Generale shares by 5 percent, offering $19.6 billion in stock and cash, and increased its bid for Paribas by more than 12 percent. A successful bid by Banque Nationale would thwart a competing offer by Societe Generale for Paribas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: The Coming of Color to American Books
description: Color is a commonplace today, but 200 years ago it was rare in American books, affordable only by upscale readers. About 150 subscribers paid the steep price of $44.50 for initial copies of the earliest color plate book in the United States, ''The City of Philadelphia, in the State of Pennsylvania North America: As It Appeared in the Year 1800.'' The book was published in parts in 1799 and 1800 by William R. Birch, and had hand-colored copperplate engravings. Its 28 pages regaled collectors and armchair tourists with pretty views of what was then the nation's capital: its buildings, streets, businesses, fashions and daily life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, EDITH B.
description: HIRSCH-Edith B. On June 7 in her 91st year in Palm Springs, CA. Beloved wife of Chester A. Hirsch and devoted mother of Edward A. Hirsch of Deal, NJ & Palm Beach, FL, John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: U.S. Relaxes the Limits on Exports of High-Speed Computers
description: President Clinton today greatly eased restrictions on computers that American companies can export to countries like Russia and China, arguing that advances in technology have made laptops and full-size personal computers just as powerful as the supercomputers of just a few years ago.

title: Women's Groups Oppose Vatican on Family Planning
description: Frustrated by the Vatican's efforts to thwart a plan to limit world population growth, 126 women's organizations from around the world presented an open letter to the Roman Catholic Church today at a conference here.

title: GTE Sues 5 Insurers in a Bid To Spread Year 2000 Costs
description: The GTE Corporation has sued five insurance companies seeking $400 million to cover its spending on Year 2000 computer repairs and testing. The case is believed to be the first to test whether insurers may be compelled to pay for at least some of the tens of billions of dollars that big companies are spending on Year 2000 repairs.

title: Mirage Resorts Profit Warning
description: Mirage Resorts Inc. warned after the close of trading today that its earnings for the second quarter would be well below expectations because of an abnormally low winning percentage from gambling tables at its casinos. It also cited expenses associated with opening new hotels and refurbishing others, and increased competition in Las Vegas.

title: Foes' Fund-Raising Up, Gore Bolsters His Team
description: Vice President Al Gore hired several new advisers today, a day after learning that both his Republican and Democratic competitors in the Presidential race had raised surprising amounts of cash in the second quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRANDT, LYNN
description: BRANDT-Lynn. The wonderful memories of our life are fresh in my mind on this day. Alan

title: Lawyer Says He Told of Fraud Case in '92
description: Seven years ago, as Federal securities regulators here were working to close a fraud case against a seemingly insignificant money manager, they received a warning from a local lawyer: The manager, Martin R. Frankel, was lying to them.

title: Despite Upturn in Rates, Dow Still Gains 95.62 Points
description: Overcoming an early stumble, stock prices climbed steadily yesterday to finish with sizable gains despite a rise in interest rates.

title: Clinton Favors Broad Rights In Palestinians' Resettlement
description: President Clinton said today that Palestinian refugees should be able to settle ''wherever they want to live,'' startling Israeli officials with what appeared to be a significant shift in American policy on one of the Middle East's most contentious issues.

title: Clapton and Dylan Tiptoe Toward Common Ground
description: There was a strange chemistry onstage on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden when Eric Clapton and Bob Dylan stood side by side, playing twin Rickenbacher guitars and playing duets on each other's songs. The occasion was Mr. Clapton's benefit for Crossroads Center on Antigua, a 12-step drug-treatment clinic that he opened last year. The concert also included performances by Sheryl Crow and the rhythm-and-blues singer Mary J. Blige.

title: Liquor companies adopt a groovy-era theme to get younger consumers to try mixed drinks.
description: IT was quite a party for a regular Friday afternoon: limbo dancers on Second Avenue, a steel-drum band and nonalcoholic samples of Malibu Rum drinks like Malibu Conga Punch. Then, a lucky few took specially equipped free ''fantasy buses'' to the trend-setting Hamptons.

title: Republicans Thwart Clinton on New Teachers
description: For the second time in three months, Congressional Republicans have voted to block the Clinton Administration's plan to hire 100,000 new teachers and reduce class sizes.

title: At the Kashmir Line: Toe to Toe and Gun to Gun
description: The Pakistani and Indian soldiers eye each other warily from observation posts on jagged Himalayan ridges that scratch across the soft blue sky like an electrocardiogram.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Gaza Dilemma: Boycott or Paycheck
description: Slapping mortar onto the wall of a new house in this Jewish settlement studded with stucco homes and palm trees, Rifat Jarjua, a Palestinian construction worker, acknowledged the other day that he was in a hopeless bind.

title: INTERNET INVESTMENT FUND
description: One of the world's top backers of Internet businesses, the Softbank Corporation, formed partnerships with Vivendi S.A. of France and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to invest in United States on-line companies that are expanding overseas. Softbank, which is based in Tokyo, will receive investments totaling $300 million from the two companies for a new $1.2 billion United States Internet investment fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITT, JACK
description: SITT-Jack. The officers and Board of Trustees of the Magen David Yeshiva (Isaac Shalom Elementary School) and the Magen David Yeshiva (Celia Esses High School) mourn the passing of our devoted and highly respected friend. His generosity helped further the education and preserve the heritage of the Sephardic Jewish world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Sitt family. Our thoughts and prayers are with you at this difficult time. Eddie J. Esses and Steven D. Shamah, Co-Presidents

title: Dotel Is Rocked, but Victory Is a Lullaby
description: Octavio Dotel will always remember the Mets' 12-8 victory over the Florida Marlins this soggy evening because it was his first victory in the major leagues. Otherwise, it would have been a day to forget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCHUTZ, SAM
description: LIPSCHUTZ-Sam. Passed away at Sarasota Memorial Hosptial (FL), Wednesday night. Age 95. Beloved husband of Gerdi. Beloved brother of Lena Schoenfeld. Beloved father of Peter J. Lipschutz and Jamie M. Lipschutz. Adored grandfather of David.

title: Officer Is Charged With Laundering Drug Profits
description: A police officer has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that he and other conspirators helped a Queens travel agency to launder $10 million in drug profits, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, YAAKOV, RABBI
description: WEINBERG-Yaakov, Rabbi. The Orthodox Union deeply mourns the Rosh Yeshiva of the Ner Israel Rabbinical College of Baltimore. A brilliant intellectual and master of Torah scholarship, his piety, genius, saintly example and fatherly concern leave his many students and all of Klal Yisrael in deep mourning. May the Lord comfort his family and all Israel as He will surely comfort the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mandell I. Ganchrow, M.D., Pres. Marcel Weber, Chmn., Bd. of Dir. Rabbi Raphael B. Butler, Exec. VP Rabbi Pinchas Stolper, Sr. Exec. Howard Tzvi Friedman, Chairman, NCSY

title: Disability Law Can't Protect All; Park and Walk
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: A Subtle Shift to a Bolder Plumage : Color Is Back as Men Rediscover Their 'Inner Peacock'
description: WASHINGTON  On an unremarkable day in a Washington office, a rather remarkable scene took place. Three gentlemen without any connection to the garment industry had a conversation about their shirts. All of them were dressed in rich, sapphire blue shirts. They were wearing elegant geometric-print silk ties. And they were chuckling about the coincidence of their all wearing these shirts on the same day. Each was trying to guess where the other had purchased his shirt. And they were noting how they liked the look of this deep color in contrast to the standard white business shirt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIEN, MAURICE B.
description: LEVIEN-Maurice B. Devoted husband of Gloria. Loving father of David and Philip. Dear brother of Sonya and Fred. Proud grandfather of Michael, William, Rachel, Joshua and Katherine. Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue and 81 Street, Friday, 11:30 AM. Interment in Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELLER, VIRGINIA
description: SCHNELLER-Virginia. Died July 1, 1999. Beloved wife of Arthur Schneller. Devoted mother of Jon Schneller and Arthur Schneller. Cherished grandmother of Bradley and Morgan. Proud proprietor of A. Schneller Sons, Inc., New York City, for 55 years. For more information, contact Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway, West Islip, New York 11795.

title: A Bitter Brew Of Earnings For Starbucks
description: Sipping his coffee at the Starbucks restaurant on Melrose Avenue here, Matt Siess said he loved the brew and the atmosphere. But he is skeptical about the coffee chain's new ambition to sell things beyond drinks and light food.

title: Political Memo; Bush's Big Bankroll and What It Means
description: George W. Bush's outsized, $36.3 million campaign war chest, more money than any candidate has raised so early in any Presidential election season, was the driving subject of conversation today among candidates and political experts who said it would have an inevitable impact on his competitors and reshape the landscape of campaign finance for the 2000 election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNES, BARBARA DEWEY BUCCINO
description: BARNES-Barbara Dewey Buccino, 69, of Englewood, FL., died Tuesday in Pittsfield, Mass. Wife of Orville H. Barnes Jr., mother of Michael S. Buccino of Edmonds, Wash., and Robert A. Buccino of New York; widow of Raul Buccino; stepmother of Susan L. Pullaro of Pittsfield, Rebecca J. Namislo of Stockbridge, and Sarah G. Formel and Bruce F. Barnes of Housatonic; grandmother of nine. A former employee of The New York Times, the Lakeville (Connecticut) Journal and the Millerton (New York) News. Graduate of Bard College, class of 1986. Services at 4 P.M. on July 3 at West Stockbridge Congregational Church.

title: Industry Awaits Biggest Transformation Since Depression
description: As sweeping deregulation measures to remake the nation's financial system near the Congressional finish line, an oft-heard comment is that the efforts would ''level the playing field'' among banks, securities companies and insurers, which currently have different rules of engagement for competing with each other.

title: Political Memo; Budget Bog And What Put Pataki There
description: On its face, New York State's long-running budget stalemate is simple enough. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, wants to cut, while the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, wants to add.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about legislation to limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures misstated a provision dealing with class-action suits. The agreement between the White House and Republicans in Congress would require that suits involving more than 100 plaintiffs or seeking more than $10 million in damages be filed in Federal court rather than state courts. The agreement does not prohibit such suits altogether.

title: BILL TO OVERHAUL FINANCIAL SYSTEM PASSES THE HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation tonight that would deregulate the nation's financial system by removing the last remnants of Depression-era laws that have largely kept banks, securities firms and insurance companies from entering one another's businesses.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: For the Jets' Green, the Time Is Now
description: Talk success with Eric Green and first there is the need to establish this: Whose perception of it, yours or his?

title: Chancellor Backs 2 Schools In Queens for Charter Status
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew announced yesterday that he had approved the applications of two public schools in Queens to become charter schools, but only after overcoming City Hall's fears that the independent schools would increase teacher salaries.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A hundred years ago, the Five Points Gang wreaked mayhem from its headquarters at the Brighton Dance Hall on Great Jones Street. The block has calmed down, but the memory is enshrined in Five Points, a restaurant that must have the gang leader Paul Kelly (born Paolo Antonini Vaccarelli) scratching his head.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Altos Hornos de Mexico, a steel company, misstated its relationship to the Chase Manhattan Bank. Chase has $2.2 million in loans outstanding to Altos Hornos, guaranteed by the United States Export-Import Bank. Chase is not one of Altos Hornos's large creditors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: On My Mind; Saving Public Colleges
description: For weeks, I have had the most important report on the most important university in the life and future of New York City. But I did not read it. I just glared at it.

title: Political Briefing; Gore Is Followed By AIDS Protesters
description: Vice President Al Gore has more than enough problems on the campaign trail these days, what with the Republican front-runner, George W. Bush, in front of him in the polls and fund-raising and his only Democratic rival, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, beginning to pick up traction in the rear. Now add to that the noisy AIDS protesters who have begun showing up at just about every major campaign stop, more than 3,000 of them when Mr. Gore passed through Philadelphia on Monday.

title: Boyfriend, 15, Is Charged In Fatal Beating of Child
description: A 15-year-old boy has been charged with murder, and his 27-year-old girlfriend has been charged with child endangerment in the beating death of her 20-month-old son, the police said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about King Hassan II of Morocco misstated the year that King Farouk of Egypt was overthrown. It was 1952, not 1956.

title: Eschmeyer Might Be Right Fit for the Nets
description: Sitting at home and watching as David Stern made one trip after another to the podium to announce the latest selection in Wednesday night's National Basketball Association draft, Evan Eschmeyer was not feeling any pain in his surgically repaired right foot. All the discomfort for the 6-foot-11-inch, 255-pound center was emotional, not physical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL IN $203 MILLION DEAL FOR LEXFORD
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, a leading owner of apartment buildings, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Lexford Residential Trust for $203 million in stock, making its first move into the lower-income housing market. Equity Residential, a real estate investment trust based in Chicago and controlled by the billionaire Sam Zell, will pay 0.463 share of its stock for each share of Lexford. The swap valued Lexford at $20.86 a share, a discount to its closing price Wednesday of $23.875. Equity Residential will also assume $530 million of debt. Lexford, based in Columbus, Ohio, mainly owns one-story complexes rented to people with annual incomes of $25,000 to $35,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Red Hot Buttons in Lee's Steaming 'Sam'
description: Spike Lee's fiery ''Summer of Sam'' has as much to do with the summers of 1989 and 1999 as it does with the tabloid fevers of 1977, which are so electrifyingly rekindled here. It was in 1989 that the film of Mr. Lee's that ''Summer of Sam'' most resembles, ''Do the Right Thing,'' arrived on the wave of sensationalism and outrage that continue to swamp some of his best efforts. So here he is fielding complaints about having bruised the tender feelings of David Berkowitz, the .44-caliber killer whose murderous rampage and purple prose brought New York City to the boiling point 22 years ago.

title: Embryo Cell Research: A Clash of Values
description: Is research on human embryonic stem cells ethically justified? Theologians have a clear answer -- in fact quite a few of them, depending both on their faith and their relative doctrinal position within it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINGER, JOY
description: BINGER-Joy. On June 30, 1999. Beloved wife of Lester. Cherished mother of Merry and the late Lloyd. Dear sister of Elayne Haas. Services on Friday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Wellwood Cemetery.

description: A former lawyer who has been a frequent candidate for office in Brooklyn was convicted yesterday of registering to vote from an address where he did not live. It was the third time the former candidate, John Kennedy O'Hara, had been tried on charges of election fraud.

description: McCAFFREY-Joseph F., 76. Of East Brunswick, NJ, formerly of N.Y.C., July 1, 1999. Husband of Christian A. Hogan. Father of Joseph F., John, Christopher, Richard and Robert . title: Milosevic's Vision of Glory Unleashed Decade of Ruin
description: On the eve of the NATO bombing of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic turned to the American envoys facing him. ''You are a superpower,'' he said. ''You can do what you want. If you want to say Sunday is Wednesday, you can. It is all up to you.''

title: Down Home at the Met: A Folk Art Get-Together
description: If you're looking for the quintessential work of American folk art: sharp, linear, powerfully patterned and full of Yankee pizazz, stop. You could hardly do better than Molly Wales Fobes, more familiar as ''Lady With Her Pets.'' As depicted in 1790 by the folk artist Rufus Hathaway (1770-1822), she sits stiffly in a chair, holding a fan in her right hand, her left awkwardly positioned in her lap. Above her solemn countenance sprouts a pair of giant plumes from a fashionable wig shaped like a hedgehog. Nearby, a parrot perches on a ring; two butterflies hover above it, a smaller bird is poised atop her chair, a smirky black cat nestles next to her very full skirt.

title: Lord Whitelaw, 81, Key Aide And Fixer for Mrs. Thatcher
description: William Whitelaw, a key aide to his fellow Conservative Margaret Thatcher while she was Britain's Prime Minister, died in his sleep overnight, his family said yesterday. He was 81 and was long associated with the town of Penrith in northwestern England.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Hollywood Says, 'Let's Put On a Show!'
description: ''CALIFORNIA CLASSIC'' is that an $8 bottle of pretentious white wine or a goat-cheese pizza topped with avocado and ginseng? In fact, late last month, it was the collective label for four days of automotive events here in an area where uncommon cars are common but high-end car events are rare.

title: Childs Has Surgery on Knee
description: Chris Childs underwent arthroscopic surgery to remove loose cartilage from his right knee yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital North Division. The half-hour procedure was performed by Norman Scott, the Knicks' physician, according to a team spokesman.

title: In Dullsville, Playing Chicken With Life
description: Near the end of ''Trestle at Pope Lick Creek,'' Dalton, an angelic blond teen-age boy who may have done a very bad thing, hypothesizes about a light that appears when people die. His father says he thinks the light should be red. ''Yeah,'' says Dalton, ''like the sun, when you look at it with your eyes closed.'' Soon after, in a flashback, Dalton's girlfriend explains why she wants him to watch her run across the trestle rather than running with her: ''Because we can't watch ourselves. We can't remember ourselves. Not like we need to.''

Christine Todd Whitman conceded today that the police force had also mistreated its own employees by tolerating a culture of racial discrimination and sexual harassment.

description: Stephen M. Case, the founder and chairman of America Online Inc., agreed yesterday to buy a 41.2 percent stake in the Maui Land and Pineapple Company, a pineapple grower and resort operator, for about $40 million. Mr. Case agreed to buy the stake in the company, based in Kahului, Hawaii, from the Harry Weinberg Family Foundation Inc., the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation Inc. and the 300 Corporation. Maui Land's shares rose $4.6875, or 31 percent, to $19.875. Mr. Case, who was born and raised in Hawaii, agreed to buy about three million shares at $13.25 as a long-term investment, said Jim Whitney, an America Online spokesman.

The homophobic epidemic of '98, which spiked with the October murder of Matthew Shepard, has turned into the homophilic explosion of '99.

His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

The company cited difficulties in arranging acceptable financing to create its planned campus of state-of-the-art sound stages as part of a sprawling 1,000-acre development near Los Angeles International Airport.

title: BENCHMARK TO BUY AVEX ELECTRONICS FOR $289 MILLION
description: Benchmark Electronics Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Avex Electronics Inc. from the privately held J. M. Huber Corporation for $289.1 million in cash and stock, in a deal that unites two electronics manufacturers. Huber will receive $255 million in cash and one million Benchmark shares. Benchmark's shares jumped $3.3125 each, to $37.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Avex, based in Huntsville, Ala., and Benchmark, based in Angleton, Tex., provide contract electronics design, manufacturing and testing services. Avex, which had revenue of $841 million in 1998, employs about 4,400 people. Benchmark, which has a work force of 2,200, posted revenue of $524.1 million for 1998. Huber is based in Edison, N.J.

title: A Male Guard's Claim Of Harassment Is Upheld
description: A state judge yesterday upheld a jury award of $3.75 million in a sexual harassment lawsuit by a state prison guard and ordered that the woman he accused of harassing him be transferred out of the prison.

title: A Composer of Film Scores Plays Away From the Camera
description: In the best of the 200 or so films he has composed music for, Michel Legrand's strong suit has been his quick empathy, his ability to crawl inside the character of Barbra Streisand (in ''Yentl'') or Catherine Deneuve (in ''The Umbrellas of Cherbourg'') and compose and arrange a score that evokes their movements, personalities and innermost thoughts. This is why the feeling, the mood -- usually a light, romantic one -- of his music is often more memorable than the melody, and why many of his compositions have been so embraced by jazz improvisers.

title: Rubin Is Kidnapped, but, Hey, Who Cares?
description: In his last 24 hours as Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin scolded Congress for legislation that would make life easier for money launderers, cleaned out his office and then watched in mock horror as President Clinton's closest advisers played out their fantasy: That Mr. Rubin had been captured by Japan's Ministry of Finance and held for a bizarre ransom.

description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a theater festival in Alaska celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Off Broadway movement misstated the location of Independence Community College, from which the event's founder came. It is Independence, Kan., not Independence, Mo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSEY, JEAN GARDINER CHISHOLM.
description: LINDSEY-Jean Gardiner Chisholm. A leading businesswoman and philanthropist, died in New York City Tuesday at age 71. She was Managing Partner of Brandon Petroleum Properties and President and Managing Trustee of the Chisholm Foundation. In 1992 she received the Mississippi Philanthropist of the Year Award. She is survived by two sons, Alexander of Seattle, WA, and John of Greenwich, CT; a sister, Cynthia SaintAmand of NY, and three grandchildren. The funeral will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Laurel, MS on Wednesday, July 7 at 1:00 PM. Memorial service in NY to be announced.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; SUIT SEEKS INHERITANCE
description: A woman who says she was the companion of the late Mexican television executive Emilio Azcarraga Milmo has filed a $32 million lawsuit against his son, Emilio Azcarraga Jean, chairman of Grupo Televisa S.A. de C.V., and several other large investors in the company. She contends that they conspired to defraud her of her inheritance from Mr. Azcarraga Milmo. Officials from Televisa, the world's largest Spanish-language broadcaster, said the suit of Adriana Abascal, a former beauty queen, amounts to blackmail. Mr. Azcarraga Jean's sister, Alessandra Azcarraga de Sepul, has threatened to file a similar suit. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: GLYNWED TO BUY CANADA'S LEADING PIPE MANUFACTURER
description: IPEX Inc., Canada's largest maker of plastic pipe and fittings, is to be sold to Glynwed International P.L.C. for $352.9 million. The sale was announced yesterday by Ivaco Inc., which owns IPEX with Scepter Holdings Inc. Glynwed, based in London, is an engineering company. Ivaco, based in Montreal, makes steel, steel-fabricated products, plastic pipe and fittings, and precision-machined components. Scepter, based in Toronto, is a private investment company.

title: The Summer of Evil
description: The New York City that brims with health and vibrancy today seemed destined for a different ending in 1977. The city went broke and grew steadily dirtier and more disheveled. A blackout plunged millions of people into a darkness punctuated by fiery riots and the screeching voices of looters. While televising baseball from Yankee Stadium, cameras panned the horizon for the flame-tinged columns of smoke spawned by arsonists who single-mindedly torched the South Bronx.

title: Don't Impoverish Serbs
description: To the Editor:

They identified themselves today, taking a variety of routes to arrive at this destination.

Hirsch of Greenwich, CT., and Richard A. Hirsch of Honesdale, PA. Beloved sister of M. Ronald Brukenfeld. Dear grandmother of Douglas A. Hirsch, Karen Gelfand, Elisa Fischer, Nancy Hirsch Burr and Catherine Hirsch. Great-grandmother of four.

title: Koch Remains Hospitalized As Heart Attack Is Diagnosed
description: Doctors determined yesterday that former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who was hospitalized with chest pains on Thursday, had suffered a moderate heart attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: Drugs on Line Are Good for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets's Bad Night Turns Terrible
description: In the clubhouse, after a 16-0 shellacking by the National League East-leading Atlanta Braves, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine mustered a sheepish smile and said, ''Well that was interesting, wasn't it?''

title: Y2K Liability Limits
description: The Clinton Administration's ill-advised turnabout on legislation designed to limit the liability of computer and software manufacturers for Year 2000 computer problems will hurt consumers and small businesses. The Y2K defect is in some computers and software that record years by the last two digits. Unless corrected, the glitch could cause serious malfunctions when the date rolls over to 2000 and a computer confuses that with 1900. For months the White House voiced opposition to both House and Senate bills that would restrict the legal rights of those injured by a Y2K computer failure.

title: Dudley's Diabetes
description: To the Editor:

title: DUPONT AND MONSANTO DISCUSSED MERGER, FILING REVEALS
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company held merger discussions with the Monsanto Company early this year as part of its plan to build up its life sciences business, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The talks took place as DuPont was also negotiating a buyout of Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. Pioneer agreed to sell, though DuPont left open the possibility of a deal with Monsanto after DuPont completes the acquisition of the 80 percent of Pioneer it does not already own, according to the filing. The disclosure is the first public acknowledgment that DuPont and Monsanto have held talks.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Thursday about ''Shadow: Five Presidents and the Legacy of Watergate,'' by Bob Woodward, included the book's incomplete version of a quotation from President Gerald R. Ford. In his second election-year debate with Jimmy Carter in 1976, Mr. Ford said that ''there is no Soviet domination of Eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford Administration.'' The book omitted ''Eastern.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN EDGES UP. A major economic report, the tankan, by Japan's central bank on Monday is expected to show improving business confidence. In New York, the yen settled at 121.01 to the dollar, up from 120.78.

title: Lirong Journal; Tibetans, and Vultures, Keep Ancient Burial Rite
description: The vultures gathered on the mountainside to watch.

title: Clinton and South Korean Leader Warn the North Against Testing Missile
description: President Clinton and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea used a brief meeting in Washington today to make a show of solidarity against North Korea and to warn it against testing another long-range missile in coming weeks.

title: TALKING ABOUT KUBRICK
description: The director seemed bigger than life, but who was he? Peter Bogdanovich talks to those who knew the man behind the legend. An oral history, in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Corrections
description: A Political Memo article yesterday about the Bush campaign treasury and its effect on the Presidential contest included an incorrect figure for the spending ceiling in New Hampshire imposed by the Government on candidates who accept Federal matching funds for the primary season. It is $661,200, not $6.6 million.

title: G.M. and Ford Report Gains In June Car and Truck Sales
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company reported today that their car and truck sales edged higher last month as the entire auto industry recorded its best June in history and its second-best month ever.

title: A Bold Underlead of an Ace Undermines a Spade Game
description: The Women's International Team Trials in Las Vegas this week ended in a victory for Jill Meyers, Randi Montin, Tobi Sokolow, Janice Molson, Renee Mancuso and Shawn Quinn. They won the final by 86 imps against Lynn Deas and her team, and will represent the United States in the Women's World Team Championship in Bermuda in January.

title: Technicians Say F.A.A. Causes Big Delays in Air Traffic
description: Hundreds of technicians who maintain the nation's air traffic control computers picketed at 53 airports today, handing leaflets to holiday travelers saying the Federal Aviation Administration had caused big delays by mishandling its modernization program, not hiring enough technicians and not consulting with them on the new equipment.

title: Crowds Denounce Milosevic In Opposition Stronghold
description: Whistling and jeering, about 10,000 people filled the main square of Yugoslavia's second-largest city tonight to demonstrate against Slobodan Milosevic and heard a parade of local opposition politicians threaten that if he does not resign as president soon, they will throw him out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, L. DENVER.
description: HART-L. Denver. It is with deep sadness that we announce the death of the Reverend L. Denver Hart, Senior Associate Rector of St. Bartholomew's Church and devoted friend and colleague, on June 30th, 1999. He is survived by his partner, Bruce Webber, of New York; his mother, Jane Hart, of Zelienople, PA; and his brother, James Hart, of Palmyra, PA. Vigil prayers and visitation, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Monday, July 5, 6-8PM. Burial Service and Requiem at St. Bartholomew's, Tuesday, July 6 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the L. Denver Hart Memorial Fund, C/O St. Bartholomew's, 109 East 50th Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Driver Sought in Attack On Detective at Airport
description: As doctors struggled to save the life of a police detective run down with a car by a drug suspect, investigators began an interstate hunt to find the man they believe carried out the attack at Kennedy International Airport early yesterday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUGGENHEIMER, RANDOLPH
description: GUGGENHEIMER - Randolph. The board of directors and staff of the United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of Randolph Guggenheimer, a tireless and passionate advocate on behalf of high-quality health care for the residents of Harlem, whom we honored with our Distinguished Community Service Award in 1992. North General Hospital, which he served as founder and chairman emeritus, stands today as a testament to his vision and purpose. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife and sons and the entire Guggenheimer family. Howard Smith, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr., President

title: INSIDE
description: Strong Economy Adds Jobs

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: A Child (and an Adult) of War; A Military Historian Puts a Vivid Cast on World War I
description: During World War II, John Keegan and his family were evacuated from London to Taunton in the western English countryside. While German bombs fell on London, he grew up listening to stories about his father's service in World War I. ''He was a very gentle person, a most unlikely soldier,'' he said in an interview, ''but it was the most important experience of his life.'' And hearing about it became one of the most important experiences of his son's life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: South Korea Halts Talks In Dispute On Families
description: South Korean officials said today that they were suspending talks with North Korea because it had refused to discuss reuniting families divided since before the Korean War of the early 1950's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Oh, the Places He Went! When Dr. Seuss Took His Whimsy to War
description: In a world that still reverberates with the conflicts of World War II, it isn't really surprising to learn that Dr. Seuss, beloved creator of ''Hop on Pop'' and ''Horton Hears a Who,'' sharpened his artistic skills drawing political cartoons of Hitler and Mussolini. Nevertheless, it is fascinating to realize that the shadow of Fascism lurks beneath the shell of Yertle the Turtle and that Uncle Sam is a distant antecedent of the Cat in the Hat. Whether these discoveries say something about the seriousness of Dr. Seuss or the cartoonish nature of American culture is another question.

title: Despite a recent report, the question of authority still divides Roman Catholics and Anglicans
description: For anyone investing in future Christian unity, the dialogue between Anglicanism and Roman Catholicism would not be a hot stock. Perhaps no other two branches of a divided Christianity are so close in spirituality, doctrine and ritual, and yet in recent years the two churches have often seemed to be going in opposite directions.

title: Architects' New West Side Story; G.M. Plaza Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN CHALLENGE ON RUM
description: The European Union will seek World Trade Organization action against a United States law that it said unfairly stripped the French liquor company Pernod Ricard S.A. of its exclusive right to sell a rum brand that Bacardi Ltd. says it also owns. Pernod Ricard, the world's fifth-largest liquor maker, contends that an April court ruling was based on a United States law that violates trade rules. The 1998 law denies legal protection for trademarks confiscated by the Cuban Government, which acquired the trademark Havana Club rum after its former owner fled Cuba. Pernod Ricard has a joint venture with a Cuban Government company to make Havana Club rum.

title: Mario Puzo, Author Who Made 'The Godfather' a World Addiction, Is Dead at 78
description: Mario Puzo, the best-selling novelist and screenwriter who created ''The Godfather'' and made the Corleones the most famous -- and infamous -- of Mafia families and an enduring myth in American culture, died yesterday at his home in Bay Shore, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, EMANUEL
description: LAUB-Emanuel. Dear husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Barry, Jeffrey, Robert and (Stephanie). Cherished grand father of Justin, Jodi, Jeremy and Jillian. Fond brother of Harold. Manny was a member of Local 338 RWDSU, AFL-CIO since 1948 and President since 1976. Services Sunday, 10 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Man Held in Killings In 2 Boroughs in Day
description: A man killed two women, one in Brooklyn and the other in Queens, within hours of each other yesterday and then called the authorities to confess, investigators said.

title: Is $1 Trillion Windfall as Ephemeral as a Breeze?
description: Where did Congress and the Clinton Administration find $1 trillion?

title: Readying Emergency Teams for Terrorist Attacks
description: As a paramedic on the Jefferson County disaster response team, Rick Robbins is typically called on to handle chemical spills and rescues. He has never encountered CS, a powerful kind of tear gas, on the job.

title: A Long Trip To the Met For a Tatar Love Story
description: ''The Fountain of Bakhchisarai,'' one of the most famous ballets created in the Soviet Union, will be presented for the first time in the United States when the Kirov Ballet performs it on Tuesday, Wednesday and next Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House.
