title: Like the Beach, Only With More Gravity
description: Thanks to the booming economy, more Americans than ever are expected to travel this summer. The prospect of crowded national parks and the unstable situation in Europe have led many families to look elsewhere when planning their annual getaway.

title: Conference Adopts Plan On Limiting Population
description: A United Nations conference reached agreement today on a plan to curb the world's population growth that includes recommendations that have drawn objections from several conservative Muslim and Roman Catholic countries.

title: HONG KONG STOCKS SURGE
description: Hong Kong stocks posted their biggest gains in three months yesterday, led by banks and developers, on signs lower interest rates will continue to revive demand for loans and apartments. The Hang Seng index rose 652.44, or 4.8 percent, to 14,184.58, its highest close since Oct. 9, 1997, and its biggest one-day gain since April 7. HSBC Holdings P.L.C. and Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd. paced gains after the United States Federal Reserve indicated on Wednesday that it was not likely to raise rates a second time soon, after announcing a quarter- point increase. Hong Kong's market was closed on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENEBAUM, HENRY
description: GREENEBAUM-Henry. Of Scarsdale, NY on July 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances Greenebaum; dear father of Barbara Klein and Judith Greenebaum; dearly loved grandfather of Mark, Elizabeth, Craig, Christine, Peter and Kara Lazarus, Elise and Robert Buchsbaum, Jessica and Brian Klein; adored great-grandfather of Jack and Caroline Lazarus. Funeral service Sunday 12 noon at Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. Interment is at Mount Hope Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Showing in Theaters: The Digital Revolution; Cinemas Test a Projector Prototype That Makes Spools of Film Obsolete
description: As Theater 1 at the Loews Cineplex filled for an afternoon showing of ''Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace,'' Peter Melnyk, a movie projectionist for 28 years, repeated the time-worn ritual of his trade, spraying air into the innards of a 1960's vintage movie projector to clear dust before lacing the film through its spools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: MCI Will Raise A Phone Charge
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., the nation's second-largest long-distance company, said this week that it would increase customers' phone bills to help pay for a $2.25 billion Government Internet subsidy program.

title: Unions Protest Newark Officers' Suspensions
description: Officials of Newark's two police unions said yesterday that the city's police director had acted prematurely and unfairly in suspending nine police officers without pay in the station house beating of a suspected child molester on June 14.

title: Serb Suspect In Atrocities Is Arrested By French
description: The French police arrested a Serbian paramilitary leader and war crimes suspect here today, raiding his apartment in the early hours of the morning and confiscating weapons and ammunition.

title: Hackers Break Into Computers Of Internet's Governing Group
description: Hackers broke into network computers run by the Internet's new governing body yesterday in an apparent attempt to fan the flames of a continuing struggle for control of the lucrative business of assigning Internet addresses known as domains.

title: HERTZ CONSIDERING ACQUISITION OF FORD'S AXUS UNIT
description: The Hertz Corporation, the car rental company, said yesterday that it was considering buying the Ford Motor Company's Axus International unit, which leases a fleet of cars, primarily in Europe. Axus International, based in London, was a Hertz unit before 1995. A re-acquisition would require Government approval and an independent evaluation. Hertz, based in Park Ridge, N.J., said an acquisition of Axus is consistent with its strategy of developing its core businesses. The company said the deal could be made within 60 to 90 days.

title: After 17 Years, Grunfeld Is Off Knicks' Payroll
description: Two months after Ernie Grunfeld was demoted when the Knicks were on the verge of missing the playoffs and held accountable for the acrimony that existed between him and Coach Jeff Van Gundy, the team officially severed its 17-year tie with him yesterday.

title: French Aide Named to Lead Rebuilding Effort
description: Describing the challenge as awesome, Secretary General Kofi Annan chose the French Health Minister today as his chief representative to run the United Nations' vast civilian operations to be set up in Kosovo.

title: U.S.A. FLORAL EXPECTS 1999 EARNINGS TO FALL SHORT
description: U.S.A. Floral Products Inc., the world's No. 1 distributor of flowers and plants, said yesterday that it had hired two advisers to consider strategic alternatives and that it expected 1999 earnings to fall short. Shares in the company fell $1, or 13 percent, to $6.5625, giving it a stock market value of $111 million. U.S.A. Floral, which is based in Washington, said it had retained two New York-based investment banks, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and Citigroup Inc.'s Salomon Smith Barney. The company's shares have fallen 56 percent in the last year as a worldwide glut cut prices of roses and chrysanthemums. U.S.A. Floral had about $589 million in sales last year.

title: Preserving Peace in Belfast
description: Five days of intense negotiating in Northern Ireland have not yet produced an agreement to let the historic peace plan signed last year go forward. To fill the dangerous vacuum, the British and Irish Governments yesterday offered a public proposal for Northern Ireland's politicians to take back to their constituents for discussion. Since the inflammatory season of summer marches begins Sunday, and agreement has been elusive so far, acceptance is not assured. But we can hope that a few days' consultation with their rank and file will allow David Trimble, the Unionist leader, and Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, to build enough support for the plan to overcome the objections of the extremists in their midst.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT DEAL
description: Berisford P.L.C., a British manufacturer of restaurant and kitchen equipment, has offered $712 million in cash and assumed debt to acquire Scotsman Industries of Vernon, Ill., to create one of the world's largest manufacturers of commercial food equipment. Scotsman Industries' board is recommending acceptance of the bid, which sent Berisford shares soaring by 13 percent to 272.5 pence. The bid values Scotsman shares at $33, and its stock soared $10.8125 a share, to $32.625. London-based Berisford would also assume $348 million of Scotsman debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUND, ISABEL MEYERS,
description: MOUND-Isabel Meyers, 93, died early Sunday, June 27, 1999 at her residence in Newport News, VA, where she has resided for the past three years. A native of New York City, she attended Hunter College and taught early childhood education at the San Reno School in the City. Her volunteer commitments to The Red Cross and Mount Sinai Hospital spanned more than 50 years of service. She was predeceased by her husband, Milton N. Mound and her daughter, Rona M. Drucker. Survivors include her daughter, Margo M. Drucker, her sons-in-law Erwin B. Drucker and Stanley W. Drucker of Newport News, VA, five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREEGER, LAWRENCE
description: KREEGER-Lawrence, on July 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Jeanne. Loving father of Andrew, Arthur, Susan and Deborah. Dear brother of Mildred Davidson and the late David. Adoring grandfather of Emma, Isabel, Arden, Katherine, Molly and Emily. Devoted uncle and great-uncle. He will be deeply missed. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Graveside service Monday, 11:30 AM, Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Pull off the road if you want to use an electric shaver, if you want to put on lipstick, if you want to use a cell phone. But if you're driving, for goodness' sakes, then keep two hands on the wheel.''

title: Alexander Hamilton as He Was Never Meant to Be
description: It's hard to think of a more outdated concept than ''sovereign immunity,'' which the Supreme Court recently used in three decisions freeing states from lawsuits in state courts for violations of Federal laws. In 1946 Justice Felix Frankfurter described state sovereign immunity as ''an anachronistic survival of monarchical privilege,'' since it derives from the Crown's immunity to prosecution in British courts without its consent. Such a practice has no logical place in a nation that not only rejected monarchy in 1776, but insisted that henceforth everyone, lawmakers included, should be equally bound by the law.

title: Drugs on Line Are Good for All
description: To the Editor:

title: It's All Joni Mitchell Onstage, but She's in the Audience
description: Interpreting the mid-1970's music of Joni Mitchell isn't a straightforward task because the records she made then were perfect crosses between professionalism and seance. They were the sound of Los Angeles studio pop at its most elastic, and their arrangements were not just functional brickwork but a blurring of improvisation and composition, with little instrumental quirks inscribed everywhere within.

title: About New York; Unlikely Dive Into the Brine: It's a Living
description: THE rain fell in fat, wet drops on Thursday morning, splattering atop the 15 orange barrels outside Lower East Side Pickles as the proprietor, Joe Davide, squinted at the sky and pronounced business ''sour.''

title: Charter Unit Plans to Study Broad Array Of Questions
description: The commission reviewing the City Charter announced last night that it would look beyond the question of who should succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani if he is elected to the United States Senate, and take on a sweeping list of issues from education to organized crime.

title: Authorities Accuse Prosecutor Of Stealing a Wallet in Court
description: A senior prosecutor in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office was arrested yesterday after court officers said they saw her stealing a wallet from a colleague's knapsack in a courtroom, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: A Princess Whose Bearing And Speed Eclipse Sentiment
description: The Kirov Ballet's new production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' has been the subject of intense discussion this week. Much of the talk has centered on the authenticity of detail and spirit in this attempted return to the 1890 original and on what Sergei Viharev's restaging has to offer to audiences of the 1990's. (It takes some getting used to a ''Beauty'' whose Lilac Fairy looks, in her historically correct costume, like Boadicea.)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE FALLS. Orange juice declined 5.7 percent on expectations that shipments from Brazil will flood the market. Frozen concentrated orange juice for September delivery fell 4.6 cents, to 75.9 cents a pound.

title: For a World Apart, a Lesson in Social Work
description: In a nondescript building, up a flight of stairs and behind unmarked doors, a dozen ultra-Orthodox men sat hunched over desks, furiously coloring away.

title: In Just One Town, Phoning and Driving Don't Mix
description: It is illegal to drive while talking on a cell phone in this Cleveland suburb, the only place in America with such a ban.

title: Finder's Fee in Fine Fillies' Footsteps
description: The Astoria has been run for 93 years as a launching pad for promising 2-year-old fillies, some of whom, like Ruffian and Meadow Star, went on to great things. And when the race was run yesterday at Belmont Park, it may have launched Ogden Phipps's fine filly Finder's Fee, who shot from deep in the pack to first place in the final yards and defeated Deed I Do by a head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow, S.& P. and Nasdaq All Set New Closing Highs

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's appearance with Senator Charles E. Schumer and other New York leaders at a White House meeting to argue against proposed cuts in Medicare misstated the estimated cost to New York State teaching hospitals. Senator Schumer says it is $3.2 billion over the next 10 years; $39 billion is his figure for hospitals nationally.

title: Why the Disabled Sue
description: To the Editor:

title: Kosovars Celebrate Their Declaration
description: This city exploded into celebration tonight as thousands of Kosovar Albanians turned out in the streets to celebrate the anniversary of their declaration of independence, the first since the NATO air war returned Albanians to Kosovo, free from Serbian rule.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mexico's Senate Blocks Election Reforms
description: Lawmakers from Mexico's governing party have killed a package of election reforms that would have monitored spending in the presidential primary campaigns now under way and allowed Mexican expatriates to vote in the national elections next year.

title: After Earlier Grumbling, Mayor Backs Head of School Board
description: After considering an effort to oust William C. Thompson Jr. as president of the Board of Education, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he wanted Mr. Thompson to stay on, saying that a change in leadership could postpone improvements to the public school system.

title: John Mullin, 85, Whose Magnetic Tape Freed Radio Broadcasters
description: John T. Mullin, who brought broadcasting and the record industry together with the magnetic audiotape technology that revolutionized them in the late 1940's, died on June 24 at his home in Camarillo, Calif. He was 85.

title: Coca-Cola Recalls Water in Poland After Bacteria Are Found
description: In its second beverage recall in Poland this week, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it was removing all half-liter bottles of its Bonaqua Plus purified water from stores because Polish Government scientists had detected coliform bacteria in the product.

title: Talks With Fleury Are Going Well
description: The Rangers made no announcement yesterday regarding their attempt to acquire the free agent Theo Fleury, but someone with knowledge of the negotiations said that the talks had gone well and that the high-scoring right wing could be signed by early next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Edward Dmytryk, Film Director, Dies at 90
description: Edward Dmytryk, the versatile director whose best films were taut, realistic and at times explosive and who, as one of the ''Hollywood 10,'' was jailed for refusing to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist, died on Thursday at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 90 and the only member of the 10 who recanted and named names.

title: Sports of The Times; Slammin' Sampras A Footnote
description: IN case anyone has forgotten, Pete Sampras is here, too, back on his favorite surface, trying to win a record-tying 12th Grand Slam event. I thought I should mention this before we discuss the big news of the Wimbledon day, which wasn't that the sun finally shone.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Sylvia Sidney yesterday misspelled her original surname. It was Kosow, not Kossow.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENESYS S.A., Montpellier, France, a provider of teleconferencing services, agreed to buy Denver-based Williams Companies' conferencing unit for $39 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Seduction Stripped To the Essentials
description: ''Giselle'' has many faces, as the Kirov Ballet reminded us on Thursday night when Diana Vishneva and Andrian Fadeyev, as a young village lass and an unusually innocent seducer, triumphed in this first of six performances that the Kirov is presenting (tomorrow excepted) through Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Ulster Is Given An Ultimatum To End Impasse
description: The British and Irish Governments delivered an ultimatum Friday night to the feuding politicians of Ulster: resolve the impasse that threatens the Northern Ireland peace settlement or see their hard-won new legislature shut down.

title: After a Month's Lull, Employers Report Strong Job Gains for June
description: After idling in May, the great American job engine is purring again.

title: An Uphill Struggle at City College
description: At its founding as the Free Academy more than 150 years ago, City College was viewed as a radical experiment in providing social mobility to immigrants and other disadvantaged young people. The experiment was a stunning success, and the accomplishments of its brightest students brought the college fame as a Harvard for the proletariat.

title: Broad Rally Lets Dow Resume Its Record-Breaking Ways
description: On a day when investors and traders had their sights set on the long holiday weekend, the Dow Jones industrial average rose almost 73 points, reaching a new high for the first time in seven weeks. The two other marquee stock indexes set records for the third consecutive day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTMAN, LEE
description: FELTMAN-Lee. The members of the New York Freudian Society mourn the passing of a good friend who generously and frequently shared with us his legal wisdom. Our heartfelt condolences to our colleagues: his wife, Shirley, and his daughter Lenore, and to Joan and his beloved grandchildren Barbara Stimmel, Ph.D President,

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Briefing column yesterday about AIDS protesters misstated an estimate of the number of them who showed up at a political appearance in Philadelphia by Vice President Al Gore. It was 300, not 3,000.

title: Tennis Cinderella's Father Has a Name: Julius Erving
description: With each surprising victory at Wimbledon, Alexandra Stevenson, the 18-year-old rising tennis star, faced another set of questions -- intensifying curiosity about everything from her style of play to her experiences as a black woman in a predominantly white sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Sports of The Times; Mets' Chance to Make a Statement
description: THERE was talk from the Mets that this series with Atlanta would be a barometer, a measuring stick for how far the team had come in the last month. If the game was a stick, Atlanta used it to thrash the Mets back to reality last night.

title: Myers Industries Expands
description: Myers Industries, the maker of plastic storage products and tire service equipment, agreed today to acquire the Dillen Products Company for an undisclosed amount of cash and assumed debt to expand its gardening containers business. Dillen makes and distributes plastic planters and trays. The company, based in Middlefield, Ohio, had 1998 sales of about $40 million. Myers, based here, makes reusable plastic and metal containers. It had 1998 sales of about $392 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEY, ELIZABETH
description: McVEY-Elizabeth, 87. Of Scottsdale, AZ died July 1, 1999. Born in New York, she worked for Metropolitan Insurance Co. in New York City. Survived by sisters, Frances A. and Jane Mary of Scottsdale, AZ; brothers, William G., New York; James, New Jersey; Robert, Scottsdale, AZ; four nephews, four nieces, three great-nieces. Mass Tuesday 10 AM Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Scottsdale. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Contributions to favorite charity. For more information contact Messinger Mortuary, Scottsdale, AZ, 480-945-9521.

title: Lightning Hits Control Center And Grounds Many Planes
description: Air traffic across the northeastern United States was snarled for hours tonight, delaying tens of thousands of travelers on the eve of a holiday weekend, after lightning hit New England's main air traffic control center, in Nashua, N.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, SIDNEY R., DR.
description: WACHTEL-Sidney R., Dr. 78, of Boynton Beach, Florida. Passed away June 27, 1999. Survived by his wife Roslynne, stepsons Bruce and Kenneth Steinthal. Services were already held.

title: An Officer With a Love For Kin and Colleagues
description: The night watch is not the shift that a detective with more than 20 years on the Port Authority police force would usually choose, but Philip Stephenson, who was critically injured yesterday by a suspect fleeing in a car, had specifically requested the overnight detail for the last four or five years.

title: Honduran Boy Who Told of Solo Trek Tests Positive for TB
description: The 13-year-old Honduran boy who duped New Yorkers with a tale about a 3,200-mile solo odyssey to search for his father in New York is being treated for tuberculosis at University Hospital and Medical Center at Stony Brook on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Architects' New West Side Story
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Encourage More People to Give Blood
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Freshmen Remain Undefeated
description: In an all-American heat of the Temple Challenge Cup at the Henley Regatta yesterday, Harvard's freshman heavyweight team, undefeated in the regular season, added St. Joseph's of Philadelphia to its list of victims, winning by two and a half lengths in 6 minutes 56 seconds over the 15<diamond=16-mile Henley on Thames course.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, RICHARD H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Richard H. We forever love and forever remember. Nina, Shep, Jason and Mom

title: A Needless Fight Avoided
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani showed good sense in not trying to oust William Thompson from the presidency of the Board of Education, as was rumored for several days. Such a move might have led to the resignation of Chancellor Rudy Crew and thrown the system into turmoil as it approaches a difficult new academic year. It could have been unwise for Mr. Giuliani politically as well, since driving Mr. Thompson out of the presidency and possibly running off Mr. Crew would have left the Mayor bearing full responsibility for New York City's distressed schools as he considers a potential Senate race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICH, SPO
description: OESTREICH-Spo. In her 93rd year, passed away of natural causes Thursday night at her home in New York City. The widow of Charles H. Oestreich, she was also the cherished mother of David Oestreich, Joan Kend and the late Richard Oestreich, the adored grandmother of Debra Rubin, Elizabeth Fein and Caren Cohen, and the devoted great-grandmother of Henry, Charles, Catherine, William and Abigail. A graduate of Hunter College, a poet and an art collector, she was a brave and beautiful lady who will live in the hearts of her loving friends and family forever. May God grant her sweet repose.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The Fourth of July will be observed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: THE TAINTED TOUR: A special report.; Drug Scandals Dampen Cycling's Top Event
description: The Tour de France, one of Europe's legendary sporting events, will draw 180 of the finest bicycle riders in the world Saturday to a theme park in western France. From there, they will embark on the Tour's annual three-week race to Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANTOR, BERNARD
description: CANTOR-Bernard. Miss you more than ever. Iris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: 2 Found Guilty Of Hospital Fraud Charges
description: Two executives of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation were found guilty yesterday of defrauding Federal health care programs through the submission of bogus expense claims to the Government in the first jury verdicts stemming from the investigation of potential wrongdoing at the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMPEROR, GEORGE
description: EMPEROR-George. Age 76, born August 27, 1922 in Brooklyn, New York. The son of Thomas and Catherine Massey Emperor, last known to have resided in Brooklyn. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please contact the Rome D.D.S.O., collect AC 315-336-2300 with any special funeral arrangements.

title: For 500 Sets of Twins, It's Interdependence Day
description: Five hundred sets of identical twins converged yesterday on a public park in Newark for the first festival of the Garden State Twins Association.

title: BRAZILIAN SUPERMARKET DEAL
description: Carrefour S.A. of France continued a buying spree of Brazilian supermarkets with the acquisition of Roncetti, a regional chain. In its third acquisition in a month, Carrefour will take control of a chain of 13 supermarkets and one hypermarket with a strong presence in the state of Espirito Santo. The transaction is part of a wider battle in the food retailing business with Cia. Brasileira de Distribuio, a Sao Paulo-based operator of supermarkets under the Po de Aucar name. Carrefour is Brazil's largest retailer.

title: Clinton Critic Is Key to Deal To End Tie-up On Judgeships
description: President Clinton has finally agreed to an unusual bargain that obliges him to nominate as a Federal judge a Utah Republican who is vigorously opposed by several environmental groups, Congressional and Administration officials said this week.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean independence leader, misstated his age. He was 82, not 62.

title: Chase to Raise Some Automated Teller Fees
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank, said this week that it had raised the fees it charges noncustomers to use automated teller machines in the New York area.

title: A Famous Cookie And a Face to Match; How Wally Amos Got His Hand And His Name Back in the Game
description: For an entrepreneur who was down on his luck it was almost too good a deal to pass up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: High Court Undermined the People's Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Kids to the Test
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Scene of the Crime; Kojak Would Recognize Kosovo
description: KOSOVO is a huge crime scene.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 22 of The Times Magazine today, with the article about Stanley Kubrick, misstates the origin of a picture of Sue Lyon. It was taken by David Sutton at a promotional event; it is not from the movie ''Lolita,'' which was made in black and white.

title: Now, AOL Everywhere
description: OVER the last year, the walls of America Online's rapidly expanding headquarters here have been dotted with plaques declaring the company's mission: ''To build a global medium as central to people's lives as the telephone or television . . . and even more valuable.''

title: Call Me Lonely
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban on Gatherings For Work Is Defeated
description: Legislation that would have made it illegal to look for work on a public street in Suffolk County was defeated last week after being shouted down by legislators and civil rights groups as racist and unconstitutional.

title: Why Horse Farms Need To Be Saved
description: I was glad to read that the County Executive is taking steps to preserve farmland in Westchester (''Trying to Halt the Push of the Bulldozers,'' June 14). But if Mr. Spano and the Board of Legislators wish to preserve the remnants of the county's agricultural past, they should take immediate action to include ''horse farms'' under the protection of the state's Agricultural Exemption Act.

title: Sports of The Times; Sampras, Who Never Went Away, vs. Agassi, Who's Back Again
description: THE pigeon appeared just about the time Tim Henman was trying to prove he wasn't one himself. Pete Sampras, down a set, on serve at 4-3 in the second, was beginning to find the range. Naturally, the bird landed on Henman's side of the scarred lawn, and scampered about, like a bouncing volley, from the ball boy's clutches.

title: Dancing In the Dark
description: Sure there's a dance floor, but with the big bands blaring away for all to hear, couples are dancing all over Lincoln Center plaza (above, near left). Lindys are hopping and foxes are trotting at the Midsummer Night's Swing festival (Tuesday through Saturday until July 24). Crowds swell to 5,000 on salsa nights, but jigs and reels and cha-chas are big draws as well. Daisy and Paul Soros and the William H. Kearns Foundation are among the largest sponsors of the monthlong festival, now in its 10th year.

title: Maria Tiu, Adrian Frankum
description: Maria Teresa Tiu and Adrian Robert Frankum were married yesterday at Bridgewaters in New York by the Rev. Robert T. Hollett, an Episcopal priest.

title: Teaching Johnny The Appropriate Way to Flirt
description: The most troubling aspect of your article was not the incidents of student-to-student sexual harassment described, but the ambivalence expressed by Supreme Court justices and school administrators about whether the issue is overblown.

title: Teaching Johnny The Appropriate Way to Flirt
description: I'm one who thinks the Milk-Bag Incident is indeed kind of amusing. Perhaps an appropriate response might have been for the girls to say, 'Oh, how disgusting,' and leave the table. Instead, we have the usual passive-aggressive response: ''Sometime in the course of the next few days, the girls . . . appear at the office.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, GRACE
description: FRASER-Grace On July 1. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Loving sister of Esther, Rachel, Sam and Mollie. Adored aunt of Jeffrey and Andrew. Cherished great aunt of Evan, Bradley and Wayne.

title: Britain Awaits Rogue Trader With Interest In the Spoils
description: For a while, he was the kid from nowhere whose Midas touch made millions for his patrician overlords. Then, when it all turned sour, he was the Rogue Trader whose breath-stopping losses epitomized the dizzy excesses of the markets in the mid-1990's.

title: Strategy for the Senate Race: Stay in Game, Then Win It
description: Tom Byrne had just defeated one of those two-hand pastrami-and-turkey sandwiches they serve at the New York Deli on U.S. 1 here, so maybe he was entitled to feel a little cocky.

title: Shanan Kolker, Michael Rosengarten
description: Shanan Joss Kolker, the daughter of Dr. Paul Kolker of Old Westbury, N.Y., and the late Susan Kolker, is to be married this evening to Michael Eric Rosengarten, the son of Debby and Howard Rosengarten of Syosset, N.Y. Rabbi Seth Sternstein will officiate at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: In This Neighborhood, Front Stoops Double as Libraries
description: Park Slope is not what it used to be, said Ray O'Neill, a longtime resident. The hometown bars are gone, he said, and socializing on the stoop is a thing of the past.

title: A Procession Of Elusive Images From the Merlin Of Surreal Form
description: FLAT, empty suits of clothing laid out across the stage rise and walk as the actress Fiona Shaw reads a graphic description by the novelist Umberto Eco of decaying corpses that dwell in the land of the dead. A rampant red rooster violently tears sections from a long scroll of paper drawn from the hands of a blue angel hanging over the stage. A little girl, a doll figure with a Buddha-like china head, mimes joyful wonder as she gazes at meteorites through a huge telescope, while a snow owl undulates its feathery sleeves.

title: Your Neighbor's Trees . . .; No Joyce Kilmer, Maybe, But No Scourge, Either
description: To the Editor:

title: Telling Them What They'll Pay to Hear
description: I ONCE knew a woman who couldn't seem to get her career off the ground. Her personal finances were a shambles, and she had little experience in the world of business. Naturally, she became a management consultant.

title: Low-Cost Insurance
description: After a campaign to enroll more than 23,000 children in low-cost health insurance, Westchester is offering coverage to adults who cannot afford health insurance and are not eligible for Medicaid.

title: And in the Next Gallery, A Younger Competitor
description: IMAGINE inventing Kleenex and then having someone usurp your position as the No. 1 facial tissue. Or creating the Q-tip and finding another cotton swab breathing down your market share. That is the situation of Acoustiguide, a New York company generally regarded as the first audio-guide firm, whose name is nearly synonymous with taped museum tours.

title: Outlaws in Greasy Aprons; Flouting Propane Code, New Yorkers Grill Outdoors
description: Phyllis Norton-Towers, a real estate broker in Brooklyn Heights, enjoys a charmed urban life. She lives in a brownstone apartment with a garden where turtles swim in a makeshift pond and plump roses climb a wooden trellis. Her dinner guests relish the cloth-covered garden furniture, the sauvignon blanc and especially the cuisine made possible by the barbecue: a Weber grill fueled by a 20-pound propane tank.

title: Filipinos Get Taste of Home in Little Manila on First Ave.
description: On a hot, humid summer day, New Yorkers might want to reach for an Italian ice or a smoothie. But New Yorkers living near Stuyvesant Town can satisfy their hankering with a halo halo, a layered Philippine dessert of boiled and sweetened kidney beans, chickpeas, yam, jackfruit, bananas and crushed ice. Or they can slake their thirst with Aqua de Coco, a canned coconut drink as common in the Philippines as is Dr. Pepper in the United States.

title: In the Rockaways, Hope for a Revival
description: Bill Daly, an 11-year resident on the Rockaway peninsula, has seen ferries come and he has seen ferries go. So it is no wonder that he is a little skeptical of another plan to give the Rockaways daily ferry service to Manhattan.

title: DATABANK: June 28 through July 2; In Market After Market, a Summer Rally
description: Records dropped like flies in the hot summer sun last week.

title: Next Stop, Another World, One With Milking and Mennonites
description: For seven summers, 15-year-old Jason Stenbar has gladly traded the commotion of the city and its sweltering heat for two weeks of tranquillity on a farm in Virginia.

title: This Water-Quality Project Is Just a Boondoggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinner Comes With Plenty of Water
description: AS the boat docked, I witnessed the changing of the guard. Passengers streamed off the ferry that had sailed from the First State to the Garden State. They hauled their Ralph Lauren and Ann Taylor bags, fatigued from a day of outlet shopping in Rehoboth, Del. Then the Delaware-bound tourists got on board, lugging sheer plastic bags filled with Cape May salt water taffy and fudge.

title: 'Pay to the Order Of *%#*!*%*5*!!%#!*'
description: People who are irate about paying parking tickets, fines or tax bills and let the authorities know it by inscribing their checks or payment envelopes with angry, insulting and even obscene remarks are exercising their First Amendment rights, according to the state Supreme Court, and they should not to be held in contempt of court.

title: The View From/Thornwood; The Car Proud Show Off Their Classic Machines
description: IT is the Fourth of July, and what better day to celebrate that most American of love objects, the automobile?

title: Suffrage Issue Dominating a Kuwait Election
description: Kuwaitis voted today in what may be the country's last all-male elections, after a campaign dominated by a heated national discussion of whether it is time to allow women political rights.

title: Teaching Johnny The Appropriate Way to Flirt
description: To believe that children and teen-agers can and ought to deal with severe, prolonged and even criminal harassment on their own is to ask more of them than we do of adults. Somehow we have come to condone as ''normal'' behavior -- at least in the context of contemporary school culture -- an astonishing array of antisocial acts, including extreme, relentless and sometimes open teasing, taunting, bullying, shunning, physical assault and harassment of all kinds, as long as they stop short of murder. Perhaps the Supreme Court decision in the Davis case will help us draw the line earlier, before the next youngster resorts to a gun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, VIVIAN
description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn until Saturday 8:30AM. Funeral liturgy S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Professionals and Students, Learning From Each Other
description: INFLUENCE in art is often elusive, for it gets filtered through diverse personalities and often surfaces after a long period of time. The opportunity to observe definite influence through side-by-side comparisons can therefore be instructive and a tonic. Such an occasion is the seventh edition of Art Reach at City Without Walls here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, L.
description: HART-L. Denver. It is with deep sadness that we announce the death of the Reverend L. Denver Hart, Senior Associate Rector of St. Bartholomew's Church and devoted friend and colleague, on June 30th, 1999. He is survived by his partner, Bruce Webber, of New York; his mother, Jane Hart, of Zelienople, PA; and his brother, James Hart, of Palmyra, PA. Vigil prayers and visitation, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Monday, July 5, 6-8PM. Burial Service and Requiem at St. Bartholomew's, Tuesday, July 6 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the L. Denver Hart Memorial Fund, C/O St. Bartholomew's, 109 East 50th Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: From Markers of the Dead, Ties to the Past
description: MERIWETHER LEWIS is buried on the Natchez Trace, right where he died in 1809. The spot, in the deep green, still rural back country of Tennessee, is among my favorite places.

title: At Gettysburg, a Stand for New Jersey
description: AVERAGING well over a hundred years on active duty, the monuments to New Jersey units at Gettysburg are showing wear.

title: Gilt-Edged Bubbly
description: The South Fork Gold Coast needn't look farther than Sagaponack for a stylish sparkling wine that plays smartly into its lavish spending habits.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A SEMICLASSIC drama about two Western drifters, a tale of a Broadway actor taken over by a Shakespearean role, Fellini's memorable story of a tragic prostitute and a superb boxing drama highlight the film selections on television this week.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-4-99: Salient Facts: Computer Surveillance; Software to Watch Over You
description: Computer users these days may have a right to feel paranoid. A new generation of software is making it easier than ever for employers and parents to keep an eye on everything that workers or family members do on their computers. ''Employees usually don't mind once it's explained to them,'' says Kelly Haggerty, product manager at Elron Software. ''It's only Orwellian when organizations spy and don't tell employees.'' As it happens, most of the new software can easily be configured so that computer users won't know they're under observation -- not until they're reprimanded, anyway. Herewith, a sampling of state-of-the-art electronic surveillance.

title: A Patel Motel Cartel?
description: 'You're getting the last room in Huntsville,'' the man at the front desk rasped. I was in the heart of a certain kind of Texas -- the kind I'd probably only visit in pursuit of a story -- and the room was a godsend. I thanked the man and we shook hands -- not a gesture you often see enacted between owner and customer at the front desk of an Econo Lodge. But he was Indian and so am I, and it was our little way of touching base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, NANCY
description: LEVY-Nancy Magyar, a poet and photographer, passed away at her home in Manhattan. She was 56 years old. She will be missed by her sons Jonathan and Jeremy, and her three grandchildren Sierra, Akash and Ishan. Donations can be made in her memory to the New York Public Library.

title: Crash Delays Races For U.S. and Canada
description: An American crew and a Canadian crew were involved in a crash that delayed their races for several hours yesterday at the 150th Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Nicole Rachel Tucker and David McKay Keith misspelled the name of the school from which the bride's mother retired as the dean of students and a teacher of special education. It is Murry Bergtraum High School, not Murray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, CAROL (NEE KORNGUT)
description: HOROWITZ-Carol (nee Korngut) On July 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Mervin. Devoted mother of Brook and Andrew Berger and the late Susan Horowitz. Adored sister of the late Richard Korngut. Loving grandmother of Adam and Douglas Berger. Dear aunt of Carol and Hank Herman and Steven Korngut. Cherished great-aunt of Matthew, Greg and Robbie Herman. Services Monday, 11 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Wisconsin's Welcoming Door
description: TOURISTICALLY speaking, the Midwest gets a bad rap. No Pacific Ocean. No Rocky Mountains. No Miami Beach. No Appalachian Trail. But the milquetoast image that flyover travelers have of the nation's heartland is not really fair. Sure, much of the Midwest is flat and land-locked, but it has its share of surprises.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JEFFREY LEMIEUX; Clinton's Medicare Plan: A Solid Step One
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON promised to issue his own plan to reform Medicare when his appointees to a bipartisan Federal commission, whose chairman was Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, blocked agreement last March.

title: A Millet Revival In Massachusetts
description: Van Gogh, for one, loved the work of Millet, the 19th century French painter of peasant life and labor. He declared Millet his ''father'' and ''eternal master,'' and used his works to assist his early drawing efforts. But as the modernist star rose over the last 50 years, Millet fell out of favor in the art world.

title: Bookend; Life, Literature and the Pursuit of Happiness
description: When Walt Whitman declared in 1855 that ''the United States themselves are essentially the greatest poem,'' what kind of country was he talking about?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Hamptons Style Touches Hampton Bays
description: HAMPTON BAYS is not the Hamptons,'' said a friend who has a house there. Still, with the coming of Bistro 26, this laid-back community is acquiring a bit of Hamptons style.

title: Which Way the Fed? Sorting Out the Signals on Interest Rates
description: THE inflation debate has been whittled down to a single issue.

title: A Strong Dollar Means Savings in Europe
description: PACK up and get going. Europe is cheap. And don't be troubled by the new single currency, the euro. Think in marks, francs, lire, pesetas and escudos and you will see what a bargain the Continent is.

title: 76 Trombones Are Just the Beginning
description: ASKED how she manages to organize one of the oldest and largest Fourth of July parades in New Jersey, Jill Worth gave her cheerful laugh and said:

title: Spot in the Spotlight Again
description: With luck there will be no thunder, lightning or rain on Friday when the Classical Theater of Harlem stages its outdoor production of ''Macbeth.'' It is a rare staging of the play in Harlem -- Orson Welles did a famous production in 1936 -- and one of few traditional theater productions there, say the founders of the company, which was formed four months ago.

title: Emily Yang and Roger Chang
description: Emily Yang, a daughter of Shiu-mei Yang and Dr. Huey-Lang Yang of Tenafly, N.J., and Taipei, Taiwan, was married yesterday to Roger Chieh Chang, a son of Chu Chien Chang and Kuang Piao Chang of Princeton Junction, N.J., and Taipei. The Rev. Jewelnel Davis, the university chaplain at Columbia University, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: The Nation; Uncle Sam Learns Thrift While America Spends
description: IN announcing last week that the Federal budget surplus would be even more over the next 15 years -- a mind-boggling $1 trillion -- than anticipated a few months ago, President Clinton likened the Government to a profligate consumer suddenly endowed with the means and discipline to get out of debt and save for the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICH, SPO
description: OESTREICH-Spo In her 93rd year, passed away of natural causes Thursday night at her home in New York City. The widow of Charles H. Oestreich, she was also the cherished mother of David Oestreich, Joan Kend and the late Richard Oestreich, the adored grandmother of Debra Rubin, Elizabeth Fein and Caren Cohen, and the devoted great-grandmother of Henry, Charles, Catherine, William and Abigail. A graduate of Hunter College, a poet and an art collector, she was a brave and beautiful lady who will live in the hearts of her loving friends and family forever. May God grant her sweet repose.

title: Deep in The Republic Of Chevron
description: The delta region of southern Nigeria, where the mighty Niger River drains into the Atlantic Ocean, includes some of the most inhospitable territory on earth. It's the world's largest mangrove swamp, 14,000 square miles of thickets, channels and lagoons all but impenetrable to any but the most practiced eye. It's also oil country, dotted with wells and flow stations, where about two million barrels of crude are collected each day and piped to central stations for transport abroad.

title: Op-Art; What It Looks Like in America
The Way We Live Now: 7-4-99: Questions for Moby; The Soul of A New Machine
description: Q: A lot of other musicians are inspired by collaboration. But to produce your music, you rely almost entirely on electronic machines and digitized data. Does that sort of labor ever get lonely?

title: Bye, Bye, 'Ballyhoo'
description: When a play is recurrent, it is also replaceable. So no one at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick was upset about dropping the year's most unavoidable play, Alfred Uhry's ''Last Night at Ballyhoo.'' Not when ''Down the Garden Paths,'' a brand new comedy-drama by Anne Meara, materialized in its place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Legal Immigrants, Too, Lack Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Reception
description: Midnight Champagne

title: Better Than TV
description: HOW TO READ A POEM

title: Programmer's Playtime
description: What did Mark Eppley, creator of Laplink, the most popular software for transferring files between personal computers, do on his 21-month vacation? ''I got into diesel equipment,'' he said at a party during the recent PC Expo in New York. ''A tugboat, a bulldozer and a crane. I built a yurt, a treehouse and a stage.'' (A yurt is a circular canvas structure most common in Mongolia.)

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Subway Series
description: Ralph Ginzburg discovered that while there is always something newsworthy to photograph in New York, the logistics can be a nightmare. He logged 18-hour days and covered 1,000 events to collect the images in I SHOT NEW YORK (Abrams, paper, $24.95). Ginzburg, a publisher turned spot news photographer, filled his 1995 daybook with images of nearly 90 publicity stunts, more than 50 celebrity sightings, 40 or so sporting events and parades from Pulaski Day to the annual ''Dyke March.'' His images range from the exuberant (a Spider-Man balloon from the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade prowls the skyline in a wide-angle shot, and junior high students defy gravity in their glee at being let out on the last day of school) to the pedestrian (O. J. Simpson's acquittal is marked by a lackluster picture of the zip strip in Times Square). Ginzburg has a good eye for candids -- in one sequence, former President Gerald R. Ford picks his teeth with a fingernail, inverts a bread plate to look at the make and honks his nose. The captions, by the photographer's wife, Shoshana Ginzburg, occasionally lapse into tabloid tastelessness (a photo of an amputee is slugged ''Without a Leg to Stand On''). Ginzburg is not a master of the black-and-white medium -- his images are often indifferently lighted and printed, and lack tonal range -- but his book is a heartfelt portrait of the extraordinary diversity of daily life in the city, and of New Yorkers' love of bread and circuses. Eric P. Nash

title: AIDS Memorial Set For Lasdon Park Site
description: THE first AIDS Memorial Garden on the East Coast will be established at the the county's Lasdon Park Arboretum and Veterans Memorial here.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Old Houses, Rain or Shine

title: Hard Line at Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: National Parks May Be Roomier
description: FOR those eager to see national-park attractions they have been reluctant to tackle, from Old Faithful at Yellowstone to the Grinnell Glacier at Glacier Park, from the Sequoias in California to Acadia in Maine, this is a particularly fortunate year. Getting in may be less of a problem than in past years.

title: June 27-July 3; Independent Counsel Law Dies, and Mourners Are Few
description: With little fanfare and no mourning, the independent counsel law died after 21 years during which prosecutors appointed under the statute rummaged through the public and private lives

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Commercial Property /Connecticut; Trading Floors Proliferate in Fairfield County
description: THE view from the mezzanine overlooking Warburg Dillon Read's busy 65,000-square-foot trading floor here suggests a spectacular movie set. Occupying what the company says is the largest such space in the country without pillars, its ceiling ranges from 30 to 50 feet high and it fills the fifth and sixth story of the seven-story building, accommodating 800 traders and some 2,000 computers.

title: . . . Plus Book Clubs and Jazz; The Jazz Scene Is Alive And Kicking, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Scramble To Find More Space; Bulge From the Baby Boom Emerges in Closets and Trailers
description: BLAME it, if you like, on Pearl Harbor.

title: Heather Benderson, Robert Lento
description: Heather Anne Benderson, the daughter of Carol Benderson and Dr. Albert Benderson of Levittown, Pa., is to be married this afternoon to Robert Joseph Lento, a son of Denise and Robert Lento of Woburn, Mass. Rabbi Susan Schnur is to officiate at the Benjamin Franklin House in Philadelphia.

title: Three Americans Play Lead Roles in Wimbledon's Final Acts; Graf-Davenport: Aiming for No. 1
description: Steffi Graf, whose reverence for Wimbledon and its quaint Center Court lawn is symbolized by her seven titles here, and Lindsay Davenport, who has finally outgrown her disdain for this ever-mutating surface, dispatched a pair of teen-agers today in the semifinals and gained their place in Wimbledon's Super Sunday lineup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, JIM NICHOLS
description: BURTON-Jim Nichols On June 26, 1999 in Tucson, Arizona. Formerly of Southport, CT. Husband of Mary (nee Weimar). Father of John and his wife Meehee of Seoul, Korea; Scott of Bridgeport, Ct. and Katherine of New York City and grandfather of Jacqueline Esul Burton. He was a graduate of the Taft School and attended Amherst College. Donations in his memory may be made to the Taft School, 110 Woodbury Road, Watertown, CT. 06795.

title: How Stylish People Don't Describe Themselves
description: THE idea is that you're 200 years old and you can choose from 50 items within your lifetime,'' said Tiffany Dubin, the director of the fashion department at Sotheby's auction house, describing the premise for a book on style she is putting together with Ann E. Berman, a writer. ''So what are you wearing?''

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

title: How Greenwich Village Got the Way It Did
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, MARY KATHRYN LYNCH
description: KURTZ-Mary Kathryn Lynch Devoted wife of the late Maestro Efrem Kurtz, passed away after a long illness at her home in London on June 27th, 1999. Mrs. Kurtz, originally from Houston, TX. was a loving aunt to her two nephews, John Wyatt and Richard Wyatt, and to her other nephews, nieces, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Through her passionate involvement in the arts, she enriched the lives of so many. An extraordinary lady, a thoughtful and caring friend, she will always live in our memory.

title: One He Didn't Invent
description: To the Editor:

title: An Ambivalent Single Among Mixed Doubles
description: ALTOGETHER too much attention as been paid to the old meanings, the revisions, the new meanings and the interpretations of character in what is touted as a ''new and improved'' version of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth's ''Company'' at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center here.

title: Cynthia Clark, Michael Robinson
description: Cynthia Yvonne Clark and Michael George Robinson were married yesterday in Montego Bay, Jamaica. The Rev. Carlton C. Clarke performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Anglican Church.

title: The Stevenson Saga: Rising Star's Initiation
description: The first time I met Alexandra Stevenson, in the late 80's, she was a merry child in San Diego splashing through swimming lessons and slamming a tennis ball over the net. She was big and strong for her age, and her paternity -- all I knew then was that her father was a famous former professional athlete -- promised major jock genes. Her mellow sweetness was a contrast to her mother's intensity. Later, I thought it might also be a result of it.

title: Rebuilding The Beaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Guide column last Sunday about the ''Hunters of the Sky'' exhibition at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers misstated the opening date. It is this Friday; it was not last Friday.

title: Q & A/Dr. Geoffrey Gladstein; Explaining Treatments for Arthritis
description: ARTHRITIS is a devastating and chronic illness that affects 20 million people in this country. For some, it makes sitting, standing and working a painful experience. For many, anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, have been the most effective way of dealing with the pain. Unfortunately for some of those people, these drugs have side effects that trade one type of discomfort for another.

title: School Budget Rejected
description: Mount Vernon residents on Tuesday rejected a $107.9 million school budget that would have raised their tax rate by 6.99 percent. But the voters accepted a $6.1 million bond for repairs to buildings and improving technology at the city's schools.

title: Linnette Webb, Albert Black Jr.
description: Linnette Webb was married yesterday to Albert Pershing Black Jr. at the Village Chapel on Bald Head Island, N.C. The Rev. Bernard J. Gadsen, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Reading the 'Blues'
description: You might expect to run into Joyce Carol Oates at a tony cafe in Princeton, where she lives, writes and teaches, but perhaps not at a bar in Hoboken. Yet that's where you'll find her on Tuesday night.

title: A 4-H Club With Goats, Ducks and Wheelchairs
description: Twelve young people recently gathered in a room at the Schroth Center in Ocean Township to decide which of their 4-H projects should be entered in competition at the Monmouth County Fair later this month. Similar meetings are being held all over the country, but the difference at the Spirit Farm 4-H Club is that all the members have cerebral palsy or another physical or mental disability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: A Trek From War to Liberation
description: ''I'M straddling two chairs,'' says Ea Sola, just back in Paris, when asked where she considers home. The daughter of a Vietnamese father and a French-born Polish-Hungarian mother, Ms. Sola grew up in Lam Dong, in the high plateaus of south-central Vietnam. She was born near the beginning of the Vietnam war, though she refuses to reveal the year. ''When I was 12, I already found the question of age obscene,'' she says in her low, deliberate voice. ''Living through all that I had by that age, I could have responded, '40.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDNEY, SYLVIA
description: SIDNEY-Sylvia On July 1, 1999. She will be deeply missed by her family Steven, Roz, Jennifer, Jessica, Max and Zachary.

title: Theatrical Alumni
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRKEN, MAURICE
description: SHIRKEN-Maurice. Dear Moose, your sudden passing has left us deeply saddened. Our years of friendship shall never be forgotten. You will always be near to our hearts. Rest in peace. Lola and Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: F.Y.I.
description: Those Village Rebels

title: Where Riots Raged, a Neighborhood Emerges
description: SEVEN years after the Los Angeles riots shook Southern California and the world, the words ''South-Central'' still evoke the open wounds of urban decay and social dislocation. But here on a wide swath of once-grand Vermont Avenue at 81st Street, seedlings of renewal are taking root this summer.

title: A Fragile Mind Bent In a Psychedelic Era
description: LIKE Bob Dylan's motorcycle accident or the sandbox Brian Wilson built in his living room, Alexander (Skip) Spence's freakout is the stuff of rock myth. In 1968, Spence, a guitarist for the San Francisco pop-psychedelic band Moby Grape, was in New York working on the group's second album. He hooked up with a woman who was known as a witch, and she gave him bad acid. Spence disappeared for a few days, and when he turned up again he was banging down the hotel room door of the band's drummer with a fire ax. The drummer wasn't there, so Spence proceeded to the recording studio in a taxi, ax still in hand. At the studio someone wrestled the ax away from him, but charges were pressed and Spence went to jail. He was given a choice: prison or a psychiatric hospital. He chose Bellevue, and he was there, doing penance, for six months.

title: Rachel Carter, Markus Boser
description: Rachel Carter, the daughter of Camilla and Michael Carter of Batcombe, England, was married there yesterday to Markus Boser, a son of Ruth Boser and Dr. Otmar Boser of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Fitzgerald-Lombard, the Abbot of Glastonbury, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

title: Roadblock to a Peace Pact: Irish Mostly Say 'No'
description: John Hume, a 1998 Nobel Peace Prize winner who heads the moderate Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party, nodded toward the lumpen brick Stormont Castle Buildings where talks to keep the Northern Ireland peace agreement alive were in their fifth grinding day.

title: Serving Up Hearty Meals of Information on Wheels
description: Charlene A. Patterson, 19, can rattle off a list of attractions in upper Manhattan the way other college students might list their favorite ballplayers: the Yeshiva Museum, the African-American Wax Museum, the Morris-Jumel Mansion, the Studio Museum. But even though she grew up in Harlem, Ms. Patterson had not heard of most of these places until a few weeks ago. ''To tell the truth, I've lived here all my life and really didn't know there were this many things in the community,'' she said.

title: The Geography of Desire
description: The Elusive Embrace

title: Free Outdoor Concerts For Family Outings
description: OUTDOOR concerts make family outings especially pleasant, and free admission also helps. Today at 2 P.M., for instance, the Bronx Arts Ensemble Jazz and Dixieland Band is assembling for its yearly Fourth of July Salute to George M. Cohan ''under the linden tree'' in Woodlawn Cemetery at Jerome and Bainbridge Avenues in the Bronx. The vocalists Cathy Gale and Paul Acquino will sing some of Cohan's patriotic songs along with other favorites by Irving Berlin, Duke Ellington and W. C. Handy. There is free parking at the cemetery. For directions, call (718) 601-7399.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREGAL, HENRIETTA ANN
description: KREGAL-Henrietta Ann On July 1, 1999. Loving sister of Jesse and Joseph. Dear aunt of Heidi, Rachel and Ariel. Great aunt of Sara. She will be profoundly missed. Service private.

title: Truancy for Adults
description: Summertime is here, and the living isn't as easy as it should be. Have you ever creatively fibbed to excuse yourself from work? And just what were you up to instead? Or have you ever caught anyone else playing hooky, and what did you do about it? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: June 27-July 3; Vodka and Water, a Deadly Mix
description: Vodka is Russian for ''little water,'' a playful diminutive ludicrously out of place given what it does to those who drink it before taking a swim. In Moscow alone, 144 swimmers drowned between May 1 and June 21, and on a particularly brutal weekend in mid-June, as many as 16 died each day -- 3 more than the daily average for the entire United States.

title: Part Time, Full Speed
description: Q. After being on maternity leave for six months, I have returned to work half time for half pay -- in theory, at least. My company, however, has something of a workaholic culture, and I have two fears: first, that I will face pressure to work nearly the full week despite the reduced salary and, second, that even after I return full time in a few years, I will forever be on the Mommy Track, with raises and promotions scarce. Any advice?

title: For Those Who Dare, Some Pearls in the Junk-Bond Seas
description: IN some ways, it is a paradox: high-yield bond funds performed better than any other type of fixed-income funds in the first half of the year, yet investors continued to shun them.

title: Visual Depths Convey the Mood of a Place
description: THE current show, titled ''Summer Places,'' at the Chappaqua Public Library here, curated by Larry D'Amico, the director of the library's gallery, features works that go beyond the everyday by transmitting the mood or atmosphere of the places they represent.

title: Babes in Toyland
description: THE SETTING -- In a dizzying blur of toys, nearly 450 young professionals gathered last Tuesday at the Hasbro Building on 23d Street. They were attending the Adults in Toyland benefit for the Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders of New York University Medical Center. The Junior Committee of the Hassenfeld center sponsored the event, raising $130,000.

title: TROPHY
description: The Gucci inflatable ring (a k a inner tube to all but the leisure class) is floating into view at pools across the Hamptons. While the black vinyl water toy is slightly bigger than the average tube and a bit thicker, the draw, for $190, may be the calming sight of a bobbing rubber lifesaver covered in interlocking G's.

title: Melissa Lange and Jon Cermak
description: Melissa Bernadine Lange, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Lange of Colorado Springs, was married there yesterday to Jon Adam Cermak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cermak of Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Stella, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in Shove Memorial Chapel at Colorado College, with the Rev. Bruce R. Coriell, who is the college chaplain.

title: Church of Milosevic's Rise Now Sends Mixed Message
description: A handful of black-robed, full-bearded Serbian Orthodox priests bobbed on the edges of a noisy crowd that assembled this week in the Serbian town of Cacak to demand that President Slobodan Milosevic resign.

title: Study Center Planned On Rockefeller Land
description: WHEN Peggy Dulany first approached her mother, Peggy Rockefeller, with the idea of converting part of the family's farmland and two stone barns here into a nonprofit education center, her mother was incredulous.

title: Free Agents Listening As the Wooing Begins
description: Over the next three weeks or so, Charles Oakley will be a popular man. Maybe not in the vein of Anfernee Hardaway, Mitch Richmond and Vin Baker -- All-Stars looking for their next multimillion-dollar contract. But as one of 187 free agents who cannot sign a deal until Aug. 1, Oakley is expected to be courted by several franchises seeking that special, nasty disposition for their playoff-bound team.

title: Armstrong's Comeback Continues With Victory
description: ''It looks good for me,'' Lance Armstrong said this afternoon about the short prologue course that opened the 86th Tour de France. A few hours later he showed how good it was by winning the race easily.

title: The Gloom Tube
description: DENNIS POTTER

title: Kashmir Thwarts India-Pakistan Attempt at Trust
description: Nearly two months into an armed conflict over the disputed territory of Kashmir, India and Pakistan -- the world's newest nuclear powers -- are once again playing the tired roles of time-tested enemies.

title: Abundance Reigns at Argentine Outpost
description: EVERY restaurant has a spirit and style of its own. It is quickly apparent that Gaucho's Grill, the new Argentine spot at 1141 Jericho Turnpike in Huntington (547-5534), is a South American fiesta. It brings the hearty food of the pampas to Long Island. A guitarist and vocalist from Quito, Ecuador, singing Latin love songs, circulate among the tables (on Friday and Saturday nights) as waiters lug huge platters of parrillada a lo gauchos or mixed Argentine grills to serious eaters untroubled by cholesterol, calories or fat. This is big beef country Argentine style, South America's answer to the growing number of Brazilian rodizio barbecues in Nassau and Suffolk, a part of the steakhouse revival sweeping the country.

title: A Book and Video Shop Finds a New Home
description: A bookstore and videotape rental shop that was on Broadway for 18 years has been forced by higher rents to move to Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Parents and Debtors
description: To the Editor:

title: Around Los Angeles, Drive-In Relics
description: Southern California is the Valley of the Kings when it comes to 1950's and 60's roadside architecture. Googie Tours, (323) 980-3480, offers three- to five-hour minivan excursions ($40) through the San Gabriel Valley, Hollywood or the Westside of Los Angeles, concentrating on such landmarks as the oldest remaining Bob's Big Boy and a 1953 McDonald's. The weekend tours also visit bowling alleys and malls from the era.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The Fourth of July will be observed.

title: Border Crossings
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed David Margolick's article (''Bordering on an Obsession,'' June 13), having spent many years crisscrossing Europe by train, where my pulse pounded like Poe's telltale heart as the cold knock on the door was followed by ''Passports please!''

title: Fumes at Hotel Send 4 People to Hospital
description: Four people were hospitalized and more than 100 were evacuated from the Crowne Plaza Hotel and surrounding stores in midtown Manhattan yesterday morning after high levels of carbon monoxide were discovered in a basement of the hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYMEL, JULES
description: BOYMEL-Jules Of Boca Raton, FL. Died July 3, 1999. Survived by his wife Pauline and daughters Natalie Kampen and Susan Udin. Memorial service to be announced.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Office Space for Sublet Jumps as Companies Revamp
description: LIKE families trading their current home for a larger or smaller one as their space needs change, companies have been rearranging their corporate houses at an increased rate in the last six months due to mergers, acquisitions or consolidations, brokers say.

title: Bias by State Police Protested in Atlantic City
description: Forty to fifty demonstrators were arrested today when the Rev. Al Sharpton took his civil disobedience campaign to Atlantic City to protest racial profiling by the New Jersey State Police.

title: Getting in Free
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Hemingway's Chair

title: Reasoning the Fourth
description: It has been 223 years since the first Fourth, the one commemorated on this anniversary, and in that time Independence Day has been celebrated in just about every possible way, with emotions ranging from a throb of sanctity to irate mockery, with fireworks, parades, doubleheaders, hot dogs, speeches, demonstrations, John Philip Sousa and long afternoon naps on what feels delightfully like the second Saturday in the week. This is still the least commercial holiday in the American holiday roster. No one has figured out a way to sell the public on exchanging Independence Day presents, and you can only use so much red, white and blue bunting before the front porch and the eaves start to look overdressed. The few things that always sell well for the Fourth -- explosives -- are illegal in most states. One good flag lasts a very long time.

title: Then and Now, Revisit to a Chef-Owned Spot
description: WHEN we drove past Kathleen's in Stamford recently, we realized that it had been six years since the American-style restaurant opened. Perhaps it was time to revisit.

title: Your Neighbor's Trees . . .; No Joyce Kilmer, Maybe, But No Scourge, Either
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Quarterly For the Hungry Explorer
description: For people who like to dine at out-of-the-way places and explore new areas of the city, Noshnews is a new quarterly publication that focuses on a different New York neighborhood in each issue.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Fleetwood American Eagle; Proof That You Can Take It With You
description: WHEN Americans take to the road, a lot of them want a home away from home. Consider that recreational vehicles are not just hot, they are sizzling like the burgers on the nation's grills this holiday weekend.

title: Stars and Stripes to Drool Over
description: Congress may be debating a flag-burning amendment, but parents across the country are focusing on the wash-and-wear properties of stars and stripes as children's clothing manufacturers splash flag motifs on bikinis, backpacks and more. While the original Ralph Lauren flag sweater ($70 at the Ralph Lauren store at Madison Avenue and 72d Street) is now a toddler classic, other designers and clothing chains are looking unusually patriotic. Tommy Hilfiger did his children's gear in graphic blocks of red, white and blue. Old Navy introduced flag-motif swimsuits, tank tops and sunglasses ($5.50 to $16); the Gap offers flag shirts, overalls and rompers ($6.50 to $32), and the Children's Place chain is selling out of ''Place America'' T-shirts and caps ($5). Even European brands like I.K.K.S. and Chevignon are incorporating stars, stripes and flag appliques, which are moving quickly at Space Kiddets, a boutique at 46 East 21st Street. ''But I wouldn't search for any deep political significance,'' said Cynthia Radocy, the owner of Space Kiddets. ''American icons are hot with Europeans. Flags sell.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Kosovar Refugees Need the Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Recognizing Those Offers That Can't Be Accepted
description: The great strength of the speculative sacrifice is that you can almost always get some opponent to scoff at it and swallow it.
