The sacrifice of a pawn gives the opponent something palpable; he knows that if nothing awful happens to him in the middle game, he will have great chances of winning the endgame. There are many players who figure that if they cannot see their own doom in the next five moves, they can defend anything. And go on to win. Among the great classical players who thought in those terms, the world champions Wilhelm Steinitz and Emanuel Lasker stand out.

title: Style; Is He or Isn't He?
description: John Travolta, Nicolas Cage, Tom Hanks, Billy Crystal, Michael Keaton . . . any child could tell their hairlines are in retreat, and yet it's the one facet of their much-publicized lives that is guarded with a fanaticism formerly reserved for nuclear-weapons technology and Presidential peccadilloes. Those closest to the problem are so tight-lipped they would make Gary Cooper sound logorrheic. They are the hair wranglers, the men and women on a movie set who fatten every strand and herd it into place to keep the bare spots undercover.

title: For the Summer, Flowers to Match the Ocean and the Sky
description: TO some people, the phrase ''American blues'' conjures up images of smoky nightclubs and B. B. King wailing away. To me, it brings to mind a stunning array of native perennials. These flowers look effortlessly beautiful in their natural habitats across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: A Public Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: Search for Stripers Whets Appetite
description: In angling there are few second chances -- for the angler or the fish. The striped bass, the supreme flyrod gamefish of the shallow waters of the Northeast, is a happy exception.

title: Corrections
description: Grouped picture credits at the bottom of page 1 in the Travel section today pair photographers with subjects incorrectly. The photographs, all for The New York Times, are by Kevin Moloney (state capitol, Denver), Jeffery F. Davis (American Folklore Theater, Wisconsin) and Jackson Hill/Black Star (Commander's Palace, New Orleans).

title: The Growing Roster of the Unretired
description: IN 1983, Jack and Elaine Wyman sold their advertising agency in San Francisco and retired to Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 62 and she was 57; they looked forward to relaxing after a lifetime of work.

title: Painting a Princess
description: When Qian Yi was a girl in Shanghai and studying the ancient art of Kunqu, which is as much restrained ballet as it is opera, she never thought she would get to play Du Liniang, the lovelorn heroine of Tang Xianzu's 16th-century masterpiece, ''The Peony Pavilion.'' The role, she says, is the greatest honor to which a woman in Chinese opera can aspire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVELSON, DEDE
description: SAVELSON-Dede We have lost our dearest friend. Dede's talent, energy and wonderful personality will live on in her beautiful family, Brian, Gary, Daniel, Eric, Kim and Kenny, as well as in the many hundreds of young people she inspired. Our sympathies to her husband Bob, her dad Abe Porchenick and her mother-in-law Elly Savelson. Funeral Monday 11AM at Bet-Am-Shalom, White Plains, NY. The Krupman Family

title: 2 Kosovo Albanians Are Slain As Peacekeepers Open Fire
description: British peacekeeping troops shot two Kosovo Albanians dead last night, one of them a well-known Kosovo Liberation Army soldier. Two civilians were severely wounded in the same incident, which occurred during a wild street celebration marking the Kosovo Albanians' freedom from Serbian rule.

title: Debra Bauer, Adam Cohen
description: Debra Lynn Bauer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart B. Bauer of Framingham, Mass., is to be married today to Adam Max Cohen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Max H. Cohen of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Alvin I. Lieberman is to officiate at the Ocean Cliff Hotel and Resort in Newport, R.I.

title: Helen Rosenfeld, Asheesh Advani
description: Helen Elisabeth Rosenfeld, the daughter of Annelise Rosenfeld and Dr. Jack Rosenfeld of Ossining, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Dr. Asheesh Advani, a son of Priya and Aju Advani of Marietta, Ga. Cantor Claire Metzger is to perform a ceremony incorporating elements of the Hindu and Jewish wedding traditions at the Mansion on Turner Hill, a historic house in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Turnpike Expects to Offer Off-Peak Toll Rates
description: When the New Jersey Turnpike has an electronic toll collection system in place and is ready to propose overall toll increases, toll charges will vary with the time of day to encourage use of the turnpike at off-peak hours, said Edward Gross, the turnpike system's executive director.

title: Summer Meet Markets At Central Park's Fields
description: DAVID HILLER adjusted his sunglasses and stretched out on the blanket he was sharing with a couple of friends. A 28-year-old news photographer for Channel 4, he contemplated the social scene at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park. ''This is like the beach,'' he sighed. ''All that's missing is the water.'' He watched a pack of young women troop by searching for ''good space,'' the smell of suntan lotion wafting behind them.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions last Sunday with an article on school budget elections reversed the identifications of two polling places. The larger picture showed New Rochelle High School and the smaller one Albert Leonard Middle School in New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: Will a Harlem Plant Become a Son of Fresh Kills?
description: What does the closing of the Fresh Kills landfill have in common with a plan to submerge part of the West Side Highway? To some Harlem residents they both harbor the same danger: more garbage in their part of town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MEYER
description: HOFFMAN-Meyer The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community of Columbus, Ohio, beloved brother of Martin (and Geraldine Schottenstein) Hoffman, who is a longtime supporter and leader of Yeshiva University. Heartfelt condolences are extended to: his wife, Evelyn; son, Craig; brothers, Martin and Phil (and Sonya) Hoffman; sisters Molly Hoffman, Mildred Hoffman and Annette Hoffman; Leah (and Harold) Franck; as well as to the entire Hoffman/Schottenstein family. May the Hoffman family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: A No Way on One-Way Idea
description: Everyone in Bay Ridge, it seems, wants to save the neighborhood from the horrors of traffic congestion. But what one group sees as a plan to reduce traffic jams with one-way avenues, another group fears would make the problem worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Sarah Haiby, Salil Kumar
description: Sarah Beth Haiby, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Haiby of Rockville Centre, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Salil Kumar, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Anil Kumar of Harahan, La. Cantor Doreen Gammell is to officiate at Timber Point Country Club in Great River, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ARTHUR H.
description: BAUM-Arthur H., died on June 25, 1999 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved husband of Toby. Loving father and father-in-law of Florence and Bernard, Brenda & Lawrence. Loving grandfather to H. Bruce, Joann, Cynthia, Robert, Kathi, Ira & Pamela. Loving great grandfather to Jared, Dylan and Max, Jennifer and Ashley. He will be greatly missed.

title: The Universal Borders of Brian Friel's Ireland
description: THEY say that an artist writes for the youth of today, the critics of tomorrow and the schoolteachers of ever afterward. The Irish playwright Brian Friel, who is celebrating his 70th birthday this year, has managed to produce masterpieces that please all three constituencies at once.

title: Dennis Brown, 42, Reggae Singer With an Enduringly Sweet Style
description: Dennis Brown, a popular and prolific Jamaican reggae singer, died on Thursday at University Hospital in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 42.

title: Nancy Walsh and John Smith Jr.
description: Nancy Beth Walsh, the director of dormitory services at the Juilliard School in New York, was married yesterday to John Zachary Smith Jr., an assistant professor of economics at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Town Justice Richard Christensen of Germantown, N.Y., officiated at the Vassar College Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, JACOB H.
description: ROSENBERG-Jacob H. Beloved husband of Clara. Devoted father of Alan, Jay and Saul. Services today, 12 Noon ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Coryatt Resurfaces as a Starter for the Cowboys
description: Quentin Coryatt was the No. 2 pick in the 1992 draft by Indianapolis. Steve Emtman was that draft's first pick. Emtman. Coryatt. One-two in '92. What a draft for the Colts. Emtman was a monstrous defensive lineman and Coryatt, a linebacker from Texas A&M, was speedy and strong, and their blend of athleticism and savvy was supposed to lift the Colts into contention.

title: A Threat to Student Privacy
description: The Orleans Parish School Board in Louisiana has ill-advisedly joined other educational institutions in considering broad student testing for drug abuse. The board is reviewing a program that would require random testing of all students involved in athletics and extracurricular activities, with voluntary testing for the rest of the student body.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: How Greenwich Village Got the Way It Did
description: To the Editor:

title: Variable Annuities
description: The quarterly tables listing the performance of variable annuities were not available for publication today. They are scheduled to appear next Sunday in Money & Business.

title: On Japanese TV, the A B C's of Money
description: THE world of high finance could hardly believe the news on the front page of The Financial Times last month. Goldman, Sachs & Company, as snooty as Wall Street's notoriously snooty white-shoe firms get, was sponsoring a TV program for Japanese homemakers? Surely someone had confused the firm with Procter & Gamble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNO, JAY
description: BRUNO-Jay, 63. Of NYC and Wallkill NY on June 27 of cancer. Born in the Bronx, NY, Jay was a print salesman and served in the 82nd Airborne Division from 1954 to 1957. He is survived by his loving wife Susan, son Jay (Orlando Fl.), son Michael (Pine Bush, NY), mother Evelyn Kirkwood (Dania Beach, Fl.), brother Stephen (Ft. Lauderdale, Fl.) and sister Lynne (Hollywood Fl.) A gathering of family and friends will take place at the Church Center for the United Nations, 777 UN Plaza (44 St. and 1st Ave.) on Wednesday, July 7 from 2-4 and 6-8PM. A celebration of Jay's life will begin at 7PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, FELIX, DR.
description: GLASS-Felix, Dr. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Epstein). Loving father of Lonnie & Joel Parker, Dr. Michael and Debbe Glass and Caasi Glass. Cherished grandfather of Dana, Matthew, Hillary, Ryan, Alisha and Stephen. Dear brother of Beatrice Lester and Ruth Fensterheim. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Crossing Pathways With Sculpture
description: THE yearly Sculpture Walks in Stamford have all been successful in informally mixing art with life. An imposing number of pieces are plunked down art in the middle of town, and those who cross paths with the art are asked to deal with it on their own terms, apart from the official ones often imposed by galleries and museums.

title: Dr. Joseph B. Wheelwright, 93, A Jungian Analyst and Teacher
description: Joseph B. Wheelwright, a driving force behind the spread of Jungian psychoanalytic teaching, died on June 22 at a convalescent home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 93.

title: In America; Stanton And Anthony
description: The latest splendid effort from the documentary film maker Ken Burns is about two women who barely register in the consciousness of late-20th-century America, but whose lives were critically important to the freedoms most of us take for granted.

title: . . . Plus Book Clubs and Jazz; The Jazz Scene Is Alive And Kicking, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 4, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Like a Suit, Only Cooler
description: Wallpaper prints in matching hats and shirts have been revived by young men seen around Manhattan. They give a Caribbean twist to the splashy postcard sunset Hawaiian varieties of 40's beachcombers or 60's surfers. The shirts are short sleeved, loose-fitting and squared off. And the key is the look is to wear them outside the trousers with that matching fabric hat.

title: A Helpful Hint To the Government
description: For much of his 35 years in Britain, Mohamed al-Fayed, the Egyptian-born owner of Harrod's department store, has been waiting in vain to be admitted to British citizenship and issued a British passport, for reasons that British officials are still generally unwilling to discuss.

title: Victor A. Bonomo, Maker Of Candy Bars, Dies at 100
description: Victor A. Bonomo, who created and marketed Bonomo's Turkish Taffy, the brittle candy bar whose wrapper instructed buyers to smack it and crack it into many edible pieces, died on June 26 at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 100.

title: If Twins Look a Bit Green, It's Only Rookie Fever
description: The American League will announce its starting All-Star team tomorrow. Do not look for any members of Tom Kelly's kindergarten to be on it.

title: Coming to Terms With Iowa
description: IN central Iowa, where I grew up, trains seemed to be an inextricable part of my life. I remember the time, riding in the car with my family and my sister's friend, we passed under a bridge as a train crossed above us.

title: Legal Immigrants, Too, Lack Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A Better War'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMPEROR, GEORGE
description: EMPEROR-George Age 76, born August 27, 1922 in Brooklyn, New York. The son of Thomas and Catherine Massey Emperor, last known to have resided in Brooklyn. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please contact the Rome D.D.S.O., collect AC 315-336-2300 with any special funeral arrangements.

title: Leonore Kim, Joshua Plaut
description: Leonore Sung-Hee Kim, the daughter of Inkum Kim of Agoura Hills, Calif., and Chang Jay Kim of Granada Hills, Calif., was married yesterday in New York to Joshua Andrew Plaut, a son of Anne and Jonathan Plaut of Summit, N.J. Justice George B. Daniels of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Yale Club.

title: Playing With Firearms
description: Sometimes an interview does not say what you meant it to say. Recently, I was interviewed by Jeffrey Goldberg (June 13), and I made some remarks that came out very badly indeed. In truth, they were not remarks that I (or anyone else) ought ever to have made, and for that I deeply apologize. I am not the things suggested by the column. I am not a bigot or an anti-Semite, as my friends and business associates can tell you. For those who do not know me, I am and have always been respectful of people from all walks of life. But I deeply regret having shown my lack of sensitivity and I reg ard it as a sobering lesson.

title: Few Balks At Closing Ballparks
description: A FEW months back, Dave Aust, a Seattle Mariners executive, was wracking his brains for a fitting send-off for the Kingdome, the Mariners' ballpark since 1977, which closed last Sunday.

title: A Show Befitting a 17th-Century Man of Curiosity
description: ON a table in the workshop of the Museum of Jurassic Technology sits a three-foot-tall clay model of a sunflower. It has delicately curling leaves and a fine head. When it is complete, explains Kelly Coyne, the museum's administrative director, this flower will stand in a bowl of artificial water, with a long, thin rod projecting from the center of its corolla and a brass ring, inscribed with numbers marking the hours of the day, encircling it. Created by Bridget Marrin, a member of the museum staff, this will be a faithful model, based on original drawings of a magnetic sunflower clock (the theory was that the sunflower would move with the sun, its rod pointing to the time of day) conceived by Athanasius Kircher, a 17th-century Jesuit scholar and inventor, and subject of a forthcoming exhibit at the museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: A Choir Director in the Bronx Has Big Dreams
description: Bruno Casolari might have been nervous, herding 120 children from the South Bronx onto buses going to St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: To Cape Cod
description: To the Editor: Your article on Provincetown, ''A Sandy Stage for Many A Character'' (June 6), was interesting and informative. But our service was omitted.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Shakespearean Comedy . . .

title: Cable Service Disrupted For 30,000 Customers
description: Cable television service for about 30,000 customers on the West Side of Manhattan was disrupted for several hours yesterday after a telephone-conduit maintenance crew severed a major underground television fiber-optic cable, a Time Warner spokeswoman said.

title: The Heat's On, and the Mets Are Parched for Runs
description: Fred Wilpon, one of the Mets' co-owners, said his general manager, Steve Phillips, gave him a briefing yesterday on the Mets' attempts to upgrade their starting rotation before the July 31 trading deadline. But the Mets have had a more pressing need than a front-line starter against the Atlanta Braves.

title: E.R.
description: Eleanor Roosevelt

title: Yes, as a Matter of Fact, He Is My Baby
description: At one point we thought about starting a club, my friend Lisa and I. Something along the lines of a support group for middle-class black mothers. Our crowd seems to constitute a limited maternal genre in many parts of Manhattan, where so often the baby in the stroller is white and the woman pushing it is black or brown.

title: Liquor-Drenched Legacy Of the Lower East Side
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Struggles to Find Space for Day Laborers
description: The sun was barely up when the immigrant day workers began to gather here along New York Avenue, waiting curbside to be hired by the landscapers, carpenters and other contractors who would drive up in vans and pickups.

title: Mock Penthouse Raises Questions Over Plan for Real One
description: After stiff opposition from neighbors, a plan to build a multistory penthouse on a historic building at Riverside Drive and 91st Street has been rejected by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Amanda Krell, Ronald Gimondo
description: Amanda Emily Krell and Ronald Dean Gimondo were married in Hartford yesterday. Judge Robert McWeeney of the Connecticut Superior Court officiated at the Hartford Club.

title: In the Wild Fund Kingdom, Anyone Can Wear a Crown
description: IN kindergartens these days, all the children are special. You're special if you have blue eyes, but also if you have brown eyes. You're special if you like cookies. You're even special if you live in a house, although not any more special than if you live in a car.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT PARK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRINKLE, PETER BRIAN
description: TRINKLE-Peter Brian On June 29th, 1999, in Dallas, Texas, at age 67 after a brief illness. A New York resident for 27 years, he worked for the Exxon Corporation for his entire business career until retirement in 1997. Devoted husband and father, he is survived by his wife Benita, his son Peter, his daughter Liza, and his sister Jean Weedon. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Museum of Natural History or the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Ms. Hoover And Mr. Rose
description: Heidemarie Ruth Hoover, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. B. Penrose Hoover of Lebanon, Pa., is to be married today to Michael Tod Rose, a son of Karol L. Rose of Darien, Conn., and Alan J. Rose of New York. Rabbi Louis Zivic is to perform the ceremony at Beth Israel Synagogue in Lebanon.

title: Mulch, and Pinch the Herbs
description: Mulch to discourage water-and-nutrient-hogging weeds, conserve water and keep soil (and therefore roots) cool. Organic mulch, especially compost, also adds nutrients and improves soil texture as it breaks down.

title: Humbled By the Company He Kept
description: PROFANE and imperious, Richard Harriton has for two decades run Wall Street's biggest clearing operation, the Bear Stearns Securities Corporation, with an iron hand. A tough guy up from the streets of Brooklyn, his us-against-them view of the world meshed nicely, associates say, with Bear Stearns's macho culture and obsession with the bottom line.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LETTER TO LORENZO

title: Short and Sweet
description: In keeping with the theory that hors d'oeuvres and bites from other people's plates have no calories, chefs are creating micropastries this summer. ''They're the latest dessert for dieting models and photo shoots,'' said Jonathan Ducrest, the executive assistant to Francois Payard, whose restaurant and patisserie, at 1032 Lexington Avenue (73d Street), offers tarts, napoleons, babas and eclairs (all mini, all $1.75). ''Mini used to mean three or four bites,'' Mr. Ducrest said. ''Now it means one.'' At the Little Pie Company, 424 West 43d Street, the current craze is two-inch cheesecakes in plain, mango, butterscotch or chocolate swirl ($1.75 each). Yura & Company, at Third Avenue and 92d Street, sells diminutive cupcakes and cookies ($8 to $16 a pound) and, by special order, finger-food-size ice cream sandwiches and one-ounce butterscotch pudding cups. Small, however, doesn't mean simple. The ''New York, New York'' pastry at Payard, a cream cheese mousse on a lemon biscuit with berries, has a minikin Manhattan skyline silk-screened in chocolate along its sides. ''These are thin and gorgeous indulgences,'' Mr. Ducrest said, ''for thin and gorgeous people.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Legal Immigrants, Too, Lack Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INTOCI, EMANUEL J.
description: INTOCI-Emanuel J. On July 3, 1999. Beloved father of Guy Intoci. Loving father-in-law of Catherine. Cherished grandfather of Guy, Jr., and Alexandra. Dear brother of Sally Corrao. Beloved husband of Victoria. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Rd., East Northport, LI. Funeral mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, at St. Matthew's RC Church, Dix Hills. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale. Donations: Oskar Kalb Memorial Foundation, 2 Eaton Lane, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREEGER, LAWRENCE
description: KREEGER-Lawrence, on July 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Jeanne. Loving father of Andrew, Arthur, Susan and Deborah. Dear brother of Mildred Davidson and the late David. Adoring grandfather of Emma, Isabel, Arden, Katherine, Molly and Emily. Devoted uncle and great-uncle. He will be deeply missed. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Graveside service Monday, 11:30 AM, Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Reports of Coercion in a Mexican Election
description: Battling to maintain control over Mexico's most populous state, the governing party has been testing the limits of electoral legality, buying or coercing the votes of poor Mexicans who are to cast ballots in elections for governor on Sunday, according to electoral watchdog groups and interviews with residents.

title: Sissi, of Brazil, Has Right Stuff With Left Foot
description: It did not discourage Sisleide Lima do Amor when the boys in the streets of Salvador, Brazil, did not want her to play in their pickup games. Inevitably, she got her way. ''I owned the ball,'' she said.

title: For Swiss, Some Soul Searching After Losing a Bid for Olympics
description: Like chocolate, cheese, precision watches, the Red Cross, skiing and banking, the Olympic movement has been linked for decades with Switzerland. The city of Lausanne has long been headquarters for the International Olympic Committee and home to its spectacular lakeside museum.

title: Happy Whatever
description: If you missed the Jersey Shore's own Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes at the New Jersey Arts and Music Festival in Newark last month, you have another chance to hear them today. But get thee to the PATH train: they're playing the free Fourth of July concert at Battery Park in lower Manhattan at 3:30 P.M. Sharing the bill is Dr. John, that roving ambassador of New Orleans style, who also played the festival. B.Y.O. blanket for seating. Information: (212) 835-2789. . . . Speaking of holidays, the First Night New Jersey Coalition is expecting more than 100,000 guests at 18 arts-oriented, alcohol-free New Year's Eve parties throughout the state. The theme for the worldwide millennial celebration is ''Share the Light, Ignite the Spirit.'' Now, only six months (minus four days) left to find a date.

title: Correction
description: A brief article on June 20 about finding theater ticket bargains in New York misidentified the Web site of a theater information service.

title: Why Should New York Have to Dial 646?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dirt on a Dig
description: When Chris Ricciardi and his fellow archeologists found two glass eggs while excavating the grounds of the Hendrik I. Lott House in Marine Park, which was a family farm in the 18th century, they were clueless. Mr. Ricciardi, a graduate student and a director of the Lott House Archaeological Project, listed the glass eggs as a mystery object on one of two Web sites about the dig. ''Then someone in the Midwest wrote us an E-mail,'' Mr. Ricciardi recounted. ''He said: 'What's wrong with you? They are hen-laying eggs,' '' ersatz eggs placed under reluctant chickens to encourage them to lay the real thing.

title: REASON IS SOUGHT FOR LAG BY BLACKS IN SCHOOL EFFORT
description: Taking on one of the most troublesome and contentious issues in American education, school officials and educators around the nation have begun discussing why the academic achievement of black middle-class and upper-income students lags behind whites of comparable socioeconomic status.

title: This Space Occupied
description: EMBRACING DEFEAT Japan in the Wake of World War II. By John W. Dower. Illustrated. 676 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company/ The New Press. $29.95.

title: Judith Schnelwar, Gary Gladstein
description: Judith Ann Schnelwar and Gary Stephen Gladstein are to be married today at a private house in Katonah, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Hammerman is to officiate at the ceremony, in which Rabbi Irwin Wiener, the brother-in-law of the bride, is to take part.

title: When Youths Choose Life on the Streets; A Shelter Offers Runaways and the Homeless a Bed and Advice on Where to Turn Next
description: ON a warm Friday evening, teen-agers were beginning to gather on street corners, congregate in parks and roam the housing projects here. It was time for Jeffery Richardson and Jacqueline Fiorello to get to work.

title: How a Creole Singer Wowed Them in Shangri-La
description: THE story of the making of ''Genghis Blues'' is a classic labor-of-love, rags-to-riches story, set in the documentary world (where riches mean critical acclaim, not monetary reward). Two brothers, Adrian and Roko Belic, recent college graduates obsessed with making their film, paint houses, run up credit cards, depend on Mom for emotional and nutritional sustenance and apply to foundations and are turned down (save for one $2,000 grant, roughly 1 percent of their film's cost). They hop on a plane, shoot 150 hours of video in a far-off land, return home, run up more credit cards and spend month after month editing into the wee hours.

title: Can Joe Camel Grow Up?
description: The people who brought you Joe Camel, eager to promote cigarettes despite a legal settlement banning marketing that might reach children, are now sponsoring explorations of the art world's farthest frontiers. The line between philanthropy and marketing, however, can be as hard to find as the sites of some of the cultish events they underwrite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOMER, GEORGE DUPONT
description: BOOMER-George DuPont Born in Boston, MA, October 31, 1921. Died in Chocorua, NH, July 1, 1999. He was the only son of Lucius M. Boomer, who was the President, Chairman of the Board and builder of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. He founded Hodges International, Inc., which supplied mostly licensees of very large American firms in Europe. From there he retired in 1992. He was married to the late Joan and Clarina and his present wife Nola, who survives him. He had one son, John, resident of Maine, and one daughter, Jorgine, resident of Manhattan. Funeral in New Hampshire. Memorial service in Manhattan to be announced later. Please omit flowers, donations to: Sheltering Arms Childrens Fund. BOOMER-George duPont. The Board of Directors and staff of Sheltering Arms Childrens Service note with sorrow the passing of George duPont Boomer, President of the Board for 12 years. His support, optimism and good humor were inspirational to all of us. Henry A. Lambert, Chairman Wayne R. Mucci, Exec. Director

title: Israel's New Coalition
description: To the Editor:

title: Spinning Pizza With a Twist
description: In the pantheon of party dances, there is the classic funky chicken, the cheerleader-patterned Y.M.C.A., the disco-flavored electric slide and the saucy macarena. If Tony Modica, a Queens restaurateur with stars in his eyes, gets his way, the pizza dance will join this hallowed list.

title: Miss Markowitz And Mr. Bennett
description: Sharon Renee Markowitz and Marc Benjamin Bennett are to be married today by Rabbi Seymour Essrog at the Riviera Country Club in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: June 27-July 3; Fed Raises Interest Rates Just a Tad, Just in Case
description: There is little evidence of inflation. But there is enough fear of it that the Federal Reserve raised interest rates a notch, to make sure the economy does not get derailed by a spiral of rising wages and prices.

title: Sports of The Times; Just Five Years Later, Nations Reverse Roles
description: THERE it is, in my T-shirt drawer, one of my favorite gamers. Some artist did a fine job reproducing both the Stars and Stripes and the Brazilian flag with that other-worldly white globe, and a soccer ball floating in between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACBRIDE, KENNETH RHOADES
description: MacBRIDE - Kenneth Rhoades Broadcaster, died on June 29th, 1999 at age 58. His special wit, talents, dedication and responsibility will be remembered and missed by all who encountered him. Ken is survived by his wife, Diana, of Ramsey, NJ; his mother, Marie, of Laguna Hills, CA.; his sisters Nancy Plamann of La Canada, CA, and Holly Ohlson of Lennox Head, Australia; his nieces Kendall Plamann of San Francisco, CA, Ashley Ohlson of Lennox Head, Australia, and Heather Berthold of Washington, DC; his nephews Chris Plamann of Okinawa, Japan, Nicholas Ohlson of Lennox Head, Australia, and Sebastian MacBride of Landing, NJ. Alumnus of Northwestern University and Senior Operations Specialist, Ken worked for NBC Network Television in New York, NY for 35 years. He recently founded and served as CEO for MacBride Consultants, Inc. He was a student of Japanese language and culture, and a member of the Apple Developers Group. A cherished dad, loved by his children, Ken's strength of character and leadership created a great base of knowledge and resources on which to build their futures. He was loved and will be remembered by son Beau and his wife, Honora Griffin MacBride, of Ramsey, NJ, and their children, Brendan, Kelly and James who called him Grand Dad Ken; son Jeffrey and his wife, Miwa Suzuguchi MacBride of Obu, Japan, and their daughter, Anna who called him Kenji; and daughter Samantha MacBride Pellettere and her husband, Scott, of Paterson, NJ, and Scott's son Anthony who called him Pop Ken. A Memorial Service will be held at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue in Ramsey at 8:00 PM on July 5th. The family will receive friends on Monday from 2-4 and 7-9. Memorial donations to the following are welcomed by the family: Cabrini Hospice, Cabrini Medical Center, 227 East 19th Street, NY, NY 10003; Ramsey Swim Team, c/o Ramsey Municipal Building, 33 North Central Avenue, Ramsey, NJ 07446; and Ramsey High School Japanese Exchange Program, 240 East Main Street, Ramsey, NJ 07446.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONDREN, HAROLD M.
description: FONDREN-Harold M. Died on July 2. An authority on abstract expressionism, he was a well known figure in the New York art world. He is survived by his brother Darl. At Hal's request, there will be no service.

title: Odd Spots on Tour
description: DOZENS of New York City guidebooks are available, and it is safe to say most do not suggest these stops: a McDonald's with a doorman; Conan O'Brien's former residence; a stamp and lettering shop in Manhattan; a ''door to nowhere'' on Avenue A. But a new ''tour,'' a performance called ''Tourguide?'' commissioned by the Public Art Fund, features these offbeat spots and more.

title: Uphill (and Downhill) Battle
description: Alyssa Knowles of Chatham loves riding roller coasters. She is also concerned about people who need organ or tissue donations. These seemingly unrelated facts have come together in her odyssey to ride a total of 70 roller coasters in two weeks, garnering pledges (25 cents to a dollar for each coaster) for organ donation organizations. Ms. Knowles, who is a nurse at a musculo-skeletal transplant foundation, along with her two children, aged 5 and 7, and their babysitter, mapped out a Coasting Toward Awareness tour scheduled to start yesterday with a spin on the five coasters at Kennywood Park, near Pittsburgh. They will move on to areas in Ohio, Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, Kentucky, Viriginia and Washington D.C., all with several coasters. The final fling will be July 17 back in New Jersey at Six Flags Great Adventure in Jackson and its seven coasters. While she is away, she will still take pledges by phone at (973) 635-0228; leave a message when you hear the ''Wheeee!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHA, JAMES J.
description: BEHA-James J. Loving husband, father and grandfather, died July 3 at United Hospital. He was 82 years old. His family includes his devoted wife of 51 years, Macy Ann, his son James A. Beha II and his wife Nancy, his daughter Ann Beha and her husband Robert A. Radloff. He is also survived by his grandchildren Mary Alice, James J., Christopther R. Beha, and Macy and Allison Radloff. Mr. Beha graduated from Williams College and the Harvard Law School. He was a senior partner at the law firm of Gasser & Hayes, and served as trustee of numerous charitable and civic organizations in New York City including the NYU Medical Center. Mr. Beha was a Knight of Malta, and a member of The Order of The Holy Sepulchre. He was also a loyal member of The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY and the American Yacht Club. Friends may call Tuesday, July 6 from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be Wednesday, July 7, 11 AM at The Church of the Resurrection. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, or Constableville Public Library, Constableville, NY, would be appreciated.

At the entrance to the store, she turned to me with a smile and said, ''Come grow old with me, the best is yet to be,'' and disappeared inside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Hit the Beach
description: The pedestrian title doesn't even hint at the humanity displayed in BY THE SHORE (Atlantic Monthly, $24), a first novel from the English-born actress Galaxy Craze. This exceptional book captures perfectly the hopes and hurts of childhood. May, the 12-year-old narrator, and Eden, her 6-year-old brother, are children of different absent fathers. They live with their mother, Lucy, in the modest seaside inn she runs in an unnamed English village. In a winningly matter-of-fact way, May describes her former life in London, dropping clues about Mum's wild life style, which sounds like something out of the British sitcom ''Absolutely Fabulous'': boozing and partying with her girlfriends, bringing home the stray rock star and simultaneously loving and neglecting her sensible daughter. Now that those days are long past, Lucy is mostly succeeding at being a good mother. Then along comes Rufus, a London writer who is seeking a quiet haven and who is being pursued by a glamorous editor who's more interested in him than in his poetry translations. As the children and Lucy grow increasingly fond of kindly, solid Rufus, May's playboy father decides to visit for the first time in three years. And that's the plot. Craze's skill is in seeing so clearly through a vulnerable child's eyes: the way it feels when your mother gives your new towels from Grandma to a guest, or when you hurt your only friend without meaning to. She also beautifully portrays the unspoken but painful rivalry among mother, daughter and son for Rufus's friendship. (Occasionally Craze loses her youthful voice, but not often enough to matter.) Snippets of dialogue tell a lifetime of stories. And the tension, which Craze manages to build with nothing more than a white lie or a misunderstanding, is so palpable you'd think you were reading a thriller. Having come to care deeply about this fragile bunch, you'll wish them nothing less than a Hollywood ending. Carol Peace Robins

title: A 'Little' Museum With Big Clout
description: We were quite amused and perplexed to see the Science Museum of Long Island referred to as a ''pocket museum'' in the June 20 article, ''Inventing a Science and Technology Museum.'' Over the years, the museum has attracted luminaries such as the Nobel Prize winner Frank Oppenheimer, the astronaut Scott Carpenter, the Russian cosmonaut Viktor Savinhykh, the oceanographer Sylvia Earle, the environmentalist Jim Fowler and the Antarctic specialist Rita Mathews. These and other top scientists have visited the museum and contributed to our courses, workshops and lectures because they felt our hands-on science programs for children were substantive and dynamic. Our director, Dr. John Loret, is a marine biologist who has participated in expeditions with Thor Heyerdahl. Dr. Loret, a former Explorer's Club president, has led more than 35 global science expeditions himself. You don't draw a stellar caliber of people like the ones mentioned to collaborate with or direct an organization when you're merely a ''pocket museum.''

title: Corrections

title: Can Nonprofits Also Be For-Profits?
description: I wonder how many readers noticed the rhetorical sleight-of-hand in ''New Arts Space Keeps Faith With White Plains'' (June 6). State Senator Nicholas A. But the council anticipates for-profit activities in the building described. Evidently, no one questions where nonprofit ends and for-profit begins or why taxpayers who live elsewhere should pay ''for the revitalization of downtown White Plains'' if local businesses want out.

title: June 27-July 3; Mitral Valve Problems Are Not So Serious After All
description: As many as 28 million Americans who were told they are in danger of stroke, heart failure and other problems because of mitral-valve prolapse probably do not have to worry. A new study showed that about 2.4 percent of the population -- not the 5 percent to 15 percent previously estimated -- have the condition, an abnormally long, floppy valve that can cause blood leakage in the heart. And in those who do have it, it was found no more likely to cause the feared complications than those who do not.

title: Marjorie Kozart And Kevin Volpp
description: Marjorie Lubell Kozart, a daughter of Elizabeth Kozart and Dr. David M. Kozart of Philadelphia, is to be married at her parents' house this evening to Dr. Kevin Gerhard Ming Volpp, the son of Dr. Ching Y. Volpp and Dr. Gert P. Volpp of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Julie Greenberg will perform the ceremony.

title: In This Race, 3 of the 5 Runners Left a Benchmark in the Dust
description: THE stock market's turn from big growth stocks to smaller issues and value stocks in the second quarter was good news for investors with diversified portfolios, including the five money managers who assembled hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption with the art reviews last Sunday misidentified an abstract painting in the ''Old Friends'' exhibition at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton. It is ''Clear Water,'' by James Bohary, not ''Rise to Light '99,'' by Frank W. Wimberley.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: STEALING GLIMPSES

title: Horses and Ponies, a Bit of Revelry, Too
description: THERE were quite a few events someone could enter in this year's Ox Ridge Charity Horse Show, held in mid-June at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club in Darien. Over the course of a week -- during which the weather was remarkably cooperative -- there was the dinner dance, a landscape designers' competition, boutiques and a V.I.P. tent for mingling. With events like these, who needed a horse?

title: Arab TV Gets a New Slant: Newscasts Without Censorship
description: In millions of homes and offices across the Arab world, television sets are regularly tuned these days to Al Jazeera, a hard-hitting Arabic-language news channel that explores issues long suppressed by the region's rulers, including the lack of democracy, the persecution of political dissidents and the repression of women.

title: Keeping Our Pride In Our Westhampton
description: Sunday morning, as I sipped coffee on my deck with the herons stalking the marsh in my Westhampton backyard, I sat 20 miles closer to the city than Southampton Village and read, with some satisfaction, your article ''Warily, Southhampton Revisits Traffic Issues'' [June 27] about the misery faced by all those who drive east of the Shinnecock Canal.

title: Resilient Egypt
description: To the Editor: Nancy R. Newhouse's account of Egyptian tourism's recovery after the 1997 massacre (''Egypt: The Convoy Route,'' May 16) summons my recall of a place and people.

title: June 27-July 3; New York Pauses for a Tall Tale
description: On the last leg of what still seems a remarkable journey, Edwin Daniel Sabillon charmed the city. The 13-year-old Honduran boy told a heart-rending, though made-up, tale to strangers he met in Miami, who bought him a bus ticket to New York City. He arrived on Sunday and after a few hours of sightseeing, he was picked up by a taxi driver who was captivated by his smile and touched by his story. The driver alerted the police, the police alerted the news media, which naturally alerted the Mayor, and Edwin was a sensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUGGENHEIMER, RANDOLPH
description: GUGGENHEIMER - Randolph Age 91. Beloved husband of Elinor C. Loving father of Charles, Randolph, Jr. and Jane. Grandfather of Randolph III, Elizabeth, Steven, Julia, Lynn G. and Jonathan Horowitch, and six great-grandchildren. Interment private. Memorial service Thursday, July 8th, 11AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: North General Hospital or the charity of your choice.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Story Begins Essays on Literature. By Amos Oz. Harcourt Brace, $20.

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: After Stanley Kubrick died in his sleep of a heart attack on March 7, even the New York tabloids reported the news with an auteur slant, headlining the director's generally bleak view of life. Words like ''secretive,'' ''reclusive,'' ''strange,'' ''mysterious'' and ''cold'' were repeatedly used to describe him. It's true that the 13 feature-length films he made over 40 years present a disenchanted, sardonic and generally pessimistic view of humanity, but the lifelong friends, intimate associates and family members I spoke to conjure a far more complicated picture of a man who could be deeply reserved but also outgoing, meticulous and laid back, loving and self-absorbed.

title: Ned Bassen, Susan Campbell
description: Susan Millington Campbell and Ned Henry Bassen, partners in Hughes Hubbard & Reed, the Manhattan law firm, were married on Friday. Judge Denny Chin of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated in his chambers.

title: Backtalk; Becoming a Yankee Fan, By Way of Hollywood
description: In 1941, Teresa Wright, a fresh-faced young actress from New York -- fittingly, the Bronx -- had just been signed to a long-term contract by the movie producer Samuel Goldwyn. He had seen her in ''Life With Father'' on Broadway and was captivated by her performance.

title: Morris County Is Raising The Cost of Holding Raves
description: Morris County officials say they hope to make it too expensive for promoters to stage any more of the all-night dance parties called raves at the Mennen Arena in Morris Township after 80 people were arrested at one there last weekend, mainly for marijuana possession.

title: A Voluminous Library for What Ails You
description: IN a room at Griffin Hospital's Health Resource Center in Derby, Anne and John Verbiskas of Orange pore over medical research papers.

title: Brooklyn Man to Be Charged With Killing 2
description: A Brooklyn man who phoned the police on Friday to say that he had killed his girlfriend and his ex-girlfriend has been charged with one of the murders and will be charged with the other, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: The Smokestacks Are Back
description: AN OIL driller, a maker of industrial cutting tools, an acquisitive steel producer and a paper company. Those were the kinds of blue-collar stocks that fueled returns of the top-performing mutual funds in the second quarter.

title: Rustic Adirondack Retreat
description: IN a rare episode of solitary self-indulgence, I spent three exquisitely peaceful days wandering through fragrant pine woods, kayaking on a pristine mountain lake and strolling across a lagoon on a 300-foot boardwalk to a Japanese teahouse -- all part of a visit to the world of Adirondack camps where the privileged ''roughed it'' in the early 1900's.

title: Hemingway Hometown Celebrates a Centennial
description: For decades there was no love lost between Ernest Hemingway and his hometown, Oak Park, Ill., just west of Chicago. The town, then stodgy and straitlaced, snubbed the swashbuckling adventurer, and Hemingway, in turn, lampooned Oak Park as a village of ''broad lawns and narrow minds.''

title: The Cleanest Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Spinning Dialogues on Love and Time's Incursions
description: THE office of the filmmaker Olivier Assayas is in an out-of-the-way corner of the Ninth Arrondissement in Paris, off a courtyard with a small fountain. Inside, the rooms have the white-washed airiness of a summer house. When the director arrives, he steps carefully and abstractedly over his assistant's puppy, asleep in the doorway.

title: Streetscapes /64th Street Between Park and Lexington; Architectural Fashion Reflected in a Block
description: THE block of 64th Street from Lexington to Third Avenues is locally famous as an architectural Wild West show: since the block is not included in the landmarked Upper East Side Historic District, big-budget renovations have transformed the old brownstones with a free hand. But the block to the west, 64th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, is included in the district, and several current alterations there present a noticeable contrast.

title: The Postindustrial Revolution
description: The Great Disruption

title: INSIDE
description: Kashmir Clash Grows Edgier

title: MY BIGGEST MISTAKE: Milton Friedman
description: Milton Friedman has been the intellectual spark plug of the conservative movement for 60 years, providing sharp-edged analysis in support of causes from monetarism to school vouchers. Monetarism -- the doctrine that the Federal Reserve could keep the economy on an even keel merely by allowing the money supply to grow slowly and evenly over time -- was offered as an antidote to the Keynesian doctrine that Government needed to manipulate spending and taxes to keep the economy out of depression.

title: Border Crossings
description: To the Editor: David Margolick's observations on border crossings were highly appreciated by this frequent traveler. Mr. Margolick would no doubt be gratified to know that the Hungarian-Romanian border still offers a James Bond-like experience, at least on the Romanian side of the border. This is because of the large number of Hungarians living in Transylvania, an area that belonged to Hungary until the Treaty of Trianon in 1920. There is still a great deal of tension regarding this situation, and this probably explains more of what Mr. Margolick experienced a dozen years ago than other factors.

title: Budget Freeze Spreads a Chill Past Albany
description: New York State's budget is more than three months overdue, and the delay is beginning to have real consequences for programs that affect people across the state.

title: Unsettling Heart Ailment Sends Spencer to Sideline
description: Instead of playing left field at Yankee Stadium yesterday, Shane Spencer was lying at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center being treated for an irregular heartbeat. It is never enjoyable to be poked and prodded inside a hospital, and the mysterious aspect of a 27-year-old who has never had previous heart problems suddenly experiencing them added to the delicate nature of Spencer's condition.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: Sulawesi Wonders
description: To the Editor: My wife and I visited Sulawesi recently. Part of our motivation, as Barbara Crossette implied (''Sulawesi, Exotic and Worldy,'' May 2), was the alluring account by Alfred Russel Wallace, mostly notably in ''The Malay Archipelago.'' Consequently, we too visited the Bantimurung waterfall, where we also saw young children selling butterflies in cellophane.

title: Homes Built to Instill Pride in Ownership
description: ON the north side of West 134th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues heavy scaffolding partly hides an abandoned and decaying five-story tenement. It is hemmed in, east and west, by three once-elegant brownstones that for many years have stood faded and empty, their disheveled exteriors hollow-eyed and partly stripped. Their ravaged dignity has depressed neighbors, as well as congregants at the landmark St. Philip's Episcopal Church across the street, providing a constant reminder of the neighborhood's decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASANAVE, CAROLYN J.
description: CASANAVE-Carolyn J. On June 23rd, 1999, at home surrounded by family and friends after a six year battle with breast cancer. Veteran actress of musical comedy in New York and Los Angeles. She will be remembered by all for her incredible courage, talent, love and generosity. She is survived by her beloved husband, George, parents Robert and Alice Thomson, brother Scott Thomson and sister Arlene Calkins.

title: A Hunt for a Better Mortgage
description: ABBY RODGERS is not one to haggle. She buys cars at list. In early April, in need of a mortgage, she turned to a large lender, tentatively accepted a loan at just under 7 percent, with no points, and went away happy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Hard Line at Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: A Less Famous Civil War
description: THE little Kansas ravine hugging the Missouri border was ghostly silent and seemingly detached from the outside world on a rainy day in late November, but John Greenleaf Whittier's tribute to those who died on the spot 140 years ago filled my head as I tramped the grassy hillside. His poem -- published in The Atlantic Monthly in the autumn of 1858 -- focused the country's attention on the war developing along the Missouri-Kansas border long before shots were fired at Fort Sumter. He wrote:

title: Heather Funke, Christopher Helle
description: Heather Rani Funke, a daughter of Kathy and Robin Funke of Minot, N.D., was married yesterday to Christopher Sutherland Helle, the son of Nancy and Herb Helle of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Joseph Gillespie, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Basilica of St. Mary in Minneapolis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, JACK
description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. Services Thursday, 12:30PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the New Jersey section last Sunday about a business called Beach 'n' Billboard, which embosses advertising on the sand, referred incorrectly to the reaction of municipal officials to the idea of doing business with the company. While four officials interviewed were either skeptical or opposed, there was no basis for saying that ''Most Beach Towns Say Ads Detract.'' As the article reported, officials of only 11 towns were telephoned, out of dozens on the shore, so it is not clear what most towns think.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: That Family Figure Watching Over Us Is Not Big Brother
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, Uncle Sam wasn't born on the Fourth of July but on Sept. 13, 1766, in Arlington, Mass. And he had many guises before James Montgomery Flagg painted a stern, white-haired man proclaiming, ungrammatically, ''I want YOU for U.S. Army.''

title: Mets Must Make Do Without Franco
description: It has been so long since John Franco was seriously injured that even his wife, Rose, didn't understand what he was talking about late Friday night.

title: Brosius' Hit Leaves Yanks In the Spirit of 1998 Season
description: Their faces turn sour and their heads wag whenever anyone brings up the 1998 season: the American League-record 114 regular-season victories and the World Series sweep of the San Diego Padres. This season's Yankees aren't last season's Yankees, their mantra goes.

title: There Ought to Be a Law. Maybe.
description: ON this most historic of weekends, virtually every New Jerseyan will be celebrating the miracle that is American democracy by thinking one of the following thoughts:

title: June 27-July 3; Clinton Backs 2000 Bill
description: All spring, President Clinton urged Democrats in Congress to oppose a Republican bill to limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures. Detrimental to consumers, he said, and a precedent for restraints on litigation. Most Democrats obliged, despite pressure from the computer industry and other businesses constituents. After Republicans made some small concessions, the President changed his mind. The Senate and House quickly approved the agreement, and Mr. Clinton promised to sign it.

title: SOAPBOX; Down on the Count Who Needs All Those Millennium Clocks?
description: NO publication should print another article that contains the word ''millennium'' until well into the year 2999. It is anxiety-provoking enough thinking about all the Y2K disasters waiting to happen -- the bank will lose track of the $17 in interest I earned on my savings account last year; my favorite Chinese restaurant will cross wires with the trust and estates department at a major law firm. As a result, a codicil bequeathing my worldly possessions will be slipped under the door of every apartment with my telephone exchange.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Tears and Cheers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELIAS A.
description: COHEN-Elias A. Although fortyseven years have passed, since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige'' his devoted family, his many loyal friends, and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 81st year. Tranquillity Camp Inc. Earlton, New York Pearl C. Miller, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGLER, FRANCES
description: FOGLER-Frances The Board of Trustees, administration and medical staff of the Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center record with deep sorrow the passing of Frances Fogler, beloved mother of Richard J. Fogler, Chairman of Surgical Services. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Fogler and his entire family. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena President and CEO Sheldon S. Berman, M.D. Sr VP and Chief Medical Officer Malcolm Z. Roth, M.D. President Medical Staff Arthur Kay, M.D. President Medical Board

title: . . . Plus Book Clubs and Jazz; Book Club Members Read the Riot Act
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Corral an Expanding Tax
description: The alternative minimum tax, enacted 30 years ago to make sure that every rich person pays some income taxes, is increasingly a burden on the middle class. But fixing it is easy, according to a report by the staff of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation.

title: Considerations for Building a Concrete Slab
description: A CONCRETE slab rests on a sand base on the ground. It can be used as a patio or as an extension to the driveway -- a space to park your boat, say, or trailer. Because it rests on the ground and not on footings, it cannot be used as a floor for a building like a garage.

title: Slowly but Surely Charting the Waters
description: IT'S monotonous and repetitive, and the results are rarely dramatic. The captain describes it as ''mowing the lawn.'' But the work has its moments, and when it's done it will provide a clearer picture of the navigable waters surrounding Long Island.

title: Off the Newsletter Pages And Into the Marketplace
description: ''BUT can they invest in the real world?'' That is the question that uncharitable money managers use to dismiss successful investment newsletter editors. After all, it is one thing to beat the market on paper. It's quite another to do so when running a mutual fund.

title: Denver
description: World renowned for skiing, Colorado actually draws more tourists in the summer than in the winter. In the past, Denver was often only a pit stop on the family driving vacation. But today the city sparkles with world class attractions, meriting at least a weekend stopover before tackling the Rockies.

title: Nicole Cunitz and Andrew Laskin
description: Nicole Avi Cunitz, a daughter of Huguette and Jonathan A. Cunitz of Westport, Conn., is to be married today to Andrew Michael Laskin, a son of Joyce Beckenstein of Pompano Beach, Fla., and Dr. Richard S. Laskin of Manhattan. Rabbi Robert Orkand is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Celebrity Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprewell Must Go For a Point Guard
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: DINING OUT; Heading West and Up Instead of East
description: YOU are dining in the rustic Blane Room of the landmark Coach 'n' Paddock restaurant, tucked among the hills of Hunterdon County. Named for the former homestead's original owner, Dr. John O. Blane, the chamber -- one of eight dining areas of varying vintages (this one is circa 1685) -- emanates spirit with its thick stone walls, imposing fireplace and open-beam ceiling.

title: Nathalie James, Matthew Connelly
description: Nathalie James, the daughter of Marie-Helene James of Portsmouth, N.H., and the late Darwin Rush James 4th, was married yesterday to Matthew Connelly, a son of Maureen and Thomas J. Connelly of Brightwaters, N.Y. The Rev. William Saunders, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at Little Harbor Chapel in Portsmouth.

title: Fiona Brady and Carl Mehling
description: IF you were to stop Carl Martin Mehling in the street and ask him to empty his pockets, you probably wouldn't find just the usual apartment keys, credit cards and other detritus of modern city life.

title: Ideas & Trends; From M.D. to I.P.O., Chasing Virtual Fortunes
description: EVERY Tuesday and Thursday morning at 8, Dr. Domenica Vacca, an obstetrician-gynecologist who quit practicing medicine two years ago when her son was born, arrives for work at a white-shingled three-story building in rural Owings, Md. For the next eight hours, she sits in front of a computer terminal and holds private electronic conversations with people seeking her advice on everything from herpes to menopause.

title: When Artists and Writers Shared the Scene
description: WHEN did all the fun go out of the art scene? American art may be alive and kicking, but no one can pretend there's a scene surrounding it. We're in an age when artists, critics and curators conduct themselves like harried lawyers, socializing not in downtown dives but over midtown business lunches. They go to bed and wake up at normal hours. They have to get to work on time. They are professionals -- and, truth be told, they make me nostalgic for Frank O'Hara, the legendary poet who doubled as an art critic, a museum curator and an all-purpose symbol of bohemia's final moments in New York.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 4, 1999
description: Weeks

title: POSTINGS: 4 Warehouses Sold for $8.5 Million; Changes Due At 10th and 14th
description: In a move that could lead to further gentrification of Manhattan's Far West Side, a group of four turn-of-the century warehouse buildings on 10th Avenue near 14th Street have been sold. The three-story buildings, with a total space of approximately 75,000 square feet, were purchased for $8.5 million by William Gottlieb, an investor who has focused on Greenwich Village and areas to the west.

title: . . . Plus Book Clubs and Jazz; Book Club Members Read the Riot Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot July 4th. Our anniversary day... ''and the memories linger on.'' Joyce

title: At a Wedding, It's Still Not In to Be Out
description: SO it's 1999 and you're gay. So what? Your boss is gay. Ellen's gay. Will of ''Will and Grace'' is gay. Rupert Everett, who is gay and played a gay man in ''My Best Friend's Wedding,'' is now playing Mr. Right in ''An Ideal Husband.'' The media understand you. Your neighbors do, too. So do your parents. You're well integrated and well connected. In fact, without being boring, you're as self-actualized as any post-modern urban gay person can be.

title: Dangerous Eggs
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A New Ardsley Spot for Tastes of Thailand
description: THAI HOUSE is the newest restaurant to open in the tight cul-de-sac immediately north of the intersection of Ashford Avenue and Saw Mill River Road. It is easy to miss the stubby little dead-end street, and parking can be a trial. And once there, one can as easily overlook the entrance to this restaurant, sandwiched as it is among the storefronts of at least a half-dozen other eateries.

title: John Stears, 64, Dies; Film-Effects Wizard
description: John Stears, the father of James Bond's lethal Aston Martin, the Jedi Knights' light sabers, the endearing robots R2-D2 and C-3PO and a host of other ingenious movie gadgets and special effects, died on Monday at the UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 64.

title: . . . Plus Book Clubs and Jazz; The Jazz Scene Is Alive And Kicking, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Hershiser's Best Pitch Is His Brainball
description: UNTIL he joined the Mets this season, the lasting memory of Orel Hershiser in Shea Stadium was seeing him warm up in the Dodgers' bullpen as the fourth game of the 1988 National League Championship Series stretched past midnight into extra innings. With a record streak of 59 scoreless innings that season, he was baseball's best pitcher, but the Mets had a 2-1 series lead, winning both games that Hershiser had started.

title: Son Is Accused of Killing His Father And 2d Man in Their Hospital Room
description: A 49-year-old man calmly walked into a Brooklyn hospital yesterday with a knife and a hammer in a bag slung over his back, then killed his ailing father by slashing his throat, beat another patient to death with a hammer and seriously wounded his sister before he was subdued by security guards, law enforcement officials said.

title: Memorable Matinee
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Mother Love; Democrats Try Pitching to Maternal Instincts
description: AT a news conference recently in one of the Capitol's many gilded chambers, Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat, offered a myriad of reasons why a Democratic proposal to give patients new rights within their health insurance plans made sense. She spoke of longer hospital stays, greater access to specialists, better overall care.

title: Habitats /Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; A Co-op Owner Learns How to Be a Fixer-Upper
description: A LOT of New Yorkers have no idea what a boiler looks like, let alone how one works. That's the beauty of being an apartment dweller. Maintenance is someone else's problem.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Julius Erving's acknowledgment that he is the father of the tennis player Alexandra Stevenson misattributed a quotation. It was Alexandra, not her mother, Samantha, who described herself as ''the epitome of the American dream'' because she was brought up by a ''single parent, multicultural.''

title: Fuming Over Parking Lots
description: When it became clear this spring that the Korean American Presbyterian Church of Queens could evict Cheng's Oriental Express from the Bowne Street storefront the restaurant has occupied for nine years, Cheng's owner, Yat Kwai Cheng, asked his customers to sign a petition. He wanted the church to allow the restaurant to remain for at least a year, until it could move into a nearby storefront.

title: Which Way the Fed? Sorting Out the Signals on Interest Rates
description: THE Federal Reserve is not in the business of trying to confuse investors. With testimony, speeches and comments from its chairman, Alan Greenspan, and other Fed officials, the central bank's leadership has done its best to telegraph all its moves in recent years. That is why there was no surprise when the Fed announced on Wednesday that its short-term interest rate target was rising a quarter of a percentage point, to 5 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINERMAN, JAMES
description: DINERMAN-James On July 2, 1999. Beloved father of Alice Eve and Robert David. Treasured brother of the late Jean Berger, and the late Harold and Mortimer Dinerman. Devoted son of the late Alexander and Edna Dinerman. Cherished uncle of Ellen, Ruth and David Dinerman, and Joel and Nancy Berger, and favored brother-in-law of Miriam Dinerman. Revered longtime colleague of Marilyn Jann and Bill Levine. He was predeceased by his wife of 29 years, Helen Schneider Dinerman. Service Tuesday at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Contribtutions in his memory to Helen S. Dinerman Memorial Foundation, 136 E. 57 St., Rm. 505, NY NY 10022.

title: Flush Times and Hungry Republicans Generate Bush Campaign Windfall
description: Gov. George W. Bush's colossal $36.3 million campaign treasury was built on three pillars: a home-court advantage that allowed him to hit up Texas supporters, enthusiastic support from Republican governors, and the vast fund-raising network of his father, the former President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SAM
description: JACOBS-Sam On June 2nd, 1999. Beloved husband of Claire; devoted father of Robert and Alice Ullmann; grandfather of Katie. Our heartfelt sympathy to the family. The Lindemann Foundation

title: Parking Tickets Seizure Is Unacceptable
description: Nassau County Executive Gulotta recently proposed a law to seize the cars of parking ticket scofflaws with three or more tickets. This is a sad day for the residents of Nassau County and a desperate attempt by Mr. Gulotta to generate revenue for the county without raising taxes. The proposed law doesn't take into account the amount of money owed, only a ''three times you're out'' rule. This is morally unacceptable for a parking ticket. For example, a person who may receive three parking tickets in one week for reasons that may not even be the fault of the registrant or driver (i.e.: stolen car parked illegally and not found for a week or two, defective parking meters, missing parking signs, a health emergency that creates a hospital stay of a week or more, etc.) Citizens will be forced to hire a lawyer to fight for their rights over a parking ticket!

title: FILM; A Student of Young Love Turns to Middle Age
description: ''WHO told you I had sons?'' bellows Eric Rohmer, as he stiffens straight up behind his desk. ''I never talk about my private life. Never! No, no, no!''

title: A Market for Used Car Parts That Detroit Never Dreamed Of
description: IT would be hard to miss Jim Gary's modest house on a big corner lot here. It's the one with the 25-foot-tall purple dinosaur in the backyard, the 6-foot-long red and yellow ants near the front walk, and a pink, yellow and green pterodactyl holding the mailbox at the end of the driveway.

title: Muslim Officer Suspended Over Goatee
description: ALTHOUGH Christopher M. Letz has served six years with the New York State Park Police, he would be the first to concede that he hardly fits the central casting image of a uniformed officer.

title: County, Not Private Company, to Build Golf Course
description: WESTCHESTER is ready to build its sixth public golf course, described as a ''premier course,'' on 174 acres in New Castle, on the site of the defunct Hudson Hills Golf Course.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Oyster Bay, N.Y.; A Historic, Homey North Shore Hamlet
description: SOME of the finest homes in Oyster Bay were new or soon to be built when President Theodore Roosevelt was keeping summer hours nearly a century ago only miles from the homey downtown of this richly historic hamlet on Nassau County's North Shore.

title: Correction
description: A brief article last Sunday about the opening of Glatt Gourmet, a deli on East 86th Street, misstated the price of the sliced steak sandwich on garlic bread with fries. It is $12.95, not $11.95.

title: Corrections
description: A review on June 13 about ''Against the Tide: The Battle for America's Beaches,'' by Cornelia Dean, carried an erroneous price supplied by the publisher for the book. The price is $24.95, not $26.95.

title: Katherine Varker, Stephen Ibach
description: Katherine Anne Varker, the daughter of Dr. Carolyn B. Varker and Richard E. Varker of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Stephen Christopher Ibach, a son of Ann W. Ibach of Malvern, Pa., and the late Norbert K. Ibach. The Rev. Dr. Julia Ross Strope, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Merion Tribute House in Merion Station, Pa.

title: . . . Plus Book Clubs and Jazz; Costly Camping Equipment May Be Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; Juggling Jobs by Jet
description: For Roger Penske, there's the weekday job, as chief executive of the Penske Corporation, a truck-leasing, auto-retailing and engine-manufacturing company that operates around the world. And then there's the weekend job, as chairman of Penske Racing Inc., the most successful Indy car racing team in history, with 99 wins at tracks around the nation.

title: China and Norway Leap Into Spotlight
description: The goalkeeping of China's Gao Hong and the scoring prowess of Norway's Ann Kristin Aarones will be the key factors in Sunday's semifinal between the two powerhouses in women's soccer. The leaping ability of these two players, who were both doubtful to be in the tournament because of illness and injury, could determine the outcome.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Marjorie Gubelmann; All the Formalities
description: MARJORIE plays like a 30-year-old and entertains like a 50-year-old,'' said Earl Crittenden, a political writer and law student, who was awaiting his dessert at a dinner last Saturday night. Marjorie Gubelmann was the hostess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Perfecting The Esthetic Of the Past
description: GOING forward by looking back may be bad advice, but American Ballet Theater has danced better and better the more it has concentrated on the past -- a 19th-century repertory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel.
