Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: $140,000 -- and A Bargain
description: It is ironic that Miller chooses ''The Journal of Plankton Research'' as his example of ''dubious research.'' One does not have to be a biologist (and I am not) to know that plankton are the indispensible bottom link in the food chain, without which the food we eat and even the air we breathe would be in jeopardy. Now that environmental pollution threatens the health of plankton worldwide, it is not hard to see ''social value'' in plankton research.

title: June 27-July 3; Fewer Gay Men in New York Are Contracting AIDS
description: The largest survey of the sexual health of gay men in New York City has found a significant reduction in their levels of risky sexual behavior.

title: Corrections
description: The Word & Image column on June 13, about the corrupting influence of corporate wealth, misstated the amount of contributions made by hedge-fund companies to Republican candidates for Congress in 1996. It was $165,000, in individual checks of $5,000 each, and not 165 checks for $5,000.

title: Chelsea Morning, Noon and Night
description: FIGS +

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, EMANUEL
description: LAUB-Emanuel Dear husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Barry, Jeffrey, Robert and (Stephanie). Cherished grand father of Justin, Jodi, Jeremy and Jillian. Fond brother of Harold. Manny was a member of Local 338 RWDSU, AFL-CIO since 1948 and President since 1976. Services Sunday, 10 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Your Neighbor's Trees . . .; No Joyce Kilmer, Maybe, But No Scourge, Either
description: To the Editor:

title: Architect of His Own Undoing
description: THE LAST TREK -

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Alan McLean, A Psychiatrist And Writer, 73
description: Dr. Alan Angus McLean, a psychiatrist and an authority on mental health in the workplace, died Monday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 73 and lived in Westport, Conn., and Gig Harbor, Wash.

title: What's as American as a Sitcom? A Quiz
description: Situation comedies have been a staple of the American entertainment diet ever since Philo T. Farnsworth invented television in 1927. Following in the footsteps of Felix the Cat, the very first image ever broadcast, scores of sitcom characters have entered our homes. Some were quickly shown the door; others have become crazy old friends. How many do you remember?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LINDENBAUM, ABRAHAM M. (BUNNY)
description: LINDENBAUM-Abraham M. (Bunny) March 12, 1909-July 3, 1980 Lovingly remembered. Belle, Sandy, Linda, Erica, Laurie

title: All for Esoterica
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/The Rev. Anthony D. Sorgie; Sacred Music Helps Define Religious Life
description: WHILE other preschoolers were singing their ABC's, the Rev. Anthony D. Sorgie back in 1960 was singing Gregorian chants and some of the Roman Catholic Church's most sacred music. A few years later, in 1965, at 9, he was part of a choir that sang for Pope Paul VI at Yankee Stadium on his visit to the United States.

title: Just the 6 of Us: Models' Housing Isn't Pretty
description: TWO pretty, young women were lazing in their sparsely decorated living room, watching an ''X-Files'' video and contemplating the evening's options. Go to the club of the moment? A restaurant with an unlisted number? That new Stephen Dorff movie?

title: Strike's Hangover
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Teaching Johnny The Appropriate Way to Flirt
description: It is about time that the Supreme Court acknowledged sexual harassment as a problem in schools (Cynthia Gorney, June 13). Too bad that four of the justices still don't get it: ''An inescapable part of adolescence,'' one writes in his dissent to Aurelia Davis v. Monroe County Board of Education, describing a child's repeated vulgar advances toward a classmate. The ''boys will be boys'' excuse has got to go.

title: Port Authority Announces Expansion for Newark Airport
description: Continental Airlines and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will undertake a $1.37 billion expansion of Newark International Airport to accommodate 5.5 million more passengers a year by 2004.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Supreme Court term that ended in June characterized one Court opinion incorrectly. In a case involving the Federal Communications Commission, AT&T Corp. v. Iowa Utilities Board, the Court upheld the F.C.C.'s authority to supervise telephone deregulation under a 1996 Federal law. It limited the agency's authority in some other respects.

title: When Life Was Simple, and So Was TV
description: Once upon a time in America, there was a magical place called Hooterville. It was a community where the three most attractive women were free to swim naked each week in the local water tower, the highest I.Q. belonged to a pig and it wasn't considered embarrassing to grow up with the first name Eb.

title: Pops and Classics Out of Doors
description: THE Levitt Pavilion in Westport has begun its 26th summer of open-air concerts on the banks of the Saugatuck River. There will be a ticketed benefit performance on July 23 with Willie Nelson; otherwise, all events are free at 8 P.M. daily except Mondays, the Pavilion's nights off, and Wednesdays, when the family shows begin at 7.

title: Laura Albritton and Eric Sevos
description: Laura Elizabeth Albritton and Eric Pascal Sevos were married yesterday morning by Mayor Francois Cavallier of Callian, France, in the City Hall there. A Roman Catholic ceremony followed yesterday afternoon at the Church of Our Lady of the Assumption in Callian, at which the Rev. Jean-Claude Castello officiated.

title: June 27-July 3; An Official Welcome Back For the Resurgent Bald Eagle
description: The bald eagle, the symbol of American freedom, was officially removed from the list of animals threatened with extinction. At a White House ceremony, President Clinton credited efforts under the Endangered Species Act for the bird's return.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a meeting between Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and a group of Congressional Republicans misidentified one person present. He was Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, not a security guard.

title: In New York Race For Senate, Pacing Takes Prominence
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton shows up at Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's upstate New York farm on Wednesday, offering herself as his potential successor after his retirement next year, it will be a full 489 days until the election. Nevertheless, as of yesterday, nearly 200 reporters and other media representatives from around the world had signed up to record the event, and then to chase the First Lady across central New York for four days of ''listening to New Yorkers.''

title: Ruling Challenged
description: One of the families that successfully sued the Bedford public schools for promoting pagan religious practices did not live in the town at the time of the trial, making at least some of the findings by Judge Charles L. Brieant 3d in Federal District Court in White Plains last month moot, said Neil M. Block, a lawyer for the school district.

title: Ideas & Trends: Turks and Kurds; A Corner of the World That Peace Forgot
description: TO outsiders, the solution to Turkey's long conflict with Kurdish insurgents may seem easy and obvious. Over the last few weeks, the rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan has made it as clear as the air that envelops the rugged mountains in the war zone. Let us Kurds use our language freely, let us have a television station, and acknowledge our ethnic identity, he said at his recently concluded treason trial. Then we will stop waging a war that has cost Turkey more than $100 billion and the lives of more than 30,000 people over 15 years, in the process tearing the country apart and blackening its name abroad.

title: Manager Resists Trip to Cleaner's
description: Many a necktie has succumbed to a spill from a shaky-handed waiter, and there is nothing unusual about a customer writing to seek reimbursement from the restaurant for cleaning or replacing the garment.

title: Conflicts at Home Mine the Road to Independence
description: Lashanda Washington was a street-smart, fight-hardened girl of 16, riding a city bus home from school, when she saw the face that she had been dreaming about for years.

title: The World; Bombs Are Smart. People Are Smarter.
description: TOWARD the end of the Balkans air war, rarely a day passed when NATO did not triumphantly declare that allied warplanes had destroyed several more Yugoslav tanks or artillery pieces with precision-guided bombs or missiles.

title: When a Magnate Tried to Play Movie Censor
description: WHEN Orson Welles made his masterpiece ''Citizen Kane'' in 1941, it was no secret that the film's protagonist, Charles Foster Kane, was a barely fictionalized version of William Randolph Hearst, the newspaper magnate whose enormous empire was then beginning to falter under a barrage of debts. But there was a drama behind the drama, as Welles -- then just 25 and swelled by the arrogance of youth and genius -- found himself up against the full force of Hearst's fury. Hearst was desperate to stop the film, no matter what the cost, and nearly succeeded in having it destroyed before it had ever been released.

title: Former Coach Shot to Death Near Chicago; Others Injured
description: A white gunman cruised the streets of Chicago and its northern suburbs on Friday evening, shooting from a car at a dozen people, all of them black, Jewish or Asian. An African-American man, a former basketball coach at Northwestern University, was killed, and six Orthodox Jews walking home from Sabbath prayers were injured.

title: Spigot of Pleasure From New Zealand
description: No matter how often you pour it, Stoneleigh Vineyard's 1998 sauvignon blanc is a spigot of pleasure, like the nymphs on Roman fountains.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, ISABEL W.
description: ROSENBERG-Isabel W. Isabel dearest

title: Agent Maligned
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BENJAMIN'S GIFT By Michael Golding. Warner, $22.

title: Science Fiction
description: END OF DAYS (Eos/Avon, $16), by Dennis Danvers, is a worthy sequel to last year's ''Circuit of Heaven,'' an exuberant cyberspace romance that read like ''Romeo and Juliet'' with a happy ending. This time Danvers offers not one but two pairs of star-crossed lovers. Yet the focus has subtly shifted. While love is still the answer, what is being questioned now is the nature of life in the Bin, a virtual-reality paradise filled with downloaded souls who have forsaken their bodies for a hassle-free existence in a vast computer orbiting Earth.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-4-99: On Language; Stump Words
description: When in California, you'll want to go to SoMa. Down in Florida, don't miss SoBe. And in Connecticut, the place to go is SoNo.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLAN, MARK J.
description: CAPLAN-Mark J. Miss you, forever in our hearts and minds. Mom, Dad and Ron

title: Word for Word/The Nuremberg Laws; On Display in Los Angeles: Legal Foreshadowing of Nazi Horror
description: THE 1935 Nuremberg Laws of Hitler's Germany surely rank among the most chilling documents of the 20th century: By legally excluding Jews from German life, they helped set the Holocaust in motion. But until the opening last week of an exhibit in Los Angeles, none of the originals signed in Hitler's hand had ever been publicly displayed.

title: A Hidden 'Little Farm' at the Landfill: 72 Marijuana Plants
description: The police thwarted an illicit act of agriculture on Monday when members of the Staten Island Narcotics Unit uprooted 72 fledgling marijuana plants in a remote corner of the Fresh Kills landfill.

title: Backtalk; Athletes on the Track Must Prove Their Pain
description: Last week's national track and field championships were held in Eugene, Ore., known as Track Town, U.S.A., for the way the city embraces the sport. And the talk of the town was an athlete who did not compete: Michael Johnson.

title: A New Focus for Mussorgsky With 'Boris' as Lens
description: THE most famous image of Modest Mussorgsky -- and one of the most gripping of all 19th-century Russian paintings -- is Ilya Repin's portrait of 1881: with its red nose, swollen eyes and sweaty, unkempt hair, the countenance of dissolute genius.

title: Tax Arrest Shakes Agency
description: A FORMER state tax agent was arrested late last month on charges that after auditing one of the largest department store chains in the state and hitting them with a more than $50,000 penalty, he privately offered his services to the company to get the tax bill reduced for a fee, a case that has shaken the Department of Revenue Services.

title: Moving On After Vote In Pleasantville
description: Now that the majority of a divided Pleasantville has spoken [''Westchester Takes Second Place in School Budget Rejections,'' June 27] it is time to begin the healing process, a time to seek taxpayer support and a time for joint solutions. I hope the Superintendent and the Board of Education will rise to the challenge of bringing the community together, to accept the responsibility of providing alternatives and make a commitment to involve in discussion supporters from both sides of the June 15 referendum, which was defeated.

title: 30 Hours of Nonstop Opera, and It's Free
description: THE singers are polishing their horned helmets, stockpiling throat lozenges and boning up on every aria in their repertory. A bit of midsummer madness will envelop northern Westchester next weekend, when more than 100 opera singers descend on Jefferson Valley for 30 straight hours of opera.

title: Q. & A.
description: A Tenant's Storage Space

title: Lisa Kemp and Douglas Perlman
description: Carol Elizabeth Kemp, a daughter of Rowena C. Kemp of Virginia Beach, Va., and Peter A. Kemp of Dallas, is to be married this afternoon to Douglas Louis Perlman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerold M. Perlman of Westport, Conn. Judge Alan H. Nevas of Federal District Court in Bridgeport, Conn., will officiate at the Inn at Longshore in Westport.

title: Newark Hails Baseball's Return, but the High Cost of a New Stadium Raises Doubts
description: Groundskeepers painstakingly leveled the clay-orange dirt around home plate this week, and masons grouted between the earth-hued blocks at the entrance to the new Riverfront Park stadium, which is bringing minor league baseball to New Jersey's largest city for the first time in 50 years.

title: MUSIC; Inching Closer To the Impact Of Rachmaninoff
description: CRITICS tend to be suspicious of piano rolls. And no wonder, given the technical hanky-panky that went into the process of creating them.

title: When Hope Springs Eternal, Ask Why
description: THINGS have been a bit dismal of late at the Iomega Corporation, the maker of Zip, Jaz and other data storage units and computer disk drives. The stock of Iomega, a full-fledged member of the former highflier club, traded at $27 three years ago. On Friday, it closed at $4.6875, down 36 percent for the year.

title: $140,000 -- and A Bargain
description: Your writer argues that 80 percent of basic research is ''idle, tenure-earning junk with little or no social value.'' Ouch!

title: A Church Responds, and a Treasure Is Saved
description: AT about the time the the Civil War began, one of the architects who was helping to design Central Park in Manhattan was hired to create a home for Francis Tomes, a hardware importer, just across the way from the old Knapp Tavern in Greenwich.

title: A Report That North Korea Has Plans to Test-Launch a Missile
description: North Korea has confirmed that it is prepared to test a missile, a prominent Japanese visitor to the country said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Nassau Bonds Take a Ratings Dive
description: Warned repeatedly by credit rating agencies that its dependence on one-shot revenues and its $300 million budget deficit were matters of deep concern, Nassau County finally paid the price last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: On Fraud, Front Line Is The Board
description: FIVE years ago, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, stunned the New York City real estate industry when he charged 80 managing agents and four management companies with taking millions of dollars in kickbacks from scores of vendors over seven years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNICK, MARY ANN
description: RENNICK-Mary Ann The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Mary Ann Rennick, associated with The Times from 1979 until retiring in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOSEVELT, ROBIN A.
description: ROOSEVELT-Robin A. Age 45, of Saylorsburg, PA, formerly of NYC. Died Friday at home. Survived by two brothers, Nicholas and George, and a stepsister, Fay Fisher. He had been an Information Officer, Palestine Programs for the UN. Funeral services to be announced later. For information, Gower Funeral Home, Gilbert, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, MAURICE, M.D.
description: GRUBER-Maurice, M.D., age 93, on June 29, 1999, just two months after his wife, Ethel, passed away. Father of Vera and George. Grandfather of Julie and Jessica. Devoted his life to the practice of medicine in Boro Park, Brooklyn, for nearly fifty years.

title: New Orleans, a City of Serious Eaters
description: TO assert that New Orleans is serious about its restaurants is like saying that mountains are high and water is wet: It's a natural fact. Offer even a tentative opinion about a particular restaurant to a resident of this food-crazed city and chances are the response will include not only a detailed history of that establishment and its food, but a list of a half-dozen other places that are better, and subtle suggestions about why partisans of the restaurant in question are so misinformed.

title: Marking Connecticut's Yankees On the Battlefield of Gettysburg
description: AS the sun set 136 years ago today, the Confederate Army began a retreat from Gettysburg, the bloodiest battle of the Civil War. Now a 4,000-acre National Park, the site is dotted with 1,500 monuments to the three days of battle. Eleven of those commemorate Connecticut units: one artillery battalion and five infantry regiments. Of their 1,285 men, 369 were casualties, including 75 who died.

title: TENNIS: Three Americans Play Lead Roles in Wimbledon's Final Acts; Sampras-Agassi Offers Glamour
description: Two men on a history-seeking mission today chose Wimbledon as the storybook stage to rekindle a riveting rivalry that had been in remission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE DEVENOGE)
description: BULL-Josephine M. (nee deVenoge), of Glen Rock, NJ, formerly of Richmond Hill, NY, died June 8, 1999. She was 86. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of JoAnn Masterson of Washington Crossing, PA, and Marilyn Nagle of Glen Rock, NJ. Devoted sister of Harry deVenoge of New Smyrna Beach, FL. Adoring grandmother of James P. and Bill Masterson, Patrick and Walter Nagle. Cherished by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow in Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. Visitation 7-9 p.m. Thursday, and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Friday at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. For more information, call 201-444-7650. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: For Miles of Waterfront, Dozens of Plans; Visions of Providing Recreation and Protecting Maritime Heritage, While Balancing Development and the Environment
description: IN 1962, Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring'' was published and the environmental movement was born. In 1968, Paul Ehrlich wrote ''The Population Bomb,'' putting forth the concept that, when it comes to population growth, less is more.

title: Constance Shacklock, 86, Mezzo-Soprano
description: Constance Shacklock, an English mezzo-soprano who made more than 500 appearances at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden between 1946 and 1956, and then undertook a second stage career in musical theater, died on Tuesday. She was 86.

title: Fry Sage Leaves or Add Mint for Salads Beyond the Ordinary
description: IN ''The Book of Household Management'' (1861), the author, Mrs. Beeton, gives a list of essential items for a picnic. They include ''a stick of horseradish, a bottle of mint sauce well corked, a bottle of salad dressing, a bottle of vinegar, made mustard, pepper, salt, good oil and pounded sugar. If it can be managed, take a little ice. It is scarcely necessary to say that plates, tumblers, wine glasses, knives, forks and spoons must not be forgotten; as also teacups and saucers, three or four teapots, some lump sugar and milk, if this last named item cannot be obtained in the neighborhood. Take three corkscrews.''

title: In Glen Cove, Matriarch of a Political Family
description: MARGUERITE HOLMES SUOZZI is not used to talking about herself. But in Glen Cove, a city where the name Suozzi has a Kennedyesque aura, Mrs. Suozzi is the quiet matriarch, the Rose Kennedy of a political dynasty with a small-town cachet. For 48 years, she has presided over a dinner table where the talk is invariably local politics. Most of the time, she's the one doing the listening.

title: Why Should New York Have to Dial 646?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Second Opinions; The Hard Lessons Of Health Reform
description: MIDWAY through announcing his proposal to revamp Medicare last week, President Clinton seemed to notice that there were ghosts in the room.

title: Gate-Crashers Lurking in the Mulch: Weeds
description: SOMETIMES they are called the uninviteds. Plants that just usurp growing space without the least concern for any sense of design or pleasure.

title: High-Tech Meets Low-Tech in Two New Coasters
description: The retro look has hit the world of roller coasters in a big way. Two monster-sized coasters, each built of old-fashioned wood but designed using the latest in computer technology, have recently opened in California and Florida.

title: Summer Is Here, But Where Are The Lifeguards?; To Fill the Chairs, State Learns to Be Inventive
description: WITH only about 100 people on the beach and the water temperature a frigid 58 degrees last month, Rob O'Brien, a lifeguard at East Beach at Cove Island Park in Stamford, did not have to worry about anyone venturing out too far.

title: Star-Spangled Banner Gets Cleaned (in Public)
description: The Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History has begun the painstaking process of conserving the Star-Spangled Banner, and it is doing it in full view of the public, behind a glass wall.

title: After a Dark Year, the Asian Sky Is Filled With Fireworks
description: WHAT a difference a year makes. Last Fourth of July weekend, American investors were basking in the glory of 22.9 percent and 30.4 percent gains in their domestic and European stock funds, respectively, over the previous 12 months. But Asia funds were down more than 52 percent.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Decrepitudes
description: SUGAR AND RUM

title: An Idea of Home
description: The Way People Run

title: Nike Boycott
description: Even as classes drew to a close last month at the Crittenden Middle School in the Byram Hills School District, students in Mary T. Staudt's sixth-grade language arts classes persisted in their efforts to let Nike, the Oregon footwear company, know that they disapproved of some of their procedures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: June 27-July 3; Clinton Eases Restrictions On Computer Exports
description: A month ago it seemed as if reports of Chinese spies and technology leaks would result in a crackdown on high-technology exports to China. Wrong. Under pressure from Silicon Valley, President Clinton announced that he would make it far easier to ship high-performance personal computers and microprocessors to China, Russia and other nations. In an era when supercomputer speeds can be reached on a $2,000 laptop, the President concluded, it makes sense to control only the most rarified technology. The Republicans, including George W. Bush Jr., seemed to agree. The Silicon Valley, by the way, is a wellspring of campaign money. DAVID E. SANGER

title: Competing or Not, Here They Come: Freeport and Glen Cove's Bashes
description: The similarities between the village of Freeport and the city of Glen Cove are hard to miss.

title: Atlantic City Basketball Team Wins Championship, Then Folds
description: Moments after the victorious Atlantic City Seagulls basketball team celebrated their championship season Wednesday with a Boardwalk parade, its owner confirmed that the team would not return next year.

title: Editorial Observer; What Is This, the Tammy Wynette Strategy?
description: ''I made the major pitch, but Mrs. Clinton chimed in.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-4-99: Urban Diarist; Tanning and Authenticity
description: Monday: Leaving for a beach vacation next week. Thinking about tanning and authenticity.

title: Lynette Galante And Alex Ross
description: Lynette Marie Galante, the daughter of Regina Carey of Holbrook, N.Y., and Joe Galante of Nashville, was married yesterday to Alex Kendall Ross, a son of Barbara and Michael Ross of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Howard Cohen officiated at the Miller Place Inn in Miller Place, N.Y. Msgr. James Lisante took part in the ceremony.

title: Company Ties Its Future to Floating Docks
description: THIS is high season for Bo Bohmert, who owns Bohmert Brothers Marine Services in Mamaroneck.

title: A Lawyer Opponents Can Like
description: MAYBE Lewis Carroll's Red Queen was right: Sometimes it really does take all the running you can do to keep in the same place.

title: POSTINGS: In Times Square, a New Landmark: I. Miller Building, With 4 Calder Sculptures; There's No Business Like Shoe Business
description: On Broadway's newest landmark are four delightful sculptures by Alexander Calder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: $140,000 -- and A Bargain
description: So if I'm understanding Matthew Miller correctly (June 13), universities might try getting rid of professors, unpopular fields of study and libraries in order to cut costs. That way, all the ''little Rockefellers'' can hear their star professor live, while the rest of us can ''choose'' to pay smaller sums to attend Cyber U. via the Internet. It might go something like this: Click on 1 for a question about the course as a whole. Click on 2 for a question about supply and demand.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-4-99: The Ethicist; Eyewitness Blues
description: At the supermarket, a charming woman in her 70's paid the checker, then popped a box of cereal, which had not been scanned, into her bag. A cheery 'goodbye' and off she went. I wanted to ask, 'Did you forget to pay for that?' but I couldn't. What was my responsibility?

title: New York Yacht Club Puts Boston on Itinerary
description: It sounds like that Yankee-Red Sox thing again. But this is about boats, not bats and balls. For the first time in more than a century, the New York Yacht Club has included Boston as a port of call during its annual cruise. The visit isn't going to fill a grandstand with fans. But it is apt to elicit some of that Fenway kind of pride.

title: Sapphire Handles The Heat In Prioress
description: Jerry Bailey got stepped on by a horse and missed his chance to ride in two stakes races at Belmont Park yesterday. But the star jockey, who had a bruised left leg, had less grief than the undefeated filly Gather the Day, who was bumped at the start of the Prioress and finished fifth, ending her four-race winning streak.

title: Ferry Tales Can Come True
description: As boarding time approached for the 2 P.M. ferry to Staten Island, a throng of camera-girded tourists fired questions at Monica Paquette at the information kiosk at Whitehall Terminal. Germans, Egyptians, Swedes and Brooklynites wanted subway, bus, train and Statue of Liberty information. Ms. Paquette quieted them by putting her hand up like a traffic cop. She crisply dealt with each request. Everyone made the boat.

title: Water Polo
description: In this game, summer's best T-shirts float to the top.

title: Band of Angels
description: To the Editor:

title: Filling a Skill Shortage, Close to Home
description: WHEN Dan Lopez was a freshman at Oak Grove High School in San Jose, Calif., a teacher asked his class if anyone was interested in being the first to try a new program that would prepare students for careers in the travel and tourism industry.

title: Regina Narkiewicz, Todd Stump
description: Regina Sophia Narkiewicz and Todd Allen Stump were married yesterday at Club Med Columbus Isle on San Salvador, the Bahamas. Roderick A. Turnquest, the Administrator of San Salvador, officiated.

title: Peculiar in Providence
description: Consider a television show called ''Hartford''? What would it be about -- an actuary? ''Providence,'' however, is a hit about a plastic surgeon (Melina Kanakaredes) who moves back to her dysfunctional family in the title city, which in the opening shot looks like Monte Carlo with chowder. ''Family Guy'' is a new animated Fox series about a dysfunctional Rhode Island family. ''Outside Providence,'' a film about a dysfunctional prep school student, will open in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: June 27-July 3; A Long-Ago Slight And a Murdered Child
description: It's a staggeringly upside-down tale. By all accounts, Ronald L. Shanabarger of Franklin, Ind., married in anger, conceived a child in anger and looked on in anger as his son was born. As quick-flaring angers go, his was ancient: before he married, his wife-to-be had refused to cut short her vacation cruise when his father died, and he silently vowed revenge.

title: June 27-July 3; Hubbell Pleads Guilty
description: Webster L. Hubbell walked out of a Federal courthouse last week with a remarkably good deal; he pleaded guilty to a felony count of lying to regulators and a misdemeanor count of failure to pay taxes, and avoided jail time even though he has already served time for a felony.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: CABINS ON SALE -- Holland America is discounting three new cruises on the Maasdam and one on the Rotterdam this summer and fall. The Maasdam's seven-day sailing from London to Boston, departing Aug. 29, with the Harry James Orchestra on board, ranges from $799 a person, double occupancy, for an inside stateroom to $1,699 for a veranda suite; its seven-day cruise from Boston to Montreal, departing Sept. 5, costs $999 to $1,999, while a seven-day Eastern Caribbean cruise departing Nov. 22 from Ft. Lauderdale is $799 to $1,699. On the Rotterdam, an eight-day cruise from Venice to Rome departing Nov. 9 ranges from $999 to $1,999. Air fare is extra. Information: (877) 724-5425.

title: Suspect Sought In Attacks Said To Kill Himself
description: The man suspected in a two-state shooting rampage against Jews, blacks and Asian-Americans fatally shot himself on Sunday night after police pursued him in rural southern Illinois, an F.B.I. spokesman in Salem, Ill., said today.

title: Stresses of Milosevic's Rule Blamed for Decline in Births
description: Before Serbia went to war with the West, Vesna Markovic wanted three children. Since the Kosovo conflict, she has often been sorry that she has one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEDRO, GEORGIE V.
description: PEDRO-Georgie V. Passed in her 95th year, of natural causes, on July 2, 1999. Beloved wife of George, loving mother or Laura and Donald. Adoring grandmother of Kevin, Marla, Paul, Laura, Donna, Donald, Bruce and Patty. Adored great-grandmother of Stephen, Elisabeth, Lindsay and Laura. We forever love and forever remember. Till we meet again. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, 2 PM, Tuesday, July 6.

title: Media Talk; City's Mystique Seduces a Publisher Again
description: The Southern charm of Savannah, Ga., -- a crucial character in the best seller ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil'' -- has seduced a New York publisher once again. St. Martin's Press is paying a six-figure advance for a previously published first novel set in the balmy coastal city by a native son who tirelessly promoted his work with Rotary Club appearances and articles in ''Podiatry Today.''

title: An Alarming Prosecution in Iran
description: President Mohammad Khatami hopes to strengthen the rule of law in Iran and repair ties with the West. But his efforts are threatened by the dubious espionage charges that clerical prosecutors brought against 13 Iranian Jews. Mr. Khatami, who has been trying to limit his conflicts with conservative clerics before an important parliamentary election, has been cautious in speaking out on this case. But this is a case he cannot condone if he wishes to improve ties with the West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Captured in Stories, The World He Left; For Author's Debut, Tales of Orthodox Jews
description: Stalin has issued the order to arrest and execute the most prominent Jewish writers in the Soviet Union. Through a clerical error, one of the 27 men arrested is an unknown, unpublished writer named Pinchas Pelovits. In the tragicomic fable ''The 27th Man,'' the forlorn Pinchas -- a Zelig among the immortals -- writes a story that the other captives applaud. Facing death, he finally finds an audience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKELHAMMER, PHYLLIS
description: BERKELHAMMER-Phyllis. On July 3, 1999. Beloved mother of Wendy Grammas. She will be deeply missed. Services Tuesday 9 AM, at Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich, CT.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 18 about a debate in Kuwait over women's right to vote reversed the relationships of two Kuwaiti officials to Sheik Ahmed al-Jaber al-Sabah, the Emir. The Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah, is the Emir's cousin. The Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Jaber al-Sabah, is the Emir's brother.

title: Who's Getting the Goods on Us?; Regulating Investigators
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Lose Seventh in Eight Games
description: FOXBORO, Mass., July 4 -- Another game without any foreign aid and another loss for the MetroStars today, this time by 3-2 to the New England Revolution at Foxboro Stadium. It was three defensive lapses by the MetroStars that led to the goals, including two by Joe-Max Moore.

title: Park Custodians in Bronx Save Boy, 13, From Drowning
description: Yesterday started out like any other Fourth of July for Gary Cullen, a 23-year veteran of New York City's Parks Department who is a senior maintenance supervisor at Orchard Beach in the Bronx.

title: Overshadowed Texas Sextuplets Are Receiving Belated Help
description: For the parents of the world's first surviving octuplets, born here in December, the birth was followed by a wealth of gifts, including a 5,300-square-foot home, a tractor trailer loaded with baby furniture and a lifetime supply of diapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, L. DENVER
description: HART-L. Denver. It is with deep sadness that we announce the death of the Reverend L. Denver Hart, Senior Associate Rector of St. Bartholomew's Church and devoted friend and colleague, on June 30th, 1999. He is survived by his partner, Bruce Webber, of New York; his mother, Jane Hart, of Zelienople, PA; and his brother, James Hart, of Palmyra, PA. Vigil prayers and visitation, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Monday, July 5, 6-8PM. Burial Service and Requiem at St. Bartholomew's, Tuesday, July 6 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the L. Denver Hart Memorial Fund, C/O St. Bartholomew's, 109 East 50th Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Gilman Kraft, 73, Performing Arts Publisher
description: Gilman Kraft, the owner of Playbill magazine in the 1960's and more recently the owner and president of Performing Arts magazine in California, died on June 27 at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 73 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, ELLEN
description: GERSON-Ellen. Dear daughter of Beatrice G. Nelkin and the late Louis Gerson. Former librarian at the Haskell Library of the Blind, passed away on Friday, July 2, 1999. Devoted cousin and neice, caring friend to many. She will be missed by all. Services at the United Hebrew Community of New York, 201 E. Broadway, 12 noon, Tuesday, July 6th.

title: Key Foe, Back From Exile, Dares Milosevic to Jail Him
description: A key figure in the Serbian opposition movement who fled during the war with NATO returned this evening and dared President Slobodan Milosevic to arrest him.

title: All-Star? Jeter Stats Are All-World
description: If Derek Jeter is elected as the starting American League shortstop for next week's All-Star Game, as expected -- the results of the balloting will be announced today -- it will come in the middle of what could turn out to be one of the greatest performances by any Yankee player ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Talk of a Still Higher Bid for British Pubs
description: Punch Taverns Group Ltd. said over the weekend that it was prepared to increase its $:2.85 billion ($4.5 billion) cash offer for the British pubs of Allied Domecq P.L.C. after a rival bidder, Whitbread P.L.C., sweetened its own proposal on Friday.

title: Nation's Economic Boom A Faint Echo in Appalachia
description: ''The economic boom?'' asked Donna McDonald at her roadside flea market rack of used clothes -- humbly frayed offerings that she has been buying more than selling lately as local customers survive until their welfare checks next week.

title: Correcting the Count, at 88
description: One of the world's richest men said in his memoirs, ''I always say I wouldn't mind going to jail if I had three cellmates who played bridge.'' That was Warren E. Buffett, chairman of the holding company Berkshire Hathaway, and to make confinement more tolerable he should perhaps have appended the word well. He has that consideration in mind when he arranges a bridge game after the annual meeting of his company in Omaha, and in 1995 it included Bob Hamman, the world's top-ranked player, and Sharon Osberg, winner of two world titles.

title: Clemens Loses Zip and the Yanks Get Zapped
description: Scientists have documented global warming in this century, but nobody needed to tell the Texan Roger Clemens that it was panhandle hot at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Clemens returned to the Yankees' dugout after pitching another inning in the thick heat and said drolly, ''I think they just dumped a pail of water on the rocks.''

title: Foul Enough To Be Funny
description: If you're reading this matchbook cover, you might just be funny enough for a career in the glamorous world of Hollywood screenwriting! Are you interested in making hundreds of thousands of dollars for just a few days' work with a pencil? In canoodling with celebrities? In traveling to foreign film festivals?

title: No Moves Are Smooth For Mets and Bonilla
description: Even when he is not playing, controversy seems to follow Bobby Bonilla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Staten Island Prosecutor Faces Lawyer in Bid for Re-election
description: Four years ago, the Staten Island District Attorney, William L. Murphy, a Democrat, pulled off something of a political achievement by withstanding a formidable challenge from the Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, the island's best known Republican official.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: The Past Is Prologue for Armstrong
description: Two days into the 86th Tour de France, the jury is still out on whether the race has kept its popularity with a public weary of doping scandals. But there was no doubt today that Lance Armstrong's victory in the opening prologue on Saturday, after his battle with cancer, was exactly the symbol the race organizers had wished for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICH, SPO
description: OESTREICH-Spo. In her 93rd year, passed away of natural causes Thursday night at her home in New York City. The widow of Charles H. Oestreich, she was also the cherished mother of David Oestreich, Joan Kend and the late Richard Oestreich, the adored grandmother of Debra Rubin, Elizabeth Fein and Caren Cohen, and the devoted great-grandmother of Henry, Charles, Catherine, William and Abigail. A graduate of Hunter College, a poet and an art collector, she was a brave and beautiful lady who will live in the hearts of her loving friends and family forever. May God grant her sweet repose.

title: 'South Park' Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: As Neighbors Sit Outside, Woman Is Killed by Gunfire
description: A 27-year-old woman was killed early yesterday when a bullet hit her in the head as she sat chatting with a neighbor on the stairs outside her Brooklyn home, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, MARY ELLEN
description: CLARK-Mary Ellen, 72. Died on April 6, 1999. Beloved sister of Frank, William and Helen Clark Thiemann. Longtime New York City resident. Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Who's Getting the Goods on Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: CUNY's Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Tarloff, Screenwriter, 83
description: Frank Tarloff, an Academy Award-winning screenwriter who was blacklisted during the McCarthy era, died on June 25 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

title: This Time, a Trio Shows What Strings Can Do
description: The string quartet repertory is the most extensive and richest in all of chamber music. So it's not surprising that legions of successful string quartet ensembles have appeared over time to play it. This is not true of string trios (violin, viola and cello). Without the extra violin a string quartet provides, most composers have found it harder to divvy up a piece's musical elements in effective ways. The repertory, though distinguished, is smaller. And there have been few permanent, let alone prominent, string trio ensembles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INTOCI, EMANUEL
description: INTOCI-Emanuel. Oskar Kalb Memorial Foundation is deeply saddened by the loss of one of their founding members and past President. His deep commitment to the very young contributed to the growth and success of this organization dedicated to the well-being of children throughout the world. Roland J. Kalb, Chairman Debbie Frascone, President

title: U.S. and Scurry Beat Brazil at Its Own Game
description: They had played two games in four days, connected by a coast-to-coast flight. And when today's Women's World Cup semifinal ended, the exhausted American players were left sprawling in the locker room, backs aching, happy for the 2-0 victory over Brazil, even happier for five days to recover for the championship game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, EDITH
description: POSNER-Edith. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Service 11 AM, Monday, at Kol Ami Chapel. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Mark A. Hershey, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Trader Who Broke Barings Is Back in Britain From Asian Jail
description: Nicholas W. Leeson set foot on British soil today for the first time since his wild trades on Asian futures markets in 1995 ran up debts of $1.4 billion, which brought down Britain's oldest merchant bank and landed him in a Singapore jail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Federal Seers, Telling Nation's Fiscal Fortune
description: Kathy Gramp peered beneath the stacks of paper on her desk and poked through the drawers, an expression of bafflement on her face. Her calculator was at large.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Tuesday about ''A Hot Dog Program,'' broadcast on Wednesday on PBS, misstated the location of the Cozy Drive-In, a hot-dog restaurant featured in the program. It is in Springfield, Ill., not Springfield, Ohio.

title: Syrian President Due in Russia Today as Mideast Diplomacy Starts to Revive
description: A surprise trip to Russia by the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, is looming as the first step in an expected flurry of Middle East diplomacy as Arab and Israeli leaders jockey for position in a peace effort that is suddenly showing signs of life for the first time in three years.

title: Essay; Independents' Day
description: Ready for a little political mischief on a holiday weekend? Let us consider what could upset the seemingly preordained Bush and Gore nominations.

title: How to Control Medicare Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAKINSKI, RUTH
description: TRAKINSKI-Ruth. Beloved wife of Simon. Devoted mother of Esther, Amy and Vivian. Service Monday, 11:30 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about new digital film projectors misidentified the man demonstrating one. He was Richard Sutton, a technician for Hughes-JVC, not Kevin Romano. A related caption misspelled the surname name of a film projectionist in some copies. He was Peter Melnyk, not Melnyck.

title: Piraeus Bank Bids $5.2 Billion To Acquire Ergo, a Greek Rival
description: Piraeus Bank S.A. has agreed to buy Ergo Bank S.A. for 1.65 trillion drachmas, or $5.2 billion, in cash and stock. The deal would create Greece's third-largest bank in assets and thwart a 426 billion drachma hostile bid by EFG Bank European Financial Group, which has its headquarters in Geneva.

title: TENNIS: Sampras Scales the Summit as Davenport Dismisses a Legend; Graf Gamely Bids Wimbledon Adieu
description: Determined to make peace with Wimbledon's grass courts, which had never before been kind to her, Lindsay Davenport conducted her own cram course last month in the privacy of a friend's backyard court in Tustin, Calif.

title: Isle w/ History, Harbor Vus
description: During a helicopter ride with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan on Oct. 22, 1995, President Clinton offered to sell Governors Island to New York City for $1. More than three years after the President's generous offer, the city still lacks the kind of credible, comprehensive proposal for the 172-acre island's redevelopment that Congress and the White House will need before they can approve any deal.

title: U.S.  IS  EXPECTING KASHMIR PULLBACK BY PAKISTANI SIDE
description: After three hours of hastily arranged meetings here between President Clinton and the Pakistani Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, Administration officials said today that they expected that Pakistani-backed forces would soon withdraw from their mountain redoubt on the Indian side of the cease-fire line in Kashmir.

title: Silicon Valley Doesn't Need a Reality Check
description: People seem to think that we here in Silicon Valley live in some sort of reality-distortion field just because houses have been known to sell for $1 million more than the asking price. They can't wait for those stock-rich young entrepreneurs, who have never experienced an industry recession, to be shocked when the market takes a sudden turn for the worse.

title: Record Labels Assert Control in Cyberspace
description: When it comes to portents of gloom, doom and despair, the record industry has lately been ticking off a litany of threats, real and imagined, posed by the Internet: Bands selling new albums directly over the Net; independent artists and labels posting thousands of music files on line; music piracy on the Web, and on-line audio sites creating large libraries of tunes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the budget stalemate in Albany included an erroneous figure from the State Comptroller's office for the increase in New York State spending during the last fiscal year. It was 8.4 percent, not 11.7 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; One Step Forward, And Two Steps Back
description: ON their treadmill to maybe missing the National League wild-card berth again, the Mets keep falling to the occasion.

title: Honoring Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Viktor Chebrikov, 76, Leader Of K.G.B. in Spying Heyday
description: Viktor M. Chebrikov, who led the Soviet K.G.B. through much of its final tumultuous confrontation with the West in the 1980's, died unexpectedly on July 1, the intelligence service's successor, the Federal Security Service, reported on Saturday.

title: S.U.V.'s Don't Belong in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about a man who attacked three people at a Brooklyn hospital misstated the condition of one victim. Michael D'Ambrose, 88, was severely beaten with a hammer but did not die in the attack. An article about the case appears today on page B3.

title: Coffee That Eases The Conscience
description: Once there was Maxwell House and Folger's. Now there's Costa Rican Terrazus and Sumatran Mandhelings, with attributes as baffling to the average consumer as those of wines. ''Full body, very rich, with an array of grace notes modulating from nut and smoke tones through hints of wine in the finish,'' as one Guatemalan brew was described in the trade magazine Coffee Journal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLETS, HOWARD, JR.
description: WILLETS-Howard, Jr. Age 75, of Ridgefield, CT, Rye, NY, native, 1949 University of Virginia alumni, retired director of marketing and sales of the Great Northern Paper Co. of Millinocket, ME, a member of the First Congregational Church and Silver Spring Country Club both of Ridgefield, CT. Husband of the late Louise (nee Tracy) Willets, and father of Michael Palmer, Howard Willets, III, Nelson Spencer Willets, Jonathan Price Willets, Tracy Palmer-Woods, Amelia Willets-Bozicnik and Andrea WilletsWard, grandfather of fourteen and great-grandfather of one. A memorial service will take place in Ridgefield, CT. Memorials to the Alzheimer's Association, PO Box 2292, Westport, CT 06880, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Ahead of the Field on a Borrowed Horse
description: Public opinion polls indicate that George W. Bush is currently the overwhelming choice of voters over all other contenders in both parties, even though most people admit they don't know enough about him to make an intelligent choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on June 13 about the romantic comedy series ''As Time Goes By,'' on WNET, misspelled the given name of the actor who plays Lionel. He is Geoffrey Palmer, not Jeffrey.

title: TENNIS: Sampras Scales the Summit as Davenport Dismisses a Legend; Graf Gamely Says Goodbye
description: Determined to make peace with Wimbledon's grass courts, which had never before been kind to her, Lindsay Davenport conducted her own cram course last month in the privacy of a friend's backyard court in Tustin, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: It's a Record Day for Sprinters in Stakes at Belmont
description: Temperatures soared but records fell at Belmont Park yesterday, as the two featured holiday races produced a stakes record and a track record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Winning With Class, Exiting With Class
description: DON'T argue with the evidence, especially when it's stacked against you. Andre Agassi tried hard to stir up his passions, his competitive juices, but eventually realized he would have to concede the day, surrender a court that is owned by another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHA, JAMES J.
description: BEHA-James J. Loving husband, father and grandfather, died July 3, at United Hospital. He was 82 years old. His family includes his devoted wife of 51 years, Macy Ann, his son James A. Beha II and his wife Nancy, his daughter Ann Beha and her husband Robert A. Radloff. He is also survived by his grandchildren Mary Alice, James J. and Christopther R. Beha, and Macy and Allison Radloff. Mr. Beha graduated from Williams College and the Harvard Law School. He was a senior partner at the law firm of Gasser & Hayes, and served as trustee of numerous charitable and civic organizations in New York City including the NYU Medical Center. Mr. Beha was a Knight of Malta, and a member of The Order of The Holy Sepulchre. He was also a loyal member of The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY. He was also a member of the American Yacht Club. Friends may call Tuesday, July 6, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be Wednesday, July 7, 11 AM, at The Church of the Resurrection. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, or Constableville Public Library, Constableville, NY 13325.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, SOL

title: Holiday Parades March By, But the Heat Is Just Settling In

But on a sweltering Fourth of July, people across the New York region turned out gamely for parades, picnics and fireworks and flocked to beaches, parks and other retreats to escape an old-time scorcher.

title: Compressed Data; After Skimming the Manual, Settle Down With the Book

The user manual for MS-DOS in 1982, for example, was 486 dense pages; the manual for Windows 95, with literally tens of thousands more features, was a stingy 95 pages.

Now elbowing its way into the fray is TNN, the Nashville Network, which last week announced a three-year deal with an outfit called Extreme Championship Wrestling for an hour-long show on Friday nights.

The economy here is booming just as loudly as in New York City, its neighbor to the west, with unemployment at 2.8 percent, 25,000 new jobs cropping up every year, and sales tax receipts growing at better than 3 percent annually. Its population of 1.3 million is one of the wealthiest in the nation, with median household income of more than $73,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Editorial Observer; Australia's Great Barrier Reef, Under Assault
description: The Great Barrier Reef stretches more than 1,200 miles along the northeast coast of Australia, the largest system of coral reefs in the world. It is not a single continuous structure but a mosaic of some 2,800 fringing reefs around islands, freestanding platform reefs in the open sea and ribbon reefs that parallel the northernmost shoreline. Segments seen last week on a cruise through its middle sections, from Townsville to Cairns, have the look of thriving underwater communities, where reef-building hard corals and gently swaying soft corals support a rich array of colorful fish, sea turtles, clams and other marine life. But here and there patches of bleached or dying corals provide a hint of the myriad threats that have some scientists convinced that the long-term health of the reef is in danger.

title: Who's Getting the Goods on Us?; Law Protects Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Right-Hand Man Is a Friend With a Midas Touch

Bush was ''Boosto'' or ''the Bombastic Bushkin,'' Joe O'Neill was ''Spider'' and Donald L. Evans was usually ''Evvie'' or ''Donnie.''

title: Compressed Data; A Good Nerd These Days Must Be Able to Stream

A decade ago they would have been the geeks setting up the school computer lab. But these days, the tekkie nerds have gone on line and multimedia -- at least judging from three Dearborn High School students in Michigan who were in Manhattan last week. The young men attended the Streaming Media convention at the Sheraton New York, where they demonstrated last term's project from their advanced video production course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.

His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

O.K., it was part of a play, ''The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui,'' by Bertolt Brecht, in the first American appearance by Brecht's own company, the Berliner Ensemble. (And it was Berkeley.) Still, it was a little startling, even for a visitor to the Bay Area bent on attending a number of events, each of which, in its way, was attracting attention for the disjointed cultural elements it brought together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: In Search of the Reasons For Anti-Gay Violence

title: Private Mailbox Services Call New Postal Rules Unfair

title: 50 Years Later, Her Chansons Find New Audiences

She walks regally to the microphone and starts singing, her arms soon sketching in the air the very ardor of her words. In no time, the audience warms to her. A few songs later, it is on its feet. By the end, it won't let her go.

title: By Design; More Exposure for Sandals

title: Rethinking Dams
description: Last week construction workers began dismantling the 24-foot-high, 917-foot-wide Edwards Dam on Maine's Kennebec River. This was an important moment in the struggle to restore the nation's rivers to good health. It marked the first time that the Federal Government had ordered the destruction of a private hydroelectric dam against the owner's wishes. It could also inspire the removal of other dams whose environmental costs now outweigh their benefits.

description: Alarmed by what they see as the potential for mishaps with patients taking herbal remedies for everything from depression to memory loss, anesthesiologists have begun urging people to stop taking the herbs and supplements before having surgery.

title: Kicking Away Pounds and Assailants
description: The last time I hopped around in an exercise class, George Bush was in the White House and Spandex ruled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRINKLE, PETER BRIAN
description: TRINKLE-Peter Brian. On June 29th, 1999, in Dallas, Texas, at age 67 after a brief illness. A New York resident for 27 years, he worked for the Exxon Corporation for his entire business career until retirement in 1997. Devoted husband and father, he is survived by his wife Benita, his son Peter, his daughter Liza, and his sister Jean Weedon. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Museum of Natural History or the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SOLOMON I.
description: KAPLAN-Solomon I. Of Hampton, NH, on July 2, 1999. Husband of Beatrice (Kantor), grandfather of Jody Smith and his wife Susan of Leominster, MA; brother of Robert Kaplan, his wife Evelyn, and of Ada Nogee, all of Pompano Beach, FL; and several nieces and nephews. Private services will be held at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. He worked all his life in the shoe business and was a member of the 210 Foundation and the Harvard Club. Donations may be made to the 210 Foundation, 56 Main Street, Watertown, MA. 02472.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDINET, ERIC
description: BAUDINET-Eric. Age 58 of NYC and East Quogue. CEO of Action and Leisure, Inc. Passed away on July 2. Born in Paris, France, he moved to Canada and then New York where he founded several successful businesses. He became a leading respected and cherished figure in the sporting goods world. A man of incomparable generosity, compassion and courage, he also sported a great sense of humor that bestowed happiness upon all those who had the privilege of knowing such a gentle man. Beloved husband of Catherine Sauve-Baudinet, he leaves in mourning his brother Jean-Claude and his sister Christine of Montreal, his sister Marie-Lorraine of Paris, several loving nephews and nieces; a devoted staff and a great number of true and deeply saddened friends all over the world. Memorial service to be announced.

title: A Woodstock Where Teeny Is Everything
description: Richard Schlar went to Woodstock 30 years ago to watch Jimi Hendrix, the Who and Janis Joplin. Now he's back at the site, Max Yasgur's farm, and a little confused by the scene.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, DAVID
description: COHEN-David. My beloved Grandpa, I think of you every day with all my love. Freya

title: PRI in Mexico Shows It Can Win
description: For years now, opposition politicians have argued that the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which by hook or crook has won every presidential election since the 1920's, could not win another one because its luster had been dimmed by years of corruption and arbitrary rule.

title: Eugenio Florit, Poet and Critic, 95
description: Eugenio Florit, a Cuban poet, translator and critic, died on June 29 at his home in Miami. He was 95.

title: United Church of Christ Elects New Head and Shifts Leaders
description: The United Church of Christ, a denomination that traces some of its roots back to the Puritans, yesterday elected as its new president the Rev. John H. Thomas, a minister widely known for his work in ecumenical relations.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cnet is singed by the offbeat logic of the Internet investor.
description: CNET was one of the very first companies to build a business on the World Wide Web, but it has rarely benefited from the special dispensations that investors accord most Internet companies.

title: New Fight Over the Old Art of Drug Compounding
description: A generation ago, when people took prescriptions to the local drugstore, there was a good chance that the pharmacist, rather than just pulling a prepackaged item off the shelf, would actually mix and measure ingredients to fill capsules or create ointments or cough syrup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKEL, MICKEY
description: PERKEL-Mickey. Beloved father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Died June 16. He was 76 years old. He loved his family and friends and they loved him. He cared, devoting much time and energy to many social causes throughout his life. He was a veteran of World War II and a prisoner of war for two years. In recent years he was very active in the Brooklyn Key Chapter of the American Ex-Prisoners of War. He was greatly loved and missed by many, especially his children, Amy McCarthy and Charles Perkel, and grandchildren Rachel and Sarah, Josh, Maggie and Ben.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGATSTEIN, PINA
description: AGATSTEIN-Pina. On July 3. Beloved wife of the late Michael, loving sister of Ronald Gruen and sister-in-law Ethel. Adored mother of Phyllys, Faye and Robert. Services will be held noon, July 6, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, NY. The family suggests donations in memory of Pina to United Cerebral Palsy Association, 380 Washington Ave, Roosevelt, NY 11575.
