description: BASEBALL

title: Sampras the Best Ever? A Grand Thought
description: Pete Sampras's straight-sets victory over Andre Agassi for his sixth Wimbledon singles title elevated him into new territory on the all-time appreciation list of tennis greats.

title: Fungicide Found on Coke Cans in Germany
description: Faint traces of fungicide have been found on five cans of Coca-Cola, the Agriculture Ministry in the southwestern German state of Baden-Wurttemberg said today.

title: It's Test Time for N.T.T.'s Global Ambitions
description: Junichiro Miyazu heads Asia's biggest company, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, and he is about to make it even bigger.

title: Does Kids' TV Have to Be Edifying?
description: All praise Bill Nye, the Science Guy! A pox upon the Power Rangers!

title: A Crackling Energy Defies the Elements
description: Joel Sachs and a hardy young band of students and graduates of the Juilliard School resumed their annual battle with the elements in the Summergarden concert series on Friday evening. Since the garden in question is the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art, the elements, like the immediate surroundings, are as much man-made as natural.

title: In More Office Cubicles, the Dog Has Its Day
description: In most respects, Kratz & Jensen is a sleek, efficient Manhattan public relations firm, with white ceiling fans, brushed aluminum accents and ample windows overlooking the Flatiron district. Look closely, however, and something altogether unexpected flashes by. Was that a tail?

title: Editorial Observer
description: The right to love and live with the person we choose is fundamental to the concept of freedom. But laws that made it a crime to marry, live with or have sex with someone of a different race restricted that freedom over much of the country for more than three centuries. Laws against interracial marriage were enforceable in 17 states when the Supreme Court declared them invalid in 1967.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan's Executives Say Business Mood Improves

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSER, ELEANOR F.
description: STRASSER-Eleanor F. On July 5, 1999 at age 83. Beloved wife of the late Robert Strasser. Loving mother of Peter, Donald and Stephen. Adored grandmother of Scott, Joanne, Jeffrey and Danny. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday, July 7 at 4PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANGE, EGON
description: BANGE-Egon. On July 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Gertrude (nee Miethe), loving father of Marianne and father-in-law of Casey Zmuda. Cherished brother of Rudolph. Also survived by forty-five nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193rd St. Visiting hours, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Wednesday, St Kevin's R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Kevin's Church or Florham Park First Aid Squad, 60 Felch Road, Florham N.J. 07932.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELHERTZ, HERBERT
description: EDELHERTZ-Herbert. On June 28, 1999. Former President of the Northwest Policy Studies Center in Kirkland, WA. A lawyer and expert on white-collar crime, he managed nationwide prosecutions for the Criminal Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, then established the Batelle Law and Justice Center in Seattle, WA. He created the National District Attorneys Association Economic Crime Project and was a Director of the National Center on White-Collar Crime. He is survived by his wife Ruth; a daughter, Jean; a son, Paul; a grandson, Benjamin; and a sister, Millicent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

description: To the Editor:

description: FORMAN-Henry. On July 4, 1999. Devoted husband of Yetta. Beloved father of Deena Rosenthal & Marvin. Cherished grandfather of Ian and Tallulah, Sara and Alisa. Fond brother of Rose Spielman and Leon. Graveside service Tuesday, 2 PM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Numico Seeks Food Concern
description: Royal Numico N.V., Europe's top baby-food maker, said today that it was offering $2.5 billion to buy the General Nutrition Companies as it sought to become the global leader in specialized foods.

title: Finding the Right Tactics to Prevent Lyme Disease
description: This is no time to get complacent about Lyme disease, the most common tick-borne illness in the country. Although the Food and Drug Administration licensed the first Lyme disease vaccine for people in December, we continue to have problems preventing this usually treatable but sometimes devastating bacterial disease. The three-dose vaccine is effective but not perfect, and disease-bearing ticks are expected to be unusually abundant this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNIN, GEORGE MAYER
description: KUNIN-George Mayer. Loving father and brother. Died July 5. His children, Jennifer, Tony, and Sarah, and his brother, Edward will miss him. Memorial service will be held at 5 PM, July 7, at the home of Ed Kunin, 328 Toilsome Hill Road, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice at Home, 765 Fairfield Avenue, Bridgeport. CT. 06604.

title: Stifling Heat Retains Grip on East Coast
description: A second day of 100-degree temperatures from the Carolinas to New England yesterday turned the holiday into a time of torture, with vacationers fleeing beaches that scorched their feet, only to find that some highways had buckled in summer's ferocity.

title: ACCORD WITH NATO LETS MOSCOW ADD TROOPS IN KOSOVO
description: NATO and Russian military commanders resolved their differences over Russia's role in the peacekeeping operation in Kosovo today, clearing the way for about 3,600 more Russian troops to arrive in the Serbian province after weeks of wrangling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, RICHARD C.
description: HERTZ-Richard C., Rabbi, Rabbi Emeritus. Of Temple Beth El in Bloomfield Hills, MI. Beloved husband of Renda Hertz. Dear father of Nadine Urben, Ruth Joyaux and her fiance Sam Canon, and Bradford (Stefanie) Ebner. Loving grandfather of Randy (Melanee) Wertheimer, Jordan Wertheimer, Daniel Joyaux, Brooke Ebner, Alexa Ebner, and Grant Ebner. Brother of the late Judge Frederick Hertz. Uncle of John Hertz. Services and interment in Detroit. For further information call the Ira Kaufman Chapel 248-569-0020.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TITTMANN, FRANCIS S.
description: TITTMANN-Francis S. Age 57. On July 3, 1999. Longtime resident of Huntington. Loving father of Andrew, Allison, Alicia, Christopher and Bryant. Proud and loving grandfather of Patrick Francis. Beloved brother of George, Matthew, Andrea Zeiner and Christine Wells. Loyal friend of many. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday, 25 and 7-9 PM, at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc.. Funeral Mass Thursday, St. Hugh of Lincoln R.C. Church. Burial to follow at St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Trocarier House.

title: Sleepless Gun for Hire Joins the First Lady
description: AT 9:15 this morning, a sleep-deprived Howard Wolfson is to accompany a lawyer to the Federal Election Commission in Washington as the lawyer files a piece of paper establishing the Hillary Rodham Clinton for United States Senate Exploratory Committee. After tending to the television cameras, and perhaps savoring his small role in history, Mr. Wolfson will then travel to Albany and begin caring for 200 reporters assembling from around the world who are to trail Mrs. Clinton, starting tomorrow, on a four-day campaign trip across New York; the opening day, simultaneously, of the wildest ride of Mr. Wolfson's life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROL, TEOFIL (TUVYE)
description: GROL-Teofil (Tuvye), Professor. A distinguished historian and Yiddishist, died on July 1, 1999 in Perugia, Italy after an extended illness. Born in Warsaw, Poland in 1915, Professor Grol was a survivor of the ghettos of Warsaw, Brest Litovsk and Bialystock, and a World War II partisan. He taught in several colleges in Poland. Following the 1968 anti-Semitic campaign in Poland, he emigrated to Paris, France, where he wrote for a number of Jewish newspapers. He was a regular contributor to the Jewish press in Poland, Argentina, South Africa, et. al. Author of several historical works in Yiddish, Prof. Grol also wrote a volume ''Grands Moments de Histoire Juive,'' and a novel, ''C'est Arrive en Pologne.'' Prof. Grol is survived by his wife of 56 years, Maria Grol of Paris; daughters Prof. Regina Grol of Buffalo, New York, her children Hanna and Benjamin; and Dr. Halina Grol of Perugia, Italy, and her sons David and Samuele.

title: Orioles' Surhoff Makes His Case for All-Star Designation
description: Joe Torre said yesterday that he had not been besieged by his neighbors or anyone else in Westchester County to name B. J. Surhoff to the American League All-Star team. Torre lives in Harrison; Surhoff grew up in the adjoining town of Rye.

title: Accounts
description: * EMC Corp., Hopkinton, Mass., which makes computer-storage systems, to Arnold Communications, Boston, part of Snyder Communications, to handle its North American account, which had been at Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Benitez Is Mets' Saving Grace
description: Nights like the last two can let people think that Armando Benitez is ready to assume the closer role full time with the Mets, even after John Franco comes back from the disabled list.

title: From 'Jewel in the Crown' to a Man of Many Facets
description: Tim Pigott-Smith's 14 episodes of fame came in the mid-1980's, when his portrayal of the sadistic police superintendent Ronald Merrick in ''The Jewel in the Crown'' made him the villain British and American television viewers loved to hate. In the ensuing 14 years, Mr. Pigott-Smith has had a busy career, but fame has not been part of it. And, he said, he doesn't miss it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAHEN, LEONARD, DR.
description: BRAHEN-Leonard, Dr. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted father of Lindy Brahen, Dr. Norman Brahen and Cheryl Toffler and father-in-law of Susan and Van. Cherished grandfather of Matthew and Rachel Toffler. Loving brother of Dr. Louis Brahen. Services Wednesday, 11AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAWLEY, KENNETH M.
description: FRAWLEY-Kenneth M. Of Tuckahoe, NY on July 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Theresa Martin Frawley. Devoted father of Kenneth and Christopher Frawley. Beloved grandfather of Kenneth and Emily. Brother of Margaret Dineen, Virginia McDonald and John and James Frawley. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM Tuesday & Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, on Thursday, July 8 at 9:45 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Iona College Scholarship Fund, 715 North Avenue, New Rochelle, New York 10801.

title: Israeli Cabinet Appointments Seem Aimed at Consolidating Barak's Control
description: By appointing loyal old-timers to two key posts in his Cabinet and keeping a third for himself, Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak appeared today to be trying to consolidate his hold on power as he completed his Government.

title: GAS SUPPLIER BROADENS REACH
description: Britain's dominant natural gas supplier, Centrica P.L.C., said it would buy the Automobile Association, the country's leading provider of roadside assistance, for $1.74 billion. With competition building to supply natural gas business to homes and businesses, the acquisition was designed to broaden Centrica's reach into financial services and other areas where the Automobile Association's 4.4 million members provide a ready network of potential customers. Centrica's stock rose up to 2.2 percent to $:1.5225 ($2.401), its highest since 1997. Alan Cowell

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: People
description: * Paul C. Atkinson was named to the new post of vice president for advertising sales at America Online Inc., Dulles, Va. He had been vice president for advertising at The Wall Street Journal, New York, part of Dow Jones & Company.

title: Medicine's Steamy Side, for and About Interns
description: The first of July marks the day that hospitals open their doors to the new crop of interns, a number of them clutching dog-eared copies of a pot-boiler novel called ''The House of God.'' Published 21 years ago, the book chronicles a year in the life of an intern training at one of the best hospitals in the country, which the author will not identify.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SISTER CECELIA
description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; Addressing An Attitude Problem
description: AS I begin to write this, the morning newspaper is slipped under the door of my hotel room. There is a huge photo of Steffi Graf, running two-thirds the length of a broadsheet page. Pete Sampras has been reduced to a small, one-column head shot, along with the last few paragraphs of the accompanying story.

title: Hong Kong's Invaluable Courts
description: Two years after Hong Kong was returned to China, the independence of its courts has been breached. At the behest of Tung Chee-hwa, the man Beijing chose to be the territory's chief executive, the mainland's legislature last month overturned an important immigration ruling by Hong Kong's highest court.

title: Plenty of Dirty Jobs in Politics And a New Breed of Diggers
description: Feeding an almost insatiable demand for negative information in today's world of bruising politics, private investigators are playing a larger -- though mostly hidden -- role in the public arena, digging up dirt on everyone from regulators to elected national and small-town officials.

title: South Africa Starts New Era With a Burst Of Invective
description: South Africa's second post-apartheid elections are over, but it looks like the mudslinging may just be getting started.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERDINGER, JANET E. (NEE WEISKOPF)
description: MERDINGER-Janet E. (nee Weiskopf). On July 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leonard Neger and Harry Merdinger. Devoted mother of Patricia Neger Neufeld and Judith E. (Dr. Craig) Rosen. Loving sister of Melvin Weiskopf. Devoted grandmother of Matthew and Lauren. title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: Illinois Utility Deal
description: The Illinova Corporation's Illinois Power Company unit said today that it had agreed to sell its Clinton, Ill., nuclear power station to the Amergen Energy Company for $20 million. Amergen is jointly owned by the Peco Energy Company of Philadelphia and British Energy P.L.C. Illinois Power said it expected regulatory approval of the transaction by year's end. Under the terms, Illinois Power will purchase at least 75 percent of Clinton's electricity output for its customers through 2004.

title: Midwest Gunman Had Engaged In Racist Acts at 2 Universities
description: Hate arrived in the neighborhoods of Indiana University, in Bloomington, in the early morning darkness of spring 1998, as a criminal justice major named Benjamin Nathaniel Smith drove his light blue Ford Taurus down residential streets, tossing little plastic bags of pamphlets into yards.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''How hot is it? Imagine standing in a sauna with a fireplace, and the fire is roaring, and you're doing jumping jacks -- in a mink coat, well, it's about 10 degrees hotter than that.''

title: The Reception of DiCicco Is Loud and Clear
description: When Tony DiCicco's mother was born, her parents were so happy to have a daughter, after three sons, that they named her Welcome. DiCicco has been just as gladly received as coach of the women's national soccer team.

title: A Cure as Close as the Nearest Phone
description: Many women suffering from urinary tract infections may be able to skip a trip to the doctor's office, be safely diagnosed and receive prescriptions by telephone, according to a study in the current issue of The American Journal of Medicine.

title: Gore Campaign, Trailing Among Women, Sharpens Its Pitch to Them
description: The first thing Al Gore mentioned in every speech last week was that his oldest daughter was past her due date and about to make him and his wife of 29 years grandparents. (Wyatt Gore Schiff, 6 pounds 3 ounces, finally arrived on the Fourth of July, timing that the Vice President will surely mention in future speeches.)

title: Washington Talk; In Shadow of Republicans' Dole, Democrats Seek a Woman
description: The name game always starts with Senator Dianne Feinstein, which is no surprise. With her high profile and decades of political experience, Senator Feinstein, a California Democrat, has long been considered a credible Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, BEATRICE
description: GREENSTEIN-Beatrice. On July 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Loving mother of Ruth and Naomi. Dear sister of Samuel Zutty and Rose Nottonson. Dedicated teacher of the disabled. Memorial services were held. Contributions in her memory to Meals on Wheels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Boy, 6, Drowns at Pool Party; 3 Other Fatalities Are Reported
description: A 6-year-old boy who was playing in a backyard pool with a large group of other youngsters drowned on Sunday night during a Fourth of July party attended by about 50 people, the Suffolk County Police said today.

title: Nostalgia For Punk, But a Fresh Comeback
description: ''Can I get a word in?'' Joe Strummer growled from the stage at Irving Plaza. The English punk patriarch was trying to explain one of his new songs on Wednesday night, but the crowd would not stop yelling for hits by his old band, the Clash.

description: GEORGES-Vivian, daughter of Mary and the late Nicholas, sister of Velia and Spero and Daniel and Joyce. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Killing His Relative
description: A 21-year-old man was charged early yesterday with killing an elderly relative in her Brooklyn home, the police said.

title: Conflict in Kashmir Stirs Fund-Raising Fervor Among Indian Immigrants
description: For years, earthquakes, floods and other natural calamities back home have kindled patriotic sentiments among immigrants in this country, compelling them to open their checkbooks in the spirit of good will. Now, in a moment of unprecedented nationalist fervor, Indian immigrants in New York City and across the United States are sending home dollars to aid Indian Army soldiers involved in the conflict in Kashmir, the contested mountainous terrain on the India-Pakistan border.

title: Rising Lake Slowly Stalks a North Dakota Town
description: Jim Yri, a tall, sunburned farmer with movie star looks and the folksy style of Jimmy Stewart, has battled North Dakota blizzards and wheat fungus and, lately, appallingly low crop prices. But now he is in a struggle with a lake that he is afraid he just might lose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.

title: Federal Court Sets High Standard for Fraud Suits
description: In a victory for high-technology companies and others facing securities fraud suits, a Federal appeals court ruled on Friday that such suits must be dismissed at the outset unless they contain detailed evidence of deliberate fraud.

title: $150 Million Shopping Center in Harlem Moving Forward

Roosevelt Drive in East Harlem is on the verge of being demolished, and plans are moving forward to replace it with a $150 million shopping center, one of the largest commercial developments in Manhattan in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHA, JAMES J.
description: BEHA-James J. Loving husband, father and grandfather, died July 3, at United Hospital. He was 82 years old. His family includes his devoted wife of 51 years, Macy Ann, his son James A. Beha II and his wife Nancy, his daughter Ann Beha and her husband Robert A. Radloff. He is also survived by his grandchildren Mary Alice, James J. and Christopther R. Beha, and Macy and Allison Radloff. Mr. Beha graduated from Williams College and the Harvard Law School. He was a senior partner at the law firm of Gasser & Hayes, and served as trustee of numerous charitable and civic organizations in New York City including the NYU Medical Center. Mr. Beha was a Knight of Malta, and a member of The Order of The Holy Sepulchre. He was also a loyal member of The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY. He was also a member of the American Yacht Club. Friends may call Tuesday, July 6, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be Wednesday, July 7, 11 AM, at The Church of the Resurrection. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, or Constableville Public Library, Constableville, NY 13325.

The Sunday Times of London said Cable and Wireless had been approached by would-be buyers including Deutsche Telekom A.G., France Telecom S.A., the Bell Atlantic Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. Alan Cowell

title: COLOMBIA ALTERS OIL POLICY
description: In an effort to stimulate stalled production and attract foreign producers, the Colombian state oil company, Ecopetrol, has instituted more liberalized terms for oil exploration contracts. As a result of the changes, announced over the weekend, Ecopetrol will reduce its initial stake in any new field from 50 to 30 percent of output to assure a quicker return for its partners, but will also cut back on its share of field development costs by the same proportion. Colombia runs the risk of becoming a net importer of oil within five years if no significant new discoveries are made. Larry Rohter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERR, FREDERICK J., JR.
description: HERR-Frederick J., Jr. Of Greenville, DE. Died on July 3, 1999. Age 88. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. to Frederick J. Herr Sr. and Meta Hansen. Mr. Herr served as a Lt. Commander in W.W. II-first in Chile in Naval Intelligence and later in active duty on an attack transport in the Pacific. He worked in the financial world for half a century. He started his career as a runner on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, graduated from New York University, and became a Utilities Analyst at the Lehman Corporation. He subsequently was Financial Vice President of the Central and Southwest Corporation and later served as Vice-Chairman and a Director. Mr. Herr also served as a Director of the Bank of Delaware. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Florence L., son Roger F. of NYC, daughter Evelyn Anderson and her husband Judd, of Baltimore, MD, granddaughters Christina and Clare Anderson, and sister Ethel Betz of Wilmington, DE. A memorial service Saturday, July 10, 1PM at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1502 W. 13th St, Wilmington, DE. 19806. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Westminster Presbyterian or Habitat for Humanity, 900 Washington St., Wilmington, DE. 19801.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, PHYLLIS CHAMBERLIN
description: MERRILL - Phyllis Chamberlin. Passed away on July 4th, 1999, in Palo Alto, California. Born in Oakland, California, on October 5th, 1907, she was the daughter of William Richmond Chamberlin and Mabel Davidson Chamberlin of Berkeley, California. She attended the Anna Head School and the University of California at Berkeley and was a member of the class of 1929 and the Pi Beta Phi sorority. On September 28th, 1933, in a garden ceremony in Yokohama, she was married to the late Gregor Charles Merrill of Berkeley, California, the United States' Vice Consul to Japan. Subsequently, the Merrill's were sent to Manila in the Philippines and then to Antwerp, Belgium. They returned to the United States shortly after the beginning of World War II. During the war, while Gregor Merrill served as an intelligence officer in the U.S. Navy, Mrs. Merrill, her daughter, Beverly Phyllis and son, Hugh Anthony moved between San Francisco, Rockland, Maine, and Washington, DC. In 1946, the family moved to New York City where Mr. Merrill worked for Texaco. In 1948, Gregor Merrill became the manager of CALTEX, France, in Paris where the family resided until returning to New York City. In 1960, the family returned to their roots in California and took up residence on the Peninsula. Phyllis Merrill is survived by her daughter, Beverly Phyllis Merrill; her son, Captain Hugh Anthony Merrill, USN (Ret) of Santa Barbara; a brother, William Richmond Chamberlin; and two grandsons, Charles Rhett Merrill and Alexander Heyward Merrill. Memorial gifts may be made to the Children's Health Council, the San Francisco Opera, or the San Francisco Foundation.

title: WOLTERS KLUWER AGREES TO ACQUIRE BANKERS SYSTEMS
description: Wolters Kluwer United States, a subsidiary of the Dutch publishing company Wolters Kluwer N.V., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Bankers Systems Inc. of St. Cloud, Minn., a provider of legal documents, software and services for the financial services industry, for $190 million. Bankers Systems, with a customer base that includes 14,000 financial institutions, specializes in electronic and print forms for account, loan and retirement plan administration. After the deal, Bankers Systems, which posted revenues of about $100 million in the 1999 fiscal year, will become part of CCH Inc., a Wolters Kluwer unit that provides tax and business law information.

title: East Coast Mobilizes in a Block-by-Block Resistance to the Stifling Heat
description: They canceled summer school here in the nation's capital, dimmed the lights in much of the Massachusetts Statehouse and sent block captains out to check on the elderly in Philadelphia's row houses.

title: Comtech to Split Shares
description: Comtech Telecommunications Inc. said today that it would split its shares 3 for 2. The stock split will increase the number of shares by half, to 4.1 million, while reducing the value of each share by a third. The new shares will be issued July 30 to stockholders of record as of July 16. Comtech, based in Melville, makes electronic and telecommunications equipment. It has annual sales of $36 million. In trading today, the company's shares closed at $16.25, up $2.75.

title: Glitch Over Language Proficiency Mars Test Results in California
description: California students made modest gains in every subject and nearly every grade in a test of basic skills this spring, according to results reported last week. But what seemed like a big victory for opponents of bilingual education evaporated when a reporting error was found to have inflated the scores of non-English-speaking students.

title: High Noon: Restaurants Fight to Draw a Crowd
description: A BUSINESS lunch today is positively Spartan compared with those fabled three-martini events a quarter-century ago. The martinis have been replaced by iced tea, mineral water, possibly a single glass of wine. The hearty dishes that lingered until dinner, like pot-au-feu, have become grilled chicken or a salad. The leisurely two-hour interlude has slipped back to an hour or less and, for many, into carryout at the desk or sandwiches in the conference room.

title: Hello Fender, Hello Gibson; Out of the Garage and Into Rock-and-Roll Day Camp
description: There is a rhythm to day camps, whether they are focused on soccer, computers or just enduring summer days while parents work. The cars line up, the children -- at first a bit unsure -- emerge, the counselors greet them, and off they go.

title: Obstacle to a Tobacco Suit
description: The Clinton Administration has been exploring ways to bring a lawsuit against the tobacco industry to recoup the billions of dollars spent treating smoking-related illnesses under Medicare and other Federal medical programs. Forty-six states reached a $206 billion settlement with tobacco companies last year to recover state Medicaid costs connected to smoking. A successful Federal suit could bring in new revenues that would shore up the Medicare trust fund and help reduce smoking by raising cigarette prices.

title: In Russia, Charity Rides On Corporate Shoulders
description: Businessmen are often vilified in Russia as exploiters, who flout tax laws and played a role in the financial crash of last August.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC DENIES TALKS OVER ISRAELI COMPANY
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, one of the biggest makers of angioplasty products, denied an Israeli newspaper report yesterday that it was in talks to buy Medinol Ltd. of Jerusalem, which developed the Nir coronary stent. The newspaper Ha'aretz reported that Boston Scientific, which already owns about 20 percent of Medinol, was in discussions with other shareholders to buy the remaining shares. The Nir stent is marketed by Boston Scientific, of Natick, Mass., and has become one of the top-selling stents in the United States since it received regulatory approval last year. Medinol will be valued at $1.5 billion to $2 billion for the sale, Ha'aretz reported.

title: Bounding With Energy, East and West Meet

The company, which was founded by the American modern-dance choreographer Rosalind Newman last year and is based in Hong Kong, is a collection of 12 lithe, good-looking young performers who seem capable of meeting any challenge. And Ms. Newman has given the dancers sleek choreography that draws on their lithe energy and individuality even as it makes interesting points about human relationships and social history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVA, WILLIAM
description: RIVA-William. Born in Detroit, Michigan, July 18, 1919. He grew up mostly in Europe, later returning to attend Wayne University where his skills as scenic designer flourished. After Pearl Harbor he enlisted in the Army where his superior command of several languages quickly sent him overseas as a special translator. Refusing officer's candidate school, he remained a master sergeant throughout the Second World War, proud that his overseas stay-ofduty bars exceeded those of most generals. On returning to the States, he became Resident Stage Designer and teacher at Fordham University's prodigious Drama Department in New York, where he met his future wife, Maria Riva. On Broadway he designed the first production of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''The Medium'' in the round, having invented the concept of a scrim enveloped circular stage lit in such a way that, although appearing solid, was perfectly transparent for the audience to see the performance without being distracted by the audience across the stage. In the Fifties his award-winning, innovative commercial designs for television set visual standards still in use today. Riva became and remained a very successful designer and inventor of toys and board games, forming his own international agency to help other inventors. He died on the third of July in Bern, Switzerland, survived by his wife of fiftytwo years, their four sons-J. Michael, John Paul, and J. David of California and Peter of New York-and seven grandchildren.

title: AMERICAN TOWER TO ACQUIRE WATSON COMMUNICATION
description: The American Tower Corporation, one of the country's largest owners of broadcast and wireless communications towers, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Watson Communication Systems Inc. for about $73 million in cash to add towers in the San Francisco Bay area. Watson is closely held and is based in San Francisco. The Boston-based American Tower will have more than 4,000 towers after it closes pending transactions. The shares fell $1.1875, to $24.3125. American Tower also said it had completed a $38.8 million acquisition of Commsite International Inc., an antenna-site development and management company based in Vienna, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

description: STURZ-Beverly Elaine Groden. Beloved wife and mother. Compassionate, loving and energetic grandmother. Died July 6 at home in New York City, surrounded by her immediate family. Born in Ellwood City, PA, she moved to New York after studying chemistry and math at Western Reserve in order to become a ballet dancer and model. She later earned masters degrees in education from New York University and Teachers College of Columbia University, and taught tirelessly as an elementary and special education teacher for 27 years, predominantely at P.S. 75 on the Upper West Side. Beverly was an active member of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism on West 86 Street, and exercised three days a week until the last month of her life. She is survived by her husand Robert, sister Louise, children Nancy and James, and three grandchildren Ziv, Geffen and Maytal. She is missed by those who knew and loved her. A memorial service is planned for Wednesday, July 7 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street, at 3PM. She will be buried in the Hebrew Cemetery in Raleigh, NC the following day. Donations please to the American Cancer Society, or to the S.A.J., in Beverly's name.

And Henry Fox, 79, could not help but recall the days during World War II when he would fry eggs on the deck of his aircraft carrier in the Philippines. ''Now that was hot,'' he said, basking in the air-conditioned Red Hook Senior Center and thinking about his much hotter home. ''We used to make bets on who could fry 'em the quickest.''

title: VEHICLE SALES DROP
description: Brazil's vehicle sales declined in June as high domestic interest rates sapped consumer financing. Sales fell 1.5 percent, to 92,960 units from May, the third consecutive monthly decline. Compared with June 1998, sales plunged nearly 20 percent. The decline comes amid a retrenching by auto manufacturers that began last year when the Government raised interest rates to prevent a rapid depletion of foreign currency reserves. Since March, rates have fallen to 21 percent from 45 percent. In the first six months of 1999, sales fell 19 percent, to 523,257 units. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Hershiser Rebounds On One Day Of Rest
description: Reaching 200 career victories was his goal before the season. But last night, Orel Hershiser said No. 199 might just turn out to mean more.

title: CBS Picks Chief for TV-Stations Unit
description: The CBS Corporation, owner of the highest-rated United States television network, named John Severino, the former president of ABC-TV, to head CBS's group of 16 television stations throughout the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a departure from the traditional rank and file of these groups. These are not people who live in trailers. There is a concerted effort on the part of white supremacist leaders to recruit college-bound middle- and upper-middle-class kids.''

title: Donor Implicates Mexican Party in Scandal
description: A financier who recently disclosed that he was a donor of large sums to President Ernesto Zedillo's presidential campaign before he broke with the governing party and fled Mexico now says that senior party officials conspired with him in 1994 to arrange $4 million in illegal donations to the Zedillo campaign.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Relax, Flan Watchers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: 2 Foreigners Are Allocated To MetroStars
description: The MetroStars have acquired two of the three foreign players due them from Major League Soccer. Sasa Curcic of Yugoslavia, a playmaking midfielder who is familiar with Coach Bora Milutinovic, and Mohammad Khakpour, a defender who played for Iran in the 1998 World Cup, were signed by the league yesterday and allocated to the MetroStars.

title: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL; 3 Players For Liberty Are Named All-Stars
description: Three Liberty players were named as starters to the first Women's National Basketball Association All-Star Game next Wednesday at Madison Square Garden, the league announced yesterday. Point guard Teresa Weatherspoon, center Kym Hampton and forward Rebecca Lobo -- who is injured and will not play -- were elected by the fans.

title: Motorola Unit to Add 1,400 Positions
description: The Network Solutions Sector unit of Motorola Inc. said today that it planned to create 1,400 positions in engineering and in research and development.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KORN, IRENE
description: KORN-Irene. The Board of Directors, Offices and Employees of Colonial Commercial Corp. mourn the passing of Irene Korn, beloved wife of Bernard Korn, Chairman and President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORIERO, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: TESORIERO-Joseph A., M.D., 72. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Lisa Tesoriero Miller, Linda T. Osborne, Jeanine Tesori and Sue Coyle. Devoted grandfather of Haley, Liam, Chloe, Tess, Siena, Shelby and Joseph. Also survived by a brother, Robert Tesori. Visiting hours 24 and 7-9 P.M. Friday, Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 A.M. Saturday, June 12, at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment will be private.

title: GPU TO BUY REST OF MIDLANDS ELECTRICITY
description: GPU Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the half of the British power provider Midlands Electricity P.L.C. that it does not already own from the Cinergy Corporation for $700 million in cash. It will also take on $1.1 billion in debt. The Cincinnati-based Cinergy said it would have a third-quarter gain of 43 cents a share from the sale. GPU, of Morristown, N.J., said it expected the acquisition to improve its earnings by 4 or 5 cents a share starting next year. The companies joined to buy Midlands in 1996 for $2.6 billion. Cinergy, which has 1.4 million power customers in Ohio, Indiana and Kentucky, paid $500 million in cash and assumed more than $800 million in debt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about air traffic problems in the Northeast misstated the location of Green Airport in Rhode Island. It is in Warwick, not Providence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETZLER, MILDRED FRANCIS
description: WETZLER-Mildred Francis, 83. Of Fort Myers, FL, formerly of Deal, NJ, on June 28. Beloved wife of Samuel G. (Sonny) Wetzler, cherished mother of Elizabeth Shevach (Allen) and Constance Gatta. Adored grandmother of Caroline Ansell, Allen Shevach Jr., Margaret Ansell Podell (Lance), John Ansell, Kathryn Shevach Mekrut (Roger), great-grandchildren Joshua Shevach and Ethan Podell. Loving brother of Irwin Francis. Contributions may be made to the Billy Shevach College Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 60131, Fort Myers, FL. 33906.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURZ, BEVERLY
description: STURZ-Beverly. The Society for the Advancement of Judaism records with profound sorrow the death of our longtime, devoted member, Beverly Sturz. We extend our condolences to her entire family. Julie Schonfeld, Rabbi Michael Davidson, Bd. Chm.

title: Foreign Investors Lose a Round at Russian Ship Concern
description: The board of Russia's largest shipping company elected a ranking official of the Russian Government as the company's chairman today, bowing to pressure from a powerful regional governor who has expressed anger over the influence of foreign investors in post-communist Russia.

title: 2 Jail Guards Face Charges Involving Sex With Inmates
description: Government prosecutors charged two guards at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan yesterday with engaging in sexual activity with inmates, which is illegal.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The single European currency touched another record low against the dollar amid more signs of weakness in the European economy. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0226, down from $1.0240 on Friday.

title: The Chimps Don't Have Free Will
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EFTC CORP., Denver, an electronics company, plans to lay off 150 employees, about 6 percent of its work force, and sell its repair and warranty-service business to Jabil Circuit Inc., St. Petersburg, Fla., for $30 million. EFTC expects a second-quarter operating loss of 15 to 20 cents a share.

title: So, a Chicken Walks Into a Bar
description: THE best chicken I ever tasted wasn't the poulet de Bresse stuffed with truffles that I had in France. It wasn't the chicken wrapped in lotus leaves and baked in a mound of clay in Hong Kong. It wasn't even my Aunt Annette's plump, golden braised capon, although it comes close. No, the best chicken I ever tasted came off a barbecue pit in Memphis, where it had been smoked upright in a singularly undignified position -- straddling an open can of beer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORRIS
description: HERMAN-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Shya Herman on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: New Promises on Kashmir
description: After a timely intervention by President Clinton over the weekend, Pakistan may be ready to bring about the withdrawal of hundreds of armed Islamic militants fighting Indian soldiers in the mountains of Kashmir. The pledge to take ''concrete steps'' on the border with India, including the withdrawal of the militants from Indian territory, was made by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif after a hastily scheduled meeting with Mr. Clinton in Washington. It was a welcome promise that could defuse tensions. But Mr. Sharif could have difficulty executing it. In the face of continued fighting in the mountains, he must persuade the army and supporters of the militants in Pakistan that it is the right course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, DANIEL
description: FINKEL-Daniel, 90, on June 8, 1999. Loving husband of Jean. Devoted father of Barbara and Bob, Mindy and Bruce. Adoring grandfather of Brett, Alyse, Andrew and Matthew. Contributions to Congregation Eitz Chaim, Box 183, County Road 105, Monroe, NY 10950.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: A Beverly Hills Bakery Opens in Lower Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACK, DICK
description: PACK-Dick. We are saddened by the sudden passing of Television Quarterly's brilliant editor Dick Pack. Two decades ago he came to us and guided TVQ to become a publication of quality and universal respect. The magazine will always stand as a tribute to his leadership, intelligence and irresistible personality. To his wife Laura, his close family and friends and all of us at the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, we offer our deepest sympathy. He leaves us with something very wonderful. We have been richer as human beings and as professionals for having known him and worked with him. Respectfully, John Cannon, President National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences

title: Senate Riders Put Some on the Inside Track
description: The Senate is setting up a festival of favors for oil, gas, timber, mining and ranching interests in its spending bills this year.

title: Gulfstream Park Has Sale Agreement
description: The merger trend in thoroughbred racing has taken a major step forward with the owners of Gulfstream Park in Florida confirming yesterday that they had reached an agreement to sell the track to Frank Stronach, the Canadian financier and horseman, for $95 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Business Day yesterday about a $43 billion takeover offer from Total Fina of France misspelled the name of the company Total is seeking to acquire. It is Elf Aquitaine, not Acquitaine.

title: Push for Wholesale Banks Stalls in Overhaul of Law
description: They go by the name ''woofie,'' although, in truth, they do not have much ''woof'' to them. The term woofie refers to a type of wholesale bank that was to have been created in the financial overhaul measure that recently passed both houses of Congress. In reality, however, the measure has dragged on so long that an idea that seemed sparkling many years ago has little backing or meaning today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, TED E.
description: BECKER-Ted E., Sr., M.D. On July 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Amy Mayes Becker. Loving father of Ted E. Becker, Jr., Stephen Becker, Chris Becker, Amy Barovick and father-in-law of Jon Barovick. Cherished grandfather to Christina, Jessie, Sean, Katrina, Elisabeth, Jeremy and Sam. Services Sunday, July 11, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday about John Stears, a special effects artist, misstated the date of his death. It was April 28, not June 28; the family announced the death late in June.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: Founders Gave 'Nature' Its Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Without Air, Sweating Starts Early For Students
description: Anna Baker pressed her forehead against bottled water to cool off. Lydia Yim wiped her brow with a wet paper towel. Abdul Hanne simply wished he was at the beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, STANLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Stanley. Of Westfield, NJ, died June 8. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Kobrofsky), devoted father of Cathy Rien and Garry Goldberg, loving grandfather of Matthew, Rheana & Fallon. Funeral services will be at 1 P.M., Thursday, June 10, at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES TO BUY CULINAR, UNITING HOSTESS
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation of Kansas City, Mo., which owns the United States rights to Twinkies and other Hostess-brand snack cakes, announced plans yesterday to buy Culinar Inc., a snack-cake maker based in Montreal, for an undisclosed price. Culinar, which markets bread and snack cakes in Canada and the northeastern United States, owns the Canadian trademark for Hostess.

title: Blast-Furnace Weather
description: The triple-digit temperatures that have scalded much of the East Coast over the past few days provoked a peculiar counsel for overheated New Yorkers. City residents were advised to find their relief not at the shore or in the country, but in the more traditional sites of daily commerce. Exhorted not to exert themselves outdoors, urbanites were urged to find air-conditioning -- at a work station, at the corner movie house, at the nearest indoor restaurant. Shopping was encouraged -- not window-shopping, since sidewalks had begun to soften even the hardiest of soles, but indoor browsing, loitering at the freezer case at the grocery store, hunting not so much for bargains as blowers.

title: Roadblock to Holbrooke's U.N. Nomination Is Apparently Lott
description: Last week the office of the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, refused to identify two Senators secretly blocking a final confirmation vote on Richard C. Holbrooke as chief diplomat to the United Nations. Now it turns out that Senator Lott is one of the two, Government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, LANA LEE
description: MacARTHUR-Lana Lee. Born February 9, 1946. Died June 4, 1999. Age 53. Loving mother of Chase Menton. Loving wife of Frank Allen. Loving sister of Jean Harris and Larry Lupear. A woman who has touched us all with a smile and a warm embrace. Keep us safe and warm, for you are here in our thoughts and hearts, our spirits and our souls. Memorial service Saturday, June 12, at WuTang Physical Culture Association. With love, your chosen family

title: Exhibit of Vietnamese Art Rouses Immigrant Anger
description: The Vietnamese immigrants gathered outside the Bowers Museum of Cultural Art here believe that the Communists they crossed an ocean to escape are haunting them again, this time with paint and canvas.

title: INDIA GETS LOAN
description: India secured its first major World Bank loan since the United States suspended economic sanctions against India and Pakistan in June 1998 for conducting underground nuclear tests. Edwin Lim, the World Bank chief in New Delhi, signed an agreement to give an interest- free loan of $385.7 million to finance welfare projects for women and children in five Indian states and a primary education project in the state of Rajasthan. P. J. Anthony

title: STAAR SURGICAL SPURNS OFFER FROM UNDISCLOSED BIDDER
description: The Staar Surgical Company said yesterday that it had rejected an offer to buy at least 51 percent of its common shares outstanding at $15 each, saying the bid was inadequate. Staar, based in Monrovia, Calif., said the undisclosed bidder did not respond to the company's request to provide information about the proposal, including the identity of the party making the offer, its financial resources and the specific terms. Staar, which makes medical devices for patients with refractive, cataract and glaucoma problems, disclosed the offer on June 23. The shares rose 37.5 cents, to $13.875.

title: Yankees Show Their Resilience And Grit
description: The Yankees traded David Wells for Roger Clemens on the first day of spring training, and the distractions and hurdles were just beginning. Manager Joe Torre learned he had cancer, Don Zimmer took over, Hideki Irabu was nicknamed fat toad by the owner, Darryl Strawberry was arrested. The Yankees slumped. Their defense kept giving games away.

title: PHONE STAKE SOLD
description: China Telecom (Hong Kong) Group sold a 1.3 percent stake in Cable and Wireless HKT, Hong Kong's dominant phone company, for $407 million to finance telecommunications projects in mainland China. The company, controlled by China's Ministry of Information Industry, sold 156 million Cable and Wireless HKT shares. The share sale will leave China Telecom Group, controlled by the Ministry of Information Industry, with a 10.86 percent holding in Cable and Wireless HKT, known until this month as Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWAG, ELIAS J.
description: GOLDWAG-Elias J. On July 6, 1999. Devoted husband and dear friend of Shirley. Beloved son of the late Dr. Joseph Goldwag and Jenny Goldwag. Service Thursday, July 8, 12noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHO, MORLEY
description: CHO-Morley. The Board of Trustees of the China Institute in America mourns the passing of our friend and colleague Morley Cho. As a Trustee Emeritus, with his commitment and dedication for over a quarter of a century, he has contributed immeasurably toward building China Institute into the preeminent center for learning about China that it is today. China Institute's members and staff extend deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Nancy and daughters Emily and Renee. We will all miss his guidance and wisdom.

title: Hillary by Default
description: Is the soul of the New York State Democratic Party so dead that, even with Chuck Schumer's triumphant win over Al D'Amato last year, it can't come up with one Democratic New Yorker to fill Daniel Patrick Moynihan's Senate seat?

title: INDUSTRIAL GAS OFFER
description: Shares in the industrial gas supplier BOC Group P.L.C. soared after the company said it was considering a new joint bid by Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown, Pa., and Air Liquide of France. It rejected an earlier bid of $11 billion from the same suitors two weeks ago. The British company, the world's second-largest supplier of industrial gases, said that the new proposal was ''not satisfactory in a number of important respects'' but that it would explore ''these issues to see if they can be addressed.'' Alan Cowell

title: Syria Signals Its Willingness To Reopen Talks With Israel
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, in Moscow for the first time since the end of the cold war, signaled tonight that he might be ready to rejoin the Middle East peace effort he abandoned after Benjamin Netanyahu became Israel's Prime Minister in 1996.

title: A Kabuki-Style Western, Noisy and Hyperactive
description: The eardrums get a particularly punishing workout these days at the Flea Theater, where the rock 'em, sock 'em samurai of ''Benten Kozo'' pummel, slash and kick-box their way through a frenetic American reinterpretation of Kabuki, the centuries-old Japanese theatrical form.

title: Woman's Suicide a Bizarre Note in Fraud Inquiry
description: Two years ago, a young woman named Frances Burge was found dead in Greenwich, Conn., hanging by a rope from the deck of a luxurious house.

title: Descendants of Slave's Son Contend That His Father Was George Washington
description: Did George Washington father a son with Venus, a young slave who lived on the estate of his half brother John Augustine Washington?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBIN, JACK
description: LUBIN-Jack. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Marvin and Rae. Devoted grandfather of Todd and Linda, Phillip, Kirk and Michelle, and Dana. Adoring brother of Joseph. Service Thursday, 12PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: Stage-Struck Booksellers Keep Progress In the Wings
description: This is how Rozanne Seelen describes her marriage: ''The wife says to the husband: 'I want a vanilla ice cream cone. Not chocolate, not strawberry, vanilla. The husband goes out and brings back a tuna fish sandwich. And she says, 'Thank you.' ''

title: Berry Desserts, Sophisticated and Simple
description: NEW JERSEY blueberries are in the Greenmarkets, velvety red and gold raspberries beckon jewel-like from tiny baskets and, soon, big shiny blackberries will be available to pick in the countryside or to buy at farm stands. What a trove!

title: INSIDE
description: Bar to Holbrooke Vote

title: America's War, Germany's Peace
description: The apparent settlement of the dispute between Moscow and NATO over where Russian troops will be deployed in Kosovo clears the way for addressing a more important question: Will there continue to be American troops there? There need not be; Kosovo may finally allow Europeans to assume primary responsibility for a political and military problem in Europe.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Cena Closes

title: Accounts
description: Kaye Group, New York, an insurance company, to Mezzina/Brown, New York, to handle a new account, redesigning and marketing its Web site, Kayegroup.com. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Chavin Lambert Advertising, New York, handles print duties.

title: Hedge Fund Reimburses $1.3 Billion To Investors
description: Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund whose near failure last fall rocked world financial markets, returned approximately $1.3 billion of capital to its investors yesterday.

title: Metro Business; Sentence in Stock Fraud
description: A reputed mob associate, whose voice on Federal Bureau of Investigation wiretaps helped break open a Federal prosecution of organized crime's attempt to infiltrate Wall Street, was sentenced yesterday to eight years in prison for cheating investors in a stock fraud.

title: Acid and Smelting Vats Evoke Fear of Grisly Burials by Serbs
description: Some NATO officials and local residents say the mile-deep shafts, the steaming smelting vats and the tanks of hydrochloric acid at the Trepca mine here were used as a vast disposal site for the bodies of ethnic Albanians killed by Serbian forces, and the international war crimes tribunal has agreed to investigate their suspicions.

title: Dark Theme Ushers In Pilobolus
description: Pilobolus Dance Theater proved as ingenious as ever when it opened its season on Monday night at the Joyce Theater. In the past the company has often used its acrobatic choreography in a playful, whimsical or bizarre manner. But Pilobolus has also been drawn to darkly dramatic subject matter, and this evening of four works, one of them a premiere, emphasized themes of violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERLOCK, WILLIAM
description: SHERLOCK-William, ''Bill''. William Bill Sherlock, a resident of Rye Brook, New York, died on Tuesday, July 6, 1999. He was born February 28, 1928 in Nyack, N.Y. to the late Thomas and Alice Murray Sherlock. He grew up on the West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Sherlock married Sissy Coyle in 1959. He is survived and loved by his wife Sissy, sons William Jr. and Robert, daughter in-law Cindy. He was predeceased by a son & daughter. Visitation will at the Craft Memorial Home, Inc., 40 Leicester St., Port Chester, N.Y., on Wednesday and Thursday, July 7th and 8th, from 5-9PM. Funeral mass will be at the Corpus Cristi Church, 136 South Regent St., Port Chester, N.Y. on Friday, July 9th at 9:30AM. Interment will follow at the St. Mary Cemetery, Rye Brook, N.Y. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the YMCA of Stamford, Washington Boulevard, Stamford, CT. 06901 or the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, N.Y. 10707.

title: Surely, We Can Make Children's TV Better
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: ROSENTHAL-Sylvia (nee Peck). Of Woodcliff Lake, NJ. On July 5, 1999. Wife of Dr. Seymour. Devoted mother of Drs. Laurie and Michael Bleicher, Dr. Andrew and Karen Rosenthal, Amy Rosenthal and Alan Safron. Dear sister of Dr. Harvey Peck & Betty Thompson. Loving grandmother of Laurence and Colby Bleicher, Jared and Lindsay Rosenthal & Lena Safron. Contributions could be made to Temple Emanuel of Woodcliff Lake and Good Samaritan Hospital Foundation of Suffern, New York.

description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEE, JANE L.
description: ALLEE-Jane L. On July 2, 1999. She will be missed by her husband John Allee, her children Amy, Peter and Jennifer and their spouses Burl, Lois and Ted, her grandchildren Matthew, Nina, Sian & Dylan, her brother William and many other family and friends. Contributions may be made in her memory in care of Dr. Ruth Oratz, New York University Hospital, Division of Oncology, Research Fund, 560 First Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10018.

title: Corrections
description: An interview in Science Times yesterday with Dr. Michael L. Dertouzos, a computer scientist who is concerned about the social impact of computers, misstated the site of the creation of the World Wide Web. Tim Berners-Lee invented the Web and wrote the first software for it in 1990 and 1991 while working at the CERN physics laboratory outside Geneva. He joined the Laboratory for Computing Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSER, ELEANOR F.
description: STRASSER-Eleanor F. On July 5, 1999 at age 83. Beloved wife of the late Robert Strasser. Loving mother of Peter, Donald and Stephen. Adored grandmother of Scott, Joanne, Jeffrey and Danny. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday, July 7 at 4PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to The New York Hospital Emergency Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCEWEN, DOLORES
description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARISER, HOWARD
description: PARISER-Howard. July 2. Age 65 Husband of Bobbi. Father of Jeffrey and Michael. Son of Lillian. Brother of Judith Gurlitz, Jon and the late Robert Pariser. Funeral was held. He will be missed.

title: Quirky but Real, the Beat Goes On
description: The world might as well defer to Cher's miraculous powers, because, as she sang in one of her hits at Jones Beach on Monday night, she really can turn back time. Cher can find her way back into relevance again and again, and it's not exactly because she changes with the trends. Instead she waits, like the sentinel of an enchanted world, and judges when it's safe to open up a trade route. Her judgment has not always proven correct, but right now it is impeccable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, REV. STANLEY F.
description: GROSS-Rev. Stanley F. Died July 5, 1999 at age 77 at New York Hospital. Skiier, Mountaineer, Pilot, Priest and beloved Father and Grandfather. He was a former clergy member of St. Thomas Fifth Avenue, Church Of The Heavenly Rest and Church Of The Transfiguration (Little Church Around The Corner). He was a member of the National Ski Patrol (National Number 1805) and the former Patrol Leader at Belleayre Mountain New York. He was an extremely accomplished mountaineer and rock climber with many first ascents in the Bugaboos, Dolomites and Shawangunks. He served in the military as a Bomber Pilot during W.W. II and Korea. He was our beloved father and grandfather who taught us and loved us so much. Services will be held Thursday, July 8, 1999, 11AM at Church Of The Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) 1 East 29th Street, New York City. We miss you and love you. Tag, Bill, Laura, Harrison, Victoria

title: Sugar in the Everglades
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT J.
description: McDONALD-Robert J. June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Ann McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, June 13, 1999, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, June 14, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUGGENHEIMER, RANDOLPH
description: GUGGENHEIMER - Randolph. Age 91. Beloved husband of Elinor C. Loving father of Charles, Randolph, Jr. and Jane. Grandfather of Randolph III, Elizabeth, Steven, Julia, Lynn G. and Jonathan Horowitch, and six great-grandchildren. Interment private. Memorial service Thursday, July 8th, 11AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: North General Hospital or the charity of your choice.

title: Middle Eastern Fare, Simple and Cooling
description: WHEN the weather is really hot, the idea of eating a rich, elaborate meal is almost as repellent as spending a morning in the liquefying swelter of a subway platform. But some foods are intended for the heat. They don't tax the body with complexities or create undue internal combustion. Middle Eastern cuisine, refined over centuries under the blazing desert sun, soothes and refreshes. It stimulates the mouth with lively flavors but is generally light and healthful, allowing those who can't afford a postprandial snooze to get on with the day.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICANA JOINS STAR ALLIANCE
description: Mexico's second largest airline, Corporacion Mexicana de Aviacion S.A., announced it was joining the Star Alliance, the world's largest airline association whose members include United Airlines, Lufthansa and Singapore Airlines. When Mexicana joins the alliance next year, passengers will be able to use frequent flier credits with other member airlines. Rick Wills

title: Hoffa Chooses Leader for Reform Effort
description: James P. Hoffa, the new president of the teamsters' union, plans to hire a respected former Federal prosecutor to set up an in-house anti-corruption program for the 1.4 million-member union -- the first step in an effort to persuade the Federal Government to end its decadelong oversight of the teamsters.

title: Like an Oven, by the Oven
description: Piara Singh leaned into the 150-degree heat above the tandoori oven in the kitchen of the Jackson Diner in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday and slapped the circle of bread dough against the oven wall inside as quickly as he could.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: MONSANTO CO., St. Louis, named Hendrick A. Verfaillie chief operating officer. He remains president.

title: Searching for Good, Affordable Bordeaux
description: ONE day in June, I was sitting at the bar of the Hotel Mercure Pont d'Aquitaine here, having a cold Kronenbourg with an old friend from California, Bob Thompson. We were both in town for Vinexpo, the trade fair held in Bordeaux every two years. He buys wine for an airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMINGHAM, JANE TANNER
description: TRIMINGHAM-Jane Tanner, on June 8, in Bermuda. Survived by her children, Linda Warriner, Peter Trimingham, Thomas Trimingham, Alison Mitchell, her brother, Ogden Tanner, 8 grandchildren, & one great-grandchild. Memorial service June 14 in Bermuda. Donations to P.A.L.S., PO Box DV19, Devonshire DVBX, Bermuda.

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER TO BUY 8 CONNECTICUT PLANTS
description: The Northern States Power Company, based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that its NRG Energy unit had agreed to buy eight power plants in Connecticut from Northeast Utilities, New England's largest electric utility, for $460 million in cash. Northern States said the plants, run by Northeast's Connecticut Light and Power unit, together generated as much as 2,235 megawatts of electricity, enough to light 2.2 million homes. Northern States sells electricity to 1.5 million customers in North and South Dakota, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin. Northeast Utilities, based in Berlin, Conn., has 1.7 million customers in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

title: Mixing Up Perceptions, on Canvas and Off, in Calgary
description: Off the canvas, Chris Cran can be as elusive as one of his paintings. Certainly he exhibits all the trappings of an art world denizen: black jeans, black boots, black leather jacket. The tousled curls framing a crop of serious features. The charm. The attitude.

title: Sutton Wins Bid to Become Defendant in Apollo Theater Suit
description: Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, was granted his request yesterday to become a defendant in a lawsuit that accuses the directors of the Apollo Theater of mismanaging the Harlem landmark by failing to collect millions of dollars from Mr. Sutton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: SHARES OF DRKOOP.COM SURGE OVER AMERICA ONLINE DEAL
description: DrKoop.com Inc., an Internet site founded by the former United States Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, said yesterday that it would become the largest health information provider for America Online Inc., the No. 1 on-line service, sending DrKoop.com shares up 56 percent. The shares rose $13.25, to $36.875, adding about $365 million to the market capitalization. The company will pay America Online $89 million over four years and will give America Online warrants to purchase shares of DrKoop.com. Under the deal, the 19 million customers of America Online and its Compuserve unit will begin receiving health articles, information on diseases and other services from DrKoop.com, based in Austin, Tex., in the fall.

title: Clinton, in Poverty Tour, Focuses on Profits
description: Nothing motivates business like the prospect of profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, DOROTHY
description: ISAACSON-Dorothy (aka Petchenik) (nee Stauber) of Cherry Hill, NJ. Wife of late Philip Isaacson. Mother of the Honorable Barbara Berman and Elaine Mayers. Grandmother of Stacy Joy Berman, Jodi Lee Berman, Robert J. Berman and Jennifer Mayers. Services are on Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, New Jersey. Interment at Beth Israel Memorial Park. Contributions to the American Cancer Society or the Jewish Geriatric Home, Cherry Hill, NJ.

title: Cu Chi Journal; Visit the Vietcong's World: Americans Welcome
description: The rattle and pop of automatic weapons greet a visitor. Young women in the black pajamas of the Vietcong flit through the woods. A man in green fatigues picks his way down a narrow trail, leading a small platoon of foreign tourists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLUSKEY, OLGA NEWTON
description: McCLUSKEY-Olga Newton. On July 4. Beloved wife of the late J. Sterling McCluskey. Beloved step mother of Shirley Simms. Adored step grandmother of Carson and James Simms. Mrs. McCluskey was the founder and president of the New York Chapter of the Friends of Winston Churchill Memorial and Library at Westminster College in Fulton, Missouri and was also a member of the Board of Governors of the Winston Churchill Memorial and Library. She was awarded an M.B.E. and an O.B.E. by Queen Elizabeth for her tireless work for British charities. Interment private. A memorial service will be held Friday, July 9, at 3:30PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Winston Churchill Memorial and Library, 501 Westminster Ave, Fulton, Missouri 65251.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWLER, MIRIAM
description: KOWLER-Miriam, 87. On July 5, 1999 after a long illness. She was born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She was the beloved wife of the late Samuel and the devoted daughter of the late Solomon and Sadie Mann. She is surived by two loving sons, Daniel and Richard, dear sister Ruth and five cherished grandchildren, Suzanne, Andrew, Laura, Amelia, Carolyna.

description: They peddle hatred to children, with a brightly colored Web page featuring a coloring book of white supremacist symbols and a crossword puzzle full of racist clues.
