title: Goodwill Games Headed for Bosnia?
description: The war in Bosnia from 1992 to 1995 destroyed nearly all the athletic sites of the 1984 Winter Olympics in Sarajevo.

title: Business Travel; Some airlines are allowing customers to use cell phones while a plane is still at the departure gate.
description: PASSENGERS were still filing down the aisle. The American Airlines flight attendant had to scoot around them to pounce on the miscreant like a hall monitor cornering a school scofflaw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: I.B.M. to End Chip Deal With Toshiba
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will sell its half of a computer-chip plant to the joint owner, the Toshiba Corporation, as I.B.M., the No. 1 computer maker, scales back its low-profit memory business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRKNER, MELVIN D.
description: BIRKNER-Melvin D. On July 5, 1999, of New York City, in his 69th year. A devoted brother and dear friend. Services Thursday, July 8, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEEKES, CAROL THATCHER
description: WEEKES-Carol Thatcher, 60, died July 5 in Richmond, NH. Beloved wife of Robert and devoted mother of John (of Bloomington, IL), Jeffrey (of Stroudsburg, PA), Elizabeth (Mrs. Benjamin Kunz of Hamden, CT), Jennifer (Mrs. Daniel Koprowski of Amherst, MA) and Julia (Mrs. Joseph Spuria of Auburn, NH). She also leaves eight adoring grandchildren and a sister, Mary Louise Tate (Rye Beach, NH). Carol attended Vassar College and lived for many years in Garden City, NY where, while raising her loving family, she was employed by the Cathedral of the Incarnation. For the past 10 years, she lived with her husband of 41 years at Fox Call Farm in Richmond, NH. During this time, she served on the Vestry and Altar Guild of St. James Episcopal Church in Keene, NH, and the Board of the Fitzwilliam Garden Club, and volunteered at Applewood Nursing Home. In recognition of a life time dedicated to charitable causes, she was designated a Community Hero by the U.S. Olympic Committee in 1996 and carried the Olympic Torch as it passed through Keene on its way to the Summer Games in Atlanta. Carol was also the leader of the Monadnock Parkinson Support Group, an organization she founded in 1997. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, in Keene, NH, on Monday, July 12, at 10:30 AM. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to the American Parkinson Disease Association, 1250 Hylan Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SAMUEL
description: JACOBS-Samuel. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Samuel Jacobs. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Sam Wasserman, President

title: Blackout Stops Trains and Electricity for 200,000
description: There was a mix of chaos and calm on the streets of upper Manhattan last night as an area including some of the city's most impoverished and densely populated neighborhoods was plunged into darkness.

title: Young Australian Sprinter Will Have to Wait His Turn
description: Jay Sweet is a 23-year-old Australian in his first Tour de France who insisted beforehand that he was not intimidated by most of the greatest sprinters in bicycle racing, although in his heart he must have known that he was going to a sword fight armed with a penknife. Then, he crashed twice and badly sprained his left ankle.

title: At Last, a Vitamin Pill Wrapped in a Tortilla
description: AT last, we know what Dilbert's nameless corporation produces: burritos. But not just ordinary burritos.

title: Parcells Signs Player From Europe
description: Although Bill Parcells was one of the few coaches in the National Football League not to send a player to the N.F.L. Europe this spring, he liked one player there well enough to sign him.

title: Labor Dept. Accuses Boeing Of Blocking Inquiry Into Bias
description: In an unusual legal clash between the Government and its second-largest defense contractor, the Department of Labor filed three lawsuits against the Boeing Company yesterday, accusing it of blocking an investigation of charges of racial discrimination at the company.

title: Vegetarian, and Liking It, on the Web
description: I AM oppressed with a dread of living forever,'' George Bernard Shaw wrote when he was almost 85, adding, ''This is the only disadvantage of vegetarianism.''

title: J. Curtis Counts, 83, Nixon Friend and Labor Mediator Who Averted Conflicts
description: J. Curtis Counts, a veteran labor negotiator who directed the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service for an old friend, President Richard M. Nixon, died on June 30 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: Global Sales of Computer Chips Grow 12%
description: Worldwide sales of computer chips rose 12 percent in May from a year ago, led by surging sales in Asia and Japan, an industry trade group said today.

title: Bob Backus Is Dead at 72; World's Best Weight Thrower
description: Bob Backus, who used weight training to help overcome serious illness and became the world's best weight thrower, died on June 30 at Vencor Hospital in Boston. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: At 200 New York City Sites, Shelter for the Overheated
description: Iris Maddox had just made an executive decision. She would send somebody out for ice cream. But the temperature outside was 99 degrees, and none of the refugees from the heat volunteered to leave the city's emergency cooling center where she was the main helper.

title: Not-Guilty Plea in Slaying a Surprise to Family and Lawyer
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISE, AARON
description: WISE-Aaron, Rabbi. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. He was founding rabbi of Congregation Adat Ariel in Los Angeles in 1947 until his retirement in 1978 when he became rabbi emeritus. He was founder of Making Marriage Work at the University of Judaism. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Miriam, children Tamar and Yitzhak, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about Pokemon Pinball for the Game Boy referred incorrectly to a feature. The first cartridge to include a built-in mechanism that causes the Game Boy to vibrate is Top Gear Pocket, not Pokemon Pinball.

title: It Was a Good Day for an Air-Conditioner. Just Try to Find One.
description: After hundreds of customers demanding new air-conditioners nearly came to blows over a sidewalk delivery to P. C. Richards in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the chain store employed the extreme tactic yesterday of handing out numbers as if the buyers were waiting to order at a deli counter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, BERNARD M.
description: COLE-Bernard M. Formerly of Yonkers NY. Passed away on July 5. He was born on August 21, 1907 and graduated from Columbia University School of Pharmacy in 1930. The proprietor of Cole Pharmacy in Yonkers, he was the husband of Elizabeth (Bee) Cole who predeceased him. His children, Loraine Ehrlich of Hartsdale and Robert Cole (Ingrid) of Oakland, CA. survive him, along with five grandchildren, Steven (Deborah) Spencer, Jeffrey (Allison) Spencer, Mark (Juliet) Spencer, Anders (Shoshana) Cole, Rebecca (Eugene Brandon) Cole, six great grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Graveside services 2:30PM Thursday July 8.

title: Survey of Businesses Shows Faster Pace of Growth in June
description: Business at banks, farms, retailers and other nonfactory companies expanded in June at a faster pace than in May, a survey of corporate executives showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, RICHARD
description: STERN-Richard (Dickie). Of Cedarhurst, Long Island. Devoted husband of Joan, loving father of Kenneth, Wendy, Michael and the late Gary, cherished grandfather, dear brother of Geraldine. Service ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' Hewlett, Long Island, 9:30 AM, Wednesday.

title: The Radar New York Needs
description: It took several calamitous accidents to persuade Congress and the commercial aviation industry to develop a radar system to detect wind shear, the severe downdrafts that cause airplanes to lose control. That system is now in use or scheduled to be built nationwide -- except in New York, where politics and bureaucratic infighting in Washington have stalled the installation of devices that can give air traffic controllers advance warning.

title: Sports of The Times; A Bad Swing At the Fans By Gonzalez
description: IF you're going to throw a tantrum, make it a big one. Better to throw your snit at, say, 495,817 people, the population of Cleveland according to the latest census estimate, than to fling a pique at one.

title: Watts Up with the Heat
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Straw Poll Lures Cash From Bush
description: Only days after George W. Bush said his would be a penny-pinching Presidential operation, his campaign shelled out a remarkable $43,500 for one day's use of a plot of land outside an arena in Ames, Iowa, so that he can greet participants arriving there for a straw poll next month.

title: 6 Are Killed in Ethnic Strife in Solomon Islands
description: The Solomon Islands, the group of tropical Pacific islands that witnessed some of World War II's most intensive battles, is once again the scene of strife, this time of its own making.

title: McDonald's Heads to Court Over a Burger King Meal
description: It's just the sort of thing parents frown on -- a food fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, RUTH
description: WOLF-Ruth. Of New York City, born in Berlin and recently living at Glen Arden, Goshen NY died June 1. She lived a long, full life. Ruthie was a pioneer in creating high fashion for pets. Her successful company, Ruth Wolf Dog Accessories was known throughout the world. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. We will think of her and her dear husband Jackie every day. Gloria, Martin, Teddy and Jennifer Greenstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REVERE, BRAD
description: REVERE-Brad. Died July 5th. Long time loyal employee Lincoln Building, New York City. Funeral July 8, 1:30PM, Moravian Cemetery, Richmond Road, Staten Island.

title: As Chaplin or Lloyd Cavorts on Silent Screen, the Accompanist Keeps Up
description: They cannot take their eyes off the movie screen for more than a few seconds.

title: Brazil's Leader Undercut By His Quarreling Allies
description: The Brazilian Congress has adjourned for a midwinter recess, and probably no one is happier than President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who has repeatedly seen his political program and personal prestige sapped by squabbling among the parties that supposedly support him.

title: What's Bright and Shady in the Heat?
description: TALK about pitching a tent and putting on a show. Every summer come May, Georges Piette, a construction consultant, and Skip Dailey, an insurance broker, rig a 15-foot-by-12-foot roof of awning fabric in the garden behind their Park Slope row house, to entertain their friends beneath and to stage a little privacy for themselves.

title: Marimekko Didn't Go Away, It's Just Been Sleeping
description: In the 1960's and 70's, women wore chartreuse and yellow Marimekko checks. Men wore black and gray Marimekko stripes. Children's sheets were blue with red trucks. In 1991, Marimekko, a Finnish company, closed its Manhattan store. Although Crate and Barrel sells Marimekko bedding and Kiitos/Marimekko, 698 Madison Avenue (62d Street), sells its clothes and some fabrics, the company has kept a low profile of late. But this month, more than 100 Marimekko designs, some new, some old but recolored, are being introduced by DelGreco Textiles. They include Fujiwo Ishimoto's Aatto, top; Siesta, left, and Puistokatu, above, in linen ($93 a yard). To the trade at DelGreco, 232 East 59th Street; (212) 688-5310.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSELMAN, BERNARD
description: KESSELMAN-Bernard. July 6, 1999, New York, New York. Born February 7, 1909. Loving husband of Ethel and father of Laura & Amy. Devoted grandfather of James, Rachel, Athena and Bernard. He was a dedicated teacher for 50 years as well as an activist in the New York City Teachers' Union. Called before a government committee investigating Communist Party membership, he was forced to retire from the public school system, but soon resumed teaching at Woodmere Academy, where he was a favorite among students and faculty. A lover of gardening and music, his intellect and charm will be missed by many. A memorial service will be held at 4PM July 10 at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 W. 64th St.

title: Applying Lessons of Ikebana, Arranging Nature and Art
description: THE first thing people notice about Robert Homma is his three-foot-long braid. It gleams, it moves, and it ends just below his waist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, GEORGE S.
description: DILLON-George S. The volunteers and staff of the March of Dimes note with sorrow the passing of our former Chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime friend. Mr. Dillon, a volunteer for nearly 40 years, was a member of the Board from 1972 to 1990 and served as Chairman from 1980 to 1984. From 1990 he served as an Honorary Trustee. His dedication to excellence in our biomedical research program and his concern for saving babies from birth defects, prematurity, and low birth weight will be greatly missed. Our deep condolences to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNELLY, PATRICK J.
description: HENNELLY-Patrick J. on July 7, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Della. Loving father of Michael and Michele. Dear brother of John, May and the late Michael, also a dear uncle to many. Reposing Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. (W. 261st St.), Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial 10 AM Friday at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to VNS Hospice of NYC, 1250 Broadway 4th Floor, New York, NY 10001 would be deeply appreciated.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: SUMMER BOOK CLUB -- Public libraries learned long ago that if you want to get children to read books over the summer, you probably need to dangle a prize before their eyes. Now a new Web site called Book Adventure has brought the same concept to the Internet. The site, www.bookadventure.com, offers prizes to children who earn points for successfully answering on-line questions about the books they have read. Points can be redeemed for prizes, like gift certificates to Barnesandnoble.com.

The animals aren't roaming free, but ''the design is to look as if they're free,'' said John A. Gwynne, the director for design of the Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs the zoo.

title: In America; Two Victims
description: On the evening of May 18, 1982, a woman who was visiting a nature preserve with her husband in Buffalo, N.Y., was attacked and raped. The woman had walked away from her husband and was on an isolated path when the attack occurred. She told police she had been heading back to their parked car, where she had planned to sit and read.

title: Mets' Lost Day: Franco, Ventura and the Game

Ventura was off balance after trying to avoid the pitch and he stumbled to the dirt, landing awkwardly on his already bent left knee and his already aching foot.

title: Man-Made Breezes to Help Tame the Heat
description: WHEW! When it's this hot, circulating air is critical. ''It cools the body more rapidly than stagnant air,'' said Dr. Scott Kalish, a doctor of emergency medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital. ''And it's easier to breathe if air is moving.'' So, while fans don't actually cool the air, they can, if properly positioned, assist air-conditioning by directing air your way. Moreover, new features like remote controls, timers with sleep cycles, even mechanisms that mimic nature's variable breezes can customize your comfort.

title: Messiaen's Private Music for Organ
description: Messiaen treated the organ as his private musical instrument. It was hardly private in its power and scope, but it was secluded, removed from the world at large by virtue of where it was. While other instruments go out and meet the public, church organists -- and Messiaen was one all his adult life -- invite the public almost as an afterthought. Their function is liturgical, with God and a congregation as primary audience.

title: For Books, It Pays To Surf Around
description: PARIS  People around the world who want to buy books in English know about Amazon.com and its arch-competitor, barnesandnoble.com. Both of those on-line booksellers do substantial mail-order business outside the United States. The Web has made available millions of books that were previously hard to come by outside English-speaking countries.

description: McEWEN-Dolores. The League Treatment Center's Board, staff and children send our deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Mark McEwen and his family, on the loss of his mother. Our prayers are with you.

title: Toyota Is Seeking to Stop Use of Seniority to Set Pay
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker, is negotiating with its union to eliminate seniority as a major factor in determining the salaries of white-collar workers.

title: I.B.M. WINS $1.2 BILLION CONTRACT FROM FRENCH RETAILER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had won a $1.2 billion contract to run computer systems for the French retailer Galeries Lafayette S.A. Under the 15-year contract, the largest of its kind in France, I.B.M. will manage the computer network for the Galeries Lafayette department stores and Cofinoga, its credit card supplier. About 280 Galeries Lafayette workers will become I.B.M. employees in the next four years. I.B.M. also disclosed separate pacts with the National Road and Motorists Association of Australia and Ace Ltd. The three agreements combined are worth about $2 billion.

title: Cool Falling Water Makes for a Warm Welcome
description: First impressions count; sometimes they can also soothe. For cancer patients at the Laurance S. Rockefeller Outpatient Pavilion at 160 East 53d Street, part of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the first image is of water trickling down a slate wall framed by bronze willow branches, below. The water wall, by Cliff Garten, a Los Angeles sculptor, is designed to comfort. Mary-Jean Eastman, the Manhattan architect who designed the pavilion, said, ''It's about hospitality.'' The pavilion, which opened last month, has a water garden on each floor, living plants, a television set for amusement, and free fresh fruit and espresso. Honey-colored maple, ash and pear add warmth to the spaces.

title: Tobacco Industry Loses First Phase Of Broad Lawsuit
description: A Florida jury yesterday found against the nation's biggest tobacco companies in the first class-action case to reach a verdict, holding that they conspired to hide the danger and addictiveness of cigarettes.

title: Answers Are Sought on Blackout's Causes
description: Shortly after 10 on Tuesday night, after hours of work on seven short-circuited power cables serving the north end of Manhattan, Consolidated Edison workers prepared to turn two of them back on. The goal was to restore electricity to 15,000 customers who had been without power all that scorching day and much of the night before.

title: Rushmore to Buy Two Day-Trading Firms
description: Rushmore Financial Group Inc. said today that it would buy two day-trading firms in a continued expansion of its on-line investing business.

title: Woman, 18, Drowns in a City Pool in Brooklyn
description: An 18-year-old woman died yesterday after she was found unconscious on the bottom of an outdoor municipal pool in Brooklyn -- the same pool where two other swimmers have drowned in the last 11 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, FRANK L.
description: MORTON-Frank L. Age 87, of Boca Raton, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY. On Tuesday, July 6, 1999 at Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton. Beloved husband of Edith Morton & the late Gladys Morton. Loving father of Dr. Robert Morton & Dr. Joyce Johnson, devoted grandfather of David Morton, Courtney Morton and Gabriel Johnson. Survived by brother, Dr. Leonard Morton & loving relatives and friends. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 7205 West Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach on Friday, July 9, 1999, 10 AM.

title: Sports of The Times; Americans Still Dine Together
description: BACK a few decades, there was a Boston Red Sox team so dysfunctional that a night on the road was described as 25 players going off in 25 taxis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ABRAHAM S.
description: BAUM-Abraham S. 90 years. Of Spring Valley, NY, formerly of Lake Worth, FL. and Scarsdale, NY. Suddenly on June 8, 1999. Husband for 62 years of the late Mae Weiner Baum. Retired CPA and Past District Deputy Grand Master 8th Masonic District of Manhattan. Loving father of Betye and Alan Wasserman, Spring Valley, NY and Stanley and Louise Baum of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of Roberta Ginsberg, Andrew Wasserman, Rachel Baum and Lauren Baum, and great-grandfather. Graveside services today, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Why Racial Gap Persists in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Showers, Rotting Food, Then Lights, Then Dancing
description: Seven months after surviving open-heart surgery, Richard Carter had no intention of being done in by a blackout.

title: As Plain as the 'Nose' on Your Chip
description: OF all the senses, the realm of smell remained relatively mysterious and unexplored by technology until very recently. Now scientists and engineers are beginning to build electronic noses, and the race is on to create palm-size machines and find applications for them.

title: Common Ground Elusive as Technology Have-Nots Meet Haves
description: FOR the average Internet user in the United States, life is a never-ending stream of dilemmas: Upgrade now or later. Order I.S.D.N. or wait for cable modem service to arrive. Buy the Palm V organizer or go with the one that connects to the Web. Check E-mail while on vacation or leave the laptop at home.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: U.S. Sand Supplier Is Sold
description: Hanson P.L.C., the second-largest building materials producer in Britain, said today that one of its units had purchased the closely held Tidewater Sand and Gravel Inc. of Oakland, Calif., for $44 million. The deal, part of a program of acquisitions by Hanson, was for cash. Hanson said that a subsidiary, Hanson Building Materials America Inc., had acquired Tidewater and its affiliate, the Moe Sand Company. Tidewater Sand is the largest producer of marine-dredged aggregates in the San Francisco Bay area. It had revenue of 1998 of $15.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, JOHN J.
description: SULLIVAN-John J. Dear husband of Christina. Cherished father of Lynn, Craig and Jeffery. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72 St., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11 AM. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, CT.

title: All Nature Mourns Late Leader, North Korea Says
description: Flowers are said to be blossoming out of season in North Korea as nature joins the people in expressing admiration for President Kim Il Sung on the fifth anniversary of his death.

title: Adding Access In Israel
description: Right now, a visit to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem requires stamina, for climbing a hill and darting in and out of doors. So, James Ingo Freed, who designed the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, is creating a new entrance pavilion and visitor center for it. His design, above, will bring visitors through a three-sided corridor and a curved building encircling a cube. ''I took the curve of Noguchi's mud sculptures on the western slope of the hill,'' Mr. Freed said, referring to Isamu Noguchi's garden created in the 1960's, ''and joined it to the existing cubist shapes.'' New buildings will house an auditorium, lecture rooms and restaurants. Martin Gruss, a Manhattan investor, donated $42 million of the $50 million cost of the 130,000-square-foot project. Construction will begin in 2001.

title: You've Got Mail: Hello Muddah (and CC: Faddah)
description: THEY are not quite jumping through hoops, but camp counselors have to be pretty creative to get their campers to write home during the summer. On certain nights at some camps, getting a seat in the dining hall is contingent upon presentation of a letter, addressed and stamped. Contests in which letters are drawn from a hat, with the winning writer getting a free trip to the canteen, are also common.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, H. BOONE
description: PORTER-H. Boone. The Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter, one of the Episcopal Church's most influential priests and thinkers and whose many achievements include the 1979 revision of the Book of Common Prayer, died on Saturday, June 5. An author, artist, educator and philanthropist, he was 76 and lived in Southport, Connecticut. The vision of the Rev. Dr. Canon H. Boone Porter's 44 years of ordained ministry aimed to revitalize the Episcopal Church through education, liturgical reform and inclusion of its marginalized members. His work of raising up new leadership, enriching Christian worship and creating a central place for women, Afro-and Native Americans and rural communities in the Church was often opposed but succeeded in redefining the Episcopal Church's relationships within itself and with the world. The Rev. Ralph McMichael, a noted professor at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, Wis., recently commented: '' Dr. Porter's ministry has been, and continues to be, so rich and varied that it is hard to designate his legacy in the Episcopal Church in one or two ways. He is liturgical scholar, professor, pastor, editor and missioner. He has shaped our liturgy, our parishes, our prayer book, our publications and our view of ministry and mission of the Church. A descendant of the family of early American explorers, the Boones, Dr. Porter was born in Louisville, KY into a prosperous business family (his father founded the Porter Pain Company) and showed an early interest in the beauty and mystery of nature and humanity. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and his study of art and philosophy at Yale College in the 1940's was interrupted by World War II. He fought in the Pacific Theater, where he served with Army Intelligence during General MacArthur's campaign to retake the Philippines and occupy Japan. After the war, Dr. Porter completed his studies at Yale and entered the Berkeley Divinity School, also in New Haven. There, under the direction of Dr. Edward Hardy, he began his study of liturgy and worship that later became his foremost and world renowned expertise. This led him to read for a doctorate in early Christian baptismal rites at Oxford University in England in 1952. In 1954 he returned to the United States to teach Church History at Nashotah House Episcopal Seminary near Milwaukee, WI. Four years later, Dr. Porter became the first tenured professor of liturgy at General Theological Seminary in New York City, the Episcopal Church's oldest theological seminary. There he served on committees at the Episcopal Church's National Headquarters, 815 Second Avenue and his graduate program liturgy attracted and shaped key people in the next generation of Church leadership.

title: Boeing Picks G.E. to Build Engine for Its Long-Range 777 Jet
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had chosen the General Electric Company to build the world's most powerful jet engine for a new ultra-long-range version of its wide-body 777 jetliner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENREICH, JOSEPH I.
description: SONNENREICH-Joseph I. Joe's life enriched us all by virtue of his goodness, his integrity, his wisdom, and his pride in family achievements. We shall ''Sing his Praise'' as we honor him, in loving remembrance of his life, at services today Thursday, June 10, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:30 AM. The Sonnenreich Family

title: Seek -- but on the Web, You Might Not Find
description: Search engines just cannot keep up with the Web. That is the finding of two scientists for the NEC Research Institute who have spent the past six months determining how many Web pages exist -- and how many are actually picked up by the likes of Alta Vista and Yahoo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR
description: KRISTELLER-Paul Oskar. Columbia University Libraries mourn the passing of Paul Oskar Kristeller, Woodbridge Professor Emeritus of Philosophy in the University, scholar, benefactor and friend of libraries and librarians around the world.

title: CHINA CLOSES COMPANY
description: China's financial regulators ordered the closing of one of Shanghai's largest trust and investment companies, citing a crushing debt load. The company, the Pudong Lianhe Trust and Investment Corporation, was formed only three years ago to finance commercial property projects. It was a victim of the property glut that devastated real estate prices and left many buildings vacant. Pudong Lianhe has assets of about $850 million, and debt of about $1.2 billion. The debt will be taken over by the Agricultural Bank of China, the principal shareholder. Seth Faison

title: A Summons to Peace
description: Israel's new Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, is acting like a statesman. With an eloquent inaugural speech Tuesday and plans for a quick round of meetings with Arab leaders before visiting President Clinton next week, he seems committed to reviving the stalled quest for Mideast peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LOUIS
description: GOLDSTEIN-Louis. On July 6, 1999 at age 85; loving husband of Magda (Blaufeld); cherished father of Julie Ellis and Susan Goldstein; caring father-in-law of Charles Ellis and Joseph Crucilla; sweet papa of Jonathan Ellis and Sarah Crucilla. Survivor of the Holocaust; beloved patriarch of his entire extended family; generous; selfless; the personification of good. We will miss you. Donations to U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC.

title: In Norway, A Nanny Standard For Movies
description: A country where violent films and videos are banned, pornographic cinemas are nonexistent, and advertisers are forbidden to focus on children was probably not what President Clinton had in mind this summer when he challenged Hollywood to tone down its act.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LUNA, GEORGE C.
description: DE LUNA-George C. Beloved husband of Barbara. Cherished father of George, Robert, and John. Devoted son of Dorothea. Loving brother of Eugene. A career banking executive, George de Luna was revered internationally for his insightful analyses and accurate predictions in foreign currency exchange. Over 30 years he served as vice president at Citibank, Security Pacific and Irving Trust, working in New York, London and Toronto. A graduate of Colby College, he held degrees in psychology, math and physics. Epitomizing integrity and honesty, he was 66 when he died on July 6 following a battle with cancer. He will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers please send donations to prostate cancer research, Medical Oncology, Columbia Presbyterian.

title: Darkness Puts a Hospital Into Emergency Mode
description: Victor Ordonez, a 55-year-old blood cancer patient, went without a shower yesterday and his bathroom was pitch black. But the power failure that had hobbled New York Presbyterian Hospital -- darkening hallways, canceling surgeries, closing clinics and shutting down the air-conditioning -- came as a relief to him.

title: Vallone's Son Considers Run For His Father's Council Seat
description: In a city where political dynasties are nearly as common as politicians, the prospect of yet another son following in his father's footsteps does not often make waves. But the possibility that Peter F. Vallone Jr., a son of the well-connected and influential City Council Speaker, may succeed his father on the Council is something that has politicians throughout the city talking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, MICHAEL TAFT
description: WELCH-Michael Taft. Former Chairman of the Credit Policy Committee of Citicorp, now part of Citigroup, and a member of its Policy Committee died July 3, 1999 after a long illness. Mr. Welch of Scarborough, New York and Bray's Island, South Carolina was a well known international banker in the energy industry working in this country and abroad. Prior to heading up the bank's credit policy area he was the Division Head for Northern Europe based in London and later Global Energy Head. Shortly before his retirement in 1998, Mr. Welch was Managing Director for Energy and Mining in Citicorp's ''emerging markets'' area. Born in Tulsa, Oklahoma in 1942, Mr. Welch was a Magna Cum Laude graduate of Princeton University and earned an MBA from Harvard University. He served in the U.S Navy for three years. At the time of his death, Mr. Welch was a member of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Briarcliff Manor, New York. He is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Ruegg and his daughter, M. Alexandra Bayha of South Orange, New Jersey. Burial will be private. The date and time of a memorial service will be announced shortly. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Cancer Care, 1180 Avenue of the Americas, New York, New York 10036.

title: Plants and Company, Styled to the Max
description: LAST week, as garden designers labored under a brutal sun to create instant gardens for the Garden Design Show at Mecox Gardens, in Southampton, N.Y., the plants were not only wilting from the heat -- they were being buried under Style.

title: Energy Secretary Agrees to Idea of Agency on Nuclear Weapons
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said today that he would work with Congress to establish a more independent nuclear weapons program as a remedy for security problems, but key details of the proposed reorganization are still in dispute, officials said.

title: 18-Hour Blackout Ends as Heat Fades
description: After a blackout that lasted nearly 19 hours, power was restored to most of northern Manhattan yesterday, but unimpressed city officials angrily threatened legal action against Con Edison, saying the utility had failed to build a power system able to withstand intense heat waves.

title: Computer Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: A Virtual Reality That's Best Escaped
description: VIRTUAL reality can offer users a chance to enter into a variety of fantasies. Most are appealing. But at a recent meeting of the American Psychiatric Association, psychiatrists, and others could spend three to five minutes experiencing an animated version of the auditory and visual hallucinations that plague many schizophrenics.

title: Higher-Speed Lines Leave Door Ajar for Hackers
description: ABOUT two weeks after Frank Keeney was first connected to cable modem service in Pasadena, Calif., he discovered that along with the delights of a 24-hour connection and high-speed Internet access came the potential for big trouble.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMARCO INC., Santa Ana, Calif., a provider of wireless products and services, will sell its services businesses to focus on wireless communications and increase shareholder value.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORGAN, JOSEPH A., (REVEREND)
description: DORGAN-Joseph A., (Reverend), S.J. July 6, 1999. Brother of William J. Dorgan of Lancaster, PA. Entered Society of Jesus 1943, ordained June 26, 1956. Friends may call at St. Ignatius Residence, 53 East 83rd. Street, Friday, July 9th, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of The Resurrection, Saturday, July 10, 1999 at 11:00 AM, at St. Ignatius Church, Park Avenue at 84th St.

title: Prison Sentence For Baron Broker
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan sentenced Roman Okin, formerly the star salesman at A. R. Baron & Company, a brokerage house that collapsed three years ago, to three to nine years in jail yesterday for his role in defrauding investors of millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, FRANCIS J.
description: DALY-Francis J. Of East Moriches on July 6, 1999. Beloved husband of Muriel, devoted father of Michael Daly and Eleanor Kobel, dear brother of Helen McLaughlin, the late AnneMarie McCullogh, the late Monsignor Thomas R. Daly and the late Raymond Daly, also survived by 3 grandchildren. Mr. Daly was a member for over 50 years and past president of the Fire Bell Club of New York and an Honorary Fire Chief of the City of New York. Reposing Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Road, Westhampton Beach. Funeral Mass Friday at 10 AM at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in memory of Mr. Daly may be sent to the NYC Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, N.Y. 10475.

title: Video Game Worker Dismissed For Selling Fantasy Real Estate
description: A popular expression about real estate is ''they're not making more of it.'' But when it comes to virtual real estate, a video game employee not only made more of it -- he lost his job for selling some over the Internet.

title: The Blackout and Its Causes
description: New Yorkers and their political leaders responded admirably to Tuesday night's power shortages, including a sudden blackout in the Washington Heights and Inwood neighborhoods of Manhattan. Though trapped in darkness and suffocating heat, thousands of residents north of 155th Street displayed the kind of grit and grace that made for a largely peaceful night. The Giuliani administration, meanwhile, successfully scrambled to insure public safety and offer aid and shelter for those who needed it, thereby discouraging the violence that marked the 1977 citywide blackout. In fact, every major player in this heat and power crisis performed creditably, except for Consolidated Edison.

title: The Big City; Grand Designs Warrant Wary Looks
description: SOME of the world's most illustrious architects have grand designs for the 12 blocks between Pennsylvania Station and the Hudson River. Their schemes, unveiled last week at a competition sponsored by the Canadian Center for Architecture, call for parks and hotels, a riverfront stadium, a new Madison Square Garden and a glass-covered commons big enough to hold 90,000 people.

title: Thor Kappfjell, 32, a Daredevil Who Leapt to Fame in New York
description: Thor Axel Kappfjell, a parachutist who frustrated the police and entertained the public with daredevil leaps from some of the world's tallest buildings, including the World Trade Center, the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building in New York, was killed on Tuesday after he miscalculated a stunt jump from a cliff in Norway, The Associated Press reported. He was 32 and lived in Drammen, Norway.

title: Addition to Consumers' Arsenal: net Complaint Services for Hire
description: GIVEN the service economy's hire-someone-else mentality, which leads some people to pay others to walk the dog and tutor the children in baseball, it is no wonder that you can now hire Internet businesses to complain on your behalf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, SEENA
description: CUTLER-Seena. Of Great Neck. Beloved wife of the late B. Robert Cutler. Devoted mother of Andrew and Sindy and Rabbi Matthew and Sharon. Cherished grandmother of Brooke, Alexa, Benjamin, Micah and Julia. Loving sister of Howard and Annette Schwartz of California. Service Friday, 11 AM at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, King's Point, New York.

title: Ford Hires Another BMW Executive
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had hired the president of BMW North America to help build Ford's worldwide luxury car brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, TED E. SR. M D.
description: BECKER-Ted E. Sr. M D. The Child Analysts of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute mourn the loss of their esteeemed colleague, Dr. Ted E. Becker Sr. He had a unique ability to understand children, and was an outstanding and gifted child analyst. He was responsible for training a generation of child analysts during the years he chaired the Child Analysts Committee. His interest, enthusiasm and commitment to child analysis, his skills as a teacher and supervisor, his personal warmth, his directness and integrity, served as an inspiration and model for us all, and drew many to the study of child analysis. He was our friend and guiding spirit. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Dr. Amy Becker, and to his family.

title: U.S. Officials Say Aid for Terrorists Came Through Two Persian Gulf Nations
description: United States officials say they believe that two suspected terrorists wanted by the F.B.I. have received help through two Persian Gulf countries with close ties to Washington, complicating the Administration's counterterrorism efforts.

title: Vaccine in Mice Offers Hope In Fight Against Alzheimer's
description: Scientists working with mice have developed a vaccine that has proved highly effective in both preventing and reversing one of the primary brain abnormalities associated with Alzheimer's disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEAGUE, MICHAEL
description: TEAGUE-Michael. Scholar, author, historian, photographer, and dear friend to many died on June 25, 1999, in Washington DC. British born, Mr. Teague was educated at Harrow and Oxford University and spent a number of years working in Portugal and Brazil before coming to the United States. Mr. Teague's authored works include Mrs. L-Conversations With Alice Roosevelt Longworth. In addition, Mr. Teague's photographs of Portuguese 18th century architecture and historic Portuguese sailing vessels have been published and exhibited in cultural centers and museums around the world. In recent years, Mr. Teague played an active role in fostering cultural exchange between the United States and Portugal, devoting considerable time and energy to the establishment and maintenance of ongoing programs on behalf of the American Portuguese Society. Although we will miss him greatly, he will always be with us. We are indeed blessed he was part of our lives. Kurt P. Ross Guy B. Lawrence Monie Begley Astrid Krevitz

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about Americans celebrating the Fourth of July misstated the organization membership of 10-year-old Austin Spade. He is a Webelos Scout, a member of the senior division of the Cub Scout program -- not yet a Boy Scout.

title: G.O.P. to Seek Cut in Capital Gains Tax
description: House Republicans said today that they would seek to cut the top tax rate on long-term capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent as part of the big tax-cutting bill they will take up next week in the face of opposition from President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ELIZABETH (ELSE)
description: STERN-Elizabeth (Else). Wife of the late Fred Stern. Survived by her beloved daughter Lorie Alexander, grandchildren Leslye Alexander and Jeff Alexander, and great-grandchildren Rachel and Jonathan. Predeceased by her beloved son-in-law Harold Alexander and by her sister Stefanie Kudesh. Born 1903, in Bad Hamburg, Germany, Mrs. Stern's heroism in smuggling monies outside Germany to sponsors enabled members of her family to escape Nazi Germany. With her husband, she helped establish a premier chocolate company in the U.S., Koppers Chocolate. Her family will miss her keen intelligence, beauty, grace and dignity with which she carried herself through the 20th Century. Services private.

title: Disney Settles Bitter Suit With Former Studio Chief
description: The Walt Disney Company and Jeffrey Katzenberg, its former studio chief, announced the settlement today of a rancorous lawsuit filed by Mr. Katzenberg that had opened a curtain on the lives of Hollywood moguls whose egos, financial bonanzas and personal furies are usually kept veiled.

title: Ericsson Abruptly Ousts Its Chief Executive
description: Ericsson A.B., the Swedish telecommunications company that is the world's third-largest mobile telephone producer, ousted its chief executive today in a surprise move only 15 months after his appointment, sending its stock spiraling down nearly 8 percent.

title: Hewlett-Packard to Shut Down Production of a Cult Favorite
description: Before there was Palm Pilot mania, there was Palmtop mania. The Palmtop 200LX was the latest in the LX line made by Hewlett-Packard. A tiny notebook (weighing less than a pound), it was the last popular PC to be made to run on MS-DOS.

title: Port of Choice: Easy U.S.B.'s
description: Q. I have a new Pentium III PC and a printer that can work with U.S.B. or parallel connections. Which should I use to hook up the printer?

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARBROUGH, MARK, M.D.
description: YARBROUGH-Mark, M.D. The Department of Psychiatry, Weill Medical College of Cornell University, New York Presbyterian Hospital, is deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our respected colleague and friend, Dr. Mark Yarbrough, who completed adult and child and adolescent residencies at the Payne Whitney Clinic. We mourn his loss and extend great sympathy to his family. The family requests that donations be sent to: Mark Yarbrough Memorial Fund, Payne Whitney Clinic, 525 East 68th St, NY, NY 10021, Attn: Dr. Theodore Shapiro, Box 140. Jack D. Barchas, M.D., Psychiatrist-in-Chief Philip J. Wilner, M.D. Medical Director Elizabeth L. Auchincloss, M.D. Director of Residency Training Theodore Shapiro, M.D., Director Child Psychiatry Stefan Stein, M.D., Professor Professor of Clinical Psychiatry

title: Immigration Hurdle
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Museum's Restructuring Sows Fear Among U.S. Curators
description: Since Malcolm Rogers took over as its director five years ago, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has been riding pretty high. Attendance has jumped, many exhibitions have won praise, and the museum's once-precarious finances have been shored up.

title: Naysayers, Thriving in the Heat
description: In 1896, with the Industrial Revolution as his backdrop, Svante Arrhenius, a Nobel prize-winning chemist, first theorized that the mass consumption of fossil fuels -- coal, oil and natural gas -- would gradually push earth's temperature upward. He calculated that in the distant centuries to come, humanity would flourish in a more benevolent climate, one that would open up the sparsely settled reaches of the Northern Hemisphere to agriculture and to commerce as never before.

title: In Feisty Takeover Battle, Devil May Be in the Snacks
description: In the world of mergers and acquisitions, the best negotiations amount to something of a poker game. Never let your opponent know what you are thinking. Show your hand only when you must. And always serve good snacks.

title: A 4th Republican Blocks a Vote on Holbrooke's Confirmation
description: The long-delayed nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to become chief American diplomat to the United Nations hit a new snag today, as another Republican Senator disclosed that he was blocking a final Senate vote on the nomination.

title: On the Beach Without Tom
description: This is the summer of no Tom Clancy novel, and one would have thought that publishers of that loosely defined genre, men's action fiction, would have stocked the bookstores with contenders. Surprisingly, they haven't. One publisher said that everyone was afraid of Hannibal Lecter, a genre unto himself, who is loose again atop the best-seller lists.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORRIGAN, PAUL
description: CORRIGAN-Paul. Gone too soon, lovingly remembered on his birthday. P.

title: Editorial Observer; Making Political Hay on Mr. Moynihan's Farm
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's upstate farm went into full media alert for Hillary Rodham Clinton's visit. The Moynihan barn was cleaned out to make room for portable toilets by the Senator's chief of staff, who swore he had done it voluntarily on his day off. The hay was cut, baled and replaced by a field full of satellite dishes.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Computers Open a Window on the Body
description: VISIBLE HUMAN CD MALE 2.0

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! (And It Wobbles?)
description: POOR Superman. First kryptonite, now video games. Judging from a new Nintendo 64 cartridge named for its superhero, nothing is as detrimental to the Man of Steel as a game controller. In a virtual environment, Superman seems all too human.

title: Waste Management Shares Fall 36% on Profit Warning
description: Skittish investors sent shares of Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest trash hauler, into free fall yesterday, a day after the company warned analysts that revenue and earnings for the second quarter were much lower than anyone had expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MIRIAM SCADRON
description: STONE-Miriam Scadron. June 6, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Melvin Stone, mother of Deborah, Fred and Doug. She was an accomplished musical composer and dedicated wife and mother. Memorial service Thursday, June 10, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Walt Disney Settles Suit With Former Studio Chief

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RAYMOND
description: RICHMAN-Raymond. Of Melbourne, Florida. Loving father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. February 22, 1908-June 8, 1999.

title: Karadut Journal; On a Peak in Turkey, Closing In on a Fabled Tomb
description: Hidden in a chamber deep inside a mountain in remote southeastern Turkey, guarded by giant busts of gods and kings carved more than 20 centuries ago, lies the tomb of an ancient king that may contain great riches.

title: Hill Faces A Choice: Fordham Or Greece
description: Bob Hill got in his car in San Antonio last night and drove to Dallas, hoping that somewhere along the way he would come to a decision.

title: A Rambling Trapeze Troupe Aims To Evoke Every Emotion but Fear
description: During their days in the circus, a half-dozen young French trapeze artists always felt ready to perform for longer than their allotted time. They were also convinced that the public wanted more of them too. So six years ago they founded a new company, Les Arts Sauts, dedicated exclusively to the flying trapeze. And to distance themselves from circus tradition, they then added music and mystery to their show. They have not looked down since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNAWAY, WALTER HUBERT
description: DUNAWAY-Walter Hubert. Retired EVP of Jeffries Avlon, Inc., NY, NY, June 7, 1999 in Lumpkin, Georgia. A Navy Veteran of the Korean War, he was a survivor of the USS Cochino which went down in the North Sea in 1949. Survived by wife Colleen of Lumpkin, GA (formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY); daughter Elizabeth Levin of Berkeley Heights, NJ; brothers John & Royce and sister Carolyn Taylor and two grandchildren. Donations in his memory to the Lumpkin, GA Volunteer Fire Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDEA, THOMAS J.
description: GILDEA-Thomas J. Of Saddle River, New Jersey, died on July 6, 1999 at his home. Beloved husband of Isabel Gaye Bulick Gildea, her children Susan Reynolds, Jeff and Bill Bulick, his stepsons, Drew and David Ferrari whose mother Jane Becton died in 1978. Loving uncle of Charles A. Gildea of Saddle River, Sharon Christ of Wyckoff and Mary Ann Kelleher of Bedford, New Hampshire. He was a specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange for 39 years, retiring as a partner with MJ Meehan and Company in 1985. He was a long time volunteer at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, New Jersey. The family will receive relatives and friends Saturday from 9:00 to 9:45 AM in the Msgr. Kavin Center, located behind St. Gabriel the Archangel RC Church, 88 E. Saddle River Road, Saddle River, New Jersey. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10:00AM in the main church, with interment to follow in Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ. As there are no visiting hours at the funeral home, donations instead of flowers to the Valley Hospital Auxiliary, c/o The Valley Hospital, Linwood and North Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ 07450 would be appreciated by the family. Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood NJ 201-444-7650.

title: Air Canada Prepares for Strike Threatened by Flight Attendants
description: The possibility of air travel chaos in Canada loomed closer today as negotiators sought to avert a strike threatened for early Thursday by flight attendants of Air Canada, the nation's largest airline.

title: Despite Upward Rate Pressure, Key Gauges Set Records
description: The three most popular stock market averages pushed to record closings yesterday despite upward pressure on interest rates and general disregard for shares of smaller companies, which fell.

title: Clinton, Amid the Despair on a Reservation, Again Pledges Help
description: Offering tax credits, loan guarantees and other incentives to encourage private businesses to create jobs and housing, President Clinton swept into the destitute Oglala Lakota Sioux reservation today, by many measures the sickest, most hopeless, most squalid corner of America.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. In life you were always joyfully there. You are gone 13 years but you are still here. Everlasting love, Harry

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; I.M.F. LOAN APPROVED
description: The International Monetary Fund's board voted to approve a $4.2 billion credit for Mexico in hopes of safeguarding the country against a currency crisis during next year's presidential election. The I.M.F. loan, which will be paid out in seven installments in the next 17 months, is part of a larger credit package under which the country will also have access to loans from the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank and the United States Eximbank. Financial crises have occurred in Mexico during each presidential transition since 1976. Rick Wills

title: Franco Could Miss Rest of the Season
description: John Franco is facing the possibility that he may miss the rest of the regular season with a finger injury.

Interment will be private.

title: G.M. Internet Sales Hit Snag in Texas
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, has been denied a license to sell used cars directly to Houston customers through the Internet because Texas does not let manufacturers own or control dealerships.

title: When the Home PC Is a Homemade PC
description: SHORTLY after 2 A.M. on a Sunday last January, my wife and baby daughter, and even the cat curled up at my feet, were asleep. But I could not have been more awake.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery numbers yesterday misstated the result of the New York Win 4 game. The correct number was 6169.

title: TENNIS; A Competitor in Lace
description: When she takes the court, the biggest winner in the history of the United States Tennis Association wears lace: lace dress with lace sleeves, lace socks and a lace wristband, and if need be, she will bring a knee bandage lined with lace. And she always has pearls around her neck. Dodo Cheney takes her style seriously.

title: It's a Land Of the Free (Computer)
description: SWEPT up in the phenomenal rush of the global Internet that it helped create, the personal computer industry is undergoing a fundamental transformation.

title: Police Say Woman Stabs Man Who Attacked Her
description: A woman who said she had just been raped in Far Rockaway, Queens, was helped by several passers-by to overcome and then stab the man she said was her attacker, the police said. The wounded man, a convicted rapist on parole, was hospitalized in stable condition, the police said.

title: Defense Dept. Urges Industry To Cooperate With Europe
description: The Pentagon is pursuing a new policy of encouraging trans-Atlantic mergers and joint ventures in the military industry, and is beginning direct talks with European allies and major contractors in Europe.

description: COGGIN-James Radford. Prominent NY luthier, died of cancer July 6. Survived by sisters Lola Wilhelm and Hazel Herring. He is missed by friends, and musicians who play his violins and violas.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Nasdaq's Tarzan Complex; Big Swings in Opening Prices Prompt Calls for Change
description: When DrKoop.com announced an $89 million deal on Tuesday to provide its health-information services to the 17 million subscribers of America Online, investors rushed to trade both stocks. Those who bought and sold America Online shares in the opening minutes of trading all got close to the same price, but those who traded DrKoop.com got prices that varied by as much as $2 a share on a $35 stock.

description: O'BRIEN-Sister Cecelia. On June 8, 1999. She was a member of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd for over 55 years and will be greatly missed by all. She is also survived by her brother Thomas, her sister Rita, and many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St) NYC, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45 AM Saturday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Monday at Mt. St. Benedict's Cemetery, West Roxbury, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Sisters of the Good Shepherd Ministry Fund, 8231 Don Caster Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 will be appreciated.

title: New Libyan Cooperation Leads to Renewed Ties With Britain
description: Britain said today that it was resuming diplomatic relations with Libya after 15 years because Tripoli had agreed to assist the British police in the investigation of the fatal shooting of a London police officer outside Libya's Embassy in London in 1984.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PLUNGES. Sugar fell more than 6 percent amid weak demand from Russia and ample supplies from Brazil and Europe. In New York, sugar for October delivery fell 0.37 cent, to 5.37 cents a pound.

description: ''I think I have some real work to do to get out and listen and learn from the people of New York and demonstrate that what I'm for is maybe as important -- if not more important -- than where I'm from.''

title: Pacts Reached on Congo and Sierra Leone
description: A small nation in Africa took a big step toward peace today and a big African nation took a small one.

title: Fraud Conviction Reversed In Air Crash Insurance Case
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday threw out the fraud convictions of a leading airline insurer and its former chief executive who had been accused of trying to avoid financial responsibility in a 1987 commuter plane crash in California.

description: HALPERN-Jack. On June 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jennifer and Julie. Loving son of Elsie and the late Joseph. Dearest brother of Alan and Norman. title: Accounts
description: * InternetFlorist.com, St. Paul, a Web-based floral products retailer, to Hunt Adkins, Minneapolis, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO PAY $491 MILLION TO GET REST OF UNIT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $491 million for full ownership of a Japanese joint venture with the Yokogawa Electric Corporation that makes measurement devices. Hewlett-Packard will buy Yokogawa's 25 percent stake in Hewlett-Packard Japan Ltd. and make the joint venture a wholly owned subsidiary. The company makes and sells electronic measurement instruments and markets Hewlett-Packard's computers and printers in Japan. Hewlett-Packard shares fell $1.0625, to $99.3125. Hewlett-Packard formed the joint venture in 1963, when Japanese law restricted foreign ownership of businesses to 50 percent or less. The law changed in 1973.

title: 6 Rescued by Coast Guard
description: A Coast Guard helicopter rescued six crewmen yesterday from Double Bullet II, a 76-foot catamaran that capsized in rough seas while competing in the Transpacific Yacht Race. One sailor was treated for hypothermia at a San Diego hospital and released.

title: LVMH'S SALES JUMP
description: Bernard Arnault may not succeed in taking over Gucci, but his existing business is picking up. Buoyed by a turnaround in the demand for luxury goods from Asia, LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. said its sales climbed 18 percent in the last three months. The company said sales from Asia, not counting those at its duty-free stores, climbed 33 percent. For the first six months of 1999, sales increased 15.5 percent over the year before, to $3.7 billion. LVMH will publish detailed results on Sept. 16. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: A Wee Bit of Heather

title: SONY IS SHUTTING NORTH AMERICAN WIRELESS PHONE UNIT
description: The Sony Corporation said late on Tuesday that it was shutting its North American wireless phone business and dismissing about 200 employees in engineering, sales and marketing. Sony is making the move, which it expects to complete by the end of September, because the business has ''had a tough time staying competitive in that area,'' a Sony spokesman, Greg Dvorken, said. The business, Sony Digital Telecommunications of America, operates as part of Sony Electronics Inc., which has more than 25,000 North American employees. Sony will continue its wireless-technology research and development operations in San Diego.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLUSKEY, OLGA NEWTON
description: McCLUSKEY-Olga Newton. On July 4. Beloved wife of the late J. Sterling McCluskey. Beloved step mother of Shirley Simms. Adored step grandmother of Carson and James Simms. Mrs. McCluskey was the founder and president of the New York Chapter of the Friends of Winston Churchill Memorial and Library at Westminster College in Fulton, Missouri and was also a member of the Board of Governors of the Winston Churchill Memorial and Library. She was awarded an M.B.E. and an O.B.E. by Queen Elizabeth for her tireless work for British charities. Interment private. A memorial service will be held Friday, July 9, at 3:30PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Winston Churchill Memorial and Library, 501 Westminster Ave, Fulton, Missouri 65251.

Media buyer in the advertising field for more than 50 years. Memorial service to be held June 19, 1999 at The Church of the Assumption, Riverside Avenue, 1:30PM in Westport, CT.

title: Clinton Restricts Imports of Brazilian Steel and Australian Lamb
description: Despite a booming American economy, President Clinton moved today to restrict imports of two politically sensitive products -- steel from Brazil and lamb from Australia and New Zealand -- in response to complaints from unions and farmers that their livelihoods were threatened by a surge of under-priced imports.

title: Hillary Clinton Begins Pre-Campaign in a New Role for Her
description: The First Lady of the United States flew into New York on an Air Force jet today and presented herself as a potential candidate to replace Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan upon his retirement. Standing at Mr. Moynihan's side at his farm here, Hillary Rodham Clinton described questions about her residency as legitimate and said she would attempt to address them in the months ahead.

title: World Wide Banks: On-Line Financial Choices Grow
description: JACK JACKSON can't remember the last time he wrote a check and hasn't spoken face to face with a bank teller in years. Mr. Jackson has handled his personal banking on line with Bank Boston since 1989, and he expanded to on-line banking for his public relations business three years ago.

title: Phone Company to Ignore Ban and Continue Work in Afghanistan
description: A small New Jersey telephone company says it will disregard an order by President Clinton banning Americans from doing business with the Taliban, the Islamic fundamentalist group that rules Afghanistan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Inside Out and Outside In; The New, Improved Outdoors
description: THE story goes that when Philip Johnson showed Frank Lloyd Wright inside his 1949 glass house in New Canaan, Conn., the father of Fallingwater and other architectural masterpieces asked if he was meant to take off his hat.

title: IRISH PHONE COMPANY PRICED
description: The Irish Government announced that the price of its shares in Telecom Eirann, the nation's telephone company, would be 3.07 Irish pounds, the equivalent of $3.99. The Government sold shares representing its 50.1 share of the company and raised an estimated $4.3 billion. The new shares, which will be traded on the Irish stock market for the first time on Thursday, were expected by Government officials to produce an immediate profit of about 15 percent for the 574,000 individual Irish investors. James F. Clarity

title: Redecorating In the Abstract
description: The ghost of Mondrian haunts Wolf-Gordon, a wallpaper showroom in the D.& D. Building, where more than 500 samples are framed in black: a zebra print here, burgundy linen there.

title: Yes, Virginia, Free Software
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Chief Joins Effort on Drug Insurance for Elderly
description: It may be the hot political issue of the moment in Washington, but from here, the Federal Government's rising debate over coverage of prescription drugs for the elderly looks a bit late, a bit leisurely.

title: What Happened When the World Trade Center Lost Its Marbles
description: When the renovated World Trade Center plaza, right, reopened last month with a new granite surface, some New Yorkers wondered what had happened to the 40,000 marble pavers that once graced the plaza. Do tons of marble just vanish? Well, yes and no. Some of the marble had been replaced with concrete over the years, so last summer, contractors removed only 24,000 marble pavers. And then? Oh, ignominy! The marble was sent to a recycling station in Brooklyn, crushed and turned into fill for New York City streets.

title: Economic Scene; If doctors win the right to organize, patients could lose.
description: A CLOSELY divided American Medical Association, which represents about a third of the nation's physicians, has voted to form a union to represent its members in collective bargaining with health plans, hospitals and universities. The rise of managed care has shaken the cozy world of these high-paid, elite professionals. Now they are seeking cover from two groups they used to shun: unions and the Democratic Party, which is leading the charge in Congress to clamp down on corporate managed care.

title: The Magic Suddenly Disappears for Cone
description: When David Cone fell into trouble tonight, he tried his whole Houdini act. He threw from different arm angles. He changed speeds, fired breaking balls and splitters and fastballs. He slowed his delivery, he accelerated it.

title: Farmers Must Bow to Change, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: With Fleury's Signing Near, Rangers Turn to Lesser Needs
description: After more than a week of intense negotiations, the Rangers are expected today to sign Theoren Fleury, the high-scoring free agent, in a move designed to provide the scoring firepower they have lacked in recent seasons.

title: A Tough Act To Follow
description: TO Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the TKTS booth that ornaments Times Square like an oversize red and white box kite is one of the ''symbols of the renaissance'' of New York City.

description: Blasting away worries that the growth in Internet usage is slowing, Yahoo Inc. posted results yesterday for the second quarter that exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Clinton's Cosmetic Poverty Tour
description: As President Clinton travels across the country this week visiting poor areas, he should stop referring to them as ''pockets'' of poverty. It is not just a matter of pockets. Persistent poverty is endemic in cities and rural areas and is increasingly present, if less visibly so, in suburbs.

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL ACQUIRES CE DRILLING FOR $65 MILLION
description: National-Oilwell Inc., an oil services provider, said yesterday that it had bought CE Drilling Products Inc. for about $65 million in cash. CE Drilling, with sales of about $100 million last year, makes Emsco drilling machinery and Wilson mobile rigs. National-Oilwell, with sales of $1.17 billion last year, designs, makes and distributes equipment used in oil and natural gas drilling. The Houston-based National-Oilwell said its sales would probably decline this year from 1998 as exploration companies struggle to recover from a slump in oil prices. National-Oilwell expects to increase profit by providing parts and services to current CE Drilling customers.

title: S.A.S. Switches To Leo Burnett
description: Scandinavian Airlines System has named offices of the Leo Burnett Company to handle its worldwide account, which had been at Observera Grey in Stockholm, a unit of Grey Advertising, for five years. Billings were estimated at $13 million.

title: Trouble in the Backyard
description: More quickly than the political opponents of Slobodan Milosevic had dared hope, grass-roots dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav President is surfacing across much of Serbia.

title: INSIDE OUT AND OUTSIDE IN; Feathering the Nest Outdoors
description: IN a city like New York, every square foot of open space is a treasured commodity, and nobody appreciates that fact more than urban gardeners. As a breed, they're a hardy lot, highly adaptable and ready to overcome all obstacles; in these respects, they're not so different from the gardens they create. And create them they do: in window boxes, on terraces, in brownstone yards no bigger than a hankie and on rooftops -- especially on rooftops (as any aerial view of New York City will bear out).

title: El-Guerrouj Sets Record in Mile
description: The mile was once the glamour race of track and field, the race that made international heroes of Glenn Cunningham, Jim Ryun, Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett. The most memorable race in history may have been Roger Bannister's breakthrough in 1954, when he became the first to run a mile in faster than four minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, KATHARINE HALEY
description: DONAHUE-Katharine Haley. The Officers and Directors of the Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former President, Mrs. Frank M. Donahue, and extend deepest sympathy to her family and friends. Katharine Haley Donahue served the Garden Club with great distinction and extraordinary ability as its President (1985-1987), and in many other capacities. Beginning in 1971, she served as Director, Treasurer, and Chairman of both the Finance and Public Relations Committees. Mrs. Donahue was the recipient of many rewards from the Garden Club of America during her long and distinguished career. Among them, was the Medal of Merit and the Zone Creative Leadership Award. Mrs. Frederik C. Hansen Jr., President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, HOWARD
description: MANDEL-Howard. On June 7. Painter, sculptor, theater designer. Beloved partner for 40 years of Ed Graham, brother of Joseph, uncle of Lewis. Cherished cousin of Sylvan Mandel. Friend & inspiration to many. Mr. Mandel served in the Second World War, rose to the rank of Major and was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Clusters and Purple Heart. He was a Tiffany Fellow and a Fullbright Scholar. His works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Chrysler and Butler Museums and several colleges and universities. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the League for the Hard of Hearing or the Village Center for Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOYER, M. LAWRENCE JR.
description: NOYER-M. Lawrence Jr. A corporate attorney and former assistant United States Attorney, died Wednesday, July 7 at the Albert Einstein Hospital in Bronx, New York. Mr. Noyer died from a pulmonary embolism. He was 40 years old. Mr. Noyer graduated from Georgetown University in 1980 with a B.S. in Foreign Service and in 1983 from Fordham Law School, where he was Editor of the Fordham Law Review. From 1983 until 1985, Mr. Noyer clerked for the Honorable Joseph McLaughlin, a former District Court Judge for the Eastern District and currently a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. After serving as a corporate attorney at Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alexander in New York for one year, Mr. Noyer joined the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York, where he spent eight years as an Assistant U.S. Attorney. From 1994 to 1997 Mr. Noyer was a partner at Zuckerman Spaeder Goldstein Taylor & Kolker in New York. At the time of his death, Mr. Noyer was a Director and General Counsel of Barclay's Bank, PLC. Mr. Noyer is survived by his wife, Pamela Davis, a son, Griffin, a daughter, Claire; four sisters, Christine Seaver of Palo Alto, California, Elizabeth Feld of Plandome, New York, Mary Ann Noyer of Westport, Connecticut, and Nadine Rote of Larchmont, New York; a brother, Dr. Charles Noyer of Larchmont, New York and his mother Mary E. Noyer of Westhampton Beach, New York. Mr. Noyer was pre-deceased by his father Maurice L. Noyer. The family requests that donations be sent to the Einstein Weiler Fund, c/o P. Tsahas, Medicine 7NW Weiler Hospital, 1825 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461. The wake will be held Friday, July 9, 1999 at the Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY, from 2-4pm & 7-9pm. The funeral mass will be Saturday July 10, 1999 at St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont New York at 10am.
