Our deepest sympathy to them, his devoted wife Anna and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Cerone's Back in the Minors, and Loving It
description: YESTERDAY, lawn mowers were nosing around brilliant green sod, new netting draped the bullpen, and the video scoreboard looked over the unfinished 6,200-seat stadium and out to the Newark skyline, as well as -- Please, Dear Baseball God -- fans-to-be in Manhattan and the North Jersey suburbs. Under sparkling blue skies aching for a sweet afternoon game, construction workers were everywhere, readying Riverfront Stadium for opening day, July 16.

title: At Home in a Showroom
description: When Antonio Citterio, a Milanese architect, designs showrooms for Vitra, a European furniture company, they are not tableaux of matching desks and chairs. ''We present product in a simple, not overdesigned, space,'' Mr. Citterio said. In May, when Vitra opened its showroom at 557 Pacific Avenue in San Francisco, his credo remained intact. The two-story, 3,500-square-foot showroom, open to the public, even has a serene niche for Vitra's miniature chairs, far right. Mr. Citterio worked with two other designers, Terry Dwan of Milan and Briggs MacDonald of San Francisco. This month, Vitra reissued four George Nelson 1950's clocks, right; $260 to $300 at Lost City Arts, 275 Lafayette Street (Prince Street); (212) 941-8025.

title: More Soap Than Laundry Detected in Disney's Case
description: The trial of Jeffrey Katzenberg's suit against the Walt Disney Company was eagerly anticipated by Hollywood-watchers for the look it would provide into the sometimes secretive operations of the Magic Kingdom. Indeed, Hollywood executives and Wall Street analysts were astounded that Disney would even let the case go to trial, thereby allowing the company's dirty laundry to be aired in public.

title: ANATOMY SITES
description: BRAIN SITE

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR REMAINS STEADY. The dollar was little changed against the yen and the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.23 yen, up from 122.02 on Tuesday, while the euro was unchanged at $1.0226.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Happy Birthday, Bobs. It's almost two years. There will never ever be another you. Love always, Johnnie, Ted, Cathy & Pa

title: C. W. Lillehei, Leader in Open-Heart Surgery, Dies at 80
description: Dr. C. Walton Lillehei, a pioneer in open-heart surgery, valve replacements and the electronic pacemaker, died on Monday at his home in St. Paul. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERLOCK, WILLIAM
description: SHERLOCK-William. It was our privilege and great pleasure to have enjoyed the friendship of Bill Sherlock and his beloved family. We admired and loved his style, humor, generosity and gentle demeanor. Our deepest sympathy to Sissy, Billy and Robert. Rest in peace, Bill, you will be missed. Pete, Connie and Jeff Mogull

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSON, IRVING B.
description: BERSON-Irving B. On July 7, 1999. Loving husband of the late Mildred. Devoted father of Ilene Tanenbaum, Joan Winokur, Susan Turchin and Vicki Stein. Cherished grandfather. Mr. Berson was the President and Founder of Berson & Wishna and Wright & Lato. He was an active member of the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn and in later years a member of the Fort Lee Jewish Center. A funeral service is scheduled for 12 noon today at Temple Beth El, 415 Viola Road, Spring Valley, NY. For information contact Hellman Memorial Chapels, 914-356-8600.

title: No Broadway Shows on New Year's Eve
description: Responding to what are expected to be record crowds in Times Square, Broadway theater owners have announced that no performances will take place this New Year's Eve.

title: Learning 3 Elements of Play: They're All Called Counting
description: For more than 30 years Eddie Kantar has been one of the world's best bridge writers and one of the most prolific. His latest product, a pair of books on defense, is perhaps his best. ''Modern Bridge Defense'' and ''Advanced Bridge Defense'' are well planned and well presented, sure to improve the average player who aims to become more expert. They are available from the author at 2700 Nielson Way, No. 334, Santa Monica, Calif. 90405 for $22 each, including mailing, or $40 for both.

title: A Little-Noticed World of Wonders
description: WAITING FOR APHRODITE

title: Sports of The Times; Oil Can Boyd at Peacem With His Own Team
description: DENNIS (OIL CAN) BOYD was talking about peace, and being at peace. But Boyd, the intense, tightly wound pitcher, had never seemed at peace or at rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELYE, EDWARD E., MD
description: SEELYE-Edward E., MD The Department of Psychiatry of Weill Medical College of Cornell University, New York Presbyterian Hospital, records with deep sorrow the passing of Dr. Edward Seelye, esteemed psychiatrist at the Westchester Division from 1959 until the time of his death, July 3, 1999. During these four decades, Dr. Seelye held several leadership positions at the hospital. He will be missed by colleagues and patients. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Seelye family. A memorial service will be held on July 15 at Ridgeview Congregational Church, White Plains, NY, 7:30PM. Jack D. Barchas, MD, Psychiatrist-in-Chief Philip J. Wilner, MD, Medical Director Virginia L. Susman, MD, Associate Medical Director

title: Mets Feel Slighted By All-Star Selections
description: The Mets and the defending World Series champion Yankees are among only eight teams with winning percentages of .571 or higher this season, but they will have relatively little representation at next Tuesday's All-Star Game in Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAKINSKI, RUTH
description: TRAKINSKI-Ruth. The Brokers and Staff of Douglas Elliman are saddened by the death of our valued long time colleague and friend, Ruth Trakinski. Ruth joined Douglas Elliman in 1990 and demonstrated through her wisdom and elegance the skills of a consummate professional. She will be remembered always for her wit and great charm. Our condolences to her husband Simon, and her daughters, Esther, Amy & Vivian.

title: A Curiosity Of the 1930's Is Revived By the Kirov
description: As the first dramatic ballet that became a model in the 1930's for contemporary dance in the Soviet Union, ''The Fountain of Bakchisarai'' is a historical curiosity worth visiting.

title: 'Wild West' Showdown For Early TV Writers; Lawsuit Seeks Royalties for 60's Series
description: Four months ago, Gilbert Ralston, a top television writer in the 1950's and 60's, lay dying of congestive heart failure at the Sandpiper Court Yard, a home for the elderly near Charleston, S.C. ''I've had a good life, a full life, an interesting life,'' his son, Michael Ralston, recalled him saying. ''I don't have any issues except one. 'Wild, Wild West.' ''

title: Militants Vow To Battle On In Kashmir, Defying Sharif
description: Three days after Pakistan's Prime Minister assured American diplomats that he would seek the withdrawal of Muslim guerrillas from the Indian-held part of Kashmir, no pullback has taken place. Pakistan's Foreign Minister expressed doubts about whether the Government would be able to persuade the men to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, JIM
description: KUNZ-Jim, 65. Of New Windsor, NY, retired banker with Bank of New York, died suddenly at his home on June 1, 1999. He was born November 4, 1933, in Mount Kisco, New York, to Nancy Kunz and Edward Andrews. Jim served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War in the Military Police, K-9 Section. As a community icon, he led the Lancers Marching Band of the Thornwood, NY, Fire Department for 20 years to many local, state, and regional titles and national recognition. Jim is survived by his brother, Gordon Kunz, of Stamford, CT; a sister, Jane Fredrick, of Hampstead, MD; a daughter, Leah Getlan, of Las Vegas, NV; beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and many loving friends. He was predeceased by companion Jon Rowen. A graveside service and burial will be held by the family at 11 A.M. Saturday, June 12th, at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY, for relatives and friends. Rev. Chris Hutchinson will officiate. In honor of Jim's love of flowers and music, please make contributions to the New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY, or the American Guild of Musical Artists, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRIZVER, JESSIE
description: STRIZVER-Jessie. July 24, 1904July 6, 1999. She died peacefully at her home, surrounded by love. Adored mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She is survived by daughter, Evan Epstein, grandchildren, Mark Epstein, Gail and Foster Faerman, and great grandchildren, Christopher and Ryan Epstein; Jessica, Julie and Daniel Faerman. The family wishes to express deepest gratitude to her six ''angel'' caregivers. Services were held at the chapel of Temple Beth Israel, 5600 North Braeswood at 1:00 PM Wednesday, July 7, 1999, followed by interment at the Woodlawn Cemetery, Beth Israel Memorial Gardens, 1101 Antoine.

title: Japanese Premier Is Off to Mend Fences (He Hopes) With China
description: Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi leaves today for a major visit to China that aims to soothe relations between the great powers of East Asia and to improve the prospects of China's admission into the World Trade Organization by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, BEVERIDGE
description: WEBSTER-Beveridge. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the death of faculty member emeritus, Beveridge Webster, who was a member of the piano faculty from 1946 to 1990. Through his artistic integrity, his brilliant intellect and his engaging wit, Beveridge enriched the entire institution and had an enormously positive influence on the art of the piano in America and around the world. We send our deepest condolences to his wife and his entire family.

title: NEW ISRAEL LEADER MOVES TO RESTART MIDDLE EAST TALKS
description: Moving swiftly to make good on his pledges to restart the stalled Middle East peace effort, Ehud Barak announced as he moved into the Prime Minister's office today that he would hold a series of meetings with Arab leaders and President Clinton in the coming days.

title: Joaquin Rodrigo, 97, Master Of Spanish Classical Music
description: Joaquin Rodrigo, a major figure in Spanish classical music whose haunting masterpiece, ''Concierto de Aranjuez,'' inspired dozens of interpretations worldwide, including a jazz version by Miles Davis, died on Tuesday at his home in Madrid. He was 97.

title: Wanted: A National Commitment to Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILES, ALBERT
description: SMILES-Albert. On June 7, 1999. He was a businessman in real estate and general contracting. Devoted husband of Blanche. Beloved father of Lynn and Joan. Services were held Wednesday.

title: Putnam and Buyout Firm Form Joint Venture
description: Putnam Investments, the mutual fund manager, and the Thomas H. Lee Company, a buyout firm, said today that they had formed a partnership to offer investments in hedge funds and private companies to wealthy individuals and institutions.

title: A Classic Success Story Gets a Nod From Clinton
description: When Josie Ippolito was 7 years old, she loved to get up at 3 A.M. to help her father make tortillas in their small family shop in this struggling section of south-central Phoenix.

title: 12 War-Crimes Suspects Held By NATO's Police in Kosovo
description: NATO military police have detained a dozen people suspected of war crimes since NATO arrived in Kosovo 25 days ago, the result, officials say, of vigorous policing and a new determination on the part of the NATO-member countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts & Ideas pages on Saturday about the military historian John Keegan rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from his new book, ''The First World War.'' He wrote that the war ''destroyed the benevolent and optimistic culture of the European continent,'' not ''the European conflict.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTOR, HUGH WALDORF
description: ASTOR-Hugh Waldorf. Aged 78, in London, Monday, June 7th, peacefully following a stroke. Private family funeral. Memorial service to be held in London in the autumn.

title: The Rural Poor Need Democracy and Jobs; A Backup Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Shock
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a retrospective of work by the Canadian painter Chris Cran misstated the ownership of the 49th Parallel, a Manhattan gallery that showed his work in 1992. The gallery, which has since closed, was largely subsidized by the Canadian Government. It was not owned by Jared Sable, Mr. Cran's dealer in Toronto.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Milosevic's Governor in Kosovo Gets NATO Protection
description: It is one of the ironies of peace enforcement here that NATO soldiers, called in Friday night to protect Serbian representatives of the Yugoslav Government, shot dead two young heroes of the Kosovo Albanian rebel movement.

title: Yes, Virginia, Free Software
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTS, PHILLIP
description: ALBERTS-Phillip, on June 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Michelle and Julie, Steven and Jane, Alan and Nancy, Rebecca and Roger. Brother of Joan Onorato. Grandfather of Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Mellisa and Jonathon. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30AM.

title: Bartle Gets More Unilever Work
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer-products giant, has expanded its relationship with Bartle Bogle Hegarty in London, giving the agency its first American assignment, with billings estimated at $20 million.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day on June 28 referred incorrectly to the damage caused by the computer virus known as Melissa. It cost companies more than $300 million in labor and lost productivity, according to ICSA.net, a computer security company; the virus did not destroy data.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Beethoven, to Rebalance the Menu
description: The major classical-record labels, drunk on the early promise of the CD in the 1980's, grasped at every new project in sight. Further besotted in the early 90's by the greater profit margin in reissues, they grasped some more, emptying their archives. Then, in recent years, they awoke to the whopping hangover of a glutted market and loudly swore off the standard repertory.

title: Cipollini Peeks Out of Pack To Win 4th Stage of Tour
description: Where's Cipo?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, IRVING JEROME
description: FELDMAN-Irving Jerome. Irving Jerome Feldman, 87, on July 6th. Beloved husband of Phoebe Evans Feldman for 59 years, son of Louis and Esther, stepson of Jeanette, brother of Josephine Rubenstein, devoted father of Michael, Chester, Elissa, Robert, Adam and Louise, loving grandfather of Lauren, Lisa, Jonathan, Max, and Ally Feldman, Danielle and Sonia Tarantolo, Sam and William Borenzweig, father-inlaw of Barbara, Marcia, Barbara, Claude, Barbara and Joseph. Services 1 PM July 9 at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN D.
description: COHEN-Norman D. Uncle Norm, We'll always remember your: handsome smile, positive attitude, flamboyancy, stories, Father's Day, straw hat, ''Hiya, baby!'', ''See you soon, God willing.'' Kisses and hugs, The Cooper and Regenstein Clans

title: Stalking the next demographic, good old Grey opens a stand-alone unit to pursue Generation Y.
description: SEEKING to bolster its presence in a market segment that is growing faster than the number of Web sites devoted to Britney Spears, ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' the Backstreet Boys or ''American Pie,'' Grey Advertising Inc. has opened a stand-alone agency devoted to the very consumers who would consider such sites to be ''all that'': youngsters.

title: As Empire Crumbled, Frankel Turned $10 Million Into Diamonds
description: As Martin R. Frankel's insurance empire melted down in May and he prepared to flee the country, he converted $10 million into the hardest of assets: diamonds.

title: Soul of the Eames Machine
description: NEARLY 50 years ago on a bluff in Pacific Palisades overlooking the Pacific, Charles and Ray Eames assembled their house and companion studio from prefabricated parts ordered off the shelf. The steel structure, prominently featured in an Eames exhibition currently at the Library of Congress, was hailed as the prototype for an industrially produced house that could yield a humane environment at minimal cost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLITS, FREDERICK E.
description: WILLITS-Frederick E. Of Glen Cove, Long Island on July 6, 1999 age 85. Beloved husband of the late Glenny. Father of Karen W. Zentgraf, Frederick E. Jr., and Phebe W. Bergenheim. Grandfather of four, great-grandfather of two. Service at Matinecock Meeting House on Saturday at 1:30PM. Interment Matinecock Burying Ground. Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations to Matinecock Monthly Meeting or Friends Academy.

title: Business Publications Name Executives
description: Two publications have named new top business-side executives.

title: NEWS WATCH; A Quagmire Revisited: Simulating Vietnam
description: It's January 1964. You have 16,500 military personnel in South Vietnam. Your approval rating is 73 percent. So, President Johnson, what's your move?

title: Kicking It Around
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Nets Get Backing On Arena Project
description: Prudential Insurance Company of America has offered to arrange up to $170 million in financing for a proposed arena to be built by the Nets in Newark, the company said today.

title: A Victory for Tobacco's Victims
description: A Florida jury's strong ruling against the tobacco industry in the first class-action lawsuit to reach a verdict may prove a watershed in the history of tobacco legislation. The cigarette makers earlier settled with all the states for $246 billion for Medicaid costs arising from smoking-related diseases. But those settlements did not deal with the potential claims of millions of individual smokers, which may be far more expensive to resolve.

title: Generations Almost Blend In '34 Ballet
description: The kind of weight and urgency that helped make ''The Fountain of the Bakchisarai'' so thrillingly exotic on film in 1953 are no longer a part of dance. To see the work today -- as presented by the Kirov Ballet in a staging by Sergei Radlov of the 1934 original by Rostislav Zakharov -- is to see not less, perhaps, but something very different. If the ballet were a tapestry, it would look more like the work of Matisse than the rich hangings designed by Valentina Khodasevich for this production, given the even musical flow of the dancing and the somewhat abstracted acting.

title: National News Briefs; Task Force Is Formed In Shootings by Police
description: In the wake of shootings by the police in Los Angeles and Riverside, Federal officials today announced the formation of a special unit of government lawyers to investigate and prosecute civil rights violations.

title: Friel Fetches Chekhov Via Dublin: Serebryakov, We Hardly Knew Ye
description: The nighttime sky glows with summer lightning, and the listless residents of the estate wilt in the suffocating heat. Yet a discernible nip chills the air of the Gate Theater Dublin's new production of ''Uncle Vanya.'' It is an emotional cold front that lowers the temperature of Chekhov's stifling household and leaves its members as distanced from one another as solitary figures in a winter whiteout.

title: Goodrich and Allied Signal Settle Lawsuit
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company and Allied Signal Inc. agreed today to settle Allied Signal's legal challenge to Goodrich's $2.2 billion purchase of Coltec Industries, Goodrich said, removing the biggest obstacle to the merger's completion.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, BEVERIDGE
description: WEBSTER-Beveridge. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the death of faculty member emeritus, Beveridge Webster, who was a member of the piano faculty from 1946 to 1990. Through his artistic integrity, his brilliant intellect and his engaging wit, Beveridge enriched the entire institution and had an enormously positive influence on the art of the piano in America and around the world. We send our deepest condolences to his wife and his entire family. Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Officer Is Acquitted In Squeegee Shooting
description: A police officer who shot and wounded a squeegee man while off duty last year in the Bronx was cleared of all criminal charges yesterday by the judge who presided at his nonjury trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEOGERIAN, DONALD C. ''DON''
description: GEOGERIAN-Donald C. ''Don'' of Darien, CT on July 1, 1999. He was a retired Portfolio Manager, Dreyfus Balanced Fund. Husband of Helen M. Geogerian. Father of Peter, Daniel, & Douglas Geogerian. Grandfather of Brianna and Noah. Brother of George and Lawrence Hardy. Memorial Service will be held at the First Congregational Church of Darien, CT on Monday, July 12, 1999 at 11:00 AM. Gifts may be made to the Donald C. Geogerian Trust, Moore, Phillips, Duncan, One East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: 3,000 Rally Against Milosevic, to Only a Feeble Response
description: Protesters against President Slobodan Milosevic gathered in the main square of this small southern town tonight, while the Government, which had planned to stage a rally of its own in response, failed to do so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, EILEEN
description: HEALY-Eileen. The Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York, Inc. (CIDNY) and Independent Living Services mourn the loss of our esteemed Board President for the last decade, Eileen Healy. A beloved and respected leader in the independent living movement, Eileen was a lifelong advocate for the rights of people with disabilities. We, her colleagues and friends, will remember her dedication, energy and commitment as we continue her work. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her mother and entire family.

title: Essay; For 3K Freedom
description: A cry for self-determination is again sending shudders through world capitals. This time it's in Kashmir, a lovely land coveted by autocratic Pakistan, most of it occupied by 600,000 troops of democratic India.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, HERBERT
description: FREED-Herbert, 72. Of Suffern, NY on July 7, 1999. Son of the late Reuben & Ethel Freed. Dearly remembered by wife Bette, children Linda & Phil Schlissel, Carol & Richard Cohen, Janice & Jeffrey Katz, Steven & Gale Freed; sisters Marilyn Scherzer, Evelyn Marshak, & Elaine Lindenblatt; former wife Rita Freed; grandchildren Andrea, Robert, Stacey, Jessica, Danielle, Benjamin, Matthew and Ryan; step children David Shapiro & Jaimie & Michael Bolnick. Service today 12noon Parkside Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills.

title: Mets Slink Into Series Against the Yankees
description: Yesterday kept resembling one of those perilous afternoons for the Mets, the kind of lethargic game in which they were in front of the Expos yet were not really in control. There was a listless atmosphere and the Mets always seemed to be in danger of being lulled to sleep and into feeling that they were fine. But they were not.

title: Old Buildings Had Ways of Keeping Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAWER, JEROME, M.D.
description: BRAWER-Jerome, M.D. On July 4, 1999, of Hackensack, NJ (formerly of Paterson & Hawthorne, NJ). Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Steven, David and Louis, loving grandfather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNETT, THOMAS A., ESQ.
description: HARNETT-Thomas A., Esq. Of Ridgefield, CT, formerly of NYC. At the age of 75. Husband of Doris (nee Van Dien) Harnett. Father of Doris, Thomas, William and Kathleen. Former Superintendent of Insurance of the State of N.Y. (1975-1977) and founding partner of Gallagher, Harnett & Lagalanti (NYC). Funeral Mass Saturday at 10:30AM at St Mary's Church, Ridgefield, CT. Contributions to Fordham University School of Law, 140 W 62nd St, NY, NY, 10023.

title: McEnroe Is Hallowed (Age, Mouth and All)
description: Not even John McEnroe, the infamous tennis tyrant whose verbal volleys drew as much attention as the ethereal shots launched from his racquet, was spared a series of rude awakenings upon turning 40 this year.

title: Positive Ratings for Soccer Are Raising Some Eyebrows
description: In 1996, the United States Olympic women's soccer team was barely noticed by NBC, even when it defeated China for the gold medal.

title: Sehorn Adds Bulk to Brashness
description: Jason Sehorn spends most of his time these days in a California gym. His stomach is so rippled he could wash his clothes on it, and his biceps look as if two small cars were tucked under his skin. If it is possible, Sehorn is faster than he was before tearing ligaments in his knee at the beginning of last season while returning a kickoff for the Giants. In every way, Sehorn is more of a physical specimen than ever. He is Deion Sanders on Met-Rx.

title: How Photography Makes Celebrity So Irresistible
description: In 1954, Photoplay, the doyen of fan magazines -- it had been around since 1911 publishing feel-good stories written by publicity agents -- printed an article about the early love lives of Jeff Chandler and Susan Hayward, who were childhood friends. The article was flattering, but Chandler, the magazine said, thought it invaded his privacy. So Photoplay polled its readers. The question (accompanied by another full-page glossy of Chandler, beaming) was: Is it proper to write about a star's private life?

title: Metro Business; Restaurant Operator Files for Chapter 11
description: The Riese Organization, one of the city's biggest fast-food restaurant operators, is seeking bankruptcy protection to help it repay $140.7 million.

title: Brokerage Firm Is Indicted In Fraud Case
description: The Manhattan District Attorney brought an indictment yesterday against A. S. Goldmen & Company, a small New Jersey brokerage firm, and 26 employees on charges that the firm had orchestrated a securities fraud that had cost thousands of investors $100 million in losses.

title: U.N. Backs Mine Expert Expelled by Iraq
description: The United Nations defended a mine-clearing expert who was expelled today by Iraq, and expressed concern about Baghdad's continuing attempts to bar employees of certain nationalities or groups from working in the country.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Firm Showings By Two Issuers Aid Treasuries
description: Bond prices rose yesterday as Freddie Mac and the Ford Motor Company found buyers for $9.8 billion of securities, reducing the glut of new sales that drove up Treasury yields earlier in the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARION, M.D.
description: DAVIS-Marion, M.D., on July 7, 1999. Beloved sister of Evelyn Gunter and loving aunt of Curtis L. Gunter, Jr. Interment private.

title: Canadian Cold Front Casts Chill Over Shea
description: How dare that pestiferous bunch of anonymous players from Canada intrude on the Mets' preparations for their interleague rematch with the big bad team from the Bronx. Who are these Montreal Expos who keep getting in the Mets' way?

title: Don't Turn Dams Into Villains
description: To the Editor:

title: Nike Is Sued Over Tiger Woods Golf Ads
description: The Acushnet Company has sued Nike Inc. over its use of Tiger Woods in television advertisements for Nike's golf clothing and shoes.

title: Freedom to Drive, but Not Too Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Shafik al-Wazzan, 74, Leader Of Lebanon in Tumultuous 80's
description: Shafik al-Wazzan, Prime Minister of Lebanon during the tumultuous 1980's, died yesterday at his home in Beirut. He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, HARRY COLUMBUS
description: ISAACS-Harry Columbus. Former Senior Vice President of The BVD Company; civic leader in his home community of Rye, New York, which honored him with a key to the city; a founder and president of The Rye Community Synagogue and active volunteer with The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and Jewish Welfare Board; founding member of Roosevelt College in Chicago; former president of SUNY/Purchase affiliates; and honorary Hopi Tribal member. Harry Isaacs is survived by his wife of 63 years, Natalie; his daughter, Naomi; his son Richard; his son Stephen and daughter-inlaw Ava; his grandchildren Ilan, Ariel, and David; and his brother Irving and sister-in-law Joan. A memorial service will be held in August.

title: Quilts That Hew to Discipline Even as They Dazzle
description: ''Beyond the Square: Color and Design in Amish Quilts'' is a reticent but festive summertime gift from the Museum of American Folk Art. And its title has a familiar ring. It suggests a sequel, Hollywood style, to ''Homage to the Square,'' the series of color study paintings by Josef Albers that have long been considered a paradigm of modernist abstraction.

title: Cipollini Sprints To Another Victory
description: The fifth stage of the 86th Tour de France, a warm, rolling 233.5-kilometer jaunt (146 miles) from the entrancing chateau town of Bonneval to Amiens, was won in a sprint finish yesterday by Mario Cipollini, who also won the fourth stage the day before.

title: Chip Hooper -- 'California Dreamin' '
description: Edward Carter Gallery

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Books; The Humble Bug, and How It Grew
description: HE summer reading season coincides with the summer driving season. Here, just in time for perusal at poolside or in a beach-bound traffic jam, is a look at some new books with automotive themes.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Pistachio Ice Cream
description: IF you were thinking about going to see the Yankees and the Mets at Shea Stadium tonight, tomorrow afternoon or Sunday afternoon, you'd better have a ticket by now. If not, fuhgeddaboutit. All three games are sold out.

title: Kazakhstan Blocks a Launching by Russia
description: Three days after a Russian rocket disintegrated over a grain-growing region of this Central Asian republic, the Government barred Russia from carrying out a scheduled launching today from Baikonur Cosmodrome.

title: Mexican Audit Pinpoints Bank Corruption
description: A report to be released soon concludes that Government regulators allowed corrupt practices to drive Mexico's banking system into insolvency, forcing a financial rescue that has cost taxpayers $80 billion in four years, lawmakers here said today.

title: Don't Turn Dams Into Villains
description: To the Editor:

title: Philharmonic Echoes Its Beethoven Cycle
description: It makes sense for Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic to have a presence in the Lincoln Center Festival, but couldn't either the orchestra's or the festival's artistic administrators come up with something unusual, provocative or novel for them to do?

title: Making a Belated Pilgrimage
description: Lamenting the life of the Mississippi Delta, racing from an Appalachian hamlet to an inner-city Walgreens, embracing the vast desolation of the land of the Sioux -- these are unusual things for a President to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERES, RUDOLPH
description: BERES-Rudolph. July 7. Dear friend of David Archer. Longtime executive with Colgate-Palmolive. Memorial service Monday, July 12, 10:30AM at Saint John The Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street at 1st Avenue.

title: Don't Turn Dams Into Villains
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Real Estate; A Rental Neighborhood Along the Hudson's Edge
description: From Port Imperial Boulevard, which parallels the nearly milelong Hudson River waterfront in West New York, N.J., the view is of a changing landscape. What was an industrial wasteland is being reborn as a $700 million residential community, called Port Imperial North, which is to have 4,300 residences on 100 acres hugging the river's edge in this Hudson County town atop the Palisades cliffs across from midtown Manhattan.

title: Pedro Barbeito
description: Basilico Fine Arts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRELLES, SOLOMON, JOSEFINA
description: TRELLES - SOLOMON - Josefina. On July 7, 1999 of New York, NY. Beloved sister of Esther Trelles Asteinza, Ricardo, Carlos, Isola Trelles, Maria L. Marzol, Paul Trelles and the late Alejandro. Step daughter of Evelia Trelles. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, one grand niece and two grand nephews. Memorial Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, Saturday, July 10, 1999 at 9:30 AM.

title: The Resistance to Mr. Milosevic
description: Even some of Slobodan Milosevic's strongholds are now the scene of large street rallies calling for him to step down. While this display of clear thinking by ordinary Serbs is cheering, it is not likely to result in a quick change in leadership. He has faced widespread protests in the past and outwitted his opposition, and he holds the power to do so again.

title: Lincoln Center Festival '99: What's Playing, Where and When
description: Lincoln Center Festival '99 runs through July 25 at several Manhattan locations, with most in the Lincoln Center complex. Tickets for individual events range from $15 to $60 (or $210 for admission to the entire ''Peony Pavilion'' series), and can be purchased through CenterCharge (212) 721-6500 and Ticketmaster (212) 307-4100. Festival information: (212) 875-5928. The New York Video Festival, part of the Lincoln Center Festival, runs from July 16 to 22 at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center; video tickets are $8.50 and $12 ($5 and $10 for members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center). Video schedule information: (212) 875-5600. A schedule of Lincoln Center Festival performances follows:

title: Bill Komoski
description: Feature, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEEREY, JOHN J., REVEREND
description: HEEREY-John J., Reverend. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the former parochial vicar of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, NY, on July 6. Reposing 2 to 4 and 7 to 10 PM Friday, July 9, in Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, NY. Funeral Mass at 10:30 AM Saturday, July 10, at Resurrection-Ascension Church, 61-11 85th St., Rego Park. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Slash And Burn Urban Renewal
description: You live in a battered neighborhood in an ag ing city Buffalo or Baltimore, Hartford or Detroit. Next door or down the street is an abandoned house where crack is being sold or squatters congregate or fires are set. If you complain, the chances are pretty good that your local government will respond by tearing down the house, using Federal grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, special state demolition money or even city revenue.

title: Sun and Ancient Stone: 19th-Century Palestine
description: It seems almost too much of a coincidence that the quintessentially modern form of picture-making, photography, was invented just in time to catch a basically unchanging world before it was about to make a radical leap into the modern era.

title: Old-Time Family Values. From Chris Rock. Really.
description: Chris Rock is making Littleton jokes. What's wrong with ''these white kids shooting up schools?'' he asks, two and a half months after the massacre in Colorado that left 14 students and a teacher dead. And why, he wonders, are people looking for social ills that caused it?

title: Retailers Post Robust Gains In June Sales
description: Keeping time with the nation's rocking economy, retailers posted another month of robust sales gains in June.

title: Art directors are taking a greater role in defining and executing a brand's look and image.
description: ALEXANDER GELMAN came to New York from Moscow six years ago with few contacts in advertising but an impressive ''book'' of design work from a big Russian publishing house where he was creative director.

title: Roadblock in Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: AGREEMENT AT AIR CANADA
description: Air Canada avoided a complete shutdown yesterday by agreeing to terms with 5,100 flight attendants who had threatened to strike at midnight on Wednesday. The airline, which carries 60,000 passengers a day, operated normally, although it had begun preparing to cancel all flights. Last-minute bargaining produced a 15 percent increase in pension benefits for the flight attendants, who had earlier won a 12 percent increase in wages over three years.

title: Miguel Angel Rios and Sergio Vega
description: CRG

title: SUNY to Review Its Vote Approving Charter Schools
description: The State University of New York is moving to reopen its approval of three taxpayer-financed charter schools -- including two in New York City -- after complaints from the New York City Schools Chancellor and others that the university's trustees acted in secret when they reviewed the applications.

title: North Korean Missile Parts Said to Be From Japan
description: Two Japanese members of Parliament charged today that key elements of North Korea's missile program come from Japan, and they called for tighter export restrictions.

title: Think Again Before Borrowing a Cup of Sugar
description: Suspect Thy Neighbor was the commandment behind some of the best, most delectably unnerving films of the 1970's. And with its strong echoes of paranoid classics like ''The Parallax View'' and ''Rosemary's Baby,'' the crackerjack thriller ''Arlington Road'' keeps that alarmist spirit alive. Tapping into fears much more contemporary than those stirred up by old staples like witchcraft and assassination plots, the film dares to suggest that the convivial people in khakis at the suburban back-yard barbecue could be a lot like Rosemary's neighbors. Only worse.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines Prudential $20 Million
description: Receiving yet another sanction for misleading customers for more than a decade, the Prudential Insurance Company of America was fined $20 million yesterday by the National Association of Securities Dealers, the highest fine ever imposed by the association.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Stars That Creep And Slither

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGO VIDRE, JOAQUIN
description: RODRIGO VIDRE-Joaquin. Composer, Honorary Member of the SGAE Board. The Authors and Publishers of Sociedad General de Autores y Editores (SGAE) share the loss of the family of this great composer that has universalized Spanish culture.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee climbed as colder weather expected in Brazil next week could bring damaging frost to the world's largest crop. In New York, coffee for September delivery rose 2.35 cents, to 96.45 cents a pound.

title: I'm Taking My Family Public
description: We're more profitable than Amazon.com, have more growth potential than General Motors, boast a more stable leadership and fewer marketing fiascos than Coca-Cola. Consequently, with the Dow and Nasdaq hitting record highs seemingly every other day, I have decided, after discussing it with my wife and exercising the proxy of our newborn son, to take my family public.

title: Competition Gives Headaches To Brazilian Phone Customers
description: Like many people who tried to place telephone calls as competition in Brazil's long-distance market gradually opened this week, Antonio Carlos do Amaral Maia felt like slamming down the receiver.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Innocents in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRENS, EVA
description: BEHRENS-Eva. On July 8, 1999. Age 80 years. Beloved wife of the late Walter Behrens. Beloved friend of Norman Barsel. Devoted mother of Andrew and Peter. Memorial services Sunday 3PM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard, corner 66th Avenue, Forest Hills. Donations to the American Diabetes Foundation will be appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO AT NEW LOW. The euro set another record low against the dollar after the European Central Bank said it would not try to halt the currency's decline. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0214, down from $1.0226 on Wednesday.

title: Clinton Ends Visit to Poor With an Appeal for Support
description: Flanked by Magic Johnson, President Clinton wrapped up his four-day tour of poverty in America today with a whirlwind visit to a job-training program at a high school in the heart of the Watts section of Los Angeles, then challenged corporate executives to provide more support for preparing disadvantaged students for jobs in the booming information economy.

title: Mediterranean
description: The Mediterranean continues to tug at the appetites of New Yorkers. Here are 12 restaurants that offer food from points all around the Mediterranean. (These restaurant summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Fran Drescher Tries the Stage

title: Travel Tip: A Girl Can Lose Her Illusions in Tuscany
description: ITALIAN FEVER

title: BASKETBALL; The Cream of the Point Guard Crop
description: Recruiting analysts love them, high school opponents loathe them and college coaches lust after them. Andre Barrett, Taliek Brown and Omar Cook are a point guard trinity in New York, the best in a deep crop of Class of 2000 floor leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD
description: SHEPPS-HOWARD. 9/1/53-7/9/92 WE MISS YOU EVERY DAY, IN EVERY WAY...LIFE PERSISTS. WE SEE YOUR BEAUTIFUL FACE-YOUR EYES,HEAR YOUR LAUGHTER....WE WANT MORE

title: MR. YEN STEPS DOWN
description: Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's Vice Finance Minister for international affairs, left, better known as Mr. Yen for his sway over the markets, stepped down and was succeeded by Haruhiko Kuroda, formerly international bureau chief at the Finance Ministry. Mr. Kuroda surprised reporters recently by declaring in English rather than Japanese that premature strengthening of the yen would be undesirable. Local reporters noted that Mr. Sakakibara often made key currency policy statements in English and that Mr. Kuroda might carry on the tradition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOIS, ALICE TRIMBLE
description: DUBOIS-Alice Trimble, on July 8, 1999. Beloved by many friends. Will be greatly missed. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, July 9th, 7-9 PM, with service Saturday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the British National Art Collections Fund, Millais House, 7 Cromwell Place, London, England SW7 2JN.

title: Treasury Chief Urges Inner-City Investment
description: The new Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, went to Harlem yesterday to encourage more private investment in poor neighborhoods and announced the formation of a new mentoring program to allow inner-city entrepreneurs in New York to draw upon the expertise of large corporations.

title: Oprah Winfrey and Hearst to Start Magazine
description: Oprah Winfrey frequently graces the covers of women's magazines, but now she is getting in on the editorial side of the publishing business.

title: Singaporeans Wait for a Stock Freeze in Malaysia to Melt
description: Historic rivalries and a politically charged stalemate between this city's stock exchange and its counterpart in neighboring Malaysia are teaching investors here a new twist in the time-honored investment strategy of buy and hold.

title: V.A. Chief, Under Fire, Is Said To Plan an Early Departure
description: Togo D. West Jr., the embattled Secretary of Veterans Affairs, has told President Clinton that he plans to resign before the end of the term but has set no date for his departure, a White House official said today.

title: LOBBYING AGAINST GOLD SALES
description: South Africa's Gold Crisis Committee, made up of mine owners, mine union leaders and Government officials, will send a delegation to try to persuade the Group of Eight industrial countries not to make more sales of gold from central bank reserves. The falling gold price is expected to cost the country nearly 12,000 jobs as mines close or lay off workers.

title: G.E.'s Quarterly Earnings Top Expectations
description: The General Electric Company, benefiting from its continued push into high-margin service businesses as well as from improved efficiency, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, slightly beating analysts' expectations.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANSON, HAROLD L.
description: DANSON-Harold L., formerly of Larchmont, NY, husband of the late Henrietta, father of Alan and Larry. Grandfather of Ben, Josh, and Rob. At the Forrestal Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, Princeton, N.J., on July 6, 1999. Funeral arrangements will be private.

title: Israeli Chief Begins Quest As Squabbles Rise at Home
description: As Ehud Barak, Israel's new Prime Minister, prepared today to fly off to Egypt on the first leg of an ambitious mission to make regional peace, he was facing down a Welcome Wagon of political squabbles on the home front.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 2 Held in Fatal Attack on Homeless Man
description: Police officials said yesterday that they had arrested two Manhattan men in the death of a homeless man who was beaten outside Tompkins Square Park on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLISON, JAMES C.
description: ALLISON-James C., 73. Died Friday, July 2, 1999, at Hospice By The Sea, Boca Raton, FL, after a brief illness. Mr. Allison, who had served as a volunteer at the Hospice, died of complications from lung cancer. He was a resident of Delray Beach, FL. Born January 23, 1926, in Live Oak, FL, Mr. Allison was a retired fashion designer and had moved to Florida 13 years ago from New York City and Connecticut. He had attended Washington University in St. Louis, MO, and was a graduate of Parsons School of Design, New York City. He was an Air Force veteran of World War II, serving in the Pacific theater. Mr. Allison is survived by his companion, James N. Baldwin, of Delray Beach; a sister, Ann Montgomery, of Talladega, AL; a brother, Edward, of Fort Worth, TX; and four nephews. A memorial service was held Wednesday at Unity Church of Delray Beach. Contributions in his name may be made to Hospice By The Sea, 1581 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33431.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Saturday about a revival of the 1974 Jerry Herman musical ''Mack and Mabel'' by the Barrington Stage Company in Sheffield, Mass., misstated the title of a dance number. It is ''Tap Your Troubles Away,'' not ''Tapping Your Blues Away.''

title: ABBOTT IS BUYING PERCLOSE FOR $680 MILLION
description: Abbott Laboratories said late yesterday that it would buy Perclose Inc. for about $680 million in stock to expand its hold on the fast-growing market for mechanical heart valves and closure devices. Abbott will exchange $54 of its shares for each share of Perclose. Under its new chief executive, Miles D. White, Abbott has been aggressive in expanding through acquisitions. The purchase of Perclose will give Abbott access to products that allow doctors to seal repaired arteries. The shares of Perclose, based in Redwood City, Calif., fell $8.50, or 18 percent, to $39.50, yesterday before trading was halted. The company said it was recalling some of its product because of problems with the needles. The problem has been resolved, it said. Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., fell 68.75 cents, to $42.875.

title: Is Hillary Clinton A Carpetbagger?; Money Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: Viewing Pieces Of Palestine
description: Playing himself in his film ''Chronicle of a Disappearance,'' Elia Suleiman is called onto a stage in Jerusalem to explain his less than obvious methods of moviemaking to an audience of ordinary citizens, among whom, it is supposed, he will be shooting parts of ''Chronicle of a Disappearance.'' But as he adjusts the microphone to speak, audio interference develops. A technician darts out to correct the problem and withdraws. Again Mr. Suleiman begins to speak, but again there is interference. Again the technician scrambles. After several repetitions of this, the audience begins to lose interest, reading, making cell phone calls and finally leaving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELSON, LILLIAN (MENDELSON)
description: DELSON-Lillian (Mendelson). On July 8, 1999 in her 97th year. Pianist, vocal coach, entertainer extraordinaire. Beloved daughter of the late Goldie and Joseph, adored aunt of Linda, Karen, Len, Julie, Lewis, Jonathan, Rhonda and Joshua. Graveside services 1PM Sunday, July 11th at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ.

title: Susan Wanklyn
description: Cheryl Pelavin

title: National News Briefs; Grant to Aid Hispanics
description: A group seeking to double the percentage of Hispanic students earning college degrees announced yesterday that it had received a $50 million grant from the Lilly Endowment, a private foundation in Indianapolis.

title: Roche Sets Price for Genentech Share Sale
description: Roche Holding A.G., Europe's fourth-biggest drug maker, said today that it planned to sell about 17 percent of Genentech Inc., a United States biotechnology company, to the public at $85 to $95 a share.

title: Gephardt Bows To Jews' Anger Over a Nominee
description: After protests from Jewish organizations, the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, decided late yesterday to withdraw his appointment of an American Muslim leader to a Congressional counterterrorism commission, an aide said.

title: At the Helm of Gore's Campaign, 2 Old Friends Who Don't Speak
description: Bob Squier is more than just another consultant to Al Gore. He has worked for Mr. Gore since the early 80's and is among his half-dozen closest friends and advisers. Funny and smooth, Mr. Squier relaxes the Vice President and frequently travels with him. He is typically the last person Mr. Gore sees before a debate or an important speech.

title: FINANCIER IMPRISONED
description: A Swiss financier, Werner K. Rey, was sentenced to four years in prison for his part in the collapse of his business empire, which left $2.6 billion in debts. Mr. Rey, who avoided trial for seven years by fleeing to the Bahamas, was found guilty of fraud and falsifying documents by a court in Bern. Former associates testified that Mr. Rey, 55, had misled banks to gain loans when his company, Omni Holding, was going public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRYGER, WANDA
description: KRYGER-Wanda. On July 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edmund, cherished mother of Wanda and Edward, Edmund and Maureen, Robert and Nancy and Albert. Loving grandmother of Lisa, Michael, Jennifer, Robert Jr., Cindy and Edward. Dear friend and business associate of Susan Bell, Laura Hall and the late Ruth Ann Nicholson. She was a remarkable lady who will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. Visiting Friday, July 9th, 2-4PM and 79PM at George S. Hassler Funeral Home, 980 Bennetts Mills Road, Jackson, New Jersey, phone (732) 364-6808. Mass of Christian Burial Sat., July 10th at 10:30 AM at St. Veronica Church, 4215 Highway 9 North, Howell, NJ 07731. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the St. Veronica School Scholarship Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRIDES, CHRISTY H.
description: PETRIDES-Christy H. On July 6, 1999. Survived by three sons and one sister. A graveside service will be held Saturday, 11AM, Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNEBORN, CLARA, LOUISE
description: SONNEBORN-Clara-Louise. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Tom Weiner Rabbi Shira Milgrom Mark A. Hershey, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEAN, Q.A. SHAW JR.
description: McKEAN-Q.A. Shaw Jr. The Board of Directors, Members and Staff of Fountain House express their deep sorrow on the loss of our friend and colleague Shaw. He became Treasurer in 1987 from 1990, served as the President of the Board for 3 years and later headed-up our successful Fund for Fountain House. He continued to serve as Treasurer until his death. Shaw's generosity of spirit, dedication, energy and talents have benefited all who came into contact with him, and his high standards of excellence have been a key ingredient in helping our clubhouse programs achieve national and international recognition for serving men and women with major mental illnesses. We extend our deepest sympathy to Linda and his family. His friendship and kindness will be missed by us all.

title: Keeping Tigers Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: Strawberry Permitted to Work Out in Tampa
description: Darryl Strawberry, currently suspended from Major League Baseball, will be allowed to resume workouts Friday at the Yankees' minor league complex in Tampa, Fla. His return to New York, however, may not occur at Yankee Stadium, but in Staten Island, home of the team's rookie-league affiliate that began play this year.

title: POWER SYSTEM USE IS PRESSING LIMITS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The blackout that stilled upper Manhattan for nearly a day was a sort of distress call, a warning that as the demand for electricity sets records, the power systems in the New York metropolitan area are creeping perilously close to their physical limits, experts in the field cautioned today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWAG, ELIAS
description: GOLDWAG-Elias. The administration and staff of Beth Israel Medical Center are deeply saddened over the death of our dear friend and devoted volunteer, Ely Goldwag. Ely was a great spirit who was devoted to Beth Israel Medical Center Singer Division. His constant smile was a comfort to the countless patients he visited, and a delight to the many members of the staff he befriended during his many years of volunteer activity. He was a special man who is missed. Our hearfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Shirley, and all who loved him. Matthew E. Fink, MD, President Gail F. Donovan, Executive Vice President Terry Rizzo-Williams, Director of Volunteers

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN STEEL LAYOFFS
description: Mexico's largest steel manufacturer, Altos Hornos de Mexico, said it planned to lay off 25 percent of its white-collar staff and freeze the salaries of workers who stay. Besides the layoff of 2,000 workers, a move executives say will save $33.2 million yearly, the company plans to raise at least $30 million from sales of assets unrelated to production. But there was no word on how Altos Hornos will rework its $1.8 billion debt, on which it defaulted in April. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think that this heat wave should sober all of us up to recognize that we have a really big problem, and we need to plan for the future right now.''

title: The Bureau of Inverse Technology
description: Postmasters

title: British Bank Wins Dispute With the I.R.S.
description: In a stunning defeat for the Internal Revenue Service's efforts to restrict strategies that foreign corporations employ to avoid taxes, a Federal judge ruled in favor of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of Britain in its demand for a $180 million tax refund.

title: A Protest From Vietnamese Traditions
description: The first dance presentation of Lincoln Center's Festival '99 is ''Voila Voila,'' which marries Vietnamese musical traditions with deliberately reductive contemporary dance ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HERMAN
description: WEINSTEIN-Herman Great Neck NY). Beloved husband of the late Freda S. and Ruth B., devoted father of Suzan Weinstein-Witte and late Ida Freiberg, dear father-in-law of William Freiberg, loving grandfather of Peter, Michelle, Jeffrey, Melissa, Joanna, and great-grandfather of Ryan and Isaac. Services Sunday ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 800-378-1892.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSMAN, EUGENE
description: ROSSMAN-Eugene. On July 6, 1999 at age 68. Loving husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Jeff and Lori, David and Lauren and Caran and Larry. Cherished Papa to Evan, Adam, Samantha and Jason. Adored brother of Evelyn and Phillip Levine and Jeanette Reiss. He will always be with us and his music will play on in our hearts and minds.

title: TWO JUDGES CLEAR WAY FOR SFX TO BUY LIVENT'S ASSETS
description: Livent Inc., the financially troubled theater production company, won United States and Canadian court approval yesterday to sell most of its assets to SFX Entertainment Inc. of New York for about $128 million. SFX, the world's largest producer of live entertainment, had offered to buy Livent for $90.8 million in cash, plus as much as $37 million in future payments. Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, and Justice John Ground of Ontario Court, participating through a satellite link, cleared the purchase. Livent is based in Toronto. SFX is acquiring Livent's theaters in New York, Chicago and Toronto and rights to future and current productions, including ''Fosse'' and ''Ragtime.''

title: Hunting for Something Wild? The Fun of Fungi
description: When reporters are asked to go off the record, it's usually because of talk, not turf. But there I was, on a Saturday early in May, sworn not to reveal the location of the New York Mycological Society's annual morel breakfast and hunt, which opens the mushrooming season. As elusive as they are prized, wild morels were then selling in a Greenwich Village gourmet shop for $130 a pound, making the quest for secrecy understandable. May the mushroom mossad not terminate me if I imprecisely situate this hunt in a wooded area of Westchester County that is the site of two abandoned apple orchards, a favorite habitat of morels.

title: Beijing Seems to Lose Battle Over Who Is the Real Lama
description: In a carpet shop in this dusty town in Sichuan province, east of Tibet, two photographs are prominently displayed on the main wall.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Resurging Oil Prices Lead Rally in Commodities
description: The prices of key commodities, whose decline helped restrain inflation the last few years, are climbing again.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: N.A.S.D. Fines Prudential $20 Million for Deception

title: Hill Ready to Sign as Coach at Fordham
description: Bob Hill spent yesterday at a resort in Texas, playing a round of golf, lifting weights and enjoying his free time with his family, just the sort of things that he will soon have less time for. While he walked the course, his agent was putting the finishing touches on a 10-year contract that will make Hill the head basketball coach at Fordham University.

title: Second Man, 88, Dies After Hospital Attack
description: An 88-year-old Brooklyn man who was beaten with a hammer on Saturday in his hospital bed died of his injuries yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: CAT SCAN PROCESS COULD CUT DEATHS FROM LUNG CANCER
description: Death rates from lung cancer could be greatly reduced if smokers and former smokers were routinely given CAT scans of their lungs, doctors are reporting today. The scans use a new technique that is far more sensitive than conventional chest X-rays and can detect tumors when they are small enough to be cured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NGAI, SHIH, HSUN, M.D.
description: NGAI-Shih-Hsun, M.D. The Board and membership of the Chinese American Medical Society mourn the passing of its founding member, Dr. Shih-Hsun Ngai, Professor Emeritus of Anesthesiology and Pharmacology at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. His strength, vision and leadership will be missed. Our deep condolences go to his wife, Hseuh-Hwa Wang, M.D., Executive Director of CAMS and their children. Raymond Fong, M.D., President

title: Gaultier, a Fashion Original, Links Up with Hermes
description: PARIS  The French designer Jean-Paul Gaultier, best known for putting men in skirts and Madonna in a conical bra, found a business partner Thursday in the traditional luxury house of Hermes. It is a marriage of opposites that surprised the fashion world.

title: Mellow and Full of Charm Under the Autumn Sun
description: ''Autumn Tale'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival as ''A Tale of Autumn.'' Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2, 1998. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Feeling Wanted, Fleury Becomes a Ranger
description: Theoren Fleury knew the Rangers meant business when Neil Smith and Dave Checketts showed up at his agent's office in Winnipeg last week, ready to talk numbers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNLIMITED SOLUTIONS INC., Columbus, Ohio, agreed to be acquired by NSB Retail Systems P.L.C., Basingstoke, England, the top provider of software and support services to British apparel retailers, for $59 million.

title: Big Racial Disparity Persists in Internet Use
description: A new Federal survey shows that while minorities are increasingly gaining access to computers and the Internet, the racial divide remains stark, with black and Hispanic families less than half as likely as whites to explore the Net from home, work or school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULDOON, AUDREY
description: MULDOON-Audrey. The leadership of Continuum Health Partners, Inc. and the staffs of the departments of Ophthalmology at its partner institutions express their sympathies over the death of Audrey Muldoon, beloved mother of our longtime colleague and friend, Thomas Muldoon, MD. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Dr. Muldoon, his family and their loved ones. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Robert G. Newman, MD President

title: Oshima Journal; Ah, When Nets Were Full, and So Was Life at Sea
description: It is just past dawn as Yasushi Yamashita guides his white fishing boat through the waves, finds his buoy and then grunts as he hauls his nets to the surface in hopes of a surprise.

title: New York Life Picks Berlin Cameron
description: The New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had awarded its advertising account to Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York.

title: ABC Radio Hires Internet's Matt Drudge
description: The ABC Radio network has hired Matt Drudge, who composes an Internet news-and-gossip column called the Drudge Report, to do a Sunday night radio talk show that will be syndicated across the country.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day on Monday about a wearable computer made by a group of high school students from Dearborn, Mich., misspelled the surname of a Microsoft executive who had seen it. He is Anthony J. Bay, not Bray.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Jet Wars of the Future; Airbus Prepares to Take On 'the Boeing That Will Be'
description: In the giant hangers here where Airbus Industrie's single-aisle jetliners are assembled, only a handful of workers can be found, testing systems, attaching the landing gear or drilling holes to fasten wings to the fuselages.

title: With Delay in Sentencing, Gotti Gets Time to Pay Fine
description: A Federal District Court judge today postponed sentencing for John A. Gotti until early September to give Mr. Gotti more time to raise the $1 million he must pay as part of an earlier plea agreement on racketeering and extortion charges.

title: Hill Said to Be Priceline.com Choice
description: Priceline.com in Stamford, Conn., which operates a discount-travel Web site, has awarded its account to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopoulos in Boston, advertising executives informed of the decision said yesterday. Billings for the account, which had been handled by Heater Advertising in Boston, were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOYER, M. LAWRENCE, JR.
description: NOYER-M. Lawrence, Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of M. Lawrence Noyer, Jr., a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Urban Minstrels With Roots in Suburbia
description: On a sticky afternoon last week, Adam Schlesinger and Chris Collingwood took a ride to Utopia Parkway. These musicians, who lead the band Fountains of Wayne, had been to that corner of Queens many times, but not often on the physical plane. Mostly they go there within a song, the title track of the band's new album-length invocation of Eastern Seaboard suburbia.

title: 2 G.O.P. Rivals Surprise Journalists' Conference
description: Two Republican Presidential candidates made last-minute appearances today at a convention of thousands of Hispanic, African-American, Indian and Asian-American journalists here, after reading a newspaper article highlighting their decision to decline an invitation to speak and take questions at the convention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINS, PAUL M.
description: WILKINS-Paul M. On July 7, 1999, Of Jericho, Long Island. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted stepfather of Susan and Karen. Cherished grandfather of Sam, Lisa, and Ira. Services today, 2PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Old Buildings Had Ways of Keeping Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Buildings Had Ways of Keeping Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: A Civil Action

title: Following the Food From Soil to Soup Pot; Some Restaurant Chefs Don Overalls and Try Growing Their Menus
description: That lettuce on the plates of the power lunch crowd at the Four Seasons? The spinach and kohlrabi served at Della Femina? The baby leeks at Gramercy Tavern? The mixed greens at the Manhattan Ocean Club?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARIAN M.
description: MILLER-Marian M. The daughter of Robert Watt Miller and Elizabeth Folger Miller, died on Saturday, July 3, 1999, after a short illness. She was born on July 9, 1930. Marian had been living in Manhattan and Bridgehampton for the past thirteen years. Marian, nature and dog lover, spent her last years at her beach house in Bridgehampton. She is survived by her children, Ford Edwards, Hammond Edwards, Geoffrey Edwards, Christie Jones, and Janie Manet.

title: Mets May Go To Japan
description: A tentative schedule has been drawn, but nothing has been set for Major League Baseball's plan to open the 2000 season in Japan, neither agreement with the players association nor commitments from teams, a baseball official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINERMAN, JAMES
description: DINERMAN-James, 77. On July 2, 1999. Beloved father of Alice Eve and Robert David. Treasured brother of the late Jean Berger, and the late Harold and Mortimer Dinerman. Devoted son of the late Alexander and Edna Dinerman. Cherished uncle of Ellen, Ruth and David Dinerman, and Joel and Nancy Berger, and favored brother-in-law of Miriam Dinerman. Revered longtime colleague of Marilyn Jann and Bill Levine. He was predeceased by his wife of 29 years, Helen Schneider Dinerman. Services were held. Contributions in his memory to Helen S. Dinerman Memorial Foundation, 136 E. 57 St., Room 505, NY, NY 10022.

title: Workers' Free Wine Ends, But South Africans Still Pay
description: Magrieta Manus and her husband, Bastiaan, have lived and worked on the same vineyard here for more than 40 years, making do with their nine children in two dilapidated rooms set on such a steep hill that their rocky, slanted dirt floor is usually damp from the rain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, MARILYN FULLER
description: CASEY-Marilyn Fuller. On July 7, 1999. Beloved wife of John L. Casey. Cherished mother of John M. Casey, Charles F. Casey, Edward C. Casey, also survived by brother Milton A. Fuller, sister Ellen Fuller Kaufmann, granddaughter Skye Reid Casey, grandson Aidan Alvah Casey. Service Saturday, July 10, 10 AM at St Rosalie's Chapel on the corner of Walnut Avenue and Montauk Highway in East Quogue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to MADD or Vincentian Fathers.

title: Lowe's Network Expands to Japan
description: Lowe & Partners Worldwide in London, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had expanded its agency network to Japan by entering into a partnership with, and taking a minority equity stake in, Standard Advertising in Tokyo.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The cello is a large instrument. But Cello, the restaurant, could hardly be smaller. It's tucked into the basement of an an Upper East Side town house, the new headquarters for Cello Music and Film Systems, which designs and builds home theaters.

title: Talented Mare Is Back After a Year's Absence
description: It will be the sixth race at Belmont Park today, an allowance with a purse of $52,000, but it will really be a drama in one act titled, ''The Return of Mossflower.''

title: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (to Be the Entree)
description: Francis Veber's giddy, lightweight odd-couple comedies are guilty pleasures. Enough French moviegoers know that to have made ''The Dinner Game'' the second-biggest hit in France last year, after ''Titanic.'' But for all the beguiling silliness of his best French farces, like ''Les Comperes'' before it became ''Father's Day,'' few have traveled well. Bad things happen to Mr. Veber's fluffy conceits when they cross the Atlantic, as evidenced by a sorry string of remakes like ''Jungle 2 Jungle,'' ''Pure Luck'' and ''The Toy.'' ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' which he wrote with Edouard Molinaro, is still the best-known illustration of this filmmaker's light, remake-ready touch.

title: Forgotten Corners of America
description: Few places in America are as impoverished as the Pine Ridge Indian reservation in South Dakota. On Wednesday, President Clinton sat on a dilapidated porch belonging to a woman who had 28 people living in her five bedrooms. He heard about the troubles of a place where the unemployment rate among the Oglala Sioux is 73 percent. The day before, on a sweltering afternoon, he walked through the boarded-up streets of the Mississippi Delta town of Clarksdale.

title: Journey in a Labyrinth of Dreams
description: At his best, Robert Wilson can reduce you to the state of a spaced-out, slack-jawed teen-ager, the sort who attends midnight shows of Disney's ''Fantasia'' with an attitude of religious awe. ''Oh, wow,'' you think, as Mr. Wilson summons yet another phantasmal image that seems to have stepped right out of your own subconscious. ''How incredibly cool.''

title: Goodbye Tiger Stadium, With a Blast
description: Tiger Stadium, ancient and run down by modern ball-park standards, never appealed to the esthetic side of Tino Martinez. But, he added with a smile before tonight's game, he always liked hitting here.

title: Campaign Flight Subsidies
description: With the launching of Hillary Rodham Clinton's undeclared Senate campaign, taxpayers are no longer paying for her trips around New York. Or so it is said. In fact, the cost of Mrs. Clinton's flights on Air Force jets will be reimbursed only by the equivalent of first-class air tickets for her and her campaign assistants. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, meanwhile, has begun using private jets for his campaign travel, and is also paying the owner the equivalent of first-class fare. In effect, both campaigns are being subsidized -- by the taxpayers in Mrs. Clinton's case and by private jet owners in Mr. Giuliani's. There ought to be a better way.

title: The Observer Considers a Deal With a Canadian Publishing Giant
description: The Canadian newspaper publisher Conrad M. Black -- whose company, Hollinger International Inc., publishes The Jerusalem Post, The Chicago Sun-Times, The Daily Telegraph in London and 61 of Canada's 105 daily newspapers -- has turned his eye to New York City, and is examining the weekly newspaper The New York Observer.

title: SMITHKLINE TO CUT 800 JOBS AT FIVE ANTIBIOTICS PLANTS
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Europe's fifth-biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it planned to cut 800 jobs, or about 1.4 percent of its work force, as it consolidates its antibiotics manufacturing operations. SmithKline, which makes antibiotics like Augmentin and Amoxil, plans to end production at five plants in Spain, France, Mexico, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Five others -- in Scotland, England, Belgium, France and Singapore -- will become the company's main antibiotic centers. The plan is part of a larger effort announced Feb. 9 to streamline operations and save more than $300 million a year by 2002 to compete better in the $300 billion drug industry.

title: Turbulence Hurts 63 Aboard Jet
description: Sixty-three people, including four flight attendants, were slightly injured yesterday when a Continental Air Lines jet flying from Newark to Puerto Rico encountered severe turbulence just south of Bermuda.

title: For 3d Year, No. 7 Line Tops a Ranking of Subway Service
description: Amid the surging use of the subways and rider-friendly innovations like discounted fares and Metrocard vending machines, one fact of subway service remains the same: some lines work much better than others.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton's Poverty Tour Highlights a Mixed Record

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELBALSO, HENRIETTA (HENNY)
description: DelBALSO-Henrietta (Henny). To a lady we loved very much, the fondest of memories and deepest sympathies to her son Paul. The Ostrau Family

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the rock musician Mark Sandman on Tuesday misstated his age. He was 46, not 47.

title: U.S. Issuing New Rules to Gain Contracts
description: Even before the Clinton Administration issued new rules that would bar Federal contracts to chronic corporate lawbreakers, the United States Chamber of Commerce was attacking the rules, calling them an arbitrary ''blacklist'' and a sop to organized labor.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Capturing the Listeners In Genghis Khan Country
description: Fifteen years ago, Paul Pena, a blind San Francisco-based blues musician of Cape Verdean descent, was listening to his shortwave radio when he was riveted by some eerie vocal sounds on a program broadcast from Radio Moscow.

title: Are the Primaries Over Before They've Started?
description: The news last week that Gov. George W. Bush has already garnered more than $36 million in campaign money is evidence of two alarming developments in our Presidential nominating system.

title: F.A.A. Says Boeing Failed to Disclose Problem
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that the Boeing Company had known for more than a year about a safety defect in the fuel valves of its 757 jets, but failed to tell regulators. The agency proposed a penalty of $392,000.

title: Officer Acquitted in Squeegee Man's Shooting
description: An off-duty police officer who shot and wounded an unarmed squeegee man last year in the Bronx was cleared of all criminal charges yesterday by the judge who presided at his nonjury trial.

title: Panel Urges Plan to Curb Proliferation Of Weapons
description: The Government's efforts to fight the spread of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons are disorganized and overlapping, says an independent commission that calls for a new White House czar to direct a streamlined defense against ''a grave threat to the United States.''

title: The Guns of Africa
description: If the opponents in Congo's 11-month war sign their planned cease-fire agreement, they will be trying to bring closure to the single event that has destabilized all of Central Africa: the genocide in Rwanda. It won't be easy.

title: Truckers in Argentina Halt a Crippling Strike
description: Tens of thousands of truck drivers halted a three-day-old nationwide strike today after the lower house of Congress voted to postpone a new vehicle tax intended to cover a $100-a-month raise for teachers.

title: A Dream Beckons: Future to Past And West to East
description: The peony is a hardy flower. Its theatrical counterpart has survived 400 years in China and now a trip across the Pacific. It has been thwarted by bureaucrats at home, shortened and modernized abroad. Now, as ''The Peony Pavilion,'' it faces another test: maximization. Placed at the center of Lincoln Center Festival '99, Tang Xianzu's wandering epic of love, death and the supernatural is testing the endurance of both its players and its audience: 6 episodes, 20 hours, the cycle to be repeated three times this month.

title: Blackout Spoils Research Work In Medical Labs
description: Columbia University medical researchers said yesterday that the power failure that darkened northern Manhattan may have destroyed or set back by months hundreds of experiments into illnesses from Alzheimer's disease to cancer to AIDS.

title: Paddling Offshore to His Destiny, Steel Lures and Pride in Tow
description: The notion that I could combine two of my favorite summer pursuits, sea kayaking and fishing, came to me last year. I read an account of a New York City firefighter fishing from a kayak in the Atlantic off Montauk. The man hooked a 40-pound bluefin tuna, then for 45 minutes was dragged on what 19th-century whalers called a Nantucket sleigh ride. The story struck an atavistic chord. I had an ancestor, Jesse Halsey, who was a Sag Harbor whaling captain, and it must have been from him that I inherited a mad urge to go offshore. Call me Ishmael or just call me crazy. This summer, I had my first opportunity to use one of man's original fishing boats -- the kayak -- to chase the mighty bluefin tuna and elusive striped bass.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Album of the Week
description: THE BETA BAND -- (Astralwerks). Where Kid Rock reconfigures rap for the testosterone-addled hard-rock crowd, the Beta Band remakes rap for fans of cerebral low-fidelity indie-rock (call it wimp hop).
