Full of samples, drum machines, beatboxing and gentle Scottish-accented rapping in addition to standard rock-band instrumentation and all kinds of noisemakers, this first full-length album by the Beta Band often sounds like a recording-studio party where instruments are seen more as toys. Rhythms are often punctuated by whistles, bells, cheers, trotting horses and sounds not unlike a cuckoo clock, while as many as four different genres of music are pressed back to back within a single song. But the talent of the Beta Band is that, like any good jam band, the chaos occasionally crystallizes into beauty, in this case very gentle, introspective pop songs like ''It's Not Too Beautiful.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARCIA, MARIO FRANCIS
description: GARCIA-Mario Francis, 81, of Woldbrook Drive, Windham, ME, died Wednesday at his home. Born in Brooklyn, NY. Son of Marcelino and Mary Greevy Garcia. He was schooled at Brooklyn Preparatory School and received his B.S. degree from Georgetown University School of Foreign Service. Mr. Garcia had owned and operated Garcia & Diaz, a steamship company, in Manhattan. He moved to Windham 12 years ago from Asharoken, NY. He was a member of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Windham. During World War II, Mr. Garcia was an intelligence officer in the Army and later served as a fighter pilot instructor in the Army Air Corps. Surviving him are his wife of 57 years, Janet Mary (McConville) Garcia of Windham; two sons, Peter M. Garcia of Auburn, ME, and Stephen J. Garcia of Cranford, NJ; one daughter, Linda L. Marion of Wooster, OH; five grandchildren, Adam Garcia of Lewiston, ME, Matthew Garcia of Los Angeles, Jonathon Marion of Jasper, IN, Katherine Marion of Somerville, MA, and Susan Marion of Washington, DC; and two great grandchildren. There are no visiting hours. A memorial Mass will be held at 10 AM Saturday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Route 302, North Windham, ME. Rev. Ed Thomson will officiate. For more information, contact Dolby Funeral Chapel, Windham. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to St. Joseph's College, 278 Whites Bridge Road, Standish, ME 04084.

title: White House And First Lady Are at Odds Over Jerusalem
description: Taking a position that differs from her husband's policy on a rancorous Middle East dispute, Hillary Rodham Clinton says she considers Jerusalem the ''eternal and indivisible capital of Israel'' and favors moving the American Embassy there from Tel Aviv as soon as possible, according to a letter released by her aides today.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: New Landmark For 'Talk' Party

title: Metro Business; Utility Dividend Possible
description: Northeast Utilities, New England's largest utility, said yesterday that it was considering reinstating its dividend by the end of the year, two years after suspending it because of problems at its Millstone nuclear power complex in Waterford, Conn.

title: Ronny Graham, 79, Actor and Mel Brooks's Writing Collaborator
description: Ronny Graham, an actor and writer who worked in theater and films and who was known for his frenetic pacing and ear-to-ear leer, died on Sunday at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 79 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 30 about Coca-Cola's handling of the recall of its beverages in Belgium and France last month misspelled the surname of Belgium's Health Minister. He is Luc Van den Bossche, not Van den Brossche.

title: The Road to Manhood, Paved in Raunchy Jokes and Pie
description: Which scene is the grossest? The beer scene? The pie scene? The toilet scene? All over the country during the next few weeks, teen-agers able to wangle their way into the R-rated comedy ''American Pie'' will be comparing notes and debating the carefully measured jolts of a high school sex farce that knows exactly how far to push the envelope without seriously offending anyone. Basic bathroom humor, after all, doesn't have to worry about being politically incorrect. That's one reason it's so popular nowadays.

title: Tatyana Murray
description: I-20 Gallery

title: 'Kill All Lies'
description: Luhring Augustine

title: So, How Much For the Degas?
description: Since it is considered taboo to ask the price of a work of art hanging on the walls of a museum, it was daring for Sarah Hyde, a curator at the Courtauld Institute of Art's gallery in London, to organize an entire exhibition based on the value of art in its permanent collection.

title: Sola Sierra, Chilean Crusader For Human Rights, Dies at 63
description: Sola Sierra, who campaigned to bring to justice those responsible for the death of her husband and hundreds of other Chilean dissidents during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, died on July 1 at a hospital in Santiago, Chile, where she lived. She was 63.

title: LYONNAIS SHARES JUMP
description: The shares of Credit Lyonnais S.A. jumped on their first day of trading. The shares closed at 29.01 euros, compared with the initial public offering price of 26.2 euros for institutions and 25.5 euros for individuals. The French Government priced the stock to insure the success of the sale of the bank, which is recovering from unbridled expansion that pushed it near bankruptcy in 1994.

title: A Gospel Performer Who Applies His Multiple Talents to One End
description: Few of us, whether we're fundamentalists or nonbelievers, are aware of how deeply religion penetrates our lives: it informs everything from our ambitions to our way of thinking about ourselves and the world, and to what extent we think about those things at all. The same is true of music: Nearly every note we hear on the radio is informed by religion, whether you want to trace it to the mix of African spirituality and Protestant hymnody that is the cradle of most black American music or further back to the early ecclesiastical musical developments that are the cornerstone of Western music.

title: Is Hillary Clinton A Carpetbagger?
description: To the Editor:

title: Part of Eye's Function Grows Clearer
description: Researchers have found a protein that regulates the blood vessels in the eye, a discovery that may help explain the longstanding puzzle of how the transparent parts of the eye are usually kept free of blood vessels.

title: Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq to Another Record
description: Technology stocks swept the Nasdaq market to its fifth record in six sessions yesterday, while other widely watched gauges sagged, rallied, then faded again to finish lower.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Is Hillary Clinton A Carpetbagger?; Not an Exam
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney to Join Operations Of Studio and ABC Units
description: The Walt Disney Company became the first large Hollywood production studio to put its operations under the same umbrella as a television network when it announced yesterday that it would consolidate its television entertainment divisions into one unit.

title: In Ploy, G.O.P. Plans Debate on Democratic Patients' Bill
description: In an odd bit of political jujitsu, Senate Republican leaders said today that they would use a Democratic bill as the main vehicle for four days of debate next week on the rights of patients buffeted by turmoil in the health care industry.

title: Metro Business; Lower Gas Bills Coming
description: New Jersey Natural Gas customers will see lower utility bills starting this month.

title: Liza Lou -- 'American Glamorama'
description: Grand Central Terminal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, ST. JOHN, SR.
description: CASEY-St. John, Sr., RSHM, age 89, at Tarrytown, New York, July 2. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 69 years. Musician and educator, served at Marymount Schools and Colleges in Tarrytown & Manhattan, NY; Richmond and Arlington, Va., and at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown. Survived by a brother, Laurence F. Casey, and many nieces and nephews.

title: Thousands Lack Power, Mostly on Lower East Side
description: And on the second day, thousands of New Yorkers were still without power.

title: Between Magazines, a Break for Maternity
description: IN his 11 days of life, Oliver Betts Brown has acquired, among other gifts, a Ralph Lauren cotton undershirt, a Donna Karan baby blanket, three Comme des Garcons button-down shirts and one off-white cashmere cardigan. His mother says he now has enough clothes to last for, approximately, ''forever.''

title: A Radiant Spirit at Home in Quiet Geometries
description: ''God is in the details'' may be a hackneyed phrase, but it freshens up considerably in front of Clara Gutsche's photographs of the interiors of Canadian convents and the nuns who live there. Fifty-four of these images, in both black and white and color, form Ms. Gutsche's show at the Americas Society, her first solo in New York City.

title: Tough Lessons in Identity At the Fraternity House
description: Timeliness is the principal virtue of ''Defying Gravity.''

title: Rethink Borrowing That Cup of Sugar
description: In a stylish throwback to the paranoid thrillers of the 1970's, ''Arlington Road'' casts Jeff Bridges, near right, as a professor who uncovers a conspiracy almost in his backyard, with Tim Robbins, far right, and Joan Cusack playing smiling, sinister suburbanites to perfection. They may not be witches, but the characters in khaki at this film's bland barbecues are even worse neighbors than the ones in ''Rosemary's Baby.''

title: Consumer Borrowing Expanded in May
description: Borrowing by consumers grew at the fastest pace in four months in May, led by record demand for cars and trucks, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Well-Known and Worn-Out
description: It is safe to say that no one from the cast of ''On the Waterfront'' had watched the women's national soccer team practice until the actor Karl Malden showed up today, along with about 2,000 members of The Sopranos, those adolescent warblers who were in full-throated Mia-mania.

title: Jolly Pots In Hot Colors Are Back
description: After the return of hippie chic, will Bizarre wares be next?

title: SOFTBANK SAYS IT WILL INVEST $91 MILLION IN MORNINGSTAR
description: The Softbank Corporation said yesterday that it would invest $91 million in Morningstar Inc. in return for a 20 percent stake in the company. The companies, which formed a joint venture in Japan last year, said the money would be used to accelerate the growth of Morningstar's Internet business. Softbank, a software distributor in Japan, holds interests in more than 100 Internet-related companies. Morningstar, of Chicago, is a privately held company that provides research and analysis of mutual funds, stocks and variable annuities.

title: At $90 Million, Rothschild Sale Exceeds Goals
description: Records were broken one after another for Old Master paintings, medieval manuscripts and antiques of every variety at Christie's today as more than three and a half hours of feverish bidding erupted over a trove of treasures looted by the Nazis and returned to the Rothschild family this year by the Austrian Government.

title: Reservists a Crucial Factor In Effort Against Milosevic
description: Beneath a sign for the Swing Jeans Shop, a dozen or so Serbian policemen in powder blue uniforms stood around tonight, glaring at locals who dared gather here for the fourth night running to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Indonesia Military Sorts Out Its Role
description: Every morning, marine guards prop their plastic riot shields in menacing rows outside the Parliament building. Then, shirts off, they jog around the seat of Indonesia's Government as if they own the place, chanting aggressively.

title: Props Take Off In Internet Sales
description: Movie memorabilia often takes on a life of its own. Fans of old films will pay huge sums for items like the ruby slippers Judy Garland wore as Dorothy in ''The Wizard of Oz'' or wait in long lines to view gowns worn in classic movies or even the cars that stars once drove. But New Line Cinema has discovered, to its surprise and delight, that in today's speeded-up world, moviegoers no longer wait a generation to covet props from films. They want them now and are willing to pay big bucks to get them.

title: Man Burns Estranged Wife, Then Kills Himself, Police Say
description: A 38-year-old man severely burned his wife with a chemical and set fire to the Long Island house of his employer and former landlord before hanging himself in Prospect Park, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONCY, MICHELE
description: BONCY-Michele. On Thursday, July 8, 1999. Sister of Fabienne Boncy Taylor, Reginald Boncy and Judith Boncy-Scholz. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue at Harrison Street, NW, Washington, DC on Saturday, July 10 from 3 to 5 P.M. where services will be held at 5 P.M. Interment in Haiti. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Les Soeurs de la Madeleine, 84 Engle Rue, Americane and Rue Pavee, Port of Prince, Haiti, Attention: Sister Francis.

title: Rothschild Treasures Set Records
description: Artworks looted by the Nazis from the Austrian branch of the Rothschild family sold for prices well above their estimates at an auction last night at Christie's in London. Article, page A6.

title: Islander Arena Deal Has Strings Attached
description: Although the Islanders' owners have offered to finance most of the cost of building a new arena to replace Nassau Coliseum, at least three conditions must be met to complete a deal, including the county's buying out the current lease from SMG, the company that runs the arena.

title: U.S. Moves to Tighten Reins On New Internet Regulator
description: Responding to growing criticism of the way the Internet's new governing body is operating, the Commerce Department told the nonprofit group today to eliminate a $1 fee on Internet address registrations, to open its board meetings to the public immediately and to draft clear restrictions on the boundaries of its authority.

title: Hillary Clinton's Campaign Spurs A Wave of G.O.P. Fund-Raising
description: With calls to ''pillory Hillary,'' conservative and Republican organizations are mobilizing to raise millions of dollars all over the country in an effort to crush Hillary Rodham Clinton's all-but-certain Senate candidacy in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIBEL, ARIE, M.D.
description: FEIBEL-Arie, M.D. The Medical and Dental Staff of Coney Island Hospital mourns the loss of our dear friend and long time colleague, Arie Feibel. Dr. Feibel, Chairman, Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, a beloved and respected leader for many years. In addition to a comprehensive understanding of medicine, Dr. Feibel was unusually knowledgeable about every aspect of culture, politics and life. We will remember his dedication, energy, and commitment as we continue his work. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Ruth, and son Theodor and all who loved him. His brilliant intellect and engaging wit will be missed by us all.

title: DROP IN CANADIAN UNEMPLOYMENT
description: Unemployment in Canada hit a nine-year low in June, dropping half a percentage point from the previous month, though few additional jobs were created. While still substantially higher than the rate in the United States, unemployment in Canada has dropped to 7.6 percent, the lowest level since June 1990. But Statistics Canada said the half-point decrease was primarily caused by a decline in the number of people registered as actively seeking work rather than by job growth, which has been disappointing.

title: A Balance of Power
description: Faced with an increasingly competitive marketplace in which nimble companies are rewarded by investors, Consolidated Edison has been shedding its work force in recent years as part of a wider effort to trim costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEDRO, GEORGIE V.
description: PEDRO-Georgie V. Passed in her 95th year, of natural causes, on July 2, 1999. Beloved wife of George, loving mother of Laura and Donald. Adoring grandmother of Kevin, Marla, Paul, Laura, Donna, Donald, Bruce and Patty. Adored great-grandmother of Stephen, Elisabeth, Lindsay and Laura. We forever love and forever remember. Till we meet again. Interment was held on Tuesday, July 6 at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, EILEEN
description: HEALY-Eileen. We mourn the passing on July 7, 1999 of our beloved friend and colleague who was a devoted, committed and outstanding leader of NGO activities of global importance at the United Nations. Her passing leaves a void that cannot be filled. Conference of Non-Governmental Organizations in Consultative Relationship With U.N. (CONGO) NGO Committee on Aging NGO Committee on the Status of Women NGO Committee on Mental Health

title: Legal Journal; Legal Scholar to Finish Work of His Late Mentor
description: Two nationally known black legal scholars were separated by more than a generation but connected by a shared view of the world. One died last winter. Now the other, in a final tribute that is something like one man completing another's last sentence, is finishing his friend's incomplete books and articles.

title: The High Cost of Long Island Politics
description: Creating a fiscal crisis in a prosperous suburban county during one of the biggest economic booms in American history takes some doing, but the Nassau County Executive, Thomas Gulotta, has pulled it off. The county ended 1998 with a deficit of nearly $200 million, and is wrestling with another big projected gap this year. Its ridiculous property tax assessment system, which has turned challenging assessments into a local industry, is costing the county more than $100 million a year in refunds. In the latest blow, Standard & Poor's has announced that it is reducing the rating of the county's bonds to BBB -- near junk status.

title: DuPONT TO COMPLETE ITS DIVESTITURE OF CONOCO
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company has set the terms for splitting off its 70 percent stake in Conoco Inc., giving DuPont shareholders as much as $11.5 billion and completing the divestiture. DuPont, the largest chemical company in the United States, said it would swap 2.95 shares of Conoco class B common shares for one share of DuPont common stock. The tax-free exchange is an 18 percent premium to Conoco's closing price on Thursday. DuPont shareholders can exchange a maximum of 148 million shares. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., sold a 30 percent stake in the Houston-based Conoco to investors last year as part of its plan to focus more on its life-sciences business.

title: TV Choices for Kids; Quality Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; BUFETE DEADLINE LOOMS
description: With only six days left before payment of a $100 million bond issue is due, Bufete Industrial S.A., a big Mexican construction and engineering company, has given no hint about how it will refinance the debt. Trading of Bufete's shares was temporarily suspended this week after the stock fell more than 20 percent in one day. The company has seen its business drop during years of austere Government spending and slow privatization of the electric and petrochemical industries. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: ALLIED SIGNAL SELLS ONE BUSINESS AND BUYS ANOTHER
description: Allied Signal Inc. sold its Laminate Systems business yesterday to Rutgers A.G. for about $425 million and purchased Johnson Matthey P.L.C.'s electronics unit for $655 million. ''Divesting Laminate Systems removes us from the lower-margin laminate industry, and acquiring Johnson Matthey Electronics supports our business strategy to enter additional higher-margin specialty segments,'' Allied Signal's chief executive, Lawrence A. Bossidy, said in a statement. Johnson Matthey Electronics, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., had sales of $671 million for the year ended March 31. It is one of the leading suppliers of materials to the semiconductor industry. Rutgers, based in Essen, Germany, is a plastics and chemicals company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, LEO R., DR.
description: SCHWARTZ-Leo R., Dr. 7/10/95. Forever remembered. Forever loved. G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEAN, Q.A. SHAW JR.
description: McKEAN-Q.A. Shaw Jr. The Board of Directors, Members and Staff of Fountain House express their deep sorrow on the loss of our friend and colleague Shaw. He became Treasurer in 1987 from 1990, served as the President of the Board for 3 years and later headed-up our successful Fund for Fountain House. He continued to serve as Treasurer until his death. Shaw's generosity of spirit, dedication, energy and talents have benefited all who came into contact with him, and his high standards of excellence have been a key ingredient in helping our clubhouse programs achieve national and international recognition for serving men and women with major mental illnesses. We extend our deepest sympathy to Linda and his family. His friendship and kindness will be missed by us all.

title: Cancer Study Prompts Surge in Desire for CAT Scans
description: After reading yesterday morning about a new study by researchers at Cornell Medical Center showing that CAT scans could provide early detection of lung cancer in smokers and former smokers, Richard Bauer called Cornell to find out when he could have the test.

title: Tribal Colleges Need More Federal Money
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Barak's Peace Mission

title: Heat Wave Toll Climbs to 27 Dead in New York City
description: The number of deaths directly tied to the record heat in New York City this week had risen to 27 through Thursday, a spokeswoman for the City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Wednesday described the frustration of a Maryland prosecutor on learning that a Montgomery County teen-ager had pleaded not guilty to a murder charge in Israel after avoiding extradition to the United States. The teen-ager, Samuel Sheinbein, had assured the Israeli courts that if tried in Israel, he would plead guilty to the murder of a classmate in the United States. The American prosecutor expressed concerns about Israel's ability to win a conviction.

title: FEDCO TO SELL ITS REAL ESTATE ASSETS TO TARGET STORES
description: Fedco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its real estate assets, including 13 stores in Southern California, to the Dayton Hudson Corporation's Target Stores for about $120 million. Fedco, based in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., is the nonprofit operator of 10 membership retail stores and 3 appliance and furniture centers. Fedco, which is going forward with the deal under a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition, said it would cease its retailing operations after holding close-out sales of existing inventories. Target, a national retailer based in Minneapolis with 859 stores in 41 states, intends to remodel most of the stores and dispose of the rest.

title: A Strong Debut for Liquid Audio Stock
description: Shares of Liquid Audio Inc., which sells software that lets consumers download music from the Internet, more than doubled today in their first day trading.

title: Working Hard, More or Less; Studies of Leisure Time Point Both Up and Down
description: In a society in which the long lunch has gone the way of the screened-in porch and free time often seems as rare as a telephone without call waiting, it is surprisingly difficult to get a definitive answer to the deceptively simple question of whether Americans have more or less time on their hands than they used to.

title: In One County, the Blackouts End, but Not the Grumbling
description: After three days of sporadic blackouts, all electricity was restored yesterday to thousands of homes and businesses in 10 towns in Monmouth County, N.J. But some mayors and police chiefs were fuming about what they called spotty and confused communications with the utility company, GPU Energy.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS STEADY. The chief currency analyst at Mellon Bank said the dollar remained strong against the yen despite heavy foreign demand for Japanese equities. The dollar settled at 122.38 yen, down from 122.61.

title: Tribal Colleges Need More Federal Money
description: To the Editor:

title: ALCOA PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 20 MILLION SHARES
description: The Pittsburgh-based aluminum giant Alcoa Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to 20 million shares, or about 5 percent of its stock outstanding. The company announced a buyback of 20 million shares in January, under which about 12 million were actually purchased. It has about 367 million shares outstanding. Alcoa said it would buy the shares in the open market and use them for employee-benefit plans and other purposes. The shares rose $.1875 yesterday, to $62.625.

title: Music That Reels In Sound With a Net Spread Wide
description: Classical music lives much of its current life in the past. Its present is a continuing fumble in search of identity. The future seems a hopeless puzzle. Yet occasionally, there are breaks in the clouds and a few glimpses forward, be they for better or worse. One is Ryuichi Sakamoto's score for ''The Days Before: Death, Destruction and Detroit III,'' Robert Wilson's production for Lincoln Center Festival '99 at the New York State Theater. Mr. Sakamoto may not signal music's future, but the ingredients for such a future were skulking around inside his music on Thursday night.

title: Barak's Quest Starts With Boost by Egypt
description: The new Prime Minister of Israel promised today to ''turn every stone'' in the quest for a broader Middle East peace. But he cautioned that it would be a few weeks before he would be ready to make his first moves.

title: Republican Senator Urges Income Tax Cut to Aid Middle Class
description: Seeking to give a modest break to middle-class taxpayers as the budget surplus swells, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee today proposed reducing the lowest Federal income tax rate to 14 percent from 15 percent.

title: THE SHAPE OF ABORTION TO COME
description: The French pill RU-486 is finally coming to America. It may leave the abortion war without a battleground. A report by Margaret Talbot, in The Times Magazine.

title: Sports of The Times; Final Game Owes Great Debt to China
description: EVER since the American organizers took out their indelible-ink pens and plotted the inexorable march from sea to shining sea, there were chauvinistic and realistic expectations that the Yanks would win this 1999 Women's World Cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALE, HENRY
description: GALE-Henry. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Rosenthal). Devoted father of Jeffrey and Sharon. Cherished son of the late Lee & Sam. Services at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Cooper & Cypress Ave.'s, Brooklyn Sunday at 11AM

title: Rebates Rise on Some Chrysler Models
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the third-largest auto maker in the United States, said this week that its Chrysler unit had increased rebates to help sales of slow-selling small cars.

title: Police Say Brooklyn Man Beat His Wife to Death
description: A 32-year-old Brooklyn man beat his wife to death yesterday and then assaulted the man he suspected of having an affair with her, the police said.

title: Indexes End on High Note for a 2d Consecutive Friday
description: For the second consecutive Friday, the stock market finished the week with a hat trick, as all the three major indexes reached new highs. Bond prices ended slightly lower as the Ford Motor Company completed the biggest corporate bond issue ever.

title: Election Money? Help Yourself
description: With all the campaign finance scandals and abuses of recent years, at least one barrier has not been breached: Federal officeholders have not actually found a way to take large campaign contributions and put the money into their own pockets.

title: Acquitted Officer May Face New Charges
description: Police officials said yesterday that they would probably bring departmental proceedings against the officer acquitted of criminal charges in the shooting of an unarmed squeegee man. But they said it would be difficult to establish violations of police procedure because they would be using much of the same evidence used in the criminal trial.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOPNICK, MAX
description: CHOPNICK-Max. July 8, 1999. Husband of Anita Stevens and the late Marjorie Marsh Chopnick. Brother of Gertrude, Sandra and Charles. Stepfather of the late Charles Enfield. Counselor-at-law, philanthropist, mentor who enriched the lives of so many. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial Wednesday, July 14, 2:00 PM at 21 West 52nd Street, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: With Runners on Base, Piazza Strikes a Blow
description: Mike Piazza spoke of atonement yesterday before the latest subway series began.

title: THAILAND CUTS BANK RATE
description: Thailand's central bank cut its official bank rate for the second time in two weeks to a record low, aiming to revitalize the nation's economic recovery by lowering borrowing costs. The benchmark rate was cut 1.5 percentage points, to 4 percent, effective immediately. The bank made a similar reduction on June 25. The rate, the Thai equivalent of the United States Federal Reserve discount window rate, was previously lowered in February. Before that, the central bank had not reduced the discount rate since August 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONAS, ILSE
description: JONAS-Ilse. Age 91, died July 8 in Pittsburgh, PA. Beloved wife of the late Fred Jonas, devoted mother of Jeffrey and Carla. She worked tirelessly for the National Council of Jewish Women and Camp Louemma. She will be missed by all those she touched. Services Sunday, 11AM, Schwartz Bros Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. For information 718-263-7600. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: The First Lady Backs Farmers On Milk Cartel
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton completed her first campaign tour across New York today with an embrace of the state's dairy farmers, declaring her support for Federal legislation that would assure them higher prices but likely force up the price of milk for consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, MICHAEL J.
description: FRIEDLANDER-Michael J. Michael, you were a lifelong friend to Susan and me. We shall always cherish the many wonderful moments spent in your company. Our condolences are extended to your wife, Michelle, to Marilyn, your loving sister, and John, your brave and loyal son. Susan and Peter Schweitzer

title: Day Trading: Not a Sure Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNEBORN, CLARA L.
description: SONNEBORN-Clara L. On July 8, 1999, Clara Louise Sonneborn (nee Lauer). Loving wife of the late Henry Sonneborn III. Beloved mother of Peter Sonneborn. Beloved sister of the late Elinor Israel. Devoted sister-in-law of Lisette S. Scheuer. Beloved aunt of Ann S. Neumann, Henry W. Israel, Jr., Susan I. Levin and Barbara I. Goldner. Also survived by loving great nieces and nephews. Funeral services and interment will be held in Baltimore on July 11, 1999. A memorial service will take place at the Chapel at the Osborn, 101 Theall Road, Rye, NY on Thursday, July 22nd, 11 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, C.L.S. Memorial Fund, 1620 McElderry St, Reed Hall East, Rm 2217, Balt., MD 21205. For info call Levinson Funeral Home 1-800-338-1701.

title: Tailors and Bidders Prosper By Showing Suits That Fit
description: Whenever you have a fit with your partner in a competitive auction, it is almost invariably right to show it irrespective of strength. That is a general principle of bidding, and players who neglect it regularly get the worst of it. An example is the diagramed deal, played last month in the fourth annual charity game for the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation, in aid of a little-known neurological disease.

title: TV Choices for Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Plan for Japan Cable Clears Hurdle
description: The Federal Communications Commission granted a license to a group of companies led by the AT&T Corporation today to build an undersea fiber optic cable between the United States and Japan.

title: Carnival Orders New Ship
description: Carnival Cruise Lines said today that it had exercised an option for a new $375 million, 2,112-passenger ship to be named the Carnival Pride. The builder will be Kvaerner Masa-Yards of Helsinki, Finland, where a sister ship, the Carnival Spirit, is under construction and scheduled to enter service in early 2001. Carnival is a unit of the Miami-based Carnival Corporation, a cruise line operator with annual revenue of $3.3 billion.

title: SLIDE IN CURRENCY IS CHILLING EUROPE
description: It was supposed to be a symbol of new strength and unity, a sign that Europe had finally achieved economic parity with the United States.

title: China Wins Japan Backing To Join World Trade Group
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan met here today and announced that they had reached a trade agreement that effectively won Japan's endorsement for China to join the World Trade Organization.

title: Bilingual Schooling That Works
description: The national reputation of bilingual education has never been worse than it is today. Last year a long-gestating revolt in California culminated in the passage of a proposition forbidding mandatory bilingual instruction. Not many people realize, though, that there is at least one type of bilingual education that works: dual immersion.

title: A Flock Divided; In Rochester, Choice Is Between Priest and Catholic Church
description: All her life, Peggy Shufelt, a seventyish Rochester homemaker, tried to be a good Roman Catholic. Every Sunday she went dutifully to Mass, even if it seemed coldly formal and left her feeling vaguely empty.

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY CRITICIZES POLICE IN NEW YORK CITY
description: In a long investigation of the New York Police Department, Federal prosecutors have amassed evidence of systemwide problems in the department's handling of police brutality complaints, and they are pressing the Giuliani administration for reforms, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETZLER, ESTELLE
description: WETZLER-Estelle. On July 5, 1999. Beloved sister of Dorothy Bracken & Jack Wetzler. Funeral service Monday 10AM, July 12, St. Joseph's Monastery, Baltimore, MD. Condolences to Maureen Kirby-Smith, 602 Charing Cross Road, Baltimore, MD. 21229.

title: Three Sentenced in Archer Daniels Midland Case
description: Three former executives of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, including the son of its former chairman, Dwayne Andreas, were sentenced today to terms ranging from two to two and a half years in prison for their roles in a worldwide scheme to fix prices of a feed additive manufactured by the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, CAROLINE LAWRENCE
description: MURRAY - Caroline Lawrence. Beloved sister of Toby Murray and Midge Baldrige. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: About New York; Motley Crowd Calls Park Special Place
description: TOMPKINS SQUARE PARK began as a marsh, became a center of protest and is most recently a symbol of how a tattered park can blossom. Though this week it is best known as a murder scene, it is more than that.

title: Saudi's Visit To Arms Site In Pakistan Worries U.S.
description: Two months ago, Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister, Prince Sultan bin Abdelaziz al-Saud, made an unusual visit to the Pakistani nuclear and missile facilities near Islamabad, causing alarm in the Clinton Administration.

title: An Early Submarine Born in Heroism
description: While history may be written by the victors, the losers are sometimes remembered with respectful affection. So here is ''The Hunley,'' a television movie that takes its inspiration from a fascinating footnote to the Civil War, saluting a small band of Confederate patriots who served with honor.

title: Yes, Sampras Likely to Play In Cup Singles
description: Pete Sampras initially swore off Davis Cup participation for 1999, then softened his stance and volunteered for doubles duty to support the singles stalwarts Jim Courier and Todd Martin in Boston next weekend for the centenary quarterfinal against Australia. But all indications are that Sampras will be in harness for two singles matches in the three-of-five-match competition July 16-18.

title: $4.9 Billion Jury Verdict In G.M. Fuel Tank Case
description: In what is believed to be the largest award ever in a personal-injury lawsuit, the General Motors Corporation was ordered today to pay $4.9 billion to six people severely burned when the fuel tank of their 1979 Chevrolet Malibu exploded after a rear-end collision.

title: How We Judge Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOIS, ALICE TRIMBLE
description: DUBOIS-Alice Trimble, on July 8, 1999. Beloved by many friends. Will be greatly missed. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, July 9th, 7-9 PM, with service Saturday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the British National Art Collections Fund, Millais House, 7 Cromwell Place, London, England SW7 2JN.

title: City Agency Head Resigns After a Clash on Jail Care
description: The director of the city agency that oversees health care for jail inmates has resigned, city officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Leiter's Clark Kent Routine Continues
description: Al Leiter has been the unmistakable constant that has helped take the Mets from utter turmoil 33 days ago to absolute euphoria last night. They were a team in disarray and caught in an eight-game losing streak when Leiter opposed Roger Clemens and the Yankees in the Bronx last month. Remember that team?

title: Gastineau Gets 15 Days in Jail After Harassment Charge
description: Mark Gastineau, the former Jets defensive end who had a reputation for being volatile both on and off the field, was sentenced to 15 days in jail yesterday after being arrested on charges of violating an order of protection obtained by his wife.

title: SYSCO TO BUY A CALIFORNIA MEAT DISTRIBUTOR
description: The Sysco Corporation, North America's largest food-service distributor and marketer, said yesterday that it was buying the Newport Meat Company of Irvine, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. Separately, Sysco said it would buy back another eight million shares to improve shareholder value. The acquisition of the closely held Newport Meat, which has annual sales of about $100 million, is the Houston-based Sysco's first in California. Newport Meat supplies meats, game and frozen seafood to 1,000 restaurants, private clubs, gourmet food stores, and luxury hotels and resorts in southern California.

title: Fordham Makes It Official: It's Hill
description: Frank McLaughlin, the Fordham University athletic director, spent the past week holding his breath, waiting for a decision from Bob Hill. McLaughlin finally exhaled yesterday morning, as he was heading out of town for the weekend, when he got the news that Hill had agreed to a 10-year contract to become the Rams' head basketball coach.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on June 24 about golfing sites on the World Wide Web misstated the ownership of pgatour.com. It is run by the PGA Tour, not the Professional Golfers Association. A screen illustration with the article was published in error. It was from www.globalgolf .com, not www.globalgolfguide.com.

title: Op-Art; NEW YORK CITY SUMMER CALENDAR 1999
description: Ross MacDonald is an illustrator. Bill Scheft is a former monologue writer for David Letterman.

title: Corrections
description: The Digital Commerce column in Business Day on Monday about efforts to foster on-line discussion groups referred incorrectly to ''American Love Story,'' a PBS documentary that will be the focus of on-line discussions produced in September by Web Lab, a nonprofit group. The documentary is not part of the series ''P.O.V.''; it will have 10 episodes running over 5 evenings, not 5 episodes. Personal anecdotes for the discussion are being gathered on the PBS Web site at www.pbs.org, not on Web Lab's site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGFELD, BERNARD, RABBI
description: KLIGFELD-Bernard, Rabbi. Devoted husband of the late Julia. Loving father of Michael, Alisa, and Adina. Proud grandfather of Jennifer, Adam, Ari, Eli, Justin, Jacqueline, and Emilie. Rabbi Emeritus of Temple Emanuel of Long Beach, NY, and Beth Shalom of Sun City, AZ. Founder with Julie of Jewish Marriage Encounter. Revered teacher. Donations to the United Jewish Appeal and American Cancer Society. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 10:30 A.M., Sunday.

title: Some Telltale Signs
description: Some of the Yankees closest to Darryl Strawberry noticed his mood swings in spring training and how, in the words of one teammate, ''he seemed like a completely different person'' at times. They figured Strawberry's anger was a result of the chemotherapy treatment he was undergoing for his colon cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, TED E. SR. M.D.
description: BECKER-Ted E. Sr. M.D. The Family of Dr. Becker ask that contributions in his memory be made to the Foundation of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute, with the designation that they be used for the furtherance of child analysis.

title: European Union's Commission Is Revamped After a Scandal; a 'New Era' Is Promised
description: The president of the European Union's Executive Commission announced the appointment of 19 commissioners today, promising ''a new era of change'' after the forced resignation of the entire previous commission last spring after accusations of corruption.

title: Blair Spokesman Defends Alliance Briefings : A Key Adviser to NATO Assails Kosovo Coverage
description: LONDON  A key figure in the media campaign waged by NATO governments during the conflict in Kosovo criticized Western journalists on Friday for devoting as much coverage to alliance blunders and Serb civilian casualties as to the atrocities committed by Serb forces against ethnic Albanians.

title: Muslims Denounce Gephardt For Withdrawing a Nominee
description: American Muslim groups said yesterday that they were stunned and betrayed by the decision of the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, to revoke his appointment of an American Muslim to a Congressional counterterrorism commission.

title: Rebel Trial In Turkey Evokes 1925 Case
description: In what may or may not have been an eerie coincidence, the death sentence recently given to the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan was handed down on the anniversary of the death sentence given to Turkey's last famous Kurdish rebel leader.

title: Some Internet Stock Offerings Are Quiet Except for All the Shouting
description: Some chatter on Wall Street this week disrupted what is customarily a quiet period.

title: Agrarian Philosophy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHACKMAN, DOROTHY
description: SHACKMAN-Dorothy. Beloved wife and mother, passed away on July 7th, 1999 in Los Angeles, California, after a lengthy illness. She was blessed with a generous heart, an innocent spirit, and a beautiful singing voice. Devoted to her family she was preceded in death by her husband Dr. Nathan Shackman and is survived by their son Dr. Daniel Shackman of Santa Barbara, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GERALD
description: FRANK-Gerald. Of Lynbrook, LI on July 9, 1999. Husband of June for 49 years. Father of Peter and Emily. Father-in-law of Michele Parker. Grandfather of Dara and Elana. Brother of Doris Ferraro. He was a Veteran of WWII (Chief Finance Officer in the Middle East) and the Korean War. He was a CPA (Partner with Frank & Zimmerman & Co., LLP) and an attorney. Past president of Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook and its treasurer for 15 years. He will be missed. Services at Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook, Sunday, July 11th. at 12 noon.

title: Akers Saves Energy To Give It All She's Got
description: Her father has attended every American match in the Women's World Cup, but sometimes he is too nervous to watch. Bob Akers could not bear to see his daughter, Michelle, take a penalty kick against Brazil in the semifinals, so he buried his head in his hands, she said. She didn't miss the kick, but he did.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR TUMBLES. Sugar fell for the fourth time in five days, as buying from Russia dropped after shippers rushed to beat an Aug. 1 increase in import duties. In New York, sugar for October fell 0.12 cent, to 5.52 cents a pound.

title: Trump Planning to Demolish World's Fair Casino in Atlantic City
description: Donald J. Trump plans to demolish his World's Fair casino in Atlantic City around the end of the year and may build a 4,000-room, $750 million gambling complex in its place, officials of his development company said yesterday.

title: RACING CHAMPIONS GETS AN OFFER OF $11 A SHARE
description: The Racing Champions Corporation, a maker of automobile racing collectibles and souvenirs, received an offer yesterday of $11 a share, or about $182.6 million, from the closely held Enna Corporation. Enna's offer tops an earlier bid of $10 a share from the closely held investment company Racing Acquisitions Inc., which was rejected last month by Racing Champions. Racing Champions, based in Glen Ellyn, Ill., also makes Nascar replicas, Press Pass trading cards and AMT model hobby kits. It had sales of about $156.5 million in 1998.

title: U.N. Survey Finds Wide Destruction in Kosovo Villages
description: Two-thirds of the houses in villages across a wide swath of Kosovo are uninhabitable because of war damage, mainly burning by Serbs; most of the schools are severely damaged or destroyed; much of the water is polluted, and a large part of the agriculture is ruined, according to a United Nations survey released this week.

title: Curbing Y2K Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: Swerve and Sharp Elbow Cost a Hotfoot the Stage
description: Tom Steels of Belgium, who had already won two sprints in this Tour de France, badly wanted to win the sixth stage today because it ended in the French town of Maubeuge, just across the border from his home. Erik Zabel badly wanted to win because he had finished second twice in the last three days and had not yet won a stage. Mario Cipollini badly wanted to win because he had won the previous two days and is insatiable, as all great sprinters are.

title: Waste Management Executives Sold Shares
description: Executives of Waste Management Inc. sold $57.6 million of company stock in May, eight weeks before the company said it would miss earnings forecasts, setting off a 37 percent decline in its share price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, EILEEN
description: ROSEN-Eileen, 77, of Lake Worth, FL died Friday in Ridgewood, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Solomon Rosen. Devoted mother of Mark, Kenneth and Sanford. Sister-in-law of Sidney Rosen. Cherished mother-in-law of Karen and Dolores. Loving grandmother of Emily, Adam, Sarah, Nicole, Caity and Leigh. Sister of Sybil Kirsch and Kay Sperling. Services Sunday July 11, 1999 at 1:00 PM at Menorah Gardens & Funeral Chapel, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: BASEBALL; Strawberry Tries Again To Return To Yankees
description: At 8:42 this morning, Darryl Strawberry entered the Yankees' minor league complex in a silver Ford Expedition.

title: Bruno Voices His Support for Easing the Stringent Rockefeller-Era Drug Laws
description: Joining critics of New York's stringent drug laws, the leader of the State Senate said this week that he favored giving judges greater latitude in determining sentences for drug offenders.

title: Valentine Making Light As He Makes His Points
description: Bobby Valentine scooted along the runway between the dugout and the Mets' clubhouse yesterday and acted as rabid as fans willing to paint their hair orange and blue.

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend yesterday about House Full o' Praise, a gospel series that began Wednesday at the New York Society for Ethical Culture in Manhattan as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99, misstated the closing date and the number of performances. The final performance, the only one at Avery Fisher Hall, is on July 17, not July 16. There are nine performances, not eight.

title: Soccer's Move: Grass Roots to Grand Stage
description: When Julie Foudy attended the 1994 men's World Cup final at the Rose Bowl, the 1999 world soccer championship for women was five years on the horizon and was still being planned for small stadiums on the East Coast.

title: G.O.P. 'Compassion' Comes With Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, HANNAH
description: FRANK-Hannah. Of River Edge, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Leon; devoted mother of Harvey Frank and Ruth Singman; loving grandmother of David, Sharon, Charles, Robert, Cindy and Randi; greatgrandmother of Rebecca and Samantha. Graveside services at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY on Sunday 11 AM. For further information: Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ 1-800-522-0588.

title: Pete Conrad, 69, the Third Man to Walk on the Moon, Dies After a Motorcycle Crash
description: Pete Conrad, who flew to the Moon nearly 30 years ago and became the third man to walk upon it, died Thursday evening after crashing his motorcycle near Ojai, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MILTON
description: GOLDSTEIN-Milton. On July 9, 1999. Beloved father of Linda and Stanley Bergman, and Jeffrey and Natalie Goldstein. Grandfather of Amy, David, Andrew, Jesse, Matthew and Jamie. Loving companion of Lillian Rothstein. Services Sunday, July 11th. at 9:30AM, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard, and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Third-Party Candidacies Worrying Party Leaders
description: Republican Party leaders meeting here said today they were distressed, even alarmed, that conservative contenders for the Presidential nomination might mount third-party candidacies to protest the party establishment's embrace of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROUSSIN, ARTHUR RICHARD
description: ROUSSIN-Arthur Richard. March 12, 1926-July 11, 1993. ''What shall assuage the unforgotten pain and teach the unforgetful to forget?'' Dante Gabriel Rossetti I'll never forget. Stupy

title: A Force Now In the World, Citizens Flex Social Muscle
description: Twenty years ago social activists could identify only one independent organization working to protect the environment in Indonesia. Today there are more than 2,000, an environmental network based in Jakarta reports.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a man who the police said attacked his wife and set fire to his landlord's home before killing himself in Prospect Park misidentified him at one point in some copies. The dead man was Bogdan Koscinska; Robert Koczor is the landlord.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGGIN, JAMES RADFORD
description: COGGIN-James Radford. Prominent NY luthier, died of cancer July 6. Survived by sisters Lola Wilhelm and Hazel Herring. He is missed by friends, and musicians who play his violins and violas.

title: Koch Is Called Fit to Leave Hospital
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch is to be released from the hospital today, nine days after suffering a heart attack, his former press secretary said last night.

title: Kashmir Town Buries Dead, and Fights On
description: Six holy warriors were buried here today beside an apricot tree in Martyr's Square. Their bodies did not require any of the usual ritual washing or the cover of a white shroud. They were placed in their graves just as they had fallen, martyrs already ascended into heaven.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's going to take more than a village to defeat Hillary Clinton.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Batman's Robin Shaves His Legs? Erotica as a Portrait of the Age
description: It may be that erotica is always a bit bizarre, particularly if one isn't initiated into its codes of desire. For one left unseduced, it can seem discomforting and comical, like Zero Mostel playing ''the chauffeur and the contessa'' with wealthy widows in Mel Brooks's film ''The Producers.'' Erotica can make one feel like a voyeur, observing humanity in all its desperate nakedness, inventing extreme excitements.

title: CLARIANT SOLD HOLDINGS
description: Germany's largest drug maker, Hoechst A.G., sold its entire stake in the chemical maker Clariant A.G. for 2.8 billion euros ($2.9 billion), despite expectations that lackluster demand for chemical assets would trip up the sale. Shares of Clariant surged 6.8 percent, their biggest one-day gain in eight months. Hoechst sold shares for 645 Swiss francs ($411) each.

title: Sports of The Times; Joe Torre's Real News About 2001
description: WHEN Joe Torre casually mentioned in a television interview that he was ''not thinking about'' managing the Yankees beyond the 2001 season, it didn't deserve the headlines it received. The Yankee manager was merely repeating what he had first mentioned as long ago as last October when he signed his two-year contract extension.

title: Uproar Against Navy War Games Unites Puerto Ricans
description: For two months now, about three dozen people have occupied the eastern tip of this small island seven miles off Puerto Rico, trespassing on property controlled by the United States Navy in an act of deliberate defiance.

title: Putrajaya Journal; A Leader's Buildings Succeed, at Least in Excess
description: Until last month, Malaysia's new capital city was more rumor than reality. Tightly guarded, rarely photographed and cloaked in mystery, it lurked somewhere in the endless glade of palm-oil plantations south of Kuala Lumpur -- an Atlantis on dry land.

title: They Sought Change and Found Death
description: It has been almost 30 years now since a night of deadly rioting in Belfast prompted Britain to send in army troops to try to restore order in Northern Ireland. Since then at least 3,200 people, many of whom were simply caught in the crossfire, have been killed. In ''The Freedom of the City,'' whose evocative revival is being presented as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99, the Irish playwright Brian Friel tells the fictional story of three of them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUERTH, NORMAN
description: FUERTH-Norman. We always will love and always will miss you. Joanee, Glenn, Tommy, Elyse and your grandchildren.

title: The Resolute Rediscoverer of the Harpsichord
description: During her life Wanda Landowska was quick to claim credit for rescuing the harpsichord from the oblivion it had fallen into by the late 19th century. At the beginning of the 20th century, virtually the only place one could find a harpsichord was in a museum, a musically useless artifact next to other furniture and relics of the Baroque era.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Heady Aroma of Recovery; An Ancient Trade Propels Indonesia's Economy Ahead
description: On a clear day, Singaporeans can see recession-wracked Indonesia from their southern shore. From their living room, Seah Soo Lin and his son Jeng Jye can smell the archipelago's budding recovery.

title: G.O.P. 'Compassion' Comes With Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, STEPHEN F.
description: COHEN-Stephen F. Survived by his mother Dorothy M. Cohen, brothers Ronald L. Cohen of Boca Raton, FL, Kenneth H. Cohen of Kensington, New Hampshire and Alan C. Cohen of Tacoma Park, MD. Also five nieces and nephews. Graveside services Sunday at 11:00 AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Any inquiries please call Parkside Chapels at 718-896-9000

title: Editorial Observer; Mexico's Few Real Voters Finally Speak Out
description: Since 1940, Mexico's presidents have been chosen by an electorate of one. Each president picked the next nominee of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, and each nominee won handily against largely token opposition, by fraud when necessary. President Ernesto Zedillo has declared he will be the last beneficiary of the dedazo, or the pointing of the finger. Instead the PRI will have a national primary in November to choose its candidate for the general election in July 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD
description: SHEPPS-HOWARD. 9/1/53-7/9/92 WE MISS YOU EVERY DAY, IN EVERY WAY...LIFE PERSISTS. WE SEE YOUR BEAUTIFUL FACE-YOUR EYES,HEAR YOUR LAUGHTER....WE WANT MORE

title: Red Wings Sign Wregget as Backup
description: The Detroit Red Wings signed the free-agent goalie Ken Wregget as a backup for Chris Osgood, the team said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, BACKER, RUTH
description: ADLER-BACKER-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Harry A. Adler and Irving Backer. Adored mother of Barbara Weiner and Stephen Adler. Loving grandmother of Alisa and Eric Adler, Geralyn, Lucas, Howard and Paul Weiner. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's Chapels, Inc. (Riverside Building), 331 Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, NYC. Contributions may be made the Ruth Adler-Backer Memorial Fund of the American Heart Association, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, N.Y. 10168.

title: Capriati to Play Graf in Mahwah
description: Before there were such modern prodigies in women's tennis as Martina Hingis, Anna Kournikova and Venus and Serena Williams, there was Jennifer Capriati. She was a Wimbledon semifinalist at 14, the world's sixth-ranked player at 15 and an Olympic champion at 16.

title: Cleveland Museum Was the Buyer Of a Prized Rothschild Portrait
description: The Cleveland Museum of Art emerged today as the buyer of the most prized painting in Thursday's blockbuster sale of Rothschild family treasures: a Frans Hals portrait of a stern-faced Amsterdam merchant that commanded $12.8 million, a record for the artist.

title: Clinton Says G.O.P. Seeks To Avert Vote On H.M.O.'s
description: Gearing up for next week's Senate debate on patients' rights to medical care and insurance, President Clinton lambasted Republican leaders today for what he suggested were cynical delaying tactics intended to defeat Democratic efforts to establish minimum Federal standards for health maintenance organizations and insurers.

title: Tribal Colleges Need More Federal Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the use of CAT scans to detect lung cancer referred incorrectly at one point to steps taken when tumors are detected. Some, but not all, are removed immediately. Others are monitored and removed only if they grow.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNIONBANCAL CORP., San Francisco, a bank holding company that is majority-owned by Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd., said it would cut about 500 jobs, or 5 percent of its staff of 9,800.

title: Clemens Falters as Mets Take Center Stage
description: Armando Benitez whipped a game-ending strike past the Yankees' Chili Davis last night, whirled in a full circle and pumped his right fist, once, twice, five times. Five pumps, one for each of the runs the Mets scored off Roger Clemens. Five pumps for the magnificent performance of Al Leiter. Five pumps for the Mets' badly needed big-game victory.

title: Escobar Has Surgery
description: Alex Escobar, one of the brightest prospects in the Mets' organization, underwent surgery in Manhattan yesterday to repair a torn labrum in his left, nonthrowing shoulder.

title: Religion Journal; Pitching Nonviolence to Hollywood
description: After two teen-age gunmen murdered 12 classmates and a teacher in Littleton, Colo., in April, the wave of public revulsion was big enough to crash around Hollywood, as people sought a way to explain such a horrible event. Society suffers when children are exposed to so much violence on television and the movies, went the familiar complaint.

title: MANEUVERS SHOW RUSSIAN RELIANCE ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Reflecting its growing dependence on nuclear weapons for defense, Russia's military carried out mock nuclear strikes in a major exercise last month, the Defense Minister said today.

title: SHARES OF GENERAL GROWTH FALL AFTER STOCK SALE
description: Shares of General Growth Properties Inc., one of the largest shopping mall companies in the United States, fell yesterday after the company sold 10 million new common shares at a below-market price, raising about $332 million to finance acquisitions and developments. The company's shares fell $1.875, or 5 percent, to $33 on the New York Stock Exchange, as investors and analysts questioned the reasoning behind the sale. Analysts calculated that the sale would increase the amount of General Growth's shares outstanding by 16 percent. The company sold the shares to Lehman Brothers Inc., which is reselling them to investors. General Growth, which is based in Chicago, owns and manages 125 malls in 39 states.

title: Day Trading: Not a Sure Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, FRANK L., MD.
description: MORTON-Frank L., MD. Age 87, of Boca Raton formerly of Mamaroneck, NY. On Tuesday, July 6th, 1999, at Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton. Beloved Husband of Edith Morton and the late Gladys Morton; loving Father of Dr. Robert Morton and Dr. Joyce Johnson; devoted Grandfather of David Morton, Courtney Morton and Gabriel Johnson, survived by Brother, Dr. Leonard Morton and loving relatives and friends. Dr. Frank Morton was a graduate of The New York University School of Medicine. During WWII, he served as an Industrial Medical Officer, and Lieutenant Colonel in the US Air Force. Dr. Morton was a General Practitioner in Larchmont, NY, on the staff of New Rochelle Hospital, until 1969 when he earned an MPH degree at The University of Michigan, and finished his career in public health and epidemiology. Funeral services were held July 9th, 1999 in Delray Beach, Florida.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Is Ordered to Pay $4.9 Billion in Burn Lawsuit

title: Montenegrins, Angry at Serbs, Talk of a Split
description: The Government of Montenegro, once careful not to provoke Big Brother Serbia in Yugoslavia, appears to be moving swiftly toward independence, and seems ready to fight for it if necessary.

title: Brazil Devaluation Is Boon for Border Town
description: The 40 percent devaluation of the Brazilian currency, the real, has shaken stock markets across Latin America and pushed neighboring Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay into deepening recessions. But people are smiling in Chuy.

title: On-Line Grocer Is Setting Up Delivery System For $1 Billion
description: Only a month ago, Webvan Group Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up that sells groceries on line, was taking its first orders from customers. Today it placed a sizable order of its own, asking Bechtel, the engineering and construction giant, to build distribution and delivery centers in 26 markets.

title: Teachers' Union Head Urges More Flexibility in Contract Talks
description: The president of the American Federation of Teachers called yesterday for a drastic change in the way union contracts are negotiated with the nation's 17,000 school districts, saying individual schools should have far more power to make educational decisions in consultation with their teachers.

title: James Farmer, Civil Rights Giant In the 50's and 60's, Is Dead at 79
description: James Farmer, a principal founder of the Congress of Racial Equality and the last survivor of the ''Big Four'' who shaped the civil-rights struggle in the United States in the mid-1950's and 60's, died yesterday at Mary Washington Hospital, in Fredericksburg, Va., where he lived. He was 79.

title: SWISSCOM BOUGHT INTEREST IN DEBITEL
description: The Swiss telecommunications company Swisscom is buying a 58 percent share in the German wireless company Debitel, which has 3.8 million customers. Under the $1.7 billion deal, Swisscom will acquire 32 percent of the company's shares from the car maker DaimlerChrysler and the remaining shares from Divaco, a joint venture of the trading company Metro and Deutsche Bank. The acquisition will nearly double Swisscom's customers, to 7 million.

title: Showing the Way on Gun Control
description: There are signs that Congress may yet approve some gun control measures this year despite last month's debacle in the House that saw Republican leaders and a powerful Democrat, John Dingell of Michigan, conspire to kill a modest gun control package already passed by the Senate. The House version was so weak that even supporters of gun control voted against it.

title: Mare's Perfect Mark Is Spoiled in Return
description: Mossflower, the speedy mare with arthritic ankles, came back from a one-year layoff yesterday and unexpectedly lost for the first time in her career when she was outrun by 4 lengths by Delta Music in the sixth race at Belmont Park.

title: Day Trading: Not a Sure Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Oneida County Seeks Fines From Woodstock '99 Organizers
description: Oneida County is seeking to levy fines of as much as $1.5 million against the organizers of the Woodstock '99 music festival, but the organizers and county officials say they expect the three-day concert to begin as planned on July 23 in Rome, N.Y.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICH, SPO
description: OESTREICH-Spo. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Spo Oestreich, the wife of our former esteemed member Charles Oestreich, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to her family. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, President

title: KN ENERGY TO ACQUIRE A RIVAL PIPELINE COMPANY
description: Shares in the pipeline company KN Energy Inc. soared yesterday as analysts applauded its move to acquire a rival, Kinder Morgan Inc., for $506 million in stock. Shares of KN Energy climbed $6.6875, or 54 percent, to $18.875, with more than 17.5 million shares changing hands. Kinder Morgan gained 25 cents, to $38.625. Under the proposed deal, which was announced late on Thursday, Kinder Morgan's chief executive, Richard Kinder, will serve as chief executive of the combined company, while KN Energy's chief executive, Larry Hall, will step down. The new company will adopt the name Kinder Morgan. The combination will create a company with more than 30,000 miles of pipeline transporting natural gas, refined petroleum products and natural gas liquids.

title: Sparks of Modernity Transform a Classical Style
description: There would seem to be little in common between George Balanchine, who left the Soviet Union for the West in 1924, and Rostislav Zakharov, a choreographer who remained in Leningrad at Balanchine's alma mater, the Kirov Ballet.

title: Federal Inquiry of Police Draws Mixed Reaction
description: News that Federal prosecutors have found systemwide problems in the New York Police Department's handling of brutality complaints brought a triumphant ''I told you so'' chorus from longtime police critics yesterday, though they continued to disagree about how best to reform the department.

title: Kosovo Gypsies Now Among Vengeful Neighbors
description: Crammed into a schoolhouse, 30 to a room, or living in pitched tents in the school grounds, their horses tethered nearby, the Gypsies of Kosovo are living in a precarious state. Always at the bottom of the social pile in this sectarian society, they have now hit their nadir.

title: A Son Rises In Texas; Ross Perot Jr., the Builder, Puts His Stamp on Dallas
description: WHEN it comes to dynasties, Gov. George W. Bush has said that his father's idea of the perfect son was Al Gore. Ross Perot's idea of the perfect son is Ross Perot Jr.

title: A Vulgar Title, a Canceled Show, a Cry of Censorship
description: A group of musicians has accused the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, an avant-garde museum in Long Island City, of censorship. The center's directors canceled the group's performance because its title contained an obscenity aimed at the police.

title: Settling for Prevention
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is trying something new in its quest to teach a lesson to those accused of wrongdoing. In two recent settlements, the commission asked the accused parties, neither of which admitted or denied any wrongdoing, to pay for educational programs to help others avoid future transgressions.

title: Apartment Project Is Pitting Gardener Against Gardener
description: Two gardens grow side by side in the East Village. The City Council says one must die to make way for an apartment and retail project. On Thursday, 50 advocates marched in front of Council offices at 250 Broadway protesting the decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, EILEEN
description: HEALY-Eileen. The six NYC Independent Living Centers, founders of the New York Independent Living Consortium, deeply mourn the passing of our cherished colleague and friend. We shall miss Eileen's wisdom, intelligence, cunning wit, leadership, dedication and charm. No one ever ran a meeting like Eileen. Her skillful expertise of plowing through Board agendas and reaching consensus was quite unique. Her seat at the head of our table is now empty but we pledge that the work she helped start will be continued. Deepest sympathy to her family, friends and the countless number of people with disabilities who knew and loved this outstanding lady.

title: F.A.A. Misses Deadline on Setting Rules for Air Tours
description: Ever since the collision of two aircraft filled with tourists in the Grand Canyon 13 years ago, safety officials have urged the Federal Aviation Administration to step up its oversight of air tours. After a spate of air tour accidents in Hawaii, the F.A.A. promised in 1995 to write new national rules by the end of 1997, calling it ''a high priority.''

title: In a Bathhouse, Sisters Under The Skin
description: THWACK. Splat. Dainty Japanese women pummeled, slapped and kneaded flesh in every corner of the room. Bodies smeared with Vaseline and pureed cucumber lay everywhere. Across the steamy bathhouse an attendant in a black lace bikini poured milk over a female torso. Nearby, my friend bore closer resemblance to a swamp thing than to the elegant flutist who had performed a concert earlier. I didn't, indeed couldn't, laugh. My facial muscles were frozen by the green goo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOPNICK, MAX
description: CHOPNICK-Max. July 8, 1999. Husband of Anita Stevens and the late Marjorie Marsh Chopnick. Brother of Gertrude, Sandra and Charles. Stepfather of the late Charles Enfield. Counselor-at-law, philanthropist, mentor who enriched the lives of so many. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial Wednesday, July 14, 2:00 PM at 21 West 52nd Street, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: Questions for Liza Lou; The Venerable Bead
description: Q: Your biggest sculpture installation, ''Back Yard'' -- a glimmering, over-the-top mirage of Americana -- was made with 30 million tiny glass beads, each of which was applied by hand. It's a complex piece that could inspire a number of different readings. But one thing's clear: you've got a serious thing for beads. How did it get started?

title: East Harlem Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Flings With Staying Power: The Surfer Dude of Sport Utilities
description: SPEND some time with auto company brand managers and you hear the same phrases over and over. ''Active families,'' for instance, or ''extreme sports'' -- shorthand for the activities that are thought to obsess 20-somethings: mountain biking, kayaking, snowboarding, parasailing. Older joints ache at the possibilities.

title: Pont-Aven Art
description: To the Editor: I read with great pleasure Craig R. Whitney's recent article on Pont-Aven, ''A Backwater That Inspired Art'' (May 23). It is a wonderful Breton village.

title: July 4-10; Barak Takes Charge in Israel
description: Ehud Barak, a highly decorated former general, took office as Prime Minister of Israel with an absence of pomp. This is not unusual for Israel, where there is something of an aversion to standing on ceremony. But it seemed to reflect the long delay -- seven weeks -- between Mr. Barak's victory and his swearing-in.

title: Ms. Anderson And Mr. Gray
description: Katherine Scranton Anderson, the daughter of Elizabeth Radley Anderson of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Douglas S. H. Anderson, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Christopher Jon Gray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary R. Gray of Chippewa Falls, Wis. The Rev. John D. Schule, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Welcome To the Club, Finally
description: Once upon a time, as the saying went, it was a man's world. But times and customs change. The transition has not always been without conflicts, perils and abrasions, but the mail shows that the change has clearly been for the better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, ELY
description: GOLDENBERG-Ely. Of Scarsdale, NY, on July 8. Husband of Mathilda Goldenberg, father of Michael Goldenberg, father-in-law of Rita Goldenberg, grandfather of Greer and Max Goldenberg, stepfather of Arthur, Jake and Lisa Maslow, step-grandfather of Rachel, Aaron and Alex Maslow. Funeral service Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at the Chapel In The Woods, Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY.

title: Lori Marshak, Ira Melnitsky
description: Lori Jill Marshak is to be married this evening to Ira Bruce Melnitsky at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Leon Morris is to perform the ceremony.

title: What's a Record Exec To Do With Aimee Mann?
description: I should be riding on the float in the hit parade/instead of sitting on the curb behind the barricade/another verse in the doormat serenade. -- Put Me on Top,'' Aimee Mann

title: A Need for Foreign Aid
description: For a nation of America's wealth, providing aid to alleviate misery in the poorest countries is a worthy cause. But foreign aid is also important to protect American interests. Assistance that helps prevent foreign political conflicts or economic calamities can reduce the need for far more costly future American involvement.

title: The Tide Pool as Talent Pool (It Had to Happen)
description: WHEN children pick up the remote control to watch cartoons, they find shows about the likes of CatDog, a two-headed mutant (or ''bicranial quadriped,'' as it prefers); Arthur, an aardvark who wears glasses; a large blue bear who seems to run an animal commune, and whatever the Teletubbies are. Children's television hits in recent years have starred giant turtles with martial-arts skills and a purple dinosaur who appears to be on a sugar high. Even the classic cartoon shows are about smart-aleck rabbits, sadistic lisping canaries and laughing woodpeckers. So maybe a series about a talking sea sponge isn't so odd.

title: SOAPBOX; Takeout Turnaround
description: I REMEMBER clearly the first time my husband and I ventured north to look at apartments in Washington Heights.

title: Time to Pour and Cure Concrete Slab
description: LAST week this column described the preparations for constructing a concrete slab. This week it will outline the procedures for ordering and pouring the concrete.

title: Making Horror Horrible Again: Into a Forest Full of Witchery
description: AT the start of ''The Blair Witch Project,'' in place of opening credits, a title card announces that the film was assembled from video and 16-millimeter footage found buried in the foundation of an isolated cabin near Burkittsville, Md. The three filmmakers, who had traveled there to interview residents about the legendary witch and dozens of unsolved child murders that occurred in the area over the last 200 years, are said to be still missing.

title: Illness Bonds Rabbi and Mentor
description: Like so many New Yorkers, Sidney Kleiman has a demanding job. As the rabbi of Congregation Talmud Torah Adereth El, an Orthodox synagogue on 29th Street just east of Lexington Avenue, he works every day, including weekends and holidays. He gets in at 6 A.M. and leaves between 6 and 11 P.M., depending on the workload. He's always on call.

title: Don't Sell Mozart Short
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Gnawing at Your Fund, And Now It Has a Gauge
description: SOMETHING is eating into mutual fund returns. It is called market impact cost -- in essence, the impact that buy or sell orders can have on stock prices. And Barra Inc., a research and consulting firm in Berkeley, Calif., has developed a program to let investors see how much those costs are affecting a portfolio's performance.

title: Heat Left L.I. No Margin for Error
description: About 109,000 homes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties lost power during the recent heat wave, officials at the Long Island Power Authority said today. And they are grateful the number was so low.

title: Bugattis in Cleveland
description: The name Bugatti is most often associated with the classic French automobiles built between the two world wars. But Ettore Bugatti (1881-1947), who created the car company in Alsace, was part of a family of artists, and from July 18 to Sept. 19, the Cleveland Museum of Art will present ''Bugatti.''

title: It's the Economy, Sir
description: Name-Dropping

title: Union Alerts Players to Treat the New N.B.A. Drug Policy Seriously
description: Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, does not believe the problem is as rampant as it is perceived. Still, he and the player representatives for the 29 teams agree that with the N.B.A. soon to begin testing for marijuana, it is time to educate the masses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMAN, MURRAY
description: TUCHMAN-Murray. 74, Ft. Lauderdale. Passed away July 6, 1999. Formerly of NYC. Survived by wife Caryl; children Michi (James) Wexler, Bud (Kathy) Tuchman; grandchildren Jesse, Lonnie, Lucky; brother Stephan and his nieces and nephews. Murray was a loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle.

title: Erving's Charade
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Now Playing: The Three Faces of Edie
description: Edie Falco wants to clear up a few misconceptions: She is not Carmela, the sharp-tongued suburban Mafia wife she portrays in HBO's mob hit, ''The Sopranos.'' Nor is she Terry, the hard-drinking jazz musician's wife in the Tony Award-winning Broadway play ''Side Man.'' And forget about Diane, the morally challenged correctional officer in HBO's prison series ''Oz.'' She's not even close.

title: Cynthia Kahn, Bruce Sherman
