description: Cynthia Leigh Kahn and Bruce Stephen Sherman were married last evening by Cantor Robert Abelson at the Pierre in New York.

title: A Fantastic Voyage Into Williams's Mind
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS began writing ''Camino Real,'' then called ''10 Blocks on the Camino Real,'' a year before ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' opened on Broadway.

title: Off the Shelf: Woodstock Memories
description: THE SETTING -- On the fourth floor of Barnes & Noble at Union Square on Wednesday evening, a crowd, most of them aging baby boomers, waited coolly for the man who opened Woodstock, Richie Havens.

title: Sports of The Times; Unfulfilled Dream of Ricky Byrdsong
description: RICKY BYRDSONG was buried in Atlanta yesterday, eight days after he was killed in Chicago in a racist's rampage that left two dead and several wounded. The athletic community remained in a state of shock. The former Northwestern basketball coach was a well-liked member of a sprawling coaching fraternity. Among those attending memorial services in Evanston, Ill., last Wednesday were the Big Ten Commissioner Jim Delany; the former Michigan coach Steve Fisher; the former Arizona players Sean Elliott and Steve Kerr, now with the San Antonio Spurs, and Eastern Kentucky Coach Scott Perry.

title: The Burden of Inevitability
description: Bill Bradley is having an enviable political moment. His race for the Presidency no longer seems as quixotic or self-indulgent as it did only a few months ago. The former Senator and basketball star suddenly has status, which in today's politics translates as the hefty $11 million now simmering in his campaign treasury. Thus, the political class, including democratic donors and journalistic commentators, is sniffing an unexpected contest, and giving this underdog his break. Added weight is allotted to his earnest words and even what once may have sounded deadly dull has now been labeled refreshing and unpackaged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, CLAIRE REIS
description: KAHN-Claire Reis, age 88, July 9, formerly of Brooklyn. Retired teacher from Fort Hamilton High School. Services to be announced. Information: Winchester Funeral Home, Charlevoix, MI. 231-547-2881

title: Jumping Off the Bandwidth Wagon
description: IN a dingy warren of cables and wires on Manhattan's Upper East Side, phone calls are starting to look a lot like pork bellies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIBERT, WILLIAM L.
description: SEIBERT-William L. Of Miami, Florida, formerly of Bronxville, New York, died on July 8, 1999 in Charlottesville, VA. Born June 27, 1905 in Brooklyn, NY. He was the son of the late William Hill Seibert and Bernice Eugenia Higbe. He was preceded in death by his wife Marjorie Fell Seibert. Mr. Seibert was a graduate of St. Paul's School in Garden City, NY, Princeton University and Fordham Law School. He was a member of the Sons of the Revolution; the Princeton Club; past president of St. Andrews Golf Club and past president of the US Men's Curling Assoc. He was a member of the 7th Regiment National Guard NYC. Survivors include a son William Hill Seibert II and his wife, Joyce Rockhill Seibert of Miami, Florida, two stepchildren Marcia Darlington of Short Hills, NY, and Dr. Harrison McMichael of Paoli, PA, grandchildren William Lincoln Seibert II and his wife Teresa Steele Seibert of Oregon City, OR, Kimberly Ariane Seibert of New York, NY and Chantal Seibert of Boston, MA, and two great grandchildren Arionne Marie Seibert and Alexander Lincoln Seibert of Oregon City, OR. Interment occurred at Friends Cemetery in Old Westbury, Long Island, New York.

title: Skip the Parched Lawn; Do Water Elsewhere
description: THE long hot summer has barely begun, yet few need to be reminded that the ground is powdery dry. Long hours of slow soaking rains are needed.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BILLY AND GIRL

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; How Green Was My Monster
description: Boston's quirky little Fenway Park, the site of this week's All-Star Game, has been the scene of so many heartbreaks and dashed hopes that it is to Beantowners what the Bridge of Sighs is to Venetians. Johnny Pesky's muffed relay throw in the 1946 World Series; Tony Conigliaro's horrific beaning in 1967; Bucky Dent's bloop homer for the Yankees in the 1978 playoff -- the list is incised on the heart of every Red Sox fan, an unmatchable record of bad karma. Tear the place down, Ted Williams cheerfully advises in his introduction to FENWAY (Houghton Mifflin, $30), a ''biography'' in words (by Dan Shaughnessy, a sports columnist at The Boston Globe) and pictures (by Stan Grossfeld, an associate editor at The Globe). Contrary to legend, Fenway has never been a hitter's park, Williams says, and it is tough on fielders as well. Williams's opinions are not universally shared, but despite the efforts of some die-hard preservationists, the wrecking ball is almost certain to descend on Lansdowne Street early in the next century, by which time Fenway will, with almost equal certainty, be the oldest ball park left. Inevitably, Fenway has become a kind of literary landmark, inspiring countless overwrought threnodies and pastorals, but Shaughnessy's text is (by local standards) straightforward and unsentimental. Grossfeld's images are sparkling and upbeat, evoking not the park's gloomy history but its charming eccentricities and ever-startling greenness -- a place where it was always heaven to be miserable. A striking exception is some pictures of the dank, graffiti-strewn room behind the left-field wall, the fabled Green Monster, where the scoreboard operators while away their time waiting to post the end-of-inning numbers; they, too, are relics, among the few manual scorekeepers left in the big leagues, and their lair looks like a place where Quasimodo could cheerfully bed down. Charles McGrath

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. 1937-1999. Beloved son of the late Irving and Mollie. Adored father of Sophie. Loving soulmate of Sue Rothwell. Cherished brother of Martin (Susan), Henriette Miller (Herb) and the late Marjorie Sanders Visner (Sidney). Distinguished uncle of Jessica, Miranda, Jasmine, Adam and Emmanuel Isaac Sanders, Samuel Sanders Visner and the late Dr. Marc Sanders Visner, Dr. Robert, Bart and Phyllis Miller. Samuel, an inspiration to us all, dedicated his life to music. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Cleaning the Sound . . .
description: The New York City concern of Hazen & Sawyer will test biological nutrient removal at the Mamaroneck Wastewater Treatment Plant to determine which technologies will best improve the purification process. County Executive Andrew J. Spano said he expects to see a 55.8 percent reduction in nitrogen levels in the Sound -- ''one of Westchester County's jewels,'' as he calls the waterway -- in the next 15 years.

title: 'A Sort of Monument to Our Loss'; Amid Profusion of Flight 800 Aftereffects, Its Leading Icon Will Be Dismantled
description: IT was three years ago this Saturday that Trans World Airlines Flight 800 took off from Kennedy International Airport for Paris and 12 minutes later exploded in the twilight sky off the East End. All 230 passengers and crew members aboard the Boeing 747 jet were killed and twisted metal shards and flaming debris were spread for miles across the ocean below.

title: U.N. Plans Force in Congo After Cease-Fire
description: The United Nations is preparing to send a large peacekeeping force to help stabilize Congo once a cease-fire is signed, despite reservations by the Clinton Administration.

title: The Caribbean Wonders: Where Are the Tourists?
description: AFTER a slow winter and spring, tourism officials in the Caribbean were hoping for better things for the rest of 1999. The NATO bombing in the Balkans heightened those expectations, on the assumption that many travelers would shun that part of the world and head for the Caribbean.

title: English Silver From the Other French Revolution
description: WHEN looking at good English silver from the 17th and 18th centuries, one should remember that it was meant to be seen by the flicker of candlelight. In such light, silver shimmers with the fluidity of water. Seen under lighting that suggests candlelight, the 112 pieces of silver in ''The Huguenot Legacy: English Silver 1680-1760,'' an exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in Manhattan, is like a glittering ocean with more than a few lobsters, dolphins and water monsters surfacing in the decor of the objects.

title: Lee Moody, Cormac McCarthy
description: Lee Rachel Moody, a daughter of Lisa and Richard Moody of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married yesterday to Cormac Reid McCarthy, a son of Eithne McCarthy of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Paul McCarthy of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher R. Sherrill officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh took part in the ceremony.

title: Karla Silverman, Peter Mendelsund
description: Karla Noelle Silverman, the daughter of Tanya M. Melich and Noel L. Silverman of Manhattan, was married last evening to Peter Aron Mendelsund, the son of Judith Mendelsund of Manhattan and the late Benjamin Mendelsund. The Rev. Stephen S. Garmey, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Phone Bills
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's column about exorbitant phone bills for calls from hotels (Practical Traveler, June 20), rang true.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Marlon Richards; Thrifty, With a Pedigree
description: AT 9 P.M. on Monday, the temperature sign on Manhattan Mini Storage on Varick Street read 103 degrees. A few blocks west, inside a gritty club called Don Hill's, Marlon Richards tucked in his billowy white shirt to neaten up for a party celebrating the first issue of Cheap Date, a magazine about punk rock and thrift-store shopping produced largely by children of upper-crust families.

title: Jennifer Weber, Laurence Bailen
description: Jennifer Lash Weber, a daughter of Melinda and Donald Weber of Ridgefield, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Laurence Scott Bailen, a son of Helene Bailen and Dr. David Bailen of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Robert Levine is to officiate at the Wainwright House, a holistic education center in Rye, N.Y.

title: Uncharitable View
description: Since the earliest days of our republic, charity has played a pivotal role in defining the American character; on this point, see de Tocqueville, among many others. Thus, when Cohen states that ''even the best-intentioned charity is no friend of democracy,'' he is off base. Charity and charitable organizations are integral to our democracy.

title: Rafting On Idaho's White Water
description: SCREAMS rise above the roar of white water just ahead. But as the big rubber raft plunges out of sight below, I'm not worried. My 14-year-old daughter, Emily, is in the boat with three other girls and an expert guide. They aren't yelling out of fear. They are screaming as loud as they can for the sheer fun of it.

title: The Fish at the Aquarium Would Call This a People Story
description: A renovation at the New York Aquarium now allows visitors to feel they are inside a fish tank, not just peering into one.

title: ART REVIEWS; Images and Ideas From an Unforgettable Decade
description: 'Contemporary American Masters: The 1960's'

title: White Men Can Jam
description: LOST CHORDS

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FROM MAE TO MADONNA

title: Allons, Enfants . . .
description: As anyone who's actually read Victor Hugo knows, ''Les Miserables'' is not about the French Revolution. (That's another musical.) But it's the Broadway production of ''Les Miz'' that is sending cast members to the Manor in West Orange to sing the praises of the bleu, blanc et rouge in honor of Bastille Day. The party will be a little late: Bastille Day is Wednesday, but on Broadway that night's show must go on. So the Manor's celebration, complete with French cuisine, French wines and a Gourmet magazine tribute to the French culinary spirit, will take place next Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Comme toujours, freedom comes with a price, in this case $95 a person, plus tax and tips. Information: (973) 731-2369.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Guido Costa

title: Streetscapes / 55 Central Park West; The Changing Colors of an Art Deco Landmark
description: CENTRAL PARK WEST, more than any other Manhattan street, was influenced by the Art Deco movement, which in a brief outburst of construction in 1929 and '30 changed the character of what had until then been a street of fairly standard architectural style. One of the most distinctive buildings, 55 Central Park West, is midway through a restoration of its unusual brick facade, shaded from deep purple at the bottom to yellow-white at the top.

title: Crime
description: In his new Elvis Cole novel, L.A. REQUIEM (Doubleday, $23.95), Robert Crais does what he always does -- only this time he does it as if he means it. The same goes for his private eye, who drops his adolescent swagger in the heroic act of helping his friend and partner, Joe Pike, to stop the vengeful killer who is framing Pike for his own crimes. The writing doesn't fool around, either, and what starts as a routine search for a rich man's pampered daughter becomes a tense face-off with a killer and a serious examination of the limits of friendship.

title: Cheryl Sucher, William Macready
description: Cheryl Pearl Sucher and William John Macready were married on Monday in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated at the Essex House.

title: Find a Penny (Or $5), Pick It Up . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Unlocking the Mystery of the Pines; Summer Is the Season to Study the Complex Ecosystem Covering 22 Percent of the State
description: IN the Pine Barrens, it is high season for mating, hatching, blooming and photosynthesizing. So it is high season for biologists, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNICK, MARY ANN
description: RENNICK-Mary Ann. On June 27, peacefully at St. Vincent's Hospital. Survived and missed by niece Cecile Parker, niece Dorothy Buermann, nephew Harrie Richardson, many grand nieces and nephews, and many friends. She was employed from 1979 to 1995 by The New York Times. Special thanks to Jennifer and Sonja. A memorial service will be announced for a later date. Contributions may be made in her memory to the New York Public Library.

title: From Inn to Speakeasy to Hangout, and for Sale
description: IT may be the last call for the Canoe Place Inn off Montauk Highway in Hampton Bays, a legendary watering hole for bootleggers, politicians and mobsters that saw its heyday in the 1920's to the 1940's. The inn has been put up for sale, with the owners hoping to lure a resort hotel developer to the site.

title: Where the Trout Jump Onto the Hook
description: THE mountain goats had climbed down the 300-foot rock wall separating Montana from Idaho in the night and now, in the dim light of early morning, they stood at Slagamelt Lake, whiter than the mist rising from the surface. I watched them, three nannies and two kids, until a trout rose between us. When I looked up from the ripples the goats were gone, enveloped in thick fog.

title: Ideas & Trends: Life Styles of the Rich and Felonious; Steal a Bundle. Get Out of Town. Now Try to Call It Home.
description: THE duffel bag full of diamonds makes for a great plot twist, no doubt about it. Also the ''to do'' list that began, ''Launder money.'' All in all, the tale of Martin R. Frankel is already making a most satisfying addition to the lore of that most modern of outlaws, the fugitive financier.

title: In Wine Country, Can White or Red Ever Be Green?
description: FARMERS and vintners in California's Napa Valley have long exploited the region's combination of soil, climate and topography to make wines that can compete with those of the great Bordeaux estates. Shrewd marketing and a robust economy have given premium Napa wines a romance and prestige that help lift sales of wine produced throughout the state.

title: A Symbolic Dam That Must Come Down
description: To the Editor:

title: They've Kicked Their Way to Fame. What's Next?
description: A s I rehabilitate my injured knee on the eve of the W.N.B.A.'s Inaugural All-Star Game, I have been watching and reading a lot about the Women's World Cup. The excitement and attention that surrounded this soccer team reminds me of the national and Olympic basketball teams I played on in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, DANIEL
description: JORDAN-Daniel. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Riverdale Jewish community, beloved husband of Karen and son of Gladys L. and the late Dr. David M. Jordan, YU Guardians and Founders of our Sy Syms School of Business. Dr. and Mrs. David Jordan are Fellows (Bonim) of the affiliated YU High Schools, where they established a scholarship in their name. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Karen; children, Debra and Michael; mother, Gladys L.; brothers, Alan (and Iris), Mark, and Robert (and Karen); and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: In the Region /Westchester; Redoing an Ex-I.B.M. Building to Fit Small Tenants
description: ONE of the last office buildings in the county to be abandoned by I.B.M., at 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue, recently staged a reopening of sorts as it tries to transform itself from a headquarters building into one that can attract a variety of tenants, some as small as 3,000 square feet.

title: Personal Missions Fuel Small Publishers
description: AS a teen-ager, James Mustich Jr. loved to prowl the back rooms of used booksellers on Fourth Avenue near Astor Place in Greenwich Village. For Jonathan Rabinowitz, the lure was the stacks of the public library in Passaic, N.J., and later at Columbia University.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; For Children and All Growing Things
description: A group of eight girls from New York City stood around a flower patch on a summer camp's farm, learning about a plant's basic needs. The counselor asked the girls, all 12 years old, what a plant needs in order to grow.

title: Anthony Sparks and Anita Dashiell
description: Anita A. Dashiell and Anthony Sparks, actors in New York, were married last evening by the Rev. Herbert Watson Jr. at St. Mark United Methodist Church in Hanover, Md.

title: Miss Shissias and Mr. Bombardieri
description: Monique Lisa Shissias, the daughter of Eileen and James Shissias of Titusville, N.J., was married yesterday to Jon-Robert Bombardieri, the son of Patricia and Richard Bombardieri of Clifton, N.J. The Rev. Robert Archon performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Annunciation in Elkins Park, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, JOSEPH J.
description: KUHN-Joseph J. 61 years of age, of Houston, Texas, formerly of Queens, NY, on July 7, 1999. Mr. Kuhn retired from the City of Houston as Chief of Personnel with Health and Human Services Dept. He was a graduate of St. John's University, Jamaica, NY. He is survived by his loving family, wife Patricia (nee Smith), sons and daughter-in-law George and Lisa Kuhn; Tim Kuhn, Brian Kuhn and Mike Kuhn; sisters and spouses, Betty and Dr. Joe Petrus; Peggy Dooley; Helen and Dick Long; brothers and spouses, Paul and Jane Kuhn; Bill and Marty Kuhn and granddaughter Sydney. Also survived by numerous other relatives and friends. Visiting hours Sunday 7:00-9:00 at George Werst Funeral Home, Cooper Avenue, at 72 St., Glendale, NY. Mass of Christian burial Monday, 9:15AM at Our Lady Queens of Martyrs RC Church, Forest Hills. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: A No for a Restaurant Row
description: For decades, residents of the narrow, shaded blocks of Bedford Street between Downing and Houston, and of Downing Street between Bedford and Varick, have thought of their small neighborhood as a tranquil oasis, largely free of the foot traffic and noise that is common on nearby blocks of Bleecker Street and Carmine Street.

title: Tradition and Consistency in Banksville
description: DINING at La Cremaillere must be considered an investment. Guests do not come here for a ''little something'' to eat. They set aside time to dine graciously and to be cosseted by the most pleasant staff this restaurant has employed in years. From the first greeting in the parking lot to the final farewell from the entire ensemble -- all orchestrated by Robert Meyzen, the proprietor, -- both known and first-time diners will feel welcome and valued.

title: A Newspaper War Unfolds in Red Bank
description: The writer's creed ''the pen is mightier than the sword'' has not stopped Geraldo Rivera from hedging his bets -- using his newspaper column to offer a competing editor a knuckle sandwich.

title: Past Military Rule's Abuse Is Haunting Brazil Today
description: Nearly a decade and a half of democracy have erased the abuses of military rule from the memory of most Brazilians. But two cases dating from that unpleasant 21-year period have suddenly been thrust into the national spotlight, creating embarrassment and discomfort for the current civilian Government, which had no involvement in the events.

title: VIEW; Give Me Your Huddled Masses, Yearning to Be Firm
description: THE less you spend on your health, the healthier you become. This is why East Africans, training barefoot on the savanna, so routinely humiliated America's best long-distance runners, despite millions spent on college training programs. And if the logic here is flawed, I don't want to hear about it.

title: The View From /Katonah; A Day of Art, Food, History and More Food
description: IF it's noon, this must be Caramoor. So joked one participant in a recent progressive feast of food, art and history along what promoters are calling Katonah's Cultural Mile. While this was not exactly on the scale of a whirlwind tour through Europe (remember the movie ''If It's Tuesday, This Must Be Belgium''?), it was a compressed but thorough look at the Katonah Museum, Caramoor and the John Jay Homestead State Historic Site, all within a mile of one another on or near Route 22 here.

title: Directed by One Who Knows
description: The ever-popular ''Mame'' and the rarely produced ''Rags,'' the first two musicals of the new season at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, are most likely to capture the public eye. But how can theater mavens overlook the season's third show, ''Noises Off''?

title: New Face, New Sheen at Gallo
description: SEVEN years ago, when the giant E. &J. Gallo Winery began its assault on the more expensive, $12-and-up wine category, Gina Gallo was just 25 and preparing for a career in sales with the family business. Today she is a winemaker at the money-is-no-object Sonoma operation of the company and, perhaps more important, the face of the new Gallo in a multimillion dollar ad campaign aimed at giving the venerable brand a new veneer of prestige.

title: Collection Agency Going After EZ-Pass Scofflaws
description: At least 50,000 people who have whizzed through the EZ-Pass lanes at the bridges and tunnels between New York City and New Jersey without paying will get letters from a collection agency within the next few weeks as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey begins a crackdown on scofflaws.

title: Gehrig Uniform Brings $451,541
description: A Florida man paid $451,541 at an auction Friday for the flannel pinstriped Yankee uniform worn by Lou Gehrig 60 years ago when the first baseman declared himself the ''luckiest man on the face of the earth.''

title: Threatened Coast Guard Base Will Stay in Cape May
description: In a speech that brought cheers from residents of Cape May, veterans and employees of the city's Coast Guard Training Center, Adm. James Loy confirmed last week that the facility there will remain open.

title: SOAPBOX; The Sands of Time
description: MY son John and I were driving down the main street on Long Beach Island in the summer of 1988, trying to find a beach house for a week. We had our requirements. It had to be right on the shore with a view of the ocean. It had to be within walking distance of miniature golf and the movies -- John was 11. It had to sleep 8 to 10, allowing for my family of six plus a few friends. And it had to cost no more than $500 a week. We were cruising the strip, checking each Realtor for a cancellation that we could pick up for half price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, HANNAH
description: FRANK-Hannah. Of River Edge, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Leon; devoted mother of Harvey Frank and Ruth Singman; loving grandmother of David, Sharon, Charles, Robert, Cindy and Randi; greatgrandmother of Rebecca and Samantha. Graveside services at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY on Sunday 11 AM. For further information: Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ 1-800-522-0588.

title: DATABANK: July 5-July 9; Even the Heat Didn't Slow the Markets
description: With little to complain about except triple-digit temperatures, American investors wiped their brows and sent the stock market into new territory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, BERNARD (BUD)
description: SCHINDLER-Bernard (Bud). Of Hewlett, NY. On July 4, 1999. Age 74. Beloved husband of Louise Samuels Schindler, father of Jean Schindler Bozman and the late James David Schindler. Grandfather of Ariel Marie Schindler, Gregory Evan Bozman and Lisa Nichole Bozman. Brother of Beverly Derman and Ted Schindler. He leaves a daughter-in-law, Ann Hession Schindler and a son-inlaw, Larry L. Bozman. Born in Brooklyn, he served in the U.S. Navy from 1943-1946. He was a graduate of Yale University, Class of 1947. He was a principal of SLS Environetics, a New York officeplanning firm from which he retired in 1973. While with SLS, he designed office space in the Seagram's Building in New York and in Chicago's Sears Tower when it was first constructed. As an independent consultant, he designed office space at the United Nations headquarters in Manhattan. He was the proud captain of the 1934 wooden boat Vee Gee III. A private funeral was held on Tuesday, July 6, at the Lieber Funeral Home in Valley Stream, NY. Donations may be made in his memory to the Five Towns Child Care Center, 112 Wahl Ave., Inwood, NY, 11096, and the Nature Conservancy's South Fork/Shelter Island Chapter, P.O. Box 5125, East Hampton, NY, 11937.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, J. WENDELL
description: FORBES-J. Wendell of Ridgefield, CT, on July 7, 1999. At the age of 75. Husband of Carolyn I. Forbes. Father of James W., Jr. Grandfather of Sara, Carolyn and Emma. Brother of J. Alison Forbes and M. Elaine Pritchard. Memorial service at 11 AM Friday, August 6, 1999, at the First Congregational Church of Ridgefield, Ridgefield, Connecticut.

title: Correction
description: The Stocks in the News listing on the DataBank page last Sunday misstated the change in worldwide future orders at Nike Inc. The company announced that future orders for athletic shoes and apparel -- scheduled for delivery between June and November -- were up 4 percent from the corresponding period last year; they were not down 5 percent for shoes and 28 percent for apparel. For the United States alone, the company said, its future orders were down 5 percent over all.

title: In the Ranks of the County's Volunteer Army; Committees Deal With Issues Dear to Citizen's Hearts, Ranging From Consumerism to the Environment
description: WHATEVER your cause, whatever your ethnic group, whatever your interest, the county probably has a voluntary group for you.

title: July 4-10; Weapon Against Lung Cancer
description: Smokers and former smokers aged 50 and over could greatly reduce their risk of death from lung cancer by having yearly CAT scans of their lungs, doctors reported. The scans are far better than conventional chest X-rays at detecting tumors when they are small enough to be cured, and might increase survival rates from 12 percent to 80 percent, researchers said.

title: July 4-10; Summer in the City
description: New Yorkers were not happy. Too darn hot. So, being New Yorkers, they thought: Let's sue someone! Then the idea wilted. But when the lights went off in upper Manhattan -- among other things, jeopardizing freezers full of Columbia University medical research -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened just that, accusing Con Edison of not doing its homework.

title: Calculating Irrationality
description: In the two and a half years since Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent a brief shudder through the market with the phrase ''irrational exuberance,'' the Dow Jones industrial average has climbed from 6,381.94 to 11,193.70.

title: He's Down but Not Out
description: Few executives have mastered the art of living well as fully as Marshall S. Cogan. But now Mr. Cogan, chairman of Foamex International and a director and former chairman of United Auto Group, is mastering the art of cutting back. Earlier this year, he sold his Long Island home, in Southampton, for about $10.5 million. He is also selling part of his modern art collection through Vivian Horan, a New York dealer.

title: Man, 45, Is Shot to Death Near Bar in Queens
description: A man was fatally shot Friday night near a Queens bar that some neighbors and civic leaders have described as a trouble spot.

title: A 50-50 Split Means Fewer Worries for Growers
description: THE ballroom was jumping with Chilean music, and plates of hors d'oeuvres were circulating. But the wine very nearly missed its own party.

title: Word for Word/Hemingway Memorabilia; Marketing a Myth: Papa's Got a Brand New Bed
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY brilliantly cultivated his elephantine public image during a 30-year reign as America's most famous writer.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 11, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column on June 20, about the Gardiner-Tyler house on Staten Island, misstated the given name of a recent owner. He is Martin Gillen, not Arthur.

title: Dougherty Has Slim Lead And a Lot of Pursuers
description: With one round to go in the United States Senior Open, the most important tournament for golfers 50 and older, the surprise halfway leader, Ed Dougherty, remained on top today, but only barely. About a dozen pursuers, including the tour's premier player, Hale Irwin, will have a reasonable chance of catching him when the pressure of this major championship reaches its peak this afternoon.

title: Backtalk; Observing the Yin and the Yang
description: Ring the bells that still can ring.Forget your perfect offering.There is a crack in everything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVA, WILLIAM
description: RIVA-William. Born in Detroit, Michigan, July 18, 1919. He grew up mostly in Europe, later returning to attend Wayne University where his skills as scenic designer flourished. After Pearl Harbor he enlisted in the Army where his superior command of several languages quickly sent him overseas as a special translator. Refusing officer's candidate school, he remained a master sergeant throughout the Second World War, proud that his overseas stay-ofduty bars exceeded those of most generals. On returning to the States, he became Resident Stage Designer and teacher at Fordham University's prodigious Drama Department in New York, where he met his future wife, Maria Riva. On Broadway he designed the first production of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''The Medium'' in the round, having invented the concept of a scrim enveloped circular stage lit in such a way that, although appearing solid, was perfectly transparent for the audience to see the performance without being distracted by the audience across the stage. In the Fifties his award-winning, innovative commercial designs for television set visual standards still in use today. Riva became and remained a very successful designer and inventor of toys and board games, forming his own international agency to help other inventors. He died on the third of July in Bern, Switzerland, survived by his wife of fiftytwo years, their four sons-J. Michael, John Paul, and J. David of California and Peter of New York-and seven grandchildren.

title: Anand Overwhelms Karpov In a Computer-Aided Match
description: ''Advanced Chess,'' invented and named by Garry Kasparov, is the extension of a traditional consultation game, with the exception that in place of human collaborators, the human adversaries are each teamed with a computer. Last year, in the first exhibition of this hybrid form of chess, Kasparov played only to a 3-3 tie match with the Bulgarian grandmaster Veselin Topalov, a disappointing result for the champion indicating that the computer diminished his usually great play.

title: PULSE; Do Dumbbells Move So Fast?
description: America is embracing all things ethnic, from Asian clothing to Old World beauty products like henna. Belly dancing, long confined to Arabic and Moroccan restaurants, is shimmying its way into clubs (Club Ibis, 321 West 44th Street) and hip restaurants (Chez Es Saada, 42 East First Street, and Kush, 183 Orchard Street, near Houston Street).

title: Any Day Is Friday
description: A new casual uniform has swept the workplace this summer, taking the confusion out of dressing down for many women. The business districts are awash with this trend: the fitted shirt, worn out, over skirts and trousers, for an offhand look. It is part of the change in women's fashion from the traditional two-piece suit to separates. This casual shirt is featured by all the big retailers, and it conveys a casual neatness acceptable in almost any office, comparable to men's khakis and polo shirts. While women still dress up on special occasions, fashion for the 21st century will be based on comfort and utility.

title: Polishing the Gallic Art of a Well-Honed Verbal Jab
description: ''IN France, comedy is what we call 'une maladie du regard,' an outlook dooming you to see what is ridiculous in life,'' said the writer-director Francis Veber.

title: Stalking A Shiny Quarry
description: EACH day, Luis Reyes leaves his home in the Bronx carrying a thin wooden pole twice his height with a wad of chewing gum stuck on the tip. He takes the No. 6 train to 86th Street and Lexington Avenue, steps out onto the pavement and begins looking down.

title: Finding Power Within
description: New Yorkers struggled last week with a stifling heat wave and the city's first prolonged blackouts in years, but even while they suffered, residents and city officials found ways to endure. Police officers directed traffic, people tended to their elderly neighbors and some merchants and restaurateurs offered food to passers-by at no charge, preferring that to throwing away perishables that were destined to spoil without refrigeration.

title: New Name, Same Rigging For Marine Supply Store
description: The boating supply store that has been at 12 West 37th Street (between the Avenue of the Americas and Fifth Avenue) since 1981 has undergone a second name change. The store, originally called Goldberg's Marine, was known as E & B Discount Marine until June 25. The next day it reopened as West Marine, but still carries largely the same merchandise, said David Silberstein, the manager.

title: His Life Was a Forgery
description: FROM A HIGH PLACE

title: THEATER; Two Quasimodos Are Swinging Into Action
description: ALL right, class, a pop quiz. ''Notre Dame de Paris'' is which of the following:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GERALD
description: FRANK-Gerald. Of Lynbrook, LI on July 9, 1999. Husband of June for 49 years. Father of Peter and Emily. Father-in-law of Michele Parker. Grandfather of Dara and Elana. Brother of Doris Ferraro. He was a Veteran of WWII (Chief Finance Officer in the Middle East) and the Korean War. He was a CPA (Partner with Frank & Zimmerman & Co., LLP) and an attorney. Past president of Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook and its treasurer for 15 years. He will be missed. Services at Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook, Sunday, July 11th. at 12 noon.

title: Learning About The Earliest Alaskans
description: Alaska's indigenous culture is the focus of the new Alaska Native Heritage Center in Anchorage. Through arts and crafts demonstrations, dance performances and interactive displays, visitors can learn about the people who have inhabited Alaska for thousands of years.

title: Seeing British Columbia By Rail, Bus and Ferry
description: BC Ferries, which serves the British Columbia coast, is joining with railroad, bus and hotel companies to offer self-guided tours of British Columbia. Many packages include an Inside Passage voyage, a 15-hour daylight trip between Port Hardy, on the northern tip of Vancouver Island, and Prince Rupert, on the north coast of the British Columbia mainland.

title: Personal Touch Tours for Art Enthusiasts
description: BARBARA SPECTOR'S company takes clients just where its name promises: Inside Art. And once they have gone there, by way of one-day lectures or longer tours in the United States and abroad, most people want to go again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARION, M.D.
description: DAVIS-Marion, M.D., on July 7, 1999. Beloved sister of Evelyn Gunter and loving aunt of Curtis L. Gunter, Jr. Interment private.

description: MAHLER-John Stephen. Marking ten years, your love, talent and craziness is deeply missed. Love, Danny

title: Sports of The Times; No Goals Scored, Two Champions, A Bright Future
description: The Curse of the Rose Bowl struck again today. A glorious breakthrough sports tournament was decided by the utilitarian solution of penalty kicks.

title: IN MY... BRIEFCASE: TOM FRESTON
description: The sun never sets on the MTV cable empire, which means that Tom Freston, the chairman of MTV Networks, spends much of his time circumnavigating the globe. He never goes anywhere without his sleep blindfold, earplugs and a bottle of melatonin, the sleep aid, in his soft-leather briefcase.

title: Sandra Cox and Spencer Deering
description: Sandra Ellen Cox, the daughter of Mary Beth and Daniel Cox of Winnetka, Ill., was married there yesterday to Spencer Simon Way Deering, the son of Lynn and Anthony Deering of Baltimore. The Rev. Joseph Shank performed the ceremony at the Winnetka Congregational Church, with the Rev. Jack Dennis, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part..

title: Jennifer's Journey
description: A WARM light slants through an empty concrete courtyard at Rikers Island and into a small visiting room where dozens of blue and green plastic chairs are arrayed in rows. Jennifer Willis sits by the window, her thin body swallowed by a slate-gray jumpsuit. Resting her chin in her palm, she purses her lips.

title: Browning's Poetry From a Woman at a Store
description: To the Editor:

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; When Casual Becomes Crass
description: WHO are the young businesswomen of tomorrow? One need look no further than the 20-something, miniskirt-clinging, cleavage-revealing, midriff-bulging, tattoo-touting assistants and interns of today.

title: Andro Hangs in a Quiet Limbo
description: It took Lee Stevens of the Texas Rangers 11 years -- parts of nine seasons in the minor leagues, and two full ones in Japan -- to finally stick in baseball's major leagues. The 32-year-old Stevens is not wasting his shot; he's chasing every edge he can get.

title: Will Profit Motive Cure Poverty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Ervin Thomas Ricketts
description: Deborah Burgess Ervin, the daughter of Cynthia and Dean Ervin of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Jeremy Ricketts, a son of Alison and Robert Ricketts of Abbots Bromley, England. The Rev. William L. Sachs performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Wilton.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; State's Site Standards Upheld, but Debate Continues
description: IN the last decade, builders and municipalities have taken their debate over mandatory statewide residential site-improvement standards from the legislative and regulatory arenas to the courts.

title: Fugitive In the Family
description: I found the timing of your publication of Emily Yoffe's Lives column about her father on Father's Day (June 20) every bit as meanspirited as the man who inspired her to write it. What a horrible little tale to tell on a day that is meant to honor fatherhood.

title: The Return of the Jitters
description: WHAT does it take to scare -- and to entertain -- an audience in 1999? Producers are money-minded second guessers, not soul searchers. Few wonder about the deeper contemporary issues of what they market as popular entertainment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, JEANETTE
description: RUBIN-Jeanette, beloved wife of the late Seymour, cherished mother of Barbra (and Robert), Leland (and Mary) and the late Fern. Devoted grandmother of Jean Rose Bernowich, Lauren and Brittany Rubin. Services Monday, 11:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Seasonal Dance On the Hudson
description: EVERY July for the last eight years, choreographers, dancers, garden lovers and dance aficionados have congregated at the Wave Hill public garden for the Dances for Wave Hill series. The performances, produced by Dancing in the Streets, have returned to the tranquil space, mixing nature, art and music at the height of the outdoor season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIERSH, BETTY
description: KIERSH-Betty. In Cherished Memory and Unfailing Love. Your husband, sons, daughter-inlaws and grandchildren.

title: G.O.P. RENEWS PUSH FOR A BIG TAX CUT, CITING THE SURPLUS
description: After nearly two decades in which their desire for big tax cuts was overwhelmed by efforts to eliminate the Federal budget deficit, Republicans in Congress will begin a concerted push in the coming week to pass the largest and most broadly distributed tax reduction since 1981.

title: 2 Jets and Ex-Teammate Are Arrested
description: Two New York Jets players and a former teammate were arrested early yesterday after a brawl in a Long Island bar in which a man and a woman were punched and two police officers were injured by flying glass from the shattered window of their patrol car.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: On Language; Swim Suits
description: Usually respectable publications -- from Sports Illustrated to Vogue -- regularly fling modesty to the winds and publish annual best-selling swimsuit issues. Because most ogling readers are more interested in an ambience of prurience -- that is, nearly nude women's bodies -- than in sports or fashion, these issues sell gazillions of copies.

title: Lauren Cohen, Scott Stricof
description: Lauren Elise Cohen, the daughter of Dr. Anita Cohen and Dr. Herbert Cohen of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Scott Elliot Stricof, the son of Richard Stricof and Nancy Stricof, both of New York. Rabbi Robert B. Lennick officiated at the Hyatt Regency in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ideas & Trends: Karma and Helms; A Stick for China, a Carrot for Tibet's Lobby
description: IT'S not every day that Jesse Helms and the Beastie Boys find themselves comrades in arms.

description: When Pino Arlacchi, the director of the United Nations International Drug Control Program, addressed the General Assembly 13 months ago and proposed eliminating opium poppy and coca leaf cultivation in 10 years, his strategy was greeted with polite skepticism.

Indeed, even though many of CUNY's critics served on the task force that wrote this report, the news is that CUNY is doing slightly better than similar institutions.

description: The authorities have arrested a 20-year-old Brooklyn man who they say shot and killed a woman as she sat on the stoop of her Bedford-Stuyvesant building last weekend.

description: Eutrophication has become a byproduct of development near many lakes, but at least at the largest recreational lake in northern Westchester -- Mohegan Lake in Yorktown -- anglers and swimmers have better times to look forward to.

description: Thomas Aquinas Harnett, a lawyer specializing in insurance who was Superintendent of the State Insurance Department in the 1970's, died on Wednesday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 75 and had formerly lived in Manhattan and Suffern, N.Y.

title: Political Memo; For G.O.P. Contenders, Straw Poll Looms Large

But it has come down to that for the former Tennessee Governor, as well as for half a dozen other hopefuls seeking the Republican nomination in 2000.

title: In Japan, Alibis Are An Industry
description: ANYONE who believes that respectability is priceless has not been to Japan lately. Here it sells for $100 a month.

title: Doubling Up on Star Power
description: SINCE the dawn of recording, combining two popular opera singers in an album has often proved a canny business venture. From Caruso and Farrar to Callas and di Stefano, Pavarotti and Sutherland, and Alagna and Gheorghiu, record buyers have responded enthusiastically to the sparks that can ignite when two musical artists with distinctive voices, personalities and interpretive styles come together.

title: Mark O'Brien, 49, Journalist And Poet in Iron Lung, Is Dead
description: Mark O'Brien, the subject of an Academy Award-winning documentary about his journalism career, conducted mostly from an iron lung, died on July 4 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 49.

title: Financial Consulting At a Higher Level
description: The nation supports an army of financial planners. But regardless of whether they consult these professionals, 6 out of 10 Americans seek financial guidance from a far more established source. They pray.

title: A Classic Toronto Haunt Stands Smartly Again
description: Torontonians liked what the Windsor Arms said about them. A reserved, rather clubby hotel with British airs when it opened in 1927, it evolved -- as did Toronto -- into something surprisingly smart while staying itself.

title: Looking at 100 Years of Time and County
description: ON July 13, 1900, when the cornerstone on the Old Nassau County Courthouse in Mineola was laid, Gov. Theodore Roosevelt tapped an iron box into it with a silver trowel. The time capsule marked the birth of Nassau County a year earlier.

title: Gregory Boosin and Dara Webster

title: Albany Lags In Effort to Cut Electricity Use
description: At a time when the rising demand for energy has stretched the New York metropolitan region's power system to the limit, the state has quietly scaled back its effort to promote energy conservation. New York was once a leader among states, but its main program to encourage conservation of electricity has been reduced by 75 percent in the last six years, much to the dismay of environmentalists.

title: Correction

We will all be keepers of your memory. Our deepest sorrow for Alan, Shirley, Jed and our dear daughter-in-law, Pam. Judith, Joel, Bob and David

description: A RESTAURANT called World Pie is, as Yul Brynner said in ''The King and I,'' ''a puzzlement.'' What is it, part of a nationwide chain? A pizza parlor? A pizza of all nations franchise? A bakery that specializes in fruit pies? A hip take-off on American Pie?

description: SHAREHOLDERS of the Kaufmann Fund must wax nostalgic as they consider its recent performance and wonder if the fund's best days are behind it.

description: Republican leaders, troubled by the party's failure to unite behind a candidate to take on Hillary Rodham Clinton in the New York Senate race next year, said today that they had privately debated whether their national chairman should intervene to discourage a primary battle.

description: TWO years ago, Caramoor in Katonah began a project that filled a gap in the New York operatic scene, a multifaceted program to present masterworks in the bel canto style. In addition to overseeing lectures, recitals and master classes, Will Crutchfield, Caramoor's director of opera, has conducted concert versions of Donizetti and Rossini operas, garnering admiring comments from all sides.

The most ambitious of Benito Mussolini's building plans, the 420-acre EUR was to be an entirely new city rivaling in scale and grandeur the capital of his imperial predecessors.

title: Truancy for Adults
description: Summertime is here, and the living isn't as easy as it should be. Have you ever creatively fibbed to excuse yourself from work? And just what were you up to instead? Or have you ever caught anyone else playing hooky, and what did you do about it? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

description: Have a problem, or an opinion? Here's how to let somebody know in Washington.

title: POSTINGS: 354 Apartments at Seventh Avenue and 24th Street; Old Garment Factory to Become Chelsea Condos
description: Big and bold are the signs outside Chelsea Mercantile heralding its conversion from four interconnecting commercial buildings at 252 Seventh Avenue into a condominium with 354 studio to four-bedroom loft apartments that went on the market in late May.

title: Phillips's Comeback Faces a Block
description: In the National Football League, a 1,000-yard season and the seduction that is talent can go a long way to repairing a checkered past. If you dragged your girlfriend down three flights of stairs, punched her in the head and then kicked her in the chest, all can be forgiven if the talent is there. If you are jailed for 23 days because of a probation violation and drunken driving, you will get another chance. Accused of assaulting a second, and then later a third woman? No problem -- a team will come calling anyway.

title: Q&A: Dr. Shelley M. Klein; Paper Born of Necessity Aids the Disabled
description: WHEN her second child's hearing problem was diagnosed, Dr. Shelley M. Klein of New Rochelle thought she already knew about disabilities and how to find programs and recreational outlets. Her first child had been born with a developmental disability, and Dr. Klein, who has a doctorate in biomedical science, thought that having been through it before she could easily navigate the system for her daughter, now 14.

title: Piazza Can't Get Enough of All This
description: Mike Piazza celebrated his monumental role in a dramatic and memorable victory at Shea Stadium yesterday by filling his plate with pasta and chicken before slipping into a cramped film room to watch a videotape of what had just transpired over nine draining innings. Piazza needed to see it again. He had to see it again.

title: The Little White Bombshell
description: The woman waiting for her abortion is 20 years old, a college student, wan and pretty, with long black hair and glasses. She arrives for her appointment promptly at 10 A.M., neatly dressed in pressed jeans and loafers, but her voice is shaking a little when she signs in at the front desk and her shoulders stay hunched, in what might be shyness or self-protection. She follows the nurse-practitioner into the examining room and lies down without being asked. During the exam, she winces and cries, making hardly a sound. But afterward, sitting up, her fingers laced together in her lap, she is almost talkative. ''Did you think about maybe keeping the baby or giving it up for adoption?'' the nurse-practitioner asks kindly. ''Yes,'' says the young woman, ''but I knew I didn't want to do that. My parents are having all kinds of financial difficulties. I know they'd want me to finish school.'' Besides, she says, her voice a little stronger now, though her sentences still end in that questioning upward lilt of late adolescence, ''I want to finish school. I don't want to work in a 7-Eleven all my life.'' And, after a long pause: ''I want to have kids someday, but I want to be able to take care of them so they won't be miserable.'' When the nurse asks if she has been using birth control, she says yes, she's on the pill, but she doesn't take it all that regularly. ''My boyfriend and I want to try that injection -- Depo-Provera? -- 'cause the pill makes me sick.''

title: Harry Eckstein, 75, Professor Who Studied Political Culture
description: Harry H. Eckstein, a political scientist who argued that a critically important role in determining whether democracy succeeded in a country was played by the country's political culture, or what he called its authority patterns, died on June 22 in Hoag Hospital in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 75 and lived near Newport Beach.

title: Using High Tech to Lighten Traffic Burdens
description: EMILIO C. SOSA knows that for every minute a lane is closed on the major highways of Long Island, there is a backup delay of four or five minutes.

title: Gangs Turn to New Trade: Young Prostitutes
description: Two years ago, Maria joined a Brooklyn gang whose members would beat and rob her for sport. She endured the abuse, her friends said, because she was desperate to belong.

title: In America
description: Bill Clinton's mood was upbeat. The appearance with Gov. Gray Davis and Magic Johnson at the high school in Watts had gone well. Now he adjusted his long legs in the back seat of the limousine and began answering questions about his effort to draw private investors to some of the poorest regions of America.

title: When Pop Becomes The Toy of Teenyboppers
description: SHE was about 11 years old and breathlessly excited, surrounded by three girlfriends and chattering into a cellular phone. ''Britney was awesome!'' she gasped, jumping up and down. ''She was hot!'' The girl was in the lobby of the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., between acts at Zootopia '99, a radio-station charity concert with a bill featuring cute boys (98 Degrees, Sugar Ray, Jordan Knight, Joe McIntyre) and a perky girl (Britney Spears) singing about love, love, love. Britney's fan was probably talking to another girlfriend. But at that moment, she could have been giving dictation to the American pop marketplace.

title: Advertising and Morals
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Storage Lockers
description: ONE of the frustrations of modern life is having lots of stuff but nowhere to put it. In a city where closets become bedrooms, empty space becomes a treasured amenity.

title: From a Soccer Mom To a Producer of 'Wit'
description: LAST September Lorie Cowen Levy of Irvington was a soccer mom. Today she is the associate producer of the play ''Wit.'' Her transformation from a stay-at-home mother to a producer was almost as unlikely as the emergence of ''Wit'' as a smash hit. A serious play. A depressing subject. Written by an unknown kindergarten teacher. Nevertheless, ''Wit'' became a runaway box office and critical success, even before capturing the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St. NY, NY 11:30am on Tuesday, July 13th. Interment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Our Towns; As Neighbors, Nixons Proved Easy to Take
description: SOME people in Westchester County, N.Y., are atwitter and others are aghast at the possibility that the President and Mrs. Clinton might settle there at the end of the Clinton Presidency. If they do, they will hardly be the first former Presidential family to head this way. After all, Ulysses S. Grant retired to East 63d Street in Manhattan, Grover Cleveland retired to Princeton, N.J., Teddy Roosevelt went back to Sagamore Hill on Long Island.

description: Congo Cease-Fire Is Signed

title: Apartment Fire Kills Coney Island Woman
description: A 65-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed and four other people were slightly injured by a fire in the woman's Coney Island apartment late Friday night, police and fire officials said.

title: 'Sex' Sells, in the City and Elsewhere
description: THE Tongue and Groove club in Buckhead, a well-manicured suburb of Atlanta, is the sort of place that might make Carrie Bradshaw and her friends raise their well-groomed eyebrows to the roof. Definitely the sort of place that would send Carrie, the New York sex columnist played by Sarah Jessica Parker in the HBO series ''Sex and the City,'' straight to her laptop, cigarette dangling from her lips, ironically hip gold name necklace and Playboy bunny pendant nestled in her cleavage. ''It was the sort of place where girls wore miniskirts with more than a hint of spandex, and butterfly clips in their hair,'' she might have written. ''Occasionally, they fished frosted lip gloss out of their tiny leather shoulder bags.''

description: When it comes to offshore racing, few regattas in the world compare to the Champagne Mumm Admiral's Cup. Like sterling on damask, it is a prestigious yacht-racing affair seldom tarnished by the avant-garde of open sailboat design.

description: Re: Your article on June 27 [''Warily, Southampton Revisits Traffic Issues''] about Southampton wanting to re-examine the traffic problems of Long Island and seek support for building new roads.

description: From New York Harbor to Lincoln Center to Tarrytown, stars of summer night, obht shipboard and ashore.

title: Pet Sounds
description: Daniel B. Rappoport has been in the business end of the music profession for about 20 years. Until now, the music he has marketed has been for people. His latest effort, though, is meant for the ears -- and psyches -- of dogs, cats and birds. ''Pet Music'' is a three-CD set he produced to ease pets through the absence of their human companions. Mr. Rappoport, who lives and works in Teaneck, said he learned that 40 percent of visits to veterinarians was for animals' reactions to separations and stress. Though many owners of animals leave the television or radio on when they leave, Mr. Rappoport thought nonstop relaxing music (without commercials or, say, the clashing cymbals of some classical music) might work better. We woke our cats to try the music out on them. They certainly appeared relaxed as the guitar-and synthesizer sounds filled the room. The set, $19.95, is available at petmusic.com or at Petco stores. The cover art is by Mr. Rappoport's 6-year-old daughter, Rivka.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about management of Long Island's bays misstated the number of local governments that endorsed a plan for the Port Jefferson Harbor complex. It is four, not five; the Village of Poquott has not joined the Town of Brookhaven and the Villages of Port Jefferson, Belle Terre and Old Field in the agreement.

title: Squint, And Trust Your Ears
description: It's a little late to ask Ricky Martin to pay a house call to serenade you, considering that his first album sold more than 600,000 copies in its first weeks. Scott McCraney, on the other hand, has a boombox and will travel. Last month, Mr. McCraney, right, an aspiring actor, began performing as a Ricky Martin look-alike at elementary schools and private parties in the Boston area. Mr. McCraney says that for $500 plus transportation costs, he will go anywhere in the United States to provide an hour of entertainment, dancing and a lip-sync version of ''Livin' La Vida Loca,'' Mr. Martin's current hit. Mr. McCraney is not exactly a dead ringer -- he's two inches shorter than the Latin heartthrob, and in profile the resemblance weakens. But that didn't faze fans like Roseleen Dello Russo, 12, who gasped when she saw the act at a recent Father's Day concert in Revere, Mass. ''At first I thought it was really Ricky Martin,'' she said. ''I couldn't believe it. I was screaming, and all the girls were trying to touch him.'' Mr. McCraney is somewhat more deprecating. ''I've been looking in the mirror for 19 years and I haven't seen Ricky Martin yet,'' he said. ''But some people have also said from a certain angle I look like Tom Cruise.'' BILL POWERS

title: Is It Really Art Or Is It Obscene?
description: WHEN Mark DelVecchio, 39, a Shelton parent, asked the school transportation department to change his daughter's bus route earlier this year so she would not have to pass a 15-foot high replica of Michelangelo's ''David'' at a corporate office park, it sparked a debate in town that resulted in Mr. DelVecchio fielding phone calls from incredulous neighbors and national television news stations.

description: India's Prime Minister said today that the military had chased out or killed most of the Pakistani soldiers who have occupied strategic mountain tops on the Indian side of Kashmir, even as Pakistan's Prime Minister continued efforts to convince men he insists are Islamic freedom fighters, not Pakistani soldiers, to withdraw voluntarily.

At 43, Mr. Hill had mortgaged his home, along with several income properties, and abruptly ended a successful 20-year career as a landscape architect to open a family food store.

title: Plan to Switch Armory Shelters Has Some on the Defensive
description: It took time, but people who live near the Kingsbridge Armory eventually grew accustomed to the women's homeless shelter that has been their neighbor for three years. Now the thought of a new neighbor, a shelter for homeless men, has again rattled the neighborhood.
