title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, BACKER, RUTH
description: ADLER-BACKER-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Harry A. Adler and Irving Backer. Adored mother of Barbara Weiner and Stephen Adler. Loving grandmother of Alisa and Eric Adler, Geralyn, Lucas, Howard and Paul Weiner. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's Chapels, Inc. (Riverside Building), 331 Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, NYC. Contributions may be made the Ruth Adler-Backer Memorial Fund of the American Heart Association, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, N.Y. 10168.

title: Making a Science Center Grow, Without Imax
description: SOMETIME in the next few months, trucks will rumble through the city carrying pieces of the weather-beaten rockets from the Mercury and Gemini eras that have towered next to the New York Hall of Science in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park since it was built for the 1964-65 World's Fair.

title: 'Just Plain Folks'
description: To the Editor:

title: Melissa Hammond, David Fishman
description: Melissa Hope Hammond and David Kenneth Fishman were married last evening in West Point, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan Eichorn officiated at the West Point Club at the United States Military Academy.

title: The Nation; For Better and Worse, Poverty's Poster Child
description: WHEN President Clinton headed to the back roads of Appalachia last week to call attention to those left out of the nation's pageant of prosperity, his visit had a distinctly familiar air. John F. Kennedy, Robert Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson had all made the trip more than 30 years ago.

title: Exchange Rates
description: To the Editor: American Express in Italy, and I assume other countries, gives a lower rate of exchange on its own travelers checks than the competing money exchange shops. I recently got back from Rome. The Amex office there was offering 1,720 lira on the dollar. The little shop next door was offering 1,760 with no additional charge. When I was in Venice and Florence two years ago, it was pretty much the same.

title: Morris D. Crawford Jr., 83; Headed Bowery Savings Bank
description: Morris D. Crawford Jr., who headed the Bowery Savings Bank from 1965 until 1980, died of congestive heart failure, according to his wife, Dorothy, on Wednesday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 83.

title: A Symbolic Dam That Must Come Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Bioweapons, And Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Minding The Meetings
description: Q. I recently took over as head of a department in which a weekly meeting is a longstanding tradition. All the employees (about 20) discuss what they have been working on and offer suggestions for future projects. The problem is that when we go around the table, I'm met more often than not with blank stares and monosyllabic responses. Typically, the same one or two people do the majority of the talking. How can I make these meetings more productive?

title: 12 Artist-Teachers Take Paper in Hand
description: EXHIBITIONS at the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk have been primarily about printmaking, etching and lithography. But now the four-year-old center, situated in a renovated 19th-century stone carriage house, is taking a broader outlook with ''On Paper/Of Paper,'' on display through Aug. 21.

title: A Year Later, Marriott Isn't Big Enough
description: When Marriott International opened a large hotel on Adams Street near the Brooklyn Bridge last year, it seemed like a bold move. Business travelers to Brooklyn already had their pick of accommodations in lower Manhattan. Tourists in the borough seemed so unusual that they made headlines.

title: The Man Who Would Be President
description: From a Cabinet member's diary on the eve of a Presidential campaign: ''The Vice President is becoming more and more truculent. . . . He would interrupt and say to the President, 'Well, didn't I tell you so?' 'You remember I brought that up two or three years ago.' . . . The breach is evidently widening.''

title: Despite Low Prestige and Pay, More Answer the Call to Teach
description: After years of shying away from the field, a growing number of college students, including those from elite liberal arts colleges, now say they want to be schoolteachers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHACKER, BETTY
description: STEINHACKER-Betty. Born in 1900. Passed away July 9, 1999. Loving wife of the late Albert. She is survived by her sons Mark and Paul and granddaughters Michelle and Wendy and is lovingly remembered by all who knew her vivacious personalty and warm spirit.

title: In Shift, Ulster Approves Protestant March in Belfast Tomorrow
description: The British Government in Northern Ireland approved today the holding of a perennially contentious Protestant Orange Order parade on Monday near a Roman Catholic neighborhood in Belfast, the capital of the northern province.

title: There's Something About Garbage
description: TUESDAY is the high point of my week: garbage collection day, a ritual of cleansing and purification when all the excesses of the past seven days are swept away and out of sight. On a Tuesday morning, everything is potential garbage to me, as I hunt through the house with my all-consuming extra-heavy 30-gallon drawstring trash bag. When the bag is out at the end of the driveway in the big green can (secured with a rubber strap for the amusement of the neighborhood dogs), I feel a solid sense of achievement. As long as I keep putting out the garbage, I postpone the inevitable moment when I become garbage myself.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sometimes I say to my doctor, 'Why do I need all these drugs?' He'll take me off one, and add two more. ''

title: Starbucks Was Not Amused
description: The round green and white stickers can be spotted on skateboards and guitar cases in the East Village and on the Lower East Side, the image at first glance resembling the logo of the Starbucks coffee company. But what distinguishes these emblems from the ones that appear on cups and other items from Starbucks are the words around the border.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THE week's round-up of vintage films on television ranges far and wide - from an Indochinese rubber plantation to an African uprising, from an Irving Berlin musical set in San Francisco to an Oscar-winning World War II documentary in the skies over Germany.

title: Lives; Self-Storage
description: By the time the Manhattan skyline comes into view toward the end of our summer weekend, the feeling in the car is a cross between cabin fever and combat fatigue, underscored by the dread of being back too soon and the mad, persistent anxiety that the wrong turn might forestall the moment when we trundle into a stuffy, unlighted apartment and unload duffel bags crammed with memories, leftovers and laundry.

title: Correction
description: A photograph of a Brazilian soccer player last Sunday, with an article about the absence of interest in women's soccer in Brazil, was published in error. It showed a player known as Ro naldinho but not the Ronaldinho who was compared in a Brazilian news magazine to the American star Mia Hamm (and who is known outside Brazil as Ronaldo). The player shown is younger and less prominent.

title: Malcolm Carpenter, 77, Researcher of the Brain
description: Malcolm Breckenridge Carpenter, a retired neuroanatomist who helped map the pathways of the brain that coordinate movement and equilibrium, died on June 25 at Hershey Medical Center in Pennsylvania. He was 77 and lived in Hershey.

title: Libation That Restores Like Chicken Soup
description: FIGHTING allergies, colds and flus is bad enough, but how many have had to face a wine tasting of more than 125 different bottles through their aches and sniffles? I find it difficult to concentrate on wine when chicken soup and ginger ale are the only liquids that appeal to a queasy stomach. Fuzzy bunny slippers just do not satisfy the fashion police at a tasting event like this.

title: All the Presidents' Messes
description: SHADOW

title: 'A Breather' From the Tycoons
description: As the champagne and Oysters Rockefeller circulated at the Museum of American Financial History in lower Manhattan on Thursday evening, the financial historian Ron Chernow -- author of ''Titan: The Life of John D. Rockefeller Sr.'' and guest curator for the museum's new exhibit, ''Rockefeller Revisited'' -- confirmed that he was at work on a new biography. But his subject may surprise his Wall Street fans: Alexander Hamilton.

title: Rebecca Jackson, Benjamin Wright
description: Rebecca Kenney Jackson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thad Alwill Jackson of Needham, Mass., was married yesterday to Benjamin Taliaferro Wright, the son of Capt. Richard Taliaferro Wright of Charleston, S.C., and the late Anne Talcott. The Rev. John Lombard performed the ceremony at the Trinitarian Congregational Church in Concord, Mass.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99; Land of the Free Market
description: I live just beyond the dilating fringe of the New York metropolitan area, in the kind of place that was called ''the country'' until a few years ago. That's when the ratio of urban refugees to farmers shifted in a way that made that designation feel self-conscious, so people began calling it ''the exurbs,'' a word formerly used only by urban theorists. The place still looks the same, with lots of forests and fields outlined by old stone walls, but you sense it's been brought under the cultural and economic jurisdiction of Manhattan. How can you tell? The quality of the coffee has suddenly gotten much better.

title: A Piano Sonata Created From Fire and Ice
description: AS the dust slowly settles over the second half of the 20th century, the music of Jean Barraque comes ever more clearly into view as one of the time's great monuments. Last year his complete output, of just six big works and an electronic essay, was released in a set of recordings made by the leading ensemble Klangforum Wien. Now come two further versions of his Opus 1, the Piano Sonata of 1950-52, in performances by Pi-Hsien Chen (Telos TLS 006; CD) and Herbert Henck (ECM 1621; CD).

title: Ideas & Trends; Putting Private Education to the Test
description: FOR many parents in urban America, agonizing over whether to send their children to public or private schools has become a ritual fraught with concerns about money and fears that a public-school education is a sentence to a life of second-class opportunities.

title: Act II: Producer Finds New Artistic Medium
description: SIXTEEN years ago, the Broadway producer David Black was mired in deep depression. Having lost nearly $1 million of other people's money overnight on a show, he retreated to his home in Stonington to avoid rehashing his doleful experience to his Broadway friends. When he started receiving impersonal, generic Christmas cards from distant friends, he had had enough.

title: The Hazards of Trying to Sneak It In
description: IF, like Florida's First Lady, you have been known to skirt the rules when bringing back merchandise from abroad, you may want to mend your ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, NATHAN B.
description: BIDERMAN-Nathan B. Age 95 in Palm Beach, FL, on July 9, 1999. Husband of the late Ruth and the late Evelyn. Father of Burt and Mark. Father-in-law of Carol and Wendy. Grandfather of Rebecca, Philip, Robin, and Eric. Brother of the late Sol and Morton. Graveside Services 2 PM, Monday at Union Fields Cemetery.

title: The Negotiator
description: MAN WITHOUT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTVO, GEORGES
description: RITTVO-Georges. The entire Polytechnic University family expresses its heartfelt sorrow and mourns the passing of Georges Rittvo, father of Steven M. Rittvo, alumnus and trustee of the university. We extend our condolences and profound sympathy to the family upon its loss.

title: Ideas & Trends: Common Causes; Left and Right Are Crossing Paths
description: THE bedfellows get stranger and stranger: Henry J. Hyde, the anti-abortion, right-wing Republican Congressman, joins forces with Barney Frank, the gay, left-wing Democrat, to curb Federal power in property forfeiture: Ron K. Unz, the conservative Republican who helped end bilingual education in California, argues against school vouchers in the pages of The Nation, a leftist magazine; the Clinton Administration fights its longtime allies, the trade unions, over their support of steel import quotas.

title: Laura Notman, Mark Diamond
description: Laura Shoshanna Notman and Mark Diamond are to be married this morning by Rabbi Sally Finestone at the Codman House, a house museum in Lincoln, Mass.

title: Heather Ure, John Dunagan 2d
description: Heather Eileen Ure, a teacher, and John David Dunagan 2d, a graduate student, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Michael Corrigan officiated, assisted by the bride's father, the Rev. Lincoln Ure 3d, also an Episcopal priest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, JULES ALAN
description: WEIN-Jules Alan. Born in New York City. Beloved husband of Friedl. Loving father of Tova and Cathy. Devoted grandfather of Matthew, Julian and Aaron. Formerly Professor of Humanities at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. Died on June 29, 1999, in Boston, Mass. He served as a cryptanalyst in the Army Air Force intelligence helping to break enemy codes during WWII. Returning to New York, he earned his doctorate in Comparative Literature from Columbia University, which also awarded him the Bayard-Cutting Fellowship. A social activist as well as a poet, he received the annual Lola Ridge Memorial Award by the Poetry Society of America for the best poem on a theme of social significance. He was a avid athlete and traveler. He loved camping and the outdoors, especially Lake George and his farm in Salem, New York. His family will always cherish memories of his enthusiasm for music, literature and art, his infectious humor and energy, and his loving, warm, playful, compassionate nature.

title: A Biblical Musical, Written by the Young and Still for Youngsters
description: WHENEVER the choir of 25 children onstage at the Paper Mill Playhouse here chimed in, clapped hands and turned to and fro, 6-year-old Jeremy Goldberg wriggled to the edge of his orchestra seat, dead center in row F. He cupped his face between his clenched fists, raptly attentive, as if engaged in critical analysis or comparative study.

title: Alice Osborn and Clinton Chase Jr.
description: Alice Elisabeth Van Cortlandt Osborn, the daughter of Anne Hampton de Peyster Todd Osborn and Frederick Henry Osborn 3d of Garrison, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Clinton Blight Chase Jr., a son of Rosemary Pomeroy Chase and Clinton B. Chase of Monroe, Conn. The Rev. Francis H. Geer performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Philip's Church-in-the-Highlands.

title: The Holocaust Survivor Who Can Let Death Go
description: WHENEVER central casting is called on to fill the role of a Holocaust survivor, rarely does it cast against type. Indeed, whether onstage or in films, the Holocaust survivor is often reduced to a one-dimensional cliche, a cartoon of a stock character that seems to dominate the perceptions of those in the dramatic arts. Apparently, filmmakers and playwrights like their Holocaust survivors tortured, tyrannical and delusional -- often all at the same time.

title: From the Highest Level, a Call for Action
description: Those eager to limit the availability of the dietary supplement androstenedione include Barry McCaffrey, President Clinton's antidrug chief, who last week said he was trying to finance a study that could lead to the substance's being labeled a steroid, and thus ordered off retail shelves across the country.

title: Who Was the United States Playing?
description: Did China matter to ABC Sports at the Women's World Cup yesterday?

title: The Color Of Suspicion
description: As a captain in the New York City Police Department, I read your article with interest. What you call racial profiling, I refer to as target hardening. Gender, race and age are three of the many demographics police officers use to eliminate people from the mix of who may be stopped for questioning. (Gender, in most cases, is the first factor taken into consideration when looking for violators.) A thorough knowledge of the area you work in is necessary -- who lives and visits there, the socioeconomic makeup, physical layout, types of crime occurring. This information is part of the target-hardening (or profiling) process that takes place long before an officer sets foot on the gas pedal.

title: Worn First in the Himalayas
description: Pashmina underwear. Yes, as impractical as it may sound, the superfine and expensive fabric, made from the wool of Himalayan goats, is no longer used just for brightly colored shawls, but for intimate apparel as well.

title: Plan for School Ignites Fears
description: In its effort to relieve school overcrowding, the Board of Education is considering building an 800-seat high school on the grounds of a defunct, partly razed welding plant. But the plan is attracting opposition from local civic leaders who worry that the site may have traces of chemicals and heavy metals.

title: Tara Tamny and Matthew Young
description: Tara Rebecca Tamny, the daughter of Myrna Tamny and Dr. Martin Tamny of Closter, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Matthew Adam Young, a son of Dr. Meredith Young and Morton Young of Manhattan. Rabbi Ari Fridkis is to officiate at Estherwood, a historic house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Gospel With Its Eye on the Hip-Hop Generation
description: IN an early-19th-century book titled ''Methodist Error, or Friendly Advice to Those Methodists Who Indulge in Extravagant Religious Emotions and Bodily Exercises,'' the Rev. John F. Watson warned of a ''growing evil'' among black churchgoers in Philadelphia. Through a thinly veiled anger, Watson described vividly a typical worship scene: he heard highly improvised, repetitious singing. He called it ''short scraps of disjointed affirmations, pledges or prayers, lengthened out with long repetition choruses.'' Making matters worse, he saw ecstatic religious dancing that looked very much like its African counterpart accompanying the singing.

title: Emily Russo and Peter Aronson
description: Emily Beth Russo and Peter E. Aronson are to be married today. Rabbi Batsheva H. Meiri is to officiate at the George Washington Manor, a restaurant in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Yes, It's Difficult To Improve On Perfection
description: WALL STREET is a natural habitat for bulls and bears. But it is a precarious place for pigs.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Inspectors Exhausting Their Cash
description: Tony Cifelli regarded his new $45,000 dynamometer with a mixture of admiration and regret. ''It's sitting there, looking pretty,'' said Mr. Cifelli, an auto mechanic in Ewing Township. ''I want to start using it and getting it dirty, but I won't be able to until the end of the year. Come August, it's going to cost me $1,500 a month.''

title: Antitrust In the Slow Lane
description: THE outcome of the Government's suit against Microsoft, filed 14 months ago, is still far from certain, and the endgame may be two or three years away, after appeals that may well reach the Supreme Court.

title: As Campaign Starts Swiftly, Both Parties Are Scrambling
description: Major candidates in the 2000 Presidential campaign, their assumptions turned upside down in the early going, are scrambling to revise their strategies and retool their political machines for a contest that has opened far more swiftly than either the Democrats or the Republicans foresaw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGGIN, JAMES RADFORD
description: COGGIN-James Radford. Prominent NY luthier, died of cancer July 6. Survived by sisters Lola Wilhelm and Hazel Herring. He is missed by friends, and musicians who play his violins and violas.

description: The United States Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited American Specialties of Yonkers, a metalworking business, for 28 alleged violations of OSHA standards, 24 of them termed serious. The agency is also proposing penalties of $67,050 against the company.

title: Sunlight and Shade Infuse Sculptures
description: WHILE light and sculpture are inseparable, site-specific sculpture makes unusual use of light. The sun becomes part of the creative process, highlighting a different facet of an outdoor work with each passing hour.

title: Open Wide, And How About A Massage?
description: KERRY KEHOE looks forward to visits to her dentist. That is when she gets to sit back and relax because while the dentist, Linda Golden, works on her mouth, Ms. Kehoe gets a foot massage. Later she gets her neck, shoulders and back rubbed, too.

title: Silverbulletday Returns in Victory
description: Silverbulletday, who ran seventh against colts in the Belmont Stakes in her last start, returned to her old form and winning ways yesterday by easily taking the $250,000 Monmouth Breeders' Cup Oaks at Monmouth Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, BORUCH
description: GOLDSTEIN-Boruch. On July 5, 1999, age 87, of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of the late Anna. Devoted father of Rochelle and father-in-law of Gary. A wonderful man and Yiddish poet whose love of Yiddish language and culture will always be our inspiration. We will cherish our special memories.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: NIESSNER-Charles F. 88 on July 9, 1999. Husband of the late Marie (nee O'Rourke). Beloved father of Charles B. (Janice McGuire) of New York; Pat (Don) Palmer and Catherine (Frank) Schmidt of Littleton, CO. Beloved grandfather of Cristine (Sean) Grace, Weehawken, NJ; Jennifer and Eric Schmidt, Littleton, CO. Also survived by brother Martin, Southern Pines, NC and many nieces and nephews. He retired as Battalion Chief in NYFD, 15th Battalion after 35 years of service. Family will receive friends from 2-5 and 7-9 on Sunday and Monday at East EndCinquemani Funeral Home, 725 Gunhill Rd., Bronx. Funeral mass Tuesday, 9:30 at Immaculate Conception Church. title: For Elderly, Pills Are Blessing and Curse
description: Talking over lunch this week in the dining room of the American Postal Workers House, a federally subsidized residence for the elderly, 87-year-old Leah Greenstein pulled from her purse a well-worn card on which she keeps a list of her medications.

title: A Brutal Cure
description: A reader (Letters, June 20) was alarmed that the mother of the young man with tuberculosis in Lisa Belkin's article (May 30) works loading food onto airline serving trays. This concern is unwarranted. The microbe that causes TB is not transmitted through food or by touching objects handled by a person with TB. It is transmitted through the air, when people with infectious tuberculosis cough. TB is an infectious disease, not an inherited one. While family members and other close contacts may have an increased risk because of long periods of exposure to infectious tuberculosis patients, the vast majority never develop the disease. Furthermore, standard public-health practice is to screen contacts of people with infectious tuberculosis to detect any cases and provide treatment.

title: Ideas & Trends; Slippery Slope on The Playing Field
description: IT happened again this year. Another drug scandal in sports. This time, it involved more than a dozen cyclists in Swiss and Italian races failing blood tests, including Marco Pantani of Italy, last year's winner of the Tour de France.

description: My Darling Elia

title: July 4-10; Capital-Gains Cut Is Sought
description: House Republicans said they wanted to cut the top tax rate on capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent in the tax bill they will take up this week. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said the reduction would extend the economic boom by stimulating more investment.

DeVilbiss of Palm Coast, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Edwin Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

description: JUST in case you were wondering, all those air conditioners turned on last week helped push the state's electricity usage to an all-time high.

title: Menu Drawn From India, Highlighted With Fiery Seasonings
description: HOT weather? Hot food. Just think about the countries that dote on dishes bolstered with chilies, curry mixtures and other fiery seasonings. Invariably, they are sultry places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONAR, EULALIE HILTS
description: BONAR-Eulalie Hilts. Of Larchmont, NY. Died July 5 at her home. She was born in NYC on July 9, 1941. She was a retired Associate Curator at the National Museum of the American Indian, Smithsonian. She curated the exhibit of Navajo textiles called ''Woven By the Grandmothers'', which opened in NYC on October 6, 1996; and edited the exhibit catalogue ''Woven By the Grandmothers: 19th Century Navajo Textiles From the National Museum of the American Indian'' (Washington, 1996). In her 14 year career at the museum, her main interest was the Southwest, especially Navajo textiles. She is survived by her husband, James Bonar; daughters Lee Wierdsma, Gay Wierdsma, Lindsay Wierdsma; son, John R. Wierdsma III; and grandson, Simon Haats. Burial in Nantucket, MA. will be private.

title: Emily Schwartz, William Calamita 3d

The mall failed; the comedy clubs bombed; the casino was aborted by politicians who favor Atlantic City, and the ski lift is still on the drawing board.

title: Refusing to Wilt, U.S. Wins Soccer Title

And so the United States won soccer's world championship over China by the sport's most tense and capricious arbiter -- penalty kicks.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tracey Stearns and William Weil
description: Tracey Tyler Stearns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Stearns of St. Helena Island, S.C., was married yesterday to William Sylvan Weil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Weil of Washington and New York. Kermit F. Reilly, a justice of the peace in Londonderry, Vt., officiated at Hildene, the Robert Todd Lincoln house in Manchester, Vt.

title: The Lion King
description: True At First Light

title: Cori Sherman, Phillip Thune
description: Cori Lynn Sherman was married last evening to Phillip Ross Thune. Rabbi Daniel T. Grossman officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Home Cooking In the East Village
description: BRUNETTA'S

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUSSMAN, JACK R.
description: SUSSMAN-Jack R. Lovingly remembered today and everyday. Bette S.

title: Sea Protected Areas Are Source of Debate
description: Konstantino Papoulidis lives to fish.

title: Style; Master of the House
description: Anyone who has ever lived in one knows a house is human. Its construction is a birth, its demolition a death, and in between it glows or glowers, mute and moody. So it follows that Eugenio Zanetti, Hollywood's most visionary production designer, would be asked to invent a house for ''The Haunting,'' to be released July 23, that makes the actors -- Liam Neeson, Lili Taylor and Catherine Zeta-Jones -- look, well, almost wooden by comparison.

title: Chasing Perfection: A Portrait of Fischer-Dieskau
description: ALL superlatives for the artistic impact and record-setting extensiveness of Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's singing career have long since been exhausted. It is to the credit of Bruno Monsaingeon, the director of a documentary film on the singer just released by Atlantic Records, that he finds a way to make the stale kudos fresh. Leonard Bernstein sings tonelessly at an orchestra rehearsal and dryly admits, ''Fischer-Dieskau I'm not.'' The soprano Elisabeth Schwarzkopf observes that perfection is unattainable and amends that with ''Fischer-Dieskau, perhaps,'' kissing the air. Yehudi Menuhin just says his name, trails off and looks happy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNING, JOSEPHINE CAIN, ESQ.
description: GRUNING-Josephine Cain, Esq. Passed away on July 9. Beloved wife and partner of the late John E. Gruning, Esq. Mother of J. Victor Gruning (Stephanie), Jacqueline G. Dolan (Peter), the late Frank J. Gruning II, Christopher P. Gruning and G. Donald Gruning (Kate). Survived by two sisters, Eleanor V. Burgess and Marion C. O'Keefe; brother-in-law and wife Mary S. and Carl H. Gruning, as well as eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Wake Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Joseph P. Clavin & Sons, 78th Street and 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass will be held at St. Anselm Church, 82nd Street and 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, on Wednesday, at 10 AM. Donations to St. Anselm Church, 356 82nd St., Brooklyn.

title: July 4-10; Record Set in Mile
description: For those who treasure the breaking of supposedly impenetrable barriers, Roger Bannister will always be a hero. In 1954, the Briton became the first to run a mile in less than 4 minutes, doing so in 3 minutes 59.4 seconds. Now international track meets generally bypass the mile in favor of the slightly shorter 1,500 meters. Still, the mile retains glamour, so there was excitement when Hicham el-Guerrouj, a 24-year-old Moroccan, lowered the world record to 3 minutes 43.13 seconds in Rome. Had he run that time in Bannister's record race, he would have beaten Bannister by 120 yards. FRANK LITSKY

title: Mideast's Ripe Moment
description: As Prime Minister Ehud Barak sets off on an ambitious course to forge a comprehensive peace in the Mideast, he heads out into a region of several aging leaders weary of the logjam of Israeli-Arab hostilities.

title: Weighing In on Repricing
description: Options repricing has been a hot topic on Wall Street since last year, when the Financial Accounting Standards Board proposed requiring companies that reprice executive stock options to reflect the value of the change as an expense on their income statements.

title: One Glorious Creature, Going Like the Wind. . .
description: THE Bruce Museum exhibition called ''The Thoroughbred: Born to Run and Jump'' documents the life and times of the racing breed. To begin with, viewers learn that Thoroughbred does not mean the same thing as purebred. Three lithographs -- ''The Byerley Turk,'' ''The Darley Arabian'' and ''The Godolphin Barb'' -- acquaint viewers with the trinity of 18th-century horses to which all claimants to being Thoroughbreds must trace their direct male lineage.

title: Editorial Notebook; New From Faulkner: An Old Story
description: In the spring of 1948, with tensions rising in the South and Southern Democrats rebelling against the civil rights program President Harry Truman had proposed to Congress that February, a New York literary agent sent a short story by William Faulkner to The Atlantic Monthly and Harper's Magazine. It was a fractured time. World War II, by wrenching Americans out of their accustomed lives and routines, had forever broken the foundation of segregation -- the assumption by blacks and whites alike that the system was ordained and enduring. That it would change was not yet clear, but the earth had cracked. In July, Truman ordered an end to discrimination in the armed services and civil government ''as rapidly as possible.''

title: La Difference
description: THE FIRST SEX

title: My Dinner With Colin
description: PERHAPS it was because I don't have a television show of my own or that I've never been interviewed by Charlie Rose. Perhaps it was because being seated well at Balthazar or 44 is beyond me. More likely it was because Damon Runyon got it right when he wrote that ''a freeloader is a confirmed guest.''

title: Habitats / West 85th Street; Restoring an Apartment In Dumpster Deco
description: YOU have to wonder. Did it ever occur to the dogs that their routes had suddenly changed, that they were taking long detours, walking past construction sites and debris-filled Dumpsters? Because for several months, while the owners of Johnny Dog Walkers were squiring their charges around the Upper West Side, they were walking even more than usual, looking for cast-off materials that might be used to restore the owners' new apartment.

title: The Cement Ceiling?
description: Despite the well-publicized accusations that Christian L. Curry had to fake E-mail to make it look as if his employer, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, harbored employees with racial bias, the overwhelmingly white world of corporate management is genuinely tough for minorities to break into, according to a group of 109 blacks, Hispanics and Native Americans who are already on the inside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUGELMAN, ARTHUR E.
description: KUGELMAN-Arthur E. On July 10, 1999 at age 71. Beloved husband of Stephanie. Loving father of Sarah and Dana. Devoted brother of Ileane Eisenberg and the late Davey Kugelman. Cherished uncle of Douglas, Sheryl, Adam, Ben, Rebecca and Alexander. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, July 11th, 7-9 PM, with service Monday, 9:30 AM. Interment to follow at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or Gilda's Club.

title: The View From/Hartford; A $22 Million Restoration for Mark Twain House
description: LIKE the slow evolution of a novel, the Mark Twain House has become a work in progress. The 19-room mansion where Samuel Clemens wrote ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' is undergoing a $22 million renovation that is expected to return the house to its original condition.

title: A Shaky Pillar in Harlem; Black-Owned Carver Bank Seeks Solid Financial Base
description: As a symbol of Harlem's economic revival, almost nothing would seem to beat the Carver Federal Savings Bank building on 125th Street. Four shiny stories of stone and brass and skylights, it is a monument to the bank's five-decade transformation from a struggling storefront into a pillar of its flourishing community -- and the largest African-American financial institution in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBIN, FRANCES ANN
description: ROBIN-Frances Ann, 87. Of Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of New York City, passed away July 4, 1999. Graveside services at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ, 10:30AM Monday. For information: 201843-7600. She will be truly missed by all who knew her.

title: Marion George and Alexander Petron
description: Dr. Marion Artemis George, a pediatrican and internist, and Dr. Alexander William Petron, a pediatrician, were married yesterday in Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. John Alexandrou performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian.

title: Death on Mazllum Shasivari Street
description: The streets of Djakovica, a city of 80,000 in southwest Kosovo, were already deserted at 8 P.M. on March 24, when NATO bombs smashed into Serb military installations on the edge of town. Afterward, the town lapsed once more into silence. Around midnight, residents saw about 50 Serbs in military dress, each carrying a five-liter gasoline can, walking toward Old Town, a neighborhood surrounding the city's 16th-century mosque. At 1:15 A.M., flames appeared from the rooftops of Old Town. Djakovica's ordeal had begun.

title: On the Other Hand: A New Repertory
description: GARY GRAFFMAN may have heard every crack about playing with one hand behind his back. In a sense, his demanding job as president of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia would suggest that anything else he does at all is done with one hand behind his back. But in 1979, he developed a mysterious weakness in the muscles of his right hand. He continued to perform, delving into the shadowy repertory for the left.

title: Backtalk; Sports And Sex Are Always Together
description: In another time, I pitched a proposal on the sexual implications of sports to a magazine called Eros. The rejection letter came swiftly; the editor said there were no such implications because, as any fool could see, sports was pure sex in the first place.

title: In G.O.P. Territory, Many Are Willing to Give First Lady a Chance
description: At the Cooperstown Diner, where the waitresses swat regulars who lean back in their chairs, many in the breakfast crowd said that Hillary Rodham Clinton, the would-be New York Senator who has never lived or worked in New York, could survive being branded a carpetbagger.

title: July 4-10; Setback for Tobacco Industry
description: A Florida jury ruled against the tobacco industry in the first class-action smoking case to reach a verdict. Anti-smoking groups said the ruling, which held that the nation's biggest tobacco companies conspired to hide the dangers of cigarettes, could cost the industry billions of dollars.

title: Summer Flings With Staying Power: A 3-Pointed Star That Promises Sun and Moon
description: THE mercury is soaring and the power is out. It's time to hit the streets, and it sure would feel great to go topless. In a convertible, that is.

title: Uncharitable View
description: I think your questioner really wanted to know whether workers jeopardize their jobs by not taking part in fund-raising drives. Pressure may come not so much from peers as from managers who have a dollar goal to meet.

title: Bedevil the Pests That Bedevil You
description: Keep up with weeding and watering. Use dilute foliar sprays of liquid seaweed, instead of high-nitrogen fertilizers, which encourage the excessive growth that aphids love; this will also boost resistance to fungal diseases. Stop pinching fall bloomers like chrysanthemum and aster.

title: At Last on Hispaniola, Hands Across the Border
description: Twice a week, this border town opens its gates so that Haitians can come in.

title: Defibrillators Installed At Chicago Airports
description: Chicago has installed portable heart defibrillators at Midway and O'Hare Airports. Monique Bond of the City of Chicago Department of Aviation said that 33 of the devices have been put into corridor walls at O'Hare and 7 at Midway. The battery-powered devices, Hewlett-Packard Heartstream Forerunners, are no more than a minute apart at walking speed, she said, and can be removed and used immediately.

title: Painting as He Writes, With a Love of Paradox
description: AS a writer, I'm an amateur,'' declares the Italian playwright Dario Fo with a sly deadpan that leaves his listeners waiting for a punch line. ''But as a painter, I'm professional. Fellini was the opposite: a professional in the cinema and an amateur painter. He's not in my league.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE GOOD TIMES

title: OPINION; Hey, L.I.R.R., I'm Perfect for You
description: RECENTLY the Long Island Rail Road distributed leaflets throughout its trains inviting riders to apply for engineering positions. After a first dismissive glance I took a second look, for it occurred to me that I might be the ideal candidate, having no technical training whatsoever but being endowed with a deep appreciation for slapstick comedy.

title: Will Profit Motive Cure Poverty?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lives and Work of Women, And Where They Intersect
description: A PANEL discussion at the Gallery of South Orange on a recent Sunday afternoon had no announced topic, but its subject quickly became the routine life of an artist, and how that life can be reflected in art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, CAROLINE LAWRENCE
description: MURRAY - Caroline Lawrence. Beloved sister of Toby Murray and Midge Baldrige. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Maria Ginzburg, Marc Sgaraglino
description: Maria Ginzburg and Marc Adam Sgaraglino, associates at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, were married yesterday. Mayor Cary F. Staller of Old Field, N.Y., officiated at the Old Field Lighthouse.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Dim Lights, Middle-Sized City
description: David Henry, the 28-year-old narrator of David Eddie's first novel, CHUMP CHANGE (Riverhead, paper, $13), has any number of bad habits, mostly regarding food, drink, cigarettes, the occasional controlled substance and gainful employment. Fortunately -- at least for the reader -- he has no interest in being cured of them. Though ''Chump Change'' begins, like ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' with our hero on a downward spiral, Eddie draws an essentially cheerful story out of his outsized (6 feet 5 inches, 225 pounds) character's quest to ''succeed in the true sense of the word,'' which means finding his way as a writer while failing everywhere else. And David Henry has a talent for failure. Fleeing New York after precipitately quitting his letter-filing job at Newsweek, he needs his soon-to-be-ex lover to buy his plane ticket home. ''A new low,'' he says. ''I have to borrow from my girlfriend in order to leave her.'' Back in Toronto, he hangs out with an old buddy named Max, mooches drinks, lucklessly courts Les, the beautiful daughter of an advertising magnate, mooches more drinks, has a disastrous romance with a hapless Korean artist and begins to earn a living as a writer. Plot is not remotely the thing in this picaresque tale -- Les, for instance, basically just drops out of sight -- nor is character development: Eddie pays so little attention to other characters that the book starts to feel sloppy. His talent lies in the infectious enjoyment he takes in describing his protagonist's exploits. As entertaining as it is, ''Chump Change'' may only be David Eddie warming up. Matthew Flamm

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'Flights of Fancy'

title: Sheri Caplan and Kenneth Merkatz
description: Sheri Jayne Caplan and Dr. Kenneth Alan Merkatz are to be married this evening at the Pierre in Manhattan. Rabbi Lawrence A. Hoffman is to officiate.

title: A Roiling Mosh Pit of Greed and Creativity
description: Here is one way to look at American network television: as a vast creative engine composed of talented, ambitious individuals, many striving to plumb their deepest thoughts and feelings and make that rare and most satisfying of connections with an involved and appreciative mass audience.

title: U.N. Poverty Agency Vying With Aid Offices for Cash
description: Mark Malloch Brown, the new chief of the United Nations Development Program, had barely moved into his spacious office with its panoramic views of the East River and the United Nations when he got some bad news: Denmark and Germany, mainstays of his agency's $2 billion budget, were slashing their annual contributions.

title: Portland Museum Show Gathers Space Artifacts
description: ''Imagine Space!,'' a collection of space artifacts, is on view through Sept. 6 at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry in Portland.

title: A Second Look at Second-Quarter Forecasts
description: EXPECTATIONS are pretty high as the second-quarter earnings season gets into full swing this week, with reports scheduled from Intel, Apple Computer, International Paper, Merrill Lynch, Pfizer, Whirlpool, Weyerhaeuser and others.

title: Opening Doors, and More
description: Christie's, the 223-year-old auction house, has moved to lavish Rockefeller Center headquarters, and Gil Perez, its doorman since 1976, has taken to the new site like a Rockette takes to the stage at Radio City.

title: Bookend; Sex and Longing in Old Vienna
description: THIS seems to be Arthur Schnitzler's year in the English-speaking world. In ''The Blue Room,'' we saw all of Nicole Kidman -- well, not in a good light -- in a daring adaptation by David Hare of one of his most dazzling works for the stage, ''Reigen'' (''The Round Dance''). Ten couples pair up for the ultimate pleasure, one of each continuing with a different partner until in the last scene the prostitute, who has appeared in the first sketch, appears once more.

title: Gerry Henneman, Bosley Crowther
description: Margery Clifford Henneman of Princeton, N.J., and Francis Bosley Crowther 3d of Palmyra, Va., were married yesterday in St. Andrew's Chapel at the Woodberry Forest School in Madison, Va. The Rev. Theodore McConnell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: July 4-10; The Mystery of Venus and George
description: Sometime in 1784 or 1785 a boy was born to Venus, a slave on the estate of George Washington's half-brother, John Augustine Washington. The boy, named West Ford, was treated with special favor. John Augustine's wife, Hannah, instructed in her will that he should be freed and taught a trade.

title: Cipollini Wins 4th Consecutive Daily Stage
description: Mario Cipollini, the champion Italian sprinter, closed out a glorious week in the Tour de France today by winning his fourth consecutive daily stage, equaling a feat last accomplished in 1930.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: I Log On, Therefore I Am
description: THE METAPHYSICAL TOUCH

title: Newark Population Grew A Bit, Census Estimates
description: After losing population for nearly three decades, Newark gained 644 residents between July 1997 and July 1998, according to United States Census Bureau estimates released at the end of last month.

title: Michael Tweed and Elizabeth Ross
description: Elizabeth Ross and Michael Tweed were married yesterday by the Rev. Harry C. Green, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Developing an Illinois Suburb, With Principles
description: ''COMPACT, transit-oriented development'' is how planners say, ''a suburb where you can walk to the train station from your house.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEAN, QUINCY ADAMS SHAW, JR.
description: McKEAN-Quincy Adams Shaw, Jr. of Rumson, New Jersey, died suddenly of a heart attack on Thursday, July 8, 1999. Wonderful husband, loving father, tremendous grandfather, great friend. Son of Q.A. Shaw McKean and Margarett Hunnewell Sargent, graduate St. Paul School, Harvard College, Columbia Law School. Senior partner and former head of New York City office of Scudder, Stevens and Clark, investment counsel firm. Served as Board President & Treasurer of Fountain House, international organization reaching people with mental illness. Trustee and chair of Human Resources for Meridian Health Systems and Meridian Hospital Corporation. Survived by his wife Linda Huntington Borden, his children Cressida Sargent McKean (Borthwick), Quincy A.S. III and Jocko Borden McKean, his grandchildren: Hanna, Ian, Amanda, Lucas, Quinny, and Jack. Also survived by his sister Margarett McKean Vernon, his brother, Henry P. McKean II, & his half brothers, John Winthrop McKean, Thomas McKean, Robert Winthrop McKean and David McKean. His late sister was Jenny McKean Moore. A service will be held on Tuesday, July 13th, at St. Georges by-theRiver, 10 Waterman Avenue, Rumson, NJ at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Fountain House (425 West 47th Street, N.Y. N.Y. 10036) would be welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDE, GLORIA
description: LANDE-Gloria. On July 9, 1999. Beloved wife of Adam. Loving mother of Deborah and Clifford. She is deeply loved and will be profoundly missed. Services Sunday 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Op-Art
July 4-10; Gephardt Drops a Nominee
description: When Salam Al-Marayati was appointed in June to a Congressional terrorism commission, Jewish groups quickly protested. While Mr. Al-Marayati is known as a moderate among American Muslim leaders, and has built relationships with Jewish groups in Los Angeles, where he lives, he also has made statements suggesting that Palestinian terrorism arises from ''despair and suffering.''

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Other Side of Silence.

title: Peter Pan, Not Sunny
description: I, like millions of others, have always assumed, as did your writer, that the figure of Marilyn Miller depicted by the sculptor Alexander Stirling Calder on the I. Miller building [''There's No Business Like Shoe Business,'' July 4] was of the actress in ''Sunny,'' one of her greatest successes. It only proves that even when engraved in stone, mistakes can be made and perpetuated.

title: The Real Asian Miracle
description: CONFUCIUS LIVES NEXT DOOR

title: Ms. Angelo, Mr. Mobasser
description: Katherine Bach Angelo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Angelo of New York, was married yesterday to Francois Mobasser, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Shapour Mobasser of Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. J. Randall Nichols performed the ceremony at the Elberon (N.J.) Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: A Khrushchev Is Pledging New Allegiance
description: Four decades after his father, Nikita S. Khrushchev, provocatively vowed from the Kremlin, ''We will bury you,'' Sergei N. Khrushchev awaits American citizenship, happily prepared to pledge allegiance to the United States as its newest patriot.

title: Discovering Poetry Even in the Clutter Around the House
description: OUR modern lives are replete with stuff, clogged with both the essential and the essentially worthless. Kitchen drawers and bedside tables hide secret ecosystems of hoarded rubber bands, rogue Q-Tips and cryptic plastic widgets whose purpose has long since been forgotten. Left unchecked, these agglomerations grow and spread, becoming small universes unto themselves. For the 30-year-old conceptual artist Sarah Sze, this material profusion presents more than just a housekeeping problem. It's also the rich source for her sprawling found-object installations -- works that celebrate the lyrical potential in clutter, the meaningful relationships that people develop with even the most impersonal trappings of their everyday environments.

title: Suzanna Dwyer and Andrew Harrison
description: GROWING up on Green Avenue in Lawrenceville, N.J., Suzanna Duncan Dwyer and Andrew James Harrison were childhood buddies -- they built treehouses together, rode dirt bikes, made home movies and played football until dark.

title: The Big Heat
description: GREENHOUSE

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday listing tourist attractions in upper Manhattan gave an outdated location for the Museum of the American Indian. It moved in 1994 to the former Custom House in lower Manhattan; it was previously on Audubon Terrace.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOODS, FRANCIS
description: WOODS-Francis. First anniversary. I will always remember you. Love, Eileen

title: Can't Decide Where to Eat? Phone Service Helps Choose
description: Among her friends and family, Andrea Blake became known as an expert on restaurants. ''For some reason I was the one'' whom everyone called for advice on where to eat, she said.

title: Sunflowers to Display Without Soiling the Doilies
description: LIKE most children, I picked flowers for my mother. Dandelions from the backyard, tulips from the flower bed, sunflowers and Queen Anne's lace from the roadside ditch. One was as good as another when the urge to be generous struck, and they all looked beautiful to me.

title: POSTINGS: 'High Performance Building Guidelines'; City Manual on Being Green
description: The chapter headings include ''Daylighting and Sun Control,'' ''Good Indoor Air Quality,'' ''Energy Management,'' ''Water Reuse'' and ''Environmentally Preferable Materials.''

title: The World; Peace Strains the Army
description: EVEN before NATO's bombs stopped falling in Yugoslavia, the Pentagon's war planners and like-minded lawmakers on Capitol Hill started asking a question that would have seemed unthinkable not long ago: Is America's military too small?

title: Pure Storybook: Mets Win One to Remember
description: The Yankees bashed nearly a half-mile of home runs against the Mets yesterday, they came from behind twice and recovered from what some of them thought was the longest home run they had ever seen. But the Yankees still needed a single strike to hold their one-run lead and win this three-ring circus of a ball game.

title: www.njpactickets.cheap
description: What's it like to have your own Official Airline? For the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, it's having a corporate friend that can help fill seats. And for techno-savvy audience members, it's a source of discounts.

title: July 4-10; Russia Gains Kosovo Role
description: After weeks of wrangling, NATO and Russia agreed on a role for Russian troops in the peacekeeping force in Kosovo. Paratroopers who will make up most of Russia's 3,600 troops began arriving at Kosovo's main airfield on Tuesday, following a tense weekend during which NATO blocked Russian aircraft from landing.

title: Instant Company
description: What were you doing 12 weeks ago?

title: In the Region / Long Island; As Rents Climb, Co-op Sales and Prices Turn Up
description: She found a $120,000 one-bedroom co-op at 600 Shore Road through a local real estate agent, Marilyn Topper, closing on June 16. The 94-unit oceanfront building has an indoor pool. Her apartment has a side view of the ocean and her $600 a month maintenance includes taxes and heat. With mortgage payments, her monthly costs are $1,300, which is $300 less than one-bedroom rentals in Park Slope, she said.

title: Back, Sold Out and Playing In the Key of E Street
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN is coming home in triumph -- again. Starting Thursday, the Boss of traditional rock-and-roll will be back at Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford for 15 sold-out nights. The only record he had to break was his own from 1992, when he set the benchmark for the entire music industry by selling out 11 shows at the 20,000-seat arena.

title: Michael K. Hooker, 53, Chancellor With a Community Approach
description: Michael K. Hooker, the chancellor of the University of North Carolina who took a high-technology, community-oriented approach to higher education, died on June 29 at U.N.C. Hospitals. He was 53 and lived in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Q and A
description: Fishing in Normandy

title: Tribe Sees a Future In Passenger Boats
description: THE June launching of the $8 million Bo Hengy, a 115-foot high-speed ferry boat with a 200-passenger capacity, represented a milestone in the business enterprises of the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation.

title: High on the Trail in Wyoming
description: TWENTY horses -- 10 with packs, 10 with riders -- were following Caldwell Creek in single file down narrow Brown Rock Canyon. The rain had been steady and hard for 30 minutes; cascades of water spilled off high canyon walls. The creek roiled, tossing logs and boulders as if they were bath toys. Our mounts struggled to keep their footing as forest floor metamorphosed into water course. A cry went up; we turned to see a surge of water and mud exploding over the rim. Minutes later a mud tsunami came crashing halfway to the hips of the last pack horses.

title: Where Baseball Belongs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: A Question of Character; Beyond the Bar Exam
description: TO win admission to the bar in New York State, law school graduates are asked to deny under oath that they have ever belonged to any group ''advocating or teaching that the Government of the United States, or any state or any political subdivision thereof, should be overthrown.''

title: The Mayor Gets Hot Under the Blue Collar
description: THE ship of state is pitching madly in a sea of controversy, and Mayor Deborah C. Whitcraft has lashed herself to the helm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERES, RUDOLF
description: BERES-Rudolf. July 7. Longtime executive with Colgate-Palmolive. Memorial service Monday, July 12, 10:30 AM at Saint John The Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street at 1st Avenue.

title: The Color Of Suspicion
description: In Jeffrey Goldberg's article (June 20), police officers are quoted as saying that they believe most drug dealers are black or Latino, and that therefore it is justifiable to stop cars whose drivers are black or Latino. This conclusion is based on a common statistical fallacy. Even if it is true that most drug dealers are black or Latino, it does not follow that most blacks and Latinos are drug dealers. The fact is that hunches based on skin color instead of on credible evidence mostly turn out to target innocent people.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: Phenomena; Lovely Day for a Storm
description: Frank Blau, a database designer from Issaquah, Wash., has never met a storm he didn't like, but hurricanes are definitely his favorite. ''I don't want to use the word sexual, but there's something about the process of a hurricane that really appeals to me. You can see it coming; you feel it building; you can put yourself in as much danger as you want. Come late summer, if I can swing it, I'm heading to the Outer Banks to catch the peak of hurricane season.''

title: July 4-10; Mrs. Clinton's Listening Tour
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton began her first full-fledged campaign trip to New York at an upstate farm belonging to Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a fellow Democrat who is retiring from the Senate next year. He said he hoped she would succeed him.

title: Uncharitable View
description: Thank you, Ethicist (June 20)! For years, I've struggled to tithe my income to various charitable causes and volunteer my time to philanthropic institutions. Now Randy Cohen assures me that all I need to do is vote for those politicians who promise to raise my taxes the most!

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAMMERLING, MEG AND BOB
description: HAMMERLING-Meg and Bob. Mom and Dad, this would be your 40th. We know you are together somewhere. We miss you madly. Love, Brooke, Katie and Rob

title: Loss of a Grocery Hits Hard
description: The closing of the largest supermarket serving Coney Island's co-op towers has panicked many of the 35,000 residents, particularly elderly ones who fear that the loss of the store will destroy their independence.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: Salient Facts: Contaminated Seafood; Sea Sickness
description: WAITER, HOW'S THE VIBRIO VULNIFICUS TODAY?

title: Near the City, Under the Highway, Marshland Worth Preserving
description: Drivers on the sprawling cloverleaf that connects Interstates 195 and 295 just south of Trenton catch sight of greenery veined with winding creeks. They are looking at the Hamilton-Trenton Marsh, a 1,250-acre wetland just off the Delaware River that is home to more than 700 species of plants, and hundreds more species of birds and other creatures. Sites of historical significance in it include the Abbott Farm National Historic Landmark, a 6,000-year-old American Indian settlement, and the Watson House, Mercer County's oldest standing house. But it also has a Public Service Electric and Gas power generating plant, a sewage treatment plant, an oil pipeline, the ruins of a 19th-century amusement park and old illegal dump sites.

title: Amy Schure, Michael Shay
description: Amy Rachel Schure and Michael Anthony Shay are to be married today at Carltun on the Park in East Meadow, N.Y. Village Justice Robert C. Williams of Rockville Centre, N.Y., is to officiate.

title: Elizabeth Tigett And Dylan Parks
description: Elizabeth Lee Tigett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Ray Tigett of Houston, was married yesterday to Christopher Dylan Parks, the son of Susan Beasley of Philadelphia and Stephen Parks of Taos, N.M. The Rev. Terry J. Thompson, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Casa Vista Clara, a private house in Taos. Blue Spruce Standing Deer, a medicine carrier and a member of the Tiwa tribe of the Taos Pueblo, took part in the ceremony.

title: Sports of The Times; Newest Hall of Famer Still Full of Surprises
description: THE name of the game John McEnroe always played best was surprise. Where was the next volley going? When was the inevitable tantrum coming? What Robin Williams is to comedy, McEnroe was to tennis. He made it up as he went along. He played it this way, right through a quirky and typically rambling induction yesterday into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: Veteran Lilly Does Job
description: All those games, all that experience, led to that moment this afternoon when Kristine Lilly was in exactly the right place at the right time.

title: A Heck of a Parking Fee
description: After she helps that special someone select a Patek Philippe and a couple of Rolexes, the woman who gives with style might also buy him something to put them in. Perhaps a $3,600 leather and silk watch box from Scatola del Tempo of Barzano, Italy, featured in an advertisement in this month's Robb Report, a magazine for well-heeled consumers.

title: For Mrs. Clinton, A Primary Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Turf Battle on Floating Pier
description: The Fourth of July was not so glorious for hundreds of people who turned up to find that the daylong Pier 63 Waterfest on the Hudson River had been shut down by the Fire Department. The closing has raised questions about which agencies have jurisdiction over the piers.

title: For Would-Be Brokers
description: For on-line traders who want a glimpse of the real thing (and can still afford it), there's Stock Market Place in Toronto. The 6,000-square-foot exhibit, in the center of the financial district, recreates the bustle of floor trading with a global media wall and hands-on exhibits. Stock Market Place, 130 King Street West, Toronto, (416) 947-4676, is open Monday to Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Food; The Pod Squad
description: Consider the poor pea. Although it is gorgeously green and plump, it lives a sheltered life. But not even such a claustrophobic existence can tarnish the pea's enduring sweetness.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: Shop Talk; The Parent Trap
description: Last month, four teen-agers from Bergen County, N.J., ran away from home and roamed the streets of New York for four days. They didn't return until a tourist spotted them sleeping on a stoop near Times Square and alerted the police. In New York, the story made headlines, pointing up how much the city had changed since the days when kids could go there to get lost forever. But how did it play back home? Here, the father of 15-year-old Daniel Breitling and the parents of 15-year-old Melissa Hollender talk about how they raised their children and why they might have run off. (Lynn Reeves, the mother of the other two teen-agers involved, was willing to take part, but Breitling and the Hollenders, who believe that her son Adam was the instigator, declined to speak with her. ''Yes, it was Adam's idea,'' says Reeves. ''But nobody held a gun to anybody's head. Nobody said, 'You can't call your mother.' All of our children are equally accountable for this.'')

title: $140,000 - And a Bargain
description: I agree with Matthew Miller (June 13) that colleges need to continue cutting costs, but his suggestions for doing so are misguided. He proposes that most faculty members should forget research and just teach. But good teachers are precisely those who are engaged in their fields, those whose passion for inquiry inspires their students.

title: Baby, It's Cold Inside
description: Who in the Northeast or Midwest, sweltering through the record heat early last week, didn't daydream about being Iceman?

title: Will Profit Motive Cure Poverty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond the Glass Menagerie
description: Wheaton Village is bringing more than a touch of glass to Millville next weekend. The Creative Glass Center of America and the Art Alliance for Contemporary Glass are presenting a three-day international symposium, exhibition and sale for glass artists, collectors, gallery representatives and museum curators.

title: TELEVISION / RADIO; The 'Pals' Files: Memos From a Sitcom Suit
description: Network Memo: April 26

title: Converting Dollars to Canvas
description: Of the world's 10 busiest, highest-spending art-collecting couples or individuals, 8 are Americans, according to a survey of dealers, auctioneers, museum officers and collectors by the magazine Artnews. They are Leon D. Black, the financier, and his wife, Debra; Eli Broad, the homebuilding and financial services entrepreneur, and his wife, Edythe; Donald and Doris Fisher, founders of Gap Inc.; David Geffen, the entertainment executive; Samuel J. Heyman, the New York investor, and his wife, Ronnie; Henry R. Kravis, the leveraged-buyout artist, and his wife, Marie Josee; Ronald Lauder, whose family owns Estee Lauder, and Stephen A. Wynn, who has stuffed his new Las Vegas hotel with masterpieces. The other two, in Europe, are Charles Saatchi, the British advertising executive, and Francois Pinault, the French investor. So much for fears that all the world's great art would end up in Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, SYLVIA
description: MANDELBAUM-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Cherished mother of Sue and (Joseph) Bruno, Phyllis and (Gene) Fernbach. Adored grandmother of Amy Jo and (Jeanmarc), Michael, Jonathan and Marjorie and (Marc). Treasured great-grandmother of Solenne and Adelaide. Sylvia was a member of HERJCC Choir & the United Choral Society. Services today, 12:30 at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: July 4-10; Vaccine in Mice Offers Hope in Alzheimer's Fight
description: Scientists have developed a potential vaccine for Alzheimer's disease. Researchers at Elan Pharmaceuticals in South San Francisco, a division of the Elan Corporation of Dublin, used mice that had been genetically altered so they produced plaques of amyloid protein in their brains, a primary abnormality in Alzheimer's.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FRANK O'CONNOR A Life. By Jim McKeon. Mainstream/Trafalgar Square, $35.

title: Phone Bills
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's column came a week after I checked out of the Windsor Court Hotel in New Orleans -- but not until challenging perhaps the most absurd phone charges I have ever incurred at a hotel. While in New Orleans, I made two calls to New York City from my room, with each call lasting about 10 minutes. Imagine my shock when the two calls were listed on my bill at a total cost of $55.

title: Protecting Pop
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, TED E. SR. M.D.
description: BECKER-Ted E. Sr. M.D. The Family of Dr. Becker ask that contributions in his memory be made to the Foundation of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute, with the designation that they be used for the furtherance of child analysis.

title: From the Formal to the Fresh, a Special Spring
description: SINCE it ain't over till it's over, it may be premature to declare the New York City Ballet's 50th anniversary year at an end. The celebration continues through July 24 at the company's summer home, the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in upstate New York. Nonetheless, the sum went beyond the parts in the recent City Ballet season at the New York State Theater.

title: For Mrs. Clinton, A Primary Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Racial Profiling Tops N.A.A.C.P. Agenda
description: The nation's oldest civil rights organization returned yesterday to New York, the city of its founding, to celebrate its 90th birthday and confront issues as topical as racial profiling by the police and getting more blacks to use the Internet.

title: Subcontinental Drift
description: Interpreter

title: July 4-10; My, What Big Teeth You Have
description: A colorful mural at Knossos, Crete, from around 1600 B.C., shows a school of dolphins swimming in a sea of fish, serene and seemingly happy. Since then, smiling dolphins have become an icon of inner peace. Authors and new-age centers hail them as superior beings with much to teach humans. Swimming with the dolphins, they say, can heal emotional wounds and open reservoirs of deep spirituality.

title: Forced to Share The Inner-City Turf
description: For the last several years, Richard Huber, the chief executive of Aetna Inc., has been quietly trying to tap the business potential of the nation's central cities, which have long been neglected by big private insurance concerns like his. Aetna has recruited African-American and Hispanic sales representatives to canvass their inner-city neighborhoods for customers, not only for managed-care plans but also for retirement accounts, another big part of the company's portfolio.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: Word & Image; Hidden in the Web
description: The Times spends several hundred million dollars a year to gather, digest and deliver its unique package of daily news, creating quite a bargain for readers who pay $6 to $10 a week to receive it. Yet The Times tells you on its front page that you could also get it all for nothing on the Web. Just punch in www.nytimes.com, read as much as you like and print out whatever you need to keep.

title: . . . And Lungs May Be Key In the Anatomy of a Horse
description: THE interactive science exhibition called ''Horse Play'' represents a first for the Bruce Museum -- which sometimes seems to have covered every conceivable stretchable topic. (''We've done boats and planes,'' said the museum's science curator Marianne Smith, ''but not horses.'')

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the rivalry between Acoustiguide and Antenna Audio as producers of audio museum tours misidentified the system used by the Museum of Natural History. It is Antenna Audio, not Acoustiguide. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the name of an Acoustiguide client. It is the Museum of Modern Art; there is, of course, no Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art.

title: Jehovah's Witnesses Hold Forth at Coliseum
description: IN an arena more used to the sight of body checks and the sounds of hockey fans, Frances Sosa quietly climbed into a swimming pool last week and prepared to begin a new life.

title: Elton Brand Is Chosen No. 1 In $9 Million Basketball Deal
description: ELTON BRAND, the Duke University sophomore from Peekskill, goes back to his roots just as strongly as he goes to the basket. A week ago last Wednesday, he was the first selection in the National Basketball Association draft. His first professional contract will be $9.2 million for three years.

title: QUICK BITE/Maplewood; Like Grandma Would Have Made, If She Had Been Italian
description: I've tried, I really have. But it's the rare occasion when I can wander through the center of Maplewood, either going to the movie theater or the pet store or some errand, and not be lured into the Roman Gourmet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAW, CAROL HENNING
description: SHAW-Carol Henning. Born July 11, 1939 Died November 19, 1998 Don Shaw

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Newtown, Conn.; Pre-1800 Houses, Fine Schools and Horses
description: ALMOST 300 years since it was founded in 1711, this sprawling, pastoral community is scrambling to hold onto its hometown image and rural landscape while coping with population growing as inexorably as Pinocchio's nose.

title: The Tree That Knew Too Much
description: BUXTON SPICE

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Sensuality and Lore in Works From India
description: THE title ''Peacocks and Pleasure Domes'' is an immediate alert that the small but exquisite show of paintings and drawings at the Hammond Museum here elevates the sensual above the didactic. Plenty of lore and scholarship lie under the surface of these works from India, but the wall text is kept to a minimum. Another clue that there is a premium on pleasure is the admission by Abigail Free, the museum's director, that the color of the lettering stenciled on the wall is a tribute to Diana Vreeland's observation, ''Shocking pink is the navy blue of India.''

title: Insignia Group's Expanding Universe
description: IT would be hard to argue that Andrew L. Farkas, the chairman and chief executive of Insignia Financial Group, is afraid of change.

title: Weather Hazards
description: Prolonged dry weather has prompted the county to impose a ban on open fires and restrictions on barbecuing in all 16,000 acres of Westchester parks.

title: Testing State-Run Districts: Reading Drops, Math Gains
description: All 11th graders in the state were tested in reading, writing and mathematics this past year. Last week, the state Board of Education released scores for the three districts that have been taken over by the state -- Jersey City, Paterson and Newark. All three declined in reading and improved in math.

title: Union Sq. Art Wall Is Large But, Ultimately, Just Flat
description: To the Editor:
