description: FRIEDLANDER-Michael J. Michael, you were a lifelong friend to Susan and me. We shall always cherish the many wonderful moments spent in your company. Our condolences are extended to your wife, Michelle, to Marilyn, your loving sister, and John, your brave and loyal son. Susan and Peter Schweitzer

title: F.Y.I.
description: Remnants of a Manor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNEBORN, CLARA L.
description: SONNEBORN-Clara L. On July 8, 1999, Clara Louise Sonneborn (nee Lauer). Loving wife of the late Henry Sonneborn III. Beloved mother of Peter Sonneborn. Beloved sister of the late Elinor Israel. Devoted sister-in-law of Lisette S. Scheuer. Beloved aunt of Ann S. Neumann, Henry W. Israel, Jr., Susan I. Levin and Barbara I. Goldner. Also survived by loving great nieces and nephews. Funeral services and interment will be held in Baltimore on July 11, 1999. A memorial service will take place at the Chapel at the Osborn, 101 Theall Road, Rye, NY on Thursday, July 22nd, 11 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, C.L.S. Memorial Fund, 1620 McElderry St, Reed Hall East, Rm 2217, Balt., MD 21205. For info call Levinson Funeral Home 1-800-338-1701.

title: The Best That Sag Harbor Has to Offer
description: THE Beacon is Sag Harbor's hottest new restaurant. It is also its best. The same winning team that opened red/ bar in Southampton last season is responsible for this charmer.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: The Ethicist; What Can I Say?
description: I see my friends take discounts for which they're not really eligible, buy and wear clothes they later return, stiff waiters and in many other ways cheat the system. I find this deplorable. Then again, when I was young I used to do many of the same things. How can I justify my righteous attitude when I've been just as guilty? And what do I say when my friends brag about these dubious achievements?

title: A Van Cliburn Winner at the Keyboard
description: FOR several years now, South Shore Music has supplemented its regular summer chamber series with non-subscription concerts introducing winners of the Van Cliburn International Competition. On Friday evening at 8, at Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, the tradition continues with a recital by Aviram Reichert, the winner of the bronze medal at the 1997 auditions. Mr. Reichert's program lists two sonatas by Beethoven, an Impromptu by Schubert and Ravel's ''Valse.'' Ticket holders are invited to picnic in the church garden and enjoy a pre-concert talk at 7, then to stay on after the recital for a reception to meet the artist. The number to call for tickets is (203) 227-0695.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Down Payment Loans
description: Saying that a lack of affordable housing thwarts companies trying to attract employees, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has announced a down payment assistance program, which would help low- and moderate-income workers buy houses.

title: A Subverter of Cliches About 50's Conformity
description: FROM the fluorescent nostalgia of ''American Graffiti'' (1973) to the satiric condescension of ''Pleasantville,'' recent movies have assured us that the Eisenhower era was a time of mass, unthinking conformity, of sexual prudishness and stable, nuclear families living in suburban split-levels -- a paradise for some, a hell for others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HERMAN
description: WEINSTEIN - Herman. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long-time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: There Is Nothing Like a Dane
description: 'DISCOVERING HAMLET'

title: Belgrade's Bitter People Shun Protests for Now
description: During his 12 years in power, whenever Slobodan Milosevic has been on the ropes, most of the punches have been thrown here in the Serbian capital.

title: Oceanfront Property
description: THE menu said that the seared French foie gras was accompanied by a pear chutney and a celeriac and pear salad. I would hate to have to testify to that in a court of law. The truth is that I was so smitten with the thinly pounded, salty, rich foie gras that I simply do not remember tasting anything else.

title: New Park Doesn't Insure Success
description: The Cleveland Indians set the standard. Beginning this Thursday with the Seattle Mariners, a growing group of teams will try to achieve it: move into new park, sell it out every game, finish first every year.

title: Serious Beef With a Bonus: Italian Flavor
description: FOOD fads come and quickly fade away, but steakhouses go on forever. Carmen Anthony Steakhouse in Waterbury is one of the newer ones and, from its inception, has been a steady success. Deservedly so, too, for it offers some of the better values in the area.

title: Koch Is Out of Hospital; Beame Is Treated for Pains
description: After being treated successfully for what doctors called a moderate heart attack, former Mayor Edward I. Koch left the hospital yesterday, wreathed in smiles and trailed by reporters.

title: On the Seamier Side Of the Bull Market
description: Another day, another $100 million lost by investors to securities fraud.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 31 of the Arts & Leisure section today about gospel music misstates the closing date of ''House Full o' Praise,'' a series of concerts included in Lincoln Center Festival '99. (A music review in Weekend on Friday also misstated the date, as well as the number of performances.) The series ends its run at the Ethical Culture Society on Friday, but there is a ninth performance -- at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday.

title: Giveaways by Yankees Are Proving to Be Costly
description: Their 9-8 loss to the Mets at Shea Stadium yesterday did not discourage the Yankees. It disgusted them, because once more they played horrible defense and gave away runs.

title: A Stunned Franco Is in the Spotlight
description: Matt Franco was dazed by his own success.

title: I'm a Few Electrons Short Of a Full Directory
description: WHEN it comes to technology, I'm reminded of Goldilocks and the three bears. Some people have way too much. Others have way too little. And then there are those -- and most people usually put themselves in this category -- who have it just right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTOPHER, PATRICK J.
description: CHRISTOPHER-Patrick J. On July 9, 1999, beloved Husband of the late Margaret (nee Gorman), loving son of the late Gerald and Mary C. Christopher, cherished father of Patricia and Gerald, dear godfather of Joan Licursi. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Graduate of Manhattan College, Class of 1931. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, NYC, on Monday and Tuesday, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday, 10 AM at St. Veronica R.C. Church, interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to The Christian Brothers Auxiliary, Lincroft, New Jersey.

title: Law Supports Bilingual Education
description: IN June, the General Assembly overhauled Connecticut's bilingual education statute, requiring bilingual teachers to be better qualified and parents to get more involved in the program . And, for the first time, it mandates standards for students and sets a time limit on their participation in bilingual classes.

title: Angus MacDonald Dies at 60; Was Scottish Bagpiper of Note
description: Angus MacDonald, whose verve and virtuosity made him one of the world's best and best-known bagpipe players, died on June 25 in a hospice in Edinburgh, Scotland, where he lived. He was 60.

title: The Color Of Suspicion
description: If Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris had been black, who knows what black kids in high schools would have been made to endure. But because they are white, it is a societal problem, and something has to be done about it, including, perhaps, posting the Ten Commandments in schools! When black kids misbehave, all blacks become criminals. Thank God, it is only the color of suspicion that is black and not the color of crime.

title: Uncharitable View
description: My reaction to Cohen's column was a resounding, Yes! As a public librarian, I have preached the theme that private money drives out public funding.

description: IT started with a bullfight and ended with a lot of investment bankers and fashion designers skinny-dipping in the hotel pool.

title: With a Celebration Of Dutch Freedom, He Frees Himself
description: JIRI KYLIAN makes his appearance dressed all in black and riding a bicycle, which seems fitting for a Czech choreographer who is also artistic director of the Netherlands Dans Theater. This being a country none too respectful of hierarchies, however, his arrival at the Lucent Danstheater, his company's headquarters here, goes almost unnoticed. For all his international fame, Mr. Kylian does not play the star in his own house.

description: IN the two decades since John Belushi bellowed, ''Your honey or your wife!'' as a corpulent killer bee on ''Saturday Night Live,'' those relentless, aggressive insects have passed out of the realm of schlock movies and sketch comedy and into the daily reality of life in states along the Mexican border, beginning nine years ago in Texas.

title: Secretive Chinese Spiritual Group Holds Protest and Wins a Retraction From Beijing
description: Nearly 1,000 members of a spiritual movement known as Falun Gong held a two-day demonstration inside Government headquarters in a southern Chinese city this week, a human rights organization reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOY, SARAH MILLIS
description: McCoy-Sarah Millis, on July 6, in Boston. Daughter of journalist and historian Walter Millis and stepdaughter of fashion journalist Eugenia Sheppard. She is survived by three children, Amanda, David and Jessica McCoy, and a brother Walter Millis, Jr.

description: It is so distressing to me to hear the Town of Southampton speak of the traffic conditions without one mention of the dangers of Montauk Highway and County Road 39.

description: The New Brunswick Cultural Center has announced a reorganization ''that will give the State Theater status as an independent member company.'' So what does that mean?

title: Uncharitable View
description: Give me private charity every time. As is not the case with the tax collector, if you don't like the way a private charity spends its resources, you can stop giving it money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, DAVID F.
description: JACKSON-David F., 61, in New York, July 3, 1999. Born in Camden, Maine. He is survived by brothers Glenn and Thomas and his stepmother Pearl Wadsworth, all of Maine. He was a graduate of Parsons School of Design. His interior design studio, Hollyhocks, Ltd., was well known in Manhattan and Southold. Friends, clients and family will miss the sparkle of his style and the lilt of his laughter. For information on memorial services, please call 570-296-6249.

title: The Valley Guys and Their Quirks
description: IN the second half of the 19th century, as in the second half of our own, American inventors and engineers were forging a definitive subculture and style.

description: The MetroStars got a foreign player in time for last night's game at Chicago but still were shut out for the seventh time this season, losing to the Fire, 2-0.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; As women start to use the Internet more for shopping, the prospects sharply improve for on-line retailers.
description: WHILE the E-commerce engine has been warming up in recent months, it remains fueled largely by the wallets of affluent men and computer geeks. That fuel, however, is about to receive a powerful additive: X chromosomes.

title: Sega Is Giving New Product Special Push

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. 1937-1999. Beloved son of the late Irving and Mollie. Adored father of Sophie. Loving soulmate of Sue Rothwell. Cherished brother of Martin (Susan), Henriette Miller (Herb) and the late Marjorie Sanders Visner (Sidney). Distinguished uncle of Jessica, Miranda, Jasmine, Adam and Emmanuel Isaac Sanders, Samuel Sanders Visner and the late Dr. Marc Sanders Visner, Dr. Robert, Bart and Phyllis Miller. Samuel, an inspiration to us all, dedicated his life to music. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: The Way to Woodstock? Look for the B-52; Concert Organizers Try to Rekindle Spirit of '69 on a Closed Air Force Base
description: If there ever was a symbol of what Woodstock is not, the hulking gray B-52 bomber casting shadows over Chestnut Street is it.

title: Winning Isn't the Only Thing; There's All That Drama
description: What is it about the dramas of sports that makes them infinitely more interesting than most other celebrity stories? The nonstop flow of media gossip and news chat is making entertainers, actors and even the ostensibly bold stars of rock and hip-hop seem pretty humdrum. X tells us what it means to be a creative person. Y tells us about the role models who changed her life. X, Y and Z tell us whether they think they look better with or without their clothes on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALTROW, ARNOLD P.
description: PALTROW-Arnold P. Of Palm Beach, FL; formerly Great Neck, NY on July 10, 1999. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Dorothy, his four children and their spouses, five grandchildren and the memory of his late grandson Keith, and five great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held privately at a later date. Donations may be made to Valley Forge Military Academy, Wayne, PA or the Keith Adam Paltrow Memorial Scholarship Fund at Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.

title: From High to Low, Hopefuls for 2000 Are Awash in Funds
description: Representative Shelley Berkley, a freshman Democrat from Nevada, has raised nearly half a million dollars in 10 weeks. Mayoral candidates who are not even favorites are also filling their war chests. And the Democratic National Committee is out of debt.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: War Crimes Tribunal Appeals to Unconventional Judge
description: LEAVING a life-tenured Federal judgeship for a two-year term on the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Patricia M. Wald is setting out, at age 70, on her next great adventure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POHL, GORDON
description: POHL-Gordon. July 10. Of Swampscott, MA and Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Lynbrook, NY. Husband of Edith (Jones). Father of Richard & Frances Pohl of Swampscott, MA, Donald & Asnat Pohl of Boston, MA. Grandfather of Matthew & Noah Pohl. Graveside services at Hungarian Fields Cemetery, Queens, NY, on Monday, July 12, at 2 PM. Memorial observance Tuesday evening, Wednesday and Thursday at his late residence. Contributions in his memory may be donated to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALZBERG, NORMAN
description: MALZBERG-Norman. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Compressed Data; E-Commerce Twist: Full-Service Shipping
description: Commercekey, an Internet start-up, has come up with a business plan with a new wrinkle in the crowded electronic commerce market. In addition to peddling software and transaction services to help businesses set up shop on the Web, the company, with roots in the Greek shipping industry, has its own world class fleet of cargo vessels standing by to deliver customers' merchandise around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, MICHAEL J.
description: FRIEDLANDER-Michael J. 61, loving husband of Michele Trufant Friedlander, father of John Friedlander, brother of Marilyn Cohen, died July 8, 1999, in Fairfax Hospital, Fairfax, VA, after a brief illness. A true horseman and a passionate supporter of 3-day eventing, Michael encouraged many riders and horses at all levels of the sport. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and Princeton University and was a skilled commodities trader from early childhood, ultimately founding and chairing M.J. Friedlander Co., Inc. He will forever be missed for his consummate style, joyful wit and tremendous love of life. Donations may be made to favored charities. Following Michael's wishes, there will be no services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILBERT, MARY JANE (NEE BRACKEN)
description: HILBERT-Mary Jane (nee Bracken). Age 82, of Fairfield, CT, died on July 11, 1999. Alumna Class of 1938 of the College of Mt. St. Vincent. She is survived by her husband Thomas F. Hilbert, Jr. and children Thomas III, Lawrence, Reverend Michael, S.J., and Anne; daughters-in-law Peggy and Nina; grandchildren Patrick and Frances. There will be no wake. Funeral mass on Tuesday, July 13, at 11:30 AM, St. Pius X Parish, Fairfield, CT.

title: Eichelberger Holds On For U.S. Senior Title
description: On an afternoon dominated by two surprise contenders, one slipped and the other surged. Dave Eichelberger, and not Ed Dougherty, claimed the biggest golf tournament of his life, the United States Senior Open.

title: FOES REPORT PLAN TO BEGIN PULLOUT IN KASHMIR REGION
description: India and Pakistan said today that guerrilla infiltrators battling Indian troops in the last two months along the icy ridges and mountaintops of Kashmir would begin a phased withdrawal, heralding an end to the latest confrontation between the world's newest nuclear powers.

title: Essay; Disaster Never Came
description: ''Fate has ordained,'' a saddened President was prepared to say, ''that the men who went to the moon to explore in peace will stay to rest in peace.''

title: No Escape From Solitude Despite Close Encounters
description: The Expressions Dance Company smashed dramatic situations into smithereens and presented them as sharp choreographic fragments on Thursday night when it appeared in the Asia-Pacific Contemporary Dance Festival at the Kaye Playhouse. This modern-dance troupe from Brisbane, Australia, made a strong impression in two works offered under the general title ''Decadances.'' Although each was by a different choreographer and could be presented independently, both evoked feelings of frustration and loneliness in many brief scenes.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ledee's Efforts Lift Spirits
description: Ricky Ledee innocently exited the bathroom of the visitors' clubhouse yesterday with toilet paper tucked into the back of his uniform pants. Ledee walked across the clubhouse, and the paper unraveled behind him for 20, 30, 40 feet before finally ripping. As teammates giggled, Ledee was oblivious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTOPHER, PATRICK J.
description: CHRISTOPHER-Patrick J. On July 9, 1999, beloved Husband of the late Margaret (nee Gorman), loving son of the late Gerald and Mary C. Christopher, cherished father of Patricia and Gerald, dear godfather of Joan Licursi. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Graduate of Manhattan College, Class of 1931. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, NYC, on Monday and Tuesday, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday, 10 AM at St. Veronica R.C. Church, interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to The Christian Brothers Auxiliary, Lincroft, New Jersey.

title: Books' Hero Wins Young Minds; An Apprentice Wizard Rules the World (at Least Its Bookstores)
description: Hannibal Lecter and Harry Potter are shaping up as the summer's must reads. Harry who?

title: Do Voters Gain From Primaries?
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From China: 'So Close, So Close'
description: Those fateful penalty kicks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLITZER, DOROTHY
description: WOLLITZER-Dorothy. 95, of New York City. Adored wife of the late Herman Wollitzer. Beloved mother of Nancy Kirshberg and Myrna Wollitzer. Loving grandmother to Meryl Kirshberg Chae and Jeffrey Kirshberg. Graveside services, July 13, 1:00 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: The Kirov Bids Farewell With Purity of Style
description: A prolonged ovation, laced with cheers, closed the Kirov Ballet's two-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Packed with major debuts, the weekend began on Friday night with dramatically improved performances in the company's all-Balanchine bill and featured a touching Maya Dumchenko as the heroine of ''The Fountain of Bakhchisarai'' on Saturday afternoon. The end came on Saturday night with Irma Nioradze, a dancer new to New York this season, in ''Giselle'' with Igor Zelensky.

title: Deer Tick, Suburbs' Scourge, Is More and More at Home
description: On Fire Island, where the hot look for summer gardeners now includes masking tape, long sleeves and multiple pairs of socks, ticks drift down from the trees onto plates of pasta, horrifying the guests. In Putnam County, N.Y., about an hour north of New York City, a surveyor who makes his living traipsing through high grass ends every workday hunched over a pair of tweezers, hoping to yank the critters out of his skin before it is too late.

title: Prison Series Seeks to Shatter Expectations
description: Crucifixion. Cannibalism. Slow death by eating glass. Sexual mutilation. Is there nothing Tom Fontana won't depict on his HBO prison series, ''Oz''?

title: Do Voters Gain From Primaries?
description: To the Editor:

title: Offerings Scheduled This Week in Equities
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Media Talk; Time Editor Is Critical of Brill's Content
description: On Thursday afternoon, several dozen reporters, television producers, newspaper editors and columnists found themselves staring at a blistering letter, sent to them by Norman Pearlstine, editor in chief of Time Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARITA, ANTONINA
description: STARITA - Antonina. Beloved mother of Laura, Vittorio, Louis, Paul, Joseph, Regina Saat and the late Rita Palermo and Regina Celeste. Also survived by 16 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Reposing at Cusimano & Russo Funeral Home, 2005 West 6th St., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of the Resurrection, Tuesday, 10:15 AM, St. Brendan's R.C. Church. Interment, Holy Cross Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Metropolitan Hospice of Greater New York or Fr. Benedict Groeshel, C.F.R. would be appreciated.

title: Magic Names Davis As an Assistant
description: The Orlando Magic named Johnny Davis, former coach of the Philadelphia 76ers, as an assistant to Coach Doc Rivers yesterday. Davis, 43, spent the past two seasons as an assistant coach with the Nets, but was dismissed March 18 along with Coach John Calipari and the rest of his staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOM, NILA B.
description: BLOM-Nila B. Beloved mother of Jackie, Terri, Steve and Lorrie. Devoted grandmother of Edward, Jessica, James, Saskia and Gabrielle; proud great-grandmother of Lauren. We celebrate her loving and generous nature. A kind and gentle spirit, caring nurse, crossword enthusiast and friend to all she knew.

title: Unlikely Lobbyist Will Lead H.M.O.'s Into Battle
description: When the Senate takes up legislation on Monday to define patients' rights, Democrats will argue that hundreds of people have been injured or even died because they were denied necessary care by cost-conscious health maintenance organizations.

title: Police Seek Woman, 78, Missing and in Ill Health
description: A 78-year-old woman from Wantagh has been missing since Saturday morning, the Nassau County police said last night.

title: Absolut, the top-selling imported vodka in the country, extends its brand for a fourth time.
description: THERE'S an old saying that nothing rhymes with ''orange.'' So there may not be a rhyme for a multimillion-dollar campaign to pitch a new orange-flavored variety of Absolut vodka -- but there certainly is a reason.

title: Compressed Data; High Technology For Money Management
description: You may not be a Silicon Valley gazillionaire, but here is your chance to manage your money like one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, HENRY
description: LIEBERMAN-Henry. On July 11, at age 85. Beloved husband of the late Helen, loving father of Amy and Jacob, cherished grandfather of Sarah and David, beloved brother of Lewis and the late Gerold. Graveside services, Monday at 2:30 PM, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, NY.

title: Congressional Study Disputes Worth of Lower Alcohol Limit
description: The Federal highway safety agency has overstated the effectiveness of state laws that lower the limit for alcohol in the bloodstream to be considered legally drunk, a Government review has found. The review concluded that lowering the blood-alcohol limit alone did not demonstrably reduce the number or severity of alcohol-related car crashes.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Somebody could walk in off the street and not know anything about baseball, and they would know this guy is good at what he does, just because of the passion he shows for each pitch, the intensity.''

title: Jean Chisholm Lindsey, Leader Of Business and Civic Groups, 71
description: Jean Gardiner Chisholm Lindsey, a business and civic leader who in the 1980's served as an officer, trustee or member of 18 organizations and foundations at the same time, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan on June 29, according to her son John.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies of the main news section yesterday with the continuation of an article about the United States' victory in the Women's World Cup final misidentified the player holding the winners' trophy. She was Carla Overbeck, not Cindy Parlow.

title: And Strong TV Ratings, Too
description: The Women's World Cup victory by the United States team over China on Saturday produced an astonishing 13.3 overnight Nielsen rating, at least doubling ABC's expectations. By comparison, the National Basketball Association finals between the Knicks and San Antonio Spurs generated an 11.3 average national rating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOPNICK, MAX
description: CHOPNICK-Max. July 8, 1999. Husband of Anita Stevens and the late Marjorie Marsh Chopnick. Brother of Gertrude, Sandra and Charles. Stepfather of the late Charles Enfield. Counselor-at-law, philanthropist, mentor who enriched the lives of so many. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial Wednesday, July 14, 2:00 PM at 21 West 52nd Street, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Berlitz Will Use 'Sesame Street' to Teach English
description: Berlitz International is joining hands with the producers of ''Sesame Street'' to use the internationally known television program in a multimedia project to teach English as a second language to children around the world.

title: Baffert Completes Sweep As Forestry Wins Dwyer
description: Bob Baffert opened the second half of the racing season yesterday by completing a sweep of stakes for 3-year-olds in the East: on the day after his filly Silverbulletday won the Monmouth Oaks, Baffert won the Dwyer at Belmont Park with his newest star colt, Forestry.

title: 2 Big Advertisers Move Accounts
description: Two large advertisers are changing agencies.

title: Media Talk; News Media's Eye Turns More to Children
description: Children have gone from being a very low priority on the coverage lists of major national newspapers and television news networks to being a modest priority, according to a two-part study released last week. And when children appear in news reports, it is less often as victims or perpetrators of crimes than was the case five years ago.

title: American And British Law Firms Set to Merge
description: Lawyers at Rogers & Wells in New York and Clifford Chance in London announced yesterday that they had approved a merger of their firms, the first combination between major British and American law firms.

title: A Maestro of the Mound, Working on a Symphony
description: Pedro Martinez can't lift a Volkswagen. There is nothing cartoonish about his body, no Popeye forearms, no Superman chest; Martinez possesses the physical presence of a toll taker. His favorite dietary supplement could be grapefruit. But even though Pedro Martinez is slight enough to be a tattoo on the biceps of Mark McGwire, he is the Mark McGwire of pitchers in 1999.

title: Big Turnout for Minority Journalists
description: If the gathering here this week had been a medical convention, it would have been billed as a gathering of experts seeking cures for terminal nearsightedness. More than 5,000 minority journalists -- and hundreds more people who train them, hire them, study their work, make their computers and advertise with their news organizations -- spent days debating what news organizations must do to put the world in focus.

title: A Techno Buzz More Rock Than Rave
description: From swing to disco, music made mostly for dancing has been as much about its patrons as its players. Devotees gather to check out one another's moves and outfits and bask in the emotional heat raised by many bodies undulating together. This is especially true of machine-generated club music; watching rhythm scientists push buttons isn't as engaging as watching fleet-fingered bass players or muscular drummers.

title: Not Quite a Triumph in Congo
description: While its authors pitched it as a triumph, Saturday night's signing of a cease-fire deal to end the war in Congo had something of an air of fiasco about it.

title: Bonilla-Valentine Flare-Up: Strong Words in the Dugout
description: The on-again, off-again feud between Mets Manager Bobby Valentine and Bobby Bonilla is on again.

title: At Border, Arafat and Barak Meet to Build Road to Peace
description: At this sun-baked juncture between Israel and the Gaza Strip, the first Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting in seven months began today with an embrace and an exchange of gifts.

title: Giuliani Vows No Concession On Oversight Of the Police
description: Reacting to an investigation by Federal prosecutors that found widespread problems in the way the New York City Police Department handles brutality complaints, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would never agree to a Federal monitor or other outside oversight of the department.

title: Patriotism Politics
description: Surely there are better ways for Congressional lawmakers to demonstrate their love of country than to dilute Americans' free-speech rights. This simple truth continues to elude the House of Representatives. For the third time in four years, the chamber has approved a constitutional amendment that would undermine the right of free expression by allowing Congress to prohibit the physical desecration of the American flag. Once again, it is up to the Senate to block this assault on the Bill of Rights.

title: Sports of The Times; Didn't Get Enough? Wait Till Next Year
description: THE town was clamorous in partisanship. Mike Piazza recalled hearing it from both sides, even over the ritualistic cacophony of sirens, horns and assorted denunciations.

title: Senator Blocking Holbrooke Calls Albright the Real Villain
description: A Senator who is blocking a final Senate vote on Richard C. Holbrooke's nomination to be chief American diplomat at the United Nations asserted today that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was directly responsible for the delay because of her treatment of a State Department employee described as a whistle-blower.

title: Samuel Sanders Is Dead at 62; Accompanied Noted Performers
description: Samuel Sanders, a pianist who was the recital partner of choice of Itzhak Perlman, Mstislav Rostropovich, Robert White and many other instrumentalists and singers, died Friday night at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 62 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, NATHAN B.
description: BIDERMAN-Nathan B. Age 95 in Palm Beach, FL, on July 9, 1999. Husband of the late Ruth and the late Evelyn. Father of Burt and Mark. Father-in-law of Carol and Wendy. Grandfather of Rebecca, Philip, Robin, and Eric. Brother of the late Sol and Morton. Graveside Services 2 PM, Monday at Union Fields Cemetery.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: CBS Seeking Dual Payoff On Rock Series
description: Looking to enter what is becoming a growing secondary profit center for television networks -- sales of music CD's tied to programming -- CBS begins shooting this week on the most ambitious music-oriented mini-series to date, ''Shake, Rattle and Roll,'' a four-hour film filled with original or little-known songs, some composed by famous names loke Bob Dylan and Carole King, and remakes of 1950's hits performed by a long roster of contemporary singing stars.

title: Shrewd and on the Side of Justice, or So He Thought
description: THE PROSECUTION

title: Best and Brightest Vie For N.A.A.C.P. Honors
description: One minute, Dorian Logan was sneering and abusive as Sergeant Waters in Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play.'' The next, he was languid, then quivering with fear as C. J. Memphis, the guitar-strumming private whom the Sergeant accuses of murder. And the next, he was first cool, then explosive, as Pfc. Melvin Peterson, who shoots Sergeant Waters on C. J.'s behalf.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Treasury Auction Is Limited to Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Don't Get Hysterical, Mom. Just Leave a Message. Beep!
description: Not every stand-up comedian can do a routine about Karl Lagerfeld and get big laughs. Margaret Cho can and does in her witty, eminently likable one-woman show, ''I'm the One That I Want,'' now at the Westbeth Theater Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLIN, JOHN G.
description: BRESLIN-John G. Age 76, of Matawan, NJ, died Friday at St. Peter's University Hospital, New Brunswick. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, where he lived until 1971 before moving to Matawan. Mr. Breslin was former Senior Vice President of the Chicago Title Insurance Co., NY. He was former Executive Director of Independent Oil Retailers Association, New York State. He was an Attorney for Harvey Geary Association, Brooklyn, retiring 1998. He was former Attorney for the Department of Investigations, NYC, for 19 years. He was former Democratic District Captain, Brooklyn. He was twice nominated for the NY State Supreme Court. He was a former Ensign and U.S. Navy Veteran of WWII. He was a parishioner and lecturer of the Most Holy Redeemer RC Church, Old Bridge. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Patricia Ann Tully Breslin; five sons: John, Jr. of Rockville Centre, NY; Peter J. of Catonsville, MD; Hugh E. of Basking Ridge, NJ; Robert E. of Denville, NJ; James A. of Westmont, NJ; three daughters: Eleanor I. of Matawan; Mary T. Munoz of Old Bridge; Patricia A. Kessell of Newton, NJ; twelve grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Services Tuesday, 8:30 AM, at the Waitt Funeral Home, 501 Highway 79, Morganville, NJ. Mass, 9:30 AM at Most Holy Redeemer R.C. Church, Old Bridge, NJ. Burial, Holy Cross Burial Park, South Brunswick, NJ. Visiting, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: For Fourth Day, Kosovo Albanians March to Protest a Plan for Russian Peacekeepers
description: Several thousand Kosovo Albanians marched through this little town today, in the fourth day of peaceful protests against plans to station Russian troops among the NATO peacekeepers here.

title: One Killed and 2 Injured in Bronx Shooting
description: Gunfire, apparently provoked by an argument, left a 25-year-old man dead and two other people injured yesterday afternoon on a Bronx street corner, the police said.

title: The Trillion-Dollar Problem
description: Only a few years ago, the idea of Congress and the President wrangling over a trillion-dollar budget surplus would have provoked disbelief. But it turns out that the new era of surpluses is just as contentious as the old era of deficits. As Congress returns to work today, House Republicans are preparing a tax cut so large it would use up virtually all of the surplus for 10 years, leaving no money to make Medicare solvent or to avoid deeper domestic cuts. The likelihood that President Clinton would veto an outsized tax cut is only spurring them on. Lawmakers seem to favor slogans over solutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, ELY
description: GOLDENBERG-Ely. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and conveys sincere condolences to his family. Services Tuesday 10:30AM, Kol Ami Chapel. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark A. Hershey, President

title: A Time Capsule Yields Underwhelming Arcana
description: There were two pennies.

title: Columbia Names Arts School Dean
description: Columbia University today named Bruce W. Ferguson dean of its Graduate School of the Arts, effective Aug. 1. He will succeed Robert Fitzpatrick, who stepped down in June 1998 to become director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.

title: In New Jersey, Water Main Break Prompts Restrictions
description: More than half a million people in northern New Jersey were urged to boil their water before drinking it and ordered to halt all outdoor water use after a water main broke yesterday in Bergen County.

title: Vowing to Go From Scandal to Strength, City Union Looks for a Fight
description: After all the indictments and revelations of scandal, the new leaders of District Council 37, New York City's giant municipal union, have taken steps to reshape the union as the muscular force it once was.

title: Advice on Careful Counting From an International Duo
description: Edward VII of Britain, a bridge enthusiast a century ago, would have been astonished to hear that one day it would be possible to play the game with a partner on the other side of the world. But now that happens regularly on the Internet.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

description: STAVIS-Nathan. July 12, 1919 through April 7, 1995. Happy 80th birthday. We love you and miss you. Your Family and Friend
