description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN B. (JACK)
description: KELLY-John B. (Jack). Pearl River, NY, on July 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Marie, loving father of Elizabeth Fichtel of Rutherford, New Jersey, Barbara Kittle of Carlstadt, NJ, and John B. Kelly, Jr. of New City, NY. Also survived by six grandchildren. Mass of Christian burial to be held Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Margaret's R.C. Church, Pearl River, NY. Burial at the Cemetery of the Ascension, Munsey, NY. Visiting at the Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home, Inc., 100 Franklin Ave., Pearl River, NY, on Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEST, JACK
description: BEST-Jack. We at BESTMED/ HRG extend deepest sympathies to Dr. David Best and family on the loss of their dear father, Jack.

title: Media Talk; Too Few Viewers for 'Hockenberry'
description: In the pinball-fast world of cable news, where stories, correspondents and schedules are constantly changing, it takes something special to stand out. A host with a strong identity who attracts a regular following -- like CNN's Larry King -- has tremendous value, especially in prime time, where the highest-priced advertising is mined.

title: James A. Barnes Jr., 70; Helped Alert U.S. to Missiles in Cuba
description: James A. Barnes Jr., who in 1962 piloted a U-2 spy plane that helped alert the United States to the threat of a Soviet missile buildup in Cuba, died on Tuesday at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View, Calif. He was 70 and lived in Los Altos, Calif.

title: Despite Police Dismissals, Iran Protest Is the Angriest Yet
description: In a new sign of militancy, at least 15,000 Iranian students took to the streets of Teheran today in what has become a protest against a divided Government whose security forces remain in conservative hands.

title: The Big City; Seeing Con Ed In New Light, With Rivals
description: IT may not be of much comfort at the moment, but there may soon come a time when Consolidated Edison is unable to plunge large sections of New York City into darkness. Even more incredible, Con Ed could become a popular institution.

title: Paper Trail Haunts G.M. After It Loses Injury Suit
description: The $4.9 billion verdict in a personal-injury lawsuit against General Motors on Friday might be only the start of the company's problems. Lawyers and safety consultants pursuing similar cases say corporate documents used as evidence in the case, many for the first time, could be troublesome for General Motors in the future.

title: U.S. Finds No One to Back Among Milosevic's Foes
description: Despite its clear desire to see President Slobodan Milosevic ousted, the Clinton Administration is finding it difficult to capitalize on the opportunity presented by the opposition protests that have bubbled up across Serbia.

title: Life After Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Hillary Speak for New York?
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton seems set on running for the Senate from New York, and many people are asking how well someone who has not lived in the state could represent it. Mrs. Clinton acknowledged the issue last week when she said, ''I think I have some real work to do to get out and listen and learn from the people of New York and demonstrate that what I'm for is maybe as important -- if not more important -- than where I'm from.''

title: Carnoustie a Challenge or a Nightmare
description: Winning the British Open at Carnoustie Golf Club is never a breeze, especially if the wind howls.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about negotiations over ownership of The New York Observer misstated the location of The Litchfield County Times. It is in New Milford, Conn., not Litchfield.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Slaying Suspects May Be Tied To Arsons at 3 Synagogues
description: The two brothers, say neighbors, are nature-loving organic gardeners, meek, respectful sorts raised by stern, religious parents in a small farm town.

title: Kansas City Museum Picks Architect for Addition
description: The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., has selected Steven Holl, the New York architect, to design its first expansion since its opening in 1933.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rogers & Wells Approves Merger With London Firm

title: As Colombia Declares an Alert, Rebel Offensive Rages On
description: Leftist guerrillas in Colombia renewed attacks on more than a score of towns today after a Government decree set a dusk-to-dawn partial curfew in nearly one-third of the country and ordered the armed forces into a state of alert.

title: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL; Liberty Lead Crumbles Into Loss at the Garden
description: In the game's final five seconds, Brandy Reed knifed through a scrambling Liberty defense like a commuter weaving through rush-hour traffic. She slipped past four defenders, including the defensive ace Teresa Weatherspoon. She worked her way within 10 feet of the basket, lifted her right knee, jumped off her left leg and tossed a knuckleball toward the hoop.

title: Interactive Concerns Select Agencies
description: Several interactive advertisers have chosen their first agencies to accounts with combined billings estimated at $47 million to $57 million.

title: In Search of Readers, Publishers Consider Age
description: The Long Island Fiction Book Club is a suburban Port Washington, N.Y., reading group that has endured longer than some marriages and pored over the pages of more than 100 novels from Flaubert's ''Madame Bovary'' to Amy Tan's ''Joy Luck Club.''

title: Kids' TV Viewing
description: To the Editor:

title: Plenty Of Seats Available
description: For movie theater owners this summer, it is the best of times and the worst of times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBELMAN, SHERRY (NEE FIELDS)
description: SOBELMAN-Sherry (nee Fields). Of Old Tappan, NJ. Beloved wife of Alan; cherished daughter of Shirley and the late Julius Fields; devoted mother of Pam Schwartz, Jed Rothenberg; stepmother of Dayna and David Sobelman; loving grandmother of Alison Schwartz. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ, today at noon. Shiva to be observed at the residence. Contributions to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Liars Never Break A Sweat
description: Los Alamos National Laboratory has recently begun using polygraph tests to screen all of its nuclear weapons scientists. The ''lie detector'' tests were ordered by Energy Secretary Bill Richardson after allegations that China had obtained critical design information concerning our most advanced nuclear weapons.

title: Better to Fix Up Cities Than Tear Them Down; Unglamorous Tactic
description: To the Editor:

title: 25 Years of Pilobolus in a Single Night
description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater has expanded its range considerably over its 25 years of exuberant existence. The company, now midway through a monthlong anniversary season at the Joyce Theater, offered a fast survey of its changing scenes on Friday night in the second of three programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, EMILIO
description: SANCHEZ-Emilio. Cuban born painter residing in New York City. Died of heart failure on a walk in the woods in Warwick, New York, On July 8th. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St. NY, NY 11:30am on Tuesday, July 13th. Interment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Igor Belsky, 74, Dancer, Choreographer and Former Director of Kirov
description: Igor Belsky, the artistic director of the Vaganova Ballet Academy of St. Petersburg and a former director of Russia's Kirov Ballet, died at a hospital in St. Petersburg on July 3. He was 74.

title: Preventing the Next Power Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadcaster Seeks Change in Digital TV Format
description: It seems to be a hopeless, quixotic mission. The nation's transition to digital television is now in its ninth month, and more than 70 television stations nationwide have begun broadcasting on their digital channels. Hundreds more have placed orders for digital transmission equipment. At the same time, as many as 40,000 consumers have bought expensive new digital television sets.

title: What James Farmer Leaves Behind
description: James Farmer, the former head of the Congress of Racial Equality, who died on Friday at 79, was the last of the major civil rights leaders of his generation, and one of the first to begin the struggle. Moved by what he had learned in college of Gandhi's use of nonviolent disobedience, Mr. Farmer founded CORE as a local group in Chicago in the early 1940's, and it was there that he first used Gandhian tactics to integrate the White City Roller Skating Rink. It worked in Chicago, and chapters sprang up east and west, in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Seattle. But it was unthinkable to try to take the effort into the deep South in the 1940's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARDICK, BRUCE S.
description: DARDICK-Bruce S. Of Delray Beach, FLorida, formerly of New Haven, Connecticut, is survived by his wife, Leila Regen Dardick, sons Kenneth, Yaakov and Larry.

title: Ozawa and Company in a Perfect Setting, at Least for the 'Pastorale'
description: The descriptive subtitle that Beethoven provided for the first movement of his ''Pastorale'' Symphony reads, in English translation, ''Awakening of happy feelings upon reaching the countryside.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, BETTY
description: GREENSTEIN-Betty. On July 7. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, devoted mother of Herbert and Myrna and loving grandmother of Jonathan and Graham Blyth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COONEY, TIMOTHY J.
description: COONEY-Timothy J., who served in New York City government from 1958 to 1968. Died on July 7 at University Hospital in New York. He was 69 years old. He is survived by his brother Christopher of Washington, D.C.

title: Asian Rebound Derails Reform As Many Suffer
description: Just two years after it began, the financial crisis that started in Asia and spread pain around the world appears to be over -- leaving many to wonder if the symptoms have abated before the disease could be treated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISH, HERMAN L.
description: FISH-Herman L. -On July 7, 1999, age 80. Resident of San Francisco. Graduate of Queens College, class of '41. Clinical psychologist for NYC Bureau of Child Guidance for 23 years. Taught at Brooklyn and Queens Colleges and Pace Institute in Manhattan. Member of the American Psychological Association for 50 years. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Florence, his children Kenneth Fish of Fairport, NY, Victoria Reed of San Francisco, his sister Ida Pearl Karr of Georgetown, Texas, and four grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURBAUGH, PATRICIA ROPER
description: HURBAUGH - Patricia Roper. 1927-1999. Mrs. Robert G. Hurbaugh (Patricia Roper) of Rye, NY and Jupiter, FL, a leader in philanthropic and charitable work, died of pulmonary and cardiac complications on Saturday, July 10, 1999, at Westchester Country Club in Rye. She was 72. Mrs. Hurbaugh chaired major charity events in Palm Beach, including the 1984 Heart Ball. Her efforts raised significant funding for national organizations. Her activities benefited causes that included the Salvation Army, Boys Clubs, American Cancer Society, and St. Mary's/Good Samaritan Hospitals in Florida. She is a past Board member of the Palm Beach Roundtable and a Benefactor of the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts in West Palm Beach. Mrs. Hurbaugh was born June 16, 1927 in Hobart, Indiana, the daughter of Lee and Edith Busse Roper. She was the first speech and hearing therapy graduate from the University of Indiana at Bloomington where she was a member of Alpha Omicron Sorority. On October 10, 1953 she married Robert G. Hurbaugh, whom she had met at the University of Indiana. Mrs. Hurbaugh lived in Rye, NY for the past 25 years. She has also had a home in Jupiter, FL, for the past nine years and was a resident of Palm Beach for many years prior. She was a longtime member of St. Matthew's Lutheran Church in White Plains, NY. Other affiliations included the Metropolitan Club of New York City, Westchester Country Club, Rye, NY, Jupiter Hills Golf Club, Tequesta, FL, The Beach Club of Palm Beach, FL, Turtle Creek Country Club and the PGA National Golf Club in Florida. Mrs. Hurbaugh will be remembered for her universal friendliness, extending her warm attentiveness to all she encountered from store clerks to royalty. She was an extroverted humanitarian with an irrepressible wit. She took great joy in life, embracing it with exuberance. She delighted in travel and entertaining, undertaking both with distinctive flair. She enjoyed golf and bridge, playing both frequently and well throughout her life. Most of all she was a loving, devoted, and attentive wife, mother and grandmother. She is survived by her husband of 45 years, Robert G. Hurbaugh, her daughters Lee Ann Alderton and Lisa Jo Hurbaugh, her son, William R. Hurbaugh, her son-in-law Jeffrey Alderton, five grandchildren, Taylor and Bradford Alderton and Ashley, Finley and Clayton Ahearn. Calling hours are Tuesday, July 13, from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road in Rye, NY. The funeral is Wednesday, July 14, at 11 AM at St. Matthew's Lutheran Church, corner of Mamaroneck and Carhart Avenues in White Plains. Interment will follow on Friday, July 16, at 11 AM at Riverside Cemetery, Tequesta, FL. Friends may send memorial donations to American Heart Association, Palm Beach Chapter, Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUGELMAN, ARTHUR E.
description: KUGELMAN-Arthur E. On July 10, 1999 at age 71. Beloved husband of Stephanie. Loving father of Sarah and Dana. Devoted brother of Ileane Eisenberg and the late Davey Kugelman. Cherished uncle of Douglas, Sheryl, Adam, Ben, Rebecca and Alexander. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, July 11th, 7-9 PM, with service Monday, 9:30 AM. Interment to follow at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or Gilda's Club.

title: Hold It Right There
description: The Yankees and Mets had their share of base-running high jinks over the weekend. The Mets sometimes hold runners at first base in a style almost all their own: rather than remain at the bag, first baseman John Olerud darts back and forth, sometimes obstructing the sight line of the runners, sometimes getting in between the runners and the base.

title: INSIDE
description: Fighting Flares in Colombia

title: Law Firms Approve U.S.-British Merger
description: Lawyers at Rogers & Wells in New York and Clifford Chance in London approved a merger of their firms, the first combination between major British and American law firms.

title: Prisons Brim With Mentally Ill, Study Finds
description: The first comprehensive study of the rapidly growing number of emotionally disturbed people in the nation's jails and prisons has found that there are 283,800 inmates with mental illness, about 16 percent of the jail population. The report confirms the belief of many state, local and Federal experts that jails and prisons have become the nation's new mental hospitals.

title: Sports of The Times; Will Women Enjoy a League of Their Own?
description: THE advertisement was up and running in the Sunday edition of The Los Angeles Times:

title: Met Life Is Said to Be Near Deal for St. Paul Auto and Home Unit
description: Metropolitan Life, one of the country's largest life insurance companies, is expected to announce today that it is sharply expanding its auto and home insurance subsidiary by buying a unit of the St. Paul Companies, a leading corporate insurer, for more than $500 million, executives close to the negotiations said.

title: Belgian Revel in Baseball's Home
description: To the uninitiated, it may seem exceedingly odd -- daft, perhaps? -- to honor the tiny, distant nation of Belgium at the epicenter of the great American pastime during the high season of baseball.

title: Tobacco's Victims?
description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Series Protocol: Leave Your Brooms at the Gate
description: Of course, for everyone's safety, all brooms had to be confiscated.

title: Mexico Students to Continue Strike at Empty Campus
description: Digging in their heels, student protesters have decided once again to continue their strike at Mexico's huge national university, now in its 12th week, even though there are no longer any classes for them to strike against.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAUMONT, PHILIP
description: BEAUMONT-Philip. All of us at Chadbourne & Parke LLP mourn the death of our friend and colleague, Philip Beaumont, on July 3, 1999. Phil first joined our firm from Columbia Law School in 1973 and by 1980 had become a partner specializing in mergers and acquisitions. But aside from being a first-class corporate lawyer, he was so much more: a wonderful mentor to our young associates; a man who handled the most complicated corporate transactions with cool elan; and, most importantly, a loving and caring father to three wonderful daughters. Our hearts go out to them and his wife, Meaghan McGrath Beaumont. Phil, you have left the world far too young-your legacy, however, will live long into the next century.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about a couple who were admiring floating sculptures on the Pond in Central Park misspelled the surname of the sculptor. She is Andrea Zittel, not Zeitel.

title: Elliott May Face Suspension For Arrest
description: The Jets' Jumbo Elliott faces disciplinary action by the National Football League -- perhaps including a suspension -- after what the police said was a brawl in a bar.

title: Day in the Sun for the Girls of Summer After a Riveting Championship Run
description: Having won the Women's World Cup, the United States soccer team paraded around Disneyland this morning and then headed East for a blizzard of morning television shows and magazine covers. An international tour is being planned for later this year, and the team is expected to remain largely intact for the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia. Beyond that, the financial and professional future of the players remains uncertain as the euphoria from Saturday's victory wears off like a Champagne hangover.

title: Glory in Pasadena
description: With a well-calculated guess, American goalkeeper Briana Scurry lunged left, blocking a penalty kick from China's Liu Ying. Moments later, Brandi Chastain's left-footed penalty kick curved past Chinese goalie Gao Hong, into the high right corner of the goal. Scurry's save and Chastain's goal on Saturday gave the American women's soccer team the edge in a thrilling if arbitrary ending to a scoreless game, as well as their second World Cup championship in this decade. The effervescent Chastain fell to her knees, fists clenched in victory, and the sellout crowd of 90,185 fans in Pasadena's Rose Bowl stood as one to cheer this remarkable team and the lift they have given to women athletes everywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, SOPHIE
description: GREENBLATT-Sophie. Beloved mother of Peter and the late Kenneth. Loving grandmother of Bryan, Ian, Michael, and Theo. Dear great-grandmother of four. Services today at 12:45 PM at ''Parkside Chapel,'' Queens Blvd. and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JAMES ADGER SMYTH
description: JOHNSON-James Adger Smyth. 91, of Blacksburg, died Thursday, July 8, 1999, at his home, High Knob in Blacksburg, VA. Mr. Johnson, known as Adger, was a former longtime resident of Englewood, New Jersey. Mr. Johnson was born in Charleston, South Carolina, in the Edwards-Simmons House, the home of his grandfather, James Adger Smyth, then Mayor of the city. Mr. Johnson had retired as Vice Chairman and a Director of Union Carbide Corporation. A graduate of Virginia Tech, he began his career with the National Carbide Division of Union Carbide in Cleveland, Ohio. He served as General Manager of the Eveready Battery Company in Shanghai, China, during the 1930's. Following his return to the United States he held a variety of senior management positions with Union Carbide prior to be being appointed Vice Chairman in 1967. Mr. Johnson, a former Member of the Board of Visitors of Virginia Tech, was predeceased by his wife of over 54 years, Elizabeth Jenkins Johnson and his second wife of nine years, Dorothy Gentry Johnson. Mr. Johnson is survived by his children, Robert Neal Johnson of New Canaan, Connecticut, Michael Smyth Johnson of Tenafly, New Jersey, and Mrs. Kathie Foote of Ovando, Montana, as well as eight grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Contributions in his memory can be made to the American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 446, Christiansburg, VA 24073 or the New River Valley Hospice, 111 West Main Street, Christiansburg, VA 24073. For information, McCoy Funeral Home, Blacksburg.

title: Compressed Data; Wrestling Games Trounce All Comers on Video
description: Can the professional wrestler Stone Cold Steve Austin trounce those intergalactic ''Star Wars'' heroes wielding light sabers? Yes -- at least in the world of video games.

title: No Nostalgia, But an Echo Of Old Drums
description: Of the hundreds of musicians who will perform at Woodstock '99, only one is a veteran of Woodstock '69.

title: Life After Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Alaska Torn Over Rights to Live Off the Land
description: In the clearings along the broad Kuskokwim River where the Yup'ik Eskimos set up what they call their ''fish camps,'' this is a busy time. Families are racing to catch, cut and cure the fish that will last them a year, and salmon turn scarlet as they hang by the hundreds to dry in the early summer sun.

title: Patents; Magnets and coils in the keyboard may help cut recharging time for computer batteries.
description: LIGHTWEIGHT, long-lasting batteries may be the Holy Grail of the portable computer industry. Anyone who used a first-generation laptop in the early days of personal computing will remember toting a three-pound battery that lasted only a few hours. Since then, batteries for laptop and hand-held computers, notebooks and personal digital assistants have slimmed down considerably and gained longevity. But even the best lithium ion batteries are drained eventually.

title: The Heat Is On!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 7 Are Found Shot to Death in Atlanta House
description: Seven people were found shot the death inside a house in southwestern Atlanta this afternoon after an apparent domestic dispute, the police said. Two of the dead were children, and one appeared to be the gunman, who the police said might have killed himself.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Plans to Press For More Diverse TV Shows
description: Pointing out that not a single prime-time show among 26 to be introduced on the major broadcast networks this fall has an ethnic minority character in a leading role, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday announced the start of a campaign to pressure both networks and advertisers.

title: Carlos D. Ramirez, 52, Publisher of El Diario
description: Carlos D. Ramirez, the publisher of the oldest and one of the largest Spanish-language newspapers in the United States, El Diario/La Prensa, died on Sunday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 52 and lived on City Island in the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a joint venture to create a global English-language instruction business using ''Sesame Street'' characters misstated one executive's estimate of the potential market. Mako Obara, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Berlitz International, predicted a potential $4 billion global market for all children's language instruction ventures, not just for the new one, a project of his company with Children's Television Workshop.

title: Pataki Keeps Neutral Stand On Candidate For Senate
description: At a time when national Republicans are increasingly nervous about the party's failure to unite behind an opponent to run against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the United States Senate race from New York next year, Gov. George E. Pataki is still refusing to go along with his party's leaders and support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over other potential candidates.

title: Recall to Cost Coke Bottler $103 Million
description: Coca-Cola's bottler said yesterday that it would take a $103 million charge against second-quarter earnings to cover expenses associated with the recall of soft drinks in Europe last month, about 70 percent more than previously acknowledged.

title: Clues to Sentencing Mystery In the Archer Daniels Case
description: When a Federal district judge in Chicago handed down prison terms last week for three former executives of the Archer Daniels Midland Company who were convicted of fixing prices, she added a final twist to a bizarre case: the stiffest sentence went to the informant who first alerted the Government to the crime.

title: Group Picked to Run Queens School Was Ousted in Chicago
description: When New York officials selected the first eight charter schools for the state last month, they did so knowing that the school to open in Flushing, Queens, would be run by a Middle Eastern company that recently lost its contract to operate two charter schools in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, LESLIE E.
description: WEINER-Leslie E., 83. Died July 10 at Jewish Home & Hospital in the Bronx. Beloved father of Joseph and Elizabeth, brother of Rosalind Brackman, loving grandfather of Sofia & Gemma, widower of Adeline Weiner. Longtime resident of Roosevelt, New Jersey, playwright, insurance agent. Funeral will be Tuesday, July 13th, Roosevelt Cemetery, 12:00 noon. Contributions in his memory may be made to Roosevelt Arts Project, Roosevelt, NJ, 08555.

title: British Putting More Pressure On the I.R.A. To Disarm
description: With only days left before a make-or-break decision on a new government for Ulster, Britain today proposed rush legislation aimed at obtaining Protestant support by requiring the Irish Republican Army to follow an enforceable disarmament timetable.

title: Picking Apart Manners, Morals and Misbehavior
description: A SHORT HISTORY OF RUDENESS

title: White House Enters Dispute Over Radar
description: The White House has moved in to try to settle a dispute between two Federal agencies over plans to build a radar system that would detect deadly wind shear at Kennedy and La Guardia airports.

title: Primaries Encourage Voter Apathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Company Replaces Publisher at Boston Globe
description: The New York Times Company announced today that one of its key executives had moved to Boston to succeed the publisher of The Boston Globe, a member of the family that had run that paper for 126 years.

title: Sympathetic, but Don't Make Her Angry
description: Frida Kahlo lived a very dramatic 47 years. Her childhood was marred by disease, including polio. In her teens she was in a grotesque bus accident, impaled on a metal bar, which left her in pain for the rest of her life. She married and adored the muralist Diego Rivera, but her attempts to have his child failed and he cheated on her persistently, even with her own sister. She had her own affairs, with men and women, in return. No wonder she was a little self-involved.

title: A History: When the State Uses People as Guinea Pigs
description: Scientific experiments in which human subjects are abused are not new. Examples are as old as arrogance and cruelty.

title: Editorial Observer; Considering the View From Summer's Road
description: The sign of full summer is a child's bicycle -- the kind with a pastel frame, white tires and a white wicker basket on the handlebars -- strapped to the rear end of a minivan. The van, with out-of-state plates, is parked at a pullout at Bryce Canyon National Park in southern Utah. With his free hand, a father is trying to wave his family closer to a wooden sign that marks the altitude. On the sign a raven sits, wise to the ways of tourists. The man's other hand holds a video camera.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP OF OHIO ACQUIRES A BANK IN INDIANA
description: Fifth Third Bancorp, a leading bank in Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Peoples Bank Corporation of Indianapolis for $228 million in stock in its second purchase of an Indiana bank in a month. Fifth Third, based in Cincinnati, agreed to pay 1.09 shares of its stock for each share of Peoples, valuing the Indiana bank at $73 a share. Peoples, which owns the Peoples Bank and Trust Company, has nine offices and $650 million in assets. Peoples' shares gained $21.875, or 45 percent, to $69.875. Fifth Third agreed June 16 to buy CNB Bancshares of Evansville, Ind., for about $2.3 billion in stock.

title: Like Woodstock, Beads Return
description: All manner of beaded jewelry has taken off this summer, from Stella Pace's prayer-bead-inspired elastic bracelets to Indian beadwork chokers to Kazuko's refined necklaces on gold wire.

title: Test Shows Ewing's Tear Is Healed
description: A test of Patrick Ewing's injured left Achilles' tendon showed a complete healing of the partial tear that kept the Knicks center out of the National Basketball Association finals, the team announced yesterday.

title: Tax-and-Spending Talks Begin in Earnest
description: President Clinton and Republican leaders warily met today to discuss a broad array of tax and spending proposals that expose the deep divisions and distrust between the parties.

title: Trapped at the South Pole, Doctor Becomes a Patient
description: People who sign on to work at the Amundsen-Scott research station at the South Pole understand that they will not see home for a long time: from February to October, planes cannot even land.

title: Court Backs Asylum for Woman Who Fled From Genital Cutting
description: A Federal appeals court has issued a decision supporting the asylum petition of a 29-year-old native of Ghana who fled her country, she said, because she was afraid that tribal elders were going to cut her genitals.

title: BANK OFFER RESISTED
description: The French bank, Societe Generale S.A., rejected Banque Nationale de Paris S.A.'s sweetened takeover bid of $19.6 billion in stock and cash and urged investors to support its own plan to merge with Paribas S.A. Societe Generale and Paribas are fending off hostile bids from Banque Nationale de Paris, which on July 1 raised its offer to shareholders of the two banks. Societe Generale's board, trying to show the six-month battle had not affected earnings, also said it estimated first-half profit had doubled from a year earlier, when it earned 4.1 billion francs ($640 million). It gave no figures.

title: EUROPEAN CABLE DEAL
description: Europe's second-largest cable television company, United Pan-Europe Communications N.V., said it would buy Stjaern TV of Sweden from EQT Scandinavia Ltd. for $400 million in cash or equity, widening its European presence and adding 240,000 subscribers. It will also assume $50 million in debt. United Pan-Europe said it would also buy the Hungarian cable operator Ujpest for $10 million, adding 28,000 subscribers.

title: Dow Creeps to New Record; Other Gauges Are Mixed
description: Stocks were narrowly mixed on light volume yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average did edge up to a record. The struggle in the stock market came despite a big day in the bond market, where long-term interest rates fell sharply, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ending at 5.90 percent.

title: Gain for On-Line Industry on Privacy Issue
description: While finding that the on-line industry has a long way to go in protecting the privacy of consumers, the Federal Trade Commission has approved a report it requested recommending that Congress hold off on legislation to regulate how companies collect and use consumer data.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: A-1 INTERNATIONAL FOODS INC., Los Angeles, which has sales of $225 million, was bought by Royal Wessanen N.V., Amstelveen, the Netherlands, a U.S. distributor of specialty foods, for an undisclosed price as Wessanen expands in the Southwest and West Coast.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Helen Forrest, Singer During the Big Band Era, Dies at 82
description: Helen Forrest, the big-band singer whose dreamy hits with the Harry James orchestra distilled the nostalgic spirit of World War II pop, died on Sunday at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRESCH, PATRICIA
description: KRESCH-Patricia. Beloved wife of Albert, loved mother of Elizabeth, and grandmother of Natasha. Passed on away July 2nd. For inquiries: Cobble Hill Chapels, (718-875-1640).

title: Rating the Driving of Smokers Who Quit
description: Over the last few years, there has been much debate over whether people who quit smoking are more likely to get into traffic accidents. Now, scientists writing in the journal Nature say they have found no connection.

title: PATTERNS
description: Shoes Join Spade Bags

title: MITSUBISHI RATINGS CUT
description: The credit-rating agency Moody's Investors Service pushed its long-term ratings on the Mitsubishi Motor Company, Japan's fourth-largest car maker, below investment grade. The agency said Mitsubishi faced significant challenges in reducing its debt and competing in a global market that was rapidly consolidating. Moody's said Mitsubishi did not have the size to be competitive on cost and thus must find a way to build vehicles that consumers will pay a premium for. Moody's has assigned junk bond ratings to three of Japan's five largest auto makers -- Nissan, Mazda and now Mitsubishi -- thus raising their cost of capital as profits fall. Stephanie Strom

title: Goldman Sachs to Acquire Electronic Trading Concern
description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. signaled its support yesterday for new ways of trading securities when it announced that it would buy Hull Group Inc., a leading electronic trading company, for $531 million.

title: Surplus Offers No Hope for Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Revive Marriage To End Poverty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dolphins: Friend or Foe?
description: To the Editor:

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL ACCEPTS $300 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: RHI A.G., an Austrian maker of refractories and other industrial products, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Global Industrial Technologies Inc. for $300 million, topping a bid by the WHX Corporation, which already held a 10 percent stake in Global Industrial. RHI said that it had agreed to pay $13 a share and assume $200 million of debt. Global had rejected WHX's unsolicited bid of $11.50 a share in May. Global, which is based in Dallas, makes refractories and other products for metals producers and had revenue of $496 million last year. RHI, based in Vienna, is the parent company of the North American Refractories Company of Cleveland. It had sales of $1.6 billion last year. The deal was announced after the close of stock trading. Global's shares fell 50 cents, to $12.

title: Chief of Circulation Named by The Times
description: Scott H. Heekin-Canedy, vice president for strategic planning at The New York Times, has been appointed the newspaper's senior vice president for circulation. He succeeds Richard H. Gilman, who was named by the parent Times Company yesterday to be publisher of The Boston Globe. Mr. Heekin-Canedy's appointment was announced by Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager of The Times.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HICKS, H. MASON, M.D.
description: HICKS-H. Mason, M.D. July 13th, 1989. Remembered with love and respect by family, friends, patients and colleagues. Rebecca Hicks, Mason, Alan, Jim

title: From Boondocks to Bigs, On a Slider and a Prayer
description: As he sat in a hotel ballroom filled with American League All-Stars yesterday, Jeff Zimmerman was in a unique position. Not Cal Ripken, not Derek Jeter or Bernie Williams, not Roberto Alomar or Rafael Palmeiro or John Wetteland or Ivan Rodriguez or Pedro Martinez could make the claim Jeff Zimmerman could.

title: Beating the Heat
description: To cope with intense heat and humidity, the New York City Department of Health and the Mayor's office offer the following advice:

title: Final Hours of a Haven; At Fort Dix, Kosovars, and Their Rescuers, Were Transformed
description: Jane Checkan opened her arms to 8-year-old Shqiponje Dushica, whose fingernails were painted purple and red, and whose ears were somehow covered with stars in green ink from a recent bingo game.

title: A Boost To Research On Women's Sexuality
description: A host of pharmaceutical companies are working to do for women what Viagra does for men. To do this effectively, they need far more scientific data on female sexual response than is presently available.

title: INVESTORS PROPOSE $119.3 MILLION BUYOUT OF HAPPY KIDS
description: Happy Kids Inc., a designer of custom children's apparel, received an $11.50-a-share buyout offer yesterday from H.I.G. Capital L.L.C. proposing to take the company private. The transaction, supported by Happy Kids' major shareholders, is valued at about $119.3 million. Happy Kids' shares rose 18.75 cents, to $10.6875. Happy Kids has licenses to make clothing under the Ocean Pacific and B.U.M. Equipment labels and for Nickelodeon's ''Rugrats,'' the World Wrestling Federation and the four major professional sports leagues. Miami-based H.I.G., a private investment firm based in Miami, manages more than $500 million and holds stakes in more than 20 companies.

title: Ingram Micro to Work With CompUSA
description: Ingram Micro Inc., the world's biggest computer distributor, said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement valued at about $10 billion to build and service machines that the retailer CompUSA Inc. sells directly to business customers.

title: Sale of Cup Merchandise Just Didn't Take Off
description: For all the apparent savvy marketing and luck that vaulted the United States women's soccer team into the public consciousness, one area of business failed to ignite: the retail sale of licensed merchandise.

title: Q & A
description: Runaway Scars

title: Revive Marriage To End Poverty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEROWIN, CARL JESSE
description: GEROWIN-Carl Jesse, 83. Survived by his devoted wife, Joan, and daughter, Celeste. Served in the U.S. Army, World War II and was president of Jesse Flower Co. for fifty years.

title: BELLSOUTH AGREES TO SUBLEASE COMMUNICATIONS TOWERS
description: The BellSouth Corporation, the regional telephone company based in Atlanta, said yesterday that it had agreed to sublease all unused space on its 773 communications towers to the Crown Castle International Corporation for $317 million. Crown Castle, a Houston company that specializes in tower management, said it would be responsible for managing, maintaining and leasing the available space on the towers, which are in North Carolina, South Carolina, east Tennessee and parts of Georgia. In return, BellSouth, which will continue to own its communications equipment on the towers, will pay Crown Castle a monthly fee.

title: Call Me Unresponsive
description: Blame me, if you wish, for the poor showing of conservatives in opinion polls. I refuse to respond to telephone polls.

title: Real Wind Breezes In To Bolster Its Image
description: A door flew open with a crash in the midst of a panel discussion on Saturday afternoon in Blake's Barn at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. Fresh, sweet wind gusted in from the green woods and over the audience and panelists, who included the choreographer Trisha Brown, the jazz composer and trumpet player Dave Douglas and the painter Terry Winters. It proved to be one of those defining moments in life and art, for ''Five-Part Weather Invention,'' a new collaborative work by Ms. Brown, Mr. Douglas and Mr. Winters, is just as fresh and sweet and is filled with surprising gaiety.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee fell as forecasts for mild weather in Brazil, the world's biggest grower, eased concern that frost would reduce output next year. In New York, coffee for September delivery fell 4.6 cents, to 92.7 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, MORRIS D., JR.
description: CRAWFORD-Morris D., Jr. Rusty Crawford was the first Chairman of the non-profit 42nd Street Developent Corporation almost twentyfive years ago, and lucky for us he was. If we were able to jump-start the rescue of West 42nd Street it was because Rusty jump-started us. He financed the construction of Theatre Row; he found us the money to buy the then-derelict Crossroads Building; he introduced us to (among others) the Ford Foundation. The truth is, very little progress would have been possible over here without him. He is missed already. The Board of Directors 42nd Steet Development Corp/ The 42nd Street Fund

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWERS, MARCIA (PERGAMENT)
description: POWERS-Marcia (Pergament). Devoted mother of Garry and Mel; loving mother-in-law of Michael and Mary; cherished grandmother of Alicia and Paul, Holly, Lauren, Melissa and Dr. Michael Levine and great grandmother of Benjamin. Still sadly missed and remembered with great love and affection.

title: U.S. Says It Has Fingerprints Of Embassy Bombing Suspects
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that the fingerprints of two Egyptian associates of Osama bin Laden had been found on statements that took responsibility for bomb attacks against two American embassies in Africa last August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARMER, JAMES
description: FARMER-James. Democratic Socialists of America is grieved by the loss of our Honorary Vice Chair, James Farmer, on July 9, 1999. We promise to keep his passion alive as we recommit ourselves to his struggle. A memorial service is planned for the fall.

title: A Record Victory
description: Unusually brisk winds in the Transpacific Yacht Race this year enabled the favorite, Pyewacket, a 73-foot sloop owned by Roy E. Disney, to shave three hours off the 2-year-old competition record.

title: INSURANCE RULING COULD RAISE COSTS
description: Many New Yorkers, already facing increases in health premiums of more than 10 percent, could face even greater increases after a ruling by state insurance regulators.

title: Timeout in New York
description: The three-day break for the All-Star Game came at a good time for the Mets and the Yankees, Mike Piazza suggested today. The teams, he said, needed a break to recuperate from their intense three-game series at Shea Stadium over the weekend.

title: Second Agency Downgrades Nassau County Bonds Rating
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., July 12 -- A second major bond-rating agency today downgraded Nassau County's credit to near-junk status, prompting the county's budget director to accuse Democrats in Albany of blocking a bailout of Nassau ''for partisan political reasons.''

title: Pipe Repair Replenishes Water Supply In New Jersey
description: A major water main that began leaking on Sunday was repaired today, ending the third water emergency in a decade for about 750,000 residents of Bergen and Hudson Counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIETSCH, HEDWIG
description: HIETSCH-Hedwig. On July 12, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Carl. Loving mother of Werner. Dear niece of Johanna Mueller. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday at Ozanam Hall at 11AM. Funeral from Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, Inc., 36-46 Bell Boulevard, Bayside, NY. Visiting Tuesday 25PM and 7-9PM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Asia's recovery from its financial crisis omitted a given name and title in some copies for a Philippine businessman who commented on a proposal to have the Government restrict competition. He was Emmanuel Gonzalez, president of the Hotel, Resort and Restaurant Association of Cebu, a resort island.

title: Arrest of Elliott at a Bar May Hurt Jets' Chances
description: If Jumbo Elliott's arrest on misdemeanor charges stemming from a barroom brawl results in a suspension by the National Football League, the Jets' chances of continuing their remarkable surge could be in jeopardy.

title: Metro Business; Trump Posts Smaller Loss
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc., the biggest casino operator in Atlantic City, N.J., said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed from a year earlier on cost controls and marketing efforts.

title: In Africa, a Deadly Silence About AIDS Is Lifting
description: Earlier this year, AIDS became the leading killer in Africa, just 18 years after the infection was first recognized. But if political and religious leaders had responded with effective public health programs much earlier, they might have prevented hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of deaths.

title: Are Doctors Losing Touch With Hands-On Medicine?
description: In the beginning -- before, that is, the chest X-ray, the CAT scan, the transesophageal echocardiogram, the prostate-specific antigen, the thallium stress test and the gadolinium-enhanced M.R.I. -- was the physical examination. For most of the last two centuries it was medicine's most elegant diagnostic tool, the best way for a doctor to probe what was going on in a patient's interior.

title: Approval for Kansas City Southern's Spinoff
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said today it had received Internal Revenue Service approval to proceed with a spinoff of its financial services companies.

title: Left and Right, Joined?
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Aural Celebration Of Departed Friend

title: Barak's Palestinian Question
description: The American peace negotiators who exulted in Benjamin Netanyahu's defeat in elections in May now understand that Ehud Barak, Israel's new Prime Minister, may not be notably easier to deal with.

title: Grand Cherokee Production Slowed by DaimlerChrysler
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. is slowing production of the Jeep Grand Cherokee, a sign that sales of sport utility vehicles may be growing a little less quickly.

title: Earl Foell, 69, Senior Editor And Writer at The Monitor
description: Earl W. Foell, a longtime senior editor of The Christian Science Monitor with a romantic attachment to precision and clarity, died on Saturday at the M.I.T. Medical Department Inpatient Unit in Cambridge, Mass. He was 69 and lived in Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEILZER, DOROTHY (NEE KNIGHT)
description: FEILZER-Dorothy (nee Knight). Of East Meadow. Peacefully at home on July 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Ellen O'Reilly, Christine Catharine and Paul Feilzer. Loving grandmother of Mary Ellen, Edward, Patrick, John and Maureen O'Reilly, Sharon, Douglas & Suzie Catharine. Also survived by her four loving great grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 445 East Meadow Avenue, East Meadow, Wednesday from 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Funeral Thursday. Requiem at Christ the King Episcopal Church, on Thursday at 10:00 A.M. Interment, Greenfield Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Christ the King Episcopal Church Memorial Garden would be appreciated.

title: TV Ads by Congressional Wives Are a Sweet Deal for All Involved
description: The commercials begin like ordinary 30-second public service announcements.

title: William Riva, Scenic Designer, 79
description: William Riva, a scenic designer who worked in theater and television, died on July 3 in Bern. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALTROW, ARNOLD
description: PALTROW-Arnold ''Buster.'' Dearest friend to Dorothy since 1926 and to Alvin and Dorothy Schwartz since 1940. Uncle Buster to Amy and Chuck, Jane & Eddie, Tom and Lonnie, and even their children. Beloved by everyone. We will all miss him terribly. Our love and support to dear Dorothy and to all the Paltrow clan.

title: Metro Business; Oak Tree to Buy 10 Rivals
description: Oak Tree Medical Systems Inc., which operates physical therapy centers, agreed to buy 10 rivals in the New York City area for about $156 million in cash and stock.

title: Lack of Poise Is a Hazard for Olazabal to Beat
description: After a frustrating round at last month's United States Open, Jose Maria Olazabal punched a wall, broke his right hand and was forced to withdraw.

title: TAME GERMAN ECONOMIC REPORTS
description: German companies scaled back production in May and prices in Germany barely rose in June, indicating that the European Central Bank is likely to leave interest rates at record lows. Industrial production, including manufacturing, mining and output from utilities, declined two-tenths of a percent after rising in April, the Finance Ministry reported. Consumer prices rose a tenth of a percent in June and an annual four-tenths of a percent, close to a record low, the Federal Statistics Office said. While growth is likely to pick up in coming months, the production report showed that recovery would be slow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, AUGUST E.
description: RODGERS-August E., 96. Of Hollywood, Florida, died on Sunday, July 11, 1999 at the Miami Heart Institute. He lived the ''American Dream.'' Born in 1903 in Messinis (Nission), Greece, he came to the U.S. at 13 years of age. Though his first jobs were at restaurants, hotels and grocery stores in the Philadelphia area, he also worked for Westinghouse and as a messenger boy for Western Union, later becoming a Teletype Operator in Newark. In 1926 he entered Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, PA to study Electrical Engineering. It was here that he met his future wife Margaret Hull, whom he married in 1933. They celebrated their 66th anniversary this past March. In 1932, Mr. Rodgers joined the Western Union Engineering Department and continued with them until his retirement in 1972, with nearly 50 years of accumulated service. During his many years with Western Union he oversaw the introduction of several new technologies, including a coast to coast Weather-Map System for the U.S. Weather Service, and the WU Satellite Communications Network. In the 1960's he was lead Transmission Engineer, based in Paris and then Stuttgart, supervising a project to provide systems for high security encrypted communications worldwide for the combined U.S. Armed Services. This took him throughout the free world, to most of Europe, the Middle East, and much of Asia. During his retirement in Hollywood, FL, it was his spur of the moment offer to fill in for a teletype operator, who took ill, that lead to a part time job sending news stories for the Racing Form from Hialeah, Calder and Gulf Stream Racetracks, and lasting for twenty years. Besides his wife, he is survived by his daughter Ann R. Frimmet of Norwalk, CT and his son Edward N. Rodgers of Pleasantville, NY; grandchildren Roxanne Freedman and Terrence Frimmet, of Norwalk, CT; Christopher Rodgers of the Bronx, NY; Craig Rodgers of Pleasantville, NY; Curtis Rodgers of Nutley, NJ; Carin Rodgers of Pleasantville, NY; and 2 great-grandchildren. His family will receive friends at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY, Friday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. where a service will be held Friday, 8:30 P.M. Interment Saturday, Fair Ridge Cemetery, Chappaqua, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNYBACKER, JEAN RODNEY KINTNER
description: PENNYBACKER-Jean Rodney Kintner. Died July 9, 1999 after a long and productive life. Active in politics, social causes and environmental change, Jean was a tenacious Democrat. Married to Robert Kintner, President of NBC and White House Counsel, and later to Miles Pennybacker. Jean served as Board Member for The Museum of Modern Art, The U.S. Peace Corp, Channel Thirteen, and Save The Children. She is survived by her three children, Susan Kintner, of Westport, CT, Michael Kintner, of Suffield, CT, and Jeffrey Kintner, of Pfafftown, N.C., and five grandchildren. To celebrate her life, her family invites all who knew her to a prayer service and reception at Christ and Holy Trinity Church, in Westport, CT, on Sunday July 18, 1999, at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to The Jean Pennybacker Memorial Fund, Save The Children, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, CT. 06880.

title: Martinez Refuses to Forget a Snub
description: Boston's Pedro Martinez is excited about starting the All-Star Game at Fenway Park on Tuesday, but the Red Sox pitcher still harbors animosity toward Cleveland Manager Mike Hargrove for failing to start him last season. Hargrove picked David Wells, who was a Yankee then, and Martinez took the choice as a snub.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Argentine Stocks Fall Again, and Other Latin Markets Follow
description: The Argentine stock market had its worst session in seven months today, falling 8.7 percent on fears that the Government deficit was widening and a year-old recession was deepening.

description: Joe Torre, manager of the American League All-Star team, today recalled the first time he started in an All-Star Game.

title: Merrill Lynch President Resigns Post
description: Herbert M. Allison Jr., the president of Merrill Lynch & Company, resigned yesterday after he was told he would not become Merrill's top executive, extending a period of upheaval at America's largest brokerage firm and leaving it without an heir apparent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, BERTRAM L.
description: WEISS-Bertram L. Husband of Jacqueline. Father of Carol Lehrer, Kenneth Weiss and Jacqueline Dreyfus, stepfather of Valerie Padron. Grandfather of five. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 1:30 P.M., Wednesday.

description: HILTON-Edward J. On July 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Ceil (nee Satkowski). Loving father of Thomas. Son of Anna McConnell. NYPD Class of 1940, U.S. Army Normandy and France 1944, retired from Treasury Department. Visiting 9:00-11:00 A.M., at the E.C. Waldeck Home for Funerals, Thursday, July 15. Interment following at Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City, New Jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Disney to Merge Internet Holdings With Infoseek
description: Eager to assume more direct control over the future of its assets on the Internet, the Walt Disney Company announced yesterday that it would create a single company combining its own Internet holdings with the Infoseek Corporation, the search service and portal.

title: Dolphins: Friend or Foe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, EDMOND C.
description: STACK-Edmond C. Of Forest Hills, NY, formerly of Asdee, County Kerry, Ireland, proud American, veteran of Korean War, suddenly on July 11th, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Mary J. Loving father of John J. and Edmond C. Dear father-in-law of Mary Beth and Clare. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Maureen. Reposing Fox Funeral Home. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:15 AM, at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills, followed by burial at Calvary Cemetery.

title: India Holds Fire in Kashmir As Enemy Forces Pull Out
description: India announced today that it had suspended a six-week military campaign against Pakistan-based fighters who had occupied Himalayan peaks in Jammu and Kashmir state. It also said it would not fire on the fighters as long as they complete their withdrawal by Friday.

title: Malaysia Pushes Flagging Plan for Its Own Silicon Valley
description: When 25 senior executives from technology companies around the world gathered here this week to tour Malaysia's Multimedia Super Corridor project, it had all the appearance of a somewhat dutiful pep rally for a technology-friendly Southeast Asian leader.

title: Iran Protests Spread to 18 Cities; Police Crack Down at University
description: The most widespread and sustained protests since Iran's revolution two decades ago spread throughout the country today, while security police and their vigilante supporters moved to crush pro-democracy student demonstrators outside Teheran University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMBERT, JOAN L.
description: KOMBERT-Joan L. Beloved wife of Erwin. Devoted mother of Mindy and Stewart Rosenblatt, Randi & Jeff Grann, Kenneth and Nina, Dr. Daniel and Joanne. Cherished grandmother of Brandon, Alissa, Amy, Stephanie, Andrew, Alison, Annie, Michael, Nathaniel, and Matthew. Dear sister of Gerald and Greta Greenblatt. ''You will remain in our hearts forever.'' Services Wednesday 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Senate Takes Up Patients' Rights Bill
description: For the first time since a health care revolution began moving patients into managed care more than a decade ago, the Senate opened a high-stakes debate today over how to protect their rights and regulate the companies that provide health insurance for most Americans.

title: Surplus Offers No Hope for Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Julich's Dream Is Unfulfilled Again
description: The Tour de France took the day off today, and unhappily for Bobby Julich, he was not here. The Cofidis rider was back in Nice, recovering from the injuries he sustained Sunday in the time trial in Metz that knocked him out of the race.

title: U.S. and Canada Get $125 Million Ruling on Europe Beef Ban
description: A World Trade Organization panel ruled today that the United States and Canada were entitled to nearly $125 million in sanctions from the European Union because of its illegal ban on hormone-treated beef.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLITZER, DOROTHY
description: WOLLITZER-Dorothy. 95, of New York City. Adored wife of the late Herman Wollitzer. Beloved mother of Nancy Kirshberg and Myrna Wollitzer. Loving grandmother to Meryl Kirshberg Chae and Jeffrey Kirshberg. Graveside services, July 13, 1:00 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Tracking Just What The Doctor Ordered; Medicare Changes Would Bolster Prescription Management Services
description: Barrett Toan calls himself a silent partner in the health care system. And if President Clinton has his way, there will be many more like him.

title: New York to Get $28.5 Million in Heat Aid
description: In the wake of last week's lethal heat wave, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will get more than $40 million from the Federal government to help poor residents buy relief from the heat, the White House announced yesterday.

title: METS
description: A jury was picked yesterday and the trial of the Mets minor leaguer Vincente Rosario on charges of having participated in the rape of a 17-year-old woman from Buffalo 15 months ago is expected to begin today in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Blasting Off on a Mission for Cosmic Science
description: The first woman ever to command a space shuttle, Col. Eileen M. Collins of the Air Force, is to take that step soon while hauling into orbit one of the largest and most costly science payloads of all time and then guiding her winged spaceship back to Earth for a tricky night landing.

title: Man Shoots Companion And Kills Himself
description: A 35-year-old man shot and wounded his companion in their Queens apartment yesterday and then turned the gun on himself and committed suicide, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on July 3 tracing the performance of stock markets around the world in the second quarter misidentified Brazil's currency. It is the real, not the peso.

title: Kosovars at Fort Dix Scatter to New Lives
description: By Friday, just 50 from the planeloads of refugees who began arriving in May from Kosovo will remain at Fort Dix, N.J., which turned itself virtually overnight into a reception center for refugees from the overcrowded camps in Macedonia.

title: Monkey See, Monkey Do: Brain's Path From Sight to Action
description: As anyone who has endured a sales meeting knows, to achieve a goal, it is best to have a plan. And what is good for the Avon lady is good for the brain as well, even if the goal is as modest as getting an arm to reach for an object. The brain must get from Point A, where it receives a visual image, to Point B, where it signals arm muscles to act.

title: Treasury Prices Rally as Argentine Markets Drop Sharply
description: Bond prices rallied, driving yields to six-week lows, as plunging Argentine stocks and bonds led a rout in Latin America that raised the allure of Treasuries.

title: A Vitamin Boost for the Tiniest Babies
description: Researchers who studied infants with low birth weights have found that doses of vitamin A can significantly lower their risk of chronic lung disease and other problems.

title: The Long Days of Interpol's New Top Sleuth
description: HERE'S something you don't usually get from your top law-enforcement types, particularly those with their own Web sites:

title: McCall Warns of Property Tax Increases
description: The state Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, today warned that the protracted state budget stalemate could soon play havoc with annual property tax bills and would likely result in unnecessary tax increases in suburbs and small towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist Samuel Sanders, on July 9, 1999 in New York at the age of 62. Mr. Sanders was not only one of the world's most acclaimed collaborative pianists, he was a beloved teacher and an inspired chamber musician. His exquisite artistry and indefatigable spirit left an indelible mark on the lives of all fortunate to know him. To Susan, Sophie, and to his entire family we extend our deepest sympathy. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Sports of The Times; Fenway's All-Star Monster
description: IT'S known as The Green Monster or The Wall, but by any other name, Fenway Park would smell as sweet. To sluggers.

title: Almost Miller Time For a Gay Pitch
description: The Miller Brewing Company, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, has developed what may be the first American television commercial for beer to be aimed at gay consumers.

title: The 'Peony,' Just Like the Phoenix, Lives Anew
description: ''A difficult story to tell,'' Du Liniang says in Scene 48 of ''The Peony Pavilion,'' the classic Chinese opera that is the centerpiece of the Lincoln Center Festival this summer, as it was to have been a year ago. And she refers merely to her own adventures as heroine, in which, restored to mundane reality after experiencing glorious first love in a dream, she wastes away to her death only to be resurrected three years later by a return of love from her dream partner, the young scholar Liu Mengmei.

title: TAIWAN PRESIDENT IMPLIES HIS ISLAND IS SOVEREIGN STATE
description: Taiwan has abandoned the political formula that has long helped avert war with China, declaring today that it will no longer adhere to the principle that the Chinese mainland and Taiwan are two parts of the same country. Beijing's response was immediate, and furious.

description: SONNEBORN-Clara Louise. Memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM, July 22, 1999 at Congregation Kol Ami (Schulman Chapel) 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. For directions please call: 212-350-3800.

title: Pakistani Makes Case For a Halt To Fighting
description: Castigated by many as a betrayer of the dream of a liberated Kashmir, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said tonight in a televised speech that -- to the contrary -- he has helped usher the cause onto the world stage and prudently steered away from an all-out war.

title: Accounts
description: * Levitz Furniture Corp., Boca Raton, Fla., to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle creative duties for its account, which had been at Bozell Retail, New York, part of the Bozell Worldwide unit of True North Communications. Billings were estimated at $20 million. TN Media, part of True North, handles media duties.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Quality Is Up, Gate Is Down
description: The novelty that has covered the Women's National Basketball Association like a fresh coat of paint is beginning to chip.

title: School Board Ex-Member Challenges Election
description: A former board member of a Brooklyn school district has sued election officials to force a recount of ballots from the May 18 elections.

title: Gonzalez 'Out of Line'
description: Juan Gonzalez chose not to participate in the All-Star Game if he was not picked as a starter by the fans and the Texas outfielder was criticized by some for not accepting being selected as a reserve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATTON, EDDIE
description: CATTON-Eddie. The officers and leadership of UJA-Federation of New York are profoundly saddened by the untimely loss of Eddie Catton. His generosity and his commitment to world Jewry as a visionary leader of the Sephardic Jewish community will long be remembered. He was a founding Board member and the second President of the Sephardic Community Center, a longtime Chair of UJA-Federation's Syrian Sephardic Campaign, and a former member of the Board of UJA-Federation. We extend our sincere sympathies to his wife, Frieda; his daughter, Rochelle; his daughter and son-in-law, Melanie and Stephen Shalam; his son and daughterin-law, Sammy and Shirley; his brother, Harry; and his mother and father, Rachel and Sam. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P. Alan Mond, Director, Heritage Campaigns

title: Marquee Player From the 'B' List
description: The marquee player the MetroStars have been clamoring to sign to improve their performance on the field and bolster their attendance does not have tremendous marquee value after all. The MetroStars will announce today the signing of Henry Zambrano of Colombia, the last foreigner owed them by Major League Soccer.

title: Whitman's Choice Turns Down Job As Superintendent of State Police
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's attempt to overhaul the New Jersey State Police suffered a setback today when the leading candidate for the superintendent's position told her he is no longer interested in the job.

description: COLY-Robert Raymond. Of New York City and Greenport, LI on July 12, 1999 at the age of 80. Administrative Secretary of Parapsychology Foundation, Inc., NYC. Husband of Eileen (nee Garrett) Coly. Father of Lisette Coly and the late Robert Louis Coly. Fatherin-law of George E. Damalas. Brother of the late Henriette. Grandfather of Robert A. Coly, George R. Damalas and Anastasia E. Damalas. The family will receive friends at the DeFriest Funeral Homes, Inc., Main Road (Route 25), Southold, on Thursday, from 7 until 9 P.M. only. The Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial will be offered Friday 10 A.M. at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church, Greenport, LI. Interment Cutchogue Cemetery. Should friends desire, donations may be made to the North Fork Animal Welfare League, Post Office Box 297, Southold, New York 11971.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, RITA R.
description: SAGER-Rita R. The Sager family mourns the passing of Rita R. Sager, born June 5, 1941. Rita is survived by her beloved husband, Gerald, sister, Ann Goodman, brother, Perry Russ, and nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. She was a dedicated member of The Brotherhood Synagogue who truly exemplified the ideals of compassion, sharing and helping those less fortunate. Interment will take place in Richmond, VA on Thursday, July 15, at noon. A memorial service for friends, family and neighbors will take place on Sunday, July 25, at noon at The Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, NYC 10003. All contributions made in loving memory of Rita should be made to The Brotherhood Synagogue, attention: Phil Rothman.

title: Rangers Near to Signing a Backup Goalie
description: The Rangers, who have already signed three free agents to big contracts over the last two weeks, are close to signing another, goalie Kirk McLean, who would serve as Mike Richter's backup. If all goes smoothly, McLean could be announced as the newest Ranger this week, two people with knowledge of the negotiations said yesterday.

title: The Stopwatch Keeps Ticking In a Squabble Over Egos and Truth; Film Drama Shines a Harsh Light on '60 Minutes' and CBS
description: Four years after one of the low points in the history of CBS News, its decision not to broadcast an exclusive ''60 Minutes'' interview with a tobacco industry whistle-blower, a furious battle of egos and spin is unfolding over a film drama about the episode being prepared for release this fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, RUTH ANN
description: FISHER-Ruth Ann. On July 8, 1999. Wife of Gerald Fisher. Sister of Robert Bjork. Ruth was a member of the New York Junior League, the Canterbury Choral Society, the York Theatre Company and the Columbia University Business School Alumni Association. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Tuesday and Wednesday 6-9PM with a brief service at 7:30PM. Graveside service at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY, Thursday, July 15th, 2PM.

title: Mischief in the Senate
description: The long-delayed nomination of Richard Holbrooke to be chief American representative to the United Nations has hit yet another snag. By now, questions about Mr. Holbrooke's ethics and approach to policy have been thoroughly vetted. The latest problem concerns the judgment of Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and his chamber's dubious practice of letting individual senators freeze a nomination to gain leverage on an unrelated matter.

title: Israel Shows Sign of Curbing Settlement Spending
description: Taking a step to curb building in Jewish settlements, a minister in the new Government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced today that he had suspended financing for construction of new Israeli factories in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: RPM, MAKER OF RUST-OLEUM, AGREES TO BUY DAP PRODUCTS
description: RPM Inc., maker of Rust-Oleum and Varathane paints, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy DAP Products Inc. for $290 million from Wassall P.L.C. of Britain. DAP, based in Baltimore, makes caulking, sealants and adhesives for construction and home improvement. It reported 1998 sales of $227.4 million and operating profit of $24.1 million. The deal includes DAP's Canadian operations, the DAP Canada Corporation. RPM, of Medina, Ohio, said DAP would begin adding to its sales and earnings in the fiscal year ending in May 2001.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CONTINUES TO SLIDE. The euro fell to a record level against the dollar after an unexpected drop in German industrial production pushed the currency lower. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0148, down from $1.0176.

title: Saving the Graduates From Being Eaten
description: When last we saw Buffy and her friends, Angel (Buffy's true love, a good vampire) was on his deathbed, drenched with sweat, after being struck by a poisoned arrow; Willow and Oz (Buffy's good pals) were in bed together for the first time, and the Mayor of Sunnydale was eating spiders in preparation for his transformation into a demon, scheduled for graduation day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELLMAN, VIOLET (IBI)
description: SPELLMAN-Violet (Ibi). Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member, beloved wife of our devoted Gabbai and Trustee Mr. Henry Eric Spellman, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: The Lesson Hidden In the Blackout
description: Cancer and AIDS researchers at Columbia University are trying to figure out what crucial material they may have lost when some of their backup generators didn't work during last week's power blackout.

title: Judge Affirms Raise for Daily News Drivers
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld a labor arbitrator's decision to award retroactive wages to members of the drivers' union at The Daily News, a move that could eventually cost the newspaper tens of millions of dollars.

title: Hometown Hero Takes Starring (and Starting) Role
description: The passionate feelings about whether Nomar Garciaparra would be voted in as the American League's shortstop for the All-Star Game over Derek Jeter filled this parochial city for weeks. After Garciaparra squeaked by Jeter, with a late boost from Internet voters, the dominant question shifted to whether Garciaparra would be healthy enough to play.

title: The organization that specializes in the business of doing good is doing well on the Internet.
description: THE Advertising Council, the nonprofit organization that produces and distributes public-service announcements, has risen in the last four months from 23d to 9th place in rankings of the most visible advertisers on the Internet, according to Nielsen/Net Ratings, an Internet measurement service.

title: Gore Unveils Crime-Fighting Plan, From Right and Left
description: Vice President Al Gore outlined his plan for fighting crime today, essentially delivering two very different speeches in one. On the one hand, he called for gun control measures that go beyond anything President Clinton has proposed, requiring photo licenses for all new handgun owners and banning cheap handguns.

title: A Sleep Sensation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RATNER, EVELYN
description: RATNER-Evelyn. To celebrate your birthday is to recall your strength and love. Le

title: The Pen Is Mighty, but Oh That Sword
description: In ''The Fencing Master,'' a new intellectual thriller by the Spanish novelist Arturo Perez-Reverte, the title character, Don Jaime Astarloa, undertakes his most daunting assignment. A gentleman of the old school, he is approached by a seductive woman who wants him to teach her his masterly fencing secret, a sword thrust that is impossible to parry.

title: A Sleep Sensation
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a visit by Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister to Pakistani nuclear and missile sites referred incorrectly to the missile site. It is a plant near Islamabad that makes Ghauri missiles, named for a 12th-century Muslim hero; Ghauri is not the place name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JOSEPH EZRA
description: COHEN-Joseph Ezra. On July 10, 1999, after a long illness, in Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Jericho, New York. Devoted and beloved husband of Deborah, loving father of Gina and Edward, father-in-law of Martin and Judith, grandfather of Tracey, Amy, Rachel, and Jocelyn. Services to be held Tuesday, July 13th, at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, at 1:45 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in his memory to UCP of Greater Suffolk, 250 Marcus Blvd, Hauppauge, N.Y. 11788-8845, or UJA-Federation, 6900 Jericho Trnpk, Syosset, New York 11791.

title: D'Amato Trying to Settle Cipriani-Union War
description: Former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, never known for delicate diplomatic skills while in office, is now trying to settle the bitter and protracted war between the restaurant workers union and the Cipriani family over the landmark Rainbow Room and some of the city's most expensive restaurants and catering halls.

title: A Film Seeks Reality Behind Fashion's Careful Makeup
description: When Jill Kopelman was a girl of 9 or 10, she would accompany her father, Arie L. Kopelman, the president of Chanel Inc., on business trips to Paris, and among the fashion players she liked to watch were Elizabeth Saltzman and Andre Leon Talley, both editors at Conde Nast. Little did they know they were helping a young writer sharpen her eye and ear for the nuances of the fashion world.

title: Separating the Insolvable and the Merely Difficult
description: Anyone trying to cast a play or plan a social event has come face-to-face with what scientists call a satisfiability problem. Suppose that a theatrical director feels obligated to cast either his ingenue, Actress Alvarez, or his nephew, Actor Cohen, in a production. But Miss Alvarez won't be in a play with Mr. Cohen (her former lover), and she demands that the cast include her new flame, Actor Davenport. The producer, with her own favors to repay, insists that Actor Branislavsky have a part. But Mr. Branislavsky won't be in any play with Miss Alvarez or Mr. Davenport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTER, MAY
description: RITTER-May. Age 97. In Seattle, Washington, on July 11th, 1999. Formerly of New York. Beloved mother of Lawrence Ritter and Minna Lowenson. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin Lowenson, Jonathan Lowenson, Michael Lowenson and Matthew Ritter. Loving great-grandmother of Alexandra Lowenson.

title: Westchester Jail Officers Are Accused of Faking Injuries for Paid Leave
description: Like all bowlers, James Santerello, a Tuesday night regular at the Westchester Putnam Bowling League in Carmel, has had his good days and his bad. With an average of about 180 this year, he logged a high of 244 for his team on Jan. 12, but tossed in a clunker of 114 the week before.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Niagara-on-the-Lake Journal; Low Pay and Hard Work, Blessed by Immigration
description: Out in the fields, under an easy summer rain, a dozen men in blue slickers stooped over long rows of newly grafted cherry trees, staking each one so it stood straight.

title: China's Bid To Send Astronauts Into Space
description: China is closer to becoming only the third nation in history to launch humans into space, a feat that could come as early as next year, say international space experts.

title: A Sleep Sensation
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Card Scheme Tied to Car Rentals
description: One thing that hundreds of people who fell victim to an elaborate credit card scheme had in common was that they had all rented a car from the Thrifty car rental agency in Warwick, R.I., over the last three years, officials said.

title: BSMG and Euro RSCG Are Expanding
description: Two large agencies in New York are expanding their public relations and marketing arms.

title: Atlantic Coast Set To Buy Fairchild Jets
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings Inc., which operates as the UAL Corporation's United Express, today reached a tentative agreement to buy at least 55 small jetliners valued at $732.5 million from the Fairchild Aerospace Corporation.

title: Sequent Computer Systems To Be Acquired by I.B.M.
description: Sixteen years ago, 18 engineers and executives left the Intel Corporation to create a new company and a new kind of computer that would tie together multiple microprocessors, the brains of personal computers, to achieve power that rivaled conventional minicomputers and mainframes.

title: Guilty in 3 Killings, Man Is Sentenced to Die
