description: Robert Shulman, a former postal worker who was found guilty four months ago of bludgeoning three women and dismembering their bodies, was formally sentenced today to die by lethal injection on Aug. 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMIREZ, CARLOS D.
description: RAMIREZ-Carlos D. We mourn the passing of our friend, the beloved President and Publisher of El Diario-La Prensa. Carlos passed away Sunday after a long and valiant fight with pancreatic cancer. He will be missed by all of us whose lives he touched. He is survived by his parents, Don Carlos and Dona Maria Ramirez; a son, David; a daughter, Christine; a sister, Magdalena Ramirez; his fiancee and companion Pamela Merlo-Balfour; and a granddaughter, Angelica. Latin Communications Group, Inc. Martin D. Payson, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, ESTHER
description: LEVENSON-Esther. Loving wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Conrad and Emily. Caring grandmother to Georgia, Elias, Nolan and Helen, Sister of the late Harry Levine and Aunt of Rhea. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, July 13 at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Brooklyn College Foundation, Inc., designated for the Sam Levenson Memorial Fund, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11210-2889.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about a Japanese island called Oshima, as a reflection of the nation's fishing fleet, showed the location incorrectly. The scene of the article is in southwest Japan, near Nagasaki; another Oshima, shown on the map, is about 50 miles southwest of Tokyo.

title: As Stage and Star, Fenway Is in Spotlight
description: As a television stage, Fenway Park, now age 87, is as recognizable as Ralph Kramden's barren kitchen, the bustling police station in ''Hill Street Blues'' or the coffee bar in ''Friends.'' Tune in, and you know in an instant exactly where you are.

title: Hong Kong's Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN'S WORLD CUP; Riding a Whirlwind, U.S. Cup Team Takes Manhattan
description: Their plane from Anaheim, Calif., landed at Newark International Airport at 4 A.M. yesterday, and they slipped into New York City while it was dozing. By 6 A.M., the United States women's soccer team was leaving its midtown hotel and stepping onto a chartered bus. Most of the players had not had time to sleep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, SYLVIA
description: PAUL-Sylvia. On July 11th, 1999. Beloved mother to William and Marilyn, Linda and Harold, Harriet and Daniel. Grandmother of Jonathan, Mathew, Steven, Allen, Joanna and Robert. Services at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, at 11:45 A.M., Tuesday.

title: CASES; The Man Who Vanished Into His Past
description: Just over a year ago, Terry Dibert got up from his desk in the school district headquarters in Bedford, Pa., and vanished into his past.

title: Amgen Profit Rose 24% in Second Quarter
description: Amgen Inc., the world's largest biotechnology company, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 24 percent, beating estimates. The company also surprised investors by saying it planned to seek approval to market a new arthritis treatment in the United States by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, EMILIO
description: SANCHEZ-Emilio. Cuban born painter residing in New York City. Died of heart failure on a walk in the woods in Warwick, New York, On July 8th. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St. NY, NY 11:30am on Tuesday, July 13th. Interment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Globalization Widens Rich-Poor Gap, U.N. Report Says
description: Globalization is compounding the gap between rich and poor nations and intensifying American dominance of the world's economic and cultural markets, according to the latest human development report published today by the United Nations Development Program.

title: The Politics of Patients' Rights
description: After a year of stalling by the Republicans, the Senate began debate yesterday on how to curb unfair health insurance practices. There is widespread public concern that the shift to managed care has left consumers defenseless when they are improperly denied needed care by their health plans. That is the rationale for Federal action.

title: INSIDE
description: Holding Fire in Kashmir

title: Lost Chances at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: The Quill Holds the Power: Moscow's Media Wars
description: Someone not familiar with the average Russian's bent for intrigue might find it strange that one of Moscow's most influential newspapers was sold last week to an offshore investment fund run by two Iranians from a nearly empty Manhattan office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASPERS, PAUL ERIC
description: CASPERS-Paul Eric. The Officers, Board of Governors and the entire membership of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of their dear friend and devoted General Manager of the last quarter of this century, Eric Caspers. Eric's style, elegance, grace and sensitivity will be forever remembered by all who had the rewarding experience of knowing him. We send our heartfelt condolences to his cherished wife, Alethea, his devoted daughter, Nicole, and adored granddaughter, Caroline. We hope that they will always remember the love and affection that all of Beach Point had for him. Paul N. Gardner President, Beach Point Club

title: Amazon.com Gets Into Two New Businesses
description: Moving to position itself as the Internet's first true department store, Amazon.com plans to introduce two new divisions today, one for consumer electronics and another for toys.

title: Excited a Million Times Over
description: Jay Bell was elected to start at second for the National League All-Stars, but that role will have to take second place to the experience he had Sunday. As part of an Arizona Diamondbacks promotion, a female fan won $1 million because Bell hit a grand slam. ''I wanted to to hit a home run; I tried to hit a home run and fortunately I did,'' said Bell, who had already hit 23 homers this season. ''That was a much bigger highlight than being here, no question about it. I couldn't have asked for a better end to the first half than to have someone win $1 million because I swung a bat.''

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Gun Buyback Program To Become Citywide
description: A gun buyback program in Brooklyn that offered amnesty and $100 in exchange for firearms yielded 659 guns in one month and will soon be expanded to the rest of the city, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Dream Park for Sosa
description: During the work stoppage of 1994, the Red Sox signed Sammy Sosa, Kevin Appier and John Wetteland to free agent contracts. But all three were voided because the signings occurred before baseball instituted its new policies for the 1995 season.

title: When Today's Market Is History
description: ''You've got five min utes fire away,'' the editor said as she cast aside a copy of the newly published memoirs of former President Giuliani.

title: Griffey Outslugs Burnitz in the Derby
description: Despite an awesome first-round power display by Mark McGwire, Ken Griffey Jr. won the All-Star home run contest for the second successive season and third time over all tonight at Fenway Park. After McGwire fell out of the contest in the second round, Griffey defeated Jeromy Burnitz of Milwaukee, three home runs to two in the third and final round.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you have available technology as an alternative, you're going to rust at the bedside. We now have an entire generation or generations of teachers and physicians that may be not very comfortable with that bedside part.''

title: Maggette, Top Pick, Signs 3-Year Deal
description: The Magic signed the first-round draft pick Corey Maggette of Duke to the three-year $3.71 million contract prescribed by the N.B.A.'s collective bargaining agreement.

title: Primaries Encourage Voter Apathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 28 about the Presidential Library planned for Bill Clinton referred incorrectly to the Old State House in Little Rock. It was converted into a museum in 1951 and was not in use as state offices during Mr. Clinton's terms as Governor of Arkansas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONEY, JAC. A.
description: MOONEY-Jac. A. On July 11, 1999. Dearly beloved husband of Helen, devoted father of Dr. Lewis Mooney and Dr. Fredi Munger. Cherished grandfather of Ellen and Jason Mooney, and Benjamin, Jamie and Lucy Munger. Devoted brother of Ray Zwerling, Gussie Kantor and Fay Krupin, and the late Bertha Dinerstein, and Anna Krupin. Dear uncle and friend to many people who knew and loved him. He was former President of Bradley Time Corp., a division of Elgin National Industries. His wonderful sense of humor, warm smile, and compassion will be missed by all who knew him well. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Unity, the joint convention of minority journalists' organizations last week in Seattle, misstated the given name of a former San Diego reporter now at the Ford Foundation. He is Jon Funabiki, not Ron. The article also misstated the year of the group's first joint convention and misidentified a short-lived local section that formerly employed another minority journalist, at The Los Angeles Times. The meeting was in 1994, not 1995. The section was City Times, not City Weekly.

title: Merger Is Planned to Create The Biggest Offshore Driller
description: Schlumberger Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to spin off its offshore drilling unit, Sedco Forex Offshore, and merge it with Trans-ocean Offshore Inc. to create the world's largest offshore oil-drilling company.

title: Investors Flock to Big South African Insurer's Debut
description: A single South African company sold shares to the public for the first time today, and the response was so big that economists predicted that it could add 1 percent to the country's faltering economic growth rate.

title: Doomed Domes of the 'Old' Diamonds
description: Seattle is about to say hello to Safeco Field, a brick-facade palace with cedar-lined dugouts, an exquisite turf of Kentucky bluegrass and ryegrass, and a retractable steel-rail canopy to insure that the game will go on, under the sky or shielded from the rain. At $517 million, the ball park, which opens on Thursday, is the most expensive in Major League Baseball history.

title: THAILAND REOPENS BANK BIDDING
description: Thailand's central bank said it would take over Nakornthon Bank and reopen the bidding for a stake in the institution. The move came after a deal with Standard Chartered Bank of Britain was deferred. Kitti Patpongpibul, deputy governor of the Bank of Thailand, said Standard Chartered could make another offer for Nakornthon, a small, ailing bank. The Bank of Thailand has taken over six other troubled banks since the onset of a financial crisis two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, BRENDA HUGHES
description: MOORE-Brenda Hughes. On July 11, 1999. Age 56. Beloved wife of Bishop Paul Moore, Jr., sister of Lisa Hughes and Stephanie Hughes. Services will be held on Thursday, July 15, 1999 at 4PM at Calvary Episcopal Church, Church Street, Stonington, Conn. Donations may be made to the Humanitarian Project, PO Box 32307, Washington, DC 20007.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDWARD
description: COHEN-Edward. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Alan and Sandy Cohen, Kathi and Joe Fredericks. Cherished grandfather of Staci, Spencer and Rebecca. Services were held on Monday, July 12th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDE, DOROTHY F.
description: LINDE-Dorothy F. On July 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Richard, Edward and mother-in-law of Ruth and Joyce, cherished grandmother of Mark, Douglas, Karen and Peter. Also survived by seven great - grandchildren. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. A reception will be held at the Hotel Drake (Park Avenue and 56th Street) following burial.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTERN, BEATRICE GROSS
description: OSTERN-Beatrice Gross. On Sunday, July 11, 1999, at her residence in Sewickley Heights, PA. Former Human Resource Consultant for the May Company. Wife of Wilhelm C. Ostern, step-mother of Karen Ostern of Berlin, Germany; Ellen Ostern of Portland, OR and Wilhelm L. Ostern of Seattle, WA. Also survived by her step-mother Ralphine Gross of New York City; two grandchildren, Nora and Sophia Pauschinger; an aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Gelenter of Silver Spring, MD; also her devoted dog, ''Biscuit.'' There will be no visitation. A private interment will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions are suggested in her name to the Pittsburgh AIDS Task Force, C/O Joseph Costa, 905 West Street, 4th floor, Pittsburgh, PA 15221-2833. For more information contact the Richard D. Cole Funeral Home, 328 Beaver Street, Sewickley, PA. 15143, Phone 412-741-4334.

title: Lessons From the Blackout
description: Last week's blackout in northern Manhattan and power shortages in New Jersey provided timely reminders that the New York metropolitan region's power supply is not inexhaustible. On the contrary, a robust economy, combined with the increasingly widespread use of computers, fax machines and other high-tech devices, has created an appetite for electricity that could someday exceed the region's capacity to generate it. One answer is to build more power plants and transmission capacity. But that should be only one element in a broader strategy that seeks as well to conserve energy and exploit newer, more efficient technologies.

title: Ford May Receive Incentives To Build Auto Plant in Brazil
description: The Ford Motor Company may receive an incentives package from the Government of more than $700 million to build a car factory in Brazil's impoverished Northeast.

title: When Movies Confront Ethnic Groups' Sensitivities
description: If art truly imitated life or the other way around, the conjunction of Mario Puzo's death, a record-breaking heat spell and the new Spike Lee movie should have caused a combustion this month on the sidewalks of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTZT, WALTER
description: ARTZT-Walter. Tel Aviv University and its American Friends note with deep sorrow the passing of our cherished friend, Walter Artzt. He was a dedicated member of the University's Board of Governors and was admired for his great warmth and creativity. His commitment to scholarship and academic excellence found a home at Tel Aviv University, where he established the Betty and Walter Artzt Chair for History of Poetry and Literature, along with his generous support of many other programs at the University. Our heartfelt condolences to his daughters, their families, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Alan L. Aufzien, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, President Stephen Lecker, Exec. V.P.

title: MICROSOFT TAKES CANADIAN STAKE
description: The Microsoft Corporation agreed to invest $407 million in Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto, which owns Canada's largest cable TV company. Microsoft will develop software for Rogers to allow customers to link their TV sets to the Internet. Rogers had an operating loss last year and has $3.7 billion of debt. The class B shares of Rogers gained 81.25 cents, to $20.875. Timothy Pritchard

title: Unleashing An Effusive And Sensual Salsa Diva
description: With her effusion of love for every living creature, the salsa singer La India could have been starting a mayoral campaign when she performed at a Central Park Summerstage concert on Sunday afternoon. At various points, she gave boisterous praise to the Bronx (her home) and the other four boroughs, to New Jersey, and to Puerto Ricans, Dominicans, Cubans, Italians, Asians, blacks, gays, hip-hoppers and rockers.

title: U.S. Lawsuit Faults Toyota On Pollution Warning Lights
description: The Federal Government sued Toyota today, accusing it of violating the Clean Air Act by selling 2.2 million automobiles on which the ''check engine'' light would not illuminate even when the vehicles were emitting excessive pollution.

title: Panel Withholds Money for New Jets
description: A House panel dealt a potential death blow today to the Air Force's 21st-century flagship, the F-22 fighter jet, voting to withhold the $1.8 billion that had been budgeted to buy the first of the planes.

title: Retirement? Graf Looks to Mahwah Event for Now
description: Steffi Graf would not say it definitely, but the most successful women's tennis player of the 1990's strongly indicated yesterday that she would retire from the tour by year's end. But Graf said she would continue to play a few exhibition tournaments.

title: Primaries Encourage Voter Apathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorism Commission
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, MICHAEL J.
description: FRIEDLANDER-Michael J. With deepest sympathy to Michele, John and Marilyn. Michael was a special person to all of us who knew him. His wise counsel, sense of humor and most of all, his sincere and caring friendship will be missed by us all. We are better people for having known him. Your Friends at Southern Union Company

title: For Younger Muscles, Just Pump Away
description: I am not what anyone would call a typical sedentary middle-aged American. At 58, I still do at least one and usually two or three forms of physical activity every day. My regular year-round activities include fitness walking, singles tennis and lap swimming, as well as ice skating in winter and bike riding the rest of the year.

title: Stretching Machines Gaining a Following
description: At a 5,000-square-foot gym in Rio Grande, N.J., a half dozen members cluster around a large metal frame with various handles, ropes, bars and built-in benches to help its users bend, stretch and twist themselves into an array of positions.

title: One China for All?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, RUTH
description: GOLDEN-Ruth. July 13th, 1999. Dearest wife of Harold. Memorial service Friday, July 16, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAGNER, NORMAN WILLIAM
description: WAGNER-Norman William. Dear Dad, the past 30 years have only made us miss you more. Love, your famil

title: ANADARKO AND PARTNER TO SELL ALGERIAN OILFIELD STAKE
description: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, an oil exploration company, and its joint-venture partner Lasmo P.L.C. agreed to sell their stakes in an oilfield in Algeria to a unit of ENI S.p.A. of Italy for $127 million in cash. Sonatrach, Algeria's state oil company, has the right to match ENI's offer, Anadarko said. The sale also requires approval by Algerian authorities. The ENI unit, AGIP Algeria Exploration, will get Anadarko's 27.5 percent stake and Lasmo's 13.8 percent interest in two exploration blocks in the Berkine Basin of the Sahara Desert. The Houston-based Anadarko said it would use the proceeds to develop its other fields in Algeria.

title: Let Campaign Donors Remain Anonymous
description: To the Editor:

title: BOC, British Supplier of Gases, to Be Bought
description: BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain, the world's second- largest supplier of industrial gases, will be taken over and divided up by Air Liquide S.A. of France and Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of the United States under an $11.2 billion cash deal announced today.

title: Smoking's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Close Encounters of a Gonzo Kind
description: Cut through the attitude, funk and -- beg pardon, Miss Piggy -- sheer hamminess of ''Muppets From Space,'' and inside lie the remains of movies like ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ''Men in Black'' and ''My Favorite Martian.''

title: Clinton Plan to Seek Out Those Eligible for Food Stamps
description: Alarmed at a precipitous drop in the food stamp rolls, President Clinton on Wednesday will announce a major national effort to sign up people who are eligible for such aid.

title: A Controversy Plays On, but Will the Band?
description: The organizers of the Sydney Olympics seem to have devised a new event for the 2000 Summer Games: a U-turn with back flip.

title: Really Nice, and Good Looking Too
description: IT'S nice when a restaurant pleases you. It's even nicer when you please the restaurant. ''Have you ever drunk that before?'' the waitress at the Red Cat asked when a customer ordered a glass of Nicolas Feuillatte Champagne. ''It's really good.'' After scribbling down the dinner order, she could not contain herself. ''Boy, you guys are going to have a great meal,'' she said, eyes wide with envy. For a moment, it seemed as though she might throw off her apron and sit right down.

title: Japanese Regulators Consider Penalties for Credit Suisse
description: Japanese regulators met today to consider possible sanctions against Credit Suisse Group for obstructing a six-month investigation into its financial activities in Japan.

title: 'What Is China?' Taiwan's New Answer Is Puzzling
description: What in the world is Taiwan's President up to?

title: Serbian Town Bombed by NATO Fears Effects of Toxic Chemicals
description: On the edge of town, in a sprawling industrial park that held an oil refinery, a petrochemical plant and a fertilizer factory, lie the twisted pipes, scorched storage tanks, crumbled roofs and jagged detritus left by NATO bombs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, JACQUELINE (NEE DE LORME)
description: O'REILLY-Jacqueline (nee De Lorme) of Yonkers, NY. Died on Monday, July 12, 1999. Executive secretary at Hachette-Filipacchi Publishing Company in NYC. Beloved wife of Donald O'Reilly and devoted mother of James. Survived by her mother Augustine (Coignet) DeLorme of France. Dear sister of Annie Dumont, Michael and Bernard DeLorme. Reposing at the Whalen & Ball Funeral Home, 168 Park Ave, Yonkers, NY. Visiting hours on Wednesday & Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial, Holy Rosary Church, 15 Lamartine Ave, Yonkers, Friday, July 16 at 10AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, IRENE
description: REICH-Irene. The Congregation of the Malverne Jewish Center mourns the passing of Irene Reich, Charter Member and friend. Condolences to her children, Phyllis and Michael, and family. Cecile F. Vinik, President Moshe Berger, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARMER, JAMES
description: FARMER-James. The officers, members & staff of the American Jewish Committee mourn the death of James Farmer, one of our nation's most prominent and influential civil rights leaders. In 1994, AJC honored him with our Public Service Award for his lifetime of dedication as a valiant champion for civil rights & social justice. We have lost a crusader for non-violence and pacifism, a great moral thinker and activist, and a man who identified with the suffering of all peoples in their pursuit of equality & human rights. He maintained a particularly close association with and affection for the Jewish people, working to assure a mutually respectful and mutually beneficial relationship. We send our sincere condolences to his grieving family. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec Director

title: Serb Opposition Leader Now Plans Protests
description: A powerful opposition politician announced today that he would call his supporters into the streets in an effort to topple President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: The Spotlight Shifts to the W.N.B.A. and Its Stars
description: Wide-eyed and giggling, Chamique Holdsclaw and Shannon Johnson rummaged through packages of basketball cards after an autograph session at the N.B.A. Store yesterday, hoping to find their card in the stack. Holdsclaw found hers and looked over at Johnson, who was still opening packages.

title: Correction: Daily News Dispute On Wages Awaits Judge's Ruling
description: Continuing a struggle with one of its most powerful unions, The Daily News plans to ask a Federal judge to vacate a labor arbitrator's award of back wages to its drivers, the newspaper's chief legal officer said yesterday.

title: DOUBLECLICK IN $530 MILLION STOCK SWAP FOR NETGRAVITY
description: Doubleclick Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Netgravity Inc. in a stock swap valued at $530 million. Doubleclick shares rose $2.50, to $96.50. Netgravity fell $2, to $25.50. Doubleclick, which sells advertising space on a network of more than 1,500 Web sites, is offering 0.28 share of its stock for each share of Netgravity. Netgravity, based in San Mateo, Calif., primarily sells and maintains a computer software system that allows Web publishers to manage the advertising shown on their sites. The combined company will be named Doubleclick and will be based in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMBERT, JOAN GREENBLATT
description: KOMBERT-Joan Greenblatt. To our dear cousin Joan, we were all young together and we wish we had the chance to grow old together. We'll miss you. Love, Mona Streit, Beverly Siegler and Iris Chernok

title: MURDER CHARGES FILED BY FLORIDA IN VALUJET CRASH
description: An aviation maintenance company was charged with murder and manslaughter today in the 1996 Valujet crash, and a vice president and two mechanics were criminally charged with carelessly handling deadly materials. Aviation experts say these were the first criminal charges brought in an airline accident in the United States.

title: Intel 2d-Quarter Earnings Fell a Bit Short of Estimates
description: The Intel Corporation reported second- quarter revenues and earnings that fell slightly short of analysts' estimates, a situation the company attributed to a normal seasonal slowdown. Intel said it expected a strong second half.

title: Accounts
description: Flooz.com, New York, which sells gift certificates for Web-based merchants, to Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Times Square Palm

title: U.S. Asking Taiwan to Explain Its Policy After Uproar
description: Startled by the sudden declaration by Taiwan that it no longer stood by the ''one China'' policy that has been the pillar of stability between China and Taiwan, the Clinton Administration said today that it was urgently seeking an explanation from the Taiwan leadership.

title: Aaron S. Lapin, Reddi-wip Creator, Dies at 85
description: Aaron S. Lapin, a St. Louis businessman best known for putting whipped cream in a spray can, a product he named Reddi-wip, died on Saturday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Peace by 2001?
description: Talks between Championship Auto Racing Teams and the Indy Racing League about a possible reunification of the rival open-wheel racing circuits resumed two weeks ago in Indianapolis, where top-level executives from both sides met for the second time in recent months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMER, PHYLLIS SAMPSON, PHD.
description: HEIMER-Phyllis Sampson, PhD. Retired Assistant Professor, Dept. of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania. Wife of Ralph, sister of James Sampson (wife Joyce), stepmother of Paul and Robert, grandmother of Alison, Madeleine, and Rawley. Our families are grateful for her 70 years. Her ebullient personality, elegance, love of life, and courage will be missed by all who knew her. Memorial contributions to Tap Team II, 3500 Lancaster Ave, Philadelphia Pa. 19104 or the Children's Place, 2309 Ponce de Leon Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Pay Off the Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BURNHAM PACIFIC PROPERTIES INC., San Diego, a shopping center real estate investment trust, received an amended bid from the property investor Jay Schottenstein. The offer is now $13.50 a share in cash, up from $13.

title: In the Marching Band and Proud of It
description: When the Pennsbury High School football team finished its final home game of the season last November, no one left the packed stands. The players and cheerleaders stood on the sidelines. They all stayed while the 180 members of the Pennsbury marching band played music by Russian composers like Shostakovich and Rachmaninoff. And when it was over, there was wild applause from everyone, including the football team.

title: Judge Orders a City to Remove Fish Symbol From Official Seal
description: A Federal judge in Missouri has ordered the City of Republic to remove a fish symbol, known as an ichthus, from its seal because the symbol unconstitutionally depicts Christianity as the city's official religion.

title: 2 Candidates Are Leaving Republican Race
description: Seven months before the first votes are cast, two candidates are dropping out of the Republican Presidential race because of the dominance of Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Let Campaign Donors Remain Anonymous
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola Rolls Itself Over; After a Bad Year, Almost Everything Is Coming Up Rosy, and Wireless
description: A year ago, Motorola Inc. was faltering badly. Investors were dumping shares, complaining that the company had lost its way. It had missed a critical beat a few years earlier, betting on analog products when the world began craving all things digital.

title: Troubled College Inches Back; New Leader Pursues Reform, Burnishing Image of Hostos
description: Dolores Fernandez sat in her cluttered office late last month surrounded by flowers -- roses, lilies and a selection of mixed bouquets. ''I feel like I'm in a florist shop,'' she complained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, MORRIS D., JR.
description: CRAWFORD-Morris D., Jr. TIAACREF expresses deep sorrow on the passing of Rusty Crawford, former Chairman and CEO of The Bowery Savings Bank, and a valued member of the TIAA Board of Trustees from 1965 through 1985. Rusty's expertise contributed importantly to the deliberations of the TIAA Board's mortgage investment, nominating and audit committees over these years. We remember Rusty for his devoted service to TIAA-CREF, for his warmth and friendship and for his distinguished civic, business and professinal leadership in the tristate area. TIAA-CREF joins with many others in offering heartfelt condolences to his family.

title: M.T.A. Faulted for Lateness In Getting Clean-Fuel Buses
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has failed to meet its commitment to introduce hundreds of clean-fuel buses that could substantially decrease air pollution in New York City, a group of environmental and other organizations said yesterday.

title: Swiss Step Up Their Scrutiny On Transfers Of Big Money
description: Reports of suspected money laundering have sharply increased since a law that required expanded reporting went into effect last year as part of Switzerland's effort to clean up the image of its international banking, the authorities said today.

title: THE CHEF; The Days of Figs and Honey Are Here, Borne on a Bed of Ice Cream
description: THIS is just one of those great recipes, because it's so easy and so satisfying. Hot figs and cold ice cream with honey -- that's virtually all there is to it. You don't even have to make the ice cream: buy some, let it sit until it's pliable and fold in the honey.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Business Travel; The growth of electronic ticketing among the big airlines could signal the arrival of paperless skies.
description: ELECTRONIC tickets may account for no more than about 10 percent of all airline tickets worldwide, but they are beginning to make enormous strides in the United States. In recent months, USAirways and Northwest Airlines joined the ranks of major carriers whose passengers travel more often on E-tickets than on paper tickets, while at the same time E-ticketing is quickly catching on with many European and Asian airlines.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Republican Psychodrama
description: It's not a vendetta. That is what Gov. George Pataki's people say about Mr. Pataki's refusal to anoint Mayor Rudolph Giuliani as the strongest Republican candidate in New York for the Senate next year. This silence from Mr. Pataki, they insist, has nothing to do with the fact that the Mayor endorsed Mario Cuomo for governor five years ago. Who remembers such trifles? The Governor's neutrality is a way to foster the democratic process, his office proclaims. An open nominating procedure allows a free exchange of Republican ideas and promotes good government.

title: Steaks That Are Worth Their Sizzle
description: ASK chefs what they order when they go out to eat, and an astonishingly high percentage of them will give the same answer: steak. And they apparently are on the same wavelength as the rest of the country's diners. For if there is one dish that eclipses hamburger or mom's apple pie as the national favorite, it is a big, thick, juicy steak.

title: Asking More From Matrimony
description: In 1986, a much-discussed study contended that a woman over 40 had a less than 1 percent chance of getting married -- or, in the words of Newsweek, she was more likely to be ''killed by a terrorist.''

title: Citing Gains, NATO Plans To Cut Back Bosnia Force
description: NATO is planning to cut its military forces in Bosnia by half, an indication of improvements in the security situation there and of the strain on the alliance of undertaking a second Balkan mission, in Kosovo, at the same time.

title: Cruise Line Reports 62 Alleged Sex Assaults Since '93
description: In a rare acknowledgment of criminal allegations aboard the nation's growing cruise fleet, Carnival Cruise Lines reported in court papers filed today that its crew members were accused of sexually assaulting passengers and fellow workers aboard its ships 62 times in the five years that ended last August, a rate of nearly one a month.

title: Metro Business; Bid to Close 14 Stores
description: The discount clothing retailer Loehmann's Inc. said yesterday that it would seek permission from the United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware to close 14 stores.

title: Around The World In 7 Blocks
description: WHETHER seen by the sun-dappled light of day, or at night when street lamps float shadows among the green-black leaves of trees, a seven-block strip of West Fourth Street is a quintessential Greenwich Village set piece. Rose brick town houses line the narrow, perfectly peaceful stretch from Eighth Avenue to Seventh Avenue South.

title: Cruise Line Discloses Sex Assault Reports
description: In the first public disclosure by a cruise line of reported sexual assaults aboard ship, Carnival Cruise Lines revealed in court papers that its crew members were accused of sexually assaulting passengers and fellow workers 62 times in the five years that ended last August, a rate of nearly one a month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, LESTER
description: ROBBINS-Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep and abiding interest in and love for each of us. We miss you. Sheila

title: Thief Says A Rare Bird Needed Love
description: When he was arrested in January and accused of stealing a rare parrot from the Central Park Zoo, John Bryant Davilla stuck his tongue out at reporters as he was led away by the police and boasted, ''I wanted to make stew out of that bird!''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER DROPS. Copper fell as soaring stockpiles signaled that demand was still too weak to absorb higher output from Latin America. In New York, copper for September delivery fell 1.7 cents, to 76.20 cents a pound.

title: AMSOUTH PLANS TO CUT 1,400 JOBS AFTER BANK ACQUISITION
description: AmSouth Bancorp, Alabama's third-largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,400 jobs, or about 10 percent of the combined work force, in its $5.3 billion purchase of the First American Corporation, which was announced last month. AmSouth, based in Birmingham, said it would cut 160 jobs immediately. It plans to close 24 branches as a part of the acquisition. After the branch closings, the combined bank will have 680 branches in nine Southeastern states and the largest automated teller machine network in the region.

title: Top House Republican Predicts Deal on New Limits on Guns
description: After lying idle for nearly a month, gun- control legislation drew renewed attention from House Republicans and Democrats today, with one leading House Republican predicting that House and Senate negotiators would agree on several new restrictions on firearms.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Argentina Rattles a Bit, and Latin Investors Shake
description: Worries about Latin America have spooked investors again. And when worried, they jump for the relative safety of the American bond market.

title: Sony and Time Warner Make Music Deal
description: Joining the growing ranks of media companies with quasi-independent Internet units, Time Warner and Sony said yesterday that they would merge Columbia House, the music club they jointly own, with CDnow, the struggling on-line music store.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERSIN, VICTOR MAYER MOSHE BEN SHOCHNA
description: BERSIN-Victor Mayer Moshe ben Shochna. 5/26/'16-7/14/'74. The 24th of Tamuz. Dad, it has been 25 years. However, everyday your ideals are an inspiration to us all. I did learn, and it was not to late. Your loving son, NeilNachum Usher ben Mayer Moshe

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Intel Profit Increases 49% But Falls Short of Forecasts

title: Dow Falls, Led by Banks, on Fears About Latin Markets
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by big banks, including J. P. Morgan & Company and Citigroup Inc., on concern that volatile Latin American financial markets could hurt profits for companies that do business in the region.

title: U.S. Team Sprinting to Seville
description: Recent world records in the men's 100 meters by an American, and marks in the mile and decathlon by foreign athletes, have refocused attention on the track and field team the United States will send to next month's 1999 world championships in Seville, Spain. It is as strong, deep and versatile as any in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, RITA R.
description: SAGER-Rita R. The Sager family mourns the passing of Rita R. Sager, born June 5, 1941. Rita is survived by her beloved husband, Gerald, sister, Ann Goodman, brother, Perry Russ, and nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. She was a dedicated member of The Brotherhood Synagogue who truly exemplified the ideals of compassion, sharing and helping those less fortunate. Interment will take place in Richmond, VA on Thursday, July 15, at noon. A memorial service for friends, family and neighbors will take place on Sunday, July 25, at noon at The Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, NYC 10003. All contributions made in loving memory of Rita should be made to The Brotherhood Synagogue, attention: Phil Rothman.

title: Women's Team Is Going on Tour
description: The United States women's team, which won the World Cup last Saturday, is bringing its act to indoor arenas. Stan Feig, a sports promoter based in San Francisco, announced yesterday that the women would make a coast-to-coast tour in the fall, with 11 cities definite and 2 or 3 others ready if the players can clear the dates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NGAI, SHIH, HSUN
description: NGAI-Shih-hsun. July 8, 1999, at age 78, Teaneck, NJ. Beloved husband for fifty years of Hsueh-hwa. Proud father of Mae, Janet and John. Loving grandfather of Michael, Evan, Baikal, Stephanie and Julie. Loving father-in-law of David and Lisa. We love, cherish and honor you. Services Friday, July 16, 11AM, Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please donate to ''Shihhsun Ngai Research Fellowship'', c/o Alan Zank Dept. of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University., 630 W. 168 St., NY NY 10032.

title: Local Roads Off Limits To Big Interstate Trucks
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman directed the State Department of Transportation yesterday to ban large trucks traveling through New Jersey from using local roads.

title: Amex Trader Is Given Fine in Settlement
description: An American Stock Exchange member agreed today to pay a $160,000 fine to settle a case stemming from accusations that he authorized a New York Stock Exchange floor broker to trade for the gain of both on the floor of the Big Board.

title: A Useful Device, Extreme Scooping Aside
description: DURING the summer when I was growing up, my mother would cut watermelon into a basket shape and diligently empty its flesh with a melon baller, refilling the basket with perfectly round watermelon and cantaloupe balls.

title: Sports of The Times; Rose Stirs All-Century Controversy
description: NOBODY can vote for Pete Rose for the Baseball Hall of Fame, but if you get an All-Century Team ballot, you can vote for the career hits leader who has been suspended for betting on baseball. You can also vote for Shoeless Joe Jackson, the Black Sox outfielder who acknowledged accepting $5,000 to dump the 1919 World Series.

title: Reform vs. Revolution, Iran's Perpetual Tug-of-War
description: In the course of 24 hours last year, I caught a glimpse of the two worlds now colliding on the streets of Teheran. The first could be found on the hiking trails of the Elburz Mountains in northern Teheran, where young men and women sought refuge from the disapproving gaze of the Islamic morals police. At a teahouse next to the Darakeh River, I met several couples -- ardent supporters of Mohammad Khatami, the country's reform-minded President -- who were fuming that a religious zealot had just berated them for holding hands.

title: An Equipment Malfunction Kills a Construction Worker
description: A 25-year-old construction worker repairing the leaking roof of a Manhattan school building was killed yesterday when a hoist buckled and hurled him nine stories to the ground, officials said.

title: Managing a Jab While 'Listening'
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's ''listening tour'' ran into Albany's budget impasse today when the First Lady expressed seeming incomprehension about the lateness of the state budget, noting that it must cause havoc for local school boards trying to plan their fiscal years.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Albright's Pins, And Needles, Too

title: Rangers Sign McLean and Still Hunt
description: The Rangers added their fourth free agent in two weeks yesterday, signing the veteran goalie Kirk McLean to back up Mike Richter next season.

title: Jeter's Skills And Legend Are Growing
description: Derek Jeter had just finished another television interview at Fenway Park and was being approached by another reporter when he gazed toward the Green Monster and realized that he was the only American League All-Star not leaning against the 37-foot left-field fence. It was time for the team photograph, and Jeter was in jeopardy of being omitted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, BERTRAM L.
description: WEISS-Bertram L. Husband of Jacqueline. Father of Carol Lehrer, Kenneth Weiss and Jacqueline Dreyfus, stepfather of Valerie Padron. Grandfather of five. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 1:30 P.M., Wednesday.

title: House Debate on Tax Cuts Gets Under Way
description: The House Ways and Means Committee took the first step today toward a partisan showdown over how to allocate the projected Federal budget surplus, opening debate on a Republican proposal to send $864 billion back to taxpayers over the next decade.

title: Sherley Anne Williams, 54, Novelist, Poet and Professor
description: Sherley Anne Williams, a daughter of migrant workers who became an award-winning novelist, poet and playwright as well as a professor at the University of California, died on July 6 at a hospital in San Diego. She was 54 and lived in San Diego.

title: INSURANCE AUTO EXPLORING ACQUISITIONS OR PARTNERSHIPS
description: Insurance Auto Auctions Inc. has hired the investment bank Greif & Company to study ''strategic alternatives,'' including acquisitions or partnerships with other companies. Insurance Auto, based in Schaumburg, Ill., which sells salvaged cars for the insurance industry, said Greif would help it explore partnerships, share repurchases and improvements in marketing. A spokeswoman for Insurance Auto said the company was not seeking a buyer. Insurance Auto rejected a $152 million takeover bid from a rival, Copart Inc., in March. The company's stock has since risen 51 percent and is currently worth about $220 million. The shares fell 50 cents, to $19, yesterday. Insurance Auto is 15-percent-owned by the Allstate Corporation and has 51 auction sites in the United States.

title: MP3.com Raises Offering
description: The Internet music company MP3.com Inc. has raised the number of shares in its pending initial public offering to 12.3 million from 9 million. The new total includes 3.3 million shares for sale to Arkaro S.A., a unit of Groupe Arnault. MP3, based in San Diego, also said it intended to offer the shares at $16 to $18, up from the previous $9 to $11. MP3.com operates a Web site that distributes MP3 software, which compresses music into files that can be downloaded from the Internet and stored on personal computers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about protesters in Serbia misspelled the given name of a Serbian politician who may organize rallies against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. The politician is Vuk Draskovic, not Vuc.

title: BID FOR QUEBEC COMPANY
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation has made a proposal to buy Le Groupe Forex Inc., a Quebec-based producer of construction board, for more than the $408 million that the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation agreed to pay in late June. Boise Cascade, which did not specify a price, said it had sent a letter to Forex and a formal bid awaited approval by Forex's board and its controlling shareholders, the Cossette family of Val d'Or, Quebec. The family has a 42 percent interest in Forex through its holding of class A shares, which each have 10 votes. Timothy Pritchard

title: MCI Worldcom In Deal to Build Internet Access
description: MCI Worldcom Inc. made a big move into the consumer market for high-speed Internet access yesterday, announcing a partnership with Earthlink Network Inc. to sell retail services in as many as 25 markets by the end of the year.

title: Two Blue Cross Plans Agree to Affiliate
description: Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, a huge regional health insurer, announced yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to affiliate with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maine.

title: 3 Strikes, Sit Down! Martinez Dazzles N.L.
description: Pedro Martinez, still miffed because he didn't start last year's All-Star Game, dazzled the vaunted National League hitters tonight and made All-Star history doing it. The talented Boston Red Sox pitcher became the first pitcher to strike out the first four batters in an All-Star Game and wound up striking out five of the six batters he faced.

title: Dark Context To Clothe King's Naked Villainy
description: Tina Packer's ''Richard III'' begins in utter darkness, which is of course the condition into which Richard, he of the deformed body and even more gruesomely disfigured soul, plunges all of England. The lights do not rise until well into Richard's famous ''winter of our discontent'' soliloquy, wherein we discover Shakespeare's ''rudely stamped'' usurper suspended at the center of a giant web.

title: U.S. Plans Long-Term Studies on Safety of Genetically Altered Foods
description: Acknowledging the worsening trade tensions with Europe over genetically engineered foods, the Clinton Administration said today for the first time that it would conduct long-term studies on the safety of altered farm products.

title: Paine Webber's Profit Tops Wall St. Expectations
description: Posting another record quarter, Paine Webber Group Inc. reported a 26 percent gain in earnings yesterday, beating analysts' expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, NATHAN
description: DAVIS-Nathan. Husband of Ruth, father of Joyce & Harold, brother of Annette Feinsand. Died July 12, 1999. Private services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, ANN LEE
description: RAFF-Ann Lee. Beloved wife of the late Harry Jacobs and Isadore Raff, devoted mother of the late Marion Schwartz and Sharon Jacobs, loving grandmother of Harrison Schwartz, Richard Schwartz and Stephanie Wilks, great-grandmother of Robin, Julie, Zachary & Jason. Services 10 AM Thursday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: $100 Million Deal In Cable Equipment
description: Terayon Communication Systems Inc., a cable modem maker, said today that it would buy the closely held Imedia Corporation for about $100 million in stock, to expand its product line.

title: MERGER TALKS END
description: The world's top security and fire systems maker, Tyco International Ltd., ended talks to buy Williams P.L.C. after they could not agree on terms. It was the second time in less than a year that Tyco and Williams, the biggest maker of fire extinguishers, ended talks. The earlier discussions ended in November. Tyco was interested in Williams's equipment lines, which also include Yale and Chubb locks.

title: Say, 'Open, Sesame,' and Poof! Ali Baba Is Now a Girl
description: The story of ''Ali Baba and the 40 Thieves'' didn't make much of an impression on me as a child. The idea of a magic password was fun: two secret words (''Open, sesame'') that would make solid mountain rocks move, allowing entrance into a secret cave. But when Ali found all that stolen treasure inside, I lost interest. Maybe children today have a greater appreciation of how a huge cache of jewels and gold coins could change their lives.

title: Southwest Airlines Is Taking Its Low-Fare Service to Hartford
description: Southwest Airlines, the low-fares, no-frills airline that served 86.9 million bags of peanuts to its 52.6 million passengers last year, plans to take both its peanuts and low fares to Connecticut this fall.

title: Stellar Ratings For Final Game
description: The United States' victory in the Women's World Cup final last Saturday generated an 11.4 national Nielsen rating on ABC, exceeding the network's ratings for the finals of the 1994 and 1998 men's World Cups.

title: For a Surging Sorenstam, Win or Forget It
description: Annika Sorenstam is renowned for her tireless hours of practice, but there was a calm about her today as she worked her way around the Wykagyl Country Club course in a practice round for the JAL Big Apple Classic. A weight had been lifted off her shoulders last Sunday when she captured the Michelob Light Classic, ending a drought of nearly 10 months without a victory.

title: Hotel Chains Improved Their Hiring, the N.A.A.C.P. Says
description: The nation's largest hotel chains improved in hiring minority workers and reaching out to minority businesses and consumers last year, according to an annual survey conducted by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: The Best Rieslings? They're From Alsace
description: MORE than a few American winemakers are obsessed with the riesling grape. With good reason: it is arguably the finest white grape variety in the world. In this country, which mostly means California, riesling produces wines that are attractive, friendly, uncomplicated and easy to like. These are good qualities in an Airedale, not necessarily in a white wine.

title: John R. Philip, 72, Environmental Scientist
description: Dr. John Robert Philip, one of Australia's foremost environmental scientists, died on June 26 in Amsterdam while on a professional visit. He was 72 and lived in Campbell, near Canberra.

title: On Patients' Bill, Republicans Defeat Democrats' Provisions
description: In the first tests of strength on managed-care legislation, Republicans in the Senate beat back Democratic amendments today on emotional issues like emergency room access and special medical protections for women. The Republicans also went on to pass measures of their own that in large part dismantled the Democrats' managed-care bill.

title: Save Energy Now, Or Wait Until Dark
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALHEIMER, INGRID L.
description: THALHEIMER-Ingrid L. Beloved sister of Marion and Harry Loeb. Great-aunt of Catherine Rothbard, Richard Loeb and Sandra, David, Michael and Lauren. Services Thursday, 1:30PM, at Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, BRENDA HUGHES
description: MOORE-Brenda Hughes. On July 11, 1999. Age 56. Beloved wife of Bishop Paul Moore, Jr., sister of Lisa Hughes and Stephanie Hughes. Services will be held on Thursday, July 15, 1999 at 4PM at Calvary Episcopal Church, Church Street, Stonington, Conn. Donations may be made to the Humanitarian Project, PO Box 32307, Washington, DC 20007.

title: SUNY Woos Harlem Pastor To Lead Nassau Campus
description: Several top officials at the State University of New York are pressing the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, to become president of SUNY's Old Westbury campus, and he has indicated his strong interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHA, JAMES J.
description: BEHA-James J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of James J. Beha, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: EXCITE@HOME TO ACQUIRE IMALL FOR $425 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Excite@Home said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire iMall Inc. for stock valued at $425 million to expand its electronic commerce capabilities on the Excite Internet portal. Under the agreement, iMall stockholders will receive 0.46 Excite@Home share for each iMall share. Based on Monday's closing price, the deal values iMall's shares at $23.69. Shares of Excite@Home fell $1.5625, to $49.9375, and iMall slipped 31.25 cents, to $22, in Nasdaq trading. IMall, based in Santa Monica, Calif., is an electronic commerce services company. Excite@Home, based in Redwood City, Calif., provides high-speed access to the Internet via cable TV.

title: Flying With the Greatest of Ease in an Esthetic Pleasure Dome
description: Inside an inflated dome set in the greenery of Damrosch Park, esthetics and acrobatics are combined through airborne choreography to provide the generous spectacle that is ''Kayassine.''

title: Wetteland Answers Torre's Call
description: John Wetteland was sweating profusely and smiling brightly as he stood between home plate and first base at Fenway Park tonight. Wetteland had just saved the American League's 4-1 victory over the National League, and the outing made him think of the present and the past.

title: Key Witness Reappears in Case of Chinese Body-Parts Sales
description: With a key witness who had disappeared now offering to testify, Federal prosecutors have reopened their case against two Chinese citizens charged with trafficking in human organs harvested from executed Chinese prisoners, a lawyer involved in the case said yesterday.

title: VIGILANTES ACTIVE
description: In scenes eerily reminiscent of Iran's revolution two decades ago, the police fired tear gas today at thousands of demonstrators and passers-by and shot pistols and submachine guns in the air as street battles raged through huge swaths of the capital.

title: The Coolest Slice of Summer; A terrific variety of melons hits markets and menus, just when they're needed most.
description: MELONS are the aristocrats of summer fruit, their cool elegance and exotic lushness perfuming dishes with the fragrances of a flower garden. The charming palette of summer colors spans the spectrum, from the creamy white flesh of the honeydew to the brassy firecracker red of the watermelon. In sorbets and chilled soups, in cocktails and salads, or simply eaten out of hand, melons are wonderful restoratives for the long, hot summer.

title: Asia's Future, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Coca-Cola Bottler Reports Surprisingly Big Slide in Sales
description: The Coca-Cola Company's major bottler in Central and Eastern Europe reported an unexpectedly steep drop in first-half volume sales yesterday and its stock fell sharply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, ORLAND M.
description: SCOTT-Orland M. A long-time resident of Bronxville, New York, died on Thursday, July 8, at his home in Ocean Ridge, Florida. He was 82. Born in Ash Grove, MO. He graduated from the University of Missouri in 1938, and joined the IBM Corporation. He was an officer in the U.S. Navy during World War II, as an IBM specialist. Returning to IBM in 1946, he later became a Corporate Vice President and retired in that capacity in 1976. An avid golfer, prominent civic leader & an elder of the Reformed Church in Bronxville. He served his community in countless ways. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Lorrayne (Joni), son Roger of San Jose, California, daughter Sherry Ann of Reno, Nevada, as well as five grandchildren, and 4 great-grandchildren. Burial will be private. Memorial service in Delray Beach, FL. in the fall. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the National Parkinson's Foundation, Inc., Miami, FL or Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Brenda Hughes Moore, 56, Wife Of Bishop and Rights Advocate
description: Brenda Hughes Moore, a human-rights advocate and arts consultant and the wife of the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, died Sunday at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was 56 and lived in Greenwich Village and Stonington, Conn.

title: A Worried U.S. Says Little About Iran's Rising Turmoil
description: The Clinton Administration, fearful of the consequences of the Iranian Government crackdown on pro-democracy student demonstrators, is worried that its muted public statements about the protests have been twisted to the benefit of Islamic hard-liners, Administration officials said today.

title: The Attractions of Malta Don't Include Egg Creams
description: THE JUKEBOX QUEEN OF MALTA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. On your birthday the heart, like the mind, has its own memory, and in it are enshrined precious thoughts of you. Love, Harry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATTON, EDDIE
description: CATTON-Eddie. A man of outstanding vision, leadership and integrity-a pillar of the Sephardic community and liaison to the broader Jewish world. The Sephardic Community Center mourns the loss of one of its Founding Fathers and second President whose devotion, dedication, and support provided the strong foundation on which the Center stands. His community involvement included Vice President of the Yeshiva of Flatbush and longtime Chair of UJA-Federation's Syrian Sephardic Campaign. Eddie touched deeply everyone he came in contact with, leaving behind a good name and legacy of generosity throughout the world. The officers, board of directors, staff and membership of the Sephardic Community Center extend our sincere sympathies to his wife, Frieda; his daughter, Rochelle; his daughter and son-in-law, Melanie and Stephen Shalam; his son and daughter-in-law, Sammy and Shirley; his mother and father, Rachel and Sam and his brother and sister-in-law, Harry and Diane. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Rebel Push in Colombia Adds Urgency to Washington Talks
description: With sporadic clashes between government troops and left-wing guerrillas still being reported after last weekend's fierce rebel offensive, Colombia's Defense Minister and armed forces chief were set to arrive in Washington on Wednesday for consultations with American officials.

title: Is a Teaching Career Catching On?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Tells New Jersey 'Compassionate Conservatism' Is Nation's Best Hope
description: Gov. George W. Bush brought his high-rolling Presidential campaign to New Jersey for the first time this evening, telling a roomful of Republican campaign contributors that his brand of ''compassionate conservatism'' is the best hope for continuing the nation's prosperity while strengthening its moral character.

title: U.S. Officials Are Examining Clinical Trials
description: Federal health investigators have begun two separate inquiries to determine whether the rapidly changing system for clinical trials, particularly in industry-sponsored research, properly protects the interests of patients and other potential test subjects, according to Government officials and documents.

title: Asia's Future, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Killer Will Not Turn Against Man Accused of Abusing Him
description: Ignoring a judge's order and his parents' pleas, a 17-year-old murderer refused today to testify against a twice-convicted pedophile charged with sexually assaulting him in 1996.

title: Roast Chicken With Legs
description: WHEN David Liederman closed CHEZ LOUIS in 1991, I was mightily disappointed. Barring a prize-winning lottery ticket, his homage to L'Ami Louis in Paris was as close as I was going to come to that dilapidated temple of roast chicken, which is as notorious for its high prices as for its liberal applications of goose fat.

title: Why Red Wine and Cheese Have Stopped Going Steady
description: THE rule of red wine with cheese is as revered as the one dictating basic black and pearls. But in a season when chilled white wine seems so appealing, one of those rules demands to be broken, and not just as a sign of surrender to the weather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, EDWARD B.
description: CONNOLLY-Edward B. On July 12, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Blanche. Devoted father of Raymond. Reposing 2-4 and 79PM at McCaddin Funeral Home, 24 7th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Church of St. Saviour, Thursday, 10:15AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Heart Association appreciated.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Women's Soccer Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD STUFF
description: A Few New Looks For the Potato Chip

title: Soy Sauce And Fish: Match Mates
description: COOKING food in soy sauce is a tantalizing idea, but it can be tricky. In large quantities the flavor is overpowering, and in lesser amounts the sauce often burns, giving off a sharp, unappealing aroma. No wonder soy sauce is most often used as a condiment. But it actually makes a fine poaching liquid for fish, as long as you thin it with water to prevent the burning and cut the saltiness (a little sugar helps, too).

title: New York, New York
description: David Cone of the Yankees and Mike Piazza of the Mets relived the subway series, sort of, when they faced each other twice last night. Cone replaced Pedro Martinez to start the third inning and struck out Piazza with a split-finger fastball.

title: Friends of the Flag?
description: To the Editor:

title: How Barak Intends to Deal With Arabs, and Americans
description: As Ehud Barak steps into his new role as Prime Minister, he is working hard to convince the region's players that because he is a different kind of leader with a different outlook than his predecessor, he can be trusted to take a different path to peace.

title: Vanished in the Woods, Where Panic Meets Imagination
description: Like a cabin built entirely out of soda cans, ''The Blair Witch Project'' is a nifty example of how to make something out of nothing. Nothing but imagination, and a game plan so enterprising it should elevate its creators to pinup status at film schools everywhere. Shot in only eight days with no real script, this little movie is a locomotive pulling a Web site, a mythology, a special on the Sci-Fi Channel and assorted tie-ins in its wake. And all of it, including the film's cult status, has been skillfully spun out of thin air.

title: Orchestra Veteran to Lead Ballet Theater
description: Louis G. Spisto has been appointed executive director of American Ballet Theater, effective Sept. 1. Mr. Spisto succeeds Michael M. Kaiser, who resigned in November to become executive director of the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden in London.

title: Three Are Picked By Morningstar.com
description: Morningstar Inc., which provides investment information services, said yesterday that it had awarded its first assignments to handle the account of its recently revamped Morningstar.com World Wide Web site to the Chicago offices of three agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, RUTH ANN
description: FISHER-Ruth Ann. On July 8, 1999. Wife of Gerald Fisher. Sister of Robert Bjork. Ruth was a member of the New York Junior League, the Canterbury Choral Society, the York Theatre Company and the Columbia University Business School Alumni Association. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Tuesday and Wednesday 6-9PM with a brief service at 7:30PM. Graveside service at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY, Thursday, July 15th, 2PM.

title: Fateful Moment in Iran
description: The stifling Islamic dictatorship in Iran has never been a comfortable fit for a complex, youthful nation of nearly 70 million people. Now, thousands of students and other protesters in Teheran and other cities have taken to the streets to challenge the power of the fundamentalist ayatollahs. They have been greeted by violent repression. The clerics who control the security forces are in danger of misreading their nation as badly as the Shah did two decades ago if they think they can prevent change with tear gas, bullets and vigilantes.

title: A Helping of Summer Refreshment
description: The program offered by the Pilobolus Dance Theater on Monday night at the Joyce Theater resembled a glass of lemonade: it was a pleasant yet not very substantial summer refreshment.

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Refurbished Tower Keeps Its Feel
description: Yes, the Noguchi sculptures are still in place on the first floor of the building at 666 Fifth Avenue and they are actually much easier to see because of the renovations, despite the fears of preservationists. The fears were expressed at the beginning of the just-completed $20 million upgrading of the building, between 52d and 53d Streets, which included converting the T-shaped pedestrian arcade and lobby, with their Noguchi sculptures, into a unified enclosed space slathered in marble.

title: Charter Schools Are Approved Again, and Procedures Questioned
description: The trustees of the State University of New York reaffirmed their approval of the state's first three charter schools yesterday. But the approval process came under renewed fire from school officials in Albany and New York City.

title: Palestinians Move to Avoid Friction With Israel at U.N.
description: In an effort to avert friction with Israel's new Government, Palestinian leaders will seek the speedy adjournment of a United Nations meeting that was to have considered possible sanctions against Israel for human rights violations and settlement activity in Gaza and the West Bank.

title: MEXICO DUMPING WARNING
description: Mexico's Energy Minister, Luis Tellez, warned of disruptions in international oil markets and ''a very delicate economic problem'' for Mexico if independent oil producers in the United States win a dumping suit against Mexico, Venezuela, Saudi Arabia and Iraq. Mexico receives about 35 percent of its federal income from petroleum. Mr. Tellez said he would travel to Washington today to meet with lawyers preparing a defense for Mexico, Venezuela and Saudi Arabia. Julia Preston

title: Rose Still on the Outside
description: Though his view has never been in doubt, Commissioner Bud Selig indicated publicly for the first time today that he would not lift Pete Rose's lifetime ban.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMIREZ, CARLOS D.
description: RAMIREZ-Carlos D. We mourn the passing of our friend, the beloved President and Publisher of El Diario-La Prensa. Carlos passed away Sunday after a long and valiant fight with pancreatic cancer. He will be missed by all of us whose lives he touched. He is survived by his parents, Don Carlos and Dona Maria Ramirez; a son, David; a daughter, Christine; a sister, Magdalena Ramirez; his fiancee and companion Pamela Merlo-Balfour; and a granddaughter, Angelica. Latin Communications Group, Inc. Martin D. Payson, Chairman

title: Kosovo Damage Seems Less Than Feared
description: European and American officials said today that Kosovo appeared to be less damaged by war than feared. But they refused to predict the size of the final repair bill or spell out how it would be divided.

title: Arts Abroad: It Isn't So Simple To Be Canadian; Tough Rules Protecting the Culture Make for Confusion and Surprises
description: Lenny Kravitz's rowdy remake of the 70's classic ''American Woman'' had been thoroughly dissected, and the music director of Toronto's CHUM-FM radio station was satisfied that it was, indeed, Canadian.

title: CONCRETE CHOICES: A special report.; Freeways, Their Costs and 2 Cities' Destinies
description: Even a thousand feet above the valley, from the peak where Brigham Young mapped out his Mormon empire in 1847, one of the largest public works projects in the nation dominates the briny expanse of the Great Basin. Two thousand workers are pouring concrete around the clock, turning 6 lanes of Interstate 15 into 12 lanes through Salt Lake City and its loping suburbs.

title: Lawyers in Torture Case To Contest Bias Charges
description: Lawyers for some of the defendants in the kidnapping and torture of a mentally handicapped man in Keansburg say bias charges against their clients should be dismissed because they are also mentally handicapped.

title: Art Vandalism Derails Show in Rome Cemetery
description: Sometimes art does not survive death, at least in the case of some contemporary art in Rome. Four days after it opened, an exhibition titled ''Life Beyond: The Vision of Death in Contemporary Art'' closed today amid recriminations and smashed artworks.

title: Armstrong's Tour de France Tour de Force Rolls On Uphill
description: Lance Armstrong opened the defense of his yellow jersey in the best possible way today as he demolished the field in the Tour de France and won the first stage in the Alps, put even more time between him and his rivals and showed that he is the man to beat -- if anybody can -- in the race.

title: Kilimanjaro in a Can
description: America's first surf-making man-made reef is under construction here in Los Angeles, and even the surfers are worried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRICK, RAYMOND
description: BRICK-Raymond, on July 12, 1999, at age 84, of Teaneck, NJ. Devoted husband of the late Lillian Brick; beloved father of Judy Freedman, Nora Cousens and Harry Brick; dear brother to Doris Chodorow; grandfather to Evan and Seth Freedman; Rafael and Heather Cousens, Aaron and Jamie Brick; great-grandfather to Sarah Freedman. He is loved dearly by many nieces, nephews, cousins, family members and friends with whom he generously shared his appreciation for history, music and art. He had a great sense of humor and compassion. He was a passionate lover of music and was graced with a beautiful tenor voice. He sang with the John Harms Choir with his father, brother, and brother-in-law. He ran HARMOSA, owners of gas stations and distributors of Gulf products in all five Boros of New York, from 1937 to 1960. He worked on his Masters in History from NYU; earned a teaching certificate and taught Social Studies in junior high schools in NYC and Northern NJ. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, corner Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, NJ, on Thursday, July 15, at 11AM. For further information, call 1-800-522-0588. Contributions may be made in his name toward an endowment for a voice student at the Juilliard School of Music, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, New York 10023. He will forever inspire many hearts.

title: Schumer Urges Carter's Aide For U.S. Post
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer recommended yesterday that President Clinton nominate Loretta E. Lynch as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, the top Federal prosecutor for Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: Soccer Champs Savor the Moment They Seized
description: You'll have to forgive the 1999 Women's World Cup soccer champions. They're still pretty new at this celebrity thing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an arbitration involving the drivers' union at The Daily News referred incorrectly to a development in the case on Monday and misstated the newspaper's planned course of action. A corrective article appears today on page B3.

title: Calendar
description: A Helpful Author

title: Would Tax Cuts Prove Too Stimulating?
description: For all the recent talk of cutting taxes, Congress rarely cuts them when the economy is growing robustly, as it is today, and unemployment is low. The worry among economists is that the extra money in people's pockets may make an already strong economy too strong, finally stoking inflation after a long period of relatively stable prices.

title: Guns, Television and Minorities
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which endured a period of organizational turmoil several years ago, seems ready again to address issues of concern not only to minorities but Americans in general. This week Kweisi Mfume, the N.A.A.C.P.'s president, announced two important initiatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, STEPHEN J.
description: McKENNA-Stephen J. Of Levittown, L.I. On July 12, 1999. Past Grand Knight and former District Deputy of Holy Innocents Council, Knights of Columbus, Levittown, L.I. Retired foreman of New York Telephone Company and also retired from Nassau B.O.C.E.S., Naval veteran of the Korean Police Action. Active member of St. Bernard Parish, Levittown, L.I. Beloved husband of the late Irene (nee Sweeney). Loving father of Eileen Shelley, Kevin, Brian and Maureen Lehosky and the late Stephen and Kathleen. Fond brother of Jean Kelly, Claire Reinhart, James and the late Mary Goldhammer, Catherine, Patricia Hafner, John McKenna and Gail Barriere. Adored grandfather of ten cherished grandchildren. Proud uncle to many nieces and nephews. Reposing Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Avenue, (Exit 28N, SS Pkwy), Wantagh, Long Island. Funeral mass on Friday, at 9:45 A.M., St. Bernard R.C. Church, Levittown, Long Island. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. Family will receive friends Wednesday and Thursday 2-5, 7-9:30PM.

title: Yes, Woods Is Peaking, But Course Is Wicked
description: Tiger Woods arrived at Carnoustie by helicopter this morning, and perhaps it was fitting.

title: INSIDE
description: Republican Field Slimmer

title: Rabbi's Lawyer Expects to Face Charges in Death Threat Case
description: The lawyer for a Brooklyn rabbi charged with making death threats against a woman scheduled to testify in a rape case expects to be indicted today, the lawyer's attorney said last night.

title: Peru's International Defiance
description: In the international equivalent of taking your marbles and going home, Peru has announced it will no longer abide by the decisions of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights. Peru long ago accepted the court's jurisdiction, but a recent ruling against the country angered the Government of Alberto Fujimori. The court and its related human rights commission, which are part of the Organization of American States, have become important defenders of rights and the rule of law in a hemisphere where judicial systems are often too politicized or weak to protect their citizens.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Carlos D. Ramirez, publisher of El Diario/La Prensa in the United States, carried an erroneous byline. It was by Nick Ravo.

title: Women Minorities Not Getting to the Top
description: Despite the efforts of companies to diversify their top management, many minority women say there are few cracks in the ''concrete ceiling,'' the social barriers that they say prevent them from reaching the top of corporate America. They are lagging behind both white women and minority men in the kind of jobs they hold and the pay they receive, according to Government statistics.

title: Metro Business; Hudson City Sells Shares
description: Hudson City Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 54.35 million shares at $10 each in an initial public offering, completing its conversion to a stock holding company from a mutual holding company.

title: Bias Unit Investigating Incident in Park Slope
description: Detectives from the Police Department's Bias Unit are investigating an incident in Park Slope, Brooklyn, in which a woman told the police that several men shouted anti-gay epithets at her from the window of their sport utility vehicle yesterday, grabbed her and briefly dragged her down the street, the police said.

title: Notebook; Half-Price for Teachers
description: Hoping to encourage teachers in poor school districts to live where they work, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development is offering them half-price houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, H. ALAN
description: ROBINSON-H. Alan, Doctor. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. H. Alan Robinson, Professor Emeritus of Reading, who passed away on July 11, 1999, after an extended illness. Dr. Robinson, a distinguished memeber of the Hofstra faculty for 25 years, was Chairperson of the Reading Department. From 1991-1992, he served as Interim Dean of Hofstra's School of Education. Dr. Robinson, a leading expert in the field of reading, received his BS, MS and Ed.D from New York University. A member of the Reading Hall of Fame, he was President of the Internationl Reading Association from 1967-1968. A Fellow of the National Conference on Research in English, he served as President from 1971-1972. Dr. Robinson is survived by his wife, Ann; a daughter, Ruth Ann Alfano; and a son, Michael. A memorial service is planned for Monday, July 19, 1999, 11AM at Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York. In tribute to the memory of Professor Robinson, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN RISES. The yen rose against the dollar after Japan's Economic Planning Agency issued its most optimistic assessment of the economy in a year. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.32 yen, down from 122.23.

title: Political Memo; At Very Least, The Mayor Is Listening
