description: Nearly four months have passed since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stood outside Gracie Mansion in an awkward pose with the Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields. However contrived, the photo opportunity marked the end of the Republican Mayor's sustained refusal to meet with Ms. Fields and other elected officials who happened to be both Democratic and black.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. The Jerusalem Foundation mourns the passing of its friend, Samuel Sanders. Sam performed on several occassions and taught Master Classes to benefit the people of Jerusalem. His friendship, warmth, and inspirational musicianship will be missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his brother, Martin and to his entire family. Teddy Kollek, Int'l Chairman Alvin H. Einbender, Nat'l Chrm Sandra Rubin, Exec. Director

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This was not an accident; it was a crime. It was a homicide.''

title: A Dancer's 8-Decade Arc to Top Banana
description: THE tragedies swiped at her like a relentless revolving door. In 1980, her ex-husband, dance partner and soul mate, Gower Champion, died hours before the opening of his last musical, ''42d Street.'' Nine months after that, her husband, Boris Sagal, who directed television movies, was killed on location by a helicopter blade. Six years later almost to the day, her younger son, Blake Champion, 25, died in a car crash.

title: Report Says Profit-Making Health Plans Damage Care
description: Patients enrolled in profit-making health insurance plans are significantly less likely to receive the basics of good medical care -- including childhood immunizations, routine mammograms, pap smears, prenatal care, and lifesaving drugs after a heart attack -- than those in not-for-profit plans, says a new study that concludes that the free market is ''compromising the quality of care.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, ROBERT K.
description: RAISLER-Robert K. Died peacefully on July 12 at his home in New York, surrounded by his children and grandchildren. He was the son of the late Samuel and Belle Raisler of New York City, brother of the late Harold Raisler and for more than 42 years, the adoring husband of the late Dolly Wolfson Raisler (who pre-deceased him by four weeks), the father of Gordon, Steven and Lynn Jacobson and grandfather to Michael, Anthony and Joe Jacobson and Joe's finacee Jordana Matthews. As longtime President and Chairman of Raisler Corporation, a family controlled, New York based Mechanical Contracting firm founded in 1899 by his father Samuel. Robert Raisler was a strong and respected Building Trades Industry advocate, and a member of many industry and professional associations and boards. Following his World War II service in the Pacific theater as a Naval Officer and Chief of aircraft maintenance on the aircraft carrier US Boxer, he maintained a life long association with the Navy as a reserve Officer, ultimately holding the rank of Lt. Commander, Ret. Widely regarded as a true ''gentleman'', Robert Raisler was President of the University of Pennsylvania's Class of 1926, former President of the Congregation Shaaray Tefila in New York City and a philanthropist well known to many charitable and educational institutions. Services will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79 Street (at 2nd Avenue) on Thursday, July 15, 1999 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, the family request that donations be made to the Raisler Fund at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Engineering. The Engineering School's alumni office may be contacted at (215) 898-6564.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREECH, HARRY
description: KREECH-Harry. Beloved father of Wilma, adored brother-in-law of Leni and Florence, dear uncle of Diane and Paula. Services today, 10:45 AM, at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', 2576 Flatbush Avenue, corner Avenue V, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EMDEN, DENA
description: EMDEN-Dena. In cherished memory of a beloved mother and grandmother. Passed away July 14, 1988. Forever in our hearts. Howard, Jeffrey, James, Robert

title: Serb on 'Wanted' Lists Suggests Asylum in Belgium but Is Rebuffed
description: The Serbian paramilitary leader Arkan has made inquiries about whether he would be safe from arrest if he moved to Belgium, a spokesman for the chief Belgian prosecutor said today.

title: Catch 22 of Sorts
description: Nomar Garciaparra was criticized by some reporters for playing in the All-Star Game, even though he did not play in Boston's last nine games because of a strained left groin.

title: Police Baffled by Disappearance Of Pregnant Long Island Woman
description: The Nassau County police and the family of a missing Long Island woman who is nearly five months pregnant say they are baffled by the woman's sudden and unexplained disappearance over the weekend.

title: Clinton Urges G.O.P. to Shrink Tax Cuts
description: Before a round of golf and a million-dollar fund-raising dinner, President Clinton appealed today to Republican leaders in Washington to scale back their tax-cut plan to allow the Government to shore up Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, ADELE (FRIEDLAND)
description: SCHLESINGER - Adele (Friedland). Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Mother of James and Lisa, and Bret and Susan. Grandmother of Shari and Ted Baran, Nancy and David Weiss, Debra and Gary Weil, Giles & Mabu Eyre, Michael and Betsy Eyre, Christopher Eyre, Julian Eyre. Great grandmother of Rachel, Jeremy, and Daniel Baran, Adam, Sara, Amanda, and Jacob Weiss, Lavey, Aaron, and Tsvi Weil, Markoto, Akira, Thomas and Katherine Eyre. Sister-in-law of Muriel Gluck & Alvin Schlesinger. Beloved aunt and great aunt. A warm and caring person, matriarch to her entire family. Funeral on Wednesday, July 14, at 1 PM, at Plaza Funeral Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: 'Beauty' Moving From Palace To the Fontanne
description: After more than five years on Broadway, ''Beauty and the Beast'' is scaling down and changing theaters this fall, making room for another Walt Disney musical, the Elton John and Tim Rice version of ''Aida,'' opening at the Palace Theater at West 47th Street in spring 2000.

title: Manhunt Ends With Surrender In Serial Deaths
description: A Mexican fugitive suspected of killing eight people in three states, avoiding capture by hopping freight trains, surrendered peacefully today in El Paso, after members of his family negotiated his arrest.

title: Whirlpool Posts Earnings Rise
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, the largest United States maker of appliances, said today that its second-quarter profit rose a more-than-expected 23 percent on higher sales in North America.

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend on July 2 about a performance by Eric Clapton and Bob Dylan at Madison Square Garden misidentified the guitars they played. They were Stratocasters, not Rickenbackers.

title: Clinton Seeks Disclosure Rules On Changes to Pension Plans
description: The Clinton Administration proposed yesterday that companies that change from an old-fashioned pension plan to a much-disputed new type of plan popular with large employers be required to tell their workers roughly how much retirement money they stand to lose from the switch.

title: Chefs Fined For 'Tips' Under Table
description: The inmates of Sante Prison in Paris probably don't know how close they came to culinary heaven today when 34 chefs, including some of the best in Paris, were convicted of corruption in the kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELISHEVA
description: SCHWARTZ-Elisheva. The Officers, Directors, Staff and Students of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach note with profound sorrow the sudden passing of Mrs. Elisheva Schwartz A''H, beloved wife of our esteemed former SKA Rebbe and Morah D'Asrah of the Young Israel of Oceanside Rabbi Yehuda Yaacov Schwartz. May the Almighty console the bereaved family, as well as the entire community, amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Free Agents Bolster Roster
description: The Giants added five first-year free agents to their training camp roster and claimed linebacker Chike Egbuniwe off waivers yesterday. Egbuniwe spent parts of last season on the team's practice squad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPUTO, JOSEPH D.
description: CAPUTO-Joseph D. On July 8, 1999. Retired Judge, Civil and Family Court, NYC. U.S. Army, 4 years, Special Agent, overseas duty. Formerly Executive Assistant and Counsel to the Speaker of the New York State Assembly Joseph F. Carlino. Beloved husband of Donnie and stepfather of Philippa Lord. Loving son of the late Olympia & Virgil Caputo. Dear brother of Carmel Fierro, Tella Caputo, Teresa Trotta and the late Fred, Virgil, Nicholas and Olympia Ann Dell. Survived by nephews Henry Fierro, Judge Eugene Fierro, Adam Ottavino and niece Lee Ann Cardinale. Funeral was private. Contributions in his name may be made to St. Mary's Church, 440 Grand Street, NYC 10002, Attn: Msgr. Neil Connolly. Memorial Mass will be held in future.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts section yesterday about ''The Insider,'' a film drama based on CBS's refusal to broadcast a ''60 Minutes'' interview with a tobacco company whistle-blower, misstated the year a tobacco executive died. Thomas E. Sandefur Jr. of Brown & Williamson who testified before Congress about tobacco's addictive properties, died in 1996, not 1966.

title: Planter's Mr. Peanut, a dignified pitchman with a link to the past.
description: REMEMBER the commercial for Almond Joy and Mounds candies that declared, ''Sometimes you feel like a nut; sometimes you don't''? Well, an advertising character that feels like a nut all the time -- because he is one -- is helping to increase sales for a venerable brand.

title: Williams and Fenway: They Still Click
description: As soon as Ted Williams emerged along the center field warning track as a passenger in a green golf cart tonight, the fans at Fenway Park rose as one adoring group and saluted perhaps the greatest hitter in baseball history.

title: Standards Are Set for Thwarting Music Pirates
description: With few surprises, the music and electronics industries released the specifications yesterday for technology that will prevent portable digital devices from playing pirated music. Now comes the next hurdle: choosing which technology best translates the new specifications into reality.

title: A Firefighter Is Charged With Murder
description: A New York City firefighter who was accused by the police of driving drunk and plowing into the car of a Staten Island woman in March has been indicted on second-degree murder charges, the District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A review last Wednesday about a Pilobolus Dance Theater program in New York on July 5 referred incompletely to the performance history of ''Selection,'' a work on which the writer and illustrator Maurice Sendak collaborated. This was the New York premiere only; the world premiere took place earlier this summer at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C.

title: Report on Fatal Brooklyn Fire Calls City Actions Inadequate
description: Faulty alterations contributed to a floor collapse that cost two firefighters their lives during a fire in Brooklyn last summer, and city officials failed to adequately heed warnings about structural defects in the building, according to a Fire Department report.

title: Outside Pacers Have More Than Outside Chance
description: Winning a horse race is usually tough enough. Winning from the outside or the next-to-outside post position is tougher, but that is the challenge that faces The Panderosa and Badlands Hanover, the favorites for Saturday night's $1 million Meadowlands Pace in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: SUNSTONE HOTEL AGREES TO A $450 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: Sunstone Hotel Investors, a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a private group that includes some of its management for $450 million, plus the assumption of $450 million in debt. The private group, SHP Acquisitions, includes the company's chief executive, Robert A. Alter, and Westbrook Partners, a large shareholder. SHP agreed to pay $10.35 for each Sunstone share, up from the $9.50 to $10 a share it proposed in April. The shares were up 50 cents each at $9.4375. Sunstone owns 59 hotels in eight states under names including Marriott, Holiday Inn and Hilton.

title: American Airlines Lawsuit Is Dismissed
description: American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, won dismissal today of a passenger's lawsuit that had accused American, the world's No. 2 air carrier, of illegally driving smaller competitors out of business, costing consumers more for tickets.

title: Dow Jones Quarterly Profit Tops Expectations Again
description: Strong gains in advertising and low newsprint prices combined to propel Dow Jones & Company's second-quarter earnings above analysts' expectations. The company reported yesterday that its net income for the quarter reached $57.2 million, or 62 cents a diluted share, a penny above the consensus estimate reported by the First Call Corporation.

title: Save Energy Now, Or Wait Until Dark
description: To the Editor:

title: Ayala to Make August Return
description: Tony Ayala Jr., recently released from a New Jersey prison after serving 16 years on a rape conviction, will return to the ring on Aug. 20 in his hometown of San Antonio against Emanuel Esparaza (19-4). The bout will be televised on pay-per-view and will be distributed by Fox television.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Merrill Posts 23% Increase In Earnings
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm, posted robust second quarter earnings yesterday, even as the financial powerhouse struggles with infighting and tension in its upper ranks.

title: Is a Teaching Career Catching On?
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy Feigned Death to Escape Mass Killing
description: Rousted from bed and herded into a bedroom with six other family members, an 11-year-old boy was dragged from room to room by his mother's live-in boyfriend and, according to his statement to the police, forced to watch as his mother, aunt and four siblings were shot down in this city's worst mass killing of this century.

title: Justifier of Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble Lurking Beyond the Fairway
description: The narrowness of Carnoustie's fairways has drawn numerous complaints from players preparing for this week's British Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAIMO, MARIO
description: RAIMO-Mario. 64. The United Federation of Teachers is saddened by the death of our former legislative and political director July 12. A social studies teacher, Mario led the Evander Childs High School faculty in the 1960 citywide strike to secure union representation. Picketing again in 1967, he met PS 87 teacher Dolores Lanzano, whom he married. He was UFT District 11 representative, Bronx borough representative, VOTE/COPE director, Albany lobbyist and served on the UFT and New York State United Teachers boards. He helped found FIAME, an ItalianAmerican educators group, and served on the Marchi Legislative Commission to restructure New York City public schools. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from CCNY and earned a Columbia doctorate. Survivors include his wife and son Joseph of New Rochelle; daughters Alissa Minio of Rye, and Dina Emirzian of Hartford, CT; mother Filomena of the Bronx; sisters Gloria of Del Ray Beach, FL, and Lucille Gerace of Staten Island. Visiting at Romano Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square, Tuckahoe, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral 10:30 Thursday, Holy Family Church, Mayflower Avenue (off North Avenue), New Rochelle. Donations to American Heart Association, Westchester Putnam Division, P.O. Box 4209, Buffalo, NY 14240-4209 or American Diabetes Association, P.O. Box 97136, Washington, D.C. 20090-7136.

title: Vatican Tells Priest and Nun To End Their Gay Ministry
description: The Vatican yesterday ordered an American priest and a nun in Maryland to end a national ministry to gay men and lesbians, saying that the pair's work since the 1970's had strayed from church teaching that homosexual activity is immoral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKMAN, JOSEPH L.
description: BECKMAN-Joseph L. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Harvey, Janet and Barbara Roth. Loving grandfather of Marc, Amy, Andrew, Debbie, David and Susan. Services on Wednesday, 11:30 AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: A Past Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnamese Cuisine With an Accent on Fresh and Lively
description: TEN years ago, New York had only a couple of Vietnamese restaurants in the Chinatown area and one or two other Manhattan outposts. But in the early 1990's, Vietnamese restaurants began to pop up all over, becoming novel pleasures and then neighborhood staples.

title: Kedung Journal; In Rural Indonesia, Politics Is About Food Prices
description: The farther the road goes, the more beautiful the villages become, and the more desperately poor. Deep in the countryside, with a hint of ocean in the air, green rice fields stand silent except for the swish of a breeze.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARMAN, LAWRENCE
description: KARMAN-Lawrence. Age 77 of NYC and Palm Beach Gardens, FL died on July 13 at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Beloved husband and best friend of Roslyn (Boriss). Devoted father and ''pal'' to Howard (Ann) & Michael (Karen). Loving ''Paka'' to Eric. Dear brother to Myron (Lenore). His love and knowledge of sports led to a career and lifestyle that brought him much happiness and fulfillment. Former owner-director of Camps Wahconah and Potomac in Pittsfield, MA. He touched many lives and hearts over his seven decades in the camping field. He was a health and physical education teacher and coach in the NYC H.S. system for 36 years. Athletic Director of City Athletic Club for 30 years. Professional umpire of U.S. Lawn Tennis Assn. Basketball and baseball official. Past Master of Courland Lodge F&AM of 6th Masonic District. 1950 National Paddle Tennis Doubles Champion. In retirement he coordinated the Senior Men's (55+) Tennis League at PGA National Golf & Tennis Resort. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him for his warmth, gentleness, humor and upbeat personality. Services Thursday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELIZABETH (SHEINA CHAYA)
description: SCHWARTZ - Elizabeth (Sheina Chaya), wife of Rabbi Jay Yaacov Schwartz, mother of Ayala (Sarah Bracha), daughter of Rabbi Wilfred and Miriam Shuchat, sister of Margola, Rabbi Bernard Raphael, and Bryna and Joshuah Landes. Daughter-in-law of Rabbi Albert and Gloria Schwartz, sisterin-law of Shira and Rabbi Shraga Gross, Shulamith and Rabbi Yonotan Zakutinsky, Rabbi Chaim and Devorah Schwartz, Dr. Yoni and Sima Schwartz. Funeral services at Young Israel of Oceanside, 150 Waukena, corner Oceanside Road on Wednesday, July 14 at 12 noon. Shiva at 3200 Perry Avenue, Oceanside, Long Island.

title: Using Your Melon for Math
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATTON, EDDIE
description: CATTON-Eddie. The Yeshivah of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Eddie Catton, member of our Board of Trustees, beloved husband of Frieda, father of Rochelle Catton, Melanie Shalam and Sammy Catton, son of Rae and Sam Catton, and brother of Harry Catton. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Catton family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Paul Kopyt, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Executive Director

title: Political Briefing; The 'Safe' Seat That Apparently Isn't
description: Republican leaders figured Indiana's Second Congressional District was safely in the hands of Representative David M. McIntosh when they began mapping ways to retain their six-seat edge in the House in Election 2000. A solid conservative, Mr. McIntosh easily won election to a third term last year, with 60 percent of the vote, and seemed well positioned to add a fourth.

title: Chung Is Called For All-Star Game
description: Mark Chung, a midfielder who has started every game for the MetroStars this season, has been named to the Eastern Conference team to replace an injured teammate, Tab Ramos, in Saturday's Major League Soccer All-Star Game in San Diego.

title: School Prayer Is Revived As Heated Issue in Alabama
description: Public school prayer is more than an abstract issue of civil liberties in Alabama. For many students it is the stuff of everyday life, a part of football huddles and weekly assemblies, and the question of its legality has driven political campaigns and prompted mass demonstrations.

title: A Renaissance of Hispanic Artistry
description: LIKE summer lightning across the mesas, history seems startlingly close here.

title: State Auditors to Examine Books of Distressed City
description: State officials have begun auditing the books of this financially struggling city as a prelude to providing $7 million to close the city's budget gap and ordering reforms intended to balance future budgets.

title: Khatami's Key Moment
description: As any American who can remember the 1979-80 hostage crisis in Iran knows, students were indispensable to the victory of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's revolutionary ideas. Unfortunately for the clerical regime, today's protesting students have become harbingers of a counterrevolution.

title: Voters in Babylon Reject Effort to Abolish At-Large Elections
description: Town officials here had hoped that voters would make Babylon the first town on Long Island to voluntarily abolish the centuries-old system of at-large elections that critics say make it virtually impossible for blacks to win elective office.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ANNE
description: JACOBS-Anne. On July 13. Devoted wife of the late Hyman. Loving mother of Dr. Beverly S. Jacobs, Spanish teacher at Franklin D. Roosevelt High School. Services Friday, 11:30AM, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn (corner Ave. M).

title: The Volatile Issue of Taiwan
description: By most measures of civic development, Taiwan has evolved in recent years into a far more appealing model than mainland China. Taiwan's politics is now fully democratic, its economy market-based and thriving and its press free and spirited. But relations between Taiwan and the mainland remain as tense and explosive as ever, and each side takes every opportunity to provoke the other. The latest dispute was set off when Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, abruptly announced a new definition of Taiwan's status, needlessly angering Beijing and complicating relations between the United States and China.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee prices rose as forecasts for cold in Brazil, the world's biggest grower, heightened concern that frost could cut output. In New York, coffee for September delivery rose 2.2 cents, to 95.90 cents a pound.

title: Apple Reports Strong Third-Quarter Sales
description: Buoyed by impressive sales of its iMac consumer machine, Apple Computer said today that it had earned $114 million in its fiscal third quarter.

title: KOREAN CEMENT DEAL
description: The world's second-largest cement maker, Lafarge S.A. of France, will buy the cement business of South Korea's insolvent Halla Group for at least $345 million. Lafarge reached an agreement with RH Cement, formerly known as the Halla Cement Manufacturing Corporation, and could buy the unit by the end of September, said Kim Sung Jin, an RH Cement executive. Blue Circle Industries of Britain, which lost the bidding, agreed to resume talks if the Lafarge bid failed, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MAC
description: WASSERMAN-Mac. Beloved husband of the late Loretta, cherished brother of the late Marion Massey and Molly Lippman, loving uncle of Richard, Howard & Linda Massey and Robert & Carol Lippman. Services Thursday at 1PM from the I.J. Morris, Dix Hills Chapel, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills.

title: In Defense of Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIN, DORIS
description: FLORIN-Doris, of Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of Seymour; devoted mother of Steve, Roberta, Richard and Irene; stepmother of Barry; adored grandmother of Douglas, Matthew, Jennifer, Todd and Jared. Beloved sister of Lola. Services will be held at BoulevardRiverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT P.
description: BLUM-Robert P. Died Monday, July 12, 1999. Bob, an alumnus of Williams College, was a broadcast journalist, editor and producer for the three major television networks and Prodigy. He is survived by his mother, Ray, his children, Jennifer, Lesley and Joey, son-inlaw, Sean Cronin, his former wife, Frances, his companion, Arlene Spiller and his sister, Judy. Memorial service on Tuesday, July 27, 3:30PM, at Campbell's, 81st and Madison Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Guiding Eyes For The Blind, Yorktown Heights, New York.

title: All-Star Game Rating Declines
description: Major League Baseball's All-Star Game on Fox Tuesday night generated a 12.0 rating, down 9 percent from last year's 13.3 on NBC, making it the second-lowest All-Star Game telecast listed by Nielsen Media Research. The 1997 game rated an 11.8.

title: Appeals Court Declines Case Clearing Abortion Protesters
description: A divided Federal appeals court declined yesterday to review a case in which two antiabortion protesters were acquitted of blocking a clinic in Westchester County because their law-breaking was motivated by religious belief.

title: A.A.R.P. Sets Up a Taxable Subsidiary
description: The American Association of Retired Persons named a chief executive yesterday to a new taxable subsidiary. The start of the unit ends a long-running dispute with the Internal Revenue Service and clears the way for the nonprofit organization to enter new business ventures.

title: Ambitious Low-Fare Carrier Names Itself Jetblue Airways
description: It is still awaiting Federal regulatory approval and still needs to find a terminal at Kennedy International Airport, but at least the country's most ambitious new low-fare airline now has a name.

title: House Panel Votes $864 Billion Tax Cut
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved the largest tax cut in nearly two decades tonight, brushing aside a veto threat by President Clinton in pursuit of a cherished Republican goal.

title: Politics Hinted in Valujet-Crash Charges
description: The Miami-Dade County State Attorney says she is pursuing third-degree murder and manslaughter charges against Sabretech, a defunct aircraft maintenance company, because its workers' actions directly resulted in the death of all 110 people aboard Valujet Airlines Flight 592 when it crashed three years ago.

title: Group Seeks Better Signs of Subway Changes
description: New York's subway riders descend onto steamy, crowded platforms and endure what can seem like interminable waits before squeezing into cars that snake underneath the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELISHEVA (LIZ)
description: SCHWARTZ-Elisheva (Liz). We record with sorrow the untimely passing of Board Member Rebbetzin Elisheva (Liz Schwartz). Our deepest sympathies to Rabbi Y. Schwartz and her daughter, Ayala. Mikvah Association of Oceanside

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have such a complex relationship with them: we care for them, and provide them with a home, but we have no idea where they go. They have this whole mysterious life out there in the city.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Making the Big List and Making a Killing, Too
description: For years, the addition of a company to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has created an almost-riskless opportunity for speculators to profit.

title: Voice Xpress Lets You Work While on the Go
description: Let's face it; typing while you drive is not good form. Yet in a world that runs on Internet time, every minute not spent working is 60 seconds wasted.

title: Building a Dream Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: A Flat Tire Leads to Theft of Jewels
description: A jewelry dealer who stopped to get a flat tire fixed in Brooklyn yesterday was robbed of more than $100,000 in jewels by a man who may have caused the flat to set up the heist, the police said.

title: N.B.A. to Atlantic 10: Hill Gets 10-Year Deal to Coach Fordham
description: Teremun Johnson described himself as ''ecstatic.'' Jason Harris said it was ''hard to believe'' and Bevon Robin used derivatives of the word excite about 12 times in two minutes before finally admitting, ''I'm just at a loss for words right now.''

title: PRO BASKETBALL; An Injured Holdsclaw Has to Sit
description: Chamique Holdsclaw, whose shoulders have been chosen to carry the future of women's professional basketball, sat on the bench for most of the second half of last night's inaugural Women's National Basketball Association All-Star Game. She was the victim of the game's only injury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, BLANCHE
description: KAUFMAN-Blanche of Clark, N.J. Beloved wife of Max, devoted mother of Barbara Simon and Alan Kaufman, loving sister of the late Sarah Krakauer, precious grandmother of Eric, Allison, Jeremy and Dylan. Services were held. Additional information, please call ''Kreitzman's'' at 1-888-351-4414.

title: SOFTBANK TO SHED ITS 80% STAKE IN KINGSTON
description: The Softbank Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it would sell its 80 percent stake in Kingston Technology to Kingston's founders in a transaction valued at $450 million. Kingston, a closely held manufacturer of memory products for computers and other electronic devices, is based in Fountain Valley, Calif. Its founders -- John Tu and David Sun -- sold the stake to Softbank in 1996. Softbank said the sale was part of a plan to focus on Internet companies. Separately, Ziff-Davis Inc., the New York-based publisher of computer magazines, said it had hired Morgan Stanley to examine strategic alternatives, including the sale of all or some of its operations. Softbank, Ziff-Davis's largest shareholder, said it endorsed the action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYSER, EVA A.
description: KAYSER-Eva A. On July 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Rudolph Kayser. She will be missed by her many dear friends. Services Thursday 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St, Amsterdam Ave.

title: Family Planning Under Fire
description: Last year Congress disgracefully cut off funding to the United Nations Population Fund, an agency that supports voluntary family planning services, maternal and child health initiatives, and AIDS and sexually transmitted disease prevention programs in 150 countries. In April the House International Relations Committee wisely voted to restore $25 million for the program in 2000. A House vote on the State Department authorization bill containing that contribution is expected today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, BRENDA HUGHES
description: MOORE-Brenda Hughes. The Pilgrims of the United States are saddened by the death of the wife of their Vice President, the Rt. Rev. Paul Moore Jr., and convey their deepest sympathies. Henry Luce III, President Eben W. Pyne, Treasurer Mark Dixon, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYNDER, ERNST L., DR.
description: WYNDER-Ernst L., Dr. July 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Sandra. Devoted brother of Lore Levinson. Loving uncle of Dr. Robert Levinson and Dr. Martin Levinson. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to The American Health Foundation, 320 East 43rd St, NY, NY 10017.

title: PROTECTIONISM WARNING
description: A review of United States trade policy by the World Trade Organization gave the country high marks for opening its markets but warned that any return to protectionism could jeopardize the current economic prosperity. Recent American actions against Brazil over steel and against New Zealand and Australia over lamb imports were cited as worrisome protectionist moves. The 134-nation organization, which makes the rules for global commerce, reviews the trade policies of members every two years. Elizabeth Olson

title: Britain and Argentina to Allow Commercial Falkland Flights
description: The Argentine and British Governments agreed today to reinstate commercial flights between Argentina and the Falkland Islands for the first time since the two countries went to war over the archipelago in 1982.

title: Regulators to Investigate Bid for British Pubs
description: British regulators waded into a takeover brawl for the 3,500 British pubs of Allied Domecq P.l.C. today, ordering an investigation of a bid by Whitbread P.l.c. that had already been endorsed by Allied's board.

title: Is Israel Ready To Make Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Building a Dream Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: $1 Million Short But $10,000 Up
description: Jason Walters and his family won $10,000 last night at Madison Square Garden. But they missed out on a chance to win $990,000 more.

title: Littleton Students Listen to Gun Debate, Wondering if They Have Been Heard
description: Andrew Singleton, a 15-year-old from Denver, listened to the impassioned oratory on both sides of the gun control debate in Congress, but he said today that he seldom got the sense that the orators understood anything about his life.

title: What a Little Moonlight Can Do
description: ACROSS the river from the Taj Mahal in Agra, India, there was once a pleasure garden filled with the fragrance of white night-blooming flowers and blossoming trees. But the Moonlight Garden, as the 25 acres were called, was neglected even in the mid-1600's, after its builder, Shah Jahan, was imprisoned. Soon, its marble fountains, aqueducts, pavilions and watercourses, its flowers and trees, were buried by three feet of silt from the flooding Yamuna River.

title: Virtual Experiments That Go 'Kaboom!'
description: DINOSAUR ADVENTURE 3-D

title: Choreographing Bad Timing for Surprising Effects
description: Elizabeth Streb had the perfect setting for her new ''Punch the Jump,'' performed on Tuesday night at the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center. Ms. Streb's choreographic ambitions and flying dance gymnasts looked right at home under the vaulting dome of the spacious arena, which was packed for the premiere.

title: Ads Enter Skirmish Over Health Care
description: On television screens across the nation's capital this week, the images were almost inescapable. One man complains about more government red tape. A mother worries that soaring insurance premiums could deny her sick daughter treatment. An employer frets about how health-care lawsuits could cost him his small business.

title: Clinton Joins in Gore's Call for Licensing of Gun Owners
description: President Clinton today called for licensing of handgun owners and said the question before the nation was, ''Will we have common-sense gun laws, or government by the gun lobby?''

title: The Big City; TV Gives Sex In New York A Bad Name
description: NOW that HBO's ''Sex and the City'' has unexpectedly become a national hit, people across America are getting a weekly glimpse at dysfunctional New Yorkers engaging in humanity's most brutal mating rituals. It's gratifying that outsiders care enough to pay attention to our parochial obsessions. But what is this doing to the city's image?

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; BUFETE MISSES PAYMENT
description: One of Mexico's leading construction companies, Bufete Industrial S.A., will default on a payment today on a $100 million Eurobond. The company, the third in Mexico to default this year, said it was unable to get new credit to pay the debt, despite $850 million in pending projects. Rick Wills

title: Transit Riders to Pay Same Fares Next Year
description: New Jersey Transit adopted a budget yesterday for the fiscal year 2000 that keeps fares level for the ninth year in a row, the agency said.

title: Monitoring New York's Police
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani made his point this week with the usual clarity. ''My administration never compromises on matters of principle,'' he said. The principle, in this case, is that New York City's Police Department should not have an outside monitor on questions of police brutality. An overseer for the department is said to be one of the remedies suggested by Federal prosecutors in the wake of police torture of the Haitian immigrant Abner Louima two years ago. But if a Federal monitor is such a bad idea, the Mayor must come up with something better.

title: Sports of The Times; A League In Search Of a Moment
description: AT midday yesterday Angela Alfaro was on 33d Street, outside Madison Square Garden, contemplating an imposing 7-foot rim. This was at the Slam Dunk exhibit, one of 12 set up by the Women's National Basketball Association as a prelude to its inaugural All-Star Game last night, won by the West, 79-61.

title: Building a Dream Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERSHIL, NORMA CLAIRE
description: WERSHIL-Norma Claire, age 80 of St. Louis, MO. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY. She was a prominent realtor in the Westchester County area. Former owner of the Heathcote Corners Realty, of Scarsdale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Philip B. Wershil. Cherished mother of Laura Chazen, Judith Wershil and Bruce Wershil. Loving grandmother of Mollie and Ben Chazen & Russell Wershil Hasan. Funeral service on Thursday at 10:30 AM at the Congregation KOL AMI Jewish Community Center of White Plains, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, ADELE
description: SCHLESINGER-Adele. The officers, board members, principals, faculty, parents and students of the Solomon Schechter Day School of Nassau County express their sincere condolences to James Schlesinger, our treasurer, and his family, on the loss of his dear mother. May her memory be a source of love and inspiration for you and your family. Susan Aberbach, Board Chair Beth Ostrow, President

title: When a Crash Can Be a Crime
description: The filing of state charges of third-degree murder and manslaughter against the aircraft maintenance company Sabretech for 110 deaths in the 1996 Valujet crash is highly unusual, and probably not appropriate in most plane crash cases. Criminal prosecutions in this context may deter airlines and maintenance crews from fully cooperating in future accident investigations. But if there is clear evidence that the accident was caused by gross negligence that rises to criminal conduct, prosecution may be justified.
