description: KARMAN-Lawrence. Age 77 of NYC and Palm Beach Gardens, FL died on July 13 at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Beloved husband and best friend of Roslyn (Boriss). Devoted father and ''pal'' to Howard (Ann) & Michael (Karen). Loving ''Paka'' to Eric. Dear brother to Myron (Lenore). His love and knowledge of sports led to a career and lifestyle that brought him much happiness and fulfillment. Former owner-director of Camps Wahconah and Potomac in Pittsfield, MA. He touched many lives and hearts over his seven decades in the camping field. He was a health and physical education teacher and coach in the NYC H.S. system for 36 years. Athletic Director of City Athletic Club for 30 years. Professional umpire of U.S. Lawn Tennis Assn. Basketball and baseball official. Past Master of Courland Lodge F&AM of 6th Masonic District. 1950 National Paddle Tennis Doubles Champion. In retirement he coordinated the Senior Men's (55+) Tennis League at PGA National Golf & Tennis Resort. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him for his warmth, gentleness, humor and upbeat personality. Services Thursday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDOWELL, ROSA R.
description: McDOWELL-Rosa R. Beloved wife of Samuel and mother of Edward and Janet Anne McDowell. Beloved sister of Edward and Herbert Deutsch. On Tuesday, July 13, 1999. She was adored by all who knew her and is much missed. Shiva Minyan 8PM Thursday, July 15th at Apartment 8G, 900 West 190 Street, New York, N.Y.

title: Samuelsson Could Return to Garden
description: Seeking more depth and toughness on defense, the Rangers are going after Ulf Samuelsson, the free agent who is no stranger to Madison Square Garden.

title: Nasdaq Finishes at a New High With a Gain of 39.90
description: The Nasdaq composite index rose to a record, led by Intel, after the company said its earnings would improve later this year.

title: Pakistan-Backed Force Leaves Indian Kashmir
description: Indian officials said today that the withdrawal of Pakistani-backed forces from an Indian-controlled area of Kashmir was on schedule to be finished by the deadline on Friday, but they expressed outrage at what they described as a Pakistani-sponsored act of terrorism that took place on Tuesday in the Kashmir valley.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: On the Rise And on Line
description: In 1995 two Manhattan club owners started the Macintosh Music Festival to fill the summer gap left after the New Music Seminar -- a weeklong mix of panels, deal making and scores of alternative rock concerts -- collapsed under the weight of its debt. The new festival, the club owners said, would merge computer technology with live performance, posting 360-degree concert photos and written descriptions of shows on the Internet to become the first festival to take place simultaneously in clubs and on the Web. To many people at the time, the whole concept seemed like a lot of smoke blown around an attempt keep the clubs crowded and to sell more beer.

title: Criminal Charges Ruled Out In Morgan Stanley Inquiry
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the Wall Street firm that has been under legal scrutiny since it paid a person involved in the arrest of a former employee, will not face criminal charges in the case, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: On Barak Visit, Is It First Lady Hillary Clinton, or Candidate Hillary Clinton?
description: Before the date of this week's critical first meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel could be set, officials said a complication had to be overcome: Would it fit into Hillary Rodham Clinton's schedule?

title: Con Ed Questioned at Hearing on Blackout
description: The 18-hour blackout in northern Manhattan last week has raised serious questions about whether Consolidated Edison's network of underground power cables can handle New York City's growing demands for electricity, the director of the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management said yesterday.

title: Reid Sets First Defense of Title: It's Against Kelly, Not Kelley
description: David Reid said he got some incredulous looks and responses from his fans and friends after it was announced that he would make his first defense of his World Boxing Association superwelterweight championship against Kevin Kelly. They thought it was Kevin Kelley, the featherweight from Flushing, Queens.

title: Locking the Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Busing's Day Ends: Boston Drops Race In Pupil Placement
description: In the most powerful symbol yet that the era of race-based busing is ending in America, the Boston School Committee voted tonight to drop race as a factor in deciding which school a child attends. The vote will effectively end in 2000 the last vestiges of the city's busing integration program, 25 years after its violent inception tarred Boston with a reputation for northern racism and school busing strife.

title: Custom-Fit Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Adds $800,000 to Election Bank Account in Sweep Through Washington Area
description: Campaigning within a few miles of the White House, George W. Bush swept through the capital region today, picking up $800,000 in contributions, winning the endorsement of a Republican rival and promising the nation ''a fresh start after a season of cynicism.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ABBY RICHARD (HAP)
description: SOLOMON-Abby Richard (Hap) On Monday, July 12, 1999 at his New Canaan, CT. home. Beloved husband of Alva. Cherished son of Rosalie Solomon (nee Reasenberg) and loving father of Stephanie. Brother of Rita S. Drucker. He was the Manager of Marketing Analysis and Planning for Xerox Corp, having retired in 1993 and most recently President of the Xerox New England Retirees Group. He sat on the Board of Directors of P.S.C. Corporation of Rochester, NY for 15 years and Infodata Corp of Virginia. Memorial Services will be held at 11AM Friday, July 16th in the First Presbyterian Church, Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Assoctn.

title: Building a Dream Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: New Turf, Same Old Cheers
description: As Brandi Chastain prepared to hit her first tee shot this morning as part of the JAL Big Apple Classic Pro-Am at the Wykagyl Country Club, the large crowd of mostly soccer fans grew respectfully silent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, ROBERT K.
description: RAISLER-Robert K. Died peacefully on July 12 at his home in New York, surrounded by his children and grandchildren. He was the son of the late Samuel and Belle Raisler of New York City, brother of the late Harold Raisler and for more than 42 years, the adoring husband of the late Dolly Wolfson Raisler (who pre-deceased him by four weeks), the father of Gordon, Steven and Lynn Jacobson and grandfather to Michael, Anthony and Joe Jacobson and Joe's finacee Jordana Matthews. As longtime President and Chairman of Raisler Corporation, a family controlled, New York based Mechanical Contracting firm founded in 1899 by his father Samuel. Robert Raisler was a strong and respected Building Trades Industry advocate, and a member of many industry and professional associations and boards. Following his World War II service in the Pacific theater as a Naval Officer and Chief of aircraft maintenance on the aircraft carrier US Boxer, he maintained a life long association with the Navy as a reserve Officer, ultimately holding the rank of Lt. Commander, Ret. Widely regarded as a true ''gentleman'', Robert Raisler was President of the University of Pennsylvania's Class of 1926, former President of the Congregation Shaaray Tefila in New York City and a philanthropist well known to many charitable and educational institutions. Services will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79 Street (at 2nd Avenue) on Thursday, July 15, 1999 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, the family request that donations be made to the Raisler Fund at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Engineering. The Engineering School's alumni office may be contacted at (215) 898-6564.

title: Wrestlers and Accountants Now Take On Times Sq.
description: Just when it seemed that Times Square could not get more crowded, the World Wrestling Federation and a major accounting firm are squeezing into the district, which has become a kaleidoscope of tourists, neon signs, entertainment centers and corporate headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DAVID J.
description: WILLIAMS-David J. Age 66, July 9, 1999 at St. Mary Hospital, Livonia, MI. Born October 6, 1932 in England. Graduated Clarks College of Engineering in Essex, England. Resident of Bloomfield Hills, MI. Had been an area resident of 40 years. Mr. Williams was President and owner of Power Process Piping, Inc. of Plymouth, MI. Formerly with Ford Motor International. Member of Oakland Hills Country Club. Survived by his wife Evelyn Joan, two sons, Graham David Williams of Bloomfield Hills (and daughter-in-law Jennifer), Richard Allen Williams of Studio City, CA, one sister Valerie residing in England, one grandson Griffin David Williams. Funeral services were held Tuesday, July 13, 1999 at the William R. Hamilton Company, Birmingham, MI. Reception followed at Pine Lake Country Club, West Bloomfield, MI.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK -- From Darwinian To Disneyesque; In Tarzan's Evolution, a New Theory: The Survival of Nearly Everything
description: In the stunningly animated Disney film ''Tarzan,'' there is little doubt about the evil tendencies of a big-chinned character named Clayton: he wants to cage friendly apes, has little respect for women and likes to shoot first and ask questions later. He embodies egotistical maleness, a quality that, outside action films, has become the epitome of contemporary villainy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMBERT, JOAN
description: KOMBERT-Joan. Temple Avodah mourns the passing of our dear friend. Heartfelt condolences to the entire Kombert family. Board of Trustees

title: At Least Some Domain Names Draw Money at Net Auctions
description: CAN the unwieldy Internet domain name JewelersMallofAmerica.com really be worth the $2 million that its owner is asking for it on an Internet auction site? If so, the more straightforward ad.com would seem a bargain, with an asking price of only $500,000. And hispanics.com, which was bid up to only $5,100, is a gem.

title: Locking the Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the pianist Samuel Sanders on Monday omitted a survivor. She is his half-sister, Henriette Miller.

title: J. C. Penney Hires Wal-Mart Executive
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the No. 2 United States department store company, said today that it had hired Vanessa Castagna, a Wal-Mart Stores Inc. executive, to help direct its struggling domestic department stores.

title: China Proclaims It Designed Its Own Neutron Bomb
description: China announced today that it has successfully developed the design technology to make neutron bombs and miniaturized nuclear weapons on its own, the first time it has made these assertions publicly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLEN, MARGARET W.
description: CULLEN-Margaret W. On July 11, 1999. Mass at St. Sylvester's R.C. Church, Brooklyn, on Saturday, 9:30 AM. Interment in Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: At a Hopeful Moment, Feud Tears at Mexico's Left
description: He arrived an hour late for a meeting, but Porfirio Munoz Ledo, one of Mexico's most durable and pyrotechnical politicians of the left, did not apologize. Instead, he heaped blame on his driver and several aides who happened to be nearby, announcing that he intended to fire them all.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: LVMH MOET HENNESSY LOUIS VUITTON S.A., Paris, named Myron Ullman group managing director. Mr. Ullman will continue as president of the selective distribution branch until a successor is named.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Show Me the Flowers

title: Time Warner's Net Rises, Reflecting One-Time Gains
description: Time Warner said yesterday that its net income rose to $575 million, or 43 cents a share fully diluted, for the second quarter from $23 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue, however, declined 2.6 percent, to $3.57 billion.

title: Met Schedule Dismays Ballet Theater
description: Concerned that its run would be pushed deep into the summer doldrums, American Ballet Theater has voiced its dismay over an unannounced plan by its landlord, the Metropolitan Opera, to expand the opera season permamently by two weeks, to 32 weeks, starting in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOKOT, RUBIN
description: KOKOT-Rubin. Died July 13, 1999, quietly and at great peace in his sleep at 82. Beloved husband of Marian for 52 years. Devoted and cherished father of Eugene and Kevin, dearest father-in-law of Barbara and Lilia. Loving and proud grandfather of Amy and Matthew and dear ''Grandpapa'' to Oumayma and Maha. Family service to be held in California. You're greatly loved and will be greatly missed.

title: High Hopes (and Scores) Are Predicted
description: The world is about to find out if Sergio Garcia will contend for a major championship at age 19. Or if Americans will continue their recent dominance at the British Open. Or if Tiger Woods will win his second major. Or if David Duval, Colin Montgomerie or Phil Mickelson will win his first.

title: A Return To Form Is Needed By Clemens
description: Introduced as one of the 100 All-Century players before Tuesday's All-Star Game, Roger Clemens stepped forward and tipped his cap to the fans at Boston's Fenway Park -- a Yankee cap -- and the reaction was predictably nasty.

title: In Town of 11, Landlord Wins Battle in Rent War
description: A state judge has ruled that officials of Teterboro were in a conflict of interest when they voted to condemn the houses they rented after their new landlord threatened to raise the rent.

title: Provantage Stock Offering
description: Provantage Health Services Inc., which helps insurance companies manage prescription drug benefits and claims, closed 18 percent above its offering price on its first day of trading. The company sold 5.6 million shares, or a 31 percent stake, at $18 each on Tuesday, raising $100.8 million. The stock closed at $21.1875, giving it a market value of $384.6 million. About 4.8 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Provantage works with more than 3,500 plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOTT, CATHERINE (CAPPE) SEARLES
description: STOTT - Catherine (Cappe) Searles. Age 79. Died July 1, 1999 at her home in Wickenburg, AZ. She is survived by her son Robert Doulton Stott, Jr. of Grand Junction, CO., her daughter Deborah S. Stasi and granddaughters Marly and Laura Stasi of Red Bank, N.J. Memorial service will be held 10AM Saturday, July 24th at Saint Eustace Church in Lake Placid, New York. Memorial donations may be made in her honor to the American Red Cross.

title: Prosecutor Challenges Claim From Lawyers in Louima Case
description: A claim by defense lawyers for a police officer convicted in the Abner Louima case that Federal prosecutors withheld vital information is baseless, a prosecutor argued in court papers submitted yesterday.

title: Senate G.O.P. Again Prevails on Health Care Bill
description: Republicans today showed that they were calling the shots in the Senate's managed care debate, approving their own measure on hospitalization for women undergoing mastectomies and turning back three efforts by Democrats to strengthen the rights of patients.

title: Mets Sound Alert for a Starting Pitcher
description: A little more than two weeks remain before the trading deadline, and the Mets' Steve Phillips, like many other general managers, is still looking for starting pitching.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, BUD
description: ROTHENBERG-Bud. On July 12, 1999 at age 76. Of New York City and West Palm Beach, FL. Loving husband of the late Honi Rothenberg. Beloved father of Randy and Russell & father-in-law of Angela and Randi. Cherished grandfather of Samantha, Alexa, Dane, and Mitchell. His humor & good nature will be missed by all.

title: Henry Kimbro, 87, Speedy Star Of the Negro Baseball Leagues
description: Henry Kimbro, a perennial All-Star center fielder during the 1940's in a Negro leagues career that spanned 17 seasons, died Sunday at his home in Nashville. He was 87.

title: MARKETING SERVICES TO BUY GRIZZARD COMMUNICATIONS
description: Marketing Services Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Grizzard Communications Group, a closely held Atlanta-based marketing company, for $100 million in cash and stock. Marketing Services said the purchase would add Grizzard's strength in creative services and print production to its own data base, telemarketing and Internet services. Marketing Services, based in New York, said the deal would also widen its client base, now concentrated in the entertainment, publishing and financial industries. Grizzard serves financial-services companies along with nonprofit organizations, including the Salvation Army and the American Red Cross. Marketing Services' stock rose $1.1875 a share, to $28.6875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about a rally in midtown Manhattan for the United States women's soccer team carried an incorrect credit in some editions. The photographer was Lauren Winfield for The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RAYMINNIE MARKS
description: FRIEDMAN-Rayminnie Marks, July 13, 1999. Age 84. Beloved wife of the late Chester S. Friedman. Loving mother of Joseph Friedman & Rita Aron. Adoring grandmother of Jonathan and Timothy Aron and Michael and David Friedman. Dedicated volunteer to many charities and past president of The Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El. Funeral service will be held on Friday, July 16th, 10AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Womens Auxiliary or The Sunday Lunch Program of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Experimental Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Blame Deer for Lyme Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with an article about the record of Sabis, a Middle Eastern company chosen to operate a charter school in New York, was published in error. It showed Marshall Mitchell, at the left, executive director of Parents for School Choice, and John Elwell, director of school operations for Victory Schools, which is to run a charter school in Harlem. It did not show Randy Daniels, a SUNY trustee, and Scott W. Steffey, a vice chancellor at SUNY.

title: How Our Prisons Became Mental Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Gehry Plans Another Architectural Surprise for Spain
description: Frank O. Gehry drove into this medieval village, 90 minutes south of his acclaimed Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, plotting another architectural surprise for Spain in his first winery project.

title: BRITISH JOBLESSNESS DROPS
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 4.4 percent in June -- its lowest in 19 years, the Office for National Statistics said. The number of jobless was 1.28 million -- 5,200 fewer than in May. Pay increases, which had threatened to fuel inflation, fell to an annualized rate of 4.3 percent in March to May, compared with 4.6 percent the previous quarter. The data suggest the economy is growing without driving up inflation, raising speculation that interest rates, currently at a 22-year low of 5 percent, could again be cut. Alan Cowell

title: In the Tour de France, Information Can Become Power
description: At midday on July 5, the American cyclist Lance Armstrong and the rest of the riders in the Tour de France were taking things easy when the third of the race's 20 daily stages began with the riders setting out from the Loire River city of Nantes, rolling along at a touristlike 18 miles per hour.

title: ONSALE TO ACQUIRE EGGHEAD.COM, A RIVAL ON-LINE RETAILER
description: Onsale Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a rival on-line retailer, Egghead.com Inc., for about $400 million in stock to create one of the Internet's largest sellers of computer equipment, electronics and software. Onsale will pay 0.565 a share, or about $12.70, for each Egghead.com share. The company will operate under the name Egghead.com and have an estimated $500 million in sales this year. Shares of Egghead.com, based in Liberty Lake, Wash., fell 31.25 cents, to $11.75, while Onsale, based in Menlo Park, Calif., fell $1.50 a share, to $21. Onsale's @Auction site holds auctions for products including PC's, electronics, sporting goods and vacation packages.

title: In Spite of Itself, the Grand Old Game Still Thrives
description: Major League Baseball is a survivor. In spite of itself. No matter how hard officials and owners and lawyers and players try to undermine its foundation, the game rises above all.

title: Who Says Teachers Have the Easy Life?
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics as Usual in Argentina Rattles Financial Markets
description: Ever since Gen. Juan Domingo Peron remade Argentine political campaigns in the 1940's and 1950's, the tough talk has been as traditional as drinking gourds of mate tea with the masses. Presidential candidates question why the country should repay its international debt. They offer populist oratory challenging world capitalism.

title: Light Trucks Prone to Tip, Safety Tests Find
description: Federal regulators said today that nearly 100 tests on a dozen automobiles showed that the sport utility vehicles and the pickup trucks sometimes tipped up on two wheels during very sharp turns but that the cars almost never did.

title: President Resigns at Advanced Micro
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that its president and chief operating officer, S. Atiq Raza, had resigned. Mr. Raza had been considered the likely successor to Advanced Micro's chief executive, Jerry Sanders.

title: Free Service Is a Way to Keep Prying Eyes Off Your E-Mail
description: A new company in Palo Alto, Calif., has created a free E-mail service to fend off the on-line equivalent of Dumpster divers -- people who root through mail servers to find messages that you sent days, weeks or even years ago.

title: Grass Umbrellas, Blurry Clocks And More
description: Tibor Kalman, the graphic designer, died in May, but his widow, the artist Maira Kalman, said, ''He's very present.'' Not only is his company, M&Co, introducing one of his last designs, the ''Grass Umbrella'' ($45), above, but last month, the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan also became the exclusive distributor of M&Co's products, including blurry clocks and crumpled plastic paperweights. ''Tiborocity: Designs and Undesign by Tibor Kalman,'' a 20-year retrospective of his work, opens tomorrow at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. The umbrella will be available in August at the MOMA Design Store, 44 West 53d Street.

title: Back to the Moon: Apollo 11 Revisited
description: People of a certain age remember watching television in the small hours of the morning one summer day in 1969 as Neil Armstrong made his giant leap for mankind. With the 30th anniversary of the event next Tuesday, there are plenty of places on the Internet to relive (or get a taste of) those heady days.

title: Japanese Chemical Maker to Plead Guilty
description: Nippon Gohsei, a Japanese chemical maker, agreed today to plead guilty and pay a $21 million United States criminal fine for taking part in a 17-year conspiracy to fix prices for food preservatives.

title: The Season Of Collaboration
description: The riff is that writing is the loneliest and most tormenting of callings, and the romantic image of the novelist at work, amid the litter of words and thoughts, is anything but Apollonian. But what if two people write a novel together? Can they do it as well as one, locked up together as they are in what can be a jail house of familiarity? Which everyone knows breeds contempt and resentment and even skulduggery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JOSEPH E.
description: O'CONNOR-Joseph E. Born on July 9, 1928; died on July 10, 1999. Husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Kathleen O'Connor, Patricia Lippo, Joanne Rinaldi and Jacqueline Pelosi. Cherished grandfather of Danny, Caralynn, Samantha & Madeleine. Loving brother of Billy VanBramer, Helen Wysoki, Evelyn Rivera and Marion Coppa and Anna Haslin; also deceased brothers Raymond and James.

title: Working Mother Regains Custody of Two Children
description: A Florida appeals court overturned an earlier decision yesterday that had denied a Miami lawyer and mother primary custody of her two children because she worked long hours.

title: Don't Blame Deer for Lyme Disease; Ubiquitous Ticks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paddy Ashdown of Britain Is Seen by Some As Leading Candidate for Secretary-General : Hunt for NATO Chief Moves Into New Phase
description: PARIS  The search by NATO for a new secretary-general was thrown open Wednesday when the German defense minister, Rudolf Scharping, was definitively ruled out by his government.

title: Is Israel Ready To Make Peace?; Shifting Ideologies
description: To the Editor:

title: Couple Charged in African Girl's 9-Year Servitude
description: A woman who investigated child abuse complaints for New York City was arrested yesterday with her husband and charged with forcing a teen-age Nigerian girl in the Bronx into servitude for nine years, Federal law enforcement officials said.

title: Political Briefing; The Leap That Left A Chamber Loopy
description: In the last decade, more than 400 elected Democrats have jumped over to the Republican Party, many in Southern and Border states, where the Republicans have been most in the ascendancy. The latest to jump is State Senator Dan Seum of Louisville, Ky., and his leap, on Monday, was more than just another embarrassing defection. When he switched, he changed Kentucky's political history.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Agencies Selected For Media Accounts
description: Two advertisers have made decisions involving media accounts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Earnings Slump 1.8% But Still Beat Expectations

title: Umpires Threaten To Quit On Sept. 2
description: Saying that tensions were ''at an all-time high and the relationship between Major League Baseball and umpires at an all-time low,'' the umpires' union leader said that 57 of the 66 major league umpires met in Philadelphia yesterday and resigned from their jobs, effective Sept. 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHANAN, CHARLES NICHOLAS
description: BUCHANAN-Charles Nicholas. On July 13th, 1999. At age 59. Of Mesothelioma. Beloved son of Lucie (nee Trincellita), and the late Douglas, brother of Douglas and Jane, uncle and godfather of Nicholas. He was a long-time resident of Hoboken, where he grew up, and a graduate of Fairleigh Dickinson University. A memorial service will be held in September.

title: Blowing the Whistle
description: To the Editor:

title: For Inkster, It's as if '84 Is Being Replayed Again
description: Juli Inkster slipped inside the ropes at the 18th green, ushering her two daughters with her to meet two of the players in today's pro-am: Mia Hamm and Julie Foudy. Amid hugs and greetings, Inkster congratulated Foudy for the American soccer team's victory in the Women's World Cup and Foudy excitedly replied, ''No, congratulations to you!''

title: In America; Money vs. Reform
description: Donna Marie McIlwaine was 22 when she died on Feb. 8, 1997. She is buried in the Chili Rural Cemetery in upstate Scottsville, N.Y.

title: RACING CHAMPIONS REJECTS $182 MILLION OFFER FROM ENNA
description: The Racing Champions Corporation, a maker of auto-racing collectibles and souvenirs, said yesterday that it had rejected an offer of $11 a share, or about $182.6 million, from the closely held Enna Corporation. Racing Champions, which also markets Nascar die-cast replicas, Press Pass trading cards and AMT model hobby kits, said in a statement that the bid by Enna, based in Charlottesville, Va., was ''wholly inadequate.'' The offer was far below Racing Champions' 52-week high of $17.875 on May 25. Shares of Racing Champions, based in Glen Ellyn, Ill., rose $1.0938, or 16 percent, to $8.0625.

title: ACCORD IN ULSTER HITS A ROADBLOCK OVER DISARMAMENT
description: Ulster's main Protestant party said tonight that it was unwilling to join the Irish Republican Army's political wing in government as scheduled on Thursday. The decision halts all progress in the Northern Ireland peace agreement.

title: A Country Music Triangle Comes Full Circle After Six Years
description: ''Look out, Music City, 'cause I'm here now, and I ain't never leavin'!'' an aspiring country singer with the potent name of Miranda Presley (Samantha Mathis) whoops into the night from a Nashville rooftop early in ''The Thing Called Love.'' Her exultant shouts distill the optimistic down-home spirit of this cheery but trivial 1993 movie, directed by Peter Bogdanovich, about guitar-toting hopefuls converging on the country music capital at a moment when (thanks to Garth Brooks) the music was enjoying a huge spurt of popularity.

title: Enron to Buy Natural Gas From Petronas
description: The Enron Corporation, the largest energy trading and marketing company, said today that it would buy as much as 2.6 million tons of liquefied natural gas a year from Malaysia's state oil company and sell the fuel in India.

title: The Teahouse On Tar Beach
description: PIERRE SERNET, an Internet entrepreneur, was jockeying adroitly through midday traffic recently on Park Avenue in a Mercedes sport utility vehicle, equipped late 20th-century samurai style with cellular telephone and electric sunroof, talking about the Japanese tea ceremony.

title: Pataki Is Target in Bid to Expand Medicaid for Working Poor
description: Under a little-known provision in the 1996 Federal welfare law, New York has become eligible to receive several hundred million dollars a year from Washington to expand Medicaid coverage for one of its fastest-growing and most troubling uninsured populations: low-income working parents.

title: In Japan, Mired in Recession, Suicides Soar
description: In their annual sweep of the Aokigahara woods at the end of last year, police officers found 73 bodies.

title: Windows In Your Pocket
description: If the Microsoft Corporation is to sustain its dominance of the software industry in the 21st century, it must spread its Windows software far beyond desktop and portable computers and into our television sets, our automobiles, our telephones and even into our pockets.

title: House Narrowly Defeats Increase in Money for Arts and Humanities Endowments
description: The House late Wednesday narrowly defeated efforts to increase spending on the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, whose budgets have been cut or frozen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRICK, RAYMOND
description: BRICK-Raymond, on July 12, 1999, at age 84, of Teaneck, NJ. Devoted husband of the late Lillian Brick; beloved father of Judy Freedman, Nora Cousens and Harry Brick; dear brother to Doris Chodorow; grandfather to Evan and Seth Freedman; Rafael and Heather Cousens, Aaron and Jamie Brick; great-grandfather to Sarah Freedman. He is loved dearly by many nieces, nephews, cousins, family members and friends with whom he generously shared his appreciation for history, music and art. He had a great sense of humor and compassion. He was a passionate lover of music and was graced with a beautiful tenor voice. He sang with the John Harms Choir with his father, brother, and brother-in-law. He ran HARMOSA, owners of gas stations and distributors of Gulf products in all five Boros of New York, from 1937 to 1960. He worked on his Masters in History from NYU; earned a teaching certificate and taught Social Studies in junior high schools in NYC and Northern NJ. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, corner Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, NJ, on Thursday, July 15, at 11AM. For further information, call 1-800-522-0588. Contributions may be made in his name toward an endowment for a voice student at the Juilliard School of Music, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, New York 10023. He will forever inspire many hearts.

title: Another Venture in Art Auctions for Ebay
description: Greg Manning Auctions Inc. agreed today to form a venture with Ebay Inc.'s Butterfield & Butterfield unit to auction fine art and collectibles on Ebay's Internet site.

title: The Once And Future Network; Wiring the Home Has Made Big Strides, but Has Far to Go
description: IN the old days -- say, a couple of years ago -- home networks meant figuring out a way to use a personal computer and some simple X-10 modules to turn lamps on and off, control the sprinkler system and manage a simple home security system. That was before the availability of inexpensive PC's, the rise of the World Wide Web and the advent of high-speed connections to the Internet.

title: C. L. Harris, 94; Allowed Lunch Counter Sit-In
description: Clarence L. Harris, whose contribution to the civil rights struggle of the 1960's was that he did nothing at all when four black college students held the first successful sit-in demonstration at a dime store lunch counter he managed, died on Monday in Greensboro, N.C. He was 94 and spent most of his life in Greensboro.

title: INSIDE
description: China Boasts It Mastered Neutron Bomb Technology

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on July 8 about proposed changes in the Toyota Motor Corporation's system of employee compensation misstated the number of its white-collar workers in Japan. It is about 20,000, not 70,000.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: On a Tugboat, Needing a Tow

title: Locking the Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERFEL, ELSIE
description: WERFEL-Elsie. We mourn the passing of Elsie Werfel on July 14, 1999. Loving wife of the late Max Werfel. Mother of Judith & Gerald Etra. Grandmother of Stanley and Jonathan Etra. Sister of Jacob Schulman. She was devoted to her family and a passionate supporter of Hadassah and Amit. She brought happiness to everyone around her and was a role model to her family. Services Thursday, 1:30PM ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. Shiva at 121 Regent Dr, Lido Beach, NY.

title: A Farewell To a Duet For Women From 1982
description: ''Fase: Four Movements to the Music of Steve Reich,'' created in 1982, was one of the first major works by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker. After presenting this women's duet many times since then, Ms. De Keersmaeker recently announced her wish to retire it from her repertory. She and Michele Anne De Mey danced what was billed as its final performance on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ROBERTA BRONER
description: COHEN-Roberta Broner. On Sunday, July 11, 1999, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Washington, DC. Beloved wife of Norman G. Cohen. Loving mother of Jeffrey N. Cohen (Fran G. Cohen) of Washington, DC, Dr. John B. Cohen (Dr. Leslie Rodnan) of Washington, DC, and Nancy Cohen Roberts (Marc R. Roberts) of NYC. Grandmother of Craig, Jodi, Gabriel, Julia and Eli Cohen, Michael and Elisabeth Roberts. Sister of Herbert J. Broner and the late Sydna Broner. Services will be held at Adas Israel Congregation, 2850 Quebec St., NW, Washington, DC, on Thursday, July 15th, at 11 AM. Interment Adas Israel Cemetery. Contributions may be made to The Norman G. and Roberta B. Cohen Children's Fund at the Jewish Social Service Agency, 6123 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD. or The Jewish Foundation for Group Homes. Ives Pearson Takoma Funeral Home.

title: Increase in Ford's Earnings Tops Wall Street Estimates
description: The American automobile market, widely dismissed a few years ago as too competitive and glutted to be profitable, carried the Ford Motor Company to earnings that were better than expected in the second quarter. Strong United States sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks offset losses in South America and deteriorating results in Europe.

title: TLC BEATRICE NEARS FINAL LIQUIDATION WITH DISTRIBUTION
description: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc. will distribute $30 a share, a total of about $275 million, to stockholders as it nears final liquidation. The company, once the largest black-owned United States business, has been selling its units since shortly after its $985 million leveraged buyout of the Beatrice Foods international operations in 1987. The sale of its last business, the Irish potato chip maker Tayto, for about $115 million in cash, is to close later this summer. Slightly more than half of about 9.1 million shares outstanding belong to the family of the founder, Reginald F. Lewis. Payments will be made July 21 to 23 to shareholders of record on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about a computer simulation of schizophrenic experiences misstated the surname of a psychiatrist who discussed on the simulation, and paraphrased his comments incorrectly. He is Dr. Jim Jacobson. He said the simulation might be useful to help doctors realize that a patient who appeared distracted was actually hallucinating. Dr. Jacobson did not say that until he saw the simulation, he did not interpret distraction as a sign of hallucinations.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Finding Translation Help To View Word and Excel
description: Q. I use Microsoft Word and Excel and make copies of the files for my secretary. She does not have Word or Excel on her PC, and when she tries to open the files, she gets gobbledy-gook. Is there a way to open these files if you do not have Word or Excel?

title: Foreign Lenders Are Trying to Reopen Talks on a Chinese Debt
description: Foreign banks that are fearful of huge losses on loans they had thought were guaranteed are seeking to restart deadlocked negotiations with Chinese officials on ways to salvage a troubled state-owned company that owes $5.6 billion.

title: Designs From Rice Paste to Teak
description: ''Indian Interiors'' by Sunil Sethi proves there is no such thing as one Indian style. ''You have people living along India's waters in houseboats,'' Mr. Sethi said. ''You have nomadic populations that live in the desert region in western India. And you have the great princely palaces.'' All are represented in the richly illustrated book. Also in the book is a 1999 concrete-and-glass house in New Delhi, below; inside the house is a wavy teak table, above, designed to imitate the drape of fabric. The polar opposite is a house, bottom, in eastern India. ''The peasants are rice cultivators, and in the building of the house, the rice grain is pounded into a sticky white paste and used to decorate the home,'' Mr. Sethi said. The book, with 470 photographs by Deidi von Schaewen, will be $39.99, from Taschen, in August.

title: A Designer's Farewell to His Fantasy Realm
description: GEORGE LUCAS isn't the only auteur who's been working on the same fictional universe for 20 years. In the lesser-known realm of computer games, Richard Garriott is the artistic marathon runner whose creations have sustained generations of rabid fans over the decades. As the creator of Ultima, the longest-running fiction in digital media, Mr. Garriott has tended his vision from the dawn of the PC era to the wired world of sprawling multiplayer on-line games.

title: As the Clock Nears Midnight; Companies That Danced in the Year 2000 Market Need to Find New Steps Before the Ball Ends
description: Three years ago, as word spread that its software products could help solve Year 2000 computer problems, a little-known company called Viasoft Inc. became an overnight Wall Street sensation. Sales soared, and Viasoft's stock price shot up nearly eightfold in 1996, the second-biggest percentage gain that year of any company listed on the three major exchanges.

title: Election Watchdogs
description: To the Editor:

title: So Fierce That Even Stillness Speaks of Motion
description: Jiri Kylian is at his best and deepest in ''One of a Kind,'' a ballet that has the glow of a magic onyx. Bathed in both darkness and light, this new work choreographed by the longtime artistic director of the Nederlands Dans Theater made for a stunning opening on Wednesday night.

title: Merrill Sues Over Loss of Accounts
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the largest United States securities firm, has sued two brokers who quit its office in Dunwoody, Ga., this month to join Salomon Smith Barney Inc., contending the former employees stole more than 400 accounts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Neglected Park
description: To the Editor:

title: McKesson Sets Costly Charges In Restatement
description: McKesson HBOC Inc. said yesterday that it would slice $327.4 million from its revenue for the last three fiscal years to correct accounting irregularities at HBO and Company, a software maker it acquired in January.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEINTOP, BETTY M.
description: SHEINTOP-Betty M. The hurt of your loss will never go away. You are and always will be our one and only love, and you will live within each of us for the rest of our lives. Bob and David

title: For Hives and Honey In New York City; Rooftop Beekeepers Defy Law to Get That Sweet Central Park Bouquet
description: The setting -- the rooftop of a brownstone on West 113th Street in Manhattan -- hardly evoked the lazy bee-hum of rusticity. Looming to the north was the brick bulk of Butler Library at Columbia University. To the southeast jutted the latticework scaffolding of the ever-unfinished Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Lincoln wants to pull in a younger market for its new car, but hopes to avoid Cadillac's mistakes.
description: WHEN American car lovers thought of luxury cars years ago long before Lexus came along to steal boomers' hearts from BMW, which had won them over from Mercedes-Benz -- they envisioned Cadillacs and Lincolns.

title: Designing Homes for Kosovo Refugees
description: Refugees returning to Kosovo need homes. Architecture for Humanity, a competition to select the most imaginative designs for the returning Kosovars, may provide a prototype. An estimated 40,000 homes -- most made of stone, brick or concrete -- are currently uninhabitable in Kosovo, according to the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The competition is soliciting plans for a prototype house that can be built for $8,000, the cost of replacing a simple home in Kosovo, said Cameron Sinclair, the competition director and a designer at Christidis Lauster & Radu Architects in Manhattan. That firm is cosponsoring the competition with War Child, a London-based nonprofit agency to aid war victims. The jury includes the architects Steven Holl, Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. The entry fee is $25, and the submissions deadline is Sept. 27. Judging is in October, and a show of the winning designs will follow. Information: www.archforhumanity.com.

title: First Union and Fleet Report Earnings Results for Quarter
description: The First Union Corporation, struggling to regain investor confidence, said yesterday that its second-quarter operating profit fell 9.3 percent. Fleet Financial Group Inc. said its earnings had risen 14.5 percent.

title: Allied Waste Transaction
description: Allied Waste International Inc., a big United States garbage-disposal company, agreed today to sell the gas services unit of Browning-Ferris Industries' to Gas Recovery Systems Inc. for $78 million after it completes its $9.1 billion purchase of Browning-Ferris. The unit recovers methane gas from landfills, cleans it and turns it into electricity. The closely held Gas Recovery will buy the unit for cash and other considerations. It will get 15 operating plants and four under construction in Michigan, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Illinois, Texas, Virginia and Iowa.

title: Construing His Airness As a Neo-Imperialist
description: MICHAEL JORDAN AND THE NEW GLOBAL CAPITALISM

title: Take These Jokes . . . Please
description: HOW many jokes has Gary Lewis sent by E-mail in the last month?

title: Cape Town Journal; In the Sad Wasteland, a Storehouse of Memories
description: Back in 1966, the old apartheid Government, flexing its racist brawn, declared that the city's most famous mixed-race neighborhood would now be a whites-only area and promptly began bulldozing the houses.

title: Hertz Considers An Acquisition
description: The Hertz Corporation, the world's largest car-rental company, said today that it might buy a vehicle-leasing unit from the Ford Motor Company as the latest step to expand into businesses with steadier revenue.

title: U.S. Agency Settles a Suit On Disabled Immigrants
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has agreed to reconsider the citizenship applications of about 200 immigrants in the New York City area who said their physical or mental disabilities prevented them from learning English and civics.

title: A Man With a New Mission: A Computer in Every Kitchen
description: Computers may be proliferating throughout the house, but they have generally bypassed the kitchen. Bob Lampson wants to change that, and as the man who brought the Juiceman juicer and Breadman bread machine to countless kitchen counters (via countless infomercials), he may just be the fellow to do it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KASS, MITCHEL
description: KASS-Mitchel. July 15, 1992. We remember you in so many ways every day. Love, Children, Grandchildren & Great-Granddaughter.

title: Washington, Sensing a Chance for Fresh Momentum on Mideast Peace, Awaits Barak
description: Buoyed, almost to the point of ebullience, by the prospect of fresh momentum with the new Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, President Clinton and his foreign policy advisers hope that his visit will be the opening chapter of a comprehensive Middle East peace settlement that will culminate near the end of Mr. Clinton's term.

title: Shakespeare's Hostilities Of Courtship, Italian Style
description: American cinema audiences of the 1950's and 60's were thrilled to the marrow when Italian movies demonstrated that you didn't have to make nice to make love. Sniping, scrapping and thumb-biting as foreplay? How exotic, how earthy, how passionate it all seemed when Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni, or Anna Magnani and anyone, were butting heads.

title: Tibco Raises $109 Million
description: Tibco Software Inc. said yesterday that it had raised $109.5 million in the initial sale of its shares to the public. The 7.3 million common shares sold for $15 apiece, more than the expected price of $9 to $11 a share. The shares closed at more than double that price -- $32.375 -- on volume of 11.7 million shares on the Nasdaq stock market. Tibco, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., provides business software that integrates internal and external operations.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CUTS 12% OF WORK FORCE
description: The analytical instruments maker Perkin-Elmer said yesterday that it had cut 350 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, as part of a reorganization intended to reduce costs and improve competitiveness. Perkin-Elmer, formerly Perkin-Elmer Analytical Instruments, was acquired in June for $425 million by the EG&G Corporation. The seller was the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, which has since renamed itself the PE Corporation-PE Biosystems Group. EG&G, based in Wellesley, Mass., makes products for the automotive, medical, aerospace and photography industries. Perkin-Elmer is based in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAVIS, MINA
description: TRAVIS-Mina. On July 15, 1998. Remembering a special woman for years of love and fun. Claire, Marvin, Jeff and Lee

title: In Suburbs, Mrs. Clinton Stays Silent On City's Tax
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton steered clear today of a political dispute that has pitted New York City against its suburbs this year, declining to say whether she supported the repeal of the payroll tax that commuters have paid to the city.

title: The Theater of Baskets
description: Two multi-talented artists from different cultures have collaborated on a line of sturdy, finely made baskets, modern in shape and ancient in spirit. In Tenganan, a village with the oldest culture in Bali, Lou Zeldis, an American designer of jewelry, textiles and furniture and an actor in La MaMa company, has been working with Wayan Arsana, left, a master basket weaver and gamelan orchestra leader. Baskets like those above, roughly 11 inches to 20 inches across, with one to four steps, are $90 to $300 at B & B International Gallery, 601 West 26th Street, 14th floor; (212) 243-0840. The Temple basket Mr. Arsana is holding is $500 plus shipping from louzeldis@hotmail.com. WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

title: ZERO FOR ONE 2 ONE
description: Three months after its owners put the British cellular company One 2 One up for auction, potential buyers have pulled out of the bidding, having decided the price was too high. Mannesmann A.G. of Germany, which controls cellular carriers in Germany, Italy and elsewhere, confirmed that it was no longer interested, joining France Telecom, Deutsche Telekom and Vivendi. One 2 One's owners, Cable and Wireless of Britain and Mediaone Group of the United States, had hoped to receive offers of at least $:10 billion, or about $15.6 billion. Bidders reportedly refused to offer more than $:8 billion. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOPNICK, MAX
description: CHOPNICK-Max. Died July 8, 1999. You leave us ever so much better than we were, Dear Max. Your great good nature, quiet and wise counsel and steady resolve under any circumstance will be remembered as the model to strive for in our continuing efforts to bring beautiful music into the lives of those who know, or are discovering its wonders. The artists, board and patrons of NEW YORK PHILOMUSICA

title: Purchase for Macromedia
description: Macromedia Inc., a maker of Web publishing and animation software, has agreed to acquire the closely held Elemental Software for about $24 million in stock to gain software for companies doing business on the Internet. The San Francisco-based Macromedia will pay about 625,000 of its shares for Elemental, which is based in Carlsbad, Calif. Its products including Drumbeat 2000 and eStore Builder. Macromedia had fourth-quarter sales of $44 million.

title: Easy E-Mail for Travelers Without Cords, Jacks or Plugs
description: For the average laptop user on the road, getting and sending E-mail can be a chore. There's no way to plug the computer into a pay phone, and calling from a hotel room can mean changing the laptop modem's dialing properties.

title: Donald Engen Dies at 75; Led Space Museum
description: Donald D. Engen, the head of the National Air and Space Museum at the Smithsonian Institution and a former administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, was killed on Tuesday when the glider he was in broke apart over Nevada and plunged to the ground. He was 75 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Angry Response to Report on Fatal Fire
description: Relatives and union members reacted angrily yesterday to Fire Department findings that a floor collapse in which two firefighters died last summer in Brooklyn was partly caused by the failure of city housing officials to maintain the building's structural integrity.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the effect of potential tax cuts on the economy misidentified the presidential candidate who is being advised by the economics consultant Jude Wanniski. It is Dan Quayle, not Steve Forbes.

title: Turning Tables In Iran, Crowds Back Old Line
description: After six days of nationwide pro-democracy protests that deteriorated into violent rioting, huge crowds staged counterdemonstrations today in at least two dozen cities and towns, heeding the official call to praise the Islamic Republic and condemn its enemies, particularly the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANZARI, COHEN, MARIA
description: MANZARI-COHEN-Maria. December 7, 1953-July 15, 1998. Our never dying love will keep you alive forever in our hearts. Your loving family.

title: Who Says Teachers Have the Easy Life?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rubin Struggles But Advances
description: Chanda Rubin, with a whip-like crosscourt forehand, struggled to beat Jane Chi, 7-5, 7-6 (8-6), last night in the first quarterfinal match of the A.&P. Tennis Classic at the Crossroads Corporate Center in Mahwah, N.J.

title: Much Ado About War Records
description: ''Chicken hawk'' is a colorful term of derision that some have used to describe politicians, especially Republicans, who portrayed the Vietnam War as a worthy cause even though they managed to avoid fighting it. It was used effectively against Dan Quayle in 1988 and has been resurrected by the recent furor over Gov. George W. Bush's Vietnam-era military service in the Texas Air National Guard.

title: On a New On-Line Archive, The Quarry Will Be Sounds
description: Most on-line archives do a commendable job of enabling people to search what can be seen, whether rare manuscripts, literary treasures or old photographs. But searching for sounds requires a new level of technological expertise.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT WEIGHS PLANS TO BUY BACK SHARES
description: Waste Management Inc., the largest United States trash hauler, said yesterday that it might sell some assets and use the proceeds to buy back shares to increase the value of its depressed stock. The company's shares fell 37 percent on July 7 after it warned that second-quarter profit would miss estimates. Waste Management might sell some of its less-productive assets, a spokeswoman, Cherie Rice, said. Waste Management's board has not settled on any details, she said. Shares of the company rose $2 each, to $36.625.

title: NEW MEANS FOUND FOR REDUCING H.I.V. PASSED TO CHILD
description: In an advancement that promises to significantly reduce the incidence of AIDS in children in developing countries, American and Ugandan scientists have found a simple new way to prevent mother-to-child transmission of the AIDS virus that also is less costly and markedly more effective than the standard therapy in the third world.

title: Buying Spree And Inflation Hold Course
description: Everybody from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to the vacationing teacher with a 401(k) has been wondering lately how long the good times can last before inflation returns.

title: Political Briefing; She's Got Momentum, And the Name Too
description: Another Kennedy is making a move.

title: Forecasts Take Aim At the Here and Now
description: WEATHER forecasters have Doppler radar and other tools to tell them what's happening in the present and cumbersome computer models to suggest what will probably happen in the future, for a day or two, or even a month or two, ahead. But predicting in any detail what is going to occur in the next few hours is a tricky operation, prone to errors.

title: Work on Weapons Affected Health, Government Admits
description: For the first time, the Federal Government is acknowledging that nuclear weapons production during the cold war may have caused illnesses in thousands of workers, and the Clinton Administration on Thursday will announce legislation that would compensate many of them for their medical care and lost wages.

title: Exhibitions and a Tour
description: A Jeweler's Jewels

title: Rising to the Occasion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, NATHAN
description: BIDERMAN-Nathan. The Officers, Board of Trustees, Congregation and Clergy of The Jewish Center of the Hamptons, mourn the passing of Nathan Biderman, father of esteemed member and Jewish leader, Mark Biderman. We extend condolences to Mark and his famiy. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Europe Lifts Ban on Export Of British Beef After Reviews
description: The European Union executive commission announced today that its worldwide ban on British beef exports caused by the outbreak of mad cow disease was ending and that shipments could resume on Aug. 1.

title: It's Frenchmen's Party, But Italian Has His Day
description: It's all one united Europe now, bound together by open borders and a mythical common money, so why should French riders in the Tour de Motherland care so much about winning on July 14, Bastille Day, the national day of celebration?

title: Practice Make Perfect? Not Here.
description: David Duval did not bother to play a practice round today. He has seen the course. He knows it will be a brutal test. And while he is looking forward to the British Open, Duval thinks the course has been set up too severely.

title: How Our Prisons Became Mental Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh From Your Browser's Oven
description: YELL people that you're going to track their every move on a Web site, store that information in files and analyze it later, associating it with personal data they gave the site earlier, and the response might be, ''Back off, Big Brother!''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TELCORDIA TECHNOLOGIES INC., Morristown, N.J., which provides software, engineering, consulting and training services to communication networks, bought Mesa Solutions Inc., Huntsville, Ala., a systems consulting company for utilities and telecommunications businesses, for an undisclosed price.

title: Found Objects From Donghia
description: News from Donghia. The furniture and textile company has just introduced a double width (130 inch) polyester and linen fabric, above, that resembles silk Shantung; $120 a yard, to the trade. On the design front, Donghia has signed up Joseph D'Urso, a star of the high-tech movement in the 1970's. ''Joe has refined his design esthetic,'' said Sherri Donghia, the design director of furniture and textiles. ''It has a warmth to it that didn't exist in the minimalism of the 70's, that is soft, curvaceous and inviting.'' One curvy upholstered piece is asymmetrical, with differently shaped pillows, each covered with its own fabric. ''It's like a found object,'' Mr. D'Urso said. Donghia is also collaborating with Paul Mathieu, a furniture designer from Paris. The Mathieu and D'Urso collections will be introduced in January.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; W.N.B.A. All-Stars Connect, Especially With Their Fans
description: The first Women's National Basketball Association All-Star Game last night was not a contest that gave you so many great plays that your eyes wanted to pop out. It was just hard basketball, lots of fun despite too much defense. But it satisfied the Madison Square Garden sellout crowd of 18,649, including many youngsters who took part in the festivities.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN CLIMBS. The yen rose as optimism that Japan is recovering from a slump raised demand for Japanese stocks and the yen to pay for them. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.59 yen, down from 121.32 on Tuesday.

title: We Need an Energy Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: No Suspension for Phillips
description: Lawrence Phillips, the running back with a history of off-field violence, will be assessed a ''substantial fine'' when he returns to the National Football League but will not face suspension.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NGAI, SHIH, HSUN, MD.
description: NGAI-Shih-Hsun, MD. The Federation of Chinese American and Chinese Canadian Medical Societies express sincere sympathy on the loss of a founding supporter. He was instrumental in the early development of the Federation and paved the way in medicine for Chinese Americans as leaders with his position as Chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology, Columbia University of Medicine. We are in great sorrow.

title: True North Forms Global Marketing Unit
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that it was forming a global marketing services operation, Marketing Drive Worldwide, that combines units handling sales promotion, marketing consulting, relationship marketing, branding and some direct marketing.

title: For Kosovars, an On-Line Phone Directory of a People in Exile
description: AGRON SHALA, 17, hadn't seen or heard from his uncle since March, when Agron fled his home in Prizren, Kosovo. Serb forces had driven his family out of its home and over the border to Albania. Three days later, after a difficult overland trip, Agron and his mother, father and sister found themselves in Tirana, living with 2,000 other refugees in a camp in a former public park. Like many refugees, the members of Agron's family -- especially the men -- had been scattered by Serbs. Many of their fates were unknown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. On behalf of The Sherman Chamber Ensemble we deeply feel the loss of our dear Sam who infused spirit, devotion, support, humor and love into the music we made and the friendships we had. We will miss him. Susan Rotholz and Eliot Bailen

title: High-Speed Net Service Set for New York
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest local phone company in the nation, plans to begin offering high-speed Internet services to New York City customers today, seeking to get a jump on its cable television competitors.

title: Is Israel Ready To Make Peace?; Barak's Intentions
description: To the Editor:

title: Curing the Brr-Drip, Brr-Drop on Window Units
description: ''It's one of those sounds that can literally drive you crazy,'' David Zelman said. The sound: the brr-drip, brr-drop on the air-conditioner. His remedy: the Stop Drop, a 24-inch square of three-quarter-inch foam that silences an upstairs neighbor's dripping window unit. Mr. Zelman said the foam, with magnetic backing, was better than the carpet remnants most people use. It's $19.99 at Gracious Home, 1220 Third Avenue (71st Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELIZABETH
description: SCHWARTZ - Elizabeth. Naflah Ateres Roshainu. The Young Israel of Oceanside is grief-stricken in announcing the death of our beloved Rebbetzin, Liz Schwartz, Z.T.L. Her impact upon our community cannot be measured by the too few years that she graced us, but rather by the indelible impact that she has left upon us. Our entire community sits with our Rabbi and their daughter Ayala in mourning for her. In this period of national mourning for the Jewish people, may the family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Evan Torczyner, President Herb Wallenstein, Chairman of the Board

title: Truly, Madly: Courting the Contractor
description: WHEN the tank of Dale Burg's toilet cracked last February, she thought it would be as good a time as any to redo the two bathrooms in her Upper East Side apartment. Like so many other people contemplating modest renovations in these boom times, she was wrong. Four contractors turned her down. The $17,000 job didn't impress them.

title: BASEBALL -- Baseball's Shyest Superstar; Highest-Paid Yankee Still Walks Alone
description: Angry words launch themselves from deep inside Bernie Williams, his emotional silos opening and unleashing responses aimed at hurting an antagonist, the way Williams hurts when someone else fires slashing words at him. He never fires the first shot -- his parents weaned him of this instinct long ago, constantly reminding him that he needed to be respectful of others.

title: Roughing Home a Slam On the Way to a First Title
description: There are two kinds of bridge, and they are separated by a bright line: are overtricks important? They are in duplicate pairs, the staple of club and tournament play, and in board-a-match teams. They are not important in other forms of team play or in social bridge, whether the four-deal game or the rubber variety.

title: Reliving the Thrill of Roller Coaster Rides, Every Day
description: SOME people find happiness in riding roller coasters through fearsome loops, inclines and curves. They enjoy being jerked around in their seats by gravity and feeling dizzy after the ride is over.

title: Economic Scene; Cutting the tax on capital gains: the theory and the evidence.
description: CONGRESS is once again flirting with cutting the tax on capital gains, the profit from selling stocks, bonds and other investments. House Republicans, led by Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, have proposed lowering the top rate on capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent as part of an $864 billion package of tax cuts spread over 10 years. The goal, they say, is to stimulate savings, investment and economic growth.

title: Metro Business; SL Green to Buy Building
description: SL Green Realty Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a 39-story building near Pennsylvania Station for $93 million in cash, seeking to profit from the redevelopment planned for the area.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about ''Richard III,'' which is being presented by Shakespeare & Company at the Mount in Lenox, Mass., described a scene incorrectly. The corpse over which Richard seduces Lady Anne is that of her father-in-law, Henry VI, not her husband, Edward.

title: Only Two Concerns for U.S.: Duncan's Ankles
description: With seven minutes remaining and the verdict already in, Tim Duncan made a move toward the basket in the United States national team's 97-69 exhibition victory over Canada on Sunday in Orlando, Fla. But before the world's best player could finish the play with a short, smooth bank shot, he was leveled by the Canadian center, Todd MacCulloch, and sent to the floor, clutching his left heel.

title: When Overstuffed Is Just Too Stuffy
description: FORGET happiness, financial security and a healthy sex life. If you ask people what they're really looking for these days, ''a perfect sofa'' is what many are likely to say.

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS BUYS 49% STAKE IN BIRCH TELECOM
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company agreed to pay as much as $110 million for 49 percent of the closely held telephone provider Birch Telecom Inc., the first telecommunications investment for the world's largest leveraged-buyout company. Kohlberg Kravis said it would pay $60 million initially for a 35.3 percent stake, with an option to increase that to 49.1 percent for another $50 million in nine months. Birch, based in Kansas City, Mo., was founded in 1997 and provides local and long-distance phone services, Internet access and World Wide Web site-host services in Kansas, Missouri and Texas.

title: One Player's World Cup: She Also Served
description: SASKIA WEBBER, a goalkeeper on the United States women's soccer team, did not play even one-half of a match in the Women's World Cup, which the team won Saturday. Instead, she spent the entire, excruciatingly thrilling tournament on the bench, her hair spray-painted red, white and blue, cheering her team and enviously eyeing Briana Scurry, the starting keeper.

title: A Would-Be Anthem In Search of a Meaning
description: Japan is expected to get an official national anthem soon, and there's just one problem with it: people cannot quite agree on what it is about.

title: Texas Ranger's Diligent Work Ended Manhunt
description: He had promised to take his young daughter fishing last Sunday, but after several hours out on Galveston Bay, neither Sgt. Andrew Carter of the Texas Rangers nor Amber Carter, who is 3, had found much luck.

title: Evoking Sylvan Serenity In Tewksbury
description: There is rest for the weary, at the weekend home of Janet Mavec, a dealer in antique jewelry, and her husband, Wayne Nordberg, a financier. After pruning their plants, gathering berries or digging new potatoes, the couple do not have to walk all the way back to their 18th-century stone house near Tewksbury, N.J., to take a nap. Instead, they can stretch out on matching sofas under the sheltering eave of their cedar pavilion, located on an island in their man-made pond. Or they can consider the pavilion a destination, a shady place to read, eat lunch or have cocktails with friends. The airy building is a snug 10 feet by 10 feet, and rests on columns embedded in the pond. Slatted screens, which slide back and forth, control light and shade.

title: Swinging with the Times
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Get Students Writing More at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNIETZ, JOSEPH
description: DUNIETZ-Joseph. Holocaust survivor and hotelier is being mourned by the extended Dunietz family. Born March 20, 1917, Joseph is survived by his beloved wife, Edith, and his two children, Jack Dunietz and Gail Maloff. He was known affectionately as ''Papa'' to his four loving grandchildren, Jared, Jason, Joshua & Alana. He is also survived by numerous brothers, sisters, nieces & nephews. Funeral services will be held on Friday morning, July 16th at 10AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.

title: The Sadistic and Ruthless, Through a Ruthless Lens
description: As police officers go, the Japanese lawman who goes by the name Azuma Ryosuke makes Dirty Harry look like a poster boy for liberalism and forbearance.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Of a Master Fiend and a Guy Undercover in a Brothel
description: Wild Wild West

title: Met Minor Leaguer Acquitted
description: When the not guilty verdict came last night in Circuit Court in Fort Pierce, Fla., Vincente Rosario spun and bear-hugged his lawyer, Harvey Slovis. Then the 21-year-old minor leaguer for the Mets began to cry.

title: House Approves Measure on Religious Rights
description: Divided mainly along party lines, the House of Representatives debated at length today whether religious liberty or civil rights should take precedence when the two principles come into conflict.

title: Court Rejects Giuliani Suit on Tobacco Money
description: An appellate court today dismissed a lawsuit filed by the Giuliani administration claiming that New York City should get more money than the state had proposed under the terms of last year's national tobacco settlement.

title: More Jobs and More Seekers, And Unemployment Inches Up
description: The unemployment rate in New York City has been creeping up since March, and it reached 6.8 percent in June, according to data released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. Even so, the rate has been under 7 percent for four months -- the lowest levels since 1990.

title: City Hall Sues Con Edison Over 18-Hour Blackout
description: Accusing Consolidated Edison of gross negligence, the Giuliani administration sued the utility yesterday, contending that blackouts in Washington Heights and other neighborhoods last week were caused by Con Edison's failure to properly design and maintain its network of cables that distribute electricity.

title: For Young Star, Rude Awakening in Debut as Pro
description: Even in a nightmare, Sergio Garcia would probably not have imagined today's events. Garcia entered the British Open as a 19-year-old sensation, coming off his first professional victory earlier this month, and he was expected to play well.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the real estate developer Fred C. Trump on June 26 misstated the location of the White Horse Restaurant and Inn where his father supplied food and lumber to miners in the gold rush. It was in the Yukon Territory, not in Alaska.

title: 'Kid With a New Toy' (and a Red Face)
description: An offhand remark by President Clinton at a fund-raising dinner in Miami on Tuesday blossomed into a minor diplomatic incident in Washington today.

title: Managed-Care Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEN, DONALD D.
description: ENGEN-Donald D. The Directors of the Association for Rescue at Sea, Inc. express great sorrow at the untimely death of Vice Admiral Donald D. Engen, USN (Ret), a member of the Board and former president of the Association. Under his leadership AFRAS acquired two lifeboats for Britain's Royal National Lifeboat Institution. The boats, he named ''American Ambassador'' and ''Spirit of America,'' continue to put to sea with their volunteer crews to save the lives of those in peril on the treacherous waters around the U.K. With Vice Admiral Thomas R. Sargent, USCG (Ret), he also established an award to recognize a U.S. Coast Guardperson's extraordinary bravery during a sea rescue. The award is presented annually in the U.S. House of Representatives. Don will be deeply missed by all, especially his friends in the sea services. Our heartfelt condolences to Mary, daughter Candace Ellis and sons Travis, Charles and Christopher. Admiral James S. Gracey, USCG (Ret), Chairman Vice Admiral John G. Finneran, USN (Ret), Vice Chairman David D. Chomeau, President

title: Operating Earnings Increase 9.5% at Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit from operations rose 9.5 percent, lifted by strong growth in advertising revenue at the company's flagship newspaper.

title: Graf, Feeling Ill, Bows Out Of Third Set With Capriati
description: Steffi Graf had moved Jennifer Capriati all over the court tonight at the A.&P. Tennis Classic, her wicked backhands delivered with the crushing swing of a samurai sword.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Employing the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, IRVING
description: WHITE-Irving. On July 14, 1999 at the age of 81. Husband of Barbara. Graveside service at Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, NORMAN
description: SCHNEIDER-Norman. Age 88 of New York City. Devoted husband to Jo Anne, adoring father of Lois Oppenheim and Melanie Tucker, and loving grandfather of Sarah and Keith Oppenheim. He founded and was President of Allison Manufacturing Company and later was President of the Leisure Products Division of the Beatrice Cos. He gave unstintingly of himself to many charitable institutions and professional associations, and served with distinction on various corporate boards. Services will be held on Monday, July 19th at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, at 12:00 noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the New York City Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th Floor, New York, New York 10017.

title: On Fire in Meadowlands: Springsteen Is Back
description: Every step of the way, it seems, Bruce Springsteen has managed to produce the perfect songs and perfect lyrics for the soundtrack to Matt Facendo's life.

title: Deal Suggested For Trade Group Post
description: A solution to end the deadlock over the next head of the World Trade Organization appeared closer today when a compromise proposal was introduced that would allow the two contenders to split one term.

title: BREWERY DEAL ON HOLD
description: The Brazilian Government's antitrust agency suspended the merger between the country's two largest breweries, Companhia Cervejaria Brahma and Companhia Antarctica Paulista, on concern the transaction stifles free competition. The move by the agency allows the Government 120 days to study the merger before making a more complete decision. The company created by Brahma and Antarctica, called the Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or Ambev, is expected to control up to 80 percent of Brazil's beer industry, making it the world's fourth-largest brewer.

title: The Parade Of Corporate Sponsors; Marketers Line Up to Link Their Names to Events
description: The recent Portland Rose Festival began with events like the Starlight Parade through downtown -- make that the Portland General Electric/Solv Starlight Parade Presented by Southwest Airlines.

description: D'AMICO-Margaret (nee Furst). Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Rita Basso and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Patricia Muirhead, John Basso, Dana and Taj D'Amico. Adored great grandmother of Ryan, Corey, Tatum, Justin, Chynna and Sea. Reposing Vanella's Chapels, 29 Madison St., NYC until Saturday, 8:30 AM. Mass of Resurrection, St. Joseph's Church, 10:00 AM.

title: Man Shoots 4 in Bronx And Then Drives Away
description: Four men were shot last night, one of them critically injured, on a Bronx sidewalk by a man who then drove off, the police said.

title: Near Detroit, a Familiar Sting in Being a Black Driver
description: The yuppie couple were driving home through the suburb of Royal Oak after dinner and a movie when a police car behind them turned on its lights and siren.

A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to The American Health Foundation, 320 East 43rd St, NY, NY 10017.

title: SBC-DirecTV Deal Is Set, Executives Say
description: Adding television to its portfolio of digital communications services, SBC Communications Inc., one of the nation's biggest local phone companies, has agreed to a wide-ranging marketing and distribution partnership with DirecTV Inc., the big satellite broadcaster, executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, AVERY
description: SILVERMAN-Avery. The officers and staff of United Jewish Communities deeply mourn the untimely passing of Avery Silverman, the niece of Carole Solomon, National Campaign Chairman for United Jewish Communities. She was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Silverman of Villanova, PA. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will help sustain the family during this difficult time. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman of the Executive Committee Stephen D. Solender, Acting President
