title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RENSSELAER, CHARLES A. III
description: VAN RENSSELAER-Charles A. III, 73 years old, from an historical New York family of great 17th century landowners, (a million acres) patroons, & revolutionary patriots, died this morning after an automobile accident in Palm Beach, FL, his residence for the past thirty years. His famous ancestor, Stephen Van Rensselaer, the last Patroon of Rensselaer Manor, founded Rensselaer Polytech College in Troy, N.Y. in 1824. He is survived by his brother Philip Van Rensselaer of Manhattan, N.Y. and his aunt Lillian Van Rensselaer of Locust Valley, N.Y. A Funeral Service will be held at 12:30 P.M. on Monday, July 19, 1999 at St. Edwards Catholic Church, Palm Beach. Private interment will take place at St. John's Cemetery in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. For more information, contact Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Woman in Child Servitude Case Faced a Neglect Complaint in 1988
description: A New York City child-abuse investigator accused of forcing a Nigerian girl into servitude and repeatedly beating her was the subject of a 1988 complaint that she had neglected another Nigerian girl living in her home, officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 7 about a protest in Santa Ana, Calif., against a Vietnamese art exhibition misidentified a flag that was shown. It was the flag of South Vietnam, not a prewar Vietnamese flag.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR REMAINS STEADY. The yen and the euro were little changed against the dollar. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.83 yen, up from 120.59 on Wednesday, while the euro traded at $1.0219, up from $1.0209.

title: Town Hushed in '95 Crackdown Sees No Reason to Join Iran Riots
description: For the young men on the streets of this dusty, crowded, unexceptional town south of Teheran, the nationwide unrest of the last week is little more than a remote spectacle on the nightly news.

description: Odd Nerdrum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, EDNA
description: ROGERS-Edna. May 21, 1918-July 15, 1999. We deeply mourn the loss of this most beloved partner in life of 60 years of Arthur. Mother of Anita, Julie, Ruth and Chris. Grandmother of Melissa, Aviva, Rebecca and Cameron. Sister of Sadie, Aunt and devoted friend. Her life was of gracious beauty, elegance, refinement, selfless generosity of heart and soul, love of music and the arts. She passed on to her children and grandchildren the appreciation of living life to its fullest. Funeral services at 12 Noon, Friday, July 16 at Lincoln Square Synagogue, 200 Amsterdam Ave at 69 St, NYC. Interment in Netanya, Israel. Shivah begins Monday, July 19 through Friday Noon July 23 at the Rogers' home, 315 West 70 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Jewish National Fund, Rogers Family Project #

title: The Virtue of Cool
description: When hot weather dulls the appetite, it's time to seek out those cuisines that specialize in beating the heat. Here are 12 restaurants for times when the going gets sweaty. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: U.S. in a Push To Bar Vaccine Given to Infants
description: Federal health officials yesterday called for the immediate suspension of a vaccine recently recommended for all infants to protect against rotavirus, the most common cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOAN, ARTHUR B. JR
description: TOAN-Arthur B. Jr, 84, of Saddle River, NJ, died Tuesday, July 13, 1999. Magna Cum Laude Graduate of Dartmouth College Class of '36. Retired National Director of Management Advisory Services and Partner of Price Waterhouse Coopers. Author of more than 75 articles & three books on management oriented topics. Survived by his wife Ethel and children Marion Jones and Donald, two grandchildren. Memorial Service will be held August 7, 1999, at 10 AM at the Unitarian Society of Ridgewood, Ridgewood, NJ. For information, contact C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ 201-445-0344

title: U.S. Tries to Play Down China's Announcement on Bomb
description: Seeking to contain a growing crisis in Asia, the Clinton Administration tried today to play down the timing and significance of China's declaration that it had developed on its own the ability to make neutron bombs and miniature atomic weapons.

title: Prosecutor in Pedophile Case Kills Himself : Belgian Official's Death Puts Top Cases On Hold
description: BRUSSELS  The death of a top prosecutor, apparently as the result of suicide, threw doubts Thursday over Belgium's two most prominent criminal investigations and forced Belgians to revisit some of the darker moments of their country's recent history.

title: Coca-Cola Earnings Fall 21%, Reflecting Troubles in Europe
description: In part because it had to pull millions of soft drinks off the market in Europe last month, the Coca-Cola Company's second-quarter profit fell 21 percent, the company said yesterday.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: New Category For Papa's Writing

title: He's Imagining How Well You'd Fit Beneath His Skin
description: Despite the D.O.A. nature of the genre it satirizes, the demon crocodile movie ''Lake Placid'' finds a good deal to work with in newly reptile-plagued Maine. As written by David E. Kelley with tongue firmly in cheek, it provides a good cast with the challenge of keeping straight faces.

title: Elizabeth Arden campaign strives for the unconventional.
description: THE Elizabeth Arden Company received some alarming news earlier this year when it heard the results of a study of consumer attitudes about its company and the beauty industry.

title: Inflation Didn't Budge in June, U.S. Says
description: In the middle of the ninth year of one of the longest economic booms in United States history, the rate of inflation is precisely zero.

title: LUCENT TO BUY SPECTRAN FOR $64 MILLION
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Spectran Corporation, a maker of fiber optics products, for $64 million. It will also assume $35 million in debt. Lucent, the big telecommunications equipment maker, said it would pay $9 a share for Spectran, considerably below its closing price on Wednesday. Yesterday, Spectran's stock fell $2.625, or 22.8 percent, to $8.875. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., said the purchase of Spectran would support the growth of its fiber optic business. Spectran, of Sturbridge, Mass., employs about 500 people.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; On the Blacktop, a Kind of Sweat Equity
description: Natasha Green was in the Cage, and, to the surprise of the assembled spectators, she was surviving. Crouched low with her arms out splayed, she stayed with her man as he tried to switch directions and drive to the basket. Reaching out her hand, she poked the ball loose as he headed by, stripping him clean. Corralling the basketball near midcourt, she turned, took five hard dribbles and burst back to the basket for a layup.

title: State Courts Sweeping Away Laws Curbing Suits for Injury
description: More than a decade after states began enacting laws to cut back big jury awards and curtail injury lawsuits, state courts across the country are overturning one measure after another, concluding that Americans have a powerful right to settle their disputes in court.

title: 55% Rise in Boeing Profits Far Exceeds the Predictions
description: The Boeing Company delivered stronger-than-expected earnings for the second consecutive quarter yesterday and raised its estimates of future profits, giving its beleaguered investors new hope after two years of disappointments.

title: Bedroom Odyssey
description: GIVEN the grippingly bizarre settings and situations that Stanley Kubrick's films favored, what could be more startling than the scene that opens ''Eyes Wide Shut''? It's only the sight of two people who resemble glamorous movie stars getting ready for a black-tie party. ''How do I look?'' she asks, and he says she looks perfect -- even though she is perched on a toilet wearing eyeglasses with her evening gown, and he is too busy studying himself in a mirror to notice. Look no further than this for a sense of what this film's title signifies, or how craftily its illusions of intimacy seduce the viewer.

title: Album of the Week
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Monster Ballads'' (Razor and Tie). In a startling demonstration of just how strong warped memories can be, the 16-song retail version of this 1980's pop-metal anthology (also available as a double disk through television and Internet promotions) recently made its debut at No. 29 in the Billboard Top 200. Thousands are revisiting the pinnacles of schmaltz reached by the androgynous demigods of Winger, Whitesnake, Poison and Extreme. This once-shunned oeuvre is being reclaimed as great pop theater that outclasses today's stupid kid stuff.

title: Clinton Tells Colorado Youths He'll Stand Fast on Gun Control
description: President Clinton said today that he would veto the juvenile-justice bill if it emerged from Congress with provisions that weakened existing gun controls.

title: Excerpts From Debate on Lawsuits Over Health Care
description: Following are excerpts from remarks today by Senators Harry Reid of Nevada and Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, both Democrats, and Slade Gorton of Washington and Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Republicans, in the debate on a patients' bill of rights as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: CANADIAN DRUG MAKER OFFERS TO BUY SCANDIPHARM
description: A Canadian pharmaceutical company, Axcan Pharma Inc., said yesterday that it had offered to buy Scandipharm Inc., an American maker of drugs to treat gastrointestinal problems, for $85 million. Axcan, of Mont Saint-Hilaire, Quebec, has distributed Scandipharm's products in Canada since September 1997. The company said it would make Scandipharm, of Birmingham, Ala., the center of its United States operations. Axcan said Scandipharm had 1998 revenue of more than $24 million. Axcan said its offer was higher than that of a competing bidder, identified by a Scandipharm spokesman as the Trilobite Lakes Corporation, a unit of the LHC Corporation.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Long before fusion, there was Malaysian.

description: GOLDBERG-Evelyn, nee Gamson of Port Chester, NY on July 14. Wife of the late Jerry Goldberg, loving mother of Nadalyn Rosenberg & Edward Goldberg, motherin-law of Bruce McDowell and Barbara Saidel, devoted grandmother of Caren, Deborah, Anna, Isaac, Steve and Robert. Greatgrandmother of Sam and Isabelle. Evelyn brought light & music into our lives. Funeral service Friday 1PM at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, 575 King Street, Port Chester, New York. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, RUTH
description: POST-Ruth. On July 15, 1999 at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Emil. Loving mother of Richard and David and their wives Carol Post and Katlean Demonchy. Adored grandmother of Cynthia, Steven, Pamela, Randee, Lori and Jill and great-grandmother of Ethan, Matthew, Katlin, Julia, Blake, Samantha and Grant. Dear sister of Marcy. Cryptside service Sunday, July 18, 11:00 AM at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ.

title: Ireland's Precarious Peace
description: Northern Ireland's main Protestant Unionist party took only 15 minutes on Wednesday to reject London's latest compromise plan for peace. The rejection effectively shuts down the major aspects of the peace agreement signed on Good Friday of last year. For now, there will be no transfer of governing power from London to a local Assembly in Belfast with all parties represented. There will be no gradual disarmament by the Irish Republican Army. Instead, Northern Ireland enters a dangerous period when terrorism on both sides could make future compromise even stickier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RAYMINNIE MARKS
description: FRIEDMAN-Rayminnie Marks, July 13, 1999. Age 84. Beloved wife of the late Chester S. Friedman. Loving mother of Joseph Friedman & Rita Aron. Adoring grandmother of Jonathan and Timothy Aron and Michael and David Friedman. Dedicated volunteer to many charities and past president of The Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El. Funeral service will be held on Friday, July 16th, 10AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Womens Auxiliary or The Sunday Lunch Program of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Behind Umpires' Bold Move Is the Belief That Baseball's Risk Is Bigger
description: They saw a fight coming and decided that they, and not their employers, would pick the time and place to start it. Now baseball's major league umpires, whose letters of resignation, effective Sept. 2, were sent by fax to the league offices yesterday, will wait to learn if they have taken too great a risk.

title: BUCKEYE TECHNOLOGIES BUYING FINNISH OPERATIONS
description: Buckeye Technologies Inc., the largest maker of paper for automobile filters, said yesterday that it would buy most of the assets of the Walkisoft nonwovens business of the Finnish company UPM-Kymmene for $120 million in cash. The Memphis-based Buckeye said it would pay for the deal in installments over the next four years, with an initial payment of $32 million. Nonwovens are absorbent products made from a special form of cellulose. They include feminine hygiene and adult incontinence products and disposable household goods. UPM, Europe's No. 2 forest-products company, is based in Helsinki, Finland. Buckeye's stock rose $1.75 a share, to $16.50.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the effect of potential tax cuts on the economy misstated the proposal of Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida. His plan calls for $766 billion in cuts over 10 years, with $137 billion of that amount coming in the first five years, not a total of $137 billion for the decade.

title: Caddies Allowed To Wear Shorts
description: Caddies will be allowed to wear shorts at PGA Tour events on extremely hot days beginning next week, said Andy Pazder, the PGA Tour's director of administration for competitions. The change of policy comes after a caddie collapsed at the Western Open earlier this month.

title: A Thematic Feast of Avant-Garde Videos
description: Of the many unsettling images to be seen in the New York Video Festival, a weeklong series that begins today at the Walter Reade Theater, none is more provocative than the actress Kate Valk as the title character in the Wooster Group's production of Eugene O'Neill's play ''The Emperor Jones.'' Wearing blackface and a Kabuki costume, rolling her eyes and writhing before the camera like a voodoo apparition in Asian theatrical drag, the Caucasian actress adopts a cartoonishly oratorical drawl to intone the character's ravingly paranoid dialogue. Layer upon layer of calculated artifice combine to create a clashing theatrical dissonance that is further complicated by the raw emotional power erupting behind these multiple facades.

title: Reuters Says It Won't Face Federal Charges
description: Federal prosecutors will not charge Reuters Holdings P.L.C. with improperly obtaining information from a big competitor, Bloomberg L.P., Reuters said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Europe's Ambivalent Sister Gazes Across the Channel
description: THIS BLESSED PLOTBritain and Europe From Churchill to BlairBy Hugo YoungIllustrated. 558 pages. Overlook Press. $39.95.

title: What Can You Do at Death's Door? You Can Laugh
description: Although ''I'm Losing You'' was adapted from Bruce Wagner's scabrous, razor-sharp Hollywood novel by Mr. Wagner himself, it bears surprisingly slender resemblance to his book. Acerbic as it is, Mr. Wagner's first film is still very much the watered-down version. That ought to be enough, since on film, ''I'm Losing You'' unfolds in a doom-tinged, AIDS-minded milieu where the sardonic quips fly like tennis balls.

title: A Cash Vow for Mrs. Clinton
description: At a breakfast meeting with the First Lady, 75 New York Democrats pledged to raise $25 million for her expected race for Senator. Page B1.

title: No Russian Spoken Here
description: The very day that Latvia's new President, Vaira Vike-Freiberga, was sworn in last week, she faced a harsh test requiring considerable moral courage. That day, the Latvian Parliament passed by an overwhelming majority a measure that not only would have virtually banished the Russian language from public life in Latvia, but would have introduced severe restrictions into the private sphere as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIN, DORIS
description: FLORIN-Doris, of Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of Seymour; devoted mother of Steve, Roberta, Richard and Ilene; stepmother of Barry; adored grandmother of Douglas, Matthew, Jennifer, Todd and Jared. Beloved sister of Lola. Services will be held at BoulevardRiverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Sunday, July 18, at 2:30 PM.

title: Della Femina/Jeary Ends a Relationship
description: Della Femina/Jeary & Partners unexpectedly said yesterday that it would end its monthlong relationship with American Media Inc. by resigning the assignment to handle advertising for The National Enquirer. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARIL, BEVERLY
description: GARIL-Beverly. Devoted wife of Herbert. Loving & adored mother of Cindi Kristich and Scott. Dearest sister of Harry Nussbaum. Cherished grandmother. Services on Friday, at 9:45 A.M., Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OGDEN CORP., New York, which has businesses ranging from theme parks to garbage-burning power plants to aircraft services, agreed to buy the closely held Compagnie Transair, based outside Paris, to expand its aircraft operation in Europe and Africa. Terms were not disclosed.

title: One Agreement in Ulster: Assembly Session Is a Farce
description: What was supposed to have been the most important day in the evolving Northern Ireland peace agreement became today a scene of chaos, farce and recrimination.

title: Authorities Say Insurance Suspect May Be in Italy
description: Federal authorities on the trail of the suspected insurance swindler Martin R. Frankel have tracked wire transfers of nearly half a million dollars to Rome and are focusing on the possibility that he is hiding in Italy, a country integral to his complex financial dealings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, FORSTER, BRIGID
description: O'HARA-FORSTER -Brigid. Suddenly, but peacefully in London on July 5th in her 52nd year. An associate editor for Time, she will be terribly missed by colleagues, friends and family in London, New York and around the world. She was predeceased by her parents, Mary Gauntlett O'Hara-Forster and Michael O'Hara-Forster, and survived by her adopted family, stepmother, Phebe Bowditch, stepbrother and sister-in-law, Richard Lyon Bowditch and Carol Scott Bowditch, stepsister and brother-in-law, Dr. Phebe Lowell Bowditch and Andrew Bourne Sibley and four god-children, Alexandra Scott Bowditch and Charlotte Louise Bowditch, Sophie Eleanor McManus and Mage Caroline McManus. Memorial services will be held in London and New York in the fall.

title: Britons Exclaim, 'Mamma Mia!'
description: Since April fans have been flocking from Eton, from Essex, from Cornwall, and probably Cornball, too, all seeking a fix from that most palindromic and hummable of Europop groups, Abba.

title: A Passion For Manuscripts
description: Although illuminated medieval manuscripts are considered an arcane collecting category, they have attracted considerable attention recently.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, DOROTHY (POSNIK)
description: WARD-Dorothy (Posnik). Of Westwood, MA, formerly of Jackson Heights, NY, July 14. Loving mother of Alan of Westwood, MA. Beloved by four grandchildren & four great-grandchildren. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, LI, Sunday. Donations may be made in Dorothy's name to Friends of Queens Library or WNYC.

title: U.S. Anxiety Imperils NATO Fighter-Pilot Training in Canada
description: Mounting concern in the United States over the export of military technology without adequate controls is threatening an ambitious new program to train fighter pilots from several NATO countries in the vast skies over Western Canada.

title: Kubrick, Edited
description: Stanley Kubrick's last film, ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' will be shown in the United States with several sex scenes altered so it can carry an R rating instead of the far more restrictive NC-17.

title: A Change of Pace but Still in Step
description: For a contemporary rhythm-and-blues show, where backup tapes and the faithful replication of studio singles are usually de rigueur, Whitney Houston's two-hour performance at the Theater at Madison Square Garden was remarkably unscripted. Nearly every song was rearranged live, with the band waiting for Ms. Houston as she isolated a line and made it a wailing crescendo or paused mid-song to talk with fans. When guest stars like Brandy and Luther Vandross joined Ms. Houston on ''Exhale (Shoop Shoop),'' they didn't emerge from the wings: they were called from their seats in the audience and sang with Ms. Houston from the foot of the stage.

description: Vestiges of the ancients are cropping up all over.

Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

description: Russians may be divided sharply on whether the Soviet era was the ''good old days.'' But it is the time when most of them were young.

description: Ibrahim Rugova, leader of a decade of principled, but largely futile, nonviolent resistance to Serbian domination, returned here today to a political landscape that was at once transformed and confused.

title: Test Aloft Gives Pilots Glimpse of Tomorrow
description: Five thousand feet over the rolling farm country of southern Ohio, it was obvious to the test pilot of the Federal Aviation Administration's biggest research plane that the airborne experiment under way could change the nature of air traffic control.

title: A Series of Concussions Makes Beukeboom Quit
description: The Rangers' evolution continued in force yesterday. Jeff Beukeboom, the tough defenseman who was an integral part of the 1994 Stanley Cup championship team, announced his retirement. Hours later the Rangers signed Tim Taylor, a free-agent center. And the team is apparently on the verge of signing Sylvain Lefebvre, a free-agent defenseman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, HARRY
description: LEIBOWITZ-Harry, 96, on July 14. Leaves sons Michael (Sharon), and Philip (Leann) and four grandchildren. Services Friday, Crabiel Park West, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: To Aid Euro, Bank May Favor Rise in Rates
description: In a move that helped push up the sagging value of the euro against the dollar, the head of the European Central Bank signaled today that it might toughen monetary policy in the not-too-distant future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLOZZA, JOSEPH
description: COLOZZA-Joseph, suddenly on July 14, 1999 in Florida at the age of 58. Devoted husband of Valentine, beloved father of Rosemarie and Joseph. Cherished brother of Julie Porcelli and Robert. Mr. Colozza was a member of the Board of Directors of the Downtown Athletic Club. He was Vice President of Local 1814 I.L.A. and Vice President of Longshoremans Atlantic Coast Division. Funeral Mass is on Saturday, July 17th, at 2 P.M., at Ascension Catholic Church, Boca Raton, Florida. In repose Babione Funeral Home, 1100 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, Florida 33432. Phone 561-395-8787.

description: WERFEL-Elsie. Lido Beach Synagogue mourns the passing of Elsie Werfel, beloved mother of our esteemed member, Judy Etra. Daniel H. Mehlman, Rabbi

title: Advice (and a Meal) for Future Entrepreneurs
description: Imagine that as part of an inner-city summer-school project, your class had come up with an idea for a fantasy restaurant called Channel Surferz, a Times Square theme eatery boasting a disco room, a sports bar and an abundance of video screens.

title: Co-Chairmen Resign From Warner Bros.
description: Robert A. Daly and Terry Semel, the co-chairmen of Warner Brothers, announced their resignations yesterday, ending one of the most stable and successful relationships with a studio in Hollywood history.

title: Councilman Is Urged to Resign Over Comment About Jews
description: A local official's remark at an Independence Day celebration that many in his audience considered anti-Semitic has provoked calls for his resignation.

description: ''After looking at the numbers, cash on hand of $30 million, I've decided not to accept Federal matching funds during the course of this campaign.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLOW, ALVIN
description: CAPLOW-Alvin. Gracious, original, intelligent, charming, elegant, interesting, fun, stubborn, best friend. Happy Birthday. Mil

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Mark O'Brien, the subject of an Academy Award-winning documentary about his journalism career, conducted mostly from an iron lung, referred incorrectly to an editor for whom he worked. The editor, Sandy Close, is a woman.

title: Tiniest Circuits Hold Prospect Of Explosive Computer Speeds
description: Plunging deeply into a Lilliputian world that promises ultrafast, low-power computers, a research team has for the first time fashioned simple computing components no thicker than a single molecule.

title: Tax Refund Won't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Grief and Tiananmen Square
description: One of the most interesting aspects of the Asia-Pacific Contemporary Dance Festival at Kaye Playhouse has been the stories of how each of the four modern-dance troupes was founded. The Taipei Crossover Dance Company of Taiwan, which performed on Wednesday night, was founded in 1994 by a leading Taiwanese lighting designer, Lin Keh-hua, and four veteran members of the Cloud Gate Dance Theater. Cloud Gate, one of the oldest modern-dance companies in Asia, was created by Lin Hwai-min, a writer who became enamored with American modern dance as a student in New York.

title: Questions on Doping Shadow Armstrong
description: Lance Armstrong has heard the rumors and doubts.

title: Grey Wins Oracle Worldwide Account
description: The Oracle Corporation yesterday named Grey Advertising to handle its worldwide account, including advertising, media and strategic services. Billings were estimated at $75 million to $90 million.

title: VICTOR IN MORLAND BATTLE
description: The British company Greene King P.L.C. appears to have won the battle to take over the pub company Morland P.L.C. after a rival bidder, Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries P.L.C., withdrew from the battle. Greene King earlier raised its offer for Morland to $:182 million ($284.6 million), the equivalent of 540 pence a share, topping a W.& D. bid worth around $:174 million pounds ($272 million). W&D said that it believed its offer for Morland was full and fair and it did not intend to increase it.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Lost and Found'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTSKY, MARTIN
description: LUTSKY-Martin. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Jay and Teri Lutsky, Susan and Robert Scheinman and Barry Lutsky. Cherished grandfather. Loving brother of Leah and Howard Matican and Jerry and Brenda Levine. Dear Uncle and friend. Services today 12 noon ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Tussling Over Tobacco Money, Forgetting the Victims
description: My lung cancer was diagnosed last November after I'd felt unusually tired for a few weeks and had been fighting what I thought was just a cold. No, I don't smoke; nor do many thousands of people who are found to have this disease each year. But I stand to benefit from the same kind of medical research that would help someone with a three-pack-a-day habit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTELL, GEORGE L. (GERRY.)
description: MANTELL-George L. (Gerry.) Passed away peacefully in Palm Coast, FL, July 13, 1999. Formerly of New York. He is survived by his wife Shirley, his sons James and Robert and his daughter Patricia, his sister Harriet Gordan, grandchildren Alison, Steven & Ernest. Services Friday 2PM at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Bar Clarifies Conduct Rules For Lawyers In New York
description: The New York State Bar Association yesterday announced changes in its code of conduct, clarifying rules on how aggressively lawyers can solicit clients, barring lawyers from coercing sex from clients, and liberalizing the restrictions on when lawyers can talk to the press.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOBENFELD, RUTH
description: LOBENFELD-Ruth. It's 13 years, Babe, and you're still the one and only. Your love, Hone

title: Gillette Reports 19% Drop in Net Income
description: The Gillette Company, reeling from weakness in its international business and the dismal performance of some product lines, reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that matched Wall Street's previously lowered expectations.

title: Backers Set Record Goal For First Lady
description: Settling in for what is shaping up as the costliest Congressional contest in the nation's history, 75 New York Democrats sat down for breakfast with Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday and pledged to raise $25 million to finance her expected race for Senator from New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOZWICKI, STEPHEN J., REV.
description: JOZWICKI-Stephen J., Rev. Parochial Vicar of Our Lady of Czestochowa/St. Casimir's Church on July 13, 1999. Beloved son of the late Tiofil and Apolonia. Dear brother of Helen Collins and the late Alexander and Edward. Devoted uncle of many nieces and nephews. Reposing Trzaska Funeral Home, Inc., 6741 5th Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11220. Visiting Friday & Saturday 2-9, Sunday 2-5. Mass of Tranferral 7:30PM, Sunday at Our Lady of Czestochowa/St. Casimir's Church. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10:30AM. Interment to follow at St. Johns Cemetery. For information call 718-748-4860.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Smaller Computer Chips Promise Big Leap in Speed

title: Essay; Whitewash At Justice
description: The most dramatic clash between the F.B.I. and the heavily politicized Reno Department of Justice took place in February 1997.

title: A Night of Many Returns As the Boss Comes Home
description: It would have been very difficult to leave the Continental Airlines Arena disappointed tonight, when Bruce Springsteen began his first American tour with the E Street Band in 10 years. If Mr. Springsteen's work is a journey -- and it is, not just in his close relationship with his fans but also for the characters whose development he follows from album to album -- then tonight's three-hour, 26-song show stopped at nearly all points on the map.

title: Chief Executive Named at Nextel
description: Nextel Communications Inc., a nationwide provider of wireless phone services, named Tim Donahue chief executive as Daniel Akerson moved to work for Nextel's top shareholder, Craig McCaw.

title: Why Polygraphs Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau G.O.P. Says It Seeks Oversight In Bailout
description: Breaking with County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta over Nassau's deepening financial crisis, Republicans in the County Legislature say they will propose some form of fiscal oversight on Friday to help bring discipline to Mr. Gulotta's budgets.

title: An Old Fort's Last Protector; Veteran Keeps Totten, an Army Relic, From Fading Away
description: Jack Fein doesn't tell war stories. He doesn't tell love stories, either.

title: BID FOR PUBS WITHDRAWN
description: Ending a seesawing battle for control of Allied Domecq P.L.C.'s British pubs, Whitbread P.L.C. withdrew its $:2.84 billion ($4.43 billion) offer for the 3,500 pubs after Stephen Byers, the British Government minister in charge of competion issues, decided to investigate it. The move left Punch Taverns Group Ltd. as the sole suitor. Allied's board had endorsed Whitbread's bid, despite a higher offer of $:2.93 billion ($4.56 billion) offer from Punch Taverns. Whitbread's stock was up 3.7 percent, to 963 pence ($15), and Allied Domecq's shares rose 12 pence, to 587.5 pence ($9.16).

title: Perfect Timing For Kubrick Set
description: Adept at the commemorative tie-in, video has scored impressively with the Stanley Kubrick collection, 10 films released collaboratively on videocassette and digital video disk by Warner, Columbia Tri-Star and MGM/UA. A boxed set of seven of the films on DVD, priced at $149.92, is already on best-seller lists, with interest fanned by Kubrick's death in March and the opening today of his last film, ''Eyes Wide Shut'' (review on page 1 of Weekend).

title: Metro Business; Westin Hotel Is Sold
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had sold the Westin Central Park South hotel in New York City to Bass Hotels and Resorts for $62.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEUTEL, ISIDOR
description: BEUTEL-Isidor. On July 15, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Bella. Loving father of Linda and dear father-in-law or Martin Kish. He will be deeply missed. Service Friday, 1:30PM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Impatient Fans Boo Clemens at Stadium
description: Yankee fans have waited half a season for Roger Clemens to pitch like someone destined for the Hall of Fame. They have waited for Clemens to respond to big moments, in the way David Wells responded before being traded for Clemens.

title: When Humbler Hands Picked Up the Russian Tradition of Icon Painting
description: Shows of Russian icons, sacred images painted on panels, usually in the flat, frontal Byzantine style, do not pop up too often in this country. What is left of the great icons, produced from medieval times through the 17th century, is for the most part firmly ensconced in Russian churches and museums.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: INSIDE
description: A 'Farce' in Belfast

title: New Form Allows for 401(K) Cost Checks
description: Small-business owners can compare costs of 401(k) plans offered by mutual fund, insurance and banking firms using a new form developed by the three industries in cooperation with the Labor Department.

title: Despite Hisses of Detractors, Mayor Signs Lead-Paint Bill
description: First, doctors and scientists argued that a bill intended to protect children from lead poisoning would actually put them in more danger than they are now. Then, parents and tenants made impassioned pleas. And when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani remained unmoved, they resorted to hissing loudly at him yesterday from the back of the public hearing room in City Hall.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Patient Rights and Wrongs
description: With impressive but wrongheaded discipline, Senate Republicans have rejected a series of attempts to protect the rights of patients enrolled in managed-care health programs. Despite reams of opinion surveys suggesting that the public wants reform in this area, the Republicans chose to protect insurers, health maintenance organizations and businesses at the expense of patients.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Pepon Osorio

title: Book Editor Missing Near Seattle
description: Search teams using bloodhounds and a helicopter combed trails on Mount Rainier near Seattle yesterday, looking for Joseph Wood Jr., a New York City book editor last seen walking on the mountain slopes on July 8.

title: Angry Serbs Hear a New Explanation: It's All Russia's Fault
description: Serbian generals, touring the country to stanch protests and dismantle roadblocks set up by angry army reservists owed money for duty in Kosovo, are dousing one rebellious fire after another.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Republican tax proposal in the Senate referred incorrectly to the current rates. The 15 percent bracket applies to taxable income up to $25,750 for single people and $43,050 for married couples filing jointly, not to adjusted gross income -- that is, income before the standard or itemized deductions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, ROBERT K.
description: RAISLER-Robert K. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Robert K. Raisler, a magnanimous friend whose dedication to the Jewish people will long be remembered. A witness to the turmoil and trials of the Twentieth Century, he supported the fledgling State of Israel at her birth, remaining ever steadfast in his devotion to Jews in need throughout the world. We extend our sincere sympathy to all the members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Davis Cup Lineups Have Sampras Only in Doubles
description: History was in the air today at the Longwood Cricket Club, site of the first Davis Cup competition in 1900 and of a centenary quarterfinal between the United States and Australia this weekend. But Pete Sampras, now a six-time Wimbledon champion and arguably the greatest player in tennis history, will apparently not take a singles role in the encounter between Davis Cup's two superpowers, despite speculation that the United States had a secret weapon waiting in the wings.

title: Belgian Racer Makes a Move
description: Ludo Dierckxsen of Belgium and the Lampre team won the 11th stage of the Tour de France, a 123.3-mile stretch through darkly wooded hills from Le Bourg d'Oisans to St. Etienne, by 1 minute 26 seconds today over Dmitri Konyshev of Russia and Aleksandr Vinokourov of Kazakstan, and he finished 22:18 ahead of the pack.

title: Men in Blue Become the Story on Two Fronts
description: Jim Evans spotted a dozen reporters congregated near the umpires' room at Yankee Stadium about an hour before last night's game between the Yankees and the Braves. They were waiting to interview the umpires, who had submitted their resignations effective Sept. 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATTON, EDDIE
description: CATTON-Eddie. The Officers and Board of Trustees of the Magen David Yeshivah, Isaac Shalom Elementary School and Celia Esses High School, mourn the untimely passing of Eddie Catton, a devoted, generous and highly respected friend of the Yeshivah. We extend our sincere sympathies to his wife, Frieda, daughters, Rochelle Catton and Melanie Shalam, son, Sammy Catton, parents, Rae and Sam Catton, and brother, Harry Catton. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Catton family at this difficult time. Eddie J. Esses Steven D. Shamah Co-Presidents

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUBERT, PEGGY ANN
description: HAUBERT-Peggy Ann. With great sorrow we mourn the passing of our dedicated, loved and highly respected employee and friend for over twenty years. We offer our sincere condolences to her family and friends. May her memory be a source of love and inspiration for all of us. We will miss her greatly. May she rest in peace. Boulevard Funeral Home, New Milford, NJ (201) 692-0100. Calling hours: Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday, July 19, 10AM, Ascension Church, New Milford. The Department of Surgery, Columbia Presbyterian Center, New York Presbyterian Hospital

title: Portraits of the Superstar Artists, Displaying Charity Toward None
description: In 1950 Hans Namuth took hundreds of photographs of Jackson Pollock painting on his barn floor. Soon Pollock was an American icon. Was it because of his paintings or because of the photographs of him solemnly drizzling paint on canvas and sullenly smoking on the running board of his pickup truck?

title: Marriage Loses In 'Divorce Culture'
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Polls Answer a Political Need?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Maine's Coast, Vistas Are Cast in Stone
description: Like the grandeur of the West, the mountainous coast of Maine was viewed in the 19th century as a vast, untouched wilderness, even though the lands had been well trodden and shaped by Indian populations. Leading ultimately to the creation of the national parks, this perception -- call it the American picturesque -- consisted of an appreciation of natural forms of scenery that overwhelmed scattered travelers and Government expeditions by its ruggedness and austerity. Artists and chroniclers found these views particularly uplifting when enhanced by the dramatic rhythms of rough surf and spectacular sunsets.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Fund-Raising Is Furious By Candidates for Mayor
description: In some of the earliest and most furious campaign fund-raising in New York City history, the major Democrats planning to run for mayor reported yesterday that they were already building formidable war chests more than two years before the September 2001 primary.

title: Tax Refund Won't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stock index funds have finally started to lose their allure for investors seeking peak performances.
description: FICKLE, fickle.

title: Religious Rights Bill Gains
description: Despite concerns that it could be cited as sanction for bias against homosexuals, a religious freedom bill won House passage. Page A16.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Liz Deschenes, Kevin Larmon and Donald Moffett

title: Leslie Alexis Marchand, 99, Leading Biographer of Byron
description: Leslie Alexis Marchand, considered the leading authority on the poet Lord Byron, died on Sunday at his home in Englewood, Fla. He was 99.

title: NOVARTIS SEES SLOWER SALES
description: The world's No. 2 drug maker, Novartis A.G., said gains in drug sales will slow in the next quarter, adding to declines in its crop-protection business, which stalled growth in overall second-quarter revenue. The company said its second-quarter sales rose 1.7 percent to 8.43 billion Swiss francs ($5.36 billion) from 8.29 billion francs ($5.25 billion) a year earlier, in line with analysts' expectations. The 1998 figure excludes food units Novartis sold in the last 12 months.

title: EASTERN ENTERPRISES AGREES TO BUY ENERGYNORTH
description: Eastern Enterprises said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire EnergyNorth Inc. for $47 a share in stock and cash, a total of about $156 million. It will also assume debt of $45.6 million. Eastern, based in Weston, Mass., is the holding company for the Boston Gas Company and Midland Enterprises Inc., a marine transportation provider. It had 1998 sales of $935.3 million. EnergyNorth, based in Manchester, N.H., distributes natural gas in New Hampshire and Vermont and has annual sales of about $115 million. EnergyNorth shares soared $13.5625, to $43.25, while Eastern Enterprises fell $1.375, to $38.625.

title: Ernst Wynder, 77, a Cancer Researcher, Dies
description: Dr. Ernst Ludwig Wynder, who was the founding president of the American Health Foundation and who posted early warnings of cancers for smokers, died on Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan and in Westport, Conn.

title: Spenser, That Wry Sleuth, Is Once More on the Case
description: Not only is Spenser the toughest private eye who ever broke another tough guy's nose with the flick of a knuckle, but he's quick with a quotation, whether from Matthew Arnold or Rhett Butler. His main problem in Sunday's zesty A&E adaptation of ''Small Vices,'' Robert B. Parker's 24th novel, is another tough guy, known as ''the Gray Man,'' who's out to kill Spenser. Nothing personal, unless you happen to be on the receiving end of the Gray Man's sharpshooting.

title: Stanley Durwood, 78, Inventor of Multiplex
description: Stanley H. Durwood, an entertainment industry executive who is credited with inventing the multiplex movie theater, died Wednesday night at his Kansas City, Mo., home after a two-year illness. He was 78.

title: Atlanta's Mayor Defies Threat to End Affirmative Action
description: As their city faced a threat of lawsuit by a conservative group that has campaigned pointedly against race-based preferences for most of a decade, hundreds of black Atlantans let loose their ''amens'' today at a City Hall rally called by the Mayor in defiance of the threat of a lawsuit to end the city's affirmative action program.

title: Police Officer Is Charged With More Sex Crimes
description: A veteran New Jersey police officer accused last Friday of molesting three young girls was charged yesterday with sexually abusing two others seven years ago.

title: F.B.I. Faulted Over Files on China's Election Role
description: An internal Justice Department report has found that the F.B.I. and Federal prosecutors mishandled highly classified intelligence on accusations that China improperly tried to influence American elections.

title: Hunky Erotics in a Steamy (Manhattan) Never-Never Land
description: When the handsome, blond title character of ''The Velocity of Gary (Not His Real Name)'' is first glimpsed in the film, he is sashaying bare-chested through the streets of Greenwich Village flirting shamelessly with everyone who catches his eye. Before long this smirking midnight cowboy (Thomas Jane) winds up in the vicinity of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where he rescues a drag queen fresh off the bus who has just been beaten up by some gay-bashing teen-agers. He literally picks her up out of the gutter, slings her over his shoulder and strides off into the sunset.

title: ADVANCED COMMUNICATIONS SELLING UNIT TO COMPASS
description: Advanced Communications Group Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its telecommunications operations to the closely held Compass Telecommunications Inc. for $49.8 million in cash to focus on its yellow pages business. The St. Louis-based Advanced Communications is acquiring the print directory company Yptel Corporation, the Web site production company Big Stuff Inc. and Webyp Inc., which does business as Worldpages.com. Advanced Communications rose 25 cents, to $9.375.

title: Is That Risotto in My Ice Cream?
description: On the grapevine some years ago, I heard about a local chef who was offering a ''Tunafish Napoleon, Wasabi Vinaigrette'' on his menu. This strange-sounding concoction piqued my curiosity, so I decided to conduct my own personal taste-testing. I was pleasantly surprised that the dish was more of a salad than a traditional napoleon, and I have become one of this chef's biggest fans.

title: The China Cloud: Is a Bomb Being Waved at Taiwan?
description: Buried in a tiresome-looking 36-page Government report lay what appeared to be a minor scientific detail, almost invisible because it was mentioned so casually, in a passing reference three sentences long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT P.
description: BLUM-Robert P. Died Monday, July 12, 1999. Bob, an alumnus of Williams College, was a broadcast journalist, editor and producer for the three major television networks and Prodigy. He is survived by his mother, Ray, his children, Jennifer, Lesley and Joey, son-inlaw, Sean Cronin, his former wife, Frances, his companion, Arlene Spiller and his sister, Judy. Memorial service on Tuesday, July 27, 3:30PM, at Campbell's, 81st and Madison Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Guiding Eyes For The Blind, Yorktown Heights, New York.

title: Beauty and Beasts in the Rural South
description: It is unlikely that Tennessee Williams ever thought of ''Tiger Tail'' as a viable theatrical work, and the production mounted at the Harold Clurman Theater by Randy Becker and Middleschmertz Productions suggests it isn't. The text is simply a stage reduction of the script Williams wrote for the 1956 film ''Baby Doll,'' and that script in turn was cobbled together from two one-act plays, ''The Unsatisfactory Supper'' and ''27 Wagons Full of Cotton.'' ''Tiger Tail'' was simply meant to bring in some extra cash for the playwright after the film became a success.

title: E.P.A. Finds Broken Rules At Coal Plants, Officials Say
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has found that several electric companies have violated the terms under which their coal plants were ''grandfathered'' under the Clean Air Act by making major changes to produce more power without installing the required pollution controls, Federal officials said.

title: Good, Honest Folk, Savvy and Far From Highfalutin
description: The New York State Historical Association, perched over Lake Otsego, the Glimmerglass of James Fenimore Cooper fame, is celebrating its centenary this year. And the big 1930's neo-Georgian headquarters it calls home is stacked to the attic with exhibitions of American art.

title: Benitez Proves Untidy, But Cleans Up His Mess
description: It was as if it were a stickball game, and Armando Benitez was begging for a do-over.

title: Residential Real Estate; Touch of History in Wall St. Rentals
description: The 36-story former headquarters of the Bank of New York at 48 Wall Street is beginning its transformation into 277 rental apartments. More than half of them are to be furnished rentals to be leased on a short-term basis, adding a new dimension to the growing housing supply in Manhattan's financial district.

title: CONSTRUCTION LOSS
description: Mexico's largest construction company, Empresas ICA Sociedad Controladora S.A., said that it expected to report a second-quarter loss, largely because of $93 million in cost overruns on a street repair project in Bogota, Colombia, and a gas pipeline in Brazil. Executives of the company said they expected to recover some of the losses through litigation. In recent years the company has sought foreign projects to protect itself from economic swings in Mexico.

title: 2 Exchanges in Retreat From Times Sq.
description: Nearly a year after Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange created a stir in New York with grand plans to move to a new 40-story skyscraper near Times Square, the two financial markets have reversed course and now appear ready to stay in lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRION, LESTER E. JR.
description: BRION-Lester E. Jr. On July 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Lois; devoted father of Donna and David, and fond father-in-law of Hannah; loving grandfather of Julianna and Christian. Memorial reception at the Creek Club, Locust Valley, L.I., July 20th at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the National Society to Prevent Blindness, 500 East Remington Road, Schaumburg, IL. 60173.

title: Bush Forgoes Federal Funds And Has No Spending Limit
description: Gov. George W. Bush declared today that he would not accept Federal matching funds because of his enormous $37 million campaign war chest, giving him the capacity to far outspend his Republican Presidential rivals in the 2000 election, especially in early and pivotal primaries and caucuses.

title: Drug Makers Fault the Details Of Clinton Medicare Proposal
description: Top executives of the pharmaceutical industry said today that they shared President Clinton's goal of increasing Medicare beneficiaries' access to prescription drugs, but for the first time they criticized specific features of his proposal. In particular, they said they feared that it could lead to price controls.

title: SENATE APPROVES REPUBLICAN PLAN FOR HEALTH CARE
description: In the final hours of a sharply partisan debate over health care, the Senate killed a Democratic effort to expand the ability of patients to sue managed-care providers and, in a near party-line vote tonight, approved a Republican plan to regulate the companies that provide health insurance for most Americans.

title: State to Investigate New Jersey Blackouts
description: State utility regulators in New Jersey announced yesterday that they were opening an investigation into the widespread blackouts that cut power to thousands of homes and businesses during last week's heat wave.

title: BP Amoco Says It Will Cut Annual Costs by $4 Billion
description: BP Amoco P.L.C., the newly formed petroleum giant, announced ambitious plans today to cut annual costs by $4 billion over the next three years -- double the previous target -- and shed $10 billion of assets, including low-profit oilfields and refineries.

title: The Goose Glut
description: On the whole, Americans tend to be sympathetic to wildlife. They have supported the reintroduction of wolves in Yellowstone National Park, for example, as well as efforts by environmental groups and the Federal Government to protect other endangered species. But the issue gets more complicated when animals camp on their doorsteps. Suburban sprawl has created competition for space between humans and wildlife, and while nobody much likes it when deer and waterfowl are edged out of their natural habitat, there are times when the creatures rebound in such numbers that they compromise the quality of community life. Such is the case with Canada geese in Kent, N.Y., a town that encompasses Lake Carmel in Putnam County.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILANDER, HENRY
description: BILANDER-Henry. 25 years. Your memory and legacy live on. Your family

title: BRITISH DEAL FOR FRANCE TELECOM
description: France Telecom said it was paying $1 billion for a 10 percent stake in the British media company NTL Inc. and would invest more if NTL succeeded in an expected bid of $:8 billion ($12.5 billion) for the residential cable assets of Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. Earlier, NTL and Cable and Wireless confirmed they were discussing a transaction, although neither provided details. The $1 billion in cash and stock will presumably be used by NTL to help finance its bid for the cable assets.

title: Investors Buy $1.6 Billion Of Municipal Debt Issues
description: Municipal bond investors stole center stage in bond trading yesterday as they quickly bought up $1.6 billion of tax-exempt bonds backed by toll revenue from a Southern California highway.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Michael Paha and Skeet McAuley

title: Do Polls Answer a Political Need?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Umpires Defy Labor's Rule Book
description: IN baseball's medieval times, when umpires projected nobility instead of defiance, it was raining steadily when the Pittsburgh Pirates' manager, Frank Frisch, confronted Jocko Conlan, one of history's feistiest umpires. After arguing, loudly, that the weather was too soggy to play baseball, Frisch questioned Conlan's intestinal fortitude.

title: Mr. Barak Comes to Washington
description: Ehud Barak winds up his first diplomatic tour as Israel's Prime Minister with a long weekend of meetings with President Clinton that began yesterday. The mood in Washington is upbeat and encouraging, as it was during Mr. Barak's earlier meetings with Arab leaders. Mr. Clinton welcomes Mr. Barak's aspiration to complete peace agreements with the Palestinians and Syria. The two men will also explore how America can help.

title: LEAR STOCK RISES ON REPORTS OF MERGER TALKS WITH FORD
description: The stock of the Lear Corporation, the biggest maker of car seats and interiors, rose yesterday on renewed talk that the company was discussing a combination with the Ford Motor Company's Visteon parts unit. The two companies are said to have not decided how to combine the businesses. A full combination of Visteon, with annual sales of $18.2 billion, and Lear, with sales of about $12.1 billion, would rival the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, a former unit of the General Motors Corporation, as the world's largest auto parts maker. Lear's shares were up $1.75 each, to $50.375, and Ford was up 56.25 cents at $53.50.

title: Jewish Settlements Quickly Ruled Illegal
description: Less than one hour after it began, a conference on whether Jewish settlements in territories occupied by Israel violate international law adjourned today after declaring that the settlements are illegal.

title: A Reach For the Sky
description: Many small steps will be taken across Central Park tomorrow evening, all in honor of a giant leap for mankind. Children will frolic on Sheep's Meadow at the Urban Park Rangers' Moon Day festivities, a celebration of all things lunar (and a few things Martian, too).

title: H.M.O.'s Will Drop 327,000 Medicare Patients, U.S. Says
description: The Clinton Administration said today that 327,000 Medicare beneficiaries would be dropped next year by health maintenance organizations that are pulling out of the Medicare program or reducing the areas they serve.

title: COLUMBIA ENERGY EXPANDS SHARE REPURCHASE
description: Columbia Energy Group said yesterday that it would substantially increase its share buyback offer. The move came days after it rejected a hostile tender offer from Nisource Inc. Columbia, a Herndon, Va., natural gas company, said it would add $400 million to its share repurchase program, bringing the total to $420 million. The program extends to July 14, 2000. Earlier this month, Columbia Energy's board rejected a $5.7 billion hostile tender offer from Nisource, a Merrillville, Ind., electric and gas utility, and urged shareholders not to tender their shares in response to the offer. Columbia said the $68-a-share offer was inadequate and also questioned the compatibility of the two companies. Columbia's shares slipped 25 cents, to $63.6875.

title: Compuware to Buy a Software Vendor
description: The Compuware Corporation, a provider of business software and technology support services, will acquire Viasoft Inc., a leading vendor of software tools for fixing Year 2000 computer problems, for $164 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: Marriage Loses In 'Divorce Culture'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, IRVING
description: GANZ-Irving. Beloved husband of Jean; loving father of Lowell and Jeffrey; cherished grandfather of Scott, Allison, Simon, Ollie and Carl; dear brother of Alice Levinger. Mount Sinai Mortuary, Los Angeles, California.

title: When Loss Of Virginity Is the Birth Of Love
description: Late in ''The Wood,'' a savvy, good-natured comedy that follows the 13-year friendship of three black friends who met in junior high school in Inglewood, Calif., there is a flashback in which the three boys, Mike (Sean Nelson), Slim (Duane Finley) and Roland (Trent Cameron) pool their change into a kitty and swear a pact. Whoever is the first to lose his virginity will be the recipient of the accumulated cash.

title: Taiwan Has a Right to Decide Its Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island Women Plead Guilty in Baby Smuggling
description: Two Long Island women accused of being part of an adoption ring that smuggled babies from Mexico pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, MAE J. (NEE DUFFY)
description: CANNON-Mae J. (nee Duffy). On July 12, 1999, age 91. Widow of Fred. Beloved mother of Fred Jr. and the late Jean Kalberer; loving grandmother of Joan Kalberer, Jane Cicinnati, Judy Wappaus and George Kalberer. Also survived by four great-grandchildren. Reposing Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, Saturday and Sunday 2-5, 7-9:30PM. Religious services on Sunday evening at funeral home.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Syrian Peace His Aim, Barak Tells Clinton
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak told President Clinton today that Israel would embark on a ''serious effort'' in the next several weeks to restart negotiations with Syria, which is still formally at war with Israel.

title: New Video Releases
description: The General

title: WIDER JAPANESE SUPLUS
description: Japan's current account surplus widened in May for only the second time in eight months. The current account surplus, the broadest measure of the flow of goods, services and money in and out of Japan, widened 56.6 percent, to 1.3 trillion yen ($10.6 billion), seasonally adjusted. Compared with a year earlier, the current account surplus fell 23.7 percent, to 1.1 trillion yen, unadjusted, in May. The surplus fell for the fourth consecutive month from year-earlier levels.

title: Facing Adversity With Devotion to Judaism
description: BONNIE LIPTON'S first words as a candidate for the presidency of Hadassah came from Deuteronomy, and her heart: ''I have set before you life and death,'' she said to her national board, quoting Moses speaking to the Jews. ''Therefore choose life, that both thou and thy seed may live.''

title: SOFTBANK'S STOCK SOARS
description: After the company announced it would restrict its $15 billion investment portfolio purely to Internet companies, the shares of the Softbank Corporation surged to a record high. Softbank, which has stakes in more than 100 companies doing business on line, will begin realigning its portfolio by selling its 80 percent interest in the memory-chip-module maker Kingston Technology. Softbank also said it approved a decision by Ziff-Davis Inc., a publisher of computer magazines, to consider selling businesses to improve its stock price. Softbank holds a stake of about 69 percent in Ziff-Davis.

title: Kim's 15-Foot 3-Wood Proves Too Much Club
description: Burdened by a stomach virus that had limited her to just two hours of sleep and a meal of just a banana today, Mi Hyun Kim still managed to stand atop the leader board at the Japan Airlines Big Apple Classic as she played the final hole of the day. But after her second shot on the par-5 ninth hole landed on the back fringe of the green, Kim tried for the first time all day to do too much.

title: Heartless Course Conditions Decimate Field at Carnoustie
description: When the day mercifully ended, nobody who had played today could remember enduring a tougher first round in the British Open.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: An Ode To Old Age, Life's Gift
description: AT the age of 59, Marcia Tucker is bidding farewell to the New Museum of Contemporary Art in her usual style. Her swan song at the museum she single-handedly founded 22 years ago is ''The Time of Our Lives,'' an exhibition that is characteristically personal, topical, rough around the edges and intent on raising consciousness.

title: Appointment by Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that Lynn O. Matthews, publisher of The Sarasota Herald-Tribune in Florida, will become president and chief operating officer of the company's regional newspaper group.

title: Second-Round Draft Choice Seems Eager to Impress Nets
description: Before working out at the Nets' practice center today, Evan Eschmeyer took time to marvel at his good fortune.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about an arrangement by the National Association of Broadcasters to televise the wives of Congressmen in public service advertisements referred incorrectly to the main legislation sought by the broadcasters. It would let satellite companies carry over-the-air broadcasts from local television stations but prohibit them from carrying distant signals if an adequate local broadcast was available. It would not prohibit them altogether from carrying over-the-air signals.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; New Seat Belts to Get More Give and Take
description: EARLY next year, some new cars will come with seat belts that act somewhat like bungee cords, which could lower the cost of safety-belt assemblies and improve passenger protection in crashes that include multiple impacts.

title: Musical Romance With a Dirge In Its Heart
description: After the strange doings of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's ''Passion,'' no romance could be too eccentric for the musical theater, and certainly not that in ''After the Fair,'' a chamber musical adapted from a Thomas Hardy short story about a frustrated Englishwoman who plays Cyrano de Bergerac to an illiterate serving girl and the educated man they both love.

title: Chemical Fire Injures 11 At Dental Tool Factory
description: Eleven people were injured yesterday when a chemical fire erupted at a Mahwah dental equipment factory.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper rose almost 3 percent amid speculation about more production cuts in North America. In New York, copper for September delivery rose 2.2 cents, to 79.9 cents a pound.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: French Qualifier Is Over Par, but He's Ahead of the Field
description: The final four holes at Carnoustie may be the toughest finishing holes in the world. Ask Greg Norman, who triple-bogeyed No. 17 today. Or Tiger Woods, who bogeyed No. 16 and No. 18. But on the same holes where Norman and Woods faltered, an unexpected leader emerged.

title: Settlement Is Reported Near By American and Its Pilots
description: American Airlines and its pilots may be close to settling the dispute that inconvenienced hundreds of thousands of passengers earlier this year when pilots called in sick, forcing the airline to cancel nearly 6,700 flights.

title: S.E.C. Civil Suit Says Faxes About 12 Stocks Were False
description: It was the sort of thing that would grab some investors' attention: a letter mistakenly faxed to them -- written on Prudential Securities stationery and marked ''confidential'' -- predicting that shares of three companies would soon triple because ''major announcements are coming out this month.''

title: In Iowa, Clinton Makes Case for School Spending
description: President Clinton today pitched his $24.8 billion plan to modernize 6,000 schools, saying students could not do their best work in buildings ''where kids walk up the steps and they see broken windows every day, where there are rooms, in some cases whole floors they can't even go on.''

title: Build Highways Fit for Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBISH, HERBERT W.
description: HOBISH-Herbert W. On Friday, July 16, 1999. Beloved and cherished husband of Toby (nee Tesser). Devoted and loving father of Mitchell and Janice, Amy, and Richard and Florence. Adored Grandpa of Sam and Aliza. Dear brother of Stanley and Ruth. Services Sunday, 2 PM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Standards of Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Burton S. Dreben, 71, Negotiator In Tense Situations at Harvard
description: Burton Spencer Dreben, a former Harvard dean who brokered some of the most difficult negotiations between the Harvard administration and leaders of the student uprisings there in the late 1960's, died of lymphoma on Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 71 and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: Brief sports articles yesterday and on Tuesday about the trial of a Mets minor league player charged with sexual battery misspelled his given name. The player, who was acquitted, is Vicente Rosario, not Vincente. The article on Tuesday also misspelled the surname of his lawyer and referred incompletely to where the lawyer conducts business. The lawyer is Harvey Slovis, not Slovin: he has an office in Manhattan as well as one in the Bronx.

title: Alcohol-Level Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYNDER, ERNST
description: WYNDER - Ernst L., M.D., D.Sc.h.c., Dr.med.h.c. It is with great sadness that the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center notes the death of their dear friend and colleague, Dr. Ernst L. Wynder. At the time of his death, Dr. Wynder was a consultant in the Department of Medicine at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. Dr. Wynder began his career at Memorial Sloan-Kettering in 1951 as a junior resident and continued his association with us as President of the American Health Foundation. Dr. Wynder will be remembered for speaking up about what he knew to be true and sounding an early alarm about the dangers of tobacco use. He is an example to all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Wynder's family and his colleagues at the Foundation. Paul A. Marks, M.D., President And the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Fears of Military Confrontation With China Shake Taiwan Financial Markets
description: Fears of a military confrontation with China swept through financial markets in Taiwan today, causing the biggest single-day plunge in the stock index in nine years.

title: Industrial Production Gained 0.2% in June
description: Industrial production in the United States rose in June, the seventh month without a decline, led by increased demand for automobiles, computers and electricity.

title: Legislators In Nassau Approve Tax On Land Sales
description: Voting along party lines, the Nassau Legislature today approved a new 1 percent tax on property sales to help solve the county's deepening financial crisis. But Republicans in the majority made no public mention of the fiscal reforms they have conceded are necessary to rein in the county's budgetary practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, MONROE
description: SHERMAN-Monroe. Age 94, formerly of Long Boat Key, FL and Southbury, CT, died peacefully at home on Thursday, July 15, 1999. Brother of the late Barney, Maurie, Herman and Sidney. Adored husband and life's partner of the late Gertrude Horn; treasured father of the late Nancy (Dr. Lawrence) Rosenberg and Susan Sherman; beloved grandfather of Eric Rosenberg, Connie (Mark) Hochman, Dr. Mark Rosenberg (Dr. Andrea Needleman), Elizabeth (Dan) Zimmerman; Loving greatgrandfather of Amelia and Sarah Hochman; Julian and Jenna Rosenberg, and Natalie Rose Zimmerman. Metallurgist, inventor, golfer, chef, jeweler, artist, photographer, master gardener. Impassioned autodidact and perennial student of the patterns and miracles in nature, of etymology and philosophy, of quantum physics, of music and art. His kindness and generosity, his love for and absolute devotion to his family and friends, his passion for creative work, the thrill he found in being alive and in his myriad interests, have lastingly endowed and inspired all who knew him. ''I am done with great things and big things, great organizations and big successes. I am for those tiny, invisible, molecular, moral forces which work from individual to individual, creeping through the crannies of the world like so many soft rootlets, or like the capillary action of water, but which if you give them time, will rend the hardest monuments of man's pride''. (William James) Memorial service at 10:00 AM on Wednesday, July 28 at Pomperaug Woods, Southbury, CT.

title: France Matches Brazil's Big Effort
description: Gustavo Kuerten defeated Sebastien Grosjean by 9-7 in the fifth set as Brazil and France split their opening matches in a Davis Cup quarterfinal in Pau, France.

title: A Change of Course in Boston
description: Desegregation policies that assign children to public schools based on race -- sometimes busing them to achieve integration -- have lost ground steadily since they were introduced in the 1960's and 70's. Some policies have been swept away in court challenges while others were rendered moot when whites withdrew to the suburbs, making racial balance impossible to achieve. Both factors came to bear this week in Boston, which responded to white flight -- and a lawsuit challenging desegregation policies -- by eliminating race as a factor in deciding where children attend school.

title: Reich's Amalgam of Speech and Melody
description: Any good, vibrant festival takes on a life of its own, as telling thematic relationships emerge in addition to those planned. The Lincoln Center Festival, in reviving the grand Chinese opera ''The Peony Pavilion,'' originally scheduled for last year, may not have given it much thought in relation to ''Steve Reich: Four,'' a presentation of concert and theatrical works this year.

title: CHINA GROWTH LESS THAN EXPECTED
description: China's gross domestic product expanded by a slower-than-expected 7.6 percent in the first six months of the year, as extra state spending on investment projects failed to spur growth in other parts of the economy. China's G.D.P., the domestic output of goods and services, totaled 3.62 trillion yuan ($436 billion) in the first half of the year, the National Statistics Bureau said. Second-quarter growth slid to an annual rate of 7.1 percent, from 8.3 percent in the previous three months. It was the slowest quarterly rate since 6.8 percent in the second quarter last year.

title: Agreement at Last in Albany On $73 Billion Budget Plan
description: Three and a half months after the state budget was due, legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki have agreed to the outlines of a $73 billion deal, legislators and top aides said today. The plan would preserve a prekindergarten program and make no new cuts in health care, while salting away $1.8 billion to pay for future tax cuts.

title: At the Crisis Bunker, Officials Prepare
description: The heat map, transmitted by satellite from a private weather forecasting company and displayed on television monitors throughout the city's Emergency Operations Center yesterday afternoon, showed most of the Northeast fire-engine red. But a deep maroon circle over parts of Pennsylvania and western New Jersey seemed to be inching ominously toward New York City.

title: Gridlock City
description: Manhattan's hottest piece of real estate, Times Square, has gotten so crowded lately that pedestrians often have to wait in line to cross the street. The newest arrival, Conde Nast Publications, plans to hold court in its icy tower by mid-August. ABC's ''Good Morning America'' will settle nearby in September. The human gridlock can only get worse in November, when the World Wrestling Federation hunkers down in the Paramount Building to open a theme restaurant. The real theater this fall will unfold on Broadway, the street.

title: Still Second in Sibling Rivalry
description: Francois Simon has something that none of his three brothers achieved as professional bicycle racers: the blue, white and red jersey of the French national champion. But they have something he has not yet achieved: a stage victory in the Tour de France.

title: A Heartiness So Hearty It Escapes Into the Aisles
description: Warriors spread news about a festival. They did so by jogging through the aisles of the Taipei Theater. That's where the Taipei County Aborigines' Culture and Arts Group offered ''Aboriginal Song and Dance from Taiwan,'' featuring sacred ceremonies and secular entertainments associated with harvest festivals of the Ami tribe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, BENJAMIN
description: STRAUSS-Benjamin H. Died peacefully July 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Sara. Devoted and cherished father of Iris Rosenberg, Lynda Nielsen, Wendy Pouria and Beth Williams. Loving and proud grandfather of Lee and Sharon Nielsen, Kim Kavazanjian, Sean, Matthew and Sari Williams. Predeceased by wife Lillian and son Steven. Esteemed teacher in the Long Beach City Schools for 40 years. Services Sunday 9AM at ''Gutterman's Inc'' , 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Grand Jury Refuses to Indict in Assisted Suicide
description: A Manhattan grand jury has declined to indict an Upper East Side veterinarian who admitted to the police last fall that he injected a dying friend with a fatal dose of pentobarbital at her request, a day or so before she was to be moved from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center into a hospice.

title: Y.M.C.A. in Chelsea Sheds Its Tenants; 34 Men Used to Single Rooms Know New Homes Will Be Hard to Find
description: For the last 21 years, Davidson Garrett has hung his belts on the doorknob of Room 355 at the McBurney Y.M.C.A. on West 23d Street in Manhattan, written poetry with posters of Joan Sutherland and Leontyne Price -- ''my two ladies'' -- beaming down at him from the wall, eaten all his meals out because he doesn't have a kitchen, brushed his teeth in the communal bathroom down the hall and called all of this home.

title: Minors' Plan Is for Fill-Ins If Umps Quit
description: Faced with an implicit threat of an umpires strike of their own, the minor leagues have made arrangements for replacement umpires, a high-ranking official said yesterday.

title: Taiwan's Bold Move
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERS, RHODA
description: PERS-Rhoda. On July 16, 1999. Beloved aunt of Deena and Jessica Pers, Judith and Deborah DeWitt, dear great aunt, loving sister of Celia Pers, Elinor DeWitt and the late B. Elliott Pers. Graveside service Sunday 11AM at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SOARS. Crude oil and gasoline futures soared as refinery troubles in California and cutbacks by producers threatened to cause shortages. In New York, crude for August delivery rose 46 cents a barrel, to $20.62.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Iran's View of U.S.: Evil, Bumbling or Unimportant
description: At Friday Prayers here at noon today, the United States was presented as the all-powerful hidden hand behind Iran's worst civil unrest in two decades.

title: Joe Hyman, 77, Established British Textile Empire in 60's
description: Joe Hyman, a British magnate who took a brand name associated with cozy pajamas and turned it into one of the great textile empires of the 1960's, died July 6 at the age of 77.

title: Sports of The Times; Making A Case For Boomer
description: ROGER CLEMENS was back in Boston on Tuesday evening, but not to play in the All-Star Game. Instead, the former Red Sox-turned-Blue Jay-turned-Yankee was on hand to share a larger honor. He was being introduced as a member of Baseball's All-Century Team. When his name was called, Clemens, who for 13 seasons was the Red Sox' best pitcher since Babe Ruth, was harshly booed.

title: Both Parties Offer Tax-Cut Plans in Senate
description: Republicans and Democrats in the Senate laid out dueling tax-cut proposals today, but both sides said they saw room for eventual compromise.

title: Flush Bush Turns to Soft Money
description: Although George W. Bush has amassed a huge political war chest from small donations, he has apparently found a novel way to give major Republican donors an opportunity to support his campaign with large amounts known as soft money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISCUSI, MILDRED
description: VISCUSI-Mildred. The past six years have only made us miss you more. Love, Fred, Laurie, Stephen and Case

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLASTER, CECILE
description: FLASTER-Cecile (nee Bobrow). On June 30, in Stamford, Conn. Loving wife of the late Joel. Sister of Ethel Altschuler. Mother of Jackie Weisburger. Mother-in-law of Kenneth Weisburger.
