Grandmother of Debra Strachan and Douglas Weisburger. Great-grandmother of Dylan, Carley and Joel. A private graveside service was held on July 1.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an announcement by the Reuters Group that Federal prosecutors would not charge it with improperly obtaining information from a big competitor referred incorrectly to the data involved. Prosecutors were looking at whether Reuters had improperly obtained data belonging to Bloomberg L.P. that could have allowed copying of Bloomberg's analysis programs. Bloomberg's operating code was not involved.

title: The Health Care Vote: Looking Ahead
description: By the time the Senate's four-day debate over managed care ended on Thursday night, each party had won something. The Democrats had put the Republicans on record against some emotional health care proposals -- stands that they expect to highlight in the next campaign. The Republicans, for their part, passed a modest health care bill that they believe will shield them from attack next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, EDNA
description: ROGERS-Edna. A wonderful, dear and most devoted friend. Heartfelt condolences to Arthur, Anita, Julie, Ruth and Chris. Linda and Ray Ehrlich

title: Does Our Health Care Really Cost Too Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, IRVING
description: WHITE-Irving. On July 14, 1999 at the age of 81. Husband of Barbara. Graveside service at Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 would be appreciated.

title: DEBT TENSIONS IN BRAZIL
description: In a move highlighting the friction between the national Government and Brazil's cash-short states, governors have called for more access to tax revenue and for federal money to cover state pension deficits. Yet their pleas at a meeting this week were less militant than the debt moratorium declared earlier this year, a move that contributed to the financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, NORMAN
description: SCHNEIDER-Norman. The Directors and Officers are deeply saddened by the death of our long time Associate. Norman was a friend and a significant contributor during his long tenure as a Director of our company. He always found positive solutions to our many challenges, even after his retirement. We offer our condolences to his family. Jerry Shore, Chairman of Board Park Electrochemical Corp

title: Irish Need Comply
description: Unremarkably, the Rev. Ian Paisley was on his feet with an objection. His voice rumbled with biblical fury, his body shook, his finger shot out along its accustomed accusatory trajectory.

title: A Night of Many Returns for the Boss
description: It would have been very difficult to leave the Continental Airlines Arena disappointed on Thursday night, when Bruce Springsteen began his first American tour with the E Street Band in 10 years. If Mr. Springsteen's work is a journey -- and it is, not just in his close relationship with his fans but also for the characters whose development he follows from album to album -- then the three-hour, 26-song show stopped at nearly all points on the map.

title: Clinton and Barak Drawn Together by the Politics of Peace
description: After years of sparring with Benjamin Netanyahu, there was a palpable sense of embrace in President Clinton's description today of his first extended encounters with the new Prime Minister of Israel, Ehud Barak.

title: INSIDE
description: Dueling Tax-Cut Plans

title: Standards of Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Qwest's Deal For U S West Appears Set
description: The board of U S West Inc., the smallest of the regional Bell telephone companies, met last night to approve a merger with Qwest Communications International Inc., the fast-growing long-distance communications carrier, in a deal worth more than $30 billion.

title: Lawmakers Want to Allow Suing of Con Ed
description: Lawmakers from both major parties have proposed legislation that would make it easier for New York City to sue Consolidated Edison over the power failures that darkened upper Manhattan last week.

title: Clearing the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRE DISRUPTS TORONTO TRADING
description: Telephones and computer links failed in much of Toronto's financial district after an explosion and three-hour fire in a Bell Canada switching station. Derivatives trading at the Toronto Stock Exchange was temporarily shut, and some brokers could not get access to market data or place orders. Automated teller machines throughout the city did not work for hours, and intermittent disruptions on communications links to other cities were reported. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: NEW ZEALAND PACT FOR E.D.S.
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the big United States computer services company, won a 10-year contract worth $1.5 billion (New Zealand), or $800 million (United States), to manage the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand's information systems, beating a bid by I.B.M. The contract, which covers everything from Telecom's billing system to Internet services, cements E.D.S's New Zealand unit as the nation's No. 1 information technology company.

title: Corrections
description: Brief sports articles yesterday and on Tuesday about the trial of a Mets minor league player charged with sexual battery misspelled his given name. The player, who was acquitted, is Vicente Rosario, not Vincente. The article on Tuesday also misspelled the surname of his lawyer and referred incompletely to where the lawyer conducts business. The lawyer is Harvey Slovis, not Slovin: he has an office in Manhattan as well as one in the Bronx.

title: Jets' Top Pick Signs Contract
description: The Jets signed Randy Thomas, their top draft pick, yesterday. And while they now have the top two players they selected under contract -- both guards -- the Jets have no clear idea whether anyone on the team can start the season at either left or right guard.

title: U.S. Official Proposes $1 Billion for Colombia Drug War
description: Alarmed by recent advances by guerrillas here who are also involved in drug trafficking, the Clinton Administration's top anti-drug official is asking that $1 billion in emergency assistance be made available to the Colombian Government to bolster its war on drugs.

title: PACIFICORP TO SELL ITS CALIFORNIA OPERATIONS
description: Pacificorp said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its California electric service operations for $178 million to Nor-Cal Electric Authority, a public authority created last November by the city of Yreka and Del Norte County in northern California. Pacificorp, based in Portland, Ore., said it would sell the service area, which has 41,000 customers in four counties, to focus on areas where it has more customers. Pacificorp, a public utility, agreed in December to be acquired by Scottish Power in a transaction valued at $7.9 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, BLANCHE R.
description: PAUL-Blanche R. On July 15. Beloved mother of Madeline, sisterin-law of Ethel Rothenberg, aunt and great aunt. Services Sunday 10AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Avenue and E. 10 St.

title: Jones Drowns Out Boos With His Booming Bat
description: There were 50,469 fans at a raucous and clammy Yankee Stadium last night, and Andruw Jones acted as if he had heard each one. Every time the fans booed, Jones listened. He let the sounds drift through his ears and motivate him. He wanted to quiet the rowdy fans.

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY MINDEN BANCSHARES
description: The Regions Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Minden Bancshares Inc. for about $86.5 million in stock. Minden Bancshares is the holding company for the Minden Bank and Trust Company, which operates seven offices in northwestern Louisiana. It has $332 million in assets. Regions Financial, based in Birmingham, Ala., is a bank holding company with 731 offices in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, South Carolina, Tennessee and Texas.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We had many members committed to some type of increase for fiscal 2000, only to have this blow up in our faces. It reinforces the old stereotypes, it picks the scab off the wound, and it opens up public broadcasting to another big fight on Capitol Hill.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, RUTH
description: POST-Ruth. On July 15, 1999 at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Emil. Loving mother of Richard and David and their wives Carol Post and Katlean Demonchy. Adored grandmother of Cynthia, Steven, Pamela, Randee, Lori and Jill and great-grandmother of Ethan, Matthew, Katlin, Julia, Blake, Samantha and Grant. Dear sister of Marcy. Cryptside service Sunday, July 18, 11:00 AM at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ.

title: Political Notes; For Trump, a Race So Short and Sweet
description: It was one of the shortest Presidential campaigns in history.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strong Corporate Earnings Push Stock Gauges Higher

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALBEMARLE CORP., Richmond, a large maker of specialty chemicals used in flame retardants and pharmaceuticals, said it would cut 74 workers to reduce costs and increase profit.

title: India Buries Soldiers That Pakistan Won't Claim
description: Up and down some of the steepest peaks in the Himalayas are dozens of freshly dug graves of unknown soldiers, men who India insists are Pakistanis and whose nation dares not claim them.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Does Our Health Care Really Cost Too Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: Newspaper Columnist Suspended for Buying Stock Through Friend
description: A San Jose Mercury News business columnist was suspended indefinitely yesterday for taking advantage of a friend's offer to buy shares of a fledgling company at a price not available to the general public.

title: Raul Salinas's Sentence in Mexico Murder Is Cut to 27 1/2 Years
description: An appeals court today reduced the murder sentence against Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of the former President, by nearly half, to 27 1/2 years, from 50 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, DAN
description: SMITH-Dan. We will miss you and remember all the good times spent together. Sincere condolences to Esther, the children and grandchildren. Zina and Joe

title: Talks Halt On Bombing Of Embassy In Belgrade
description: Chinese and American officials wound up two days of negotiations today on compensation for the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, without reaching an agreement.

title: The Students City College Doesn't Need
description: In forcing the resignation of Yolanda Moses, the president of City College of New York, earlier this month, the trustees of the City University have at least opened the possibility of restoring more vigorous leadership to the once-proud flagship of City University. But the roots of City College's decline go far deeper than Dr. Moses's five-year tenure.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE TO BUY INFORMATION ADVANTAGE
description: Sterling Software Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Information Advantage Inc. for $6.50 a share, or $163 million, in a deal that brings together two software companies with complementary products. Information Advantage, based in Minneapolis, provides business-intelligence software. The company, which has 500 employees in 27 offices worldwide, reported revenue of $70.7 million last year. Sterling Software, a Dallas-based services company, had revenue of $719.9 million for the year ended Sept. 30. Shares of Information Advantage gained 75 cents, to $6.25, in Nasdaq trading. Sterling Software shares were up 25 cents, to $26, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: School Spirit Inc.; Millions of Cheerleaders Create a Growth Industry
description: On a recent steamy day at the University of Mississippi here, the Prince song ''1999'' blasted from loudspeakers as high-pitched yells of ''go'' and ''fight'' rose from a sea of nearly 1,000 brightly clad teen-agers scattered in clusters in the middle of campus.

title: Does Our Health Care Really Cost Too Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUBERT, PEGGYANN
description: HAUBERT-Peggyann A. Of Bergenfield, NJ on July 15th, 1999. Loving sister of Susan Haubert, Robert Haubert and William Haubert, cherished aunt of James, Katherine, William, Sean and Sara Haubert. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the Boulevard Funeral Home, 1151 River Road, New Milford, NJ (corner of New Bridge Road) on Monday, July 19, 1999 at 9 AM, then to Ascension Roman Catholic Church where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 10 AM. Interment will be in Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Friends may visit onSat. and Sun. from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: As Steinbrenner Watches, Yanks Lose in 9th
description: Strolling out of the sullen Yankees clubhouse last night, Derek Jeter recognized the voice emanating from the office of Manager Joe Torre. Smiling, Jeter stopped and leaned into the doorway to address Torre's visitor.

title: Caterpillar Sees Profit Growth Slowing in '99
description: After months of hinting at a turnaround, Caterpillar Inc., the maker of construction and earth-moving equipment, warned investors yesterday that profit growth would continue to slide this year.

title: CONNECTICUT CASE FAVORS MICROSOFT
description: It was a David versus Goliath case, a courtroom confrontation between a struggling little software maker and the mighty Microsoft Corporation.

title: What Price the Most Expensive Diamond of All?
description: Safeco Field, the most costly single-sport stadium in North America, opened for Major League Baseball on Thursday night, a $517 million expanse of art and green grass cradled by the marine air of Puget Sound and the hopes of fans long blanketed in misery. But what was once heralded as a grand local celebration of the national pastime is now soured by protests, legal threats and a growing squall over how much the public should pay for stadiums that enrich private owners.

title: Mistaken Arrest Makes Actor Miss 'Ragtime'
description: Alton Fitzgerald White, who plays a leading role in the Broadway musical ''Ragtime,'' was arrested yesterday in the lobby of his Harlem apartment building after the police received a report of drug dealing in the building and took six men into custody.

title: In Newark, a Carnival as Bears Return, With Bats
description: This city, which has been furiously reimagining itself in recent years as performing arts center and a transportation hub, donned a baseball uniform today with the opening of Riverfront Park stadium and the return of minor-league baseball to Newark after a 50-year absence.

title: State Won't Put Hospital For Criminals in Borough
description: Responding to pressure from residents, the state has withdrawn its plan to put a psychiatric hospital for sex offenders in this Camden County borough.

title: Once, Conservatives Knew the Value of Transportation
description: Abraham Lincoln called Senator Henry Clay ''my beau ideal,'' largely because he was dedicated to building America. Clay, whose nickname was ''Capital Improvements Harry,'' helped pass legislation to construct roads and inland waterways to tie America together. During the Civil War, Lincoln authorized the construction of the first transcontinental railroad. Teddy Roosevelt championed the Panama Canal, and Dwight Eisenhower created the Interstate System.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about Federal studies of concerns about genetically altered food misstated the surname of the president of the National Press Club, where Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman spoke on the subject. The club president is Larry Lipman, not Litmand.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Suit Seeks Change in Marketing and Sale of Guns
description: Joining a parade of cities and gunshot victims, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday filed the latest lawsuit that places the blame on gun makers for shootings with illegally obtained handguns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINTORINO, ANTHONY
description: CINTORINO-Anthony. A beloved staff member who gave to everyone. We shall miss his enthusiasm, caring and kindness. Tony, the staff and clients will never forget you. The Rehabilitation Institute Louise Friedman, Associate Dir. Dr. Edmund C. Neuhaus, Dir.

title: Off-Duty Detective Charged In Accident Injuring 2 Girls
description: An off-duty detective from the Bronx Street Crime Unit was arrested in Rockland County Thursday night after his car ran down two 15-year-old girls, leaving them critically injured, and he subsequently refused to take a breath screening test, officials said yesterday.

title: Fear of Attack Cancels Cohen's Trip to Albania
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen canceled a trip to Albania this week, in part because of fears of a terrorist attack there by followers of Osama bin Laden, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: On Altered Food, Let Market Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the second-quarter earnings of The New York Times Company misstated the affiliation of Nathaniel Palmer, a securities analyst who commented on the company's acquisition of Abuzz Technologies Inc. He is with the Delphi Group, not the Digital Group. The article also misstated the increase in advertising revenue at The Boston Globe for the quarter. It was 1.8 percent, not 1.4 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ROBERT P.
description: BLUM-Robert P. The Members of the Board of Directors of the New York Society for the Deaf wish to express their condolences on the death of Robert P. Blum to his immediate family, his mother Ray, and his sister Judy. Robert P. Blum is the son of the late Joseph G. Blum who was the first Chairman and former President of the New York Society for the Deaf. Stephen E. Adler, Chairman Paul L. Kohnstamm, President Pearl Johnson, Exec. Dir.

title: The Fool Who Saved the Nation, and Other Historical What-If's
description: What if World War I had never happened? What if John F. Kennedy hadn't been assassinated? Fascination for such scenarios is growing, with a handful of books on that theme to be published this fall. Yet such counterfactual, or virtual, history, as it is often called, has long intrigued historians, filmmakers and others with its suggestion that destiny hangs on a single event, or even a triviality. In ''What If. . . ?,'' a 1982 collection of historical fictions edited by Nelson W. Polsby that is now out of print, a handful of scholars challenge the tendency to take the past and present for granted, imagining what would have happened if, for instance, Hitler had gotten the atomic bomb. The political scientist William H. Riker, who died in 1993, speculated that the United States might never have been created but for a vote cast 212 years ago yesterday. As he explained in his preface:

title: Long, Painful Trip Home Is Completed
description: Edgar Rivera lost both his legs -- and nearly his life -- when a stranger pushed him in front of a subway train as he was heading home.

title: On Altered Food, Let Market Rule; Too Little, Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: Reid's Talent Is Enough To Retain W.B.A. Title
description: It looked like an ominous sign when Kevin Kelly entered the ring tonight and the Australian flag one of his cornermen was carrying was mounted on the pole upside down, an international signal for distress. Kelly was an unknown quantity going against David Reid, a well-trained Olympic gold medalist who had won a world championship in just 12 professional fights.

title: Reminder to Insurers
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide to City Schools Chief To Quit Post Next Month
description: Chiara Coletti, one of the three top aides to Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, said yesterday that she would resign next month to become a vice president of the College Board, the organization in charge of the Scholastic Assessment Test, the standardized college-entrance test.

title: Tell-All Book Creates Furor at Vatican
description: When ''Gone With the Wind in the Vatican'' appeared in bookstores in February, few people noticed the account of intrigue, homosexuality and corruption within the Vatican bureaucracy.

title: Parnevik Manages Par Amid His Sniffling
description: Jesper Parnevik usually plays well when he doesn't feel well. He started today's second round of the British Open with a high temperature and was bothered by allergies. Little wonder that he shot an even-par 71, leaving him at three over par for the tournament (145), just two strokes off the lead.

title: Chief of Tenneco to Resign After Spinoff
description: Tenneco Inc., the maker of Monroe shock absorbers and Hefty trash bags, said today that Dana G. Mead would retire as its chief executive after the company spins off its packaging business to shareholders later this year.

title: TURNER'S SHARES RISE FOLLOWING ACQUISITION OFFER
description: The Turner Corporation, one of the largest construction companies in the United States, said yesterday that it was evaluating an offer by an unidentified investment group to buy the company. Peter Steiner, an investor, and his affiliates disclosed in a regulatory filing that Turner had received an offer that valued its shares at more than ''the highest market price at which the common stock has ever traded.'' The stock of the New York-based Turner rose $3.75, or 21 percent, to $21.25 before trading was halted. Mr. Steiner is a member of a Swiss investment group that owns 23.8 percent of Turner. He also is chairman of Karl Steiner Holding A.G., described as Switzerland's largest construction services and project development company.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about early fund-raising for the next New York mayoral election misstated the amount raised so far by a potential candidate, Fran Reiter. She has reported the total as $101,555; $67,280 is the amount that Ms. Reiter says is eligible for city matching funds. The article also misstated the matching formula under the city's old campaign law. Individual contributions up to $1,000 were matched dollar for dollar, not two to one.

title: Build Highways Fit for Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Gates Hits $100 Billion Mark, More or Less
description: Last month, in the largest gift ever by a living person to a charitable foundation, William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, donated $5 billion to support education and health care causes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EUGENE J.
description: COHEN-Eugene J., M.D. Died at home on July 16, 1999 at the age of 87. Devoted husband of the late Regina Gluck Cohen, M.D., for 58 years. Loving brother of Lorraine Silberthau. Brother-in-law of Sylvia & Irwin Grossman & Dorothy Margolin. Dear uncle of many nieces & nephews. Services Sunday, 1:00 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts to the Regina Gluck, M.D. Memorial Fund, North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: 'Iceman' Closes Tonight, And Then, 'Amy's View'
description: Two Broadway hits will close this weekend. The revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh'' closes after tonight's performance at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. Directed by Howard Davies and starring Kevin Spacey, the drama will have run for 10 previews and 102 regular performances.

title: HOUSE IS PREPARED TO CUT OFF FUNDS FOR F-22 FIGHTERS
description: Leaders of both parties said today that the House planned to cut off money for the Air Force's $70 billion F-22 fighter program, a highly unusual decision that has stunned the Pentagon and military contractors.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 26 about the religious connections of Martin Frankel, the fugitive money manager from Greenwich, Conn., referred incorrectly to restrictions imposed by the Archdiocese of Washington on the Rev. Peter Jacobs, a Roman Catholic priest involved in Mr. Frankel's dealings. In 1983 the archdiocese suspended Father Jacobs's authorization to function as a priest, an action that invalidates marriages he may have performed since then. The action did not invalidate other sacraments possibly performed by Father Jacobs, like baptisms or the celebrations of Mass.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a conference in Geneva on Jewish settlements in Israeli-occupied territories misstated the outcome. The conference did not declare that the settlements were illegal; it said that the Fourth Geneva Convention, which forbids transferring populations in occupied territories, is applicable to the territories occupied by Israel and that its provisions should be fully respected in those territories.

title: It's All Virtual Unreality In a Show on TV News
description: ''The truth doesn't have to be accurate,'' says George Findlay. He should know. As a television news producer with nary a crumb of ethics, professional or personal, George manipulates the truth whenever he can.

title: Barak Charms Clinton
description: After years sparring with Benjamin Netanyahu, President Clinton yesterday had warm words for Prime Minister Barak of Israel after the two leaders met at Camp David.

title: Remaking a Vast Frontier in China's Image
description: South of this onetime camel stop on the Silk Road, bulldozers and men with spades flounder in the wickedly fine sand, leveling dunes into fields in China's own version of the taming of the West.

title: Canadian Franchisers Sue Ford Over Lincoln-Mercury Conversion
description: Canada's Ford dealers are suing the Ford Motor Company of Canada for breach of contract over its plan to convert more than 100 Lincoln-Mercury outlets to the Ford name, creating 25 percent more Ford dealers across the country.

title: Chirac's Remarks at SS Massacre Site Trace Brutality's Lineage
description: ''It is good for everyone to know how to forget,'' the French historian Ernest Renan observed in 1882, and to preserve national unity France has often chosen to overlook the most uncomfortable moments of its past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETKIN, ANN
description: ETKIN-Ann. Died on July 15, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Dr. William Etkin. Beloved mother of Judy Levy and Asher Etkin. Grandmother of Jonathan and D'vora Levy, and Daniel and Benjamin Etkin. Great grandmother of Isaac Levy. Teacher and Bronx Municipal Hospital Auxiliary Officer. Memorial donations may be made to Bronx Municipal Hospital.

title: M. Lawrence Noyer Jr., 40; Prosecuted Brother of D'Amato
description: M. Lawrence Noyer Jr., a former Federal prosecutor who headed the mail fraud case against Armand P. D'Amato, the brother of former Senator Alfonse D'Amato, died July 7 at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. Mr. Noyer, who lived in Larchmont, N.Y., was 40.

title: Journal; Is Mike Wallace Ready for His Close-Up?
description: Just when the American media had checked out of Monicagate rehab, secure in the knowledge that only shut-ins have time for the press-bashing panels on C-Span or the ecclesiastical prose of Brill's Content, along comes Hollywood to ruin everything. In November the country will be bombarded with the most high-profile screen account of big-time, brand-name journalism since ''All the President's Men,'' and while it may well prove a hit, it's not going to set off another stampede to the nation's journalism schools.

title: The Face of the Future Is a Thing of the Past; Buckminster Fuller's Papers Are Moving, And His Heirs Hope for Revived Interest
description: Perhaps the most illuminating impression one gets from a stroll through the Buckminster Fuller Institute, a cramped warren of offices in the balcony of an old movie theater here, is how familiar all the artifacts produced by this great thinker seem today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRION, LESTER E.
description: BRION-Lester E. Jr. On July 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Lois; devoted father of Donna and David, and fond father-in-law of Hannah; loving grandfather of Julianna and Christian. Memorial reception at the Creek Club, Locust Valley, L.I., July 20th at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the National Society to Prevent Blindness, 500 East Remington Road, Schaumburg, IL. 60173.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR EDGES UP. With the euro unable to extend its two-day rebound, the dollar gained in lackluster trading. It also rose against the Swiss franc and the pound. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0196, down from $1.0219.

title: Heat Is On U.S. Team as Australians Win Twice
description: The Australians wore ponytails and white war paint under their baseball caps, immune to the 126-degree swelter on the hardcourts and to the dress code at the 122-year-old Longwood Cricket Club. Patrick Rafter and Lleyton Hewitt, along with the green-haired, yellow-faced fans they call the Fanatics, were not here to make a fashion statement today.

title: Replanted in France, Algerian Arts Bloom
description: As Algeria's civil war escalated through the 1990's, the demise of the country's cultural and intellectual life seemed almost anecdotal compared to a civilian death toll rising above 50,000 and an economy in disarray. Culture, however, was not an accidental casualty of war. In a carefully orchestrated campaign to smother intellectual freedom, artists, movie and theater directors, writers, singers and journalists were singled out for death threats and murder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEIN, JOSEPH
description: SHEIN-Joseph, MD. Adored by his loving wife Osnass (nee Charchat) of 53 years. Adoring children, Dr. Ruvan and Karen Shein, Avrom Shein, Dr. Leon and Jill Shein. Cherished grandchildren Arianna, Rebekah, Mariessa, Joshua, Benjamin, Jonathan, Allison. Loving family, devoted friends, patients, colleagues, nurses, and the North Shore Hospital administration and staff are in inconsolable pain and grief. How do you let go a legend as courageous, compassionate, brilliant, caring, with sense of humor, moral ethical standards which knows no equal. Capacity to love and be loved. Took care of the needy, heal the sick and gave credence to the meaning of life. You justified the ten commandments. With aching hearts, never say goodbye darling. We will meet again and continue the wonders of our fortunate, tranquil, happy cultured life as a family who was inspired by your passionate love and devotion. A man of class, dignity, nobility. Thank you my husband, thank you dad, thank you grandpa (Pappa) Joe, for being our greatest gift. Deep emotional love and tears will never cease. Funeral services will be held Sunday, July 18th. 11AM. at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York, opposite Great Neck Station.

title: Writing Codes, Movies and Now a Book
description: When he was 8, Leo Marks broke his first code, a cost code in a signed first edition of ''The Gold Bug'' by Edgar Allan Poe. He was looking at the book in his father's London bookstore at 84 Charing Cross Road (yes, the store in Helene Hanff's popular memoir of that title). From then on, he said, he had two ambitions, to learn as much as he could about codes and to be a writer, possibly of movies, his favorite Saturday afternoon pastime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ANNA JOY
description: FREEDMAN - Anna Joy, 21 months old, beloved daughter of Diane S. and Perry D. Freedman and sister of Samuel Freedman. Adored granddaughter of Renata and Jack P. Schwebel and of Jack and the late Joy Freedman. Cherished niece of Judith and Andrew Lerman, Barbara and Timothy Davis, Lisa and Paul Berger and Renee and Mark Freedman. Funeral services at 10AM, Sunday, July 18, at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Road at Route 22, Armonk, NY, 914-273-2220.

title: Build Highways Fit for Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: House Supports Trade Benefits To Aid Africa
description: The House approved a far-ranging American economic initiative for Africa today that offers enhanced trade benefits in exchange for the adoption of free-market practices by African nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILES, DAVID C.
description: GILES-David C., 37, of San Jose, CA, CTO of Acropolis Systems, died early July 14, 1999 in an automobile accident near Keystone, Colorado. He was born July 22, 1961 in Waterton, NY. After serving a term in the USAF, Dave graduated with honors from DeVry Institute of Technology in Columbus, Ohio. A devoted husband and father, he is survived by his wife Lidia and three children, Fernanda, Bruno and David, Jr. Also survived by his brother Ernie (Claude) and two sisters, Amy and Sue. Friends are invited to attend Funeral Services Sunday, July 18, 1999 at 1:30 PM at Oak Hill Funeral Home's Chapel of Roses, 300 Curtner Ave., San Jose, CA. Burial to follow at Oak Hill Memorial Park, San Jose, California.

title: Speedy Legs Carry Reed to Victory
description: Luck must be on Rick Reed's side this season because, for the most part, he hasn't been all that good.

title: Breaking a Gun-Control Barrier
description: A group of about 95 Colorado teen-agers visited the Capitol this week to talk about the shootings at Columbine High School and the need for more stringent restrictions on firearms. They left with the unmistakable impression that the Republican-led Congress has yet to grasp the devastation caused by gun violence. Fortunately, the Democratic Presidential contenders do grasp the problem. Marking a possible turning point in the gun-control debate, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley have offered gun-control plans that go beyond anything being considered by Congress and even beyond the sound but limited measures put forth by the Administration.

title: 11 Days After the Blackout, City Nervously Watches Mercury Rise
description: New York City, barely recovered from a deadly heat wave that plunged whole neighborhoods into darkness 11 days ago, braced for more scorching weather this weekend with its Emergency Operations Center on alert and Con Edison trying to assure a jittery population that its engineers could avert a blackout this time.

title: Cooper Industries Job Cuts
description: Cooper Industries, the manufacturer of Halo lighting fixtures, said today that it would lay off an undisclosed number of workers as it consolidates its power tools and hand tools divisions to cut costs and raise profits. The tools unit, which will be based in Lexington, S.C., will account for a quarter of the Houston-based manufacturer's $3.7 billion in revenue, said John Breed, a Cooper spokesman. He said most job cuts would come in administrative functions because the manufacturing operations are so different. The unit will consist of 59 plants in North and South America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.

title: 2 Charged With Murder And String of Robberies
description: Law enforcement officials arrested two men yesterday who they said carried out a month-long robbery spree in Brooklyn that left one man dead.

title: AIR PRODUCTS EXPECTS A DISAPPOINTING QUARTER
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc. warned yesterday that its third-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates because of weak demand for chemicals and equipment. Air Products, the world's fourth-largest maker of industrial gases, expects profit from operations of 48 cents a share in the quarter ended June 30, below the average estimate of 56 cents from analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Shares of Air Products, based in Allentown, Pa., fell $4.375, or 11 percent, to $36.9375, in trading of 4.6 million shares. This week Air Liquide S.A. and Air Products said they would jointly buy BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain for about $12.9 billion.

title: Woman in Servitude Case Cleared in '88 Inquiry
description: A New York City child abuse investigator accused this week of keeping a Nigerian girl in servitude was exonerated in a 1988 investigation of possible neglect involving a second Nigerian girl, child welfare officials said yesterday.

title: Long Island Congressman Is Said to Be Leaving G.O.P.
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Long Island Republican who has regularly found himself at odds with his party leaders in Washington, is prepared to defect to the Democratic Party, Democrats in Washington and in New York said last night.

title: Biological Parents Win in Implant Case
description: A justice of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a black baby who was born to a white Staten Island woman after an embryo mix-up at a fertility clinic belongs in the permanent custody of his biological parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSINEK, JULIA
description: RUSINEK-Julia. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our members Roza & Henry Rusinek's daughter. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: PBS Stations Shared Donor Lists With Democrats, Stirring Trouble
description: At least three public television stations in the biggest markets in the country say they have been trading their lists of contributors with Democratic fund-raising groups, a practice that may be legal but that some Congressional Republicans suggest could jeopardize the public financing of all public television and radio stations.

title: Kournikova Gets the Cheers, But Coetzer Wins the Match
description: Amanda Coetzer ignored the pleas of a partisan crowd yelling encouragement for Anna Kournikova tonight, and with a steady game won, 6-4, 6-4, to advance to the semifinals of the A.&P. Tennis Classic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, JEAN
description: STEINBERG-Jean. On July 14th. Beloved aunt of Richard and Judy Kaplan & Gerald & Maury Kaplan. Great aunt of Emily, Amanda, Rachel and Jennifer. Sister of Muriel Kaplan. Cherished friend to many and active community supporter. Services Sunday 12:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SYLVIA
description: SCHWARTZ-Sylvia, 86, of Crugers formerly of New York City died Thursday at Community Hospital, Dobbs Ferry. Survivors include her loving daughter Erika Schwartz, MD; her devoted granddaughters Lisa Schwartz & Katie Armet. Funeral Sunday 10 A.M., Ferncliff Chapel Secor Road, Hartsdale. Memorials to Foundation for Community Hospital at Dobbs Ferry, 128 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. 10522 appreciated.

title: Ronald N. Yurcak, 57, Junk Bond Trader and a Milken Associate
description: Ronald N. Yurcak, a pioneering junk bond trader at Salomon Brothers who later worked closely with Michael R. Milken during Drexel Burnham Lambert's heyday in the late 1980's, died Tuesday. He was 57.

title: Build Highways Fit for Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: CENDANT TO BUY BACK 50 MILLION SHARES
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back 50 million shares at $22.25 each under the terms of a Dutch auction that the company conducted last month. Cendant, a provider of consumer and business services based in New York, had offered to buy back up to 50 million shares in a range of $19.75 to $22.50. In a Dutch auction, a company states the number of shares it will buy back and, instead of stipulating a specific price, sets a range in which stockholders can tender their shares. The highest price within the range that the company must pay to get back all the desired shares becomes the purchase price for all the shares. Cendant said its shareholders tendered 56.1 million shares at $22.25 or less. Shares tendered in excess of the 50 million or in excess of the $22.25 price will be returned.

title: West Virginia, Home Of the Gray in America
description: Ken Hechler may be the only candidate in the post-Monica era of American politics who gets away with singling out female strangers in a crowd of constituents, holding out his arms and grinning as he gently asks, ''May I give you a hug?''

title: Does Our Health Care Really Cost Too Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: Using the Forcing Defense To Take Control of Trumps
description: If the opening leader has length in trumps, he should usually lead a long suit, attempting to force the declarer to ruff, rather than a short suit, hoping for a ruff. An excellent example is the diagramed deal, played last month at the Beverly Club, 150 Central Park South, in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams.

title: Radio Caller and Giuliani Clash On Son's Death at Hands of Police
description: The caller to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's weekly radio show yesterday morning identified herself as Margarita from the Bronx, and told the station workers who screen his calls that she wanted to talk about Con Edison, which the the city has sued over last week's blackout in northern Manhattan.

title: Belgrade's CARE Captives
description: This week in Belgrade a panel of military judges heard the appeal of three employees of the humanitarian group CARE, who in May were convicted of espionage and given long prison terms -- one of them 12 years. The appeal provides an opportunity for Slobodan Milosevic to free these men, and end an apparently baseless prosecution that opens all humanitarian workers to the threat of arrest.

title: Lenders Regard Mexican Economy With Suspicion
description: Mexico's stock market and economic statistics are among the healthiest in Latin America. But the failure of two major companies to meet debt payments this week focused attention on the plight of scores of other heavily indebted concerns, marooned without credit by the country's four-year banking crisis.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: BEYOND FORGERY
description: It was a master swindle: hire a painter down on his luck to forge works by artists like Giacometti and Braque. The forgeries were easily detectable, but the fake provenance wasn't, and therein lay the genius. The art world may never know how much damage was done. A report by Peter Landesman, in The Times Magazine.

title: Two World Shakers Share a Single Program
description: Coming up with interesting themes for programming has never been Kurt Masur's strength. His idea for the New York Philharmonic's contribution to Lincoln Center Festival '99 was typically curious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, FORSTER
description: O'HARA-FORSTER -Brigid. Suddenly, but peacefully in London on July 5th in her 52nd year. An associate editor for Time, she will be terribly missed by colleagues, friends and family in London, New York and around the world. She was predeceased by her parents, Mary Gauntlett O'Hara-Forster and Michael O'Hara-Forster, and survived by her adopted family, stepmother, Phebe Bowditch, stepbrother and sister-in-law, Richard Lyon Bowditch and Carol Scott Bowditch, stepsister and brother-in-law, Dr. Phebe Lowell Bowditch and Andrew Bourne Sibley and four god-children, Alexandra Scott Bowditch and Charlotte Louise Bowditch, Sophie Eleanor McManus and Mage Caroline McManus. Memorial services will be held in London and New York in the fall.

title: Reuters Shares Rise After Inquiry Ends
description: Shares of Reuters Group P.L.C. rose yesterday a day after it said that Federal prosecutors would not charge the company with improperly obtaining information from a big competitor, Bloomberg L.P.

title: George E. Brown Jr., 79, Dies; A Congressman for 18 Terms
description: Representative George E. Brown Jr., an 18-term California Democrat who used his seniority and influence to promote science in general and space exploration in particular, died early today in Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 79 and lived in San Bernardino, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, FRED MAX
description: ROSENBERG-Fred Max, 90. Loving brother, uncle and friend. Your contribution to education and the underserved can never be measured. Graveside services, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Sunday, July 18, 11:00 A.M.

title: Beliefs; Millennial fears in the year 1000: apocalypse then, apocalypse now and apocalypse forever.
description: When Patricia Bernstein, a Houston writer long fascinated by the Middle Ages, began research for an article about the year 1000, she was under an impression shared by many educated Americans.

title: Pak Manages to Maintain Her Lead and Her Composure
description: By the time Se Ri Pak reached her final green today, the crowd had grown at least five deep on every side. After a bogey that left her with a one-stroke lead in the Japan Airlines Big Apple Classic, she was pushed through the gallery by security guards. A crowd of Asian journalists waited, and then a long session with the American news media.

title: MOST IN H.M.O.'S WOULDN'T BENEFIT FROM SENATE BILL
description: Despite all the talk about protecting people in health maintenance organizations, most people in H.M.O.'s would gain no tangible benefit from many of the consumer-protection standards approved by the Senate this week as part of a bill to define patients' rights, lawyers and health policy experts said.

title: INTEGRATED BUYS SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT SYSTEMS
description: Integrated Systems Inc., a developer of security software, said late on Thursday that it had bought the closely held Software Development Systems for $40 million in stock and cash. Integrated Systems said it would merge Software Development Systems, a Chicago-based maker of software-debugging products, with its Diab Data subsidiary. The combined company will operate independently as Diab-Software Development Systems and have more than $20 million in annual revenue.

title: Restitution Law
description: Under a new state law that allows municipalities, fire districts and other emergency service providers to seek restitution for costs associated with false bomb threats, parents may be held accountable for their children's actions.

title: Amid Apollo 11 Nostalgia, Questions on NASA's Fate
description: Over dinner a few weeks ago, a former astronaut who walked on the Moon and one of the Apollo flight directors got to skylarking about the good old days, something people do when they think of their past receding and a big anniversary approaching, in this case the 30th anniversary of the Apollo 11 lunar landing on July 20, 1969.

title: Salute to Chinese
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Suit Ended, Work to Start on Watchung Square
description: AFTER two years of legal wrangling, the fate of 78 vacant acres along Route 22 in Watchung where the Lockheed Electronics complex once stood has been decided.

title: Short Menu, Tall Ideas in New American Style
description: TIBWIN GRILL, in a corner brownstone diagonally across from the Shubert Theater on College Street, is the latest entry along what has become New Haven's restaurant row.

title: We Can't All Win The World Cup
description: There were 20 of us piled up in my living room last weekend, 12 adults and two high school boys and six raucous 13-year-old girls in soccer jerseys and stars-and-stripes face paint, and at the close of the Women's World Cup final, as we were hollering and clapping each other on the back, this gorgeous Nike advertisement came on television and grabbed all the women by the throat. Maybe you saw it: small elated girl in the stadium stands, transfixed by the action on the field below, and on the screen the printed message: ''To the little girl in Section T, Row 17, Seat 9, from the U.S. women's soccer team: Thank you.''

title: What Candidates Did in War Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: What to Do When Busing Becomes Irrelevant
description: The end came with hardly a whimper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, RUTH
description: POST-Ruth On July 15, 1999 at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Emil. Loving mother of Richard and David and their wives Carol Post and Katlean Demonchy. Adored grandmother of Cynthia, Steven, Pamela, Randee, Lori and Jill and great-grandmother of Ethan, Matthew, Katlin, Julia, Blake, Samantha and Grant. Dear sister of Marcy. Cryptside service Sunday, July 18, 11:00 AM at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ.

title: Where the Ante Is Always Going Up
description: THIS is the story of five brothers and a temptation-filled city. It is the story of how one of those brothers picked up three cards from a poker table and found himself staring into the pit of personal destruction. It is the story of a monumental effort by some of this nation's best minds to address a vexatious, volatile issue. It is, in fact, a darned complicated story, so we'll dispense with any more of these irksome foreshadowing sentences.

title: Arrests in Injury Cases Termed a Warning
description: THE arrest of four correction officers last week on charges that they faked disability injuries and a fifth on a charge that he falsified a Westchester residency while collecting disability pay is meant to be a warning to others who may be doing the same things that their days of cheating the taxpayers are over, Westchester officials say.

title: Food; Well Preserved
description: There used to be one reason to can: necessity. Summer is short, winter long. Putting food away for the cold months was a woman's way of making hay.

title: Picked Up and Dusted Off, A Ski Chain Starts Anew
description: BY late last week, word had spread around the Killington area in Vermont, where the economy depends upon the ski trade, that something even better than a heavy snowfall was on its way. It was a heavy downpour of cash.

title: Essay on Little League Accentuated the Negative
description: To the Editor:

title: A Reign Of Terror
description: Q. The director of the small nonprofit organization where I work is absolutely impossible. She is controlling and has poor management skills, and her mood swings result in unpredictable tirades. As a result, we have high turnover at all levels. Our board members are aware of the situation, but their attitude seems to be that, as long as the work gets done, it doesn't matter how the office is run. Any advice?

title: Ceaseless Novelty in A Lifetime Of Dance
description: TALKING about Merce Cunningham's choreography can lead to an attack of the nonlinear. Words like possibility, multiplicity and flexibility burst out like the unexpected movements in his dances.

title: End Shootouts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: This Broker Really Takes A Long View
description: I CAN'T see what all the fuss is about,'' said Frank W. Fletcher, a 95-year-old stockbroker. ''My father was pushing a hand mower well into his 90's.''

title: No More 'Sex,' Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay on Little League Accentuated the Negative
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the A La Carte column last Sunday about Pinocchio Trattoria, a new restaurant in Port Washington, misstated the telephone number. It is 767-9229.

title: Bellong Mahathera Is Dead; Cambodian Monk Was 110
description: The Venerable Dharmawara Mahathera, a high-ranking Buddhist monk who advised kings and prime ministers and established a new life after the age of 90 as a Buddhist leader in the United States, died on June 26 in Stockton, Calif., and his body was cremated as part of a 14-day ceremony that ended on July 10.. He was 110.

title: New Jersey Troopers Enjoy Strong Public Support Despite Charges of Bias
description: As Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has struggled to change the racially discriminatory culture of the state police, she has run into a surprisingly stubborn obstacle: the agency's steadfast support among white New Jersey residents.

title: At the Desk, Off the Clock And Below Statistical Radar
description: YOUNG assistant professors at Cornell University once had time to paint their own houses. Now nights and weekends are devoted to research and writing as they struggle to win tenure. ''Painting your own house is not something you even think about anymore,'' said Robert Frank, a tenured Cornell professor today who did his own painting as an assistant in the 1970's.

title: In Season of Play, Daunting Struggle to Learn
description: Outside, summer beckons, with bikes to be ridden, video games to be played, cartoons to be watched, Barbies to be pampered for hours on end.

title: To the Barricades Again: One Civilian's Gridlock Plan
description: A graphic artist who works in midtown has come up with a plan to replace those unpopular pedestrian barricades the police erected in December 1997 at busy intersections. Ted Ostindien, who says his plan is cheaper and more pedestrian-friendly than other alternatives the city has explored, has been trying to persuade officials to consider his idea. So far, they aren't sold on it.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-18-99; Debt Voyeurs
description: When it comes to living large on pilfered cash, Martin Frankel -- who is accused of making off with $335 million -- deserves all the attention he has been getting. Here was a guy nervy enough to make a to-do list on which item one was launder money. A guy who secured the use of the Vatican's bank account for his financial chicanery. An essentially geeky guy, by all accounts, whose tastes in spending ran to satellite dishes, computer terminals, bondage videos and bodacious female ''retainers.'' (Yeah, baby!) Yet Frankel's saga of economic malfeasance hasn't held my attention the way the saga of Leonard and Elfreda Massie did.

title: New Kid on The Block
description: How interesting that Spike Lee admits to encountering almost no racism during his childhood in an integrated Cobble Hill, Brooklyn (June 27). One might conclude, therefore, that his professional gruel of hip-hop culture and racialist politics is an exclusively ideological posture and perhaps even a self-serving career decision. But give Lee his proper due: he never misses an opportunity to cast black people from his former ''hood'' in the worst possible light. Christmas in July, indeed! Since Lee admittedly doesn't consider taking Pampers, sofas and even Cadillacs to be a crime, at least not when the lights are out, no wonder he considers the Mayor's attempt to make New York a safer city for all its citizens to be the work of an ''evil'' personality.

title: Remembering Hopewell Before Suburban Sprawl
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Getting Real in the Other China
description: HERE'S a riddle: How do you make a country richer and more democratic and at the same time outmaneuver a huge, luggish neighbor that wants to ''reunify'' with you?

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-18-99: Salient Facts: Pools; Just Add Water
description: In the 70's, pools shaped like big-ticket consumables were big. Auto enthusiasts commissioned car-shaped pools, and rock stars did guitars. These days, however, pool buyers are after subtler charms -- free-form, lagoon-style pools integrated into elaborate landscaping, a seamless union of nature and plumbing. But one thing remains the same: the desire among pool owners to impress their friends. ''We're in the business of building 'whoa-damns,' ''says Brian Van Bower, a Miami pool designer and builder. ''People show the pool and everybody looks and goes: 'Whoa! Damn!' ''Here's what's making a splash in backyards across the country.

title: July 11-17; A Vaccine Is Halted
description: A year ago, health workers were elated when the first vaccine against rotavirus, the most common cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children, was licensed and recommended for all infants in this country. But the joy has now been muted; Federal health officials called for immediate suspension of the vaccine because post-marketing monitoring suggested a link between it and 20 non-fatal cases of a painful blockage of the bowel called intussusception. LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: My Mother The Big Screen Turkey
description: YOU would think the critical drubbing of ''Wild, Wild West'' this month -- on the heels of critical drubbings of ''The Mod Squad,'' ''My Favorite Martian,'' ''The Avengers'' and ''Lost in Space'' -- might give the slightest bit of pause to the original thinkers bent on recycling defunct television shows for the big screen.

title: Bookend; The Modernist From Maine
description: I have known and loved the poems of Edwin Arlington Robinson for practically 50 years. When I was 14, his poems seemed agreeably gloomy to me. His subjects are good-for-nothings, nonstarters, weaklings. I liked how Robinson treated them -- archly, satirically, harshly, just as I thought they deserved. And his poems were easy to memorize, with their ineluctable meters and never-failing rhymes. Here's an example, ''Reuben Bright,'' from ''The Children of the Night,'' published in 1897, when Robinson was 27:

title: Dakota Death Trip
description: FROM THE BLACK HILLS By Judy Troy. 284 pp. New York: Random House. $23.95.

title: Orchestra Concerts Abound This Week
description: SUMMER in Westchester does not normally offer too many orchestra concerts, but this week the Westchester Philharmonic, the Yonkers Philharmonic, the Orchestra of St. Luke's, the New York Philharmonic and the Public Works Orchestra are all performing here.

title: Yanks Breeze; Jury Is Still Out On Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte was in the ninth grade when he began dating his future wife, Laura, who was a grade behind him at Deer Park High in Deer Park, Tex. She has watched him pitch from bleachers and grandstands for a dozen years, in high school and the minors, and when she suggested recently that Pettitte had lost his competitive fire, he was not sure quite how to respond.

title: A Stage Champion's Summertime Good-bye
description: IF you love well-written plays with substance, then it is difficult to imagine the theater without Lloyd Richards, a man who has not only dedicated his life to the stage but has had an extremely successful run. Yet, by his own admission, all long runs must end.

title: A Place for Immigrants To Telephone and Fax
description: At Calling Center, which opened last month in the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood, people can make an international call in one of nine private phone booths for 49 cents a minute after a $1 initial charge per call.

title: Long Island Congressman Quits G.O.P., Citing 'Extremists'
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes, a mercurial Republican who has frequently butted heads with House Republican leaders, announced today that he was becoming a Democrat because his own party had been captured by ''extremists.''

title: New Airline Policies Aim to Improve Service
description: Faced with the possibility of new Federal regulations, the airline industry last month announced a series of new policies to improve customer service. But it may be up to six months before the reforms take effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AMICO, MARGARET (NEE FURST)
description: D'AMICO-Margaret (nee Furst) Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Rita Basso and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Patricia Muirhead, John Basso, Dana and Taj D'Amico. Adored great grandmother of Ryan, Corey, Tatum, Justin, Chynna and Sea. Services were held Saturday, July 17, 1999.

title: Miss van den Broek, Mr. Semansky
description: Amy Cornelia van den Broek, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albertus W. van den Broek of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Chartz Semansky, the son of Jane Chartz McEldowney of Berkeley, Calif., and Michael P. Semansky of Benecia, Calif. The Rev. William Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Wickenden Chapel in Marion, Mass.

title: Braves Have Answer For Yankees' Critics
description: What's wrong with the Yankees? WHAT'S wrong with the Yankees? What's WRONG with the Yankees? What's wrong with the YANKEES?

title: House Republican Defects to Democrats
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Republican from Long Island who has often tangled with his party's leaders in the House, announced that he was becoming a Democrat because the Republican Party had been captured by ''extremists.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOPNICK, MAX
description: CHOPNICK-Max Died July 8, 1999. You leave us ever so much better than we were, Dear Max. Your great good nature, quiet and wise counsel and steady resolve under any circumstance will be remembered as the model to strive for in our continuing efforts to bring beautiful music into the lives of those who know, or are discovering its wonders. The artists, board and patrons of NEW YORK PHILOMUSICA

title: In Canada, Our Culture or Theirs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Discounts Proliferate As 42d Street Changes
description: Reflecting the dynamic nature of business in prime midtown locations, three stores on West 42d Street just west of Fifth Avenue are going out of business and will be closed or relocated by the end of the month.

title: Streetscapes/Grand Army Plaza; Spaces that March to Different Drummers
description: ONE of Donald J. Trump's current projects, raising the sunken plaza in front of the General Motors Building, on the east side of Fifth Avenue from 58th to 59th Streets, brushes against one of New York's early preservation battles and focuses attention on the entire Plaza area itself. For the construction of the General Motors Building in 1968 followed bitter protests over its changes to the Grand Army Plaza, complaints that remain unresolved even by the work in progress.

title: Sounding A Drumbeat: We're All Alone
description: ''FAIR enough then. So we're alone.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, FORSTER, BRIGID
description: O'HARA-FORSTER -Brigid Suddenly, but peacefully in London on July 5th in her 52nd year. An associate editor for Time, she will be terribly missed by colleagues, friends and family in London, New York and around the world. She was predeceased by her parents, Mary Gauntlett O'Hara-Forster and Michael O'Hara-Forster, and survived by her adopted family, stepmother, Phebe Bowditch, stepbrother and sister-in-law, Richard Lyon Bowditch and Carol Scott Bowditch, stepsister and brother-in-law, Dr. Phebe Lowell Bowditch and Andrew Bourne Sibley and four god-children, Alexandra Scott Bowditch and Charlotte Louise Bowditch, Sophie Eleanor McManus and Mage Caroline McManus. Memorial services will be held in London and New York in the fall.

title: Laura Kehoe And Eric Maillis
description: Dr. Laura Gaeta Kehoe, a daughter of Frances and Ronald Kehoe of Boston, was married yesterday to Eric Franklin Maillis, a son of Dr. Lawrence Maillis of Wilmette, Ill., and the late Margaret Maillis. The Rev. Stuart Sandberg performed the ceremony at St. Cecelia's Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: An Outsider's Belated Moment in the Sun
description: WHAT was once out now seems to be in. Who would ever have imagined a Maxfield Parrish retrospective at a respectable museum like the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, with a scholarly catalogue? Similarly, a few 20th-century painters with no formal training, like Horace Pippin, have become subjects of serious interest and are gaining mainstream recognition.

title: The Nation: Agony of Victory; America Finds It's Lonely At the Top
description: IT is impossible to pinpoint the moment when America's successes in the 1990's moved from a topic of grudging admiration around the world to a constant source of annoyance at Washington's triumphalism to a rationale for mistrust and resistance.

title: Mayor Improves Image of Birmingham but Not Racial Split
description: For the last 20 years, each time he walked into the City Hall he transformed, Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. has passed by the name T. Eugene Connor carved into the building's cornerstone.

title: Visitors to Greece
description: To the Editor: Stephen Kinzer's ''Correspondent's Report'' on tourism in Greece (June 6) tackles a difficult subject that deserves clarification. Indeed, a lot has changed since the article was written.

title: Working for the Fun of It
description: Neuberger Berman, the investment company, calls it ''surprising'' that the more money people make, the less likely they were to say in a survey it sponsored last spring that they would quit their jobs if they received a windfall inheritance. Among earners of less than $125,000 a year, 54 percent said they'd quit, while only 28 percent of those making $250,000 or more would. But if job satisfaction rises as one climbs the ladder, it's hardly surprising that those with high earnings are more likely to love what they do. Or perhaps the result confirms what many at drone level suspect: that the more money you make, the more fun it is to go to work. BARBARA IRELAND

title: Assisted Living Projects Draw Elderly and Rules
description: AT the end of last year, faced with four proposals for building assisted living centers and other forms of housing for the elderly, Linda Cooper, Supervisor of Yorktown, turned to the County Planning Department with questions about parking, market saturation and possible conversion in case a project does not attract its intended market or the operators go bankrupt.

title: Delays Are Clogging Many European Airports
description: ON a recent afternoon, the Lufthansa flight from Cologne, ordinarily as predictable as the tides, lumbered into Fiumicino airport outside Rome an hour and a half late. Bedraggled passengers bumped into others from the Crossair flight from Basel, usually a reflection of Swiss punctuality, which was 50 minutes late.

title: Olympian Prices
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Edwin A. Bernstein's letter ''Olympian Prices'' (June 20). I have had a similar experience with obtaining accommodations in Sydney for the Games.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Starting Out in the Evening

title: Children's Books; Don't Just Do Something, Sit There
description: Daisy, the duckling who learned to mind her mother in the well-regarded picture book ''Come Along, Daisy!,'' is back in a companion volume, DAISY AND THE EGG (Little, Brown, $12.95; ages 3 to 7), written and illustrated by Jane Simmons.

title: Stanley Soble, 59, Theater Casting Director
description: Stanley Soble, casting director for the Center Theater Group/Ahmanson Theater and the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, died on July 6 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 59.

title: Was Sports Bra Celebration Spontaneous?
description: Before the Women's World Cup, Mia Hamm was the undisputed star of the United States team and the idol of soccer-playing girls nationwide. After the United States victory, the torch was passed to a black Nike sports bra.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 18, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MERDE

title: July 11-17; Cruise Line Discloses Sexual Assault Cases
description: Carnival, the world's biggest cruise company, disclosed in court papers that its crew members had been accused of sexually assaulting passengers and fellow workers 62 times in a 5-year period that ended last August. Though details on the incidents were sparse, it was the first time anyone in the cruise industry had disclosed statistics on shipboard crime.

title: The Aura Of the Aura
description: I was reminded of the reasons I find Bill Bradley an appealing national figure when I read Melinda Henneberger's article (June 27). The final paragraph (in which Bradley spoke of the McGwire-Sosa home-run contest and politics) summarized my prediction that the ticket will be Gore-Bradley for the Democrats in 2000. Both candidates are qualified, cerebral and even complement each other. The trust issue will be important, and both pass that test. A dignified duo would increase the chance of a Democratic victory.

title: With Kinder Face, the Left Is Blossoming in Uruguay
description: From Monday through Wednesday, Tabare Vazquez fights cancer as one of Uruguay's leading oncologists. From Thursday through Saturday, he runs for President -- and along the campaign trail he wags his finger at smokers urging them to ''lay off the poison.''

title: OUTDOORS; Catching a Large Fish Isn't a Simple Task
description: My taste buds have never met a softshelled crab they didn't like. To me, this molting blue crab is especially likable when cooked on a grill after having been marinated in a mixture of ranch dressing, olive oil, fresh garlic and lemon juice.

title: Aspen Journal; Footing Security Bill for President Upsets a Big-Money Town
description: This is a town of good and plenty, where a majority of the population can be divided roughly between the haves and the have mores.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Say Formaggio
description: Celebrity journalism took its first delirious breaths on Rome's Via Veneto, during Italy's post-World War II boom, and the street was littered with royalty, both celluloid and actual, at play until the early hours of the morning. Armed with Rolliflex cameras, sunglasses and a fierce gonzo attitude, the first paparazzi prowled the cafes on their Lambrettas. Some of the best trophies were bagged by a photographer named Tazio Secchiaroli, the designated leader of the pack and the model for the character Paparazzo in Fellini's film ''La Dolce Vita.'' Secchiaroli found gold in staging confrontations with his prey -- an alarming flash, an overturned table, a starlet on the run -- creating little incidents,'' as he says in TAZIO SECCHIAROLI: Greatest of the Paparazzi (Abrams, $49.50), to ''produce great features that earned us a lot of money.'' And, not so incidentally, earned the ''victim'' a lot of press coverage. A happy arrangement all round. This delicious picture book was edited by Diego Mormorio, a photography critic, in collaboration with the family of Secchiaroli, who died last year at the age of 73. His paparazzi shots have their own artless beauty -- the anti-esthetic so popular now in fashion magazines, seen in the white, flash-lit faces of Anita Ekberg and Anthony Steele, for example, frozen in a series of flight-and-fight photographs. Brigitte Bardot, Ursula Andress, Marcello Mastroianni are lovingly and lushly pictured in repose and at work, off and on the sets at Cinecitt. And what can you say about the actress Secchiaroli called ''La Loren,'' with whom he had a 20-year collaboration? She is large and comely, and her exposition here brings back an old song about the hunter being captured by the game. Penelope Green

title: Sampras's 'Sweet Victory' in Five Sets at Doubles Keeps U.S. Alive in Davis Cup
description: When Pete Sampras raised his racquet to serve for the doubles victory that saved the United States Davis Cup team from elimination by Australia today, the on-court thermometer had already boiled over at 129 degrees. The radar gun had short-circuited, 5,300 overheated fans at the Longwood Cricket Club were screaming ''Pete, Pete, Pete,'' and Sampras was close to a meltdown himself. After 3 hours 28 minutes of tussling with Mark Woodforde and Sandon Stolle on the sizzling hardcourts, he wanted out of the inferno.

title: Tennis Elbow?
description: Summertime is here, and the living isn't as easy as it should be. Have you ever creatively fibbed to excuse yourself from work? And just what were you up to instead? Or have you ever caught anyone else playing hooky, and what did you do about it? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LETTERS OF TRANSIT

title: Call It Easy Street or Windfall, Lottery Gold Can Fade Fast
description: IF 1999 is an average year for lottery winners in Westchester County, five people will achieve the promise of ''a dollar and a dream'' and win the jackpot offered by New York state every Wednesday and Saturday. Sixty-three residents have made the big hit since the lottery began 33 years ago.

title: A Room Where Farm Children Went to School, When They Could
description: The Old Wall Historical Society has acquired a 20-by-40-foot wooden building that has floorboards soaked with oil, holes in two side walls and the roof, and tin walls and a ceiling that are covered with grime. For much of the past 60 years, the building has been used as a lawn mower repair shop. But its current condition is not the way the historical society members picture the building.

title: Going South, To Harlem
description: CHARLES'S SOUTHERN-STYLE KITCHEN ++

title: Sports of The Times; To Win, the Braves May Need to Sweep New York
description: AS the millennium approaches, the Atlanta Braves are perched where they have been for a decade: in first place in the National League East. And they're there, as always, because of pitching.

title: Another Big Shift Down at the Firehouse: Women Volunteers
description: WHEN Patricia DiBella walks down the street or into the supermarket, it's not uncommon for her to hear a child say, ''Oh look, it's the lady firefighter.''

title: In the Region/Long Island; A Move-Up Niche in the Old Neighborhood
description: IN an unincorporated area of the Town of Huntington known as Old Chester Hills, Frank L. Jaklitsch, president of Long Island Home Development in Dix Hills, has a subdivision called the Enclave under construction on nine acres. The eight houses will share a cul-de-sac with nine others that were built about 10 years ago.

title: Flower Power
description: The Artist's Widow

title: A Primal Tuscan
description: Every molecule of '95 Conti Contini Sangiovese, a primal Tuscan red, seems packed with sexy up-front flavor, almost more than even seasoned wine lovers can manage.

title: Mountain Madness
description: Climbing High

title: Patrol Keeps an Eye On Bridgeport Boaters
description: ON a rainy Sunday morning, Deputy Harbormaster Paul Cipolla nudges the Bridgeport 42 out of its slip onto Cedar Creek and heads south through Black Rock Harbor to Long Island Sound. At 10:30 A.M. there are few boats out, but the radar screen shows a nasty tumor of thunderstorms heading from the north; the Coast Guard is broadcasting warnings of heavy rain and high winds, suggesting that boaters seek safe harbor immediately.

title: Helping Glen Island
description: James Maisano, a Republican County Legislator representing parts of New Rochelle, Pelham and Pelham Manor, said the county-operated Glen Island Park in New Rochelle -- which he said ''has had many acquaintances'' and not enough ''real friends'' -- deserves some extra attention.

title: Colleen Codey, Edward Hughes
description: Colleen Marie Codey and Edward Arden Hughes are to be married this afternoon in Convent Station, N.J. Msgr. Robert T. Sheeran, the president of Seton Hall University, is to officate in the Holy Family Chapel at the College of St. Elizabeth.

title: 'The Heart Of the Tenderloin'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mission Impossible
description: ORPHANS OF THE COLD WAR

title: Reaching New Heights in Aerial Ads
description: WHATEVER it was that the Wright brothers had in mind when they struggled to make the first powered flight 96 years ago, bigger, brighter advertising horizons were probably not in the picture. Nevertheless, ad slogans are as much a feature in today's wild blue yonder as 747's and satellites. Nowhere do those ad slogans enjoy better visibility than the skies over Long Island, with 110 miles of quality bathing beach and millions of sky-gazing sunbathers each summer.

title: Key Opposition Leader Joins Rally Asking Milosevic to Resign
description: A leading opposition politician, Vuk Draskovic, appeared today for the first time at a rally calling for the resignation of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the formation of a transitional government leading to new elections.

title: SOAPBOX; The U-Haul Bus Lines
description: EVER since the Metrocard was introduced in 1994, bus ridership has increased significantly, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. More people, more annoying habits, more baggage. Not the shopping bags and briefcases you might expect. But real baggage. Large, odd and oversized.

title: C. Herwitz, 72, Major Collector Of Art From India
description: Chester Herwitz, who with his wife, Davida, amassed one of the world's largest collections of modern art from India, died on June 17 in a three-car collision in Petersham, Mass. Mr. Herwitz, who lived in Worcester, Mass., was 72.

title: In Canada, Our Culture or Theirs?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Plight Of the Polite
description: CAN you be a real New Yorker if you can't kvetch?

title: Clinton Warns Against G.O.P.'s Tax Cuts
description: Stepping up his attack on Republican tax-cutting proposals, President Clinton said today that the cost of the tax bill moving through the House would rise to unimaginable levels and threaten the nation's ability to deal with its most pressing long-term problems.

title: Ghana Dream Homes Inc.
description: Looking to buy that first home but frustrated by high prices in the suburbs? Consider a visit to Kwasi Kissi's real estate office on East Tremont Avenue, where a newly constructed three-bedroom house goes for just $45,000.

title: O.K., Sports Isn't Solely About Sex
description: Equating sex and sports last week was a mistake for which I have been taken to task and for which I now apologize. There is far more to sports than sex. There is also drugs and violence. And they seem to be fun, too.

title: The Man Whose Stuff Is Still on the Moon
description: ON July 20, 1969, when the lunar module carrying American astronauts landed on the moon, Tom Kelly was in Houston, sitting in a small, windowless room across the hall from Mission Control. Surrounded by rows of consoles, he could see everything that was happening, talk to flight control and converse with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ANNA JOY
description: FREEDMAN - Anna Joy, 21 months old, beloved daughter of Diane S. and Perry D. Freedman and sister of Samuel Freedman. Adored granddaughter of Renata and Jack P. Schwebel and of Jack and the late Joy Freedman. Cherished niece of Judith and Andrew Lerman, Barbara and Timothy Davis, Lisa and Paul Berger and Renee and Mark Freedman. Funeral services at 10AM, Sunday, July 18, at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Road at Route 22, Armonk, NY, 914-273-2220.

title: Lisa Grumhaus, Jonathan Haas
description: Lisa Fentress Grumhaus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Grumhaus of Lake Forest, Ill., was married last evening at her parents' house to Jonathan Mark Haas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Haas of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Jennifer Grumhaus Daly, the bride's sister, who is an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Hills, Trees And Maybe A New Park
description: With the city and a developer getting set to negotiate over preserving six hillside acres of Jones Woods, between York and Prospect Avenues, in New Brighton, zoning revisions prompted in part by a controversial development there have been approved by the city's Planning Department, an important step in the process of turning them into law.

title: Rachel Swarns and Henri Cauvin
