description: Rachel Lucille Swarns and Henri Edward Cauvin, newspaper reporters in Manhattan, were married yesterday. The Rev. John P. Duffell performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in St. George, Staten Island.

title: Fired Workers, Roiled Tenants
description: When Stellar Management bought a 15-story building with 101 apartments at 150 East 85th Street in May, then dismissed 6 of the 8 building workers without notice or severance, the former employees turned to Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union for legal counsel and moral support.

title: Q&A/Pamela Thomas-Graham; Author Explores Issues Through Heroine
description: PAMELA THOMAS-GRAHAM is not Nikki Chase, the heroine of her mystery novels, but the two have much in common. Both are black professionals with Harvard degrees, and through Nikki Ms. Thomas-Graham is able to explore many issues, including racial profiling, interracial dating and the role of flamboyant black activists.

title: Freeways Make an Easy Scapegoat for Sprawl; Alternative Zoning
description: To the Editor:

title: A Resigned City Braces for Another Stretch of Hot Weather
description: First the good news: the temperatures actually were cooler yesterday than those that seared the metropolitan region over the Fourth of July weekend. But most people, until they looked hard at a thermometer, refused to believe it.

title: He Just Keeps On Drilling
description: John R. Stanley, whose oil-patch booms and busts echo more loudly than almost anyone else's, is at it again. After a third corporate bankruptcy filing in 20 years, he has lined up his creditors behind a reorganization plan submitted on Friday that would let him drill for natural gas once more. But they took his biggest toy away.

title: Paella Beyond the Usual: From Quail to Seaweed
description: EVERYONE loves a good paella, but how often do we come across one? Recipes in all-purpose cookbooks and the concoctions served in restaurants are often far from the authentic dish.

title: Chemistry Cleans Up A Factory
description: THEY all played their classic roles once word got out last November that a Dow Chemical Company contractor had repeatedly spilled toxic dust intended for Dow's incinerator.

title: Shares That Track Assets Add Value At a Cost
description: MOST COMPANIES are not shy about doing most anything they can to increase their stock prices. A growing number have concluded that the best way to accomplish that goal is to create an entirely new piece of paper.

title: In Nyack, Visual Touches Match the Food
description: A RESTAURATEUR who has not tested every seat in his restaurant for comfort and view may as well be selling shoes. This pronouncement brings us to one of the reasons we like Lu Shane's, as might any diner who has been assigned a place facing a dead wall. Lu Shane's seating arrangement provides engaging prospects to all diners and is only part of the thoughtful, easy elegance designed by the decorator, Laura Day.

title: At Age 23, Capriati Continues Comeback
description: In 1990, when she was 14, Jennifer Capriati became the sensation of tennis. That year she became the youngest player to be ranked in the world's top 10, the youngest to be seeded in a Grand Slam tournament (12th at Wimbledon), the youngest to win a match at Wimbledon (she got to the fourth round). At 16 she became the youngest player to reach $1 million in career earnings. She defeated Martina Navratilova, Monica Seles and Gabriela Sabatini.

title: Career Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIDGES, HAROLD V.
description: BRIDGES-Harold V. Of Hampton Bays. A retired operations engineer at Columbia Broadcasting System in New York City died on July 6 at Southampton Hospital. He was 93 years old. Mr. Bridges' CBS assignments over 30 years included broadcasts of The New York Philharmonic, The Boston Symphony and The Cleveland Symphony. He served in the rostrum of every National Convention from 1948 to 1962 in the Call of States. He officiated at Cape Canaveral in the moon flight of 1969. He attended New York University for television engineering and was a member of the I.B.E.W. and The Audio Society of New York. He is survived by a niece, Mrs. Howard Johnson (nee) Rosemarie Crawley of Montclair, NJ and a cousin Mrs. Barbara Creaser of Torrington, CT and six grand nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Lillian Bridges Crawley and a nephew, John J. Crawley. For more information contact R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Inc., 94 East Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial was held on July 9th from St. Rosalie's Church in Hampton Bays followed by an interment in Calvary Cemetery. Remembrances may be made to the Dominican Sisters, PO Box 1028, Hampton Bays, New York 11946-0404.

title: The View From/Yonkers; Reunion at Orphanage Remembers Good Life
description: WHEN Lynn Keyser McSpedon feels unhappy, she gets in her car and drives from her home in Hawthorne to the Julia Dykman Andrus Memorial children's home here. ''It gives me a warm feeling, a safe feeling, a feeling like I'm coming home, just to drive through the campus,'' the 55-year-old Mrs. McSpedon said.

title: Knight-Errant Spenser, With Soulful Eyes
description: Robert B. Parker has written more than 25 novels about a Boston private eye called Spenser, after the Elizabethan poet who wrote ''The Faerie Queene.'' Like the noble warriors in that 16th-century allegory, this tough-but-tender hero fancies himself a knight on a lifelong quest to do good, protect the innocent and beat the bad guys to a bloody pulp. To further his heroic calling, Spenser keeps his body strong by jumping in the ring with professional boxers at the last sweaty-socks sports gym on the Eastern Seaboard. And we know his heart is pure because he is slavishly faithful to his lady love, a sexy shrink named Susan Silverman, and would lay down his life for his best friend, a hired killer named Hawk.

title: July 11-17; No Fishing
description: Church and state, forever separate -- that's American bedrock. No city would dare, say, depict Jesus on a town hall banner. But as with any self-respecting issue, vast gray areas emerge. If two lines cross in a town logo, some will see a Christian symbol; others, well, two lines crossing.

title: A Shaky Start Keeps Hershiser From No. 200
description: The story line sounded too perfect to be true: Orel Hershiser going for his 200th career victory on a day with a turn-back-the-clock promotion.

title: Lachine Canal
description: To the Editor: Judith Yarnall's article ''Montreal: Two Wheels, Few Hills'' (June 27) describes the Lachine Canal and the early days of Lachine, a suburb of Montreal, Quebec. To me, the name of Lachine always evokes Saul Bellow. The author, who was named Nobel laureate in Literature in 1976 ''for the human understanding and subtle analysis of contemporary culture that are combined in his work,'' was born there in 1915.

title: A Flier who Erred on the Side of Caution
description: John F. Kennedy Jr. was a relatively new pilot, flying a well-equipped and relatively new single-engine plane.

title: Kevin Godbout, Pinar Kodaman
description: Pinar Hatice Kodaman, a daughter of Nermin Kodaman of Douglaston, Queens, and the late Dr. Hilmi I. Kodaman, was married on Friday to Kevin Michael Godbout, the son of Carol O. Behrman of Madison, Conn., and Robert M. Godbout of Summerville, S.C. Edward L. Kalinowski, the First Selectman of Portland, Conn., officiated there at St. Clements Castle, a historic house.

title: Van de Velde Grabs Carnoustie by Throat And Won't Let Go
description: It was a spectacular round of golf, almost stunning considering the difficulty of the golf course, the magnitude of the tournament and the obscurity of the player who did it.

title: Filling the Space Atop Symphony Space
description: WHAT'S gray, 108 feet 11 inches long, 5 feet 5 inches high and weighs 23 tons? Answer: The solution to a vexatious and long-running development dilemma on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: An Analyst Creates, Well, a Kind of Head Shop
description: Even in the information age, one advantage of living in a big city is that if you need a rare item, you can get it immediately at a small specialty store and not pay shipping charges. One such store is the recently opened Other Books bookstore, at 224 West 20th Street (between Seventh and Eighth Avenues) in Chelsea.

title: Style; Radical Chic
description: In ''The Matrix,'' the high-tech movie that invites its audience to rage against the machine, Keanu Reeves and his cohorts wear trendy uniforms to rebel: the now-notorious black trenchcoats and the kind of clothes that are euphemistically called man-made but are actually machine-made.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 27 about Americans' changing perceptions of Latin pop music misspelled the middle name of an authority on African studies who commented. He is Robert Farris Thompson, not Ferris.

title: Vanessa Fox, Samuel Halpert
description: Vanessa Sergeant Fox, the daughter of Marion and Reeder Fox of Ardmore, Pa., was married yesterday to Samuel Robert Halpert, a son of Florence Murray Halpert and Michael P. Halpert, both of Philadelphia. The Rev. Charles R. O'Hara performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: In Cornwall, Two Coasts In Four Days
description: WHY Cornwall? People are always singing its praises, of course, rhapsodizing over its extreme weather, its rugged terrain, its dizzying coastal paths, its clotted cream, its superior sheep. There is no question that it is a perfect place to walk along a cliff and contemplate a failed love affair or have an existential crisis: however self-indulgent you feel, your mood will be drowned out by the sound of the waves crashing beneath you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROBERT AUGUSTIN
description: KING-Robert Augustin, 88, passed away on Friday, July 9th, 1999 in Memorial SW Hospital in Houston. Bob King was born on September 3, 1910 in Marion, Indiana, the son of Roy Melvin King and Estella Bernice Sheron King. He moved to Oklahoma at age 18 and earned a BS in chemical engineering from the University of Oklahoma at Norman, class of '35. Bob was a 2nd Lieutenant in the Field Artillery Reserve. He joined Phillips Petroleum Company in Borger, Tex., in 1935 as a ditch-digger and worked his way up to chief chemist. He left Phillips in 1943 to join E.B. Badger & Sons as a senior process engineer, working in New York and London until 1953. During this time he was involved in the Lend-Lease program and the planning stages of the Marshall Plan. From 1954-1956, he was the district manager for Stone & Webster in New York. In 1957, he became the managing director for Badger Company in The Hague, Netherlands. He left in 1964. In 1965, he founded King-Wilkinson, Inc., and guided it as president until 1984. In 1985, he founded Robert A. King, Inc., and functioned as president until 1998, when he assumed the role of chairman. Bob King is survived by his wife, Johanna Akkerman King; his son, Robert Alexander King; daughters Mary Elizabeth, Sharon Johanna and Estella Regina; grandsons Robert Frederick and James Dudley Wesseldijk and James Bernard King; granddaughters Rebecca King O'Rian and Deborah King; great-grandson Aidan O'Rian. A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M., Thursday, July 22, 1999 in the chapel of Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, 1010 Bering Drive, Houston, Texas. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Robert A. King Chemical Engineering Scholarship Fund, University of Oklahoma Foundation, 100 Timberdell, Norman, Oklahoma 73019.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGER, RALPH, DR.
description: BERGER-Ralph, Dr. A monument dedicated to the memory of the late Dr. Ralph Berger will take place at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y., Sunday July 18 at 11:00 AM. Dr. Berger is survived by his daughter Madelyn, sister Edna B. Citrin and brother, George Berger

title: A Quaint and Watery Refuge
description: ASK to flip through the family photo album of a person who grew up in former East Germany and chances are excellent that you will discover the following image: a group of people seated on benches in a long black flat-bottomed boat, perhaps a table set with coffee or beer between them, and a standing gondolier holding a punting pole astern. The idyllic sun-speckled canal along which they ride cuts through a fairytale woods of birch, poplar and alder trees. The effect is timeless. Only the passengers' attire divulges the moment in the last century from which the two-dimensional faces gaze back.

title: Losing Patience on Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Not in the Hamptons, but Not Far Behind
description: CANTUSA, a new East End restaurant, is neither in the Hamptons nor Italian. Rather it is a country-cute, red farm house in Speonk with flowers blooming in boxes out front and in pots on each table, lace curtains, Tiffany lamps, skylights, a back-lighted antique breakfront and a sign that says, ''Dine, Quench, Chill, Thrill.'' Add personable enthusiastic young owners, Isabelle and Craig Cohen (she's from Canada, he's from the United States. Hence, Canada to U.S.A. or Cantusa), modest prices, and Vincent Barbuto, a creative chef willing to take chances, and you have a restaurant that can charm even fussy, demanding Hamptons types.

title: Radha Mehta, Ashesh Badani
description: Dhara Mehta, the daughter of Dr. Nagin Mehta and Dr. Hansa Mehta of Hartsdale, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Ashesh Badani, a son of Madhu C. Badani of Calcutta, India, and the late Chhotalal N. Badani. C. B. Agnihotri, a Vedic priest, is to perform a Hindu ceremony at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Take the Plane to the Bus to the . . . Wait a Minute
description: As the Newark Airport shuttle bus crawled through the long-term parking lot last Tuesday, Wallace Schroeder felt a nervous tickle in his throat.

title: A Skirmish Over the Hepatitis B Vaccination
description: FOR as long as the vaccine for Hepatitis B has been in general use, some parents have been fighting it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN, MICHAEL
description: ROSEN-Michael July 18, 1980. Special man. Lovingly remembered always. Your family

title: You've Got Mail. You're Being Watched.
description: ''IT was tragic,'' recalled Mary Beth Heying, a principal at Edward Jones & Company, the brokerage firm in St. Louis. In April, an employee had complained to the human resources department after receiving an E-mail containing inappropriate material, meaning off-color jokes, pornography and so on. ''We investigated and found that a large number of associates were involved'' in distributing such messages, Ms. Heying said. Depending on ''the egregiousness of their involvement,'' she said, the company dismissed 19, warned 41 and allowed 1 to resign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLAMY, HARRY
description: BELLAMY-Harry The Board and Staff of Brooklyn Public Library extend condolences to Trustee and past President, Bonnie Bellamy on the loss of her dear father. May he rest in peace. Hon. Marsha Steinhardt, President Martin Gomez, Executive Director Brooklyn Public Library

title: The View From/Norfolk; Raising the Curtain on an Old Jewel
description: THE old opera house in Norfolk last featured live entertainment 50 years ago. The building, which has been closed since 1994, has also been a restaurant, grocery store and a barber shop. Once a source of architectural pride, the Apple House, named after the old grocery, had become an embarrassment to the town.

title: Modell's One Bad Move Doesn't Require Another
description: Two years after Art Modell moved his team from Cleveland to Baltimore, one of the most controversial acts in the history of the National Football League, he was asked if he felt his chances of being elected to the Hall of Fame had evaporated. ''I think that ship has sailed,'' he said.

title: Rehearing Szell: Intensity Without Ponderousness
description: AT a time when so many orchestras and conductors are changing partners, it is good to be reminded of the artistic benefits of retaining a long-term maestro. One such reminder comes in the form of a Sony Classical reissue of two classic recordings by the Cleveland Orchestra under the direction of George Szell: Prokofiev's Fifth Symphony, recorded in 1959, and Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra, recorded in 1965. These performances may not induce discophiles to part with their version of the Prokofiev by Herbert von Karajan or of the Bartok by Fritz Reiner, but both offer orchestral playing of breathtaking refinement while challenging the notion that Szell was a dour taskmaster and an interpretive literalist.

title: IN MY... FRONT SEAT: CHRISTOPHER WHITTIER
description: Christopher Whittier rides the information highway and the concrete highway at the same time.

title: Dot-Com Products at Instinet
description: The Instinet Corporation, the Reuters Group unit that operates the world's biggest private electronic trading network for institutional investors, plans to offer stock trading, mutual funds and retirement accounts through a new brokerage firm called the Instinet.com Corporation.

title: College Dreams of a Grand Public Plaza
description: Not too long ago, overnight accommodations around Astor Place consisted of a curbside or a door stoop. No more.

title: Unemployment in the State Rose a Bit in June
description: The number of jobs available in New Jersey increased in June, but the unemployment rate also rose slightly to 4.9 percent from 4.7 percent in May, according to the state Department of Labor.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: LUCKY MAN, LUCKY WOMAN By Jack Driscoll. Pushcart, $24.50.

title: Exit Strategy
description: BREAKOUT

title: Housing Grant
description: White Plains will receive a grant from the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for emergency repairs to houses owned by the elderly.

title: INQUIRY ESTIMATES SERB DRIVE KILLED 10,000 IN KOSOVO
description: At least 10,000 people were slaughtered by Serbian forces during their three-month campaign to drive the Albanians from Kosovo, according to war crimes investigators, NATO peacekeeping troops and aid agencies struggling to keep up with fresh reports each day of newly discovered bodies and graves.

title: Our Towns; Jungle's Gift: Pure Water From Sewage
description: IN his 28 years working at sewage treatment plants, John L. Jankiewicz has not known much excitement. You watch gauges, check the bacteria that digest waste, find cheap ways to dispose of sludge, keep turning gray water into clear water.

title: Logging Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Splash! Swimming Pools Proposed for City Rivers
description: META BRUNZEMA'S dream pool will float in the Hudson River. Through its transparent floor swimmers will be able to peer down and watch the fish swim by.

title: Political Briefing; It's Taking Care Of Political Business
description: Retail politics.

title: Jim Grady and Ilana Epstein
description: Ilana Syma Epstein, a daughter of Kathy Candel Epstein and Dr. Fred J. Epstein of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Alexander James Grady, a son of Alexandra D. Grady of Rowayton, Conn., and the late John H. Grady. Karen W. Fox, a justice of the peace in Greenwich, officiated at the Greenwich Country Club.

title: Word for Word/Billboards From God; Did Somebody Say, 'Give Me a Sign, Lord'?
description: WHETHER it rains or freezes, and even if you don't have a plastic Jesus on the dashboard of your car, you might have a hard time avoiding reminders of God on highways across the country this summer. Since last fall, billboards and signs bearing the messages here have appeared on roads in some 40 states from Alaska to Texas.

title: July 11-17; Refugees Say Goodbye To an Army Post
description: With the last refugees from Kosovo expected to leave in the coming days, Fort Dix prepared to end its brief life as a gateway for victims of ethnic cleansing, and go back to being a training camp for military rservists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EUGENE J., M.D.
description: COHEN-Eugene J., M.D. Died at home on July 16, 1999 at the age of 87. Devoted husband of the late Regina Gluck Cohen, M.D., for 58 years. Loving brother of Lorraine Silberthau. Brother-in-law of Sylvia & Irwin Grossman & Dorothy Margolin. Dear uncle of many nieces & nephews. Services Sunday, 1:00 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts to the Regina Gluck, M.D. Memorial Fund, North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Commercial Property/Way West on 14th Street; Changing From a Place for Meat to a Place to Meet
description: THE contrast could hardly be more stark. There in the city's traditional meat-packing district on 14th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, art galleries, trendy restaurants and stores are mingling with men in bloody aprons.

title: Umpires Taking Huge Gamble With Threats
description: Said a man with great insight into the way the real world works: ''You never ask for something you might get.''

title: Where Beauty and Tranquillity Reign
description: ABU TALIB wears a wide- brimmed straw hat and his presence is reflected in every fragrant fruit tree, rosebush and collard green growing in the two-acre community garden called Taqwa on 164th Street and Ogden Avenue in the South Bronx.

title: The Aura Of the Aura
description: In her caricature of Bill Bradley as a boomer jock-senator turned evasive Presidential populist, your writer fails to mention that Bradley's biggest ''big idea'' - campaign finance reform -- is backed up by his refusal to accept PAC contributions or individual donations over $1,000.

title: Talks Fail to End Mexico University Strike
description: Talks between striking students and authorities from Mexico's largest university aimed at settling an 88-day-old shutdown have collapsed, making the possibility of police action to open the campus more real.

title: Story Time
description: From the evidence of ''Room to Grow,'' Montclair is not only populated by plenty of children, but it is also home to plenty of children of writers. Of the 22 authors who contributed to the collection of essays about rearing children, 6 live in Montclair, and so does the editor, Christina Baker Kline. She was the editor of ''Child of Mine: Original Essays on Becoming a Mother.'' This followup ($23), published by Golden Books, focuses on children age 2 to 10, and about a third of the contributors are men. The Montclair authors are Rosemary L. Bray, on having a couple of sons; Alice Elliott Dark, on deciding to have just one child; Jon Katz, on the joys of the after-school car pool; Michael Laser, on being a stay-at-home dad; Jill Smolowe, on the rhythms of time shared with her 4-year-old daughter, and Valerie Wilson Wesley, on conveying African-American values to her daughters. In the introduction, Ms. Kline writes that the book is not meant to offer advice but to be ''a metaphysical guide to parenting'' through its stories.

title: Rachel Felder, Howie Weinberg
description: Rachel Felder, the daughter of Myrna and Raoul Felder of New York, was married on Wednesday to Howie Weinberg, a son of Sara Weinberg of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Al Weinberg. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani officiated in the Blue Room at City Hall.

title: Making Travel Easier With Favorite Treats
description: EVERYBODY loves a summer vacation. Often the most depressing moment, however, is parting with your pet. The soulful stare and pleading eyes can stay with you for hours. Taking them along is an option, but it requires planning ahead, special considerations and certain risks.

title: 3 Men Shot in Subway Station on East Side
description: Three men were shot and wounded last night at the 59th Street and Lexington Avenue subway station, the police said. One victim was listed in critical condition.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The regret on our side is, they used to say years ago, we are reading about you in science class. Now they say, we are reading about you in history class.''

title: To Shoot, Or Not To Shoot? Now, Decide in 2.9 Seconds
description: IT was a test, and the two young police recruits were nervous. Standing in front of an interactive video simulator, laser guns in their holsters, the recruits were patrolling a virtual mall when they suddenly came across a man holding a brick. The recruits drew their guns.

title: Wet 'n' Mild at a Water Park
description: ON the third day of the July heat wave, I couldn't stand it any longer. Dragging myself out from under the air-conditioner, I drove east to a place that had previously been just a legend to me: the Splish Splash Water Park, just outside Riverhead.

title: A South Fork Refresher
description: The vines were high and neat -- almost manicured, it seemed from a distance -- at Channing Daughters in Bridgehampton. The airy, homey tasting room was bathed in light. And the most pleasing wine sampled during a leisurely visit to the beautiful 25-acre estate last week was the '98 sauvignon blanc.

title: From In to Out Faster Than You Can Say 'Washed Up'
description: BATHED in the glow of a giant television screen in the Virgin Megastore at Union Square, a couple stood watching Madonna's latest video, ''Beautiful Stranger,'' last week. As the ever-trendy singer cavorted with a snaggle-toothed 60's throwback in a velvet suit and ruffled shirt, one turned to the other and said, ''This is that Austin Shag guy or whatever.''

title: Gender Bias
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: THE SPRING TONE By Kazumi Yumoto. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Alison Siegel and Michael Novara
description: Alison Beth Siegel, a daughter of Karen Herbstman of Rumson, N.J., and Jeffrey Siegel of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Peter Novara, a son of Lydia and Peter Novara of Bethpage, N.Y. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Salvatore Umana, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Outriding A Posse of Midlife Blues
description: RECENTLY, a girlfriend and I loaded up my horse Smokey, a stocky black gelding, and his friend Leo, a bay quarter horse, for a trip that spanned time as well as space. We traveled 250 miles from the Twin Cities to the Canadian border to ride the trails at a lodge offering a newly created long weekend for horse people called B.Y.O.H. -- Bring Your Own Horse. I was motivated by classic midlife events: my father-in-law was dying, I had logged two decades in a job that had increasingly less sunlight and open air, and it was time for a dose of adventure while I could still swing a leg over the saddle.

title: By George
description: GEORGE ELIOT

title: A Resurgent Knoblauch Answers All Questions
description: Chuck Knoblauch is like an unbreakable code, unreadable, without rhyme or reason. Just when it seemed as if his throwing jitters and lackluster hitting might affect his confidence forever, Knoblauch is reborn again.

title: What Candidates Did in War Matters; Look at the Record
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LONG ISLAND CITY

title: Go Slow on Tax Cuts
description: Cutting taxes always sounds good in Washington, and it may be inevitable that Congress will pass a tax cut before next year's election. But if that is to happen, the grandiose cutting plans proposed by the chairmen of the Congressional tax-writing committees need to be scaled back substantially.

title: The World; A Year After Bombings, A Case of Diplo-Jitters
description: THE United States Embassy in Madagascar, a coffee-growing island nation hundreds of miles off the east coast of Africa, might not seem a likely target for terrorists from the faraway Middle East.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Defunct Equine Estuary

title: Singing Horses!
description: The Real Wild West

title: Editorial Observer; Kashmir: A Story of 'Blowback' in Paradise
description: Under pressure from the United States and some of its own close allies, Pakistan has apparently brought about the withdrawal of the insurgents who infiltrated into India last spring to support the uprising in the disputed region of Kashmir. What no doubt must have initially seemed like a good idea to Pakistan's military turned into an embarrassing blunder. Last year, India looked like the neighborhood bully when it tested a nuclear weapon. Now it is Pakistan that is seen as the aggressor.

title: Painting Portraits With Words
description: THE woman and the man chatting over drinks and appetizers at Lady Jane's Restaurant here might have been any two 40-somethings relaxing after a long day at work, until you noticed that she was assiduously taking notes. An interview? Maybe she's a journalist and he's a source. But she keeps on taking notes, looking back and forth between her companion and her notebook, even when he's not talking. And then, the talk ranges too randomly for that, from musical tastes (he has just replaced a 20-year-old Clash LP with a CD) to concerns about overdevelopment around the local waterfront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, DANIEL I.
description: SMITH-Daniel I. Dear husband of Esther. Devoted father of Lorie (Gary) Hershkin and Gary (Lori) Smith. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jared, Andrew, David and Alex. Services Sunday, 12:30PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Souls Under Siege In a Land of Limbo
description: SOMEWHERE, there's a plaza that unites the lost and the lonely. ''It would be inexcusably selfish to be lonely alone,'' observes an old man with a lance, who has wandered into one of the dead-end streets where ''the spring of humanity has gone dry.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTTS, GEORGE H.
description: POTTS-George H. February 28, 1952-July 19, 1997. To live in the hearts we leave behind, is not to die.

title: Denmark Sheds Some Light on Dark Ages
description: Denmark has proclaimed 1999 its Medieval Year, highlighting the many archeological digs, burial mounds, churches and museums that offer information on the period from about 1000, when the Danes turned from paganism to Christianity, to 1536, the year of the Reformation. More than 400 events, including lectures and workshops, have been scheduled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTSON, IRIS
description: ROBERTSON-Iris Aged 90, educator originally of Panama, RP died July 6 in Brooklyn, NY. She is survived by her sister Miriam Robertson-Best and other members of the Robertson family in Panama and the U.S.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-18-99: Questions for Mark Morris; Dance of a Lifetime
description: Q. You've just made a major announcement: you're opening your own place, a big dance center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. How did it come about?

title: Kelly Haas, Jason Church
description: Kelly Marie Haas, a daughter of Noreen and Charles Haas of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Jason Lee Church, the son of Priscilla Church of New York and David Church of New Orleans. The Rev. Francis Gallogly performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: The Norton Simon Museum Lightens Up
description: LAST year, Los Angeles art-world insiders who wanted to avoid waiting months for tickets to park at the new J. Paul Getty Museum in Brentwood could simply drive over to the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena to see the collection the Getty wanted but didn't get. In the late 1980's, Simon -- the Hunt Foods industrialist who in 25 years amassed a nearly encyclopedic array of Old Master, Impressionist and 20th-century classics -- decided against merging his collection with a museum that, had he agreed, might today be called the Getty-Simon or the Simon-Getty.

title: Elizabeth Bussiere and Daniel Cohen
description: Elizabeth Bussiere and Daniel Asher Cohen are to be married today at the Habitat Wildlife Sanctuary in Belmont, Mass. Rabbi Neil Kominsky is to officiate.

title: Filmmakers' Time To Shine at Festivals
description: FILM buffs, prepare to enter the fray: it's festival time on the Island.

title: Just Don't Expect a Coupon
description: No, he wouldn't be so crass as to change his Web site's address to Buydiana.com. But anyone wanting electronic suggestions on buying the right clothing, jewelry and gifts can now rely on the same man Princess Diana used as her personal shopping companion. Roberto Devorik, the London retailing and fashion consultant (to clients like Versace, Christian LaCroix, Missoni and Oscar de la Renta) and man about town, has just joined Bestselections.com, the New York-based Internet company.

title: Political Briefing; A 'Safe' G.O.P. Seat? Democrats Lining Up
description: When Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio abandoned his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination last week, he made life easier for all those Republican leaders who are promoting George W. Bush as the party's best hope in Election 2000. But Mr. Kasich left them with a problem when he also announced that after nine terms, he planned to give up representing Ohio's 12th District in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRION, LESTER E. JR
description: BRION-Lester E. Jr On July 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Lois; devoted father of Donna and David, and fond father-in-law of Hannah; loving grandfather of Julianna and Christian. Memorial reception at the Creek Club, Locust Valley, L.I., July 20th at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the National Society to Prevent Blindness, 500 East Remington Road, Schaumburg, IL. 60173.

title: From the Fields to a Parking Lot Near You
description: ''WE grow for taste!'' blared the sign on Sy and Elida Griskonis's truck, parked one recent Thursday in the lot behind the Fleet Bank in Livingston. The couple had arrived early to stake out their spot and display produce and plants grown on their 60-acre farm in Blairstown. From arugula to zucchini, basil to thyme, nasturtiums to hot pepper plants, they had it all. As a customer paid for her selections, the burly, bearded Mr. Griskonis couldn't help but boast, ''The lettuce was cut 24 hours ago.''

title: Following the Money To the America's Cup
description: In 1992, shortly after winning the right to challenge the United States for the America's Cup, Italy could not get enough of the American Paul Cayard. But now the Italians have a new focus, new money and a new skipper. And no one knows that better than Cayard, a mostly forgotten yachtsman in Italy these days.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, HYMAN
description: RULNICK-Hyman July 18, 1993 In Loving Memory, your dear daughter, Joyce.

title: A Young Composer Remade?
description: SOME artists bloom young; others do not find themselves until they are a decade or two into adult life. George Benjamin, the 39-year-old English composer who is in residence at the Tanglewood Music Center Festival of Contemporary Music, which begins on Thursday in Lenox, Mass., and will feature his music, has followed both patterns.

title: In Canada, Our Culture or Theirs?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pair of 'Twin Sisters' Appear Perfect for Poster
description: Casey Lafleur and Katera Elam, both 10, sway back and forth to a melody that, by now, they know by heart. Fans of the first order, they are rehearsing for a duet in homage to their idols, the Olsen twins. Both girls are clearly obsessed with the twins, Mary-Kate and Ashley, who, as stars of their own videos and the television series ''Two of a Kind,'' are the sensation of the under-13 set.

title: Joining Peace Corps Inc.
description: IN the past, it was easy to spot Peace Corps volunteers. They wore Birkenstocks and loose-fitting, gauzy garb. They often had wide-eyed notions of saving the world. To many of them, ''capitalism'' was a four-letter word.

title: In Westport, a Gala With Willie Nelson
description: EVERY so often the Levitt Pavilion in Westport is host to a benefit party to support the more than 50 free concerts that make up the rest of its summer season. This year the benefit is on Friday evening at 9, when the country music performer Willie Nelson holds forth. General admission tickets are priced at $45 or $60.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: GOD IS A BULLET By Boston Teran. Knopf, $24.

title: Summer Fun at Hudson Piers
description: AT several Hudson River sites, the Hudson River Park Trust will give people a chance to catch a few fish, attend a New York-themed film festival, relax with tai chi lessons and take part in other activities during its seventh season of free events.

title: Amy Falbaum and Erik Blauberg
description: Amy Susan Falbaum and Erik Karl Blauberg, chefs at the ''21'' Club in New York, were married by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegal last evening at the James Beard House in New York.

title: Girls: Get a Job!
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCCER; A Dream Becomes Tangible
description: In 1991, Julie Foudy was a 20-year-old starter for the United States women'snational team that won the inaugural Women's World Cup. Back then, she had to convince her father that it was worth making the trip from their home in Mission Viejo, Calif., to China for the game. So little attention was paid to the team's achievement that one of its sponsors took out newspaper ads to publicize the victory.

title: Used Lexus From Microsoft: 6 Windows, Never Crashed
description: Bill Gates's golden touch reaches well beyond his personal wealth, which edged up by $6 billion-plus last week to more than $100 billion. It was also a good week for the stray cats and dogs in Redmond, Ore., who may soon be sleeping more comfortably thanks to the allure of a car Mr. Gates once owned.

title: Habitats/Greenwich Village; Getting Started, With Her Parents' Help
description: WHEN Jessie Carry graduated from Princeton last year, she and two friends began looking for apartments in New York. It quickly became clear, however, that the friends were able to afford something beyond Ms. Carry's reach. One was going into banking, the other into the construction business. Whereas, Ms. Carry says, ''I was not destined for financial greatness.'' She planned to look for a job in magazines, which are legendary for their paltry starting salaries.

title: Alexa Boer, Ranch Kimball
description: Dr. Alexa F. Boer and Ranch Cannon Kimball were married last evening at the Washington National Cathedral. The Rev. John B. Butcher, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Sex Appeal for the Physically and Financially Fit
description: ''THE A.I.V. Roadster is a purist's car, meant for one thing: driving,'' Danny Panoz warned, obviously anxious that a test driver might write critically about his baby's lack of creature comforts.

title: The Aura Of the Aura
description: Bradley's refusal to strap on the marionette strings, otherwise obligatory in politics nowadays, is a virtue that Henneberger has mischaracterized as ''crotchety.'' Overqualified candidates like Bradley speak above the din of today's sound-bite-driven races.

title: The Nation: The Problem With Getting Tough; When an Accident Is a Crime
description: PLEAS for justice are routine after an airplane crash, and they are generally played out in civil courts, where survivors and relatives of victims sue for damages. But last week, in a surprising move, prosecutors won criminal indictments against a maintenance company, two mechanics and a superior in the crash of a Valujet plane in the Everglades in 1996.

title: Unseen Passions
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Succeed in Art
description: The best advice I was given during four years as an art student in the early 1970's was to keep my pencil sharp. Even this recommendation was subject to ridicule by those members of the faculty charged with bluff and theory. Deborah Solomon's (June 27) pencil is very sharp indeed. Best read since Tom Wolfe's ''From Bauhaus to Our House.''

title: POSTINGS: $25 Million, 12 Stories, 100 Rooms in SoHo; For Thompson Street, A New Boutique Hotel
description: The building site in SoHo turned out to be precarious. ''There were very old walkup buildings on each side, and one was not in the best of condition,'' said Alan Reich of York Hunter, the contractor. ''There was some very poor soil.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEIN, JOSEPH, MD.
description: SHEIN-Joseph, MD. Adored by his loving wife Osnass (nee Charchat) of 53 years. Adoring children, Dr. Ruvan and Karen Shein, Avrom Shein, Dr. Leon and Jill Shein. Cherished grandchildren Arianna, Rebekah, Mariessa, Joshua, Benjamin, Jonathan, Allison. Loving family, devoted friends, patients, colleagues, nurses, and the North Shore Hospital administration and staff are in inconsolable pain and grief. How do you let go a legend as courageous, compassionate, brilliant, caring, with sense of humor, moral ethical standards which knows no equal. Capacity to love and be loved. Took care of the needy, heal the sick and gave credence to the meaning of life. You justified the ten commandments. With aching hearts, never say goodbye darling. We will meet again and continue the wonders of our fortunate, tranquil, happy cultured life as a family who was inspired by your passionate love and devotion. A man of class, dignity, nobility. Thank you my husband, thank you dad, thank you grandpa (Pappa) Joe, for being our greatest gift. Deep emotional love and tears will never cease. Funeral services will be held Sunday, July 18th. 11AM. at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York, opposite Great Neck Station.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, MARCUS
description: ROSS-Marcus July 19, 1997. Till the day I no longer weep when I think of you-till the day I can laugh with someone new-till the day the sun forgets to shine-my love, your image is burned into this soul of mine-I love you. H R to M R

description: To the Editor:

description: When we last left the National Football League's final foursome -- Denver, the Jets, Minnesota and Atlanta -- each team was vowing it would return to at least the conference championships. It is easy to understand why.

description: 'Selections: Collage'

title: The Nation; Looking for Attention With a Billion-Dollar Message
description: AFTER jurors announced a staggering verdict of $4.9 billion against General Motors on July 9, a juror explained the panel's fury at the company. ''We're just like numbers, I feel, to them,'' he said. ''Statistics.''

title: Kimberly Druker, Pel Stockwell
description: Kimberly Anne Druker, the daughter of Mrs. Albert H. Elfner 3d of Boston and Ronald M. Druker of Newton, Mass., was married yesterday in Brookline, Mass., to William Apel Stockwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Stockwell of Boxford, Mass. Rabbi Allan Press officiated at the First Parish of Brookline. The Rev. Colin Leitch, a Unitarian Universalist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: A Serb With a Prophetic Intuition for His Country
description: IT is not an easy time for a Serbian filmmaker to be releasing a new movie in the United States, even for a veteran director like Goran Paskaljevic, who has long opposed Slobodan Milosevic's regime, who has expressed his shame over the atrocities committed by Serbian forces in Bosnia and Kosovo, who has been denounced as a traitor by the official press in Belgrade. For all that, he remains a Serb, and, as such, he is expected to throw light on the collective madness that has gripped a good many of his fellow Serbs of late.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBISH, HERBERT
description: HOBISH-Herbert Our dear departed friend who through sheer courage, tenacity and optimistic spirit kept his dignity and mental strength through decades of debilitating illness. He never waivered in his sense of responsibility to his employees, his customers, his friends and above all to his loving family. To Toby, his dearest love, friend and companion for over 50 years with whom he shared the highs and lows of life's journey, to Mitchell and Janice, Amy, Rick and Flo, Sam and Aliza, and their wonderful extended family, our love and condolences. We are immeasurably richer by having been his friend. Marian and Merri

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE; Two Pet Shops Sharing the Same Turf Get Their Backs Up
description: A pair of Burmese kittens scuffled last week in their close quarters at Urban Pets on Christopher Street, rolling around behind the glass, disturbing the sleeping cats above. The kitten fight is a metaphor for the store's tumultuous relations with a newer pet shop, Feathers and Feed, less than a block away.

title: The Suharto Shadow
description: Considering who lives here and what people have been saying about him recently, the road known as Sandalwood Street, in the district of Jakarta called Menteng, is a remarkably sleepy and unmenacing place. Little more than a mile away is Freedom Square, the heart of official Indonesia, with its multilane traffic, its Government ministries and military headquarters. But here in Menteng, palms and mango trees rustle above the red-tiled bungalows, and beneath them are tiny stalls selling noodle soup and cigarettes. You might not even notice the heavy wooden barricades, looped with barbed wire, discreetly stacked in reserve at the side of the road. And when the soldiers step out from their wooden guardhouse halfway down and ask you to turn back, they do so with apologetic smiles.

title: Futures Shock
description: Devil Take the Hindmost A History of Financial Speculation. By Edward Chancellor. 386 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: For Folk, the Season Has Turned Again
description: THE folk groups playing on Saturday at the Great Auditorium in Ocean Grove come from a 1960's vastly different from the one NBC made a mini-series about. This was folk as most popularly defined by the Kingston Trio, before most Americans had ever heard of Vietnam or taken part in a protest.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-18-99; On Language: Bloopies!
description: The moment has arrived for our annual coveted Bloopie Awards. Note how the adjective coveted (from cupidus, ''desirable,'' its heart penetrated by Cupid's arrow) is wedded to the proper noun Bloopie (from blooper, an oops sound influenced by blunder, originally a baseball term for a ball looped by the batter just beyond the infield, and if not caught synonymous with Texas leaguer).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVNER, BENJAMIN
description: KOVNER-Benjamin Long-term resident of Mamaroneck, NY, on July 17 at the age of 97 in Greenwich, CT Hospital. Beloved husband of Kathleen Jane Kovner. Loving father of Michael, Peter and the late Kay Kovner and father-in-law of Roberta. Adored grandfather of Matthew and Alexandra. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, July 20, 6-9 PM, with service Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Eye Institute, 2020 Vision Place, Bethesda, MD 20892.

title: Art. Life. Revolution!
description: Benefits indoors and out, and a toast on Bastille Day.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Shards of Light
description: Glyn Maxwell's poems present a sensibility and maturity that transcend his years (he was born in Hertfordshire, England, in 1962), and also his time and place. The work in his latest collection, THE BREAKAGE (Houghton Mifflin, $22), blends the brutally honest introspection of American poets like Frost and Lowell with accessible, lighthearted language reminiscent of mid-20th-century British masters like Auden and Betjeman. A series of letters in verse to the English poet Edward Thomas, killed in World War I, forms the heart of the book. In these ''letter poems,'' Maxwell evokes the simple, idyllic pleasures of country living and uses them as a sounding board, a means of exploring and accepting the demands of a poet's life: ''Each of us / Is writing, Edward, asking the great space / Below us what is missing still, what gift / Will make us whole again.'' Maxwell, who was educated at Oxford and now teaches at Amherst College, distinguishes himself with a host of dexterous and nimbly honed lines and images. Indeed, the ''breakage'' of the book's title serves as a neat metaphor for poetry's capacity to shatter the often dark block of human experience into beacons of meaning and light. Andy Brumer

description: RIBACK-Milton On July 8, 1999. Loving husband, family man and friend. Raconteur and entrepreneur. Former president of the Advertising Club of New York, publisher of Plus-Profit Publicity and founder of Press Agents Shining Hours (PASH).

title: Gardener's Choice: Triage Strategy for a Dry Spell
description: IN the whole of June there was less than an inch of rain, and half of July had passed with little more than an occasional spiteful mist that encouraged mildew but did nothing to assuage the thirst of my garden.

description: The European Commission lifted the worldwide ban on British beef exports that it imposed three years ago after an epidemic of a brain malady in cattle known as mad cow disease (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) was found to be responsible for transmitting a related brain-wasting disorder (new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) to humans.

description: Politicians these days are raking in huge gobs of campaign cash, more than ever before. So when a Presidential candidate turns down $16.5 million, there can only be one explanation: It's not enough.

They now say ''Go Away,'' which the management decided was more in keeping with New York's personality. Other Manhattan hotels have also been rewriting some rules of the lodging game to distinguish themselves. In a business that has embraced standardization for decades, the new watchword seems to be singularity, expressed in amenities like pillows chosen from menus, heated toilet seats and ''floating beds.''

As in ''Let's turn on the Channel 7 and see what's on.''

In weddings in particular, it's not just about the celebration of this new beginning, it's about loss -- this person is changed now. And laughter, especially embarrassed laughter, can be a set of conflicted emotions bubbling up as well.

title: PULSE; Ready for Y2K
description: The experiment began in a longshoremen's bar in Red Hook, Brooklyn, with two brown pills followed by a round of Budweisers and whiskey, then a few imprudent vodkas with grapefruit juice. ''You will wake up fresh,'' promised Corrine Jacobson, the marketing director for Liverite, a pill that claims to prevent hangovers. A mix of vitamins and beef-liver extracts, Liverite is sold in bottles of 60 tablets for $15.99 at pharmacies and health food stores like CVS and General Nutrition Centers as a dietary supplement to boost liver function. (It has not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.) Recently, the makers started marketing it as a ''Y2K hangover cure.'' After a suggested second dose before bed and six hours of sleep, the result, in this case at least, was some fatigue but no headache or nausea, and even a surprisingly chipper feeling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSTICK, JUANITA DIANE
description: BOSTICK-Juanita Diane Age 68, of NYC, died on July 14, 1999, at her Tudor City residence. Funeral services will be on Friday, July 23, at 10 AM, at Ridout's Elmwood Chapel in Birmingham, AL, with Dr. R. Maurice Boyd of the City Church of New York, officiating, with burial at Elmwood Cemetery. Visitation will be at Ridout Chapel, Thursday, 5-7 PM. A ''Memorial Celebration'' is planned in NYC on August 19. For details call 212632-1308. Diane is survived by three brothers. Educated in Birmingham school system, Diane received her BS degree in home economics from the University of Alabama and did graduate study at NYU School of Retailing. After serving as Field Secretary for Phi Mu, she began her career with Avondale Mills in 1953 and climbed the corporate ladder from Designer in Sylacauga, AL, to Stylist, then Assistant VP in NYC, before being promoted to VP for Fabric Design in 1978, breaking the glass ceiling before others even dreamed of doing it and serving as an inspiration and advocate for career women. Diane was featured in articles in Women's Wear Daily, Daily News Record, Birmingham News and several textbooks. She served on the Home Economics Advisory Board at Auburn University, the Advisory Committee of the Institute for Women Executives at UA; and spoke to many college classes and groups. She was a member of: Women's Wear Committee Color Association of the US; the Fashion Group, Inc, serving on the Board of Governors and numerous committees; the NY Fashion Designers; International Needlepoint Guild; and Who's Who in American Women. Diane was a founding member of the City Church of New York; worked with the Talbot Perkins Children's Services; chaired a Benefit Concert for Project Hope; was active in Tudor City Association; was a member of the DAR and UDC. The University of Alabama was Diane's first love and she served it faithfully, and was honored by the University in return. She was Regional VP of the National Alumni Association; received the ''Distinguished Alumna Award''; served on the Advisory Board of the Women's Athletic Program; was co-founder of The Greater NY Alumni Association, one of the strongest and most active in the nation. This chapter inducted Diane into its ''Hall of Fame'' and elected her ''Honorary President'' for life and established the J. Diane Bostick Endowed Scholarship Fund for clothing, textiles, and interior design students. The College of Human Enviromental Sciences twice presented Diane with The Agnes Ellen Harris Distinguished Alumnus Award, its highest honor, once for career accomplishments and once for her love and commitment to the College. Memorials may be made to the J. Diane Bostick Scholarship Fund, c/o The University of Alabama, Box 870158, University, AL 35487.

title: Patriotic Communists
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Shadow Drama in Iran; For Once, the Veil That Hides Conflict Slips
description: THINGS are not always what they seem in this country of high walls and black veils. Invasions, occupations, foreign meddling and arbitrary rule over the centuries have have made politics a dangerous game, and Iranians have learned some survival strategies: improvisation, role-playing and even deception.

title: Into a Delicate, Guilty Mind
description: MEET Benoit: bon vivant, raconteur and smalltime intellectual. His parents are shopkeepers, his girlfriend plays the flute, and he would be great company were he not a mass murderer. Benoit is the hero of ''Man Bites Dog,'' a 1992 classic of underground Belgian cinema. In the course of this 92-minute pseudo-documentary, he quotes Jacques Brel and rails against the architecture of low-cost housing while killing old people, women and children.

title: A Weary Postal Service Proceeding on Schedule
description: Defending the yellow jersey of its and the Tour de France's leader, the United States Postal Service team spent another uneventful day today, but even on quiet days the psychological and physical toll is high on a team trying to control the race.

title: Eye Openers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Delicate Line Between Ethics and Morality
description: RESOLVED to demonstrate that a life in the theater does not preclude having a life, Elizabeth D'Ottavio and Bram Lewis, actor, director, teacher and prime mover of the Phoenix Theater for almost a decade in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., then in Purchase, N.Y.,have one week to go, in John Robin Baitz's two-character play ''Three Hotels'' at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls, N.Y.

title: A Playground Collective
description: Fifteen years ago, two families wanted their young children to be able to walk from one family's backyard to the other's without going into the street. The problem was they had five yards between them, some with fences.

title: God Exists, Philosophically
description: SPINOZA

title: Q & A/Manuel F. Meneses; Navy Award Goes to Sailor From Hartford
description: MANUEL F. MENESES JR., a chief petty officer on the U.S.S. San Juan at the Naval Submarine Base in Groton, has been chosen as the Atlantic Fleet sailor of the year, designating him the best enlisted person in a pool of 69,000 serving on ships on the East Coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, RUTH (NEE O'BRIEN)
description: WHITE-Ruth (nee O'Brien) Born in 1907, died in Peterborough, NH on July 17, 1999. Mrs. White was a life-long resident of Brooklyn as well as Francestown, NH. Ruth graduated from Packer Collegiate Institute in the 1920s and was a devoted member of Flatbush Tompkins Congregational Church. She served for over 50 years and was past president of Brooklyn TB and Health and National Director of American Lung Association and Brooklyn Thoracic Hospital. She was included in ''Who's Who in American Women'' in the 1960s, 70s and 80s. Mrs. White was honored by Brooklyn with ''Ruth White Day.'' She was predeceased by her husband Wallace B. White and is survived by her son John W. White, four grandchildren Brigham, Brooke, Jof and Jordan; and two great-grandchildren. Interment at Greenwood Cemetery.

title: A Quiet Detour Off The Rhine
description: UNLIKE the Rhine, Germany's Lahn River has no Lorelei to lure unsuspecting sailors to their destruction. It has no treacherous rapids or mermaids lurking in its depths. But seductive it is as it wends its way through the Hessian heartland of western Germany, a scenic region of small historic cities and villages.

title: One for the Road and a Roll of Quarters for the Photo Booth
description: After midnight in an East Village lounge bar, the live music has given way to the jukebox. To commemorate the evening, two women in their mid-20's clamber into the bar's vintage 1957 photo booth. Four blinding flashes later, they tumble out to collect the strip of pictures.

title: Is This for Real?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Him: The Perfect Lawn Is a Status Symbol Again
description: CAN I walk on it?'' first-time visitors often ask Robert Esernio as they stare at his property in Mahopac, N.Y. There's no mistaking Mr. Esernio's lawn. In a development of similar new houses with mostly burnt, brown lawns lumpy from the excavator's backhoe, his is the really green, rolling, luxuriant one, the one with mowing lines like straight brush strokes up and down a fine piece of suede.

title: On Luna's Orb
description: Throughout history, the Moon has been a byword for mutability, its inconstancy an emblem of the inconstancy of human affairs. One night it rises dark, a new Moon. One night a sliver of it hangs in the western sky, nearly catching Venus within its horns. One night it lies distended on the eastern horizon, not a sphere but a flattened disk slipping out of Earth's shadow. On no two consecutive nights has it ever risen at the same time or in the same shape. Even now, 30 years after humans first set foot on the Moon, it still seems natural to attribute these qualities to the orb itself rather than to the perspective from which we view it.

title: Children's Books
description: THE BIRCHBARK HOUSE

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about United States Customs Service rules on overseas purchases, under which Columba Bush, the wife of the Governor of Florida, was fined recently, misstated the Governor's given name. He is Jeb Bush; George is his brother, the Governor of Texas.

title: 18 Wheels, 1,000 Gripes As Truckers Face Limits
description: Standing outside Mr. O's Family Restaurant, a one-story frame building advertising ''Soft Ice Cream'' on Route 31 here, Terry Bennett, a trucker from Maryland, didn't appear to be in a good mood.

title: An Unsung Hero of the Space Age
description: MANY people will be remembered on Tuesday, the 30th anniversary of the first lunar landing. But as Long Island celebrates its role in building the Grumman lunar module that made the historic feat possible, we should also salute one crucial individual in the effort who was neither engineer nor astronaut.

title: Margaret Lynch, Thomas Doyle 3d
description: Margaret Harrison Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Lynch of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Capt. Thomas Robert Doyle 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle Jr. of Danbury, Conn. The Rev. Donal R. Kehew performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Andrews Church on Block Island in Rhode Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 4 about the coming HBO film ''RKO 281'' misstated the title of a television documentary that inspired the new film's producer, Ridley Scott. It was ''The Battle Over Citizen Kane,'' not ''The Making of Citizen Kane.''

title: Martha Ells, M. J. Addesa 3d
description: Martha Mason Ells, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Fischer Ells of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in Stony Creek, Conn., to Michael J. Addesa 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Addesa Jr. of Andover, Mass. The Rev. Wayne Jacobson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Stony Creek Church of Christ.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Oliver Platt; A Wash and Shampoo
description: LOOK out, it leaks,'' Oliver Platt warned his companions as his 1985 Jeep Wagoneer went through the pulsing jets of the Broadway-Houston Car Wash in downtown Manhattan. On July 7, the night before, Mr. Platt had been chatting with David Letterman about his part as a pompous crocodile expert in the horror spoof ''Lake Placid.'' On this night, looking somewhat more disheveled, he was escaping from his East Village household to run errands before the family's drive to Maine the next day.

title: The Nation; Beyond the Bluster Over Health Care
description: AFTER listening to the rancorous debate in the Senate over health care reform last week, it would seem obvious that differences between Democrats and Republicans are profound. The Democrats wanted to give powerful new Federal rights to patients in managed-care plans. The Republicans countered with narrower regulations.

title: HARNESS RACING; The Panderosa Rallies Late To Win Meadowlands Pace
description: When The Panderosa's owner, Bob Glazer, saw his horse heading down the final half-mile of the $1 million Meadowlands Pace tonight, he was not smiling, but he certainly was not sweating, either.

title: Shannon Johnson, Benjamin Ames
description: Shannon Beth Johnson and Benjamin Butler Ames were married yesterday by the Rev. Erin Splaine, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Pierce House, a historic home in Lincoln, Mass.

description: THE MOUSE OF AMHERST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIAN, CLARA (NEE CLAIRE HAMRAH)
description: LIAN-Clara (nee Claire Hamrah) Age 86, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, before moving to The Haven of Toms River, NJ; died July 10, 1999, of natural causes. She began piano lessons at age 65 and became proficient enough to give full recitals at art galleries, senior citizen villages and nursing homes in the New York and New Jersey area until her death. Wife of the late Fred J. Lian, President of West Potato Company, of New York. Mother of Jane, Carol and Mary. Mother-in-law of Jack and George. Grandmother of Nicole, Christopher and Michael. Sister of George and the late Adma, Louise, Alice and Elias. We celebrate her radiant smile and generous nature. A kind and gentle spirit, and friend to all she knew. A memorial Mass will be held at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church, 74th St and 4th Ave, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY, on Sunday, August 22, at 10:15 AM.

title: DATABANK: July 12-July 16; A Happy Return to Technology Stocks
description: Investors hovered around technology companies like bees near honey, lifting the Nasdaq to three consecutive highs. For the week, the technology-heavy index climbed 2.5 percent. For the year, it is up 30 percent.

title: An Urban Shepherd; Harry Theodore Can't Afford to Live Indoors. But He Feeds a Hungry Family of 14.
description: THE short, sunburned man in the dirty T-shirt stands in an empty parking lot and shouts a few words in rapid Greek. Suddenly, a dozen dappled, honey-brown dogs bound toward him through a maze of rusty metal and other debris.

title: Infamous Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: In Step With Comfort
description: In the never-ending search for the new shoe, women have moved beyond the shelves of Jimmy Choo and Niketown. Now they're venturing into orthopedic (or make that comfort-prioritized) shoe shops like Selby Fifth Avenue, which offers comforts beyond the Birkenstock cork sole.

title: Children's Books
description: THE SILENCE IN THE MOUNTAINS By Liz Rosenberg. Illustrated by Chris K. Soentpiet. Orchard, $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Shaping a Spinoff
description: No one disputes that Kansas City Southern Industries' most valuable asset is the Janus Capital Corporation. The question is, what will the company do with it?

title: Who Is the Governor Now? DiFrancesco's Getting Closer
description: It will be at least 18 months before Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco gets his long-awaited opportunity to move into the Governor's office, and it may never happen at all.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALKIN, HENRY
description: MALKIN-Henry Loved forever ...never forgotten. A year since you're gone and you're missed & loved more each day. Forever in our hearts and thoughts. Marilyn and Maureen The Rosettis & The Steins

title: John Kennedy's Plane Vanishes Off Cape Cod
description: A small plane carrying John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and her sister disappeared late Friday off the Massachusetts coast, and by yesterday afternoon the authorities had recovered debris from the airplane off Martha's Vineyard.

title: Ernest Hemingway's War Wounds
description: When he was in his mid-20's and searching quite deliberately for the style that would transform American fiction, Ernest Hemingway got this reminder from Gertrude Stein: ''Hemingway, remarks aren't literature.'' That remark came back to me while reading ''True at First Light,'' the writer's unfinished fictional memoir, published with a great deal of hype this month. The Hemingway sound is still there -- that unmistakable rhythm -- but there is something off-putting about the story of the 1953 safari the writer went on with his fourth wife, Mary Welsh. It's as if Hemingway felt that anything that caught his attention in the bush was worth writing down. You feel as if every time Hemingway turns his back, Mary and the local hunters can't wait to escape from his camp and get out of his sight.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Joan Wight, Wife and Model for Author Herriot
description: Joan Wight, the widow of the Yorkshire veterinarian who wrote under the name James Herriot and the model for a character in his books and television programs based on them, died on Wednesday. She was in her 80's.

title: Spy vs. Spies
description: IRREPARABLE HARM

title: Replacing an Interior Door
description: MANY new homes have interior hollow-core doors. Though functional and lightweight, the doors are also plain looking and not particularly sturdy. Usually, homeowners like to replace them with something more decorative and substantial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, MONROE
description: SHERMAN-Monroe Age 94, formerly of Long Boat Key, FL and Southbury, CT, died peacefully at home on Thursday, July 15, 1999. Brother of the late Barney, Maurie, Herman and Sidney. Adored husband and life's partner of the late Gertrude Horn; treasured father of the late Nancy (Dr. Lawrence) Rosenberg and Susan Sherman; beloved grandfather of Eric Rosenberg, Connie (Mark) Hochman, Dr. Mark Rosenberg (Dr. Andrea Needleman), Elizabeth (Dan) Zimmerman; Loving greatgrandfather of Amelia and Sarah Hochman; Julian and Jenna Rosenberg, and Natalie Rose Zimmerman. Metallurgist, inventor, golfer, chef, jeweler, artist, photographer, master gardener. Impassioned autodidact and perennial student of the patterns and miracles in nature, of etymology and philosophy, of quantum physics, of music and art. His kindness and generosity, his love for and absolute devotion to his family and friends, his passion for creative work, the thrill he found in being alive and in his myriad interests, have lastingly endowed and inspired all who knew him. ''I am done with great things and big things, great organizations and big successes. I am for those tiny, invisible, molecular, moral forces which work from individual to individual, creeping through the crannies of the world like so many soft rootlets, or like the capillary action of water, but which if you give them time, will rend the hardest monuments of man's pride''. (William James) Memorial service at 10:00 AM on Wednesday, July 28 at Pomperaug Woods, Southbury, CT.

description: In the Ceramic Tradition
