description: The Boy in the Lake

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, DAVID, PH.D.
description: LEEDS-David, Ph.D. Of Woodmere, N.Y. Died July 12, 1999 at the age of 77. A noted psychoanalyst and founder of the Leeds Institute, Dr. Leeds was in private practice on Park Avenue, Manhattan for over thirty years. He graduated from New York University and received his Ph.D. from Yeshiva University. He was analytically trained at NPAP and specialized in family therapy. Dr. Leeds was a proud veteran who served as a Lt. J.G. in the Merchant Marines during WWII. He is survived by two sisters, his sons Rodd Leeds and Richard Leeds, his daughter Eilene Brostoff, four grandchildren and Roberta Leeds. Services July 14th, 11:30AM at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, L.I.

title: Q & A
description: Bypassing Lines in Italy

title: July 11-17; A New Regimen To Fight AIDS in Newborns
description: Developing countries have long sought a simple, affordable way to prevent mother-to-child transmission of the AIDS virus. A study reported from Uganda last week suggested that it may be a drug, nevirapine, that has been marketed in the United States since 1996. Both mother and newborn take nevirapine once -- the mother during labor and the baby by the third day of life. The total cost is $4.

title: Handier Health Care for South Norwalk
description: LOCATION, location, location. It works in real estate and it works in health care.

title: When a Rosy Picture Should Raise a Red Flag
description: WITH stock prices near their highs and corporate earnings looking great, investors might think they can take a vacation from the grunt work of analyzing company financial statements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRICCETTI, THOMAS
description: BRICCETTI-Thomas Composer and conductor Thomas Briccetti died on May 27, 1999 in Perugia, Italy, his home since 1984. Born January 14, 1936 in Mount Kisco, NY to Thomas Briccetti and Joan Filardi. Student of pianist Dr. Jean Dansereau, composers Bernard Rogers, Samuel Barber, Peter Mennin and Alan Hovhaness, conductors Drs. Richard Lert and George Szell. Associate Conductor, Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra; Music Director, St. Petersburg (FL) Symphony, Fort Wayne Philharmonic, Cleveland University Circle, Omaha (NE) Symphony, Stavanger (Norway) Symphony Orchestras, North Carolina School of the Arts, orchestras in Perugia and Bergamo, and frequent guest conductor in Europe and USA. Recipient Prix de Rome in composition; Ford Foundation Composers Fellowship; Yaddo Foundation grant. His 1986 orchestra work, ''Illusions,'' received a Pulitzer Prize nomination. Briccetti is survived by his brother, Dr. Albert Briccetti of Redlands, California, sister Joan Briccetti of St. Louis, Missouri; a son, David Briccetti of Lafayette, California and a daughter, Katherine Briccetti-Clark of Berkeley, California. A memorial service will be held in Pius X Hall of Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY, on August 28, 1999 at 1:30 P.M.

title: Ospreys Reproduce
description: A pair of ospreys has produced offspring in Rye, the first time in more than 100 years that the species has hatched in Westchester, said Jack A. Robbins, the county's Deputy Commissioner for Conservation and Historic Preservation. Two osprey babies emerged from their eggs on June 20 at Marshlands Conservancy, a county nature preserve near Long Island Sound, Mr. Robbins said.

title: Hip, Free and Middle-Aged
description: THE WONDERS OF

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A Machined Model of Affordable Design
description: DAVID HOVEY is an unreformed modernist, enchanted by technology, beguiled by new materials and fascinated by the problem of affordable housing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISTER, GERTRUDE MCMASTERS SMITH
description: WISTER - Gertrude McMasters Smith Of Swarthmore, PA on July 13, 1999. Wife of the late John C. Wister. Survived by her sister Mary Thornton Smith, ten nieces and nephews and 39 great nieces and nephews. Interment in Laurel Hill Cemetery, Ridge Ave. above 35th St., Philadelphia, PA on Tuesday, July 27, 1999 at 2:00 PM. Memorial service to be held in the Fall. Contributions in her memory to Tyler Arboretum, 515 Painter Rd., Media, PA 19063 or Scott Arboretum, Swarthmore College, 500 College Avenue, Swarthmore, PA, would be appreciated. J. Nelson Rigby Funeral Home, Media, PA.

title: Russian Priests Accuse a Bishop, Plunging the Church Into Turmoil
description: Set on the Ural mountain divide between Europe and Asia, this city has long been at the crossroads of Russian history.

title: Navajo Lawsuits Contend U.S. Government Failed the Tribe in Mining Royalty Deals
description: John W. Fritz, an Interior Department official during the Reagan Administration, has long wondered why his decision to sharply increase the coal mining fees paid to the Navajo Indians was blocked.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Words and Music, Circa 1810
description: It's mid-July, and you're tired of building your wardrobe around T-shirts and shorts. You crave a return to a more civilized time, when ladies drifted through cool, green English landscapes wearing Empire-style muslins, glowing instead of sweating. But ''Masterpiece Theater'' isn't obliging this week. What to do, oh, what to do?

title: A Way to Give It Before You've Got It
description: Last year, Chris Evans sold Accipiter, a 22-month-old maker of software that manages Internet ads, to CMGI for $55 million and joined the ranks of Americans with enough cash to become philanthropists. Now Mr. Evans, 33, has invented a way to help newer entrepreneurs get into giving while all of their cash is still tied up in their young companies.

title: Where Summer Is Spoken, With Savor
description: SOME East End restaurants have had as many previous lives as Shirley MacLaine. The building at Main Street and Ocean Road in Bridgehampton is one. It was Melon, One Ocean Road and for the last few seasons the Bridgehampton Cafe. Now it is Henry's, and it looks like a keeper.

title: A 'Show Boat' Worthy of Its Score
description: IT took more than 40 years for a once-popular entertainment to re-emerge as a classic art form.

title: The World; The Other Prime Minister's Visit
description: ON the Israeli Prime Minister's visit to Washington last week, everything went swimmingly.

title: Misfortune Again Strikes A Family That Knows it Well
description: The big white tent was still set on the lawn between the Kennedy family compound here and Nantucket Sound for the planned wedding reception this afternoon for Rory Kennedy, the youngest of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy's children.

title: How to Succeed in Art
description: I'm hoping that all those young art wannabes in schools around the country are learning more than pedantic theory and empty verbiage. Fifteen years after graduating with an M.F.A., I'm still trying to figure out how to translate all that meaningless art discourse into a meaningful paycheck.

title: The Ukrainian in Him
description: To the Editor:

title: Suites and Nothing But At 2 Vancouver Hotels
description: Visitors to Vancouver have two new luxury all-suite hotels to choose from. The Sheraton Suites Le Soleil, which opened in March at 567 Hornby Street, sits about two blocks from the cruise terminals and is in the heart of the business district. The 122 suites are furnished in crimson and gold, with silk brocade coverlets, down duvets and Biedermeier-style furniture. Each has two-line speaker phones with data ports and high-speed Internet access. The hotel's restaurant, Oritalia, features Asian and Mediterranean-style preparations. Doubles are $284 (at $1.48 Canadian to the American dollar); (604) 632-3000 or (877) 632-3030.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: THE WILD COLORADO: The True Adventures of Fred Dellenbaugh, Age 17, on the Second Powell Expedition Into the Grand Canyon. By Richard Maurer. Crown. $18. (Ages 10 and up) Although popular accounts of Maj. John Wesley Powell's exploration of the Colorado River made it seem like one trip, in fact there were two, and the records of the 16-month second expedition were carefully kept. The story of the perilous journey as told through the experiences of a teen-age artist, including some of his drawings as well as photographs, is an exciting adventure.

title: The MP3 Revolution: Getting With It
description: JUST a year ago, writing an article about MP3 meant going into elaborate detail in defining the technology. At that time, the term -- shorthand for the 1992 formula used to compress audio into manageable, easy-to-share computer files -- had been mentioned in only four articles in this newspaper; since then, it has been mentioned in more than 85, becoming a part of the entertainment vocabulary almost as quickly as the name Lewinsky became part of the political one.

title: INSIDE
description: G.O.P. Split on Health Care

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, BENJAMIN H.
description: STRAUSS-Benjamin H. Died peacefully July 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Sara. Devoted and cherished father of Iris Rosenberg, Lynda Nielsen, Wendy Pouria and Beth Williams. Loving and proud grandfather of Kim Kavazanjian, Lee and Sharon Nielsen, Sean, Matthew and Sari Williams. Predeceased by wife Lillian and son Stephen. Esteemed teacher in the Long Beach City Schools for 40 years. Services Sunday 9AM at ''Gutterman's Inc'' , 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: 10-Way Tie at World Open Ends in a Flurry of Playoffs
description: Ten grandmasters tied for first place in the World Open Tournament at the Adams Mark Hotel in Philadelphia over the Fourth of July weekend. They were: Jaan Ehlvest of Estonia, Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Igor Novikov of Ukraine, Gregory Serper of Uzbekistan, Georgy Timoshenko of Ukraine, Alex Yermolinsky of Euclid, Ohio, Vladimir Akopian of Armenia, Boris Gulko of Fairlawn, N.J., Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh and Alexander Fishbein of New Providence, N.J. Each got a diluted prize of $3,250.

title: Traffic Deaths Said to Increase Where Speed Limit Went Up
description: Fatalities rose 50 percent on stretches of highway where the speed limit has been raised to 65 miles per hour, according to an analysis by The Press of Atlantic City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTFEST, SIDNEY
description: ALTFEST-Sidney On July 15, 1999, at age 94. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Sunday, July 18.

title: Type A Travels
description: To the Editor: I read Jill Eisenstadt's essay about traveling with a Type A father (June 20) with great amusement, and a small sense of deja vu. My type A husband did relax and enjoy himself, once we reached our destination. But at overnight stops, our children quickly learned to take their clean clothes for the day into the bathroom while showering lest they get packed and stowed away in the car with the rest of the luggage!

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Name That Neck
description: Nameplate necklaces, those gold chains embellished with the wearer's name in loopy script, had been stowed away next to the leg warmers. But they have been reading ''fashionable'' again since Sarah Jessica Parker wore her ''Carrie'' necklace on the HBO series ''Sex and the City.'' Fans of the show are heading to Chinatown stores like the Golden Dragon (318 Canal Street), where a basic gold nameplate can be ordered for $40. Patricia Field, the show's costume designer, got the idea from inner-city style. ''The trend never died down with the ethnic girls,'' said Ms. Field, who sells nameplates by special order at her store at 10 East Eighth Street for about $100. ''A nice thing to do is to hang a personal charm on them,'' Ms. Field added. On Ms. Parker's necklace, she hung a Playboy bunny. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Round They Go Again, as Full of Fun as Ever
description: IT has been more than 35 years since the Holy Modal Rounders' debut album (completed on the eve of President John F. Kennedy's assassination) announced Peter Stampfel and Steve Weber's intention of creating a new, irreverent, benignly irascible world through the found objects of American music, and 18 years since they recorded as a duo. Therefore, the release last week of ''Too Much Fun'' (Rounder CD3163), an ur-assemblage of Civil War relics, jazzy scat, twining fiddle lines and impromptu silliness by a pair who, though leaner and grayer, have kept both sensibility and chops intact, occasions the same sort of feelings of puzzlement and gratitude as an unexpected reunion with a long-lost classmate.

title: Ruth Levenstein, Robb McDaniels
description: Ruth Kerney Levenstein, a daughter of Dr. Mary K. Levenstein and Earle H. Levenstein of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Robb Alexander McDaniels, the son of Beverly C. McDaniels and John F. McDaniels of North Hampton, N.H., and Rougemont, Switzerland. The Rev. Otto Hentz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: Tara McCreery and Simon Wood
description: Tara Mawn McCreery, the daughter of Gay and William G. McCreery of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there on Friday to Simon James Wood, the son of Carol Thomas of Tiptoe, England, and Peter Wood of Blandford, England. Msgr. Edward Connors performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church.

title: Fending Off Mites and Disease
description: Spider mites thrive in hot, dry weather and feed on many plants. If leaves have pinpoint stippling, look for an infestation and spray with horticultural oil. Cut back sickly yellow foliage of perennials, like columbine, and herbs, like lovage, that mites have attacked.

title: Tax Professionals See Pitfalls in the New I.R.S.
description: For Robert N. Kolb, a lawyer in Walnut Creek, Calif., 1997 and 1998 were especially good years as people with overdue taxes sought his help fending off collectors from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Economist Laureate, Quill in Hand
description: AT 90, John Kenneth Galbraith has just published his 34th book, ''Name-Dropping,'' (Houghton Mifflin, $26) a memoir featuring F.D.R. and Eleanor, Jack and Jackie, Adlai and L.B.J. He has been speaking to packed auditoriums, and now he is ready to hop on a plane to London, where he will be giving a speech on ''The Unfinished Business of the Century.'' And he is already hard at work on Book No. 35. ''I get uneasy unless I've spent part of every day writing,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZABEL, ANNE
description: ZABEL-Anne The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum, and of the Israel Museum are deeply saddened by the death of Anne Zabel, mother of our fellow Director and staunch supporter, William D. Zabel. We extend deepest sympathies to Bill, Deborah and the entire family. Judy Steinhardt, President, AFIM James Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM Carolyn Cohen, Exec. Dir., AFIM

title: Sari Padorr and Howard Saltz
description: Sari Padorr and Howard Saltz were married last evening by Rabbi Sandra Cohen at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Denver.

title: Less Thrill, More Chill In Day Trading
description: THERE was a trace of eulogy in the young day trader's voice as he reflected on how different the world looked after April, a month in which once-sizzling Internet stocks began a steep slide that cut the sector's value by at least 20 percent in just nine weeks.

title: Czech Mate
description: SACRIFICE

title: The Garden As Eden, And Therapy; Residents Who Share a Passion For Things That Grow
description: MARSHA NEWMAN, a teacher who says she knows ''zero'' about plying the earth, is nevertheless passionate when it comes to the kaleidoscope of color playing through her formal garden on five acres in Bedford, one tended mostly by professionals.

title: Nassau's Fiscal Mess: Years in the Making
description: JUST how did Nassau County, one of the nation's wealthiest communities, manage to run up a record budget deficit during an economic boom?

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-18-99: The Ethicist; Cut-Rate Rationale
description: The other day I noticed an unusual sign in the window of a kids' clothing and toy store: Lesbian Moms, 10 Percent Off. Is this ethical (not to mention legal)? I can't imagine a store boasting a sign, White People, 10 Percent Off, for example. But that really got me thinking: what about those Ladies' Nights at bars? - Gina D., Manhattan

title: The Bounce From Stock Buybacks
description: BURNED once, shame on you; burned twice, shame on me. That variation on an old saying explains much investor behavior. It takes a lot to persuade investors who have already lost money in a given stock to keep believing in it if it keeps falling, no matter what its fundamentals.

title: FILM; The Masterpiece a Master Couldn't Get Right
description: EVERY movie director has movies he hoped to make but couldn't, usually for financial reasons (the favorite unmade projects of established directors usually tend toward the epic.) More than any director of his generation, Stanley Kubrick enjoyed freedom from these constraints. After the successes of ''Dr. Strangelove'' and ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' in the 60's, Kubrick was largely able to make what movies he liked.

title: Halifax
description: Halifax's past looms larger than usual this summer as the city marks a milestone: 250 years ago this June a flotilla carrying 1,000 families arrived from England to settle along this impressive natural harbor.

title: Young Rebels
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay on Little League Accentuated the Negative
description: To the Editor:

title: Eclipsed
description: Thanks for Bill Keller's (June 27) fascinating look at the Soviet space race. I agree that precise comparisons between the American and Soviet programs are difficult, if not impossible. Yet when Keller notes that ''the Russians have lost fewer lives in their space program than the Americans,'' I wonder if this comparison also includes lives lost on the ground by launch crews and ancillary workers. James Harford, in his 1997 biography of Sergei Pavlovich Korolev, notes at least two instances, including a disastrous 1960 explosion that is now estimated to have taken 165 lives.

title: Competitors Can Teach You a Lot, but the Lessons Can Hurt
description: A FEW years back, a big pharmaceuticals company -- name withheld to protect the embarrassed -- benchmarked its delivery methods against a competitor's. The rival was combining product shipments from different divisions, enabling it to negotiate bigger, and thus lower-priced, shipping contracts. The pharmaceuticals company figured it would do the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKERING, MARTHA HOLDING
description: PICKERING-Martha Holding, 70. Of Princeton, NJ and West Palm Beach, FL, on July 15, 1999 of breast cancer at home in Princeton. Wife of Donald A., mother of Stowe H. Tattersall, Samuel C. Tattersall and Martha T. Giancola, grandmother of David H. Giancola and Edith C. Tattersall. Sister of Audrey H. McCargo, stepmother of Donald A. Pickering, Jr. and Dorothy Pickering Bossidy, stepgrandmother of Stuart C.C. Pickering. She was predeceased by her sister, Nancy H. Tansill. Interment private in Edgartown, MA. Memorial service at 11 AM on Saturday, September 11, at Trinity Church, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Martha Holding Pickering Memorial Fund at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CARL K.
description: KLEIN-Carl K. Age 93. Formerly of Englewood, NJ, died July 16, 1999 in Miami Beach, FL. Husband of the late Sylvia, he is survived by his sons Richard and Arthur and their wives Joan and Roberta. Esteemed grandfather of Jonathan, David, Elizabeth, Catherine and Pamela. Brother of Meyer. Graveside services Tuesday, July 20, 1PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Shiva to be followed at the home of Arthur Klein.

title: Although Up 5, He's Pressured
description: Almost everyone leaving Carnoustie tonight wondered the same things. Could Jean Van de Velde, who has never contended in a major before, hold on to his five-stroke lead? And if not, who would overtake him?

title: Appeals Court Blocks an Artist From Photographing 100 Nudes
description: The Giuliani administration won a round yesterday in its legal fight to keep a Brooklyn artist from assembling 100 naked people in lower Manhattan for a photograph.

title: Indoors, or Out, the Geranium Is at Home
description: FEW plants have the versatility of geraniums. These colorful plants are at home anywhere.

title: Julia Pershan, Jonathan Cohen
description: Julia Bennett Pershan, a daughter of Kathryn and Richard H. Pershan of New York, was married last evening to Jonathan Zubrow Cohen, a son of Betsy and Edward E. Cohen of Philadelphia. Rabbi Harry Z. Sky officiated at the summer house of the bridegroom's family on Islesboro in Maine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELIZABETH
description: SCHWARTZ-Elizabeth Congregation Ohav Shalom mourns the tragic death of Elizabeth (Elisheva) Shuchat Schwartz, who was a truly inspiring role model as Rebbetzin of our Kehila during the tenure of her husband, Rabbi J. Yaacov Schwartz. Her warmth, optimism, vibrance , spirit and deep devotion to our community will never be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, daughter Ayala, parents Rabbi Wilfred and Miriam Shuchat, sister Margola, brother Rafi, sister Bryna, our beloved member, and brother-inlaw Joshua Landes, our Vice President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, FRED MAX
description: ROSENBERG-Fred Max, 90. Loving brother, uncle and friend. Your contribution to education and the underserved can never be measured. Graveside services, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Sunday, July 18, 11:00 A.M.

title: Colombia Is Reeling, Hurt by Rebels and Economy
description: Almost every day now, it seems there is some piece of bad news to lower spirits and raise fears here. If it isn't one guerrilla group attacking on the outskirts of the capital, it is another hijacking a plane or blowing up the country's main oil pipeline. If it isn't unemployment rising to an all-time high, it is the peso plunging to a record low against the dollar.

title: Remembering Mohawk Ironworkers' Urban Haven
description: George Norton, 52, a Mohawk Indian and an ironworker, has seen his neighborhood change over the years from an urban center for Mohawks, with their own bars and grocery stores selling traditional foodstuffs, to a place where an American Indian presence is barely visible.

title: A Connoisseur of Cool Tries to Raise the Temperature
description: IN ''The Killing'' (1956), one of Stanley Kubrick's earliest feature films, a man talking about his cronies in a racetrack heist remarks: ''None of these men are criminals in the usual sense. They've all got jobs and they all live seemingly normal, decent lives, but they've got their problems and they've all got a little larceny in them.'' Change ''a little larceny'' to varying degrees of ''a lot'' and you've got a pretty good description of Kubrick's entire body of work -- a cerebral, often brilliant oeuvre that purveys an insistently Hobbesian view of life as short, nasty and brutish, and man as a deeply flawed creature decidedly closer to the savage apes in ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' than that film's blissful star child.

title: Kathleen Murphy, Edward Jasaitis
description: Kathleen Alice Murphy and Edward George Jasaitis were married yesterday by the Rev. John Murray at St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church in Concord, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINEY, DANA MICHELLE (NEE CLERICO)
description: MINEY-Dana Michelle (nee Clerico) On July 16, 1999. Beloved wife of Kevin. Loving daughter of Ann and Vincent Clerico. Cherished sister and friend of Vincent Clerico and Tracy Quinn. Devoted aunt of Jeffrey, Christopher, Matthew, Melissa, Bernadette, Robert, Emily and Renee. Reposing at the Harden Funeral Home of Bayside, 209th St. and Northern Blvd. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:15 AM, Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Dana's courage, strength and dignity was an inspiration to us all.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Here's the Deal on Van Gundy: Knicks' Coach Is Back, but for How Long?
description: First, the precarious nature of Coach Jeff Van Gundy's job status was supposed to end when Allan Houston's jump shot propelled the Knicks past the despised Miami Heat in the first round of the playoffs. When that did not happen, it was assumed that Van Gundy would be granted his desired security as a result of subsequent victories over the Atlanta Hawks and the powerful Indiana Pacers and the Knicks' gallant effort against the San Antonio Spurs in the N.B.A. finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, PAULA
description: WOLFF-Paula On July 16, 1999 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Leon; cherished mother of Elaine; devoted sister of Erna Herz; caring aunt of Huguette, Annik, Liane, Josette, and their families; loving sister-in-law of Marthe and the late Rene, Suzanne, Achilles, Robert, Sylvia, and Benno; deeply valued by a large extended family and many friends. Born in Breisach, Germany, September 30th, 1919, daughter of the late Emilie (nee Itzkowitz) and Hermann Wurmser. Came to America in 1937; worked hard to bring her mother and sister here. Valued her Jewish heritage throughout her life. She will be remembered for her courage, strength, generosity of spirit, and enormous capacity to make and keep friends from every walk of life. She will be so very missed by so very many. Service at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Q. & A.
description: Noise From Fans on The Roof

title: The World: Meanwhile, Back in Bosnia; Slowly Starving Serb Defiance
description: AFTER years of obstinacy, the Serbs finally gave in here last month. Local Serb nationalists allowed the majority Muslim town council -- elected in absentia more than two years ago -- to take official control of a town that has stood as a symbol of Serb defiance and brutality in Bosnia.

title: In America; How Many Innocent Prisoners?
description: One way or another Vincent Jenkins will be freed from the Green Haven Correctional Facility in upstate Dutchess County, where he has served nearly 17 years of a life sentence for a rape he didn't commit.

title: With a Big Scoop, a Deeper Harbor
description: WITH a mouth as big as a one-car garage and a capacity of more than 30 tons in a single gulp, a shiny new dredge, one of the largest of its kind, is being prepared for its first job: eating up the bottom of the Kill Van Kull, the waterway connecting the ports of Newark Bay with New York Harbor.

title: July 11-17; A Doctor Is Forced To Heal Herself
description: An Air Force jet flew an emergency mission over the South Pole last Sunday to drop medical supplies for a member of a research team who discovered a lump in her breast. But the case is more difficult than Government researchers revealed: the patient will have to treat herself, because she is the only doctor on the 41-member team at the isolated Antarctic base. Her diagnosis has not been disclosed. Because of harsh winter conditions, she cannot be flown out until October or November. DENISE GRADY

title: The Fine Art of Biting Into Japanese Cuteness
description: SINCE the late 1980's, a number of younger Japanese artists have emerged on the international scene to challenge the old notion that all modern art from Japan is merely a pale imitation of modern art from the West. Among them are Yasumasa Morimura, Tatsuo Miyajima, Mariko Mori and Takashi Murakami, whose goofy, glossy work has found an avid audience outside Japan. Rooted in Japanese popular culture, Mr. Murakami's art communicates across borders in a media-driven era of global pop to which fashion, animation, music and electronic gadgetry from Japan have all contributed. It is now the focus of ''The Meaning of the Nonsense of the Meaning,'' a mini-retrospective on view here at the Center for Curatorial Studies Museum at Bard College through Sept. 12.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 18, 1999
description: Weeks

title: America's Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: In Canada, Our Culture or Theirs?
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Succeed in Art
description: I wonder why Deborah Solomon spent time picking on art students for networking and showing in galleries before they graduate. After all, many find themselves with more than $50,000 in debt after getting their M.F.A.'s., so if they can sell work and if their faculty mentors are willing to help them make connections, what's wrong with that? Don't professors in other disciplines help their graduate students?

title: Often the Runner-Up, Kane Now Eyes Victory
description: As her 15-foot putt on the 18th hole at Wykagyl Country Club trickled into the cup today, Lorie Kane raised her arms triumphantly, acknowledged the applause of the crowd and excitedly hugged her caddie. That the birdie only brought Kane within two strokes of Sherri Steinhauer, her playing partner and leader of the Japan Airlines Big Apple Classic entering Sunday's final day, did not diminish the celebration. For Kane, the celebration is practice.

title: Iran Students Halt Protests But Still Press For Changes
description: Student leaders today announced a temporary ban on pro-reform demonstrations, but pressed the Islamic Government on a long list of demands, including the resignation of the country's chief of police.

title: Two-Faced Once More
description: How does an actor follow the act of playing two roles in a musical? By playing two roles in another musical.

title: And Now for a Little Organized Revisionism
description: THAT ominous high-pitched organ tremolo. Greek temple ruins over blue Sicilian waters. Yup, we know where we are. We're back in Godfather country. This time it's the Mafia world (oops, the world of ''tradition'' and ''honor'') of Joseph Bonanno, the long-retired boss (he prefers ''father'') widely known as Joe Bananas, who is now, at 94, truly the Really Absolutely Very Last Don.

title: Marymount College Names Alumna as Interim President
description: ANNE SLATTERY, the newly appointed interim president at Marymount College here, knows how to make a good first impression. When she met with members of the faculty, recalled Dr. John Lawry, chairman of the psychology department, who has been with the Roman Catholic college for 34 years, ''she walked into the faculty lounge and was incredulous that there were no air-conditioners.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RENSSELAER, CHARLES A.
description: VAN RENSSELAER-Charles A. III, 73 years old, from an historical New York family of great 17th century landowners, (a million acres) patroons, & revolutionary patriots, died this morning after an automobile accident in Palm Beach, FL, his residence for the past thirty years. His famous ancestor, Stephen Van Rensselaer, the last Patroon of Rensselaer Manor, founded Rensselaer Polytech College in Troy, N.Y. in 1824. He is survived by his brother Philip Van Rensselaer of Manhattan, N.Y. and his aunt Lillian Van Rensselaer of Locust Valley, N.Y. A Funeral Service will be held at 12:30 P.M. on Monday, July 19, 1999 at St. Edwards Catholic Church, Palm Beach. Private interment will take place at St. John's Cemetery in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. For more information, contact Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: July 11-17; Thinking Small. Real Small.
description: As remarkable as today's supercomputers are, they may seem like Model-T's in less than a decade. Scientists say they have taken the first tentative steps into a world of computing that would be far smaller and faster than today's silicon-based machines.

title: Jennifer Rowe, Michael Staisil
description: Jennifer Lynn Rowe was married yesterday to Michael John Staisil at the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago. The Rev. John H. Boyle performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, NORMAN
description: ROSENTHAL-Norman, Dr. For the past 50 years, he was the Great Neck, N.Y., physician and healer in the grand tradition of medicine. His passing is like the extinguishing of a bright light-so brilliant was his personality, and so incisive was his medical judgment. We, among his closest friends and associates, were charmed by his dashing wit and touched by his loyalty to friends and patients alike. Judith and Mordecai Berkun Ellen and Myron Conovitz Marion and Isadore Horowitz Bette and Donald Stein Marcia and Leonard Zigelbaum

title: Political Briefing; In a Swift Campaign, Some Fast Polls, Too
description: It is still early in the Election 2000 nominating game, but in the for-what-it's-worth department, here are the results of some polls taken in various states in recent days.

description: FEINSTEIN-Harry. 7/18/80. Our beloved husband and father, close to our hearts always. Francine, Nina, Beth and David

title: Reaching for the Big Bang, With Bumps
description: SCIENTISTS and engineers toiling on a new $600 million device touted as a tool that will extend the frontiers of science are beginning to sound a little frustrated by delays in the first major milestone in a months-long startup procedure.

title: Near Paris, a Salute To Saint-Gaudens
description: Augustus Saint-Gaudens (1848-1907) is often called the American Michelangelo, but his father was French and he studied in Paris, participated in important Parisian salons and eventually retired to a New Hampshire farm named after his father's village in the Pyrenees. This year marks the first major retrospective of his work in France: Through Oct. 18, over 100 of Saint-Gaudens's monumental sculptures, portraits and numismatic designs, gleaned from public and private collections, will be displayed at the 17th-century Chateau de Blerancourt northeast of Paris. His celebrated public commissions include Civil War memorials to Lincoln, Admiral Farragut, General Sherman, Col. Robert Gould Shaw (on Boston Common) and the exquisite double-eagle gold coins created at the behest of Theodore Roosevelt. More intimate works are also presented in this exhibition -- informal portraits, delicate cameo jewelry, and a copy of the sweetly elegant Diana, the sculptor's only female nude, which first served as a weathervane atop the original Madison Square Garden.

title: Family Vacation for Everyone
description: EVERYBODY loves a summer vacation. Often the most depressing moment, however, is parting with a pet. Those pleading eyes can stay with you for hours. Taking them along is an option, but it requires planning ahead, special considerations and certain risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, BLANCHE R.
description: PAUL-Blanche R. On July 15. Beloved mother of Madeline, sisterin-law of Ethel Rothenberg, aunt and great aunt. Services Sunday 10AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Avenue and E. 10 St.

title: Into the Unknown
description: The articles by Richard Ford and Stanley Crouch (''In the Same Boat'' and ''Black Like Huck,'' June 6) are beautifully written and, of course, revealing. Revealing in that they not only show the personalities of these two men but also the wider issues in society about what used to be called ''the Negro Question.'' A misnomer, since it is really a white question.

title: In Internet Spinoffs, Where Should the Riches Fall?
description: AS companies plan to sell shares in their Internet operations to the public, they face a quandary: whether to limit the potentially huge stock benefits in the spinoff to the unit's employees or managers, or to share the wealth throughout the company.

title: Lisa Gedzelman, John Leone
description: Lisa Gedzelman and John Leone were married last evening at the Yale Club in Manhattan. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated.

title: Violent Wrestlers Seen as a Cut Above; Combatants Suffer Real Injuries, Much to the Audience's Delight
description: As the crowd of hundreds chanted, ''Make them bleed! Make them bleed!'' Frank Iadavaia raised the metal garbage can above his head and heaved it into the ring.

title: Intensive Search Is Normal, Officials Say, But Level of Interest Is Far From Common
description: It began with a 2 A.M. phone call from a Kennedy family friend to the Coast Guard office in Woods Hole, Mass., reporting a private airplane missing. The information the caller gave was sketchy. She did not, at first, even identify the passengers.

title: Brimming With Style
description: Baseball caps, beware. A new hat has been tossed into the ring, one that captures the flavor of the 1920's flappers' cloche and babies' beach hats of the 30's. Pulled deeply down on the head for a small, rounded look, it is the perfect top to today's minimalist silhouette. These inexpensive, crushable, machine-washable fabric hats are major accessories for young New Yorkers this summer.

title: July 11-17; A Fugitive Is Found
description: After months of eluding the authorities, who had linked him with eight brutal killings in Texas, Illinois and Kentucky, Angel Maturino Resendez, a Mexican drifter with a fondness for aliases, disguises and travel by freight train gave himself up in El Paso after his sister negotiated his surrender with a Texas Ranger.

title: The Greening of 14th Street: Seedy Remnant Closes
description: The last remnant of 14th Street's seedy past, an adult video store near Third Avenue, closed last week. In years gone by, the block was the domain of crack-addled prostitutes and transients who lived in the Sahara, a single-room-occupancy hotel above the sex shop, one of several that had operated in the vicinity over the last 20 years.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Making Love Modern

title: A 20th-Century Master Scam
description: Before John Myatt was sentenced to prison in February for his part as a forger in perhaps the most ingenious and damaging art con of the 20th century, he lived in a humble cottage on a narrow lane in the idyllic Staffordshire village of Sugnall, a three-hour drive northwest of London. To his neighbors, he appeared to be an unremarkable painter who had never established a style with which to spawn a career. He also wrote catchy pop tunes. If Myatt was known for anything, it was for a hit single, ''Silly Games,'' which made the British Top 40 in 1979.

title: Soaring Softly Takes 5th Straight on Grass
description: By a fortunate bob of her chestnut head, the filly Soaring Softly won her fifth straight race on the grass yesterday and stayed undefeated in 1999 when she nosed out Tampico in the New York Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Jodie Siegel and Edward Sharon
description: AS a high school freshman in Washington, Edward Wadsworth Sharon badly needed a confidante. His older sister had just gone away to boarding school, leaving him alone with his mother. His father, John H. Sharon, who had been a foreign policy adviser to President John F. Kennedy, died when Edward was 6.

title: My Not-So-Brilliant Career
description: JEM (AND SAM)

title: Mortgage Contingency Clauses
description: MOST people know that a contract to buy a house or apartment usually contains a clause that allows the buyer to get out of the deal if he or she does not qualify for a mortgage.

title: Web Ropes in Horror Film's Fans
description: THE SETTING -- The midnight opening of ''The Blair Witch Project'' on Tuesday night attracted a line of fans stretching well around the corner of the Angelika Film Center. The low-budget horror film, made in eight days by five friends from the University of Central Florida, has been promoted heavily on the Internet for months. Tickets for the three late-night screenings were sold out days in advance, but that didn't stop the truly devoted, who began to line up for seats at 10 A.M. They wore ''Blair Witch'' T-shirts and clutched posters, some bragging that they had already seen bootleg tapes. The filmmakers mingled with the crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMAN, CHARLES P.
description: ROMAN-Charles P. Loving husband of Orpha. Loving father of Roger and Ron. Loving grandfather of Lindsay and Ryan. Charles - the very best a man could be.

title: New Kid on The Block
description: How could Eric Messinger let Spike Lee get away with blaming his wife, Tonya, for every non-P.C. decision his family made? Why did Lee decide to leave Brooklyn for the Upper East Side? Tonya. Why is he sending his kids to private instead of public school? Tonya, of course!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, ROBERT K.
description: RAISLER-Robert K. Died peacefully on July 12 at his home in New York, surrounded by his children and grandchildren. He was the son of the late Samuel and Belle Raisler of New York City, brother of the late Harold Raisler and for more than 42 years, the adoring husband of the late Dolly Wolfson Raisler (who pre-deceased him by four weeks), the father of Gordon, Steven and Lynn Jacobson and grandfather to Michael, Anthony and Joe Jacobson and Joe's finacee Jordana Matthews. As longtime President and Chairman of Raisler Corporation, a family controlled, New York based Mechanical Contracting firm founded in 1899 by his father Samuel. Robert Raisler was a strong and respected Building Trades Industry advocate, and a member of many industry and professional associations and boards. Following his World War II service in the Pacific theater as a Naval Officer and Chief of aircraft maintenance on the aircraft carrier US Boxer, he maintained a life long association with the Navy as a reserve Officer, ultimately holding the rank of Lt. Commander, Ret. Widely regarded as a true ''gentleman'', Robert Raisler was President of the University of Pennsylvania's Class of 1926, former President of the Congregation Shaaray Tefila in New York City and a philanthropist well known to many charitable and educational institutions. Services were held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79 Street (at 2nd Avenue) on Thursday, July 15, 1999. The family request that any donations be directed to the Raisler Fund at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Engineering. The Engineering School's alumni office may be contacted at (215) 898-6564.

title: Daughters of American Evolution
description: I DISTINCTLY remember being 11 and preparing for Come As You Wish You Were Day at school. In baggy jeans and a boy's flannel checked shirt and with my face strategically smudged, I proudly announced that I was Scout of ''To Kill a Mockingbird.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Flowers and Hands

title: Atlantic City Center Offers Welcome, but No Plumbing
description: The Atlantic City Visitor's Welcome Center, a circular $3.7 million affair just outside the city along the Atlantic City Expressway, is set to open later this month. It has one glaring omission, as far as Atlantic City's Mayor, James Whelan, is concerned -- there will be no public restrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIGHTMAN, IRMA SHORELL
description: LIGHTMAN-Irma Shorell July 18, 1994 You were an original-there will never be another like you. Thank you for 40 fabulous yearsIt was never dull. See you, H.A.L.

title: POSTINGS: Groundbreaking at Montefiore; Bronx Children's Hospital
description: A groundbreaking ceremony is scheduled to take place next Saturday for a 106-bed children's hospital in the Bronx that is to include, in addition to specialized advanced care facilities, a domed observatory on its roof.

title: Bicycle Pilgrims
description: To the Editor: David G. P. R. Duffy suggests in ''A Pilgrim's Rewards, Step by Step'' (May 30) that it is also possible to make a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela by bicycle.

title: Of Central Park They Sing
description: A NEW operatic project could hardly receive a more auspicious introduction than that to be accorded over the next five months to ''Central Park,'' a trilogy of one-act operas by three American composer-librettist teams. That's why the flak that the project has stirred up among many people concerned about the future of American opera, especially American composers, has been so noteworthy.

title: Virginia Klunder, Allan Braslow
description: Virginia Klunder, a daughter of Rita and John Klunder of Astoria, Queens, is to be married today to Dr. Allan Braslow, the son of Ina and Saul Braslow of Stamford, Conn. Judge Ingrid S. Braslow of Westchester County Family Court in White Plains, the bridegroom's cousin, is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: Rummana Hussain, a painter and conceptual artist who was also active in Indian politics, died on July 5 at her home in Bombay. She was 47.

title: A Child's Garden of Haring
description: He began his career in the city's subways, drawing simple outlines in white chalk on the black paper that covered unused advertising space. Later, as his career took off, Keith Haring became a darling of the 1980's downtown art world. By the time he died of AIDS in 1990 at 31, his brightly colored cartoonlike figures could be seen just about everywhere, in galleries and museums, on MTV set decorations, in advertisements for vodka and watches.

title: What Candidates Did in War Matters; Hypocrisy Uncovered
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Proposal Advancing for Tallest Stamford Tower
description: THE Louis Dreyfus Property Group goes before the Stamford Zoning Board tomorrow evening with a plan to build what would be the tallest structure in Stamford, one floor higher than the 22-story Landmark Building, which is now the city's highest.

title: PULSE; Mother Knows Best
description: The year was 1973. It was my mother's first day in America, and her Afro was picked to perfection, her gold hoop earrings were gleaming and she was wearing a chic, handmade dashiki dress from her homeland, Nigeria. Now, inspired by the resurfacing of dashikis in bohemian coffee shops in the Fort Greene and Clinton Hill areas of Brooklyn (and by a need to wear something comfortable in the heat), I pull out the multicolored heirloom that Mother promised would be back, and pair it with Capri pants.

title: Log Cabin, With 1,000-Acre Backyard
description: TO get the confusing part out of the way: the Idaho Rocky Mountain Ranch is not really a ranch, and while it is in the northern Rockies, the mountains visible from the front porch of the ranch's main building -- snowcapped peaks towering 3,000 feet or more above a basin that is already 6,700 above sea level -- are called the Sawtooth Mountains, birthplace of the Salmon River and a lure to wilderness lovers and backpackers who gladly climb heart-stopping trails for a glimpse of a hidden Alpine lake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKURNICK, DORA
description: SKURNICK-Dora Age 93, on July 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Morris Skurnick. Devoted mother of Francine Rockman (and husband Elliott) and Eugene Skurnick (and wife Blanche). Beloved sister of Rae Silverman, adored grandmother of David, Elizabeth and Miriam. Services are 9:30 a.m. Monday, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: 2 Are Charged With Rape In Gramercy Park Home
description: Two men were charged yesterday with robbery and rape in an early morning gunpoint attack in Manhattan, the police said.

title: INVESTING WITH: Erin Sullivan; Fidelity Aggressive Growth Fund
description: AT Fidelity Investments, known for a willingness to let young stock-pickers run big funds and invest aggressively, Erin Sullivan may be the quintessential portfolio manager.

title: Black and Gold Beauties of Emilia
description: THE secret weapon of the best Italian eating is respect for the ingredients, and a tiny bottle of an exotic near-black vinegar and a golden wheel of grainy cheese represent two of the most revered ingredients in the Italian spectrum. Both come from Emilia, the inland half of Emilia-Romagna, the region between the Apennines and the northern Adriatic.

title: Malaria a Focus Of Health Group
description: MALARIA was in its usual top spot on the agenda when 1,800 experts in travelers' health met in Montreal last month. Malaria protozoa, which move in parasites spread by mosquito bites, have evolved strains resistant to drugs faster than human research can catch up. There is no vaccine, and the disease causes the deaths of a million people annually in Africa alone.

title: Room With a Virtual View
description: At a glance, the security camera looks like any other. But instead of watching for suspicious activity, this camera simply takes in the weather.

title: Miss Erickson And Mr. Coad
description: Kathleen Ann Erickson, a senior probation officer, and Brian Douglas Coad, an assistant United States attorney, both with Federal District Court in Manhattan, were married on Friday. The Rev. Martha Anderson performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

title: The Push of Gravity, The Pull of Gravity
description: WHAT goes up must come down is the law of gravity as well as of temporary exhibitions. The two domains have now coincided in a show at the Stamford branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art in ''Zero G: When Gravity Becomes Form.''

title: Travel on Wheels
description: To the Editor: Thank you for Penny Wolfson's essay, ''Balancing Act in a Wheelchair'' (June 27). As someone born with a disability due to a muscular dystrophy-related condition, I was both touched and angered by her account of traveling in Italy with her disabled son.

title: The Things Birds Do After They Fly Away
description: Sir David Attenborough scoured the planet to make ''The Life of Birds,'' his 10-hour documentary series on the extraordinary attributes of man's avian neighbors, which has its premiere on PBS on Tuesday. Over three years he visited 42 countries, stalking carnivorous parrots in New Zealand, waiting on a Mexican beach for exhausted echelons of ruby-throated hummingbirds completing a wing-straining 500-mile sea crossing from Texas.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: CHINHOMINEY'S SECRET

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.; A Sense of the Past In a Diverse Village
description: AFTER living in Beverly Hills for seven years, Laura and William Carraro, a freelance film producer, longed for the things they couldn't find there.

title: Religious Council Tells Gay Group Thanks but No Thanks
description: Daniel Dromm, co-chairman of the Queens Lesbian and Gay Pride Committee, did not think it out of the ordinary when his group received a letter from a Roman Catholic-Jewish interfaith group soliciting money to sponsor a concert.

title: Not the Waltons, but It Is Michael Learned and Ralph Waite
description: NO, it is not a Waltons' summer. Or any other sort of wholesome family reunion or holiday. Having returned for a television Easter (1997), Thanksgiving (1993) and a wedding (1995), after eight years starting in 1972 as John-Boy's Mama and Papa, Michael Learned and Ralph Waite are together again in a new play, ''Chasing Monsters,'' which is to open tomorrow at the Westport Country Playhouse.

title: Piazza and the Mets, Still Batting Second
description: For one weekend last weekend -- New York's baseball spotlight finally belonged to Mike Piazza, and he seized it with two three-run home runs as the Mets took two of three games from the Yankees.

title: Abstract Ink Drawings and Photocopies
description: SOMEWHERE in our subconscious, object- and event-based memories transform from real-time representations to distorted and fragmented abstractions. This collection of remnants can reappear in spontaneous drawings, as is the case in the art of a Brooklyn resident, Susan Sills. Her exhibition of ink drawings, transfer prints and photocopies is titled ''Kaleidoscope'' and is on display at the Manhattanville College Library Gallery here.

title: Paddle in One Hand, Brochure in the Other
description: KELLY WEBSTER, 8, was ready for the trip. ''I like to go up the river,'' she said. Her dad, Peter Webster, slid a 13-foot, yellow and white, two-seater kayak off his car and carried it down to Middle Cove, behind the town park on Main Street in Essex. Kelly settled into the front seat; Mr. Webster shoved off, and soon they were paddling across the cove as they began a trip on the new Connecticut River Estuary Canoe/Kayak trail.

title: The World; Now That the Wars Are Over, Utopia Seems More Distant
description: THE warm and fuzzies have vanished from peacemaking.

title: Sirens Raise Firefighters, and Noise Complaints
description: SOON after Paula M. Persich, her husband and three young children moved into their new home here last August, the siren at the firehouse across the street went off.

title: Kashmir War, Shown on TV, Rallies India's Unity
description: The crowd heaved and moaned and pushed up against the plain wooden box that held the body of Suresh Kumar, an Indian soldier killed in the fighting with Pakistan over Kashmir. But as the lid was pried open, the throng parted easily to let television cameramen in for a close-up of the young man's mother. Her eyes brimmed with tears as she gave her son's face a final caress.

title: Energy Dept. Plans Action On Blackouts
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson will propose six steps to reduce electricity disruptions in severe weather in a speech on Monday, including Federal investigations of power blackouts like the ones that plagued New York and other cities this month, department officials say.

title: In Riverhead, Where the Buffalo Roam
description: THE plains start at the intersection of Reeves and Roanoke Avenues, just beyond downtown Riverhead. Grazing in a field littered with cobs of corn, 32 buffalo are home on Ed Tuccio's range.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, ELIZABETH
description: BRENNAN-Elizabeth, formerly of Manhasset, died May 19 in Pennsylvania. She was the wife of the late John M. Brennan, a respected golf writer who wrote for the New York Times and several other publications and was a onetime Metropolitan Golf Writer's Association Golf Writer of the Year. Mrs. Brennan was born in 1903 in Poland, but grew up in Bayside, N.Y. Her father, Peter Mileski, was a builder and store owner. She was attached to the early motion picture business on Long Island before marrying and moving to Manhasset in 1940, where she lived until the mid 1990s. Her automobile was always recognized by the vanity license plates ordered by her husband-''BBB'' for Beautiful Betty Brennan. She was predeceased by her only child, the late Elizabeth M. Sanson of Edgartown, Mass. She is survived by two sisters, Estelle Barron of Bayside, N.Y., & Gladys Locker of Oakdale, N.Y., along with grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Services included a wake at Fairchild & Sons Funeral Home on Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, Mass at St. Mary's Church in Manhasset & interment in Mount St. Mary's Cemetery in Flushing on June 3rd.

title: In Georgia, Days of Wine and Roadsters
description: SO what does the nicotine skin patch have to do with wine, golf champions and, yes, really cool sports cars? Royalties from the transdermal patch have helped to pay for the Panoz family's delightfully disparate conglomerate, a host of enterprises that includes Georgia's only serious winery and the company that builds a car the racing legend Parnelli Jones has dubbed ''the great American roadster.''

title: Just Speak Into the Lamp
description: INSIDE THE OVAL OFFICE

title: Christina Boyle And Michael Cush
description: Christina Elaine Boyle, a daughter of Susan and Edward J. Boyle of Manhasset, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Rene Cush, a son of Francoise and Joseph T. Cush of Smithtown, N.Y. The Rev. William J. Bergen performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: In Gardens Where the Unusual Is Nurtured
description: FOR 23 years, Frederick and Mary Ann McGourty, the owners of Hillside Gardens in Norfolk, have taken cues from Nature herself, designing, planting and maintaining 20 perennial beds using unusual plants to embellish the gently sloping terrain surrounding their 18th-century farmhouse. Visitors come from all over the country to see uncommon perennials in an unpretentious setting.

title: Wrongful Arrest of Actor Is Blamed on Bias
description: A day after Alton Fitzgerald White was arrested, strip-searched and then released when the police acknowledged they had erred, the actor, who plays a leading role in the Broadway musical ''Ragtime,'' said it seemed as if life had imitated art.

title: For Her: It's A Handbag Moment
description: TRACEY JACKSON'S collection of nearly 100 handbags is displayed with a reverence usually reserved for reliquary objects. The purses -- limited-edition Gucci bags, one-of-a-kind vintage styles, beaded pouches from India -- rest on tables and shelves all around her Upper East Side town house. ''Not just the usual 10021 collection,'' Ms. Jackson proudly pointed out, referring to her ZIP code.

title: Poet and Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: King of the Road
description: THE DISTANCE

title: Veterinarian Is Convicted Of Abusing Animals in His Care
description: An East Brunswick veterinarian was convicted last week of 14 counts of abusing animals in his care. It was the first case of its type in at least 15 years in New Jersey, according to the Richard J. Alampi, executive director of the New Jersey Veterinary Medical Association.

title: Bradley McLean and Miriam Krause
description: Miriam Elaine Krause, a daughter of Mavis and Victor Krause of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bradley McLean, a son of Pamella Blake McLean and Prof. L. Deckle McLean of Macomb, Ill. The Rev. Dr. F. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

title: Another Entry for King of the Sky
description: FROM Mario Garnero's penthouse office in a skyscraper he built here, the view invokes the way Mario de Andrade, Brazil's modernist writer, once described this city -- ''a great mouth with a thousand teeth.'' In almost every direction, crops of steep structures jut out of the concrete in a show of the magnitude of Sao Paulo, the third-largest metropolis in the world, after Tokyo and Mexico City.

title: Miss Kordonowy and Mr. McGarry
description: Rachel Louise Kordonowy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Kordonowy of Deephaven, Minn., was married yesterday to James Michael McGarry 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. McGarry 3d of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Andrew Waldo performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Minneapolis, with the Rev. Daniel R. Sweeney, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: A County Fair, of Sorts, For a High-Flying Sport
description: AIRBORNE marriage proposals, windblown weddings, rites sacred, profane or merely silly. ''If you can imagine it, it's probably been done in a balloon,'' said a buoyant John Schneider, an Avon restaurateur and self-proclaimed hot-air balloon fanatic.

title: Gilding The Water Bottle
description: People may tote them around like second handbags, but plastic water bottles are still not considered elegant enough to be set on the tables of many fine restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKINS, SYLVIA (NEE COLEMAN)
description: ELKINS-Sylvia (nee Coleman) Devoted wife of Theodore. Loving and adored mother of Joseph and Steven (Claudia). Dearest sister of Beatrice and Evelyn. Cherished grandmother of Hamilton. Services Monday, 11:15 AM, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Republican Rebels in the House Are Seeking to Pass a Tougher Bill on Managed Care
description: A group of House Republicans, in defiance of their leaders, are trying to pass much tougher regulation of managed-care plans than the Senate adopted last week and say they can win if they can force a vote.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: SOAPBOX; Pick-Me-Up
description: WE gentle motorists stand warned by the ''Amy Vanderbilt Complete Book of Etiquette'': ''Don't pick up hitchhikers.''

title: July 11-17; Race-Based Busing Ends in Boston
description: Twenty-five years ago, riots and rocks and beatings turned Boston into the epicenter of national turmoil over busing ordered by the courts to speed school desegregation. Now the Boston School Committee has ended the last vestiges of that era by voting, 5 to 2, to drop race as a factor in deciding which school a pupil would attend.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENSER, RUTH AND SIDNEY
description: GENSER-Ruth and Sidney. Happy 51st Anniversary. Enjoy dancing among the stars. Love, Barbara and Jay

title: Anna Saalfield, Michael Traggio
description: Anna Laidlaw Saalfield, a daughter of Agnes Gund, the president of the Museum of Modern Art, and a stepdaughter of Daniel Shapiro of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Paul Traggio, a son of Teresa and Robert Traggio of Portland, Conn. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton officiated at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The Rev. John Sheaffer, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Losing Patience on Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: TriBeCa's Concern for 'Such a Nice Man'
description: The normally quiet TriBeCa neighborhood that is home to John F. Kennedy Jr. and his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, turned into a media jungle yesterday afternoon, as the police guarded the building where the couple live and reporters stationed themselves outside, searching for people who knew the Kennedys.

title: One Giant Leap for Humankind
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On Day Made for Legends, Cone Pitches Perfect Game
description: In an improbable setting, David Cone performed an improbable feat yesterday. He pitched the Yankees' second perfect game in little more than a year, and he did it playing in front of Don Larsen, who pitched a perfect World Series game for the Yankees in 1956.

title: Kane Has One Goal: To Quit Being No. 2
description: After today's bitter defeat in the Japan Airlines Big Apple Classic, the 18th green was all too familiar to Lorie Kane. After eight hours of golf, Kane had played No. 18 six times, including five grueling playoff holes. And there was another familiar feeling for Kane: once again, she had a tournament well within her grasp, and once again, she let it slip away.

title: After a Flurry of Concern, Shuttle Is Ready for Liftoff
description: Shrugging off last-minute technical concerns about a $1.5 billion telescope aboard the space shuttle Columbia, NASA today cleared the shuttle and the first woman to command one for a delivery mission already laden with pitfalls. Liftoff from the Kennedy Space Center remained set for 12:36 A.M. Tuesday, 30 years to the day after American astronauts first landed on the moon.

title: A Peek at Life in an Artists' Retreat; Yaddo's Archives, Acquired by the New York Public Library, Illuminate Creativity
description: When the race track is quiet, visitors to Saratoga Springs, N.Y., sometimes wander over to the 400-acre wooded estate nearby known as Yaddo, the renowned artists' retreat. But they can only peek inside. While Yaddo's rose garden is open to the public, its 55-room turn-of-the-century mansion and surrounding studios are off limits to everyone but the writers and artists who go there seeking uninterrupted time to think and to create.

title: One Republican's Journey to the Other Side of the Aisle
description: ALREADY, a few of the Republicans Representative Michael P. Forbes deserted when he switched parties on Saturday have been dropping hints that the Congressman is not altogether stable.

title: Donal McCann, Irish Actor With Powerful Style, Dies at 56
description: Donal McCann, whose often understated but emotive, transfixing style won him widespread recognition as Ireland's best actor, died on Saturday at Our Lady's Hospice here. He was 56.

title: Big Tobacco Deserves All Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, BERTHA
description: DANIELS-Bertha. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Aaron Daniels. Loving mother of Naomi Daniels Oltarsh (Kenneth). Much loved grandmother of Valerie Oltarsh McCarthy (Rob) and Frederic D. Oltarsh (Rosa), and loving great-grandmother of Alexander Carde Oltarsh. An exceptional woman of great intelligence and charity. Funeral services 12:15 PM, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: A French Athlete Fades. Does It Sound Familiar?
description: For more than four and a half hours and 118 miles, most of France held its breath today, wondering whether one of its own was finally going to win a stage of the Tour de France after two weeks of domination by Italians, Americans, Estonians, Spaniards and Belgians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKERING, MARTHA HOLDING
description: PICKERING-Martha Holding, 70. Of Princeton, NJ and West Palm Beach, FL, on July 15, 1999 of breast cancer at home in Princeton. Wife of Donald A., mother of Stowe H. Tattersall, Samuel C. Tattersall and Martha T. Giancola, grandmother of David H. Giancola and Edith C. Tattersall. Sister of Audrey H. McCargo, stepmother of Donald A. Pickering, Jr. and Dorothy Pickering Bossidy, stepgrandmother of Stuart C.C. Pickering. She was predeceased by her sister, Nancy H. Tansill. Interment private in Edgartown, MA. Memorial service at 11 AM on Saturday, September 11, at Trinity Church, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Martha Holding Pickering Memorial Fund at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: Candidate, uh, First Lady Has Elegant Dinner for Barak
description: Demonstrating just how valuable the platform of the White House can be for a Senate candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton helped give a dinner here tonight for Ehud Barak, the Prime Minister of Israel, overseeing a gala that could only increase the goodwill toward Mrs. Clinton among Jewish voters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHEINMAN, WILLIAM X.
description: SCHEINMAN-William X. The family and friends of Bill Scheinman would like to announce a memorial service to be held on Saturday, July 24, 1999, at 2:00 PM. The service will be held at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, New York, NY 10023, in the Adler Room (room 514).

title: Swinging In Midair With Wit And Magic
description: One envied the Brenda Angiel Dance Company, which performed on bungee cords here on Saturday night at Page Auditorium at Duke University in the American Dance Festival. The breeze must have been considerable and possibly even cool as the dancers swung through the air. And who would not want a chance to defy gravity, particularly in such a buoyant, lighthearted way?

title: Capriati, Nearing Peak, Defeats Rubin and Past
description: MAHWAH, N.J., July 18 -- Jennifer Capriati is on a roll. It is nothing dramatic, perhaps, but given her tennis and personal history, things are looking up for the one-time prodigy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIACONIS, SAMUEL J.
description: DIACONIS-Samuel J. On July 15, 1999, age 76. Awarded the Bronze Star for service in W.W. II, he devoted his professional life to education, teaching American History for almost 40 years. He was past President of St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church. Survived by his wife Mary, two children Elizabeth and John, son-in-law Glenn, and four grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVNER, BENJAMIN
description: KOVNER-Benjamin. Long-term resident of Mamaroneck, NY, on July 17 at the age of 97 in Greenwich, CT Hospital. Beloved husband of Kathleen Jane Kovner. Loving father of Michael, Peter and the late Kay Kovner and father-in-law of Roberta. Adored grandfather of Matthew and Alexandra. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, July 20, 6-9 PM, with service Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Eye Institute, 2020 Vision Place, Bethesda, MD 20892.

title: Artistic and Political Fireworks Erupt In Dutch Troupe
description: Deep conviction or cheap shot? That is the question to ask of the surprise antiwar protest with which Jiri Kylian ended a new program by his Nederlands Dans Theater as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99.

title: Behind Warner Bros. Resignations, the End of a Freewheeling Era
description: The surprise announcement on Thursday that Robert A. Daly and Terry Semel were leaving their jobs as co-chairmen of Warner Brothers after nearly two decades marked not only a turning point at the multibillion-dollar entertainment conglomerate but the end of a freewheeling era when Hollywood moguls behaved like rajahs and operated independently of corporate bosses.

title: Microsoft Set to Sell City Guides to Rival
description: In what would be a major consolidation in on-line city guides, the Microsoft Corporation is on the verge of selling MSN Sidewalk to Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch in a stock transaction worth $240 million, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: John F. Kennedy Jr., Heir To a Formidable Dynasty
description: John F. Kennedy Jr., a scion of the nation's most celebrated political dynasty, was reported lost and presumed dead in an accident that resounded this weekend with echoes of the family's many misfortunes.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; With 9 Points in Overtime, A Steady Robinson Delivers
description: The intensity was building inside Madison Square Garden yesterday, the game boiling because of an altercation late in the second half.

title: M.I.T. and Harvard Give Boston a Niche
description: To meet Boston's technology elite, first finagle an invitation to one of Robert M. Metcalfe's parties. His salons, as Mr. Metcalfe -- co-inventor of the computer technology named Ethernet -- calls them, are high-technology schmooze sessions, with perhaps a string of investors chatting up a chief executive in the hallway or two entrepreneurs courting a partnership at dinner.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's getting to be a

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMANTOV, ASHER
description: SIMANTOV-Asher, age 63. We mourn the passing of the beloved brother of Simha and Levi Simantov of New York. Condolences to the entire family in Israel.

title: To Invigorate Literary Mind, Start Moving Literary Feet
description: Running! If there's any activity happier, more exhilarating, more nourishing to the imagination, I can't think what it might be. In running the mind flies with the body; the mysterious efflorescence of language seems to pulse in the brain, in rhythm with our feet and the swinging of our arms. Ideally, the runner who's a writer is running through the land- and cityscapes of her fiction, like a ghost in a real setting.

title: Haze and Darkness Combined to Make Flight to Martha's Vineyard Risky, Pilots Say
description: So far, Federal aviation officials have found no rule or regulation that was broken during John F. Kennedy Jr.'s ill-fated flight from New Jersey to Martha's Vineyard on Friday night.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, MAXINE G.
description: PRESS-Maxine G. Devoted wife of George. Beloved mother of Aric and Amy. Cherished grandmother of Sarah, Rebecca and Joshua. Services today, 10 AM, at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, 21 Old Westbury Rd., Old Westbury, NY.

title: Sweet TV Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: When It's 98 Degrees Outdoors, Staying Indoors Is the Best Escape
description: Gooey. Viscous. Steamy. Torrid.

title: Paradyne Stock Triples
description: Paradyne Networks Inc. more than tripled its offering price in its first day of trading on Friday, bolstered by investor enthusiasm for companies that enable high-speed Internet access. The company and existing shareholders sold 6 million shares at $17 each on Thursday, raising $102 million. The sale represented a 20 percent stake. The shares closed at $56.25 after about 12.6 million shares changed hands in Nasdaq trading. The company, based in Largo, Fla., now has a market value of $1.71 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about a call by Federal health officials to suspend the use of a vaccine against rotavirus in infants misstated the method of administering it. The vaccine is given orally, not by injection.

title: McCain Renews Push for Debate On Campaign Finance Overhaul
description: Senator John McCain, a sponsor of legislation to overhaul the campaign finance laws, said today that he would start using parliamentary tactics this week to try to force the issue to the Senate floor unless Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, agreed to set aside a ''reasonable period of time'' to consider the bill.

title: New Equity Offerings Are Scheduled For the Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: INSIDE
description: Congo's Failing Cease-Fire

title: Media Talk; Radio Station In Boston Drops Imus
description: Boston is Don Imus's kind of town. Bostonians argue, sometimes louder than New Yorkers, and they view a well-considered insult is an art. Talk radio, one of the purest venues for argument and creative invective, goes back a generation on radio stations like WEEI in Boston. Don Imus is Boston's kind of guy.

title: Henderson Doesn't Run, But He Walks and Hits
description: He is 40 years old. And he is no longer the most feared base runner in the game, or even on his own team. But Rickey Henderson can still take over a game, and he did it again tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, EDNA
description: ROGERS-Edna. The West Side Institutional Synagogue Men's Club mourns the passing of its co-Chairperson of the Annual Youth Concert Award. She was a valuable member of this committee. Our heartfelt condolences to Arthur Rogers and family. Alexander Rauchman, President Joel Sagall, Treasurer

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; It's beginning to look as if users would rather pay directly for services on the Internet than wade through advertising.
description: TO their great shared financial benefit, Internet investors and entrepreneurs and the market analysts who serve them have convinced each other and most of the rest of the world that the only truly Internet-centered business model is one in which on-line users pay nothing for content.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the big-band singer Helen Forrest on Tuesday included a credit erroneously in her recording history with Artie Shaw. It was Billie Holiday, not Ms. Forrest, who recorded ''Any Old Time'' with the Shaw orchestra.

title: Rescue Search in Kennedy Crash Ends; Coast Guard Tells Family There Is Little Hope
description: After two fruitless days of searching for a plane that disappeared off the coast of Martha's Vineyard with John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife and his sister-in-law, the Coast Guard said tonight it had all but given up hope of finding survivors and now was focused on recovering their remains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFER, TERRY
description: HOFFER-Terry. Age 77, of NYC, on July 17, 1999. Cherished wife of Abby. Adoring mother of Marc, Candy, Paul and Shirley. Loving grandmother to Deborah. Devoted sister to Sylvia and unforgettable to all who knew her. Services 9:30 AM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions in her name be made to Women's American ORT, c/o Abby Hoffer Ent., 223-1/2 East 48th St, NYC 10017.

title: Ear Training: A Digital Music Primer
description: As recently as two years ago, the recording business relied on a stable of technologies that had evolved from Thomas Edison's scratchy rolls through cut acetate, pressed vinyl records and magnetic tape to the compact disk -- all without serious threats to the major labels' bottom lines. Then, on college campuses, students with fast Internet connections discovered that a sound compression technology called MP3 packed virtually perfect copies of music into a file small enough to distribute rapidly on line. Suddenly the device that recorded the music was also the machine that stored it and the technology that distributed it.

title: Foe Suggests Giving Milosevic Immunity To Get Him to Quit
description: A leading Serbian opposition politician says the best way to get President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia out of power is to seduce him to resign, promising him immunity from arrest or extradition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOOMAN, ROBERT
description: SHOOMAN-Robert. The Neighborhood Cleaners Association International mourns the untimely death of our Director of Special Projects. Robert had just finished designing and teaching the first certification class to licensed dry cleaners when a tragic car accident took his life. His energy, enthusiasm and dedication to the work of the NCA-I was only surpassed by his joy of life, his warm heart and his good soul. He was a true friend to all who knew him. Bill Seitz, Executive Director Nora Nealis, Associate Director Staff and Members of NCA-I

title: Seattle's New Ball Park
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa Confronts Brutalities Of One Man
description: In his drab denim shirts and army-style green sweaters, Eugene de Kock answers questions for hours, rarely showing any signs of emotion. His face is lineless, his eyes small behind thick glasses that make him look more like the class nerd than South Africa's most notorious apartheid-era henchman.

title: A new information service on Internet ads slices through the logistics of programming.
description: A MONITORING service is being introduced that promises to provide information about advertising on Web sites in, well, Internet time.

title: Ford Motor Shifts Work to WPP Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company has consolidated the Ford brand's South American account with J. Walter Thompson, part of WPP Group P.L.C., by awarding duties in Brazil to J. Walter Thompson Publicidade Ltda. in Sao Paulo. Billings were not disclosed. The account had been handled for four years by Young & Rubicam Brazil in Sao Paulo, part of the Young & Rubicam Advertising Latin America unit of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Broadcom to Buy Hothaus For $280 Million in Stock
description: The Broadcom Corporation, a leading maker of high-speed communications semiconductors, agreed today to buy Hothaus Technologies Inc. for $280 million in stock, enhancing its position in the emerging market for phone calls using Internet technology.

title: For Van de Velde, a Crushing Collapse, And for Lawrie, a Soaring Comeback
description: Leading by three strokes as he reached the par-4, 18th hole, Van de Velde did the unfathomable. He triple-bogeyed. He hit bad shots. He made terrible decisions. And he allowed what should have been the greatest moment of his career to become the worst.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports of The Times; Deja Vu All Over Again: Berra's Magic Day
description: YOGI BERRA stayed away from Yankee Stadium for 14 years; yesterday, Berra, easily one of the most popular players and the greatest catcher in Yankee history, returned to Yankee Stadium for an overdue tribute. He came for a day dedicated in his honor.
