This was an afternoon filled with plaques and plaudits, antique banners, a trip to Italy, an audience with the Pope, even a $100,000 contribution to the Yogi Berra Museum. But for someone like Berra, a player whom former teammate Bobby Richardson said had a knack for attracting good fortune, this day called for something beyond gifts. This day called for magic.

title: Israel Will Buy 50 F-16's In Its Biggest Arms Deal Ever
description: Israel confirmed today that it plans to add at least 50 more F-16's to an already formidable jet fighter fleet, signaling a determination to maintain decisive regional air power superiority even as it pursues peace deals with its Middle Eastern neighbors.

title: 3 Shot and 21 Arrested In Subway Gang Brawl
description: Twenty-one people were arrested yesterday on charges stemming from a gang-related brawl in a midtown Manhattan subway station that ended with three people shot and wounded, the police said.

title: Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, Private Woman Who Was New to Fame
description: Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, whose marriage to John F. Kennedy Jr. catapulted her and her understated glamour to fame, was reported lost and presumed dead on a flight Friday to Martha's Vineyard, Mass., along with her husband and her sister Lauren Bessette.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, FLORENCE POWERS
description: DEWEY-Florence Powers. On July 5th, 1999, of a heart attack at her Shoreham West home in Washington, DC. Born August 31st, 1911 at Shrewsbury Manor, Shrewsbury, NJ. Wife of the late Maj. Gen. Lawrence R. Dewey. Daughter of the late Harry Lord Powers and Elizabeth Hazard Powers of NY and NJ. A true army wife, she traveled the world with her West Point ''duty, honor, and country'' husband as helpmate and hostess entertaining enroute Chiang Kai-shek, the MacArthurs, the Eisenhowers, the Pattons, Haile Selassie, De Gaulle and the Shah of Iran. Florence was a superb horsewoman and a fabulous cook. She had great warmth and charm and will be missed by her adoring family and friends. She was a member of the Colonial Dames of America-Chapter III, the Ladies Board of St. John's Community Service and the Sulgrave Club. She is survived by her four children, Lt. Col. L.R. Dewey of VA, Mrs. Francis J. Hughes and Donald H. Dewey of Washington, DC, Mrs. Christopher Vance of Charlotte, NC, seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren; also by three sisters, Mrs. C.V.B. Cushman of CA, Mrs. Edward M. Pflueger and Mrs. Hans A. Frech of NYC. She was also the sister of the late Jesse W. Powers of CA and Mrs. Richard E. deButts of Upperville, VA. Her funeral and interment will be with her husband of 63 years at Arlington National Cemetery, July 21st.

title: Sweet TV Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAYLOR, JAMES H.
description: NAYLOR-James H. Born Schuylerville, NY, 1912. Passed away July 16, 1999. Service and interment in Schuylerville, NY.

title: Old Ship's Admirers Lack Repair Funds
description: Nearly a year after the Regina Maris, a 90-year-old barkentine, was towed into Hempstead Harbor here and heralded as the centerpiece of a waterfront revitalization effort, the aging ship is still hoping to lure enough financial help to secure her survival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ELIZABETH
description: SCHWARTZ-Elizabeth. Congregation Ohav Shalom mourns the tragic death of Elizabeth (Elisheva) Shuchat Schwartz, who was a truly inspiring role model as Rebbetzin of our Kehila during the tenure of her husband, Rabbi J. Yaacov Schwartz. Her warmth, optimism, vibrant spirit and deep devotion to our community will never be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, daughter Ayala, parents Rabbi Wilfred and Miriam Shuchat, sister Margola, brother Rafi, sister Bryna, our beloved member, and brother-inlaw Joshua Landes, our Vice President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIDGES, HAROLD V.
description: BRIDGES-Harold V. Of Hampton Bays. A retired operations engineer at Columbia Broadcasting System in New York City died on July 6 at Southampton Hospital. He was 93 years old. Mr. Bridges' CBS assignments over 30 years included broadcasts of The New York Philharmonic, The Boston Symphony and The Cleveland Symphony. He served in the rostrum of every National Convention from 1948 to 1962 in the Call of States. He officiated at Cape Canaveral in the moon flight of 1969. He attended New York University for television engineering and was a member of the I.B.E.W. and The Audio Society of New York. He is survived by a niece, Mrs. Howard Johnson (nee) Rosemarie Crawley of Montclair, NJ and a cousin Mrs. Barbara Creaser of Torrington, CT and six grand nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Lillian Bridges Crawley and a nephew, John J. Crawley. For more information contact R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Inc., 94 East Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial was held on July 9th from St. Rosalie's Church in Hampton Bays followed by an interment in Calvary Cemetery. Remembrances may be made to the Dominican Sisters, PO Box 1028, Hampton Bays, New York 11946-0404.

title: Compressed Data; G.E. Applies Its Talents To Internet Housekeeping
description: The General Electric Company's three-year-old Web page has just had a face lift to prepare for total reconstructive surgery in the fall.

title: The Big City; In an Age of Apartness, The Family Everyone Knew
description: YESTERDAY afternoon, shortly after immigrants from Austria and Korea deposited bouquets of flowers, two middle-aged women left votive candles burning on the sidewalk outside the home of John F. Kennedy Jr. in TriBeCa. They said they had never done anything like that before.

title: Recipe: Melon and Organic Strawberry Soup With Fruit Sorbet
description: Adapted from Bouley Bakery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEIN, JOSEPH, MD.
description: SHEIN-Joseph, MD. Adored by his loving wife Osnass (nee Charchat) of 53 years. Adoring children, Dr. Ruvan and Karen Shein, Avrom Shein, Dr. Leon and Jill Shein. Cherished grandchildren Arianna, Rebekah, Mariessa, Joshua, Benjamin, Jonathan, Allison. Loving family, devoted friends, patients, colleagues, nurses, and the North Shore Hospital administration and staff are in inconsolable pain and grief. How do you let go a legend as courageous, compassionate, brilliant, caring, with sense of humor, moral ethical standards which knows no equal. Capacity to love and be loved. Took care of the needy, heal the sick and gave credence to the meaning of life. You justified the ten commandments. With aching hearts, never say goodbye darling. We will meet again and continue the wonders of our fortunate, tranquil, happy cultured life as a family who was inspired by your passionate love and devotion. A man of class, dignity, nobility. Thank you my husband, thank you dad, thank you grandpa (Pappa) Joe, for being our greatest gift. Deep emotional love and tears will never cease.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Mainstream TV Bets on 'Gross-Out' Humor
description: This summer the movies have been filled with crude language, bathroom humor and sex scenes that include the defiling of an apple pie. Brace yourself for the fall television season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTHIZER, HAROLD
description: RUTHIZER-Harold. On July 17, 1999, at age 90. Formerly of Roosevelt, NY, and for the last 16 years of Coconut Creek, FL. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted and loved father of Marilyn and Allen Greenberg, Jeffrey and Monica Ruthizer, Grant and Mimi Ruthizer and Theodore and Jane Ruthizer. Cherished grandfather of Dr.'s William and Hilary Greenberg, Elizabeth and Alan Cohen, Caroline and Mitchell Nussbaum, Jessica and Robin Ruthizer, Joshua and Alexander Ruthizer. Affectionately known as ''Poppy'' to his five great-grandchildren, Jonathan, Rachel and Jordana Cohen and Robert and David Greenberg. Adored friend and companion of Bella Grossman. From 1944 to 1980 Harold was the owner of ''Roosevelt Hardware'' on Nassau Road, Roosevelt, LI. Funeral service on Tuesday, July 20, at 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Images and Emotions Carry Television Coverage
description: Television, the medium that was thrust into the modern era of wall-to-wall breaking-news coverage by the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy, used all the tools it has mastered since then to chronicle the scant facts and copious emotions about the disappearance of the single-engine plane John F. Kennedy Jr. was flying to Martha's Vineyard.

title: Steinhauer Edges Kane In 5-Hole Playoff
description: In the moonlight you could hardly see the tears beginning to mingle with the sweat under Lorie Kane's eyes. But you did not have to see them to know they were there. They came almost as soon as Sherri Steinhauer rolled in an improbable 35-foot birdie putt to finally put an end to a heart-wrenching five-hole sudden-death playoff.

title: Marketers Set Test Of TV-Internet Link
description: Four large marketers said they would take part in a large study measuring the effect of a new technology on television viewing and Internet use. The participants in the study, commissioned by Worldgate Communications in Trevose, Pa., and conducted by Nielsen Media Research, are General Motors, the Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies, Sprint and Warner-Lambert. The study, covering 1,000 households in Ohio, will test the effects of channel hyperlinking technology, which enables TV viewers to use the Internet through links tied to the programs they see.

title: Rescue Search in Kennedy Crash Ends; Streams of Strangers Keep Vigils
description: The steady stream of visitors across the decades to the graves of President John F. Kennedy and his brother Robert sadly quickened today as the nation kept vigil for John F. Kennedy Jr.

title: People
description: * Michael Baulk was named chairman of BBDO Europe, London, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, succeeding Jean-Michel Goudard, BBDO's president for international, who headed European operations on a temporary basis after the departure last year of David Wheldon. Mr. Baulk will continue as chief executive of AMV Group, London, also a unit of BBDO.

title: How Profits Affect Patient Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Zipprodt, 74, Costume Designer
description: Patricia Zipprodt, the Tony Award-winning costume designer whose career extended from theater to dance to opera to film and television, died on Saturday at her home in Greenwich Village. Ms. Zipprodt was 74.

title: Behind the Scenes With Ann and Abby
description: In a story of rival twin sisters, even Ann Landers and Abigail Van Buren, it's tempting to ask, ''Which one is the evil twin?'' Based on tonight's Lifetime film ''Take My Advice: The Ann and Abby Story,'' it depends.

title: War in Congo Rattles On Despite Accord
description: More than a week after the signing of a cease-fire accord to end the war in Congo, the fighting continues, the rebels say they have captured more territory and the countries embroiled in the year-old conflict are trading accusations that the agreement has been violated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRMAN, DOROTHY
description: BEHRMAN-Dorothy. On July 17, suddenly but peacefully at age 100. Widow of Herman. Loving mother of Dr. Stanley and Dr. Lawrence. Mother-in-law of Nancy and Carole. Adored grandmother of Dr. David (Allison), Susan (Joseph) Pasciolla and Peter (Josephine) Grayson. Great-grandmother of Sara, Alex, Michelle and Bradley. Memorial gifts to The Herman and Dorothy Behrman Scholarship Fund at the School of Dental Medicine, University of Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPPRODT, PATRICIA O'BRIEN
description: ZIPPRODT-Patricia O'Brien. On July 17, 1999. Three time Tony award winning theater costume designer and prominent ballet, opera and film costume designer. Wife of the late Colonel Robert E. O'Brien, Jr. Survived by her beloved sister, Constance ZipprodtZonka and six nieces and nephews, Kathy, Roger, Lynn, Daniel, Heidi and Milo, children of sisters Constance Zipprodt-Zonka and the late Barbara Zipprodt-Pavlik. Services Saturday, July 24, at Trinity Episcopal Church, Upperville, VA. Interment private. Memorial service in New York at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Complex Telephone Takeover Battle Ends in Compromise
description: One of the fiercest takeover battles in recent years has ended in a gentlemen's agreement, with the telecommunications rivals Qwest Communications International Inc. and Global Crossing Ltd. agreeing to split the spoils between them.

title: How Profits Affect Patient Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Girls in Deep Trouble, Not Just From Hadrian
description: From strip to hip. That is the unlikely metamorphosis that has taken place at Show World, the former Times Square sex superstore, which was shut in May by the Giuliani administration. Collapsable Giraffe, a young SoHo theater company that revels in ironic twists, is bivouacked these days in one of the emporium's darkened playrooms with a brash and salty performance piece it calls ''Three Virgins.''

title: Music to Skateboard By: Fast and Loud
description: Seasoned fans brought surgical masks to the New York stop on this year's National Vans Warped Tour, ready to brave the dust bowl that Randalls Island would become. By midafternoon on Friday its bone-dry earth was stomped loose by hundreds of sneaker-clad dancers. The less prepared covered their mouths with bandanas or their T-shirts as they threw themselves into the swarming mosh pits bordering the field's four stages, which kept going from early afternoon until after the scalding sun went down.

title: A Renaissance In Computer Science; Chip Designers Search for Life After Silicon
description: It was a chance meeting between a self-described ''physicist gone bad'' and a chemist. And it may someday lead to the creation of a new breed of computers based on tiny electronic switches, each no thicker than a single molecule.

title: Cortona Journal; Act 2: Quest for Tuscan Pasta and Great Plastering
description: A loud voice pierced the dreamy stillness of Frances Mayes's rose-and-lavender-filled Tuscan garden. ''Is this the house?'' an American tourist hollered up from the iron gate. With sudden awe, he added, ''Is that Ed?''

title: Media Talk; Parody of Talk Magazine Upsets Disney
description: Talk magazine, the offspring of Hearst Magazines and Miramax that is being edited by Tina Brown, has yet to hit the newsstands. But it has already inspired a parody -- and a bit of lawyerly snarling.

title: Prosperity Builds Mounds of Cast-Off Clothes
description: Hour by hour, cars and trucks back up to the Salvation Army's warehouse loading dock on the edge of the prosperous East Side here and disgorge clothing. Skirts and parkas, neckties and tank tops, sweat pants and socks, a polychromatic mountain of clothes is left each week, some with price tags still attached.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, CARL K.
description: KLEIN-Carl K. Age 93. Formerly of Englewood, NJ, died July 16, 1999 in Miami Beach, FL. Husband of the late Sylvia, he is survived by his sons Richard and Arthur and their wives Joan and Roberta. Esteemed grandfather of Jonathan, David, Elizabeth, Catherine and Pamela. Brother of Meyer. Graveside services Tuesday, July 20, 1PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Shiva to be followed at the home of Arthur Klein.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Wireless TV Finally Gets Validation
description: The telecommunications industry is not known for being cyclical, but don't tell that to Matthew Oristano.

title: BASEBALL: Cone Remains Perfect Mystery to the Young Expos; Montreal Sensed A Historic Day In the Making
description: He was the last Montreal batter to face David Cone yesterday, and afterward, Orlando Cabrera dispensed with the false bravado. Sure, Cabrera admitted, the prospect of making the final out in Cone's perfect game crossed his mind -- in the sixth inning.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: More Than 100 People Protest Shooting of Movie
description: More than 100 protesters demonstrated against a movie production company's film shoot last night in Harlem, saying that the company had treated the neighborhood poorly.

title: It's My Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RELKIN, HARRIETTE (NEE MYRANS)
description: RELKIN-Harriette (nee Myrans). Of Clearwater, FL, formerly of North Woodmere, NY. Beloved wife of Abraham. Loving mother of Bruce (Katie), Janice (Howard) Parker. Cherished grandmother of Russ, Eric and Alex Relkin and Lara and Danielle Parker. Services today, 11:30 AM, in ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Cat Thief Wins, Taking Swaps Stakes by a Head
description: In a return match between veterans of the Triple Crown series, Cat Thief outran General Challenge in a blistering homestretch duel yesterday at Hollywood Park and won the Swaps Stakes by a head.

title: Knoblauch Rescues A Perfect Game Again
description: David Cone will get his line in the record books for a perfect game right below David Wells's. Anyone who wants to read between the lines, though, will see Chuck Knoblauch's name there.

title: How Profits Affect Patient Care
description: To the Editor:

title: How Profits Affect Patient Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BARAK PINS HOPES FOR MIDEAST PEACE ON NEXT 15 MONTHS
description: The Prime Minister of Israel, Ehud Barak, has set a target deadline of 15 months for achieving a comprehensive framework for peace in the Middle East, a time line chosen in part to dovetail with the American political calendar and the Presidential election, Israeli officials said yesterday.

title: Patents; Architects debate concepts behind housing design.
description: ARCHITECTS often protect their work from being plagiarized in the same way that authors do: through copyright. Whether it is a mystery novel or an architectural plan, copyright protects against unscrupulous copiers who try to steal a creative work word-for-word or brick-by-brick.

title: Shutdown Looming at Nevada's Oldest Bordello
description: For all its troubles, the Mustang Ranch is still one popular bordello, running the same as normal.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about the Voice Xpress portable recorder with speech recognition software misspelled the name of the company that introduced it. The company is Lernout & Hauspie, not Lernhout & Hauspie.

title: Compressed Data; Former Browser Foes Unite In Tellme Networks Start-Up
description: The post-browser war armistice continues at Tellme Networks Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up that would already be rich if buzz were money. Brad Silverberg, a former senior vice president at the Microsoft Corporation, who remains a Microsoft consultant, is becoming an investor and board member of Tellme.

title: Australia Outlasts the U.S. in Davis Cup
description: His own captain had declared Todd Martin an invalid today before he limped out for his confrontation with Patrick Rafter. But it took 3 hours 14 minutes before Martin finally gave up the ghost in the brutal five-setter that clinched this Davis Cup quarterfinal for Australia.

title: Media Talk; Now Opening for Business on Sundays
description: Is this co-branding or cross-dressing? Come Sunday Sept. 12, The Denver Post and The Minneapolis Star Tribune will look like their familiar selves, but there will be four pages inside that look like, read like -- in fact are -- The Wall Street Journal.

title: Bronx Race Novelty: a Likely Candidate
description: Two years ago, Jose Rivera, a City Councilman from the Bronx, gave strong but fleeting consideration to running for Bronx Borough President, while the incumbent, Fernando Ferrer, ran a brief campaign for Mayor. Then, Mr. Ferrer decided to seek re-election, dashing Mr. Rivera's plans for higher office.

title: Rangers Are Building On Shaky Foundation
description: Assuming they announce the expected signing of Sylvain Lefebvre today, the Rangers will have added six free agents in two weeks. This is a remarkable recruiting effort that will dramatically change their roster and affect hockey's economics.

title: Polls on Tax Cuts Find Voters' Messages Mixed
description: Nearly two-thirds of Americans think their taxes are too high. But few of them worry much about it, and most people would rather have the Government spend money on popular programs than cut taxes.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Certain Words Are No Longer Forbidden
description: The curse is officially over. Or should be. No announcer should ever fear jinxing a pitcher who is en route to a no-hitter or perfect game by uttering those words before the deed is done. Last year, the MSG Network's Ken Singleton and Jim Kaat bandied ''perfect game'' and ''no-hitter'' and David Wells suffered no hex. And yesterday, Channel 5's Tim McCarver and Bobby Murcer trotted out the terms early, with no ill effects for David Cone.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 10 about a $4.9 billion award in a personal injury lawsuit against General Motors used an incorrect given name in some editions for a University of Southern California law professor who commented on the amount. He is Greg Keating, not Gary.

title: Ambiguity Hinders Taiwan-China Dialogue; Equality at Table
description: To the Editor:

title: Wells Has A Quick Welcome By Phone
description: After David Cone was joyously carried off the field by his teammates, after he finished hugging everyone in a Yankee uniform and after he pointed to different corners of Yankee Stadium to thank the fans who supported every emotional pitch of his perfect game, he returned to the clubhouse, and a telephone call was waiting. It was David Wells, and the perfect pitcher had perfect timing.

title: Farewell to a Friend
description: There comes a time in every generation when the light of youth flickers out, when some tragic accident unearths buried anxieties about the senselessness of death and the brutality of living. It's as if suddenly, an entire generation's optimism is deflated, and all that is left is the limp reality of growing old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSHKOFF, MARTIN
description: HERSHKOFF-Martin. Age 78. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 54 years. Devoted father to Kenneth and Helen. Loving grandfather to Lauren, Joshua and Ben. Died suddenly at home on July 17, 1999. A graduate of City College, an Army veteran from WW II, a retired certified public accountant, Marty was a lover of books and ideas, and will be sorely missed by his family. Services are July 19 at noon, I. J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

title: Purists of the Pen Defy a Point-and-Click World
description: In the hotel's grand ballroom, a retractable wall separated the inhabitants of two worlds, one robustly modern, the other quietly struggling just to stay alive.

title: The Fail-Proof Teaching Test
description: The Allies won World War II.

title: Just a Member of the Staff
description: At this time of overwhelming concern about the fate of John F. Kennedy Jr., and of those with him in his small plane, it is natural to wonder at yet another Kennedy tragedy.

title: Whitlow Wyatt, 91, Pitcher Who Starred With the Dodgers
description: Whitlow Wyatt, a key figure in the Brooklyn Dodgers' celebrated 1941 National League pennant victory and a leading pitcher of the early 1940's, died Friday at a hospital in Carrollton, Ga. Wyatt, who lived in Buchanan, Ga., was 91.

title: Beyond 2000: Further Troubles Lurk in the Future of Computing
description: When David Andre noticed that the Windows NT operating system would not allow him to set the date on the clock of his Toshiba 510CDT laptop past 2079, he performed a dangerous experiment: he set the time to 11:59 P.M. on Dec. 31, 2079, and let the clock roll over to 2080.

title: Lawrie Becomes A Local Hero
description: Having started the day 10 strokes behind Jean Van de Velde, Paul Lawrie was asked if he really believed he would win the British Open.

title: Water Scarce, Barcelona Plans Big Pipe To Tap Rhone
description: Water shortage is far from anyone's mind on the banks of the mighty Rhone River as it surges from the high glaciers of Switzerland down through eastern France. Along its 500-mile route, it is fed by many tributaries until the river spills, largely untapped, into the Mediterranean Sea.

title: New Neighbors Pushing at the Edge; Brooklyn Hasidim Seek to Expand Into a Black and Hispanic Area
description: Like many of his neighbors in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Charles O'Connor has grown accustomed during the last few months to frequent and unwanted visits from strangers interested in buying the home he has owned for 35 years. One day, though, the banging on his front door was like an alarm. Mr. O'Connor opened it to find a man hammering up a ''For Sale'' sign, even though he had already told the man's real estate company that he did not wish to sell.

title: Treasury Sets Bill Auctions For Financing In the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a fifty-two week bill being auctioned Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Aaron S. Lapin, the creator of Reddi-wip, misidentified a survivor in some copies. Carol Lapin is a daughter-in-law, not Mr. Lapin's widow.

title: Essay; Is Life Unfair?
description: ''Life is unfair,'' said President John F. Kennedy when asked about the resentment that reservists, who had ''done their time,'' felt about being called up for Vietnam service.

title: A Small-Town Nightmare Steeped in Scary Literature
description: Thousands of fans chanted ''Bruce'' in excited anticipation at a sold-out show on Friday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom. Bruce Springsteen, it seems, wasn't the only Bruce in the area reuniting with his former band mates. Bruce Dickinson, who led Iron Maiden through its glory years as the reigning horror-fantasy British heavy-metal act of the 80's, was performing his first United States show with the group after having quit to pursue his solo career in the early 90's.

title: Man, 19, Is Beaten to Death
description: A 19-year-old man was chased down a Queens street and then beaten to death by a group of men yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Compressed Data; Mining the Value In a Carload of Averted Eyes
description: The elevator ride has always presented a social dilemma: people captive in a tiny room, awkwardly silent and unwilling to make eye contact. The piped-in Muzak version of the Beatles' ''Penny Lane'' does nothing to ease the discomfort.

title: Turkey Is Astir Over Book Of Army Veterans' Views
description: A taboo fell in Turkey earlier this year when a book appeared containing interviews with 42 army veterans, many of them disillusioned by their role in fighting Kurdish insurgents.

title: Recalling Some Champions Who Played in Another Era
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame inductions in San Antonio on Wednesday night will have a sad note. Bobby Goldman, one of the players who was elected in the living category, died shortly after the voting. He was a member of the Aces team that won many national and world titles from 1968 to 1982.

title: Russia's Nuclear Defense
description: Budget cuts and political changes have so weakened Russia's once-formidable armed forces that Moscow's military planners now feel obliged to rely on nuclear weapons to defend their frontiers against even a nonnuclear attack. That alarming shift in planning was underscored by the extensive war games Moscow recently conducted, the largest such maneuvers since 1991. Faced with a simulated invasion by an unnamed Western foe, Russian forces first responded with conventionally armed defenders. But when these failed to halt the attacker's progress, Russian commanders felt compelled to order nuclear strikes.

title: Tragedy Revisits the Kennedys
description: For millions of Americans, watching television this weekend was an act of haunting sadness. The nation seemed caught in yet another enactment of a news documentary we first saw almost 36 years ago -- the media massed outside the Kennedy compound in Hyannis Port, the family gathered inside to comfort, to pray, and to hope against hope that it would not have to mourn yet another young and promising life cut short.

title: A Colombian Guerrilla's 50-Year Fight
description: He was born Pedro Antonio Marin and took the name Manuel Marulanda after he became a guerrilla half a century ago. But all over Colombia, people know him simply as ''Tirofijo,'' which translates as ''Sureshot.'' He acquired that intimidating nickname because of his military prowess, but in recent years his political aim has proved nearly as unerring.

title: Ambiguity Hinders Taiwan-China Dialogue; Evolving Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Policing the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambiguity Hinders Taiwan-China Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, NORMAN, DR.
description: ROSENTHAL-Norman, Dr. For many years Norman was our family physician and our dear friend. He was deeply valued as both. He will be profoundly missed. Dorothy and Harold Ames

title: An Opening for Campaign Reform
description: Politicians often like to say that they will not be slaves to public opinion. ''I don't run polls to tell me what to think,'' Gov. George W. Bush declares. That would be reassuring, except that Mr. Bush and others are harvesting campaign donations from special interests that expect to exert an influence more powerful than public opinion. Last week, Mr. Bush announced that his $37 million war chest was so big he would spurn Federal matching funds in the primaries and ignore campaign spending limits in effect since the 1970's. If he gets the nomination, Mr. Bush will almost certainly try to outdo President Clinton in raising vast sums of unregulated ''soft money'' for his party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLMAN, RUTH
description: SOLMAN-Ruth. 90, wife of the New York artist Joseph Solman (for 65 years), died in her sleep Saturday morning, July 17. A Ukranian-born US immigrant (1923) and NYU graduate (1932), she was a candidate for the New York State Assembly in 1952 (on the American Labor party ticket), a PTA president (at the Little Red School House), an art gallery director, Russian translator, energetic hostess and dedicated partner in the career of her husband, whom she fiercely loved, as she did her children (Paul and Ronni) and her grandchildren (Rachel Solman, Sara Rushton, Joanna Freeman-Solman and Evan Rushton). She was loved fiercely in return. Her chief illness was Parkinson's disease, from which she was in decline for the past four years. Her death was a peaceful release. She will be remembered in portraits by numerous American artists and by all who knew her. The family is receiving at home today. There will be a memorial service in the fall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Broadcom Plans to Acquire Hothaus for $280 Million

title: Microsoft Capitalism As Mirror Of America
description: THE PLOT TO GET BILL GATES

title: Big Tobacco Deserves All Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Now Man Has Gone Before
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRITZ, SEYMOUR
description: GRITZ-Seymour. 70 years old. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father, grandfather, uncle and brother. His friendship will be missed by all those who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORTORELLA, SALVATORE L.
description: TORTORELLA-Salvatore L. On July 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Camille. Devoted father of Michael. Decorated Army veteran of World War II. After a distinguished career in Army counterintelligence, he retired a Major in 1965. Honored teacher for the Theodore Roosevelt H.S., Bronx, N.Y., for some 15 years, member of the Knights of Columbus, Wakefield Council no. 2922 and the Retired Officers Association. Viewing Tuesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM at the David J. Hodder and Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Avenue), Yonkers, N.Y. Mass Wednesday, St. Barnabas Church, 9:45AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, JOHN L.
description: CAHILL-John L. On July 18, 1999. Devoted husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Theurer). Beloved father of Elizabeth and Margaret Mary Colome. Cherished grandfather of one. Funeral Thursday, 9:15 AM from The Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Bklyn. Mass Good Shepherd R.C. Church, 10:15 AM. Interment Saint John's Cemetery.

title: Bailout Audit in Mexico Cites $7.7 Billion in Dubious Loans
description: A Canadian auditor presented a report today about the Mexican Government's rescue of its banks concluding that about $7.7 billion of the loans absorbed by the bailout were highly irregular or plainly illegal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASKY, CHARLES & LASKY, ESTELLE
description: LASKY-Charles & LASKY, Estelle July 18th & July 20th On their birthdays and every day. Always loved and always remembered. George and Joyce

title: Power Stands Up to Heat, but Not to Thunderstorms
description: Power use in New York City soared to the second-highest level ever yesterday as temperatures topped 95 for the fourth day in a row, but it was not the heat that wiped out power to Consolidated Edison customers. Thunderstorms raked across the region late in the afternoon, knocking out electricity to more than 7,000 buildings in New York City and southern Westchester County, Con Ed said.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: 'Innocent Spouse' Gets No Sympathy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTHIZER, HAROLD
description: RUTHIZER-Harold. On July 17, 1999, at age 90. Formerly of Roosevelt, NY, and for the last 16 years of Coconut Creek, FL. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted and loved father of Marilyn and Allen Greenberg, Jeffrey and Monica Ruthizer, Grant and Mimi Ruthizer and Theodore and Jane Ruthizer. Cherished grandfather of Dr.'s William and Hilary Greenberg, Elizabeth and Alan Cohen, Caroline and Mitchell Nussbaum, Jessica and Robin Ruthizer, Joshua and Alexander Ruthizer. Affectionately known as ''Poppy'' to his five great-grandchildren, Jonathan, Rachel and Jordana Cohen and Robert and David Greenberg. Adored friend and companion of Bella Grossman. From 1944 to 1980 Harold was the owner of ''Roosevelt Hardware'' on Nassau Road, Roosevelt, LI. Funeral service on Tuesday, July 20, at 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Cell Phone Is Blamed In Fatal Car Crash
description: A teen-age driver who looked down for a cellular phone collided head on with a motorcycle driven by an off-duty police detective, who was killed, the police said yesterday.

title: State Police Finalist Was Criticized for Role in Terror Inquiry
description: One of the five candidates to head the troubled New Jersey State Police is a Federal agent who was widely criticized for his role in shutting down the surveillance of a group of terrorists several months before they succeeded in bombing the World Trade Center.

title: Elf Aquitaine in $50 Billion Counterbid for Rival
description: Reviving the ''Pac-Man'' defense against hostile takeovers -- gobble up the company that wants to gobble up you -- the big French oil company Elf Aquitaine S.A. made a $50 billion counteroffer today for the rival Total Fina S.A.

title: Big Japanese Brokers Post Strong Earnings
description: Japan's top three brokerage firms posted first-quarter profits today that rose as much as tenfold as a rally in the nation's stock markets increased trading commissions.

title: Fast Track Isn't Fast Enough
description: ''This is our fast track.'' So said leaders of the European Union last month as they signed the Rio Declaration calling for free-trade talks between the union and Latin America and the Caribbean. Although the obstacles to any substantive agreement are large, this challenge to United States leadership in the hemisphere must not be ignored.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Vows column on Sunday misspelled the bride's given name. As the column reported, she is Jodi Claire Siegel, not Jodie.

title: Camden Seeks Bankruptcy Protection, Angering State Officials
description: The city of Camden filed for bankruptcy protection today, a move that state officials denounced as an attempt to divert attention from the city's unwillingness to submit to fiscal reforms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, ELSIE
description: STILLMAN-Elsie. Passed away on Monday, July 19, 1999. She was the wife of the late Dr. Raymond E. Stillman. Beloved mother of Dr. Michael Stillman and Dr. Robert Stillman and sister of Eva Kaye. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, David, Jessica and Joel. She was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, July 22nd at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamoroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAND, HELEN T., PH.D.
description: GRAND-Helen T., Ph.D. Beloved wife of the late Henry G. Grand, M.D. Devoted mother of Robert, Dr. Walter and Dr. Laura Bartels. Mother-in-law of Claudette, Dr. Laura Ureta and Robert Bartels. Loving grandmother of Dr. Russel and Stephanie Bartels, Eric Bartels, Yvonne, Jordana, Eric and Emily Grand. Great grandmother of Parker Bartels. Services today, 1:30 PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, KATHLEEN
description: O'SULLIVAN-Kathleen. Affectionately known as Kay, died peacefully on July 14 in Hampshire England. Formerly from Parker Crescent, Manhattan. The funeral will be held on July 22, at Park Crematorium, Guildford, England. God grant you eternal happiness. Your friends in America

title: A Faster Track to Mideast Peace
description: It has taken Israel's new Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, less than two weeks to breathe life and urgency into the stalled quest for Mideast peace. By setting a 15-month timetable for reaching broad agreement on a final settlement with the Palestinians and a deal with Syria covering both the Golan Heights and Lebanon, Mr. Barak is making clear that he believes that the basic issues can be resolved relatively quickly, if all sides are committed to peace. That will not be easy. To encourage steady progress, Mr. Barak and President Clinton have agreed to meet regularly at four-month intervals.

title: SANTA FE SNYDER TO BUY STAKE IN SHELL OIL DISCOVERIES
description: The Santa Fe Snyder Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire working interests in four Shell Deepwater Development Inc. discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico for $210 million. Santa Fe Snyder estimated that the acquisition, which includes unexplored acreage, will add production of 11,500 barrels of oil a day next year. Shell will retain a majority working interest in the properties and continue as operator. Santa Fe Snyder, an independent oil and gas company based in Houston, was formed by the merger of Santa Fe Energy Resources Inc. and the Snyder Oil Company in May. It has annual revenue of $290 million. Shell Deepwater is a unit of the Houston-based Shell Oil Company, the United States arm of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.

title: Goodbye, Cowtown; Denver Enters the World Arena
description: Just after World War II, John Gunther wrote in ''Inside U.S.A.'' that ''the remarkable thing about Denver is its ineffable closedness,'' calling it ''probably the most self-sufficient, isolated and complacent city in the world.''

title: Lawrie Wins By Avoiding The Danger Up the Creek
description: This year's British Open will be remembered both for its drama and for its difficulty.

title: FREE INTERNET SERVICE
description: Bowing to the emergence and growing popularity of free Internet services in Britain, AOL Europe announced that it would introduce one next month. The company, a joint venture of America Online Inc. and Bertelsmann A.G., hopes to compete against subscription-free newcomers like Freeserve, a unit of Dixons Group P.L.C., which displaced America Online as Britain's most-used Internet service provider. Called Netscape Online, the new service will not replace America Online's other subscription-based services like AOL U.K. and Compuserve. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SIGMUND (SIGGY)
description: LEVINE-Sigmund (Siggy). Our dearest brother, friend and playmate. We miss you already. You will always be in our hearts. With love, Carole and Jerry

title: Rookie Gives Mets A Pleasant Problem
description: Octavio Dotel's performance tonight suggested that he could be attractive enough, all by himself, for the Mets to trade him for a top starter before the July 31 trading deadline. But now the Mets must decide if they want to keep him instead.

title: Real Test for Teachers Comes in the Classroom; CUNY Policy Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Halts Company's Sale of Apparel From Sweatshop
description: In the first use of a state law that holds a clothing company accountable for exploitative labor practices of factories producing its garments, a judge ruled yesterday that the state can stop a Brooklyn apparel maker from selling shirts and skirts assembled in a factory that had underpaid its employees.

title: A Top Adviser to a Much-Advised First Lady
description: WHEN Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a baby shower at the White House last summer for Mandy Grunwald, it was an event that prompted one of Ms. Grunwald's friends, the USA Today columnist Walter Shapiro, to observe that ''the kid may have peaked too soon.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBENBERG, GERALD
description: LEBENBERG-Gerald. 57. Of Thiells, NY, died of a heart attack on Sunday, July 18, 1999. He is survived by his loving wife, Flo, three devoted daughters, Margot, Michelle and Ivette, two sons-in-law, a grandson, and his sister and brother-in-law, Estelle and Carl Fryburg. Gerald was loved and admired by all and will be greatly missed. The funeral will be held on Tuesday, July 20, 1999 at Hellman's Funeral Parlor in Spring Valley, NY. Family will sit shiva at his home in Theills, NY. Donations can be sent to the Jewish Federation in Gerald's name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JACK, DR.
description: FRIEDMAN-Jack, Dr. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY, mourns the death of its member and extends deepest sympathy to the family. Alan J. Hartstein, President Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi

title: TALKS ABOUT SALE OF PUBS
description: The battle for the 3,500 British pubs of Allied Domecq P.L.C. has taken another confusing turn. Punch Taverns Group Ltd., the main contender for the pubs after Whitbread P.L.C. withdrew from the bidding, said that it, too, was pulling out, but then it changed tack to say that talks had resumed. Punch lowered its earlier offer of 2.9 billion [pounds] to around 2.7 billion [pounds] after Whitbread's withdrawal. Allied Domecq confirmed that talks with Punch were continuing but said it had been in touch with unidentified new suitors. Punch is 70 percent owned by the United States private equity firm Texas Pacific. Alan Cowell

title: 'One China' Policy Ignores Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: What's a Doctor to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: CSX IN TALKS TO SELL SHIPPING BUSINESS TO MAERSK
description: The stock of the CSX Corporation rose yesterday after it was reported that the company was in talks to sell its international container-shipping business to Maersk Inc. A transaction could be announced as early as this week and involve about $800 million in combined cash and assumption of debt, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday, citing people familiar with the talks. CSX's stock rose $2.25 a share, to $51.1875. Both CSX, based in Richmond, and Maersk, which is Danish-owned but based in Madison, N.J., declined to comment. Maersk, a subsidiary of A. P. Moller Group of Copenhagen, is the largest container-shipping company in the world.

title: Real Test for Teachers Comes in the Classroom; Good Guessing Is a Skill
description: To the Editor:

title: Defendant in Diallo Shooting Changes Lawyers
description: One of the four officers charged with murder in the Amadou Diallo case has dismissed his lawyer, Marvyn M. Kornberg, and replaced him with Burton B. Roberts, the irascible former chief administrative judge for State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: INSIDE
description: An Old Drug Is Found To Aid Heart Patients

title: Relief for the Long-Distance Runner?
description: Long-distance runners and others performing strenuous exercises have long known that they should eat carbohydrates after workouts to replace the energy stores they have exhausted. Now a report in The Journal of Nutrition suggests that eating meat, dairy products and protein bars containing the amino acid leucine after intense exercise also significantly cuts down on the time muscles need to recover, at least in rats.

title: Leading the AIDS Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Everett Greenbaum, 79, Comedy Writer
description: Everett Greenbaum, an award-winning film and television comedy writer for programs like ''Mr. Peepers,'' ''The George Gobel Show,'' ''The Andy Griffith Show'' and ''M*A*S*H,'' died on July 11 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 79 and lived in Encino, Calif.

title: THOMSON STAKE MAY BE SOLD
description: France is preparing to cut sharply its stake in Thomson-CSF, Europe's biggest military electronics maker, labor union officials said, in a bid to help its prospects for partnerships in Europe. The state will cut its stake to less than 20 percent from 44 percent, according to the union CFDT, partly through the sale of 10 percent of Thomson to Alcatel S.A., Europe's largest telecommunications equipment maker, and 10 percent to the public. The union, which holds two Thomson-CSF board seats, did not say what would happen with the other 4 percent.

title: Letting Butterflies Flutter Free; Enlightened Insect Lovers Forget the Net and the Pins
description: The regular Saturday-morning rush of soccer moms and joggers filled the Starbucks here recently, but something was different about a cluster of people hunkered over some tables in a corner.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Accounts
description: * Fax4free.com, Los Angeles, to the Rabuck Agency, Los Angeles, as agency of record for the American introduction of its free worldwide faxing Web site. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Forum on Year 2000 Is Pushed Back
description: City officials yesterday put off plans for a citywide forum for residents to question public and private leaders about preparations for Year 2000 computer problem.

title: Theater Troupe to Buy Berkshire Site
description: The National Music Foundation, a nonprofit organization for the promotion of American music, has shelved its plan to establish a performing arts complex with an educational center and a musicians' retirement community in the Berkshires. Over the weekend, the organization agreed to sell its 63-acre site in Lenox, Mass., near Tanglewood, to Shakespeare & Company for $5.1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPPRODT, PATRICIA O'BRIEN
description: ZIPPRODT-Patricia O'Brien. On July 17, 1999. Three time Tony award winning theater costume designer and prominent ballet, opera and film costume designer. Wife of the late Colonel Robert E. O'Brien, Jr. Survived by her beloved sister, Constance ZipprodtZonka and six nieces and nephews, Kathy, Roger, Lynn, Daniel, Heidi and Milo, children of sisters Constance Zipprodt-Zonka and the late Barbara Zipprodt-Pavlik. Services Saturday, July 24, at Trinity Episcopal Church, Upperville, VA. Interment private. Memorial service in New York at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Metro Business; Keyspan to Expand Queens Power Plant
description: Keyspan Energy, the owner of natural gas and electricity utilities in and near New York City, will expand its power plant in Ravenswood, Queens, to provide 12 percent more electricity when demand is high, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUNIHAN, DOROTHY ANNE
description: COUNIHAN-Dorothy Anne, of Stamford, CT (formerly of Islip, NY), on July 18, 1999, in her 83rd year. Beloved wife of Thomas R., M.D. Loving mother of Anne Sheila Miles, Mary Tangney, Sr. Martha Counihan, O.S.U., and Claire Counihan. Cherished grandmother of three. Fond sister of Jean Van Delft, Peggy O'Connor, Betty Dowdell, Marie Lou McEvoy, and William McEvoy. Funeral Mass, Wednesday, 10:45AM, St. Mary's RC Church, East Islip, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Islip Public Library, or the Islip Chapter of the AAUW. For information contact the Overton Funeral Home, Inc., Islip, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROADUS, ANNE BOWEN
description: BROADUS-Anne Bowen, on July 18, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Carlisle Broadus. Devoted mother of Anne Elizabeth Holding of Lafayette, California and Margaret Carlisle Saling of New York City. Cherished grandmother of Amanda Carlisle Holding, Katherine Sinclair Holding, Joseph Carlisle Saling and John Pritchard Saling. Mrs. Broadus graduated from Sweet Briar College (VA) and received her Master's degree in Social Work from Columbia University. She was active in many charities in NYC, among them the Society of The Third Street Music School Settlement, of which she was an Honorary Director. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 21, at 4:30 PM in the Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Society of the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11 Street, NY NY 10003.

title: Neat Package Hides Issues In Phone Deal
description: As the smoke clears from the communications industry's latest takeover battleground, the companies that recently fired so many billion-dollar salvos -- Global Crossing, Frontier, Qwest and U S West -- have left unresolved questions scattered like so many shell cases.

title: Umpires' Strategy Is a Mystery to Everybody Except the Umpires
description: By signing letters of resignation, major league umpires have placed themselves in peril, labor experts on both sides of the collective bargaining fence say. Richie Phillips, the umpires' labor leader, disagrees. It won't be long before Major League Baseball finds out who is right.

title: Computers vs. Books On Trip to the Library
description: It was a trip both prosaic and profound.

title: Q & A
description: Perfect Pitch

title: Portable Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Graft Cases Remind South Koreans of Bad Old Days
description: Corruption has long been something of a national pastime in South Korea. With few laws and little Government effort to prosecute offenders, many Koreans have come to regard bribes, payoffs and kickbacks as part of political life.

title: Profits Rise at Citigroup and Other Banks in 2d Quarter
description: Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit surged 21 percent as robust consumer spending and the resilient stock market bolstered earnings at several leading banks.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy yesterday misidentified the college from which her sister Lauren graduated. It was William Smith College, not its affiliate, Hobart; both are in Geneva, N.Y.

title: Motorola to Sell Part of Its Shares in Nextel
description: Motorola Inc., one of the world's biggest cellular phone makers, said today that it would sell 2.8 million shares of Nextel Communications Inc. in the third quarter, reducing its stake in the nationwide wireless carrier to 19 percent.

title: Umps in Minors Put Off Vote
description: Minor league umpires yesterday postponed until today a decision on whether to strike the 16 minor leagues under the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues.

title: Jakarta Reportedly Predicts East Timor Will Vote to Split Off
description: Indonesia is preparing to relinquish control of East Timor after 23 years of occupation, and it believes that independence advocates are highly likely to win a referendum next month, says a supposedly authentic internal Government report that has been made available to reporters by advocates of independence.

title: Delta Is in Talks With 3 Agencies
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it was in discussions over advertising work that is now being handled by Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.

title: Repeat Repeat Repeat Repeat. Minimally.
description: When Minimalism emerged in the late 1960's, this innovative music of repetition shook up the contemporary music establishment and produced some rhythmically hypnotic, fleetingly beautiful works. But, many critics say, as a stylistic development Minimalism has had its day, and the music has lost its freshness.

title: Aching Backs, Through the Generations
description: The vast majority of Americans will suffer from back pain at some point in their lives. In fact, only the common cold causes more employee absenteeism. Now, a study in the current issue of Science indicates that one of the most common back problems, intervertebral disk disease, or sciatica, may be an inherited disorder.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ATLANTIC INTERNATIONAL ENTERTAINMENT, Boca Raton, Fla., named John Copelyn chairman. Mr. Copelyn is chief executive of Hosken Consolidated Investments, which owns 20 percent of Atlantic.

title: The Deliveryman Asks: Need Ice? Who Doesn't?
description: ''The whole thing with ice,'' said Will D'Ariano, a.k.a. Chilly Willy, ''is people find out they have none and they panic. Everybody waits to the last minute. Then they call up and say: 'I need ice! I need ice! I need ice! I need it now!' ''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee rose as cooler temperatures in Brazil, the world's biggest grower, prompted concern that frost could reduce output. In New York, coffee for September delivery rose 1.95 cents, to 94.9 cents a pound.

title: Pfizer Reports Gain in Profit And Deal in Price-Fixing Case
description: Pfizer Inc., the nation's second-largest drug maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit had risen 13 percent on increased sales of medicines including the high-blood-pressure pill Norvasc, the antidepressant Zoloft and the antibiotic Zithromax.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Kennedy family's misfortunes referred incorrectly at one point to the cousin of John F. Kennedy Jr. who was killed by a drug overdose in 1984. It was David Kennedy. As noted earlier in the article, David Kennedy's brother Michael was killed last year in a skiing accident.

title: Muted Day In Capital For Cup Champions
description: The Women's World Cup soccer champions visited the White House today for a celebration that was tinged with melancholy over the apparently fatal flight of John F. Kennedy Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, AMELIA
description: NEWMAN-Amelia. On July 18th, 1999 in Boynton Beach, Florida. She is survived by her husband, Louis, and her two sons, Steven and Richard, and their wives, Tina and Megan. Loving grandmother of Isabella and Eli. Dear sister of Sylvia. Brought up and raised in Leeds, England, Amelia married as a war bride in 1945, moved to New York and lovingly raised and enjoyed her family in Plainview, Long Island for many years. She was a devoted wife, loving mother, grandmother, sister and friend. Amelia will be dearly missed and remembered. Services in Florida with interment in New York.

title: Freshman Senator Bucks His Billing, and the G.O.P.
description: Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, was not supposed to be like this.

title: Search for Editor Lost While Hiking on Mount Rainier Is Suspended
description: A five-day search for a New York City book editor who was last seen hiking on snow-blanketed Mount Rainier near Seattle on July 8 has been suspended, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWINING, JEAN KNOOP
description: TWINING-Jean Knoop. On July 18, 1999 at the age of 83. Formerly employed with Cahill Gordon in NYC and a member of many organizations including the English Speaking Union and the Mendelssohn Glee Club of NY. Beloved wife of the late Geoffrey Twining. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday, July 22, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery.

title: Reviews Narrowed At Avis and Solar
description: Two marketers said yesterday that they had narrowed account reviews that are expected to end next month.

title: $21 Million Award in Sex-Harassment Case
description: A jury awarded $21 million today to a woman who said she had been sexually harassed at a DaimlerChrysler factory here that builds the Jeep Grand Cherokee.

title: I.R.S. May Be Slower to Seize Some Assets
description: In a new break for owners of assets, the Internal Revenue Service will issue regulations tomorrow allowing people with overdue taxes to keep their stocks, businesses and homes if they can show that they need them to pay for medical care or basic living expenses.

title: Guards Face No Charges In Death of Inmate
description: Criminal charges will not be filed against Albany County correction officers who restrained an inmate who later died, but some disciplinary action is still possible, officials said yesterday.

title: Three Indicted In Bank Case; Funds Diverted, U.S. Charges
description: Three former executives of the Bankers Trust Corporation were indicted yesterday on Federal criminal charges that they diverted $15.5 million of unclaimed customer money into the bank's own accounts from 1993 to 1996 to lift their department's financial results.

title: A Doctor Learns the Hard Way That Love and Medicine Don't Mix
description: You have a glass of white wine in one hand and a cracker in the other when that odd shooting pain starts up in your right hip again. But what luck -- standing right next to you at the buffet table, looking around for someone to talk to, is your second cousin Harry the doctor, a lovely guy, one of your favorite people and a noted hip expert.

title: Are Americans Turning Their Backs on Science?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDEL, SUSAN
description: LUDEL-Susan. Loving daughter of Kinny (Corinne) and the late Wolly Ludel, sister of Jackie, Bill and Tracy. Aunt of Sophie and Wally. Memorial at Campbell Funeral Home, 81st and Madison Sunday July 25 at 3PM.

title: Women Make Water Polo Their Own
description: At age 11, Julie Swail of Placentia, Calif., wangled her way out of swim practice by picking up the slack in a boys' water polo game being played in an adjacent pool. By the final whistle, she knew she had found her sport. ''It was physical, aggressive and required a lot of endurance, everything I was looking for and hadn't found in swimming,'' she said.

title: Delta Profit Up as Traffic Grows, But Continental's Earnings Drop
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in the latest quarter rose on higher traffic, while Continental Airlines Inc.'s profit fell because of competitive pricing and rising labor costs.

title: Did Busing Cause Suburban Flight?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, EMMA MARIE ABBETT
description: HILL-Emma Marie Abbett, 77, died, July 17, at Greenwich Hospital. Mother of Marie ''BK'' Bates of Cos Cob, Trudy Hill of Warren, CT, sister of Sheila Abbett of Greenwich and Naples, Fla. Grandmother of five. Services will be held at 9:30 A.M. on Friday July 23, in Christ Episcopal Church, 254 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT 06830. Interment will be private in Southampton, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the church.

title: Common but Confusing: Workers' Wrist Ailments
description: Many people feel alarmed when they begin to experience numbness and tingling in their hands and wrists, assuming that they must have carpal tunnel syndrome, the sometimes disabling nerve disorder. Now a new study -- the most comprehensive to date -- finds that they are often wrong, although the disease is more prevalent than had been expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ETHAN
description: ALLEN-Ethan, at age 92, on July 17th. at his home after a long illness. He was a Partner in the Law Firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher from 1939 until his retirement in 1995. He is survived by two grandsons, Dr. William Ethan Allen and David Brice Allen; and by his great granddaughter Claire Allen. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced.

title: Soon to Bow Out, Argentine Brushes Off the Boos
description: The wild mutton-chop sideburns are gone. The televised cheek-to-cheek tangos with marquee entertainers are a thing of the past. And when President Carlos Saul Menem does take the occasional spin in a hot sports car these days, his bodyguards no longer need to make death-defying weaves through traffic to chase after him.

title: 2 Leaders: To Speed the Peace Effort
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference yesterday in the Old Executive Office Building by President Clinton and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: City Hospitals' First Survey of Satisfaction Among Customers Finds It Unexpectedly High
description: Following the lead of department stores, fast-food chains and now even private hospitals, the city's sprawling public hospital system has conducted its first-ever customer satisfaction survey.

title: 'One China' Policy Ignores Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Money Goes to Medical Research
description: Looking far down the road and envisioning a time when Michigan might be associated as much with medical research as with automobiles, Gov. John Engler today signed legislation that will devote $50 million a year to spurring research in a ''life sciences corridor'' across a southern swath of the state.

title: Microsoft Selling City Guides to Ticketmaster for $240 Million
description: The Microsoft Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Sidewalk series of Internet city guides to a rival, Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch, in a stock deal worth $240 million.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN RALLIES. The yen rose against the dollar amid a growing appetite for Japanese securities and the currency to buy them. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.80 yen, down from 120.98 on Friday.

title: Raising Funds: Impeachment Is Powerful Tool
description: Fund-raisers for both the Republican Party and the Democratic Party have discovered that invoking the impeachment of President Clinton still dredges up raw emotions and motivates Americans to write checks to candidates seeking election in 2000.

title: Lefebvre Is Latest To Join Rangers
description: With the signing of defenseman Sylvain Lefebvre yesterday, the Rangers' summer makeover appears complete. The shopping spree in which the team added six free agents -- a total of eight new players if the two prospects acquired on draft day are included -- seems finally done.

title: Ruling Favors Ex-Officer Said to Have Helped Mob
description: A Federal appeals panel yesterday dismissed most of the charges against a former police officer convicted of telling organized crime figures that one of their associates was a Government informer.

title: Russians Gaze With Envy Across the Border at China
description: Ten years ago, when Russians gazed across the Amur River into China, all they could see was a scraggly forest and an occasional smokestack. What lay beyond was a mystery, sealed by a border shut tight.

title: Bank Earnings Increase; Wells Fargo Is Up 29%
description: Among the financial companies reporting higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, Wells Fargo & Company said its profit jumped 29 percent, and Bank of New York, the world's biggest processor of securities transactions, increased net income 9.5 percent.

title: CALIFORNIA ENACTS THE TOUGHEST BAN ON ASSAULT GUNS
description: Six years ago this month a disgruntled businessman named Gian Luigi Ferri took two TEC-9 semiautomatic pistols into the office tower at 101 California Street here and, in less than 15 minutes, killed eight people and wounded six others before turning a gun on himself and committing suicide.

title: A Gospel Extravaganza Goes Beyond Imitation
description: ''In case you don't know, we're all from the church,'' explained the gospel singer Donnie McClurkin, motioning behind him at the more than 60 choir members onstage at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night. He grinned electrically as he stated the obvious. ''We can't read music, really,'' he said. ''We all used our hymn books as tambourines and as fans. If a song had a beat, we took it out, and if it didn't, we put it back in. We'd open the book,'' he said, mimicking a spiritual sung with goody-goody reverence. ''And then we closed the book.'' One line took a full 10 seconds as he repeated and repeated a word and then a fraction of a word; he was both putting his devotion under a microscope and exploding it into pure ecstatic sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, MARY
description: DANN-Mary. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Devoted mother of Jeffrey, Douglas and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Courtney, Linsey, Erica, Alex, Jamie and Emily. description: Harvard has appointed Mark Mazzoleni, from Miami University of Ohio, as its new men's hockey coach.

title: Sports of The Times; A Golfer's Decisions, Decisions
description: IN golf, it's known as managing your game. It's making the correct decision on which club to hit and where to hit your ball as much as it is making the correct swing. Decisions, decisions.

title: At Home, Yankees Are Far From Perfect
description: To Joe Torre, it was as if someone kept taking first base and moving it farther away. Or so it seemed to the Yankees' manager.

description: LISMAN - Lee Cunningham, passed away on July 19, 1999 after a long illness. She is survived by her loving husband, Richard D. Lisman and two devoted daughters, Hilary Bogert and Cyrena Fink; two grandaughters, Brigitte Jeanne and Chloe Lawrence and five brothers, A.Brean Murray, Sean, Noel, Kevin and Grant Cunningham, and numerous nieces and nephews.
