In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Rogosin Kidney Center of New York Hospital or The St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton, NY.

title: More Than Mere Glamour
description: Now that the assessments of John F. Kennedy Jr.'s short life have begun, the general impression seems to be that his importance had more to do with his good looks, his glamorous aura and his good nature than with any particular contribution he made to American politics or society. But that would be a misreading of who he was.

title: CENTRICA TO SELL STORES
description: Britain's dominant supplier and marketer of natural gas, Centrica P.L.C., said it would take a charge of $:60 million ($93 million) this year to close its 243 retail stores. The stores lost $:33 million in 1998 and $:25 million in the first half of this year. Centrica, which was spun off from British Gas in 1997, will continue to supply cookers and other products that had been handled at its stores through home shopping connections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERFEIN, RICHARD
description: SILBERFEIN-Richard of Springfield, N.J. Beloved husband of Carol Pedicini-Silberfein. Adoring and adored father of Julie Rose and Tori Jill. Cherished son of Jane and Michael Silberfein. Loving son-in-law of Vicki and Rudy Pedicini. Loyal and devoted brother of Andrew and Amy, James and Diane and Roseanne. Beloved grandson of Anne Engelhardt and Ann Silberfein. Fun, loving uncle of Joshua, Rebecca and Caroline. Services Gutterman - Musicant, corner of Passaic and Park St, Hackensack, NJ, today at 1:30PM.

title: What Flies, Steals and Sings Bel Canto?
description: KATONAH, N.Y., July 18 -- Among the annual fixtures now at Caramoor is a bel canto opera, brightly cast, finely prepared and smartly presented under the musical direction of Will Crutchfield. This year's choice was a piece that for most of the last century has been known only by its overture: Rossini's ''Gazza Ladra,'' or ''The Thieving Magpie.'' Does the rest live up to that brilliant opening? In a way it does not attempt to, for the work is one of the period's ''semi-serious'' operas, in which characters out of opera buffa begin to feel within themselves early Romantic pangs of emotion.

title: Foreign Affairs; Ayatollah Deng
description: I spoke to an Iranian friend in London the other day who told me a story about his brother back in Teheran, who had recently visited one of the popular cyber-cafes in the Iranian capital. His brother described seeing a bearded, obviously religious young man trading stocks on line, who at one point stood up and shouted across the Internet cafe, ''Hey, I just made $1,000.''

title: Moscow Journal; At Long Last, Rain! But How Red Square Sizzled!
description: It rained in Moscow today, an event not normally regarded as international news but which, in this parboiled Russian summer, has occurred roughly as often as men bite dogs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PERRIGO CO., Allegan, Mich., the No. 1 U.S. maker of store-brand drugs, plans to sell its personal-care business, which has sales of $190 million, to Cumberland Swan Holdings, a concern owned primarily by Nashville investors, to focus on its over-the-counter pharmaceuticals and nutritional products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Seoul Intercedes on Daewoo Debt Crisis
description: The South Korean Government stepped in today to prevent affiliates of the sprawling Daewoo Group from slipping into bankruptcy and causing a wave of bankruptcies in the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVNER, BENJAMIN
description: KOVNER-Benjamin. Long-term resident of Mamaroneck, NY, on July 17 at the age of 97 in Greenwich, CT Hospital. Beloved husband of Kathleen Jane Kovner. Loving father of Michael, Peter and the late Kay Kovner and father-in-law of Roberta and surrogate father to Jean. Adored grandfather of Matthew and Alexandra. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, July 20, 6-9 PM, with service Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Eye Institute, 2020 Vision Place, Bethesda, MD 20892.

title: State Officials Issue Water Usage Alert
description: State officials issued a water shortage alert yesterday and urged residents to refrain from watering their lawns and washing their cars.

title: Kennedy's Creation, George, Was Struggling
description: John F. Kennedy Jr. had in recent weeks begun to discuss the fate of his nearly four-year-old political magazine, George, with advisers at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank.

title: Hewlett-Packard Picks Rising Star at Lucent as Its Chief Executive
description: Abandoning a long tradition of picking its leaders from within its own ranks, the Hewlett-Packard Company announced today that it had chosen as its next chief executive a woman who earned her power and reputation in the telecommunications industry.

title: STARWOOD BUYING TIME-SHARE DEVELOPER
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Vistana Inc., a vacation time-share developer, for about $403.9 million in cash and stock. Starwood said the deal valued Vistana, based in Orlando, Fla., at $19 a share, consisting of $5 a share in cash and the balance in Starwood shares. Vistana's stock was unchanged yesterday at $17.25 in Nasdaq trading. Vistana had 1998 sales of $234 million and operates 10 resorts -- 4 in Florida, 3 in Colorado, one in South Carolina and 2 in Arizona. Starwood, based in White Plains, operates more than 700 hotels and resorts in 72 countries under such chains as Sheraton, Westin and Four Points.

title: What's a Doctor to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia's Embryos Of Enterprise; A New Breed of Small Entrepreneurs Springs From the Financial Chaos
description: Ernest Shakarov, a former investment banker, is among the few Russians who could easily have kept living comfortably after a crisis shattered the securities industry here.

title: Portable Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNEBORN, CLARA LOUISE
description: SONNEBORN-Clara Louise. Memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM, July 22, 1999 at Congregation Kol Ami (Schulman Chapel) 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. For directions please call: 212-350-3800.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F., JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F., Jr. The Board of Directors, the Advisory Board and the Staff of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation extend their most heartfelt condolences to the families of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, John F. Kennedy, Jr. and Lauren Bessette on their presumed deaths. We also send our sincere thoughts to John's colleagues and associates at George magazine and Hachette Filipacchi Publications who have been loyal supporters of the work of the Foundation. John and Carolyn were just beginning to come into their own and we admired them so much. This is an unexpectedly premature tragedy and a great loss to what they would have both become. Evelyn Lauder, President Deborah Krulewitch, Treasurer Susan Hirschhorn, Exc. Dir

title: G.E. in Contract With Columbia/HCA
description: The General Electric Company, the world's largest maker of diagnostic-imaging equipment, said today that the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation had agreed to a five-year, $1.5 billion contract to use G.E. imaging machines, including X-ray and ultrasound equipment.

title: Evocations Of Diana, Derring-Do, And a Curse
description: He was the custodian of a family's curse, a patrician dynasty's tragic prince whose pride -- even arrogance -- led to his downfall. He was a reckless adventurer, seized with a death wish that played itself out in the hazy skies off Martha's Vineyard. For Americans, he was the same royal orphan as Diana was for Britons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCHANSKY, KATZ, ROSALIE
description: KOCHANSKY - KATZ - Rosalie. Aged 84, formerly of New York, NY, died peacefully at the Sarah Newman Nursing Home, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, July 18, 1999. Loving wife of the late Eli Katz, she leaves a sister, Ethel Mullen of Scranton, PA and Washington, D.C. Artist, educator, author, Rosalie was educated at the University of Florence; Sorbonne, Paris, France; Brooklyn College (BA); and City College of New York (MA). She expressed her devotion to children by teaching for the New York City Board of Education, specializing in visual learning and remedial reading, and generously supporting the ALYNAmerican Society for Crippled Children in Israel. Author of ''Kinesthetic and Visual Learning,'' 1963; ''Katz Game-Test for Dyslexia,'' 1968; and cookbooks. Contributor to ''Women's Wear Daily,'' and ''Lingerie Merchandising.'' Awarded Brooklyn Museum (1954-55) and New York University (1955-57) Art Scholarships. First Prize as most promising artist in show, Washington Square Outdoor Show, 1955. Independent, creative, and a world-traveler, Rosalie will be missed by all who knew her. At Rosalie's wishes, any donations should be directed to the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute for Science, 51 Madison Avenue, New York, New York (212) 779-2500.

title: A New Chief of Planning
description: Is Selected by The Times

title: Not All Hit It Rich in the Internet Gold Rush
description: As Barnesandnoble.com was preparing to go public in April, employees talked giddily about their future wealth. Having accepted stock options as a big chunk of their compensation -- a common practice among Internet ventures -- many of them dreamed that their shares would mimic those of companies like Theglobe.com, whose stock shot up 500 percent on the first day of trading.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a pop music review in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about Bruce Springsteen's reunion concert on Thursday with the E Street Band at the Continental Airlines Arena in New Jersey misstated the closing date of their American tour. The last concert at the arena is on Aug. 12, but the tour will continue into the fall; the last date announced so far is Oct. 17 in Los Angeles.

title: PLUS: PRO FOOTBALL -- GIANTS; Brown's Recovery
description: Running back Gary Brown continues to recover from a motorcycle accident last month, though the Giants say a deeply bruised buttocks could slow him at the beginning of training camp, which starts in Albany in nine days.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; In Infancy, Reducing the Odds of Obesity
description: Babies raised on formula are twice as likely to be obese at age 5 or 6 as breast-fed babies, a survey of more than 9,000 Bavarian schoolchildren has found.

title: BIOCHEM BUYS BACK STOCK FROM GLAXO WELLCOME
description: Biochem Pharma Inc., Canada's No. 1 biotechnology company, said yesterday that it had bought back eight million shares from Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the world's biggest maker of AIDS drugs, for $160 million. The buyback, at $20 a share, cut Glaxo's stake in Biochem, based in Laval, Quebec, from 12.2 percent to 5.3 percent of the 100.9 million remaining common shares outstanding. Biochem, which invented the AIDS and hepatitis B drug lamivudine, or 3TC, paid Glaxo $80 million yesterday and will pay another $80 million in 18 months. The two companies began their drug development in 1990.

title: The Cross Words Over Crossbars Wind Down as a Lawsuit Is Settled
description: A battle over flagpoles in city parks, which escalated from a seemingly obscure esthetic disagreement into a lawsuit and political brouhaha for the Giuliani administration, has apparently been resolved.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Remaking a Mirror

title: Apollo Opened Window on Moon's Violent Birth
description: Science was low on the agenda when two Americans landed on the Moon 30 years ago today, beating the Russians in one of the cold war's most costly and daring contests. But in time, the six Apollo landings from 1969 to 1972, in which a dozen people roamed another world, probing its composition and taking hundreds of rocky samples, led to a major surprise.

title: Charles Roman, the Brains Behind the Brawn, Dies at 92
description: Charles P. Roman, the not particularly husky ad man and executive who created classic advertisements for the bodybuilder Charles Atlas, including the one about a 97-pound weakling, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 92 and lived in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: I.B.M. Earns $2.4 Billion, Up 65 Percent, in Quarter
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had earned $2.4 billion in the second quarter, up 65 percent, largely because of a gain from the sale of its Global Network Internet unit to AT&T.

title: Gains and Losses on H.I.V.
description: A recent survey of gay and bisexual men in New York City showed encouraging evidence that many members of the gay community are acting responsibly to reduce the risk of H.I.V. infection. The survey, an unusual collaboration between the Department of Health and the Gay Men's Health Crisis, a nonprofit AIDS organization in New York, supports a growing consensus that perhaps only half as many gay men in the city are infected with H.I.V. as in 1985. But the survey also points to breakdowns in education about H.I.V., especially in black and Latino communities.

title: Mrs. Clinton Postpones Trip To New York
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday postponed what would have been her third trip to New York as a prospective Senate candidate in as many weeks, citing the disappearance and presumed death of John F. Kennedy Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, EMIL, PROFESSOR
description: GREENBERG-Emil, Professor. Age 89. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Funeral July 27th, 1PM, Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Call 718-939-9405

title: Tickets to Fantasies Of Urban Desire; Each Leads to a Different New York
description: New York City may be the most diversified, competitive, high-priced flesh market in the world, especially in the summertime, when half the population struts around in a state of semi-undress. On certain evenings, as the streets teem with gym-toned bodies and attitudes to match, you have the sense of a million sexual fantasies in the naked city converging in one giant imaginary orgy.

title: Visitors' Bureau President Gets Job Ultimatum
description: Executives at the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau have asked Fran Reiter, the bureau's president, to resign if she intends to continue exploring a potential bid for the mayoralty in 2001.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My friends, guns do kill people.''

title: Review/Fashion; The Cult of Personality, Wrapped Up in Couture
description: Anyone who thinks that the semiannual made-to-measure collections are about $20,000 silk dresses doesn't understand haute couture. Between the big shows, which are timed so as not to interfere with the life of fashion -- the gossiping, the eyeballing of the noonday crowd at the Ritz bar, which is like information central -- there is the inevitable round of parties.

title: 2 Are Shot, One Fatally As They Sit in a Car
description: One man was shot dead and another was wounded early yesterday as they sat in a parked car on a street in Upper Manhattan, the police said.

description: LONDON-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Murray London. Loving sister of Benjamin Newman and the late Tillie Chait and Irving Newman. Adored Aunt, Great Aunt and friend. She inspired love. Services Tuesday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Keep the Fiber Bandwagon Rolling, for Heart and Health
description: You've heard it now for years: fiber is good for you. Eat more whole grains, dried peas and beans, fruits and vegetables if you want to stay healthy. Fiber protects the colon against cancer. It also helps the heart by lowering cholesterol, reduces the risk of developing diabetes and facilitates weight control.

title: Movie Sets Serbs' Emotions on Edge
description: The most popular movie this summer in Serbia is a historical drama about war, love and vengeance called ''The Knife.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, MORRIS ALBERT
description: GROSSMAN-Morris Albert. On July 19, 1999. Beloved father of Rita Roth and Harriet Muss. Devoted brother of Max. Graveside service Tuesday, 11AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLOZZA, JOSEPH F.
description: COLOZZA-Joseph F. We mourn the loss of our partner and friend Joseph F. Colozza. His presence is irreplaceable. July 26, 1940 to July 14, 1999. Phyllis Shafran and Robert P. Weir

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Will Mp3.com soar to No. 1 with a bullet, or languish in the Wall St. cut-out bins?
description: THE bands cracking the Top 10 music chart this week are Red Delicious and the Streaming Geeks. No, the hit list is not the Billboard Top 40, but one from Mp3.com, an unconventional force in the music industry that is scheduled to make an initial public offering of stock this week.

title: Shuttle Mission Is Aborted Six Seconds Before Launching
description: A last-second engine shutdown early today dealt Air Force Col. Eileen Collins a temporary setback in her drive to become the first woman to command a space shuttle mission.

title: A Great Pretender Now Faces the Truth of Illness
description: Seated in her wheelchair on a terrace at the university hospital, Wendy Scott gazed out at a thunderstorm that had blackened the noon skies and tried to explain why she had spent 12 years of her life traveling from one hospital to another in Britain and Europe, pretending to be ill so that she would be admitted as a patient.

title: Cardinal and Family of Convicted Officer Meet
description: John Cardinal O'Connor met yesterday with the family of Charles Schwarz, one of two police officers convicted in the station house torture of Abner Louima, and expressed his concern and ''continuing interest'' in Mr. Schwarz's case, according to people who attended the meeting.

title: Foodmaker Name Change
description: Foodmaker Inc., the owner of the Jack in the Box fast-food hamburger chain, said today that it would change its name to Jack in the Box Inc. effective Oct. 4. The change will coincide with a planned expansion into the southeastern United States, with openings of restaurants scheduled for Nashville; Charlotte, N.C., and Baton Rouge, La. The company, which ranks fifth among quick-service hamburger chain, has rebounded after weathering an outbreak of deadly illnesses caused by contamination that was traced to its food six years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York Public Library's acquisition of the archives of Yaddo, the artists' retreat in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., misspelled the surname of a composer who spent time there. He was Aaron Copland, not Copeland.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Curious Exploration on the Keyboard
description: Dropping in on the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival at the Mannes College of Music to hear Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations on Friday evening might have seemed like sticking in a thumb to pull out a plum. What came out instead was a prickly pear, uncooked and all abristle.

title: Combining 2 Identities: Arab in Israel Parliament
description: When he was sworn in last month as a member of Israel's Parliament, Dr. Ahmad Tibi, an Israeli Arab, rose for the national anthem as the newly elected legislature was inaugurated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PEERCE, STUART B.
description: PEERCE-Stuart B. 4 years-rest in peace. We all miss you. Love, Lois, Margie, Mark, Steve, Wendy, Carol, Pamela, Benjamin and Sar

title: DEFAULT ON STEEL COMPANY BOND
description: India's third-largest steelmaker, Essar Steel Ltd., said it did not have the money to repay a $250 million Eurobond that is due today and would ask bondholders for time to raise money. Essar said it would submit a plan in the next three months on how it will repay the bonds, either by borrowing to refinance them or rolling them over by extending their maturity dates.

title: New York, New York: Skyscrapers and All
description: He didn't want to leave when he was a free agent after the 1995 season, he didn't want to leave after last season and he doesn't plan to leave after this season. Everything might be up to date in Kansas City, where he grew up, but for David Cone, New York is the only place to play major league baseball.

title: Marketing services are gobbled up, and other tales of agency consolidation.
description: MORE agencies and agency companies are agreeing to deals to sell full or partial control to larger firms, as the acquisition boom remaking Madison Avenue continues.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Citigroup Profit Rises 21% As Nearly All Areas Grow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LEON
description: GOLDMAN-Leon. Age 96 in Boynton Beach, Fla. Formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY. Husband of the late Beatrice Wohlberg. Father of Ira (Marylin), Lowell (Harriet) and Linda Grossman (Fred). Grandfather and great-grandfather. Founder of A-A Ambulance & Oxygen Service, Bronx, NY. Leader in Bronx business community. Burial King David cemetery, NY Tuesday at 1pm.

title: Kennedy Rebuffed Overture In Senate Race, Torricelli Says
description: John F. Kennedy Jr. was sought out as a possible candidate for a Senate seat from New York but declined to run even before Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed interest in the race, according to a Senator who spoke with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINEMAN, FREDA
description: FINEMAN-Freda. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend our sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch of the Bd Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: TIFFANY IS INVESTING IN DIAMOND PRODUCER
description: Tiffany & Company said yesterday that it would invest $72 million in the Canadian company Aber Resources Ltd. as part of an agreement that the jewelry retailer said would secure a major portion of its diamond needs. Tiffany said Aber, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, holds a 40 percent interest in the Diavik Diamonds Project in Canada's Northwest Territories. Production of gem-quality diamonds is expected to begin in 2002. Tiffany said its investment would give it a 14.9 percent stake in Aber. Aber shares closed Monday at $9.75, up 62.5 cents, or nearly 7 percent, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, ELEANOR L.
description: ALEXANDER-Eleanor L. On July 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Maxwell M. Alexander. Loving mother of Jane Leslie Burgin, James D. Alexander and their spouses David Burgin and Barbara F. Alexander. Adored grandmother of Marissa Brooke and Marni Erin Alexander. Dear sister of the late Richard J. Lax. Services Tuesday, July 20, 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood N.J.

title: Anthony W. Marshall, 93, TV Producer
description: Anthony W. Marshall, who with his family produced some of the most successful television comedies of the 1970's and 80's, died on July 12 at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 93.

title: Stanley Tretick, 77, Photographer Of Kennedys at the White House
description: Stanley Tretick, the Look magazine photographer known for his intimate pictures of the Kennedy White House, including one of John F. Kennedy Jr. as a toddler playing under his father's desk, died yesterday at a nursing home in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 77.

title: Politics and Public TV Don't Mix
description: Organizations that depend partly on public money to survive should not play politics -- or even appear to be playing politics. In an extraordinary display of carelessness, this simple and self-evident rule was breached by public television stations in Boston, New York, San Francisco and Washington, which allowed lists of their donors to be used by the Democratic Party. It appears the stations were not consciously trying to help the Democrats. Instead, in their zeal to raise money, they allowed brokers who specialize in mailing lists to rent lists of their donors to other groups that included the Democrats. In the process, they handed a weapon to Republican opponents of public broadcasting.

title: U.S. Frees African Woman Who Fled Genital Cutting
description: A 29-year-old woman from Ghana who fled her country, fearing genital cutting, and ended up in an immigration jail in the United States was released last night after more than two years in custody, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZYNSTEIN, SOLOMON
description: ZYNSTEIN-Solomon. Memorial service will be held for our beloved Solomon Zynstein late President of Masada Sarband on Tuesday July 20, 10am at Cedar Park cemetery Paramus, NJ Family and friends will be attending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARMORSTEIN, ROBERT JOEL
description: MARMORSTEIN-Robert Joel. Of Teaneck, New Jersey on July 17, 1999. Loving companion of Debra K. Stein. Devoted father of Daniel and Gary. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca. Services ''Gutterman Musicant'', 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 11:00 AM.

title: Easing Israel's 'Burden'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Early Start for Healthier Habits
description: Elementary schoolchildren who were taught healthy behaviors in a National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute preventive health trial are still practicing them three years later, according to a follow-up study that examined the children's food and fitness behaviors over time. The results appear in the current Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine.

title: Share Prices Move a Bit Lower, With Dow Losing 22.16
description: Stock prices staged a modest retreat for the first time in four sessions yesterday, despite a wave of glowing earnings reports from some of the nation's biggest corporations.

title: Thought Extinct, a Few Javan Rhinos Are Seen in Vietnam
description: The Javan rhinoceros of Vietnam, a species long thought extinct, has been found clinging to existence in extremely small numbers. After tracking footprints, scientists from the World Wildlife Fund have managed to photograph the rare animal, but its fate remains in doubt.

title: Restoration of State Tuition Aid Is Seen as Budget Nears Finish; In Albany, Legislature Convenes Conference Panel
description: The state budget will restore $134 million in tuition assistance for low-income college students that Gov. George E. Pataki had proposed cutting, but it is not likely to contain a major expansion of the state's anti-tobacco program, legislators and key aides said today.

title: LABOR UNREST IN METALS
description: Two workers were badly hurt and 200 arrested on a picket line near the Columbus Highveld Stainless Steel Plant in Middleburg, South Africa, during a strike over wages. Columbus's exports have been hurt by United States anti-dumping rulings. In another labor-management dispute in South Africa's metals industry, the Oryx Gold Mine was denied a court order forbidding a strike by 4,000 workers over plans to lay off 600 because of falling gold prices. Donald G. McNeil Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONOVET, MEYER H.
description: KRONOVET-Meyer H. Of Palm Beach, Florida and Great Neck, N.Y. Passed away on July 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Jane Platzek and Harriet Gross and father-in-law of Mitchell Gross. Cherished grandfather of Diane, Nancy and Alex Gross and Steven and Daniel Platzek. Adored brother of Juliette Hordes and Sol Kronovet, and the late Joseph, Milton, and Alfred Kronovet and Stella and Florence Abraham. Funeral services will be held on July 20th at 2:15pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAUVIN, ROBERT J.
description: CHAUVIN-Robert J. Suddenly on July 16, 1999. Loving husband of Nancy. Devoted father of David. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave., at 12th St., Garden City, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Services, 11am on Wednesday at the funeral home.

title: Kennedy Flight Ended in a Plunge, Radar Shows
description: The last flight of John F. Kennedy Jr. ended in a plunge at 10 times the normal rate for a descent, radar data released today showed, offering a possible explanation for searchers' failure to recover remains or significant pieces of wreckage from the crash.

title: CARREFOUR BUYS STORES
description: Carrefour S.A. of France bought 33 supermarkets in central Brazil, proceeding with an expansion plan that has made it the country's largest retailer. The acquisition gives Carrefour 81 supermarkets in Brazil as well as 67 of the giant discount stores known as hypermarkets. Carrefour bought the stores for an undisclosed amount from Mineirao, a company with a strong presence in Belo Horizonte, Brazil's third-largest city. The food-retailing industry in Brazil is consolidating as family-run chains have been squeezed by high interest rates. Larger companies with cash for expansion have gone on takeover sprees. Simon Romero

title: AFTER LAYOFFS, FIRST UNION WILL HIRE 2,000 TELLERS
description: After dismissing 5,850 employees to cut costs, the First Union Corporation will hire more than 2,000 tellers, after the sixth-largest United States bank realized its branch staff was not adequately serving customers. A First Union spokeswoman, Allison Rash, said the bank had been short by about 1,000 tellers for several months. The bank decided last week that it needed to hire another 1,000. There is a high turnover rate among tellers, she said. In March, the bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., said it was eliminating 5,850 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, to offset higher spending on businesses including capital markets, capital management and retail delivery. Of that number, fewer than 2 percent worked in branches, Ms. Rash said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIPPER, ABE
description: KNIPPER-Abe. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Esta, devoted son of Harry & Ita, dear brother of Benny, devoted son-inlaw of George & Fannie Hoffman. Services today, Tuesday, 1PM, Gutterman's Rockville Centre, NY In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Holocaust Museum, Washington, D.C.

title: Pack Up Your Secrets In an Old Kit Bag
description: The Opera Festival of New Jersey has developed into a small oasis during the summer opera drought. And now that it performs at the 900-seat McCarter Theater here, rather than in a school auditorium in somewhat more out-of-the-way Lawrenceville, it has a higher profile and draws audiences from New York and Philadelphia. This summer, the festival's 16th, it sold out almost all the performances on its three-work schedule: Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' and Dominick Argento's ''Postcard From Morocco.''

title: What's a Doctor to Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUSKIN, CELIA IRENE
description: DUSKIN-Celia Irene, of Brooklyn, NY. Born on July 30th, 1900. Died July 18th, 1999. She was 99 years old. Wife of the late Murray, mother of Florence Clarke, Lester and Kenneth Duskin, grandmother of 6, great-grandmother of 3, great great-grandmother of 1. Services at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, on Wednesday at 11:30 AM. Interment Ivandell Cemetery, Somers, NY.

title: People
description: * Gary VonKennel was named chief executive at Tracy-Locke Promotional Services Group, Dallas, part of the Diversified Agency Services unit of Omnicom Group. He succeeds Bruce Orr, who said in a statement that he was leaving to ''make a professional change.'' Mr. VonKennel had been president at Multi-Dimensional Marketing, Dallas, which is being acquired by Tracy-Locke for undisclosed terms.

title: Real Test for Teachers Comes in the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Raises Tax on Food From Europe
description: In the latest round of a continuing dispute with Europe, the United States today imposed tariffs intended to double the price of imports as familiar as Dijon mustard from France and as obscure as the ''guts, bladders and stomachs of animals (other than fish), whole and pieces thereof.''

title: Rider for an Italian Team Is Ousted for Using Drugs
description: In the first drug scare since this year's Tour de France began, an Italian team announced today that it had dismissed a rider after he told a race doctor that he used a cortisone substance to treat a knee injured in a crash last month.

title: Fighting Over Where to Say 'Amen'
description: The heroine of ''School Prayer: A Community at War'' is Lisa Herdahl, a woman who took on a Mississippi town in her fight against the religious messages broadcast daily over the local high school's intercom. But what makes this ''P.O.V.'' documentary more than a familiar celebration of civil liberties is its portrait of the townsfolk. Depending on a viewer's attitude toward such matters, they can be seen as a pious community trying to maintain deeply held values or as people who have done more Bible reading than reading of the Constitution.

title: Baffling Hepatitis Virus Is Isolated, Scientists Say
description: Italian researchers believe they have found the last major piece of the puzzle of blood-borne hepatitis.

title: Mankind On the Moon, 30 Years Later
description: Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins went forth in peace for all mankind, and came back with a bag of rocks. On July 20, 1969, Armstrong and Aldrin (right) made boot prints on the Moon and a giant impression in history. In the meantime, those rocks have changed planetary science. A brief history of Apollo 11, page 2.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Wild Wild West'' on June 30 and the Taking the Children column in Weekend on Friday misstated the movie's rating. It is PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), not PG (Parental guidance suggested).

title: Seikaly Tells Skeptical Nets He's Healthy
description: Rony Seikaly, the Nets center with so much promise but so little durability, is playing competitive basketball again. The 6-foot-11-inch Seikaly has been practicing with the Lebanese national team and plans to compete this week as his native country tries to qualify for the Asian championship finals. While this should provoke excitement on the Nets' part, Seikaly's recent history of injuries has the club tempering its reaction. Since being traded to the Nets on Feb. 19, 1998, Seikaly has missed 61 of a possible 79 games with injuries.

title: Real Test for Teachers Comes in the Classroom; Salary Weeds Out Best
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINTON TO PRESS SYRIAN TO REOPEN TALKS WITH ISRAEL
description: President Clinton pledged today that he would get in touch with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to emphasize that a ''golden opportunity'' lay before him to complete a peace deal with Israel. Mr. Clinton spoke as he and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel ended a series of meetings.

title: In Search of Lunar Water, Spacecraft Will Crash Land
description: NASA's Lunar Prospector is to crash land at the Moon's south pole on July 31 in a bid to find hard evidence of lunar ice, which might one day help sustain lunar colonies. The plucky spacecraft has already found hydrogen, the major component of water, at the lunar poles.

title: By Design; Not Your Average T-Shirt
description: The T-shirt may have originated as a man's undershirt, but it has evolved into a fashion item for women in a range of styles and colors. As such, it is a must-have basic for summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIBSON, ABRAHAM
description: LAIBSON-Abraham. July 18, 1999. Of Philadelphia, PA. Husband of the late Molly (nee Liebow), father of Dr. Peter Laibson and Audrey Wolf, father-in-law of Ruth Laibson and Dr. Gerald Wolf. Brother of Gertrude Rosen. Also survived by six grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Tuesday, 3:00 PM at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island. For information, contact Joseph Levine & Son at 215927-2700.

title: Patterns
description: Couture on Screen

title: Sampras's Role Cited In Davis Cup Defeat
description: Regrets, anyone?

title: Profit at Microsoft Rose More Than 60% in Quarter
description: With its business surging on several fronts, the Microsoft Corporation reported yesterday that its quarterly profits increased more than 60 percent in the quarter ended June 30, exceeding analyst expectations.

title: The Art of Not Choking
description: What often separates champions from also-rans in sports is the ability to close the deal, to finish strong so that certain victory does not slip away. This has as much to do with mental stamina -- an athlete's capacity to deal with nerves -- as it does with physical talent. Last weekend two gifted athletes faced similar high-pressure situations an ocean apart, with two entirely different outcomes. In Carnoustie, Scotland, an unknown Frenchman named Jean Van de Velde blew a seemingly insurmountable lead to lose the British Open. In Yankee Stadium, David Cone coolly blew away the final three Montreal batters to complete only the 16th perfect game in major league history and the third for a Yankee.

title: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL; Liberty's Top Scorer Is Proud of Versatility
description: Her game is as intricate as the braids in her hair, the ones that seem to start at her forehead, flow over her head and down to her shoulders like a waterfall. Vickie Johnson is a steady presence, a dependable player so remarkably hemmed into the Liberty fabric that her accomplishments sometimes seem unremarkable.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Hasidim who are seeking to move into Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to a billboard. Though it included some Hebrew expressions, the sign was in Yiddish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, BERTHA
description: DANIELS-Bertha. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late Aaron Daniels. Loving mother of Naomi Daniels Oltarsh (Kenneth). Much loved grandmother of Valerie Oltarsh McCarthy (Rob) and Frederic D. Oltarsh (Rosa), and loving great-grandmother of Alexander Carde Oltarsh. An exceptional woman of great intelligence and charity. Funeral services 12:15 PM, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Stalked by Deadly Virus, Papaya Lives to Breed Again
description: On the island of Hawaii, on what had been acres of withering, disease-infested plants, farmers this summer are walking among rows of lush green trees, harvesting the world's first crop of genetically engineered papayas.

title: Tests on Strep Vaccine Restart, Gingerly
description: For the first time in 20 years, medical researchers will soon test in people a vaccine against group A streptococcus, the bug that causes strep throat and rheumatic fever and is feared as the ''flesh-eating'' bacterium.

title: Man Held for 1980 Killings Outside a Gay Bar Seeks Release From Hospital
description: A man who shot and killed two people and wounded six others outside a Greenwich Village gay bar in 1980 is seeking to be released from the maximum security hospital where he has been held for the last 14 years.

title: Making Sense of the World Economy
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Profit Higher For Bank One And Mellon
description: The Bank One Corporation and the Mellon Bank Corporation reported higher second-quarter profits yesterday based on the rising stock market and increasing consumer spending.

title: Finally, We're Ready to Cut, but How?
description: It seems that a tax cut is inevitable. But no one, including the Republicans in Congress, seem to agree on the specifics. How much? Who should benefit? And how should alternative ways of cutting taxes be judged?

title: G.O.P. LEADERS TRY TO STEM A REVOLT OVER BIG TAX CUT
description: Republican leaders in the House scrambled today to head off a revolt by party moderates and avert a humiliating defeat on their signature issue of tax cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, GRETA
description: TANNENBAUM-Greta. On July 19, 1999. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Robert, Shari and David. Services Wednesday 10am from ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Blvd 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Camden Officials Ask State to Take Over Daily Operations of City
description: Noting that Camden's increasing dependence on state aid had effectively destroyed local political control, the City Council voted yesterday to press the state to take over day-to-day operations of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, ALPHONSUS
description: MAHER - Alphonsus, Brother O.S.F. On Monday July 19, 1999. Beloved son of the late Thomas and Margaret Maher. Brother of Jean DeFosse, Dorothy Haggerty and Robert Maher. Also survived by 14 nephews and nieces and 12 grand nephews and grand nieces. Wake Thursday 2-4:30PM and 79PM at St. Francis Center, Planting Field Road, Upper Brookville. Mass of Christian burial Friday 10:30AM at St. Francis Center. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, Long Island.

title: A New Variety Of Flower Child In Full Bloom; Music and the Internet Nourish a Counterculture
description: ''I don't know what a hippie was,'' said Benjy Eisen as he stood near a sink filled with dishes in a Winnebago parked at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on Thursday. ''I'm a kid of the 90's. In our generation we don't have Vietnam stories, we have Lollapalooza tales. Our war stories are about the car breaking down on the way to a show.''

title: Russia's Nuclear Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Vacations
description: It's that time. For the annual escape, a special section offers advice on what clothes to take and how to pack them, on cameras to carry, books to read, audiotapes to play in the car, videos to rent, sunless tan creams to apply, Web sites to beam up and cool stuff to show off on the beach. Also: tips for food lovers, for spouses and for the vacation-impaired (a k a workaholics). SECTION G

title: A Mother's Place Is . . .
description: The first thought of most new mothers is not, ''How quickly can I put this thing into day care?!'' More often it's the anxious, heartbreaking query, ''How long will I be able to take off from work?'' And even, ''Do I have to go back to work at all?''

title: In Greenwich Village, The Walks Never End
description: WITH its legendary indoor attractions -- Off Broadway theaters, art movie houses, jazz clubs, restaurants and idiosyncratic shops -- Greenwich Village is a neighborhood for all seasons. Yet as a 54-year resident, I cherish summer. That is when the West Village blossoms, literally and figuratively, revealing its great outdoors most intimately to walkers.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Deficit Sets a Record

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSOHN, LEONARD MAXWELL
description: MENDELSOHN-Leonard Maxwell, 83, of Lake Worth, FL. Our family gem. Beloved husband of Sylvia, cherished father of Paul and Shelley, Rosanne and Howard Cohen. Devoted grandfather of Dori and Michael, Hal and Julie, Eric, & David. Great-grandfather of Emma, Hope, and Richard. Dear brother and brother-in-law of Felix & Mona Mendelsohn, Evelyn and Abe White, Bernice Pollock, Marty and Norma Freedman, Thelma and Bernie Teitelbaum. Services will be held Thursday, July 22, 1999, 12:00 PM, at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ROBERT H.
description: MOORE-Robert H. (Skipp). Age 63. Passed away July 18, 1999. National Black Theatre's staff and friends mourn his untimely death. We will sorely miss his guiding force as Real Estate Project Director and Consultant for our Harlembased Theatre Arts Complex on 125th Street and Fifth Avenue. His dedication to the success of NBT's Real Estate Project can only be surpassed by his commitment to service and good will. Services will be held Thursday, July 22, 11AM at Hanson Place Methodist Church, 144 Saint Felix Place, Bklyn, N.Y.

title: End of Sales Tax on Clothes Is Delayed in Budget Talks
description: Lawmakers negotiating details of the state budget have agreed to resurrect the Quick Draw video lottery game, and to postpone the elimination of sales tax on clothing for three months, legislators and aides to the Governor said today.

title: Justice Department Approves Merger of Allied Waste and Browning-Ferris
description: The Justice Department gave its approval yesterday to one of the largest mergers in the trash hauling business on the condition that the combining companies, Allied Waste Industries and Browning-Ferris Industries, sell operations in 18 metropolitan areas in 13 states, from Massachusetts to California.

title: Mysteries in the Mirror of a Dutch Master's Soul
description: For more than 40 years Rembrandt made a point of looking into the mirror and recording what he saw. As a result, more than for any other major artist, self-portraits came to represent an important part of his life's work. They show his development and virtuosity as a painter. They also chronicle his aging until shortly before his death at 63 in 1669. But why did he paint himself so often?

title: Americans Show Faith in the Power of Green Tea
description: THIS summer, iced green tea has become the beverage of choice for the health conscious, threatening to leave such standards as black tea, coffee and even white wine in the dust. While some drinkers are no doubt drawn to green tea for the novelty of it, most are probably hoping that it will reduce their risk of certain diseases, including cancer and arthritis.

title: Who Needs to Get Away When Manhattan's Right Here?
description: IT is embarrassing in some New York circles not to go away for the summer. But since moving to the city in 1974, and settling in a vista-rich perch of an apartment on Riverside Drive in Manhattan, I have found leaving New York depressing. That's why returning is always sheer elation, especially driving over the George Washington Bridge and catching sight of that gorgeous expanse of river, cliffs and sculptured stone buildings I call home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, JEAN F.
description: SHERR-Jean F. On July 19, 1999. Age 79. Beloved wife of Abraham I. Sherr. Loving mother of Rita, Barbara and Alan. Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, July 21 at 2PM. Interment to follow at Salem Field Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARNEILLE, LENORE SCULLIN
description: DARNEILLE-Lenore Scullin. At home, Bridgehampton, NY, July 19. Born in St. Louis, October 8, 1906 to Charles and Stella Scullin, brought up in St. Louis and Washington, DC, moved to NY in 1926, married to Floyd G. Blair until 1952. Beloved mother of Mary Lenore Blair and the late David Gilbert Blair. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Bladen Jackson Darneille of Washington, DC, and Bridgehampton, NY, where they spent their summers. Memorial service Friday, July 23, 11:30AM, Church of the Queen of the Holy Rosary, Bridgehampton. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alumni Development Office, Miss Porter's School, 60 Main St., Farmington, CT. 06032, or the Choral Society of the Hamptons, P.O. Box 1031, Bridgehampton, New York 11932.

title: Sovereignty for Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks to Get First Look at First Pick
description: Frederic Weis finally gets his Knicks indoctrination this week. Against a collection of draft picks, free agents and journeymen, Weis, the team's first-round draft pick, will lead New York into the Boston Shootout Summer League.

title: LOAN FOR LOEWEN
description: A bankruptcy court has approved a request by the Loewen Group Inc. of Canada, one of the largest funeral home operators in North America, to draw on a $200 million survival loan arranged by First Union National Bank. Now Loewen, which filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States and Canada on June 1, must get creditors to agree on its reorganization plan. Timothy Pritchard

title: In America; The Death of A Child
description: As I watched the grim, relentless coverage of the Kennedy-Bessette tragedy over the weekend I thought of Dr. Irwin Redlener, who is president of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Garish, Ghastly and Glorious
description: It was a dark and stormy night.

title: BASKETBALL; Robinson To Rescue Once More For Liberty
description: When it matters most, Crystal Robinson appears like a sea gull, swooping in to rescue the Liberty when the offense looks as if it is about to strap itself into the dysfunction of seasons past. She darts through screens, catches the basketball, sets her feet and then jumps, her body as straight as a pencil. More times than not, especially in the clutch, the ball goes softly through the net.

title: Adelphi President Likely to Be New CUNY Chief
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have selected Matthew Goldstein, the president of Adelphi University and a former head of Baruch College, as their choice to be the next Chancellor of the City University of New York, the two officials said in a joint statement yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, LEE CUNNINGHAM
description: LISMAN - Lee Cunningham, passed away on July 19, 1999 after a long illness. She is survived by her loving husband, Richard D. Lisman & two devoted daughters, Hilary Bogert & Cyrena Fink; two granddaughters, Brigitte Jeanne and Chloe Lawrence and five brothers, A. Brean Murray, Sean, Noel, Kevin & Grant Cunningham, numerous nieces and nephews, & mother-in-law Sylvia Lisman. Services to be held at St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton, NY. Friday, July 23 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Rogosin Kidney Center of New York Hospital or to The St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton, New York.

title: Patients and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTIAN, ROBERT
description: CHRISTIAN-Robert, on July 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Ilyne, April, and Robyn. He lived his life full with honor and love.

title: Hallmark Cards Expands Roster
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. expanded its agency roster yesterday by awarding a major branding assignment with undisclosed billings to Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.

title: Sports of The Times; Clemens Is Looking For His Keys
description: FIRST came a morning schmooze with Regis and Kathie Lee, and then came the key to New York, New York. At City Hall yesterday, it occurred to an appreciative David Cone that maybe the glad-handing had gone too far.

title: House Defies President on Education Bill
description: Bucking President Clinton's angry protests and threat of a veto, the House tonight approved a $2 billion bill for teacher training and recruitment that did not require, as the President wished, that more than $1 billion be devoted to his initiative to reduce class sizes by hiring an additional 100,000 teachers nationwide.

title: A Lot of Degradation and a Little Bit of Humor
description: The desperation is anything but quiet in ''In Arabia, We'd All Be Kings,'' a harrowing new play by Stephen Adly Guirgis that is being given a menacing staging under Philip Seymour Hoffman's direction by the Labyrinth Theater Company.

title: What the Fashionistas Choose to Fold, Pack and Carry
description: PREPPING for a week in the sun is a snap for Jane Schub. The president of Bubbe's Best, a children's toiletry company, Mrs. Schub rattled through her drill with a Girl Scout's efficiency. ''I take everything I'm interested in packing, which is almost always black,'' she explained. ''I put it on the children's settee, which is also upholstered in black, and then I containerize everything. My underwear is black, and I put that in a black mesh bag. My shoes go in black grosgrain shoe bags that I had specially made. And my suitcase -- that's black, too.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLETUTTI, JOSEPH F.
description: VALLETUTTI-Joseph F., Dr., 74 years old. Humanitarian, human services professional, philanthropist and leader in the Italian-American community. Died after a long, courageous battle against cancer. He was born in Brooklyn and graduated from Franklin K. Lane High School. After service in the Navy during World War II, he completed bachelor and advanced degrees at NYU. He received an honorary Doctorate in Commercial Science from St. John's University. He was CEO of Valletutti Associates, President of Americans of Italian Descent of New York, Executive Director of the Italian American Center for Urban Affairs, Trustee of St. John's University's Italian Cultural Institute and recruitment officer in Padula, Italy for the Frank Valente Scholarship Program at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. He was recipient of the International Gold Medal from St. John's University and the first Gold Medal for Education and Culture awarded to an American by the Italian Government. He is survived by his wife Mildred, son Peter, daughter Joya, his twin Dr. Angelo Valletutti and brother Dr. Peter J. Valletutti. Visiting hours at Lloyd Home, Bayside, Wednesday and Thursday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9. Funeral Mass Friday 9:45 at St. Robert Bellarmine Church in Bayside. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Italian Chair, Italian Cultural Institute, St. John's University, Jamaica, New York 11439.

title: HEALTHEON TO PROVIDE ON-LINE PRESCRIPTIONS FOR MERCK
description: The Healtheon Corporation, which links doctors, insurers and patients through the Internet, said yesterday that it would provide on-line prescription services to customers of Merck & Company's pharmacy benefits unit. The unit, Merck-Medco, the largest American pharmaceutical benefit provider, will help pay for the development of an Internet-based service that will allow doctors to see a patient's medical history and the drugs available for treatment, Healtheon said. Shares of Healtheon rose $4.625, to $63.125, while shares of Merck fell $1.9375, to $68.6875.

title: Europe's Rights Court Taking On Increasingly Sensitive Cases
description: Tucked away in an ultramodern building, the European Court of Human Rights is beginning to take on high-profile cases that are making it more visible to the 800 million people -- from Iceland to Vladivostok, Russia -- that it is meant to represent.

title: Maneuver by Kennedy's Plane Suggests He Was Disoriented
description: John F. Kennedy Jr. twice turned away from Martha's Vineyard just before his plane began plunging toward the sea on Friday night, Federal investigators said today, leading several authorities on aviation to conclude that he had become lost or disoriented.

title: Chip Maker Has Quarterly Profit Gain
description: Texas Instruments Inc., a leading maker of semiconductors for cellular phones, said today that its second-quarter earnings had more than doubled, fueled by soaring demand for its chips.

title: But Couture Outfits Grab Public's Attention : Wild, and Unwearable
description: PARIS  The Phantom Menace has struck high fashion with designers at this week's couture shows divided between attention-grabbing futurism and clothes for the terrestrial world.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell more than 5 percent after a Venezuelan oil official signaled that OPEC could soon raise output, capping a rally in prices. In New York, crude oil for August delivery fell $1.07, to $19.37 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASKA, MARGARET FORD
description: TASKA-Margaret Ford. Of NYC died July 13, 1999. She is survived by her husband, her brother and two nephews. A memorial service will be held in the fall. A graduate of Connecticut College for Women, Mrs., Taska worked for the Office of War Information in London, in Luxembourg and in Germany. Upon returning to NY after the war's end, she joined the newly created CARE where she became executive secretary to the successive heads of that organization until her retirement in 1986. She was also active in the League for the Hard of Hearing.

title: Cubans Now Choosing Smugglers Over Rafts
description: They used to be called balseros Spanish for ''rafters'' -- after the rickety crafts of plywood, inner tubes and empty oil drums they launched from the beaches of Cuba, praying that the homemade boats would hold together long enough to cross the treacherous Florida Straits.

title: Kennedy 'Curse' or Needless Risk-Taking?
description: To the Editor:

title: Picking Up The Pieces In a Basement Jam Session
description: Some arrived at 6 P.M. to line up for tickets, others showed up when doors opened at 9; some were told the show started at 10:30, and others came as late as midnight and even 2 A.M. They all had to wait until nearly 3:30 yesterday morning, when the Artist Formerly Known as Prince came onstage at Life for a small club show that was first announced earlier that day. His first words: ''Do you mind if we take a few minutes to tune up?''

title: Certification Test Can't Predict a Teacher's Talent
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Side Of Eggplant
description: EGGPLANT is so strongly associated with the cuisines of Italy and southern France that no matter what the cooking method, it is usually prepared with olive oil and garlic. But with a few changes, you can make a relish that turns a plain boneless chicken breast into an unusual and appealing dish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDEL, SUSAN
description: LUDEL-Susan. Loving daughter of Kinny (Corinne) and the late Wolly Ludel, sister of Jackie, Bill and Tracy. Aunt of Sophie and Wally. Memorial at Campbell Funeral Home, 81st and Madison Sunday July 25 at 3PM.

title: The South Meets Jamaica in a Small Spot in Chelsea
description: PLANNING a rendezvous at Maroons can be confusing. This new restaurant is divided into a small, handsome dining room and a separate homey lounge. Unless you realize this, you could spend 10 minutes waiting for your friends in one room, only to discover they'd been sitting in the other, accessible only by stepping out onto 16th Street and walking past a stoop to a second door.

title: Home Builders Say Outlook Is Dimmer
description: The expectations of United States home builders fell in July, as mortgage rates continued to climb, according to the monthly survey of the National Association of Home Builders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUM, STEPHEN
description: CRUM-Stephen. On July 20, 1999 of Kinnelon. Beloved husband of Barbara Ann (nee Moussab). Loving father of Matthew, Jeffrey and Caitlin. Dear brother of Cindy Porco. Funeral services will begin on Friday 9:00 AM from the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, 781 Newark Pompton Turnpike at Route 23, Pompton Plains and a Mass will be celebrated 10:00 AM at St. George Orthodox Church, Little Falls. Interment will follow at Our Lady of Magnificat Church Cemetery, Kinnelon. Friends may call Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Donations to the Kinnelon Soccer Club or Compassionate Care Hospice, 1373 Broad Street, Clifton would be appreciated by the family.

title: From Century 21, a promotion of 21st-century baseball.
description: IN unusual promotional marketing effort co-sponsored by Major League Baseball and a big corporate advertiser, Century 21, will try turning tradition on its head by turning the clock ahead.

title: The Midas Touch
description: Chicken droppings would turn into tax breaks under one of the dozens of narrow provisions in the tax bills before Congress that benefit one particular interest or another. Page A18.

title: Drug Makers Reporting Mixed Results During Second Quarter
description: The world's largest pharmaceutical companies are expected to notch some healthy gains in second-quarter earnings this week, but analysts are not convinced that will be enough to rouse investor interest.

title: TV NOTES
description: Strength Gains For Wrestling

title: Stone Asset Fraud Case Widens
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan has unsealed indictments against four more people in connection with accusations of stock fraud manipulation at Stone Asset Inc., an unregistered broker-dealer where, the authorities say, about 200 investors were defrauded of about $1.5 million.

title: Mourners Pay Tribute In Tribeca
description: They came with votive candles, handwritten poems, American flags and video cameras. Since last Saturday, when the news broke that John F. Kennedy Jr. was missing over the sea off Martha's Vineyard, people have been flocking to the cobblestone street in lower Manhattan where Mr. Kennedy and his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, lived during their three years of marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, ALAN
description: RAPOPORT-Alan, on July 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Arlene. Loving father of Michael, Alyssa and Lauren. Devoted son of Julius. Dear brother of Leonard and Gladys,and Philip and Debbie. Cherished uncle and friend to many. He will be missed. Service Thursday, 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Just Don't Call It Dining
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, EDNA
description: ROGERS-Edna. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Edna Rogers, and offer their deepest sympathy to her husband, Arthur Rogers, her children and the entire Rogers Family. Alpine Country Club Michael Bergstein, President

title: And Even Ice-Cube Size Counts
description: SHAKEN or stirred? It's a question that sounds like the ultimate in sophistication. But the truth is that James Bond, despite his smug smile, knew only the half of it. Cocktail-making technique, a highly evolved skill, is as important to bartenders as a drink's recipe. And often it's the technique -- including the style of the shaker and the size of the ice cubes -- that distinguishes one great mixologist from another.

title: Smokers Are Both Used and Abused
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAUS, NORTON T.
description: FAUS-Norton T. Of Boca Raton, FL and Darien, CT on July 19, 1999. Husband of June Northrop Faus. Graduate Stanford University in 1931 and received his MBA from Harvard in 1933. Retired Presiding Partner of MacKay-Shields Economics, Inc in 1973. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Interment private.

title: Night Manager of Times Sq. Hotel Is Killed
description: The night manager of a hotel in Times Square was fatally stabbed inside the hotel last night by a co-worker who then ran off, the police said. The victim, Ali Ezari, 31, was stabbed in the head and stomach about 8:30 P.M. after an argument and died at St. Vincent's Hospital about an hour later, the police said.

title: Officer Wounded by Gun He Found in Air Vent
description: A police officer was shot in the hand yesterday morning when he reached into an air vent on a Bronx rooftop that turned out to be a hiding place for a handgun, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AEGIS GROUP P.L.C., London, named Douglas Flynn chief executive effective Sept. 1, succeeding Crispin Davis, who is leaving to join Reed Elsevier P.L.C. as chief executive. Mr. Flynn is now managing director of News International P.L.C., part of News Corporation.

title: PUB DEAL
description: The battle over Allied Domecq's 3,500 British pubs has finally produced a deal between Allied Domecq and Punch Taverns Group Ltd. The $4.3 billion deal would make Punch Taverns Britain's second-largest bar owner, after Nomura International P.L.C. The agreement followed six weeks of wrangling during which the rival suitor Whitbread P.L.C. withdrew because of regulatory concerns. Analysts said they did not rule out new bids from other potential buyers. Punch Taverns, which is privately held, said it would finance the deal in cash, assumed debt and shares in Bass P.L.C., which has pledged to buy as many as 650 of the Allied Domecq pubs. Alan Cowell

title: Nasdaq Plunge Of 3.5% Leads Broad Retreat
description: Stock prices declined sharply yesterday on worries that conditions cannot become much better -- and could become worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIPPER, ABE
description: KNIPPER-Abe. The Board of Governors and members of Inwood Country CLub record with sorrow, the passing of Abe Knipper. Beloved husband of Helen and we extend deepest sympathy to the family. Robert Scharf, Pres. David Gruber, Secy

title: In Case You Wondered, Giuliani Likes Baseball
description: Three weeks ago today, New York's No. 1 baseball fan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, was playing catch with youngsters on the infield at Shea Stadium after announcing that Chase Manhattan Bank would donate 125,000 baseball tickets to youth organizations and foster children.

title: STERIS TO GET ISOTRON OF BRITAIN FOR $110 MILLION
description: The Steris Corporation, a maker of sterilization products, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Isotron P.L.C. of Britain for $110 million. Steris, which makes sterilization systems for health care, research, food and industrial companies, said the purchase of Isotron would help it expand into Europe. Steris has operations in the United States and Canada. Isotron earned $6.4 million on $20.9 million in revenue for the year ended June 30, 1998. Steris earned $65.5 million, or 93 cents a share, for the year ended March 31, 1998. Steris, based in Mentor, Ohio, expected to close the purchase in 30 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EUGENE J.
description: COHEN-Eugene J., M.D. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of New York Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Medical College of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Eugene J. Cohen. A leader in the field of endocrinology, Dr. Cohen's distinguished career spanned over 60 years. His commitment and dedication resulted in advances in medical research, education and patient care. We join with all those who knew him in mourning his loss and extend our deepest condolences to his family. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Stephen & Suzanne Weiss Dean Weill Medical College of Cornell University David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman, President & CEO New York Presbyterian Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTENTHAL, LINDA
description: BERTENTHAL-Linda. On July 20th, 1999. Loving mother, grandmother, sister and friend. Services are on Thursday at noon at The Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Pressed, Bush Identifies Some of His Biggest Financial Backers
description: Bowing to criticism from several groups, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has revealed the identities of some of the ''Pioneers'' who have raised at least $100,000 each for his deep-pocketed Presidential campaign.

title: TEREX TO BUY RAYTHEON UNIT FOR $170 MILLION
description: The Terex Corporation, a maker of heavy-duty trucks, cranes and earth-moving equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cedarapids Inc., a subsidiary of the Raytheon Company, for $170 million in cash. Cedarapids, with annual sales of $200 million, makes equipment used in road construction, including crushing and screening machinery and asphalt pavers. The company has operations in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and Glasgow, Mo. Terex, of Westport, Conn., is in the midst of a program to expand its range of products and build its presence overseas. Raytheon, the big Lexington, Mass., military electronics company, said the sale would allow it to focus on its core business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERA, ISAAC
description: CHERA-Isaac. We are deeply saddened by the loss of Isaac Chera. He was a patriarchal leader of his family, possessed of great compassion, wisdom and humor. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Edward Labaton, Goodkind Labaton Rudoff & Sucharow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, CLARA
description: GORDON-Clara. On July 20, 1999. Beloved mother of David and Maury. Loving mother-in-law of Wendy. Cherished grandmother of Barri and Spencer. Loving sister of Sylvia Orloff and Alvin Lorberfeld. Services Wednesday 12 noon from ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: 10 Gizmos You Simply Cannot Do Without at the Beach
description: WHEN a United States Marine storms a beach he totes a pack weighing up to 80 pounds. It is loaded with everything from extra socks to survival gear to ready-to-eat meals. This means the Marines carry only slightly fewer accouterments than the average American family does when it storms a beach. Well, the following won't help you pare down, and some items are pricey. But this is fin de siecle America, when competing armies on beaches from Rehoboth to Redondo will be using the latest and the best. Don't be left behind.

title: Radio Ad Campaign Attacks Hiring Law
description: Opponents of legislation that would require school districts to notify unions before hiring private companies for noneducational services started a radio campaign yesterday to defeat the measure.

title: Ex-Teacher To Head School Board In Newark
description: After four years of bitter grumbling by politicians, educators and parents who said that the state takeover of the Newark public schools had spawned an administration of carbetbaggers, the Board of Education has selected a former math teacher who has worked in Newark for more than 30 years as its next superintendent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They know they have to make it to land. When they're getting this close, they're desperate. We can expect desperate people to do desperate things.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F. JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F. Jr. The Board of Directors and staff of the Consortium for Worker Education mourn the passing of a great friend to the working people of New York, John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and his sister-in-law Lauren G. Bessette. John Kennedy Jr. worked closely with the Consortium and its member unions, the CSEA, Health Care Local 1199, and District Council 1707 to establish the Kennedy Fellows Program at the City University of New York. This program provides advanced skills for union members specializing in the developmentally disabled. Throughout the process of developing this prpogram, he exhibited dedication, a thorough understanding of the needs of all workers, and a profound respect for all those he encountered. Intern, his commitment earned the respect of those he met and helped. His legacy, through the Kennedy Fellows Program, will continue to bring greater recognition to the outstanding contribution of our direct care union members by enhancing their skills in delivering services to individuals with developmental disabilities. Barry Feinstein, Chairman Jay Mazur, President Irwin Polishook, Treasurer Edward Malloy, Secretary Vice Presidents: Jack Caffey, James Conigliaro, Josephine LeBeau, Dennis Rivera, Barry Liebowitz, M.D., Anthony Rumore, Damaso Seda, Peter Ward, Philip Wheeler Joseph McDermott, Exec Director

title: Donaldson Posts 16.5% Earnings Gain
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings unexpectedly climbed nearly 16.5 percent as merger advisory, securities underwriting and trading income all rose.

title: Belgrade Officials Plan Back Pay for Protesting Reservists
description: In an effort to assuage popular grievances and to stop a wave of protests by unpaid army reservists, the Yugoslav Government will authorize overdue payments to reservists, pensioners and teachers in a meeting on Wednesday, senior officials said today.

title: 7 Charged in Drug Scheme Said to Use Hasidic Couriers
description: In their black hats, dark suits and sidecurls, the stream of young Hasidic men flying home from Europe seemed unlikely to raise the suspicions of United States Customs officials.

title: Lycos Is Starting an Internet Venture Fund
description: Lycos Inc., the Internet search site, plans to form a $70 million venture-capital fund to invest in start-up Internet companies that may provide content and services to its Web sites.

description: TAKING a vacation is a lot like having great sex: those who can, do it, anytime and anywhere. Those who can't, read about it, anytime and anywhere.

description: Qwest Communications International Inc. will pay U S West Inc. $850 million if it terminates a $45.2 billion merger agreement, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

title: The City's Epicenter of Self-Expression
description: THE East Village may be one of the last neighborhoods that you would think clears out in the summer. Despite the semiregular expressions of alarm at the arrival of yuppies, it has not become a land of pied-a-terre populated by country-home owners or Hamptons shareholders. Generally, residents are there year-round.

title: Organ Transplant Panel Urges a Broad Sharing of Livers
description: In an effort to settle a bitter economic and scientific feud over who should get donated organs, a panel of independent experts recommended today that scarce livers be distributed across broad geographic areas so that the sickest patients receive them first.

title: A Farewell to Lemons
description: To the Editor:

description: FRANK-F. Alexander. On July 19, 1999 of Solebury Township, PA and New York City, New York. Brother of Ruth F. Cook of Hamden, CT. Also survived by two nieces, two nephews, eight grand nieces and nephews and his longtime friend and companion John Stuart Burns. He was an attorney and president of Citizens Savings Bank, NY, NY. Memorial services will be announced at a later date by Leaver-Cable Funeral Home.

description: GROSS-Ludwik, M.D. On July 19, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Augusta Gross, loving father-in-law of Leslie B. title: Hugh Fish, 76, Who Made Thames So Clean the Salmon Came Back
description: Hugh Fish, a British environmental engineer whose love of pristine rivers helped clean up the Thames -- clean enough for salmon to thrive after 150 years -- died on May 26 in Wallingford, Oxfordshire. He was 76.

title: Beijing Detains Leaders of Sect, Watchdog Says
description: In what could be the start of a broad crackdown, dozens of leaders of the Buddhist Law spiritual movement were detained by the police today in 14 Chinese cities, according to a Hong Kong-based human rights group.

title: Words That Make the Miles Fly By, Even in Traffic
description: IN Sag Harbor, you used to be able to count on hearing ''Moby-Dick,'' unexpurgated, over the course of the Labor Day weekend. The former whaling village on the north side of the South Fork of Long Island has more than the average number of literary types among its townspeople, and as many as could crammed themselves into a comfortably shabby secondhand bookstore called Canio's and listened as others took turns reading Melville aloud. There was great pleasure to be had as an adult being read to, not least in having time enough to be caught up in the tale. I always stopped in, if only for a chapter or two.

title: Panel Wants Freshmen Eligible in Basketball
description: A 27-member panel recommended to the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday that freshmen continue to be eligible to play basketball. But the college presidents, athletic directors and the retired North Carolina coach Dean Smith, who made up the panel, recommended that the N.C.A.A. tighten the rules governing freshmen and also reward colleges that have high graduation rates for basketball players.

title: Jury Awards $5.7 Million In Police Killing Of a Hostage
description: A Manhattan jury awarded $5.7 million yesterday to the family of a woman killed by police officers who fired 29 shots at an armed bank robber who used her as a human shield during a 1993 Upper West Side gun battle.

Norman was loved and admired by all and will be greatly missed. Funeral will be held Wednesday, July 21, at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, N.Y. 10:30 AM, Family will sit Shiva at his home in Far Rockaway. Louis J. Septimus & Co.

Where can you find transportation and rooms at reasonable prices and places that haven't nearly shut down because of foul weather or because they're not popular at that time of year?
