title: ENRON TO EXCHANGE STAKE IN UNIT FOR PROPERTIES
description: The Enron Corporation, the largest energy trading and marketing company, said yesterday that it would exchange 76 percent of its ownership in the Enron Oil and Gas Company, a stake valued at $1.2 billion, for properties that Enron Oil and Gas owns in India and China. Enron said the move is part of a plan to ''establish E.O.G. as a widely held public company that will be independent of Enron.'' Enron owns 53.5 percent of Enron Oil and Gas, an oil exploration and production company, and gets about 3 percent of its revenue and 7 percent of its profit from that interest. Shares of Enron Oil and Gas fell 68.75 cents, to $20.4375, while Enron shares rose 25 cents, to $85.5625.

title: Microsoft Is No Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: A Summit in Central Park; Boulder Gives Climbers a Taste of the Mountain
description: Climbers are drawn to steep, forbidding places: Mount Everest (29,028 feet) in the Himalayas. Aconcagua (22,834 feet) in the Andes. The Matterhorn (14,700 feet) in the Alps. The Harlem boulder (13 feet) in New York City.

title: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY 11 DEALERSHIPS FOR $54 MILLION
description: Sonic Automotive Inc., the third-largest publicly traded auto retailer, agreed to buy 11 dealerships for $54 million in cash and stock as it builds its network in Las Vegas, Nev. and the southern United States. Sonic said it would pay about $11.2 million in convertible preferred and common stock and the rest in cash. Acquisition of the dealerships, which had combined revenue of about $285 million this year, is expected to be completed by year's end.

title: Looking for a Camera? Focus on the Point-and-Shoots
description: WHEN it comes to cameras to tote on vacation, think small. For travel, or for street scenes back home, today's point-and-shoot cameras, which are inexpensive and convenient, produce pictures as good as the big, expensive cameras we once lugged around.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARGAND, GREGORY PAUL
description: ARGAND-Gregory Paul. Beloved son. 12/05/50-7/21/83. A joy has taken flight. Mom and Dad

title: The Albany Budget Minuet
description: Finally the New York State Legislature has resumed work on its budget, now 112 days late, with a $73 billion spending plan that was mapped out the old-fashioned way, behind closed doors. Last year's open negotiations were deemed a failure by the lawmakers after Gov. George Pataki, Zorro-like, slashed through much of the Legislature's early effort. Now, declaring that their process is more like Washington's, the Governor, Assembly Speaker and Senate majority leader have adopted a structure that cedes only small changes to 10 conference committees open to the public.

title: Russia Frees Journalist Who Exposed Nuclear Dumping
description: A crusading Russian journalist was freed from a Vladivostok jail today after a military court ruled that he had misused his office but was entitled to amnesty.

title: Seymour Tilles, 74, Management Consultant
description: Dr. Seymour Tilles, a vice president and founding partner of the Boston Consulting Group who also helped found the Technion Institute of Management in Israel, died June 29 at a hospital in Boston. He was 74 years old. He died of leukemia, his wife, Gloria, said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  INGERSOLL, ROBERT

Dennis Middlebrooks and Warren Allen Smith Free Thinking Activists of N.Y.

title: Going, Going, Gone; Perfecting the Art Of the Tasty Escape
description: ONE should eat to live, not live to eat, or so the saying goes. But by profession and by inclination, I do both. Eating dominates my daily schedule, most of my waking thoughts and nearly all of my writing life. So, what do I do on vacation? I eat.

description: Ward 6 in the hospital here could not be much more crowded: Bethsheba Bosibori, 52, lay in bed with a woman she did not know, with another sitting at her feet and a third coughing on a mat on the floor. In all, 113 women were packed into a room with 23 beds.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. liked the fried chicken, Sammy Davis Jr. and Cab Calloway the corn muffins and catfish. And the late Mayor Harold Washington held legendary strategy sessions over the baby back ribs and black-eyed peas.

title: Philip Morris Food Business Offsets Soft Tobacco Sales
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest tobacco company, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings, excluding charges, rose nearly 3 percent as its Kraft food unit increased sales and cut costs, softening declines in cigarette profits.

title: Taiwan's New Doctrine Unintelligible in Chinese
description: Even with all the justifications, interpretations and clarifications that Taiwan's leaders have offered up in recent days to try to explain their new relationship to the Chinese mainland, one thing stands out: They can't say it in Chinese.

title: $21.3 Billion Deficit For May Is a Record; Markets Feel the Heat : U.S. Reports Unexpected Widening of Trade Gap
description: NEW YORK  The U.S. trade deficit ballooned to a record $21.34 billion in May, the government reported Tuesday, a bigger-than-expected gap that called into question America's ability to finance its appetite for imports.

In contrast, the dollar climbed against the Japanese yen after the Bank of Japan sold yen for dollars through the Federal Reserve.

title: Federal Inspections of Hospitals Are Badly Flawed, Harsh New Report Says
description: Federal investigators said today that hospital inspectors were generally unable to detect substandard care or to identify incompetent doctors because the inspectors ''strive to foster a collegial atmosphere'' and do not aggressively scrutinize practices that could threaten patients' lives.

description: Pilot House Associates, the investment vehicle for Amos B. Hostetter, the cable television pioneer, plans to announce today that it has agreed to invest $5 million in Resort Sports Network Inc., a small, private provider of recreational sports programming on television and the Internet, executives close to the deal said yesterday. Pilot House Associates, based in Boston, is to receive a 20 percent stake in Resort Sports, which is based in Portland, Me., and runs 35 cable television stations that provide weather and recreation information in 56 vacation communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARTH, HAROLD
description: HOWARTH-Harold. A longtime resident of Rowayton, CT died at home on Saturday, July 17. An accountant, he was a retired partner of Ernst & Young, and an active member of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT. Born in Bolton, England in 1920, he immigrated with his family to New Bedford, Massachusetts as a small child. The son of the late William and Hester Howarth, he is survived by his elder brother William of San Diego, California, a nephew, Dr. Jonathan Kelley, and many friends, and was predeceased by his longtime companion, Donovan Hogan. He attended local schools in New Bedford, won a scholarship to Boston University, where he continued in graduate school, and later taught. On the eve of World War II, he was commissioned in the U.S. Army, and served in the Pacific in New Guinea and the Philippines as an artillery officer on the staff of General Rhett Stuart. Discharged from active duty as a major, he was an active reservist for some years. He joined Leidersdorf which later merged with what was then Ernst and Whinney and served until his retirement in 1979. A gifted classical pianist, in his later years he discovered a talent as an amateur actor with St. Luke's Players. Since retirement, he had taken an annual month-long trip to England and remained a devoted Anglophile. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Book of Remembrance, 1864 Post Road, Box 3128, Darien, CT 06820 or to Boston University, Attn. Stewardship, 599 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA 02215.

title: World Trade Group Agrees On Split Term for Director
description: Members of the World Trade Organization resolved a prolonged and bitter dispute over who would be its next leader today by agreeing that the two finalists will share the job in consecutive three-year terms, with the New Zealand candidate going first, followed by his Thai rival.

Memorial Service at St. William Roman Catholic Church, Naples, July 31 at 11 AM. Burial in Ireland. For more information contact Fuller Funeral Home 941-592-1611.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPPRODT, PATRICIA O'BRIEN
description: ZIPPRODT-Patricia O'Brien. On July 17, 1999. Three time Tony award winning theater costume designer and prominent ballet, opera and film costume designer. Wife of the late Colonel Robert E. O'Brien, Jr. Survived by her beloved sister, Constance ZipprodtZonka and six nieces and nephews, Kathy, Roger, Lynn, Daniel, Heidi and Milo, children of sisters Constance Zipprodt-Zonka and the late Barbara Zipprodt-Pavlik. Services Saturday, July 24, at Trinity Episcopal Church, Upperville, VA. Interment private. Memorial service in New York at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, ROSE
description: SILVERMAN-Rose. On July 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Isidore. Loving mother of Ilene Montana and Jane Meyers. Dear grandmother of John and Nicole. Cherished aunt. Service Wednesday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Arthur Katz, 91, the Maker Of Corgi Toy Cars, Is Dead
description: Arthur Katz, whose Corgi brand of miniature cars thrilled a generation of children, many of whom became collectors as adults, died on June 25 near his home in London. He was 91.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Colombian guerrilla war referred incorrectly to a Liberal Party politician assassinated in 1948. He was a candidate for President; he did not hold the office.

title: Smokers Are Both Used and Abused
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Kennedy Effect: In Publishing . . .

title: In Dotel, Phillips May Have Answer
description: For nearly two years, he has been touted as the top pitching prospect in an organization devoid of them. On Monday night at Camden Yards, the Mets right-hander Octavio Dotel demonstrated why.

title: Yahoo Completes Deal
description: Yahoo Inc. said today that it had completed its of Broadcast.com Inc. for $5.05 billion in stock and options, adding audio and video programming. Yahoo will take a third-quarter charge of about $22 million for the acquisition. The company will exchange 0.7722 Yahoo share for each share of the Dallas-based Broadcast.com and will convert Broadcast.com options into 5.12 million Yahoo options.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Verge Comes to Town

title: In Gamblers' Paradise, Adventure Is a Safe Bet
description: IT may not be the roof of the world, but this artificial granite peak is billed as the tallest freestanding indoor climbing structure on the planet. And Nancy Borchardt, an emergency medical technician in St. Louis and the mother of two teen-age boys, had just scaled all 75 feet of it.

title: Trade Deficit Set a Record During May
description: A surge of imports driven by the continued strength of the American economy pushed the United States trade deficit to another record in May, more than $21 billion, fueled both by rising oil prices and growing evidence that China is using exports to support its lagging economy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a reduction in the murder sentence of Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of the former President of Mexico, misstated the year that the current President, Ernesto Zedillo, is to leave office. It is 2000, not 2001.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: For a Thirsty City, It's a Cocktail Summer
description: IT'S 6:30 in the evening, and the crowd is sipping mint-garlanded mojitos, spark ling flutes of Champagne-and-vodka mambo kings and lovely, apricot-toned Floridians with squiggles of orange peel dangling from the rims of the glasses. The scene is not South Beach or the Bahamas, but Madison Avenue, on the four-sided balcony bar at Asia de Cuba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JAY BENTLEY
description: FRIEDMAN-Jay Bentley, DDS. Professor Emeritus at NYU College of Dentistry. Respected faculty member since 1932. Noted fundraiser, adored by peers, students, and patients (hands of gold). Beloved husband of the late Judith. Devoted father of Marilyn and Rosalynd, cherished grandfather of Janet. Services from Temple Israel, 140 Central Avenue, Lawrence, L.I. Wednesday, 1:30PM.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Dissolving Yeast in Milk or Water

title: THE CHEF; Summer Herbs: A Search for Perfection
description: IF fresh fruits and vegetables are the vocabulary of summer, fresh herbs are the accent, instilling the light dishes of the season with character and liveliness.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO SPLIT ITS STOCK
description: Tyco International Ltd., the world's largest maker of security systems and fire-detection equipment, as well as industrial valves and undersea fiber optic cable, said yesterday that it would split its stock two shares for one. Shares of Tyco, which is based in Bermuda and has administrative offices in Exeter, N.H., have climbed 56 percent in the last year, while the Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 18 percent, and the company has begun or completed more than $28 billion in acquisitions in the last two years. Shares of Tyco rose $2.1875, to $103.375, yesterday, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAAD, RONALD, F.
description: VAAD-Ronald, F. Deceased from cancer on July 18, 1999. He was an actor and director. He was born in Omaha, Nebraska, October 20, 1935. Survived by his brother, Bruce Vaad and his sister, Linda Proplesch and his domestic partner, Donal A. Currie. Donations to God's Love We Deliver.

title: Duval-Woods Rushing to Daylight
description: When Tiger Woods and David Duval meet in their match-play duel on Aug. 2, they will not only be fighting for the $1.1 million winner's prize.

title: Picking and Packing Portobellos, Now With a Union Contract
description: For farm workers in the South, where government officials and companies often boast about the absence of unions, what was going on in the bustling lunchroom at Quincy Farms was nothing short of extraordinary.

title: Statement of Grief By Wife's Family
description: Following is the statement on Monday from the Bessette and Freeman families read by a family friend, Grant Stinchfield, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: 2 GUN COMPANIES IN NEW YORK TALKS
description: In a move that could lead to a major break in the solidarity of the gun industry, two major gun makers are negotiating with the New York State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, over a lawsuit he plans to file against gun manufacturers, people involved in the discussions said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TULCHIN, FANNIE
description: TULCHIN-Fannie. 97 years old. Wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, great-grandmother. July 18, 1999. Services private.

title: NEW PUBLISHING CHIEF
description: After searching nearly a year, Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British-Dutch publishing giant, announced that it had named Crispin Davis to be its new chief executive, beginning in September. Mr. Davis, 50, is chief executive of the media services company Aegis Group P.L.C. Reed Elsevier, which owns Lexis-Nexis and the business-to-business publishing unit Cahners Business Information, is reorganizing its management structure by naming one chief executive to replace two co-chief executives, Nigel Stapleton and Herman Bruggink. The company's British parent is Reed International P.L.C.; its Dutch parent is Elsevier N.V. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Editorial Observer; Hemingway and the Drama of the Writer's Self
description: About the time T. S. Eliot was advancing the idea that an artist's progress is a ''continual extinction of personality,'' another American, 11 years Eliot's junior and just out of high school, was putting in a brief apprenticeship at The Kansas City Star and preparing to head off to the war in Europe. He -- Ernest Hemingway, that is -- reached the Italian front in June 1918 and was badly wounded by early July, narrowly avoiding a more complete extinction of personality than even Eliot seemed to require.

title: Airbus in Lead On Plane Orders
description: Airbus Industrie shot ahead of its rival, the Boeing Company, in winning airplane orders in the first half of 1999, racking up sales of 234 planes against 120 for Boeing, according to figures from the two companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHADE, HAROLD R.
description: SCHADE-Harold R., Dr. Of Gilgo Beach, LI and Freeport, LI. Beloved husband of Ann Schade. Devoted father of Nancy Schade Hearne, Jane Ann Butehorn, Harold R. Schade II, Mary Alexis McCormack and Christian S. Schade. Proud and cherished Pop Pop of fifteen grandchildren. Funeral Mass St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Montauk Highway, Bay Shore, Friday 11:00 AM. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Interfaith Nutrition Network, P.O. Box 7661, Freeport, NY 11520 or Good Samaritan Hospice, 655 Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, NY 11702. For more information contact Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home.

title: Fire Chief Shot in Head 5 Times During Argument at Queens Gym
description: A veteran fire chief was shot and critically wounded outside a Queens exercise center yesterday by a man who had often quarreled with the chief and who had also tangled with other patrons of the gym, the police said.

title: Landman to Succeed Purnick As Times Metropolitan Editor
description: Joyce Purnick will step down as metropolitan editor of The New York Times after two years of supervising the paper's largest news department, it was announced yesterday. Jonathan Landman, the editor of The Week in Review, will succeed her.

title: American Honda Cuts 2 Agencies
description: The American Honda Motor Company unexpectedly dismissed two roster agencies yesterday by consolidating general-market national and regional advertising assignments for its two car brands, Honda and Acura, at Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Whitman Defends State Police Finalist Criticized for Role in Terrorist Inquiry
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today defended the credentials of a candidate to head the New Jersey State Police -- a Federal agent who has been criticized for ending surveillance of a group of terrorists several months before they bombed the World Trade Center in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROVER, GEORGE
description: ROVER-George. On July 18, 1999 in his 88th year, attorney-at-law. Beloved father of Sally, Randy, Susan, Stuart, Georgia and Holly. Cherished husband of Louise Redden Rover. Adored grandfather of Elliot, Daniel, Valerie, Amanda, Jonathan, Nicholas, Jordan, Andrew and Jesse. His strength and love will be with us always. Services are private, Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Bakst Shoots a 66 For 1st-Round Lead
description: Ken Bakst, the 1997 United States Golf Association Mid-Amateur titlist, shot a four-under-par 66 yesterday and took the first-round lead in the New York State Open at the Bethpage State Park Black Course in Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: PBS Stations Admit Swaps Of Donor Lists Since 1981
description: At least 28 public television stations have exchanged names of their donors with political organizations affiliated with either or both of the major political parties, according to a partial survey made public today by officials for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: FORD GETS REDUCED INCENTIVES
description: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil released a decree providing the Ford Motor Company with tax breaks and Government financing for its plan to build a $1.3 billion factory in Brazil's underdeveloped northeast. But in an effort to appease industrial groups in the country's south, Mr. Cardoso removed some of the decree's original terms that would have given Ford more generous incentives. Simon Romero

title: Our Towns; A Fraternity Of Pilots In Mourning
description: AT the Essex County Airport, the last spot on earth that John F. Kennedy Jr. walked, well-wishers brought flowers and hand-penned messages over the last couple of days, and pilots talked of him as one of their own.

title: The Kennedy Family's Statement About Their Loss
description: Following is the statement from the Kennedy family on the letterhead of Senator Edward M. Kennedy dated July 19:

title: Why Single Out Cake?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the second-quarter earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation misstated the amount of a charge related to a factory in France. The charge was $770 million, not $770 billion.

title: Latin Accents in a Room With an Edge
description: SLEEK, slinky creatures crowd the bar at Vandam. With a Darwinian instinct for social display, they perch on the tall stools and preen, agreeably conscious that they have chosen a flattering setting.

title: From California, Toasty, Mellow Nut Oils
description: EUROPEANS, especially the French, have always had a monopoly on good nut oils, which are a luxury in vinaigrettes and a fragrant substitute for butter on grilled fish. But now, a two-year-old company in California is making what are probably the best toasted nut oils on the market.

title: How Student Pilots Are Drilled For Conditions Kennedy Saw
description: Four days after John F. Kennedy Jr.'s single-engine plane plunged into the Atlantic, it remains uncertain whether the reason was mechanical failure, his own inexperience or something still unimagined.

title: With All Those Unseen Movies, This Is No Time to Rest
description: REST on your vacation? There is no rest for the overextended. This is just an opportunity for catching up -- on sleep, reading, talking to the people you live with and, maybe, seeing films that you missed during the year. Here are 10 possibilities from the movie season past.

title: A Lunch Of Fish, Elephant And 'Achoo'
description: There's something new to see in midtown Manhattan at lunchtime. Dance programs are being offered by Anita Durst, Despina Stamos and Tony Silva, producers of a series called Deli Dances in Times Square. The shows take place at 12:30 P.M. in a former delicatessen at 110 West 42d Street, just west of Sixth Avenue, and on Monday dancers attracted passers-by by cavorting on the sidewalk in front of the building. Then everyone went inside for 35 minutes of pleasant choreographic snacks.

title: Going, Going, Gone; Tips for Travelers In the Married State
description: TRAVEL can put extra strain on a marriage. Being the same old couple in a new and different place is a disorienting experience. All too often, when people don't know where they are, have jet lag or can't speak the language, figure out the money or maintain intestinal regularity, they grow hostile. And since they don't know anybody else to take it out on in Kyoto, they take it out on each other.

title: Melons: Pure Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Low Fat's Lowered Expectations; Procter & Gamble Overestimates America's Olestra Craving
description: In a corporate dining room at the Procter & Gamble Company's headquarters in Cincinnati two years ago, John E. Pepper, the chief executive, stabbed his fork, by turns, into salad, chicken-vegetable stir fry and carrot cake.

title: THE FINE PRINT: The Tax Bills; When Lawmakers Look Homeward
description: Buried deep in the giant tax-cut bill that the Senate Finance Committee began debating today is fine print that could turn chicken droppings into a tax shelter.

title: BELL ATLANTIC TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN FRONTIER UNIT
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the 50 percent of Frontier Cellular, a wireless phone venture in New York and Pennsylvania, that it does not already own from the Frontier Corporation. The price was not disclosed. The transaction will add more than 400,000 customers and 34,000 square miles to Bell Atlantic Mobile's 6.4 million subscribers and 120,000-square-mile service area. Frontier Cellular serves metropolitan areas like Rochester, Syracuse and Buffalo, as well as more rural areas like Chautauqua, N.Y.

title: With Ponson Going Distance, Orioles Prevent a Mets Sweep
description: Sidney Ponson pitched a six-hitter to power the Baltimore Orioles past Al Leiter and the Mets, 4-1, at Camden Yards tonight. The 22-year-old right-hander from Aruba also prevented the Mets from sweeping the three-game series and from pulling within two games of the first-place Atlanta Braves for the first time since June 25.

title: Accounts
description: * Knight/Trimark Group, New York, to Gotham Inc., New York, part of the Interpublic Group, to handle the account of the financial services company, which had been at Doremus & Co., New York, part of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million.

title: Kennedy 'Curse' or Needless Risk-Taking?; Nation of Strangers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Drags Feet in Kosovo, Pentagon Leaders Declare
description: Opening a new rift between the Pentagon and the United Nations, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and Gen. Henry H. Shelton, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, criticized the United Nations today for not moving faster to create a new police force and civil administration in Kosovo.

title: Genentech's Shares Surge 31% As Roche Holdings Sells Stake
description: Shares of the biotechnology company Genentech Inc. rose 31 percent from their offering price yesterday in the biotechnology company's debut on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Company Short on Buzz but Long on Results
description: Hoover's Inc. has seen its main business grow 145 percent a year since 1995 and has been around almost a decade. It has little debt and nearly turned a profit in the last quarter.

title: A Scandal and Search For Two Italian Siblings
description: ''My Brother, My Sister, Sold for a Fistful of Lire'' remembers one of the darker chapters of post-World War II reconstruction in Europe. With much of Italy in ruins, a Neapolitan-American adoption agency arranged for tens of thousands of impoverished children to be transported to the United States, where they were sold to American adoptive parents for $10,000 a head.

title: A Vote for Democracy Abroad
description: In most repressive countries today, civic activists such as election monitors, labor organizers, independent journalists and human rights groups look to Washington for support. But the Senate may vote any day to end one of their most important lifelines. Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, has persuaded the Appropriations Committee to recommend that the National Endowment for Democracy's funding drop from $31 million to zero. The Senate should defy him and vote to preserve an organization whose mission is more vital than ever.

title: New Path of Israeli Settlers: Moving Toward Mainstream
description: Enter this king-size bedroom community for Jerusalem and the frontier image of the hard-core Jewish settlement fades fast.

title: Cracks in the Glass Ceiling
description: Carleton S. Fiorina, the new chief executive officer of the Hewlett-Packard Company, says there is no need to focus on her gender in discussing her appointment. ''I truly hope,'' she told reporters after her appointment was announced, ''that we are at the point now where everyone has figured out that the accomplishments of women across industry demonstrate that there is not a glass ceiling.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAUFFER, EUNICE
description: STAUFFER-Eunice (nee Bennett). Of New York City, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. On July 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late John Stauffer. Graduate of Wellesley University and Oxford (St. Hilda's). Devoted mother of Debora Swan. Cherished grandmother of Holly J. Swan, Laura D. Barnard, and Harmanus Swan III. Loving great grandmother of Rory Matthews Pyne. Dear sister of John D. Bennett, former Surrogate of Nassau County. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre Thursday from 10 AM to 11 AM. Religious services to follow. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society in her name.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Profit Beats Forecast But Market Share Shrinks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, NATHANIEL
description: KATZ-Nathaniel. We mourn the loss of our esteemed partner and beloved friend. We will cherish the memory of his wise counsel, his remarkably youthful spirit, his generosity, his genuine concern for the well being of each of us and his unfailing kindness. His career was marked by integrity, by devotion to the highest professional standards and by a commitment to the best interests of his clients. His life will always be an inspiration to all who knew him; we will never forget him. The Partners and Staff of Tuchman, Katz, Schwartz, Gelles & Korngold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWINING, JEAN KNOOP
description: TWINING-Jean Knoop. On July 18, 1999 at the age of 83. Formerly employed with Cahill Gordon in NYC and a member of many organizations including the English Speaking Union and the Mendelssohn Glee Club of NY. Beloved wife of the late Geoffrey Twining. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday, July 22, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery.

title: Drug Counselor to New Woodstock Crowd
description: IT is easier than you might think to pick out Dr. Paul Michael Ramirez, the director of psychiatric services for the Woodstock festival, among his professorial colleagues at Long Island University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, LEONARD
description: KAUFMAN-Leonard, Dr. Of Croton-On-Hudson and Hillsdale, New York. Died on Monday, July 19, 1999 at Phelps Memorial Hospital. Dr. Kaufman was in practice in Ossining, New York, and served as the Medical Director of Skyview Nursing Home and National Patent Corporation. Dr. Kaufman is survived by his wife of 45 years Joy, his children Randy Hustvedt and Peter Kaufman, his daughterin-law and son-in-law, Ann Waterfall and Eric Hustvedt, and his grandchildren Emma and Willa Kaufman. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Sleepy Hollow, New York.

title: 20 Hindus Slain in Kashmir, Apparently by Muslim Insurgents
description: Twenty Hindus were killed in three incidents before dawn today in what is feared to be a stepped-up campaign of hit-and-run tactics by Muslim insurgents in remote areas of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, officials said.

title: Gilding the Crab
description: To the Editor:

title: Certification Test Can't Predict a Teacher's Talent; City College's Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPPS, GERALDINE
description: EPPS-Geraldine. Beloved mother of Miles, Elliot, Peter and Jonathan. Loving grandmother. Services Wednesday, 10:45 AM at ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 66th Ave., Forest Hills.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCI WORLDCOM INC., Jackson, Miss., said it would buy Wireless One Inc., Jackson, Miss., for $23 million in cash and the assumption of an undisclosed amount of debt.

title: The No-Sun Tan: A Trend Spreads
description: PROBABLY a tube of Lait Auto-Bronzant (that's self-tanning milk to you, bub) ought to find its way into one of those millennial time capsules.

title: A Summer Adventure: Journeying Into the World of the Unfamiliar
description: WHAT'S a vacation without guilt? For most Americans, no vacation at all. Elsewhere in the world, a trip to the beach is a mindless, happy frolic in the sun. An American takes a book, a serious book. ''Irregular French Verbs,'' perhaps, or a Dostoyevsky novel. And doesn't read either one.

title: Sweet Desserts, No Ordeal
description: EVEN people who love to cook have days when they don't have time to dawdle at the cutting board. So, cookbook writers have responded with many books geared toward speed. They are rarely filled with original recipes. Rather, they are packed with familiar ones that have been dissected and reconfigured -- much in the way manufacturers retool a production line -- to save the home cook a few precious minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTZ, HAROLD
description: MALTZ-Harold. On July 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Kenneth and Jeffrey & father-in-law of Nancy. Loving brother of Scott, William, Leonard, Bea and Jean. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin and Laura. Services Thursday, 12 noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: NOTEBOOK; Help on the Web
description: The State of Texas has been a leader in the movement toward more standardized tests to gauge and compare student performance. Now there is a Web site devoted to helping students get some extra practice on those tests.

title: CORBIS AND PICTURE PRESS TEAM UP IN EUROPEAN VENTURE
description: The Corbis Corporation, owned by William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, has formed an alliance with Picture Press, based in Hamburg, Germany, to sell pictures in Austria and Germany. Seattle-based Corbis, the world's largest image archive, will license 2.1 million digital images to Picture Press, a unit of the closely held Gruner & Jahr Publishing House. Corbis has 65 million pictures by the photographer Ansel Adams and news photographers from United Press International and other agencies, as well as fine art. Corbis, which will market to commercial clients like public relations firms and advertising agencies, acquired Sygma of France last month to supplant Getty Images Inc. as the No. 1 picture collection.

title: The Empty U.S. Seat at Mideast Talks: A Boon for All
description: One of the enduring images of the late and unlamented period in American-Israeli relations that ended with Ehud Barak's victory over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is that of a senior State Department envoy with a tape measure marking off the width of Shuhadah Road in Hebron, in the West Bank.

title: Commissioner to Make Decision on Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry's immediate future as a Yankee is expected to be decided tomorrow by baseball's commissioner, Bud Selig.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: McCain Gets Debate on Campaign Finance Bill
description: Senator John McCain today dropped his threats to force an immediate Senate confrontation over campaign finance legislation after winning a commitment from Senate leaders to hold a full debate no later than mid-October on an overhaul of the law governing campaign donations.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on July 14 about Aaron S. Lapin, the creator of Reddi-wip, misidentified a survivor in some copies, and a correction in this space on Monday was erroneous. Carol Lapin is a sister-in-law, not a daughter-in-law and not Mr. Lapin's widow.

title: Israeli Tries to Assure Arafat On West Bank Withdrawals
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak tried to reassure Yasir Arafat today that Israel will move more quickly to complete withdrawals from the West Bank than the 15-month target he set for an overall Middle East peace settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVNER, BENJAMIN
description: KOVNER-Benjamin. Long-term resident of Mamaroneck, NY, on July 17 at the age of 97 in Greenwich, CT Hospital. Beloved husband of Kathleen Jane Kovner. Loving father of Michael, Peter and the late Kay Kovner and father-in-law of Roberta and surrogate father to Jean. Adored grandfather of Matthew and Alexandra. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, July 20, 6-9 PM, with service Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Eye Institute, 2020 Vision Place, Bethesda, MD 20892.

title: Patients and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, GERALD A.
description: PARSONS-Gerald A. Died unexpectedly on July 5, 1999 at his home in the Salishan Hills, on the Oregon Coast. He was 70 years old. Many kind words have been shared with the family by those who proudly considered him their friend. He will be missed by us all. A memorial has been established through Marylhurst University. Contributions are being taken by the Development office, P.O. Box 261, Marylhurst, OR. 97036.

title: Armstrong, Using Head as Well as Feet, Nears Ultimate Victory
description: Lance Armstrong rode a brilliant tactical race in the Tour de France today, then turned on the afterburners and showed that he remains powerful as well as brainy. The American leader of the United States Postal Service team did not win the daily stage but, barring injury or illness, he sewed up the overall victory when the three-week Tour finishes in Paris on Sunday.

title: Kleinfeld, Threatened Bridal Emporium, Gets New Owners
description: Kleinfeld, the huge bridal emporium in Brooklyn, has been acquired by a newly formed investment concern that plans to restore it to its former glory as the busiest wedding-dress outlet in the nation.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Pepsico Profit Is Up 50%, Aided by Spinoff of Bottler
description: Showing solid company-wide results, Pepsico said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 50 percent, based in large part on a one-time gain from the spinoff of its bottling operations in the spring.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SONNETT, CARL
description: SONNETT-Carl. Thinking of you always, love and kisses from the boys, the Princess, Meri, Stacy and Tony

title: G.M. Profit Beats Wall Street Expectations
description: Pocketing higher profits even as its market share continues to erode, the General Motors Corporation said today that it earned $1.73 billion in the second quarter, a vast improvement over the $306 million it earned from continuing operations during the same period last year, when there was a costly strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, ROSALIE
description: SMALL-Rosalie (nee Krasnoff), 88, peacefully at home on July 19, 1999. A long time resident of Riverdale and the Bronx. Loving wife of the late George J. Small. Beloved mother of Sandra (Mariano) Rechy, Barbara (Gerald) Singer and Lynn (Dennis) Friedman. Much loved grandmother of Suzanne (Carlos) Hernandez, Marianne Rechy and Geoffrey and Jennifer Singer. Services Riverside Park West Funeral Home, 180 Amsterdam Ave, Thursday, July 22, 9:45 AM, (212) 362-3600.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the civil rights leader James Farmer on July 10 referred incorrectly to the locations of school closings that resulted in a protest march he led in 1959. The march was called after schools in several Virginia communities were closed to avoid court-ordered integration. Schools in Richmond were not closed.

title: Summertime, And the Facts Are Jumping
description: Summer is when the most children fly unaccompanied by an adult. Last July, a record 52,937 children ages 5 to 11 flew unchaperoned on Southwest Airlines.

title: Albright to Ask China to Set Taiwan Talks
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that when she meets in Singapore this weekend with China's Foreign Minister, Tang Jiaxuan, she will appeal for a peaceful resolution of the dispute with Taiwan.

title: Finding the Unexpected on www.ididn'tknowthat.com
description: ONE of the great vacation pleasures is breaking away from the beaten path to find a lesser-known pleasure in an out-of-the-way spot, like coming across a quirky roadside market on a winding Kentucky byway. And one reward for digging your way past the Web's megamalls can be finding sites that tell you what you didn't realize you wanted to know, like the one listing the best roadside markets in Kentucky (www.kyfb.com/roadside.htm).

title: Woman on a Mission
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Architectural Compositions
description: A few years ago, a museum of three greenhouses, one with fruit trees, opened in Japan. The Museum of Fruit, as it is known, is odd, but stranger still is what it has inspired: a haunting CD of electronic music by David Toop. It is the third in Caipirinha Music's ''Architettura'' series, in which modernist buildings act as muses for hyper-modernist music. The others are ''Waterloo Terminal'' and ''Tower of Winds''; $15.98 each at www.caipirinha.com.

title: UNICOM TO ACQUIRE A HEATING AND COOLING CONTRACTOR
description: The Unicom Corporation, owner of Chicago's dominant utility, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Midwest Mechanical Inc., a heating and cooling contractor based in Willowbrook, Ill., for an undisclosed price to enter a business that is expected to grow faster than power sales. Midwest Mechanical, with annual revenue of about $45 million, designs, installs and services heating and air-conditioning systems for 1,600 businesses in the Chicago area. Utilities have been buying such contractors so they can offer more services, helping them retain customers as they lose their electricity monopolies to deregulation. Unicom, the parent of the Commonwealth Edison Company, said it would retain Midwest Mechanical's 250 employees.

title: Briggs Adds a Corner Man, but Will It Matter?
description: Working with the trainer Emanuel Steward has given the heavyweight Shannon Briggs a fresh mental approach to boxing. No one will know whether it makes a difference until Briggs meets Frans Botha in Atlantic City on Aug. 7.

title: I Link, Therefore I Am: a Web Intellectual's Diary
description: ONCE in a great while a Web site appears, seemingly out of nowhere, and casts a spell. Such is the case with Lemonyellow.com, an on-line intellectual diary that makes the reader want to dig deeper and deeper.

title: The Big City; Public Price For the Loss Of a Kennedy
description: MOST Americans are probably glad that no expense was spared to find the plane of John F. Kennedy Jr. But many of them might also have a hard time justifying the government's extraordinary efforts in this case, which officially was nothing more than a relatively routine accident involving a private citizen.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOOLARD, CHARLOTTE A.
description: WOOLARD-Charlotte A. A memorial Mass for Charlotte A. Woolard, who died July 17, will be held at Holy Trinity Catholic Church on 36th Street between N and O Streets N.W. at 3PM on Thursday, July 29. Parking will be available at Georgetown Visitation School, 35th and Volta Streets N.W. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contrubitions be made to the Charlotte Woolard Memorial Fund, part of the Fund for New American Plays, The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, D.C. 20566.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Peonies Yet to Come

title: A New Agency Opens in Oregon
description: A longtime direct marketing executive, Tim O'Leary, has opened Respond2 Inc. in Portland, Ore., an agency focused on television and the Internet. Mr. O'Leary, 39, is chairman and chief executive at Respond2; he had most recently been chief executive at Tyee Group in Portland, a direct-response agency. Respond2 opens with 20 employees working on accounts with billings of $20 million to $30 million from clients that include the American Film Institute in Washington and two Miami-based cruise lines, Carnival Cruises and Norwegian Cruise Lines.

title: ZINC STRIKE AVERTED
description: Workers at Cominco Ltd.'s zinc smelter at Trail, British Columbia, voted to accept a mediator's proposal on wages, pensions and other benefits to avoid a strike. The smelter is one of the largest in the world, producing 300,000 metric tons of zinc a year and employing 1,660 members of the United Steelworkers union. Meanwhile, more than 1,000 miners at Highland Valley Copper in southern British Columbia, which is 50 percent owned by Cominco, remain off the job. The mine was closed in mid-May when the workers refused to accept wage cuts. Timothy Pritchard

title: Three People, Dying Young
description: With the tortuous retrieval of a small airplane and its passengers from the ocean floor, the nation can begin formal mourning over the deaths of three promising citizens, while families and friends grieve their more personal and intimate loss. The private memorials tomorrow in New York City and Saturday in Connecticut will not be based on one family's mythical place in our public psyche or on the celebrity of the victims or the drama of their last helpless moments, but on the untimely, incurable loss.

title: Runaway Banks Without Brakes: Mexico's $71 Billion Lesson
description: In the early 1990's Mexico's bloated Government sold off the banks it had seized from private hands a decade earlier, in a proud campaign to get ready to compete in the fast, mean world of modern global finance.

title: Cutbacks at Carrier
description: Carrier Corporation, the world's largest maker of heating and air-conditioning systems, will eliminate 200 management jobs at its factory in Dewitt, N.Y.

title: The Last 20 Years of a Larger-Than-Life Figure
description: HEMINGWAY

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He asked me why I was so nervous and I said, 'You're a part of American history.' He told me he was just like anybody else and offered me an autograph if I held the elevator. I just had to be here today, even though I doubt he'd like all this fuss.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TREIMAN, OSCAR BARD
description: TREIMAN-Oscar Bard. You were talented-and a National Clarinet Contest Winner, hardworking and good-thoughtful and compassionate, wise, deep, witty and a loving and dependable friend. Happy 80th! You're deeply loved

title: Latvia's Language Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Is Blessed With Stamina, Age Has the Wiles
description: The cream of the world's junior players will gather in Miami Beach early next month for the World Junior Team Championships. Most are 20 to 25 years old, but it would be possible to assemble a strong foursome of teen-agers. They could, in theory, play a match against the world's best octogenarians.

title: NEWS WATCH; Journalist's Memoir Chronicles 40 Years of Covering Civil Rights
description: Earl Caldwell began his career as a reporter in the 1950's and spent 40 years covering the civil rights movement for eight newspapers, including The New York Times. Mr. Caldwell was the sole reporter at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis when Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered, and his coverage included the Black Panther Party and the urban riots of the 60's. But he was more than a witness to events: he refused to cooperate with Government surveillance and prosecution of the Panthers -- a battle he ultimately lost in the Supreme Court. His stance, and similar cases, set in motion in many states the enactment of shield laws to insure the protection of reporters' sources.

title: David Ogilvy, 88, Father of Soft Sell In Advertising, Dies
description: David Ogilvy, the ad executive who dreamed up the eye-patch wearing ''man in the Hathaway shirt'' and many other iconic advertising campaigns, died yesterday at Chateau Touffou, his home near Bonnes in the Loire Valley of France, after a year of declining health, according to a spokeswoman for Ogilvy & Mather. He was 88.

title: A Table By Way Of E = mc2
description: In a world full of ultra-adjustable office furniture -- orthopedic pieces that crank and roll into every conceivable position -- the Atomic Table is refreshing. It morphs, but just for fun.

title: CHINA DEBT IS DOWNGRADED
description: China's sovereign credit rating was cut for the first time by Standard & Poor's, which warned that Government spending was hiding the extent of the nation's economic slowdown. The company cut the sovereign rating to its second-lowest investment grade. level. That is China's lowest rating since May 1997 and takes the nation back to the level first assigned by S.& P. in 1992. S.&P. also cut the ratings of the Bank of China and four other major financial institutions to junk, reflecting ''the lessened capacity of the central Government to support'' them.

title: Regulators Seize Documents From Coca-Cola in Europe
description: In the latest twist to the Coca-Cola Company's fortunes -- or misfortunes -- in Europe, its offices in four European countries have been raided by regulators who seized company documents that may lead to an investigation of the company's competitive practices with big customers like supermarkets.

title: An Imaginary Church Created in a Real One
description: On Tuesday evening Jon Gillock ended his series of Messiaen recitals on the organ at Riverside Church with the inevitable grand finale: the ''Book of the Holy Sacrament,'' which was the composer's farewell to the instrument, written in 1984 between his opera, ''St. Francis,'' and the final sequence of orchestral works. In the middle of all these public pieces, the ''Book'' was a private moment.

title: Mahaheng Amatsho Journal; Seer's Life: Win a Few, Lose a Few, Take an Aspirin
description: As a seer to kings, Mmatsepo has had her hits and misses.

title: Inventive Chefs Are Cooking From History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATALON, LAURIE
description: MATALON-Laurie. We are saddened by the loss of the wife, mother & grandmother of Ralph, Mitchell, Craig, Tina, Alexandra & Miles. Her life was a beacon of light to all who knew her. Services Friday, 1 PM at Hellmans, Spring Valley, New York. Burial to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Political Briefing; Women to the Rescue Of Elizabeth Dole
description: She has said time and again that she is not running as a woman but instead is a woman running.

title: Fear of Flying Can Be Healthy
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Admits Brake Flaws After Inquiry
description: After a five-year Federal investigation, General Motors acknowledged today that the anti-lock brakes on 3.6 million sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and full-size vans would be slow to stop the vehicles under certain circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, ALBERT
description: GROSSMAN-Albert. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved father of Harriet (& Joshua) Muss & Ruth (and Emanuel) Roth, and brother of Max Grossman. Harriet and Joshua Muss are YU Benefactors; she is a National Board member of the YU Women's Organization and he serves on the Yeshiva College Board of Directors. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Muss/Grossman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower National Chairman, YUWO

title: Pottery to Perk Up a Still Life
description: Can pottery have personality? Cor Unum, a Dutch producer of ceramic art pieces, thinks tableware can be witty, handsome, provocative and helpful. To that end, Cor Unum hires architects, artists and industrial and fashion designers, and then provides computer-aided design and manufacturing to expand their ideas. Olav Slingerland designed the Banana Dish (above), with banana-shaped indentations, and the Piso vase (top), with an angled neck and square base. Like people, Pisos perk up when tightly grouped. The dish is $80; each vase, $41. AG International of Santa Barbara, Calif., plans to introduce the line at ''Accent on Design,'' a trade show, from Aug. 15 through 19 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Available from AG at (805) 563-5444.

title: Drug Makers Report Higher Profits in Quarter
description: Drug makers, led by the Schering-Plough Corporation, reported higher second-quarter profits yesterday as advertising increased sales of medicines for depression, diabetes and allergies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWINING, JEAN KNOOP
description: TWINING-Jean Knoop. On July 18, 1999 at the age of 83. Formerly employed with Cahill Gordon in NYC and a member of many organizations including the English Speaking Union and the Mendelssohn Glee Club of NY. Beloved wife of the late Geoffrey Twining. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday, July 22, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper fell after a drop in United States home building touched off concern that demand for wire and pipe may be slowing. In New York, copper for September delivery fell 2.2 cents, to 74.75 cents a pound.

title: A Speaker Under Pressure Beseeches His Party's Members
description: One after another, all afternoon, House Republican dissidents were summoned to the office of Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, who sought their votes to pass a $792 billion tax cut, the centerpiece of the leadership's agenda.

title: Council Votes Big Raises for Top Officials
description: The City Council voted yesterday to approve pay increases of 10 percent to 28 percent for the city's top officials, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and the Council's own 51 members. The raises had been recommended by a panel of three private citizens that is convened every four years to consider the pay levels of the city's top elected leaders.

title: Making a Mac Do Windows
description: Q. I have a new iMac and need to install Virtual PC so I can use a Windows accounting program. What do I need to run Virtual PC?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOLBERG, BEATRICE S.
description: KOLBERG-Beatrice S. Happy Birthday, Aunt Beatrice. Deeply loved and sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F. JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F. Jr. The Board of Directors, Members, Staff and Program Participants of AHRC New York City wish to express their condolences, sympathy and grief at the tragic passing of John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife Carolyn and his sister-in-law, Lauren Bessette. John Kennedy's personal and heartfelt contributions to the careers of those who serve people with mental retardation, as well as his significant impact upon the lives of the very people we serve will never be forgotten. It is our hope that we may, in various ways, also pursue those human goals which ennobled his mission. We are honored and grateful for having been allowed to participate in the development of the training program at the City University of New York, and to have functioned as committed partners with the Reaching Up Foundation in the development of this, and the Kennedy Fellowship Programs. Scores of Kennedy Fellows are emerging from the various schools of CUNY equipped to better serve people with disabilities than ever before. Without John F. Kennedy Jr., this would not have happened. We convey our sadness and support to John's family and to the family of his wife and sister-in-law. You are in our prayers. Al Agovino, President AHRC Michael Goldfarb Executive Director AHRC

title: So Familiar, So Private
description: WOMEN identify with Melissa Bank, whether she likes it or not. In the midst of a whistle-stopping, 16-city tour to promote her best-selling 30-something Bildungsroman, ''The Girls' Guide to Hunting and Fishing'' (Viking), she has come face to face with readers who all act as if they know her intimately. Not only that, many of them seem to think she knows them really well, too.

title: Kidney Failure Imperils Career of Spurs' Elliott
description: When Sean Elliott tiptoed along the baseline in Game 2 of the Western Conference finals in May and let fly the most memorable 3-pointer of his career, the winning shot was immediately dubbed the Memorial Day Miracle. Looking back, how the 31-year-old forward even played that game against Portland and eventually helped the San Antonio Spurs win their first National Basketball Association title may go down as a much more remarkable feat.

title: To Start a Day at the Desktop, A Chance to Smile and Play
description: THERE are a lot of procrastinators on the Internet, or at least that is what a Dutch startup called Bitmagic hopes. The company intends to bring entertainment to the Net in the form of computer games, animation and interactive cartoons delivered to the user's desktop each day.

title: It's a Daily Production for Ramirez
description: Manny Ramirez digs his right foot into the back of the right-handed batter's box and glances toward the first-base side to focus for a second. Then Ramirez moves his left foot into the box, taps the dirt with his bat and waves it slowly through the strike zone once, sometimes holding the bat steady until the pitcher begins his motion. Then Ramirez is ready.

title: Sports of The Times; Boggs Stays Well Ahead Of the Curve
description: WADE BOGGS is still doing the superstition thing, ''driving everyone around me nuts.'' Wearing his favorite shirt every day, leaving the park at the same time, retracing his steps in and out. Eighteen years of unshakable habits, of applying these principles to the religion of hitting, have brought him to the threshold of a careerlong dream. Why stop now?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIMPERT, SOPHIA D.
description: LIMPERT-Sophia D. 7/22/84-Remembered lovingly by her family on the 15th anniversary of her death.

title: A Foolish Tax Bill
description: House Republican leaders struggled mightily to force their party ranks into line yesterday before they managed to muster enough votes to indicate they can pass a huge and irresponsible tax cut. That so many moderate Republicans were reluctant to embrace the cause was a good indication that there is little public demand for such a bill. Only the true believers in the tax-cutting gospel of the Reagan years would think a tax break of this size would be sound policy and smart politics today.

title: Reluctant Typists
description: To the Editor:

title: ARQULE TO GET UP TO $117 MILLION FROM PACT WITH PFIZER
description: Arqule Inc. said yesterday that it would receive as much as $117 million over four and a half years to supply the drug maker Pfizer Inc. with chemical compounds. Shares of Arqule, based in Medford, Mass., soared 39 percent, or $1.875, to $6.625. The company's chemists try to create compounds that can interfere with naturally existing chemicals linked to human diseases. The contract includes an initial payment of $16 million and annual payments of $20 million to $27 million to Arqule, which had 1998 revenue of $22.2 million. Pfizer will own exclusive rights to the hundreds of thousands of drug-making compounds developed.

title: The Casino Effect in Asian Stock Markets
description: In one of Southeast Asia's perplexing riddles, investors keep plowing money into the region's stock markets even as governments dither over the urgent financial and regulatory overhauls many of them promised in the wake of the economic crisis that began two years ago.

title: PLUS: EMPIRE STATE GAMES; After 22 Years, Event Heads to Long Island
description: For the first time in its 22 years, the Empire State Games has moved from upstate New York. The amateur event, which draws more than 6,000 athletes in 28 sports, begins today at various sites on Long Island, including Hofstra and Stony Brook universities, and ends on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, CARTER V.
description: COOPER-Carter V. 27 January 1965-22 July 1988. Golden and True Mom and Anderson

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES FURTHER. The euro climbed after a report showed German construction orders rose in May, suggesting European growth is reviving. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0530, up from $1.0413 on Tuesday.

title: CB RICHARD ELLIS TO REORGANIZE BUSINESSES AND CUT JOBS
description: CB Richard Ellis Services Inc., a provider of commercial real estate services, said yesterday that it planned to consolidate its nine business lines into three and eliminate 70 managerial positions. The moves are aimed at saving $11 million a year. The company, based in El Segundo, Calif., also told securities analysts that earnings for the second quarter would probably be 16 cents a share, because of weakness in its North American leasing and sales business. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had predicted 33 cents a share. The shares fell $3.1875, or 16 percent, to $16.25.

title: Sports of The Times; Hodgepodge Agenda An N.C.A.A. Evasion
description: EARLIER this week, a blue-ribbon panel appointed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association offered pointed advice on how to manage student athletes. Not all student athletes, just the association's golden geese: basketball players, specifically those at the top 100 men's programs.

title: Cruise Line Pleads Guilty To Dumping of Chemicals
description: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., the world's second-largest cruise-ship line, pleaded guilty today to routinely dumping oil and hazardous chemicals from nine ships in coastal waters around the United States and promised to pay an $18 million fine.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Merger Deal With Plenty Of Intrigue
description: Yesterday's $2.1 billion agreement by Cincinnati Bell to acquire IXC Communications clearly lacked the cachet of last weekend's merger deal between U S West and Qwest Communications International, but it said at least as much about the telecommunications industry's strategic direction -- and it involved even more board room bloodshed.

title: Woodstock Arrives And Mood Is Mellow
description: Psychedelic school buses are cruising through downtown, raising eyebrows. Bands of wannabe hippies are illegally camping in the woods on the outskirts of town, raising suspicion. And rumors, benign and hideous, have already begun spreading around town faster than blotters of brown acid.

title: Working at Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EFFRON, DAVID
description: EFFRON-David. On July 19, 1999 in Poughkeepsie, NY. Beloved husband of Judith. Devoted father of Sara and Helen and son-in-law Geoff Lieberman. Loving grandfather of Laura and Molly.

title: Gun-Safety Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Under Pressure, Council Votes to Build Water Plant Under Bronx Golf Course
description: The City Council voted yesterday to approve the construction of a water filtration plant on the site of Mosholu Golf Course in Van Cortlandt Park in the northwest Bronx.

title: A Summer Camp in Harmony
description: Fifty New York City schoolchildren sit in a classroom at the Manhattan School of Music, barely awake but ready to sing.

title: Mind Over Matter: A Computer Makes It Work
description: THE control of a mechanical device by the brain has long been relegated to the realm of science fiction, and for good reason. Measuring the signals from individual neurons over time presents enormous technical challenges. Even more daunting, brain-hardware interactions would seem to require a much deeper understanding of the brain's basic messaging system than currently exists.

title: In Search of Fun Among the Dunes
description: IT'S a hot Friday in July, and we've been driving in circles through the sandy sprawl of Beach Hampton, near Amagansett, somewhere between the ocean dunes and Montauk Highway, where weekend houses are plunked on tiny lots, cheek by jowl.

title: The Right Leader for CUNY
description: Political infighting and chaotic management have made the last few years especially damaging for the City University of New York, driving off first-rate talent and causing potential replacements to rule out CUNY. After failing for nearly two years to find a permanent Chancellor, the Board of Trustees has settled on an excellent candidate, Matthew Goldstein, the president of Adelphi University and a former head of Baruch College.

title: Hampton Fields' Flowers
description: Rooster Flowers sells bunches of blossoms starting at $2.99 that look as if they were gathered up in a sun-splashed field. Indeed, in summer most of its flowers -- daisies, Queen Anne's lace, sunflowers, snapdragons -- are, grown on 28 acres in Bridgehampton, N.Y., and sold on Long Island at stores like King Kullen in Bridgehampton and Schmidt's in Southampton and East Hampton. In spring, it opened a shop on the Upper West Side (below), at 366 Amsterdam Avenue (78th Street). A second branch is to open next week at 452 Columbus Avenue (82d Street); another in August at 2 Columbus Avenue (59th Street). When frost is on the Hamptons, Rooster will get flowers from the Netherlands. FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: Fidelity Joins With Schwab In Electronic Stock Trading
description: Fidelity Investments and the Charles Schwab Corporation have been fierce competitors in virtually every business in which they operate -- mutual funds, stock brokerage, on-line trading. But yesterday they said that they were joining forces.

title: Deception in Marathon Has Race Officials Seeing Double
description: One of the top finishers in South Africa's most famous road race admitted today that he had cheated by running it in relays with his virtually identical brother.

title: Latvia's Language Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Want New Technologies? Here's the Latest Model
description: The opening night event for the Digital Club Festival at Irving Plaza on Tuesday, sponsored by Columbia Records, felt like any other New York music industry gathering. The crowd thinned and swelled as people met friends, planned nights of show hopping and paid vague attention to the performers.

title: Accounts
description: * Total Entertainment Network, San Francisco, which sells family games over the Internet, to Butler, Shine & Stern, Sausalito, Calif., as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Study Cites Risks for Women Under 50 With Heart Attacks
description: In people under 50, heart attacks are far less common in women than in men, but when they do occur, women are more than twice as likely to die, doctors are reporting today.

title: Kodak Plans More Job Cuts But Posts Profit for Quarter
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would close some manufacturing operations, cutting as many as 2,500 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, ELSIE
description: STILLMAN-Elsie. Dearest Mom, you've been a part of my life for close to forty years. Your zest for life, love of family, generosity and elegant style will remain with me forever. Love, Carol Baunshweiger

title: NATIONSRENT AGREES TO A TWO-PART CAPITAL INCREASE
description: Nationsrent Inc., which offers leasing of equipment like backhoes and bulldozers, agreed yesterday to a private equity offering and new loans that will increase its cash to about $455 million. The cash will be used in part to complete acquisitions. Nationsrent will sell $100 million in convertible preferred stock to Investcorp, a global investment group. The stock is convertible at any time into 14.3 million shares of common stock at $7 a share. If all the shares are converted, Investcorp will own about 20 percent of the shares outstanding. Nationsrent, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., also increased its senior credit line to $800 million from $500 million. The shares rose 6.25 cents, to $6.125.

title: Profit Up 6% at Times Mirror; 2% Rise at Los Angeles Times
description: Buoyed by a turnaround at The Los Angeles Times, where national advertising volume increased by 33.5 percent, the Times Mirror Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 6 percent.

title: It Takes Just One, And Jeter Hits It Out
description: How frustrating it must be for clubs like the Tampa Bay Devil Rays to think they have the defending champion Yankees right where they want them and then realize it was the other way around all along.

title: With Reed On Mound, The Mets Move Up
description: Rick Reed had a somewhat shaky outing once again, but one thing was clear after the Mets' 7-3 victory tonight over the Montreal Expos at Olympic Stadium. The Mets are just two games behind the first-place Atlanta Braves for the first time since June 25.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a fire chief who was shot and critically wounded outside a Queens exercise center misidentified the hospital that is treating him. It is North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y., not Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens.

title: U.N. Says It's NATO That Lags in Kosovo
description: Stung by American charges that the United Nations is moving too slowly in creating a police force and civil administration in Kosovo, a senior United Nations official suggested today that it was NATO members who were at fault for not fully deploying all their soldiers.

title: For Linux Users
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKER, HYMAN
description: LASKER-Hyman. On July 20, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Devoted father of Lawrence and Joann Lasker, Doris and Sy Drantch and Donald and Madeline Lasker. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Graveside services were held on Wenesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, PHILIP
description: LEVIN-Philip on July 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Harriet. Loving father of Patricia and Jeffrey. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends. Service private.

title: Art From Closed Museum Gets New Chance to Be Seen
description: In the 1980's, when he was flush with cash, the television magnate Emilio Azcarraga Milmo decided to create a modern-art museum that would give Mexico City a new aura of sophistication and make it a respectable stop on the international art circuit.

title: Stumping At the Bookshelf
description: These days, when a Presidential candidate throws his hat into the ring, there is often a book attached to the brim. Unfortunately for the cause of public debate, most of these works are about as naked as a hand or a bald head in their obviousness. This year the unseemly early start of the campaign has already produced the promise of four books by candidates. George W. Bush has written what his publisher calls a ''statement about his life and politics,'' which will be in bookstores in December. John McCain will weigh in in September. The campaign positions of Steve Forbes, the publisher, have been promised in book form in two weeks.

title: Nassau County Is Late to Pay Social Services
description: Dozens of social service agencies have not had their expenses reimbursed by Nassau County in months, and officials representing the agencies said today that some may soon have to turn to layoffs or even closings.

title: Essay; The Cherubic Commando
description: The new Prime Minister of Israel, Ehud Barak, stopped moving through a welcoming throng to ask me: ''Do you remember what you told me after Bibi defeated Peres?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, ABRAHAM, HAZZAN
description: LEVITT-Abraham, Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a respected colleague of over four decades. A brilliant composer with a beautiful voice, he quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of his congregants with dignity, warmth and care. We extend our sympathy to his wife Lynne, to his family and loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Chaim Najman, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Shape of beer to come. Beverage packaging gets more emphasis.
description: THERE is that ancient wisdom about not judging a book by its cover. But in the beverage industry, some companies seem convinced that they can win consumers over to their products by putting the usual brew in an unusual package.

title: North Korea, Ignoring Warnings, Proceeds With Plans to Test-Fire Missile
description: Despite stern warnings from the United States, Japan and South Korea, North Korea is proceeding with plans to test-fire a long-range ballistic missile this summer, diplomatic and security officials say.

title: More Than Meets the Eye
description: Here is a pool house that riffs on the familiar and comes up with something sublime. ''I call this the Jennifer Bartlett pool house,'' said Lee Mindel, a Manhattan architect whose firm, Shelton, Mindel & Associates, designed the structure without any actual help from Ms. Bartlett, the painter who typically turns plain outdoor elements -- a tree, a boat, a shed -- into elegant iconography.

title: An English Palace That Holds an Art Deco Dream
description: ELTHAM PALACE is one of the greatest modernist houses in England, a country in which domestic modernism was mostly a wan affair. Inside the restrained red brick and stone building, 11 miles from the center of London, is a newly restored platinum-blond Art Deco interior. The palace offers a rare insight into what was avant-garde in the 1930's and is a tribute to an idiosyncratic and modernist couple, Virginia and Stephen Courtauld, philanthropists whose wealth was based on rayon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEEWEISS, PAULINE (NEE GOLDFINE)
description: SCHNEEWEISS - Pauline (nee Goldfine). 6/2/13-7/22/96. Rivie, I love you forever. Sam

title: Silicon Valley's Own Work Threatens Its Domination
description: ''Don't look back,'' the legendary baseball pitcher Satchel Paige once said. ''Something might be gaining on you.''

title: Soup Line to the Left, Armanis to the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: IRELAND EMPLOYMENT BOOMS
description: A booming economy in Ireland has pushed unemployment below 100,000 for the first time in 20 years, according to the Government's Central Statistics Office. The unemployment rate of 5.8 percent, about half the European Union average, compares with a rate as high as 16 percent in 1993. The number of unemployed, the office said, is now 95,100. James F. Clarity

title: Is Strawberry Right in Left?
description: Joe Torre wants Darryl Strawberry back, but the Yankee manager has refrained from lobbying with Commissioner Bud Selig for the slugger's return. Selig will decide today whether Strawberry can return from a suspension that was triggered by his no-contest plea in a drug-related arrest.

title: Two Views of a Changing Vision
description: Been to Kennedy International Airport's T.W.A. terminal lately? Now it's crammed with machinery for processing the huddled masses. Once, it represented Eero Saarinen's most visionary work, featured in ''Ezra Stoller: The T.W.A. Terminal,'' a photo exhibition (above) at the Danzinger Gallery, 851 Madison Avenue (70th Street) through Aug. 13. Next month, Princeton Architectural Press will begin a monograph series ($19.95), ''Building Blocks,'' starting with ''The T.W.A. Terminal'' (top) by Mr. Stoller.

title: Soup Line to the Left, Armanis to the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Senator and Nephew, An Especially Close Link
description: Since 1968 Senator Edward M. Kennedy has been the patriarch of his family, the one many nieces and nephews called for advice or help. But his connection to John F. Kennedy Jr. had many special qualities.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Technology Helps Shares Make First Advance of Week
description: Stocks rose yesterday for the first time this week, led by computer-related shares like Microsoft, as Internet companies reported better-than-expected results.

title: Nun Opens Vatican Doors to the Net
description: THE Vatican was never a place associated with openness. Popes don't give interviews or news conferences, and the high walls around Vatican City are a kind of metaphor for a tradition of discretion that reaches back centuries.

title: Clinton Mistily Recalls Kennedy's White House Visit
description: In a misty reminiscence, President Clinton said today that John F. Kennedy Jr. came to the White House a year ago for the first time since his father was assassinated in 1963, and visited only when he had felt ready.

title: National News Briefs; Space Shuttle Launching Is Delayed a Second Time
description: Menacing weather within 10 miles of the Kennedy Space Center here early today grounded the space shuttle Columbia and its first woman commander on their second try at liftoff.

title: Lowe Wins Part Of iPlanet Account
description: The San Francisco office of Lowe & Partners/SMS has been awarded the off-line account of iPlanet, a new venture that offers software for Internet commerce. It is part of an alliance of Sun Microsystems and the Netscape Communications Corporation unit of America Online; Lowe is part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, ALAN
description: RAPOPORT-Alan. To our beloved friend. Your passing leaves a void in our lives. Goodness and a gentle way, coupled with your smile, always came shining through. We will miss you, but remember the good times shared. We say so long, not goodbye. Rest in peace, our dear friend. Gloria and Larry Klein and Family

title: In E-Mail, Many Ways to Say Goodbye
description: IN the emerging traditions of electronic mail, the proper way to say good-bye is still under construction.

title: Reports On Kennedy 'Dream Home' Are False
description: A local architect and town building department officials said there was no truth to news reports that John F. Kennedy Jr. and his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, were building a sprawling three-story ''dream home'' in this affluent Connecticut suburb near the New York State border.

title: Peace Stirs in Congo; So Does Political Ambition
description: The longtime opposition politician sat comfortably on his front porch one day this week, an arm's length from a cell phone that pealed with a call every few minutes. Having just emerged from 18 months in prison for criticizing President Laurent Kabila, the politician, Joseph Olenghankoy, was inclined to be generous.

title: Corrections
description: A map on June 30 with an article about the local effects of global warming over the next century, and the coastal areas that will be vulnerable to flooding, omitted the data source. It was Vivien Gornitz of the Center for Climate Systems Research of Columbia University.

title: Choreographic Villages From Around the Globe
description: In its earliest years, the American Dance Festival offered a place and a time to work to pioneers of American modern dance. The summer dance festival, now on the campus of Duke University, is today best known for its revivals of modern-dance classics by black choreographers and for its encouragement of dance students and choreographers from around the world. The focus of the festival's latter involvement is the annual ''International Choreographers'' program of commissioned works created during the festival with student dancers as performers.

title: Rebels Without a Cause
description: Some days it is impossible to understand American politics unless you remember that while most politicians are lovable, they are also breathtakingly self-absorbed. The people who choose such a miserable life style in the first place tend to have an insatiable desire to dominate every room they enter. And when they come to Washington, they enter a work environment that only further magnifies their self-importance.
