title: Brown Leads Field After Two Rounds
description: Mark Brown, a former college catcher who gave up baseball to concentrate on golf, shot a one-under-par 69 yesterday and took a two-stroke lead with a 137 after two rounds of the New York State Open at the Bethpage State Black Course in Farmingdale.

title: Bear Stearns Income Is Up, As Fees Grow From Trading
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that profit in its most recent quarter rose 56 percent, to a record, as a stock market rally and a comeback in mortgage bonds lifted trading and commission revenue.

title: Limits on Power and Zeal Hamper Firearms Agency
description: It was another routine transaction in the deadly business of how criminals get their guns.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Steady Eddie Cox, the Discreet Son-in-Law
description: WHAT did you call your father-in-law?''

title: A New Place on the Internet To Explore Space's Wonders
description: On Tuesday, the 30th anniversary of the moon landing, no giant steps were made into space but a small step was made on the Web. Space.com, a new site devoted to the world beyond Earth, was officially launched in New York.

title: From 3Com, a New Palm Pilot, Priced for the Limited Budget
description: With competition from Windows CE P.D.A.'s at one end and a spate of new low-end knockoffs at the other, the Palm division of 3Com has introduced a new version of the popular Palm Connected Organizer, better known as the Palm Pilot. The new Palm IIIe, released this week at a retail price of $229, is geared to the low end of the market -- to people who want a P.D.A. but balk at a $300-plus price tag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSOHN, LEONARD
description: MENDELSOHN-Leonard. Lenny, a wonderful, loyal and respected friend, always interesting and a delight to be with. We shall remember our days and nights together. Our condolences to Sylvia, his loving and devoted wife, and to the family. We join you in your sorrow. Bea and Bill

title: Footprints in the Sand From the 60's
description: UP a sand drive that peels off a back road there is a relic from a vanishing world: a modest 75-by-25-foot glass-walled pavilion -- one story, two bedrooms, two baths, a sunken living room, a galley kitchen and a perfect view.

title: U.S. Cancels Military Aides' Visit to Taiwan
description: President Clinton said today that he was canceling a visit to Taiwan by Pentagon officials planned for this week out of concern that it could heighten tensions between Taiwan and China.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan July 22, 1945 to February 21, 1993 Today, and every day, we celebrate your birth with pride in your remarkable and heroic life. Today, and every day, we embrace you with love and mourn our irreplaceable loss.

title: House Votes $1.4 Billion for Embassy Security; Senate May Balk
description: The House agreed today to spend $1.4 billion next year to protect American embassies from the sort of terrorist attack that left two American embassies in East Africa in ruins last summer.

title: In Paris, Jones Cruises And Greene Is Tested
description: Maurice Greene and Marion Jones sat side by side in the warm-down area, exchanging pleasantries about Paris and each other's speed as the men and women from the television crews leaned forward with their lenses and long microphones to try to muscle in on the conversation.

title: Excerpts From President Clinton's Wide-Ranging News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference by President Clinton yesterday at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Vulcan Ventures Withdraws From Planned Investment in Datek
description: Vulcan Ventures, the venture capital fund financed by the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, has pulled out of its part of a planned $300 million investment in the Datek Online Holdings Corporation, partly because of concerns about criminal and regulatory investigations into the on-line brokerage firm, according to people close to the situation.

title: Living the 8-Bit Dream in a 32-Bit World
description: AS a mathematician at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Steve Judd harnesses the power of Unix work stations and Cray supercomputers to detect and prevent the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSS, LAWRENCE L.
description: SCHLOSS-Lawrence L. On July 21 at age 98. Beloved husband of the late Janice. Loving father of Norma Wellington Koster. Cherished grandfather to Dean Wellington, Augusta Wellington Black, and Abraham Wellington and greatgrandfather to Ian, Jacqueline, Emma and Isabel. He was loved by all. Services Friday, 11AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: An Artist Whose Creations Live Out Among the People
description: Pepon Osorio, who was awarded a MacArthur Foundation ''genius'' award last month, has had his art displayed in the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of American Art. But to take in his latest mixed-media installation, you have to head up to the Young World Store on Third Avenue in East Harlem and look between the racks marked ''Girls 4 to 6X'' and ''Toddler Girls 2 to 4T.''

title: RYDER IN DEAL TO SELL BUS UNIT FOR $940 MILLION
description: Ryder System Inc., the largest United States truck-leasing company, will sell its school bus business to Firstgroup P.L.C., Britain's largest bus operator, for $940 million in cash. The sale will enable the Miami-based Ryder to focus on its logistics and truck leasing and rental businesses and to increase earnings, which have disappointed investors. The unit, Ryder Public Transportation Services Inc., made up about 11 percent of Ryder's 1998 revenue of $5.2 billion. The acquisition by Firstgroup, its largest outside Britain, gives the company a bigger part of the faster-growing United States market.

title: Bodies From Kennedy Crash Are Found
description: On the fifth day of a search that accompanied a great national wake, a red sonar blotch led searchers to the bodies of John F. Kennedy Jr. and his two passengers, trapped in the shattered fuselage of his plane on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Price Soars, but Hefty Copter May Not
description: The idea, back in 1983, was to replace the Huey helicopter, the workhorse of the Vietnam War, with a fast, cheap, light craft called the Comanche.

title: When Idealism Sets Teachers Back
description: To the Editor:

title: BP AMOCO TO MARKET LOWER-SULFUR GASOLINE IN ATLANTA
description: BP Amoco will offer a lower-sulfur gasoline at its 550 stations in the Atlanta area four years before it is required to do so under state regulations. Only premium grade will be offered with the lower sulfur content. BP Amoco's goals are to help reduce emissions that produce ground-level ozone, or smog, and to attract more customers. The step is to be announced today by Rodney F. Chase, the deputy group chief executive of BP Amoco, and Carol M. Browner, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Armstrong Is Engulfed by a Frenzy Over Salve
description: Lance Armstrong continued to make news on two fronts today: he protected his commanding lead in the Tour de France with only four more race days to go and he found himself ensnarled in still more charges and countercharges about drugs, with cycling's governing body and Armstrong both stating that he has been using a skin cream, with authorization, to treat saddle sores.

title: 2 Internet Companies Have Solid Quarter
description: Despite a slowdown in the growth of on-line use in the spring, two of the largest Internet companies reported results yesterday that largely confirmed analysts' expectations for the quarter ending on June 30.

title: Cooking Up Books At Home
description: MORE than one-third of America's 120 million workers do all or part of their work at home. While they may go to work in fuzzy slippers and bathrobes from time to time, home-office workers who want to compete with larger companies cannot afford to be casual or sloppy in their business correspondence. They need to produce the same high-quality reports and brochures as the big corporate offices do, but with fewer resources. They want to look like a million bucks without spending a million bucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, F. ALEXANDER
description: FRANK-F. Alexander. On July 19, 1999. Beloved brother of Ruth F. Cook. Cherished uncle of Daniel and Debbie Lorber, Henry and Liz Lorber, Julia Benson, Carol and Larry Rizzolo; loving great-uncle of Andy Lorber, Michael Benson, Katie Lagana, Eric Lorber, Greg Rizzolo, Sarah Benson, Douglas Rizzolo, David Benson and Trevor Rizzolo. A true Renaissance man, patron of the opera, collector of fine wines, chef extraordinaire, mentor and friend to all, and a country gentleman of Bucks County, Pennsylvania. Your wonderful spirit, wit and worldliness will remain forever in our hearts. You will be missed by all who knew and loved you.

title: Guessing Who Is on Line
description: MANY people have heard of the Turing test, the famous probe of computer intelligence named after Alan M. Turing, the British mathematician who suggested it. He proposed that if a computer could carry on a typed conversion with a person and successfully impersonate a human, that computer could be called intelligent.

title: Hallmark Buys a Rival
description: Hallmark Cards Inc., the nation's largest greeting card company, said today that it had bought Dayspring Cards Inc. from Cook Communications Ministries, broadening Hallmark's appeal in the fast-growing Christian card market. Financial terms were not disclosed. Dayspring, based in Siloam Springs, Ark., employs 400 people. It had sales of $52 million in the fiscal year that ended in May. The company publishes more than 150 million cards, including the Joyfully Yours line.

title: Daniel H. H. Ingalls, 83, Sanskrit Scholar and Harvard Professor
description: Daniel H. H. Ingalls, an impassioned scholar of the ancient Indian language Sanskrit and a longtime professor at Harvard University, died on Saturday at Bath County Community Hospital in Hot Springs, Va. He was 83 and lived in Hot Springs.

title: CUNY Chairman Eager To Present Chancellor
description: Not a man to waste a minute, Herman Badillo, chairman of the City University of New York, scheduled a news conference for this morning to present Matthew Goldstein, his candidate to be CUNY's next chancellor, after Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani endorsed his appointment on Tuesday.

title: Government Seeks an Ad Ban and Label Warning for Cigars
description: Responding to the rapidly growing popularity of cigars, the Federal Trade Commission recommended today that Congress impose restrictions on them like those already on cigarettes, including health warning labels and a ban on television and radio advertising.

title: When Idealism Sets Teachers Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: 'Fearful Symmetry' Now in Pixels Bright
description: WILLIAM BLAKE, the British poet, painter, engraver and printmaker who died in 1827, has been called the first multimedia artist for his hand-produced books of elaborately illustrated poems. Students who study Blake in high school or college, however, seldom fully experience his work, reading texts that are accompanied by poor-quality reproductions of his artwork.

title: Wraparound Sight and Sound You Can Wear on Your Head
description: Virtual reality continues to get a bit closer now that Sony introduced a new version of its Glasstron. The product mixes a pair of eyeglasses that simulate a 52-inch screen in front of the viewer with a pair of headphones that provide sound.

title: Belgrade Presents Schedule For Reservists' Back Pay
description: In an unusual open meeting of the Government intended to help assuage popular grievances after the Kosovo conflict, the Yugoslav Defense Minister announced today that army reservists would be paid overdue wages in installments over the next six months.

title: Novel Heart-Rate-Monitor Bra Shows Potential as a Lifesaver
description: The soccer star Brandi Chastain's Nike bra is not the only prototypical undergarment making the news this month. Kursty Groves, 26, an industrial design engineering student at the Royal College of Art in London, has invented a high-tech brassiere, called the Techno Bra, that features a built-in heart-rate monitor, wireless telephone and a Global Positioning System locator.

title: Spying Furor Brings Vote In Senate For New Unit
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a major overhaul of the Department of Energy today, creating a new agency within the department to oversee nuclear weapons programs in the wake of allegations of Chinese espionage.

title: Modular Solutions in a World Without Closets
description: THE more closet space you have, the more house you have,'' said Mary Danowski, a designer at Poliform, an Italian furniture maker with a showroom in New York. As industrial living spaces proliferate, so does the array of ingenious freestanding closets. The more efficient and organized the storage space, the less overwhelming the inevitable clutter will be. It's a theory, anyway.

title: Concessions by G.O.P. Leaders Breathe Life Into Tax-Cut Plan
description: After a day of frantic arm-twisting and deal-making, Republican leaders in the House took a big step toward salvaging their cherished tax-cutting bill early today, winning a critical procedural vote rewriting the legislation to quell a revolt by party moderates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, NATHANIEL
description: KATZ-Nathaniel. July 20th, 1999, at 91 years of age. Dearly loved husband of Audrey Stevens Katz, adored uncle of Geri Shapiro, Daniel Katz & Jeff Katz and devoted brother-in-law of Margaret Forsyth. Service Thursday, July 22, 11:30A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC., New York, the women's clothing maker, agreed to buy a 7 percent stake in Kenneth Cole Productions Inc., New York, the shoe and clothing-accessory designer, for $29 million. It is buying the shares at a discount to the price on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CENDANT PLANS TO SHED SEVERAL BUSINESSES THIS YEAR
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell ''several nonstrategic businesses'' in the second half of 1999 to help pay down debt and repurchase shares. The company said it expected to receive more than $1 billion from the sale and would use the proceeds to reduce its term loan by $350 million to $400 million and its shares outstanding by 40 million to 50 million. The company expects to have about 735 million shares outstanding on Dec. 31, about 21 percent less than it had last November, when it began a repurchase program. Cendant offers travel-related, real estate-related and other consumer and business services. The prospective sales were announced after the shares closed at $21.1875, down $1.1875.

title: A Bulb With a Dark Side
description: HOW many light bulb jokes does it take to change a halogen?

title: Barak on Europe's Role
description: The Israeli leader, Ehud Barak, told Prime Minister Tony Blair today that the allied effort to halt tyranny in Kosovo showed that Britain and the European Union could play a significant role in providing conditions for peacemaking in the Middle East.

title: Attachments #@%&#@ Are Full #+@&* cents# of Surprises
description: IMAGINE receiving an envelope that just will not open, or a sheaf of papers folded so intricately that they require an instruction manual to unfold, or a letter containing nothing but gobbledygook -- symbols and letters that are completely unintelligible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKINS, LYNN
description: PERKINS-Lynn, July 20. Beloved husband of the late Alice. Ever devoted & adoring father of Pamela. Cherished uncle. Proud & beloved member of Fountain House, NYC. Memorial serv.to be announced.

title: Seeing Schizophrenia
description: To the Editor:

title: U.P.S. Going Public And Its Employees Hope for Windfall
description: Ever since two Seattle teen-agers started a telephone message service in 1907 that grew to become United Parcel Service of America Inc., the company, now the world's largest package delivery service, has been a rarity in corporate America.

title: At News Conference, Clinton Takes On All Comers and Denies He Is 'Winding Down'
description: President Clinton held his second lengthy take-all-comers news conference in a month today to demonstrate his command of the issues and to try to put to rest any hints of looming lame-duckism.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Democrats React To Kennedy Crash

title: Johnson & Johnson to Acquire Centocor
description: Out to strengthen its pipeline of new drugs, Johnson & Johnson announced yesterday that it would buy Centocor Inc., one of the nation's largest biotechnology companies, for $4.9 billion in stock.

title: Latvia's Language Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Pattern Cited in Missed Signs of Child Abuse
description: More than three years after the death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo prompted an overhaul of New York City's child welfare agency, a rising number of abused or neglected children reported to the agency have died, and an advocacy group says the cases show a continuing pattern of caseworker and agency mistakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, ESTHER H.
description: GRUBER-Esther H. Age 98 in Briarcliff Manor, New York. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Gruber. Devoted mother of the late Alan Gruber & the late Althea Landau. Mother-in-law of Harriet Gruber. Loving Grandmother of Diane Graeb (John), Ruth Archuleta (Carlos), and Miriam Landau. James Gruber (Janet), Marian Montgomery (Walter) and Steven Gruber (Elizabeth). Great Grandmother of 16. A woman of great intelligence and grace. Graveside Service on Thursday, July 22 at 1:30 PM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. For information call Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

title: Small Gestures of Grief for a Young Man Larger Than Life
description: Anthony Owens pulled from his pocket a small square of paper, worn from being unfolded so many times. On one side was the letterhead of Hachette Filipacchi, publisher of George magazine. On the other side was John F. Kennedy Jr.'s autograph.

title: When Idealism Sets Teachers Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORDES, PETER A.
description: BORDES-Peter A. On July 19. Founder, chairman and chief executive officer of Greater Media, Inc. Born in Bridgeport, Conn., Mr. Bordes had homes in Princeton, New Jersey, Annapolis, MD., and Nantucket, MA. He graduated from Yale in 1949, did graduate work at Columbia and served as a Lieutenant in the Coast Guard. Prior to the recent sale of its cable television properties, Greater Media was one of the nation's largest privately held media companies. It currently owns 14 major market radio stations and community newspapers in New Jersey. Mr. Bordes is survived by his wife, Lee, daughters Cristina & Stephanie, & sons Peter Jr. and Stephen. A memorial service will be held at 1 PM Saturday, July 24, at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton. Contributions may be made to the Center for Marine Conservation, 1725 DeSales St., NW, Suite 600, Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Chase Manhattan Earnings Show Strength in All Areas
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose a greater-than-expected 25 percent partly because of strength in Internet investments, trading, investment banking and credit cards.

title: Fighters Customizable for Combat
description: FIGHTER MAKER does for martial arts what a deejay's turntable does for records: it takes you from simple play into a playground of mixing, matching, sampling, editing and recombination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBITETTO, RUTH DEVLIN
description: DiBITETTO-Ruth Devlin. Cherished wife of George. Beloved mother of Jane Sheridan of Lafayette, LA and George Jr. of Alexandria, VA. Loving grandmother of Devlin. Died June 29th. Services were private.

title: China Said to Prepare Ban on Sect; Protests Go On
description: Ratcheting up its campaign against an amorphous but fast-growing spiritual movement, the Chinese Government is expected to announce today a nationwide ban against the movement, Buddhist Law, according to reports in three Hong Kong newspapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLIS, PHILIP
description: MALLIS-Philip, at age 76, on July 20, 1999; loving brother of Maxwell Mallis and the late Meyer Mallis and Anne Gold; brother-in-law of Vera and Sylvya Mallis, and the irreplaceable ''Uncle Philip'' of Francine and Richard Wachtell, Harvey and Susan, Stephen and Linda, Stephanie and Fern Mallis, Joyce and Avner Markusfeld and Joanne Lampley, and beloved great-uncle of eleven nieces and nephews and five great-great nieces and nephews; and best friend of Ruth Moss. He loved his family, basketball-especially the Knicks. He loved the 'garment center', traveled the world, had a special love of fine food and wine, the arts, and was crazy about cats and penguins! Services will be held on Thursday at 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: After the Pyrenees, It's All Downhill As Armstrong Coasts
description: Putting the drug issues aside for a mind-clearing climb of four immense mountains, Lance Armstrong came through the Pyrenees today with a decisive lead that should make him the Tour de France's winner when the race ends Sunday in Paris.

title: Orthodox Bishop in Russia, Accused of Corruption, Is Removed
description: In an unusual disciplinary action, the Russian Orthodox Church has removed a Bishop who has been widely accused of corruption and sexual impropriety.

title: Lessons of the F-22
description: The House of Representatives should follow the lead of its Appropriations Committee and deny the Air Force money for buying the costly and unnecessary F-22 fighter. The F-22, also opposed by Speaker Dennis Hastert and the minority leader, Richard Gephardt, had been scheduled to begin production next year at an average cost of $200 million per plane. The Senate has already approved buying six F-22's. But if the House stands firm in a vote expected today, only research money will be available next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELON, MARTIN
description: YELON-Martin. Age 90. Died peacefully at home. Retired pharmacist. Beloved husband of Fanny. Father of Arthur and Judy, Bill & Harriet and Midge and Howard Lefkowitz. Grandfather of Sarah, David, Cindy, Joshua, Rachel and Jessica. Adoring great grandfather. Predeceased by grandsons Sasha and Michael. Martin was born and brought up in Brooklyn, graduated from Boys High School & Brooklyn College of Pharmacy in 1930. He loved sports and was an avid tennis player. He is the last of nine Yelon siblings. In his last years, he got his greatest pleasure from the new babies-Jessica, Alex, Zachary, Adam and the most recent Anna Kate and Talia. Funeral service Friday, 10:30AM graveside. Call Parkside Forest Hills for information.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALOFF, RUBIN.
description: MALOFF-Rubin. In loving memory of Rubin Maloff. July 22, 1998.

title: BOTTOM IN BRITISH RATES
description: Further cuts in British interest rates, now at a 22-year low, seem unlikely after the release of the minutes of a Bank of England policy-making committee meeting on July 8 showed the panel voted without dissent to keep the benchmark rate unchanged at 5 percent. It was the first time in a year that none of the committee's members had called for a rate reduction. The policy makers have reduced rates seven times in the last 10 months. Alan Cowell

title: Apple Offers iMac's Laptop Offspring, the iBook
description: With its corporate comeback gaining momentum, Apple Computer Inc. introduced a powerful notebook computer yesterday intended for the consumer market -- a machine that breaks new ground in the personal computer industry for both its industrial design and its use of wireless technology.

title: INSIDE
description: Cruise Line Admits Dumping

title: In Seeking Firearms Deal, Spitzer May Set Standard''
description: If New York's State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, sues the gun industry as he has threatened, he will simply join a long line of 23 cities and counties that have already done so.

title: Cell Phone Outlaw
description: An airline passenger who ignored repeated requests from the pilot and crew to turn off his mobile telephone was ordered today to spend a year in jail for ''recklessly and negligently endangering'' a British Airways flight in September carrying 91 passengers from Madrid to Manchester.

title: Economic Scene: Cream in Labor Market's Churn; Why Job Losses Are Rising Amid Job Hunters' Nirvana
description: At a time when joblessness has fallen to just 4.3 percent of the work force and employers are loudly complaining about labor shortages, companies are also announcing record numbers of layoffs. It doesn't seem to make sense, does it?

title: Doctor Groups Fault Medical-Plan Merger
description: The American Medical Association and the Medical Society of New Jersey have asked the state's Attorney General to examine the proposed acquisition of Prudential Health Care by Aetna Inc., saying the merger would severely limit health care choices for hundreds of thousands of New Jersey residents.

title: Investment in Webhire
description: Webhire Inc., which produces Internet software to assist in corporate recruiting and hiring, said this week that Softbank Capital Partners L.P. had agreed to invest $20 million in it and buy 1.67 million Webhire shares from Amazon.com Inc. The investments -- a total of about $31 million -- will give Softbank, the Internet investment arm of the Softbank Corporation, the Japanese software distributor, a 40 percent interest in Webhire, which is based in Lexington.

title: Police Officer Quits Job After Sex Abuse Charges
description: A police officer charged with sexually abusing five young girls resigned last week while in jail, officials said yesterday.

title: Bringing an Alien And a Robot to Life; The Gestation of the Simpsons' Heirs
description: A little over a year ago, Matt Groening had a tough decision to make: should his robot's head be square or rounded?

title: Baseball Prepared to Accept Umps' Resignations
description: Major League Baseball is prepared to accept its umpires' resignations and could take that step as early as tomorrow, a person with knowledge of the official thinking said yesterday.

title: Inventive Chefs Are Cooking From History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, LEE CUNNINGHAM
description: LISMAN - Lee Cunningham, passed away on July 19, 1999 after a long illness. She is survived by her loving husband, Richard D. Lisman & two devoted daughters, Hilary Bogert & Cyrena Fink; two granddaughters, Brigitte Jeanne and Chloe Lawrence and five brothers, A. Brean Murray, Sean, Noel, Kevin & Grant Cunningham, numerous nieces and nephews, & mother-in-law Sylvia Lisman. Services to be held at St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton, NY. Friday, July 23 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Rogosin Kidney Center of New York Hospital or to The St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton, New York.

title: Gunman Shoots Two In Car in East Harlem
description: Two men were injured yesterday afternoon when a gunman fired at their car on a crowded street in East Harlem, the police said. As of late last night, no one had been arrested in the shooting, which left one of the victims in serious condition.

title: Bank Dips Its Toe in South Bronx; Commerce Gingerly Follows Housing in Ex-Wasteland
description: Hilda Hernandez stared, stepped back, stepped up. She stared some more. The look on her face suggested that a flying saucer had just landed in her neighborhood.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: PENTAGON MISUSED MILLIONS IN FUNDS, HOUSE PANEL SAYS
description: Congress says in a new report that the Pentagon defied the law and the Constitution by spending hundreds of millions of dollars on military projects that lawmakers never approved, including a super-secret Air Force program. The Pentagon acknowledged some of the accusations tonight, saying honest mistakes led to its failure to notify Congress about the way it was spending money.

title: For Henderson, No Place Like Home
description: Though he already holds enough records to fill his own room in Cooperstown, there is a mark within Rickey Henderson's reach he covets more than any other.

title: Actor Resumes Role After Ordeal
description: It is rare for a star in a hit Broadway show to receive an ovation from his fellow cast members. But Alton Fitzgerald White got one yesterday, five days after he was mistakenly arrested on drug charges and strip-searched, then released after the police acknowledged their error.

title: PORTUGAL THWARTS DEAL
description: Portugal is standing by its veto of an alliance between a Portuguese financial company and a Spanish bank despite the threat of legal action by the European Union. The Finance Ministry said it ''reaffirms its conviction that it acted in full compliance with the relevant national and European laws.'' The Government contends there are irregularities in a proposed alliance between the Champalimaud Group, which controls the insurer Mundial Confianca and three banks, and Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain. But the Government has been accused of trying to shield Portugal's second-largest financial company from a foreign takeover.

title: Circuit City on the Web
description: Circuit City Group, the No. 2 United States consumer-electronics retailer, has begun selling on its Web site, www.circuitcity.com., with offerings of about 800 products, including camcorders, digital cameras, phones and vacuum cleaners. Circuit City said it would add more products before the Christmas season and would eventually include large appliances and personal computers. The company said on-line shoppers would be able to avoid shipping costs by picking up their orders at its stores.

title: Cut Capital Gains Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Working at Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN LEGAL MERGER
description: The European law firm Linklaters & Alliance said it would add Italy's No. 2 legal firm to its network of lawyers in Britain, Germany, Holland, Belgium, France and Sweden. London-based Linklaters said it would merge with Gianni Origoni & Partners, which has 145 lawyers, in September. The combined firm would be the world's third biggest with 2,200 lawyers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fear of Flying Can Be Healthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Soup Line to the Left, Armanis to the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.P.S. Plans to Go Public, Raising at Least $3 Billion

title: New Police Drug Policy Takes On Hemp Oil
description: A New York City Police Department policy that took effect this week has some officers wondering whether poppy seed bagels are now as off-limits to them as heroin, graft or consorting with organized crime figures.

title: Oerter, 63, Is Winning The Duel With Aging
description: Al Oerter, the only athlete to win a gold medal in the same event in four consecutive Olympics, looks as young as ever.

title: Imaging: From Daguerreotypes to Satellites
description: WWW.LCWEB.LOC.GOV

title: Ludwik Gross, a Trailblazer in Cancer Research, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Ludwik Gross, who influenced cancer research by showing that viruses could cause cancers in animals, died on Monday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 94 and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: 4 Essex Investigators Conducted Illegal Drug Raid, Officials Say
description: Four Essex County, N.J., investigators were indicted yesterday on charges that they raided a drug suspect's apartment in East Orange without a warrant, beat him, then lied to cover it up, officials said.

title: Apple Shrinks Its iMac To Size of a Notebook
description: How can Apple Computer top the phenomenal success of the iMac? With an iMac to go, Apple's chief executive, Steve Jobs, said yesterday at the Macworld trade show in New York City.

title: Fillies on Collision Course
description: The star filly Dreams Gallore flew into New York from Kentucky the other day on a strategic mission: to take her next step on the path that will lead to a showdown with Silverbulletday for championship honors among the nation's 3-year-old fillies.

title: With Trees Like These, Who Needs Acorns?
description: America likes to build mansions with great rooms, giant televisions and closets. Now that everything in the home has been inflated to comic proportions, greenery is having a hard time keeping up. Nothing looks so odd in front of a huge house as six-foot-tall trees dragged home from the nursery in the back of the Jeep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LUDWIK, M.D.
description: GROSS-Ludwik, M.D. On July 19, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Augusta Gross, loving father-in-law of Leslie B. Samuels, dear brother of Felix Gross, loving uncle and cherished by family and friends. Funeral services Thursday, July 22, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory to a worthy cause benefiting research on cancer or AIDS.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC CUTS
description: An austerity plan announced by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company will reduce its work force by 10 percent, or about 1,900 jobs, in the next 18 months. The cutbacks are aimed at helping Canadian Pacific match the efficiency of its more profitable rival, the Canadian National Railway Company. Rob Ritchie, president and chief executive of Canadian Pacific, said the cuts would be heaviest among unionized workers, but management and administrative jobs will also be reduced. The company, a transportation, energy and lodging conglomerate based in Alberta, also said that second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent but that the reorganization would result in a $199.3 million accounting charge. Timothy Pritchard

title: Hotel Clerk Is Charged In Co-Worker's Murder
description: A clerk at the Carter Hotel in Times Square was charged yesterday with murdering a co-worker on Tuesday by stabbing him in the stomach with a knife and hitting his head with a hammer, the police said .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARNEILLE, LENORE SCULLIN
description: DARNEILLE-Lenore Scullin. At home, Bridgehampton, NY, July 19. Born in St. Louis, October 8, 1906 to Charles and Stella Scullin, brought up in St. Louis and Washington, DC, moved to NY in 1926, married to Floyd G. Blair until 1952. Beloved mother of Mary Lenore Blair and the late David Gilbert Blair. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Bladen Jackson Darneille of Washington, DC, and Bridgehampton, NY, where they spent their summers. Memorial service Friday, July 23, 11:30AM, Church of the Queen of the Holy Rosary, Bridgehampton. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alumni Development Office, Miss Porter's School, 60 Main St., Farmington, CT. 06032, or the Choral Society of the Hamptons, P.O. Box 1031, Bridgehampton, New York 11932.

title: Canada Seizes Chinese Boat Smuggling In 100 Immigrants
description: A ship with no name carrying more than 100 Chinese immigrants without identification papers has been taken into custody by Canadian authorities off the coast of Vancouver Island in what is believed to be the largest interception of immigrant smuggling on Canada's West Coast.

title: Corrections
description: A highlight listing for tomorrow in the Television section last Sunday has become outdated. The rock group Aerosmith will not be appearing in ''Woodstock '99'' on Pay-Per-View.

title: Let's Not Get Too Wired
description: The Commerce Department has just reported that 67 percent of Americans still do not use the Internet. Even 38 percent of households with personal computers don't have an Internet connection.

title: Body Ware
description: To the Editor:

title: John Steelman, 99; From Riding the Rails to Top Truman Aide
description: John R. Steelman, a onetime hobo from Arkansas who later earned a Ph.D. in economics and became one of President Harry S. Truman's closest aides, particularly on labor matters, died on July 14 at a retirement home in Naples, Fla. He was 99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIER, I. MARTIN
description: SPIER-I. Martin. On July 20, 1999. Loving uncle of Jill. Great uncle of Jaya. Beloved soulmate and companion of Eugenie Woodrow. Close associate of Pauline Zirin. Service Friday, 9:45am, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory to Hadassah B'nai Brith, or American Cancer Society.

title: Political Briefing; A Run for the Senate, Or a Brawl for It?
description: Although Mike DeWine, an Ohio Republican, easily won election to the Senate in 1994 and has since shown well in the polls, Democratic leaders have always considered his support thin. So when he helped lead the charge to remove President Clinton from office, the Democrats' hopes to oust him in Election 2000 rose, in good part because Mr. Clinton carried Ohio in both 1992 and 1996.

title: Uncovered Short Positions
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange edged up a quarter of a percent in the most recent monthly period, the exchange said yesterday. Uncovered short sales rose to 3.73 billion shares for the month ended July 15, compared with 3.72 billion shares in June.

title: Maximum Applause for a Minimalist
description: There was another full house and another standing, cheering ovation at the end of Tuesday night's all-Steve Reich concert, the last of four presented by the Lincoln Center Festival to honor this pioneer of Minimalism. And once again the diversity and enthusiasm of the audience was heartening. It's not often that staid Alice Tully Hall is filled with so many dressed-down, wide-eyed young people.

title: A Nation in Mourning
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Excerpts From the Fed Chairman's Testimony to Panel
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, presented his semiannual report on the economy to the House Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIVYAK, JEFFREY L.
description: ZIVYAK-Jeffrey L. Devoted husband of Irene. Beloved father of Michael and Jennifer. Loving son of Manya. Dear father-in-law of Liz and Andre. Services are today, at 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. Donations in his memory can be made to NYU Law School, 40 Washington Square South, NY, NY 10012 or NAFDI (National Foundation for Depressive Illness), PO Box 2257, New York, NY 10116.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, HENRY
description: BIRNBAUM-Henry, 82. Died suddenly and tragically July 21, 1999. Born in St. Gallen, Switzerland, he served in an army intelligence unit 1941-1946, and was an investigator at the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials. He was the Chief Librarian at Brooklyn College 1952-1961, when he became University Librarian at Pace University, where he served with distinction for thirtythree years. Prior to his retirement in 1994, Pace University paid him the ultimate tribute by naming their library in his honor. He is survived by his brother Sol, his nephews Philip, Irwin, and Jeffrey, his nieces Phyllis, Marilyn, and Arlene, plus ten great and nine great great nephews & nieces. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, W. 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan on Monday, July 26 at 12:15 PM.

title: The Night Is Young but Full of Detours
description: ''Trick'' is a tenderhearted boy-meets-boy story that manages to incorporate the courtship-interruptus style of the Doris Day era into a Greenwich Village one-night stand. Its two doe-eyed principals are likable and shy, despite the steamy circumstances under which they meet. Lonely Gabriel (Christian Campbell, Neve's angelic-looking brother) ventures into a gay bar where the go-go dancer is sensationally hunky, and finds the whole experience so unsettling that he leaves in a daze. Then, on the subway home, who should appear but the dancer himself, Mark (John Paul Pitoc). Mark makes it clear to Gabriel that the night is still young.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Speech on Goals
description: Following is an excerpt from a speech delivered yesterday in Indianapolis by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the front-runner for the Republican Party's Presidential nomination, as provided by Mr. Bush's Presidential exploratory committee:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABAY, SONIA
description: GABAY-Sonia. Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of Sonia Gabay, beloved mother of its devoted member, David Gabay, and extends heartfelt condolences to David and Caroline, and the entire bereaved family. Yaakov Bienenfeld, Rabbi Ed Leventhal, President

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a senior United Nations official's criticism of NATO efforts in Kosovo rendered part of his comment incorrectly. The official, John Ruggie, an American adviser to Secretary General Kofi Annan, said the United Nations' relief workers and police were supposed to get ''up and running'' while the NATO force restored a secure environment. He did not say the force had already restored such an environment.

title: Pedophile Pleads Guilty To Molesting a Teen-Ager
description: A day after a New Jersey judge threw out the most serious sex abuse charges against him, a convicted pedophile admitted today that he molested Sam Manzie 13 months before Mr. Manzie murdered a sixth grade boy in 1997.

title: Young Sun Lim -- 'The Room of the Host'
description: Leibman Magnan Gallery

title: Tardy Kosovo Rebels Force Extension of Arms Deadline
description: A failure by the Kosovo Liberation Army to turn in a sufficient number of its heavy weapons, including mortars and antitank and antiaircraft guns, has forced NATO commanders to extend the deadline for compliance with a disarmament agreement to Saturday.

title: Foreign Affairs; Tick, Tock, Tick . . .
description: You couldn't make this up. Prime Minister Ehud Barak's favorite hobby is repairing old watches. It is so fitting, because if Mr. Barak has to juggle anything these days it is the multiple clocks ticking away in the Middle East -- some of which are of the innocent cuckoo variety and others of which have dynamite attached. The Israeli leader's tenure could well be titled ''Beat the Clocks.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the death of John F. Kennedy Jr. with his wife and her sister in an airplane crash attributed a statement about them imprecisely. It was Carolyn and Lauren Bessette's family -- not the Kennedy family -- who said: ''John and Carolyn were true soulmates, and we hope to honor them in death in the simple manner in which they chose to live their lives. We take solace in the thought that together they comfort Lauren for eternity.''

title: Trustees Anoint CUNY Chief With a Pledge Not to Meddle
description: The trustees of the City University of New York yesterday unanimously chose a new Chancellor who has intimate knowledge of the university and a reputation as a strong manager with high academic standards.

title: INDIA CRITICIZES DUTIES
description: India denied a United States accusation that its companies were dumping cut-to-length steel plates on the United States market. Indian steel comapnies were exporting to the United States only at internationally competitive prices, an official of the Steel Ministry said. The United States decision to impose preliminary antidumping duties of up to 59 percent on exports of steel plate to United States will mainly affect India's largest steel maker, the state-run Steel Authority of India Ltd.

title: Honors
description: * Carla Loffredo was elected president of the Advertising Club of New York, succeeding Steven Farella, who continues as chairman. Ms. Loffredo is senior partner and brand communications director at J. Walter Thompson, New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson Worldwide unit of WPP Group P.L.C. Also, Robert Mate was elected first vice president; he is vice president and publishing director at Meredith Corp., New York.

title: BRAZIL ON-LINE BANKING
description: An agreement was reached between Banco do Brasil and ZAZ, the Internet provider owned by the Spanish company Telefonica S.A., to provide the bank's clients with limited free Internet access to promote on-line banking. The accord gives Banco do Brasil and ZAZ clients five free hours a month of web access. Banco do Brasil, Brazil's largest bank, with nine million customers, is negotiating similar agreements with Internet companies throughout the country. Its competitors, Banco Bradesco and Unibanco, two large private-sector banks, already provide sophisticated on-line banking services to clients.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Powerful Indians Limp Into Yankee Stadium
description: They are a fragile team, these Cleveland Indians, much more fragile than a team sporting the best record in the major leagues should be. They have endured serious injuries, sloppy pitching and nearly two months of ordinary play.

title: The Great Beyond Via the East River
description: The author and critic Alfred Kazin, who grew up in Brooklyn as the child of poor immigrants from Russia, wrote elegiacally about the Brooklyn Bridge, considering it both his link to the joys of Manhattan and the needle that stitched him to America. Last month his widow, the writer Judith Dunford, marked the first anniversary of his death by casting his ashes into the East River in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge. It was, she writes, ''just where he wanted to be.''

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW; Beyond a Famous Shot, The Art of a Lifetime
description: It sometimes happens that a single work of art becomes so famous that it is indelibly identified with an artist; ''The Mona Lisa,'' for instance, or ''The Thinker.'' But most people know that Leonardo also painted ''The Last Supper'' and that Rodin also made ''The Kiss.'' Photographers, who make thousands more images than any painter or sculptor, are not so lucky. Some of them are known by a single image alone.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: New Video Releases
description: Payback

title: After a So-So Outing, Pettitte Still on the Block
description: If Andy Pettitte had pitched like a bona fide No. 2 or No. 3 starter in the first three months of this season, his outing yesterday would have been perfectly acceptable. He allowed four runs in six innings in the Yankees' 5-4 victory over Tampa Bay, and recorded his second consecutive victory.

title: I.R.A. Blames Britain for Breakdown of Peace Accord
description: The Irish Republican Army blamed the British Government today for last week's breakdown of the Northern Ireland peace settlement, saying hopes for the accord were now ''substantially diminished.''

title: China Steps Up Its Drive to Halt Dissident Sect
description: China stepped up its offensive against the Buddhist Law movement today, announcing a ban on the organization and unleashing a barrage of charges against its founder that revealed how seriously the Government takes the sect as a challenge to its control.

title: INSIDE
description: House Rejects Fighter Jet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHELAN, MARION A.
description: WHELAN-Marion A. (nee McDonough). Peacefully at home in her 90th year on July 22, 1999. Wife of the late John J. Whelan. Loving and devoted mother of Maureen Flood, John K. Whelan, Virginia Howard and Kathleen Sancton. Adored grandmother of Edmund R. Flood, Virginia E. Flood, AnneMarie Whelen, Kathleen A. Friery, Christopher J. Whelan, Patricia M. Flood, Maureen E. Michels, Ellen M. Howard and Kevin A. Howard. Cherished great-grandmother of Allison and Brian Friery and Sean and Daniel Michels. Predeceased by seven brothers and three sisters. Family will receive friends on Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville. Funeral Mass Church of the Annunciation, Crestwood, NY by her fond nephew Rev. John T. Monahan on Saturday, July 24 at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAIKIN, MAX JAY
description: CHAIKIN-Max Jay. On July 21st, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Helen Leidner Chaikin. Loving father of Joyce Chaikin Ahrens, Lynn Chaikin Epstein, Monroe Jay Chaikin. Brother of George and Fred Chaikin and Sarah Stone. Dear grandfather of Kimberley, Matthew, Darin, John, Melissa, Russell and Eric. Service Friday, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168th Street, NY, NY 10032.

title: Disney's Profit Increases Less Than 1%
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose less than 1 percent as slower merchandise sales and marginal gains in broadcasting offset growth at its theme parks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARDAY, ZOLTAN
description: ZARDAY-Zoltan, M.D., 65, at his home in Manhattan on July 7, 1999. Loved husband of Linda Perkin and father of Nicolette. Funeral in Budapest on July 30. Memorial service in December in New York City.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Hastert Triumphs, but Faces a Long High-Stakes Negotiation
description: By narrowly securing passage of a $792 billion tax cut today, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert won a sweet victory and avoided a precipitous collapse of his party's bargaining position for budget talks with President Clinton. But there is still a long road ahead in a high-stakes negotiation that is likely to set down many of the themes of the 2000 campaign.

title: A blitz by new media helps old media foil forecasts of doom.
description: THE boom in the new media of the Internet is supposed to portend the beginning of the end for traditional media along with a similar fate for the traditional advertising agency. But don't waste time trying to tell those purported dinosaurs about their impending doom: They're too busy counting the money pouring in from, of all places, the very companies that are supposedly going to put them out of business.

title: Warner-Lambert Reports Profit Rise
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said today that its second-quarter profit rose 36 percent on growing sales of Lipitor, a cholesterol-reducing drug, and Neurontin, an epilepsy treatment.

title: Giuliani Panel Asked to Consider 40 Changes to the City Charter
description: Researchers working for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Charter Revision Commission recommended 40 potential changes to the City Charter yesterday, including some that would diminish the budgetary and land-use powers of the City Council and others that would change the electoral process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, GEORGE
description: BAKER-George. Devoted and loving husband, father. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Hilda, his daughters, Wendy Baker and Joy Weber and his son-in-law, Dr. Norman Weber. Also his grandchildren, Aron Weber and Cindy Epstein and great-granddaughter, Jocelyn. He leaves one brother, Dr. Ben Baker. He will be missed by all who knew him. Donations may be made to The Queensboro Hill Jewish Center, 156-03 Horace Harding Blvd., Flushing, NY 11367, Rabbi Philip Rabinowitz, officiating.

title: Matinee Days: The Madness Is Curable
description: WEDNESDAY, of course, was matinee day, meaning another day of wall-to-wall people in the theater district.

title: Ernst & Young Gets Breaks To Stay in New York City
description: In a deal that marks the first time the city has granted tax breaks to keep an accounting firm from leaving, the Giuliani administration and the state have agreed to provide Ernst & Young with a $20 million incentive package to build a skyscraper in Times Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ANTHONY LANE
description: ADAMS-Anthony Lane, 54, of Greenwich, CT, died Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital. Born in Salt Lake City, Utah, Mr. Adams was the son of Elaine Evans Adams and the late Lane Webster Adams. He was the husband of Louise Rambo Adams. Mr. Adams was a Managing Director Investment Counsel for New Bridge Partners, LLC. He was a Graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and Harvard University. He was a member of the Lane W. Adams Achievement Award in Care Giving, Harvard Medical School Neurology Dept., a Board Member of the New York Racket & Tennis Club, Board Member of the Brook Club in NYC, National Golf Links of America in Southampton, NY, and the Round Hill Club. In addition to his wife and mother of Greenwich, Mr. Adams is survived by a son Anthony Lane Adams, a daughter Isabelle Adams, both of Greenwich and a sister Victoria Adams Quan of New York, NY. Services will be announced at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to Quan Fellowship in Neurobiology at Harvard Medical School, c/o Mary Beth Pearlberg, Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St., Bldg. A, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Lawmakers Pass Bill On Money For Military
description: The F-22 fighter jet was defeated in battle in Congress tonight, as the House voted overwhelmingly for a military spending bill that withheld $1.8 billion to buy the first six of the 21st-century warplanes.

title: Refugee Has Racquet and a Plan to Return
description: THREE months ago Shkumbin Mustafa, 22, who claims the title of Kosovo's tennis champion, was watching bombs fall on his hometown, the capital, Pristina. Now he's a pro at the children's camp at Green Hollow Tennis Club in East Hampton, N.Y., living at the manager's house on Three Mile Bay.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Politicizing Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Tells Analysts The Future Is Good, Sort Of
description: In summing up its year for financial analysts and investors today, a supremely confident Microsoft Corporation gave few indications that it felt embattled in its legal struggle with the Justice Department over antitrust issues. In fact, it defiantly asserted that these are the best of times for the PC industry.

title: C.I.A. Says Chinese Embassy Bombing Resulted From Its Sole Attempt to Pick Targets
description: The Director of Central Intelligence disclosed today that the agency had selected just one target in the 11-week air war over Yugoslavia, and its decision led to the accidental bombing of the Chinese Embassy in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F. JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F. Jr. The Board of Trustees, consumers, families and staff of YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities mourn the tragic loss of John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and his sister-in-law Lauren G. Bessette. John Kennedy Jr.'s commitment to individuals with disabilities and his pivotal role in nurturing the development of a professional workforce has resulted in a better quality of life for people with disabilities and a significantly well-trained and respected staff. We are proud to have been associated with John in these ventures and are forever grateful for his support. Through his Reaching Up, Inc., the Kennedy Fellowship Program and his proactive relationships with the City University of New York and the not-for-profit community, John has created a lasting legacy. Marcella Fava, Chairperson Paul H. Levitz, Ph.D. Vice Chairman YAI's Board of Trustees Joel M. Levy, D.S.W. Chief Executive Officer, YAI Philip H. Levy, Ph.D. President & C.O.O., YAI

title: S.E.C. Settles 4 Cases Offering 'Free Stock'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is cracking down on offers of so-called free stock, an increasingly popular method of attracting investors to Internet ventures.

title: Another U.S. Rate Hike?Greenspan Hints at 'Yes'
description: NEW YORK  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, sounded a hawkish note in congressional testimony on Thursday, saying the U.S. economy seemed to be growing too fast and indicating the central bank was likely to raise interest rates to slow it down.

title: U.S. Indicts 15 in Brokerage Firm Fraud Case
description: Fifteen people have been indicted on charges that they took part in a scheme to bilk tens of millions of dollar from investors on three initial public offerings, the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Barbara Chase-Riboud
description: Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Lyrical Lapses in Old Truths In a Crumbling Irish Family
description: The past is devious, dangerous and altogether uncertain in Brian Friel's ''Aristocrats,'' an elusive, shape-changing creature that can suddenly strike and wound without warning. While one of the play's characters, a middle-aged child of a man, may insist that the decaying family home to which he has returned was never haunted, it is of course filled with ghosts. This is Brian Friel's Ireland, after all, and for those who inhabit it, history is, as it was for James Joyce's Stephen Dedalus, a nightmare from which no one awakes.

title: Yield to Innovation Ahead: A Fleet of Democratic Dreams on Wheels
description: Nine vehicles meant to be the cars of the future have arrived at the Museum of Modern Art just in time for ''Different Roads: Automobiles for the Next Century.'' Their sleek forms and bright surfaces reflect the collective weight of contemporary design intelligence, which intends them to be easy on the human body, the environment, the eyes and the pocketbook, if you consider an average price of $10,000 to $20,000 easy.

title: 'Persuasion'
description: Lombard-Freid Fine Arts

title: 17 Companies Were Big Sites of Bush Giving
description: Individuals connected with 17 corporations or firms combined to give $50,000 or more to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, with the partners, associates and employees of one Houston law firm contributing a total of $184,850 to Mr. Bush's Presidential campaign, a study released today shows.

title: 'Soft Money' Compromise Taints Reform Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Kennedy Curse, and Other Myths
description: This week has been inexpressibly sad for those of us who had known John F. Kennedy Jr. since the day of his birth nearly 39 years ago. To rage at the cruelty of fate is of no avail. To rage at the fatuity of thoughtless media commentaries is perhaps just as futile, but it is difficult to remain silent, even during a period of grief, about some of the nonsense that has been mixed in with all the heartfelt expressions of sorrow.

title: Glowing Remembrances Of a Scottish Childhood
description: ''My Life So Far,'' a winsome childhood reverie of family life in Argyll, Scotland, in the late 1920's, offers such a muted, smoothly textured swatch of British nostalgia that you feel no qualms about languishing in its ''Masterpiece Theater'' vision of a safer, saner, more shining past. With its soft-focus portrait of a mildly troubled family viewed through the adoring eyes of a frisky little boy, it suggests Ingmar Bergman's ''Fanny and Alexander'' with all its demons comfortably subdued.

title: Boo! A Spooky Old House
description: Walls warp, statues morph and things go bump in the night as Liam Neeson plays a doctor who wants to study fear in ''The Haunting,'' from the director of ''Speed'' and ''Twister.'' And Lili Taylor (right), Catherine Zeta-Jones and Owen Wilson are colorfully cast as human guinea pigs.

title: Wells Is Offering Cone Some Practical Advice
description: Asked what David Cone should do between his perfect game over the Montreal Expos on Sunday and his next scheduled start, against the Cleveland Indians on Friday night, David Wells quickly answered, ''Go get drunk.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the News Summary in some editions yesterday, with an entry about Royal Caribbean Cruis es' guilty plea to dumping oil and chemicals at sea, was published in error. It showed a ship of Carnival Cruise Lines, not related to the day's news development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, HERBERT MICHAEL
description: KESSLER-Herbert Michael. On July 21, 1999. Loving father of Robin, Gordon & Bradford. Cherished grandfather of Alexander, Morgan, Chase and Samuel. Devoted husband and friend to many, he lived life to the fullest. We will miss him. Service on Friday, 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: KAISER PROVIDES DETAILS OF DEPARTURE FROM NORTHEAST
description: Kaiser Permanente, which said last month that it would pull out of the Northeastern United States, announced details yesterday of its planned departure. Kaiser, a nonprofit company that is the largest United States health maintenance organization, will shut down unprofitable health plans in Massachusetts and Vermont and sell its money-losing plans in New York and Connecticut. The four states account for 558,000 of Kaiser's 8.5 million members. Kaiser, based in Oakland, Calif., said it had agreed to sell its New York business, which has 270,000 members, to Capital District Physicians' Health Plan and its Connecticut H.M.O., which has more than 50,000 members, to Connecticare Inc. Kaiser declined to give the terms of the sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUPU, CORINA IOANA
description: LUPU-Corina Ioana. With deep sorrow, the family announces the untimely death of their beloved daughter, sister and niece, Corina Ioana Lupu. A memorial service will be held at 10 a.m. on Sunday July 25 at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton New Jersey.

title: A Private Ceremony at Sea For the 3 on Kennedy Plane
description: The ashes of John F. Kennedy Jr., a reluctant celebrity who had found snatches of privacy on kayaks and yachts, were committed to the deep this afternoon during a Roman Catholic ceremony carried out beyond the reach of long-range television cameras.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an advocacy group's report on a pattern of mistakes by the Administration for Children's Services in New York City misstated the year of a Federal lawsuit by the group, Children's Rights Inc., seeking a court takeover of the city agency. It was late in 1995, not 1999; a settlement was reached this year.

title: The Celebrity Who Was a 'Regular Guy'
description: In a city where glitz and grit cross paths on a regular basis, where good works and good looks sometimes join forces for just a night, John F. Kennedy Jr. had mastered the anomaly of being a celebrity ''regular guy.''

title: Focusing a Green Eye on Car Plants
description: HOW green is your Volvo? Its manufacturer is happy to tell you, in its recently published Environmental Product Declaration, a cradle-to-grave look at the pollution generated by the manufacturing, use and eventual dismantling of its S80 luxury sedan.

title: After Some Setbacks, Rivera Rights Himself
description: A blown save confuses Mariano Rivera in the way an incorrect answer might confound a math genius. Rivera will ponder and fret over failure, for in his mind all the factors should add up: he is better than the hitters and his stuff is overwhelming and, therefore, he should succeed. A plus B equals C.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Lisbon Bounty

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Pilot of Packed Japanese Airliner Dies After Subduing Hijacker
description: The pilot of a jumbo jet with 517 people aboard seized and disarmed a hijacker today, but he was fatally stabbed in the scuffle.

title: Setting Her Own Precedents; Hewlett's Chief Prefers the Path Less Traveled
description: Carleton S. Fiorina recalls dropping out of law school at the University of California at Los Angeles as one of the most difficult decisions she ever made. She had long assumed she would become a lawyer, following in the footsteps of her father, a Federal judge.

title: Europe Rides Bumpy Computer Road to Year 2000
description: Perhaps fittingly, Germany's first real scare about Year 2000 computer crashes came on a Friday the 13th.

title: Let New Moms Leave the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: A Youth Of 80 Kicks Up His Heels
description: Eighty years young, Merce Cunningham speaks to audiences wordlessly, surprisingly and directly through his choreography and his dancers. The brief celebratory season of his work presented by Lincoln Center Festival '99 through this weekend captures this spirit and features the spectacular new ''Biped,'' as well as guest appearances by the New York City Ballet and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Fed Chief Warns About Stocks and Tax Cuts
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned anew about euphoric stock markets today and pledged to act ''promptly and forcefully'' to prevent any revival of inflation.

title: REPUBLICANS PASS BIG TAX CUT TO SET STAGE FOR DEBATE
description: Republicans in the House put down their marker today in the debate over how to allocate projected Federal budget surpluses, passing the largest tax cut in nearly two decades despite a veto threat from President Clinton.

title: Settling H.M.O. Disputes
description: To the Editor:

title: GEAC COMPUTER AGREES TO BUY JBA HOLDINGS OF BRITAIN
description: The Geac Computer Corporation, a Canadian company that specializes in hardware and software for libraries, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire JBA Holdings P.L.C. of Britain for $137 million. JBA, based in Birmingham, England, sells software to manage inventories, payrolls and other functions known as enterprise resource planning. The company's main customers are in the food and beverage, apparel, automotive supplier and electronics industries. It had 1998 revenue of more than $330 million. Geac Computer, based in Markham, Ontario, had 1998 revenue of $428 million.

title: Compaq Selects Little-Known Insider to Take Company Helm
description: After looking at about 75 potential candidates, the Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had chosen its relatively unknown chief operating officer, Michael D. Capellas, as its president and chief executive.

title: Pretty Is as Pretty Does, and What It Does Is Not Pretty
description: In the guise of sending up beauty pageants (now there's a new one!) ''Drop Dead Gorgeous'' manages to load up on stereotypes, sneer smugly at Minnesota, stage a scene in which beauty contestants vomit en masse and make its audience wince through what may be a record number of miserably unfunny jokes. Under these circumstances, putting the words ''drop dead'' in the title really is tempting fate.

title: The Adventures of a Justice-Seeking Gizmo
description: Once in a while, junkyards yield up a gem, but most of the time they are only a lode of trash.

title: Trace International Files for Bankruptcy
description: The longtime Wall Street investor Marshall S. Cogan has put his closely held holding company, Trace International Holdings Inc., into bankruptcy protection, the company said.

title: Musical Memories in Understated Style
description: One sure-fire definition of a show business trouper nowadays is a resume that includes having once worked on the stage with Mae West. Gene Barry, the 78-year-old actor and musical comedy performer whose credits run from the television series ''Bat Masterson'' to the Broadway musical ''La Cage aux Folles,'' recalls having had that honor, in 1944. In his engaging cabaret act at the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel, an anecdote plucked from that experience centers on what happened when West insisted he dye his mustache for a part and applied her own homemade concoction to it.

title: From the Water's Edge
description: In 1799 a London cartographer named William Heather prepared a map of coastal New England. On Heather's chart the Atlantic Ocean is a blank, a generality of uninked paper. But Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket, home of fishermen and whalers in those days, are surrounded by shoals of numbers, each one the result of a depth sounding taken with lead and line paid out over the gunwales into a troublesome, unsteady sea. To that same sea, so well sounded and still so restless two centuries later, the Kennedy and Bessette families have restored the ashes of their children, John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and her sister Lauren.

title: Sometimes a Witness Needs Brains as Well as Protection
description: Some days the witness protection program sounds like a good idea. Walk out of your house with nothing but the clothes on your back; leave behind the stress-filled job, the debts, the complicated relationships (with the notable exception of those within the immediate family), all those appointments, all those calls to return. Someone hands you a plane ticket and new identification, and you fly away to a new city, where a house, a car and a whole new life await.

title: Let New Moms Leave the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Czech Goalie Signed
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that they had agreed to terms on a contract with the free-agent goaltender Milan Hnilicka.

title: Let New Moms Leave the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Kraft Foods Shifts Three Accounts
description: Kraft Foods, owned by the Philip Morris Companies, has reassigned accounts among three roster agencies with total billings estimated at $23.4 million.

title: Secret Campaign Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Educator's Bonus Hinges on Test Scores
description: The new Superintendent of Newark's public schools will be entitled to salary bonuses of as much as $20,000 per year if students show significant improvement in standardized test scores under her leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIFFANY, GORDON
description: TIFFANY-Gordon, 86 years old. From Weare, N.H. Died Tuesday at his home. Born in Port Chester, New York. The son of Henry Dyer & Beatrice (Gordon) Tiffany. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and was a 1935 graduate of Yale University. He was a graduate of Columbia Law School and later graduated from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts School. He is survived by one son, William F. Tiffany of Weare, NH, one daughter, Jean G. Tiffany of Portsmouth, NH, five grandchildren, two great grandchildren, several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife, Ellen (Auchincloss) Tiffany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHINN, C.O.
description: CHINN-C.O. Legendary Civil Rights figure in Canton, Mississippi. Afraid of no one, he gave courage to those around him, helping make Madison County the first covered by the '65 Voting Rights Act. He lived to see son Robert and daughter-in-law Mamie elected judges. He is survived by his wife, Minnie Lou, sons Robert and Henry Lee, grandchildren and great-granchildren with whom we share pride in knowing him and sorrow at his passing. Charney V. Bromberg William H. Forsyth, Jr. Tom Manoff

title: Paul Flato, Jeweler to Stars On Screen and Off, Dies at 98
description: Paul Flato, the innovative American jeweler whose diamonds were worn by Hollywood stars like Greta Garbo, Rita Hayworth and Merle Oberon, died July 17 in a nursing home in Fort Worth. He was 98.

title: Let New Moms Leave the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Signs Bill On State-Aid Increases
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill into law yesterday guaranteeing yearly increases in state aid to local municipalities based on the rate of inflation.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa prices increased on concern that the Ivory Coast, the world's biggest grower, would produce less than expected from its second crop this year. In New York, cocoa settled at $1,069 a metric ton, up $35.

title: Bradley Proposes Revamping Federal Campaign Finance System
description: Asserting that big money is the root of multiple problems in American politics, Bill Bradley, the former Senator from New Jersey, proposed a sweeping overhaul of the Federal campaign finance system today.

title: Allegations of Sleaze Set Off A New Controversy for Tories
description: LONDON  Since taking over as leader of Britain's demoralized Conservative Party two years ago, William Hague has worked patiently to rebuild the party's membership and revamp its image with fresh talent and policies.

title: Editorial Observer; How the Racial Literacy Gap First Opened
description: My great-grandfather John Wesley Staples (1865-1940) was vain about writing and scribbled even grocery lists theatrically, gesturing grandly with the pencil and pausing between words to lick its point. A fuss over a shopping list seems ridiculous -- until you consider that John Wesley was born in the slaveholding South, where educating black people was illegal until after the Civil War and where aggressively literate blacks were seen as subversive and even dangerous well into the 20th century. Modern writing on the role of race in academic achievement generally discounts this history. But the only way to grasp the extent of the problem is to acknowledge that black literacy was obstructed as a matter of law for more than a century.

title: Woman Found Slain in Central Park
description: A 39-year-old woman who appeared to have been sexually assaulted was found slain yesterday atop a hill near the northern tip of Central Park, with her head badly beaten and some of her clothes ripped from her body, law enforcement officials said.

title: Predicting A Defining Moment
description: The newspaper accounts of the time would not have been so different from the kind we read today.

title: Things That Go Bump, and Worse, in the Night
description: ''The Haunting'' shows what happens when four visitors disturb the equilibrium of Hill House, a colossal, chokingly ornate hideaway where no inch is left unadorned and the prevailing style is Gothic Nouveau Riche. Under the circumstances, ''The Flaunting'' would have made a better title. This latest special-effects free-for-all from Jan De Bont (''Speed,'' ''Twister'') is a lavish illustration of how to take a fairly modest black-and-white horror film from 1963 and amplify it so relentlessly that the sight of the flying cow in ''Twister'' would not be all that amiss.

title: Taiwan's President Declines To Soften His New Doctrine
description: Defying pressure to soften his stance, President Lee Teng-hui reaffirmed today that Taiwan will only talk to China as a separate state, and he predicted that China would eventually accept Taiwan's new position. Mr. Lee called his new diplomatic tack 'friendly and positive,' and not provocative, as Beijing has termed it.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: By Any Means Necessary, From Baiting to Boasting
description: Mighty, exhilarating, focused, thought-provoking, body-rocking, the greatest hip-hop group ever: that was Public Enemy at Tramps on Wednesday night.

title: A Schumann First Draft on His Kind of Piano
description: In the concert hall, Robert Schumann's Piano Concerto is less ubiquitous than it was a couple of decades ago, but a vast backlist of recordings has helped it retain its status as one of the most popular concertos in the repertory, and the very definition of a war horse. But Robert Levin, the pianist and musicologist who is to play the work tonight with Sir John Eliot Gardiner and the Orchestre Revolutionnaire et Romantique, is hoping his reading will help audiences hear the work a bit differently.

title: Sports of The Times; L.T. Gladly a Guinea Pig for His Kids
description: WHEN he was L. T., the best outside linebacker ever to play football, he thought of Giants Stadium as his office.

title: U.S. Is Said To Investigate Datek Trading
description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is investigating trading activities at Datek Securities that took place as recently as two years ago, according to an official close to the case.

title: INTELLIQUEST AGREES TO SELL DIRECT-MARKETING DIVISION
description: Intelliquest Information Group Inc., a technology market-research company, agreed yesterday to sell its IQ2.net direct-marketing division to Naviant Technology Solutions for $46.5 million in cash. IQ2.net owns a data base of Internet-user households and provides related marketing services. Intelliquest, based in Austin, Tex., will also enter a partnership with Naviant, a closely held technology consulting company in Newtown Square, Pa., to use the combined Naviant-IQ2.net data base for its Internet research. Intelliquest said it planned to focus on its main research and growing Internet businesses.

title: FOOD PACKAGING MERGER
description: Finland's largest maker of food packaging, Huhtamaeki Oy, will buy a Dutch rival, Royal Packaging Industries Van Leer N.V. for 1.4 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in cash and debt, creating the world's largest maker of paper and plastic containers. Huhtamaeki will pay 29.04 euros a share, and the Helsinki-based company will also take on 445 million euros in debt. The combined entity, with sales of 2.8 billion euros and businesses in 55 countries, will unite Van Leer's Chinet disposable plates and bowls with Huhtamaeki's Polarcup and Sealright brands.

title: Trudi Schoop, 95, Pioneer In Therapy Using Dance
description: Trudi Schoop, a popular Swiss-born comic dancer who became a pioneer in the use of dance movement to treat mental illness, died on July 14 at her home in Van Nuys, Calif. She was 95.

title: Dreams Gallore Making a Run at the Star Fillies
description: Coming up fast on the outside in the race for 3-year-old filly honors: Dreams Gallore. Not Silverbulletday and not Excellent Meeting, both from Bob Baffert's richly stocked barn in California, both veterans of the Kentucky Derby, both acknowledged superstars of the filly class.

title: 'Artist in the Marketplace' -- 19th Annual Exhibition
description: Bronx Museum of the Arts

title: MINE STRIKE THREATENED
