description: South Africa's gold industry, the world's biggest, faces a nationwide strike in as little as two weeks unless managers retract plans to dismiss workers, the country's biggest mining union said. The National Union of Mineworkers threatened to expand a seven-day strike by 4,100 miners to protest proposed job cuts at Gold Fields Ltd., the world's second-biggest gold company, to include as many as 200,000 workers nationwide. South African gold companies, which have the highest average production costs in the industry, need to cut more than 80,000 jobs to survive with prices at a 20-year low, the Chamber of Mines says.

title: Let's Slow Down on Holbrooke's Case, Lott Says
description: Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, has ordered his staff to take a ''second look'' at the nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to be the chief United States delegate to the United Nations to determine if the veteran diplomat is fit for the post, the Senator's office said today.

title: Loved, Abandoned, Sold: Safe-Deposit Auctions; Mysteries Up for Bid at Auctions of Safe Deposit Items
description: There were lots like 158: one Keystone Everflash camera, one calculator, one clock radio and two Monster Mash LP's. It went for $46.

title: Weary Riders Sprint to Finish With the End in Sight
description: Most of the riders in the Tour de France are weary and mainly looking forward to the end in Paris on Sunday, which should have meant that the long, flat stage today would be raced at a moderate speed by a compact pack. Piano, piano, as the riders say -- quietly.

title: '7 Women 7 Years Later'
description: Andrea Rosen

title: Starr Set to Speak at a Conservative Fund-Raiser
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, has agreed to be the keynote speaker at a November fund-raiser for a group calling itself ''Minnesota's conservative think tank,'' drawing criticism from a Democratic Senate candidate in that state.

title: Metro Business; Vornado Widens Holdings
description: Vornado Realty Trust said yesterday that it had bought the lease to a 33-story Manhattan office building, increasing its position as the largest office-building landlord in New York.

title: An Island Loved for What It Doesn't Have
description: To be frank, my first thought as the ferry pulled into the dock at Block Island was: Uh-oh.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: AFRICA

title: In a Coup for Cable, HBO's 'Sopranos' Receives 16 Emmy Nominations
description: HBO's acclaimed drama ''The Sopranos'' today became the first cable-network series to be nominated for an Emmy Award for best drama, and also earned more Emmy nominations -- 16 -- than any show, broadcast or cable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGILVY, DAVID
description: OGILVY-David. Yours is a legacy of intellect, civility and creative energy that survives in the great agency you founded and the people you've taught. We mourn the passing of David Ogilvy. Your friends at Davis & Gilbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, ROBERT K.
description: RAISLER-Robert K. Penn Engineering notes with sadness the passing of our alumnus and friend. Robert Raisler was President of the Class of 1926 and the 1993 recipient of The Yarnall Award for Excellence in Engineering. Always a gentleman he was admired by students, faculty and alumni of the school. We will miss him. Eduardo D. Glandt, Interim Dean

title: Where Life Is Brutal, Humiliation Becomes Sport
description: When a character in Goran Paskaljevic's film ''Cabaret Balkan'' declares Belgrade to be ''a hemorrhoid'' on the anatomy of the world, it is one of the nicer descriptions of a city that this almost unbearably vicious movie depicts as hell on earth. Mr. Paskaljevic, a Serbian filmmaker passionately opposed to Slobodan Milosevic, has called his movie a black comedy. Maybe so. But the only laughs to be gotten from this acerbic, powerfully acted ''La Ronde'' of cruelty, torture and unrestrained anger come from the mouths of enraged characters as they gleefully inflict excruciating pain and humiliation.

title: Former Army Chief Denounces Milosevic
description: The former chief of the Yugoslav Army said today that he was considering entering active politics and called for the peaceful ouster of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, charging that he has politicized the army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, PHYLLIS
description: BUSCH-Phyllis, Dr. (Schnell). A teacher and writer, born in 1909 in Manhattan, died on July 14 at her home in Lakeville, CT after a brief illness. Dr. Busch, the widow since 1989 of the prominent international lawyer Benjamin J. Busch, received her Bachelor's Degree from Hunter College and her Ed.D. from New York University. She taught for many years at Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn and then at Montclair State University and The City University of New York. A child of the lower East side, she became a devoted naturalist & was the author of many books for children about ecology and the environment, four of which are in the process of publication. Dr. Busch contributed her time to numerous school groups & was an enthusiastic membner of such organizations as The Sharon Audubon Society and The Nature Conservancy to which rememberances may be made. She is survived by her sons Eric of Philadelphia and Frederick of Sherburne, New York, and by two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in the autumn.

title: Crossing to the Great Beyond via the Brooklyn Bridge
description: On a beautiful sunny day this June, just a shade over a year after the writer and critic Alfred Kazin died, his ashes were consigned to the East River in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: RELIASTAR IS ACQUIRING PILGRIM CAPITAL FOR $258 MILLION
description: The Reliastar Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Pilgrim Capital Corporation, a fund manager, for $258 million in stock and cash. Reliastar, based in Minneapolis, is a financial services company involved in life insurance, banking and other businesses. It said Pilgrim shareholders would receive $12.50 cash and half a Reliastar common share for each Pilgrim share. Reliastar will also assume $31 million of debt. The acquisition would add the $7.6 billion managed by Pilgrim Capital, which is based in Phoenix, to Reliastar's fund unit, which manages about $4.4 billion. Together, they would have $12 billion in mutual fund assets and 32 funds.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about second-quarter profit at Bear Stearns misstated the reason for a $108 million charge taken in the second quarter of 1998. The charge was related to a lawsuit involving the firm's investment banking division, not litigation involving A. R. Baron, a defunct brokerage firm for which Bear Stearns acted as a clearing agent.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Business; Con Ed Says Buyers Seek Nuclear Plant
description: Consolidated Edison has received several inquiries about its Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County, Eugene McGrath, its chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDELL, JEFFREY R.
description: BEDELL-Jeffrey R., Ph.d. The Department of Psychiatry at Mount Sinai School of Medicine/ Mount Sinai-NYU Health and Mount Sinai Services Elmhurst Hospital Center, mourn the passing of Jeffrey R. Bedell. A distinguished researcher in community psychiatry and talented clinician and teacher, Dr. Bedell was an Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Mount Sinai and Director of the Community Options Program at Elmhurst Hospital Center. His innovative work in cognitive, behavioral and rehabilitative therapies with the severely mentally ill will be remembered with respect and fondness by consumers, and colleagues. Prior to working at Mount Sinai, Dr. Bedell was the Director of the Behavior Therapy and Rehabilitation Program at Albert Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and the Chairperson of the Department of Community Mental Health at the Florida Mental Health Institute, Tampa. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife and family. The family requests in lieu of flowers, that donations be sent to The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Community Options Program, c/o Dr. Ann Sullivan, Elmhurst Hospital Center, 79-01 Broadway, Elmhurst, N.Y. 11373. Memorial service 3PM Saturday, July 24, 1999, Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, N.Y. 914949-0566. Kenneth L. Davis, MD, Chairman The Faculty and Staff of the Department of Psychiatry Mount Sinai Medical Center and Elmhurst Hospital Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKEY, BARBARA A.
description: MACKEY-Barbara A. (nee Healy), of New York, NY, on July 21st, 1999. Beloved wife of Edward. Loving daughter of William A. and the late Doris M. Healy. Devoted sister of William A. Healy, Jr. and his wife Carol, Carole Wittenberg and her husband Gary, Gail M. Burns and her husband William, and Nancy J. Healy. Cherished daughter-in-law of Edward W. and Rose Mackey. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 AM, at St. Paul The Apostle R.C. Church, Cedar Swamp Road (Rte. 107), Brookville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Barbara's memory to the American Cancer Society would be deeply appreciated.

title: Ford Workers in Brazil Strike Over Shift of Plant
description: In a move that increased tension over the Ford Motor Company's plan to build a $1.3 billion car factory in Brazil's poor northeast, far from the industrial south where most of this country's auto industry is concentrated, 1,500 workers at the company's truck plant here went on strike today, fearing that their jobs are threatened.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Sounds Like . . .

title: The Battle for the Berkeley Airwaves Rages On
description: By 8 A.M., a dozen or so protesters were standing in front of the offices of radio station KPFA, holding signs asking the drivers zooming across Martin Luther King Jr. Way to ''Honk for Free Speech.''

title: Court Ruling Favors 2 Who Left Baby Outside
description: A Danish tourist and a Brooklyn man arrested in May 1997 for leaving their baby daughter in a stroller outside a restaurant can sue the city for its handling of the incident, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: 'Gimmick' Eased Passage Of Tax Bill
description: All day on Wednesday, Republican leaders negotiated with a small band of moderate Republicans who were threatening to bring down the party's cherished tax-cut bill on the ground that Congress might be risking money the Government did not have.

title: 'Mozart on Television' -- New Painting From Germany
description: Deitch Projects

title: CBS TO EXCHANGE ADVERTISING FOR 20% STAKE IN RX.COM
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 20 percent interest in Rx.com Inc. for $37.5 million in advertising and promotion over four years. Rx.com, based in Austin, Tex., is a privately held on-line retailer of over-the-counter medicines and vitamins. The company said it planned to offer prescription medicines late this year. CBS, the New York-based broadcaster and media company, has also invested in Medscape.com, an Internet site that offers peer-review reports and journal articles organized by medical specialty.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: This Time, Nothing Gory

title: Hershiser's 200th Keeps Mets Rolling
description: Orel Hershiser had a special feeling when he got his 199th career victory, because it was his 100th after shoulder surgery that nearly ended his career.

title: A Tale of Angst and a Girl With the Devil in Her Head
description: Rosie (Aranka Coppens) is an adolescent Belgian girl with a Mona Lisa smile, something she badly needs for dealing with the volatile adults in her life. Growing up in a gloomy, semi-industrial Antwerp setting, she lives with a woman named Irene (Sara de Roo), who becomes furious if Rosie tries to call her ''Mummy.'' She fends off Irene's boyfriends, of whom there are apparently quite a few. And as Patrice Toye's film soon makes clear, her closest relatives are not any help to her. The film first finds Rosie in an institution for delinquent girls, with the question ''Are you sorry you did it?'' hanging ominously in the air.

title: Heinz Selling Its Weight Watchers Unit
description: The H. J. Heinz Company broke up the odd couple of food and dieting yesterday with an agreement to sell its Weight Watchers diet-class business to a European investment firm for $735 million.

title: The Silence on Under-Age Drinking
description: An important public health cause suffered a setback recently when the House Appropriations Committee killed a sensible plan to include anti-drinking messages in Federal efforts to discourage youngsters from using illicit drugs. The full Senate defeated a similar measure.

title: Bootlegging, Murder And Other Family Values
description: Here's an offer you can refuse.

title: ABC Extends McKay's Contract
description: The longtime ABC broadcaster Jim McKay signed a multiyear contract extension, the network said. McKay, 77, will continue to be the host of ABC's coverage of horse racing and the British Open and will have a recurring role on ABC's Wide World of Sports.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deal for Prudential Unit Seems Close to a Give-Away

title: In Iran, Islam Can Spur Change
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAK IN LOGJAM ON ALBANY BUDGET
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders removed the last major obstacle to a new state budget today, reaching agreement on a plan to spend more than $700 million on school repairs, new housing for the mentally ill, highway projects and a smattering of tax cuts.

title: Cities Turn to U.S. Gun-Tracing Data for Legal Assault on Industry
description: In an undercover operation last year, Chicago police officers posed as local gang members and went shopping for firearms. Their targets: the suburban gun stores that had sold the largest number of guns recovered from city crime scenes or seized by the police from people carrying them illegally.

title: French Utility to Raise Stakes in Two Pay-TV Companies
description: Vivendi S.A., the French utilities giant, made a double lightning strike on Europe's rough-and-tumble pay-television industry today, agreeing to pay around $2.7 billion in cash and stock to increase its holdings in the Continent's two biggest pay-TV stations -- Canal Plus S.A. of France and B Sky B of Britain.

title: A New Outlet For Indie Films
description: For moviemakers who can't find distribution for their work, a lifeline of sorts has been thrown by the on-line retailer Amazon.Com. Abide by a few regulations, and a film that might have played a festival or two but was never bought, or a student film, or a pick-up production financed by friend, parent and credit card could be just as available as ''Forrest Gump'' and ''Titanic.''

title: In Iran, Islam Can Spur Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTIG, JANICE M.
description: LUSTIG-Janice M. Devoted wife of Donald. Beloved mother of Jack and Julie Lustig and Sheri and Steven Suzzan. Cherished grammy of Julie, Samantha, and Kimberly. Dear sister of Myrna Hibel. Services today, 1 P M at Midway Jewish Center, 330 South Oyster Bay Rd, Syosset, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, RUBY P.
description: SCOTT-Ruby P., daughter of John and Estelle Scott, passed away on July 13, 1999. Services were held at Calvary/St. George Episcopal Church on July 19, 1999, with interment at Woodlawn Cemetery in Bronx, New York.

title: Promise Found in Alternative To Vaccine Barred for Babies
description: An experimental vaccine for rotavirus, the leading cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children, may be more effective and easier to deliver than the standard vaccine, a new report says.

title: CAREMATRIX TO CONSIDER BECOMING A PRIVATE COMPANY
description: The management of the Carematrix Corporation, an operator of retirement communities that has had a 68 percent drop in its share price this year, is considering taking the company private. The company's board voted yesterday to look into a leveraged recapitalization or other alternatives. The company, based in Needham, Mass., said it was seeking an investment banker to help explore its options. Carematrix and other operators of retirement communities have been hurt because of reductions in government funds as well as the possibility of more government oversight. Carematrix, whose shares traded as high as $31.125 in November, slipped 37.5 cents, to $9.75, leaving the company with a current stock market value of about $175 million.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Tuesday about preparations for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia reversed the identities of two crew members in some copies. Those walking behind the commander, Col. Eileen M. Collins, and the pilot, Jeffrey Ashby, were, from the left, Michel Tognini, Catherine G. Coleman and Steven A. Hawley.

title: FLORIDA COMPANY IS SUSPENDING SALES OF TIMBERLANDS
description: The St. Joe Company, Florida's largest private landowner, said yesterday that it would suspend sales of its timberlands until the market improves and it evaluates new markets. The company, which announced in March that it would sell about 800,000 acres of northwest Florida timberland, said market conditions had weakened since then because of mill closings, low pulp prices and competition from other land sellers. St. Joe, based in Jacksonville, Fla., a former paper company turned developer, has been selling timberlands and sugar-cane land as it seeks to focus on commercial real estate. The company said that in this case, the auction process revealed a number of options for the lands' use that will now be evaluated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LOUIS
description: PHILLIPS-Louis. Died peacefully on July 17 in Stamford, CT. Loving husband of the late Teddy, adored uncle and cousin of three generations. Distinguished educator, musician, and gentleman.

title: It's Hard to Keep Executives at AT&T
description: At a meeting of the AT&T Corporation's board on Wednesday, the two sides of the company's executive incubator were hard at work. The nation's biggest communications company takes executive development seriously, and this was the directors' chance to learn about some of the company's possible future leaders.

title: An International Cast Has Nets Thinking Big
description: The Nets have a vision. It is of Keith Van Horn posting up small forwards, of Jayson Williams banging with power forwards and of somebody, anybody, scoring, rebounding and defending from the center position.

title: Anne Woolliams, 72, Teacher And a Leader of Stuttgart Ballet
description: Anne Woolliams, a British ballet teacher who played a major role in the international success of the Stuttgart Ballet and who became artistic director of the Australian Ballet and the Vienna State Opera Ballet, died in Canterbury, England, on July 8. She was 72 and lived in Canterbury.

title: Cities Mount Assault On the Gun Industry
description: While Congress debates the fine-tuning of laws governing who can buy guns, Chicago and at least 20 other cities and counties have begun a broad legal assault on the gun industry similar to the one started by states five years ago against cigarette makers.

title: Mexico City Journal; Uncensored: The Lives of Mexico's First Ladies
description: The official reaction to Sara Sefchovich's modest initial attempt at a book about Mexico's First Ladies, a 1982 photo collection accompanied by a few biographical details, was immediate and draconian.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HERMAN MILLER INC., Zeeland, Mich., the No. 2 maker of office furniture, said it would acquire Geiger Group Inc. for about $39 million in stock and cash to expand its wood furniture product lines.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''So Mr. President, we say, what's wrong in letting American taxpayers keep more of their hard-earned money. We trust them to spend it right, and we think you should too.''

title: Problem Gamblers' Debts Worse Than Ever in 1998
description: Compulsive gamblers in New Jersey were deeper in debt last year than ever before, according to a recent study.

title: Window-Shopping: Is It Mr. Right or Just Mr. Raw?
description: Has it really been 30 years since Broadway audiences gasped at the sight of the cast of ''Hair'' standing nude on stage for a few minutes? Now theatergoers at the Actors' Playhouse in Greenwich Village gaze casually and smile good-naturedly as the cast of ''Naked Boys Singing'' performs its lightly teasing opening number, ''Gratuitous Nudity,'' and much of the rest of the show, equally unclothed.

title: Umps Unite As Baseball Hires Backups
description: Undaunted by the prospect that their careers could end any day, major league baseball umpires contended yesterday that they had stemmed the tide of defections from their ranks. At the same time, however, Major League Baseball began hiring minor league umpires as replacements for major leaguers who are resigning as of Sept. 2

title: Clinton Aides Seek Alternatives To an I.M.F. Sale of Some Gold
description: Faced with mounting opposition in Congress, the Clinton Administration began backing away today from plans to have the International Monetary Fund sell a portion of its gold reserves to finance debt relief for some of the world's poorest nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, ROSALIND JUDY
description: POLLACK-Rosalind Judy. Beloved wife of Bernard; devoted mother of Marlene, Steven, and Jamie. Veteran of WWII. Docent at Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts. Services Sunday 12 noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN CLIMBS. The dollar sank to a five-month low against the Japanese yen as United States stocks and bonds fell on concern that interest rates will rise. In New York, the dollar slid to 116.70 yen, from 118.10 on Wednesday.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Can New York take another northern Italian restaurant? Sure, if it's as sleek and confident as Viceversa.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: It's Not Easy Bein' Green

title: Proof of God Arrives in a Small Brown Envelope
description: A CORNER OF THE VEIL

title: Inso to Eliminate 150 Jobs
description: The Inso Corporation, which makes digital publishing software, said today that it would cut 150 jobs, or more than 20 percent of its work force, and take a second-quarter charge of $6.8 million. The cost associated with the job cuts, and the closing of some sales and administrative offices, totals $4.5 million. The rest of the charge is for writing down some product development costs and discontinued products. Inso expects annual savings of $17 million from the revamping. Shares of Inso fell 31.25 cents, to $4.50. They have dropped 82 percent this year.

title: Gina Berriault, 73, an Author Of Deft Novels and Short Stories
description: Gina Berriault, an award-winning writer of short stories and novels, died on July 15 at Marin General Hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. She was 73 and lived in Sausalito, Calif.

title: Trouble Over Taiwan
description: Tinkering with the status of Taiwan is the diplomatic equivalent of handling nitroglycerin. President Clinton seemed well aware of the dangers as he carefully picked his words this week in commenting about heightened tensions between Taiwan and China. President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan would do well to follow Mr. Clinton's example. Unhappily, he shows no sign of doing so, and yesterday declared that negotiations between Taiwan and the mainland would not move forward until Beijing acknowledged the island as a separate state.

title: Iberian Appeal
description: Judging by the crowds that often fill these 12 restaurants, the robust cooking of Spain and Portugal is highly appealing to New Yorkers. Paradoxically, new Iberian restaurants open only occasionally. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Politicizing Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide Says Barak Accepts Syrian Formula to Resume Talks
description: A top aide to Prime Minister Ehud Barak said today that Israel was prepared to resume peace talks with Syria from the point where they broke off three years ago, accepting a formula demanded by Syria as a basis for renewed negotiations.

title: Budget Office Says Clinton Underestimated Cost of Drug Plan
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that President Clinton had grossly underestimated the cost of his proposal for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs.

title: Pepsi Acknowledges Role in Putting Coca-Cola Under Inquiry
description: The European Commission's raid this week on Coca-Cola offices in four countries followed complaints from competitors, including Pepsico, that had accused Coke of unfair business practices intended to keep rival products off store shelves.

title: Suspect, 35, Is Arrested In String of Robberies
description: A 35-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday in connection with a string of 12 robberies at businesses in Manhattan dating back to April, the police said. The man, Samuel Lopez, would walk into a store, pose as a customer and then pull out a silver handgun and demand money, said Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWELL, MAY M.
description: DOWELL-May M. On July 19, 1999, age 87, Retired Director of Special Projects Library, Columbia Broadcasting System. She witnessed and participated in the development of radio and later television news broadcasting from 1935 to 1977. Originally from Paterson, New Jersey, she resided in New York City since 1952. She was a member of the American Women in Radio and Television, Advertising Women of New York, and the special Libraries Association, and she was an active parishoner of St. George's Episcopal Church, where she will be interred. Survived and lovingly remembered by her niece, Wendy Moxcey of Bristol, Maine, nephews, Peter Dowell of Atlanta, Georgia and John Dowell of San Francisco, California, a grand niece, and four grand nephews.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Adirondack Vistas In the Artist's Eye And in the Visitor's
description: AS art exhibitions go, ''The View From Asgaard: Rockwell Kent's Adirondack Legacy'' is a small show: just 23 paintings and some lithographs, drawings and artifacts. But it has the makings of a big draw nonetheless, and not just because it is on view at the Adirondack Museum in Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y., in the heart of Adirondack State Park.

title: Residential Real Estate; Large Luxury Condominiums Sell Steadily at East Side Tower
description: With 76 family-size apartments and amenities that include a screening room and personal wine-storage units, the Empire is the latest entry to Manhattan's luxury condominium market. The 32-story, $75 million building is rising on a site on the Upper East Side that was once home to the so-called Cottages, a row of 1930's stores topped by apartments overlooking an interior garden that supporters spent more than a year unsuccessfully trying to save.

title: Peter Saul
description: George Adams

title: Watchdog for the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Severed Head Is Found At a Plant in Brooklyn
description: A severed human head turned up yesterday on a conveyor belt at a private trash-processing plant in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Pipers and Tears at a Memorial Service
description: Flanked by Irish and American flags, a dozen bagpipers filed into St. Patrick's Old Cathedral last night as the soaring stone walls echoed the wail of Gaelic dirge. On the same day that a Navy destroyer dropped the ashes of John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and her sister Lauren G. Bessette off the coast of Martha's Vineyard, more than a thousand New Yorkers gathered for a memorial service at the 184-year-old Catholic church that has nurtured generations of Irish immigrants.

title: The Night Side of Black and White
description: ''The Single Future of the Night,'' a small exhibition of photographs at Gallery 292 in SoHo, has but one subject: darkened houses and buildings whose owners are fast asleep. The buildings seem to breathe in the night air, and the quiet cars in front of them relax. The windows are black blanks. The leaves on the trees are white against the black sky, black against white walls and gray when blowing. They have no color of their own. The street signs point one inanimate thing in the direction of another. The commercial signs call out to no one in particular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, RICHARD
description: BENSON-Richard. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the passing of our long-time and dedicated superintendent of Union Field Cemetery, Richard Benson. We will always remember his committment to our Congregation. We send deepest condolences to his wife, Pat and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President Arnold Harkavy, Cemetery Chair

title: Agency Head Defends Effort For Children
description: The Commissioner of the city's child welfare agency angrily defended his reform efforts yesterday and questioned the motives of an advocacy group that issued a report focusing on the rising number of fatalities among abused and neglected children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, NATHANIEL
description: KATZ-Nathaniel. We mourn the loss of our esteemed partner and beloved friend. We will cherish the memory of his wise counsel, his remarkably youthful spirit, his generosity, his genuine concern for the well being of each of us and his unfailing kindness. His career was marked by integrity, by devotion to the highest professional standards and by a commitment to the best interests of his clients. His life will always be an inspiration to all who knew him; we will never forget him. The Partners and Staff of Tuchman, Katz, Schwartz, Gelles & Korngold

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some editions on Tuesday about divers entering the water to search for John F. Kennedy Jr.'s plane carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Bill Greene of The Boston Globe.

title: Wanted: American Physicists
description: The most important lesson of the recent suspected Chinese spy case is not that we must guard against foreign nationals who are conspiring to infiltrate our national laboratories. Rather, it's that American scientific pre-eminence is at risk because there are so few good young American physicists and labs must fill their ranks instead with foreign-born scientists.

title: Public Hospitals' Survey
description: To the Editor:

title: After Delays, Shuttle Lifts Off With First Female Commander
description: After a year of technical delays and two frustrating waits on the launch pad, the space shuttle Columbia blasted off from Cape Canaveral early this morning carrying the $1.5 billion Chandra X-ray Observatory, and vaulting its commander, Col. Eileen M. Collins of the Air Force into the ranks of aviation pioneers like Amelia Earhart and the Soviet cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova, the first woman in space.

title: Feelings of Deep Grief, Even When Their Cause Surpasses Understanding
description: In her tidy, pink-curtained apartment here, Jenny Catanzaro, a retired hospital laundress, snipped out the local newspaper's reprint of the Bessette-Kennedy wedding photo, the one in which Carolyn Bessette Kennedy's hair gleams silver-gold as her groom holds her hand to his lips. She plans to frame it and hang it next to President Kennedy's picture on her wall.

title: Filter Aid to Poor Through Churches, Bush Urges
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that the Federal Government should ''rally the armies of compassion in our communities'' by providing tax incentives and Federal funds to churches and neighborhood groups to help the needy.

title: Critics Catch Up to a 21st-Century Jet
description: Flags from 46 states line the entryway inside the 2-million-square-foot hangar where the F-22 fighter jet is being assembled in Marietta, Ga., representing ''all the states where some part of the plane is being produced,'' said R. S. Rearden Jr., Lockheed Martin's vice president for the F-22.

title: U.S. Proposes Rules to Better Treatment With Methadone
description: Dissatisfied with the system for dispensing methadone, the Clinton Administration yesterday proposed creating a national accreditation of methadone treatment centers as a way of holding them more accountable for keeping addicts off heroin.

title: Brown Wins At Bethpage
description: Mark Brown, relying on his long putter, salvaged a three-over-par 73 yesterday and finished with a 54-hole total of 210 to win the $100,000 New York State Open by two stokes at Bethpage Park Black Course in Farmingdale.

title: Weis Shows Some Flair but Needs Work
description: At one point during the Knicks' minicamp practice today, Coach Jeff Van Gundy stopped a drill and gave Frederic Weis some helpful instruction: When the player you are assigned to guard is preparing to shoot a jump shot a few feet away from the basket, Van Gundy said, please, raise your hand to at least give the appearance of contesting the shot. Then he raised his own hand in a this-is-how-you-do-it gesture.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; It's magic: Aetna buys Prudential Health Care for $1 billion and, analysts say, gets it for nothing.
description: IN the next 10 days, Aetna Inc. expects to complete what it has called its billion-dollar purchase of Prudential Health Care. Seven months after the agreement was announced, though, neither side has disclosed the full details. And analysts, left to sort the acquisition out for themselves, now say the price is really closer to zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGER, RITA R.
description: SAGER-Rita R. A memorial service will be held 12 Noon Sunday, July 25th at The Brotherhood Synagugue, 28 Gramercy Park South, New York City

title: Album of the Week
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Onda Sonora: Red Hot and Lisbon'' (Bar/ None). The idea of world music -- a utopian vision of different cultures swimming in the same direction in the name of entertainment -- has hardly ever been better served than on ''Onda Sonora,'' a record made by various voices from around the Portuguese-speaking diaspora and masterminded by the producers Beco Dranoff and Andres Levin.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: CHOOSING THE BABY'S SEX
description: First, parents were able to find out their child's sex. Now technology is giving them the choice. A mother of two boys explores the options for science, and for herself. A report by Lisa Belkin, in the Magazine.

title: Mobil's Profit Is Flat and Chevron's Drops
description: The Mobil Corporation, the No. 2 American oil company after Exxon, which is acquiring Mobil, said yesterday that second-quarter operating profit was almost unchanged, although it still edged past analysts' forecasts. Chevron, the No. 4 oil company also reported earnings yesterday, but it had a 22 percent drop as a result of refinery accidents.

title: Sports of The Times; Stickball's City Flocks To Baseball
description: THE Mets and Yankees are kicking and scratching, rumbling in their respective ways toward some improbable subway series.

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIES TO GET MEXICO OFFSHORE BUSINESS
description: Global Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the offshore marine construction business of its Mexican joint venture for $72 million. It will also assume debt of $65 million. Global also said it had sold its interest in the joint venture, CCC Fabricaciones y Construcciones, to the other principal shareholder of CCC, Grupo Consorcio de Fabricaciones y Construcciones S.A. Terms were not disclosed. Global, based in Lafayette, La., provides construction services to the offshore oil and gas industry. It had revenue of $342.2 million in 1998. Global's shares rose 62.5 cents, to $11.0625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about China's crackdown on a spiritual movement referred incorrectly to the leader of the 19th-century Taiping Rebellion, Hong Xiuquan. He said he was Jesus' brother, not son.

title: Paying For All That Back And Forth
description: Glossed over in the recent controversy regarding the repeal of New York City's commuter tax is the fundamental economic link between New York and its suburbs. The region depends on the city as its economic engine, while the suburbs provide choices in housing and schools for the region's jobholders. It's a mutually dependent relationship. Without attractive suburbs and an excellent transportation system, New York City would long ago have been unable to keep much of its talented work force.

title: Even for Death's Escapees, the Myth Says, There Are Rules
description: Resurrection from the dead may be the most universal of mythic ideas: a devoted savior descends to the netherworld to restore a loved one to life. But there is always a price to be paid: natural law is rarely overturned without penalty and pain. Persephone must return to Hades. Lot's wife, insufficiently awed by her rescue from her death-ridden home, glances back and turns into a pillar of evaporated tears. And the Christian story of resurrection leaves the final transformation incomplete, pending the spiritual perfection of mankind.

title: GERMAN PRICES RISE
description: German inflation accelerated in July, as consumers paid higher prices for fuel and vacations, raising concerns that the European Central Bank will increase interest rates. Four German states said their prices rose four-tenths or five-tenths of a percent in the month ending in mid-July, more than expected, compared with increases of zero to two-tenths of a percent the previous month. Nationwide figures will be released on Monday. Taken with Italian reports on Thursday, the figures indicate the European Central Bank may need to raise rates by early next year.

title: After Hiccup at Liftoff, Shuttle Puts Telescope Into Space
description: Astronauts on the first space shuttle mission led by a woman checked ''telescope delivery'' off their list of tasks only hours after liftoff today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MYRON J.
description: COHN-Myron J. On July 23, 1999 at Albany, NY. Practicing attorney for more than 50 years in Schenectady, NY. He is survived by his wife Elaine, two sons, John Myers & his wife Lucy, of Chicago and Bill Myers of Ballston Lake, NY. Brother of Morris Marshall Cohn of Schenectady, NY and Rita Clayman, also of Schenectady. A brother, Milton Cohn, M.D. and a sister, Elizabeth Weisberg, predeceased him. Grandfather of Alexander, Jack and Caroline Myers. Services at Congregation Beth Emeth, Albany, NY on Sunday, July 25, at 2 P.M. Contributions to a charity of one's choice. For more information, contact Levine Memorial Chapel, 518-438-1002.

title: Local Centers Try to Span 'Digital Divide'
Sosa Totes Weight of His World
description: Striding to the players' entrance at Shea Stadium, Sammy Sosa was surrounded by eight police officers even though there is little doubt that it would be hard for him, with biceps the size of an officer's leg, to find an obstacle too tough to get around.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: A New-Play Specialist Goes To the Park With Tartuffe
description: ''Hang up my hair shirt.''

title: WHITE CAP INDUSTRIES SET TO BE TAKEN PRIVATE
description: White Cap Industries will be taken private in a $240 million buyout led by a management group and an affiliate of Leonard Green & Partners L.P. In the transaction, announced after markets closed on Thursday, the buyout group will pay stockholders $16.50 for each of their shares. The stock jumped 32 percent yesterday, rising $3.75 a share, to $15.25, in Nasdaq trading. White Cap, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., sells tools and materials to professional contractors. It had sales of $292.3 million in the year ended March 27. The buyout group consists of Greg Grosch, founder and chief executive of White Cap; other members of White Cap management, and an affiliate of Leonard Green, a Los Angeles merchant bank group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, INEZ KOSSEFF
description: SIEGEL-Inez Kosseff. We mourn the loss of our beloved mother, sister and friend, who was an integral part of the Long Beach community for over 50 years. Her memories will live on through her four children, Caryn, Joy, BarriLynn and Frederic; her four grandchildren, Spencer, Courtney, Blake and Julia; her sisters and brother, Linda, Susan, Cheryl and Gary; her dear friend and father of her children, Howard, and all those who were fortunate to know and be touched by Inez. Her wonderful spirit, kindness and loving ways will be cherished forever. Inez fought a courageous battle with ovarian cancer for over five years and requested that all donations be made to ''The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund,'' 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, New York, NY 10119-0165. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: A Worthy Tax Credit for New York
description: The Albany budget process consists of a long stalemate followed by the hasty negotiation of a deal between the Governor, Senate majority leader and Speaker of the Assembly. This year's scramble is running true to form, leaving the possibility that a valuable tax break for low-income workers -- some of whom are former welfare recipients -- might fall by the wayside.

title: Kennedy Tragedy Is a Special Case
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Generating Significance To Apply To Celebrity
description: That sickening thud in the stomach so many people felt on hearing that John F. Kennedy Jr.'s plane was missing had nothing to do with a family curse or his role in history. Hearing this news was more like learning that Princess Diana had died or that a brick had fallen off a building and killed a passerby. Here was someone who, in a flash, had literally vanished from the face of the earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORY, CONSTANCE THAYER
description: CORY-Constance Thayer. Died July 21, 1999 in Williamsburg, VA at age 87. Educator and tutor of elementary school children with Master's from Teachers College, Columbia. Formerly of Englewood and Demarest, NJ and Amagansett, NY. Widow of David C. Cory. Mother of Christopher, Eleanor, Robert, Thayer, and Hoyt. Former officer, First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, NJ. Member, Junior League, Devon Yacht Club. Funeral service Sunday, July 25, 1 PM, St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 1333 Jamestown Road, Williamsburg, VA. Contributions to Smith College Alumnae Fund, 33 Elm St., Northampton, MA 01063.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LUDWIG
description: GROSS-Ludwig, M.D. The Cancer Research Fund of the Damon Runyon-Walter Winchell Foundation notes with profound sorrow the loss of a former Fellow (1951, 1968), Dr. Ludwig Gross. He was a pioneer and his innovative work serves as an inspiration to future scientific generations. Catherine M. Cahill, Exec. Director Cancer Research Fund of the Damon Runyon-Walter Winchell Foundation

title: $35 Million Approved For Urban Aid
description: Breaking a yearlong logjam, the seven-member board that administers a huge Government program to stimulate economic development in upper Manhattan and the South Bronx voted yesterday to spend nearly $35 million on loans, grants and investments, more than the total amount committed since the program began in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, MARIE
description: MARINO-Marie. Died July 22, 1999. Joined her beloved husband Frank for eternity. Dear mother of Patricia A. Lawler, and Francis J. and Shelly Marino. Grandmother of Kathleen M. Hall, Stephen F. Lawler & Andrea E. Marino. Great grandmother of Danielle & Lindsay Hall. Reposing Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton Street, Bklyn. Funeral service Greenwood Cemetery Brooklyn, Monday 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, CATHERINE C.
description: CLARKE-Catherine C., 95, on July 22, 1999, of Katonah, NY. Wife of the late Richard W. Clarke. Mother of H. Cartan Clarke and Richard W. Clarke Jr. and the late Michael deS. Clarke. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and nineteen great-grandchildren. Visiting hours Sunday, from 6-7 PM, with a rosary at 7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Katonah, NY, Monday, 11 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Michael deS. Clarke Memorial Fund, c/o Amherst College, 100 Boltwood Ave., Amherst, MA 01002-5000.

title: Looking for Happiness? It May Be Very Near; When the Heart Sings, Part of the Cortex Gets Busy
description: The secret to happiness, it turns out, may not be wealth or power. Or love or success or faithful friendship. Or Ray Charles crooning ''Georgia on My Mind'' or even chocolate mousse.

title: MAGNETEK BUYS CLOSELY HELD EMS GROUP OF COMPANIES
description: Magnetek Inc., a maker of energy-saving electrical equipment, said yesterday that it had bought the closely held EMS group of companies, which specialize in electronic parts that regulate electric motor performance. Terms were not disclosed. The Cincinnati-based group of companies, which includes EMS Inc., Electromotive Systems Inc. and EMS/Rosa Automation Engineering Inc., had revenue last year of more than $50 million. Nashville-based Magnetek had $1.2 billion in revenue in the fiscal year that ended in June 1998, the latest full-year figures available.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Once, when they asked John what he would do if he went into politics and was elected President, he said, 'I guess the first thing is call up Uncle Teddy and gloat.' I loved that. It was so like his father.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 14 about Canada's efforts to limit American cultural influence misspelled the given name of a Canadian songwriter whose work was recorded by Rod Stewart. He is Marc Jordan, not Mark.

title: WOMAN IN THE NEWS -- Eileen Marie Collins; Woman's Work: Space Commander
description: Like so many of the 40-something men she works with, Eileen M. Collins dreamed as a child that she would fly in space someday. But her dream long seemed little more than that, because until 1978 little girls could not grow up to be NASA astronauts.

title: English of Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO TOP MARKETS READY TO BECOME PUBLIC COMPANIES
description: The two largest United States stock markets, the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market, are moving quickly to convert from nonprofit institutions to for-profit corporations, with the New York exchange confirming yesterday that it could be ready to sell shares to the public as early as mid-November.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILDNER, PATRICIA
description: BILDNER-Patricia. Today on your birthday we think of you with love and fond memories. Nina, Judith and Mossa

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about vigils that were being held for John F. Kennedy Jr. misstated the location of his father's birthplace, where one vigil occurred. It was in Brookline, Mass., not Boston.

title: Perfection in Everything but the Opponent
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN RISES. The dollar fell as traders scooped up the Japanese currency, which has become more attractive on a brightening outlook for the Japanese economy. The dollar closed at 116.55 yen, down from 116.70 on Thursday.

title: New Russians Spread Money on Riviera, but Lack the Panache of the Czars
description: On the glittering Mediterranean coast of France, one handy indicator of who is up and who is down is restaurant menus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDELL, JEFFREY R.
description: BEDELL-Jeffrey R., Ph.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Jeffrey R. Bedell, an Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Mount Sinai and Director of the Community Options Program at Elmhurst Hospital Center. A distinguished researcher in community psychiatry and talented clinician and teacher, Dr. Bedell was associated with the faculty of Mount Sinai from 1995 to 1999 and was respected by his colleagues for his innovative approaches in congnitive, behavioral and rehabilitative therapies with the severely mentally ill. He will be remembered fondly and sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Lynn. Helene L. Kaplan, Chair, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: Dow Dips Slightly and S.& P. Index Ends a Rough Week
description: Stocks fell yesterday, wrapping up the worst week for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since September, on concern that interest rates are headed higher.

title: H. W. Brosin, 94; Led Psychiatric Groups
description: Dr. Henry Walter Brosin, a former president of the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology, the American Psychiatric Association and the American College of Psychiatrists, died in Tucson, Ariz., on July 3, three days short of his 95th birthday.

title: U.S. Quietly Resuming Aid for Some Anti-Milosevic Groups
description: After a month of demonstrations throughout Serbia against President Slobodan Milosevic, the Administration quietly decided this week to lift restrictions on support for Serbian opposition groups and free aid for opposition political parties, the independent media, lawyers and other groups promoting democracy in Yugoslavia.

title: Kennedy Tragedy Is a Special Case
description: To the Editor:

title: With One Swing, Jeter Knocks Out the Indians
description: No, these are not the 1998 Yankees. Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte have struggled, Joe Torre missed more than a month because of prostate cancer, and Jorge Posada and Scott Brosius and Paul O'Neill all slumped early in the year. And still they have the best record in baseball, after they beat the Cleveland Indians, 9-8, in a raucous 10-inning game last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Banned Movement's Head Urges Talks With China
description: The leader of the fast-spreading spiritual movement banned this week by the Chinese Government asserted yesterday that his group had no political ambitions and called on the Government to engage in dialogue.

title: Woodstock '99 Kicks Off, But Without the Stardust
description: As James Brown kicked off Woodstock '99 with his classic refrain of ''Get on up,'' 50 ticketholders patiently stood in line outside the Playstation trailer, waiting to play their favorite video games for 15 free minutes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about photography collections on the Web misstated the address for the New York Public Library's on-line collection of stereoscopes. It is:

title: Condoms for Women Gain Approval Among Africans
description: The female condom, seldom used in the West, is catching on here and in many parts of the developing world, slowly becoming an important new weapon in the fight against the AIDS epidemic.

title: The Politics of Public Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Citing Threats, F.B.I. Suspends Public Tours of Headquarters
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced an indefinite suspension of the popular tours of its headquarters after receiving what it termed ''unconfirmed threats.''

title: Political Notes; A Line Waits Impatiently for a Seat Still Occupied
description: It was seven weeks ago that Gov. George E. Pataki nominated State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., a Queens Democrat who crossed party ranks to endorse the Republican Governor last year, for a judgeship on the State Court of Claims. The nomination of Mr. Waldon prompted a half-dozen candidates in Queens to begin scrambling for the open seat.

title: Shift on Tax-Cut Bill: Gain or Loss for Moderates?
description: A few days ago, a group of moderate Republicans said they adamantly opposed a $792 billion tax cut because it was far too large. But after the measure passed on Thursday, many of the same people wore satisfied smiles. Why? Because they had forced a relatively minor change in the largest tax cut bill in 18 years.

title: F-22 Is Judged Unfairly
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Saturday showing the amount of money raised by Presidential candidates and how much they had on hand by June 30 understated the figures for Patrick J. Buchanan, Lamar Alexander and Robert C. Smith. A corrected chart appears today on page A10.

title: English of Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: IBP, BEEF PROCESSOR, TO PURCHASE PORK PLANTS
description: IBP Inc., the world's largest beef processor, won approval yesterday from a United States bankruptcy judge to buy pork plants from Thorn Apple Valley Inc. for $115 million in cash and debt, topping a bid from Cargill Inc. It will also assume $2.5 million in industrial revenue bonds in Arkansas. IBP, based in Dakota Dunes, S.D, raised its June 25 offer of $112 million after the Excel unit of Cargill filed a competing bid with the court this month. Thorn Apple Valley sought protection from its creditors in March after a costly meat recall and a drop in hot dog exports.

title: Tax-Cut Bill Could Well Revive a Thing of the Past: The 'Three Martini Lunch'
description: Remember the ''three martini lunch''? Much like the martini itself, it may well be making a comeback.

title: WEBVAN GROUP RAISES $275 MILLION IN FINANCING
description: The Webvan Group, which operates the on-line grocery and drug megastore www.webvan.com, said yesterday that it had raised $275 million of financing from strategic and financial investors, representing a 6.4 percent stake in the company. The investments put a total value on the company, based in Foster City, Calif., and still privately held, of more than $4 billion. The investors included Softbank Capital Partners L.P., the Japanese-based software distributor and publisher; Sequoia Capital, a venture capital company, and investors associated with Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Earlier this month, Webvan announced it was placing a $1 billion order with Bechtel Group Inc. to design and build 26 automated warehouses across the United States.

title: Serbian Opposition Leaders Underwhelm Large Rally
description: Several thousand citizens gathered in the rain this evening for a rally that displayed all the problems the Serbian opposition is having in its effort to oust President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: The Politics of Public Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Tragedy Is a Special Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Going With the Flow, Pianistically
description: Andrew Hill makes the piano mumble and drawl. Though usually classified as a 60's vanguardist, Mr. Hill's playing isn't hot tempered and expressive; indeed, it often seems like writing with no punctuation.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS SOARS. Searing weather sent natural gas, which utilities burn to generate electricity, to an eight-month high. In New York, gas for August delivery rose 5.55 percent, or 13.3 cents, to $2.528 a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Doors Closed, Kennedys Offer Their Farewells
description: In the simple stone church where his mother brought him to worship as a small boy, John F. Kennedy Jr., the country's most famous namesake, was remembered as a young man who shouldered the ponderous weight of legend and was still ''becoming the person he would be'' in a memorial Mass yesterday that united generations and ideologies.

title: BRAZILIAN JOBLESSNESS RISES
description: Brazil's unemployment rate increased to 8.4 percent in June from 8.37 percent a month earlier, as hiring by industrial conglomerates failed to offset a wave of corporate cutbacks. After the figure was announced, two state-controlled companies in Minas Gerais, Brazil's second-largest state, said they were considering layoffs. Cemig, an electric utility, may dismiss 400 workers, while Copasa, a water treatment company, could cut 200 jobs. Gov. Itamar Franco of Minas Gerais asked the companies to search for alternatives.

title: Hancock County Journal; Luckless County Joins Landless Tribe
description: By 10 o'clock on a typical summer's morning, Hancock County is almost deserted.

title: Frank M. Johnson Jr., Judge Whose Rulings Helped Desegregate the South, Dies at 80
description: Frank M. Johnson Jr., the legendary Federal jurist from Alabama whose historic civil rights decisions led to ostracism, cross-burnings and death threats but helped to change the face of the segregationist South in the 1950's and 1960's, died yesterday. He was 80.

title: A Return to Mugginess
description: Remember how hot it was last weekend? The stickiness? The temperatures in the high 90's? The steam-room feel in the air?

title: In the Land of Joyce and Yeats, a Struggle to Read A B C's
description: Ireland, with its rich heritage of great writers, has one of the highest illiteracy rates of the world's developed countries.

title: ERICSSON PROMISES TURNAROUND
description: The world's third-ranked cellular phone manufacturer, Ericsson A.B. of Sweden , pledged a turnaround after reporting that its second-quarter profits were down by 32 percent, to $273 million. The fall was ascribed to reduced sales of mobile handsets and the cost of cutting 11,000 jobs. The company's chief executive, Lars Ramqvist, promised to ''have the company back on track by the end of the year.'' Investors believed him, and Ericsson stock rose almost 8 percent, to 254 crowns. In contrast, its archrival, Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, reported a 61 percent surge in second-quarter profits on Thursday, but its stock fell 3.4 percent because investors had expected even more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASTERSON, REV. HAROLD
description: MASTERSON-Rev. Harold J. CSP on July 23, 1999 at age 89, was born in White Plains, NY. Ordained a Paulist priest on January 29, 1937. During his sixty-two years of priesthood, he served: nineteen years in mission work based in Detroit, New York, and Toronto; two years as a U.S. Navy Chaplain; three years in parish ministry in New York and Minneapolis; six years at the Paulist Grand Rapids Information Center; nine years in the preaching apostolate based in St. Austin's, TX; three years as assistant novice master in Oak Ridge, NJ; and twenty years assisting in various capacities at parishes in Florida. A wake will be held at Saint Catherine's Church, 1649 Kingsley Avenue, Orange Park, FL on Monday July 26th from 6-8PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Saint Catherine's on Tuesday, July 27th at 10AM. Interment will be at Mount Paul Novitiate, Oak Ridge, New Jersey.

title: London Journal; Prophet of Left Is Quitting Office, Not His Calling
description: Tony Benn has roused a lot of passionate opinions since he joined the House of Commons in 1950, but the one he most fears now is approval.

title: Park Murder Belies Fact That Crime Has Plunged
description: When it comes to crime in Central Park, perception has always been more important than reality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F. JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F. Jr. All persons living with disability and those who have worked to extend the opportunities of everyday life for those with disabilities mourn the passing of John F. Kennedy Jr. With Reaching Up, John demonstrated and used his leadership and commitment to advance the careers of countless workers and established a national model. His deep concern and compassion for persons with mental retardation, and for those with chronic illnesses who need the help of a caring society has lost a spirited voice and a true champion. Our hearts go out to his family and to the family of Caroline Bessette Kennedy and Lauren Bessette, who have suffered such a tremendous personal loss. Arthur Y. Webb, President and Chief Executive Officer Village Care of New York

title: INSIDE
description: NATO Patrol in Kosovo Finds Bodies of 14 Slain Serbs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGILVY, DAVID
description: OGILVY-David. Yours is a legacy of intellect, civility and creative energy that survives in the great agency you founded and the people you've taught. We mourn the passing of David Ogilvy. Your friends at Davis & Gilbert

title: CAROLINA POWER AND LIGHT MAY SELL ITS INTERNET UNIT
description: The Carolina Power and Light Company, which bought the North Carolina Natural Gas Company this month, said it might sell its Internet unit and focus on energy sales. Carolina Power, based in Raleigh, N.C., bought Interpath Communications Inc. in December 1997 for an undisclosed price. Interpath, which had 1998 revenue of $43 million, helps businesses in the Southeastern United States set up Web sites and E-mail and sells other Internet and telecommunications services. Carolina Power, which has 1.2 million electricity customers in North Carolina and South Carolina, has added new businesses because its main business, power sales, is opening to competition.

title: Gore Takes Aw-Shucks Tour (and Hits a Bump)
description: It was supposed to be a friendly and photogenic river trip, a chance for Al Gore to be seen in a less formal setting, paddling a canoe on the Connecticut River. Reporters were invited along, to describe the sight of the Vice President dressed in khakis and a polo shirt, friend of the environment.

title: Hassan II of Morocco Dies at 70; A Monarch Oriented to the West
description: King Hassan II, who ruled Morocco for 38 years, acted as a go-between in Egyptian-Israeli efforts to make peace and prolonged the life of his 300-year-old dynasty in an era when monarchies in Libya, Egypt, Iraq and Iran fell to socialist revolutions or the force of militant Islam, died yesterday in Rabat. He was 70.

title: An Athlete Is Forced to Learn Caution
description: Jim Druckenmiller, the San Francisco 49ers' reserve quarterback, sounded tired. He said he had slept about three hours on Wednesday night, the day before his rape trial went before a 12-member jury in Christianburg, Va. He thought about his future, and the very real possibility that he might spend the rest of his life in prison.

title: Campaign Reform Gains an Ally
description: The Congressional proponents of campaign finance reform gained an important ally this week when Bill Bradley called for overhauling the system. Mr. Bradley suggested fundamental changes in the ways elections are financed and promised to reject soft-money donations to his Democratic Presidential campaign, if Republicans do the same.

title: Parolee Charged in Central Park Killing
description: A Bronx man on parole was charged yesterday with murdering a mentally ill woman whose body was found in Central Park on Thursday.

title: TRUCKERS THREATEN STRIKE
description: Brazilian truckers plan a one-week nationwide strike, starting tomorrow, to protest what they see as unfair treatment by Government authorities. Trucker organizations are calling for lower tolls, more lenient policies on traffic violations and improved security on highways. Although some of Brazil's estimated 960,000 miles of roads have been privatized in recent years, most roads are in precarious condition. Only about 10 percent of the country's roads are paved, and some major highways are plagued by cargo theft.

title: PRIVATIZATION FOR IRISH AIRLINE
description: The Irish Government said it planned to privatize Aer Lingus, the heavily subsidized national airline. The next step, according to Ireland's Enterprise Minister, Mary O'Rourke, would be to seek an ''operational alliance'' with British Airways and American Airlines. Then, she said, Aer Lingus stock would be sold to the public, perhaps within six months. Aer Lingus needs about $210 million to buy new planes and other equipment in the next 18 months.

title: Enforcing Gun Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Stays in Foster Homes Shortened, Agency Says
description: Troubled children, including those up for adoption, are spending less time in foster care before being placed in permanent homes, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Neuberger Fund Firm Again Considers Selling Shares to the Public
description: Neuberger Berman L.L.C., one of Wall Street's last large private investment partnerships, appears poised to try again to sell its stock to the public in an offering that analysts expect will value it at more than $2 billion.

title: CORRECTION: Money for The Presidential Campaign
description: A chart last Saturday listing amounts raised by Presidential contenders from Jan. 1 to June 30 of this year and how much money they still had on hand on June 30 listed incorrect amounts for Patrick J. Buchanan, Lamar Alexander and Robert C. Smith.

title: Bringing the Khmer Rouge to Justice
description: Even as some of those who committed genocide in Rwanda and Bosnia are being brought to international justice, perpetrators of one of history's most horrifying slaughters have escaped. Now, however, the United Nations is moving closer to establishing a court to try leaders of the Khmer Rouge, whose members killed more than a million of their countrymen when they ruled Cambodia from 1975 to 1979. Secretary General Kofi Annan is deciding on the details of the court he will recommend that the U.N. support. The court will be in Cambodia and needs the approval of Cambodia's strongman, Hun Sen. But it must also feature effective international controls to insure that it can do real justice and will not be manipulated by Mr. Hun Sen.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.& P. and Dow Jones Drop On Interest Rate Concerns

title: Take 2: Rogers to New York, Only This Time It's as a Met
description: Kenny Rogers is usually perceived as the decent yet enigmatic pitcher who could not succeed with the Yankees in New York. Drop him in a low-pressure city like Oakland, Calif., and he would be effective. But Rogers has long wanted to dispel the notion that the city turned him into another Ed Whitson, and now the left-hander will get the chance in a different borough, after the Mets acquired him from the Athletics yesterday for two minor leaguers.

title: On-Line Fans Of a Stock Feeling Pain
description: For most of this year, the chat on the Internet had it that Sunrise Technologies International Inc., a small California medical device company, was a stock sure to deliver a bountiful return.

title: Knicks Solidify Van Gundy's Future by Extending His Contract
description: The often uncertain and always precarious future of Jeff Van Gundy as the coach of the Knicks has been cleared up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, ADELE K.
description: HEYMAN-Adele K. On July 21, 1999. Cherished wife of the late Harold Heyman, beloved mother of Arlene and Lester Friedman, Marjorie Mintzer Miller, Jerome Miller, Candy and Steven Dubner. Loving grandmother of Diane and Mark, Robert and Deborah, Jill, Peter, Allison, Michelle, & Wendy and Stephen. Great grandmother of Eric, Brian, Lauren and Leah. Sister of Jay and Sally Bennett, Lester and Frances Shapiro, and Daniel & Claire Shapiro. Services will be held at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, New York on Sunday, July 25 at noon.

title: Israel Army Computer Corps Builds Success in Business
description: Israel's Mossad intelligence service is famous as a school for spies. Now the Israeli army's computer corps, called Mamram, is gaining renown as a training ground for successful entrepreneurs.

title: FORSTMANN & CO. SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: A New York textile manufacturer, Forstmann & Company, said yesterday that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. The company, a New York-based maker of wools and worsteds, also said it had reached an agreement with its bank group, led by Bank of America, for $50 million in financing to meet operating needs while it continues in business. The company said it had hired Butler Chapman & Company, an investment banking firm, to identify potential buyers, merger partners or investors. Forstmann has suffered from deep price-cutting in the industry that has accompanied a flood of imports from Asia.

title: EMPIRE STATE GAMES; Another Nystrom Draws Attention
description: His last name, Nystrom, is a reprieve from the present for Islanders fans who have watched their franchise be swallowed by misery. The name Nystrom takes them back to honorable times when Stanley Cups were won.

title: Cash-for-Sterilization Plan Draws Addicts and Critics
description: The billboards make an unusual offer.

title: Editorial Notebook; Death of a Legendary Horseman
description: There is no such thing as a horse whisperer. There never has been and never will be. The idea is an affront to the horse. You can talk and listen to horses all you want, and what you will learn, if you pay close attention, is that they live on open ground way beyond language and that language, no matter how you characterize it, is a poor trope for what horses understand about themselves and about humans. You need to practice only three things, patience, observation and humility, all of which were summed up in the life of an old man who died Tuesday in California, a man named Bill Dorrance.

title: Clintons Limit New York Vacation Plans in Election Calculation
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton are planning an August vacation partly on Martha's Vineyard and partly in New York State, including a weekend of fund-raising in the Hamptons, officials said.

title: Suit Against Utility Cites Loss of Power, and Cash
description: A dozen Monmouth County residents and merchants have sued GPU, their electric company, saying that three days of sporadic blackouts this month cost them money.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEE HECHT HARRISON, Woodcliff Lake, N.J., a unit of Adecco S.A., the world's No. 1 temporary-employment agency, Lausanne, Switzerland, bought two employment services companies: Jarosz Associates, based in Chicago, and Russell-Rogat Inc., based in Cleveland. The price was not disclosed.

title: An Endplay by Levin Makes His Ninth Trick Reappear
description: After nine months of effort, beginning at the grass-roots level, the Grand National Team Championship reached its conclusion at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today. After 16 deals of 64 scheduled in the final, the Los Angeles team led Florida by 14 imps.

title: New 'President' of Belarus Flees the Crackdown on Dissidents
description: Crackdowns on those who oppose President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus have led the chief opposition figure to flee to Lithuania after his supporters voted him acting president and proclaimed the Lukashenko Government at an end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUPU, CORINA IOANA
description: LUPU-Corina Ioana. With deep sorrow, the family announces the untimely death of their beloved daughter, sister and niece, Corina Ioana Lupu. A memorial service will be held at 10 a.m. on Sunday July 25 at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, BENEDICT
description: WOLF-Benedict. On July 23, 1999 in his 94th year. Adored husband of the late Miriam J. Wolf. Beloved father of Dr. Deborah W. Tanzer. Cherished grandfather of David, Kenneth & Charles Tanzer. Loving brother-in-law of Gertrude J. Bonime. Fond uncle and great uncle. He was a child of his century and inspired a generation of caring and commitment to social justice. Services Sunday, July 25th, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cashing In on Security Worries; Bad Times Are Good Times for Car Armorers in Brazil
description: One morning in March, two gunmen unleashed a point-blank barrage at the driver of a sedan carrying the three school-age children of Jorge Paulo Lemann, one of Brazil's wealthiest men. The car's glass did not shatter.

title: Beijing Continues Its Campaign Against Sect
description: A day after it outlawed a fast-growing spiritual movement, the Chinese Government continued its campaign of invective today against the group, known as Falun Gong.

title: An Ungrateful Staff
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA TYING CANCER TO ELECTRIC POWER FOUND TO BE FALSE
description: A Federal investigation has concluded that a scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., faked what had been considered crucial evidence of a tie between electric power lines and cancer. The disclosure appears to strengthen the case that electric power is safe.

title: Lawyer for Elliott Is Looking to Move Case
description: The lawyer for Jumbo Elliott, the Jets tackle accused of several misdemeanor offenses following a barroom brawl earlier this month, said yesterday that he would try to remove the case from Long Beach, N.Y., and present it to a Nassau County grand jury.

title: 5 Held in Robbery Spree Including Attacks From Long Island to Westchester
description: Five young men were arrested and charged this week in a series of robberies, some of which included kidnapping, assault and sexual abuse, the Suffolk County police reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEKMAN, PAULINE
description: ELEKMAN-Pauline (nee Cutler). Age 88. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Devoted mother of Allen (Estelle) and Joel (Peggy). Loving grandmother of Gary and Daniel (Vicki). Proud great grandmother of Shayna and Jamie. Graveside services Sunday 10:30 AM at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island. Contributions may be made to Hadassah, 111 North Wabash, Chicago, IL. 60062.

title: French President Stirs Anger During Visit to West Africa
description: Before President Jacques Chirac of France embarked on a five-day trip to Africa, he said he would carry a message emphasizing the importance of democratization and the rule of law to four countries short on both.

title: Ventura Says He Won't Be Presidential Candidate in 2000
description: Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota opened the national convention of the Reform Party tonight by saying that he would not accept a draft as the party's nominee for President next year.

title: Pataki Says Budget Fight Is Near End
description: With the state budget 114 days late, Gov. George E. Pataki today finally expressed optimism that he and the Legislature were nearing the end of their work on a spending plan for this fiscal year.

title: Better Rest Stops Ahead, Turnpike Director Says
description: State officials have announced plans to spruce up 11 of the New Jersey Turnpike's 12 service areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ANTHONY LANE
description: ADAMS-Anthony Lane, 54, of Greenwich, CT, died Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital. Born in Salt Lake City, Utah, Mr. Adams was the son of Elaine Evans Adams and the late Lane Webster Adams. He was the husband of Louise Rambo Adams. Mr. Adams was a Managing Director Investment Counsel for New Bridge Partners, LLC. He was a Graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and Harvard University. He was a member of the Lane W. Adams Achievement Award in Care Giving, Harvard Medical School Neurology Dept., a Board Member of the New York Racket & Tennis Club, Board Member of the Brook Club in NYC, National Golf Links of America in Southampton, NY, and the Round Hill Club. In addition to his wife and mother of Greenwich, Mr. Adams is survived by a son Anthony Lane Adams, a daughter Isabelle Adams, both of Greenwich and a sister Victoria Adams Quan of New York, NY. Services will be announced at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to Quan Fellowship in Neurobiology at Harvard Medical School, c/o Mary Beth Pearlberg, Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St., Bldg. A, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Network Standards as Emmy Handicap
description: Broadcasters began to get a bit huffy about the annual Emmy Awards nominations a few years ago, when cable networks like HBO and Showtime began racking up most of the nominations in the categories of mini-series and made-for-television movies. Last year many were really peeved when Tom Hanks's expensive 12-part series, ''From the Earth to the Moon'' for HBO, won the Emmy for best mini-series.

title: A Visit to One New Children's Hospital Will Become a Trip to a Space Station
description: It is not enough to be just a hospital anymore. The fierce competition of the managed care era has given rise to the health care network, the center for treatment of a single disease, the suite with five-star amenities.

title: South Korea's Market Declines 7.34%
description: South Korea's benchmark stock index had its largest one-day loss ever today, as measured in points, as interest rates continued to surge amid the fallout from the Daewoo Group's debt crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOGARTY, GERARD W.
description: HOGARTY-Gerard W. 7/24/91 We continue to celebrate the joy of your life. Mother, Tim, Family and Friend

title: Takeover Bid Is Canceled
description: The Enna Corporation, a closely held investment firm, said today that it had withdrawn its bid of $11 a share, or $182.6 million, for the Racing Champions Corporation, a maker of auto-racing collectibles and souvenirs. Racing Champions, which also markets Nascar die-cast replicas, Press Pass trading cards and AMT model hobby kits, said in a statement on July 14 that the bid by Enna, based in Charlottesville, was ''wholly inadequate.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, IVAN
description: RUBIN-Ivan, 60, of Bluebell, PA, died Friday, July 23 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Loving father of Jamie and Debra. Devoted brother of Burton and his wife Suzanne. Beloved by his late wife Mona and fiancee Kathy Traystman, Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave on Sunday, July 25 at 11:15 AM. In lieu of flowers donations in Ivan's memory to Cancer Care, Inc. would be deeply appreciated.

title: Kennedy Tragedy Is a Special Case
description: To the Editor:

title: French Rider Remains in the Shadows
description: Amid scattered cries of ''la Broche, la Broche,'' a nickname he despises, Laurent Brochard was making his way to the sign-in for the 18th stage of the Tour de France this morning when the air was suddenly ringing with air horns, screams and squeals.

title: Great Game, Lousy Name
description: Even men in my generation, who came of age in the 1960's with a strict code of coolness, find it impossible not to call forth an embarrassing metaphor when our sons first play a team sport.

title: Historians Give Romans Better Marks In Democracy
description: To most historians of this century, the Roman republic was a corrupt oligarchy ruled by a rich and decadent aristocracy despite its democratic Constitution, popular assemblies and regularly elected officials.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about Web sites that sell vintage computers or related accessories misstated the address of a site that offers a downloadable Windows version of an XZX Spectrum emulator program, which lets a modern computer simulate an eight-bit Spectrum Sinclair machine. It is: www.ics.uci.edu/savoiu/winxzx

title: Summer Gas Prices Rise in U.S., Continuing Trend
