description: Gasoline prices across the country have risen moderately in the summer driving season, continuing an upward trend that began earlier in the year as oil-producing nations cut back supplies.

title: The Responsibility of the Scientist
description: In early May, I sat with six other Nobel laureates on the stage of the magnificent Philadelphia Music Hall, responding to a group of more than 1,100 finalists in the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair. Whereas we were well prepared to be asked about quarks, black holes and organ transplants, we were all surprised by the students' intense questioning about issues of ethics and morality: How did scientists feel when they worked on nuclear weapons? Would our knowledge of genes lead to unethical and possibly immoral applications like cloning?

title: Indians Have Answer for Cone, and Quickly
description: In the first inning last night, David Cone threw to first base five times, which was five more times than he threw to first during the entire game in his last start. Cone didn't throw to first in his last start because the Montreal Expos never put a runner on first base, or any base, for that matter.

title: Perfection in Everything but the Opponent
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Win Road Game At Shea
description: Slowly but surely, the Mets keep gaining ground on the Atlanta Braves in the National League East. Last night they did it with a stirring comeback, rallying after Sammy Sosa's three-run first-inning homer for a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs and pulling within a game and a half of the Braves for the first time since May.

title: Perfection in Everything but the Opponent
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, DOROTHEA WARREN
description: FOX-Dorothea Warren. On July 22, 1999 in New Fairfield. CT. At age 85. Illustrator and Author. Wife of the late Charles Fox.

title: Calculating the Big Board's True Value
description: How much would the New York Stock Exchange be worth if its own shares were traded on the Big Board?

title: Religion Journal; From Witches to Angels, Alternative Spirituality
description: At times in the past year, people practicing spiritual ideas that fall outside the mainstream of major faiths have made news largely because of their beliefs. Examples include the Wiccans in Massachusetts, modern-day witches who protested a political commercial they considered insulting in last fall's governor's race there, and the small, similar group on a military base in Texas who touched off debate this spring after reports that they were practicing nature-centered rituals in their off-hours.

title: In Cyberspace, Rivals Skirmish Over Messaging
description: America Online closed its on-line service yesterday to new software from two of its fiercest rivals, Microsoft and Yahoo, that had been designed to tap into one of America Online's most popular features: instant messages.

title: Publisher Leases Large Space in the East Village
description: The American subsidiary of VNU, the Netherlands-based company that publishes Billboard magazine and The Hollywood Reporter, has signed a lease for 465,000 square feet of space at 770 Broadway, the former Wanamaker department store, between Eighth and Ninth Streets in the East Village.

title: Baseball Says Some Umpires Are Safe
description: On a critical day of the major league umpires' job action, baseball officials yesterday welcomed back the umpires who had rescinded their resignations and, in effect, wished those who had not farewell. Although no head count could be established beyond any doubt because major league officials continued to maintain silence, it appeared that 33 of 36 National League umpires and at least 9 of 32 American League umpires would lose their jobs as a result of the letters of resignation they signed.

title: Aerospace Acquisition
description: The Networks Electronic Corporation, a maker of bearings and switches for the aerospace industry, agreed today to be acquired by GWB (USA) Inc., the United States arm of Gartland Whalley & Barker P.L.C. of Britain. The price of the deal was about $12.6 million in cash. Gartland Whalley will pay $7.50 a share for the 1.68 million Networks Electronics shares outstanding.

title: Where Hip-Hop and Heavy Metal Collide
description: As lead singer of Limp Bizkit, the band currently at the top of the Billboard album charts, Fred Durst has created a million-dollar persona by acting like the least likely to succeed. But Mr. Durst is not the loser he would like people to think he is.

title: A Journey from Hippie To Hip-Hop
description: How many of you don't care? the hard-core rapper DMX, using less genteel language, asked the crowd as the sun dropped in the sky on the first day of Woodstock '99. Scores of thousands in the almost entirely white audience responded enthusiastically that they indeed did not care.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Are We Ready to Lose the Next Air War?
description: With little debate and without a hearing, the full House voted this week to effectively kill the F-22 Raptor aircraft, the linchpin of the Air Force's modernization program. Fortunately, the final word is not in, and the F-22 still has strong support in Congress and from Defense Secretary William Cohen and President Clinton.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: Questions for Run-DMC; The Rap of Ages
description: Q. You guys are putting out a new record and rereleasing your old ones, too, all the way back to ''It's Like That'' from 1983. But you actually go back further than that. How did you two meet?

title: Glass Ceiling Isn't Shattered Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: July 18-24; Government Criticizes Inspections for Government
description: Patients face life-threatening risks because the private organization inspecting the nation's hospitals is ''unlikely to detect substandard patterns of care,'' Federal investigators said.

title: A Voice of His Own: Albee's Epiphany at 30
description: AT the beginning of 1958, as his 30th birthday approached, Edward Albee felt a sense of dissatisfaction bordering on desperation. Despite his incipient talent and his ambition, he had written nothing of consequence. Was he a writer or simply an observer, destined to play a secondary role in other people's lives? Increasingly, there was a feeling of emptiness and, perhaps, the idea that he would become another William Flanagan (his first mentor), a composer who never measured up to his potential. As Albee said several years later, he was ''fed up with everything, including myself.'' He was also drinking far too much.

title: Not So Fast
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Brookhaven Ion Collider Clears First Big Hurdle
description: Scientists working on the immense new ion collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory have cleared a major hurdle by successfully steering an ion beam along one 2.4-mile ring of the collider and circulating the beam for more than 600 turns around the machine.

title: Flash for the Phone
description: Like muscle cars and low-rider bicycles, cellular telephones are the latest mass-market accessory that the style-savvy want to customize. At the Dynasty Supermarket in Manhattan (68 Elizabeth Street, near Hester Street), teen-agers, hipsters and aspiring moguls hang out after work and school at a display counter across from the seafood stand, marveling at the latest replacement frames that cover the phone's face and antennae attachables to trick out their mobile units. The cell phone chop shop, run by Wendy Chu, 22, and her brother, Simon, sells frames, $8 to $30, compatible with Nokia and Ericsson brand phones. They range in style from a simple model with an Asian dragon to a lime green Hello Kitty frame that glows in the dark and flashes neon when the phone rings. Antennae caps, $3 to $10, include Asian cartoon icons like Big Mouth Boy and Melody, and some have internal lasers that blink when a call comes in. ''Fresh models arrive nearly every week from Hong Kong,'' said Ms. Chu, who keeps pace with speedy installations, popping off the old frame and screwing on a new one in less than 10 minutes. JULIA CHAPLIN

title: Women Speaking Up for Freedom and Fairness in an Irish Factory
description: TWO sorts of contemporary Irish plays are perhaps too much with us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILSON, MALA KOLIN RUBINSTEIN
description: SILSON-Mala Kolin Rubinstein. On July 22nd, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Victor Silson. Loving aunt of Diane Moss, NYC, Jacqueline Herrmann, NYC, Nurit Amir, Israel, Carmi and Uri Shalev, Israel, Michael Kolin, Canada, Pamela Sendrovich, Canada, and Mary Rosset, Canada. Dear fried of Zygmunt Modzelenski. Memorial service Monday, 11:30 AM, July 26th, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Making Movies Makes Money
description: Crime victims benefited because Denzel Washington made a movie in Paterson last year, and Wesley Lake in Monmouth County will be a little cleaner because HBO made one in Ocean Grove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, AMELIA
description: ROSENFELD-Amelia, 49, died July 17, 1999 at her home in Chapel Hill, NC. A Memorial Service will be held in Prospect Park at the 3rd Street Entrance at 6PM, August 1. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Cornucopia House, 1777 Fordham Boulevard, Suite 104, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27514. For more details call 212-614-1825.

title: David Phillips and Ellen Zweig
description: Ellen Terri Zweig, a daughter of Annette Zweig of Belle Harbor, Queens, and the late Henry L. Zweig, is to be married today to David Samuel Phillips, a son of Judy Phillips and Dr. Philip L. Phillips of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Charles E. Rudansky is to officiate at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends; My Dog Loves Me, And Other Delusions
description: ''IF you want a friend in Washington,'' the saying goes, ''get a dog.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOW, SYLVIA
description: MOSKOW-Sylvia. Age 89, of Paterson, NJ. Mother of Debrah Rosensweet (husband Gene), Michael Moskow (wife Constance). Beloved grandmother and great grandmother. Wife of the late Jacob Moskow. Arrangements were by Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus.

title: The Village Isn't Alone In Bizarre Intersections
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock Group Takes Center Stage in Civic Advocacy
description: A grassroots campaign against a local hospital's plan to expand into surrounding neighborhoods here has all the hallmarks of civic advocacy that this college town is known for: yard signs, petitions, meetings, protests and, of course, the support of one of the world's most successful rock bands, R.E.M.

title: A Week of Grieving
description: In the long week of public mourning for John F. Kennedy Jr., Americans found an almost pastoral comfort in their technological solitude. From separate rooms around the country, we learned about the crash that took the lives of President Kennedy's son, his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and her sister Lauren Bessette. Only a few found a public place to express their sorrow -- on the beach at Martha's Vineyard or the sidewalk outside the Kennedys' Tribeca apartment. Most Americans mourned into a television set and grieved into a computer.

title: The Rat Patrol
description: IN Park Slope, Jerri Mayer has been begging her neighbors to hire exterminators, stop feeding the birds and cover their trash to fight a wave of rats that began marauding through the backyards of million-dollar brownstones this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, MILDRED
description: IRWIN-Mildred. July 2, 1926-July 23, 1999. We love you and will always miss you. Virginia, Victoria and Max

title: On North Fork, an Outstanding Newcomer
description: IF Bistro Blue had opened to the west or south of Greenport, it would be better known and more expensive. Hot new restaurants (and that's what it is) are an integral part of the Hamptons mantra and are widely celebrated in restaurant-rich areas of Nassau like Manhasset, Rockville Centre, Great Neck and the Five Towns. But on the laid-back North Fork, the opening of a restaurant, even an outstanding eatery like this one, in the Sterling Harbor Marina at 1410 Manhanset Avenue, where Portabello had been in Greenport (477-3940), is no big deal.

title: Nancy Hament, Richard Scarola
description: Nancy Jane Hament and Richard John Joseph Scarola were married last evening by Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Pierre Faber, Margaret McCutcheon
description: Margaret Scott McCutcheon, the daughter of Lois and Ronald McCutcheon of Middle Haddam, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. Pierre Anthony Faber, the son of Pamela Faber and Dr. Gunther Faber of Johannesburg. The Rev. E. Page Rogers performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Ed Dempsey, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Making Up Beds And Home Pages
description: THE precise number of the nation's bed-and-breakfasts is unknown, although it is often estimated that there may be as many as 25,000 of them. For their owners, often mom-and-pop entrepreneurs, the Internet has come as a godsend.

title: The Physical-Therapist Glut
description: To the Editor:

title: An Idea Whose Time Has Gone
description: THE PASSING OF AN ILLUSIONThe Idea of Communism in the Twentieth Century.By Francois Furet.Translated by Deborah Furet.596 pp. Chicago:The University of Chicago Press. $35.

title: Sony's Builds a Mall. But Don't Call It That.
description: ON the fourth floor of Metreon, the Sony Corporation's new entertainment and retail complex here, an energetic brigade of towering, fanged, yellow-eyed monsters brings to life Maurice Sendak's children's classic, ''Where the Wild Things Are.'' They hang from the ceiling, pop out of the craggy landscape and howl when their football-field-length territory is invaded. Children scamper through an array of caves and tunnels, building towers with faux-stone blocks and yanking on the ropes and levers that make the monsters jump and twirl.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: MOONThe Life and Death of a Rock Legend.By Tony Fletcher.Spike/Avon, $30.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 36 of The Times Magazine today about campaign finance reform includes an outdated reference to the unwillingness of George W. Bush Jr.'s advisers to identify his donors. On Tuesday, after the article had gone to press, Mr. Bush did name some donors who have raised at least $100,000 each.

title: Slaying of Serbs Sets Back Effort for Kosovo Peace
description: The mutilated bodies of 14 Serbian farmers who had been fatally shot were discovered on Friday night grouped around their harvesting machine in the worst single assault against the dwindling pockets of Serbian civilians left in Kosovo since NATO troops arrived last month.

title: Historic Cemetery Cited
description: Stony Hill Cemetery in Harrison, a burial ground for black Civil War soldiers, has been put on the National Historic Register -- a designation that will allow the Stony Hill Cemetery Restoration Committee to get financing to preserve the site.

title: Party in Westport In the French Style: Kiss, Kiss, for Art
description: AIR KISSING -- first one cheek, then the other -- was de rigeur last weekend at the Gallerie Je Reviens in Westport, where more than 200 francophiles, art collectors and friends celebrated the opening of an exhibition of works by four French painters.

title: Justice in Argentina
description: To the Editor:

title: Same Congressman, New Party
description: As Representative Michael P. Forbes prepared for another day trying to convince Democrats that he was no longer a Republican, the gathering crowds at the Tanger Outlet Center here were searching for bargains, with little thought about politics.

title: More Than Just A Place To Stay: Maine; Urbane style, and no cliches, in a Victorian mansion
description: Isabel Smiles came to Maine after many years as an antiques dealer in Greenwich, Conn. Her eclectic tastes are evident as soon as you pass through the white columns of what looks like any other large private house not far from the Portland waterfront, in a residential neighborhood of Victorian mansions, and are greeted by a life-size statue of a classical goddess holding a pomegranate. This is not like most bed-and-breakfasts, in New England or anywhere else.

title: Where Boccie and Ices Rule
description: At the crossroads of 108th Street and Corona Avenue is an elbow-shaped plot just shy of an acre. It is called William F. Moore Park, and though few can recall after whom it was named, this wooded triangle has long been the town square and backyard of Corona Heights.

title: A Thread to Follow Into the Past
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I went for a drive with a friend, and at one point he popped a cassette into the car's tape deck. ''I've been out with my oldest boy,'' he said, ''so I've been educating him. He's so surrounded by today's pop music, I thought it would be a good idea for him to hear just a regular old guitar band.'' I understood my friend's impulse: how do you give a kid with more than a superficial interest in pop music some perspective on its past?

title: Idealism at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Common Ground on Federal Tax Cut
description: In the midst of the bitter debate this week over the Republican tax bills moving through Congress, it was easy to lose sight of the emerging consensus in both parties that there should be a tax cut this year.

title: Kristin Lesser, Marshall Terry
description: Kristin Ilyse Lesser, a daughter of Joanna and Lawrence Lesser of Northport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marshall MacLeod Terry, a son of Lane and H.P. Terry of Canton, Conn. The Rev. Peter Gary performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Philip of Neri Church in Northport.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELL, MOLLIE BERGER
description: BELL-Mollie Berger, July 26, 1998. Ma, missing you so very much. Laurie and Nancy

title: The Nation: Tall Order; Hoping For A Few Good Missteps
description: IT seems, at times, that they should just shut down the campaign and crown Gov. George W. Bush of Texas the Republican Presidential nominee. He has the most money. The fanciest endorsements. The highest poll ratings. The most admiring press. The scent of a winner.

title: An Italian White To Sip and Inhale
description: Umbrian fruit with liquid syllables: procanico, grechetto, verdello, drupeggio, malvasia. Blended by Marchesi Antinori, the wines from these grapes compose the thirst-slaking '98 Campogrande -- ''large field'' -- a name that evokes its citrus-grove fragrance and flavor.

title: Ideas & Trends: Camcorders at the Ready; Celebrities Celebrating Celebrations
description: AT the White House last week, the United States women's soccer team stood behind President Clinton facing an ocean of cameras that has recorded the team's every move for the last month.

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: I was fortunate to have met Kubrick in London in the 1970's on one of those rare occasions when he ventured from his house in the suburbs into town. He was a cinema original. Yet I believe he may have been hampered by obsessive compulsive disorder, a symptom of which is a tendency to get caught up in details, out of proportion to their importance. Were it not for this, I feel that Kubrick might have made many more films in a career that spanned almost 50 years.

title: Toys in the Pre-Nintendo Era
description: What a cast: Mr. Potato Head, Barbie, G.I. Joe and Raggedy Ann and Andy. What props: Frisbees, Matchbox cars, Flexible Flyers, Slinkys, Easy-Bake Ovens, Lionel trains -- to name a few.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 25, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Contrast Is Obvious: Yankees Have Arms
description: This is no way to win a pennant.

title: History Repeats Itself
description: IT'S almost impossible to pinpoint which aspect of the Knife and Fork Inn held my attention the longest: the array of fresh seafood on each table, the 14-karat gold weathervane on the roof, four generations of family photographs adorning the walls, lighted buttons indicating to servers when dishes were ready, or the brief history noted on the menu, which highlights the restaurant's destruction in the Roaring 20's by ax-wielding Federal agents in search of liquor.

title: Entrances at Dental Clinic Called Separate and Unequal
description: What some see as an effort to accommodate the special needs of their clients, others view as an act of discrimination. At least that is the case with the dental clinic of Staten Island University Hospital, where there are two waiting rooms, one a general reception area, the other for mentally retarded and developmentally disabled patients.

title: The World; Bombing Won in Kosovo. Africa Is a Tougher Case.
description: NOW that NATO's bombers have forced the Serbs to capitulate in Kosovo, the question naturally arises: Couldn't the world's big powers try the same thing in Africa, which has been in dire need of peacemaking and peacekeeping for so long?

title: Streetscapes /Giorgio Cavaglieri; Near 88, a Preservationist Is Still a Maverick
description: NEXT month New York's senior preservation architect, Giorgio Cavaglieri, whose background includes designing airfields for Mussolini's army and recycling German barracks for the United States Army, as well as work with Rosario Candela, the iconic designer of luxury Manhattan apartment buildings, will be 88.

title: Harlem Fair Seen as Sign of Literary Resurgence
description: As a literary gathering in the city that dominates American book publishing, it was modest. But among the 500 writers, booksellers and browsers gathered yesterday on the concrete plaza of the Adam Clayton Powell office tower on 125th Street, it seemed clear that something special had returned to the artistic life of Harlem.

title: Whalen Playing on Smaller Stage
description: Two weeks ago, Sara Whalen played in the biggest game of her life in front of 90,000 fans at the Rose Bowl. Yesterday, she played on a much smaller stage, in front of 1,620 fans at North Hempstead Park.

title: Alpha Geeks
description: THE NUDIST ON THE LATE SHIFT

title: A Yankee Bias
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Your Right, a Big Slab of Gray
description: On a summer day in 1992, a young street artist named Andre Charles painted a 15-by-20-foot mural on the side of a building at Lafayette and Bleecker Streets depicting the artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.

title: Sports of The Times; Is Clemens Overanalyzing Clemens?
description: THE Yankees keep waiting for Roger Clemens to be the real Roger Clemens -- the five-time Cy Young Award winner, the American League's dominant pitcher, the barrel-chested right-hander whose 20 strikeouts in a game share the major league record with the Cubs' Kerry Wood, now recuperating from arm surgery. But it's as if a stranger is impersonating Roger Clemens.

title: A Big Step In a Job That Fits
description: SHE is the angel of the New Castle Town Hall here.

title: Good, Bad and the Ugly: Knoblauch Hears the Fans
description: Chuck Knoblauch was a human weather vane in the Yankees' crazy game with the Cleveland Indians on Friday night.

title: Three Unwritten Rules of the Serbian War
description: It was ''a splendid little war,'' exulted the Secretary of State, ''begun with the highest motives, carried on with magnificent intelligence, favored by that fortune which loves the brave.'' That was John Hay after the Spanish-American War of 1898, but it could have been Madeleine Albright, celebrating victory over Serbia's Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGILVY, DAVID
description: OGILVY-David. Yours is a legacy of intellect, civility and creative energy that survives in the great agency you founded and the people you've taught. We mourn the passing of David Ogilvy. Your friends at Davis & Gilbert

title: Different Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: East Village Junkies as Historical Footnote
description: A RUSTIC Tuscan restaurant, I Coppi, opened on my block a few months ago, the kind that serves $18 plates of ravioli and $1,000 bottles of Sassicaia wine. Ever since April, when The New York Times praised it and gave it two stars, the place has been packed with uptown foodie types titillated by the idea of dining just steps from colorful punk kids with mangy hair and multiple piercings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, NORMAN, DR.
description: ROSENTHAL-Norman, Dr. Dear Norman, thank you for 30 years of superb medical care and friendship, always done with brilliance and humor. You will always be in our hearts. Norma, Philip, Lauren and Greg Stephen, Bernice Feldhun

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACONETTI, JOSEPH
description: IACONETTI-Joseph. On July 21, 1999 of North Merrick, New York. Former Owner & President of Walker & Whyte, Inc., L.I.C., N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Catherine. Loving father of Rose Marie Gauthier, Patricia Ann Ingrassia and Catherine Fry. Fond father-inlaw of Richard, Frank and Alan. Dear brother of Anthony, Mae, Thomas, Frank, James, Phyllis and the late Gene. Dearest grandfather of Richard, Steven, Christine, Frank, Jamie, Donna, Rick & Robert and great-grandfather of 10. Visiting at the N.F. Walker, Inc. Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Ave, Merrick, N.Y. Sunday 2-4 and 79PM. Funeral Mass Mon. 10:45AM at Sacred Heart RC Church, North Merrick, New York. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Glass Ceiling Isn't Shattered Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Clock of Note Runs Out of Time
description: The Carl Fischer clock is living on borrowed time.

title: Jill Zeitlin, Marc Wilenzick
description: Dr. Jill Fern Zeitlin, the daughter of Rhonnie Zeitlin and Arnold Zeitlin of Merrick, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Marc Brian Wilenzick, the son of Phyllis Wilenzick and Dr. Raymond Wilenzick of New Orleans. Rabbi Charles Klein is to perform the ceremony at the Merrick Jewish Center.

title: For Some Serbs Here, Sting of Discrimination
description: WHILE several thousand Albanian refugees pour into the Waterbury area, welcomed by their countrymen who are already here, Serbs in Connecticut say they are suffering quietly as they see on television and in the newspapers how the bombings by NATO have affected family and friends in their homeland. They say they sometimes feel the sting of discrimination when some Americans stereotype Serbs as villains.

title: Q&A/Mark Davies; Ethics as a Working Part of Official Life
description: AS executive director of the state's Temporary Commission on Local Government Ethics from 1990 to 1992, Mark Davies of Tarrytown was at the forefront of an unsuccessful effort to make radical changes in the state's ethics laws as they apply to local governments. While the Temporary Commission was abolished in 1992, he has continued to add to his credentials and share his expertise in the area of ethics.

title: The Nation: Unreasonable Suspicion; Drawing the Line on the Strip-Search
description: The jail-house drill is simple, if humiliating: Take off your clothes. Raise your hands over your head. Be prepared to bend over or squat. Someone may run a hand through your hair.

title: From Identical Twins, a Story of Two Conjoined
description: FROM a distance, on a hot July morning, two visual details set the twin brothers Michael and Mark Polish apart from the campers clustered in the palm-shaded forecourt of the Los Angeles Zoo. They are taller than the children, and their identical white T-shirts bear no identifying camp logo. In fact, the creators of ''Twin Falls Idaho,'' a darkly romantic fable of duty and desire (opening Friday) that was an oddball hit at both Sundance and the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series, are poised, identical 27-year-olds with stylishly cropped hair and an eager distributor (Sony Classics), the latter being the independent film world's equivalent of a corner office. Still, they have retained the wiry build of adolescent skateboarders, and their matching faces are so angular that they seem boyishly scrubbed -- if only of unnecessary flesh.

title: Camps Had a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Dennis Lehane; On Streets Where Fact Intersects With Fiction
description: In Dennis Lehane's mystery novels, he taps into what he describes as the ''comically fatalistic'' outlook of the working-class Irish with whom he shares this corner of New England, and to whom he unmistakably belongs. ''It's a feeling that God has a sense of humor,'' Mr. Lehane explained. ''You might not be laughing, but He is.''

title: Sarah Werner, Rukesh Korde
description: Dr. Sarah Gabrielle Werner and Rukesh Anil Korde were married last evening at the Art Alliance, a Philadelphia gallery. Judge Louis H. Pollak of Federal District Court in Philadelphia officiated.

title: A Worldly Getaway 2 Hours From Manhattan
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: The Man Who Named Hoover Inc.
description: Behind Hoover's Inc., a business information company that went public last week, there really is a Hoover. But Gary E. Hoover has shown himself better at creating successful businesses than making a killing as they matured. Mr. Hoover parted with most of his stake in Hoover's years ago, donating some to charity and using another portion for his next venture, Travelfest, a travel superstore.

title: Armstrong Wins Yet Another Stage and Prepares for a Coronation
description: Good thing Lance Armstrong didn't put his money where his mouth is.

title: Priya Kumar and Hiral Shah
description: Priya Kumar, a daughter of Dr. Chandra Kumar and Dr. Ganesh P. Kumar of Syosset, N.Y., was married on Friday to Hiral Hemendra Shah, a son of Kiran Shah and Dr. Hemendra H. Shah of New Hyde Park, N.Y. Dr. Dasan Potti, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Hindu Temple Society of North America in Flushing, Queens.

title: Nature Is Served At a New Resort
description: IT'S hard to think that the two resorts I visited last month could be in the same universe, let alone the same state. A family reunion took me to Disney World in Orlando, where three dozen of us had breakfast with Mickey, among several otherworldly events. When the family said farewells on Sunday, I drove north 75 miles on Florida's Turnpike and on Marion Country roads to the Refuge at Ocklawaha.

title: Atlantic Salmon Elude Even Dogged Pursuit
description: ''I think we'll try a Green Machine,'' said my guide, Charles Irving, thus opening another chapter in my quest for Atlantic salmon, which had it beginnings 55 years ago on the River Towy in Wales.

title: No Issue Dominates The 2000 Campaign
description: In the 1992 Presidential election, a struggling national economy was the big issue, as summed up by that year's Democratic catch phrase, ''It's the economy, stupid.''

title: Real Campaign-Finance Reform
description: George W. Bush Jr. has raised the most money of any Presidential candidate in history: $36 million and counting. Much of it was gathered by only 200 people, super-fund-raisers whom Bush has dubbed ''Pioneers.'' Should Bush get elected President next year, it is not caviling to say that those 200 people are more likely to get a phone call through, and possibly even get a favor returned, than, say, I will. So who are these very special people? Bush's campaign advisers have decided it is not in our interest to know, and there is no legal means to compel them to tell.

title: Pesticides Levels High In Rural Ground Water
description: An 18-month study of pesticides in Long Island ground water has found that levels are highest in private wells in agricultural areas of eastern Long Island, where more than 15 percent of wells tested contained amounts above state safety standards for drinking water.

title: Ms. Zborovsky, Mr. Martesko-Fenster
description: Julia Zborovsky was married on Friday to Karol Martesko-Fenster at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Harvey Abramowitz officiated.

title: July 18-24; A Test for North Korea
description: North Korea plans to launch its long-range ballistic missile this summer despite warnings from the United States, Japan and South Korea.

title: 15 Drivers Receive Summonses For Driving Through E-Z Pass
description: As part of the first crackdown on violators of the electronic toll system on the six tunnels and bridges linking New Jersey and New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey issued summonses to 15 people last Wednesday for driving through the E-Z Pass lanes at the Lincoln Tunnel without paying.

title: Scenic Tourist Trains Return to the Rockies
description: A CENTURY ago, it was the busiest train route through the Rockies: a ribbon of rail down a 1,000-foot-deep canyon, a granite gorge so narrow that at one point, engineers hung a bridge from the walls to suspend the rails over the rushing waters of the Arkansas River.

title: Newspaper Publisher Buys Into Mavericks
description: Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News, agreed to buy a 12.4 percent stake in Dallas Basketball, which owns the professional basketball franchise in the city, for about $24 million.

title: Maurice Goodman and Gerda Gallop
description: Gerda Dione Gallop and Maurice Lee Booker Goodman were married yesterday by the Rev. Joseph P. Watkins at the Holy Trinity Baptist Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Cecil D. Gallup, a great-uncle of the bride and the pastor of Holy Trinity, took part in the ceremony.

title: Requiem for an Ex-Heavyweight?
description: The end appears near for what was once one of the fund industry's hottest offerings. The trustees of the $708 million John Hancock Special Equities fund, which has badly lagged behind its peers in recent years, have proposed merging it with the John Hancock Small Cap Growth fund, which has $722 million in assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDER, WINFIELD J.
description: BRUDER-Winfield J. On July 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Sandra. Loving father of Melissa. Survived by three bothers and three sisters. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72nd St. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment Brigadier General William C. Doyle Veterans Memorial Cemetery.

title: Taking More Chances in Trusts
description: Americans who create charitable remainder trusts -- which give the donors income for life and pass their assets to charity at death -- are taking bigger investment risks these days, new data from the Internal Revenue Service show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARZULLO, SALVATORE G.
description: MARZULLO-Salvatore G. Of Orlando, FL. Formerly of Northport, N.Y. On July 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Rosalinda (nee Quintana). Father of Philip, Bruce and Jay. Grandfather of Alexandra and Christian. Retired Vice President, International Government Relations, Mobil Oil Corporation. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 16th, 1999 on Marco Island, Florida.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99; What They Were Thinking
description: De Vore Henderson (With His Father), Philadelphia, May 19, 1999

title: On Politics; Florio and Corzine Land Jabs In the Clinches and the Faxes
description: After putting up $500,000 from his own pocket as seed money to launch his exploratory campaign for the Democratic Party's nomination in next year's Senate race, Jon S. Corzine has pretty much persuaded most skeptics that he intends to live up to his vow to spend what it takes to win the nomination.

title: The View From/Guilford; After a Decade Dormant, a Golf Course Is Reborn
description: IN the summer of 1930, Gardner Wheeler thought it would be interesting to build a golf course in the Guilford Lakes section of Guilford. He was a 16-year-old student at New Haven's Hillhouse High School at the time and a budding engineer who was vacationing in Guilford Lakes with his family.

title: Body of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: A Full Season of Shakespeare
description: AFTER a recent performance of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' by the Fleetwood Stage here, a youngster asked: ''Where does Shakespeare go when it's cold outside?''

title: Lauren Lazin, Norman Green
description: Lauren Beth Lazin and Norman Scott Green were married last evening by Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SIGMUND (SIGGY)
description: LEVINE-Sigmund (Siggy). Our dearest brother, friend and playmate. We miss you already. You will always be in our hearts. With love, Carole and Jerry

title: Amanda Fenton And Eyal Gilad
description: Amanda Sara Fenton, the daughter of Arlene and Arthur Fenton of Manhattan, was married last evening to Eyal Gilad, a son of Varda and Amos Gilad of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss officated at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: New Store Offers The World in Print
description: Helping keep the global village tightly knit is a new store on Morningside Heights called Global Ink, where you can find nearly 5,000 magazines from North America and Europe and about 150 newspapers from places as distant as Egypt, Brazil and Japan. The store, which occupies 550 square feet at 2876 Broadway (between West 111th and 112th Streets), also sells imported cigarettes and cigars, and will soon have a pastry and coffee bar. The space, rented from Columbia University, was formerly occupied by a women's clothing store.

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: Peter Bogdanovich's intimate and affectionate portrait of Stanley Kubrick (July 4) was absorbing. I have never read a biography of Kubrick, although his movies are my favorites. Your article will make me watch them all again -- this time with an even deeper appreciation of the care taken in the process of their creation.

title: DATABANK: JULY 18-July 23; If It Weren't for Those Darn Profits...
description: Last week's action in American equities put the lie to the often-heard complaint that investors, swept up as they are in the Internet gold rush, had stopped caring about company profits. Now, in the thick of the season for second-quarter earnings reports, it's clear that investors do care about profits: They hate them.

title: From Paperboy to Philanthropist
description: LEGACYA Biography of Mosesand Walter Annenberg.By Christopher Ogden.Illustrated. 615 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $29.95.

title: Just in Case Your Reservoir Is Full
description: Dry soil in the vegetable garden results in poor setting of fruit, cracking in tomatoes, a reduction of female zucchini flowers and bitterness in cucumbers and greens. Water deeply if allowed, and mulch with straw or compost.

title: Can Profits Keep Surging All Year? A 'Yes' Vote
description: CORPORATE AMERICA is rolling in dough. So too, it must be added, are those who have bought and held shares during the last few years. This is not an incidental relationship.

title: After the Fall
description: The Broken Estate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHADBOURN, JOHN A. (JACK)
description: CHADBOURN-John A. (Jack), on July 23rd, 1999. Beloved brother of Jean Morton of Elm Grove, Wisconsin. Devoted uncle of Sarah and David Zubke, Mary Morton and John and Chris Morton. Nephew of Charles D. Turgrimson. Dear friend of Virginia Tolley. Associate Clinical Professor at New York Medical College. A devoted medical education teacher, repeatedly awarded Outstanding Teacher of the Year at New York Medical College. Interment in Columbus, Wisconsin. Memorial contributions may be made to United Cerebral Palsy, 122 E. 23rd St., NY NY 10010.

title: Hostetler Puts Focus on Paralyzed Son
description: Everything was going right for Jeff Hostetler. An ankle injury from a 1998 preseason game had completely healed and he had spent the last year getting into top shape. Last month, four teams showed serious interest in signing him as a backup quarterback.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's kind of like a decayed tooth. If you don't take care of it, one day you'll wake up with a mouthful of cavities.''

title: Divinely Insignificant
description: The French painter Gustave Moreau (1826-98) was a visionary who resisted getting swept up in the late-19th-century tides of naturalism and Impressionism and pursued instead his own version of an epic past. Through his eclectic use of exotic imagery, he imbued his mythical and biblical scenes with an Oriental mysticism, creating what Genevieve Lacambre, the director of the Musee Gustave Moreau in Paris, in GUSTAVE MOREAU: Between Epic and Dream (Art Institute of Chicago/Princeton University, $60), calls ''a realm of evocation, imagination and dreams.'' But to many of his contemporaries, Moreau's vision was perplexing. ''Are we in poor Judea or in the home of the opulent rajah of Mysore?'' one mystified critic asked after viewing one of Moreau's most celebrated paintings, ''Salome,'' at the Paris Salon of 1876. In the 20th century Moreau has become even more of an enigma. Largely ignored by an Impressionism-obsessed public, and often pigeonholed by critics as a transitional artist whose work paved the way for Surrealism, Moreau's best-known legacy may be that he taught Henri Matisse and Georges Rouault. ''Gustave Moreau: Between Epic and Dream,'' with more than 200 color reproductions, essays by several Moreau scholars, and Lacambre's historical and critical text about the artist's major works, examines Moreau's amazingly varied influences, which include da Vinci's ''Adoration of the Magi,'' Algerian dance costumes, Mogul miniatures, medieval tapestries and the seven labors of Hercules. The many excerpts from Moreau's own writings give the reader the clearest idea of what he aspired to: ''the flashes of illumination that one doesn't know how to situate, that have something divine in their seeming insignificance.'' Suzanne MacNeille

title: Blue Jays Want to Make It to the Playoffs, and Not Just as the Wild Card
description: No sooner did the Toronto Blue Jays overtake the Boston Red Sox for the best second-place record in the American League than they proclaimed that the wild-card spot in the playoffs would not be good enough.

title: Beyond the Savings Rate
description: THE Government's announcement last month that the savings rate was the lowest since the Depression has prompted much unease. After all, in a time of such plenty, how can Americans not be putting away some of their surplus to prepare for harder times?

title: The Oracle of the Fed
description: Alan Greenspan, who has been chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for a dozen years, is a past master of the art of Delphic Congressional testimony. So perhaps it is understandable that many Congressmen take for granted that he is always that way, and seem to have trouble understanding him when he decides to make himself perfectly clear.

title: Dublin
description: During the past decade, Dublin, once a gloomy, provincial city, has become Europe's darling. The economy is booming, and Dublin now is a regular on lists of top 10 destinations.

title: Getting Beyond Busing
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions Remain as Deregulation Nears
description: In the State Legislature's perfect world, on Nov. 14 electricity users will be liberated from the regulated monopolies that have kept New Jersey's rates 50 percent higher than the national average.

title: Building Skills in Summer School
description: ''GUYS, let's see what phrases you can come up with that have the word 'state' in them,'' Paula Higgins said to the students who sat in a circle around her at a small table.

title: Commercial Property; New Niche Hotels in Downtown Manhattan
description: WITH selling points ranging from high technology to luxury wrapped in massive stone columns to colonial touches in a historic area, a variety of new hotels have opened or will open soon in downtown Manhattan.

title: Baseball's Maddening List
description: Major League Baseball has decided to join the millennium ratings madness with its own best-of-the-century list. Between now and September, fans will be asked to examine a list of 100 players and choose two for each infield position, two catchers, nine outfielders and six pitchers. In order to correct obvious oversights, a special panel will be authorized to add up to five players to the team.

title: Art Under Foot (the Skater's, That Is)
description: When a skater pulls a handplant on a halfpipe (translation, if needed: the move pictured, but performed upside down on the precipice of a curved ramp), the graphic design on the underside of the board is briefly exposed. This design may seem arbitrary, but to the skater, it may be a crucial expression of identity.

title: Orphan Walkway Cleaned at Last
description: Weeks after crowds gathered on a new East River walkway to watch the Fourth of July fireworks, debris was still strewn on the ground and more than a dozen trash cans were overflowing with moldy food, dirty diapers and other refuse, but no one seemed to know whose job it was to haul the garbage away.

title: Wanted: One Flabby Flounder. Reward: $100,000.
description: Among the countless anglers who ply New Jersey's coastal waters every summer, flounder fishing has always been less of a sport than a cheeky euphemism for lounging astern with a couple of buddies, an AM radio and a case of ice-cold beer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHHORN, SHIRLEY
description: HIRSCHHORN-Shirley. Beloved sister of Gertrude Rachelson, sister-in-law of Murray Rachelson, Great Aunt, Aunt and friend to many, died Wednesday, July 21, 1999 in Aventura, Florida. Born on April 10, 1902 in NYC, she was the sister of the late Pauline Becher, Rita Roth & Henrietta Hirschhorn. Graveside services, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York on Monday, July 26, at 11 A.M.

title: July 18-24; A Plan to Share Organs
description: It is a question worthy of Solomon: With donated livers in short supply, who should get one? A report from the Institute of Medicine offered an answer: Scarce livers should be distributed across city and state lines, within areas of about 9 million people each, so the sickest patients get them first. The report backs a Clinton Administration plan to force broader sharing. But Congress, which ordered the study, will have the final say. SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMANN, SUSAN M.
description: WEISMANN-Susan M. On Sunday July 18. We are deeply saddened upon the loss of our beloved cousin and dearest friend. She will be sorely missed. Drs. Bob & Edith Rosenberger, London Marianne & Peter Summerfield, London

title: Our Towns; Woodstock Not in Name, But in Spirit
description: THEY traveled from Portland, Ore., and Hartwood, Va., from Cambridge, England, and Davis, Calif., to erect a rainbow quilt of dome tents, tarps and tepees across Bob Brennan's 260-acre farm here on the western fringe of the Berkshires.

title: Debating Hepatitis B Vaccine; A Vaccinated Child Who Fell Ill . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Glass Ceiling Isn't Shattered Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Pelham Parkway; A Polyglot Enclave In Central Bronx
description: ON a scorching Sunday earlier this month, the vast lawns at the center of Pelham Parkway were dotted with sunbathers and dog-walkers. Joggers rounded the dirt paths edging the greenspace and young parents pushing strollers meandered along shade-speckled walkways. It was a slice of Paris in the Bronx, a tree-lined boulevard linking Bronx Park to Pelham Bay Park.

title: Q. & A.
description: Mortgages: The Rules On Income

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: I first met Stanley when we were 10 years old; we sat next to each other in class at P.S. 90 in the Bronx. He was sweet and polite. He never spoke much, but when he did his words were well chosen. And he was never without his camera.

title: Cecilia Campos, Abraham Siuffe
description: Cecilia Elena Campos and Abraham Vicente Siuffe were married last evening by the Rev. Susanna Stefanachi-Macomb, an interfaith minister, at Coco Marina, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Eyes in Back of the Head
description: As a souvenir for ''Fame After Photography,'' a new multimedia exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the museum's Design Store at 44 West 53d Street is selling the Watcher ($9), a black Velcro wristband with a round fish-eye mirror.

title: Lots of Kid Stuff, Taken (and Displayed) Seriously
description: THE image is endearingly familiar: a monkey with wide eyes and the body of a toddler is off to some fresh mischief. Who else but Curious George, drawn by H. A. Rey? Besieged by images and text in the age of the Web, we still carry around the memories of favorite children's books. Meanwhile, the study of children's literature has come of age, with doctoral dissertations written on ''Alice in Wonderland.'' The de Grummond collection at the University of Southern Mississippi fills these academic needs and then some, as demonstrated in a sumptuous exhibit called ''The Culture of Childhood'' running through Aug. 31.

title: Irabu Stakes Post-Season Claim As the Yankees Win in a Romp
description: There will be a Yankees staff meeting in late September to prepare for the American League playoffs, with Manager Joe Torre and others circled around a table. General Manager Brian Cashman will be there, as will the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, and in that meeting they will remember what Hideki Irabu did yesterday.

title: Is It Palermo, or Pamplona?
description: ANY traveler who has attempted to stroll along a picturesque Italian side street or backed up to get a better view of some magnificent Renaissance palazzo knows about Italy's treacherous traffic -- the crazed drivers, the anarchic Vespas, the narrow sidewalks, the lack of sidewalks, narrow or otherwise.

title: Cooling Unit, Heated Dispute
description: For more than four years, residents of the St. George Tower on Hicks Street have feuded with the Jehovah's Witnesses over a cooling unit that the Witnesses have installed atop their building on nearby Clark Street. Residents of the luxury co-op said the unit was an eyesore and inappropriate for the Brooklyn Heights Historic District. They also said the noise was disturbing their peace. But the Witnesses insisted they have done everything properly.

title: Pacers and Hawks Try To Catch Up to Knicks
description: Latrell Sprewell and Marcus Camby, the explosive and fleet-footed Knicks, are still on the minds of the Indiana Pacers and the Atlanta Hawks. Having been victimized by the new-look Knicks in the Eastern Conference playoffs, two of the league's more renowned plodders are looking to become more athletic, more versatile, more Knickish.

title: Warm Scores, Brass and Strings
description: THE Silvermine Guild and South Shore Summer Concerts each have highly attractive offerings on Friday at 8 P.M.

title: The View From/New Rochelle; In Body Stocking, Puck Still Speaks Elizabethan
description: THE green knoll at Hudson Park here had a timeless look about it. The summer dusk, the 150 or so people sitting on the gently sloping lawn, attention focused on a wooden stage could have been an audience from centuries ago, except for the blue jeans, T-shirts and folding plastic chairs. The stage was hung with silk banners and framed by tall elms; behind it was a picture-window view of Long Island Sound.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 11 about living in Newtown, Conn., misstated the name of a restaurant. It is G. P. Cheffield's Steak and Fish House, not Sheffield's Continental.

title: Cohan Home Backers: It's a Grand Old Place
description: MUSIC and history were once made at a home on six waterfront acres in Kings Point. It was there that George M. Cohan lived from 1914 to 1928, when he wrote the un official World War I anthem ''Over There,'' not to mention ''45 Minutes From Broadway,'' about his daily trip to Manhattan from Great Neck.

title: A Forlorn Cigarette Billboard Prolongs Its Last Gasp
description: A cigarette billboard on the side of a Brooklyn apartment building may have been the last of its kind, state officials said last week. The tobacco companies agreed in April to take all the billboards down, but getting this one removed had proved difficult until last week, when the owner finally took steps to replace it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BORIS M.D.
description: SCHWARTZ - Boris M.D. of Wayne, NJ. Survivors are Elizabeth, Sidney Schwartz, and Miriam Levine. Beloved uncle of several nieces and nephews. Services are 10 AM today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W150 Rt. #

title: July 18-24; A Virus Found
description: For years, scientists have been unable to find a virus to account for a significant number of hepatitis cases not caused by the liver ailment's five main known viruses. Italian scientists reported strong evidence that they had discovered a new virus, the last major piece of the puzzle of blood-borne hepatitis. But confirmation and further research is needed to learn whether blood banks should routinely test for it.

title: Mr. Hughes and Ms. Accomando
description: Michelle Accomando, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Accomando of Lynnfield, Mass., was married last evening to Timothy James Hughes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hughes Jr., of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Gabriel Troy performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: Beneath a Boom Quarter
description: ONE of the companies reporting boffo earnings last week was the Bear Stearns Companies, the nation's fourth-largest publicly traded brokerage firm. A big beneficiary of Wall Street's nonstop party, Bear Stearns reported that net income for the quarter ended June 30 rose 56.2 percent from the comparable period last year. The company even managed to eke out an earnings gain of almost 2 percent for its entire fiscal year, no small feat given the upheaval in the global markets last fall.

title: Jul 18-24; Why Sammy Won't Hide
description: Suppose your testimony had landed a certain John J. Gotti in prison. You'd surely want to do just one thing -- crawl into the most remote cave you could find, and sit there quietly, fingers firmly crossed. At relaxed moments, you might permit yourself to breathe.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about a cellar apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, misstated the city's policy on making such an apartment legal. A cellar apartment, which is more than half underground, cannot be legalized; a basement apartment, which is more than half above ground, can be made legal if the Buildings Department approves the plans.

title: Two-Way Presidential Coattails
description: After his galling defeat by the Governor of Arkansas in 1992, President George Bush became something of an outcast in his own party. At Republican functions, speakers rattled on longingly about Ronald Reagan. But never about Mr. Bush. It was as if Republicans had collective amnesia about the man who led their party and the nation from 1989 to 1992.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of millennium trips on page 3 of the Travel section today gives an outdated schedule for the voyage around India by American Museum of Natural History Discovery Tours. The dates have been changed to Dec. 26 through Jan. 14.

title: Botanic Garden's Help Line Has Turned Into a Hot Line
description: After a slight drizzle in the muggy heat Thursday afternoon, a handful of volunteers wheeled the Plant First Aid Cart, with its green awning and gardening books, to its spot under a magnolia tree near the visitors center at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: RUN CATCH KISSBy Amy Sohn.Simon & Schuster, $23.

title: OPINION; M.T.A.'s Missed Opportunities
description: AS intractable as the traffic congestion problem is on the South Fork of Long Island, it's no match for the intransigence of the one public agency that could offer concrete solutions to Southampton and East Hampton Towns. Actually, concrete is a poor choice of words. Widening existing highways and adding new ones create more problems than they solve. The real solution to congestion lies in the South Fork's most valuable transportation asset -- the Long Island Rail Road. Unfortunately, its parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is woefully unresponsive to the local transportation needs.

title: Mourners Pay Respects to Third Victim of Kennedy Crash
description: More than 600 mourners gathered here this evening to pay respects to Lauren Bessette, the third victim of the plane crash that also killed John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette Kennedy just over a week ago.

title: Russian Gangsters Exploit Capitalism To Increase Profits
description: A few years ago, British intelligence and law enforcement agencies began investigating the money-laundering activities of Russian organized crime in Britain. At the center of their concerns was Semyon Yukovich Mogilevich, a man described by British authorities in one classified report as ''one of the world's top criminals, who has a personal wealth of $100 million.''

title: Passing Benchmarks, Earning More Fees
description: IT'S no secret that after a spell of subpar performance, some of the largest funds managed by Fidelity Investments have rebounded and begun to beat their benchmarks consistently.

title: Nurtured by a Canal, a Downtown Desert Blooms
description: THE Providence that greeted a generation of visitors during the dark days of urban renewal might have stood as an emblem of the demise of American downtowns. Choked with roads, strewn with rubble and crowded with hard-top parking lots, the grim center of this city seemed blighted beyond redemption.

title: Not Just for Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Vivien Malloy, Richard Hanson
description: Vivien Consuelo Malloy and Richard Carl Hanson were married yesterday in Katonah, N.Y. George Hunter Roberts, the town justice of Lewisboro, N.Y., officiated at the John Jay Homestead.

title: He Said, They Said: A Clash of Wills Over at the Bergen Museum
description: Dissension is the main exhibit by the Bergen Museum these days. Factions of its board are battling in court for control of an institution that has been left with no home and almost no money after years of financial neglect.

title: Movie Congregation Wonders: Will Rabbi Get the Girl?
description: THE SETTING -- The Greek Orthodox Church of the Ascension on West End Avenue and 91st Street, where several hundred people waited Wednesday night for their turn as extras in a movie called ''Keeping the Faith,'' while also raising money for Jewish organizations. The production company, Spyglass Entertainment, offered groups like the United Jewish Appeal and the Simon Wiesenthal Center $10 for each extra they mustered.

title: A New Look but Same High Standards
description: WHEN the Laundry restaurant closed this spring, its loyal fans were dismayed. But it was just temporary. This venerable East Hampton spot (yes, 19 years is indeed venerable in the Hamptons) was shut for renovations by its new owners.

title: The Party's Over
description: IN SEPTEMBER, THE LIGHT CHANGES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENTHAL, DORA
description: BLUMENTHAL-Dora. On July 24, 1999. Beloved wife of David. Cherished mother of Frances (Harvey) Peters. Adored grandmother of Joshua and Suzanne. Services today, 12 Noon, at Louis Hirsch & Sons, 167th St. and Jerome Ave., the Bronx. Interment Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens. In lieu, donations to Epilepsy Foundation or charity of your choice.

title: Drug War at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Agent for the Women of the Hour
description: SUE RODIN's trip to the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta changed her professional life. Having watched two of her marketing jobs disappear -- one in a corporate downsizing and the other after an unsuccessful spinoff -- Ms. Rodin, then 49, was wrapping up a consulting stint with Avon, a sponsor of the Games, and considering starting a business of her own.

title: Redskins' New Owner Does a Housecleaning
description: The shuffling of the Washington Redskins' front office has telephone lines burning in the National Football League.

title: Jul 18-24; He's Such a Perfectionist
description: David Cone won 20 games for the Yankees last year, but after the season -- when other pitchers were signing deals for as much as $105 million -- he received a polite one-year, $8 million offer from the Yankees, who were concerned about his shoulder. At 36, Cone had thrown as many as 100,000 pitches in his major-league career and he was only three years removed from an aneursym that affects the feeling in his fingertips on cold days. Despite much more lucrative overtures from the Los Angeles Dodgers and Baltimore Orioles, Cone accepted the Yankees' deal to remain in the city he loves.

title: Not Quite Opera, Not Quite Oratorio
description: THE classical-music canon does not lack for oddities. Neither fish nor fowl, works like Debussy's ''Martyrdom of St. Sebastian,'' Richard Strauss's ''Enoch Arden'' and Schoenberg's ''Survivor From Warsaw'' entice music lovers through their esthetic merits while confounding with their unconventional structures.

title: FILM; All He Did Was Create a Parade of Classics
description: ''I'M not an auteur, alas,'' George Cukor once said, mistakenly and a bit coyly. These are the first words the director uttered in ''On Cukor,'' a book-length interview written by Gavin Lambert in 1972. Cukor died 11 years after the book was published, and his death was received with nearly as little attention as the interview. In the past decade, though, interest in this consummate Hollywood professional has quietly grown. There have been a pair of biographies, a PBS documentary is currently in production, and last year he was briefly if somewhat ignobly resurrected in Bill Condon's film ''Gods and Monsters'': Cukor is the fussbudget with whom James Whale makes such catty sport in front of Princess Margaret.

title: July 18-24; A Good Deficit
description: The more American consumers spend, the more the trade deficit rises -- last month to a record $21 billion, according to figures just released. And eventually that's bad news. But for now, it's good.

title: The Right Thing, Even When It Ends Up Wrong
description: ''SUMMER OF SAM'' is misguided, reckless, grating. Yet it smells like the work of a very promising kid with a beautiful, perilous idea and more energy than he can control. And don't underestimate that energy, the life and the painful rawness. Because, to this viewer's eyes, they are so much more appealing than the mummified finesse that masks a nearly complete ignorance of human beings called ''Eyes Wide Shut.'' I know this is not what everyone is saying (in print), but it is why Spike Lee matters.

title: A Far Island of Cultural Survival
description: ON opposite sides of a stage framed by stone gates at the Arts Center in the capital city of Denpasar, competing gamelans, or orchestras, of men wearing sarongs in team colors and head cloths shot with gold sat behind ornately carved instruments, each group in turn hammering out brilliant compositions, old and new. The two clubs had vied with dozens of others to win their places at the 21st annual Bali Arts Festival, 3 weeks of some 300 performances that ended on July 17. ''The Arts Festival is our Super Bowl,'' said Wayan Rai, a professor of music at the College of Indonesian Arts here and the man in charge of this year's event.

title: INSIDE
description: China's Lagging Economy

title: Word for Word; Unsettling TV Commercials And Now, a Gross-Out From Our Sponsor
description: GROSS-OUT comedy: Its vulgarity, in movies like ''American Pie'' this summer and television shows like ''South Park,'' has younger viewers in stitches. But its proliferation -- there's more in store this fall on television -- has parents and others bemoaning anew the coarsening of American popular culture.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The World: Ominous Signals in Iran; In Islamic Mideast, Scant Place for Jews
description: TO those who monitor events in Iran, the arrest of 13 Iranian Jews on spying charges this year is a menacing sign that bigger trouble may lie ahead -- trouble that, unchecked, could cause one of the last two Jewish communities of any size in the Islamic Middle East to follow most of the others into virtual oblivion.

title: Dan Quayle Deploys His Sense of Humor
description: It's a more laid-back Dan Quayle chasing the Republican nomination this time around. The eyes that once had a startled glow that resembled, as it was often said, those of a deer caught in headlights, now have a soft twinkle.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on July 11, about Carmel, Calif., referred incorrectly to the Carmelites who were there 400 years ago. They were explorers, not settlers.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: The Lazarus Rumba

title: On the Road to 2000
description: Fireworks from Sydney to Washington and music from the Beatles to Ellington will help travelers celebrate the New Year. Following is a sampling of packages and tours available. Prices are per person, double occupancy, unless otherwise noted; deposit and refund policies can be strict.

title: Backtalk; From So Old to So Valuable
description: With 25,000 people expected to show up for the opening this Wednesday of America's most popular, most successful and arguably most beautiful race track, it's hard to believe that Saratoga's viability was ever questioned.

title: Cobra Snake for a Necktie
description: WHO DO YOU LOVE

title: A Mostly Mozartean So Far: Mostly a Success?
description: WHEN Gerard Schwarz was named music adviser of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center in 1982, his conducting career had the brilliance and momentum of a rocket streaking across the heavens. Then 34, he had resigned as a trumpeter of the New York Philharmonic seven years before to devote himself to conducting, which he had done as a sideline since 1967. He was the music director of two orchestras -- the Y Chamber Symphony (now the New York Chamber Symphony), which was created for him at the 92d Street Y in 1976, and the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, which he inherited from Sir Neville Marriner in 1978 -- as well as the founding director of the Waterloo Festival in New Jersey.

title: A Hairdo With History
description: George Washington's cheeks probably weren't gaunt enough, but his hair could have qualified him for Gucci's fall 1999 advertising campaign. Not the powdered wig but the real stuff underneath. The campaign's hair stylist, Orlando Pita, observed that Washington wore his hair short on top and long in the back. Mr. Pita adopted the hairdo, now known as a bilevel or ''the mullet,'' when he glued footlong extensions onto the crew cut of the model James Heathcoat for the Gucci ad. Except that it looked like he was going more for punk than for Presidential.

title: Local Hopes for a Concert Windfall Are Dashed
description: More than 100 miles east of the exit leading to the Woodstock '99 festival, concert-bound travelers crowded the Starbucks counter at a rest stop on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway on Friday night.

title: Information Center For Nueva York
description: A new information center and bus station operated by the New York Apple Tours sightseeing company recently opened at 777 Eighth Avenue (near 47th Street).

title: Is Wall St. Too Narrow For a New Winnebago?
description: FOR more than a million Americans, summer means hitting the road in something larger than, say, a Jeep Wrangler. Motor homes, for years dismissed as lumbering icons of decades past, are fashionable again.

title: John Ross, Ann Maloney
description: Dr. Ann Shoemaker Maloney, a psychiatrist, and Dr. John Munder Ross, a psychoanalyst, both with private practices in Manhattan, were married on Thursday. Chief Justice Thomas R. Phillips of the Texas Supreme Court officiated with Justice William Leibovitz of State Supreme Court in Manhattan at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: Everybody's Got A Hungry Heart, And a Bruce Story
description: THE sweaty guy in jeans and a work shirt is preaching to the converted.

title: Pamela Addison, A. Gifford Miller
description: Pamela Beth Addison, a lawyer, was married yesterday to City Councilman A. Gifford Miller. The Rev. Gilbert S. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn.

title: More Than Just A Place To Stay: Maryland; An 18th-century manor with a wooden swing in the garden.
description: ''Did Sir Peter Parker die right in this house?'' I casually asked my hostess, Tracy Stone, as she refilled my coffee cup. I was having breakfast in the dining room of the Inn at Mitchell House, near Chestertown, Md.

title: The Rules
description: BUILDING WEALTH

title: Immigrants Aren't Servants For the Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: The Loneliness Of the Long-Distance Cosmologist
description: The group of graduate students had gathered, as groups of graduate students do at such affairs, off to one side of the hall. The occasion was a symposium at the Space Telescope Science Institute at Johns Hopkins University, in Baltimore, and the graduate students were eyeing their elders and chatting nervously about the many major figures in cosmology in the room. One student made the inevitable joke about a bomb going off and what that would do to their field of study. Everybody laughed. ''But at least it would open up some jobs,'' said another. More laughter. ''And the first bomb can strike right there,'' said a third, nodding toward a portly, elderly man standing not five yards away. The group grew quiet.

title: A Degree, And a Stake To Grow On
description: BRUCE SCHNEIDER has always dreamed about wine: smooth merlots, rich chardonnays, complex cabernets. It makes sense, because wine practically runs through his veins. His grandparents owned a wine shop in Port Elizabeth, N.J., and his parents ran a wine importing and distribution business.

title: National Parks, Strained by Record Crowds, Face a Crisis
description: In growing numbers that now exceed 3.1 million a year, visitors travel here to America's oldest national park to marvel at wildlife, towering mountains, pristine rivers and geological curiosities like geysers, hot springs and volcanic mudpots.

title: Edinburgh Landmark Opens as Festival Site
description: One of Edinburgh's most prominent landmarks, the Highland Tolbooth -- a 19th-century Gothic-style structure that was once a church -- has been recently transformed into the Edinburgh Festival Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISLE, ALFRED
description: KREISLE-Alfred. In Redwood City, CA, on July 23. He leaves his beloved wife Lillian and his adored children Robert and Donna and Bruce. With great affection for nieces and nephews Judy and Steve Kamberg, Rhoda and Dave Nathan, Lydia and Mel Kotimsky, Marsha and Ken Blinn, and Joel Zakoff. An alumnus of CCNY, NYU and University of Santa Clara. In retirement, an enrolled agent and tax preparer. He was an avid bridge player, reaching the rank of Life Master. A sports and movie buff, and above all a truly nice, kind man. He will be missed.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: On Language; Summer Words
description: We now approach the sultry dog days of midsummer, so called because they are marked by the heliacal rise of Sirius, the Dog Star. (I often say to my dogs when they prance about in glee, ''Be Sirius.'' Sorry, there are no cat days.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARFUNKEL, CARRIE
description: GARFUNKEL-Carrie. In loving memory. Your Children and Grandchildre

title: In the Gaming Industry, the House Can Have Bad Luck, Too
description: CASINOS, it is sometimes said, do not really gamble. The odds of the games insure that over the long run, the house will come out ahead.

title: A Summertime Trio
description: Viognier, a Rhone grape grown successfully in California, has advanced further on the East End.

title: More Than Just A Place To Stay: California; An out-of-the-way inn on the site of a former stagecoach stop
description: Nestled along Highway 3 in the Trinity Alps, 60 miles south of the California-Oregon border, Carrville is truly off the beaten path. Last year, Sheri and Dave Overly reopened a remarkable inn that started as a stagecoach stop along the California-Oregon stage road in 1854.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, PETER
description: RAMSEY-Peter. Playwright, died July 14, 1999, in NYC. Peter will be remembered by his family and friends who loved him dearly.

title: Tax Cutters Aren't Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoor Sculpture With a Festive Air
description: ON the route from the entrance of Purchase College to the Neuberger Museum of Art on the college's campus here, a visitor to the ''1999 Biennial Exhibition of Public Art'' is greeted first by a field of roses and then by tinkling bells. It is hard to imagine any beginning more festive. The viewers' good mood will be sustained: the 17 sculptures sited on the grounds are diverse and smart in their own way.

title: Waltz Power Still Leaves Highbrows A Bit Dizzy
description: ''WALZEN,'' as any bibulous Viennese will tell you, is ''to twirl.'' The word means more than ''rotate,'' less than ''wanken,'' or downright stagger. Drop the umlaut, and we have what Johann Strauss the Younger and his father had Europe doing for a good part of the 19th century.

title: Food; Jam Session
description: Some people can fruits and vegetables out of habit, or to honor the vestigial memory of times when putting food aside was an imperative for survival. Others take up canning to make sense of their lives. Nine years ago, for instance, Joan Hassol, a cellist, forager, mother of six and grandmother of nine, got serious about jam. It became a contemplative ritual that eventually connected one phase of her life with the next.

title: Where Hearty Appetites Are in Demand
description: IT is always a bonus when a restaurant opens near a movie theater, as Luna Rossa in the Ridgeway Shopping Center in Stamford has been proving the past few months, drawing crowds before and after the shows.

title: Q & A/Kenneth M. Reels; Chairman's Mission: Strengthen Control Of Tribal Business
description: PROMISING to lead the Mashantucket Pequot Tribe in a new direction, Kenneth M. Reels was elected Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Council Chairman by tribal members on Nov. 1, 1998, and began serving his term on Jan. 1.

title: Three Affairs to Remember
description: THE BOOK OF HAPPINESS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEERR, LILLIAN JAMISON
description: SHEERR-Lillian Jamison. 98, a resident of Palm Beach, FL for more than 50 years. Died in a car accident Friday, July 23, 1999. She was an active member of the Palm Beach Country Club and Philmont Country Club. She was the much loved matriarch of her large and extended family. She is survived by her daughters, Muriel Kaplan and Simone Goldblum of Palm Beach, FL; her brother Sidney Jamison of Philadelphia and 7 grandchidren and 13 great-grandchildren. Services will be at Beth Sholom Synagogue, Elkins Park, PA at 2PM Monday, July 26, 1999. Arrangements by Goldsteins' Funeral Home of Philadelphia, PA.

title: That U.P.S. Mystique
description: Those virile U.P.S. delivery men will now have another source of appeal: money. Plans by United Parcel Service of America Inc. for an initial public offering, announced last week, are likely to place a high value on employees' holdings.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for CYNTHIA A. COLENDA; Seeing a Cruise Industry That's Mostly Shipshape
description: IT has been rough going for the cruise industry the past two weeks.

title: W. X. Scheinman, 72, Broker and Friend of Kenyan Leader
description: William X. Scheinman, a self-taught Wall Street analyst who became an enthusiastic supporter of the independence movement in Africa, died on May 24 at his home in Reno, Nev., of kidney failure. He was 72.

title: Little Asias, Across Dixie
description: WHERE can you find immigrant entrepreneurs from Asia revitalizing urban neighborhoods today?

title: July 18-24; Smuggled Human Cargo
description: ''The Golden Mountain'' is what many poor Chinese call North America, and the interception of a boatload of more than 100 illegal immigrants in a ship off British Columbia shows once again what people will endure to reach these shores. Some paid more than $35,000; all endured filthy conditions for more than a month. Now Canadian immigration judges must decide if they will stay, or be deported to China. ANTHONY DePALMA

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER MANHATTAN

title: Jane Brodsky, Lloyd Sprung
description: Jane Sharp Brodsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Brodsky of Newport, R.I., was married last evening at her parents' house to Lloyd Adam Sprung, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil A. Sprung of Poway, Calif. Rabbi Paul Levenson officiated.

title: Victoria Wolfe, Michael Findlay
description: Victoria Elise Wolfe, an artist, and Michael Alistair Findlay, the international director of 19th and 20th century art at Christie's in New York, were married yesterday in Montauk, N.Y. Judge James R. Ketchum, a retired town justice for East Hampton, N.Y., officiated at the home of Alphonse Fletcher and Hobart Fowlkes, friends of the couple.

title: Ossining Project Fights Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: JACQUELINE ORTIZ wants to be an actress or a model. Cynthia Infante is also interested in acting, or maybe medicine. Both are 11-year-old Ossining seventh graders who are pursuing their dreams not in acting school but in a program to prevent teen-age pregnancy.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: HURRY HOMENovella and Short Stories.By Ann Scott Knight.Four Way Books, paper, $14.95.

title: Joy Richter, Aaron Weisbrod
description: Joy Beth Richter and Aaron King Weisbrod were married last evening by Rabbi Leslie Yale Gutterman at the Astors' Beechwood, the house museum in Newport, R.I.

title: Tax Cutters Aren't Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: A Norman Rockwell Wine
description: If you want a gift for Aunt Ida and Uncle Stanley -- who were freethinking hellions in 1915, still treasure wartime Saturday Evenings Posts in the attic and imagine they scandalize the family with a risque Sunday tipple or two -- pick up a '98 Steuben made by the Tomasello Winery. Get one for yourself, too.

title: Montblanc's Clean, Well-Lighted Place
description: In an era of megabytes, a pen may not seem a very exciting personal acquisition. And why buy one that costs somewhere between $175 and $125,000? The answer, according to Montblanc, the German maker of luxury pens, is in a ''de-acceleration studio'' at its new Manhattan store at Madison Avenue and 69th Street.

title: A Heavenly Lake, 15,000 Feet Up
description: LIKE so many Tibetan journeys, our trek began with altitude sickness in a Volkswagen Santana. This is the car of choice for Lhasa cabbies, and often when they carry tourists it is difficult to tell who is suffering more, the passengers or the cars. Most of the city's battered Santanas wear a certain startled expression, as if to say: What am I doing in a place like this?

title: The Nation; Seeking Solace with Final Gestures
description: A SNUB-NOSED California child who loves to dance in glittery costumes is kidnapped from her bed during a sleep-over and murdered.
