An infant in day care, just turned a year old, is crushed to death when the Federal building in Oklahoma City explodes at the hand of terrorists. A Colorado teen-ager, proclaiming her faith in God, is shot at close range by a rampaging classmate.

title: Preparing for the Worst
description: GEORGE BRENNAN, the emergency management director of Stonington, admitted to feeling anxious at the appearance of Arlene, the first named Atlantic tropical storm of the year, in mid-June.

title: Deep in the Republic of Chevron
description: It struck me as surreal to read of an American oilman referring to a local as ''greedy,'' when Chevron is pumping 418,000 barrels a day in Nigeria. Chevron is the greedy one, doing billions of dollars in business, while those who have lived on the land for countless generations are tossed small change to keep them from rioting.

title: Counties Begin Maintaining Greens the Organic Way
description: FOR nearly a half-century, a steady diet of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, fungicides and herbicides have helped keep Long Island's golf courses looking lush. But pressure from environmental groups and suspicions that the chemicals may be a factor in the Island's high breast cancer rate has led to a restriction in the use of chemicals at some municipal golf courses. And now, both counties are building or planning organic public courses.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on June 27 about ferry service across the English Channel misstated the Web address for P & O Portsmouth Ferries. It is www.poportsmouth.com (not just www.portsmouth.com).

title: Excursions Growing as a Leisure Outlet
description: THIS year, the 165 guests at the Emelin Theater's annual fund-raising benefit were treated to a spectacular show, a brilliant sunset on Long Island Sound, produced by Mother Nature.

title: The Barber Concerto? Not This Time
description: Besides going his own artistic way, and taking his little dog everywhere, John Browning is known for performing one particular piece: the Piano Concerto that his friend Samuel Barber composed for him. No one plays this difficult, fairly uninviting work better than Mr. Browning; in fact, no one else plays it at all.

title: She's Ur-Mother, Warrior, Lover: Isn't She Divine?
description: MAJOR exhibitions of the art of India are rare in this part of the world. They always have been. Why? Nobody knows. This art has everything: epic drama and swoony sob stories, gods, gremlins and glamour queens, the human at its most human, the spiritual at its most ineffable.

title: Family Day Care: A Cottage Industry Thrives
description: AS a former broadcast journalist turned stay-at-home mom, Ulrika Citron approached the search for a preschool as she might have an investigative article. It was a painstaking project that led from her Upper East Side neighborhood to a half-dozen scattered institutions and the ritual mating dance of private school admissions. But in the end it was not a well-established nursery Ms. Citron chose for her daughter, Maya, but a homey, loosely organized program known simply as Mary's, where up to six children share toys and snacks on the ground floor of a brownstone apartment on West 75th Street.

title: Beyond Cliches
description: To the Editor:

title: Woodstock '99 Has Heat, Laconic Fans and One Death
description: A 44-year-old Massachusetts man suffered a heart attack at Woodstock '99 Friday night and died, New York State Police officials said today.

title: Debating Hepatitis B Vaccine; In Indiana, A Similar Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: In an Old Oyster Boat, No Pearls, Just Lessons
description: FRED SZTUL took out his pocketknife and jabbed it into a small gap in the hull of the Ethel Lewis, a 58-foot skipjack built in 1906. ''The rot has set in,'' he said, gently twisting the blade. ''The former owner was going to junk her, but we said, 'If she'll float, we'll take her.' ''

title: Con Ed's Outlook
description: Looking ahead into August, Consolidated Edison officials are confident -- but not certain -- they can keep the power going, even if another heat wave sets in.

title: After Power Failures, A Goodwill Campaign
description: Officials of the Connectiv Power Company said last week that it planned provide some towns with funds for advertising campaigns to lure back disgruntled vacationers who experienced power failures during the July 14th weekend.

title: On a Soapbox Wins on the Road By Upsetting Dreams Gallore
description: She has had three trainers but only five races in two years, and her third trainer wasn't sure which race he wanted her to run this weekend. But he decided at a late hour to scratch her from the $250,000 Delaware Oaks, and loaded her onto a horse van at 4:30 in the morning headed for Belmont Park, one more stop in the life of a traveling race horse.

title: SUMMER PLACES: The Beach Club; Sea, Sand and Seven-Card Stud
description: Under a color caricature of 10 fat old men playing cards, 10 mostly fat, fairly old men sit playing cards, as another summer day dwindles at the Old Westbury Beach Club.

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: Mention is made of Kubrick's attachment to animals. Some years ago I arranged to take a young tax lawyer in my firm to meet Stanley in London. When we arrived, we learned that the meeting was off. He had been sitting up day and night with a dying cat and was in no shape to discuss tax-planning matters. His priorities were not open to discussion.

title: POSTINGS: On Former Site of Brighton Beach Baths; Up to 850 Units In 16 Buildings Over 15 Acres
description: For 90 years, Brighton Beach Baths was a maze of pools, miniature golf, lockers and lounges for its members. By the 60's it had 13,000 members..

title: 'Doctor Dolittle' on Stage
description: ON July 9 the Westchester Broadway Theater gave itself a gala 25th birthday party, treating guests to dinner, dancing and a lavish revival of ''42d Street'' -- the 116th production since the first curtain went up in 1974. For the rest of the run, the only available dancing will be on stage, as conceived by Randy Skinner, who assisted Gower Champion in the original Broadway production, performed by the large cast with high spunk and spirit. Performances of ''42d Street'' continue Wednesdays through Sundays until Oct. 3.

title: In the Region /Long Island; Scripting a Future for a Movie Mogul's Estate
description: PEMBROKE, the 53-room French Neo-Classical-style mansion completed here in 1918 on Red Spring Lane, was demolished 31 years ago. But until now, its 46 acres overlooking Hempstead Bay have remained intact.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION; Spice Island
description: The struggle of the spirit against oppression -- of class, gender and sexual orientation -- is at the heart of CINNAMON GARDENS (Hyperion, $23.95), Shyam Selvadurai's second novel, set in 1920's Ceylon. Two intertwined stories are told: a renewal of an affair after 20 years between Balendran, a married family man and Ceylonese aristocrat, and Richard, an Englishman now living with a much younger lover, and the travails of Balendran's niece Annalukshmi, a schoolteacher who rails against her family's attempts to marry her to a series of dull, intellectually inferior would-be suitors. Both stories play themselves out in the politically heady days before caste-conscious Ceylon became Sri Lanka, when the homosexuality of a man of polite society was considered a ''regrettably irreversible'' disposition, and a woman who showed a sensual spirit and even a hint of freewheelingness (particularly on a bicycle) was considered ''fast.'' Faultlessly elegant but familiar in its depiction of nostalgic regret and repressed desire, ''Cinnamon Gardens'' has a sepia-toned cover and an oddly sepia-toned style, yet it is also surprisingly light reading -- it's unfettered by any attempt at highbrow heaviness. Selvadurai, the author of ''Funny Boy,'' is expert in capturing the nuances of this particularly precious time and place; there is real texture to these upper-class lives, and you can't beat the atmosphere -- hushed conversations, heated debates and private ruminations are held in luscious gardens and in grand drawing rooms. As you read, you can almost see the Merchant-Ivory adaptation playing itself out in your head. Daniel Rietz

title: Playing the Feel-Good Family Sentiment Card
description: LAST January, when ''Providence,'' NBC's new family drama, had its premiere, it was greeted with the kind of critical tongue-lashing that can drive a series from the air within weeks. The premise: A burnt-out plastic surgeon abandons her high-powered Los Angeles life style to return home to Rhode Island, where Dad is a puppy-cuddling veterinarian; Mom, who dropped dead during the premiere, remains a reassuring know-it-all in dream sequences; the kid sis, Joannie, is a pigtail-wearing single mom, and the baby brother, Robbie, is a motorcycle-riding bad boy with the proverbial heart of gold.

title: July 18-24; Landing on the Wrong List
description: Conservative critics have long complained that public broadcasting has a liberal bias, and now they believe they have the evidence needed to phase out the industry's $250-million taxpayer-funded subsidy. The president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting said at least 28 of the nation's 353 public television stations had given the names of their donors to various political organizations. It turns out that those organizations were affiliated not only with Democrats but also with Republicans, including Bob Dole's 1996 Presidential campaign.

title: Glass Ceiling Isn't Shattered Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on July 11 about the current dominance of the pre-teen-age market in pop music referred incorrectly to the group LFO. It is a trio, not a quartet.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a new, less optimistic view of peace around the world referred incorrectly to the political outlook of John Hume, the Catholic leader of Northern Ireland's Social Democratic and Labor Party. He is a nationalist who favors closer ties with Ireland, not a republican willing to countenance bloodshed to reach that goal.

title: Global Food Fights: The Worst Are Yet to Come
description: FARMERS in Vermont know what they don't like: mud season, summer tourists who hang around the town green too long after buying their maple syrup, and agricultural imports from Canada. Now add one more to the list: the World Trade Organization.

title: More Than Just A Place To Stay: Illinois; A Wright-designed B & B: the architect might have approved.
description: If you've ever wanted to live in a Frank Lloyd Wright house but have never had the opportunity, you can get a taste of what it would be like at the Cheney House in Oak Park, Ill., which has been restored by Dale Smirl, a lawyer, and opened as a bed and breakfast.

title: Anchoring a Cruise Ship Pier for Earthly Pleasures
description: In 1961, Pier 40 opened as a cruise ship terminal on the Hudson River at Houston Street, but the hulking metal structure on 15 acres has since become a 2,000-car private parking lot. With its views of downtown Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty, community leaders have long considered the pier an ideal place for recreational waterfront.

title: July 18-24; Pentagon Misspending Spree
description: The Pentagon defied the law and the Constitution by spending hundreds of millions of dollars on programs Congress never approved, the House Appropriations Committee charged. The Defense Department acknowledged failing to notify Congress about how it was spending taxpayers' funds, and admitted that the Air Force had started a super-secret ''black program'' without telling anyone, an act the House panel said broke the law.

title: 'In Shock' Over 5 Slayings
description: Minnie Graham, the executive director of the African-American Parent Council, was working in her ground floor office at the Park Hill Apartments, a housing project in Fox Hills, on the afternoon of June 19, and expecting her 19-year-old daughter to arrive any minute. Then she heard automatic gunfire outside.

title: More Umpires May Decide To Rescind and Keep Jobs
description: With the jobs of 26 of the 68 umpires already safe, a baseball official held out the possibility yesterday that more umpires could salvage their jobs in coming days if they rescind their resignations.

title: STUDY HIGHLIGHTS DISPARITIES IN AID TO TRAIN DOCTORS
description: New Government data show huge disparities in what Medicare pays to train doctors in different parts of the country, with some teaching hospitals in New York getting three or four times as much for each trainee as those in Los Angeles or Cleveland, and seven times as much as those in Houston.

title: Eyewitness Blues
description: Randy Cohen (The Ethicist, July 4) is on target about our reluctance to blow the whistle on shoplifters because of the harsh consequences they will receive. I struggled with this dilemma when I saw a woman wearing a very large coat cut a chain securing a rack of leather jackets in a department store. Wanting neither to turn her in nor let her walk away, I walked past her and said: ''I saw what you did. I hope you will leave the store right now so I don't have to turn you in.'' She hesitated for a moment before walking out.

title: A Pond by Any Other Name? Pea Soup
description: With its thick carpet of algae and aquatic grass, Goose Pond, the centerpiece of Captain Tilly Park, looks like a two-acre bowl of pea soup. ''When you sit up on the hill, you don't see a lake,'' said Bill Signorile, a retired firefighter and a member of the Jamaica Hill Community Association. ''You see a lawn.''

title: To Pick a Private Pilot, Check Hours Logged in Plane, Recent Flying and Personality
description: Each year, about 1 in 100 of the nation's private planes has an accident, and 1 in 300 has an accident that kills somebody. How can a traveler considering using something other than a commercial airline spot the risky flights in advance?

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: UNTIL THE REAL THING

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: As one who has been profoundly affected by Kubrick's films, I was glad to read Bogdanovich's excellent oral history. I was also sadly struck by the article's ending, where two of Kubrick's dear friends, Matthew Modine and James B. Harris, felt eclipsed by the supernova heat of the Cruise, Kidman, Spielberg triumvirate at the funeral. The man the trio described wasn't the same guy they knew. I wondered what Kubrick would have said about this. I imagine it might have been something like: ''Hey, Jim, Matthew, you did know me. The new kids knew me, too.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRMAN, DOROTHY
description: BEHRMAN-Dorothy. On July 17, suddenly but peacefully at age 100. Widow of Herman. Loving mother of Dr. Stanley and Dr. Lawrence. Mother-in-law of Nancy & Carole. Adored grandmother of Dr. David (Allison), Susan (Joseph) Pasciolla and Peter (Josephine) Grayson. Great-grandmother of Sara, Alex, Michelle and Bradley. Memorial gifts to The Herman and Dorothy Behrman Scholarship Fund at the School of Dental Medicine, University of Pittsburgh.

title: Kasparov and Karpov Meet, Both Still Claiming the Title
description: After a three-year hiatus, the over-the-board enmity between Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov was resumed, in the Siemens-Giants Quickplay Tournament in Frankfurt early this month. But it must not be assumed that they were making any kind of commitment to challenge each other on a regular basis. Each still insists he is the authentic world champion and the other an impostor.

title: A Year 2000 Peace Corps
description: Howard A. Rubin knew that developing countries were lagging in Year 2000 computer preparations well before the United Nations convened the first international gathering on the challenge last December. But Mr. Rubin, chairman of the Department of Computer Science at Hunter College in New York, was surprised to learn that many nations had done virtually nothing. Mr. Rubin also has a Pound Ridge, N.Y., consulting firm that bears his name and has clients including I.B.M. and Merrill Lynch.

title: Q and A
description: Ticks on Nantucket

title: Time for a Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Debating Hepatitis B Vaccine; . . . and a Friend Lost to Hepatitis
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mole In the Machine
description: Several years ago I visited Scott D. Yelich, the administrator of a computer network, at his Santa Fe, N.M., apartment. For a computer-systems manager, he had an apartment that was, perhaps, nothing out of the ordinary. A pool table covered with Asian fighting sticks dominated the living room. One bathroom featured a six-foot python, alive, breathing and wrapped around the shower rod. Much of a spare bedroom was filled by the administrator's personal computer system, with two 21-inch monitors crowding a desk and several big beige boxes wheezing in the closet. Yelich was trying to help me understand that people can easily break into computers. He explained how he'd discovered that someone who called himself Info was breaking into the network he ran at the Santa Fe Institute, a highfalutin physics think tank. Annoyed, Yelich had monitored the intrusions, discovering that they seemed to have originated at a small software firm in town.

title: What Business Was That You Said You Were In?
description: Sticking to one's knitting is the theme of the moment in the executive suites of many a large corporation, though it's usually dressed up with the fancier name of ''core competencies.''

title: Putting the Sensual Above the Didactic
description: THE title ''Peacocks and Pleasure Domes'' is an immediate alert that the small but exquisite show of paintings and drawings at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y., places the sensual above the didactic. Plenty of lore and scholarship lie under the surface of the works from India, but the wall text is kept to a minimum. Another clue that there is a premium on pleasure is the admission by the museum's director, Abigail Free, that the color of the lettering stenciled on the wall is a tribute to Diana Vreeland's observation, ''Shocking pink is the navy blue of India.''

title: California Democrats Duel With Democrats
description: California Democrats came out of last fall's elections in the best political shape in decades, capturing the Governor's office for the first time in 16 years and winning the race for Lieutenant Governor, as well as winning solid control of both houses of the State Legislature.

title: In America
description: The anger in the neighborhoods is not being heard. There was a flurry of well-publicized protests after the Diallo shooting but that's over. The cops continue to do what they want, much of it lousy. The Mayor says we're not as bad as some places, which is a comfort, I guess. A man who beats his wife is not as bad as one who kills her.

title: Courtney Hall, William Murphy
description: Courtney Brooke Hall and William Spencer Murphy, lawyers in New Orleans, were married there last evening by the Rev. Michael Kuhn at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ROY DOUGLAS
description: JOHNSON-Roy Douglas. Age 41, suddenly at his home in Richmond, Virginia (formerly of Easton, Connecticut). Beloved son of Roy A. Johnson of Vero Beach, Florida and Eleonora Wahlstrom McCabe of Vero Beach, Florida and Saratoga Springs, New York. Beloved brother of Lois Johnson Hughes and Bruce R. Johnson of Westport, Connecticut; beloved uncle of Justin and Rebecca Hughes and Caitlin and Victoria Johnson; beloved grandson of Agnes Wahlstrom and the late Magnus Wahlstrom and Florence Johnson and the late Arvid Johnson; beloved nephew of Robert A. Johnson. Graduate of ChoateRosemary Hall School, Wallingford, Connecticut (class of 1976) and the University of Richmond, Virginia (class of 1981). Private memorial services were held on Sunday, July 18 at Salem Lutheran Church, the Rev. E. Earl Okerlund officiating with interment at Mountain Grove Cemetery, Bridgeport, Connecticut. For more information contact the Larson Funeral Home, Bridgeport, Connecticut. Memorial gifts may be given in his name to the Magnus Wahlstrom Leadership Award Fund, C/O The Greater Bridgeport Area Foundation, 280 State Street, Bridgeport, CT. 06604.

title: Saltwater Fly-Fishing Brings Out Anglers
description: THE prospects seemed favorable for Kevin Callahan and Jim Simsbach one recent Saturday morning as they fished with their fly-casting rods from a small motorboat near Milton Point in Milton Harbor here. Anchored about 20 feet from shore, the two sportsmen, gauging the tide perfectly, had found striped bass feeding near a spillway dam just after sunrise.

title: Perot Tells Delegates He Will Stay Active in Reform Party
description: Rejecting calls that he step aside for fresh faces, Ross Perot vowed tonight to remain active in the Reform Party that he founded, but gave no hint whether he would seek its Presidential nomination next year.

title: Getting The Girl
description: There is nothing sleek or high-tech about this third-floor conference room in Fairfax, Va., except, perhaps, the bright red laser pointer that skitters across the eerie greenish slide of phosphorescent sperm. The projector jams periodically during the hourlong presentation, and the central air-conditioning can't keep up with the late-spring heat, so some very low-tech fans are brought in to move the muggy air around in circles.

title: Jennifer Weiss, Scott Mager
description: Jennifer Cory Weiss, the daughter of Fern and Mitchell Weiss of Great Neck, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Scott Brian Mager, a son of Mary and Ray Mager of Berkeley Heights, N.J. Cantor Steven Weiss, the bride's brother, is to officiate at the Jericho (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: A Jazz Pianist With a Brahmsian Bent
description: JAZZ has an Oedipal problem, and critics are at least partly to blame. A good deal of jazz writing comes down to matching sons with their putative fathers, the men (for they are almost invariably men) who influenced young musicians and whom the young resemble with apparently biological precision. Tracing these lines of descent may be unavoidable, and even illuminating at times. But it proves a crude, not to mention patriarchal, way of listening. (Is it any wonder that young jazz musicians revolt against the traditions handed down to them?) Consider, for instance, the reception of Brad Mehldau, who, at 28, is among the most celebrated jazz pianists of his generation. If you've heard his name mentioned, you've probably heard that he's ''the next Bill Evans.'' High praise, to be sure. But like most such comparisons, this one is more than a little misleading, as unfair as it is flattering.

title: At Hagstrom, The Map Is His Territory
description: Maps have always fascinated Errol Richardson. As a youngster, he eagerly pored over atlases of the world and his native Trinidad. As a student at the University of the West Indies, he studied cartography.

title: The Home Team
description: Stephen Engelberg's Lives essay (July 4), on the difficulty of a diehard Red Sox fan having a child who's a Yankees fan, reminded me of an exchange between my husband and my 14-year-old daughter, as she was leaving for school last October. She was upset with something one of us (or both, probably) had done and was in a foul mood, in spite of her team having just won the World Series. Her father got a smile from her as she went out the door, though. ''You should be grateful,'' he said, ''that we didn't raise you a Red Sox fan.''

title: If the Price Isn't Right
description: Congratulations! You've just been offered a terrific job with a company you've always admired. The problem is that the salary offer is very low -- not only when compared with industry averages, but also in relation to other salaries at the same company. Sure, the offer is somewhat higher than your current pay, but relocation expenses and higher living costs in the new city will eat up the difference. Should you push for more money, or would that hurt your chances of getting that dream job?

title: Anna Manzo, Scott Harris
description: Anna Marie Rosales Manzo and Scott Jeffrey Harris were married last evening at the Silvermine Guild of the Arts in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Ed Thompson, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Serb Opposition Leader Criticizes NATO Forces in Kosovo
description: A leading Serbian opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, today made an emotional attack on NATO forces, saying they had allowed the ethnic purging of Serbs from Kosovo and the creation of an Albanian state in the province.

title: Score One for Prints
description: This summer, a single exotic flower print has blossomed on the streets of Manhattan and launched a serious attack on the decade-old black minimalist look. This six-screen Gucci print is unusual for ready-to-wear. Eight screens is now considered the top for couture. In the early 1950's, Balenciaga showed a rare print of 16 screens. Other decades can be identified by their own signature print colors. The 30's were pastel; the 40's, dusty; the 50's, bold and clear; the 60's, splashy, and the 70's, psychedelic tie-dye. Recalling a fight over the sold-out Gucci design, one wearer said, ''I got the skirt and Julia Roberts got the top.''

title: Road Signs Figure In L'Affaire Fordice
description: In our last installment of the Fordice Saga, Kirk, the Governor of Mississippi, and Pat, his wife of 44 years, were at a marital impasse.

title: Up, But Not Running, on the West Side
description: Covered with rust and weeds, it stands as a grim memorial to New York City's faded industrial might, an elevated freight train platform running 1.6 miles down Manhattan's West Side, from 34th Street to Greenwich Village.

title: Oh, the Things You'll See on L.I.
description: MILLIONS of tourists from all over the world come pouring through Kennedy International Airport during the summer. Most of them head straight for the Big Apple. But some, perhaps due to poor map reading, miss the turn onto the Van Wyck Expressway and find themselves heading out to Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, DORA
description: EINHORN-Dora. Of Stamford, CT. On July 24, 1999, age 95 years. Predeceased by her husband Dr. Walter Einhorn. Survived by her loving family, nieces Diane Feldman and Judy Waldman, her nephews Gilbert Waldman and Michael Goldhamer, six grandnieces and nephews, one great-grandnephew. Retired NYC schoolteacher. Funeral service Sunday, 10 AM, at the Ballard - Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: The Behind the Wheel column of the Automobiles section on June 27 referred incorrectly to the warning to other drivers provided by new brake lights on Mercedes-Benz S-Class sedans. At 62 miles an hour, the lights' faster illumination is equivalent to about one and a half feet of extra stopping distance, not 16 feet.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: The Body/Body Problem

title: Democrats Aim for Record In Unregulated Donations
description: With George W. Bush sitting atop a $37 million political war chest, the Democratic Party is seeking to raise an unprecedented amount of the unregulated party donations known as soft money, perhaps as much as $200 million by November 2000.

title: Amy Parker, Steven Belkin
description: Amy Melissa Parker, the daughter of Carol B. Parker of Hamden, Conn., and the late Peter B. Parker, was married yesterday to Steven Charles Belkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Belkin of New Britain, Conn. Katherine Pope, a town justice in Shelter Island, N.Y., officiated at the Union Chapel in the Grove in Shelter Island Heights, N.Y., with the Rev. Louis Pressman, an Episcopal priest, taking part in the ceremony.

description: If it takes a village to raise a child, it's taking almost as many people to get the dinghy racer Meg Gaillard to the Olympic trials next April. She is sponsored by three people, coached by two, and has a friend regularly updating her Web site.

title: Jennifer Hecker, John Geekie
description: Jennifer Lynn Hecker, a daughter of Judith and Thomas Hecker of Centerport, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Thomas Geekie, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Geekie of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. J. Jeffrey Zetto, a minister of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Mount Horeb (N.J.) United Methodist Church.

title: Training Pilots to Survive in the Water
description: SINCE 1983, the National Transportation Safety Board says that more than 400 aircraft have had controlled crashes, or have ditched, in water, killing about 100 people. Such accidents, which now include the deaths of John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and sister-in-law, Lauren G. Bessette, after his plane crashed in the Atlantic, have added an urgency to efforts to train pilots in how to respond in accidents that aviation experts say are often survivable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 11 about a dispute between winemakers and environmentalists over development of hillside vineyards in Napa County, Calif., misstated the degree equivalent of a slope of 50 percent, the steepest on which farming is permitted by a county land use ordinance. It is 26.6 degrees, not 22.5.

description: NESSEN-Ward H. On Thursday, July 22nd, 1999 of Summit, New Jersey. Memorial service on July 31 at 11 AM at Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUHL, RUDOLPH
description: JUHL-Rudolph, died peacefully at home on July 21, 1999 in New York City at the age of 88. Brother of Marta Marx and brother-in-law of Walter Marx of Hollywood, FL, and cousin of Curt, Peter and John Rolland. In loving memory.

title: Claudio Rodriguez, 65, Writer Of Poems Filled With Symbolism
description: Claudio Rodriguez, whose five books of verse since the 1950's were enough to convince peers that he was among the best Spanish poets of the century, died on Thursday in a Madrid hospital. He was 65.

title: Cleanup After a Fire: Protective Suits and Fear of Hazards
description: A July 7 fire at a New York City Transit electrical substation on Essex Street took hours to extinguish, disrupted subway service, closed streets and disrupted power for days. But that was only the beginning of worries for residents, who have watched for two weeks as workers, some wearing protective suits, have carted debris out of the building.

title: THEATER; A Producer's Education: Why Broadway Slipped
description: THE forces suppressing quality musical theater today are the Broadway Establishment, which prefers to buy the future rather than undertake the labor of making it, and the conservative constituency in the National Endowment for the Arts, who insist that musical theater is not high culture and should be relegated to a lower level of Federal recognition and financial support. It is vital to do battle against both.

title: Debating Hepatitis B Vaccine; A Father Who Chose Not to Vaccinate
description: To the Editor:

title: Flood Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Skiers Can Stay At a Summer Behemoth
description: Any homeowner who has stayed at New Hampshire's Mount Washington Hotel and Resort -- one of the last of the behemoth, turn-of-the-century, seasonal grand hotels that used to dot the New England landscape -- probably paused a moment to wonder just what it would cost to heat the place. The resort's owners have decided to find out.

title: Umps: Let Them Go
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tax Cutters Aren't Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrested in Drug Case, Brooklyn Man Dies
description: A 32-year-old Brooklyn man died in the custody of narcotics officers yesterday shortly after having been arrested during a buy-and-bust operation near Prospect Park, police officials said.

title: Pride in Service At Kennedy Airport
description: David Bouchier [''Getting Service, but Without Any Smiles,'' Out of Order, July 4] has reduced some grown men to tears -- our managers at Kennedy International Airport, who have been working very assiduously to make the airport experience a pleasant one for our customers.

title: Let's Make a Deal
description: Opportunity knows no boundaries of place or time. The enterprising have found clients, investors, employees and employers in the oddest of settings - chance meetings on the subway, supermarket checkout lines or even after a fender-bending collision. What is the most unusual place where you managed - or at least tried - to further your fortunes? Or where someone else tried to pursue business with you? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be published in any medium.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: Test Run - On-Line Groceries; A Byte to Eat
description: Sometimes your refrigerator is packed with wholesome, delicious offerings; other times, it offers only 47 bottles of condiments. On a recent day I found my fridge in the condiments-only mode. And I was hungry.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
More Than Just A Place To Stay: Louisiana; Ghosts and atmosphere galore in a restored plantation house
description: At the Myrtles Plantation just outside the historic town of St. Francisville, La., the rocking chairs on the wide back veranda are empty, the broad foyer hushed, and the opulent public rooms bathed in liquid light. It's too still: the floorboards creak as you wend your way back to your room, the Judge Woodruff Suite at the top of the stairs. There are ghosts here, or at least, there are supposed to be. You jump, just slightly, at the sound of something swishing past, but it's only a cat.

title: Atlantic Beach Bridge: Tolls, Jobs and Politics
description: AS he approached the Atlantic Beach Bridge on a weekday evening earlier this month, Barry Ringelheim was shocked by what he saw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSHIRE, ROBERT VIDAL
description: WILSHIRE-Robert Vidal (The Very Reverend). Retired Dean of The Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, NY. Born 1937 in New Castle, N.S.W., Australia the son of Alan Gilbert Wilshire and Hilary Mary Havelock, Dean Wilshire died peacefully July 22nd at his home in Wilmington, NC after a brief battle with cancer. Priest, pastor, preacher and teacher, Dean Wilshire served as Dean of the Cathedral for twenty years until his retirement in 1999. He previously had served nine years as Rector of St. Ann's, Sayville, NY. Before emigrating to the United States for graduate studies in 1967, he served in Australia at several parishes and at The Southport School as its Chaplain. An honors graduate of St. Francis Theological College, Brisbane, he received a Master of Divinity in 1967 and a Master of Sacred Theology in 1968 from The General Theological Seminary, NY, NY. In addition to his pastoral duties as the Cathedral's Dean, he served for over twenty years as Registrar and Professor of Theology of George Mercer Jr. Memorial School of Theology in Garden City. The Dean was a member of the Board of Directors of Episcopal Health Services, Inc., the health care arm of the Diocese of Long Island, from 1979 to 1999. He also served the Episcopal Church as a Deputy to three General Conventions and the Diocese of Long Island on numerous commissions and committees. He is survived by his brother, Frederick Wilshire, and sisters, Jane Rowell and Alison Hurditch, a nephew and three nieces, all in Australia, by a nephew, Andrew F. Wilshire of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, NY, and by all the countless parishioners, friends and colleagues who have been nourished and enriched by him. A Eucharist and Burial Office celebrating his devoted and caring ministry will be held at The Cathedral of the Incarnation on Wednesday, July 28th, at 11 A.M., with interment to follow at St. Ann's Cemetery, Sayville, NY. Dean Wilshire has requested that any remembrances be made to the Memorial and Endowment Fund of The Cathedral of the Incarnation.

title: Backtalk; The Self-Importance of Being a Big League Umpire
description: If you've ever spent any private time with major league umpires, at their homes or out with their families and friends (they have groupies, too), you might mistakenly think that their egos are even bigger than their bellies. The self-importance of umpires is astonishing; they pretend to see themselves as somewhere between the thin red line that protected the British Empire from its own barbarism and the United States Supreme Court. When more than five umpires appear together, you expect them to start singing, ''We Are the Game.''

title: Contains Graphic Material
description: PAUL RAND

title: Swiss Reveal Secret World: Their Defense From Nazis
description: A few hundred yards away from the cable car that brings tourists to the top of scenic Mount Rigi overlooking Lake Lucerne, a large camouflage-green door carved into the mountainside opens onto a world that has been secret for 50 years.

title: Qwest's Game Of Aggressive Phone Tag
description: ON a balmy Saturday in mid-June, 70 of Joseph P. Nacchio's closest friends and family members gathered at his northern New Jersey home for boccie ball and a late supper to celebrate his son's high school graduation. Also attending were a few colleagues, including Jack Grubman, who had worked with Mr. Nacchio at AT&T years before.

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: It was to be expected that the contributors to Bogdanovich's oral history of Stanley Kubrick would consist primarily of family and those in the film industry, but this focus missed the breadth of Kubrick's genius. In doing background research on space travel and computer science for ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' Kubrick worked with Freeman Dyson of the Princeton Institute for Advanced Studies and Marvin Minsky of the M.I.T. Artificial Intelligence Lab, among others.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'Moby-Dick,' Hour by Hour

title: Pay Gaps in Money Management
description: If you want to manage assets for a living and make the most money doing it, you should work for a mutual fund company in New York or Boston, concentrate on global investing -- and be male.

title: IN MY... TRAVEL BAG -- JOHN KILCULLEN
description: As chief executive of IDG Books Worldwide, the Foster City, Calif.-based publisher of the ''For Dummies'' self-help books, John Kilcullen, 40, travels so much that he occasionally forgets his bank-card password or the location of his rental car. But he doesn't forget his strategy for airplane comfort, developed with help from other travelers and his homeopathic adviser.

title: Anna Saalfield and Michael Traggio
description: AFTER Anna Laidlaw Saalfield and Michael Paul Traggio had dated for years, she began making it clear that she wanted to marry him. Her mother, Agnes Gund, made it even clearer. Mrs. Gund, the president of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, once sent Mr. Traggio a waffle iron. It arrived with a note that read: ''Stop the waffling!''

title: Now, Endless Words From Our Sponsor
description: ALONG with 10,000 other lucky souls, I recently received a brand-new personal computer for the low, low price of nothing. The only catch is, it is trying to wrest away control of my brain.

title: Sunny Skies and Rainless Days: No Vacation for the Fire Service
description: ONE of the driest years in decades has made for one of the busiest seasons in years for the Forest Fire Service, part of the parks and forestry division of the Deptartment of Environmental Protection.

title: More Than Just A Place To Stay: New Mexico; An adobe hacienda run by the family that built it in the 1800's
description: The village of Chimayo, 30 miles north of Santa Fe, N.M., is about mud. Its very name comes from the Tewa Indian word referring to the frangible reddish stone (little more than hardened clay) that makes up the low escarpments on three sides of the upper end of the historic valley in which it is set. In the village is the renowned Santuario de Chimayo, built in the 1800's; for generations pilgrims have scooped up handfuls of ''holy dirt'' from a small hole in the floor of an antechamber. Even though it has been covered by a layer of hard stucco, the Santuario's lumpish, uneven form and massively thick walls of heavy sun-dried mud bricks reveal its adobe soul.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: The Ethicist; I'm Not a Prude, but . . .
description: I am the father of two early-adolescent boys, who are both active Web surfers. I'm not a prude, but I think exposure to the more extreme sexual images available on line is not a good thing at their ages. I could retain a secret list of the Web sites they visit. But is that ethical? Is it equivalent to putting a hidden TV camera in their room (which I would consider a violation of their privacy), or is it an acceptable way for a parent to keep informed and be able to initiate discussion of this tricky topic?- William S. Kessler, Seattle.

title: A Typical Shore Vacation (but the Seeing Eye Dogs Stay Home)
description: For 29 years, the Helen L. Diller Vacation Home for Blind Children, two blocks west of the beach in Avalon, has given visually impaired youngsters a weeklong, all-expenses-paid summer sojourn at the Jersey Shore. Founded by Mrs. Diller and her husband, William, a realtor, and members of the Stone Harbor Lions Club, the home welcomes as many as 20 vacationers, ages 7 to 15, each week from mid-June to mid-August. They are assisted by 12 counselors.

title: Mad About Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF; Prudential Selling Stake In Office Complex
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America is selling its stake in the Gateway office complex in Newark, the company announced last week.

title: Cashing In on Geography
description: When China.com, the Hong Kong-based Internet company, went public two weeks ago and saw its market capitalization zoom to nearly $1 billion, eyes lit up at Mail.com in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, RAE C.
description: ROTH-Rae C. July 22, 1999. Wife of the late Jacob L. Roth. Mother of Bernice (Seymour) Gendelman of Englewood Cliffs, NJ and Henry (Lisa) Roth. Grandmother of Jacob & Melissa, Norman, and David Gendelman. Great-grandmother of Nyssa and Asher. Funeral services will be held Sunday 11:30AM at Goldstein's Rosenberg's RaphaelSacks, 6410 North Broad Street, Phila. Family will be at her late residence Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. Commencing Wednesday the family will be at the residence of Bernice and Seymour Gendelman. Contributions may be made to the Ronald Bruce Nipon Association, 6445 Castor Avenue, Philadelphia, PA. 19149.

title: Merle Levin And Max Raab
description: Merle Kass Levin and Max Louis Raab were married on Tuesday by Rabbi William I. Kuhn at Temple Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: Fear Was His Beat
description: Every artist has the right to expect to be judged by his finest work. In this cruel season, Ernest Hemingway has been transformed by some into a commodity, and literary scruples have never been a strong point of commercial travelers. A century after his birth, he has an enduring legacy: ''The Sun Also Rises,'' ''A Farewell to Arms,'' ''A Moveable Feast,'' two dozen stories and great sentences and paragraphs and scenes in lesser books. He is our poet, in prose, about fear and the imagined encounter -- before we die -- with death. Fear was his subject matter, fear was his stock in trade. Hemingway, a brave man, was stalked by fear from the start.

title: Restoring a Century-Old Glass Tower in Chicago
description: SIX decades ahead of its time, the crystalline Reliance Building soared skyward in 1895 as a scintillating rebuke to its somber masonry surroundings, like a diamond in the rough-hewn Loop.

title: U.S. to Seek To Alter Plan For Pursuing War Crimes
description: The United States is expected to continue its campaign against politically inspired war-crimes prosecutions at a conference about the proposed International Criminal Court that begins here Monday.

title: Body Found at Kennedy Airport
description: The body of a man believed to be a missing 79-year-old New Jersey resident was found in a burning automobile at Kennedy International Airport early yesterday morning, Port Authority officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on May 30 with an article about McDonald's misidentified the chain's first franchise. The first McDonald's opened in San Bernadino, Calif., in 1948, not in Des Plaines, Ill., in 1955. It was owned by Richard and Maurice McDonald, who were brothers. The Des Plaines McDonald's, the first owned by Ray Kroc, did offer the menu and prices shown. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

description: Congressional opponents of the estate tax say it discourages savings, costs the economy more than it raises for the Government and makes it very difficult for a family-owned farm or business to be passed to the next generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, BENEDICT
description: WOLF-Benedict. We were so fortunate to know Dick and his beloved Miriam for over 25 years. Dick has now joined her, and if there is a Heaven, surely both of them are there together. While Dick added years, his mind and spirit remained forever young. He was insightful and fun to be with, and we will forever miss him. Diane and Arthur

By the time I was a freshman in college, I had had five parents and step-parents, had attended nine schools, and had nine siblings with five different combinations of parents.

description: MISHKIN-Arline Hollander. A lady. Beloved wife of the late Carl Mishkin, loving mother of Marion S. Mishkin and Susan P. Reiter, mother-in-law of Robert Reiter, dearest grandmother of Andrew Reiter. Service July 25, noon, Menorah Gardens, Deerfield Beach, FL. Interment July 26, 11 AM, Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. Donations to Chabad Lubavitch, West Boca Raton. With profound sadness. And eternal love.

O'Brien of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Jason Richard Trennert, the son of Phyllis DeSena Trennert and Richard Trennert of Smithtown, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Keenan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Live on the Web, Glimpses of East Hampton
description: THIS is the summer of iHamptons.com,'' declared Steven Gaines. Mr. Gaines, the best-selling author of ''Philistines at the Hedgerow: Passion and Property in the Hamptons,'' is the Hamptons insider of the moment, and although the comparison makes him cringe, the Liz Smith of the rolling dunes. His social chronicle, which came out last summer and was just released in paperback, boils down to, he said, ''rich people behaving badly.''

description: It was a pitch the rookie was not supposed to throw: a slider to the redoubtable Sammy Sosa. Instead, Octavio Dotel dared the major leagues' leading home run hitter, and Sosa responded by clubbing it out of the park in the third inning.

description: Rachel Elizabeth Levine, the daughter of Dr. Shirley P. Levine and Dr. Barry A. Levine of Manhattan, was married last evening to John David Rodin, a son of Ellen Rodin and Richard S. Rodin of Chevy Chase, Md. Cantor Bruce Halev officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was charged on Friday in the shooting deaths of two men on the Fourth of July, the police said yesterday.

title: Habitats /34-51 86th Street; A Garden of Delights In Jackson Heights
description: THE other night, when there was a slight breeze and an after-dinner walk seemed appealing, one neighbor after another stopped and admired the flowers in front of Frank LoRusso's and Richard Galcik's house.

title: 'Time Out of Mind'
description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuelan Leader Pushes for New Charter, but Is It Reformist Tool or a Power Grab?
description: The fate of South America's longest-running, if turbulent, democracy hangs in the balance in the vote on Sunday to select delegates to write a new constitution -- the 27th in Venezuela's history, although the first since 1961.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, CATHERINE C.
description: CLARKE-Catherine C., 95, on July 22, 1999, of Katonah, NY. Wife of the late Richard W. Clarke. Mother of H. Cartan Clarke and Richard W. Clarke Jr. and the late Michael deS. Clarke. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and nineteen great-grandchildren. Visiting hours Sunday, from 6-7 PM, with a rosary at 7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Katonah, NY, Monday, 11 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Michael deS. Clarke Memorial Fund, c/o Amherst College, 100 Boltwood Ave., Amherst, MA 01002-5000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F. JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F. Jr. The Board of Directors, Staff and Consumers of F.E.G.S. extend their deepest sympathies to the families of John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren G. Bessette. John Kennedy Jr.'s deep commitment to persons with developmental disabilities particularly his work as founder of Reaching Up Incorporated and its Kennedy Fellowship Program, has made it possible for many, including F.E.G.S. staff, to receive training, mentorship opportunities, and Bachelor's Degrees. His unique contributions to the human services workforce and his quiet, effective leadership have benefited many. F.E.G.S. will strive to continue his efforts to improve the lives of people with disabilities and others in need. Joseph Stein, Jr. President and Chair Alfred P. Miller, Executive V.P./C.E.O Lee Rambeau V.P., Developmental Disabilities

title: Appraisers: Getting to the Bottom Line
description: IT is an innocuous-looking packet of papers, or, these days, an E-mail -- several pages evaluating the ''subject residence,'' floor plans, photos of ''comparables'' and a dollar figure -- that can make or break a deal: the appraisal.

title: July 18-24; Creative Banking
description: Three former executives of the Bankers Trust Corporation were indicted on Federal charges that they diverted $15.1 million of unclaimed customer funds into the bank's own accounts from 1993 to 1996 in order to boost their department's financial results, cover budget shortfalls and even pay for the office Christmas party. Four months ago, Bankers Trust itself pleaded guilty to similar charges, agreeing to pay fines totaling $63.5 million. But the three executives, including a member of the bank's 12-man operating committee, plan to contest the charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, ANNETTE (NEE HALPERN)
description: BIRNBAUM-Annette (nee Halpern). On July 24,99, beloved mother of Barbara and Robert Lidz, Donald and Judy Birnbaum; sister of Kay Kirchheimer; grandmother of Jonathan and Bonnie Lidz, Jeffrey Lidz and Tonia Bleam, Jana Lidz, Jamie, Jennifer and Daniel Birnbaum; greatgrandmother of Matthew Lidz. We celebrate a life well-lived and cherish her 85 years of love. Funeral services Monday 10 AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Eun-Shil Ahn, Robert Steelman
description: Eun-Shil Selene Ahn, the daughter of You-Soon Ahn of Abington, Pa., and the late Sung-Keun Ahn, was married yesterday to Robert Hindle Steelman, a son of Linda and C. William Steelman of Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth Kovacs performed the ceremony at the Abington Presbyterian Church.

title: Deep in the Republic of Chevron
description: Norimitsu Onishi's article (July 4) represents Chevron's point of view in rich detail but reduces that of the locals to caricature. The Nigerian natives come across as caring only for profit. Meanwhile, Chevron is the accidental diplomat, a benign and somewhat bewildered presence. That the greed and corruption might be symptomatic of a deeply and perhaps inevitably pathological relationship between a rich corporation and poor nation, that Nigeria might be better off if Chevron just left -- these possibilities are not contemplated.

title: Man Pleads Not Guilty To Disrobing at Higbee Beach
description: A Cape May Court House man has pleaded not guilty to a charge of sunbathing nude at Higbee Beach last weekend.

title: Lives; 'I'm Too Old to Do This Again'
description: Becky, a 39-year-old former diet-center employee, who asked that her last name not be used, has had multiple drug addictions for most of her life. Following a relative's advice, she signed up for ''rapid detox,'' a controversial program designed to break opiate addictions in a single day. Advocates claim this new treatment eases the horrors of withdrawal, but many within the medical establishment have questioned its effect on brain chemistry and vascular pressure, and criticized its lack of emphasis on behavior modification. ''It's becoming a very fashionable thing to do,'' says Robert Matano, a substance-abuse specialist at the Stanford University School of Medicine. ''There's this idea that people are going in on Friday and going back to work on Monday. But there's no evidence that that happens. Becky, who has been through one detox program or another 33 times before, feels she has no choice but to take the risk.

title: David Hildebrand, 59, Statistics Authority
description: David Kent Hildebrand, a professor of statistics who often wrote about the subject, died on July 13 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was 59 and lived in Wynnewood, Pa.

title: Not the Only Ones
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM; Big Dreams, Big Hair and Other Scenes From Jersey Life
description: ERIC BROSS concentrates, his eyes narrowing, as he tries to trace the origins of his ambitions as a filmmaker, homing in, finally, on 1977.

title: Amid Unrest, Chinese Face Ugly Reality: Deflation
description: China's top leaders fled the stifling heat of Beijing this week for their annual retreat at a seaside resort, leaving behind a city swirling with propaganda about the crackdown on a spiritual movement known as Falun Gong.

title: Reconstructing Khmer Classics From Zero
description: ONE gray December afternoon in 1996, Fred Frumberg decided to quit. His secure and salaried post in charge of staff directors at the Paris Opera had lost its charm.

title: An Abstract Visionary, and a Winner
description: New Jersey was once populated by the Delaware Indians, but it's never been Navajo territory. So it may come as a surprise that Lorenzo R. Clayton, a half-Navajo artist who is one of the first five winners of the Eiteljorg Fellowships for Native American Arts, hails from Edgewater.

title: Intoxicated by God
description: Saint Augustine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, HAROLD R., M.D.
description: COOK-Harold R., M.D. July 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Honey. Devoted father of Ann, Dana and Andy. Loving brother of Blossom. Cherished grandfather of Zachary and Jessica. Service Monday, July 26, 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the City of Hope, 30 W. 26th St, NYC 10010.

title: Lazio Pursues Senate Race, Despite Republican Pressure
description: Showing no signs of backing off in his maverick bid for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island has sent a letter to Republican and Conservative Party leaders across New York, confirming that he will officially declare his candidacy with a statewide tour in mid-August.

title: Finding Courage to Speak of Son's Death
description: I AM here to tell you about my son Ian who died at age 20 of a heroin overdose,'' said Ginger Katz to the 11th graders in a Health Education class at Staples High School in Westport.

title: Strategies for Water-Metering
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Marriage, Monsters And Love
description: THEY call her the monster lady, not just because she is killing real estate values. To her daughter, Carolyn Nast, Margery Kendall is just a recluse, living year round in a summer house in the Adirondacks. But there's always Jack Carlson, ''a hop and a skip, not even a jump'' away. Indeed, Jack is always there. All Margery has to do is mention his name and Jack says, ''I'm right here.''

title: F.Y.I.
description: Halting the Heliport

title: Ever Pragmatic Singapore Is Making Art Its Business
description: IN less than five years the arts scene here has gone from invisible to explosive. With a combination of seduction and subsidies, the Singapore Government is aggressively wooing artists and arts organizations around the world to make their homes in this affluent city-state.

title: Till Death Do Us Part
description: The real-life weekday romance called ''A Wedding Story'' follows a formula as tried and true as the marriage rite itself: man and woman fall in love, put on fancy clothes and publicly declare their devotion. The only difference here is that the entire proceeding, from proposal to vow, is witnessed by more than a million viewers who have made the show one of the most popular in the eight-year history of the Learning Channel.

title: Which Way to the Egress? But Not So Fast
description: YOU can take the Barnum out of ''Barnum'' and still have a real good time. Better yet, take his wife, too -- please, as the old joke goes.

title: The Nation; No Business Like Gun Control
description: LIKE most California gun shop owners, Louis Baldridge complains about the law Gov. Gray Davis signed last Monday. ''People see that the state government has overstepped itself,'' he says of the restrictions on assault weapons, and he welcomes talk of a ballot initiative that might repeal them.

title: Debating Hepatitis B Vaccine; A Physician Makes A Case for Vaccines
description: To the Editor:

title: Victorian Inns, Baroque Breakfasts
description: THERE may have been a time when a plate of ordinary French toast was enough to dazzle a guest at the bed-and-breakfast table, but if so, that time is past.

title: Birds of a Feather And a Feather Wall In 'Flights of Fancy'
description: AS a painter and keeper of nearly 100 birds, the artist Hunt Slonem is surrounded by his subjects. The parrots, toucans and macaws that gaze out from his canvases also share his apartment in SoHo and his 10,000-foot studio in Chelsea.

description: A boardwalk scene has been set up in the parking lot of the Meadowlands Sports Complex, with carnival barkers enticing passersby to test their skills.
