description: IS golf becoming the sport that swallowed Long Island?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Jaguar S-Type; A More Compact Cat With a Classic Face
description: IF the least expensive car you offer costs $55,000 and you want to double your sales, what can you do? For Jaguar Cars Ltd., the answer seemed simple: Develop new, more affordable models to attract customers who might like a Jag but had never thought they could afford one.

title: Female Pioneers Were Also Black
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Moods of the Land and Its Other Inhabitants
description: Sally Gall

title: In the Region /Westchester; In Eastchester, Million-Dollar Homes on Small Lots
description: WITH land scarce in southern Westchester, developers are scrambling to find any available parcel they can and trying to squeeze as many houses as possible onto small plots. And since land prices are so steep, many of these builders are concentrating exclusively on luxury homes to make a profit.

title: In This Age Of Irony, New Jersey Is (Gasp) In
description: Afew weeks ago, my husband and I were invited into New York for an elegant dinner at the James Beard House. Just about everyone at our table was a Manhattanite and a food writer. I am used to fading into the background in such swell company, as nobody is much interested in a housewife and part-time writer living in New Jersey. But this time, when I mentioned my main credential -- writing this column -- I was treated like a visiting celebrity.

title: Gore Praises a Bronx Hospital As Bush Makes a Baseball Visit
description: The two frontrunning candidates for President were in New York State yesterday, one of them insisting that he was here to talk only about baseball, not politics.

title: Centerville Journal; Prized Ice Cream Jobs Create Extended Family
description: Cory Sinclair, 17, was scooping ice cream at the Four Seas as fast as he could and talking about the future.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Building a Better Camp, With a Tip of the Ball Cap to Hilfiger
description: A blimp circled overhead. Entertainers were booked. A chartered bus arrived from New York City. Benefactors were on hand.

title: Hungry Creature With a Beautiful Future
description: CATERPILLARS were once viewed with disdain. The immediate response when finding one in the garden was to get rid of them fast. The method of removal was often a swift pulling off the plant and stomp with the foot.

title: July 18-24; Crackdown on Chinese Sect
description: Its members are mostly female and middle-aged. Its practices consist of an amalgam of Buddhism, Taoism and deep breathing exercises. And its adherents say they seek only to improve their mental and physical health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MICHAEL C.
description: SMITH-Michael C. 45, an award winning creative advertising executive and photographer, died Wednesday, July 21, in Santa Fe, New Mexico, due to complications from AIDS. Smith had spent four years as a senior creative advertising executive at Warner Bros., where he supervised the ad campaigns for numerous motion pictures. Smith joined Warner Bros. in 1991 from Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York, where he had been Senior Vice President-Creative Director. From 1986 to 1989 he was Vice President-Associate Creative Director at the same agency (in 1988 and 1989 he was based in the Los Angeles office), and from 1984 to 1986 he was Vice President-Associate Creative Director at McCann Erickson Worldwide. From 1980 to 1984, Smith served as the Creative Director at Diane Von Furstenberg, Inc., and for the two years prior to that he was Art Director of Esquire Magazine. Between 1976 and 1978, Mr. Smith was Assistant Art Director of GQ Magazine. The winner of numerous awards for his work, Smith divided his time between Los Angeles and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Smith was born June 30, 1954 and raised in Helena, Arkansas. He is survived by his mother, Evelyn, and by two brothers, Gary and Randy Smith. Memorial services will be private. Donations may be made in Michael C. Smith's name to Project Angel Food, Los Angeles, where Smith had served on the Board of Directors.

title: To Spur German Economy, Schroder Offers Veer to Right
description: After nine months of confused inertia in economic policy, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has at last set out where his New Middle in politics lies -- and it is a long way to the right of anything previously embraced by the German leader's Social Democratic Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ANTHONY LANE
description: ADAMS-Anthony Lane, 54, of Greenwich, CT, died Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital. Born in Salt Lake City, Utah, Mr. Adams was the son of Elaine Evans Adams and the late Lane Webster Adams. He was the husband of Louise Rambo Adams. Mr. Adams was a Managing Director Investment Counsel for New Bridge Partners, LLC. He was a Graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and Harvard University. He was a member of the Lane W. Adams Achievement Award in Care Giving, Harvard Medical School Neurology Dept., a Board Member of the New York Racket & Tennis Club, Board Member of the Brook Club in NYC, National Golf Links of America in Southampton, NY, and the Round Hill Club. In addition to his wife and mother of Greenwich, Mr. Adams is survived by a son Anthony Lane Adams, a daughter Isabelle Adams, both of Greenwich and a sister Victoria Adams Quan of New York, NY. Services will be announced at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to Quan Fellowship in Neurobiology at Harvard Medical School, c/o Mary Beth Pearlberg, Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St., Bldg. A, Boston, MA 02115.

title: The New Frontier
description: It seems particularly appropriate that one of the rare pioneering events in American fashion was conceived by a recent immigrant.

title: Debating Hepatitis B Vaccine; Who Has the Right To Make Decisions?
description: To the Editor:

title: When Cellular Towers Blend Into Landscape
description: AS a former Mayor of the Village of Flower Hill, John Walter knew the sting of community backlash against tall communications towers that change existing skylines. In 1998, AT&T Wireless Services' dropped a plan to erect a cellular tower there after village residents complained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, IVAN
description: RUBIN-Ivan, 60, of Bluebell, PA, died Friday, July 23 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Loving father of Jamie and Debra. Devoted brother of Burton and his wife Suzanne. Beloved by his late wife Mona and fiancee Kathy Traystman, Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave on Sunday, July 25 at 11:15 AM. In lieu of flowers donations in Ivan's memory to Cancer Care, Inc. would be deeply appreciated.

title: Washington Partied Here
description: Celebrating history, cars, art, choreography and a master.

title: Tax Cutters Aren't Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A rare satire of Hollywood glamour and publicity is concocted in Victor Felming's BOMBSHELL (1933). This slapdash but sharp, hilarious fable of a Hollywood press agent (Lee Tracy) and his glamorous star (Jean Harlow) was reportedly based on the chaotic home life of Clara Bow, the director's girlfriend. One of the funniest scenes involves his semiliterate star and a fabricated interview. Harlow and Tracy play their roles with understanding relish, and funny dialogue peppers the seasoned performances by Franchot Tone, Frank Morgan and Una Merkel - Monday at 10 P.M. on TCM.

title: Women as Chief Executives: O.K., Who Could Be Next?
description: With Carleton S. Fiorina, chosen last week to lead Hewlett-Packard, becoming only the third female chief executive of a Fortune 500 company, it's not too soon to ask who might be No. 4.

title: A Welcome Refuge for the War Torn
description: CONNECTICUT has long been a refuge for immigrants and the city of Waterbury, or the Route 8 corridor, has been a particularly popular area for Albanians. It's no small wonder, then, that many of the refugees from Kosovo are finding their way into the homes of countrymen and relatives in this region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAWKIN, PHYLLIS
description: CHAWKIN-Phyllis. We mourn the loss of our cousin Phyllis. Our hearts go out to her family. Zemmel Schiff Ratner family

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the investing style of Erin Sullivan, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Aggressive Growth fund, misstated the 52-week high of Exodus Communications, a stock in the fund's portfolio. It was $148.1875, not $109.

title: As Fields Dry Up, So Do Farmers' Hopes
description: New Jersey farmers can recall a season in the late 1980's when they went 53 days without rain. Compared to this summer, with its drastic jumps in temperature, wind and drought, they say that was a good year.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: Word & Image; Rushing the Seasons
description: Since we are all obsessed with plans to greet the next century on New Year's Eve, it may seem natural for the media to be rushing the electoral calendar by two, five, even nine years. Politically speaking, as The Economist put it, the Fourth of July this year felt like Labor Day 2000, the time when we would normally just begin to focus on the choice of leaders for 2001. But what is understandable is nonetheless unseemly and in no small way undemocratic.

title: Is There Room for Fashion at the Paris Haute Couture Shows?
description: What with a white-smocked Andre Leon Talley squiring around a crew from ABC, another from the BBC following Anna Wintour, and Puff Daddy simultaneously promoting his new record and posing for a fashion shoot by Annie Leibovitz, all at the same late-night party, the autumn haute couture shows certainly were the media equivalent of shooting fish in a barrel. And this should have pleased no one more than Bernard Arnault.

title: New Blood, Old Result For Stars
description: The reinforcements have arrived. But Henry Zambrano and Sasa Curcic, the newest MetroStars, were not able to save the injury-plagued team today.

title: Crime
description: Say what you will about New Orleans -- a city that glitters with the sinister beauty of a snake in Barbara Hambly's seductive period mysteries -- it was no place for a black man in the decades before the Civil War. Benjamin January, the cultivated, Paris-educated surgeon who has already encountered prejudice, injustice and yellow fever in this series, is cursed with a voodoo hex in GRAVEYARD DUST (Bantam, $23.95) when he tries to defend his sister, a voodooienne who has been arrested for helping a woman to poison her husband. For all his cosmopolitan sophistication, January has a lingering respect for the dark magic he remembers from his childhood. But with an outbreak of cholera threatening to turn the city into a pestilential sewer, he is even more desperate to rescue his sister from her noxious prison in the Cabildo.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Room Service, I'd Like a Bone
description: What if one day dogs took over the earth, like the apes did in ''The Planet of the Apes''? And on weekends, when they went out of town, they locked up their humans in metal cages? For owners who worry about their pet karma, there's the Paws Inn, a cageless kennel at 189 Ninth Avenue where dogs romp freely with other dogs, sleep on furniture, watch television, even take phone calls.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: Expert Opinions; How To Tell the End Is Near
description: GAS-GUZZLER BACKLASH

title: Marrying Watermelon With Calamari, Octopus or Even Yogurt
description: WATERMELON, a hot weather refresher, is the all-purpose answer to effortless dessert at a picnic, a backyard barbecue or casual summer dinner. And it is most often eaten plain.

title: Brooklyn Tawking Patterns Spread East
description: OVERHEARD in a bookstore: ''Here Trevor, listen to the story about the dog.''

title: Salsa Anonymous
description: Fans of salsa say there are many signs of their addiction, among them: trying to get by with just a few hours of sleep, spending more on salsa clothes than work clothes, arguing heatedly about the steps. And when you find yourself spending hours on Salsa New York, Stephen Shaw's Web site devoted to Latin dance -- well, you're hooked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, DAVID N.
description: MYERS-David N. We deeply mourn the death of David N. Myers of Cleveland, OH who died Thursday morning July 22 at the age of 99. He was a dedicated leader and benefactor of the Jewish and secular communities. As a long-time supporter of American Friends of the Hebrew University, he supported numerous programs and established the David Meyers Skin Laboratory and David and Inez Meyers Scholarship Endowment at The Hebrew University. In addition, he was a major contributor to the Louis H. Boyar Building of the Rothberg International School. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Inez and sons Dr. Deiter Myers and Hal Myers. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, HENRY
description: BIRNBAUM-Henry, 82. Died suddenly and tragically July 21, 1999. Born in St. Gallen, Switzerland, he served in an army intelligence unit 1941-1946, and was an investigator at the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials. He was the Chief Librarian at Brooklyn College 1952-1961, when he became University Librarian at Pace University, where he served with distinction for thirtythree years. Prior to his retirement in 1994, Pace University paid him the ultimate tribute by naming their library in his honor. He is survived by his brother Sol, his nephews Philip, Irwin, and Jeffrey, his nieces Phyllis, Marilyn, and Arlene, plus ten great and nine great great nephews & nieces. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, W. 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan on Monday, July 26 at 12:15 PM.

title: The Wide, Wide World of B & B's
description: BED & BKFST 4 RENT:

title: Airport Attack At Newark Raises Fears
description: A violent incident at Newark International Airport that left a Continental Airlines gate agent near death and a passenger under arrest has led to a wave of protest among airline workers who say they have been increasingly victimized by aggravated, aggressive passengers in the phenomenon known as ''air rage.''

title: Medical Center Begins to Thrive on Its Own
description: UNTETHERED from county life support less than two years ago, the Westchester Medical Center, once a department of the county government, has been breathing well on its own on most days, hospital officials report.

title: Citing Fire Risk, Suffolk Closes Parkland
description: Citing increased risk of fire as a result of extremely dry conditions, the Suffolk County Executive, Robert Gaffney, has ordered the closing of 35,000 acres of unstaffed parkland to prevent fires.

title: In the Battle Of the Sexes, This Word Is a Weapon
description: THE London debut of ''Swetnam the Woman-Hater'' may not have been the biggest event of 1618, but it had lasting impact. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, this play introduced the word misogynist into the English language. The word caught on immediately, which makes sense, since there have always been men who have despised women. But there have always been women who have despised men. Why, then, wasn't it until 1946 that an equivalent word for hostility toward males appeared? And why, once the word misandry surfaced (in ''Scrutiny,'' a defunct British journal of literary criticism), did it sink quickly into near oblivion?

title: July 18-24; Tax Cut Passes but a Veto Lies Dead Ahead
description: Evoking memories of Ronald Reagan's big tax cut in 1981, Republicans in the House passed a $792-billion tax reduction plan. It stands little chance of becoming law but sets out the conservative view of how the nation should allocate projected budget surpluses.

title: Closing a 'Digital Divide'
description: The day for the youngest children in the Bedford-Stuyvesant computer camp begins with a song meant to jog their memories.

title: In That Wonderful Town, Libidos Are Up, But Prospects Are Down
description: THERE will be no more dating.

title: Now That Risk Has Become Our Reward
description: While the cameras focused on flowers, candles and old photos, and while sentimentality and sorrow flowed, criticisms of John Kennedy Jr. were uttered sotto voce. One whispered condemnation was that ''he took too many risks.'' We may grudgingly forgive the behavior in adolescents, but we no longer appreciate it in adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATALE, HELEN DIAO
description: NATALE-Helen Diao. Born in China. Beloved wife of Joseph. Adored mother of Audrey, Andrew and Justin. Loving grandmother of Samantha & Gabrielle. Devoted daughter of Conrad and Shu-Feng Diao. Survived by her sisters Marge Kealy and Amy Wang & her brother Edward Diao. Contributions in her memory may be made to Saint Vincent's Hospital, New York City, or to Cabrini Hospice, New York City.

title: Newport Dishabille
description: SOME Rhode Island state agency stuck a car counter outside my driveway, on the dogleg of Bellevue Avenue, just past Doris Duke's mansion, Rough Point, the last in a long line of the alternately grim and lovely mansions on Newport's Gilded Age strip. Between noon on a Saturday and noon on Sunday, 8,000 cars choked past; by 7:45 Monday morning, the counter had ticked off 3,000 more. But these are not the most telling details about summer in a city through which more than 600,000 tourists pass between May and October, eager for a look at the excesses of the last century. The real Newport, still a little fusty, still sort of stylish, chugs along, and it looks something like this.

title: To Drive It, or to Smell Like It?
description: TO the marketers promoting Jaguar for Men, the fragrance smells like a blend of ''lavender, grapefruit, tangerine, basil, bergamot, thyme, gardenia and black currant leaves'' with undertones of ''musk, fern, leather, amber and tobacco.'' In other words, it smells like money.

title: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99; Happily Ever After
description: I still occasionally have the nightmare: I am processing down a hall of some sort, and as I pass, the distorted faces of obscure relatives and forgotten school friends leer up at me from under ridiculous hats and on top of padded shoulders, mouthing fatuous congratulations. Those awful first bars of ''The Wedding March'' blast out of the organ in a wheezy fugue, and I cast around for escape. The congregation turns on me, sneering and jeering. Then the chapel doors are thrown open in a burst of light and an explosion of white taffeta. And I awake in a sweaty knot of sheets.

title: A Crime Fighter With a Zero-Tolerance Policy
description: ABOUT three weeks ago, Joseph J. Santiago started his fourth year as Newark's Police Director by suspending nine officers without pay and denouncing them for what he called an intolerable breach of trust.

title: Julie Plocinik and James Moore
description: Julie Alexandra Plocinik and James Michael Moore were married yesterday by the Rev. William T. Reynolds, a Roman Catholic priest, at River Farm, the headquarters of the American Horticultural Society in Alexandria, Va.

title: Past and Present Blend in a Cold Spring Inn
description: ANTIQUE inns too often tender fusty, musty and dark as evidence of pedigree. In many ways more agreeable is a careful blend of past and present -- light and fresh in a historical framework. The new team at Hudson House has got the mix right; there is not a wooden piggy in a neckerchief or a ducky in a bonnet in sight. Crisp country blue papers the walls, punctuated by glass cones filled with extravagant bouquets. White trim and white linens soften the lines and the feel of early Americana. Diners lucky enough to be seated near the French doors of the front room have a peerless view of the Hudson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, FREDERICK W., DR.
description: WILLIAMS-Frederick W., Dr. Died Wednesday in Trenton, N.J. Dr. Williams was a graduate of Princeton University and New York University. He worked in the U.S. Intelligence community and consulted for government and business. He published in the field of Psychology, Sociology and Art History. He is predeceased by his wife Ilse Zeisel-Williams, beloved uncle of three nieces and one nephew. Contributions may be made to Princeton University or the American Cancer Society. Farewell, Gentle Scholar.

title: Managers' Contract
description: The Board of Legislators will review tomorrow a six-year contract with Local 456 of the Teamsters Union, giving the county's 300 middle managers an average of 16.5 percent in raises through 2001. The managers have worked for nearly four years without a new contract.

title: Alliance Growth and Income Fund
description: EVEN when a second career seems a radical departure, it may not be that big a jolt. Consider the case of Paul C. Rissman, who once was an archeologist specializing in the early civilizations of India. Today Mr. Rissman, manager of the $3.21 billion Alliance Growth and Income fund, says archeology has helped his stock-picking.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: WHITE HUNTERSThe Golden Age of African Safaris.By Brian Herne.John Macrae/Holt, $35.

title: Debra Silverman, Jeffrey Rothschild
description: Debra Stacie Silverman, the daughter of Kate and Michael I. Silverman of Hartford, is to be married this afternoon to Jeffrey Lee Rothschild, a son of Carol and Steven J. Rothschild of Greenville, Del. Rabbi Ian D. Pear is to officiate at the Rivers Club in Pittsburgh.

title: Why Shouldn't the Right Leave the G.O.P.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, NATHANIEL
description: KATZ-Nathaniel. July 20th, 1999, at 91 years of age. Dearly loved husband of Audrey Stevens Katz. Adored uncle of Geri Shapiro, Daniel Katz and Jeff Katz. Devoted brother-in-law of Margaret Forsyth. Services were held on Thursday, July 22nd.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Disney's Second Ship: Ahoy, Little Mermaid
description: The Walt Disney Company knows a good thing when it sells it. So it should be no surprise that its second cruise ship will be much the same as its first. The Disney Wonder, scheduled to begin sailing Aug. 15, will look just like the Disney Magic from the pier. And once a passenger boards, the differences will be mainly decorative.

title: County Wins Awards
description: Westchester has won a series of awards from the National Association of Counties, which honors county governments for developing programs that increase efficiency. The awards went to the following programs, among others:

title: Sports of The Times; Keeping A Dream Alive
description: RONNIE FIELDS read the recent item in the newspaper, and as little sense as it made, it didn't surprise him either. A Dallas Mavericks first-round draft pick named Leon Smith set a rookie record for Generation X intransigence, when he ripped off his shirt and stormed out of his first pro practice.

title: Folly of Arming Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Routine Checks on Hot Water Heater
description: WATER entering your house from the municipal water supply comes in cold. Before it gets to your faucets, some of the water is diverted to a hot water heater, so that when you open the faucet, hot water runs out. A hot water heater is essentially a large, glass-lined steel tank with a heater under it. A layer of insulation surrounds the tank, and the entire unit is enclosed in a sheet-metal jacket.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 25, 1999
description: Weeks

title: In the Region/New Jersey; In a Strong Market, Shortages Bedevil Developers
description: THESE are good times and bad times for home builders in New Jersey.

title: Tonal Landscapes Of Bleak Beauty
description: GIYA KANCHELI'S musical landscape is unique: a bleak, blasted northern heath, shot through with the nostalgic ache of the political exile. Earlier recordings from the ECM label introduced Mr. Kancheli, a composer from the Republic of Georgia, to a larger audience with works like ''Abii Ne Viderem,'' which place a lone instrumentalist -- in that instance, the violist Kim Kashkashian -- in sharp relief against a surging, turbulent backdrop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, MARY LOUISE
description: FARRELL-Mary Louise. Devoted wife of Edgar Henry. Beloved mother of Brooke, Elizabeth and Kimberely. Adored grandmother of Wyatt, Oliver, Brooke and Alexander. Burial will be in August at The Adirondack League Club, Honnedaga Lake, Forestport, NY.

title: Beach Closings
description: Although more states and local beach communities are adopting monitoring and public notification programs to warn swimmers about pollution, record numbers of advisories and closings were logged at some of the country's beaches, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council's ninth annual beach quality guide.

title: The Art of Making Juggling Visual Music
description: SITTING barefoot on his front porch, sipping iced tea within earshot of lowing cows along his infrequently traveled Cornwall road, Michael Moschen seems at first a picture of laid-back country contentment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, COUNCIL S., DR.
description: TAYLOR-Council S., Dr. Noted anthropologist and renowned scholar Dr. Council Samuel Taylor died on Monday, July 5, 1999 at Valley Presbyterian Hospital in Van Nuys, California. He was 82 and lived in Northridge. Dr. Taylor was born in Brooklyn and attended and graduated from Yale University, where he was president of the Elizabethan Club; at the time, the club counted authors Mary McCarthy, William Penn Warren, and British poet W.H. Auden among its members. He received his bachelor's degree in 1950 and his doctorate in 1955, both in anthropology. Dr. Taylor also served in the United States Marine Corps and saw combat duty during World War II. Although offered a position at Princeton University, Dr. Taylor migrated to Southern California in 1985 to teach at the University of Southern California at Los Angeles, where he was chairman of the Anthropology Department for over five years. An avid dance enthusiast, he was consulted by Alvin Ailey and Katherine Dunham for his knowledge and expertise in authentic dance movement. Two of his numerous notable positions included Distinguished Teaching Professor of the State University of New York at Old Westbury, where he taught from 1969 to 1985, and President of the Association of Black Anthropologists, positions for which he was honored in 1985 and 1993 respectively. Dr. Taylor concluded his teaching career at California State University at Northridge. He is survived by nieces Edith and Alison, and grandnephews Richard and David. A future memorial service at California State University at Northridge will be announced. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Dr. Council S. Taylor Scholarship Fund, C/O The Anthropology Department of California State University at Northridge.

title: The Sect That Became an Enemy of the State
description: The scale and tenacity of Falun Gong, the faith-healing sect led by a Chinese guru now living in New York City, has taken everyone by surprise, even the Chinese Government. In April, 10,000 Falun Gong members suddenly turned up in Beijing for a silent demonstration outside the Forbidden City, where the Communist leaders live, and just as suddenly they were gone. That takes some organization. Now that the Chinese Government has banned the sect, it has taken on a formidable enemy.

title: Strength and Grace in the Water And Lofty Ambitions Around It
description: In a sport in which the athletes are often referred to as water ballerinas, it is easy to assume that all synchronized swimmers have a natural love for ballet and are flattered by the comparison.

title: Breaking the Mold In Yorkville
description: LA FORET +

title: Severa von Wentzel, Adam Boswick
description: Severa Elizabeth von Wentzel, the daughter of Elizabeth Cabot-Lyman of Cambridge, Mass., and Bogislav von Wentzel of Bonn, was married yesterday to Adam Reuben Boswick, a son of Sheila Evans of Ottawa and Tor Boswick of Hamilton, Bermuda. The Rev. William C. Imes, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the First Parish Church in Brunswick, Me.

title: Fewer Lawsuits? In This Country?
description: Are American investors shedding their litigious habits? Securities lawyers need not ponder second careers just yet, but a recent study says the filing rate for securities lawsuits has plummeted since 1995.

title: Think What They'd Do With 'Titanic'
description: ONE of the more unusual success stories in television history will apparently come to an end with the Aug. 8 episode of ''Mystery Science Theater 3000,'' the show that made an art of talking back to the screen.

title: Israeli's Peace Initiative Pauses After Death of Morocco's King
description: Due to the death of King Hassan II of Morocco, the whirlwind peacemaking itinerary of Ehud Barak, the new Prime Minister of Israel, has veered in an unexpected direction.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Beer and Cheese Party

title: The August Classic
description: It's not October and it's not Yankee or Shea Stadium (one can always hope), but the World Series is almost here. It's the Sandy Koufax World Series, Aug. 5 to 9, at Cochrane Stadium at the Caven Point complex in Jersey City. Taking part will be nine teams of 13- and 14-year-olds - some girls sure to be among them - from seven regions, including Puerto Rico. This is Jersey City's fifth year as site of the series, and the host team, the Jersey City Stars of Tomorrow, automatically gets a berth. Games are played by major-league rules, though the infield is smaller; spitting and scratching are optional. Opening ceremonies take place on Aug. 5 at 7 P.M., with introduction of the teams, a home run derby, competitions in throwing and other skills, and entertainment. The double-elimination tournament starts at 10 the next morning, with as many as five games a day. Admission is $5 for the opening ceremony and $3 for the following days, good for all day. Information: (201)547-5631 or www.cityofjerseycity.com

title: Column on Dog Group Implied Some Misbehavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer chart last Sunday, about Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., misstated the area code. It is 914. The chart also misstated the rush-hour commuting time. It is 42 minutes, not 53.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on July 4 about some Harlem residents' concern that the closing of the Fresh Kills landfill will mean greater use of a marine transfer station on West 135th Street misstated New York State's position on waste disposal. The state has not ruled that the city must upgrade one disposal center in each borough to handle waste after the closing of Fresh Kills.

title: Tribute to a Stadium, and to a Latin Music Star
description: TRYING to revive the spirit of the historic Lewisohn Stadium concerts held from the beginning of this century through the 1960's, Aaron Davis Hall, on the campus of City College, is inaugurating a new series of outdoor summer concerts. The first is Saturday, featuring Eddie Palmieri, the New York Latin musician, with his orchestra.

title: Two Manatees Star In Cincinnati Exhibit
description: Two Florida manatees have moved to the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden in a new exhibit that showcases more than 50 animal species native to Florida. The manatees, who collectively weigh in at more than 1,600 pounds, are the star inhabitants of Manatee Springs.

title: At Last, the Euro Looks Ready to Climb
description: THE euro, Europe's single currency, has made a rebound in the last week and a half that investors should not ignore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERER, MARTHA SCHICK
description: LEDERER-Martha Schick. Age 97. A lady from Vienna, on July 23, 1999. Died peacefully in the mountains of New York. Lived for over 40 years in Jackson Heights, NY. Born in Vienna, Austria, June 6, 1902. Beloved daughter of Karl and Friedaricka Steiner, came to America in 1940. Valued family above all and will always be remembered for her intelligence, strength, courage and life-long friendships. Beloved and cherished daughter, wife, mother, mother - in - law, grandmother, great-grandmother of 18. Honored aunt. B'nai Brith sister, wonderful friend and neighbor. ''I have fulfilled my father's command. I have kept the family together. My time was well spent.'' - From ''The Lady of Vienna,'' her autobiography. Service Sunday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, ALBERT E.
description: PETERSON-Albert E. 81, in Washington, D.C. June 30th, 1999. Cherished husband of Hattie; beloved uncle, great-uncle and cousin, and dear friend to many around the world. All mourn the stilling of that big voice.

title: Ex-Prisoner of China Seeks Insights at Old Gulag Site
description: On the outskirts of town, a former Stalinist prison stands behind a row of concrete slabs. Undaunted by warnings from local residents who wish to remember Stalin's horrors but are acutely aware that this is still state property, the Chinese-American guest scrambled up the wall.

title: William Targ, 'Godfather' Editor, Dies at 92
description: William Targ, a widely admired book editor and former editor in chief of G. P. Putnam's Sons who agreed to publish Mario Puzo's novel ''The Godfather'' sight unseen, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Wine's External Value
description: While Italians turn vineyard leftovers into bottles of grappa, the French are recycling their winemaking remains into jars of beauty products. Caudalie, a French skin-care line, has been using highly concentrated grape-seed extracts to make face creams, masks and cleansers. And in August, it will open a vineyard spa, Les Sources de Caudalie, at the Chateau Smith-Haut-Lafitte vineyard in Bordeaux.

title: Sosa Dances as Mets Supply Music
description: A sweating and gasping Bobby Valentine was pedaling furiously on the exercise bicycle in his office yesterday, trying to do more than one thing simultaneously, as usual. He talked, he read, he pedaled, he sweated and he talked some more.

title: One Who Stands Out In a Crowd of Any Size
description: A STAR is a star is a star. And Mikhail Baryshnikov is. So much for a self-evident, self-reinforcing reiteration, and its embodiment.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the debate over vaccinating school-age children for Hepatitis B misstated the age at which the vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) is administered. It is given after children are a year old.

title: The Nation: You Could Look It Up; What He Promised. And What He Did.
description: WHY, a reporter asked President Clinton at his news conference on Wednesday, did he ridicule George W. Bush's slogan of ''compassionate conservatism''? Another reporter wanted to know what the President found objectionable about the Texas Governor's ''trying to present a new moderate face for his party, just like you did for the Democrats.''

title: Forever and Ever
description: AS IT IS IN HEAVEN

title: Intimations and Regrets; Remembering Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and John F. Kennedy Jr.
description: I NEVER knew what to say to John Kennedy Jr. We were at Brown together and he lived off campus with some of my friends, but I didn't know him personally. I can't say if it was respect for his privacy or my own pride that kept me from pushing our social connections to make him aware of me in the years that followed. I knew that he would have been gracious if I had introduced myself at a party, but I also knew that he had more than enough people to talk to wherever he went. Sometimes the nicest thing you can do for someone is leave him alone, and so I was biding my time for the last 15 years until we had reason to talk.

title: Hungry Creature Gets Respect
description: CATERPILLARS were once viewed with disdain. The immediate response when finding one in the garden was to get rid of them fast. The method of removal was often a swift pulling off the plant and stomp with the foot.

title: Central Parks
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Playwrights As Librettists For a Trilogy Set in a Park
description: This is one crowded town at the moment. With the National Baseball Hall of Fame holding its annual induction today and expecting record attendance, Main Street has been packed all weekend with fans dressed in the caps and jerseys of their favorite teams, hoping to glimpse their heroes. But the induction was not the only draw this weekend. A few miles north along the shore of Lake Otsego, the Glimmerglass Opera gave the world premiere of ''Central Park,'' a long-awaited trilogy by three young, accomplished composers and three somewhat more famous playwrights.

title: This Week

description: HABER-Daisy. On July 23, 1999. Survived by Georges, Jan, Katinka, Delia. No services.

description: One of the grand aspects of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company's performances at Lincoln Center Festival '99 has been a focus on Mr. Cunningham's collaboration with major contemporary painters.

title: Australia to Sell 16.6% Stake in Telstra
description: The Australian Government said today that it would sell 16.6 percent of the Telstra Corporation, the nation's No. 1 telecommunications company, raising an estimated $16 billion (Australian), or about $10.4 billion (United States).

description: Defense projects have a curious way of evading the will of Congress and the President.

title: Donna Allen, 78, a Feminist and an Organizer
description: Donna Allen, an early standard-bearer of feminism who kept an eye on the news and communications industry from her Washington home, died on July 19 of a heart attack. She was 78.

title: Are Web Luddites Missing Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ammirati Puris And Iridium Part
description: Iridium L.L.C., the troubled worldwide wireless telecommunications network, and Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, have agreed to part ways on the company's account as Iridium seeks to replace a mass communications campaign with more narrowly focused direct marketing.

title: A Man at the Top, With Hard-Hat Experience
description: Milo E. Riverso, the man assigned to fix the problems at the School Construction Authority, has one advantage over most of its five previous presidents: He knows the city's construction industry from the inside out.

title: Making the Teaching Profession Respectable Again
description: No amount of effort to improve the quality of our schools will succeed unless we end up with better teachers. Yet, despite glimmers of renewed interest among students at elite universities, the most gifted and talented college students are not choosing teaching as a career. Indeed, the level of interest reported in 1999 is well below that expressed in the 1970's, when teaching ranked far below medicine, law and business.

title: Man in the News: Lance Edward Armstrong; Ultimate Overachiever
description: Even before October 1996, when he was found to have advanced testicular cancer, Lance Armstrong had much to prove. He had always been bright and charming, but he had also been brash, almost angry for having to show that he could overcome life's stacked deck.

title: A Champion in Paris
description: Lance Armstrong, capping a remarkable comeback from cancer, became the second American bicycle racer to win the Tour de France. SportsMonday, page D1. (Tom Able-Green/Allsport)

title: In Scenes Of Tumult, Moroccans Bury King
description: Marching under a merciless sun through streets thronged by hundreds of thousands of mourners, President Clinton and President Jacques Chirac of France led an assemblage of dozens of kings and princes, presidents and prime ministers for the burial of King Hassan II of Morocco today.

title: The Big City; Rental Laws That Leave No Winners
description: ROBERT DABROWSKI has been nominated by his landlady for the 10 Worst Tenants list, and at first glance he seems deserving. The bare facts of his resume since 1988 would strike fear into any property owner.

title: Chechen Group Trying to Ransom U.S. Aid Worker's Remains
description: In a macabre twist to one of the most persistent mysteries of the war in Chechnya, a Chechen group claims to have the body of the American aid worker Fred Cuny and is demanding a large ransom for its return, say those familiar with the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, FRANK M. JR.
description: JOHNSON-Frank M. Jr. The Directors of the Drum Major Institute wish to express their profound sympathy to the Johnson family, and to the nation at large, at the passing of a great man and a superlative jurist. Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr.'s many landmark decisions broke the cadence of segregation, and allowed the South to begin its march toward racial harmony. As we strive today to set a beat for the new millennium, we will remain ever mindful of his courage, vision, and vigilance in pursuing the ideal of equal justice for all. Andrew Young, William Wachtel Andrea Young, John McConnell

title: Ferrari Torch Is Passed To Irvine, and He Wins
description: When Michael Schumacher broke his right leg at the British Grand Prix two weeks ago, it seemed likely that the fun would be gone from the Formula One season.

title: The Dog Days of July
description: The temperature hit 97 in the city yesterday, setting a record for the second day in a row. Meteorologists expect the heat to linger. Page B5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, BATHSHEVA
description: FINKELSTEIN-Bathsheva. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the wife of our dedicated former Ritual Director of blessed memory David Finkelstein and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi David Yagoda, Chairman Dr. William Schwartz, President

description: The NCR Corporation plans to introduce software this week to improve companies' ability to track their customers' behavior.

title: Weekend Heat Sets Records and Pattern Is Expected to Continue
description: For the second day in a row yesterday, the heat broke records in New York City. On both Saturday and Sunday, the high in Central Park was 97 degrees, exceeding the records set in 1987 by 3 degrees on Saturday and by 2 degrees yesterday.

title: Throng Applauds American In Paris
description: The people who live here usually come to the Champs-Elysees, the most famous stretch of pavement in Paris, to go to the movies. There are myriad theaters along the avenue, and like most theaters in Western Europe, American blockbusters are what draw the crowds: big-budget productions with immediately recognizable stars and scripts that often stretch belief.

title: An Entrepreneurial Exception Rides The Internet in Japan
description: Masayoshi Son seems an unlikely deal maker in the bubbly and free-spirited world of the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARYSH, GERTRUDE (NEE KATSH)
description: BARYSH-Gertrude (nee Katsh). On Saturday, July 24, in Palm City, FL. Formerly of NYC, New Milford, CT, and Jamesburg, NJ. Beloved wife of 60 years of Dr. Noah Barysh, and devoted mother of Alan Barysh of Baltimore, MD, and daughter Ann Barysh and sonin-law Steven Swanger of Sudbury, MA, grandmother of Gabriel and Rebecca Swanger and loving aunt. Services Tuesday, July 27, at 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St. Donations in her memory may be made to Temple Beit Hayem, 3715 SE Ocean Blvd, Suite 103, Stuart, FL.

title: Barbara Raskin, a Chronicler Of Women's Lives, Dies at 63
description: Barbara Raskin, author of the best-selling 1987 novel ''Hot Flashes,'' about the concerns of her generation of women, died on Friday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. She was 63 and lived in Washington.

description: Rickey Henderson, using his first three at-bats to produce runs in three very different ways, led the Mets to a 5-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs last night at Shea Stadium and a sweep of their three-game series.

description: Though only 28, Seth Goldstein is an experienced member of New York's Internet industry, having started the Site Specific ad agency in 1995. But recently, he has been the Inspector Gadget of Silicon Alley.

Great aunt of Brianna, Michael, Patrick and Robert. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue at Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, RC Church, Wednesday, July 28, 9:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. title: In an unconventional campaign, ABC labels itself America's broadcasting company.
description: WOULD the crowds be as large at movie theaters showing ''American Pie'' if it were retitled ''America's Pie''? A certain network that once called itself the American Broadcasting Company is hoping a fanciful name change of a similar nature will help draw crowds to TV sets showing its programs.

title: Agency Chosen By Moe Ginsburg
description: Moe Ginsburg, Men's Better Clothing Inc. in New York has awarded duties for the creative portion of its account to Korey Kay & Partners in New York. Billings for the account, which had been handled since 1995 by Calderhead & Phin in New York, were estimated at $3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLATO, PAUL. CHRISTOPHER
description: FLATO-Paul. Christopher Walling, Inc., salutes with sadness the passing of one of the greatest American (as he himself put it), ''editors of jewelry design,'' the world's greatest salesman of jewels, an often unjustly maligned businessman, the inventor of the terms ''Champagne'' and ''Cognac'' for diamonds, and a friendthe inimitable Paul Flato. Christopher Walling, President

title: Chavez Is a Winner, As Is the Belmont Meet
description: Belmont Park ended its summertime meeting yesterday with modest gains in attendance and betting handle, with Jorge Chavez once more winning the title as the leading jockey and Todd Pletcher winning as the leading trainer. And then, horses and handlers and equipment headed for Saratoga, where the 131st season of racing in the Adirondacks will open Wednesday.

title: Armstrong Wins Tour and Journey
description: Aglow in the yellow jersey of the champion, Lance Armstrong completed the final leg of his long journey to Paris today, winning the Tour de France 33 months after cancer threatened his life and appeared likely to end his cycling career.

title: Police Suggest Suspect Choked on Bag of Drugs
description: As the Rev. Al Sharpton called for a Federal inquiry into the death of a Brooklyn man who died in the custody of the police on Saturday, law enforcement officials said yesterday it appeared that the man had died after swallowing a small plastic bag containing drugs.

title: Sal G. Marzullo, 72, Mobil Vice President
description: Sal G. Marzullo, a Mobil executive who helped put into effect a code of employment practices drawn up for American multinational companies working within the apartheid system in South Africa, died on July 13 at his home in Orlando, Fla. He was 72.

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 15 PM Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Monday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, July 27, at 10 AM. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, SIDNEY P.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Sidney P. July 24, 1999. Devoted husband of Mae. Beloved father of Saul, Marc, Jeremy and Joshua, father-in-law of Iris, Janet and Marla, grandfather of Arriel, Jason, and Gabrielle, step-grandfather of Megan and David. He was a graduate of City College and Rutgers University. As an international consultant, author, Fellow of the American Society of Quality Control, and founder of Participative Systems, Inc. he pioneered efforts between unions and management to jointly redesign work systems and labormanagement relations. Funeral services will be held Monday, 11:00, at Congregation B'Nai Tikvah, 1001 Finnegans Lane, North Brunswick, NJ.

description: I.B.M. Plans to Introduce New Data-Storage System
