title: Horton Bay Journal; They Remember Papa, But Not Very Lovingly
description: No one here would have minded what Ernest Hemingway wrote if he had stuck to describing trout fishing and hunting and swimming here in northern Michigan, where he spent every summer of his boyhood.

title: Two Accused of Raping 16-Year-Old Girl at Club, Prompting Renewed City Effort to Close It
description: Two men from New Jersey were arrested early yesterday and accused of raping a 16-year-old girl in a restroom at the Tunnel, a popular Manhattan nightclub that has long been plagued by drug problems and legal woes, the police said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: In Brief Visit to Arkansas, Mayor Will Tour a Place That the First Lady Called Home
description: In a campaign swing that promises more curiosities than a trip through the looking glass, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to fly to Little Rock, Ark., this week to raise money, give a speech and tour the Governor's Mansion, where Hillary Rodham Clinton lived for 12 years.

title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; For local merchants interested in on-line sales, faith may be the biggest element of the business plan.
description: ONLIKE most people drawn to the siren song of Internet commerce, Phil Worley started a Web site last spring with a modest goal: bring in some additional sales for the small-town hardware business. No 50-page business plan. No venture capital. No initial public offering.

title: Patents; An Internet entrepreneur finds a way for newsstand dealers to profit from subscription sales.
description: HE may have become a billionaire selling airline tickets on the Internet. But Jay Walker thinks he knows a better way to sell magazines at the newsstand, too.

title: Elf Aquitaine Won't Cut Jobs
description: Elf Aquitaine S.A., Europe's fifth-largest oil producer, has abandoned its plans to eliminate 1,300 jobs in France, the first sign that the company may be prepared to enlist union support in its attempt to ward off a $51 billion hostile takeover offer from a French rival, Total Fina S.A.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a memorial service for John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren Bessette, referred incorrectly to Carole Radziwill. She is the daughter-in-law, not the daughter, of Lee Radziwill. (An article in some copies yesterday about a memorial service for Lauren Bessette repeated the error.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNON, THOMAS J.
description: GANNON-Thomas J. Age 80, of Port Washington, LI, retired of IBM, on July 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn (Lynn). Loving father of Linda Patton (Tom), Laurie Hahl (Al), Jamie Fairley (Paul), and Mary Connolly (Kevin). Very devoted grandfather of 10. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc, Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:30 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara. Interment Tuesday, Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Ready or Not, the Jets Are Set to Open Camp
description: A high-energy Jets training camp -- probably the most difficult and taxing any of the players have faced -- will start Friday when the club attempts to improve upon a season that came tantalizingly close to a Super Bowl appearance.

title: Back in the Big City, Rogers Is Ready to Win
description: Kenny Rogers could not have No. 37, his uniform number with the Oakland Athletics. That was Casey Stengel's number, and it was retired by the Mets in 1976.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about John R. Steelman, one of President Harry S. Truman's closest aides, referred imprecisely to the uniqueness of his title. While Mr. Steelman is believed to be the only aide whose title was ''the'' assistant to the President, many people since have had the rank of assistant to the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHHEISER, EILEEN
description: HOCHHEISER-Eileen, died July 23, at home in Wesley Hills, NY. She is survived by husband Robert Hochheiser, sons Harry and David Hochheiser, daughter-in-law Judy Yanowitz, and brother Leonard Brooks. To have known her is to miss her. Services July 26, 10 AM, at Temple Beth El, Spring Valley, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, ABRAHAM W.
description: EINHORN-Abraham W. Age 91, of Spring Valley, NY. Father of W. Lee Einhorn and Loni Bader. Beloved grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services are at 12:30 PM, today, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4 (East), Paramus, NJ.

title: Leiter Can't Quite Give Bullpen a Total Break
description: When he came off the field after the eighth inning last night, Al Leiter tried to plead his case. Coasting with a four-run lead, but aware that his pitch count was growing ominously high, Leiter wanted to try to finish off the Chicago Cubs without help from the Mets' bullpen.

title: Accounts
description: * AIM Management Group, Houston, part of Amvescap P.L.C., to Richards Group, Dallas, to handle its account, which had been at Deutsch Inc., New York. Billings were estimated at $10 million. The switch consolidates accounts at Richards, which already handles an AIM sibling, Invesco Funds Group.

title: Off Broadway's Mom and Angel; A Producer Who Nurtures New Work and New Audiences
description: A lot of theater producers say they gravitate to revivals not because they are playing it safe but because it is hard to find good new plays these days. If Daryl Roth is any measure, that simply is not true.

title: Fiorentina The Show, Batistuta The Lead
description: The Gotham Cup final between Aston Villa of England and Fiorentina of Italy tonight was little more than a training exercise, with the teams' league openers just weeks away.

title: Progress on Presidential Pay
description: The next American President, whoever that turns out to be, will be getting a raise. Thanks to a bipartisan vote by the House earlier this month, Bill Clinton's successor will be making twice what Mr. Clinton does -- $400,000 a year, which is also twice what the country has paid its Presidents for the past three decades.

title: Media Talk; In Kennedy Death, Profit and Risks
description: The death of a celebrity like John F. Kennedy Jr. fills magazine racks and bookshelves almost instantly. It happened after Diana, Princess of Wales, died and again with Frank Sinatra. The death of Mr. Kennedy is no exception, but there are some differences.

title: Abelardo Diaz Alfaro, 81; Author of Puerto Rican Stories
description: Abelardo Diaz Alfaro, whose short stories gave voice to Puerto Ricans' quest for identity, died on Thursday at his home in Guaynabo, a suburb of San Juan. He was 81.

title: Why Physicists Are Hard to Find
description: To the Editor:

title: Shay Wins Grand National Team Event
description: Two major titles were decided here in the last two days at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. The Grand National team championship, which began at the grass-roots level nine months ago, was won on Friday night by a Florida squad headed by Joseph Shay, a retired businessman. He and his star-studded team of Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell, Michael Seamon and Robert Levin won the final by 43 imps against a foursome from Southern California.

title: The Republican Shift on Drug Laws
description: Joseph Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, said this month that he supports giving judges more discretion in sentencing drug offenders. That is a political breakthrough for New York's Republican Senate, which has been opposed to revising the stringent drug laws created in the Rockefeller era. Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly Speaker, should seize on Mr. Bruno's overture to push for reforms that would relieve pressure on the prison system by making the drug laws more rational and flexible.

title: Fans Rampage In Last Hours Of Music Show
description: Before the music ended, Woodstock '99 started going up in violent flames tonight as marauding bands of shirtless, bellowing men set fire to 12 trucks, looted T-shirts from concession stands and tore open cash machines in search of money.

title: Why Physicists Are Hard to Find
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, HAROLD R., M.D.
description: COOK-Harold R., M.D. July 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Honey. Devoted father of Ann, Dana and Andy. Loving brother of Blossom. Cherished grandfather of Zachary and Jessica. Service Monday, July 26, 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the City of Hope, 30 W. 26th St, NYC 10010.

title: Memo From Lahore; Editor Held 25 Days Finds Nightmare Never Ends
description: Here in this cultivated city's most exclusive neighborhood, in a large, stately home on a hushed, shady street, lives Najam Sethi, one of Pakistan's leading journalists. He married old money, but he and his wife, Jugnu Mohsin, have used their biting wit not to build greater wealth, but to skewer Pakistan's governing elite in the pages of their scrappy weekly newspaper, The Friday Times.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Compressed Data; Large Phone Contract From South Africa
description: The newly renamed American company Telcordia Technologies Inc. plans today to announce a big contract to help modernize Telkom South Africa's antiquated telephone systems and bring phone service to millions of South Africans for the first time.

title: Reverence and the Thrills of Hall of Fame Rookies
description: A record crowd came to hear and cheer the newest members of baseball's Hall of Fame today. And it was an impressive class of 1999, led by Nolan Ryan, Robin Yount and George Brett, all elected in their first year of eligibility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, MICHAEL J.
description: RUSSO-Michael J. Beloved brother of Antoinette Pierro, Ida Howard of Andover, MA. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Louis DeLuca Mayflower Funeral Home, 6022 Bay Pkwy, Brooklyn, NY, chapel hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection at St. Athanasius R.C. Church. Entombment, Wednesday, at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Born in New York City, 1917, then moved to Miami Beach in 1980. He served in World War II in the United States Coast Guard Intelligence Office in the Third Naval District and was awarded the Purple Heart. He was appointed by President Roosevelt as a court reporter to the United States Court of International Trade and retired as its Chief Court Reporter in 1972. He was also a Veteran of Foreign Wars and was Commander of the Colonel Francis Vigo Post #

title: Gordon's Grasp on Title Continues to Slip Away
description: Bobby Labonte continued his domination of Pocono Raceway, cruising to his second victory this season here in today's Pennsylvania 500. However, Jeff Gordon's failure to complete the race might have been the most significant development of the day.

title: Media Talk; Dwindling Corps Of Specialists On Aviation
description: In the forefront of the television coverage of John F. Kennedy Jr.'s plane crash were examples of an increasingly rare breed of specialist reporters. NBC's aviation reporter, Robert Hager, was the first to report that the plane was missing on the morning of July 17. And his counterpart at CBS, Bob Orr, was the first to report the details of the radar track that indicated Mr. Kennedy had turned out to sea, possibly because Mr. Kennedy was disoriented, before he lost control of his plane.

title: Long-Term Care for Elderly Merges Political and Personal
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, spent part of his Fourth of July holiday back home in Missouri, looking at retirement communities for his 91-year-old mother. Mr. Gephardt's wife, Jane, spends every other weekend in Nebraska, where her parents recently entered a nursing home.

title: Hunger Ravages Angolans in Renewed Civil War
description: The feeding room here is quiet. The children are so severely malnourished that they barely move anymore. There is no laughing, no teasing, no giggling, no squirming -- none of the things that should come naturally when 40 children are crowded together for a meal. In fact, even eating does not really appeal to them. In many cases, their mouths must be forced open and the milk slowly poured down their throats.

title: U.S. AND CHINA SAY THEY ARE MENDING POST-BOMBING RIFT
description: At their first high-level encounter since the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, the United States and China today depicted their tattered relationship as improved, despite important differences, and announced that President Clinton would meet the Chinese leader Jiang Zemin in September.

title: Talks Set for This Week On the Future of George
description: Jack Kliger, the recently installed president of Hachette-Filipacchi Magazines, plans to meet this week with the trustees of John F. Kennedy Jr.'s estate to determine the future of the political monthly magazine George.

title: A Planned Internet Yellow Pages Draws Federal Scrutiny
description: Aggravating an already charged political dispute over its monopoly control of Internet addresses, Network Solutions Inc. on Monday is set to introduce a new Yellow Pages-type directory for the Internet, built around valuable data that the Clinton Administration insists belong to the public.

title: Improving Access to Organs
description: For more than a year the Clinton Administration has been trying to improve the way human organs donated for transplants are distributed to patients around the country. But Congress, responding to intense opposition from transplant centers, has blocked the use of new Federal regulations that aim to broaden organ sharing across arbitrary local lines. A new report by the Institute of Medicine, a branch of the National Academy of Sciences, confirms that changes are needed to make the system more fair and effective.

title: Limits of Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: In Honoring Hassan, Israelis Bare Intrigue in Cause of Peace
description: The Israeli media devoted itself today to the decades of often covert close relations between Israel and King Hassan II of Morocco, paying tribute to an Arab leader who, it was often repeated, started life with a Jewish wet nurse.

title: Barak Send Soliders to Oust New Settlers' Mobile Homes
description: Facing down the first challenge to his new Government by Jewish settlers in the West Bank, Prime Minister Ehud Barak sent soldiers early today to remove five mobile homes that had been brought by settlers to expand a hilltop encampment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, EDWARD J.
description: JOFFE-Edward J. Of Jupiter, FL, formerly of Summit, NJ, on Thursday, July 22, 1999. Co-founder of Park Plastics, Linden, NJ. For information call The Werson Funeral Home, 635 North Wood Avenue, Linden, NJ, 908-486-4118.

title: Into Terra Incognita With Merce Cunningham
description: Ever since Merce Cunningham gave his first New York solo program in 1944, he has been a choreographic explorer. And he continues to travel inquisitively across time and space by creating dances for big casts and small.

title: Immigrant Family's Dream Crumbles in Grief
description: If there is an archetypal immigrant dream, Ninranjan Ramlochan seemed to have fulfilled it after he and his family left Guyana for New York in 1990 looking to better their lives.

title: For Zoe Baird, a New Opportunity for Public Service
description: The invitation was ''the kind of thing that makes your eyes glaze over,'' as one attendee put it -- a meeting to discuss the dispensation of Internet addresses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPER, BERTHA
description: JASPER-Bertha. We deeply mourn the passing of Bertha Jasper on July 24, in her 92nd year. Beloved wife of the late Ezekiel and devoted mother of Leonard and Jane, Harvey and Laura, and the late Sara Jane. Cherished grandmother of Robin Eve and Roger, Francesca and Bruce, Nina and Russell, Jennifer and Jeff, Merrill and Matt, and the late Eric Seigenfeld. Loving great-grandmother to Max, Lauren, Erica, Jake, Sam, Sara, Allie Rose and Emma. Dear sister of Pauline Runsdorf, Beatrice Lyons and the late Tilly and Miriam. Services Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Compressed Data; Playboy Loses Round Over Search Engine Ads
description: Giving a green light to a common but controversial Internet advertising practice, a Federal judge in California has refused a request by Playboy Enterprises to stop the Web search services Excite.com and Netscape.com from placing ads for pornography sites with the search results for the words ''playboy'' or ''playmate.''

title: A Passion for the Budget Drives a Michigan Republican
description: WHEN Representative Fred Upton talks about the cause that beckoned him here -- that nudges him out of bed in the morning, pings around his cerebral cortex all day and whispers to him at night -- something happens.

title: Editorial Observer; Judge Frank Johnson Goes Home to the Hills
description: Like so many of the public figures of his generation, Judge Frank Minis Johnson Jr. was marked irrevocably by the place of his birth. It is unthinkable that, in death, he should rest anywhere else. So tomorrow he will be received by the hills of the ''Free State of Winston,'' that remote, impoverished and contrary jurisdiction where he came to life in 1918.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTINE, RAY A.
description: VALENTINE-Ray A. On July 24, 1999. Beloved father of Raymond N. Valentine and wife Charlotte Marable. Dear grandfather of Alysia Valentine. Brother of Rudy Valentini. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, on Monday evening, 5-8 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, Our Savior Church, Park Ave and 38th St, at 10 AM.

title: Sports of The Times; Clemens Serves Notice on the League's Batters
description: MIKE HARGROVE sat behind a desk in the visiting manager's office at Yankee Stadium late yesterday afternoon and braced for the crush of news media members. With microphones and pads poised, Hargrove tried to put Cleveland's three-game series with the Yankees into quick perspective.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. January 17, 1911July 26, 1994. Viennese-born graphological genius, founder of the National Society for Graphology, teacher, counselor, and to the very end, a believer in the goodness of humanity, despite his concentration camp experiences. Today his love and idealism remain as guiding images for the fortunate many who knew him. Janice

title: Careless Contractors, Crumbling Schools
description: There were plenty of signs that the contractor putting a new roof on Public School 131 in Brooklyn was botching the job and cutting corners on safety.

title: Decrepit Buildings Shield Crimes of a Serial Killer
description: In the blackness of night he strikes, always in the same way. His victims are African-American women 19 to 49, all with histories of prostitution or drug abuse. He lures them into abandoned buildings, the police say, possibly with the promise of drugs or money for sex. And once there, he strangles or bludgeons them to death.

title: In Mourning, Cathedral Reconnects to Irish Roots
description: More than a century ago, Old St. Patrick's Cathedral was the pride of Irish Catholicism in New York City. The 69th Regiment of the Irish Brigade -- young volunteers from the Lower East Side -- paraded past its massive doors on the way to war in 1861. For decades, its pastors were men named Byrne, Loughlin, Quinn and Kearney.

title: Knicks and Nets Look Down the Bench at Summer League
description: As far as the Nets' coach, Don Casey, is concerned, summer league games might as well be played on blacktop playgrounds with chain-link nets and no scoreboards. That's because the guard-dominated, one-on-one displays that typify the action have more resemblance to street ball than to what is played in the National Basketball Association.

title: Voters Push Power Toward Venezuela Leader
description: In a vote that President Hugo Chavez called ''the most important of the past 100 years'' for Venezuela, his followers have won an overwhelming majority of seats in a national assembly that will write the new constitution he says he needs to carry out a sweeping ''social revolution.''

title: Amnesty in Sierra Leone Opposed by Rights Group
description: Human rights organizations are campaigning against a blanket amnesty granted in Sierra Leone under a peace agreement signed earlier this month to end the brutal eight-year civil war in that tiny, impoverished West African nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, SIMON
description: RICHARD-Simon. Age 84. Devoted husband of Ilse. Beloved father of Dorothy and Raphael Bloch. Cherished grandfather of David and Joel. Dear brother of Herbert. Loving great-grandfather of Joshua and Daniella. A longtime member of The Young Israel of Kew Gardens Hills. He will be greatly missed. Services were held Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the collapse of a building facade in Far Rockaway, Queens, that killed two people misstated the address of the building, and consequently, the building's owner. The building is at 10-51 Beach 20th Street, not 10-45 Beach 20th Street. The owner, according to the city's Buildings Department, is Alan Ades, not Lloyd Hayles.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Reform Party Takes Decisive Turn From Perot to Ventura
description: In a raucous rejection of Ross Perot, delegates to the Reform Party's national convention voted overwhelmingly today to install a chairman backed by the party's new star, Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota.

title: Q & A /Jaswant Singh, Indian Foreign Minister : India and Pakistan:Time to Get Back on the Bus to Peace
description: The nuclear-armed rivals India and Pakistan faced their worst crisis in 30 years this summer when armed intruders crossed from Pakistan's section of the disputed territory of Kashmir into the Indian-controlled section, prompting an air and ground assault by Indian forces to evict them. Shortly before he met U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright in Singapore on Sunday, Foreign Minister Jaswant Singh of India discussed the conflict over Kashmir and India's relations with Pakistan and the United States with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Pedestrian, 12, Critically Injured in Crash
description: A 12-year-old boy was critically hurt and four other pedestrians were injured in Brooklyn yesterday when a driver who crossed a double-yellow line to pass another car lost control and plowed into a line of parked cars, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, MARTIN M.
description: STONE-Martin M. Writer and long time resident of Greenwich Village, died peacefully at his Bank Street home on July 23, age 70. His impeccable style, elegance and wit will be sadly missed but happily remembered by his great friends and family, and most of all by his children, Abigail and Matthew, his daughter-in-law, Gloria, and his wife, Sally. Memorial service, Tuesday, July 27, 1 PM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERON, EVA
description: PERON-Eva. July 26, 1952. We will love and adore you forever

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think it's a miracle.''

title: I.B.M. Challenges EMC With New Data-Storage Line
description: I.B.M. is making a bid to regain its leadership position in the high-performance end of the data storage business today with the introduction of a new generation of big disk systems.

title: Times Co. to Sell Services at Digital TV Center
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would offer to sell the services of its digital operations center, now used by five of the company's eight television stations, to other stations nationwide beginning Jan. 1.

title: A Conductor Second-Guesses a Second-Guesser
description: Tableaux vivants were favored parlor games of the 19th century, with guests in costume posed in freeze-frame depicting mythological scenes or historical events. They still exist, I am told, at some American grange meetings; otherwise, the tableau has fallen prey to modern life.

title: Motel Handyman Is Tied To 4 Deaths at Yosemite
description: A motel handyman has been charged in the decapitation of a Yosemite National Park naturalist, and the F.B.I. says he is a chief suspect in the slayings of three sightseers whose disappearance in February led to a massive search and the arrests of former convicts who have been held for months as possible suspects.

title: INSIDE
description: Venezuela Votes for Change

title: A Witch's Caldron Of Success Boils Over
description: Six months ago an offbeat, low-budget horror film, ''The Blair Witch Project,'' opened to a mixed reaction at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINEMAN, FREDA
description: FINEMAN-Freda. Widow of Dr. Sol Fineman. Trailblazer, as first woman graudated from law school in Palestine under British Mandate. Retired as practicing attorney, member of New York Bar. Prize winning artist. Gracious lady lovingly remembered by friends.

title: Offerings of Equities and Debt Scheduled For Issue This Week
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Newark Airport Worker Recovering After Attack
description: A Continental Airlines gate agent who was attacked by an irate passenger at Newark International Airport last week remained in intensive care yesterday at University Hospital in Newark, but doctors said his condition had improved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, CATHERINE C.
description: CLARKE-Catherine C., 95. On July 22, 1999, of Katonah, New York. Wife of the late Richard W. Clarke. Mother of H. Cartan Clarke and Richard W. Clarke Jr. and the late Michael deS. Clarke. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and nineteen great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Katonah, New York, on Monday, 11 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Michael deS. Clarke Memorial Fund, C/O Amherst College, 100 Boltwood Avenue, Amherst, MA. 01002-5000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILSON, MALA KOLIN RUBINSTEIN
description: SILSON-Mala Kolin Rubinstein. On July 22nd, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Victor Silson. Loving aunt of Diane Moss, NYC, Jacqueline Herrmann, NYC, Nurit Amir, Israel, Carmi and Uri Shalev, Israel, Michael Kolin, Canada, Pamela Sendrovich, Canada, and Mary Rosset, Canada. Dear fried of Zygmunt Modzelenski. Memorial service Monday, 11:30 AM, July 26th, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Faith and Freedom in the Magic Known as Fiction
description: THE BROKEN ESTATE

title: Clemens Finds The Present In the Past. The Future?
description: Roger Clemens keeps strolling to the mound in search of the past, trying to prove to the Yankees and to the demanding fans that he is still one of the best pitchers in the major leagues. Just watch, Clemens must be thinking every time he holds his glove in front of his ruddy and determined face. Just watch and remember me.

title: A Festival Dreams of a Glyndebourne-en-Provence
description: With the beginning of Aix-en-Provence's annual opera festival last year, Stephane Lissner, the festival's ever ambitious director, set out to position this medieval city alongside Salzburg and Bayreuth as a summer must for European opera lovers. This year, by expanding the festival to include an 18th-century chateau set among woods and fields six miles from Aix, he seems to have Glyndebourne-en-Provence in mind.

title: SCANT RAIN RAISES FEARS OF DROUGHT IN EASTERN STATES
description: Corn leaves are shriveling into cigarlike shapes, trout are dying in hot and diminished streams and once-green lawns have become patches of yellow as exceptionally dry weather nears drought proportions in the eastern United States.

title: Baby Names, Big Battles
description: My wife has just given birth to a son. Tomorrow, the 12th day after he was born, our family will perform an ancient but simple Hindu ritual. We will sing a prayer and make a small offering to the gods, after which I will put my lips to his little ear and say to him three times: ''Your name is 'Satya.' '' Thirty-seven years ago, in Delhi, my father observed the same rite, intoning my name thrice into my right ear.

title: Editor Who Thrives on Celebrity Is Pleased With Latest Sensation
description: Only seven days and counting now until Tina Brown -- the alternately vilifed and celebrated former editor of The New Yorker and Vanity Fair -- unveils her latest project, Talk magazine.

title: JOE HILL IN HIGH TECH: A special report.; Unions Need Not Apply
description: As the labor movement sets its sights on the booming high-technology world, employees like Matt Shea, a 24-year-old software developer, seem ripe for the picking. He often clocks 70-hour weeks, his managers sometimes push him to work past midnight, and he never receives overtime pay.

title: Peter A. Bordes, 71, Broadcast Executive
description: Peter A. Bordes, the co-founder, chairman and chief executive of Greater Media Inc., a broadcasting and publishing company based in East Brunswick, N.J., died on July 19 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 71.

title: Serbian General Says Peacekeepers Don't Keep the Peace
description: The senior general who commanded Yugoslav troops in Kosovo today accused NATO forces and the United Nations of failing to establish order and ''creating unbelievable chaos in Kosovo.''

title: Essay; Point That Finger
description: We have stumbled into the era of no-fault government. Blamelessness is next to godliness; nobody in authority is held responsible for blunders, no matter how costly.

title: Security Flaw Is Discovered In Several Unix Programs
description: A leading computer security group is reporting a significant rise in potentially dangerous attacks that exploit security holes in programs shipped with the Unix operating system.

title: Several Internet Assignments Settled
description: Several Internet advertisers have made account decisions.

title: Jump in Brooklyn's Murder Rate Spurs Prosecutor to Form Study Panel
description: Disturbed by a sharp increase in murders this year, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office has assembled a task force of investigators to pore over the files on each of its 168 murder cases, looking for clues to explain the surge in fatal violence.

title: Clinton Says No To Any Tax Cut Of $500 Billion
description: The Clinton Administration said for the first time today that it would not accept a compromise $500 billion tax-cut plan proposed by a group of Senate Democrats, virtually assuring that the debate over how to spend the projected budget surplus will not be settled quickly or easily.

title: You Can Dig It!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Inches Underground, Secrets of Northern Slave Life
description: Alice Fiske, grande dame of Sylvester Manor on this coastal island, emerged from the stately Georgian house, steadying herself with a walking stick, to inspect the defacement of her handsome front lawn. She couldn't have been more pleased about the big hole there, the mark of archeologists at work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLSK, CELIA G.
description: WOLSK-Celia G., 93, formerly of Freeport, NY, on July 25th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of David and Paul. Dear sister of Myron. Devoted grandmother of Jeremiah, Alexander, Daniel, Jennifer and Matthew. She will be deeply missed by her family. Service Thursday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, JULIET BALDWIN
description: TAYLOR-Juliet Baldwin, 84. Of Nantucket, Massachusetts, died on Saturday, July 24. Widow of C. Harold Taylor; beloved mother of Willard B. Taylor and Juliet Taylor Walsh and of the late C. Harold Taylor, Jr.; adored grandmother of Martien Halvorson-Taylor, Severn Taylor, Jason Walsh, Sam Walsh, Daniel Taylor and Semira Asaro; and great-grandmother of Juliet Inga, Matthew, Kenneth and Brian. An alumna of The Brearley School and of Bryn Mawr College. Former president of Planned Parenthood of Connecticut, former trustee of The Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Facility, active in the Greenwich, Connecticut and Nantucket garden clubs and in efforts to preserve the natural beauty of Nantucket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLMAN, MARGUERITE W.
description: CULLMAN-Marguerite W., of Purchase, New York on Monday, July 26 in Manhattan, wife of the late Howard S. Cullman, mother of Marguerite P. and Brian H. Cullman, step-mother of Hugh and Paul T. Cullman. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and 25 greatgrandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday evening 5-8 P.M. Funeral Mass Friday, St. Vincent Ferrer, 66th and Lexington Avenue at 10:30 A.M. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Lighthouse International, 111 E. 59th Street, New York, New York 10022.

title: Tobacco Giant Spends Heavily Around Albany
description: In its largely successful campaign to defeat anti-smoking measures in Albany, the world's biggest cigarette maker has engaged in a lavish behind-the-scenes effort to win favor in the New York Legislature, spending tens of thousands of dollars in recent years on gifts for lawmakers, according to internal company documents and interviews.

title: Agency Will Ask Congress To Drop Gasoline Additive
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will propose that Congress no longer require oil companies to add an ingredient to gasoline that is meant to make the air cleaner, because it pollutes water.

title: Foreign Physicists Are No Security Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Disabled, Special Dogs Assume Special Duties
description: Elizabeth Twohy, who had polio as a child, needs to use a wheelchair most of the day, and the list of little things that are hard to do in a wheelchair is just about endless. But she has a friend, Ike, who helps out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASHKIN, CLARA (NEE WOOLFSON)
description: RASHKIN-Clara (nee Woolfson) Beloved sister of Selma Greenfield & Sawl Woolfson and sisterin-law of Esther and the late Dr. Stanley Greenfield. Loved aunt to many and great aunt. Dedicated school teacher at PS 91 in Brooklyn. Services Tuesday, 2:15PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Bankers Trust Is Ordered To Pay Fine
description: The Bankers Trust Corporation, which pleaded guilty earlier this year to criminal charges that it had illegally diverted unclaimed funds from its customers into the bank's accounts, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to pay a $60 million fine to the Government.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on July 13 about ''Undue Risk,'' a new history of state-sponsored unethical experimentation on humans, misstated the author's given name. He is Dr. Jonathan D. Moreno, not John.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, ERNA
description: OPPENHEIM - Erna Devoted mother of Vivian Lewis. Proud mother-in-law of New York Times correspondent Paul Lewis. Beloved Oma of Malia and Raphael, dear sister of Hilde Goldberg. Retired Chase Manhattan employee. Funeral Tuesday, 1:30PM at Hirsch and Co, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx. Shiva at Fort Tryon Nursing Home, 190 Street and Overlook Terrace.

title: Editor Forced to Resign in Dispute Over Marketing of Medical Journal's Name
description: The top editor of The New England Journal of Medicine is resigning under pressure in a dispute with its owners, the Massachusetts Medical Society, over the marketing of the journal's prestigious name as part of an expanding publishing empire.

title: Albright and Ivanov Confer; Try to Mend Ties After Kosovo
description: In what a Russian Foreign Ministry official here welcomed as the week of getting Russian relations with the United States back on track, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and the Russian Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, met here tonight in their first conversation since the Kosovo war. They touched on the Balkans, where differences remain, but dwelt more on arms reduction, Iraq and economics.

title: Next Stage of the Cellular Tour; Forced to Compete, Japan Becomes a Global Power
description: One of the nicest things the United States ever did for Japan, it seems, was to force it, kicking and screaming, to open its market for cellular phones.

title: Patterns
description: For Theater, Not Theatrics

title: Concerns in New York Area About Effects of Fuel Additive
description: The gasoline additive M.T.B.E. came into widespread use in and around New York City in 1992, where it is added to gasoline in the fall and winter to improve the burning of fuel in car engines and thus reduce some kinds of pollution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSFIELD, CHARLES F.
description: MANSFIELD-Charles F. Age 77 on July 26, 1999 of Stuart, FL and Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Charrot). Cherished father of Charles, Jr. & Mary Ann, Michael & Margaret, Patricia & Thomas Phelan, Peggy, Elisabeth and Kate. Loving grandfather of Charles, III & Dawn, John & Kathryn Mansfield and Emily Barnett. Dearest great-grandfather of Timothy, Marissa and Kevin Mansfield and Cameron Barnett. Dear brother of Alice M. Lissemore. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 & 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Anne's Church, Garden City, 10 AM Thursday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to Little Flower Children's Services (Wading River, NY 11972) or Discalced Carmelites (1525 Carmel Road, Hubertus, WI 53033) would be appreciated.

title: Judge Rules Internet Gambling Is Not Beyond Reach of State Authorities
description: In a case followed closely by law enforcement agencies across the country, a judge has ruled that New York authorities were justified in freezing the assets of an Internet gambling company, even though the company's computers are based outside the United States.

title: Bronx Shootings Leave 1 Dead and 1 Injured
description: A man in the Bronx shot a woman several times last night, critically injuring her, and then killed himself, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEERR, LILLIAN
description: SHEERR-Lillian The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Lillian Sheerr, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, Pres. Marshall L. Hess, Secy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALL, SHAYNE
description: BALL-Shayne On July 25, 1999. Beloved wife of Leo. Loving mother of David. Dear sister of Sol and Millie Fedderbush. She will be deeply missed. Service Tuesday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Special American Takes Paris
description: The cycling world venerates the Tour de France, a race that generally covers about 2,500 miles, including a climb through mountains that makes this one of the most challenging events in all of sports. Most cyclists live to win even a single segment, or ''stage,'' of the tour. But this year an American wearing the colors of the United States Postal Service led for 14 of the 20 stages and cruised into Paris more than seven minutes ahead of his rivals.

title: Bargain Travelers Trample National Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Physicists Are No Security Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Are the Best Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERHARDT, WILLIAM
description: ERHARDT-William The Board of Directors, Adminstration, Medical Staff and the employees of Trump Pavilion for Nursing and Rehabilitation at the Jamaica Hospital Medical Center note with profound sorrow the passing of our respected President of the Board of Trustees, William Erhardt. His wisdom, determination and dedication to the needs of the elderly will never be replaced. Our sincerest condolences to his wonderful and supportive family. Gregory R. Bradley, Exec. V.P.

title: Lizards With Big Appetite Find Fireflies a Fatal Attraction
description: To call the bearded dragon lizard a voracious eater would be an understatement. It happily consumes most any insect, no matter what the defense mechanism of the prey. It will gobble a cockroach that sprays irritating chemicals, or a moth laden with foul-tasting alkaloids.

title: Boston Settles Lawsuit by Harassed Minority Tenants
description: Resolving a landmark lawsuit over racial harassment by white tenants in public housing projects, the Boston Housing Authority reached a settlement with minority tenants today that Federal officials said could serve as a model for ending a handful of other such suits around the country.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Cutting the Fat for Healthier Companies
description: A new study has found that companies that offer nutrition information and provide healthy food choices in their cafeterias significantly improve the dietary habits of their employees.

title: Madison Avenue sees another spate of deals, including some acquisitions overseas.
description: ANOTHER week, another spate of deals on Madison Avenue.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCTAMNEY, JAMES JOHN.
description: McTAMNEY-James John. Of Central Valley, New York. Beloved husband of Elva, most loving father of John, Noreen, Matthew and Patricia. Adoring grandfather of Joseph & Megan. Loving brother of William. In his 63rd year. Memorial contributions to St. John's Episcopal Church, 58 Clinton Avenue, Cornwall, NY 12518. For information, contact Quackenbush Funeral Home, 117 Maple Avenue, Monroe, New York.

title: Preseason Schedule Is Announced
description: The Knicks announced yesterday an eight-game preseason schedule that includes two meetings with the Nets, two games at Madison Square Garden and a game with the defending champion San Antonio Spurs.

title: Muckler Hires A Former Assistant
description: John Tortorella, who worked under Rangers Coach John Muckler from 1991-95 when both were with the Buffalo Sabres, will rejoin Muckler as an assistant coach with the Rangers this season.

title: Net Up 12% At American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 12 percent as consumers spent more with its signature green charge cards and invested more with its financial planners.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OCEAN ENERGY INC., Houston, which explores for oil and natural gas, agreed to sell stakes in three fields in the Gulf of Mexico to the Newfield Exploration Company for about $66 million in cash to reduce debt.

title: Business Units Fail to Gain More Money
description: The Giuliani administration has denied budget increases to 10 business groups that oversee security, sanitation and other services throughout the city, in an effort to get such organizations to not only tighten their belts but also to rethink their role, a deputy mayor said yesterday.

title: Rogers Says He's Ready For a Start Tomorrow
description: Kenny Rogers threw hard for at least 15 minutes yesterday and proclaimed himself fit to take the mound tomorrow afternoon for his first start as a Met.

title: Ebay Earnings Fell 70% in Second Quarter
description: Ebay Inc., the on-line auction company, said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 70 percent as it spent more to market its Web site and add more staff and computer systems.

title: U.S. Anti-Drug Chief, in Colombia, Speaks of 'Regional Crisis'
description: The Clinton Administration's top anti-narcotics official arrived here today to assess what he described as a deepening regional crisis, one that Latin American governments fear will lead to American intervention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, DOROTHY (NEE MANELOVEG)
description: SACKS-Dorothy (nee Maneloveg) Age 88. On July 26, 1999 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Devoted wife to the late Nathan Sacks. Beloved sister of Bess Simon, Mollie Daktor, the late Simon Maneloveg and Sophie Daktor. Adored aunt to Herbert, Phyllis, Marcia, Steven, Richard, Deanna, Harvey, Sarah and Beverly Green. Loved by nieces & nephews. Stepmother to Annette Friedman and the late Fred Sacks. Burial service 2PM, July 28th at New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens.

title: Hong Kong Businessman Settles S.E.C. Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a $2 million-plus settlement today in a case involving a Hong Kong businessman whom it had accused of illegal insider trading last month in shares of the Omnipoint Corporation, a Bethesda, Md., wireless company.

title: Marguerite W. Cullman, 94, An Investor in Broadway Hits
description: Marguerite W. Cullman, a longtime theatrical investor who was also an author, died yesterday in her apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 94, and her main residence was in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, LEO V.
description: BERGER-Leo V. A giant has fallen. Esteemed client, mentor and good friend, Leo epitomized the ''Horatio Alger'' success story. An immigrant from Hungary, raised in an orphanage, Leo grew to become the largest private owner of U.S. flag ocean-going vessels in the world. A graduate of Cornell Law School and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, Leo was a man of towering and creative intellect who left a mark in the shipping business few have been able to even approach. Fiercely proud of his Jewish heritage and a man of enormous charity, Leo gave for the ''right'' reasons, not merely for honor and awards. A devoted and loving husband, brother, uncle and great uncle, and a friend of utmost loyalty. Deepest condolences to Arvi, Martin, Eva, Fred, Judy, Victor, Phyllis, Capt. John and the members of the extended Berger and Sepe families. May his memory be blessed for eternity. Harvey Schwartz, Esq. Gallet Dreyer & Berkey LLP

title: Woodstock Festival Faces a Bad Hangover; What Began With Peace, Love and Music Ends in Fire, Rampage and Loot
description: For almost three days, Woodstock '99 was exactly what its promoters had hoped for: hundreds of thousands of peaceful young people listening to music under sunny skies, untouched by incident or scandal. The problems that had plagued the 1969 and 1994 Woodstock shows -- hordes of gate crashers, miles of traffic jams, pouring rain and mud -- were gone, as the police monitored local roads like classroom proctors, and storm clouds thundered but steered clear.

title: Champagne on Champs-Elysees? But of Course
description: To the victors belongs the party, and Lance Armstrong and his United States Postal Service teammates got to celebrate in style Sunday night.

title: When M.I.T. Artist Shouts, His 'Painting' Listens
description: Within the art world, Prof. John Maeda, 32, is an anomaly -- a prize-winning graphic designer and kinetic artist with a fistful of engineering degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Watered-Down Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN PLUNGES. Corn fell as some rain in the Midwest eased concern that an earlier dry spell would damage the nation's crop. In Chicago, corn for December delivery fell 8 cents, or 3.6 percent, to $2.165 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ANNETTE WOLFF
description: KATZ-Annette Wolff Of Hollywood, FL and Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved wife and partner of Herbert Katz. Adoring mother of Jame Katz, and Jenne Katz Britell. Sister of Ethel Freeman, proud grandmother of Samantha, Penny, Sandra, Kimberly and Kenneth. Memorial donations would be appreciated to the Herbert and Annette Katz Endowment Fund, Harvard Law School, Baker House, Cambridge, MA 02138. Services were held, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Foreign Affairs; Buy Time, Not Guns
description: I've said it before and I will say it again: Taiwan is a remarkable country. And so much about Taiwan has changed for the better in the past decade. Its politics has changed to a vibrant democracy; its economy is the high-tech envy of Asia. Its media have evolved into the freest in Asia. Yes, so much has changed for Taiwan. There's just one thing that hasn't changed: its geography.

title: Market Place; Seeing Signals From Investors On Year 2000
description: A Treasury bill that matures the first week of January fetched significantly more than one that matures just a week earlier.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS TO BUY PACKAGING BUSINESS FROM ACX
description: The Sonoco Products Company, a leading maker of industrial spools and tubes used in consumer goods, agreed to buy ACX Technologies Inc.'s flexible packaging business for about $105 million in cash, doubling the size of its flexible-packaging operations. Sonoco, based in Hartsville, S.C., said its flexible packaging business and the ACX unit, part of ACX's Graphic Packaging Corporation division, each had 1998 sales of $120 million. ACX is based in Golden, Colo. Sonoco said the purchase enables it to make new products, including bags for the coffee and cookie markets, and enter new markets, such as those for beverage labels and personal care.

title: Timing Tax Cuts for When We Need Them
description: The Federal Government is virtually certain to cut taxes this year, whether it is the smaller reduction the White House supports or the larger one passed this week by the House. Yet, many economists believe that this is not a good time for a Federal tax cut -- at least not one that isn't paid for by spending cuts.

title: By Design; Two-Tone Millennium Bikinis
description: Most summer clothes have already been marked down, but a new shipment of swimsuits, labeled Preview 2000, is in stores now, just in time for August vacations. The newest styles are in two tones or in solid colors with contrasting-color trimming. And the favored style is the bikini.

title: Metro Business; Oxford Ends Its Role In a Medicare Plan
description: Oxford Health Plans will end a risk-sharing arrangement that covered 13,000 members of a Medicare health care plan in New Jersey.

title: Alarm Helps to Fight Domestic Violence
description: In a new adaptation of law enforcement technology, city probation officers in Brooklyn are using electronic bracelets to monitor the whereabouts of domestic violence offenders and to sound an immediate alarm if an offender violates probation by going within 500 feet of a victim's home, the Giuliani administration and the Brooklyn District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Short Positions on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales rose 4.4 percent on the Nasdaq market in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, said yesterday.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Unearthing a Cold Snap

title: Hunting the Hunter at Stalingrad
description: WAR OF THE RATS

title: Accounts
description: * Bell Sports Corp., San Jose, Calif., to Grant, Scott & Hurley, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had been at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: SOCCER: Aches of Satisfaction For the Love of a Game; Women Playing Soccer Because They Want To
description: They were career professionals who were also soccer moms, sideline boosters content to watch smaller versions of themselves scurrying about soccer fields. They did not fit the profile of the typical frustrated jock.

title: Whistles but Not Music From Weis in His Debut
description: At best, Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy was hoping to see a soft touch around the lane, a strong presence on the backboards and the clever passing skills that so many European basketball players possess. At worst, he thought he might see a clumsy Frenchman who was light years of development away from being ready for the National Basketball Association.

title: Man Is Said to Admit 4 Killings in Yosemite
description: A motel handyman who was dismissed as a suspect in the deaths of three tourists last February at Yosemite National Park has confessed to those killings and to the decapitation of a park naturalist last week, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Robot Craft To Cozy Up To Asteroid For Study
description: After nine months of cruising through space testing new technology for future missions, a robot spacecraft with a mind of its own is closing in for a very close encounter with a small asteroid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ARTHUR R.
description: WILSON-Arthur R. Died at his home July 22, 1999. Mr. Wilson was a Phi Beta Capa graduate of Dartmouth College and served in the Marine Corps during the Second World War. He went on to become a founder of the DR Group where he became a recognized leader in the Direct Marketing Industry. He will be missed both by his family and his many friends. There will be no memorial service. Contributions may be made in his memory to: God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10013.

title: New Hospitality: Israeli Deputies Greet Palestinian
description: A few years ago, a photo of Ahmed Qurei, one of the top three Palestinian officials, was splashed on the cover of every Israeli newspaper. It showed him stepping on an Israeli flag during a demonstration, and the image implanted itself in many Israelis' heads.

title: Washington Talk; The Issue May Be Arcane, but Debate Was Heated
description: To hear many Democratic senators today, the very fate of the Senate, if not of the Republic itself, suddenly seemed imperiled.

title: Bulls Sign Brand, The No. 1 Pick
description: The Chicago Bulls signed the former Duke forward Elton Brand, the first pick in this year's National Basketball Association draft, to a three-year, $9.96 million contract.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RALLIES. The euro continued to rise against the dollar on signs that European economies were rebounding. In New York, the euro settled at $1.06540, up from $1.0503 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEEFELD, HERMAN S.
description: BLEEFELD-Herman S. July 26, 1999. Devoted husband of Dorothy. Beloved father of Martin, Rabbi Bradley and Merrie. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Herschel, Marshall and Amy. Loving great grandfather of Benjamin. Services Wednesday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: SEAGRAM TO SELL CONCERTS UNIT TO RESTAURANT OPERATOR
description: The Seagram Company, a leading producer of recorded music, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Universal Concerts unit to House of Blues Entertainment Inc., operator of the namesake theme restaurants, for $190 million in cash and assumed debt. Universal Concerts produces and promotes live concerts and owns and runs 20 live-music venues in the United States and Canada. The sale will also give Seagram warrants to buy as much as 1 percent of House of Blues, which is based in Los Angeles. Seagram said the sale is part of its plan to sell about $1 billion of assets in the next two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, BENEDICT
description: WOLF-Benedict The partners, associates and staff of Wolf Popper LLP mourn the passing of our esteemed founding partner, mentor and friend, Benedict Wolf. Benedict Wolf was a founder of Wolf Popper LLP (formerly Wolf Popper Ross Wolf & Jones) in 1945. His wisdom guided the firm for more than 50 years. Mr. Wolf was an innovator in the field of securities class actions. Prior to founding Wolf Popper LLP, Mr. Wolf was the first Secretary and Chief Trial Examiner of the National Labor Relations Board. He was married to his beloved Miriam for more than 65 years until her passing in 1995. Mr. Wolf embodied the best qualities of the legal profession: a keen mind, compassion and commitment. Benedict Wolf was a gentleman and a scholar. We will remember him always with great fondness. The Partners of Wolf Popper LLP

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an exhibition at Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton, N.Y., on architecture from the 1960's misspelled the surname of an architect whose work is on view. He was Paul Lester Wiener, not Weiner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, MARTHA ELOISE REYNOLDS
description: LAWLER-Martha Eloise Reynolds On July 23, 1999 in New York City. Devoted wife of the late T. Newman Lawler, beloved mother of Ann Dewey and Lisa Schiff & mother-in-law of Thomas Dewey and David Schiff, loving grandmother of Thomas, Elizabeth and George Dewey, and Andrew, Scott and Ashley Schiff, & great grandmother of Frances D. Dewey and Wyatt G. Schiff. Funeral services and interment private at the Washington Irving Memorial Chapel at the Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow NY. on July 30. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62 St, NY 10021 or Bide-A-Wee, 410 East 38 Street, New York 10016.

title: Mexican Opposition Runs Its Own Clean Election
description: The opposition party that made its reputation by denouncing skulduggery has shown, on the second try, that it can hold a clean election of its own.

title: Weakness in Technology Hurts Shares
description: Stocks moved broadly lower yesterday, led by big technology and Internet issues, as concerns about the sudden drop in the dollar and a possible future increase in interest rates provided an excuse to take profits.

title: Students Are the Best Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BANC ONE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, named Richard J. Lehmann to head commercial banking and asset management operations, succeeding David Vitale, who will retire Nov. 1. Mr. Lehmann is now head of Banc One's credit card, retail and auto finance arms.

title: Next Stage of the Cellular Tour; As Europe Zooms Ahead, U.S. Fiddles With Formats
description: After 24 years as lead singer for the Leningrad Cowboys, Finland's most popular home-grown rock band, Mato Valtonen figured it was time for something new.

title: Bargain Travelers Trample National Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Ledee Makes His Case To Start in Left Field
description: Sometimes, Ricky Ledee is so desperate to show the Yankees that he can play left field neatly that he almost collides with Bernie Williams pursuing fly balls that are clearly the center fielder's plays. Sometimes, Ledee is so anxious to make up for a failed sacrifice bunt that he flails at a pitch and strikes out. He was guilty of both types of mistakes on Sunday.

title: Under Scrutiny: Citibank's Handling Of High-Profile Foreigners' Accounts
description: Two Congressional investigations, set off from different starting points, are examining Citibank and the confidential world of private banking, a growing and highly lucrative service.

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, VINCENT F. (BUD)
description: FOSTER-Vincent F. (Bud) of New Rochelle, N.Y., on July 24, 1999. Husband of Madeleine. Father of Cathleen, Michael and Nicholas. Grandfather of eight. Brother of Grace, Peggy, and the late Mary. Husband of the late Gloria. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Sons Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale on Wednesday, July 28th at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made Iona Prep Alumni Fund, New Rochelle, New York.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Housecleaning And History Cross

title: A Fungus to Kill Marijuana Has Environmentalists Wary
description: For decades, the hard part for drug agents stalking Florida's marijuana growers was finding their crop. The growers weave their plants among corn stalks and even tomato vines to foil aerial searches. In swamps, growers make berms out of muck and chicken wire and plant their crop, leaving fat, black water moccasins to stand guard.

title: Steinbrenner Cheers From the Bronx to Queens
description: George Steinbrenner watched New York's wonderful baseball weekend unfold on the television screen while he relaxed on his horse farm in Florida. He saw the Yankees draw 162,518 fans to Yankee Stadium and sweep three games from the Cleveland Indians. He saw the Mets attract 147,809 fans to Shea Stadium and swipe three games from the Chicago Cubs. Steinbrenner was clearly smiling. He really was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, ALBERT
description: GROSSMAN-Albert Bnos Israel School for Girls extends heartfelt condolences to our devoted grandparent Harriet Muss on the passing of her beloved father, Albert Grossman, a worthy and respected member of the Jewish community. May she and all the members of her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may they know of sorrow no more. Reb. N.D. Groner, Dean Mr. E. Feuer, President Rabbi Boruch L. Barnetsky, Administrator

title: ERGO RECOMMENDS EFG BID
description: Greece's sixth-largest bank by assets, the Ergo Bank S.A., advised shareholders to accept the Geneva-based EFG Bank Group's offer to buy a controlling stake, dealing a blow to a bid by the Bank of Piraeus S.A. to win control of Ergo. The bank's management reversed an earlier decision to recommend Piraeus's offer after EFG raised its offer two weeks ago. Separately, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi will buy a stake worth as much as 35 billion drachmas ($113 million) in the Bank of Piraeus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, EDWARD R.
description: GREGORY-Edward R. Of Montclair, NJ on July 25, 1999 at age seventy-seven. Beloved husband of Cecelia Dohen Gregory. Father of Joseph of Manhattan, Edward of Mendham, New Jersey, and Daniel of Ridgewood, NJ, Judith Gregory Pierce of Ballston Spa, New York, Elizabeth Gregory of Decatur, GA, Sheila McMenamin of Bernardsville, NJ, Mary Gregory Suminski of Hummelstown, PA, Jane Dwyer of Strafford, PA and seventeen grandchildren. Brother of Joan Gregory Franks of Malverne, NY, Agnes Nevin of East Goshen, PA., and Audrey Hagemaier of Roscoe, NY. Friends may call at the Moriarity Funeral Home, Montclair, NJ on Wednesday, July 28th, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:30 AM Thursday at St. Cassian's RC Church, 187 Bellevue Ave, Upper Montclair, NJ. Burial will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mount Pleasant, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Augustinian Foreign Missions, P.O. Box 340, Villanova, PA. 19085.

title: Oil Scorecard: Texaco Drops, ARCO Soars
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings fell 15 percent as profits on gasoline sales plunged. At the same time, though, rising pump prices in California made ARCO the only major United States oil company to have higher earnings in the period.

title: Cruise Officials to Report Accusations of Crimes at Sea
description: Cruise-ship industry officials said today that the industry had developed for the first time a uniform standard requiring that all reports of crimes on board ships be relayed to law-enforcement authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, CLARA (NEE HORNIK)
description: GROSSMAN-Clara (nee Hornik) Age 96. On July 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Murray Grossman, sister of Mack, Sidney, and the late Charles Hornik. Dearly beloved aunt and great aunt. Services Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel at 11:30AM Tuesday, July 27. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAZZOLA, BENJAMIN
description: GAZZOLA-Benjamin On July 25, 1999. Beloved brother of Bridget (Philip) Greco. Devoted uncle of Philip and Richard (Maria). Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Epiphany R.C. Church, is on Wednesday, 11 A.M. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery.

description: S.E.C. Chief Says Markets Must Maintain Regulation

description: Snakes in Water

description: To the Editor:

title: Clintons' Vacation Will Include Five Days Near the Finger Lakes
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have added a second New York stop to their summer vacation schedule: five days in the state's Finger Lakes region, White House officials said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There was looting and lots of damage -- but not to anyone's tents. As riots go, it was a very friendly riot.''

title: PHILIPS INVESTS IN KOREA
description: In what is being called the biggest foreign investment in South Korea, Royal Philips Electronics announced completion of a $1.6 billion investment in a joint venture with the liquid-crystal-display unit of LG Group. Phillips said the venture would significantly improve its ability to make high-quality flat panel displays used in desktop and laptop computers and consumer electronics. Such displays have been in short supply. Stephanie Strom

title: Elliott Gets Court Delay And Will Play in Opener
description: Jumbo Elliott's court date was postponed until Sept. 13, so the Jets' most experienced offensive lineman will be on hand for the season opener against the New England Patriots.

title: BIOVAIL TO BUY FUISZ TECHNOLOGIES FOR $154 MILLION
description: The Biovail Corporation International agreed yesterday to acquire Fuisz Technologies Ltd. for $154 million in cash and stock. It will also assume debt of $91 million. Toronto-based Biovail develops and makes time-release versions of existing oral drugs for treating chronic conditions such as hypertension and arthritis. It earned $45.4 million on revenue of $112.8 million in 1998. Fuisz, based in Chantilly, Va., focuses on oral drug delivery, including rapid-dissolving and controlled-release technology. It lost $23.6 million on revenue of $61.2 million in 1998. The transaction, which values Fuisz's stock at about $7 a share, will expand Biovail's pipeline of products and drug delivery platforms, the company said. Fuisz's stock rose 37.5 cents a share, to $6.0625.

title: Discord Undermines Efforts to Repair and Build Public Schools
description: A fire that was touched off by a welder working in a Brooklyn vocational school briefly trapped 150 students last year. The construction work was not supposed to begin until school was done for the day, but school administrators and construction officials could not agree on when classes were actually over.

title: Chairman of Adelphi's Trustees Is Appointed Interim President
description: Adelphi University's trustees appointed their chairman today as interim president while they seek a permanent successor to Dr. Matthew Goldstein, who has resigned to become the Chancellor of the City University of New York.

title: Perspective on Fiber
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubt Is Cast on Goal of 100,000 Officers
description: A Justice Department audit released today found that the Clinton Administration was likely to fall far short of one of its central anti-crime goals: bringing to 100,000 the number of new police officers hired around the country under a special Federal program promoted by the President.

title: Some Still Despair in a Prozac Nation
description: Nadine McGann is thinking very hard, but she cannot remember the last time that she felt joy, or happiness, or even simple pleasure.

title: Helping Churches Help
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Gaps in Treating Asthma

title: Confessions Are Reported In 4 Killings
description: A motel handyman who was dismissed as a suspect in the deaths of three sightseers last February at Yosemite National Park has confessed to the decapitation of a park naturalist last week and to the other three killings, according to an F.B.I. affidavit and to an official involved in the case.

title: Team of Scientists to Prepare a Rolodex of Life on Earth
description: A group of countries has decided to prepare ''the equivalent of a world telephone book of life on earth,'' a project that promises to revolutionize the study of biology and influence international environmental policy.

title: Something's Glittering Among the Leathers at Coach
description: Customers are in for some surprises when Coach opens its redesigned flagship in September at the high-profile corner of 57th Street and Madison Avenue. Oh, there will still be bags, but there will also be leather jackets and pants, shoes, watches, bracelets, scarves, hats, luggage and furniture. And the bags won't be only Coach's familiar sporty shoulder bags, but sleek clutches and small-handle styles, some in shiny leather and others in fabrics and exotic skins like python and alligator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARYSH, GERTRUDE (NEE KATSH)
description: BARYSH-Gertrude (nee Katsh) On Saturday, July 24, in Palm City, Florida. Formerly of NYC, New Milford, CT, and Jamesburg, NJ. Beloved wife of 60 years of Dr. Noah Barysh, and devoted mother of Alan Barysh of Baltimore, MD, and daughter Ann Barysh and sonin-law Steven Swanger of Sudbury, MA, grandmother of Gabriel and Rebecca Swanger and loving aunt. Services Tuesday, July 27, at 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St. Donations in her memory may be made to Temple Beit Hayem, 3715 SE Ocean Blvd, Suite 103, Stuart, FL.

title: In Morocco, Too, a Young King for a New Generation
description: King Mohammed VI of Morocco, the latest Arab prince to be thrust into kingship, has long been regarded here as something of an enigma, little known even to his future subjects, and only recently allowed to share the public spotlight. Yet the 36-year-old appears to have ascended smoothly to the throne, the third young Arab leader to take power in six months.

title: Kosovo's Incomplete Peace
description: The ambush murder of 14 Serbian farmers in the Kosovo village of Gracko last week is a grim sign that six and a half weeks after the first NATO soldiers began entering the province, basic security has not yet been established. With the international peacekeeping force now nearing full strength, NATO's first order of business must be creating a climate of civil peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, MARTIN
description: GINSBURG-Martin, 85. Of Miami, FL, passed away on Sunday, July 25th, 1999. He is survived by his loving wife, Natalie (Bobbie), his son, Allan Ginsburg, his daughter, Bonnie Levy, and daughter-in-law, Carolyn Ginsburg. He is also survived by his eight grandchildren, Ashley, Gregory, Jamie, Jeffrey, Kenny, Robyn, Sherri, and Stephanie; in addition to their spouses, Melissa Ginsburg & Keith Zucker. Also surviving are three greatgrandchildren, Eric, Mitchell and Ryan. He is also survived by his brother, Abe Ginsburg, and his wife, Sylvia, and their family. He was involved in many charitable causes. We would like to mention just a few. He was involved in the Byalstoker Home for the Aged in New York City. In Israel he created the Martin Ginsburg High School of Yavne and the Ginsburg Youth Center in Tiberias in addition to three additional kindergartens. He was also involved in Technion in Israel & was a founder of the Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was a true gentleman among men & an inspiration to his family and will be missed by all who had the good fortune to know him. Funeral services will be held Thursday, July 29th, at 12 Noon, Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. The Family

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the front page of Business Day yesterday about the coming debut of Talk magazine misidentified the man standing to the left of the magazine's editor, Tina Brown. He is David Kuhn, the executive editor, not Ronald A. Galotti, the publisher.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Martin Agronsky, 84, Leader Of Early News-Panel Program
description: Martin Agronsky, a veteran broadcast news correspondent who worked for all three major networks and PBS, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 84.

title: U.S. Earmarks $500 Million for Kosovo
description: President Clinton's national security adviser said today that the United States would pledge up to $500 million in relief aid for Kosovo at a conference in Brussels this week.

title: On Night Music Died, Many to Blame for Mayhem
description: Let's begin with the ''how'' before we get to the ''why.''

title: Erotic Twist for a Baroque Enchantress
description: If Robert Carsen is being hailed as a fresh young face on the European opera scene, it may have more to do with his new kudos and boyish features than his age and experience. His acclaimed, sexy new production of Handel's ''Alcina'' at the Paris National Opera is proof enough of his talent, but it took him 13 years to break into the business and another decade to reach the top. Now 45, the soft-spoken Canadian stage director is not exactly a youngster.

title: NTL to Buy Cable and Wireless Unit in $13 Billion Deal
description: NTL Inc. moved to become the biggest cable-television company in Britain today with a $13 billion deal to buy the consumer divisions of Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C.

title: Quick Draw Wins Again In Albany
description: FOR all the wrong reasons, Albany managed to get it right. That's what State Senator Frank Padavan of Queens figured four months ago when Quick Draw, the keno-style game that the Senator once termed ''video crack,'' faded unexpectedly into oblivion.

title: Finding Value in Intensive Care, From Afar
description: Staff members in hospital intensive-care units sometimes joke that the best time to be a patient is during business hours. Otherwise, they say, doctors may be scarce.

title: Jersey City Mayor Warns of Layoffs Without $27.5 Million More in State Aid
description: Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City warned yesterday that he would have to lay off most of the city's civilian employees unless the city gets an additional $27.5 million in state aid for the current fiscal year.

title: The Taylor Clan Takes Durham by Storm
description: Paul Taylor and his engaging company danced into Durham like conquering heros in what could easily have been designated Paul Taylor Week in this hometown of the American Dance Festival. Everywhere one went, it seemed, there were public lectures about and by Mr. Taylor. ''Dancemaker,'' Matthew Diamond's recent documentary about the modern-dance choreographer and his troupe, could be seen at several theaters around town. And then there were the performances at Page Auditorium at Duke University, the home of the summer dance festival.

title: Fondly Bickering 'Until We Are Dead'
description: In his years as a drama critic, George Bernard Shaw became enchanted with one of the London theater's most temperamental actresses, Mrs. Patrick Campbell. He saw her in several plays, described her in his reviews as ''wonderful'' and, sitting in the darkened theater audience, fell in love with her.

title: Strategies Stymied, Umpires Sue Leagues
description: With its resignation strategy encountering opposition from within and a stonewalling response from without, the umpires' union went to court yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEER, SYLVIA GALIN
description: SCHNEER-Sylvia Galin January 27, 1932-July 27, 1979. Beloved Mom. Much loved and much missed. I keep you close. Be with us, now and always, in heart, mind, spirit and deed. Debora

title: Year's First Baby? On Whose Watch?
description: Earlier this year, some obstetricians said that April 9 was the prime date for couples hoping to conceive the first baby born on Jan. 1, 2000.

title: Call Me Rosebud: A Whale Of a Tale
description: Wrestling with great white whales is neither a humble nor a risk-free sport. As a manual on the subject called ''Moby-Dick'' points out, the activity requires obsession, determination and the sort of gods-defying arrogance of which tragedies are made. These are, of course, traits identified with Herman Melville's vengeful Captain Ahab; they also apply to Orson Welles, the brilliant director and actor who decided with Ahabian hubris to put ''Moby-Dick'' on a London stage in the mid-1950's.

title: Crowded Ballot in Memphis Will Test a Family's Power
description: Having amassed a campaign fund of more than $500,000 and having won his last race with 74 percent of the vote, Willie Herenton, the first black Mayor in this predominantly black city, might seem to have little to worry about in his run for a third term.

title: When The Brain's Mailbox Is Full
description: Memory lapses in older people may signal that a mailbox of memory is full rather than that the brain fails to process information, a new study on memory suggests.

title: Power Failure on Staten Island Leaves 4,000 Homes in the Dark
description: More than 4,000 homes on Staten Island were without power last night as the region's latest heat wave pressed on relentlessly.

title: Ship Cove Journal; A Son of the Land Stands Up for Birds of the Sea
description: The thought of escaping this sweet and miserable land has long tempted Stan Tobin. Once or twice over the years he has even slipped off to Ireland -- where his brogue makes him sound home-grown -- with no intention of coming back.

title: Forum in Asia Raises the Heat On North Korea Over Missiles
description: SINGAPORE  Foreign ministers from Asia, the Pacific and Europe warned Monday that North Korea's ballistic missile program was a threat to regional stability and could create a new crisis in Asia.

title: The Rural Life; High Grass
description: This has been a rare grass year in parts of north-central Wyoming, in the drainages east of the Bighorn Mountains. As one rancher put it, ''you couldn't have dialed the rains in better.'' The rain fell, the grass grew, the sun came out, the grass cured, and in the early weeks of July there was a kind of tonsorial fever on the hayground watered by Piney Creek, Clear Creek and Prairie Dog Creek -- men and women neatly scissoring the grass with machine-driven sickle blades. The windrows, long lines of cut grass drying in the sun, stood almost laughably high. If all the profits of ranching lay in good grass instead of the vagaries of the cattle market, these ranchers would have been rich, their prosperity numbered in round bales, square bales and enormous loaves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PYKA, WILLIAM C. MD
description: PYKA-William C. MD. 90. Of New York and Huntington, L.I., died Saturday, July 24, 1999 at Huntington Hospital. Husband of the late Aida Pyka. Survived by his second wife, Wanda Wolinska, brother Stas Pyka, daughters Monika Dillon and Yola Carlough, son Marek, daughter-in-law Deborah, son-in-law Brian Dillon, four grandchildren and one great grandchild. Dr. Pyka was a pathologist and surgeon in Europe and a longtime practitioner in Family Medicine in New York. He was a Trustee of the Alfred Jurzykowski Foundation. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences New York would be deeply appreciated. Visiting at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington, Tuesday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Funeral mass Wednesday 9:45AM at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, 400 Main St, Huntington. Burial at St. Charles cemetery, Pinelawn.

title: Serenity Countered by Ritual Drumming
