description: The Korean choreographer and dancer Sun Ock Lee has lived in the United States since 1969. Yet she often returns to the source, drawing new inspiration in Korea from a range of traditions, artists and acolytes.

title: A BANK'S INDONESIA FOOTHOLD
description: Standard Chartered P.L.C. agreed to pay $123 million for a 20 percent stake in Bank Bali, more than doubling an earlier bid and becoming the first foreign bank to win control of a local bank under Indonesia's financial-system bailout. Standard Chartered said in April it would pay $56 million for the Bank Bali stake. But after examining Bank Bali's books, Standard Chartered and Indonesia's bank-restructuring authorities agreed that the cost of rescuing the bank had risen. Earlier this month, Standard Chartered's $162 million bid to take over Nakornthon Bank of Thailand was set back when the Bangkok took over the bank instead and invited higher offers. Wayne Arnold

title: Bargain Travelers Trample National Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Eyes at Risk, as the Blades Whirl
description: Each year 230,000 to 400,000 people are sent to emergency rooms because of lawn mowing accidents, with the majority of injuries occurring in the eyes, the American Academy of Ophthalmology reports.

title: Brokerage Chief Hired at E*Trade
description: E*Trade Group Inc., the Internet brokerage firm, hired Frank J. Petrilli, president and chief operating officer of TD Waterhouse Group Inc., to run its brokerage business.

title: Larry Kent, 86, Marketer of N.F.L. Merchandise
description: Larry Kent, who as the first president of NFL Properties, the licensing and marketing arm of the National Football League, lived to see it grow from gross revenue of $36,647 in 1963 to $3 billion in 1998, died July 14 in his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86.

title: Reed's Victory Won't Insure Another Start
description: With 9 victories in 12 decisions this season, Rick Reed has easily the highest winning percentage of any of the Mets' starting pitchers. But after his performance in last night's 7-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates at Shea Stadium, Reed said he thought that Manager Bobby Valentine might drop him from the rotation in the wake of Kenny Rogers's arrival.

title: FUGITIVE SELLS STAKE
description: The buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. gained control of an Argentine cable and media company, CEI Citicorp Holdings S.A., after acquiring $125 million of shares from a fugitive executive, Raul Moneta. Hicks, Muse acquired 39 million shares, or about 8 percent, from Mr. Moneta's companies to increase its stake to 41 percent. There had been speculation that the Dallas-based buyout firm would buy control to help put management back on track while Mr. Moneta sorted out his legal affairs.

title: Big Home Movers in Talks
description: The British moving company NFC P.L.C. said today that it was in talks to sell its worldwide moving-services business, Allied Pickford, to North American Van Lines. Allied Pickford, one of the best-known names among British home movers, operates in North America as Allied Van Lines. It had revenue in 1998 of $105.9 million. The sale would make North American Van Lines, based in Fort Wayne, Ind., one of the biggest moving companies in the world. North American Van Lines is privately held.

title: Africa and Cuba Meet in a Melody
description: The term ''Afro-Cuban'' is used liberally about a lot of new-world popular music, but Sam Mangwana's show on Thursday night, part of Lincoln Center's Midsummer Night Swing series, had a more direct subtext about the crossing of Africa and Cuba. It was presented under the banner of a tribute to Franco, the Congolese band leader who died 10 years ago and was the foremost practitioner of the Congolese rumba. Mr. Mangwana, also from the Republic of Congo, was a hugely popular singer in Franco's group in the 1970's, and since that time has furthered Franco's idea of Cubanizing Congolese music.

title: Giuliani Adviser Defends His Role
description: Since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office in 1994, one of his closest advisers, Raymond B. Harding, has come under criticism for working as a lobbyist on matters before the city administration.

title: Most School Boards Oversee Their Own Projects
description: The construction pressures bearing down on the New York City public schools are hardly unique.

title: TRUCKERS DISRUPT BRAZIL ROADS
description: Traffic was slowed on many major Brazilian roads by the beginning of a one-week strike by truckers demanding lower tolls and better protection against cargo thieves. Throughout the country, truckers formed convoys and parked their rigs alongside highways, snarling traffic. Their protest reflected the resentment of some in Brazil over privatization -- a sentiment that gained force after concessions for several important roads were sold to private companies, which raised tolls. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, EDNA (NEE GREENBURG)
description: MENDELSON-Edna (nee Greenburg) On July 25, 1999, in Lauderhill, Florida. Devoted wife of Ralph, step mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, and aunt.

title: Raul Mangalpus, 80, Dies; Power in Post-Marcos Era
description: Raul S. Manglapus, the former Philippine Foreign Secretary who embodied his country's mixture of defiance and love for the United States, died on Sunday. He was 80.

title: Out-of-It, Arrogant And a Salsa Legend
description: As musical biography, Pablo Cabrera's musical revue ''Quien Mato a Hector Lavoe?'' is a frustration. The first line of the program notes inform you that the musical is ''a product of the imagination,'' though the outline of his real personal and professional life remains more or less intact.

title: When Stock Markets Go Public
description: The financial world is changing rapidly, with advances in technology making it much easier for competitors to challenge established stock markets such as the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq. It is in part because those markets need money to invest in new technology to meet that competition that both of them are now planning to sell shares to the public.

title: Transported To Other Worlds
description: The board of Glimmerglass Opera took a calculated risk when it decided that Paul Kellogg's appointment as general manager of the New York City Opera would not conflict with his duties here as the artistic director of Glimmerglass, and that productions that began here could be shown at City Opera as well. If the productions would be seen in New York, they must have wondered, would audiences continue to flock to Glimmerglass?

title: Dumping of Tainted Silt In Ocean Is Drawing Fire
description: New Jersey environmentalists and elected officials asked Federal regulators yesterday to deny permission for a Queens fuel oil company to dump contaminated silt into the ocean four miles off Sandy Hook.

title: Jiang Zemin Shows His True Colors
description: We had many questions when we heard that the Chinese Government had outlawed Falun Gong, the faith-healing sect led by a Chinese guru living in New York, and detained thousands of its members last week. These events made us wonder: Jiang Zemin, what are you doing? What is happening in China?

title: JAPAN RAILWAY SHARES
description: Japan Railway Construction fixed an offering price of $5,594 each for one million shares in the East Japan Railway Company to raise $5.59 billion. Japan Railway Construction oversees disposal of the assets of Japan National Railway, which was privatized and divided into six rail companies in 1987. East Japan Railway is the largest of the six. Of the shares to be sold, 800,000 will be offered to investors at home and 200,000 to those overseas. The Government will still own 12.5 percent.

title: The Vote That Changed America
description: Twenty-five years ago today, the House Judiciary Committee, of which I was chairman, approved the first article of impeachment against President Richard Nixon. As I cast the final ''aye'' vote, I was keenly aware that we, Democrats and Republicans alike, had taken a momentous step in the political life our nation.

title: TRAVEL PROFIT DROPS
description: Britain's biggest package-tour operator, Thomson Travel Group P.L.C., said that its pretax profit dropped in the first half as competition ate into earnings and that its chief executive, Paul Brett, was leaving the company. The shares tumbled 11.5 percent. Thomson said it had reduced prices of vacations booked in May as the war in Kosovo and ''terrorist threats'' in Turkey deterred travelers.

title: You Take a Pitcher, You Take a Gamble
description: Looking for a pitcher to get you to the playoffs? Check out this classified ad that emanates from the West Coast:

title: CHINESE OFFICIALS HELD IN CAMPAIGN AGAINST VAST SECT
description: As part of an expanding political campaign that could affect China's economic reforms, Chinese authorities have detained about 1,200 government officials who are members of Falun Gong, the spiritual movement that was officially outlawed last week, a human rights group reported today.

title: Last New York Checker Turns Off Its Meter for Good
description: The last day of the last Checker cab in New York should have been full of nostalgia and romance, the storied retirement of a much-loved machine integral to the city's lore and lure.

title: FORD STRIKERS EXPAND PROTEST
description: About 1,500 workers at the Ford Motor Company's truck factory outside Sao Paulo pressed forward their strike for a fifth day. The employees, who are protesting Ford's plan to close the factory and transfer production to another site, also occupied an area in front of Government offices in downtown Sao Paulo. Unions are calling on Government officials to protect jobs in southern Brazil at a time Ford is planning to build a car factory in the country's poor northeastern region with Government incentives. Simon Romero

title: COMPASS BANCSHARES TO BUY WESTERN FOR $88 MILLION
description: Compass Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Western Bancshares Inc. for about $88 million in stock, entering the New Mexico banking market. Western has $285 million in assets and nine branches in Albuquerque, N.M. Compass, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., has $17.3 billion in assets and operates 293 offices in Texas, Florida, Arizona and Alabama. Last month, Compass said it would buy Hartland Bank N.A. for $85 million in cash to strengthen its banking network in Texas.

title: House Spenders Look for Bookkeeping Magic
description: Critical elements in the House Republican strategy to pass big domestic spending bills became clear tonight: a little smoke, a few well-placed mirrors and, presto, billions of dollars.

title: Can Serb Opposition Force Milosevic Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: Daewoo Is Given a New Set of Loans
description: Creditors of Daewoo Group released fresh loans today to the company, South Korea's second-largest conglomerate, and the central bank said it was ready to support financial markets in an attempt to avert the nation's biggest bankruptcy.

title: The Aged as an Inconvenience
description: My mother, almost 96 years old, has dementia and lives in a nursing home.

title: Astronomers Adopt Doomsday Index
description: To help deal with public fascination -- and sometimes undue alarm -- about possible threats from asteroids, astronomers have adopted a scale that rates the likelihood that a particular asteroid or comet will collide with Earth.

title: Often Overlooked, a Heart Disorder Puts Many at Great Risk
description: During a routine physical, a 75-year-old patient named Joseph was surprised to learn that his pulse was highly irregular: 50 beats one minute, 140 the next, seemingly without provocation. He was surprised because, he said, he felt fine and hadn't noticed any symptoms, except for three brief, isolated periods of complete lethargy that had occurred over three months.

title: Internet Stock Fever Spreads to Britain as Freeserve's Issue Surges
description: Freeserve P.L.C., the British upstart that radically changed Internet competition here by offering customers free access to the World Wide Web, transformed itself into a $3.3 billion company today by selling shares to the public.

title: Far More Poor Children Are Hospitalized for Asthma, Study Shows
description: In the first study of its kind of the nation's urban asthma epidemic, researchers have found the rate of hospitalization from the disease far greater among children in poor, predominantly minority neighborhoods of New York City than experts suspected.

title: Getting Rid of the Body Is Only Half the Problem
description: Ideas swarm like fireflies through ''The Brave,'' by the Scottish playwright Sharman Macdonald. But flashing and dying, they never cohere long enough to cast more than fitful light on the human condition or the play's particular characters.

title: What Could Go Wrong? It's His Job to Know
description: JERRY HAUER, to put it bluntly, likes guts. Meaning viscera, innards, the stuff things are made of.

title: Vargas Is Facing Assault Charges
description: Fernando Vargas, a 1996 United States Olympian who is the International Boxing Federation junior middleweight champion, and four of his friends were arrested Sunday and charged in the beating of a man at a Summerland, Calif., apartment.

title: S.E.C. Head Warns Markets Over Proposals to Go Public
description: The nation's top stock-market regulator warned the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market yesterday that any proposal to convert themselves to for-profit public companies must adequately provide for self-regulation that is ''zealous, adequately funded, and imbued with the public interest.''

title: GARTNER GROUP TO BUY BACK UP TO 15.7 MILLION SHARES
description: Gartner Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back up to 15.7 million of its common shares for between $21 and $24 each in a Dutch auction. In such an auction, the company establishes a price range, and holders specify prices within that range at which they are willing to sell their shares. The lowest price at which the company can acquire all the shares it wants becomes the purchase price. Gartner, an information technology concern based in Stamford, Conn., said it would buy up to 9.6 million class A common shares and 6.1 million class B common shares. Gartner's class A shares were up 75 cents at $22.75, and the class B shares were up $2.375 at $24.

title: Full of Wiles, Coyotes Prove Near Invincible
description: By American Indian tradition, he is the Trickster, the most cunning but also the most flawed and human of animal spirits. Noble and godlike in some ways, he is also perverse, vain, deceitful, larcenous, obsessed with sex, and a lover of pranks who repeatedly blunders into trouble and gets his comeuppance, but always bounces back.

title: Housing Data, New Offerings Cool Demand For Treasuries
description: Bond prices fell for a fourth session as record home resales and more than $22.5 billion of expected debt offerings by borrowers including Allied Waste Industries reduced demand for Treasuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, BATHSHEVA
description: FINKELSTEIN-Bathsheva The Officers, members and staff of The American Jewish Committee extend heartelt condolences to our friend and esteemed colleague, Jaime Kelstein, on the passing of his beloved mother, Bathsheva Finkelstein. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Bruce M. Ramer, Pres. David A. Harris, Exec. Dir.

title: Watered-Down Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILKES, ARTHUR G.
description: GILKES-Arthur G. Died on July 25, 1999 in Chicago, Illinois. The former Manager of Patents & Licensing and General Patent Attorney for Standard Oil of Indiana (Amoco) is survived by his wife, Ann Buckley Fullan Gilkes, four children, Arthur Gwyer Gilkes, Jr., of Pittsburgh, PA, Ann Colwell Gilkes Liu, of Chicago, IL, Judith Porter Gilkes Benson, of Newtown, CT, Jane Scott Gilkes Strassguetl, of Munich, Germany; and eight grandchildren. In addition, his sisters, Jocelyn Dittman of Syracuse, NY, Mary Louise Hickler of Venice, FL, and Frances Bowne, of Marblehead, MA, survive him. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's By-the-Sea, Northeast Harbor, Maine on Thursday, August 5, 1999.

title: Olympic Committee Settles on TBWA
description: The International Olympic Committee said yesterday that it had selected offices of TBWA Worldwide in New York, part of Omnicom Group, to create a global campaign to promote the Olympic Games.

title: Davis, No. 3 Pick, Gets a Contract
description: The Charlotte Hornets signed the former U.C.L.A. guard Baron Davis, the third pick in last month's draft, to a three-year contract.

title: Can Serb Opposition Force Milosevic Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Build Abs of Undulating Steel
description: Belly dancing has its place in dimly lit clubs, thick with incense and the beat of drums. But it is certainly not what you expect to find in an urban gym. In fact, though, you can. Both Equinox and New York Health and Racquet Club in New York have started belly dancing programs, tailoring the dance into a legitimate workout. In fact, said Judy Taylor, the director of public relations for Equinox Fitness Clubs, ''Any kind of ethnic dance is catching on nationally.''

title: San Francisco Lets AT&T Bar Cable Access to Rivals
description: In the latest skirmish of what has become a national fight, the Board of Supervisors here declined tonight to compel AT&T to open its cable television system to competing providers of high-speed Internet access like America Online.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Robinson Can't Carry The Liberty In Overtime
description: When their would-be savior, Crystal Robinson, turned human, the rest of the Liberty players reverted to wandering around the court last night, resembling children waiting for mother to pick them up from school.

title: Doctors' Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; From Earth To the Moon By Bicycle
description: FROM this Tour de France, we asked for the moon; it gave us Armstrong,'' wrote the French journalist Claude Droussent, in this week's issue of L'Equipe magazine. He referred, of course, to Lance Armstrong, the heart-emboldening and heartbreaking winner of the world's great bike race, completed Sunday afternoon in Paris, under the shading trees along the Champs-Elysees.

title: Like Father, Like Son?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Suspect at Yosemite Had Fantasy of Killing Women
description: He said he had dreamed of killing women for 30 years before he found his moment this February, when a middle-aged woman and two teen-agers on a sightseeing trip to Yosemite National Park happened to take a room at the motel where he worked as a janitor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SRERE, DR. PAUL A. DR.
description: SRERE-Dr. Paul A. Dr. Paul A. Srere, internationally known and honored scientist and professor, died on July 11 in Dallas, Tx. Dr. Srere was 73. For the past 33 years he had been associated with the University of Texas Southwestern Medical School and the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Dallas where he was Director of Basic Research. He is survived by his loving wife of 46 years, Oz; three daughters, E.A. Srere and Margot Srere of Dallas, and Dr. Hillary Srere of Montara, California; a son, Mark Srere of Washington, D.C., four grandchildren, his sister, Mrs. Sonia S. Sweeney of Los Angeles and brother, Benson M. Srere of Greenwich, Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column on July 20 about the initial public offering of Mp3.Com, an Internet music company, misidentified one of the company's major investors. It is Cox Interactive Media, not David Easterly, who is chief executive of Cox Enterprises, the parent company of Cox Interactive.

title: Deal for Bagel Maker
description: New World Coffee-Manhattan Bagel Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Chesapeake Bagel Bakery from AFC Enterprises of Atlanta for an undisclosed amount. New World, a cafe franchiser and operator based here, said the deal would add 89 Chesapeake franchised stores to its Manhattan Bagel system, bringing the total to 365 stores in 23 states, many in the mid-Atlantic region.

title: On Pro Football; Sanders May Step Away As the Lions Step Back
description: David Ware, an agent for the reclusive and elusive Detroit Lions running back Barry Sanders, was talking in a phone conversation last month about the likelihood of Sanders ''walking in when July and training camp roll around and saying: 'That's it. Enough.' See, Barry doesn't play football for the money or the glory. I'm telling you, Barry might, just might, shock the world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLT, ERWIN ISAAC
description: ZOLT-Erwin Isaac, 82. Of Boynton Beach, died July 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Esther, devoted father to Nina, Miles, Rhonda, Glen and Eric. Endearing grandfather to Amy, Jessica and Sarah. Brother to Marvin, Manny and Florence. Services to be held at Wien and Wien, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey, Wednesday, July 28th, 1999 at 12:00 P.M. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart on Monday with a story about tax policy incompletely labeled a section showing the share of taxes paid by different income groups. The section should have been labeled share of income taxes, not share of taxes.

title: Whitman Voids Official Powers Of a Prosecutor
description: Patricia A. Hurt, the Essex County Prosecutor, whose office had been accused of lavish spending, violating a suspect's constitutional rights and wrongful arrests in the April shooting of an Orange police officer, was stripped of her powers today by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who had appointed her less than two years ago.

title: Rules Issued on Year 2000 Compliance
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to shut down any broker-dealer or nonbank transfer agent whose computer systems are not Year 2000 compliant, beginning Dec. 1.

title: Giants to Sign Top Draft Pick
description: For the second consecutive year, the Giants will open training camp with their most recent first-round draft pick in uniform.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell to almost a five-month low against the yen as signs of stronger growth in Asia lured investment away from the United States. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.36 yen, down from 116.61.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILTON, MARJORY, MRS.
description: TILTON-Marjory, Mrs. Long time resident of Sugar Hill, NH, died Sunday after a long illness. Mrs. Tilton was born in New York City, daughter of Eleanor and Dr. Victor B. Seidler and granddaughter of William B. Dickson (co-founder of U.S. Steel). Survived by husband John H. Tilton, and children, Mary Ann Tilton, Frederick Tilton, John H. Tilton, Jr.

title: Denis de Coteau, 70, Ballet's Music Director
description: Denis de Coteau, a conductor of wide experience who was the San Francisco Ballet's longtime music director, died on Friday in San Francisco. He was 70 and lived in South San Francisco.

title: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?; A Forgotten Levy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEEFELD, HERMAN S.
description: BLEEFELD-Herman S. July 26, 1999. Devoted husband of Dorothy. Beloved father of Martin, Rabbi Bradley and Merrie. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Herschel, Marshall and Amy. Loving great grandfather of Benjamin. Services Wednesday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Players Hint at Boycott Over Ryder Cup Profits
description: Before the United States battles Europe at the Ryder Cup in late September, there may be a battle between the United States Ryder Cup players and the P.G.A. of America.

title: Shares Surge as Investors Chase Bargains After Selloff
description: Stocks had their biggest gains of the month as investors speculated that the drop of the last week made shares a good buy as long as interest rates do not rise much further.

title: One More Chance for Patients' Rights
description: The fight for strong legislation to protect the rights of patients in managed-care health plans has now moved to the House. The House Republican leadership will make a serious mistake if it insists on replicating the Senate's feeble efforts. Americans are plainly worried about managed-care abuses. A number of dissident Republicans have heard these concerns and are pushing for tougher patient protections, including the right to sue health plans when they improperly deny coverage. The issue is whether these Republicans can get their leaders to pay attention.

title: Cool, No Matter How They Look
description: FOR vegetables, they are a motley crew. One looks like a pale green hand grenade. Another is a dark curlicue as gnarled as a ram's horn. There are lemony spheres and skinny wands, ivory torpedoes and tiny, spiny ovoids like stretched golf balls.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about plans by President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina to run for President in 2003 referred incorrectly in some editions to the year he would run in a party primary. It would be 2003, not this year.

title: OCEAN GROUP OF BRITAIN MAKES OFFER FOR MARK VII
description: Ocean Group P.L.C., one of Britain's largest freight transport companies, offered to buy Mark VII Inc. yesterday for $23 a share, or $227 million, its third United States acquisition in a year. Mark VII, based in Memphis, had sales of $725 million and operating profit of $17 million last year. Ocean Group transports freight by air and sea, and provides warehousing for companies that include Compaq Computer and Motorola. Mark VII is mostly a logistics manager, acting as the agent between companies that ship goods and carriers. Mark VII's shares soared 29 percent, rising $5.0625 each, to $22.6875.

title: The Artist as Outsider, From Beginning to End
description: FROM A HIGH PLACE

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: One Life To Live? Composer Has More; One Life To Live? Composer Has More
description: Double lives are usually led by spies and philanderers, not doctors and musicians. But David Sulzer, an assistant professor of neurology and psychiatry at Columbia University's medical school, is leading so many lives -- one medical, several musical -- that you have to wonder where he finds the time to be all the people he is.

title: North Korea Urged Again Not to Test New Missile
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and her counterparts from South Korea and Japan appealed today to the isolated Communist Government of North Korea to accept engagement with the world rather than risk ''serious negative consequences'' with a long-range missile test.

title: In Congo War's Wake, a Massacre of the Wildlife
description: Kahuzi-Biega National Park is where Dian Fossey first saw wild gorillas. It is the first park to allow tourists to get near them, for a price that enriched local people. Bill Gates visited there in 1993, and he tipped his guide $400.

title: In Little Rock, the Other Mayor Is the Mayor
description: There were two mayors roaming around this soggy city today, but while the out-of-town Republican one with the funny accent -- Rudolph W. Giuliani -- was flanked by bodyguards and television cameras, the Democratic one, who has quietly presided over the city for the last six years, was ducking out the back door of City Hall, all by himself, for a quick drive.

title: Jets
description: The Jets will go into training camp Friday with their full complement of inexperienced guards. The number increased to five yesterday with the signing of the rookie draft choice J.P. Machado of Illinois, a sixth-round selection.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investing Strategies Golden in the 90's May Be Weakening
description: For most of the 1990's, individual investors have become rich in the stock market by sticking to a couple of relatively simple strategies: buying big-name companies whose products they know or use and piling into stocks that have already been big winners.

title: Alan Karcher, 56, Ex-Trenton Speaker, Dies
description: Alan J. Karcher, the fiery liberal Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly for two terms in the 1980's and a longtime Democratic member of the Assembly from Middlesex County, N.J., died on Monday at the home of a friend in Neptune, N.J. He was 56.

title: Youth Accused of Killing Friend While Playing With Gun
description: A 14-year-old boy unintentionally shot a friend in the head and killed him yesterday when they were playing with a gun in the stairwell of a building in the Bronx, the police said. The boy was charged with second-degree murder.

title: Consumers' Confidence in Economy Slips
description: Consumer confidence in the economy slipped this month from its highest level in more than 30 years even as Americans said they planned to increase their spending on big items, the Conference Board's figures showed today.

title: LIPA Wins Round to Recover Tax Overcharge From Suffolk
description: The Long Island Power Authority has won the latest round in its protracted legal battle with Suffolk County to recover more than $1 billion in overpaid taxes and interest.

title: U.S. Starts to Fly Eager Kosovar Refugees Back Home
description: The State Department, having flown more than 10,000 refugees from Kosovo to the United States, is now offering to fly them back home -- and is being inundated with requests.

title: Girls Admit Lying About Assault at Club
description: Two teen-age girls who reported that they were sexually assaulted in the bathroom of a Manhattan nightclub early Sunday morning have admitted that they were not attacked, prosecutors said yesterday. The two girls said the sex was consensual, the prosecutors said, and the two Jersey City men accused in the case were released from jail.

title: Walter J. Bate, 81, Professor and Biographer
description: Walter Jackson Bate, an emeritus professor of English at Harvard University who won Pulitzer Prizes for biographies of John Keats and Samuel Johnson, died on Monday at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. He was 81 and had homes in Cambridge, Mass., and Amherst, N.H.

title: Business Travel; Corporate travel managers win an important victory from Delta Air Lines on Internet fares.
description: DELTA AIR LINES' decision last week to make its discount Internet fares available to corporate customers appears to have been an important victory for travel managers, who are always looking to hold down business fares.

title: Police's Long Search for Suspect Ends After His Mother's Funeral
description: For almost a year, the police searched for a Queens man accused of shooting another man over a card game. Then came the tip that cracked the case and led to the fugitive's capture: Investigators learned that his mother had died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLESCHNER, MALCOLM K.
description: FLESCHNER-Malcolm K. The Residents of Tower Vallencay offer their heartfelt condolences to the family of Malcolm K. Fleschner, an original resident, a longtime Board member, good friend and loyal neighbor. Mr. Fleschner showed dauntless courage during his long and arduous illness, and he will be missed by all of us. The Board of Directors and Residents of Tower Vallencay

title: What's in a name? Well, no more TCI. After the acquisition, AT&T goes on a rebranding tear.
description: IF the Mercedes-Benz brand name can be affixed to a sport-utility vehicle, if the Heinz brand name can appear on mustard and if the Fritos brand name can be attached to chili, then why not use the AT&T brand name for cable television service?

title: On Campus; Columbia's colossal student center, designed by its dean of architecture, is to open in September.
description: In Alfred Lerner's student days, back in the 1950's, Columbia University had no student center. Students gathered at pubs like the Lion's Den or the West End, he remembers, ''or they just hung out.'' Not until 1960 did they get a place of their own, Ferris Booth Hall.

title: Second Thoughts Caused Split in Umpires' Union
description: The umpires' strategy to induce Major League Baseball to come to the bargaining table began to unravel as soon as some of the umpires returned home from the union meeting two weeks ago and began talking to their wives and lawyers.

title: Transactions
description: CLEVELAND BROWNS--Placed DE Derrick Alexander on the physically-unable-to-perform list.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He's never been here before, he's never worked here, he's never lived here. Today he will be announcing his candidacy for some significant major office in Arkansas, we're told.''

title: COOPER TIRE AND RUBBER TO ACQUIRE STANDARD PRODUCTS
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Standard Products Company for $36.50 a share in cash or stock, or a total of $584.4 million, in a deal that would make Cooper the largest maker of automotive sealing systems in North America. Cooper will also assume $173 million of Standard Products' debt. Cooper, based in Findlay, Ohio, said it expected revenue of $3.2 billion in the combined company's first full year of operation. Standard Products, based in Dearborn, Mich., makes sealing products, plastic trim and vibration control systems. Cooper is the nation's seventh-largest tire manufacturer. Shares of Standard Products soared 40 percent, rising $10, to $35, while Cooper fell 43.75 cents to $22.50.

title: Shuttle Makes Pinpoint Landing After Telescope-Delivery Mission
description: The first woman to command a United States space mission returned to Earth in the space shuttle Columbia late Tuesday, capping a smooth, five-day mission to deliver a telescope with a pinpoint landing in Florida.

title: A $200 Million School That May Never Open
description: It looms on a lonely lot at the edge of downtown, a hulking pile of buff brick and brown stone, like some half-finished temple or pharaoh's tomb. It would be the most expensive public high school ever built in the United States, at a cost of more than $200 million, but the Belmont Learning Center may never be finished -- and if it is, no one may want to go to school there.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Off-Duty Firefighter Shot to Death in Queens
description: An off-duty firefighter was found shot to death yesterday in the driver's seat of his Jeep in an industrial area of Long Island City, Queens, the police said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Tough Guy at the Loan Office; Backed by I.M.F., a Reformer Tackles Indonesia's Barons
description: The Klub Bimasena at the luxurious Dharmawangsa Hotel is a tribute to what remains of Indonesia's conspicuous wealth. Built on the site of the former national mint as an urban refuge for the country's oil barons, it has private suites with built-in saunas, a lounge serving Cognac and cigars, and a spacious gym where each morning Indonesia's repo man, Eko S. Budianto, can be found on a treadmill, getting in shape to go after some of Indonesia's wealthiest people.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDFINE, ROSE
description: GOLDFINE-Rose. July 28, 1998. In loving memory. Your daughter, Gloria (G.G.)

title: Serthar Journal; A 'Living Buddha' Plants an Academy
description: Nearly every day, Tibetan monks and nuns wearing blood-red robes arrive at this distant outpost after a long trek through a forbidding range of mountains.

title: Twitting Rival, Giuliani Visits Mrs. Clinton's Old Backyard
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stood on the porch of Hillary Rodham Clinton's former home here this morning, proclaimed his admiration for the people of Arkansas and brushed aside the notion that his journey into the heart of Clinton country was a brazen publicity stunt to poke fun at his potential opponent in next year's Senate race.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press on Saturday about a State Supreme Court ruling in Hartford that a mother with multiple sclerosis is entitled to a new trial against her gynecologist for ''wrongful conception'' misstated the role of Justice Ellen Peters. She wrote the majority opinion, not the dissent.

title: Journalists, or Detectives? Depends on Who's Asking
description: One of America's wealthiest and most private families found itself in an unwanted spotlight last summer as its fractious members waged a bitter courtroom fight over the family business, Koch Industries, the vast oil and gas company with headquarters on the prairie at the edge of town here.

title: With a New Image, Jackson Campaigns Outside 2000 Race
description: With Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley set to address the Rev. Jesse Jackson's coalition of civil rights groups and urban activists next week, Mr. Jackson says he will not endorse either candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination until he sees which seems more effective in championing causes he considers crucial.

title: A Smart Shift in Clean Air Tactics
description: Government policy makers, like most people, are usually reluctant to admit error. But Carol Browner, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says that Congress and two Administrations failed to foresee the dangers of a gasoline additive that has helped to make the air cleaner but, as it turns out, now threatens the nation's water supply. She has therefore ordered a prompt rollback in the use of the chemical and asked Congress to rewrite the legislation that led to its original application.

title: 18 Adventurers Die In Swiss Flash Flood
description: A flash flood apparently trapped scores of adventurers yesterday in a mountain stream in the Swiss Alps, killing 18 people.

title: FOSTER WHEELER TO TRIM 15% OF WORK FORCE
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation, one of the world's largest construction and engineering companies, said yesterday that it would cut 1,600 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, slash its dividend and shut some plants to improve cash flow and earnings. Foster Wheeler reduced its dividend by 71 percent to 6 cents a share, from 21 cents, payable Sept. 15 to shareholders of record on Aug. 16. The moves will save the company, based in Clinton, N.J., $16 million to $18 million a year and result in a pretax charge of $35 million in the third quarter. The company said it also reached an agreement with bondholders to find a buyer for its money-losing Robbins Resource Recovery Partners L.P., a solid-waste disposal and recovery operation.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the Congressional debate over taxes misstated the size of the tax cut approved by the Senate Finance Committee. It was $792 billion over 10 years, not $778 billion.

title: GLOBAL PHARMACEUTICAL TO BUY IMPAX PHARMACEUTICALS
description: The Global Pharmaceutical Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Impax Pharmaceuticals Inc., a privately held maker of drug-delivery systems, for about $120 million in stock. Global Pharmaceutical, a generic drug company, said it would combine Impax's drug-delivery systems with its own manufacturing, marketing and sales operations. Global Pharmaceutical, based in Philadelphia, said it would acquire Impax, based in Hayward, Calif., for a combination of 31.6 million of its common and preferred shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLSK, CELIA G.
description: WOLSK-Celia G., 93, formerly of Freeport, NY, on July 25th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of David and Paul. Dear sister of Myron. Devoted grandmother of Jeremiah, Alexander, Daniel, Jennifer and Matthew. She will be deeply missed by her family. Service Thursday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: House Renews China's Trading Benefits
description: The House today renewed trading privileges with China for another year, separating United States commercial interests from a long list of grievances that Washington has with Beijing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, LILLIAN (NEE ROCKWEY)
description: YOUNG-Lillian (nee Rockwey). Died on July 27, 1999 at the New York United Hospital. She was 85 years old. Lillian was born in Manhattan on June 1, 1914. For the last ten years she had been working as a volunteer at New York United Hospital. Prior to that, Lillian had worked in retail at Bloomingdales in White Plains. A longtime Port Chester resident, she was a wellrespected member of the community. Lillian had been an active member of the Women's American ORT. She was predeceased by her husband, Bernard Young. She is survived by a son, Stephen W. Young and his wife, Nili, of New Rochelle, and two grandchildren, Ethan and Noah. A funeral service will be held on Thursday 1:30 PM at Zion Memorial Chapel, 914 381-1809. Burial will follow at Mt. Eden Cemetery.

title: Federal Agency Approves Anti-Flu Drug, Overriding Expert Panel's Recommendation
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new inhaled drug today for treating influenza, overriding a panel of independent scientific advisers who recommended five months ago that the drug be kept off pharmacy shelves because it is only marginally effective and may be dangerous for asthma patients.

title: China's Repressive Reflex
description: In a step recalling Maoist political re-education campaigns, Beijing has sent 1,200 officials belonging to the Falun Gong spiritual movement to special schools to study Communist literature and recant their allegiance to the group. That is disturbing behavior from a Chinese leadership that proclaims its commitment to economic reform and modernization and that signed the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights guaranteeing Chinese citizens free expression, assembly and religion.

title: Superjaws: Lab Sharks Turn Men Into Sushi
description: So much water leaks, gurgles, sloshes and jets through Renny Harlin's waterlogged man-versus-shark horror epic ''Deep Blue Sea'' that when it comes to choosing the season's strongest, sturdiest most absorbent paper towel of a movie, there's no just contest; this one takes the prize. Think of it as cinematic Mega-Brawny with a familiar horror-movie message: don't mess with Mother Nature or she'll turn on you.

title: The Times in Joint Internet News Operation
description: The New York Times said yesterday that it was establishing a joint news operation with TheStreet.com, an on-line financial news service, as part of the Times's effort to expand and enhance its presence on the Internet.

title: 2 Democratic Factions Battle for a Judgeship in Brooklyn
description: A race for a Civil Court judgeship in Brooklyn, not usually a contest to generate much excitement, has split a host of Democratic officials into two camps, each seeking to establish its political might.

title: Mala Rubinstein, 93, Executive Who Was an Expert on Beauty
description: Mala Rubinstein, a beauty expert and longtime executive at Helena Rubinstein Inc., as well as an art collector and patron, died on Thursday at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 93 years old.

title: Mets' Present Is No Match For Pirate Future
description: The promotion was billed as Turn Ahead the Clock Night. But it was the kind of future the Mets could live without.

title: At 2d Meeting, Barak and Arafat Hint at New Timetable
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders set a two-week deadline tonight to determine if the Palestinians would accept the new Prime Minister's proposal to rewrite the time-frame and terms of their most recent peace agreement.

title: Appeal Is Denied for Death Row Inmate Who Had Asked for Speedy Execution
description: In a move that could clear the way for New Jersey's first execution in more than 35 years, the State Supreme Court denied an appeal today that had been filed by the Public Defender's office on behalf of a condemned prisoner who has asked to die.

title: Accounts
description: Lilly Pulitzer, a division of Sugartown Worldwide, King of Prussia, Pa., to Goose Ltd., Philadelphia, as the first agency to handle the account of the fashion apparel company. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $2 million.

title: TENNIS; Who Says There Is No 'I' in Team?
description: He has biceps big enough to house newborns and an upper body as impenetrable as concrete. When Stephen Welch is on the tennis court, he plays with soul and a desire that often has him crashing into the fence to track down potential winners.

title: Off the Menu
description: New 57th Street Theme

title: Assessing Impact of New Tariffs
description: WHEN Washington imposes 100 percent duties on an array of European foods tomorrow, as announced last week, the effect may be less a bang than a ripple. The prices of Roquefort cheese, Dijon mustard, tins of foie gras and fresh truffles could double. But for the most part, it seems that the impact will not shake the consumer immediately.

title: Kind, Yet Tough
description: The current debate about ''compassionate conservatism'' recalls the advice given me eight years ago when I proposed entitling one of my books ''Poverty and Compassion.''

title: College Computer Risks
description: Student financial aid records may be at special risk of crashing into confusion on Jan. 1, 2000, because of outdated college computer programs that cannot recognize the new millennium, the inspector general's office of the Department of Education warns.

title: House Leaders Try to Stem Dissent Over Managed Care
description: Stymied by Republican dissension, House Republican leaders made a tentative decision today to bypass their own committees in an effort to push legislation regulating managed care through the House before the August Congressional recess.

title: LASON TO CUT 3.5% OF 11,500-PERSON WORK FORCE
description: Lason Inc., a manager of computer records, said yesterday that it would cut 300 to 400 workers, or up to 3.5 percent of its 11,500-person work force, as it consolidates several sites to streamline operations and cut costs. The company said 24 of its 150 facilities would be closed, of which 12 came from the recent acquisition of the M-R Group. The company, based in Troy, Mich., which operates in 30 states and throughout North America, Britain, India and the Caribbean, took merger-related pretax charges of $30.8 million. Its shares rose $1.3125, to $45.9375.

title: A Summer Solution
description: IT'S the time of year when you can lose your mind buying fruit. After so many months of barely acceptable produce, now the fruit is marvelous and cheap, so naturally, when you stop at the farm stand, you don't buy just one peach. You might just bring home a bushel.

title: 14 Football Players To Plead Guilty
description: Fourteen members of the U.C.L.A. football team are expected to plead guilty in Los Angeles this morning to charges of illegally possessing handicap parking placards and using them around campus.

title: Unit of King Ranch Is Sold
description: The St. Mary Land and Exploration Company, which searches for oil and natural gas in the United States, agreed today to buy King Ranch Energy Inc. for $60.3 million in stock, to increase its reserves and earnings. King Ranch Energy is a unit of the closely held King Ranch Inc., which runs the 825,000-acre King Ranch in South Texas. St. Mary will issue almost 2.67 common shares to stockholders of King Ranch Inc., and King Ranch Energy will become a subsidiary of St. Mary Land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSFIELD, CHARLES F.
description: MANSFIELD-Charles F. Age 77 on July 26, 1999 of Stuart, FL and Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Charrot). Cherished father of Charles, Jr. & Mary Ann, Michael & Margaret, Patricia & Thomas Phelan, Peggy, Elisabeth and Kate. Loving grandfather of Charles, III & Dawn, John & Kathryn Mansfield and Emily Barnett. Dearest great-grandfather of Timothy, Marissa and Kevin Mansfield and Camden Barnett. Dear brother of Alice M. Lissemore. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 & 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Anne's Church, Garden City, 10 AM Thursday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to Little Flower Children's Services (Wading River, NY 11972) or Discalced Carmelites (1525 Carmel Road, Hubertus, WI 53033) would be appreciated.

title: BASEBALL TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: INSIDE
description: General to Leave NATO

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 20 about Sean Carroll, one of the police officers charged in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, hiring Burton B. Roberts as his lawyer misstated Mr. Roberts's position at the law firm of Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding. He is of counsel, not a partner.

title: State Queries Tobacco Giant Over Lobbying
description: New York State regulators opened an investigation yesterday to determine whether Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, drastically understated what its lobbyists spent on gifts for state lawmakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWCOMBE, BARBARA
description: NEWCOMBE-Barbara. Of Ewing Township, NJ, 66, died Sunday at her home. She retired from Sloan Kettering Cancer Center with 38 years in several capacities as registered nurse and administrative duties. Memorial services Thursday at 10:00 AM at Garefino Funeral Home, 12 North Franklin St., Route 179, Lambertville, NJ.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Restoring a Landmark Hotel to Its Gilded Glory
description: Solid-gold cutlery will not grace the dining tables and the tenor in the shower stall next door will not be Caruso, but the landmark Hotel Knickerbocker at Broadway and 42d Street may one day welcome overnight guests again, after eight decades as an office building.

title: Cashman Playing The Name Game
description: With the trade deadline four days away, the Yankees' General Manager Brian Cashman said vaguely that he is looking for anything that will improve his team. Specifically, Cashman is looking for bullpen help, according to executives and scouts who have spoken with him recently.

title: Top Court Dismisses Politician's Libel Suit
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday upheld an appellate ruling dismissing a libel suit filed by a state senator against the state teachers' union over phrases in campaign literature, including one describing him as ''the boss of bosses.''

title: Resurrecting Energy Efficiency
description: The recent heat waves have demonstrated a clear connection between America's decreasing investment in energy conservation and our increasingly unstable electricity grids. Congress and the states shouldn't wait for more blackouts to do something about it.

title: Critics Assail Ratings Board Over 'Eyes'
description: The New York Film Critics Circle has joined Los Angeles critics in attacking the Motion Picture Association of America for requiring that Stanley Kubrick's ''Eyes Wide Shut'' be altered to qualify for its R rating.

title: For Serb Draftee in Kosovo, A Close-Up of Deadly Purges
description: Vlada sleeps late and often doesn't bother to shave. He says he has stopped talking in his sleep, but he often finds himself shuddering uncontrollably, staring down at his trembling body as if it belonged to someone else.

title: A Hum, Then a Shout: The Shock of the New at Tanglewood
description: Since Seiji Ozawa instigated a shake-up two years ago at the Tanglewood Music Center, the summer training institute for young musicians in the bucolic Berkshire Mountains, there have been notable changes. This is to be expected. After all, Mr. Ozawa, the conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which sponsors and runs the institute, intended to put his stamp on the program.

title: The Chef's Touch in Every Box
description: BEING a calm, poker-face kind of guy, I rarely go into an eyes-rolling-into-the-back-of-the-head swoon, but that was my reaction on my first bite of the fabulous heirloom tomato salad at the VICTORY KITCHEN .

title: Let the Listeners Pay for Public Broadcasting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESSEL, BARBARA K. ''BUNNY'' (KRAMER)
description: NESSEL-Barbara K. ''Bunny'' (Kramer). On Tuesday, July 27, of Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Melvin B. Nessel. Mrs. Nessel died in Boston with her husband Melvin at her side. The beloved daughter of the late Herbert and Ethel Kramer was a graduate of Brookline High School in Brookline, MA and of Finch College in New York City. Bunny and Mevlin B. Nessel were married on July 2, 1945. Her devoted husband is joined in loving remembrances by their family: son, John and daughter-in-law Mary, the late Wendy, grandsons Alex and Aaron, brother Robert Kramer, nieces and nephews and aunt Charlotte Sallinger-and too, by the many good friends with whom she was associated in support of the work of: Massachusetts General Hospital, Dana Farber Cancer Center, Boston Fine Arts Museum, Brandeis University, Norton Museum of Art, Jewish Federation (Lion of Judah), Kravis Center, Boston Symphony Orchestra and Boston Children's Hospital. For her considerable energies and generosities Barbara K. ''Bunny'' and Melvin B. Nessel were recently honored by the American Jewish Committee, Massachusetts General Hospital and the Dana Farber Cancer Center. Services at Temple Israel, Longwood Avenue and Plymouth Street, Boston, on Thursday, July 29 11:00 am. (Parking available on the Riverway). Memorial observance through Friday at her late Boston residence. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Massachusetts General Hospital, Box 135, Boston, MA 02114. Information: Levine Chapel, Brookline.

title: America Online and GTE in Internet Deal
description: America Online Inc., the world's largest Internet service, and the GTE Corporation, a local phone company that is being acquired by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, will offer high-speed Internet access to America Online subscribers in 17 states from Florida to Hawaii.

title: U.S. General Who Led NATO to Retire Ahead of Schedule
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark, who led NATO forces in the war in Yugoslavia, will step down as commander of the alliance and be replaced by a high-ranking Air Force officer, White House and Pentagon officials said tonight.

title: Don't Blame Tenure
description: To the Editor:

title: War Without Will
description: To the Editor:

title: SPRINT TO ACQUIRE OPERATING UNITS OF WBS AMERICA
description: The Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 United States long-distance phone company, agreed yesterday to buy WBS America L.L.C.'s operating units, which provide high-speed wireless connections, for $108 million less assumed debt. Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., will use the units' licenses, which have the potential to reach about two million households, to supply customers with voice, video and Internet connections. Closely held WBS, based in Sacramento, Calif., provides pay-TV and Internet service in markets that include Sacramento and West Palm Beach, Fla. Sprint will assume WBS's debt and subtract it from the purchase price. Shares in Sprint fell 93.75 cents, to $50.50.

title: Let the Listeners Pay for Public Broadcasting; Diversity on the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: A Son Builds on His Father's Afro-Beat and Politics
description: With Nigeria's move to civilian rule, one of the songs being played on the radio is ''What Will Tomorrow Bring?'' by Femi Anikulapo-Kuti, son of the Afro-beat pioneer Fela.

title: The Dessert That Ate Manhattan
description: IN one night at Gramercy Tavern, I had a dish of creamy lemon panna cotta, a coconut tapioca pudding with cilantro syrup, a chocolate ganache cake, an intense chocolate caramel tart, a scoop of caramel ice cream, and bay leaf ice cream, too, a chestnut cookie, a black currant gelee, a chocolate filled with hazelnut cream, an orange macaroon and a white chocolate square with toasted coconut.

title: Lessons From an Up-and-Down Past
description: ''FROM the moment when you start to think of wine as an investment and not as something to be drunk, that's the end,'' Elie de Rothschild said almost 30 years ago, when he was managing partner of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild in Bordeaux. His words, applied to today's frenzied market, are still wise, if anyone will heed them.

title: A School in Trouble
description: At a cost of $200 million, the Belmont Learning Center in Los Angeles would be the most expensive public school ever built. But it is above an oil field, and the city's Board of Education is creating a commission to recommend abandoning the plan or spending millions more to make it work despite leaking methane gas.

title: A Little 'Ally' From Big 'Ally'
description: he most closely watched new television show of the fall season may be one that really isn't new at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHMAN, ROBINSON
description: CUSHMAN-Robinson. July 24, 1999. Husband of the Honorable Patricia D. Moore, father of William Sanderson Cushman, Alexander Hanes Cushman, Jennifer Alden Cushman Boghossian and the late Victoria Elizabeth Cushman. Brother of Elizabeth Cushman Titus Putnam. Residence Matunuck, RI. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, August 4, at 11 AM in St. Peter's by the Sea Episcopal Church, 72 Central St, Narragansett, RI. Visiting hours are respectfully omitted. Memorial donations may be made to Save The Bay, 434 Smith St, Providence, RI 02908 or Hospice Care of RI, 143 Main St, Wakefield, R.I. 02879 or Student Conservation Assn, PO Box 550, Charlestown, New Jersey 03603.

title: A Memorable Day, And One to Forget
description: As Jorge Posada chatted with reporters about tonight's 5-3 victory against the Chicago White Sox, he slid a small black-and-white picture into the left pocket of his dark slacks -- the first image of his unborn child, taken from a sonogram only hours before.

title: How to Close The Literacy Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: ENI TO INVEST IN LIBYA
description: Europe's second-largest natural gas supplier, ENI S.p.A. of Italy, will spend $5.5 billion to develop two Libyan gas fields in the biggest foreign investment since the suspects in the Lockerbie airliner bombing were handed over. Under the contract, Eni also will build a 370-mile pipeline under the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Prices Gain As Attractive Yields Lure Investors
description: Bond prices rose for the first time in a week as yields above 6 percent lured buyers.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Cox Is in Deal With Gannett For Cable-TV Subscribers
description: Continuing to expand its cable-television holdings, Cox Communications said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 522,000 cable subscribers from the Gannett Company.

title: Brazil, in a Rift With Argentina, Suspends Commercial Talks
description: Brazil has halted all commercial negotiations with Argentina after the two countries, South America's largest economies, clashed in a series of trade disputes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JOSEPH
description: COHEN-Joseph. On July 27, 1999. Loving husband of the late Mildred and son of the late Simon and Gussie Cohen. Devoted father of Rabbi Martin Cohen. Cherished grandfather of Max, Emil and Lucy. Loving father-in-law of Joan Freeman Cohen. Beloved brother of Molly Avin. Devoted companion of Helen Dougherty. Services Wednesday 1 P.M., at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Pest Is Eating at City's Edges; A Cleaner Harbor Gives New Life to Marine Borers
description: On a barge anchored just off Battery Park City and connected by a narrow footbridge to the esplanade, a team of divers and engineers is soldiering along the latest front in what has become a protracted war against marine borers, the tiny wood-gnawing creatures that are threatening to devour waterfront property all over the city.

title: Quarterly Profit Posted by Qwest
description: Qwest Communications International Inc., the long-distance phone company that is merging with U S West Inc. in a $45.2 billion transaction, posted a second-quarter profit today, reversing a loss in the period a year ago, on rising sales of Internet and data services.

title: CALENDAR
description: Etiquette as a Side Dish

title: Rookie No Soft Touch In Hard N.B.A. World
description: Mirsad Turkcan is from Turkey, which means he is supposed to be a soft player. He is supposed to run around the basketball court without an attitude, looking to make touch passes, shoot jump shots and avoid contact.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a dance review yesterday about a performance of Sun Ock Lee's ''Form Is Emptiness'' by the Son Mu Ga-Zen Dance Company at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center on Saturday omitted part of the concluding sentence. The sentence should have read: ''The drummers grow louder and the women eventually sink into a meditative pose, but not before Ms. Lee whips a braided rope off her costume and whirls it like a lariat: a shrewdly theatrical outburst of passion.''

title: Benedict Wolf, 94, Negotiator On the Federal Labor Board
description: Benedict Wolf, a New York lawyer and veteran mediator who served on the original Federal labor board, died on Friday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Team Finds NATO Bombing Left Few Environment Woes
description: A United Nations environmental team has found no evidence of a major ecological catastrophe in Yugoslavia as a result of NATO's bombing war, its leader said today. But he urged the West to provide immediate aid to help clean up significant ''hot spots'' of war-related pollution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, MARTHA ELOISE REYNOLDS
description: LAWLER-Martha Eloise Reynolds. On July 23, 1999 in New York City. Devoted wife of the late T. Newman Lawler, beloved mother of Ann Dewey and Lisa Schiff & mother-in-law of Thomas Dewey and David Schiff, loving grandmother of Thomas, Elizabeth and George Dewey, and Andrew, Scott and Ashley Schiff, & great grandmother of Frances D. Dewey and Wyatt G. Schiff. Funeral services and interment private at the Washington Irving Memorial Chapel at the Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow NY. on July 30. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62 St, NY 10021 or Bide-A-Wee, 410 East 38 Street, New York 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOTKOW, LEON
description: ZOTKOW-Leon. On July 26, 1999. He will be remembered always by his wife Charlotte and his children Susan Holik and Michael Tobias, and his grandchildren Leslie and Steven Tobias and Amanda and Andrew Holik. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Thursday, July 29th, 11:30AM to celebrate an unusual man and an extraordinary life filled with love, kindness and courage.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS PLUMMET. Soybean prices dropped as Midwest rains diminished concern that hot, dry weather had damaged the crop. In Chicago, soybeans for November delivery fell 26.75 cents, to $4.3525 a bushel.

title: Positions Harden in Instant-Message Fight
description: Hostilities continued yesterday in the bitter debate about whether Microsoft should be able to link into America Online's popular instant message system, with Microsoft rebuffing America Online's invitation to discuss a possible deal.

title: Long Hours, No Pay: Only Chef Wannabes Need Apply
description: MICHAEL ZINNER, whose day job is running the surgery department at Harvard Medical School, stood in the kitchen of Le Bernardin dressed in chef's whites instead of surgeon's greens and tried to get used to the fact that 22-year-olds thought it was perfectly all right to yell at him. For cutting the mushrooms wrong.

title: Plaintiffs in Monmouth See Power Company Negligence and Lack of Planning in Blackouts
description: When the power went out sporadically on four blisteringly hot days after the Fourth of July weekend, George J. Tzannetakis and some of his neighbors in Fair Haven, N.J., slept on their back lawns, missed out on work assignments because they could not use their computers and worried about elderly neighbors who could not get relief from the record heat.

title: Beverly to Take Big Charge Before Settling Investigation
description: Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest nursing home chain, said today that it would take a second-quarter pretax charge of $175 million to $225 million in anticipation of settling a Medicare fraud investigation.

title: Our Towns; Finding Hope In a Museum Of Hip-Hop
description: THE musical tastes of this city's Mayor may run more to Sarah Vaughan than Salt 'n' Pepa. But Ernest D. Davis realizes that if he wants to reach his most elusive constituents, the troubled kids who dabble in drugs and crime, he needs to tap into their passion.

title: China and U.S. Meet on Trade and Chilled Relations Thaw a Bit
description: China and the United States held trade talks here today and agreed to higher-level discussions later this year, a new sign of slowly thawing relations. But they remained frozen on the most prominent issue -- China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the Dot-Com Directory, a new Internet Yellow Pages-type service being offered by Network Solutions Inc., misstated the on-line address for the service. It is: http://www.dotcomdirectory.com

title: Barclays Selects a Chief, And Its Shares Gain 4.6%
description: For almost a year, Barclays P.L.C., one of Britain's largest banks, has been roiled by the resignations of two of its chief executives. And investors have anxiously awaited the next replacement.

title: A Crowded Field At Meadowlands
description: The $1 million Hambletonian for 3-year-old trotters, the sport's premier race, will highlight the program Saturday afternoon and evening at the Meadowlands. The program will also present three Breeders Crown races for older horses, and after yesterday's post-position draw, the morning-line favorites for those three races were named -- Red Bow Tie, Sanabelle Island and the entry of Fern and Lookout Victory.

title: Liberties; Eyes Wide Open
description: Everyone has been calling, wanting all the gruesome details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, JUDY
description: LIPPMAN-Judy. Temple Beth Torah in Westbury, Long Island mourns the loss of our beloved member. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Mark, daughters Rebekah and Melanie. May the family be comforted amoung the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Diane Wohl, President

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Little-Known Stocks Gain On Usually Reliable Ones

title: Kennedy Donations
description: The families of John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren G. Bessette requested yesterday that those wishing to express their condolences take flowers to a local hospital or community center or contribute to one of these causes:

title: Liberty Group to Buy Midwest Publications
description: Liberty Group Publishing Inc. will buy one daily newspaper, 10 weeklies and eight shopper publications from Midwest Newspapers Inc. for undisclosed terms, adding papers in the Midwest and Colorado.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, LEO V., CAPT.
description: BERGER-Leo V., Capt. We mourn the passing of a most cherished member of our Boys Town Jerusalem extended family. Capt. Leo V. Berger was affectionately known to us as the Captain of the Boys Town ''Ship.'' As an immigrant youth raised in an orphanage, he identified heart and soul with the students of Boys Town''his'' boys-who trace their roots to over 40 countries of origin. Capt. Berger, a respected Vice President of the Boys Town Jerusalem Foundation of America, took special delight in dedicating The Joseph and Aranka Berger Residence Hall in memory of his parents, providing a healthy and nurturing home-away-from-home environment for disadvantaged Israeli youth. The Capt. Leo V. and Arvilla Berger Scholarship Endowment enables Boys Town to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. Capt. Berger was a true humanitarian whose magnanimous support of so many deserving causes will endure as a legacy and inspiration. We extend heartfelt condolences to Leo's family and pray that our beloved Captain's memory will be a source of eternal blessing. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec VP

title: MESSAGEMEDIA TO BUY REVNET SYSTEMS FOR $66 MILLION
description: Messagemedia Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Revnet Systems Inc., a maker of direct E-mail marketing software, for about $66.5 million in stock. Messagemedia, a provider of E-mail-based marketing and customer relations management, said it planned to acquire Revnet of Huntsville, Ala., for about four millions shares. Messagemedia's shares were up $2.1875 each, to $18.4375. Messagemedia, based in Boulder, Colo., said it expected the deal to close in August.

title: Editorial Observer; Oh, to Be Young and at the Wrong Woodstock
description: Now that Woodstock '99 has ended in a nasty and embarrassing riot, young people are no doubt dying to hear more about how nice the original was in 1969, when there were no ripoff vendors selling $4 bottles of water and we all shared food and lived in peace and yada yada yada yada yada.

title: BRITISH CELL PHONE DEAL
description: The giant telephone company British Telecommunications P.L.C., will buy the 40 percent of BT Cellnet Ltd. that it does not own from Securicor P.L.C., a British security and recruitment services company, for $5.12 billion. The purchase of BT Cellnet, Britain's second-largest mobile phone company behind Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., had been widely expected. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Chemdex Shares Soar
description: Shares of the Chemdex Corporation, an on-line seller of lab chemicals and equipment with sales of $29,000 last year, closed 70 percent above their offering price after the first day of trading. Chemdex sold 7.5 million shares at $15 each on Monday, raising $112.5 million. The shares closed today at $25.50 in Nasdaq trading; the company now has a market value of $810.3 million. Chemdex, of Palo Alto, operates a Web site, www.chemdex.com, selling chemicals, enzymes and equipment from about 110 suppliers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARION, FRANCES DEITZ
description: ARION-Frances Deitz, wife of the late Jack Arion, died on July 25 at the age of 94. She is survived by her children, Jill Giattino and Michael Arion, son-in-law Russ, daughter-in-law Pam, grandchildren Gabrielle Giattino, Sonia Bruno, and Emily Arion, her sisters Lucy and Irene and devoted nieces and nephews. Before retiring in 1970, she was Director of Fund Raising for the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women. She began her career as publicist for Eva Le Gallienne's Civic Repertory Theater; joined the writing staff of Oliver Sayler. She was personal manager of Maria Ouspenskaya and Tamara Daykarhanova and served as co-director of the School for the Stage. She served as production coordinator of Theater Associates with William R. Katzell, and as coproducer of ''Finian's Rainbow'', ''Lend An Ear'', ''Joy to the World'', and ''Home of the Brave''. She led a full life and will be missed by her family and friends.

title: $25 and Under; Almonds, Mint Tea and a Night in Morocco
description: COOKIES AND COUSCOUS seems a peculiar name for a restaurant. It has the ring of an incongruous retail shop. But this tiny place, which opened in Greenwich Village about six weeks ago, has a lot more going on than its name suggests.

title: Ex-Hustler Joins the Establishment
description: Looking like a man not accustomed to rising early, Rudy Kasimakis kept yawning. It was 8 o'clock in the morning and he was about to start bowling during today's second round of the United States Open at A.M.F. Milford Lanes.

title: Lawsuit Is Filed In Barroom Incident
description: A current Jets offensive lineman and a former teammate, accused in connection with a barroom brawl July 9 in Long Beach, N.Y., have been sued by three police officers and two others who said they were injured during the incident.

title: CLEANING PRODUCTS MERGER
description: In a deal that would create the biggest manufacturer of household cleaners, Reckitt & Colman P.L.C., the British detergent company, will acquire a Dutch rival, Benckiser N.V., the maker of Calgon cleaners, for about $3.2 billion. The combined company, to be called Reckitt Benckiser, will have annual revenue of $4.8 billion. The deal should help the companies compete more effectively against the Procter & Gamble Company and Unilever. Reckitt's shares rose 12 percent, to 785 pence, $12.48, and Benckiser's were up 3.1 percent, to 54.6 euros, $58.16. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, JEWEL B.
description: ROSENBAUM-Jewel B. On July 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Jay and Glen. Dear mother-in-law of Nancy. Adoring grandmother of Peter and Maria. Great-grandmother of Madeline and Brianna Hope. Service Thursday, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, Box 179, 525 E. 68 St., New York, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURG, LILLIAN
description: HAMBURG-Lillian. On July 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Martin Hamburg. Loving mother of Marcia Carpeni and Jeff Hamburg and his wife, Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Brian, Madison and Alexandra. Service Thursday, July 29, at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or Cancer Care.

title: Hospital Inspections
description: To the Editor:

title: Jacksonville
description: Jaguars linebacker Bryce Paup tore a pectoral muscle while lifting weights last week and was sidelined indefinitely, the team said.

title: U.S. DRAWING PLAN THAT WILL MONITOR COMPUTER SYSTEMS
description: The Clinton Administration has developed a plan for an extensive computer monitoring system, overseen by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to protect the nation's crucial data networks from intruders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLANO, ANNA
description: CASTELLANO-Anna. Our deepest condolences to a very special mother of a very special friend. The Lembo's

title: The Furnace of Late July Cools ( but Briefly) for Some
description: The heat wave hitting the middle and eastern United States let up in some parts today, but only after claiming more than 30 lives. And forecasters say the relief is only temporary.

title: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Brash and Latin, Tailor-Made for Its Spot
description: CALLE OCHO landed on Columbus Avenue last December, and the Upper West Side is still dizzy with gratitude. More than a restaurant, it was like a last-minute bailout from the International Monetary Fund, a Marshall Plan for a culinarily ravaged land. Its opening has touched off a near-riot among a population so starved for restaurant excitement that the weak are being trampled underfoot as diners rush the doors.

title: Congressional Memo; When Nomination Turns to Wrangling to Impasse
description: Senator Trent Lott's decision to take a ''second look'' at the nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to be the chief American diplomat to the United Nations appears to have less to do with Mr. Holbrooke's qualifications than with the Senate's low esteem for both the United Nations and President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANO, MIRIAM
description: ROMANO-Miriam. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Zelda Breier and family on the loss of her beloved mother. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: A Thickener From Seaweed

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWE, ROBERT
description: HOWE-Robert. It is with deep sorrow that we bid farewell to our friend and esteemed colleague, Robert Howe, who passed away on Friday, July 16th, 1999. Bob first started in the futures industry in the 1970's having worked for Lincoln Staley, Prudential Bache and Monroe Trout. Bob was a wonderful mentor who was renowned for his market savvy and his wit. We were fortunate to have worked with Bob for six years and he will be sadly missed by everyone. The Staff of Princeton Economics Institute

title: Two Who Interviewed Serial Killers for TV
description: It took four years of relentless telephoning of prison officials, social workers, psychiatrists and others before Maxine Paul and her Connecticut neighbor and partner, Amy Kalafa, managed to carve their way through the institutional barricades that stood between them and their goal.

title: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?; Who Knows Best?
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. a Leader in Hiring Minority Group Members
description: In the annual report card issued by Northeastern University's Center for the Study of Sport in Society, the National Basketball Association received an overall A-minus for the hiring of members of minority groups and B for its gender hiring, while the National Football League had the lowest grade for gender with a D-plus. The N.F.L. did get a B-plus for hiring members of minority groups.

title: DEFAULT DEJA VU
description: Alagoas, a small state in northeastern Brazil, declared a moratorium on its debt to the federal Government after having trouble paying civil servants. Gov. Ronaldo Lessa of Alagoas, a state with a history of budget difficulties, halted payment on a $2.9 million loan from federal authorities on Monday. The debt moratorium, although small, reminded investors of a similar move in January by Minas Gerais state that helped trigger Brazil's financial crisis. Simon Romero

title: Insurer Establishes Foundation to Settle Lawsuits
description: Advancing its campaign to consolidate Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies in the Northeast, Anthem Inc. agreed yesterday to finance a $41 million public health foundation for poor and uninsured people in Connecticut.

title: Former Chief Of GE Capital Plans to Start Buyout Fund
description: Gary C. Wendt, who built GE Capital Services into a financial powerhouse before leaving last year in a management shake-up, is planning a buyout and private-equity investment fund that he would run with other former GE Capital executives.

title: Summer School Enrollment Is Record for New York City
description: A record number of students are enrolled in summer classes in New York City public schools, the Board of Education said this week, attributing the increase in part to the more than 40,000 failing students who have been ordered to attend.

title: Principal Is Faulted In Bomb Rumor Response
description: The city's schools investigator faulted the principal and other officials of a Brooklyn junior high school yesterday for failing to notify the police immediately after they heard rumors that eighth graders were planning to bomb the school in April.

title: How to Close The Literacy Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
