description: A map yesterday with an article about Ship Cove, Newfoundland, where volunteers clean sea birds contaminated by oil, showed the location incorrectly. The scene of the article is in southeast Newfoundland; another Ship Cove, shown on the map, is at the northern tip of the island of Newfoundland.

title: Leaders in House Covet States' Unspent Welfare Money
description: In a frantic search for the cash that they need to pass their spending bills, House Republican leaders are considering asking their party's governors to return $6 billion in unspent welfare money to the Treasury, senior aides said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN F. JR.
description: KENNEDY-John F. Jr. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Central Park Conservancy mourn the passing of John F. Kennedy, Jr. who held Central Park close to his heart. We offer our deepest sympathies to Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg and the Kennedy and Bessette families. A.J.C. Smith, Chairman Karen H. Putnam, President

title: Archipelago Sells a Stake To Instinet
description: In the latest round of a building competition between established stock markets and a group of upstart electronic competitors, Archipelago Holdings L.L.C., a leading electronic network for trading Nasdaq stocks, said yesterday that a rival, Instinet, had agreed to buy a 16.4 percent stake in it.

title: Man Accused of Molesting Adopted Son Was Cleared Earlier
description: A Brooklyn foster father who was arrested Monday night on charges that he sexually abused his 10-year-old adopted son had been investigated and cleared of a similar allegation earlier this year, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, KERMIT J.
description: BERGER-Kermit J. Of Fort Lee. Cherished son of Beatrice. Devoted father of Joshua and Jennifer. Dear brother of Gary. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, Wednesday 9:45A.M. (1-800-378-1892)

title: Saratoga Starts Up, With Stars Set to Run
description: An undefeated 2-year-old filly will lead the parade of star horses onto the Saratoga Race Course when it opens Wednesday for New York's 131st season of racing in the Adirondacks. And ready to follow them into the spotlight before the week closes are the early favorite for next year's Kentucky Derby and several candidates for this year's Horse of the Year.

title: A Reliever Is Sought As the Deadline Looms
description: John Franco viewed the news as encouraging. Three more weeks with a splint on the middle finger of his left hand, and then Franco can resume throwing again.

title: Israel's Speaker: A Prince Who Unsettles His Party
description: First there were the new rules of decorum that Avraham Burg, the new Speaker, instantly imposed on the Israeli Parliament in an effort to tame the unruly body.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: From Pasta to Pet Food, Organic Foods Fill Fairway

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Well-Read But Misspelled

title: Horses Overheat, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Premier Warns U.S. Against Role as Policeman
description: Sergei V. Stepashin, the new Prime Minister of Russia, warned today that the United States should not assume the role of international policeman, a sign that relations between the two countries remain frayed by the American-led military intervention in Kosovo.

title: Kelvin Lancaster, 74, Dies; Revised Economic Theory
description: Kelvin J. Lancaster, whose theoretical writings reshaped the economics profession's ideas about trade, industrial structure and regulation, died on Friday at his home in New York City. He was 74.

title: $6 Million in Grants Will Go to Jazz
description: The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is planning a series of grants totaling $6.7 million to further the creation, presentation and marketing of jazz in America. The amount covers the first three years of a five-year initiative, the foundation's president, Joan E. Spero, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KELVIN, ZEL
description: KELVIN-Zel 7/28/94. Forever cherished. Forever remembered. Love, Jean, Harold, Renee, Alice, Ann, Aurea, Jocely

title: KOREAN STOCKS REBOUND
description: Signs that the South Korean Government and local creditors are determined to help debt-ridden Daewoo Group out of its financial troubles sent a collective sigh of relief rippling through Korean financial markets, sending local stock prices surging. After plunging more than 100 points, or nearly 11 percent, in the two previous trading sessions, the Korea Composite Stock Price Index surged 6.4 percent. The surge was apparently spurred in part by a statement that creditors would take over the restructuring of Daewoo Group, but the Financial Supervisory Commission later retracted that statement.

title: Racketeering Convictions Overturned for 2 in Officer's Killing
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned the racketeering convictions of two gang members who are serving life sentences for their roles in the murder of a New York City police officer three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, DONNA
description: ALLEN-Donna. The National Committee Against Repressive Legislation (NCARL) mourns the death of our District of Columbia Vice Chair and long time activist. Donna has given unstintingly of her energy and scholarship over all the years, not only to NCARL and its predecessor, the National Committee to Abolish HUAC, but to the many other causes that were dear to her. She will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family.

title: Eschmeyer Can't Find Way Out Of a Hole
description: Evan Eschmeyer was matched against a familiar opponent. The Nets' second-round draft pick had the basketball with 38 seconds remaining and the chance to put his team ahead with a power move against Calvin Booth, a second-round pick of the Washington Wizards.

title: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?; Hidden From Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I was growing up, one of my favorite dishes was leg of lamb. It was a festive dish, one that my grandmother, who was from Lebanon, made whenever we all gathered for a family celebration. She would braise a whole leg with olives and lemon, and those flavors, so wonderfully Mediterranean, are one of my earliest taste memories. When I think of lamb, that dish instantly comes to mind.

title: New Immunex Stock Split
description: The Immunex Corporation, one of the world's biggest biotechnology companies, said today it would split its common stock 2 for 1, announcing the move just four months after its first split in its 18-year history. Shareholders of the company, which is majority owned by the American Home Products Corporation, will receive an additional share for each share they own as of Aug. 12. Immunex shares have tripled since November, when its rheumatoid arthritis drug, Enbrel, won United States approval. Shares in Immunex, based in Seattle, rose $5, to $117.125.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Home Costs Found Highest in New York
description: A study commissioned by New York City has found that the cost of residential construction in the five boroughs is the highest in the country, with pervasive corruption, outdated regulations and excessive labor and material costs continuing to make it prohibitively expensive to build new homes.

title: Datek Chooses Bozell And 24/7 Expands
description: Two companies with an Internet bent have made advertising news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHADBOURN, DR. JOHN A.
description: CHADBOURN-Dr. John A. It is with heartfelt sadness that the Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York announces the passing of John Atwater Chadbourn, M.D., on July 23, 1999. A native of Wisconsin, Dr. Chadbourn began his medical career as an intern at St. Vincent's Hospital in 1963. After his residency, he returned to pioneer the Mobile Coronary Care Ambulance Project, the first in New York City. Jack was a beloved physician, colleague and teacher. He consistently won the Teacher of the Year Award from the Student's of New York Medical College. His loss to all, including his patients, students and colleagues is immeasurable. We wish to offer our condolences to his family and friends. He will be sorely missed and long remembered with respect and affection. Joseph M. Jabbour, M.D. President of the Medical Staff St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHOENIX TECHNOLOGIES LTD., San Jose, Calif., a software maker, said it could not reach an agreement with Softbank Corp. of Japan on terms of their previously announced plan for Softbank to acquire a 20 percent stake in Phoenix's Internet subsidiary Ebetween.

title: Metro Business; Layoff Assistance
description: The United Technologies Corporation, the world's biggest maker of elevators and air-conditioners, said yesterday that it would pay for college courses for workers who lose their jobs in the latest restructuring by the Hartford company.

title: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?; Punishing the Strivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; 2021? Mets Miss Chance For 1988
description: THE voice on Shea Stadium's public-address system had a spooky alien squeakiness.

title: Just Not Cooking With Gas At Grand Central Terminal
description: EIGHT months behind schedule, the Mexican cafe Zocalo has opened in Grand Central Terminal, one of just four establishments open in the food court. There is just one little hitch: It has no gas for cooking.

title: The Umpires Change Their Call: They No Longer Want to Resign
description: Forty-two major league baseball umpires collectively rescinded their resignations yesterday, a signal of a failed labor strategy that will result in the loss of jobs for one-third of the union membership.

title: Suit Says Advanced-Placement Classes Show Bias
description: College admissions officers have long used advanced-placement courses as an important tool for measuring applicants and the high schools they attend. But today, in a lawsuit filed in a state court here, the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California said that yardstick was just another way of discriminating against students and schools in low-income and minority neighborhoods.

title: After Affirmative Action
description: In a continued effort to demonstrate the worth of affirmative action, University of Michigan professors have issued a preliminary study saying minority graduates of the university's law school have careers that are just as successful as those of its white graduates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, MARTIN
description: GINSBURG-Martin, 85. Of Miami, FL, passed away on Sunday, July 25th, 1999. He is survived by his loving wife, Natalie (Bobbie), his son, Allan Ginsburg, his daughter, Bonnie Levy, and daughter-in-law, Carolyn Ginsburg. He is also survived by his eight grandchildren, Ashley, Gregory, Jamie, Jeffrey, Kenny, Robyn, Sherri, and Stephanie; in addition to their spouses, Melissa Ginsburg & Keith Zucker. Also surviving are three greatgrandchildren, Eric, Mitchell and Ryan. He is also survived by his brother, Abe Ginsburg, and his wife, Sylvia, and their family. He was involved in many charitable causes. We would like to mention just a few. He was involved in the Byalstoker Home for the Aged in New York City. In Israel he created the Martin Ginsburg High School of Yavne and the Ginsburg Youth Center in Tiberias in addition to three additional kindergartens. He was also involved in Technion in Israel & was a founder of the Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was a true gentleman among men & an inspiration to his family and will be missed by all who had the good fortune to know him. Funeral services will be held Thursday, July 29th, at 12 Noon, Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. The Family

title: Wildensteins Sued Over Looted Art
description: Heirs of Alphonse Kann filed a lawsuit yesterday against the Wildenstein family, among the art world's best-known dealers, claiming that the Wildensteins stole eight rare manuscripts worth about $15 million after the they were looted from the Kanns by the Nazis in occupied France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, LOTTIE NEE SOLENDER
description: SIEGEL-Lottie nee Solender. On July 26, 1999 after a long illness. Devoted wife of the late Max. Cherished mother of Judith Ellner and Susan Hastings. Loving sister of Sylvia Tuckerman. Adoring grandmother of Patricia Groisser and her husband Gordon and great-grandmother of precious Kailyn Elizabeth. May she rest in peace. Private cryptside service is at New Cedar Park Cemetery, Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Revisiting A Prophecy Of a World Still Forming
description: ''You something new, boy.''

title: UNITED RENTALS, ON BUYING SPREE, ACQUIRES 17 COMPANIES
description: United Rentals Inc., the No. 1 United States equipment-rental company, said it had bought 17 companies with combined annual revenue of $150 million as it moves to dominate the traffic-safety market. Six of the companies are traffic-equipment rental companies, which rent barricades, warning lights and other items, with about $110 million in annual revenue. The 17 companies combined will give United Rentals 103 more sites in 23 states. United Rentals rents construction and landscaping equipment. United Rentals, based in Greenwich, Conn., has been on a buying spree since Jan. 1, buying 63 companies with combined annual revenue of $495 million.

title: State Officials Split on Move on Gas Additive
description: State environmental officials were divided today over whether Congress should act to reduce the use of a chemical used in gasoline that helps keep the air clean but sometimes pollutes water.

title: Cyberattack Detection Versus Privacy Protection
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Valentine Cringes as Rogers Winces His Way to Strong Start
description: Kenny Rogers trotted to the mound in a pristine white uniform yesterday, hoping for a fresh start with the Mets in an old city named New York. It was a new team in a new borough and in a new league, but there were still the old yet valid questions about whether Rogers could succeed as a pitcher in this demanding town after faltering with the Yankees in 1996 and 1997.

title: Interest Rates Remain Steady In Advance of G.D.P. Report
description: Treasury bond prices were little changed yesterday as investors braced for a report on the gross domestic product today that may add to the case for another Federal Reserve interest rate increase.

title: Where There's Smoke
description: In the mysterious ways of Albany, an extension of New York's feeble lobbying law is now poised for approval by state legislators. This cowardly measure to rubber-stamp the state's lobbying code for four more years has no identifiable sponsors, perhaps an indication that even in Albany the system is recognized as an embarrassment. New York State's lobbying law does not work, and if the Legislature needs any more evidence of how the public is being hijacked by special interests, the tobacco industry offers a ripe example.

title: Cable Giant Is Planning An Offering
description: Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft, who has used much of his wealth to build a cable media empire, is set to take his cable company public.

title: UGI Is Planning to Repurchase Some Shares
description: The UGI Corporation said today that it would buy back up to 4.5 million shares of its stock by means of a so-called Dutch auction.

title: The Census as an Act of God
description: Acting as though they had just discovered that the Constitution requires a census every decade, the House Republican leadership has declared that next year's national headcount will be financed with an ''emergency'' appropriation of $4.5 billion. The leaders treated veterans' health care the same way, deeming it an off-budget emergency.

title: Tab for Washington Lobbying: $1.42 Billion
description: The capital of the United States is a city with no real industry except for politics and influence, and so huge sums of money are paid to lobbyists trying to influence politicians. Last year $1.42 billion was spent in that endeavor, a research group said today.

title: Alexander Farkas, 69, Ex-Head of New York Discount Retailer
description: Alexander S. Farkas, who helped build Alexander's department stores into the place where New Yorkers went to get stylish fashions for a bargain and then watched as the chain went bankrupt, died yesterday at his home in Highland Park, Fla. He was 69.

title: Govox Digital Voice Recorder Lets Users Talk to Palms
description: You can now talk to your Palm III -- sort of. Landware (www.landware.com) introduced the Govox digital voice recorder at the Macworld Expo in New York last week. The Govox recorder, which attaches to the Palm in place of its lid, allows you to dictate notes, memos or reminders. The recorder is not linked, so recordings cannot be translated directly into text. Speech recognition is still a dream for Palm owners. For now they must play back their words. STEPHEN C. MILLER

title: June Orders For Durables Rise Slowly
description: Orders for durable goods rose at a slower-than-expected pace in June, restrained by reduced demand for industrial machinery, Government figures showed today.

title: U.S. Knew Early of Nazi Killings in Asylums, Official Documents Show
description: The diplomats at the American consulate in Leipzig, Germany, noticed a lot of strange death notices in the local newspapers in the fall of 1940. Some of the deceased were old, some not so old, but their deaths had something in common.

title: Focal in Initial Offering
description: The Focal Communications Corporation, a provider of local telecommunications services, said yesterday that it had raised $129.6 million in the initial sale of the company's stock to the public. The 9.95 million shares sold for $13 apiece, above the expected range of $10 to $12 a share. In Nasdaq trading, Focal's shares closed at $16.75. The Chicago company plans to use the proceeds for general purposes.

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Humming Off Key For Two Decades
description: ON the original model of the Sony Walkman, introduced in the United States 20 years ago this month, there was an orange button. The TPS-L2, a blue-black plastic model released in this country under the name Soundabout, played cassette tapes, but it also had a second earphone jack and an extra set of earphones. When you pushed the orange button, the sound emerged from two sets of phones.

title: Vote Near on U.N. Job
description: The Senate will probably vote next week on the long-delayed nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as chief delegate to the United Nations, a top Democrat said. Republicans have blocked the vote until the Administration addresses demands that have little to do with Mr. Holbrooke.

title: ROVER HURTS BMW EARNINGS
description: BMW, Germany's third-largest auto maker, reported a 27 percent decline in profits for the first half of the year, attributing the performance to its troubled Rover unit in Britain. BMW earned 191 million euros ($203 million), down from 261.3 million euros a year earlier. Despite the decline, investors sent shares of BMW up almost 3 percent on optimism that a reorganization of Rover would improve results.

title: The Famous Fiennes and Their Mother's 'Blood Ties'
description: Long before she started working on an unfamiliar new computer that gave her migraine headaches and long before she learned she had cancer, Jini Fiennes conceived of her sixth and most ambitious novel, ''Blood Ties,'' a cyclical tale of wounded generations and the redeeming power of love.

title: Cashman Keeps Trade Door Open
description: In the last week, three of the Yankees' primary rivals have made trades, the Mets acquiring the left-hander Kenny Rogers, the Boston Red Sox adding Butch Huskey and the Toronto Blue Jays dealing for first baseman David Segui. The Cleveland Indians, who have played the Yankees in October in each of the last two years and may again this fall, are talking to the Baltimore Orioles about pitcher Juan Guzman and have their sights set on the Anaheim left-hander Chuck Finley.

title: A Scottish Story, Told by the Objects That Shaped It
description: THE notion that Scotland is a more beguiling place than the dark and rugged land it occupies has found fitting expression in the alluring new Museum of Scotland. In a modern building set on a hillside in Edinburgh's medieval old town, the museum has a smoothly turned drum tower, a furrowed roof terrace, slender windows and a sandstone exterior with the amber flush of a sunset spreading across a Highland moor.

title: Compaq Plans To Cut Staff By Up to 12%
description: Struggling to return to profitability, the Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it would cut up to 8,000 jobs, or about 12 percent of its worldwide work force, and take a third-quarter charge of $700 million to $900 million as a result of its cost-cutting reorganization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, RICHARD PHILIP (WICK)
description: STERN-Richard Philip (Wick). Of Ojai, CA. On July 27, 1999. Husband of Helga, adoring and adored father of Lorien, beloved son of Jean and Robert Stern of Pound Ridge, NY. Deeply loved brother of Peter of Cardiff, CA., and Robert and Yuka of NYC. Loving uncle of Ren. Goodnight, our Sweet Prince.

title: On-line Archive Will Preserve Earliest English Books
description: SIX decades ago, the threat of Nazi book burnings and German bombs spurred a project to preserve some of the earliest writings in the English language on microfilm. Eugene Power, a Michigan microfilm entrepreneur who had already begun photographing the first books printed in English, was selected by the Rockefeller Foundation and a scholarly organization to make microfilm versions of treasured British collections.

title: City Tentatively Agrees to Make Crime Scenes More Open to Press
description: The Giuliani administration has tentatively agreed to make crime scenes more accessible to news organizations by changing police practices that news executives said had inhibited the coverage of crime, rallies and other events in New York City.

title: An Asthma Emergency
description: Asthma is a chronic inflammation of the respiratory system that makes breathing difficult, and in its acute forms starves its victims of air, landing them in the hospital. The disease has become increasingly common, afflicting more than twice as many people today -- about a third of them children -- as it did just two decades ago. Unless scientists find out why -- and learn to curb the increase -- asthma will clog hospital emergency rooms and undermine the national effort to control health costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MALACHI BRENDAN
description: MARTIN-Malachi Brendan. On July 27, 1999. Beloved brother of Netta Kelly and other brothers and sisters in Ireland. Dearest companion of Kakia Livanos. He was a noted priest and author. Friends may call at St. Anthony of Padua Cburch, 1360 Pleasant Valley Way, West Orange, New Jersey, Friday, July 30, 9:30am-11am, with Mass following at 11am.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPER, ETHEL MALAKOFF
description: SPER-Ethel Malakoff. On July 26, 1999, age 98. Beloved wife of the late Edward M. Sper. Loving sister of Florence Hatz. Dear aunt of Louis Creeger, Gilbert Rosenthal, Lois Carswell, Diane Michaels, Richard Hatz, Paul Horn, Rose Sper, Morris Steiner, Miriam Magdol and Ellen Fine. Her sense of humor, indomitable spirit and bright intelligence will be sorely missed. Memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: The Big City; Clean Up City? Not Unless It's City Hall Way
description: STOP them before they clean again!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, HENNI (NEE WASSERMAN)
description: FEUER-Henni (nee Wasserman). Born September 29, 1914-July 28, 1999. Loving wife of the late Jacob Feuer, and dearest mother of Gideon Feuer, Dr. Gary Feuer, and Shula Feuer, mother-in-law of Chedvah Feuer & Maureen Feuer, beloved friend of Joan Lewis. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Jeffrey and Rhonda Feuer, Shimon, Andy, Eliezer, Eitan, and Jonathan Feuer. Services Thursday 12 noon at ''Schwartz Brother-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills. Interment to follow at The New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York.

title: School Agency Is Accused of Intimidation
description: The chairwoman of a commission named by Gov. George E. Pataki to investigate possible mismanagement and corruption within the New York City School Construction Authority charged yesterday that the authority was trying to ''intimidate'' its employees into obstructing the commission's efforts.

title: Lights to Ease Boomers Down the Road
description: IF driving at night has recently become more difficult, don't necessarily blame your headlights. Once you move out of your 20's, there's a good chance that the problem has nothing to do with your car's equipment and everything to do with your age.

title: And Make It Snappy: Awhirl in a Short-Order Society
description: Yes, it is possible to have an intelligent conversation on television that is enhanced with visual approaches to matters of moment. If you doubt it, tune into ''Brave New World,'' the eight-part ''Nightline'' look at the way the world is changing around us and how those changes may be affecting human personality.

title: Doomsday From 0 to 10
description: We live, of course, in a world full of risks and the probabilities assigned to those risks. There is a statistical measure for the safety -- or danger, if you're feeling pessimistic -- of nearly any activity you can name. But all these probabilities and statistical measures are grounded on a basic assumption: the survival of Earth. You can't take everything for granted, however. Now, for people who like to worry about the sky falling, there is the Torino Impact Hazard Scale, created by Dr. Richard P. Binzel, a professor at M.I.T., and approved by the International Astronomical Union.

title: Stench Is Out, Fish Are In; Gowanus Canal Comes Back to Life After Rescue
description: The driver heading across the Union Street Bridge over the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn slowed down yesterday when he saw the crowd peering over the railing into the green water.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Whitman Says Drought Warning Is Likely
description: With much of the Northeast withering under near-drought conditions and a heat wave expected to last at least through the weekend, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey said yesterday that she would likely issue a drought warning early next week but did not expect to impose water restrictions.

title: Exhibitions, Sales and an Open House
description: Reflections on History

title: High-Tech Unions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saratoga And a Filly Get Off to Fast Starts
description: Thoroughbred racing made its summertime switch from New York to the Adirondacks for the 131st time today as the Saratoga Race Course opened for six weeks with sultry weather and a smashing performance by an undefeated 2-year-old filly.

title: BRAZIL ENERGY DEAL
description: In a sign of optimism over future electricity needs in Brazil, the Duke Energy Company paid 1.2 billion reais, or $684 million, for Companhia de Energia Eletrica Paranapanema. The deal gives Duke a foothold in the hydroelectric generation industry in one of Brazil's most prosperous regions. Duke's acquisition of Paranapanema, which serves the industrial states of Sao Paulo and Parana, is also part of a wider Latin American expansion plan by the utility, based in Charlotte, N.C. It also owns stakes in power companies in Argentina and Ecuador.

title: A Sport Called Extreme, With Reason
description: Canyoning has emerged as a trendy ''extreme'' sport, ranking somewhere between bungee jumping and whitewater rafting in its heart-thumping thrills and spills.

title: CARADON OF BRITAIN TO ACQUIRE EASCO FOR $155 MILLION
description: Easco Inc., an aluminum extrusion company based in Girard, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by Caradon P.L.C. for about $155 million. Caradon, a British building and plumbing supplies company, will offer $15.20 a share for Easco. The shares jumped 24 percent yesterday, or $2.9063, to $14.9063. Caradon said the purchase would double its extrusions sales to around $600 million. Easco, which operates 21 aluminum extrusion presses and three casting plants, earned $7.7 million on sales of $313.8 million in 1998.

title: Malcolm Shabazz Flees Detention
description: Malcolm Shabazz, who set a fire two years ago that killed his grandmother, the widow of Malcolm X, escaped yesterday from a juvenile detention center in Valhalla, N.Y., further complicating efforts by Westchester County officials to find an institution to treat the troubled 14-year-old.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Counting the Hours

title: More Gadgets For Macs
description: THE Mac is back. Apple Computer Inc., which was nearly given up for dead a year ago, has emerged as the most innovative and aggressive personal computer maker in the industry. Apple has sold nearly two million colorful iMac computers in the last 11 months, and it asserts that nearly half of those went to first-time computer buyers or people who were returning to the Mac after being seduced by cheaper but more complicated PC's based on the dominant Windows operating system.

title: For Gandhi (d.1948), a Long Due Apology
description: One hundred and five years after it tried to keep Mohandas K. Gandhi from practicing law because he was ''not of European descent,'' the Natal Law Society has unconditionally apologized for its actions.

title: Metro Business; Utility Considers Internet
description: Keyspan Corporation, which owns utilities in the New York region, said it might try to acquire or form a joint venture with a telecommunications company to tap the growing market for Internet and data services.

title: On-Line Piracy Turns From Music to Movies
description: ONE recent Friday evening, an employee in a small New York new-media company enjoyed his own private screening of ''Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me.'' The film's sound fell somewhere between hollow and muffled. The picture, washed out and slightly murky, looked like a videotape copy of a public access television show.

title: PP&L Services Deal
description: PP&L Resources Inc., a utility company, has agreed to buy closely held Western Mass. Holdings Inc., which provides construction and other services, for an undisclosed price, adding to the kinds of services it can offer its customers in New England. Western Mass., based in Springfield, Mass., has 200 employees and annual revenue of about $50 million.

title: Attic Gold A Commute Away
description: WONDERING where to go on a weekend afternoon to get out of the sweltering city and find quality antiques at competitive prices? How about the suburbs? I spent a summer Saturday shopping for antiques in suburban New York and Connecticut. As a designer (read: snob), I had had my doubts, but what I discovered was a remarkable range of stores dealing in the high-end castoffs of big-money bedroom communities.

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: And the Meek Shall Inherit Nothing
description: A YEAR after his father died in Florida, Richard Nelson, 51, can finally talk about what he calls ''the war of the glockenspiel,'' when Mr. Nelson, an organizational consultant, and his younger brother, Larry, battled for months over the instrument their father played in the Shriner drum corps.

title: NISSAN-RENAULT TIES
description: The Japanese auto maker Nissan Motor said it might team up with its French counterpart Renault S.A. to buy steel and other components to cut costs. The shares of both Renault and Nissan soared yesterday. Nissan and Renault -- which bought 37 percent of the Japanese company in May -- will save about 55 billion yen ($472.5 million) next year through joint purchases of sheet steel, the newspaper Nihon Keizai said.

title: Drifter Says He Had Sex With Up to 300
description: Nushawn J. Williams, the drifter from Brooklyn who officials say may have infected more than a dozen young women and girls in upstate New York with the virus that causes AIDS, now says that he may have had sex with as many as 300 women.

title: A Tipsy Perch for Wines
description: Olafur Thordarson's translucent resin-and-gauze wine rack ($950) looks wobbly drunk. Mr. Thordarson, 36, went to architecture school at Columbia University and worked with Gaetano Pesce for seven years. Mr. Thordarson and the pop singer Bjork were classmates in Reykjavik. ''In Iceland, the Government makes it possible for artists to do practically anything we want to do,'' he said. His Web site is www .dingaling.net. The rack, 32 1/2 inches tall, is at Klisanin Ross (address, right).

title: Inkster Eyes du Maurier for Hall of Fame Honor
description: At the three most recent L.P.G.A. major championships, players bombarded the courses with birdies. Dottie Pepper shot 19 under par to win the Nabisco Dinah Shore. Juli Inkster shot 16 under par to win both the United States Women's Open and the Ladies Professional Golf Association McDonald's Championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSMAN, CLAIRE
description: KOSMAN-Claire. On July 28, 1999. Dear sister of Shirley Breselor, loving aunt of Marilyn Breselor and Franklin Breselor. Adoring companion of her dog Murphy. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Service Thursday at 1:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Turning Old Slides Into Digital Images
description: Q. I have hundreds of old 35-millimeter slides in carousels. Is there a way to convert them on my computer myself so I can have electronic copies or send them to friends in E-mail?

title: House Hearing Focuses On Vulgar Internet Names
description: A Congressional hearing called to examine intellectual-property and trademark issues on the Internet became sidetracked today by questions about who was responsible for a flurry of obscene addresses on the World Wide Web.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Light Touch, Strong Swing And an Old-School Attitude
description: Though he's only in his early 30's, the pianist Bill Charlap is solidly old-fashioned. It would be hard to find another young jazz musician playing at his level with such deep knowledge of the songs from American musical theater. He has made three high-quality albums for the Dutch record label Criss Cross, all of them full of obscure song choices and fizzy, nuanced musicianship within a subtle delivery. It's not the next wave of jazz; if the larger jazz-record industry seizes upon him -- which, given his extraordinary talent, wouldn't be surprising -- they may be faced with the challenge of creating a trend around him that would have young listeners dressing up in seersucker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EVA
description: MEYER-Eva. On July 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Gil. Loving mother of Jacqueline Shapiro Meckler. Dearest sister of Gabriela de Fernandez. Adoring grandmother of Dolly and Izzy Meckler. Cherished aunt of Rodrigo Fricke. She will be profoundly missed by her family and friends. Service Friday, 11:15AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Giants Set Out to Fill Missing Links
description: It has been a long time since the Giants came to a training camp with so many unanswered questions, so many open jobs, so many key players recovering from serious injuries, so much uncertainty across the board that it extends from the fate of the head coach to the fortune of the team's best player, defensive end Michael Strahan.

title: Judge Refuses to Overturn Conviction in Louima Case
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the jury verdict convicting a police officer of torturing Abner Louima, rejecting an argument that prosecutors had withheld vital information from the defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTMAN, MILDRED
description: GUTMAN-Mildred. On July 27, 1999 at the age of 69 in Rancho Palos Verdes, California. Beloved wife of Fred Gutman. Adoring mother of Scott Gutman, Amy Goldberg and son-in-law Mark Goldberg. Devoted and proud grandmother of Corinne and Michael. Dear sister of Blanche Golden. We loved her so very much. She will be deeply missed.

title: Youngsters Show Off Their Many Talents
description: Shannon Miller, who won two gold medals in the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, was there. So was Bela Karolyi, the Romanian-born coach who steered Nadia Comaneci and Mary Lou Retton to Olympic glory. So was Tatyana Brikulskaya, whose exhibition demonstrated why she had become an American rhythmic champion.

title: John Doe Need Not Apply
description: FIVE years ago in Australia, back when the World Wide Web had only a few strands, a computer consultant and grandfather in Melbourne named John Carter received a message on Fidonet, a public bulletin board, intended for a John Carter who lived in South Africa.

title: Lawyer With a Bark to Make Giuliani Proud
description: MICHAEL D. HESS is disarmingly low-key, with a koala bear's smile. He importunes you to call him Mike; when dining with childhood friends, he prefers the Second Avenue Deli.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETREBA, LAURIE F.
description: NETREBA-Laurie F. Of Atherton, California. Formerly of Great Neck, New York. On July 25, 1999. Magna Cum Laude graduate Barnard College, M.A. Stanford University. Doctoral candidacy in English Renaissance at University of California, Berkeley and recipient of distinguished teaching award interrupted by illness and untimely death at Stanford University Hospital. Treasured daughter of Mildred and Sydney Netreba.

title: The Sound Of Simon And Dylan
description: They were no Simon and Garfunkel, no Bob Dylan and the Band. They weren't even as good a match-up as Bob Dylan and Elvis Costello singing ''I Shall Be Released'' during the encore of an impromptu Dylan show the night before at Tramps. But Bob Dylan and Paul Simon weren't exactly the odd couple either at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night when their tour finally came to town and they shared the stage for four songs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCH, PAUL L.
description: BUSCH-Paul L. of Wilton, CT. On Tuesday, July 27 in Boston. Beloved husband of Iris. Cherished by his three children, their spouses & partners, and his grandchildren: Jordan and Susan Busch of Wayland, MA., and their children Alex and Molly; Jeffrey Busch and Stephen Davis of New York; and Lisa Busch & David Lubin of Sitka, Alaska and their daughter Celia. Devoted brother of Hope Goodheart of New Rochelle, NY. A distinguished environmental engineer, he was president and CEO of Malcolm Pirnie, Inc., past president of the American Academy of Environmental Engineers and a member of the National Academy of Engineering. Memorial service for family and friends at 10:30 A.M., August 1, Temple B'nai Chaim, Georgetown, CT. Contributions may be made in his memory to The Nature Conservancy, Connecticut Chapter, 55 High Street, Middletown, CT 06457, or AmeriCares Free Clinic, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT. 06840

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLSK, CELIA G.
description: WOLSK-Celia G., 93, formerly of Freeport, NY, on July 25th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of David and Paul. Dear sister of Myron. Devoted grandmother of Jeremiah, Alexander, Daniel, Jennifer and Matthew. Great grandmother of Samuel. She will be deeply missed by her family. Service Thursday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: One Miracle, but Can We Hope for More?
description: In 1979, I was receiving specialty training in cancer medicine at the University of California, Los Angeles, and cared for a young man with widespread testicular cancer. The malignancy had grown insidiously and rapidly, as is often the case. By the time I saw him, the tumor had gripped his lungs and invaded his liver. There was little hope. His wife and twin daughters kept a steady vigil at his bedside, praying for a miracle.

title: Forget About the F-22
description: To the Editor:

title: A Touch Of Glamour (And Mozart) For Openers
description: Mostly Mozart has been redefining itself these last few years, and in a sense it is now two festivals in one. One is essentially a summer extension of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series: a program to be presented by the New London Consort on Sunday includes no Mozart at all, and in its two programs next week, the Kremerata Baltica is playing a single Mozart work and a Schnittke piece deconstructing Mozart, otherwise devoting its stage time to what appears to be a refreshingly broad sampling of 20th-century works. There is also a series of one-hour all-Haydn concerts by the Keller Quartet.

title: 'Art' Will Close Aug. 8
description: ''Art,'' a play by Yasmina Reza, is to close after the matinee on Aug. 8 at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The show, directed by Matthew Warchus and currently starring Buck Henry, Wayne Knight and George Segal, will have run for 600 regular performances and 20 previews.

title: Forget About the F-22
description: To the Editor:

title: Drugstore.com Up Sharply
description: The stock of Drugstore.com Inc. closed at almost triple its offering price after its first day of trading. The company sold five million shares at $18 each, above the expected range of $15 to $17 each. Drugstore.com closed at $50.25, as almost 8.9 million shares changed hands, some of them more than once, in trading on Nasdaq. Drugstore.com says it has about 168,000 customers.

title: THE MARKETS -- Big Board at Brink of Unknown; Questions Abound as Exchange Ponders Going Public
description: A quarter-century ago, when Richard A. Rosenblatt was first developing his skills as a trader on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, it was widely predicted that the Big Board's days were numbered.

title: American National Can Cuts Offering Price
description: American National Can Group, the world's second-largest maker of metal beer and soda cans, sold $510 million of shares in its initial public offering today, after cutting the price about 24 percent because of weak demand.

title: In America; Lessons From Yosemite
description: Crime-fighting is not always about justice. Too often when a crime is committed, the so-called criminal justice professionals feel compelled not to find out what really happened, but simply to arrest and prosecute somebody. Anybody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWIG, IRVING M.
description: EWIG-Irving M. A man larger than life. Died Tuesday, July 27, age 85. He will be missed by family, friends, co-workers here and throughout the world. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam, Friday, July 30 noon. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory can be sent to: Columbia University, C/O Dr. S. Schneller, 161 Ft. Washington Ave, New York, New York 10032.

title: DEUTSCHE PROFIT SOARS
description: The world's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., said its second-quarter profit rose 50 percent after its $9 billion purchase of the Bankers Trust Corporation helped trading income and as its tax bill fell by more than half as Germany cut corporate taxes. Net income rose to 1.18 billion euros ($1.26 billion) in the three months ended June 30 from 787 million euros a year earlier. Income from Bankers Trust was included in the accounts as of June 4. Deutsche Bank benefited from surging stocks and unprecedented demand for corporate bonds.

title: New Ways to Sign Off
description: To the Editor:

title: German Phone Concern in Talks to Buy British Venture
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Germany's largest telecommunications company, is in talks to buy One2One, the British mobile telephone concern jointly owned by London-based Cable and Wireless and MediaOne Group, the Colorado-based Internet service provider that recently agreed to be acquired by the AT&T Corporation, according to people close to the talks.

title: CBS Extends Deal With Head of TV Operations
description: CBS extended its deal with Leslie Moonves to serve as the president of CBS Television today, locking him into a long-term situation that will insure he continues as the leader of its broadcast TV operations.

title: Praise Doesn't Equal Fame, but Playwright Persists
description: Tom Murphy, a soft-spoken, sometimes depressed 64-year-old writer from County Galway in the west, is in the view of many critics Ireland's other great playwright -- that is, other than Brian Friel.

title: 14 Major League Umps Call Union Plan Flawed
description: While the National League debated which 13 umpires to jettison from its suddenly crowded staff, a group of 14 umpires yesterday lamented the loss of any jobs and said its union leadership's ''flawed strategy'' had hurt the umpires.

title: Compaq Returns To Ultralight Market
description: Compaq was one of the first computer makers to develop a really light laptop, the Aero, but it was a laptop before its time and it did not sell. This week, the Houston company returned to the ultralight category with the Armada M300.

title: $1.4 BILLION DESIGNATED FOR NEW STORES AND REMODELING
description: Safeway Inc., the supermarket chain based in Pleasanton, Calif., said yesterday that it would spend $1.4 billion to open as many as 75 new stores and remodel 250 others next year, as it seeks high earnings growth. Safeway, which has grown more through acquisitions than new store construction, hopes to increase per-share earnings by 15 percent a year over the next five years. That does not take into account its agreement last week to buy the Houston-based Randall's Food Markets for about $1.4 billion. The shares fell 81.25 cents yesterday, to $53.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURG, LILLIAN
description: HAMBURG-Lillian. On July 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Martin Hamburg. Loving mother of Marcia Carpeni and Jeff Hamburg and his wife, Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Brian, Madison and Alexandra. Service Thursday, July 29, at 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or Cancer Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, LEO V.
description: BERGER-Leo V. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their esteemed member Leo Berger and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Arvilla, and his family. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, President

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn Reports Profit Rose 15% in 2d Quarter
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the maker of the top-selling glaucoma treatment Xalatan, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 15 percent on stronger sales of that drug and Detrol, its incontinence pill.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about private investigators who pose as journalists misidentified an Internet publication that became the target of one investigator after it criticized a Hong Kong real estate project. The publication is Webb-site.com, not Cyberport, the name of the project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, RENEE
description: SILVERMAN-Renee. On July 27, after a long illness. Beloved mother of Carole and Richard Tunick, Jane and Mark Ross. Adored grandmother of Robert and Erica Tunick. Dear sister of Arthur and Sue Warshaw. Services private. Friends may call Sunday, August 1, after 1 PM, at the Tunick home, 21 Meadow Road, Scarsdale.

title: Create Your Own 3-D Computer Body Image
description: Now the Internet wants your body as well as your soul. A new technology, developed by Adrian Hilton at the University of Surrey in England, allows people to create realistic three-dimensional computer images of themselves in a digital photo booth. The representations, called avatars, can be used as more lifelike digital personas in Internet chat rooms or in networked computer games.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Nasdaq's Busy Year; The Market Steers Several Ways at Once
description: In the last year, Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, has struck deals to buy the American Stock Exchange, forged alliances with three overseas bourses and promised investors 24-hour access to the Nasdaq stock market. And at an N.A.S.D. board meeting today, Mr. Zarb will present his plan for making the Nasdaq market a for-profit, publicly held company separate from its regulatory unit.

title: Computer Issues Help Spark A Nasdaq Increase of 26.51
description: Computer-related stocks lifted the Nasdaq market to its second straight gain yesterday, even as a majority of other issues sagged. Activity slackened as investors braced for key economic reports from Washington today.

title: President Is No C.E.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIPP, RUTH ENDERS
description: TRIPP-Ruth Enders. For her love of beauty-her capacity for happiness-her love for us. Thank you, dearest Ruth. Husband Paul, children, Suzanne Jurmain and David Enders Tripp and grandchildren, Sara and David Jurmain. Good night, sweet Ruth.

title: An Elevated Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Most-Violent Video Games Are Not Biggest Sellers
description: In the wake of the high-school shootings in Littleton, Colo., the video game industry has been the focus of complaints by politicians and advocates who contend that its products cause real-life violence. But recent sales figures indicate that violent video games are not as pervasive as some believe.

title: Paying for Angola's War
description: To the Editor:

title: Neuberger Berman Plans Public Offering
description: Partners at Neuberger Berman L.L.C., one of the last large private Wall Street investment partnerships, have voted to become a publicly traded company.

title: SENTRY INSURANCE TO PURCHASE A DEERE SUBSIDIARY
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest farm-equipment maker, said yesterday that it would sell its John Deere Insurance Group unit, which insures dealers of its products, to Sentry Insurance of Stevens Point, Wis., for an undisclosed sum. The sale, which is subject to state regulatory approval, would give Sentry a 30-year-old company that reported about $315 million of premiums last year and also provides insurance for long-haul trucking companies. Deere, based in Moline, Ill., said its insurance arm was too small on its own.

title: An Evening Of Sweetness And Flash In the Park
description: The New York Philharmonic's free outdoor summer concerts are so much a part of the fabric of the summer in New York City -- and, these days, the cities in Westchester County and on Long Island that are on the orchestra's touring circuit -- that it is difficult to imagine a summer without them. But there have been years when sponsors came and went and when the concerts were in question, if not actually in peril.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ROSE
description: COHEN-Rose. My beloved Grandma, you are always in my thoughts. I miss you. Freya

title: Economic Scene; Tax-cut plans that undermine the progressive income tax.
description: AS the Senate debates plans this week to lower taxes, Democrats point to Republican proposals for $800 billion in cuts over 10 years and cry foul: the rich come away with gargantuan tax reductions compared with those for everyone else. Republican leaders respond that their large tax cuts are fair because high-income families pay a gargantuan share of Federal taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Paul Allen's Cable Company Plans Initial Public Offering

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It could have been us.''

title: Blackout Area Had a History Of Cable Flaws
description: The power distribution cables in upper Manhattan were among the most trouble-plagued in Consolidated Edison's system for years before seven of them failed on July 6, plunging Washington Heights into the city's worst blackout in 22 years, company documents show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORGER, MARGO
description: BORGER-Margo. Of Miami Beach, wife of the late Milton Borger, passed away July 27, 1999. Surviving are her children Lenny and Judy, Bette and Joel, grandchildren; Brett and Sondra, Jodi and Mike, Marlo and Andrew, Maggie and Roberto, Jill, Erin and great grandchildren Alex, Evan, Harry, Rebecca and Max. A finer woman never graced this earth. She cared for everyone and every living thing. Services will be at 1:00 P.M., on Friday at the Salem Field Cemetery. Information: Riverside Chapels, phone 516-487-9600.

title: Account Decisions By 3 Marketers
description: Three advertisers have made decisions involving big accounts.

title: DuPont Profit Is $917 Million With a 9% Increase in Revenue
description: DuPont said yesterday that it had earned $917 million in the second quarter, down slightly from last year but better than expected, helped by lower raw materials costs and better-than-expected results by its agricultural, performance coating and pharmaceutical units.

title: Free Hard Drive Space Whenever You Need It
description: A start-up company in Santa Monica, Calif., is offering a free desktop hard drive service on the Internet. But like many Manhattan apartments, the virtual hard drive does not come with a lot of storage space.

title: In a First, Attendance Exceeds Expectations at Lincoln Center Festival
description: Buoyed partly by popular enthusiasm and publicity for ''The Peony Pavilion,'' the Chinese opera, the Lincoln Center Festival exceeded box-office projections this year for the first time in its four-year history, officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: 9 Enter Pleas in U.C.L.A. Parking Case
description: Nine U.C.L.A. football players pleaded no contest today to illegally obtaining handicapped parking placards, and were sentenced to fines, community service and probation. And later in the day, the school suspended those still on the team for the first two games of the season.

title: 'People of Size' Gather to Promote Fat Acceptance
description: The caramel lollipops at registration; the black thong bikini that Marilyn Wann, a proud 270 pounds, wore at the pool party; the very pool party itself, for people who are usually pool pariahs: All these were political statements of defiance here at the convention of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance, as political as the T-shirts that read, ''Fat!So?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNINGTON, JACQUELINE
description: PENNINGTON-Jacqueline, 37. On July 22, 1999. Loving daughter of Sibylla, and treasured friend to many. We will always love and remember you. Service Saturday, July 31, 10AM at Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx.

title: Furor Over Flag Trails Giuliani on Visit to the South
description: As he pumped hands and collected donations in three Southern cities today, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani also found himself fending off criticism from politicians back home who were incensed by his decision to fly the Arkansas flag over City Hall.

title: Pettitte Blows a Tire and Now Must Sit and Wait
description: There was one out in the fourth inning tonight when Joe Torre stepped out of the Yankees' dugout to relieve Andy Pettitte, who waited on the mound, sweat dripping over his eyes and down his cheeks.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Hail Fellow Ill Met

title: Despite Maneuvers, China Seems Cautious on Taiwan
description: A Chinese news service reported today that the navy was conducting mobilization exercises along the southern coast, across from Taiwan. But it appears to be a relatively moderate operation that hints at little real military preparation.

title: Sears Appoints Head of Full-Line Stores
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company today named Mary Conway president of its full-line stores, succeeding Allan Stewart, 57, who will retire on Sept. 1.

title: Alexander Makes Money the Issue in New Ads Aimed at Bush
description: Lamar Alexander, a Republican Presidential hopeful, began a television advertisement campaign in Iowa today lampooning the fund-raising success of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas without mentioning his name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, DOROTHY MAE (SAXON)
description: REILLY-Dorothy Mae (Saxon). Died Monday, July 26, 1999. Wife of the late Joseph Thomas Reilly & sister of the late Gilbert Saxon. Mother of Joyce Ellen Reilly of Chatham, N.J. Aunt of Kenneth Saxon of San Antonio, Tex. Also surviving is a sister-in-law, Eva Saxon, of Brooklyn, N.Y., and a beloved family of friends. She was known to neighbors as Grandma Reilly. Services will be held 11 AM Saturday, July 31, at the Longhill Chapel in Chatham. Friends may call from 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday and Friday, July 29 and 30, at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home in Chatham, New Jersey. Those who wish may contribute in her memory to the Joseph and Dorothy Reilly Fund for Children, C/O Bradley Funeral Home, 345 Main Street, Chatham, N.J. 07928.

title: When the China Swans and Celery Dishes Just Have to Go
description: IF you've inherited a Matisse, you probably know what to do with it.

title: Metro Business; Vacco Is Promoted
description: Dennis C. Vacco, former New York State Attorney General, has been promoted to president of Waste Management's New York State subsidiaries. In the past, the company managed New York operations from offices in Canada, Connecticut and New Hampshire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNIER, HARRY W.
description: VERNIER-Harry W. On July 27, 1999 of Syosset, N.Y., age 84. Retired Vice President of Burlington Hosiery, Honorably discharged 1st Lt. US Army. He is survived by his loving wife Irene. Loving father of Joanne, father-in-law of John Behm. Cherished grandfather of Michael, and his wife Joyce of Brandon, FL., Christopher and Kathryn Luciano. Dear great grandfather of Marisa Luciano. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers please make donation to charity of your choice.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, R.C. ''JIM''
description: BROWN-R.C. ''Jim''. On July 26, 1999. Age 87. Advertising and public relations executive with BBDO and own firm. Known to Boys Town and the New York World's Fair, The Players Club and Fair Harbor. Survived by daughters Roberta Paul and Chris Orlicki and son Terry. Services on Monday, August 2nd, 11 AM, Saint Vincent Ferrer, Manhattan.

title: In Finding a Way To Create Cancer, Hope for New Test
description: Scientists report today that they have used a precise molecular recipe to turn normal human cells into cancer cells in the laboratory, triumphing in a task that sounded simple but that had eluded molecular biologists for more than 15 years.

title: And Plop It in the Showroom for Baby and Me
description: The arrival of their daughter, Tiger Lily Klisanin-Ross, now 10 months old, was inspiration for a child-friendly furnishings collection by the husband and wife team of Christopher Ross and Melisca Klisanin (above right, with Tiger Lily). Mr. Ross is now marketing wooden cribs (far right, $495), changing tables and chests of drawers.

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEERR, LILLIAN
description: SHEERR-Lillian. A truly remarkable lady nearing her century mark. We loved her dearly and will miss her. Sidney Kaplan Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, KEN
description: FRIEDMAN-Ken. Beloved son, brother and uncle. We will always remember your love, kindness and generosity. We will miss you. The Family

title: Timberland Splits Stock
description: The Timberland Company, a maker of hiking boots and shoes, said today that it would split its stock two shares for one. The company said the new shares would be distributed on Sept. 15 to shareholders of record as of Aug. 31. Timberland, based in Stratham, N.H., rose $4.50 a share, to $83.50. Its stock has risen 39 percent in the last year.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR SOARS. Sugar rose nearly 5 percent on signs that demand is steady though there is an abundance of supply on the world market. In New York, sugar for October delivery rose 0.28 cent, to 6.04 cents a pound.

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Sport of The Times; Piazza Takes A Long View To October
description: ON a day off that he didn't really want, Mike Piazza said the best thing about it was that he could admit they really didn't need him. The infielders banged the ball all around and out of Shea Stadium, combined for six runs batted in and vacuumed the ground balls Kenny Rogers was throwing at the Pittsburgh Pirates across six one-hit innings. After Dennis Cook lost Rogers's lead in the eighth, the Mets cleared their throats, ran seven men around the bases and posted a 9-2 victory for the Braves to stare at all night in Atlanta.

title: Flawed Fathers, Daughters Who Love and Learn
description: MY FATHER, DANCING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORING, MARVIN F., DR., AKA LEVY
description: LORING-Marvin F., Dr., aka Levy, on July 26, 1999. Loving son of the late Benjamin and Lena Levy. Dear father of Tsvi (Brooke) and father-in-law of Julie Landau. Cherished brother of Rosalyn Lobel and loving uncle. Services today, July 29, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Three Upsets at the Summer Nationals
description: Three of the top eight seeds were on the sidelines in the round of 16 today in the Spingold Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here. In play on Tuesday, the second-seeded foursome of Jim Cayne of Manhattan, Chuck Burger of West Bloomfield, Mich., Mike Passell of Plano, Tex., and Michael Seamon of Miami Beach, lost by 13 imps to Joseph Jabon of Bellevue, Wash., Aidan Ballantyne of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Henry Lortz and Wayne Ohlrich, both of Seattle.

title: G.O.P. Senators Repel an Effort To Scale Back Tax-Cut Proposal
description: Republicans in the Senate turned aside a Democratic plan today to limit the size of their proposed tax cut, even as centrists from both parties laid out a middle ground on which a compromise could eventually be reached.

title: Toll Now 19 in Swiss Canyon In an Adventure Gone Awry
description: With the death toll up to 19, and Swiss rescue workers still combing the rapids for two missing tourists, the river disaster in this pristine Swiss resort town on Tuesday has already led to soul-searching about adventure sports and in particular the fad of ''canyoning.''

title: Many Doctors Tell of Denial Of Coverage by H.M.O.'s
description: Many doctors responding to a new survey on managed care say some of their patients in the last two years have been denied coverage for a needed health service, from a prescription drug to a hospital stay.

title: Easdaq Listings Get New Rules
description: Easdaq, the Brussels-based pan-European stock market for growth companies, announced today that the United States Securities and Exchange Commission would permit American companies to make initial public offerings on Easdaq without registering with the S.E.C.

title: AS U.N. ORGANIZES, REBELS ARE TAKING CHARGE OF KOSOVO
description: The Kosovo Liberation Army has taken sweeping political control in the province, establishing a network of ministries and appointing local councils, seizing businesses and apartments, and collecting taxes and customs payments in the absence of a strong international police presence.

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUCKERS PROTEST FELT
description: Brazilian truckers intensified a strike that started on Sunday, halting cargo transport on most major highways. Food supplies to Brazil's largest cities were slowed, and hospitals complained that deliveries of medical supplies were delayed, while companies like Volkswagen and Fiat halted production at some plants. In Sao Paulo state, riot police clashed on blocked highways with truckers, who are calling for lower tolls and better protection from cargo theft.

title: Building a Crossword: Tools and Materials
description: CROSSWORD WEAVER

title: CADBURY PROFITS INCREASE
description: Rising demand for Dr Pepper in the United States and stronger confectionary sales in Britain and Australia helped Cadbury Schweppes' earnings rise 4.4 percent in the first half of 1999, the company, a London-based maker of candy and soft drinks, reported. In a telephone interview, Cadbury's chief executive, John M. Sunderland, said the company's strategy -- to rid itself of most soft-drink operations in a $1.1 billion sale to the Coca-Cola Company in favor of becoming a bigger player in the candy business -- was unaffected by the drawn-out regulatory review of its deal with Coca-Cola. In several large markets, including Australia, Mexico and Canada, the deal has not been approved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZWIRN, IRVING
description: ZWIRN-Irving. January 27, 1910-July 29, 1997. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Remembered with deepest love. Your voice we still hear, your love we still feel. ''Here's looking at you, kid.'

title: Black Clergy Object to Move Against Essex Prosecutor
description: Conceding that the Essex County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, had made mistakes and used some bad judgment, the head of a group of black ministers said today that none of that justified the drastic decision by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to strip her of her authority.

title: New Ways to Sign Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Constance Holman, 91, Pioneer in Medicine
description: Constance Friess Holman, the first woman to become chief resident in medicine at New York Hospital, died last Friday at Brattleboro Memorial Hospital in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 91.

title: 4 Rapes Reported At Woodstock, State Police Say
description: Four women who attended last weekend's Woodstock '99 music festival have reported that they were raped during the course of the event, the state police said. A crisis counselor who worked at the festival said that he saw at least five women being gang-raped in the midst of a thrashing, swaying crowd.

title: Toward Better Communication Across the Language Barrier
description: MEMBERS of the jet set, take note: Scientists have created speech-synthesizer technology that translates spoken words from one language into another, even when the speaker and listener are on opposite sides of the earth.

title: Road Daze: A Hand on the Wheel and an Ear to the Phone
description: TWO years ago, as Charles Finnie, an investment banker in San Francisco, was driving home from work, he did what he did nearly every time he got in the car: he picked up his cell phone and started dialing. Eyes averted from the road, he slammed into the car in front of him. No one was injured, but the impact jammed Mr. Finnie's door shut. So he climbed out through the sun roof -- still talking on the phone.

title: Airlines Weigh Calling Off An Alliance
description: The proposed alliance between American Airlines and British Airways may be called off as early as this week because the two airlines cannot get approval from United States and British regulators, according to people close to the matter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORING, MARVIN
description: LORING-Marvin. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Mens Club mourn the passing of their devoted member and extend hearfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, Pres.

title: How Manchester United Scores on Its Balance Sheet, Too
description: They were one goal down with less than three minutes to play and Manchester United seemed doomed. Then, magically, the fabled British soccer team scored twice to wrest victory in the top European tournament from Bayern Munich of Germany.

title: Carrots for Readers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Adviser Defends Decision to Retire NATO General
description: The President's top security adviser today defended the decision to speed up the retirement of the NATO Supreme Commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, by a few months to make way for his intended replacement, and the adviser insisted that the move did not signal any displeasure with the general's performance.

title: F.B.I. Joins Investigation Into Florida Inmate's Death
description: Nine men know what happened inside a 7-by-9-foot cell in Florida State Prison on the morning of July 17, when prison guards armed with stun guns arrived to forcibly extract Frank Valdez, a death-row inmate who murdered a corrections officer 12 years ago.

title: Cancer Society Quits Group on Cell Research
description: Lobbying over the issue of human embryonic stem cell research has generated so much controversy that the American Cancer Society has withdrawn its sponsorship of Patients' Cure, a group founded to publicize the medical benefits of stem cell research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHMAN, ROBINSON
description: CUSHMAN-Robinson. Paul Cushmans mourn the loss of a jovial, talented engineer. Graduate of St. Paul's and Yale. He served United Technology; in retirement he rebuilt his house, sailed heartily and created stables.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Valentine Feels Insecure
description: Since the first week in June, when three of his coaches were abruptly dismissed and Manager Bobby Valentine suggested that he should be judged on the ensuing 55 games of 1999 because his coaches had been judged on the first 55, the Mets have had the best record in the majors.

title: Music to Lose Yourself In And for Locating Yourself
description: Innovative pop music can be reduced to two categories: the kind that tries to remove the listener from a sense of place and time, and the kind that puts geography and history to use. Central Park Summerstage's triple bill on Sunday afternoon had both: Esthero, from Toronto, which makes ethereal, rootless dance music; Aterciopelados, a band from Colombia, surrounding itself in sharp-sounding technology while looking backward at the traditions of both South American music and rock, and Otto, a Brazilian singer who lies somewhere between those poles.

title: Eagles and McNabb Are No Closer
description: When Donovan McNabb finally signs a contract and puts on an Eagles uniform, he'll see just how vocal, critical and hungry fans are for a winner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLING, ANNE
description: BILLING-Anne. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Barbara Billing and Joan Feifer. Adored grandmother of Jana, Richard and Doris, and Michael. Loving aunt of Susan Silver and many nieces and nephews. Loving friend of Bess Gold. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Bway. Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 AM Thursday.

title: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN RISES. The yen continued to rise against the dollar on demand for the currency from foreign investors who are buying Japanese stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.12 yen, down from 116.36 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLESCHNER, MALCOM KING
description: FLESCHNER-Malcom King. died at home on Tuesday, July 27,1999 from complications arising from renal failure. Mr. Fleschner was born in New York City on March 25, 1918 to the late Abraham and Beatrice Fleschner. He was raised in New York and graduated from the McBurney School in 1935 and the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania in 1939. In 1941 he married Janice Hubshman, also of New York City. During World War II Mr. Fleschner served as a second lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps where he saw action in the South Pacific. In the business world Mr. Fleschner apprenticed as an executive at Macy's, worked as an investment banker at Wertheim & Co and later, with William Becker, founded a hedge fund, Fleschner Becker Associates. In 1970 he moved from Westport, Connecticut to Palm Beach. A devoted husband, father and grandfather who dearly loved his family. Mr. Fleschner will be remembered for his courage, determination, generosity and wit. He and his wife Janice traveled extensively, for many years summering in the Dordogne region of France. He gave generously to many charitable organizations, including the United Way, Planned Parenthood, the ACLU, the United Negro College Fund, the Wharton School and the Democratic Party. Mr. Fleschner is survived by his wife, Janice; son and daughter-in-law Andrew and Constance Fleschner; daughter and son-in-law Laura and Gerhard Gschwandtner; sister Rita Caine and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the United Way of Palm Beach, 44 Coconut Row, Palm Beach, Florida 33480.

title: Essay; Politician, Be Thyself
description: Politicians looking to their days of takeover now submit to imageers to find ways of makeover. They steer not by their internal compass but by some wind-sensitive telltale, and mistakenly assume that what worked for Bill Clinton will work for them.

title: Group Protests Evictions in South Lebanon
description: Hundreds of Lebanese have been expelled from their homes in Israeli-held southern Lebanon since 1985 by a local militia armed and financed by Israel, according to a report issued here today by the New York-based Human Rights Watch.

title: Harry (Sweets) Edison, 83, Trumpeter for Basie Band, Dies
description: Harry (Sweets) Edison, a member of the Count Basie band from 1938 to 1950 and a trumpeter of original, minimalist conviction who played behind singers like Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald and Frank Sinatra, died on Tuesday at his home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 83.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOFF, RICHARD, DR.
description: BERKOFF-Richard, Dr., of Rye, NY., passed away on July 28, 1999, from cancer of the pancreas at the age of 62. He is survived by his adoring wife, Ethel, his three devoted children, Jeffrey Berkoff, Gregory Berkoff and Amy Rakoff, his father, Robert Berkoff, his brother, Martin Berkoff and sisterin-law Susan Berkoff as well as by his four grandchildren, Rose, Nicole, Alex and baby Julia, due in August, two stepchildren, John and Rene Lipsio, his son-in-law, Steven Rakoff and daughter-inlaw, Claire Berkoff. He was born in the Bronx, in 1937, where he atteneded Christopher Columbus High School before going on to New York University, where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree. His plans of going to Columbia Dental School changed after graduating college when he received a chiropractic adjustment to his neck which cured him of a long standing problem with headaches, and he went on to study at New York Chiropractic Institute, instead. He received his doctorate in 1960 and opened his first office in Harlem, New York. The social unrest and subsequent riots in Harlem during the middle and late 1960's forced him to move his practice to New Rochelle, where he worked until 1980, when he opened Chiropractic Associates on Palmer Avenue in Larchmont. He was a longtime member of Westchester Country Club, where he loved to play golf with his wife and his group of close friends. It is difficult to assess the scope or the force of the impact Richard Berkoff had on his community. The number of people he helped guide, heal and support reached into the thousands. He inspired admiration and comfort with a particular quiet goodness which was his gift. In the last year of his life he continued to receive regular communications from hundreds of patients whose lives had changed as a result of coming under his care, many of whom he had not seen since his days in Harlem, forty years earlier. In lieu of flowers, it was his wish that donations be sent to his favorite charity, the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 East Jericho Tpk, Smithtown, NY 11787-9897. Funeral service Friday July 30 12:30pm at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, NY, 914-381-1809. A committal service at Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Drug Company Ads Attack Medicare Coverage of Drugs
description: ''Flo,'' an arthritic Medicare beneficiary, made her debut today in television commercials and newspaper advertisements, cautioning Congress about potential pitfalls in its effort to establish Medicare coverage for prescription drugs.

title: With U.S. Training, Colombia Melds War on Rebels and Drugs
description: This tangle of jungle and rivers is a front line in Colombia's war against the twin plagues of drugs and guerrillas, the place where the United States is betting that it can help the Colombian military finally gain the upper hand.

title: Morocco's Need for Aid Could Go Unmet
description: In the crowded cobbled alleyways of the old souk, the young men loitering in doorways and old women selling tattered wares say they know exactly what they want from Morocco's new King.

title: Accounting Board Backs Off Proposal on Research Costs
description: The nation's accounting rule makers have backed away from a proposal that would have prevented companies' from being able to write off immediately the costs of unfinished research and development projects acquired in mergers.

title: Where the Classics Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Kinshasa Journal; Papa and a Rebel Son Ask: Who's the Betrayer?
description: One of the strangest subplots in the war in Congo, a conflict of innumerable betrayals and head-spinning surprises, has been the very public disintegration of one of the country's richest families: the Bembas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWEN, MARIA SZENI
description: COWEN-Maria Szeni, July 27, 1999. Beloved wife of Leon. Devoted stepmother of Ron and loving sister of Elizabeth Moesser. Recognized abstract expressionist painter for half a century. Memorial service on Sunday, August 8, at Oakland Memorial Park, Monmouth Junction, NJ. Contributions in her memory may be made to the United Jewish Appeal, 130 East 59 St., New York, NY 10022.

title: Where the Classics Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Op-Art
Morgan Stanley Is Target Sex Bias Inquiry
description: For more than a dozen years, Allison K. Schieffelin was in Wall Street's fast lane. One of a small number of women who specialize in selling exotic financial products, Ms. Schieffelin thrived at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, one of the finance industry's most respected firms. She takes home well in excess of $1 million each year. She felt certain she would became a managing director, the equivalent of partner.

title: REYNOLDS TOBACCO SETS LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED DIVIDEND
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc., the No. 2 United States cigarette maker, said yesterday that it would pay a quarterly dividend of 77.5 cents a share, less than analysts had expected. The cash dividend is the company's first since the tobacco business was separated from the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation last month. It will be payable Oct. 1 to shareholders as of Sept. 10. The payout equals $3.10 a share on an annual basis; analysts had forecast $3.23 to $3.60. R. J.
