Reynolds, of Winston-Salem, N.C., had told analysts that it would set the dividend at about half of estimated cash earnings for 1999. The shares fell 56.25 cents, to $27.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, FRANCES (FRANKIE)
description: EISNER-Frances (Frankie) Phillips Lewis passed away peacefully July 27 in Palm Beach at 96. Beloved mother of Brenda Ballin and the late Lewis Phillips, stepchildren, Rita Rand, Micky Krulwich, Tubby Stayman & Marilyn Eisner. Devoted grandmother of Amy Penn, Michael Phillips, Leslie Ballin, Shakira Ballin and Samantha Phillips D'Olivares. Proud great grandmother of Sabrina, Derek, Gabriel, Eli and Sohphia. Interment private.

title: Orosco May Make Return to Shea
description: In their quest to add depth to their weary bullpen, the Mets have spoken to the Baltimore Orioles about acquiring Jesse Orosco, according to executives from other major league teams. The 42-year-old left-hander, who is 0-2 with a 7.06 earned run average, pitched for the 1986 World Series champion Mets, and the team is serious about bringing him back.

title: Tracking Down Cell-Phone Users
description: ONE of the big challenges for the cell phone industry in the next two years will be the task of following its customers. The Federal Communications Commission says that by early 2001, all cell phone companies will have to provide 911 operators with the location of anyone calling on a cell phone so help can get to the right place.

title: KANSAS UTILITY MAY SELL STAKE IN COMPRESSOR CONCERN
description: Western Resources Inc., the big Kansas electric utility, said yesterday that it might sell its 11 percent stake in the Hanover Compressor Company, a supplier of compressors that move natural gas through pipelines. Westar Capital, a Western unit, owns about 3.2 million Hanover shares valued around $113 million. Western acquired the stake in 1995 when it sold its gas-compression business to the Houston-based Hanover. Western, which has 614,000 power customers in Kansas, said the investment did not mesh with its business strategy, though Hanover's shares have risen about 38 percent this year. Shares of Western fell 18.75 cents yesterday, to $26.5625, while Hanover rose 12.5 cents, to $35.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, RONALD GREGORY
description: KEENAN-Ronald Gregory, 51, of Verona, N.J., died June 27, 1999, at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Utica, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at 7:30 PM Sunday, August 1, in the sanctuary of Union Congregational Church, Upper Montclair, N.J. Mr. Keenan was born in Middletown, Conn., and lived in Montclair and Verona for 30 years. Mr. Keenan graduated from Notre Dame High School, New Haven, Conn. He received BS and MA degrees in Economics at Lehigh University. He was elected to Beta Gamma Sigma, the National Economics Honor Society. Mr. Keenan was the managing director of American Re Securities Corporation in Princeton, N.J. Previously, he was the managing director of Chase Securities in New York City. Mr. Keenan was a member of the Board of Directors of the Liberty Brokerage Investment Corporation, the Mortgage Backed Securities Clearing Corporation, and the Bond Market Association, where he chaired the Mortgage and Asset-Backed Committee. Mr. Keenan was a member of the Union League Club in New York City, the Adirondack League Club in Old Forge, N.Y., and the Montclair Golf Club. He served as chairman of the Parents' Fund Committee of Smith College. He is survived by his wife, Eileen, and his daughter, Anne. Donations may be made in Mr. Keenan's memory to Smith College, Northampton, Mass.

title: From the Bird Of Bilbao To Panama's Rain Forests
description: The architect Frank Gehry (inset with Berta, his Panamanian wife of 25 years) has an epic commission. Mr. Gehry is leading a team of architects, engineers and environmentalists in developing a master plan for sites at either end of the Panama Canal, it was announced by Panama's President, Ernesto Perez Balladares. The zone began reverting to Panama this spring and will conclude with the canal by the end of the year. Mr. Gehry, whose titanium-skinned Guggenheim Bilbao in Spain resembles a Cubist bird in flight, is charged with preserving and revitalizing both architecture and nature. The master plan will include Fort Sherman and some 23,100 acres of virgin rain forest at the Caribbean mouth of the canal. The rain forest has rare bird species as well as the ruins of San Lorenzo, a 16th-century Spanish fort, above right. The once glorious, now down-at-the-heels town of Colon (top) is across the canal from the former American military base at Fort Sherman. Mr. Gehry said his conceptual design for the sites in Panama does not yet include drawings for new buildings. The Panamanian Government favors eco-tourism at the Fort Sherman site, and there are tentative plans for an eco-resort hotel. It is interesting that after so much hand-wringing 22 years ago about giving the canal away, it is ultimately the cooperation between an American architect and a team of American and Panamanian authorities that will jointly shape its future.

title: Czech Defenseman Signs Contract
description: Tomas Kloucek, a defenseman who was their sixth pick in the 1998 entry draft, signed with the Rangers yesterday. Terms of the deal were not revealed.

title: Where the Classics Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnival Cruises Raises Its Tally Of Sexual Misconduct Reports
description: Carnival Cruise Lines said today that there had been 108 accusations that crew members were involved in sexual assaults and sexual misconduct aboard its ships in a five-year period that ended last August, not 62 incidents as reported by the company two weeks ago.

title: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK; Agbayani Makes Adjustments
description: Major league pitchers took away Benny Agbayani's home run and asked him to show them his mettle and his savvy. They nipped at the corners with pitches and kept him off balance with inside fastballs. Then, opponents watched as Agbayani showed his vulnerability at the plate and his frailty in the outfield. Agbayani learned quickly that if he was to thrive, he would have to adjust.

title: Anne Richardson, 69, Patron of Literacy
description: Anne Richardson, former chairwoman of Reading Is Fundamental, the nation's largest organization promoting children's literacy, died on Monday at a hospital in Cheverly, Md. She was 69 and lived in Mitchellville, Md., a Washington suburb, with her husband, former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGUS, HAROLD J.
description: ALGUS-Harold J. On July 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Karen (Marc) & Michael (Anne). Dear brother of Seymour. Devoted grandfather of Aron, Elise, Ariel, Alexandra and Gabrielle. Services private.

title: A Way to Let Your Fingers Recharge Your Batteries
description: From the why-didn't-somebody-think-of-this-sooner file: Compaq recently filed a patent for an ingenious keyboard that uses the typing motion itself to recharge laptop batteries.

title: Rom. and Jul. Abbrev., With Mercutio as Mercutia
description: Characters tend to drop into the Present Company's ''Romeo and Juliet'' from adjoining rooftops; Juliet's balcony is a platform on an industrial scaffold; the stars are strings of construction lights in metal cages, and the young toughs from the Capulet and Montague clans do battle with chains.

title: State's Hospitals Lobby Against Medicare Cuts
description: Representatives of the New Jersey Hospital Association went to Washington yesterday to tell the state Congressional delegation that Medicare cuts under the Federal Balanced Budget Act threaten to close some of the group's 112 member hospitals.

title: Anthropology of the Present
description: The entries in a new softcover series of design directories have the chunky heft of a Boy Scout Handbook. Paola Antonelli, the Museum of Modern Art's curator for design and architecture, wrote the books' introductions. They take an anthropological viewpoint and, she said, ''Nothing could be more interesting.'' Interesting, but not stuffy: Legos are called one of Scandinavia's important contributions. ''Italy'' and ''Scandinavia'' are in bookstores ($25; Rizzoli). ''Great Britain'' and ''Germany'' arrive this winter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAUNER, SYLVIA
description: TRAUNER-Sylvia. January 20, 1915-July 29, 1984. Beloved and cherished mother and grandmother. Always remembered and missed by all. Love, David

title: Andreychuk Signs One-Year Contract
description: The Bruins signed the free-agent left wing Dave Andreychuk to a one-year, $1.2 million contract, adding one of the N.H.L's most consistent scorers to their roster.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decison by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to take away the powers of Patricia A. Hurt, the Essex County Prosecutor, misstated the given name of a prosecutor indicted last week on charges of beating an alleged drug dealer and making an illegal search and arrest. She is Priscilla Corcoran, not Patricia.

title: Metro Business; Restaurant Group Plans Sale of Stock
description: New York Restaurant Group Inc., operator of Smith & Wollensky steakhouses, plans to hold an initial stock sale that could raise as much as $35 million.

title: Gore's Plan for Success in 2000: Wide Array of Specific Positions
description: Vice President Al Gore believes he has a not-so-secret weapon in the Presidential race -- his knowledge of public policy issues. He has staked out positions on scores of topics and suggests that his opponents, both Democratic and Republican, have been vague and therefore undeserving.

title: White-on-White Eclecticism Means a Wolf in the House
description: In September, the Cuban-born decorator and photographer Vicente Wolf will open VW Home, a 3,000-square-foot showroom that will sell to the trade and the public. His licensed furniture, fabrics, lighting and accessories will be there, along with one-of-a-kind antiques, Anachini linens, Rajasthan silks and his photographs. Mr. Wolf said his showroom will look like his nearby loft, long a favorite location for stylists and photographers. The ingredients of the Wolf ''white box'' look: a buttery white-on-white palette; intricately arranged heaps of table-top props; mismatched chairs; framed art and giant mirrors leaning casually against the wall; Oriental exotica; ecclesiastical ornament, and urban junk. ''It's not meant to be a highbrow, D & D Building thing,'' Mr. Wolf said. VW Home will be at 333 West 39th Street.

title: California Company Offers Palm Memory Upgrade
description: Though the new wafer-thin Palm V got points for size and style from gadget lovers, it came with only two megabytes of RAM -- considered paltry by Palm users who like to load up with plenty of third-party applications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESSEL, BARBARA (BUNNY)
description: NESSEL-Barbara (Bunny). The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Bunny Nessel, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, Pres. Marshall L. Hess, Secy

title: He's Far From Home But Closer to Success
description: A few days after he was drafted into the National Basketball Association, Aleksandar Radojevic took a flight from New York to Los Angeles to compete in the Long Beach Summer League. The 7-foot-3-inch center, taken 12th over all by the Toronto Raptors, was dreading the six-hour flight. Until Adam Sandler walked up and introduced himself to the native of Montenegro, a region of Yugoslavia.

title: Smart Simians Run Amok in Ape Escape
description: HUMAN beings and monkeys have two things in common: good hand-eye coordination and joysticks. Both species are using the former to make great progress with the latter.

title: Longevity and History
description: To the Editor:

title: Parole Officer Denies Lying In Corruption Investigation
description: A member of the New York State Parole Board took the stand in his own defense yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and said that he had not lied to a grand jury investigating possible corruption at the board.

title: All the Comforts of '27
description: In 1927, in Monroe, Mich., Edward M. Knabusch and his friend Edwin J. Shoemaker invented the La-Z-Boy chair.

title: Leash Patrol Touts Victory In City Parks; Next, Pit Bulls
description: The Parks Department has claimed victory in its war against unleashed dogs.

title: Need Attitude? Voila, a Concierge
description: ITS front-line employees having completed a three-month training program to improve service for travelers, Amtrak announced in advertisements this month: ''10,000 employees went back to school. 10,000 concierges graduated.''

title: INSIDE
description: A Capital Industry

title: Faust, Transfigured, in an Adventurous Schumann Concert
description: Through happy planning or accident, the musical portion of Lincoln Center Festival '99 ended on a note of transcendence on Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, as Faust, earlier tormented, emerged transfigured in Schumann's ''Scenes From Goethe's 'Faust.' '' This was the most adventurous of John Eliot Gardiner's four Schumann concerts with the Orchestre Revolutionnaire et Romantique, the others having centered on the symphonies.

title: Miller Brewing moves the accounts of its two biggest brands. Again.
description: A BEER blast for two unconventional agencies known for their creative prowess turned into a beer bust yesterday when the Miller Brewing Company abruptly turned over their assignments, for its two largest beer brands, to big, mainstream shops that work for Miller's parent, the Philip Morris Companies.

title: Senior Microsoft Executive To Leave Management Job
description: Paul Maritz, a senior executive at the Microsoft Corporation, is returning to his roots as a programmer as part of the company's campaign to persuade software developers to continue to rely on its technology despite the rise of the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, MARTIN
description: GINSBURG-Martin. Abe Ginsburg, his wife Sylvia and their children Bernice and Marvin, Howard and Randi, and Jaclyn and David sadly mourn the loss of their beloved brother and uncle Martin. He will always be remembered for his gentle, caring personality and utmost devotion to his wife, family and friends. Martin was a sensitive and creative individual gifted in painting, sculpting and music. He was very philanthropic and a major contributor to schools and youth centers in Israel as well as other charities such as the Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach, the Byalstoker Home For The Aged in New York, Technion in Israel and UJA Federation. His lifelong kindness and love are memories that will not be forgotten and he will be missed by all of us who loved him dearly.

title: Dressers That Won't Stay in the Bedroom
description: THINK of these new storage units as cross-dressers. Unlike traditional bureaus that are suitable only for the bedroom, these cabinets, fit for multi-tasking, are fully as comfortable in a home office.

title: New Ways to Sign Off
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Voice Among The Plants
description: Wallpaper for tree huggers? New Eden is an irreverent new English garden magazine whose editor, Tim Richardson, 31, was a stand-up comic while at Oxford University. Its topics have included underwater flower arranging, alternatives to the fig leaf for Adam and Eve, and ''Build Your Own Grotto,'' a how-to rivaling the obsessively glue-gunned seashells of Elle Decor's editor, Marian McEvoy. Published every other month, it is $7 on newsstands; $56 by subscription from (011) 44-1622-778778.

title: Origins; Walkman Sounded Bell for Cyberspace
description: ''A YEAR here and he still dreamed of cyberspace, hope fading nightly.''

title: City Settles Lawsuit Over an Upstate Homeless Shelter
description: The city avoided a trial in a lawsuit over its operation of a homeless shelter in Orange County yesterday by agreeing to a settlement that would bar the city from helping anyone in its homeless shelters find permanent housing in the upstate county.

title: New Jersey Quickly Plans For Execution
description: With New Jersey suddenly scheduled to carry out its first execution in more than 35 years, state corrections officials were scrambling today to determine precisely where and how they will take the life of John Martini Sr., a convicted killer.

title: Sanders Puts It in Writing: He's Gone
description: As quietly and as unassumingly as he entered the National Football League, Barry Sanders has left it, simply issuing a statement yesterday that he is retiring after 10 seasons as a Detroit Lions running back.

title: Democrats Now Expect Senate to Vote on Holbrooke Next Week
description: The Senate will probably vote next week on the long-delayed nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to the position of chief American delegate to the United Nations, the Senate Democratic leader said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MESERVE, KATHLEEN K.
description: MESERVE-Kathleen K. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, New York, July 31st at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to VNA Hospice, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960 in memory of Kathleen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, THOMAS J., REV.
description: McCAFFREY-Thomas J., Rev. On July 27, 1999. Ordained for the people of New York on March 1, 1947. Born on March 1, 1922. The son of Felix & Agnes Maloney McCaffrey. He fulfilled his ministry at St. Mary's Church in Yonkers, St. Pius X Church and Our Lady of Fatima Church in Scarsdale. He was a teacher at Archbishop Stepinac High School for over 30 years teaching American history and religion. He also taught the use of sign language, often celebrating Mass using signing. He is the brother of John & Rita McCaffrey of West Palm Beach, uncle of Kevin and Karen McCaffrey and great-uncle of Tara McCaffrey. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Friday at 10 AM at Our Lady of Fatima Church in Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers donations to the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 1011 First Avenue, New York City 10022 will be appreciated.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BARNES GROUP INC., Bristol, Conn., a maker of springs and parts for jet engines, agreed to buy the nitrogen gas springs business of Allegheny Teledyne Inc., Pittsburgh, for an undisclosed price.

title: It Looks Like What?
description: To the Editor:

title: European Court Orders France to Pay Victim of Police Torture
description: France, a country that has proudly enshrined human rights since 1789, was ordered by the European Court of Human Rights today to pay the equivalent of $100,000 to a convicted Dutch-Moroccan drug dealer for violating his rights with police ''torture'' to make him confess.

title: 5 Weeks of Toil Build Toward 2 Days of Reckoning
description: On her lunch break one recent afternoon, Shawn Hunt sat on a metal folding chair outside Public School 41 in Brooklyn and sorted through some of the reasons she became a teacher seven years ago.

title: SONY PROFITS FALL
description: The world's second-largest maker of consumer electronics, the Sony Corporation, said its first-quarter earnings fell 54 percent, less than expected, as improved sales of camcorders and notebook computers helped offset lower prices for mobile phones. The company posted pretax profit from operations of 42.82 billion yen ($370 million), or 44.9 yen a share, for the April-June quarter, compared with 93.06 billion yen, or 100 yen a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected a loss. Sales fell 8.4 percent, to 1.48 trillion yen.

title: Tour de Force on the Tour de France
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The 72 Faces Of Karen Black
description: Look up Karen Black's videography and the list of credits, while falling well short of, say, John Wayne's, stretches about as long as any actor's. From 1960 and ''The Prime Time'' (a satire about a day of American television without the censors) to 1997 and ''Cries of Silence'' (about a traumatized girl found in the aftermath of Hurricane Camille), the Black entries in ''Videohound's Golden Movie Retriever'' number 72. (Wayne stands at 140.)

title: Heat Just Hangs On, Promising a Difficult Weekend
description: The relentless summer of trembling heat and bone-white days continued across the New York region yesterday as demand for electricity soared again, power failures struck thousands of homes and businesses in New Jersey and forecasters warned of yet another sweltering weekend in the doldrums.

title: Not Another Woodstock; Boredom and Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Potshots the Entire Audience Can Grasp
description: Try to imagine, if you dare, what it might have been like if Lawrence Welk had become the producer of ''Saturday Night Live.'' Out with the abrasive, off-the-wall comics and in with a perkier, more wholesome ensemble that knows that a smile doesn't have to be sarcastic. The show's wall-to-wall parody would be set entirely to music that people could hum along with. And the jokes would be old enough and broad enough so that no one in the audience would feel left out by insider hipness.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Leader Arises For Top Post In State Police
description: Looking to end her long and politically turbulent search for a new commander of the New Jersey State Police, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is preparing to offer the job to a Federal agent, Carson Dunbar, according to administration officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERBEL, GILBERT
description: KERBEL-Gilbert. of Ardsley, NY on July 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Sherry. Loving father of Judy LeCain of Saratoga Springs, New York, Richard and Claudia Kerbel of North Kingstown, RI. Devoted grandfather of Sara LeCain, Allison & Nathan Kerbel. Brother-inlaw of Ruth Moss. Also survived by one sister Sylvia Kerbel. Funeral Friday 12:00 noon, EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10461 appreciated.

title: On Field and Off, Yankees Have a Rotten Experience
description: The visiting dugout in Comiskey Park is floored with wood, and underneath it water has collected and rot has set in, creating a stench that prompted Yankees Manager Joe Torre to recall the day he uncovered a dead cat.

title: Bugatti: Generations of Artistry
description: SAY ''Bugatti,'' and most people think ''automobile.''

title: A Pillar of Opposition Who Keeps Belgrade Guessing
description: Dragoslav Avramovic is sorely tempted to heed the call, but he's nearly 80 and has serious kidney troubles, and he's not really sure the moment is ripe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPER, ETHEL
description: SPER-Ethel. The Board of Directors and Members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Ethel Sper, whose many years of friendship and devotion to the Club will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Richard M. Feldman, President Edward J. Landau, Secretary

title: Jump in Labor Cost Prompts Fear of Rising Interest Rates
description: An unexpected spike in an important inflation warning signal that tracks labor costs spooked financial markets yesterday, overshadowing a separate Government report that showed the robust American economy took a breather in the spring.

title: Perhaps Not the Best Place To Spend a Couple of Nights
description: The Haunting

title: Snacking Today: Any Time and Anywhere
description: On a Sunday morning at a Roman Catholic church here, Mary Hallan Fiorito glanced at a nearby pew to see a woman drinking a can of Coke at Mass.

title: Edmund Klein, 77, an Expert on Skin Cancer
description: Dr. Edmund Klein, whose pioneering work on skin cancer was honored with a Clinical Research Award from the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation in 1972, died on Saturday at Millard Fillmore Hospital in Buffalo. He was 77 and lived in Williamsville, N.Y., a Buffalo suburb.

title: 2 Brokerage Firms Well Known In Frenzied Day-Trading World
description: The two brokerage houses where a gunman opened fire yesterday in Atlanta, killing nine people, were among the most well known firms specializing in day trading, the fast and furious, minute-by-minute trading of stocks by computer.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Musical Strikes It Rich

title: Not Another Woodstock
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Admits He Exported Aircraft Parts Illegally
description: A Danish man admitted in Federal Court yesterday that he had falsified export documents for a shipment of aircraft parts to the Middle East, Federal prosecutors said.

title: City Charter Panel Won't Seek to Eliminate Art Commission
description: A Mayoral commission considering changes to the City Charter voted last night not to seek the elimination of the city's Art Commission in a ballot referendum this November, reversing direction on one of the 40 proposed changes that researchers working for the mayoral panel have recommended.

title: Co-Chairmen Split Duties at Citigroup
description: Citigroup's co-chairmen, Sanford Weill and John Reed, will split responsibility for managing the company, the largest United States financial services concern, according to an internal memorandum.

title: Security Training Ordered For More Energy Dept. Sites
description: Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has ordered a one-day stand-down of many of the Energy Department's research and defense-related operations next week for counter-espionage and security training in the wake of charges that China had stolen nuclear secrets from a Government weapons laboratory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Big Gain in Labor Costs Raises Fear of Higher Rates

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITENKO, BARBARA
description: WITENKO-Barbara. Happy birthday. Miss you like crazy, girlfriend. Love, Dian

title: Giants' Brown Is Sidelined Indefinitely
description: So much for the buoyant atmosphere that usually accompanies the opening day of a football training camp.

title: Unleashing Early Music's Drama
description: One might have thought that all the European period instrument ensembles that have become stars on recordings over the last couple of decades had already visited New York, where appetites for early-music recordings are healthy, and indigenous competition, while formidable, is not overabundant. But there are pleasures still to be sampled. Philip Pickett, a recorder player and one of the most imaginative early-music directors working in Britain, is just now getting around to performing in New York with the New London Consort, the ensemble he founded in 1976. The group is to make its United States debut in a Mostly Mozart concert on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Judge Orders Clinton to Pay $90,000 to Jones's Lawyers
description: In what could be the final chapter in Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit, a Federal judge today ordered President Clinton to pay Ms. Jones's lawyers nearly $90,000 in compensation for extra work they performed because of the President's false testimony about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: California Calls Off Effort to Carry Out Immigrant Measure
description: The landmark 1994 referendum that barred illegal immigrants and their children from receiving government services like a public education and became one of the most contentious political issues in California history, was declared all but dead today.

title: Thomas L. Kimball, 81; Led Wildlife Group
description: Thomas L. Kimball, former chief executive of the National Wildlife Federation, died on July 20 at Manor Care Convalescent Home in Citrus Heights, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Roseville, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAKOS, JILL KLEPPER
description: MAKOS-Jill Klepper. You are always remembered. Be with God. Jim Makos

title: Group Says Banks Don't Push Low-Cost Checking Accounts
description: Banks in New York are obligated to offer low-cost checking accounts, but it is often hard for customers to find out about them, a consumer watchdog group said yesterday.

title: Darwinian Monkeyshines Much Sung and Danced
description: There is no reason in the world that creationists shouldn't tap-dance. They may, however, want to look for a better vehicle than ''The Great Debate,'' a well-intentioned but dreadful and self-congratulatory anti-evolution musical at the Lamb's Theater.

title: Stock Funds Return to Favor With Hefty June Investments
description: Investors poured $19.2 billion into stock mutual funds last month, completing the strongest quarter for stock-fund sales in a year and suggesting that many people have regained the calm they lost last summer, when fund sales evaporated as the stock market plunged almost 20 percent.

title: Where Steel Was King, a New Spirit Reigns
description: One fine day this summer, wreckers toppled six towering smokestacks along the Monongahela River.

title: Morgan Stanley and U.S. Panel Given Deadline on Case Dispute
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have been given two weeks to resolve a dispute about whether the Wall Street firm must produce all the information the Federal agency has subpoenaed in a gender-discrimination case, people briefed on court proceedings said yesterday.

title: Dance Moves Back to Nature
description: DANCE heads for the parks, plazas and streets of the city and beyond each summer. In a working vacation of sorts, dancers have a chance to perform for larger, newer audiences, often on shared programs with artists in other fields. For audiences, summer festivals can be full of distractions not found in a formal theater setting. Still, the experience is also serendipitous and the price is right most of the time, with admission often free or by small suggested donation.

title: Phaidon Gizikis, '73 Greek Junta Officer, 82
description: Phaidon Gizikis, a Greek general who as President of Greece played a key role in paving the way for the return of democracy after seven years of dictatorial rule, died on Monday at the Nimits military hospital in Athens. He was 82 and a longtime resident of Athens.

title: Share Prices Tumble After Report Shows Gains in Wages
description: Stock prices tumbled sharply and broadly yesterday after the Government reported that employers paid unexpectedly large wage and benefit increases during the spring quarter, making it more likely -- but by no means certain -- that the Federal Reserve will again increase interest rates to avert inflation.

title: Clinton Told to Pay For False Testimony
description: In what could be the end of Paula Jones's lawsuit accusing President Clinton of sexual misconduct while he was Governor of Arkansas, a Federal judge in Little Rock, Ark., has ordered Mr. Clinton to pay nearly $90,000 in compensation to Ms. Jones's lawyers for extra work they performed as a result of his false testimony about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Lions' Sanders Says He's Down, but Watch Out for a Reverse
description: Earlier this month Detroit Lions wide receiver Herman Moore bumped into Barry Sanders while they were running errands near their homes in a Detroit suburb. It was one of the few times that anyone had made contact with Sanders, the Detroit running back. A few minutes into the conversation, Sanders dropped a bombshell.

title: POLISH TELECOM STOCK DEBUT
description: In the first public stock offering by a Polish company in the United States, Netia Holding S.A. raised $121 million on the Nasdaq stock market through the sale of 5.5 million American Depository Receipts, each equivalent to one share, at $22. Netia, which began operations in 1994, has become Poland's second-biggest telephone company behind the state-run Telekomunikacja Polska S.A. Netia provides telephone services in territories covering 13 million people or about a third of the country's population.

title: Followers of Chinese Sect Defend Its Spiritual Goals
description: Sitting around a table in the back room of a restaurant on this city's south side, four followers of Falun Gong discussed their shock and sense of betrayal at the Government's crackdown on their spiritual movement.

title: Sneaky Summer Charter Changes
description: August is not a good time to revamp New York City's government. New Yorkers shut down in August. They go away. They focus on sunblock and barbecue, like ordinary people. They are not available to discuss whether Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his successors need more power or whether city elections should be nonpartisan or what should happen if the Mayor suddenly resigns to take another job, like United States senator.

title: Craft Fails In Bid to Take Asteroid Photo
description: It could have been a great picture, but the camera was pointing at the wrong place, researchers said today of a disappointing encounter between an asteroid and a NASA spacecraft.

title: INSIDE
description: A Call for Tolerance

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, LEO, CAPTAIN
description: BERGER-Leo, Captain. With great sorrow, Dr. Allan Abramson and the Department of Otolaryngology of Long Island Jewish Medical Center acknowledge the passing of Captain Leo Berger, a dear friend and great benefactor whose tireless support of the clinical and academic goals of the Department of Otolaryngology for the past twenty-eight years has made a positive difference in the lives of countless people. His presence will be deeply missed. Dr. Allan Abramson, Chairman Department of Otolaryngology L.I. Jewish Medical Center

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Skepticism Over Korean Reform; After Daewoo Intervention, Is There the Will for Austerity?
description: The Government's decision to take charge of the overhaul of Daewoo, South Korea's second-largest and most-troubled business agglomeration, has pushed skepticism about the country's commitment to economic restructuring to the forefront.

title: In Connecticut, the Scars of War, the Works of Peace
description: When it comes to art exhibitions in Connecticut, the best place to start is New Haven, where the density is highest. The Yale Center for British Art alone has three strong shows, and the first one to see, in part because it is so intensely sad, is ''Doomed Youth: The Poetry and the Pity of the First World War.''

title: On Long Island, Celebrating Artists Celebrating Nature
description: As a place to see contemporary art, Long Island may have it over other summer strongholds that share Manhattan's orbit, primarily because so many artists have made the island's East End, known to some as the Hamptons, their base. This year, shows of -- or including -- the work of artists with local connections seem to predominate, including those at the Parrish Art Museum and the Ossorio Foundation in Southampton, the Pollock-Krasner House in East Hampton and even the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, whose exhibition devoted to the 60's has work by such Long Island-lovers as Willem de Kooning, Roy Lichtenstein and Lee Krasner.

title: Waste Management Cuts Its Profit Forecast for a Second Time
description: For the second time this month, Waste Management Inc. has warned investors that its second-quarter earnings will be tepid at best.

title: A Stereotype Hollywood Can't Refuse
description: WHAT do you think would happen if a white director went to Harlem and shot a film portraying blacks almost exclusively as gangsters, dopers and sex-obsessed stupes? How long would it take before Al Sharpton or Kweisi Mfume put protesters outside movie theaters? One minute or two?

title: A Chance That He Killed in '93
description: Before he burst into the national news yesterday as a frustrated-day-stock-trader-turned-killer, Mark O. Barton had already been at the center of an extraordinarily violent story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, MAE
description: FRANKEL-Mae. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend and colleague who, for almost four decades, helped guide MDA and inspired us to do our best for those we serve. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert Ross, Executive Director Jerry Weinberg, Director of Field Organization Muscular Dystrophy Association

title: Simon Mahlathini Nkabinde, 62, Zulu Singer
description: Simon Mahlathini Nkabinde, a singer better known as the lead groaner of the Zulu music group Mahlathini and the Mahotella Queens, died tonight, the national radio network reported. He was 62.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: First Union, Facing Doubts About Future, Replaces President
description: Continuing to wrestle with severe problems unleashed by a botched merger and a troubled business strategy, the First Union Corporation said yesterday that its president, John R. Georgius, would retire by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, SAUL
description: BLACK-Saul. On Thursday, July 29, 1999, of Manhattan. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Barry and David. Dear fatherin-law of Rosalynda and Cathey. Loving grandfather of Jeremy, Jonathan, Justin, Gideon, and Nicholas. Graveside services will be held at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ on Friday, July 30, 1999 at 1 P.M. For information, Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, BENJAMIN, HON.
description: LEVITT-Benjamin, Hon. On Thursday, July 29, 1999. Age 94. Devoted and beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Col. (Dr.) Morton H. Levitt, and dear fatherin-law of Cynthia Lynn. Cherished grandfather of Lisa Michelle and step grandfather of Nicole Valerie and Tamara Lynn. Graveside ceremony for family only.

title: Rebuilding the Balkans
description: President Clinton's meeting with more than 30 other national leaders in Sarajevo today offers a chance to get the postwar reconstruction of Southeastern Europe off to a sound start. Billions of dollars have already been pledged to help rebuild Kosovo and several neighboring countries. But a lot of this could be wasted unless Washington, the European Union and the United Nations show they have learned from their only partly successful efforts in Bosnia. This time, more must be done to build new locally based economic and political institutions so that international relief can give way to long-term recovery.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Reports of Death Are Exaggerated

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar slid as United States stocks and bonds tumbled. In New York, the dollar settled at 115.40 Japanese yen, down from 116.12 on Wednesday, and the euro rose to $1.0730, from $1.0659.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORGER, MARGO
description: BORGER-Margo. Of Miami Beach, wife of the late Milton Borger, passed away July 27, 1999. Surviving are her children Lenny and Judy, Bette and Joel, grandchildren; Brett and Sondra, Jodi and Mike, Marlo and Andrew, Maggie and Roberto, Jill, Ashley, Erin and great grandchildren Alex, Evan, Harry, Rebecca and Max. A finer woman never graced this earth. She cared for everyone and every living thing. Services will be at 1:00 P.M., on Friday at the Salem Field Cemetery. Information: Riverside Chapels, 516-487-9600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EVA
description: MEYER-Eva. On July 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Gil. Loving mother of Jacqueline Shapiro Meckler. Dearest sister of Gabriela de Fernandez. Adoring grandmother of Dolly and Izzy Meckler. Cherished aunt of Rodrigo Fricke. She will be profoundly missed by her family and friends. Service Friday, 11:15AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Martha Stewart Selling Stake in Her Company
description: For those who wish they could be Martha Stewart, now at least they can own a piece of her company.

title: In an Office Building, Scenes Of Chaos, Blood and Death
description: John Cabrer did not think. He just ran toward the noise. He saw a man running at him. The man's face was purple and red and all twisted up with panic. ''Call the police!'' the man was screaming, over and over.

title: Paying Yet Again
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Is Expected to Reject Alliance Between 2 Airlines
description: The three-year effort by American Airlines and British Airways to win approval to share revenue and to coordinate schedules and fares is expected to be rejected today by the United States Department of Transportation.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Mini-Trove Of Velazquez?

title: Can U.S. Pressure Lead to Chinese Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice-cream makers suffer through a hot summer of flat sales.
description: JULY has been declared National Ice Cream Month by one of the industry's chief trade groups, and, with local conditions resembling one of the circles of hell, far be it from us to argue.

title: Albright Tells Kosovars Not to Act Like Their Oppressors
description: There were, no doubt, dark days during the Kosovo conflict when Madeleine K. Albright wondered whether she would manage to do what she did today: address the Kosovar Albanians in their own capital.

title: Armstrong Takes City by Time Trial
description: The Lance Armstrong one-day victory tour hit town yesterday for a whirlwind sweep of television shows, news media interviews and promotional appearances. Then, before most New Yorkers could get a glimpse of the 27-year-old Texan who battled back from debilitating treatment for cancer to win the Tour de France on Sunday, the visit was over and Armstrong was headed back to Europe for more bicycle races.

title: Sports of The Times; Deciding On a Passer And a Line
description: AS the Giants and the Jets open their training camps, the heat is on. Not just this summer's scorching heat, but the quarterback heat that is always on. The Giants must decide on their quarterback, the Jets must decide on their quarterback's bodyguards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWTON, HILDA
description: NEWTON-Hilda. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Hilda Newton. We extend profound condolences to her family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: A Deserved Fine for Mr. Clinton
description: Federal Judge Susan Webber Wright has set an appropriate sanction in directing President Clinton to pay nearly $90,000 to Paula Jones's lawyers for making false statements about his relationship with Monica Lewinsky in the Jones lawsuit. The constitutional and political issues raised by the events that ultimately led to Mr. Clinton's impeachment will long be analyzed by historians. But Judge Wright steered clear of pronouncing judgment on the full harm done to the Clinton Presidency or to the office itself by Mr. Clinton's behavior. Instead she focused on his actions not as a political leader but as a litigant governed by the rule of law.

title: OBITUARY
description: NEW YORK  Anne Francis (Hazard) Richardson, 69, the wife of Elliot Richardson, a former U.S. attorney general, died of complications of Alzheimer's disease Monday in Cheverly, Maryland.

title: Waiters, a Newly Rare Ingredient; Suddenly in Demand, They Have Become Demanding
description: A press of eager diners followed the boomlet of favorable reviews about Tabla and Eleven Madison Park, the new dining establishments owned by the empire-building Manhattan restaurateur Danny Meyer. So what could be bad?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASS, CECILIA
description: STRASS-Cecilia. On July 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Ludwik Strass. Loving mother of Jan Pincus & her husband, The Honorable Edward Pincus. Cherished grandmother of Andrea and David and adoring great grandmother of Jake Multer. Service on Sunday, August 1, 1999, at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: G.O.P. Rebels Force a Delay On Health Vote
description: The House Republican leadership, facing another rebellion from some moderate and conservative Republicans, backed away from plans to consider legislation on managed health care next week, with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert conceding that a vote before the August recess was now unlikely.

title: Rule of Law in Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: With Chabrol, the High Tide Returns
description: Watch any three films by Claude Chabrol, who along with Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard helped sire French New Wave cinema in the early 1960's, and you will be struck by their timelessness. Styles in clothing, cars and hair may change from decade to decade in Mr. Chabrol's movies. But his characters' humanity is so acutely observed that the problems of men and women and of families, and the continual tug of war between people's civilized and brutish impulses, seem unchanging and deeply truthful.

title: Ah, if the Body Only Made Original Copies
description: So much for the spiritual significance of those near-death experiences. The tunnel and the light that people talk about seeing has something to do with vision-control neurons firing at random. And the sense of euphoria and inner peace just comes from various brain chemicals at work. The same thing happens to test pilots undergoing ''gravity-induced loss of consciousness'' in the centrifuge.

title: Malachi Martin Is Dead at 78; Author of Books on the Church
description: Malachi Brendan Martin, an Irish-born former Jesuit priest and Vatican scholar who went on to write thrillers about the Roman Catholic Church, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Victims Are Identified In Accident In Swiss Gorge
description: As rescue workers in helmets and wet suits continued searching rapids near here for two missing tourists, the police said today that they had identified two of the 19 victims of Tuesday's flash flood, a Swiss woman and a man from New Zealand who were guides on the disastrous canyoning excursion.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Venting (Preferably by High-Speed Connection)
description: A number of Web sites have been created to share complaints about the L.I.R.R. The comments are printed as they appear on line.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 39 Face Gambling Charges In New York Area and Miami
description: Federal and municipal law enforcement officials fanned out in the New York area yesterday to arrest 38 people in connection with a gambling operation that the police said brought in $50 million a year from more than 500 illegal-gambling spots. A 39th person, the suspected ringleader, was arrested in Miami.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSS, CHARLES B.
description: MOSS-Charles B. Our thoughts of everlasting love for you remain with us. Paula, Jinny and Charley

title: Secrecy by Kremlin Financial Czars Raises Eyebrows
description: From its 19th century headquarters in Moscow, the central bank commands an empire that stretches across Russia and beyond. It employs 100,000 people and owns a rich selection of properties, like holiday spas, apartment buildings and stables, as well as branch offices, valued in 1997 at $1 billion.

title: Gunman in Atlanta Slays 9, Then Himself
description: A securities day trader killed nine people this afternoon in two office buildings in the city's glitzy Buckhead district, eluded an extensive police manhunt for five hours and then killed himself in his van after the police pulled him over in nearby Cobb County. An additional 12 people were injured in the incident, 7 from gunshot wounds.

title: Art for Explorers Out Past the Hubbub
description: IN a summer packed, as usual, with art in museums and other sites outside New York, the possibilities for an energetic traveler include the recently reopened Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, where books, documents and memorabilia make clear why World War I was the great divide between 19th-century idealism and 20th-century fatalism.

title: Not Another Woodstock; The Wrong Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Wants Longer-Range Rockets to Meet the North's Threat : U.S. to Upgrade South Korea Missiles
description: TOKYO  The United States promised Thursday to help South Koreans counter growing military pressure from North Korea by trying to meet their demands for enhancing the number and range of their missiles.

title: A Garden of Subjects, Materials and Styles Across New Jersey
description: The two outstanding shows this summer in New Jersey are a bit of a distance from each other. One is at the Montclair Art Museum, a 45-minute or so bus trip from the Port Authority Bus Terminal. (Quicker, of course, by car.) The other is at the Noyes Museum of Art, a rustic charmer of a spot -- cedar clapboards, comfy seats, pond in back -- in Oceanville, a dozen miles north of Atlantic City.

title: Diagnosing Misogyny, Malpractice or Perhaps Both
description: CONDUCT UNBECOMING A WOMAN

title: Former State Dept. Employee Accused of Visa Improprieties
description: A House panel today accused a former State Department employee at the American Embassy in Beijing of improperly granting visas to Chinese citizens seeking entry to the United States, sometimes approving entry documents for friends of a Democratic fund-raiser in return for gifts, money and favors.

title: On My Mind; The March of Folly
description: ''A phenomenon noticeable throughout history regardless of place or period is the pursuit by governments of policies contrary to their own interests.

title: Forgettable Weather
description: Twenty-two counties in Pennsylvania declare drought emergencies. Northeast beachgoers flee to the comfort of air-conditioned movie theaters on a sweltering July Fourth weekend. Fifty-five people have died from extreme heat in the Midwest alone. Why are we suffering so much this summer? Are we suffering through some weird byproduct of El Nino, or its relation, La Nina? Inevitably, the prophets of doom are out in force, blaming the humanly caused global warming for our current distress. The world is indeed getting warmer, but history suggests that short-term extremes are nothing new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, NATHANIEL
description: RATNER-Nathaniel. On July 29, 1999. Survived by many nieces and nephews. He will be missed. GoodBye dear friend. Service Sunday 9:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: N.A.S.D. Orders Quickening Of Nasdaq Conversion Plans
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers board today authorized its staff to step up preparations for converting the Nasdaq stock market into a publicly traded company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, ALEXANDER S.
description: FARKAS-Alexander S. We will deeply miss our beloved friend, Alexander ''Sandy'' Farkas. We were privileged to witness his growth from the young president of Alexander's, to a leader of New York City, throughout his life, his compassion, humor and love. He brought as the joy of a son during our lifelong friendship. We extend our deepest sympathies to Linda, to his children, Georgette, Alexander and Cindy, to his brothers, Robin, Bruce and Jonathan and to Francine. Judge & Mrs. Francis X. Morrissey Boston, MA

title: State Begins Investigation Into Manhattan Blackout
description: The State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, has begun an investigation into allegations that the Washington Heights blackout resulted from Consolidated Edison's taking poorer care of its system there than in other parts of New York City.

title: Giuliani Approves Pact On Crime-Scene Access
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave final approval yesterday to an agreement with a coalition of news organizations to make crime scenes, demonstrations and other events more accessible to news organizations, lawyers for the city said.

title: COMMUTING IN MISERY: A special report.; The Long Island Rail Road: Busiest, but Far From Best
description: On July 6, as temperatures across New York topped 100 degrees, hundreds of commuters on their way home to Long Island's North Shore boarded the 5:47 P.M. train at Hunters Point Avenue, in Queens, as usual. And, as usual, within minutes, many of them were cursing the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAIR, KAREN KRAUSE
description: BLAIR-Karen Krause, 56, on July 29th, 1999, in North Potomac, MD. Born in Bklyn, NY, daughter of Helen Johnson Ashton of Ft. Lauderdale, FL and the late Carlton H. Krause. Loving mother of Katherine M. Sullivan of North Potomac, MD, Thomas C. Blair of Stamford, CT, Elizabeth A. Burgess of NY, and Jennifer L. Blair of Alexandria, VA. Devoted mother-in-law of Brian Sullivan and Mark Burgess. Formerly married to Thomas J. Blair of NY. Beloved cousin of Stanton and Geoffrey Hedrick. She attended the Berkeley Institute in Bklyn, Keuka College and L.I.U. She lived in Ridgewood, NJ for many years and in Rockville, MD where she was on the staff of American Speech and Hearing Association (ASHA). Previously employed as a marketing director for the Hudson River Club and for the Bowling Green Association in Mnhttn. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, August 1st, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th St., Monday, August 2nd, at 10 AM.

title: Edison Project Adds Schools and Investors
description: The Edison Project, the ambitious nationwide network of for-profit public schools, announced yesterday that it was raising both enrollment and cash.

title: Reno Denies Report That She'll Resign
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she had no plans to step down and disputed reports that she was considering resigning to become the dean at a Florida law school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, ETHEL
description: HAAS-Ethel, 96. Died July 26, 1999 in West Palm Beach. Formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Survivors include daughter, Joan Haas Einhorn, grandchildren, Nina Einhorn Motta (husband Dr. Joseph Motta), Cantor Roy Bennett Einhorn (wife Cantor Jodi Sufrin), great-grand daughters, Laura and Jessica Einhorn, Lily and Elizabeth Motta. Also survived by brothers Ralph and Morris (Murray) Asch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LILLIAN
description: STERN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Stern. Cherished mother of Judy Holland, Margery and Herbert Rosen. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. She celebrated life and helped others to do the same and will always be eternally young. Services Sunday, Aug. 1st. 9:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, YEHUDA ARYEH
description: WEINBERG-Yehuda Aryeh. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member Marsha Schwartz, and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: New European Market Raises Capital
description: The Easdaq stock market, the young European equivalent of the Nasdaq, said today it had raised 22.8 million euros ($24 million) in new capital from American and European securities firms and replaced its chief executive.

title: Gun Control Awaits Action By Conferees
description: The issue of gun-control legislation has come back to life in Congress this week, and to anyone unfamiliar with the ways of Washington, it might appear that some kind of law is about to be enacted.

title: Album of the Week
description: LEN: ''You Can't Stop the Bum Rush'' (The Work Group). Rock is bouncing back from the doldrums, with artists like Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock scoring mass adulation. But those bad boys are giving a nasty reputation to the blend of hip-hop and punk galvanizing the renewal. Woodstock's fires illuminate only one aspect of this important juncture. Others are more promising than menacing.

title: TO CUT COSTS, RESPIRONICS IS LAYING OFF 200 WORKERS
description: Respironics Inc., a maker of medical devices to treat breathing disorders, said yesterday that it would lay off 200 people, or 10 percent of its work force, to cut costs and refocus its operations. The cost of the changes are expected to reduce Respironics' earnings by about $25 million before taxes. The company, based in Murraysville, Pa., will close one factory and several customer-service operations, and open a distribution and repair center. Respironics said it would reorganize its operations into four divisions: home care, hospital, asthma-allergy and international, each with its own management and sales force.

title: SALE OF THOMSON-CSF STAKE
description: Alcatel S.A., the French telephone equipment maker, said it would raise its stake in Thomson-CSF to more than 25 percent, moving into military electronics. The purchase of 10 percent of Thomsonfrom the French Government reduced the state's stake in Thomson-CSF to 34 percent. Separately, the Government said it will allow Alcatel to sell its 44 percent stake in Framatome, a state-controlled maker of nuclear reactors. Shares in Thomson-CSF, which makes radar, satellites and missile guidance equipment, fell, since the actions did not include a move by the state to sell a further 10 percent of the company to investors, who now own 32.5 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, MELVIN
description: GREENBAUM-Melvin. We send our condolences to Rabbi Michael Greenbaum, Vice Chancellor of The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, on the loss of his father, Melvin, and join Michael, his wife and children in mourning this loss. Joan Rosenbaum, Director The Jewish Museum Robert Hurst, Chairman The Jewish Museum Board

title: Why Teaching Lost the Status It Deserves
description: To the Editor:

title: For Martin to Rip and Roll, Jets Need to Forge Opening
description: Last season the Jets were outscored in the American Football Conference by only the champion Denver Broncos, and they had a player whose rushing yardage was the second highest in club history.

title: Penetrating The Secrets Of Porcelain
description: Nearly everyone is familiar with blue and white Delft tiles from the Netherlands, but few know much about Delft's original rival in France, the Saint-Cloud porcelain factory, which thrived between 1690 and 1766 in the commune of Saint-Cloud, across the river from Paris.

title: Kodak to Shut Down Film Plant in China
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's biggest photography company, will close its X-ray film plant in Wuxi, China, and dismiss 520 workers because of strict environmental laws that inflated plant-upgrade costs.

title: Stevenson Examines Wimbledon Loss
description: Alexandra Stevenson insists that her lopsided loss in the Wimbledon semifinals four weeks ago had nothing to do with Julius Erving's announcement the previous day that he is her father. Even though she has only met the Hall of Fame player once -- at a basketball camp when she was 8 -- the 18-year-old Californian said she had no desire to meet him or his other children.

title: Senate G.O.P. Moves Ahead On Tax Plan
description: Republicans moved closer today to Senate passage of a $792 billion tax cut over the opposition of President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, but they still face the difficult task of uniting the party on what form the cuts should take.

title: Sentencing in Dublin In Reporter's Killing
description: A major Dublin drug dealer was sentenced to life in prison today after being convicted for the 1996 murder of Veronica Guerin, a prominent Dublin journalist who reported aggressively on organized crime.

title: Tale of a Menage a Trois, With the Emphasis on Deux
description: ''Twin Falls Idaho'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 9. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Men Awaiting Asylum Rulings Begin Protest Seeking Release
description: A group of asylum seekers being held at the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in Queens have refused meals over the last three days to press demands that they be released on parole until their cases are decided, immigration lawyers said yesterday.

title: FORD SETS GOAL OF SELLING SIX TIMES MORE TIRES BY 2001
description: The Ford Motor Company, the world's No. 2 auto maker, said yesterday that it would try to increase tire sales at its United States dealerships sixfold, to six million in 2001. Ford said that it would start a national advertising campaign next week and that it planned to add training programs for dealership staff and centralized tire purchasing to drive down costs. The auto maker wants to capture 12 percent of the $100 billion spent annually on replacement parts in the United States, up from 6 percent, by making tires and other parts cheaper and easier to buy. The move is part of Ford's push to keep customers after they buy a car or truck.

title: New U.S. Chief in Kosovo
description: Brig. Gen. John Craddock will be replaced as commander of American forces in Kosovo next month by Col. Craig A. Peterson in what Pentagon officials described as a normal rotation.

title: Detroit, Still Blighted, Puts Hopes in Casinos
description: With glittering lights and the roll of dice, a casino opened here today, the first of a number of promised attractions that Detroit is counting on to bring long-lost prosperity back to its blighted streets.

title: 2 Major Health Insurers Report Results
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed, while Aetna Inc., the nation's biggest health insurer, said second-quarter earnings rose 12 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the sport of canyoning misidentified an American wilderness skills school that does not teach the sport. It is the National Outdoor Leadership School, not the National Outdoor Wilderness Leadership School.

title: KIRBY AGREES TO PAY $225 MILLION FOR HOLLYWOOD MARINE
description: The Kirby Corporation, an operator of inland tank barges for the petroleum and chemicals industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Hollywood Marine Inc. for $135 million in cash and $90 million in Kirby stock. It will also assume $100 million in debt. Hollywood, based in Houston, operates a fleet of 256 inland tank barges. It had 1998 revenue of $168 million. Kirby, also based in Houston, expects the acquisition to increase its earnings in 2000. The company earned $10.1 million on revenue of $327.1 million in 1998.

title: Grey Acquires Data-Base Company
description: Grey Direct in New York, the direct marketing arm of Grey Advertising, has acquired Marketdata Solutions in New York, which offers data-base marketing services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: More Than Ready Lives Up To Name in Famed Sanford
description: For 86 years, the Sanford Stakes has been run as a milestone for many 2-year-old colts establishing their careers in racing history, notably Secretariat and Affirmed. Perversely, it is also famous as the only race the great Man o' War ever lost in 21 starts en route to establishing his own career in racing history.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER RISES. Silver prices rose amid signs of improved demand from the photography industry, the second-largest user of the metal. In New York, silver for September delivery rose 17 cents an ounce, to $5.435.

title: Pettitte's Head, It Appears, Is on the Trading Block
description: The Yankees delved deeply into trade talks involving Andy Pettitte with the Philadelphia Phillies and other teams today, after George Steinbrenner pronounced in a staff meeting that he was disappointed with Pettitte's performance this year.

title: In Parched Maryland, Governor Declares Drought Emergency
description: As the nation's capital and the surrounding region continued to bake through a long, hot dry spell, Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland today declared the first statewide drought emergency in his state's history.

title: LUBRIZOL TO CUT 200 JOBS AT OHIO FUEL ADDITIVES PLANT
description: The Lubrizol Corporation, the world's No. 1 maker of fuel additives, said yesterday it would cut 200 jobs at its Painesville, Ohio, plant by the end of next year, reducing the factory's work force by more than half and saving $21 million a year. Lubrizol, based in Wickliffe, Ohio, expects to take a charge of $30 million to $35 million in the third quarter for asset write-offs and severance expenses. Twenty-three of the plant's 36 production lines will be closed, and most of the work will shift to its Deer Park, Tex., plant. Most of the jobs will be cut through early retirements and voluntary departures, it said.

title: Hillary Clinton Shifts Her Focus to Taxes
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton came to this Republican patch of upstate New York today intent on embracing what Democrats see as a major issue in next year's Congressional elections: the Republican drive to put through the largest Federal tax cut since 1982. But she also found herself again discussing the question of whether someone who does not live in New York could represent it in the Senate.

title: WELLPOINT MAKES AN OFFER FOR ROCKY MOUNTAIN HOSPITAL
description: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, offered yesterday to pay $266 million for Rocky Mountain Hospital and Medical Service Inc., the parent of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Colorado and Nevada. The offer includes $150 million that would be spent on charitable uses as Rocky Mountain converted to a for-profit company, and $16 million that would go to Anthem Inc., which offered to buy Rocky Mountain for about $165 million. Wellpoint is moving to expand outside of California, where it operates Blue Cross of California. Rocky Mountain serves some 430,000 Blue Cross Blue Shield members in Colorado and 70,000 more in Nevada. Shares in Wellpoint, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., fell $1.5625, to $81.50.

title: FAIRCHILD SELLS ITS MINORITY STAKE IN TURKISH CAN MAKER
description: The Fairchild Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its 31.9 percent stake in Nacanco Paketleme for $48 million in cash to American National Can Group, the venture's other owner. Fairchild will provide consulting services to Nacanco, a Turkish beverage-can maker, for three years. Fairchild, which has been selling assets unrelated to its main businesses, plans to use the proceeds to pay off debt. Shares of American National Can, which began trading on Wednesday, rose 75 cents to $17.75. Shares of Fairchild, a Dulles, Va.-based maker of aircraft latches and screws, rose 43.75 cents to $10.625.

title: Gas Prices in Russia Run All the Stop Signs
description: The major contenders in Russia's 2000 presidential election already are slinging mud by the bucketful, the Kremlin is under criminal investigation and the Communist Party's once-unassailable base in Parliament is developing serious stress cracks. But as political issues go, it is safe to say all that pales next to this summer's national fixation: the price of a liter of gas.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Jerry Della Femina, ad man, is bold, bald and loud. Della Femina, the new Manhattan spinoff of his restaurant in East Hampton, N.Y., is cool, subdued and tasteful as all get-out. It's a little piece of Connecticut dropped into the heart of midtown, with dark, beamed ceilings and a perimeter of white pretend windows that look as if they came from a wraparound porch.

title: ALLIED WASTE IS SELLING SOME OPERATIONS TO REPUBLIC
description: Republic Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy certain solid-waste services assets from Allied Waste Industries for $230 million. Allied Waste, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., is selling the operations to comply with antitrust regulators who are requiring Allied and Browning Ferris Industries Inc. to sell about $500 million in operations as part of their planned merger. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said the assets it had agreed to buy included four landfill operations, 11 transfer stations and several small-container hauling businesses. The operations have combined revenue of $123 million and are located in Ohio, Georgia, Illinois, North Carolina, California and Michigan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, QUENTIN
description: WRIGHT-Quentin. On July 29, 1999, age 92. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth, loving father of John and Nancy, devoted grandfather of Joshua and Brett Wright and Lori, Chris, and Holly Rogers. Memorial service on Friday, July 30, at 1 PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. For further information contact the funeral home at 914-967-0129.

title: Metro Business; A Fitter Maidenform
description: Maidenform Worldwide Inc., the women's lingerie manufacturer, said yesterday that it had taken its final step out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection by securing $60 million in loans from GE Capital Services Corporation.

title: Can U.S. Pressure Lead to Chinese Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Revokes Credit Suisse Unit's Banking License
description: Japanese financial authorities imposed severe sanctions today on Credit Suisse Group, closing a six-month investigation into the firm's sale of derivative securities intended to help Japanese banks and companies hide huge losses.

title: Metro Business; Low-Cost Checking Called Hard to Find
description: Banks in New York are obligated to offer low-cost checking accounts, but it is often hard for customers to find out about them, a consumer watchdog group said yesterday.

title: Mubarak Offers Barak-Arafat Mediation
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who has considerable influence with Yasir Arafat, offered today to step in as an informal mediator to help settle a dispute that threatens to sidetrack the Middle East peace effort.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Long-Distance Giants Report Solid Results For Quarter
description: The nation's two largest long-distance telephone carriers, the AT&T Corporation and MCI Worldcom Inc., yesterday announced strong quarterly financial results -- propelled, paradoxically, by just about everything except long-distance telephone service.

title: RENAULT SALES RISE
description: France's No. 2 car maker, Renault S.A., said its first-half sales rose 5.6 percent, as it increased market share in Europe and Latin America. Revenue rose to 19.6 billion euros, or $20.9 billion, from 18.6 billion euros in the year-earlier period. Unit sales, which were released earlier this month, climbed 9.4 percent. Renault, which is based in Paris, benefitted from booming demand for its small cars the Twingo, above, and the Clio.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Why Teaching Lost the Status It Deserves
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients' Rights, Done Wrong
description: Even though I am a Republican Congressman, I am also a doctor, and I have continued to treat patients and deliver babies in Muskogee, Okla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFGANG, ARTHUR
description: OFGANG-Arthur, 73. Of Coconut Creek, Florida. Passed away July 28, 1999. Survived by loving wife, Joan, cherished son, Jeffrey (wife Nora) Ofgang of Pasadena, California. Adored brother to Lillian Hock. Family requests donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Jones and Rizzo Lead, But Focus Is on Inkster
description: Rosie Jones has won nine tournaments and close to $4 million in her Ladies Professional Golf Association career.

title: Pretty Woman Is Back, But Now She's Cautious
description: Nine years after sparkling her way through ''Pretty Woman,'' Julia Roberts has come a long way from that streetwalker's role. She's come so far in ''Runaway Bride'' that she plays a woman who runs a hardware store and looks perpetually ready to fix a sink. Set in the kind of folksy Maryland town that has quaint hand-painted signs and not a single chain store, this new collaboration between the stars and director of ''Pretty Woman'' takes pains, geographically and otherwise, to get as far away from Rodeo Drive as it can. The small town's streets are even roamed by a barbershop quartet.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There was blood all over the wall.''

title: Finals Pit Squad of Stars Against Dark-Horse Team
description: A team of world-class stars faced a dark-horse squad in the final of the Women's Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today. Beth Palmer of Silver Spring, Md., Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., Rozanne Pollack of Warren, N.J., Lisa Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., and Carol Sanders of Nashville, all world champions, are playing with Connie Goldberg of Merion Station, Pa.

title: A River Swim, Anyone? No Vaccine Needed
description: TWO scenarios come to mind when you hear about people jumping into the rivers that surround New York:

title: Mouse Cells Are Converted Into Brain Cells
description: Biologists have converted cells from the embryo of a mouse into specialized brain cells capable of repairing a brain defect.

title: Police Recruiting Drive Lags Despite $10 Million Budget
description: With the New York City Police Department in the midst of its largest recruitment drive ever and one month left to apply, the number of people who have signed up so far is not on a pace to set any records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSAN, KING II OF MOROCCO
description: HASSAN-King II of Morocco. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns with the people and government of Morocco the death of H.M. King Hassan II. His courageous leadership and devotion to his people and his efforts to promote peace & reconciliation in the MIddle East will always be remembered. We recall his warmth and outreach in his meetings with the Conference. We extend condolences to King Mohammed VI and pray that he will be blessed with many years of good health and success building on the legacy of his revered father. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm I. Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Parole Official's Motive Questioned at Trial
description: A Federal prosecutor strongly suggested in court yesterday that a member of the New York State Parole Board had voted to release a prisoner in an attempt to please Pataki administration officials who were interested in the case.

title: Daimler's Profit Trails Forecasts And the Shares Fall Sharply
description: Shares of DaimlerChrysler A.G. took a pounding on two continents today after it turned in flat second-quarter earnings, hurt mostly by weaker-than-expected profits from Chrysler models.

title: Two Agencies Fill Top Posts
description: Two agencies are naming executives to top posts.

title: KOREAN OUTPUT SURGES
description: South Korea's industrial output had its biggest gain in 11 years in June, as a recovery in Asian economies allowed Korean companies to sell more cars, computer chips and other products. Industrial production surged 29.5 percent last month from a year earlier, accelerating from a 21.8 percent increase in May, the National Statistical Office said.

title: RIO TINTO SHARES SURGE
description: One of the world's largest mining companies, Rio Tinto P.L.C., reported better-than-expected earnings of $509 million in the first half of 1999. While that was down from $551 million a year earlier, analysts had forecast earnings of only $470 million. The company said cost cutting had helped blunt the impact of sharply lower metals prices. The company's stock rose more than 5 percent after the earnings were announced but eventually closed unchanged after the company said it had ended talks with the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia about a joint venture.

title: Procter & Gamble Earnings Top Wall St. Expectations
description: The Procter & Gamble Company may finally be breaking out of a slump. The consumer products giant, which has been struggling with a sluggish international business and a need for bigger successes from new products, reported robust quarterly earnings growth yesterday that beat analyst expectations.

title: Can U.S. Pressure Lead to Chinese Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Can U.S. Pressure Lead to Chinese Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Allstate Sues Doctors
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking $42 million from chiropractors, doctors and others in New Jersey it has accused of submitting false insurance claims for automobile accidents.

title: Reclassify Drug Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Glaxo Says It Will Not Meet Its Sales and Profit Targets for the Year
description: Wounded by dismal sales growth in the United States, Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the world's third-largest pharmaceutical company, announced yesterday that it would not meet its sales and earnings projections for this year.

title: The Hudson Valley, Inside and Out
description: This summer, the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y., continues its exceptional multi-year exploration of David Smith's sculpture; the Katonah Museum of Art has a big survey of wildflowers in contemporary art (with works by Kiki Smith, Gregory Crewdson, John Alexander and Nancy Davidson, among others) and the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., is showing new public art projects.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOME PROPERTIES INC., Rochester, a real estate investment trust, bought four apartment complexes in suburban Philadelphia from the closely held Ridley Management Group Inc. for $32.3 million in debt, cash and securities.

title: The Shootings in Atlanta
description: In one sense, the fatal shooting of nine people in Atlanta yesterday can be seen in isolation, as the mad handiwork of a lone individual venting uniquely twisted grievances through the barrel of a gun.
