Yet the incident is also part of a larger and dismally familiar story of shootings that seem increasingly to pop up out of nowhere and in the most unlikely places -- in orderly small towns, in offices, in suburban schools, in genteel neighborhoods and, in this case, in the commercial district of the well-to-do Buckhead section of Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, ROBERT, H.
description: FARBER-Robert, H. Beloved husband of Rhoda (Harris), cherished father of Joanne and Steven, Linda and Eric and Cathy and Steven. Dear grandfather of Stacey and Andrew and Lisa. Devoted brother of Stanley. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Signings by Rangers And the Islanders
description: Two New York teams signed players yesterday. The Rangers signed minor league defenseman Terry Virtue, and the Islanders signed the veteran center Tony Hrkac.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: On Tobacco And '60 Minutes'

title: Residential Real Estate; Factory-Built Units Are Planned for Rental Development in Central Harlem
description: The new owner of two vacant lots on separate blocks in central Harlem plans to put up rental buildings totaling 28 one- and two-bedroom market-rate apartments. But instead of being built with traditional techniques, they will be manufactured in a factory and assembled on the sites.

title: Printmaking as a Magical Collaboration
description: Printmaking is not what it used to be. Which contemporary artist has created anything as consequential in print form as artists like Durer, Rembrandt, Goya or Blake? Modernism, with its rejection of tradition, insistence on immediacy and reckless pursuit of innovation, relegated the intimate, craft-bound tradition of fine printmaking to the margins of mainstream art history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, VICTOR
description: LYNN-Victor. We express our profound sorrow at the loss of our dear friend, Victor. We will miss his charm, wit and wisdom and his verve on the tennis court. Riki and Bob Larimer

title: Inquiry Pressed Into Reported Rapes at Woodstock
description: Amid growing reports of sexual assaults at last weekend's Woodstock concert, the New York State Police began interviewing people who were crisis counselors at the show and reviewed videotapes yesterday for evidence of rapes that the police said occurred in the campground and near the main music stage.

title: A Leading Sri Lankan Moderate Is Killed
description: A leading moderate who had sought a peaceful solution to the violent ethnic conflict that has raged for 16 years in Sri Lanka was killed today in its capital by a suicide bomber.

title: Steak and Potatoes
description: Historically, Texas has been identified with cattle, Kansas City with stockyards and New York with steakhouses. Nowadays cattle can be anywhere and fine beef comes from as far away as Argentina and Japan, but New York is still the king of the steakhouse. Here are 12 reasons for that. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Investment Rules In China Eased
description: Chinese securities regulators have adopted rules intended to foster investor interest in markets in China.

title: MOORE AGREES TO SELL 2 BUSINESSES TO VISTA INFORMATION
description: The Moore Corporation, the world's top business-forms maker, agreed yesterday to sell its Cyberhomes Internet real estate listing service and a real estate software business to Vista Information Solutions Inc. for at least $57 million. Moore will get cash, a seat on Vista's board, a stake of 10 to 15 percent in the privately held company and other compensation for its Minneapolis-based real estate software business and Cyberhomes. Vista, based in San Diego, owns the top United States real estate, environmental and insurance underwriting information directory. If the deal is completed, Vista Information would have more than $100 million in sales and 800 workers.

title: Big Question in the Big East: Is Miami Headed to the Top?
description: Are the Miami Hurricanes back in their 1980's national title winning form? Will they remain in the Big East? Is there life after Donovan McNabb for Syracuse? Or is Virginia Tech really the reigning football power in a lightly regarded conference?

title: Rome's Inventions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCLOUGHLIN, JOHN R.
description: McLOUGHLIN-John R. My darling husband and wonderful father. Five years of continuously loving you and missing your unique self. Our loving thoughts are with you every day and you will always be in our hearts now and forever. Vicky, Mike and Chris

title: Head of Financial Panel In Camden Resigns
description: The chairman of the state review board that is overseeing the City of Camden's finances is stepping down, state officials said yesterday.

title: Thirteen N.L. Umpires Eliminated
description: From one of the two newest umpires to two of the three most senior, the National League slashed 13 umpires from its staff yesterday, accepting their resignations as the latest development in the umpires' mass resignation strategy. Richard Phillips, the umpires' labor leader, immediately promised more action, vowing to ''fight to the death'' for the umpires' jobs.

title: Auto Union In New Push In Canada
description: The Canadian Auto Workers union is applying extra muscle at contract-bargaining time to pressure the Big Three auto makers into helping the union organize employees at Magna International Inc., one of the world's largest automotive parts suppliers.

title: BASEBALL; Deadline Has Mets And Yoshii On Watch
description: The Mets are dancing with every general manager who is dangling the key to a Ferrari -- think reliever -- before their eyes. They are trying to whisper in enough ears to find a pitcher they hope will bolster their chances of winning a pennant.

title: Widespread Panic Proves Anything But
description: Usually at concerts, the most excited fans push up to the front, riveted by their idols. Not so on Tuesday night at the first of two Roseland shows by the vastly popular, largely unhyped Widespread Panic, from Athens, Ga. The energy in the spacious theater was most intense near the back, where dozens of loose-limbed rock-and-roll gypsies grooved together.

title: Accounts
description: * Greatfood.com, Seattle, to Publicis, Seattle, a unit of Publicis S.A., as the first agency to handle the account of the specialty food-product retailer. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Sudan, Angry at U.S. Attack, Freed Bomb Suspects, Officials Say
description: Immediately after the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa last Aug. 7, Sudan detained two men suspected of being involved in the plot, but angrily released them two weeks later, after an American cruise missile strike on Sudan, American officials said today.

title: Cure for Cold Feet
description: Nine years after ''Pretty Woman,'' its stars and director join forces again for ''Runaway Bride,'' a romantic comedy that tries, geographically and otherwise, to get as far away from Rodeo Drive as it can. What's familiar about this small-town story? Julia Roberts and Richard Gere (above) and much -- too much -- more.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday in Circuits about the illegal copying of movies for on-line distribution incorrectly described the device used to play movies copied onto recordable disks knows as VCD's. A VCD can be played on a computer's CD-ROM drive or DVD-ROM drive; it cannot be played on any other type of DVD player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSI, LOLA
description: AMBROSI-Lola. On July 28, 1999. Loving wife of the late Thomas Ambrosi. Cherished mother of Janet Wertman. Adored grandmother of Liana, Holly and Elon. Dear sister of Louis L. Scher, IV and beloved sister-in-law of Ellen Galey Scher & Clara and Robert Berger. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Sunday, August 1 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Additional calling hours at Trinity Chapel, 770 Riverside Drive (158 Street) on Monday, August 2, from 10AM12PM, with services to follow.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New Issues Lift A Lucky Few Mutual Funds
description: July was a tough month for shareholders of Internet-stock funds, but not for the lucky few in the Enterprise Internet fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PYKA, WILLIAM C., DOCTOR
description: PYKA-William C., Doctor, 90, on July 24th. He is survived by his devoted companion, Wanda Wolinska; brother, Stas; two daughters, Monika Pyka Dillon and Yola Pyka Carlough; and a son, Marek Pyka, four grandchildren and one great-granddaughter.

title: Multiplex Is Planned Above Bus Terminal
description: Continuing its efforts to transfer pieces of its vast real estate empire to private hands, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it had selected a developer to build a multiplex movie theater on top of its George Washington Bridge bus station in upper Manhattan.

title: House Votes to Trim Funds for School for Latin American Soldiers
description: The House voted early today to withhold recruitment money for the Army's School of the Americas, a facility long criticized for training Latin American officers who turned out to be tyrants and murderers.

title: WELLS FARGO IN $245 MILLION DEAL FOR PRIME BANCSHARES
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the seventh-largest United States bank, agreed yesterday to buy Prime Bancshares Inc. of Houston for about $245 million in stock. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, is to exchange about 0.62 share for each share of Prime Bancshares. That values each share of Primes Bancshares at about $25. Prime Bancshares rose $2.125, or 11 percent, to $22.25, before trading was halted. Wells Fargo shares fell 50 cents to $40.3125. Prime Bancshares runs Prime Bank, with $1.2 billion in assets and 22 branches.

title: New Video Releases
description: Message in a Bottle

title: BRITISH TELECOM EARNINGS RISE
description: An increase in Internet use and cellular phone calls contributed to a 9.8 percent gain in British Telecommunications P.L.C.'s quarterly earnings to $:534 million, or $853 million. But shareholders in the company, Britain's second-biggest telephone company behind Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., sent its shares down 3.9 percent on fear that the company's plan to upgrade its network to allow new high-speed Internet services will cut into future profits.

title: Duval Denies Urging Boycott Over Ryder Cup Revenues
description: Besides playing golf at the Greater Hartford Open today, David Duval was also clearing the air. What seemed to be a brewing controversy over whether members of the United States Ryder Cup team should be paid, and the threat of a boycott, appears to be waning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROTCH, RICHARD MARK
description: GROTCH-Richard Mark. July 28th Devoted son of Herbert & Elaine. Dear brother of Mitchel, proud uncle of Steven & Daniel Grotch. A friend to all who will be dearly missed. Service today 11AM, I.J. Morris, Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; If This Is the Future, It's Not Exactly Pretty
description: CONCEPT cars have long been a staple of automobile shows because these vehicles allow auto makers to achieve two self-serving goals simultaneously: manufacturers can appear to be engineering leaders by showing off state-of-the-art technology (even if some of it is so conceptual it may never find its way into mass production) while keeping consumers hooked on one of the industry's most potent narcotics -- the dream machine.

title: Hoffa Begins Effort to Keep The Teamsters Crime Free
description: James P. Hoffa, the president of the teamsters, announced his union's most ambitious anti-corruption effort in decades today in a move he said was designed to keep the teamsters free of organized crime.

title: No. 1 Goalie in N.H.L., Hasek, to Retire in 2000
description: Dominik Hasek, the dominating goalie who led the Czech Republic to an Olympic gold medal last year and the Buffalo Sabres to the Stanley Cup finals this year, announced yesterday that he would retire after the 1999-2000 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, FRANCES (FRANKIE)
description: EISNER-Frances (Frankie) Phillips Lewis passed away peacefully July 27 in Palm Beach at 96. Beloved mother of Brenda Ballin and the late Lewis Phillips, stepchildren, Rita Rand, Micky Krulwich, Tubby Stayman & Marilyn Eisner. Devoted grandmother of Amy Penn, Michael Phillips, Leslie Ballin, Shakira Ballin and Samantha Phillips D'Olivares. Proud great grandmother of Sabrina, Derek, Gabriel, Eli and Sophia. Interment private.

title: Sidestepping One Union, Cipriani Signs Deal With Teamsters
description: Locked in a long-running battle with the restaurant workers union that has cost it tens of thousands of dollars, the Cipriani family has signed a contract with a teamsters union local, hoping the deal will bring the labor conflict to an end.

title: Can U.S. Pressure Lead to Chinese Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Preventing 'Air Rage'
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; The New Human Rights
description: In this post-totalitarian world, the human rights debate needs an update. While Americans are focusing on issues of free speech, elections and the right to write an op-ed piece, people in the developing world are increasingly focused on workers' rights, jobs, the right to organize and the right to have decent working conditions.

title: ANOTHER RATE CUT IN BRAZIL
description: The Brazilian central bank surprised investors with a deeper-than-expected reduction in its main lending rate, to 19.5 percent from 21 percent. It was the tenth cut in interest rates since March and reflects the Government's sense of urgency in trying to stimulate economic growth, with unemployment at a record high. Yet most analysts believe rates are still too high. And investors fear that a further decline in rates, without Government steps to reduce the budget deficit, will cause higher inflation. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's Administration hopes to persuade lawmakers to cut spending.

title: Accord Is Reached on Trades Of Cash for Lawsuit Proceeds
description: When Raymond White was hit by a No. 1 subway train in 1991, losing his right leg below the knee and his livelihood as a cook, he hired a law firm that failed to heed the proper procedures for suing the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, MALA
description: RUBINSTEIN-Mala. We extend our sincerest condolences to the family of Mala Rubinstein, a staunch supporter of our scholarship program for Israeli visual artists as a member of the Helena Rubinstein Foundation. Vera Stern, President Meira Geyra, Artistic Director, Israel America-Israel Cultural Foundation

title: Evolving Answers to the Why of Suicide; Is It a Medical Problem? A Moral or Social Failure? An Assertion of Freedom?
description: ''There is but one truly serious philosophical problem,'' Albert Camus said, ''and that is suicide. Judging whether life is or is not worth living amounts to answering the fundamental question of philosophy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNEITEL, GLADYS, NEE GOLDFARB
description: KNEITEL-Gladys, nee Goldfarb. After a short illness on July 27, 1999. Widow of Arnold Kneitel. Her loss is felt by her daughter and son-in-law, Barbara and Peter Lambe, her grandchildren, Danny, Andrea and Jon Lambe. Interment was private.

title: Fighting Fire With Fire: Moby's Agenda
description: On Thursday at the Bowery Ballroom, Moby, the evangelist of techno who brought that genre's synthetic beats to a wide American audience in the early 1990's, faced one of the bigger challenges fate can throw at an artist. Early in his set, as he and his band played a version of Public Enemy's ''Public Enemy No. 1,'' some smoke effects generated by a cable television crew filming the show set off the club's fire alarm.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Words cannot tell the agony. Why did I? I have been dying since October. Wake up at night so afraid, so terrified that I couldn't be that afraid while awake. It has taken its toll. I have come to hate this life and this system of things. I have come to have no hope.''

title: World Leaders Join in Pledging Effort to Rebuild Balkans
description: Next to a graveyard of Bosnia's war dead, 39 world leaders, including President Clinton, met here today to inaugurate an effort to rebuild southeastern Europe and its economy from the ravages of a decade of war.

title: Top Team's Victory Leads To Entry in Olympic Event
description: Victory for a star-studded team had an extra bonus at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Thursday night. Beth Palmer of Silver Spring, Md., Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., Carol Sanders of Nashville, Rozanne Pollack of Warren, N.J., Lisa Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., all former world champions, and Connie Goldberg of Merion Station, Pa., with Karen Allison of Jersey City as nonplaying captain, not only won the Women's Knockout Team title, but also earned a trip to Geneva in September. There, with support from Shawn Quinn of Katy, Tex., and Mildred Breed of Bryan, Tex., they will compete in the International Olympic Committee's Grand Prix tournament against a European women's team.

title: America's Role in Colombia
description: The Clinton Administration and Congress are struggling to decide what Washington should do to help Colombia, one of Latin America's most complex and troubled nations. The country's two overwhelming problems are a growing trade in cocaine and heroin and a 35-year civil war against Marxist guerrillas. President Andres Pastrana is well intentioned, and deserves American support. But Washington must draw a sharp distinction between the two struggles. Helping Colombia to reduce its narcotics production is an American interest. Getting involved in a brutal guerrilla war -- one that neither side can win -- is not.

title: 'There Is No Reason for Me to Lie Now . . . '
description: Following are excerpts from a letter and the texts of three notes apparently written by Mark O. Barton and left in the Barton home, as read by Chief Jimmy Mercer of the Henry County police and recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Mercer said that the letter was dated July 29, 6:38 A.M., and that he was omitting three telephone numbers of people mentioned at the end of the letter.

title: Sampras and Agassi Head for a Rematch
description: Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi moved closer to a rematch of their Wimbledon final on yesterday, winning quarterfinal matches at the Mercedes-Benz Cup in Los Angeles.

title: Charles F. Mansfield, 77, Bank Executive
description: Charles F. Mansfield, a former president and chief executive officer of the Marine Midland Bank in Manhattan, died Monday at a hospital in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: OIL CHANGE IN INDONESIA
description: Hoping to end 32 years of corruption practices that helped enrich the family of former President Suharto, Indonesia will strip the state-owned oil and gas company Pertamina of its monopoly on granting contracts to exploit the nation's vast petroleum reserves. The move could create new opportunities for multinational oil companies like Exxon to negotiate new contracts with Indonesia. The Government and four parliamentary factions agreed to end the monopoly after months of negotiations. Wayne Arnold

title: Parks as Playgrounds
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN CELLULAR COMPANY SOLD
description: Canada's largest phone company, Bell Canada, agreed to buy the 35 percent of the cellular provider BCE Mobile Communications Inc. that it does not already own for about $1.6 billion (Canadian), or $1.06 billion (United States), in cash. BCE Mobile holders will receive $58.75 Canadian for each of their shares. Bell Canada's parent, BCE Inc., transferred its 65 percent stake in BCE Mobile to Bell Canada in May.

title: Treasury Prices Fall Again, Pressed by Economic Reports
description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, rounding out the sixth consecutive losing month for Treasuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEHNE, RICHARD S. ''DICK''
description: KOEHNE-Richard S. ''Dick'', of Sutton, VT, and formerly of Lawrence, LI, died Wednesday, July 28, 1999, at the age of 76. He was predeceased by his wife Laura (Martin) on February 24, 1999. Survivors include: one son Nathaniel (Tom) and his wife and Madora Koehne of Brooklyn, NY; two daughters, Laura (Hoppy) Whitman of Bethel, AK, and Sarah (Mouse) Scharfenaker and her husband Mark of Denver, CO; five grandchildren, Annie, Nell, Alexandra, Molly and Ellis.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the origin of the word ''cyberspace'' misidentified the work by the writer William Gibson in which the word first appeared. It was ''Burning Chrome,'' a 1982 short story, not the 1984 novel ''Neuromancer.''

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL WILL ACQUIRE MERCHANTS BANCORP
description: The Old Kent Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Merchants Bancorp Inc. in a stock deal valued at $189 million. The move continues Old Kent's expansion in the Chicago area. Merchants Bancorp, based in Aurora, Ill., has $921 million in assets and serves suburban Chicago through 12 offices. Under the agreement, Old Kent, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., will exchange 0.83 share for each Merchants share. The ratio values Merchants at $35.12 a share. Old Kent, which has $15.93 billion in assets, said the transaction would reduce earnings by $20 million before taxes but would begin adding to earnings in 2000.

title: All Eyes Turn To the Whitney
description: Middlesex Drive won by the length of his neck yesterday in the first major turf race of the season at Saratoga Race Course, the Bernard Baruch Handicap. But the talk of the town centered on Behrens and Victory Gallop, the senior stars who led the draw for tomorrow's classic, the 72d Whitney Handicap.

title: Red Sox Still Pondering How They Can Hit Irabu
description: A man from New York walked into Jimy Williams's office yesterday, and the Boston manager immediately had a question for him. ''How are we going to hit Irabu?'' he asked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREISMAN, BERNARD
description: GREISMAN-Bernard age 82, of Fort Lee, N.J. Survived by his devoted wife Ruth of 58 years, cherished children Stewart, Cheryl and Andrew Konstandt; and adored Poppy of Matthew, Brad, Courtney and Sami. Services are 12:30 P.M. Sunday Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSLOWITZ, LOUIS (SONNY)
description: YOSLOWITZ-Louis (Sonny). On July 30th, 1999. Homler Credit Union extends sincerest condolences to the family. He will always be remembered and loved by all who knew him. Graveside service will be held on August 1st at New Montefiore Cemetery at 10:30 AM. Homler Credit Union H. Seymour Weinstein, President Harris Jacoby, Manager

title: Jets: High Expectations, but Slim at Guard
description: It was a new camp, a new motto and perhaps a more forthright Bill Parcells who sent his troops out into the blazing sun today to continue the transformation of the Jets.

title: CONGRESS CHAFING AT SPENDING CAPS
description: Congress is primed to break its own rules and spend the $14 billion budget surplus forecast for next year, according to senior members of the House of Representatives.

title: Skimping on School Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIN, JOHN JOSEPH (JACK)
description: DAVIN-John Joseph (Jack). July 30, 1999 of Annapolis, MD. He is survived by his loving wife India Bell, five sons John J. Jr., Richard, Paul Robert, Michael, Brian T., and five daughters Diane M. Ihnat, Carol A. O'Connor, Alice M. Avila, Linda C. Zurn, and Laura L. Peterson. For information, John M. Taylor Funeral Home Inc. Annapolis, Maryland.

title: Journal; The Fast Friends of John F. Kennedy Jr.
description: But enough about him. What about me?

title: LIBERTY MEDIA GROUP TO ACQUIRE CONTROL OF TODD-AO
description: Liberty Media Group, the cable television programming company run by John Malone, has agreed to acquire control of the Todd-AO Corporation, a video- and sound-editing studio, for about $92.5 million in stock. Liberty, a unit of the AT&T Corporation, will issue 2.5 million of its class A shares to gain control of half of Todd-AO's class A common stock and all of its class B stock. Liberty will swap one share for every 2.5 Todd-AO shares, valuing Todd-AO stock at $14.80 a share. Todd-AO rose $1.0625 yesterday, to $14. The agreement, announced after stock markets closed, comes about two months after Todd-AO hired Lazard Freres & Company to advise it on a possible sale.

title: Encore for a Dubious Lottery Game
description: The video screens of Quick Draw, a New York lottery game, will light up again tomorrow, luring bettors back to the bars to resume squandering their money. The machines have been dormant since March, when the law that brought Quick Draw to New York State expired. Quick Draw presents a danger to compulsive personalities because games can be played in rapid succession and the screens are often installed in bars and restaurants where players can drink as they play.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSS, CHARLES B.
description: MOSS-Charles B. Our thoughts of everlasting love for you remain with us. Paula, Jinny and Charley

title: The Right Way To Engage China
description: To the Editor:

title: 90 Asylum Seekers at Center Are Infected by Man With TB
description: Many of the foreign asylum seekers held at the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in Queens were infected with the tuberculosis microbe this month through contact with a West African detainee who reportedly entered the country already in the infectious stage of the disease, Federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Worker's Death Prompts Calls for Workfare Review
description: The death of a man who collapsed after laboring in a city park for the city's workfare program has prompted advocates to demand a review of the medical and grievance procedures available to those compelled to work in exchange for public assistance.

title: GERMAN UTILITY MERGER
description: Investors and analysts jumped on speculation that the German utility conglomerates Viag A.G. and Veba A.G. would merge their energy divisions. Despite denials from both companies, analysts and investors say that a report in the newspaper Handelsblatt rings somewhat true and that some sort of tie between Veba and Viag makes sense, with Germany's electricity market due for a consolidation. Both companies denied merger negotiations but acknowledged that general talks were going on with a number of companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, JEAN
description: ALEXANDER-Jean, 99, on July 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Cherished mother and mother-in-law of Nancy and Abner Golieb, Constance and Harvey Krueger, and Pamela and Richard Schlenger. Loving grandmother of Meg and John, Cathy, Liz and Abigail, Peggy, William and David. Great-grandmother of 15. Graveside service will be held at King Solomon Cemetery, Dwas Line and Allwood Rds., Clifton, NJ, on Sunday, August 1, at 12:30 PM.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: In Woodstock's Wake, Debates Erupt Over Security
description: As police investigators delve into allegations of rape and catalogue property damaged by marauding fans at the Woodstock '99 concert last weekend, a debate is emerging, on line and among experts in the concert business, about the performance of the festival's security force and whether it was adequate.

title: Security Flaws In Software Are Reported
description: Microsoft and Compaq Computer yesterday acknowledged several significant software security flaws that could enable intruders to gain access to the computers of millions of customers and to damage their data via E-mail or through commands sent from a malicious Web site.

title: Risks of Electric Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, ANNE
description: RICHARDSON-Anne. The Pilgrims of the United States are saddened by the death of the wife of their Vice President, Elliot L. Richardson, and convey to him their deepest sympathy. Henry Luce III, President Eben W. Pyne, Treasurer Mark Dixon, Secretary

title: Nortel to Split Its Stock
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's No. 2 phone-equipment maker, said late on Thursday that it would split its stock 2-for-1 after both the Canadian and United States shares rose by more than 70 percent this year. The split, effective Aug. 17, will be Nortel's first since January 1998. Nortel shares rose 31.25 cents today, to $88.625, on the Big Board.

title: Untangling Balkan Knots Of Myth and Countermyth
description: In a more perfect world, the warring sides in ethnic disputes over territory and equitable treatment might lay down their arms and submit themselves to a panel of historical experts who would study the record and determine which side's claims had greater merit. There would be a ruling, and each side would retire its unjustifiable demands in the face of superior historical documentation.

title: Gore Proposes Tax Breaks For Aiding the Middle Class
description: Vice President Al Gore today proposed a long list of tax breaks to address specific goals like making health care and education more affordable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORCORAN, JOHN JOSEPH
description: CORCORAN-John Joseph, loving husband to Ebba K. Corcoran, loving father to Sally Anne and Joy, and loving uncle to Christine, Fred, Jeffrey and David, passed away peacefully in his home on the 28th of July, 1999. The wake will be on Sunday, August 1, from 2-4 and 79 PM, at Flower Funeral Home, Yonkers, NY, 914-963-4137. The funeral service will be on Monday, August 2, at 9:45 AM, at St. Barnabas Church, in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENT, ALICE
description: BENT - Alice. Edwina Babst, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Earl D. Babst of New York and wife of George Payne Bent II of Greenwich, CT died Monday, July 26, 1999 at Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Bent attended Spence School in New York and Miss Porter's School in CT. She was a past member of the New York Jr. league where she was active for many years. She was a 50 year member of the Colony Club and also a member of the Greenwich Garden Club. Mrs. Bent was active in alumni affairs of Miss Porter's School, having served as a Trustee as well as a Bulletin Chairman, Branch President and Nominating Committee Chairman. Mrs. Bent is survived by her husband of sixty years and two daughters, Pamela B. Bent of Denver, Colorado, and Edwina F. Bent of Monterey, CA., and one grandson. There will be a memorial service at Round Hill Community Church Greenwich, CT. at 2:00 PM, Saturday, July 31, 1999. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her memory to Miss. Porter's School, 60 Main St., Farmington, CT. 06032.

title: Under Arid Skies, Crops and Livelihoods Wilt
description: Every morning, Magdaleno Fuentes waits by the shoulder of Route 59, hoping to find a job mowing lawns, trimming bushes or planting bushes. Eager to impress, he wears his best button-down shirt and clutches a plastic bag hiding a sleeveless gray T-shirt, specked with the toil and soil from previous jobs. Usually, he waits for a few minutes, a couple of hours at most, before the right job comes along.

title: NATO Holds 3 Albanians in Killing of 14 Serbs
description: The NATO police are holding three Kosovar Albanians as suspects in the murders of 14 Serbian farmers on July 23 in the village of Gracko, and NATO has sent weapons, ammunition and clothing to Britain for forensic analysis, officials said today.

title: Merger in Britain Creates Largest Publisher
description: Trinity P.L.C., Britain's largest regional newspaper company, announced today that it would acquire Mirror Group P.L.C., owner of one of Britain's oldest tabloid newspapers, for $:1.24 billion, or about $2 billion.

title: An Irresponsible Tax Cut
description: The House and Senate have now passed unreasonably large tax cuts that provide huge benefits for the rich and would assure that the current era of budget surpluses will be a brief one. Whatever bill emerges from a House-Senate conference committee will deserve a veto.

title: With One Well-Placed Kick, the Mets Vault Into First
description: Growing up in the Dominican Republic, Armando Benitez never played ice hockey. But this afternoon, on one of the hottest days anyone could remember at Wrigley Field, Benitez made a kick save worthy of a Stanley Cup goaltender with two out in the ninth inning. It helped preserve the Mets' wild 10-9 victory over the Chicago Cubs, and by the end of the day it had helped the Mets vault into first place, at the end of July, for the first time in nine years.

title: Searching for a Place in the Shade, Many Seek Ways to Cope With the Heat
description: How hot is it?

title: Risks of Electric Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, DAVID, DR.
description: LEEDS-David, Dr. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and member David Leeds. Heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family and friends. The Woodmere Club

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACTER, ARTHUR BERNARD
description: SCHLACTER - Arthur Bernard. Age 78. On July 30, 1999. Of Boca Raton, FL. Previously of Forest Hills, N.Y. Beloved husband of Regina. Loving father of Arlene Morelli and Jeffrey Saks. Dear father-in-law of Benedict Morelli & Rita Saks. Devoted grandfather of Justin and Alexander Morelli and Oliver Saks. Brother of Irwin Schlacter. Services 10:45AM Monday at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Friends may visit 7-9PM Sunday. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in Arthur's memory be made to a cancer research foundation of one's choice.

title: Standing Up to a Hall And Beethoven's Ghost
description: The Emerson String Quartet is becoming a victim of its own popularity. Last year tickets for its concert at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Alice Tully Hall sold out almost as soon as they were made available. So for this summer's festival the Emerson Quartet was presented in Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night. That a string quartet can attract a nearly full house to a 2,700-seat concert hall is a triumph of a kind.

title: Man Charged With Assault On Gate Agent Sues Airline
description: A passenger accused of hurling a Continental Airlines gate agent head-first to the floor at Newark International Airport last week has sued the airline, saying that it was he who had been attacked.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EMDEN, HARRY D.
description: EMDEN-Harry D. In cherished memory of a beloved father and grandfather. Passed away July 31, 1971. Forever in our hearts. Howard, Jeffrey, James, Robert

title: New York City Cancels a Music Event, and Some See a Link to Woodstock
description: City officials have canceled a music event that was scheduled to bring more than 15,000 young people to the piers in Brooklyn tonight, and the event's promoters say the city was motivated by politics in the wake of reports of violence and sexual assaults at last weekend's Woodstock concert.

title: Argentines Lift a Threat Of Sanctions
description: Argentina has retreated from a threat to impose punitive tariffs on Brazilian exports, easing a dispute between the two countries that had threatened the cohesion of the $1.1 trillion Mercosur trade bloc.

title: Beliefs; In public dialogue, the framework for discussion of religious beliefs is often something quite different. Note the Kennedy Mass coverage.
description: At the very heart of the final rites for John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife and her sister was a claim so utterly familiar, and yet so disconcerting, that almost all the coverage of the event passed over it quickly. This was not another example of media failure but an illustration of a larger problem: how distinct religious beliefs are transformed when they are filtered into public discourse.

title: Arab Named To U.S. Panel On Terrorism
description: A Justice Department civil rights lawyer, an Arab American, was named yesterday to serve on a national commission on terrorism as a replacement for another Arab American, whose nomination was withdrawn under pressure from Jewish organizations.

title: THE MAYOR'S MAKEOVER
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani is suddenly showing a kinder, gentler self as he prepares for a probable Senate run. But the old, cantankerous Rudy is never too far away. A report by James Traub, in The Times Magazine.

title: Teaching as a Torrent of Bubbling Information
description: One of the rewards of teaching is the feedback from students, delayed though it may be. ''Sometimes you get a letter 15 or 20 years later,'' Thomas T. Lyons said as he reflected on his 36 years of teaching history at Phillips Academy, one of the nation's leading prep schools.

title: USWEB/CKS TO BUY MITCHELL MADISON, A CONSULTING FIRM
description: The USWeb/CKS Corporation, an Internet marketing concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Mitchell Madison Group, a consulting firm, for shares valued at $299.3 million. USWeb/CKS, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would acquire Mitchell Madison for 14.4 million shares. The shares of USWeb/CKS were down 43.75 cents, at $20.9375, in Nasdaq trading. Mitchell Madison, of New York, was founded in 1994 by 30 former employees of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company.

title: Sports of The Times; For Jets, New Season, Fresh Starts
description: IN suffocating humidity and sweltering heat, the Jets opened training camp yesterday. Lawrence Taylor, the former Giant and Bill Parcells's embodiment of championships past, was on hand with support and an assessment. ''This team looks good,'' Taylor said. ''He always says he's got nothing, but it looks good.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, ROBERT BENJAMIN, M.D.
description: PFEFFER - Robert Benjamin, M.D. The faculty and staff of the NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of Robert Pfeffer, an attending surgeon at Tisch and Bellevue Hospitals and a Professor in the Department of Surgery at NYU School of Medicine until his retirement 10 years ago. A noted specialist in gastrointestinal surgery and an expert in hernia repair techniques, Dr. Pfeffer also served as the Chief of General Surgery at Doctor's Hospital. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Carol Pfeffer, his son, Dr. Glenn Pfeffer, his daughter-in-law, Dr. Betsy Pfeffer, and his son-in-law, Dr. John Roland, Jr., Assistant Professor of Otolaryngology at NYU School of Medicine. Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff President, NYU Hospitals Center H. Leon Pachter, M.D. Acting Chairman, Department of Surgery NYU School of Medicine Frank C. Spencer, M.D. George David Stewart Professor of Surgery NYU School of Medicine

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on July 17 about recent purchases of real estate assets by the California Public Employees' Retirement System referred to the pension fund's investment portfolio incorrectly. The fund oversees total assets in excess of $155 billion; its overseas assets are about 23 percent of that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, PAUL
description: BENSON-Paul. On July 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Dear brother of Hugh Benson of Los Angeles, Calif. Uncle of Gail Morris & Jeffrey Benson. Funeral service Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Sunday, 12 PM.

title: Britain Nominates Its Defense Secretary to Be Head of NATO
description: Britain's Defense Secretary, George Robertson, a Scottish labor union veteran whose vigorous denunciations of Yugoslav military actions in Kosovo were almost as intense as NATO's bombing campaign, today became his country's candidate for NATO Secretary General.

title: U.S. to Pay China for Embassy Bombing
description: Ending more than two months of acrimony, the United States and China agreed here today that Washington would pay $4.5 million in compensation for the victims of NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASS, CECILE
description: STRASS-Cecile. We extend our sincere condolences to the family of Jan Strass Pinkus, President of the FIT Alumni Assoication on the loss of her mother, Cecile Strass. Alumni Association of the Fashion Institute of Technology

title: KLM-ALITALIA DEAL
description: Two of Europe's biggest airlines, KLM of the Netherlands and Alitalia of Italy, will start in November to operate their passenger and cargo services under a single management, share profits and make joint decisions about aircraft and other equipment purchases. Company executives said they would not exclude a full merger in the future. The airlines said the cooperation, which they agreed to in principle last year, would bring them annual pretax benefits of about $427 million. They said they also expected to announce soon that Alitalia would be included in an existing cooperation agreement between KLM and Northwest Airlines. John Tagliabue

title: Risks That Make News
description: Inside The New York Times yesterday, there was a short wire-service article about a gold mine explosion in South Africa that killed 18 people. Four years earlier, the article said, a shaft elevator in a mine owned by the same company, Anglogold, went into a free-fall and killed 104 miners.

title: Baseball's Best? Here Are a Few More to Consider
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FICARROTTA
description: FICARROTTA Dana and Sal proudly welcome their daughter, Sydney Reed, July 17, 1999 3:14PM, 7.9 lbs, 19''. grand- parents, Jane, Diana and Joe

title: Leo Berger, 78, a Force in U.S. Merchant Marine
description: Leo Vladimir Berger, a Hungarian immigrant who spent much of his childhood in New York orphanages before becoming one of the country's largest shipping magnates, died on July 24 at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MALACHI
description: MARTIN-Malachi. The Isabel O'Neil Studio Workshop and Foundation is deeply saddened by the loss of Malachi Martin, a founding member of the Board of Trustees and longtime advocate & supporter of the art of the painted finish.

title: Which Do We Need More, Bigger Cars or Better Schools?
description: Tax-cutters claim the moral high ground. ''It's a matter of principle,'' says Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, ''to return excess tax money in Washington to the families and workers who sent it here.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, JULIAN H.
description: YOUNG-Julian H., 78, a retired executive salesman for M. Fine & Sons, who resided in Armonk, NY, at Stamford Hospital on Wednesday, July 28. Survivors include his wife Gladys Jaiven Young of Armonk, NY, two sons Allan J. Young and his wife Susan and Michael J. Young and his wife Laureen all of Maplewood, NJ, a daughter Stephanie Young Leo and her husband Michael of Gilbert, AZ and six grandchildren. A funeral service will be held 11 AM (Tomorrow) Sunday, Aug. 1 at the Nicholas F. Cognetta Funeral Home 104 Myrtle Ave. Stamford, CT with Rabbi Daniel Cohen of Temple Sharey Tefilo Israel, South Orange, NJ officiating. Interment will follow at Adudath Sholom Cemetery West Hill Rd., Stamford. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Yankees Have a Deal for Pettitte, if They Want It
description: The Yankees have a trade for Andy Pettitte they can accept or reject, they agreed in principle on acquiring the former Yankee Jim Leyritz, and they are engaged in serious talks with Baltimore for Arthur Rhodes. With Saturday's trade deadline looming, if the Yankees acquire a major league pitcher or two, like Rhodes or Tampa Bay's Roberto Hernandez, they are expected to trade Pettitte.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE TUMBLES. The end of a truckers' strike in Brazil, the world's biggest coffee grower, eased fears that shipments would be disrupted and prices slid. Coffee for September delivery fell 4 cents a pound, to 91.1 cents.

title: Scientists Fear Deep Budget Cuts Will Keep NASA Too Earthbound
description: A surprise budget cut proposed for NASA would devastate the agency's science programs and possibly force the closings of two of its major space centers, program administrators and scientists say.

title: The Bean That Wakes Up the World
description: ''All cares vanish as the coffee cup is raised to the lips,'' Sheik Ansari Djezeri Hanball Abd-al-Kadir wrote in 1587. Starbucks couldn't have said it better. Ask anyone who needs a cup of coffee (or two) before even thinking about starting the day.

title: A Law Opening Research Data Sets Off Debate
description: The proposition is simple enough: Public dollars pay for a lot of scientific research, so data from that research should be available to the public.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about wireless data services in Europe misstated the position of two American companies on a proposed standard for new wireless technology. The companies, Sprint and Bell Atlantic, support a proposal called C.D.M.A. 2000, which would be compatible with a current technology known as C.D.M.A., for code division multiple access; they do not endorse wideband C.D.M.A., which is a rival proposal.

title: John D. Dawson, 97, Antioch Administrator
description: John Dudley Dawson, an Antioch College administrator who became known to generations of students as Mr. Antioch for his role in revitalizing the college's approach to co-operative work-study education, died on Thursday at Greene Memorial Hospital in Xenia, Ohio. He was 97 and lived in Yellow Springs, Ohio.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a convention of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance referred incorrectly to Jody Abrams, a member of the group. She is a woman, not a man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, LOUIS
description: SPECTOR-Louis. On July 29, 1999. Devoted husband of Nora Weisblatt Spector, beloved father of Susan and William, adored father-inlaw of Scott and Lynn, cherished grandfather of Alyssa and Jesse and unforgettable friend of many, passed away. Services will be held on Sunday, August 1, 10:30 AM at Bloomfield Cooper Chapel, 2130 Highway 35, Ocean Township, NJ.

title: Drawn to Their Deaths By Lives in Day Trading
description: There were 22 of them, 22 people with disparate lives and interests, lives filled with children and lovers, with keeping store and fly-fishing, with building that dream house and chasing the American dream. But on Thursday afternoon, in a quiet office park here, they were 22 people with a single common interest, electronic day trading.

title: Falkland Pact Is Protested On Both Sides Of the Dispute
description: Before the ink was even dry, President Carlos Saul Menem called his recent agreement with Britain to allow Argentine tourists to visit the Falkland Islands for the first time since the 1982 Falkland war ''the crown jewel'' of his 10 years in office.

title: A Child Sees the Future in Ghosts of Airmen Past
description: Night. A light plane with a young pilot at the controls descends through fog and crashes in water. All aboard die.

title: Hong Kong Journal; A Free-Spoken Editor Won't Be Back
description: It had become a running gag in the newsroom of The South China Morning Post. Whenever the paper's outspoken British editor, Jonathan Fenby, told his staff he was leaving town on vacation, some smart aleck would pipe up, ''Are you coming back?''

title: Thoughts for Your Penny, Suddenly Scarce
description: The long-maligned penny, kicked about the sidewalks of New York, disparaged by the ''take a penny'' cups at cash registers and mocked by the ''no pennies'' signs on bridge and tunnel tollgates, is finally enjoying its revenge.

title: Sehorn's Comeback Slowed by Strain
description: There is a theme developing at the Giants' training camp: walk, don't run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, MELVIN
description: GREENBAUM-Melvin. The Jewish Theological Seminary family records with sorrow the death of Melvin Greenbaum, father of Rabbi Michael Greenbaum, vice chancellor and chief administrative officer of JTS. In addition to his son, he is survived by a daughter, Alyse, his wife Helen, three stepchildren and eight grandchildren. He is predeceased by his first wife, Sylvia. With Jewish community at the center of his life, he was an active member of his congregation, Temple Israel of Daytona Beach, FL. Contributions to JTS. May his memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, chancellor Gershon Kekst, board chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LILLIAN
description: STERN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Stern. Cherished mother of Judy Holland, Margery and Herbert Rosen. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. She celebrated life and helped others to do the same and will always be eternally young. Services Sunday, Aug. 1st. 9:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Potvin Signs One-Year Contract
description: The Islanders have re-signed goalie Felix Potvin to a one-year contract worth $2.7 million.

title: Killer Confessed in a Letter Spiked With Rage
description: After bludgeoning his wife and two children to death with a hammer, and just eight hours before slaughtering nine people in the brokerage houses where he traded, Mark O. Barton typed a chilling confession on his computer and warned that he planned to live just long enough to kill ''the people that greedily sought my destruction.''

title: U.S. Rejects Plan for Airline Alliance
description: The United States rejected an application for antitrust immunity from the would-be alliance partners British Airways, Europe's largest airline, and the No. 2 United States carrier, AMR's American Airlines.

title: COCA-COLA COMPLETES PURCHASE OF CADBURY UNIT
description: The Coca-Cola Company yesterday completed the acquisition of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.'s soda business in 155 countries for $700 million. Coca-Cola, the world's largest beverage company, also said its efforts to buy Cadbury's soda businesses in Australia, Mexico and Canada were continuing. Among the countries in which the acquisition closed were Brazil, Japan and Britain. In May, Coca-Cola bowed to European antitrust regulators and scaled down its proposed purchase, which includes the Cadbury's Dr Pepper, Crush and Canada Dry brands.

title: As Giuliani Jabs, First Lady Plays Nice as a Campaigner
description: When it comes to political combat, there are few potential targets that are off-limits for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and certainly not his likely opponent in next year's race for the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Soft Money Is Still Legal
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about House consideration of a foreign aid bill referred incorrectly in some copies to the outcome of a vote on a bipartisan amendment that would bar funds for organizations that lobby for or against abortions or promote abortion as a method of family planning. The amendment was passed, not defeated, by the 221-to-208 vote.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S.-China Deal on Bombing

title: H. S. Richardson, 79, Dies; Heir to Vicks Cold Remedies
description: H. Smith Richardson Jr. grew up in a household in which Vicks Vaporub, the cold remedy, meant more than relief from a hacking cough.

title: A Little of This and That: A Combiner on Saxophone
description: Chris Potter, a young saxophonist who is playing his first weeklong engagement at the Village Vanguard through tomorrow night, is typical of the next crop of mainstream jazz players: he's a combiner. If it's true that everything in jazz has been done, that there's no absolutely fresh territory, it's equally true that we've moved into the age of hybrids, which could sustain the art for a good long time.

title: Taylor Discusses Hall With Parcells
description: Lawrence Taylor stopped just short of asking Bill Parcells to be at the Hall of Fame inductions next Saturday, the former Giants star said today at the Jets' training camp.

title: Chairman Survives Challenge At Philadelphia Stock Exchange
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange reappointed Meyer Frucher as chairman yesterday, after the exchange's largest seatholder tried to topple him.

title: Norman Ousts Moya
description: Magnus Norman of Sweden ousted top-seeded Carlos Moya of Spain, 6-2, 7-6 (10-8), in the quarterfinals of the Croatia Open ATP tournament yesterday in Umag.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KASHA, FRANK (EPHRIAM)
description: KASHA-Frank (Ephriam). June 1, 1909-July 31, 1973 2 AV ''The Candyman''. My best friend and father remembered with much love. You would be so proud. Rest in Peace.

title: PROFIT JUMPS AT LLOYDS
description: Europe's most profitable bank, Lloyds TSB Group P.L.C., said its first-half profit rose more than expected, 43 percent, as it cut costs and earned more from mortgages. Profit rose to $:1.32 billion ($2.14 billion) from $:924 million a year earlier. Under its chairman, Sir Brian Pitman, Lloyds TSB has become Britain's biggest provider of retail financial services by buying companies like Scottish Widows Fund and Life Assurance Society, a $:7 billion acquisition announced last month.

title: Skimping on School Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: Clint Youle, 83, Early Weatherman on TV
description: Clint Youle, a weatherman at WNBQ television in Chicago who was the first to present the weather on a national television news program, died on July 23 at a hospital in Galena, Ill. He was 83 and had lived on a 120-acre homestead in nearby Scales Mound, Ill.

title: Baseball's Best? Here Are a Few More to Consider
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, EDMUND
description: KLEIN-Edmund. The Founder, Board of Trustees and Scientific Advisory Council of the Cancer Research Institute mourn the loss of Dr. Edmund Klein. Dr. Klein served as a CRI scientific advisor from 1972 until his death. His wisdom, vision and experience were indispensible in guiding the Institute through the years.

title: School Long Seen as Despots' Training Center Faces a Cutoff
description: The House voted early today to cut off recruitment funds for the Army's School of the Americas, long criticized for graduating Latin American military officers who became tyrants and murderers.

title: China Everbright Chairman Is Forced to Relinquish Post
description: China Everbright Group, one of the nation's largest financial conglomerates, announced today that its chairman had resigned and been replaced by a deputy governor of the People's Bank of China.

title: DAEWOO APPEALS TO CREDITORS
description: The South Korean business conglomerate Daewoo Group said it wanted foreign creditors to promise to roll over loans maturing this year and not to call in loans before they are due. The company sent letters to more than 70 foreign banks, seeking some sort of written pledge on their loans of about $6 billion, said a spokesman. Foreign creditors met on Thursday in Seoul to discuss their exposure to the conglomerate.

title: Old Exchange In London Tries A New Twist On Ownership
description: With the world's stock exchanges increasingly challenged by upstart electronic trading networks, the august London Stock Exchange today announced plans to end almost two centuries of clubby mutual ownership by issuing tradeable shares to its members.

title: Man Jailed on Secret Evidence Should Be Freed, Judge Says
description: A Federal immigration judge ruled yesterday that an Egyptian man kept in solitary confinement for the last three years on the basis of secret evidence allegedly linking him to a terrorist organization should be freed from jail.

title: Shimmying Her Way Into a New Career
description: You are a young female composer in a male-dominated world. Your work is played by some of the best musicians of your time, Emanuel Ax, Ani Kavafian, Peter Serkin, Andre-Michel Schub and Richard Goode. Yet contemporary music seems too hard-edged, too intellectual, without soul. Your femininity is somehow . . . unacknowledged. So what do you do?

title: Philadelphia, Miss., Journal; An Embattled Governor Stands Up Under Fire at a Historic Fair
description: As tradition dictates in Mississippi politics, Eddie Briggs, a Republican candidate for governor in next Tuesday's primary, took the podium for his allotted time this week at the 110th Neshoba County Fair, a mandatory stop on Mississippi's campaign trail.

title: A Change in Umps' Tactics Would've Been Discussed
description: If the umpires who wound up opposing their union's mass resignation strategy had opposed it internally before going public, the union would have changed the plan, the union vice president said tonight.

title: Insiders Seen Winning Posts at Warner Brothers
description: Barry M. Meyer, the chief operating officer at the Warner Brothers studio, is expected to be promoted to the top position, company executives said today. He would succeed Robert A. Daly and Terry Semel, who ran the film, television and music divisions for 20 years.

title: Johnson & Higgins Agrees to Settlement
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies' Johnson & Higgins Inc. unit has agreed to pay $28 million to settle Federal charges that it discriminated against top executives on its board by forcing them into early retirement.

title: Yanks Start With Bang and Keep on Bashing
description: Hideki Irabu kicked and pawed at the Fenway Park mound tonight, until he finally excavated to his satisfaction. Boston's Mark Portugal fell on the mound in the first inning -- and then he and the three relievers that followed were pounded by the Yankees in a 13-3 defeat.

title: Inkster Comes Up Big By Using Short Game
description: Even when Juli Inkster is not at her very best, the results can be very good.

title: The Vision Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE APPROVES BIG CUT IN TAXES, COURTING A VETO
description: The Senate voted today to cut taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years, moving the Republican-controlled Congress toward a politically charged showdown with President Clinton over how the nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses.

title: HANVIT SALE TABLED
description: One of the largest commercial lenders in South Korea, Hanvit Bank, shelved a $1 billion sale of shares after the Government refused to sell a part of its stake at the 25-percent discount that many investors demanded. Investors were reluctant to pay the current price of 8,700 won because of concerns that Hanvit will not recoup 3.6 trillion won ($3 billion) it is owed by Daewoo Group.

title: Teamsters Local Drops Pact With Restaurateur
description: The Cipriani family's plan to sidestep its longstanding problems with the restaurant workers' union fell apart yesterday when a Teamsters local withdrew from its two-day-old agreement to represent employees at three restaurants, a union official said.

title: ENTERGY WILL BUY BACK $750 MILLION OF COMMON STOCK
description: The Entergy Corporation, which owns electric utilities in four states, said yesterday it would buy back as much as $750 million of common stock, or about 10 percent of its shares outstanding, to increase the value of the shares. The company plans to repurchase the shares in the open market or through private transactions over the next two years. It has about 246.8 million shares outstanding. Entergy, based in New Orleans, sells power to about 2.5 million customers in Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi and Arkansas. It owns stakes in power plants in the United States and foreign countries that can generate as much as 30,000 megawatts. Entergy's shares were up $0.0625 each at $30.3125.

title: Jurors in Maryland Indict Linda Tripp In Lewinsky Tapes
description: Linda R. Tripp, whose secretly recorded conversations with an impressionable young friend exposed an affair that led to President Clinton's impeachment, was indicted on two criminal charges by a Maryland grand jury today for illegally taping the telephone calls.

title: Vendor of News From Afar Yields to Technology
description: It has survived almost everything New York could throw at it: wars, blackouts, the Depression, the decline of Times Square and even its revival. But now Hotalings News Agency, the purveyor of newspapers and magazines from around the globe that has become a New York City institution, is disappearing from the street.

title: Some Security Flaws Reported in Software
description: Microsoft and Compaq acknowledged software security flaws that could enable intruders to gain access to the computers of millions of customers and to damage their data via E-mail or through commands sent from a malicious Web site. Certain Hewlett-Packard computers are also thought to be vulnerable.

title: BRAZIL TRUCKERS END STRIKE
description: The Government reached a deal ending a strike that had paralyzed road transport throughout Brazil. Federal authorities agreed to suspend an increase in diesel prices, freeze tolls on some highways and send Congress a proposal that would penalize truckers less than other motorists for traffic violations. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, facing the largest strike since an oil workers action in 1995, had authorized army troops to unclog blocked roads. But skirmishes were limited to Sao Paulo state. Simon Romero

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-5

title: Whitman's Pick for Police Hinges on Democrats' Help
description: After five months of searching for the right person to head the troubled New Jersey State Police, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman finally has a candidate, but now finds herself in the uneasy position of having to work out a deal with Democrats in Washington to get him.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR FALLS. Weak stock and bond prices in the United States discouraged demand for dollars, and the currency fell to 114.48 Japanese yen, a five and a half month low, from 115.40 on Thursday.

title: Baseball's Best? Here Are a Few More to Consider
description: To the Editor:

title: Skimping on School Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC MAY CLOSE TWO REFRIGERATOR PLANTS
description: The General Electric Company may shut a refrigerator plant in Louisville, Ky., and cut 1,500 jobs, while adding production of a new refrigerator line in Mexico as part of its joint venture with Grupo P.I. Mabe S.A. General Electric, the No. 1 supplier of large appliances for newly built homes in the United States, notified the Louisville workers of the possible closing on Thursday. A company spokesman, Terry Dunn, said General Electric also planned to notify workers in Bloomington, Ind., that it may shut a refrigerator plant there that employs 3,100 people. These moves are prompted by regulations scheduled to take effect in June 2001 that will require new refrigerators to use 30 percent less energy and therefore render the existing models produced in both plants obsolete, Mr. Dunn said. The Louisville notice triggers a 45-day bargaining period.

title: McNabb and Eagles Reach 7-Year Deal
description: Donovan McNabb and the Philadelphia Eagles agreed to a seven-year contract worth as much as $54 million with incentives last night, ending contentious negotiations that were marked by racial accusations by his agent.

title: Taiwan's Special Envoy to Beijing Still Sees an Opening for Reunification
description: Taiwan's special envoy to China delivered a long-awaited statement today on Taiwan-China relations, saying President Lee Teng-hui's call for ''special state to state'' ties with Beijing did not rule out eventual reunification.

title: HIGHER RATES SEEN IN BRITAIN
description: The prospects of higher interest rates in Britain increased, reversing 10 months of decline, after the Government said the economy grew in the second quarter at its fastest pace in a year. The Office for National Statistics said Britain's gross domestic product grew at an annualized rate of 1.2 percent in the April-June quarter, exceeding expectations of an increase of eight-tenths of a percent. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: OAK TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO AQUIRE XIONICS
description: Oak Technology Inc. agreed late on Thursday to buy Xionics Document Technologies Inc. for about $70.2 million in cash and stock, to strengthen its position in the market for imaging processors and software. Oak Technology, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would offer 0.803 share of its common stock and $2.94 in cash for each share of Xionics's common stock, an overall value of $6.10 a share. Xionics, based in Burlington, Mass., makes software and technology for printers, copiers and other office machines. Oak Technology said it would merge these products with its image processors to offer hardware and software to office equipment manufacturers.

title: The Good Night Witch
description: This is the measure of phenomenal. Two weeks ago yesterday, a little $60,000 movie, produced by two film makers no one ever heard of, starring three unknown actors and shot mainly in the woods outside the tiny country town of Burkittsville, Md., opened in 27 theaters around the country, from New York City to Orlando, from Orange County, California, to Baltimore. It has no sex, no guns, no visible violence. It is about the ''legendary'' Blair Witch, whom no one ever sees, and the three aspiring young documentary film makers who interview people in the town about her by day, and then chase her through the dark woods with their cameras at night. They die trying to capture her on film, one by one. By the end of the first showing of the movie -- which is supposedly their unfinished documentary, found after their disappearance in the woods -- the teens and twentysomethings of America had found a scary new thrill, and the witch had become a movie star.

title: Skimping on School Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRITANISKY, LUCY
description: BRITANISKY-Lucy. Beloved wife of the late Leon, loving mother, adored aunt, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother and good friend to many. Services Sunday 11AM at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'', 180 West 76 St, (Riverside building, NYC).

title: Day Trades: Big Growth, Big Risks
description: Compared with the nation's largest and most well-known brokerage firms like Merrill Lynch & Company and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, day trading companies like those in Atlanta where a gunman killed nine people on Thursday have operated in near obscurity.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Senate Votes to Cut Taxes By $792 Billion in 10 Years

title: Officials Struggle to Regulate On-Line Sale of Prescription Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced steps today to curb the illegitimate sale of prescription drugs over the Internet, while officials at another agency, the Federal Trade Commission, asked Congress to require electronic pharmacies to post detailed on-line information about their licenses and the doctors who write the prescriptions they fill.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Los Angeles Board of Education's debate over whether to abandon a $200 million school project because of concerns about its environmental safety misstated the views of an outside lawyer for the school district. The lawyer, David Cartwright of the law firm O'Melveny & Myers, assured the board that it was safe to build the school on land adjoining a former oilfield only after a full environmental review and an analysis of recommended safety measures had been completed. He did not say the project would be safe without such a study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, ROBERT, H.
description: FARBER-Robert, H. Beloved husband of Rhoda (Harris), cherished father of Joanne and Steven, Linda and Eric and Cathy and Steven. Dear grandfather of Stacey and Andrew and Lisa. Devoted brother of Stanley. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Five Corrections Officers Are Charged in Beating of Inmate at Nassau's Jail
description: Five correction officers at the Nassau County jail were arrested today and charged with assaulting a man last October while he was awaiting trial on a robbery charge.

title: Elite Unit's Wearing of Uniforms Is Reviewed as Gun Seizures Drop
description: Gun seizures by the Police Department's embattled Street Crime Unit have fallen so sharply since the shooting of Amadou Diallo in February that officials are leaning toward putting some of the elite force back into plain clothes, the police said yesterday.

title: Political Notes; Mayor Basks in Controversy Over the Arkansas Flag
description: The Arkansas flag was no longer fluttering over City Hall yesterday, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani apparently wanted to bask a little longer in the controversy its presence created this week.

title: The Right Way To Engage China
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, BENJAMIN, HON
description: LEVITT-Benjamin, Hon. On Thursday, July 29, 1999. Age 94. Devoted and beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Col. (Dr.) Morton H. Levitt, and dear fatherin-law of Cynthia Lynn. Cherished grandfather of Lisa Michelle and step grandfather of Nicole Valerie and Tamara Lynn. Graveside ceremony for family only.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FORD MOTOR CO., Dearborn, Mich., is shutting down an assembly plant in Wixom, Mich., for one week because of a shortage of parts for its new Lincoln LS sedan.

title: Going to Great Lengths To Get Mets a Trade
description: Not even a three-car accident on the Grand Central Parkway could prevent Steve Phillips from flying here this morning.

title: An Aisle Unto Itself?; Pepsi's Vision: All of Its Eggs in One Shopping Basket
description: Here in the sprawling Price Chopper supermarket, between Aisle 6, devoted to detergents and dog food, and Aisle 9, the home of peanut butter and jelly, Roger A. Enrico's vision of the future is on display.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: DANA WILL SELL FORGING PLANT IT ACQUIRED FROM EATON
description: The Dana Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its forging factory in Marion, Ohio, which was acquired as part of its purchase of the Eaton Corporation's heavy axle and brake business last year. The facility employs about 300 people and had $50 million in sales in 1998, Dana said. Dana, a supplier of components for automobiles based in Toledo, Ohio, said the forging operation no longer figured in its manufacturing strategies.

title: In Mexico, Votes Can Be Bought, Study Shows
description: One-third of those who voted this month in a crucial Mexican election won by President Ernesto Zedillo's governing party now say they received groceries, scholarships, lottery tickets, crop payments or other government handouts before the vote, according to a new study.

title: Ex-General, Member of Banned Sect, Confesses 'Mistakes,' China Says
description: The Chinese authorities disclosed today that a retired army general, the highest-ranking leader in Beijing of the spiritual movement that was banned last week, has confessed his ''mistakes'' and renounced his allegiance to the organization.

title: G. C. Minor, 62, an Engineer Who Criticized Nuclear Power
description: Gregory Charles Minor, one of three middle-management engineers who caused a stir when they quit the General Electric reactor division in 1976 to protest nuclear power, died on July 20 at his home in Telluride, Colo. He was 62.
